title: New Civilian Cabinet Installed in Suriname
description: Military authorities installed a new civilian Cabinet today and introduced an interim constitution that theoretically recognizes individual rights but does not say how they will be guaranteed.

title: Books of the Times
description: DUTCH SHEA Jr. By John Gregory Dunne. 352 pages. Linden/Simon & Schuster. $15.95.

title: News of Music; TOWN HALL IS PLANNING 5-YEAR RESTORATION JOB
description: TOWN HALL has announced plans for restoring the once prestigious concert facility on West 43d Street to its former state. Tne restoration will occur in three stages over five years. Each stage is estimated to cost $500,000, and the first is scheduled to begin late in the fall.

title: CITIES SEEK AID OF PRIVATE CONCERNS TO COPE WITH BUDGET CUTS
description: City governments across the nation have become so hard-pressed for resources that they are beginning to share much of their authority for governing and development with business and other private interests.

title: Bus Plunge Kills 22 in Peru
description: A bus plunged into a deep canyon today, killing 22 people and injuring 15, the police reported. The accident occurred 45 miles east of Lima on the Central Highway, which connects the Pacific coast with the Peruvian highlands.

title: FOAM INSULATION: QUESTIONS REMAIN
description: AMERICAN homeowners became worried last February when the Federal Consumer Product Safety Commission voted to ban urea-formaldehyde foam, a type of insulation that has been installed in about 500,000 homes in the United States since the mid-1970's.

title: RCA Wins Court Case; Over Satellite Service
description: A Federal appeals court declined today to block a regulatory order that allows RCA American Communications Inc. to begin taking orders for service on its newest satellite, according to an attorney for the company.

title: E.P.A. AND OSHA, PLEASE IMITATE
description: To the Editor:

title: ON SINAI, TOO LATE
description: Egyptian leaders consider it too late to correct any conceptual mistakes made at Camp David.

title: ADOBE: SCULPTURES OF THE SOUTHWEST
description: TAOS, N.M. THE history of the Southwest, and especially of the Hispanic villages of northern New Mexico, has been written in adobe. A great deal of the history of adobe, from the mission churches of Ranches de Taos and Las Trampas to the squat brown dwellings dotting the landscape, has been written by women.

title: Wickes Loan Response
description: The ailing Wickes Companies, responding to an offer by the Allegheny Beverage Corporation to consider a loan of as much as $600 million if Allegheny could control Wickes, said yesterday that Allegheny had not presented its terms for the loan or any indication if it could actually raise the funds. Therefore, Wickes said, there was nothing for it to consider.

title: NUGGETS' STREAK AT 11
description: Alex English scored 27 points and Kiki Vanderweghe added 25 tonight to pace the Denver Nuggets a club record 11th straighte victory, a 120-119 decision over the Dallas Mavericks. Dallas had a chance to win in the closing seconds, but Jim Spanarkel missed a shot from the corner and Jay Vincent's tip-in bounced off the rim at the buzzer.

title: INA, Connecticut General Merger
description: The Connecticut General Corporation and the INA Corporation said they had completed their proposed merger, creating a major new insurance and financial services concern called the Cigna Corporation.

title: Notes On People; For Mitzi Gaynor, a 28-City Tour Is Restful
description: Spending eight months on the road, living in motel rooms and hardly knowing what city it is from one week to the next can be a grueling existence for an entertainer, but not, it turns out, for Mitzi Gaynor.

title: IT SEES NO PROBLEM OVER THE COUP
description: The Reagan Administration, while keeping the situation in Bangladesh ''under review,'' is conducting normal relations with the martial-law Government of Lieut. Gen. H.M. Ershad, who seized power last Wednesday.

title: Briefing
description: 'Absolute Rubbish'

title: WEINBERGER SAYS U.S. WILL MAINTAIN CURBS ON SEOUL'S SALE OF ARMS
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger informed South Korea today that the United States would retain its strict controls over foreign sales of arms made here under license from American defense contractors.

title: Article 034551 -- No Title
description: The Commonwealth Oil and Refining Company reported yesterday that it had a loss of $164.5 million in the fourth quarter of 1981 contrasted to earnings of $19.2 million, or $1.26 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year ago.

title: A WASHINGTON COUPLE'S 'CALIFORNIA STORY'
description: Peter McCoy's orchids began to wilt last winter. ''We lost them,'' says Mr. McCoy. ''They froze,'' says his wife, Kacey. California hothouse flowers don't do well in Washington. That's just one of the lessons that the McCoys have learned.

title: PRO-ISRAELI WEST BANK OFFICIAL WOUNDED BY BOMB
description: A West Bank village official prominent in an @Israeli-sponsored organization was wounded today by a bomb that went off as he opened his car door.

title: Two Laws Can't Run a Railroad
description: It's futile to argue with the unanimous Supreme Court decision that the Long Island Rail Road is governed by Federal labor law and not that of New York State. Although the line is no longer owned by a private company, the Court held that it was nonetheless covered by the national Railway Labor Act. And that act, unlike New York's Taylor Law, permits strikes. The decision means that some Metropolitan Transportation Authority workers will be governed by one law, the rest by another. That is bound to complicate the bargaining process.

title: Two Soviet Naval Ships Start Repairs in a Greek Shipyard
description: Repairs have started on two Soviet naval supply vessels at a shipyard here under an agreement signed this year.

title: Ivan Kovalev, 28, a Dissident, Is Placed on Trial in Moscow
description: Soviet agitation, court officials said.

title: LEGISLATURE DEFIES CAREY AND PASSES OWN STATE BUDGET
description: The State Legislature, in an extraordinary move, tonight approved a state budget of its own making. The Assembly and Senate acted over the firm opposition of Governor Carey, who threatened to veto portions of the $27 billion proposal as too expensive.

title: THEATER: 'DEATH OF A MINER,' WOMEN'S PROJECT PLAY
description: A DISTURBING paradox is presented in Paula Cizmar's ''Death of a Miner,'' the latest in the Women's Project series at the American Place Theater. Mary Alice Hager, the coal-miner heroine of this socially conscious drama, suffers the indignities and the injustices of being a pioneer in a traditionally male profession. Her fellow miners in a small Appalachian town treat her as less than a man and also as less than a woman. At the same time, her most abusive antagonist tries to assert his masculinity by molesting her sexually.

title: 5 Columbia Holders Get Coke Offer
description: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that it will pay cash for some of the shares of five principal stockholders in Columbia Pictures Industries.

title: SETBACK FOR IRAQ UPSETS GULF ARABS
description: The military setback suffered by Iraq in its war with Iran has deepened the alarm with which the Arab countries of the Persian Gulf are watching the 18-month-old conflict.

title: Sports People; Valenzuela on Mound
description: One week after ending his holdout, Fernando Valenzuela of the Los Angeles Dodgers made his first exhibition appearance of the spring. Pitching the eighth and ninth innings of a game that the Dodgers lost in 10 to Boston, 8-7, Valenzuela yielded no earned runs.

title: Pitney-Bowes
description: Pitney-Bowes Inc. said it had entered into a long-term agreement to market high-speed automatic facsimile machines made by the Toshiba Corporation and Oki Electric Industry Ltd. of Japan. The company said it expects to start marketing the products under its own name in the United States and Canada in September and in Europe in mid-1983. The speeds of the facsimile machines range from 20 seconds to three minutes per page, it said.

title: 'Shopping by Satellite' Is New Cable TV Show
description: Metromedia has joined with Comp-U-Card of America to deliver, starting next fall, a two-hour-a-day ''Shopping by Satellite'' cable TV show.

title: U.S. BACKING I.B.M. IN EUROPE
description: Reagan Administration officials today confirmed reports that they have supported the International Business Machines Corporation's position in an antitrust case brought against it by the Commission of the European Common Market in December 1980 and now pending before the commission in Brussels.

title: NETS OVERCOME CAVALIERS, BOLSTER PLAYOFF PROSPECTS
description: The Cleveland Cavaliers, with five strong starters but a weak bench, showed again tonight why they were the National Basketball Association's standard for ineptitude.

title: HIGH COURT RESTORES MURDER CONVICTION OF EX-ARMY DOCTOR
description: The Supreme Court today reinstated the murder conviction of a former Green Beret captain who was found guilty in 1979 of the murders of his wife and children at Fort Bragg, N.C., nine years earlier.

title: Bids for Oil Off China
description: Thirty-five foreign companies have applied to take part in a first round of bidding on rights to exploit China's offshore oil, the China National Offshore Oil Corporation announced today. About half are American. Six other companies notified of the bidding had not responded by yesterday's deadline.

title: Pennsylvania Ballet Sets Women's Program
description: The Pennsylvania Ballet will open its spring season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music next Tuesday, in ''In Celebration of the Woman Choreographer,'' choreographed by Doris Humphrey, Isadora Duncan, Senta Driver and Loyce Houlton. Annabelle Gamson, an interpreter of Miss Duncan's dances, will appear as a guest in the program, which will be repeated April 10 in the afternoon and evening and April 11 in the afternoon.

title: I.B.M. INTRODUCES 3 LARGE COMPUTERS
description: The International Business Machines Corporation yesterday introduced three large computers, which analysts said would fill a gap in the company's product line and intensify the pressure on its competitors.

title: BOTH SIDES IN IRAN-IRAQ WAR REPORT LAG IN COMBAT
description: Fighting on the Iranian battlefront, where Iraqi troops were forced into a 24-mile retreat in recent days, appeared today to have subsided.

title: The Trouble With Enterprise Zones
description: To the Editor:

title: Avalanches Kill 2 At California Resort
description: Two persons were killed today when avalanches hit the Alpine Meadows ski lodge and thundered through a parking lot, the authorities said.

title: VIETNAM DROPS SIX FROM RULING BODY
description: Vietnam dropped six members from the ruling Politburo today, including Gen. Vo Nguyen Giap, who is credited by the Vietnamese with defeating the French at Dien Bien Phu and the United States in the Vietnam War 20 years later.

title: Interpublic Purchase
description: It's done. The Interpublic Group of Companies has finally completed its purchase of SSC&B-Lintas, which it began in September 1979.

title: Notes On People; 'Dr. Seuss' Honored
description: Why would the National Association of Elementary School Principals give its first special award for distinguished service to children to Theodor S. Geisel?

title: MONETARY USE OF GOLD IS REJECTED
description: The United States Gold Commission today formally rejected the use of gold in either the domestic or international monetary systems.

title: Briefing
description: Proposed Alcohol Warning

title: U.S.-SOVIET ARMS TALKS GO BACK TO 60's
description: While the origins of nuclear arms talks go back to the early 1960's, the United States and the Soviet Union have been negotiating on limiting such weapons since 1969.

title: REAGAN SAYS HE MAY ALTER BUDGET IF MILITARY'S BUILDUP IS UNAFFECTED
description: President Reagan said tonight that he was open to suggestions for altering his proposed budget for the fiscal year 1983, including ''possible'' cuts in military spending so long as they did no harm to the overall military buildup.

title: PSYCHOLOGIST ANALYZED BY FREUD
description: Dr. Helene Deutsch, who in 1918 began her psychoanalysis with Sigmund Freud, died Monday in Cambridge, Mass. Dr. Deutsch, who was 97 years old, was the first woman analyst to be analyzed by Freud and before her death had become the oldest psychoanalyst analyzed by Freud.

title: Notes On People; Florio Disavows Interest in Senatorial Race
description: Representative James J. Florio yesterday ended speculation that he would seek the Democratic nomination to fill the seat vacated by the resignation of Harrison A. Williams Jr. of New Jersey.

title: KAPLAN'S NEW CHIEF CONFIDENT ON DIAMONDS
description: The diamond industry may be in the doldrums right now, but Howard Herzog, 43, voices confidence in its future. Yesterday he was named president and chief executive officer of Lazare Kaplan International. The company, he says, is the only major diamond cutter and polisher that is publicly owned. Its shares are listed on the American Stock Exchange.

title: British Ford Job Cuts
description: The Ford Motor Company, Britain's most successful major car manufacturer, said today that it would cut 1,700 foundry jobs at its big Dangenham plant near London in an effort to keep the facility open. ''There was a danger that the foundry would have to close because it was uneconomic,'' a spokesman said.

title: 'Dance as Film' Due
description: ''Dance as Film,'' an evening of films by choreographers who have used the medium as a compositional device, will be presented Tuesday at 8:30 by the Kitchen, 484 Broome Street. The program will include works by Johanna Boyce, Yoshiko Chuma, Pooh Kaye, Gabrielle Lansner and David Woodberry. Call 925-3615.

title: DANCE: SOLO IN SILENCE BY BERTRAM ROSS
description: IN his more than 20 years with the Martha Graham Dance Company, Bertram Ross stood out for his strong theatrical presence, a presence poised at an interesting point somewhere between the heroic and antiheroic. Mr. Ross has also one of the wickedest wits in the business. Both qualities shone brightly in his solo ''Raymond,'' part of a program presented by the Bertram Ross Dance Company last Saturday at the Theresa L. Kaufman Concert Hall of the 92d Street Y.

title: TRANSIT DISPUTE GOES TO A PANEL FOR ARBITRATION
description: New York City's bus and subway unions and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority declared an impasse last night in their contract negotiations. The decision sent the dispute to a three-man panel empowered to render binding arbitration.

title: THE COUNTER-TERRORISTS OF NORTHERN IRELAND
description: To the Editor:

title: SENATE MILITARY UNIT VOTES PLAN TO BUILD 2 NUCLEAR CARRIERS
description: The Reagan Administration won a key victory late today when the Senate Armed Services Committee approved a proposal to build two nuclear-powered aircraft carriers.

title: Home Beat; WEAVINGS BY INDIANS
description: ALTHOUGH we've gotten used to seeing American Indians' patterns adapted on fabrics and modern rugs, it is particularly appealing to view first hand a number of their authentic weavings. And through April 24 the gallery ACA American Indian Arts is presenting a show of about 50 such examples.

title: CIRCUS OPENS 2-MONTH STAND
description: THE Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus rolled into town yesterday for a two-month stay at Madison Square Garden. The circus has entered the space age but, happily, circuses never change too much. This is the three-ring treat that has dazzled generations of families, from the first pungent animal smells as the Garden's daredevil escalators hurtle one skyward, to the final, death-defying catapault to earth of Capt. Christopher Adams, the human rocket.

title: EXPOS GET OLIVER
description: Al Oliver, who has batted better than .300 in each of the last six seasons, became a member of the Montreal Expos today because Oscar Gamble did not want to leave the Yankees for the Texas Rangers.

title: Q & A
description: Q. I have an old brass table lamp that was bright and beautifully polished when it was first purchased. Now it is dull and will not polish, so I assume it originally had some type of coating on it. What can I use to remove this coating so I can polish it? -L.C., Bordentown, N.J.

title: WATER-BASED STAINS WORK BEST ON PINE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Michael Varese restores furniture for antiques dealers and collectors. By MICHAEL VARESE

title: INTERFERON MAY EASE CHICKEN POX THREAT TO CANCER CHILDREN
description: Treatment with interferon, a natural antivirus substance, reduced the severity of chicken pox infections in children undergoing drug treatment for cancer, according to a report in the current issue of The New England Journal of Medicine.

title: Notes On People; New Head for Hayden
description: William Gutsch, an astronomer and writer of scripts for planetariums, has been appointed chairman of the American Museum of Natural History's Hayden Planetarium in New York.

title: SENATE BACKS EASIER BROADCAST RULES
description: The Senate, by voice vote, approved a bill today to deregulate the radio industry permanently, to insulate radio and TV stations from certain types of license challenges and to provide New Jersey with its first very high frequency television station.

title: Hoover Plans Bid
description: The Hoover Company, the vacuum cleaner and appliance maker, said in its annual report that it was planning an acquisition to broaden its domestic base.

title: Basque Group Says It Put Bomb on French Train
description: A Spanish ultrarightist group opposed to the Basque separatist movement said today it planted the bomb that killed five people and injured 27 on the Paris-Toulouse express train in France Monday evening.

title: Transcript of News Session, page A22.
description: President Reagan said tonight that because the Soviet Union had ''a definite margin of superiority'' over the United States in nuclear arms, he could not agree to proposals for an early freeze in atomic weapons.

title: Helpful Hardware; CARTS FOR THE HOME
description: CARTS made for institutions and industry to carry bulky loads are also useful for the homeowner for laundry, cleaning supplies and tools.

title: ABSCAM PANEL HEAD NAMED
description: Senate Republican leaders named Senator Republican leaders named Senator Chalres McC. Mathias Jr., Republican of Maryland, on Monday to head an eight-member committee that will review the tactics the Federal Bureau of investigation used in the Abscam operation, in which undercover agents posed as representatives of Arab sheiks while investigating political corruption. The committee was formed to look into charges of Government midconduct in the Abscam operation, which led to the indictment and conviction of seven members of Congress on influence-peddling charges.

title: Sabena Worker Pay Cut
description: Workers at Sabena Belgian World Airlines, the financially ailing national carrier, have accepted a series of austerity measures including wage cuts of up to 17 percent, the airline said today. The Belgian Government, Sabena's owner, has threatened to let the airline go bankrupt unless the company's payroll is cut by $20 million and at least $10 million is saved in other costs. Sabena, which has not been profitable since 1958, operates a fleet of 22 aircraft and has accumulated debts of almost $200 million.

title: OPEC SEES PRESSURE ON NIGERIA OIL
description: Companies buying oil from Nigeria have notified that country that they plan to phase out their purchases, according to a report yesterday by Opecna, the news agency of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. But, in response to strong pressure from Saudi Arabia and other OPEC members, the companies will continue to purchase oil through April, Opecna added.

title: Critic's Notebook; WHAT'S IN A NAME? TRAFFIC JAMS, THAT'S WHAT!
description: EVERY once in a while I receive a mimeographed form from one of the various organizations devoted to keeping our dictionaries up to date. Usually these forms ask questions about words that have recently been coined or about nouns that have - horrendously, for the most part - been turned into verbs: ''concertize,'' words like that. Do these constitute valuable additions to the mother tongue, to be incorporated into the better lexicons and duly cherished? Or are they barbarisms to be rooted out before they take firm hold, if they haven't taken firm hold already?

title: U.S. Begins Inquiry Into G.M. Vehicles
description: The Government today opened an investigation into safety defects involving the General Motors Corporation's entire fleet of mid-size automobiles and sedan pickup trucks for the model years 1978, 1979 and 1980, a total of 5.3 million vehicles.

title: TAIWAN'S IMPORT BAN WORRIES JAPANESE
description: Taiwan's unilateral import ban on 1,533 Japanese consumer items, which went into effect in February, is causing deep concern here.

title: THURSDAY, APRIL 1, 1982; The Economy
description: President Reagan said he was open to changes in his proposed budget for the fiscal year 1983, including ''possible'' military cuts, but he defended his economic policy and said he would reject any compromises to alter his plan to reduce 1983 income taxes. (Page A1.)

title: MOST JEWS QUIT NORTH SINAI, BUT SOME PREPARE TO RESIST
description: Occupied Sinai, March 31 - In trucks and vans loaded with furniture and farm equipment, most Jewish settlers completed their departure from northern Sinai today, leaving behind a hard core of several hundred militants who vowed to defy the deadline imposed by the army for leaving the area.

title: Sun Debt Payment
description: The Sun Company said it had prepaid $300 million of floating rate notes issued to Seagram Company Ltd. in connection with Sun's 1980 purchase of Seagram's Texas Pacific unit oil properties. The original amount of the notes was $900 million. Sun prepaid $400 million last year.

title: ADMINISTRATION PLANNING TO PROCEED WITH TAIWAN ARMS SALES SOON
description: The Reagan Administration intends to go ahead with the sale of $60 million in military spare parts to Taiwan in the next few weeks despite warnings from Peking that such sales could endanger Chinese-American relations.

title: Mets Cut 4, Lose to Reds
description: The Mets cut four players today, leaving them with 29, four above the limit. That was a problem Manager George Bamberger said might not be solved until Sunday, the final day of spring training.

title: FED: CRITICISM ON RATES
description: Until recently, soaring prices united nearly everyone against inflation and behind the Federal Reserve Board's restrictive monetary policies to get the inflation rate down. Thanks in part to the Fed, inflation has indeed fallen sharply, but so has the economy, while interest rates have remained perilously high.

title: THE SAME CARIBBEAN?
description: In his generally laudable speech announcing the new Caribbean basin initiative, President Reagan depicted Cuban adventurism and subversion as the core of Central America's and the Caribbean's problems. Whether his grim picture is accurate or not for Central America, it left many West Indians wondering whether he was talking about the same Caribbean they call home.

title: Home Improvement
description: THIS is the time of year when many owners assess the condition of the exterior paint on their houses, checking for blistering, peeling and cracking.

title: Luxembourg Strike Planned
description: Workers plan a one-day strike on Monday that will affect primarily public transport and steel, the country's main industry, unions announced today. The strike, the first here in 60 years, is to protest Government austerity measures that were necessitated by a currency devaluation that was needed by Belgium, with which Luxembourg has a currency union.

title: COVERT AGENTS KNOWN BY ONE AND ALL
description: To the Editor:

title: STOUFFER TRIAL DEFENSE PLANS TO CALL ONLY TWO WITNESSES
description: A day after the judge in the Stouffer's Inn arson and murder trial told the prosecutor that he had failed to prove his case, the lawyers for the defendant said that they would call only two witnesses instead of the dozen or so originally scheduled. The prosecution called 42 witnesses over a four-week period.

title: WORLDWIDE OIL OUTPUT DECLINED 6.2% LAST YEAR
description: World production of crude oil fell 6.2 percent in 1981, with OPEC nations accounting for most of the decline, Petroleum Information International, a petroleum newsletter, said yesterday. The Houston publication said that 1981 output dropped by 3.6 million barrels a day, to 55.58 million, from 59.23 million in 1980.

title: RIGHTIST FLAG BEARER
description: It was election day in El Salvador, and at the headquarters of the Nationalist Republican Alliance, Roberto d'Aubuisson's aides were trying to decide where their candidate should vote.

title: Accounts
description: * Business Week magazine to Ayer Direct, a division of N.W. Ayer Inc., for circulation promotion. * Alperts Furniture, Seekonk, Mass., to Ingalls Associates, Boston.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We're like the Russian church on the eve of the revolution, arguing about the design of our vestments.'' - Senator Mark O. Hatfield, on debate on tax benefit. (A24:4.)

title: BANKS SET TO SIGN POLISH PACT
description: An agreement to reschedule $2.4 billion in debt that Poland failed to pay 500 Western banks last year will be signed in Frankfurt next Tuesday, an official of the Dresdner Bank of West Germany said today.

title: Nippon RAM Output
description: The Nippon Electric Company said today that it would start production of 64K RAM, or random access memory, semiconductors at its Scottish plant, under construction at Livingston, near Edinburgh, next October. It said it had set an initial production target of between 250,000 and 300,000 64K chips a month. Japanese products now account for about 70 percent of the world market share of 64K RAM's.

title: Washington Post Asks For Data on 2 Iranians
description: Arguing that citizenship is ''a matter of public record,'' an attorney for The Washington Post urged the Supreme Court today to give the newspaper access to documents that would confirm whether two Iranians were United States citizens.

title: WILLIAMS'S PROBLEMS CITED
description: The weight of personal responsibilities was cited yesterday as the major reason for conduct that has led Sly Williams, the Knicks' forward, to be suspended three times within the last two months. Williams was suspended for the remainder of the season when he failed to show up for last Tuesday night's game.

title: Ray Bloch, Conductor On TV and Radio, 79
description: Ray Bloch, the conductor dubbed by Jackie Gleason as ''the flower of the music world,'' died of a heart attack Monday in Miami. He was 79 years old.

title: The U.N. Today; April 1, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Committee on Nonuse of Force - 3 P.M.

title: SENATORS PRESERVE TAX BREAK, THEN APPROVE EMERGENCY MONEY BILL
description: After two days of angry debate, the Senate voted today to preserve, at least temporarily, a tax benefit the lawmakers enacted for themselves last year. The Senate then went on to pass emergency legislation needed to finance seven departments of the Government after midnight.

title: PARTY'S PALETTE INCLUDES ITALIAN PRESIDENT
description: THE worlds of art, politics and society met, mingled and parted on amicable terms Tuesday night when the Museum of Modern Art held a black-tie preview of its exhibition of Giorgio de Chirico, the late Italian painter.

title: TV: SAVING REAGAN'S LIFE
description: ''THE SAVING of the President'' is, quite simply, a television event so dramatic, so moving and so apparently authentic that the journalistic issues raised by the unusual form it takes seem secondary. At 10 o'clock tonight, ABC News' ''20/20'' will devote its first half-hour to ''The Saving of the President,'' a re-creation of the successful effort by a medical team at George Washington Hospital to save President Reagan's life in the hours after he was felled by a would-be assassin's bullet a year ago Wednesday.

title: Puerto Rico Ads Aim At Apparel Makers
description: In its effort to lure more business to the island of Puerto Rico, the Puerto Rico Economic Development Administration is taking aim at apparel manufacturers.

title: U.S. STEEL SELLS 50% OF ITS SHIPPING UNIT
description: The United States Steel Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell a 50 interest in its ocean shipping subsidiary to Federal Pacific Ltd., a Montreal-based shipping company controlled by the Pathy family.

title: Beirut Car Bomb Kills 2
description: A car bomb exploded today in the largely Christian eastern half of the city, killing two people and wounding four, the Christian-run Voice of Lebanon radio reported. The radio station said the male driver of the car and a female companion were killed when the bomb exploded ''prematurely'' just after the car crossed from Moslem West Beirut. Four passers-by were wounded, it said.

title: CONCERT: DIXON LEADS FENNELLY'S 'EMPIRICAL RAG'
description: ONE of the least understood and most often ignored developments in 20th-century music has been the gradual erosion of a sense of pulse, which is similar to but not quite the same as rhythm. Composers in our time have been so fearful of falling into anything resembling the music of recent centuries, with their strong and seemingly simple body rhythms, that they have commonly gone to the extreme of writing music that lacks any sort of regular pulsation.

title: A NUCLEAR STANDOFF
description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * State Street Boston Corp.'s long-term debt was rated A by Moody's Investors Service, up from Baa. The corporation is the holding company for the State Street Bank and Trust Company in Boston.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Anacomp Inc. said it had agreed in principle to sell the micrographics centers of D.S.I. Corp. Anacomp had previously agreed to buy D.S.I. Corp. but the antitrust division of the Justice Department said the micrographics centers had raised anticompetitive problems. The identities of the buyers were not disclosed.

title: Ballet Theater II Back
description: The 10-year-old second company to the American Ballet Theater, American Ballet Theater II, will return Saturday to New York, after a tour, to participate in a workshop. The troupe will perform in the Far East from June 14-30 in a five-city tour of South Korea and Japan.

title: General Steel Link To Lukens Set
description: General Steel Industries said its shareholders had approved the company's merger with the Lukens Steel Company. Officials said 66 percent of G.S.I.'s common shares had been voted in favor of the merger at a meeting here.

title: JAY PANZIRER, HEADED HELMSLEY BUYING UINT
description: Jay Panzirer, the stepson of Harry B. Helmsley, the real-estate and hotel chain entrepreneur, died yesterday of a heart attack in Orlando, Fla. He was 42 years old and lived in nearby Maitland.

title: Market Place; Interest Grows In Alexander's
description: TO some on Wall Street, Alexander's, the discount department store, looks more like a real estate play than a retailer. Speculation that the company's valuable properties may one day be put to more profitable use could explain why the shares rose 2 3/8, to 11 1/4, yesterday for the best percentage gain on the Big Board.

title: NEAR CRASH IS LAID TO ERROR BY AIR CONTROLLER
description: Because of an error by a veteran air traffic controller, a Trans World Airlines jumbo jet and a smaller Northwest Airlines jet came close to colliding over Lake Michigan early last month, it was disclosed yesterday.

title: 192 SPECIES OF FISH ABOUND IN CITY AREA OF THE HUDSON
description: Fish teem in the Hudson River in the New York City area, and economically the most important are striped bass and American shad, a state expert said yesterday. Both, he said, are anadromous - that is, they come from salt water to spawn in fresh water, then return to the ocean.

title: SENATE UNIT CLEARS TRUST BILL
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee, after months of fierce lobbying by companies with hundreds of millions of dollars at stake, approved an antitrust bill today that would make major changes in the way damages are assessed in price-fixing cases.

title: Dow Jones Futures Suit
description: Dow Jones & Company said yesterday that it had asked a Federal court to block the Chicago Board of Trade from trading futures contracts based on the Dow Jones stock indexes.

title: THE U.S. MUST HELP SMALL AND VITAL INNOVATORS
description: To the Editor:

title: A Rescue of Sea Law
description: The Reagan Administration seems to have struck a decent deal to preserve the chances for a global law of the sea. It traded some capitalist philosophy for higher capitalist profits.

title: BURGER KING USA GETS NEW PRESIDENT
description: J. Jeffrey Campbell was named president and chief operating officer of Burger King USA yesterday. He succeeds Jerry Ruenheck, who was promoted to president of the Burger King Corporation, which is responsible for the restaurants both in this country and abroad. There are 3,200 worldwide units, and Burger King USA operates more than 3,000 of these.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE

title: WINDOW OF OPPORTUNITY
description: Soviet gestures for dialogue with China, which were expected as the first move of any new leadership group in the Kremlin, have already begun. Peking has not responded directly, but it is making sharp noises at Washington threatening to downgrade relations over the Taiwan arms sale issue.

title: LELGISLATURE ADOPTS RESTRICTION ON WESTWAY FUNDS
description: The Legislature adopted tonight a restriction on financing for the Westway project, despite a warning by Governor Carey that the measure was ''dangerous'' and a broad hint that he would veto it.

title: People
description: * Walter S. McKenzie elected a partner of Laird & Kudner Direct Marketing.

title: Sports People; George Allen's Dilemma
description: Only six weeks ago, when Nelson Skalbania hired him as the president and chief operating officer of the Canadian Football League's Montreal Alouettes, George Allen seemed to have found a new life in the sport to which he is devoted. Now Allen says that the situation in Montreal has grown so ''ludicrous'' and ''bizarre'' that he might quit.

title: Looking the Other Way
description: Marijuana smoking and cocaine use seem to have become a tradition for some fans at Golden State Warrior home games. The Hayward Daily Review newspaper said Tuesday that last Friday and Sunday nights more than 800 people were seen openly using marijuana, cocaine or other drugs at halftime on the unlighted ramps of the Oakland-Alameda County Coliseum Arena.

title: Garrett Morris to Star In 5 Ben Caldwell Plays
description: Garrett Morris, who was one of the regulars on NBC-TV's ''Saturday Night Live,'' will star in ''The World of Ben Caldwell,'' five short plays with introductory monologues by Mr. Caldwell. The work is being produced by Woodie King Jr. and Steve Tennen and will open today at the New Federal Theater at the Henry Street Settlement, 466 Grand Street.

title: SOVIET FAILS TO UTILIZE PIPE CREDIT
description: The Soviet Union allowed a $1.1 billion line of credit from Dutch banks to expire today without using the credit to purchase Dutch equipment for construction of a planned 3,000-mile natural gas pipeline from Siberia.

title: Warner, RCA Set Accord
description: Warner Home Video, a division of Warner Communications, has given RCA a license to put 35 Warner movies on videodisk, the first time Warner movies will be produced on the RCA disk format.

title: NEW SEASON, TOO, FOR BASEBALL BOOKS
description: Each new season rekindles hopes in the hearts of fans that it will bring fame, fortune and a pennant to their hometown, but fans are not the only ones for whom there is eternal hope. Year in and out, publishers issue a flurry of baseball books, whose odds of winning fame and fortune are only slightly better than the odds that this year's World Series will be played in Wrigley Field.

title: SOME ACTING JUSTICES ARE CHALLENGED
description: As defense lawyers and prosecutors privately questioned whether acting Supreme Court justices were still legally empowered to decide cases in the light of an appeals court ruling, some lawyers began to challenge the judges in court.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate payable by savings institutionsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: John L. Messina, 60, Is Dead; Westchester Political Leader
description: John L. Messina, a Republican member of the Westchester County Board of Legislators and former Mayor of Port Chester, died of cancer Monday at the Yale-New Haven Hospital in New Haven. He was 60 years old and a lifetime resident of Port Chester.

title: Judge Acquits Police Officer In Death of Yonkers Man, 22
description: A New York City police officer who killed a 22-year-old Yonkers man in Van Cordlandt Park last year after an automobile accident was acquitted in a nonjury trial yesterday of charges of criminally negligent homicide.

title: Briefing
description: A Voice From the Past

title: Continental Fills Posts
description: Continental Air Lines announced today that it had named Francisco A. Lorenzo as chairman, succeeding Robert F. Six, the airline's founder, who has retired.

title: 50 KILLED BY MEXICAN VOLCANO
description: A long-dormant volcano that erupted Sunday has killed at least 50 people in a 10-square mile area in southern Mexico, officials said today.

title: KEY U.S. DIPLOMATS DERIDED BY TOON
description: Malcolm Toon, a former Ambassador to Moscow, said today that the Reagan Administration was using United States diplomatic posts ''as a dumping ground'' for defeated politicians and Republican financial backers.

title: News Analysis
description: New York State has 1,200 megawatts of electric power to sell at 1960's prices, and the decision of Westchester County voters on Tuesday to grab for part of that capacity may prompt a flood of other applicants, forcing 50 municipal electric systems now using the power to share it for the first time in decades.

title: ARGENTINE REGIME IS HOLDING 400 AFTER WIDESPREAD PROTESTS
description: The military Government said today that 400 people were being held for taking part in protests across the country against the regime's economic austerity program in violation of a ban on demonstrations.

title: REAGAN BREAKS EVEN IN A PERFORMANCE POLL
description: About as many Americans disapprove of how President Reagan is handling his job as those who approve of his performance, according to the latest Gallup Poll. Forty-six percent approve and 45 percent disapprove.

title: Hers
description: BOB MILLER of San Francisco is a light artist who uses the sun as his palette and prisms and mirrors for paintbrushes. One of his pieces is a collection of silver Christmas tree balls that reflect images into infinity and crinkle them up at the edges until they disappear. A few years ago he stuck his box of reflections on a long ''stem,'' planted it in a flower box, surrounded the bottom with junipers and displayed it at a local art fair. A small boy became enchanted with it and asked his mother, ''What's that?'' Bob happened to be standing nearby when she answered, yanking the boy away, ''I don't know, but it has something to do with physics.''

title: VENERABLE 'LTD.' LIMITED IN BRITAIN
description: Because of an obscure Common Market regulation, nearly all of Britain's largest and most venerable companies are being forced to drop the unmistakably British ''Ltd.'' from the end of their corporate names.

title: CITY U. QUIETLY PRESSING SEARCH FOR A CHANCELLOR
description: The search for a new chancellor for the City University of New York, which was to have been completed last month, is proceeding more slowly than expected and will continue for at least another month.

title: Olivetti Computer
description: Ing. C. Olivetti & Company, the Italian business machine manufacturer, said it had introduced a personal computer, called the M-20, with which it hopes to gain a major share of the rapidly growing computer market.

title: WHAT TO DO THIS MONTH
description: Spring Cleanup As spring advances and the city garden calls for rejuvenation, wash soot off evergreen plants by directing a stream at the tops and undersides of leaves or needles. A sponge bath with mild dishwasher detergent is even better. Remove and discard all decorative boughs or other winter mulch or protection from terrace containers, yards and street tree pits. Clear leaves and dirt from drains. Sweep terrace corners and behind planters.

title: GIBSON HAS 'KEPT COOL' IN FACE OF PAST CHARGES
description: Kenneth A. Gibson seems to be facing his indictment on misconduct and conspiracy charges in the same unruffled manner that has been his trademark through 12 years as Mayor of Newark.

title: Democrats Hail Fund-Raiser
description: More than 1,300 Democrats gathered here tonight for a $1,000-a-plate dinner whose proceeds are to be used to bolster the chances of their 1982 Congressional candidates. Sponsors said the dinner was the most successful fund-raiser the party had ever held and predicted it would net more than $1 million.

title: HOPE OF DESEGREGATION IS FADING IN BOSTON'S TROUBLED SCHOOLS
description: For two weeks after a black man was chased and taunted by a group of adolescent whites and then killed on the tracks in a Boston subway station, teachers and administrators walked delicately down the corridors of this city's court-integrated schools.

title: KOCH THE CANDIDATE MENDS FENCE TO WHITE HOUSE
description: When Richard S. Williamson, a Presidential adviser, entered a reception held here last week by New York City's lobbying office, Mayor Koch, who was in town on a two-day visit, asked him a familiar question:

title:
Sports of The Times;
AN INHERENT RISK
description: OUT behind the tote board at Aqueduct yesterday, seagulls soared near the blue-white-and-black New York Racing Association flag, which was fluttering at half-staff.

title: Chalk, Nissen to Do Logan Ads for K Mart
description: K Mart has selected Chalk, Nissen, Hanft, to be the ad agency for the Jonathan Logan brand women's sportswear that the Kayser-Roth Corporation is going to manufacture under a licensing agreement with Jonathan Logan.

title: Marcos Says He'll Seek Revision of U.S. Pact
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that he intended to ask Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger for an early renegotiation of the $500 million military bases agreement with the United States. The 35-year-old accord, which is up for renewal in 1984, still contains ''irritants and inequities,'' Mr. Marcos said.

title: DESTROYING THE DREAM
description: Look past the headlines from Israel these days -the dismissal of West Bank Mayors, the resulting protest, the shooting of Arab demonstrators - and you see a fundamental reality: Israel is trying, by force, to bring a million Palestinians under its permanent control.

title: THEATER: CENTURY OF BLACKS
description: LESLIE LEE'S ''Colored People's Time,'' the latest production from the Negro Ensemble Company, is nothing less than a history of black America from the eve of the Civil War to the Montgomery, Ala., bus boycott a century later. Given the subject, one might expect a work roughly as long as ''Roots II,'' but Mr. Lee has found a more economical, not to mention easier, way out. His play consists of 13 tidy vignettes, each with different fictional characters, each set at a moment when momentous social change is in the wind. Blink, and you just may miss World War I.

title: Going Out Guide
description: NEW ROOM

title: BAD FAITH ON ECOLOGY LAID TO REAGAN
description: Ten of the nation's leading environmental and conservation groups asserted today that President Reagan had ''broken faith with the American people on environmental protection.''

title: 11 More Haitian Bodies Found on Florida Coast
description: Eleven more bodies were found today on Florida beaches, apparently raising to at least 20 the death toll from a sunken Haitian freighter.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Television and Communications Corporation, a Denverbased subsidiary of Time Inc., has named Thomas W. Binning to a new post, senior vice president-cable investments.

title: GIBSON INDICTED FOR MISCONDUCT OVER A CITY JOB
description: A special grand jury indicted Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson and the City Council President today on seven counts of conspiracy and official misconduct.

title: HOWARD BEN TR E'S SCULPTURES IN GLASS
description: The term sculpture is increasingly used these days to define the work of certain studio glassworkers, and Howard Ben Tre's work, which is on display at the Hadler-Rodriguez Galleries through April 17, exemplifies the sculptural approach.

title: Advertising; Mobilizing A 'Western Air Force'
description: THOSE newsreel cameramen of yesteryear surely knew how to make the patriotic juices flow with those shots of flights of American bombers and fighter planes roaring overhead in formation. It took the breath away, inspired, made prideful.

title: Rains Flush Remnants Of Formaldehyde to Sea
description: Heavy rains along California's north coast today flushed the remnants of a 21,000-gallon formaldehyde spill on the Russian River out to sea.

title: Sports People; Arizona Hires Coach
description: Ben Lindsey accepted the job as basketball coach at Arizona two hours after Jack Hartman of Kansas State turned it down.

title: Braniff Holds Debt Talks
description: The Braniff International Corporation presented a plan yesterday to restructure its $733.2 million of debt to 39 of its creditors at a meeting in its headquarters at Dallas-Forth Worth Airport.

title: HATFIELD'S ARMS STAND: EVANGELICAL INFLUENCE
description: Before Senator Mark O. Hatfield of Oregon stepped to the lectern of the Rose City Park Methodist Church in Portland the other day, the Rev. James Jenkins presented the speaker in telling fashion.

title: PIANO RECITAL: MISS BOTTAZZI
description: THE Argentine-born pianist Ana Maria Trenchi de Bottazzi offered an encyclopedic program Sunday at Carnegie Hall, opening with a pair of sonatas by Domenico Scarlatti, closing with Ginastera's athletic first sonata (1952), and covering much ground in between with works by Beethoven, Chopin, Debussy and the contemporary American composer Harold Zabrack.

title: WINDS SUSPECTED IN CHUTE ACCIDENTS
description: Army officials said today that unexpectedly high pockets of wind might have caused whirlpool-like conditions near the ground Tuesday and contributed to the deaths of four paratroopers and injuries to 156 in a big airdrop here.

title: AMTRAK AND PRIVATE INVESTORS PLAN CALIFORNIA 'BULLET TRAIN'
description: An investor group working with Amtrak announced yesterday that a corporation has been formed to raise $2 billion to build a high-speed ''bullet'' train service between Los Angeles and San Diego.

title: CHAMBER: LINCOLN SOCIETY PLAYS HAYDN
description: THE Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center managed to be both unusual and substantial in its Monday night concert at Alice Tully Hall.

title: HERBERT M. DIAMOND
description: Dr. Herbert maynard diamond, who served Lehigh University as an economics professor, department head and acting dean before his retirement in 1964, died last Friday in St. Luke's Hospital in Bethlehem, Pa.

title: COMPETITION HELD KEY TO LOWER MEDICAL COST
description: When James R. Steinbach, a 62-year-old pipefitter, recently needed open-heart surgery, he faced an interesting new choice.

title: A.M.C. Backs Tax Leasing
description: The chairman of the American Motors Corporation, W. Paul Tippett Jr., told Congress today that repeal of a new law that makes it easier for businesses to buy and sell their tax benefits would result in severe unemployment.

title: Heublein Spirits Group Drops McCann
description: McCann-Erickson's Los Angeles office may have been entering a war on behalf of a client, but the New York office was getting bombed. The missile was droped by Heublein, a client since 1979, and it was in the form of a news release announcing that its spirits group is removing all brands at McCann's and distributing them to two of its other agencies.

title: ENVOY TO AUSTRIA
description: Theodore E. Cummings, United States Ambassador to Austria, his native country, died Tuesday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles after a long illness. He was 74 years old and lived in Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: Arthur Treacher's To Be Acquired
description: An Ohio investors group said it had agreed to acquire all the assets and liabilities of Arthur Treacher's Fish and Chips Inc., a unit of Mrs. Paul's Kitchen Inc., a closely held Philadelphia processor of frozen fish and vegetables.

title: Continental Phone In Telecom Pact
description: Northern Telecom Inc., the United States unit of Northern Telecom Ltd., said it had signed a three-year agreement valued at $100 million to supply its digital multiplex systems to the Continental Telephone Corporation.

title: South Africa Restricts 3 Black Union Leaders
description: The Government has banned three black trade union activists for two years each, the South African Press Association said today.

title: PHILADELPHIANS HONORING ONE OF THEIR OWN, PRINCESS GRACE
description: Grace Kelly, the daughter of a Philadelphia family who became a film actress and then Princess Grace of Monaco, returned today to a heroine's welcome, to an anointment, it seemed, as one of the city's tricentennial treasures.

title: News Analysis
description: On both right and left, the Reagan Administration finds its strategic arms policies under challenge and feels compelled to mount a vigorous counterattack to try to hold together the consensus in favor of an arms buildup that was strong a year ago but has now begun to unravel.

title: CSR of Australia Completes Loan
description: CSR Ltd., an Australian energy concern and sugar producer, said it had completed a borrowing package totaling $950 million (in United States currency) to refinance its previously announced purchase of the Delhi International Oil Company.

title: Sports People; Borg Gets Extra Day
description: The organizers at Monte Carlo have given Bjorn Borg an extra day to train for the Grand Prix tournament there, which will mark his return to competitive tennis for the first time in five months. Borg, who was to have played in a qualifying round today, will instead make his 1982 debut tomorrow.

title: CONCERT: TORONTO SYMPHONY IN 'PATH ETIQUE'
description: THAT the Toronto Symphony has made steady gains under the leadership of the English conductor Andrew Davis, its music director since 1975, was evident in the orchestra's performance Monday in Carnegie Hall, even if the playing at times lacked the consistency and finish of America's top-drawer ensembles. Though ensemble in the strings is still spotty on ocasion, what was a muddy sound several seasons ago is now certifiably ''dark,'' a weighty sound well-suited to the East European repertory that Mr. Davis seems to favor. A number of key wind and brass positions are impressively filled, and the orchestra plays with alertness and commitment.

title: SCIENTISTS MODERATE ESTIMATES OF OZONE DEPLETION
description: The National Research Council today cut by more than half its previous estimate of how much the earth's protective layer of ozone was being depleted by man-made chlorofluorocarbons released into the atmosphere, although it indicated it still saw reason for concern.

title: RANGERS WIN, 4-1, CLINCH 2ND PLACE
description: The Rangers clinched second place in the Patrick Division tonight by defeating the Black Hawks, 4-1, at Chicago Stadium.

title: Eglevsky to End Season With Pair of Premieres
description: The Eglevsky Ballet will end its season April 17 with ''Americana'' at the C.W. Post Theater and April 23, 24 and 25 at the Hofstra Playhouse.

title: SORTING OUT RULES FOR PAYING HOUSEHOLD HELP AND SOCIAL SECURITY
description: ONCE a good housekeeper or cleaning person has been found, one of the most troublesome issues to be faced by both employer and employee is how to handle the pay for tax purposes.

title: CAPITAL INVESTMENT IN SEMICONDUCTORS EXPANDED BY JAPAN
description: Japan's semiconductor industry, pushing to increase production, is in the midst of a big investment campaign that is likely to put further competitive pressure on American semiconductor makers, according to a major private survey.

title: Turk Killed in Truck Crash
description: A truck carrying liquid gas crashed into the city maternity hospital at Gaziantep, southeast Turkey, on Wednesday, killing one person, injuring three, then exploding and setting the building afire.

title: THURSDAY, APRIL 1, 1982
description: International A speedy freeze in nuclear arms was rejected by President Reagan because of what he called Moscow's ''definite margin of superiority'' over Washington in the weapons. But Mr. Reagan, at a news conference, said he remained committed to seeking an agreement with the Kremlin for reducing nuclear weapons ''dramatically.'' (Page A1, Column 6.) Salvadoran election officials announced that the centrist Christian Democratic Party apparently won 24 of the 60 seats in the new constituent assembly. The party began efforts to deter the five right-wing parties from joining in a conservative coalition that would deprive it of power. (A1:3.)

title: THE U.S. MUST HELP SMALL AND VITAL INNOVATORS
description: To the Editor:

title: CONDITION OF THE SPACE SHUTTLE HAILED AS 'TERRIFIC'
description: The space shuttle Columbia survived its eight-day flight in ''terrific condition'' with less apparent damage than on the first two missions, space officials announced today.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Sohio to Buy Coal Mine
description: The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) said it had agreed to buy a West Virginia coal mine owned by the Republic Steel Corporation and certain other Republic assets for $105 million.

title: Some Stability Returns To World Sugar Prices
description: Prices of world sugar futures appeared to stabilize yesterday after declining for six consecutive weeks. During that period the market, which had been under pressure of rising surpluses of cane and beet sugar for more than a year, was further depressed by rising imports.

title: SAINT LAURENT: NO FUSS, JUST STYLE
description: To almost no one's surprise, Yves Saint Laurent has done it again. He has put the business of fashion in perspective, made a definitive comment on how women can dress to face the perplexities of modern life and shown some very attractive clothes to boot.

title: Judging the Judge on Judges
description: The lawsuit filed by the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert Morgenthau, against New York state's Chief Judge, Lawrence Cooke, has climbed another step of the judiciary - to new heights of institutional folly.

title: SCOUTMASTER DIED OF HYPOTHERMIA IN CAVE, JERSEY AUTOPSY INDICATES
description: Scoutmaster Donald Weltner, whose body was retrieved late Tuesday night from a limestone cave in Lafayette Township, N.J., died of hypothermia, or severe exposure, suffered in his entombment for three and a half days in a narrow, sloping crevice about 16 feet underground, an autopsy indicated yesterday.

title: LONGER-TERM SECURITIES GAIN
description: Prices of notes and bonds rose yesterday, spurred by bargain hunting among foreign and domestic investors, as well as buying by speculators who were sellers earlier in the week.

title: DAVIS SET TO MAKE NEW START IN RING
description: In 1976, Olympic boxing officials voted Howard Davis, then of Glen Cove and now of Dix Hills, L.I., the outstanding fighter in the Games at Montreal. But while the other American gold medalists - Sugar Ray Leonard, Leon Spinks, Michael Spinks and Leo Randolph - went on to become world professional champions, Davis became almost forgotten.

title: FROM POLISH INTERNMENT PRISONS, TALES OF BRUTALITY
description: One day this week, letters written by martial law detainees were tossed out of the upper floors of a prison in the northern Polish town of Ilawa and fluttered down across the gray, barbed-wire topped wall onto the streets. They described a brutal assault inside the prison last Thursday.

title: CONCERT: CONTINUUM BUILDS AN EVENING AROUND WOLPE
description: OCCASIONALLY there comes an artist with the power to change an age. More often, however, it is the times that shape an art. Stefan Wolpe, whose music Continuum celebrated Saturday night at Alice Tully Hall, seems more the mirror of his times than a shaper. He was born in Berlin in 1902 and died in America in 1972; in between, his music followed as many different directions as there were social and artistic movements around him.

title: CHAD PEACE FORCE SEEKING U.N. FUNDS
description: The Organization of African Unity will seek United Nations financing to overcome a critical cash shortage facing its peacekeeping force in Chad, according to the Kenyan Foreign Minister.

title: DUARTE PARTY FIGHTS TO PREVENT RIGHTISTS FROM JOINING FORCES
description: With nearly all of the votes from Sunday's election counted, El Salvador's Central Elections Council announced today that the centrist Christian Democratic Party of President Jose Napoleon Duarte appeared to have won 24 of the 60 seats in the new constituent assembly. Leaders of the party moved to deter the five other parties from joining in a conservative coalition that would deprive them of power.

title: Technology; Cogeneration Of Energy
description: WHAT is one to make of all the talk about the ''end of the energy crisis?'' Not much, to judge by the persistent interest of industrial, commercial and institutional energy managers in finding new ways to be more energy efficient. The professional energy managers do not expect energy prices ever to return to the low levels of the early 1970's, or even to stabilize at today's levels.

title: HOUSING DISCRIMINATION: THE WAR IS NOT WON
description: To the Editor:

title: Allen Tells Japanese Premier He Will Work to Improve Ties
description: President Reagan's former adviser, Richard V. Allen, told Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki of Japan today that he would continue his efforts to eliminate communication gaps between the United States and Japan, a spokesman for the Prime Minister's office said.

title: DEPARTMENT STORES SET FLOWER SHOWS
description: Tonight at 9 P.M., after the last customer has gone, several trailer trucks will pull up to Macy's Herald Square to unload about 30 ficus trees from Florida.

title: Dow Off 1.72; Trading Slows
description: Stock prices eased slightly yesterday in slow trading. Analysts said that many investors moved to the sidelines as they awaited President Reagan's televised news conference scheduled for last night.

title: Publicker Has Loss
description: Publicker Industries reported yesterday that it had a loss of $13.2 million in the fourth quarter of 1981, compared with a loss of $1.4 million in the fourth quarter of 1980.

title: Seales Wins Decision, Continuing Comeback
description: Sugar Ray Seales, an Olympic champion in 1972, continued his comeback in the middleweight division with a unanimous 10-round decision over John LoCicero at the Felt Forum last night.

title: PRESIDENT'S NEWS CONFERENCE ON FOREIGN AND DOMESTIC MATTERS
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's news conference in Washington last night, as recorded by The New York Times: OPENING STATEMENT

title: Sports People; A Page From 'Alice'
description: A Federal judge in Newark chided the World Boxing Association for its ''Alice in Wonderland'' rules but delayed judgment on a suit by Tony Ayala. The suit would prevent the W.B.A. from staging a juniormiddleweight title bout between Davey Moore, the champion, and Charlie Weir in Johannesburg on April 24.

title: NUCLEAR-ARMS OPPOSITION WIDENS IN NEW YORK AREA
description: Through such activities as petition drives on the Staten Island Ferry, church meetings in the New Jersey suburbs, a high school essay contest in Rockland County, efforts to halt the nuclear arms race are spreading in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Neil McConnell Weds Sandra Merriman
description: In the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church yesterday, Sandra Dorothea Haig Merriman was married to Neil A. McConnell by the Rev. Thomas D. Bowers.

title: N.& W.-Piedmont
description: The Norfolk & Western Railway said it had received final approval from the Civil Aeronautics Board for its purchase, valued at $56.7 million, of a 20.2 percent interest in Piedmont Aviation Inc., the holding company for Piedmont Airlines. Since no opposition to the stock acquisition was filed with the C.A.B. by March 24, the deadline set for such filing, the agency's final approval become effective on that date, the railroad noted. Under an agreement signed on Jan. 26, N.& W. will not acquire additional Piedmont shares during the next five years without Piedmont's permission.

title: BREZHNEV IS REPORTED IN HOSPITAL
description: Rumors have spread here that Leonid I. Brezhnev, the 75-year-old Soviet leader, has been hospitalized. A Soviet press spokesman said he had no information on the matter nor was it possible to substantiate the rumors through other sources.

title: Bridge Hungarian Analysts' Book Apparently Has No Flaws
description: The multitude of books that analyze bridge deals are subject to an unhappy generalization: The reader who looks hard enough will find an error.

title: ALVIN DAVIS, NEWSMAN IN CITY
description: Alvin Davis, a former managing editor of The New York Post and an editor at The New York Times, died yesterday at his home in Brooklyn Heights after a long illness. He was 56 years old.

title: LEFTISTS FIRE ROCKETS AT THE U.S. EMBASSY IN GUATEMALA CITY
description: Leftist rebels in two speeding cars fired rockets and submachine guns at the American Embassy in downtown Guatemala City today, but no one was reported injured and only slight damage was done to the building, Government officials said.

title: THE UNEXPECTED RENAISSANCE OF THE FRENCH DOOR
description: LIGHT has always been a problem in New York City apartments. In buildings of the 1920's and 30's, where rambling apartments of 12 to 15 rooms predominate, french doors became a popular way of separating rooms while allowing light to filter from one space to the next.

title: U.S. JUDGE BLOCKS WESTWAY LANDFILL AS THREAT TO FISH
description: A 200-acre landfill needed for the construction of the Westway was blocked yesterday by a court decision based on a possible threat to striped bass in the Hudson River.

title: Briefing
description: Funeral Alternatives

title: A Richer Wimbledon
description: Wimbledon organizers announced today an 84 percent increase in prize money for this year's tournament, putting the total beyond $1 million for the first time. The new total is $1,068,060, an increase of $487,800 from last year. The men's singles winner will receive $75,000, a raise of $36,000 from last year, and the women's champion will receive $67,500, an increase of $32,400.

title: U.S. Official Supports Civil Defense Proposal
description: A senior Defense Department official today supported the Reagan Administration's civil defense program as a ''modest'' effort that was ''little more than insurance against the remote chance of a nuclear war.''

title: PRICES PAID TO FARMERS DOWN 0.8%
description: Prices that farmers received for raw products declined eight-tenths of 1 percent in March, after edging higher in the two previous months, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: UNITED NATIONS
description: Pesident Sandro Peertini of Italy today discussed international issues, particularly the problems Central America, during a 45 minute meeting with Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar.

title: MASTERING BABSON VIEW OF BUSINESS
description: Getting used to all that ivy can be fun. When William R. Dill, 51, was dean of New York University's Graduate School of Business Administration, he lived in Greenwich Village. Now he lives in a house on the campus of Babson College, 20 minutes from downtown Boston. He became Babson's president last fall. ''The house goes with the job,'' Dr. Dill said, ''and it's a delightful environment.''

title: MERCE CUNNINGHAM LECTURE
description: The career and choreography of Merce Cunningham will be discussed by David Vaughan tonight at 8:30 at the Kitchen, 484 Broome Street. Mr. Vaughan, author of ''Frederick Ashton and His Ballets,'' will illustrate his lecture with excerpts from videotapes and films, including rare footage from early performances. Tickets are $3 . Call 925-3615.

title: White Motor Reports Loss
description: The White Motor Corporation, operating under bankruptcy laws, said in a statement released here today that it had lost $4.7 million in the nine months ended Dec. 31.

title: JON HENDRICKS BRINGS BACK STYLE OF BIG-BAND ERA
description: THE singing trio of Lambert, Hendricks and Ross, which was a sensation in the jazz world 20 years ago, broke up in 1964. But the spirit and the style and one member of that group, Jon Hendricks, can be heard tonight and tomorrow at Lush Life. There, Mr. Hendricks, his wife, Judith, his daughter, Michelle, and Bob Gurland, a baritone who is not a member of the Hendrick's family, are singing some of the songs that Mr. Hendricks and Dave Lambert started creating in the late 50's along with others that Mr. Hendricks has written more recently.

title: ALLBRITTON AGREES TO TAKE OVER NEWS
description: Joe L. Allbritton, a Texas financier with experience in running distressed newspapers, has agreed to take over The Daily News, he and the owners of The News said yesterday.

title: China Tax Changes
description: China today announced new tax exemption rules for foreign companies developing its offshore petroleum fields. The rules, effective immediately, exempt several categories of equipment and materials from customs duties, the official New China News Agency said. The exemptions are for machinery, equipment, spare parts and materials imported for direct use in offshore petroleum exploration and for machine parts, accessories and materials for the manufacturing in China of machinery and equipment to be used in offshore development.

title: Sea-Law Compromise Is Welcomed by U.S.
description: The United States today welcomed a compromise proposal for mining the minerals on the sea floor, calling it ''a step forward.''

title: ST. CLARE'S TO FILE FOR BANKRUPTCY
description: St. Clare's Hospital and Health Center on Manhattan's West Side announced yesterday that it would file for bankruptcy today in Federal District Court in an effort to avert its closing.

title: Enders Asserts d'Aubuisson Will Be Allowed to Visit U.S.
description: A State Department official said today that Roberto d'Aubuisson, the Salvadoran rightist banned from the United States for two years, would be allowed to come to this country to meet with policy makers.

title: SENATE PANEL ASKS SHAVING OF OUTLAY FOR THE MILITARY
description: The Senate Armed Services Committee today proposed shaving $3.2 billion from President Reagan's $216 billion military budget.

title: A SAUDI INVESTS IN BLUEGRASS
description: Wild horses couldn't keep most owners from watching their colts run in the Kentucky Derby. Not Mahmoud Fustok. Star Gallant, whom Fustok bought for only $42,000 at a sale of 2-year-olds last year, is undefeated in four starts and is likely to be favored with Timely Writer in tomorrow's $250,000 Florida Derby, the biggest Triple Crown prep so far this year. But the colt has a long way to go before his owner will make the trip to Churchill Downs May 1.

title: Defense Rests in Trial Over 1977 Nightclub Fire
description: The defense has rested in a four-week civil trial involving the 1977 fire that killed 164 persons at the Beverly Hills Supper Club in Southgate, Ky.

title: CHOIRS LIFT THEIR VOICES TO WELCOME EASTER SEASON
description: THE correlation between music and ritual has been close throughout history and among all peoples. In the Christian churches, it has led to a spectacular, if unforseen, result: namely, the creation of a vast body of written music, whose complexity and variety have fueled constant growth and renewal. Even though Western music long ago stepped outside the church and began a life of its own, for the millennium and some centuries that it has been a recognizable entity, most of its activity has been in the service of the church that gave it birth. And it still seems to have close ties. It is interesting to see, for example, that as the Christian year reaches its zenith in the Easter season, musical activity also reaches a high-water mark and for a short time resembles the musical life that was the source of the tradition.

title: 6 KILLED AND OTHERS MISSING IN 2 CALIFORNIA SNOW SLIDES
description: Rescue workers on skis searched drifts and debris at a snow-covered resort today and found three more victims of two devastating avalanches, bringing the death toll to six.

title: VIDEOTAPE RECORDER GAINS BY PHILIPS
description: Here in the Austrian capital, Philips, the huge Dutch electrical group, is making a stand against the Japanese incursion in Europe's lucrative videotape recorder market.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Natural Resources Co. said a subsidiary had received $40 million in cash for its rights to 210 million tons of lignite coal reserves that will fuel an electrical power plant in North Dakota.

title: BUILDING SPENDING DECLINES 1%
description: Spending on new construction fell 1 percent in February from January, the Commerce Department reported today. The drop was attributed to high interest rates.

title: Chapter 11 Petition Considered by AM
description: AM International Inc., responding to published reports, acknowledged yesterday that it was actively considering filing for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws.

title: PRESIDENT'S CONDITION FOUND 'NORMAL' AFTER CHECKUP
description: President Reagan underwent a 90-minute physical examination this afternoon in which physicians found no evidence of kidney stones, cancer or any other disorder, according to a White House spokesman.

title: Who Owns the Freeze?
description: ''When I use a word,'' said Humpty Dumpty to Alice, ''it means just what I choose it to mean - neither more nor less.''

title: QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS ON HELPING 'TRULY NEEDY'
description: Since Ronald Reagan became President, there has been a steadily growing debate over whether his policies injure the people who can least afford it: the poor and the ''truly needy.''

title: A CALENDAR OF MUSIC FOR THE EASTER HOLIDAY SEASON
description: Following is a list of some of the musical presentations planned for the Easter season at churches and concert halls in the metropolitan area. Palm Sunday All Saints Church (Episcopal), 230 East

title: CENSORSHIP FOES STAGE A 'READOUT' AT LIBRARY
description: Mark Twain, Anne Frank, John Steinbeck, Ernest Hemingway, J. D. Salinger, Bernard Malamud, Kurt Vonnegut, Isaac Asimov, Eve Merriam and other authors, living and dead, had their day in the sun yesterday at a midtown rally against censorship.

title: LEASE LAW IS DEFENDED BY LONG
description: Senator Russell B. Long of Louisiana, the ranking Democrat on the Republican-controlled Finance Committee, lined up with the Administration today in defense of the 1981 law that loosened the rules governing the use of leasing agreements to sell tax benefits.

title: Addendum
description: Money magazine increasing by 5.3 percent both its advertising rates and circulation base, from 950,000 to 1 million, effective with the July issue.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Fellow came by the other day and said, 'If I could just get back up to broke, I'd quit.'

title: HOW 'DINER' FINALLY MADE IT IN NEW YORK
description: IN the movie business, one of the oddest stories of recent memory concerns ''Diner,'' which opens today (for a review, see page C3). Based on writer-director Barry Levinson's memories of his young manhood in Baltimore (the year was 1959; Mr. Levinson and the friends who hung out with him eating greasy French fries and arguing about sex, sports, music, were in their early 20's), ''Diner'' is a picture that M-G-M, the producing company, and United Artists, the releasing company, didn't seem to know what to do with. They'd tested it in Phoenix and St. Louis, business hadn't been good, so they took it back and sat on it.

title: WALL ST. ECONOMISTS DISAGREE WITH REAGAN ON RATES STANCE
description: Wall Street economists disagreed yesterday with President Reagan's statement that the Government could not do anything about continued high interest rates, and urged the President to alter his economic program by cutting back spending or repealing the tax cuts planned for next year.

title: Officer's Sense of Humor Lost on Superiors; Elusive Humor
description: All things considered, it might have been better for Dominick D'Onofrio if one of his fellow police officers in Lodi, N.J., hadn't given him the little stuffed doll in the shape of a gingerbread man.

title: MOVIE: A BAROQUE NEW 'CAT PEOPLE'
description: IT used to be that the beasts within us - a favorite subject of horror films - were metaphorical. They were Freudian elaborations of commonplace nightmares, and this, I suspect, had as much to do with the technology available to film makers as with what the films were about. When the overly ambitious Dr. Jekyll was turning into the filthy-minded Mr. Hyde, and when poor Dr. Glendon sprouted claws and fangs in ''The Werewolf of London,'' one enjoyed the transformations effected through the graceful superimpositions of successive images, much as if they were euphemisms for unmentionable desires and obsessions.

title: More Than Politics in Newark
description: Newark's Mayor, Kenneth Gibson, and its City Council President, Earl Harris, protest that their indictments for giving a no-show municipal job to a former Councilman are ''politically motivated.'' But a look at the indictments reveals no reason to consider them unfair. The grand jury alleges something far more serious than merely providing a sinecure for a political friend - a blatant disregard for the public trust.

title: BUDGET FIGHT ENHANCES ALBANY MINORITY CHIEFS
description: As political leaders here pondered the implications of the unusual state budget passed by the Legislature late Wednesday night, the minority leaders in the Assembly and Senate suddenly seemed more powerful.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Beverly Enterprises, Pasadena, Calif., has appointed J. Calvin Kaylor president of its newly created division, Heritage Health Care, in Washington, D.C.

title: CITIBANK SETS NEW CHECK PLAN
description: With consumers becoming increasingly restless about the time it takes before they can withdraw funds after depositing checks in banks, Citibank yesterday announced a program to allow most of its checking-account customers to make immediate withdrawals against their deposits.

title: FRAGILE BALANCE IS SEEN IN RIVAL NUCLEAR FORCES
description: A consideration of the strategic arsenals of the United States and the Soviet Union shows a precarious balance, with each side having a lead in certain categories.

title: Economic Scene; Reagan Stays The Course
description: WHILE seeking to dispel the charge that he is inflexible - ''a great stone face,'' as he put it - President Reagan made clear in his news conference Wednesday night that he was sticking to his program of tax cuts and military-spending increases. The message seemed to be: ''Damn the deficits; full speed ahead.''

title: Cited After Accident
description: The rhythm and blues singer Teddy Pendergrass, left paralyzed after his Rolls-Royce smashed into a tree, has been issued traffic citations for reckless driving and driving with a suspended license, authorities in Philadelphia said yesterday.

title: Balaguer Withdraws From Dominican Race
description: Former President Joaquin Balaguer, who lost his office in the 1978 election after three consecutive terms, announced today that he would not seek another term as President of the Dominican Republic.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard THE GHOSTLY LOVER. By Elizabeth Hardwick. 278 pages. Ecco Press. $12.95. A VIEW OF MY OWN. ESSAYS ON LIT- ERATURE AND SOCIETY. By Eliza- beth Hardwick. 214 pages. Ecco Press. Paper, $6.95.

title: Wrong Signal on Sea Law
description: The wish was parent to the thought in our comment yesterday on the bedeviled Law of the Sea. There has been some movement in stalled talks, and a bargain may yet be struck between the United States and third-world countries on sharing seabed riches.

title: CANADIAN URGES 'NEW RULES' IN TIES WITH U.S.
description: Canada's Ambassador to the United States said today that the changing relationship between the two nations, which share the world's longest unguarded border, required a set of ''new rules.''

title: Court Blocks Bank Merger
description: A Federal District Court in Hartford has blocked the Hartford National Corporation's $57 million acquisition of the Connecticut National Bank of Bridgeport, saying that Hartford National's proxy statements were ''materially false and misleading.''

title: Advertising; New Guide For Agency Shoppers
description: WHEN a person has such a great desire to sell advertising that he creates a cross-Channel, motorized hang-glider race just to sell the space on the underside of the wings, that is compulsion.

title: A DOMESTIC SIDE TO FOREIGN RELATIONS
description: When Charles H. Percy first went to Egypt some years ago, he had his picture taken on a camel beside the pyramids. When he went to Egypt this January, he had his picture taken again. But this time the pyramids had all but disappeared into the background. Right in front were two mechanical streetsweepers, made in Illinois, Mr. Percy's home state.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: METS (NL) - Traded Lee Mazzilli, out- f ielder, to Texas (AL) for Ron Darling and W alt Terrell, pitchers. Assigned Scott Hol- m an, pitcher, to Tidewater. YANKEES (AL) - Traded Gene Nel- s on, right-handed pitcher, to Seattle for S hane Rawley, left-handed relief pitcher. S eattle also got Bill Caudill, pitcher, and a p layer to be named. Yankees had acquired C audill from Chicago (NL) earlier last n ight as player to be named in deal last A ugust that brought Pat Tabler to Chicago f rom Yankees. BOSTON (AL) - Assigned four players t o its Pawtucket farm team: Gary Han- c ock and Chico Walker, outfielders; Eddie J urak, infielder-outfielder, and Marty B arrett, infielder. Purchased the contract o f Roger LaFrancois, catcher, from Paw- t ucket. Placed Steve Crawford, pitcher, on d isabled list.
