CHICAGO (AL) - Assigned to minor l eagues: Carlos Ibarra, Dave Steffen and E rnie Camacho, pitchers; Jay Loviglo, in- f ielder, and Leo Sutherland, outfielder. P urchased contract of Salome Barojas, p itcher, and assigned him to major league r oster. CHICAGO (NL) - Assigned Scot T hompson, outfielder, and Ken Kravec, p itcher, to Iowa. Asked waivers on Rawly E astwick, pitcher. Released Larry Cox, c atcher. DETROIT (AL) - Assigned Howard J ohnson, third baseman, and Larry Roth- s child and Jerry Ujdur, pitchers, to minor l eagues. KANSAS CITY (AL) - Cut Don Hood a nd Jim Wright, pitchers; Greg Keatley, c atcher, and Pat Sheridan, outfielder.

title: ISRAEL AND BRITAIN AT ODDS ON 2 MAYORS
description: Israel turned down a request today from a senior official accompanying the British Foreign Secretary, Lord Carrington, on his visit here to meet with two West Bank Mayors who were dismissed by the occupation authorities a week ago.

title: Fergus, on 66, Shares Greensboro Golf Lead
description: Keith Fergus dropped a 15-foot birdie putt on the final hole today to finish with a 66 and tie Danny Edwards for the lead in the first round of the $300,000 Greater Greensboro Open.

title: CHURCH LEADERS ASK FOR A-ARMS FREEZE AND AID FOR THE POOR
description: Thirty-five major religious leaders, noting the approaching United Nations special session on disarmament, issued an appeal yesterday for a nuclear arms freeze and more aid for the poor.

title: Cubs Cut Reitz
description: With the interleague trading deadline at hand and the start of the season only four days away, several baseball clubs were busy making deals or paring their rosters yesterday. Among them were the Chicago Cubs, who cut five players, including Ken Reitz, a veteran infielder who batted only .215 last season and had three years to go on a guaranteed $275,000-a-year contract.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: NOW that big bands have made a comeback, tap dancing may not be far b ehind. Ruby Keeler, the star of the film ''42d Street,'' was guest o f honor at a party on Tuesday given by George-Paul Rosell at Studio 5 4.

title: 'SELF-ACTUALIZING' THAT BENEFITS MANKIND
description: To the Editor:

title: G.E. to Furlough 8,000 Employees
description: The General Electric Company said it would furlough 8,000 of its employees at its appliance plant in Louisville, Ky., for one week, effective May 3. The company said that of this total, 2,150 will also be furloughed for a second week, effective May 10.

title: GAVEL FALLS ON DANBURY STATE FAIR
description: There were 112 Indian summers for the Great Danbury State Fair, but in six days all the material proof will be gone.

title: U.S. FIGHTS THIRD-WORLD BID TO RESUME RICH-POOR TALKS
description: A new attempt by the third world to begin the long-stalled global talks aimed at shifting wealth from rich nations to poor has run into firm objections from the United States.

title: REPORTERS ASSAIL LATIN PRESS POLICY
description: Six United States journalists, newly returned from a fact-finding trip to Central America, issued a report yesterday that condemned what it described as the suppression of press freedoms and the acts of intimidation and physical violence against domestic and foreign reporters in Guatemala, Nicaragua and El Salvador.

title: RANGERS CHANGE SCHEDULE
description: As a result of a scheduling conflict with Knick basketball games at Madison Square Garden, the Rangers announced yesterday that they would play next Thursday's home playoff game against the Philadelphia Flyers in the afternoon rather than at night. The Flyers immediately protested the change to John Ziegler, the National Hockey League president, because they would have to play two games within 24 hours.

title: 9 Papers in Mississippi Being Sold to Gannett
description: The Gannett Company announced today that it had agreed to purchase newspapers from the Hederman family of Jackson that would give the publisher the dominant voice in Mississippi's print media.

title: OLD MUSIC: 3 GROUPS IN 6 CONCERTS
description: This is a propitious weekend for looking back. Three groups specializing in early music are planning a total of six concerts, and all have set their sights and sounds on that period of four and five centuries ago known as the Renaissance.

title: Reports on Oil Prompt Record Futures Volume
description: A record number of heating oil futures changed hands yesterday in what brokers said was an uncommonly volatile session on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

title: Schlitz Rebuffs Stroh's Offer
description: The Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company's board yesterday rejected the $315 million offer from the Stroh Brewery Company to buy two-thirds of Schlitz's shares.

title: NEW U.S. MERGER RULES TO SCRUTINIZE MARKETS
description: The Reagan Administration, which some critics have called soft on corporate mergers, formally described for the first time today new guidelines it is developing to analyze proposed combinations under the antitrust laws.

title: NEWBORNS, CAPRA AND DICK CLARK
description: ''MATTERS OF LIFE and Death,'' a 13-week series beginning tonight at 10:30 on WNET, Channel 13, is a grab bag of independently produced documentaries, some of them already seen on public television. Next week's installment deals with how some Americans, anticipating nuclear war and economic upheavals, plan to tackle these disasters.

title: News Analysis
description: If there is one point of agreement on the nagging question of why interest rates remain so high, it is that nobody knows for sure what the answer is.

title: REV. MOON GOES ON TRIAL IN CITY ON TAX CHARGES
description: Opening statements yesterday in the tax-fraud trial of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon gave conflicting versions of who owned $1.6 million in bank accounts and stocks.

title: Whittaker Hearing
description: The Saudi Arabian investment in the Whittaker Corporation, a United States defense contractor, will be explored in hearings scheduled for Tuesday by the House Government Operations Committee's Commerce, Consumer and Monetary Affairs Subcommittee. Its chairman, Benjamin S. Rosenthal, Democrat of Queens, said that the hearings would examine the effectiveness of United States Defense Department rules that govern foreign companies doing classified work, and the extent of Saudi influence in Whittaker.

title: CAR MAKERS FOR AN IMPROVED CLEAN AIR ACT
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK COSTS FOR PHONE CALLS RISE TOMORROW
description: Telephone bills for the average New York City residential customer will go up an estimated $2.83 a month, or 7.1 percent, to $42.68, starting tomorrow.

title: BOSTON DROPS CONCERT WITH MISS REDGRAVE
description: Acting in response to reported protests and threats, the Boston Symphony Orchestra announced today that it had canceled planned performances later this month in which the actress Vanessa Redgrave was to narrate Stravinsky's opera-oratorio ''Oedipus Rex.''

title: TO NEW YORK CITY
description: Should a Dusseldorf manufacturer of running shoes or a plastics fabricator in Liverpool build a plant in New York City? The city thinks they should and to convince them, and dozens of companies like them, will dispatch in mid-May a star-studded trade mission to England and West Germany.

title: BREZHNEV TESTS REAGAN
description: In the deadly game of nuclear intimidation, the first move was Leonid Brezhnev's: he upset the power balance by placing all of Europe within range of his newest intermediate-range missiles.

title: AN OLD SPONGE TRADE FALTERS
description: This small Greek island, long the undisputed leader in the natural sponge trade, has been stunned by a sudden, aggressive challenge from Cuban-Americans exploiting virtually untapped sponge grounds off Key West, Fla.

title: 2 British Soldiers Are Killed By I.R.A. in Ulster Ambush
description: Irish Republican Army guerrillas waiting in ambush in an apartment that they had seized shot dead two British soldiers in civilian clothes riding in an unmarked van today.

title: Required Reading Again and Again and ...
description: Senator Ted Stevens, Republican of Alaska, speaking on the Senate floor in defense of his proposal to allow members of Congress a tax deduction for expenses incurred while working away from home. March 30, 1982:

title: UNITED STATES VS. THE UNCERTAINTIES OF DEMOCRACY
description: To the Editor:

title: BOARD OF ESTIMATE AGREES TO ALLOW A TOWER NEXT TO WARBURG MANSION
description: Landmark status was upheld yesterday for the Felix M. Warburg mansion on upper Fifth Avenue, but not before members of the New York City Board of Estimate agreed to a compromise that could permit construction of a luxury apartment building next to it.

title: RESIDENTIAL DEMAND RESULTS IN MIXED-USE PROPERTIES
description: During the last decade, the conversion - legal and de facto - of properties built for business or industrial purposes has transformed the character of such areas of Manhattan as Soho, Noho and Tribeca from predominantly industrial to heavily residential.

title: Oratorios and Other Choral Programs; Today; Alice Tully Hall, Lincoln Center. Bach's
description: St. John Passion, with Baroque orchestra, New Calliope Singers and Jon Humphrey, tenor; Lucy Shelton, soprano, and David Arnold, bass. At 8 P.M. Tickets, $6.50 and $7.50. Information: 864-6765. Palm Sunday Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue. Bach's Magnificat and Haydn's Te Deum; Brooklyn Philharmonia Chorus, directed by Alexander Dashnaw. At 3 P.M. Admission: $2 (50 cents for those younger than 12 and the elderly.) Information: 622-4433.

title: 3 Bombs Hit Buenos Aires
description: Three small explosions damaged a hotel bathroom, an American bank's facade and the entrance to a store today, but no one was injured, the police said.

title: Funds' Assets Fall Slightly
description: Total assets of 182 money market funds declined $847 million in the week ended Wednesday, to $191.21 billion, after setting records in the two previous weeks, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: JAZZ: RICKIE LEE JONES SINGS
description: SINGERS as stylish and as naturally musical as Rickie Lee Jones don't come along every day. On her two hit albums, singing her own discursive and sometimes rambling pop-art songs, she displayed the harmonic savvy and imaginatively off-center phrasing of a potential jazz singer. At the Palladium on Tuesday, she interrupted a set of originals to sing ''Lush Life'' and some other standards, and proved beyond the shadow of a doubt that she is a jazz singer, and an exceptional one. But labeling Miss Jones is really beside the point. She is a singer who blithely ignores labels, and gets away with it.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate payable by savings institutions

title: Violent-Crime Figure Down 8% in January
description: The number of violent crimes reported in New York City last January was 8.6 percent below the number reported in the same month a year ago, the Police Department disclosed yesterday.

title: No Headline
description: After Viking Penguin decided in January to provide its authors with free liability insurance coverage, it was widely expected that other publishers would eventually do the same. That expectation is apparently being borne out. Media Professional Insurance Company is offering publishers a plan similar to Viking's, which carries the endorsement of the Authors League, and the response, according to Chad E. Milton, assistant general counsel of Media Professional, ''has been a little like the Oklahoma land rush.'' Four major publishers are committed, he said, while many others are in the process of shaping the insurance package to suit their individual needs.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Sports People column yesterday incorrectly identified the winning team in an exhibition game during which Fernando Valenzuela pitched for the Los Angeles Dodgers for the first time this year. The Dodgers beat the Boston Red Sox, 8-7, in 10 innings.

title: COURT RULING FAVORS DOCTORS IN HOME-BIRTHING CASE
description: The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court ruled yesterday that a state order suspending the medical license of an upstate New York physician who delivers babies in patients' homes was ''arbitrary and capricious.''

title: Group Asks I.B.M. Role
description: A consumer group led by Ralph Nader today asked a Federal judge to set aside the Justice Department's dismissal of an antitrust suit to break up the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: 2 ARSENALS: U.S.-SOVIET BALANCE
description: Imbalance in the makeup of the Soviet and United States strategic forces has long been regarded by American defense planners as acceptable. To some thinkers the ability to perform given missions is the proper measure of a military force, not force levels.

title: Market Place; Pressure On Playboy
description: PLAYBOY ENTERPRISES lost a lucrative casino license in London last year, and next Wednesday the New Jersey Casino Control Commission will decide whether the Playboy casino in Atlantic City is to receive a permanent license.

title: New adventures for Annie coming to the stage soon.
description: Mike Nichols, Lewis Allen, James M. Nederlander and Roger Stevens - and maybe even the same dog.

title: MARCOS WELCOMES WEINBERGER AS STUDENTS PROTEST
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos and Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger greeted each other today with mutual nostalgia as a group of Filipino students nearby protested Mr. Weinberger's visit.

title: ART: AT THE GUGGENHEIM, 7 ITALIAN SHOWS IN ONE
description: AN Italian presence has made itself strongly felt in the New York art world this year, and this week it is intensified by two related events: the big Giorgio de Chirico exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art and the arrival of ''Italian Art Now: An American Perspective,'' opening today at the Guggenheim Museum, 89th Street and Fifth Avenue (through June 20). The conjunction is appropriate, because de Chirico (1888-1978) is now an admired ancestor figure for young Italian artists and his influence pervades the Guggenheim show.

title: REPORT REVEALS 'SNAP' COURSES AT L.S.U.
description: Many of Louisiana State University's male athletes, especially basketball players, took easy courses to stay eligible for competition, regardless of whether the courses would count toward degree requirements, according to an internal academic report released today.

title: Rozelle Defends Rules In Testimony at Trial
description: Commissioner Pete Rozelle testified today that the National Football League rules governing the location of professional football franchises did not constitute restraint of trade and were necessary to protect a team's profits in its exclusive territory.

title: Dr. David Mirsky, 60, Is Dead; Former Dean of Stern College
description: Dr. David Mirsky, a former dean of Yeshiva University's Stern College for Women, died Tuesday after a heart attack. He was 60 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Western Air Report Gloomy
description: Western Airlines disclosed that its auditors had stated that the company may not be able to continue in existence. The airline said that its auditors, Peat, Marwick, Mitchell & Co., had said in an opinion covering the company's financial statements for the year ended Dec. 31 that it based its evaluation on the losses during the past two years and the need to classify a part of the company's long-term debt as current.

title: Rollins Plans Charges
description: Wayne (Tree) Rollins of the Atlanta Hawks says that the M.L. Carr of the Celtics threatened him with a razor after a game in Boston three months ago and that, because the National Basketball Association has not taken what he considers sufficient action, he plans to file assault charges. Rollins says that he reported the incident to the N.B.A. office and that he is upset because Carr received only a letter of reprimand from the league.

title: MOVIES: IN 'PENITENTIARY II,' TOO SWEET GORDON GETS OUT
description: ''PENITENTIARY II,'' which opens today at the Cinerama and other theaters, continues the saga of Too Sweet Gordon (Leon Isaac Kennedy) who, at the end of ''Penitentiary'' (1980), was paroled from prison, where he had been sent on a trumped-up murder rap, after winning a boxing match.

title: Sharon Steel Deficit $15.1 Million in Quarter
description: The Sharon Steel Corporation announced yesterday that it had a deficit of $15.1 million in the latest three months, almost triple the loss of $5.4 million in its fourth fiscal quarter of 1980. Revenues dipped 4.5 percent, to $199.7 million, from $209.2 million.

title: REAGAN'S VIEW ON LAG IN ARMS BEING DISPUTED
description: President Reagan's assertion that the Soviet Union had achieved military superiority over the United States was disputed today by both proponents of a nuclear arms freeze and by one of the chief supporters of his arms policies.

title: KALLUR'S ILLEGAL-STICK PENALTY HELPS FLYERS TIE ISLANDERS, 3-3
description: The Islanders were taught the lesson of the illegal stick tonight, and it cost them a victory. The infraction allowed the Philadelphia Flyers to score a goal in the last 30 seconds and gain a 3-3 tie at the Spectrum.

title: IRAQ VOWS TROOPS WILL STAND FAST
description: Iraq vowed today to hold the new lines in southwestern Iran to which its troops were forced to retreat, and President Saddam Hussein sought to depict his troops' overall war record as a victory over the Iranian revolutionary regime.

title: 2 WIN BANCROFT PRIZE FOR AMERICAN HISTORY
description: Edward Countryman, author of ''A People in Revolution: The American Revolution and Political Society in New York 1760-1790'' (Johns Hopkins University Press), and Mary P. Ryan, author of ''Cradle of the Middle Class: The Family in Oneida County, New York, 1780-1865'' (Cambridge University Press), last night received the 1982 Bancroft Prizes at Columbia University at a dinner sponsored by the Friends of the Columbia Libraries.

title: News Analysis
description: In pressing his case for a major buildup in strategic arms, President Reagan went further than any previous President in crediting the Soviet Union with ''a definite margin of superiority.'' This has prompted disagreement over the nuclear balance and raised concern about the impact of the assessment on the Western allies.

title: Women Fill Potholes In Rich Detroit Suburb
description: Two dozen women from this wealthy suburb of Detroit have put on work pants and hard hats and filled potholes along mansion-lined Lakeshore Drive.

title: Edgar T. Rigg, Directed Holt, Rinehart Growth
description: Edgar T. Rigg, retired chairman of the board and chief executive officer of Holt, Rinehart & Winston, died Tuesday in Palm Beach, Fla. Mr. Rigg, who spent the winter in Palm Beach, was a resident of Bronxville, N.Y. He was 81 years old.

title: DUARTE IS SEEKING TO STAY IN POWER, DEFYING THE RIGHT
description: President Jose Napoleon Duarte said in an interview Wednesday night that he would try to remain in the Salvadoran Government despite the attempts of more conservative rivals to oust him.

title: NEW OPERATING OFFICER OF THOMSON'S U.S. UNIT
description: Michael Brown, who has been commuting regularly from England to the United States, will relocate here shortly to oversee the American publishing, travel and energy interests of the International Thomson Organization, the Toronto-based owner of oil and gas fields in the North Sea and former publisher of The Times of London.

title: Tanker and Tug Collide In Fog on the Mississippi
description: A Liberian tanker carrying up to 85,000 barrels of oil collided in dense fog with a tugboat pushing three barges, setting off a fire that engulfed the tanker and forced her crew members to dive into the Mississippi River.

title: Mayor Green of Philadelphia Sues a TV Station for Libel
description: Mayor William J. Green filed suit in Common Pleas Court Wednesday for more than $5.1 million, contending that WCAU-TV, a CBS affiliate, libeled him when it reported last Thursday that he was a ''target'' of a Federal investigation into alleged kickbacks and bid-rigging.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, APRIL 2, 1982
description: International The question of U.S. vulnerabilty to Soviet arms created a stir. On Wednesday, President Reagan asserted that Moscow had achieved nuclear superiority over Washington. The assertion was disputed by proponents of a nuclear arms freeze and also by Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, who is a key backer of the President's weapons policies. (Page A1, Column 5.) Moscow depicted President Reagan as a man on the defensive, forced to discuss arms control because of domestic criticism and support for a nuclear freeze. (A21:5-6.)

title: CHICAGO INVESTMENT BANKER
description: William McCormick Blair, an investment banker and a prominent member of Chicago's business and civic community for more than half a century, died Monday at his home after a short illness. He was 97 years old.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY TRUSTEES SEE '83 CHECK DELAYS
description: The three trustees of the Social Security System warned Congress today that unless it acted soon the system would be unable to pay benefits on time to retirees and survivors beginning in the last half of 1983.

title: Savin Stock Sale
description: The Savin Corporation, a manufacturer of office copying machines, said its shareholders had approved the sale of 8.3 million shares of its common stock to the Canada Development Corporation for $40 million in cash plus $35 million in noninterest bearing notes due in April 1983.

title: Two Share L.P.G.A. Lead
description: Kyle O'Brien and Lori Garbacz shot 1-under-par 71's in the cold and rain today to share the first-round lead of the $310,000 Nabisco-Dinah Shore invitation tournament.

title: South African Official Says Black Squatters Will End Fast
description: Fifty-four black squatters have agreed to end a 24-day-old fast aimed at forcing the government to allow them to live legally near Cape Town, a Government minister, said yesterday.

title: BRIEFING
description: The Boll Weevils' Pac

title: C.A.B. Action Helps Agents
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board gave final approval yesterday to a plan under which airlines must provide transportation to passengers who have purchased tickets from travel agents on an airline that goes bankrupt.

title: ITALY'S PRESIDENT PERTINI IS A MUCH-HONORED PILGRIM IN NEW YORK
description: Crossing the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge to a tiny cottage on Staten Island, President Sandro Pertini of Italy made a pilgrimage to Giuseppe Garibaldi's 1850-54 home-in-exile yesterday before exchanging toasts and witticisms with Mayor Koch at a Gracie Mansion luncheon.

title: SPERRY PRESIDENT NAMED TO TOP POST
description: Gerald G. Probst has been named chief executive officer of the Sperry Corporation, succeeding J. Paul Lyet, and will also become chairman when Mr. Lyet retires from that post on June 1.

title: O'Neill Calls Remarks By Reagan Misleading
description: The Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., accused President Reagan today of making misleading and sometimes ''completely inaccurate'' statements ''to overcome the growing feeling that the Administration is unfair.''

title: F.C.C. REAFFIRMS LIMITS ON ACCESS TO AIRWAVES BY POLITICAL GROUPS
description: In response to a plea by the National Conservative Political Action Committee, the Federal Communications Commission today reaffirmed that broadcasters were not compelled to sell air time to anyone but legally qualified candidates and that stations that did so might be open to demands by opposing groups for free time to respond.

title: CHUCK NORRIS IN 'SILENT RAGE'
description: ''SILENT RAGE,'' with Chuck Norris, is really three movies, lightly intertwined. The first is your standard horror flick, and the second is a vehicle for Mr. Norris. The third, however, has possibilities. It shows science marching on.

title: KNICKS DOWN BY 26, WIN BY 1
description: The Knicks, trailing by 26 points with four minutes remaining in the third period last night, staged an impressive comeback and beat the Cleveland Cavaliers, 111-110, at Madison Square Garden.

title: YANKEES ACQUIRE RAWLEY
description: Lee Mazzilli's five-year career as the hometown hero of the New York Mets came to an end tonight when he was traded to the Texas Rangers for two minor league pitching prospects.

title: Joseph Levi, 67, Dead; L.I. Hospital Executive
description: Joseph A. Levi, a hospital financial specialist who was active in Jewish philanthropic and civic affairs, died of cancer Wednesday at the Long Island Jewish-Hillside Medical Center in New Hyde Park, L.I.

title: 'MUSIC PLUS FILM' IN MANHATTAN PLUS BROOKLYN
description: OSKAR FISCHINGER'S ''Spiritual Constructions'' is the sort of silent black-and-white cartoon movie that a German philosopher like Heidegger might have made if he had known how to draw and if he had a sense of humor. In this 1927 film by a pioneer in experimental animation, people are sketched, involved in conversation, sitting at tables, lying in bed. But the lines that give them shape shift mercurially. Expressions change with nightmarish exuberance. A man melts into the floor and erupts in the form of a table. As he walks, the ground swells and twists under his feet tossing him about. The everyday world is a continously drifting set of lines, seeming to reflect some unsettled inner world.

title: A PLUTONIUM PERIL
description: The Reagan Administration's efforts to promote nuclear exports are hastening arrival of a ''plutonium economy'' - a perilous world in which bomb-grade plutonium is a legitimate article of daily international commerce. To avert this danger, we urgently need initiatives to curb proliferation of material used in nuclear weapons.

title: JEEP MAKES $750-$1,000 PRICE CUTS
description: The American Motors Corporation today announced a new tactic in the current round of consumer incentive programs by offering temporary price cuts, rather than rebates.

title: MARCH GOES OUT LIKE A LION IN CHINOOK COUNTY
description: Away out here they have a name for wind. It's chinook, and each winter, this city, like others along the eastern foothills of the Rocky Mountains, is pummeled by the fierce, dry winds that can roar down from the Continental Divide with the force and fury of a hurricane.

title: 'RED BADGE' IS DUE OUT AS CRANE WROTE IT
description: A classic work of American literature that millions of readers have long regarded as the great Civil War novel -Stephen Crane's ''The Red Badge of Courage'' - is about to be brought out in full,just as the author it.

title: Fiat Layoffs Set
description: Fiat, the largest Italian automotive group, will lay off 40,000 workers for one week beginning May 3 to reduce its stock of unsold cars, a spokesman said today. The company had previously announced a week of temporary suspension for 60,000 workers from April 5-12, also to pare its inventory of unsold cars. Fiat did not give the total of unsold units.

title: Eagles' Bergey Retires
description: Bill Bergey of the Philadelphia Eagles, one of the best inside linebackers in the history of the National Football League, announced his retirement yesterday at the age of 37. ''I gave it my best shot,'' Bergey said at a news conference, acknowledging that his yearlong effort to rehabilitate a severely damaged left knee had failed.

title: Rumania Debt Talks
description: The nine banks handling the rescheduling of Rumania's foreign debt have set a meeting April 19 and 20 in New York, banking sources here said today. The move followed talks between the banks and officials of the Rumanian Finance Ministry and foreign trade bank in Bucharest this week. These were aimed at collating details on the country's foreign debt to present to its more than 200 Western creditor banks.

title: FEDERAL ATTORNEY ASKED TO RESIGN BECAUSE OF INTELLIGENCE DISCLOSURE
description: The United States Attorney in San Diego has been asked to resign after he publicly confirmed the identity of a key American intelligence source, Justice Department officials said today.

title: Amax Slashes Its Dividend
description: Amax Inc., which has been paying stockholders quarterly dividends of 60 cents a share, or $2.40 a year, for the past two years, abruptly cut its quarterly dividend yesterday to 15 cents a share, or to an indicated rate of 60 cents a year.

title: 2 BRITISH SOILDERS ARE KILLED BY I.R.A. IN ULSTER AMBUSH
description: Irish Republican Army guerrillas waiting in ambush in an apartment that they had seized shot dead two British soldiers in civilian clothes riding in an unmarked van today.

title: Reagan Thrift Unit Aid Seen
description: President Reagan may consider supporting a financial assistance program to help the ailing savings and loan industry, Robert B. O'Brien Jr., president of the National Savings and Loan League, said today.

title: Sports of The Times; Gabe Paul, Baseball's Old Trader
description: WHEN he acquired the father in a trade, the son was an infant in a blanket. And a generation later he traded the son. He's now making deals with somebody whose birth once interrupted his bridge game. In the era of the free agent, 72-year-old Gabe Paul of the Cleveland Indians is a throwback to a time when baseball executives had to make trades to improve their teams. He's still operating that way. During his three decades as a major league trader, he estimates, he has made 500 deals. Of the 40 players on the Indians' original roster this spring, 21 had been obtained by their president in trades.

title: Blast at Greek Envoy's Home
description: A small bomb exploded early today outside the residence of the United States Ambassador to Greece, Monteagle Sterns, causing minor damage but no injuries, a police announcement said. A leftist group calling itself Revolutionary Popular Struggle said it was responsible, officials said.

title: Whom to Invite to the Wedding?
description: They were new in town and about to be married but had no friends to invite to their wedding. So David Bazant and his fiancee decided to invite that nice couple who live across the street from the courthouse in Annapolis, Md.

title: Larry Riley Returning To 'A Soldier's Play'
description: Larry Riley will return next Thursday to Charles Fuller's ''A Soldier's Play'' at the Negro Ensemble Company.

title: Interest Rates Decline Slightly; Move Called Technical
description: Interest rates fell slightly yesterday and, although it was the second consecutive day of lower rates, analysts said the improvement was a technical trading rally with modest investor participation. They added that they could not discern any profound improvement in investor sentiment or willingness to buy notes and bonds.

title: Why Rush the Hinckley Case?
description: Defense lawyers don't deny that John Hinckley pulled that trigger a year ago. Indeed, they want to stipulate the fact and keep the gory details as far as possible from the minds of the jurors when he is tried for attempting to assassinate President Reagan. The issue at the trial will not be whether he fired the shots, but why. The defense - the only defense - is insanity.

title: BRIDGE: TRIUMPHS OF LUELLA SLANER STOOD OUT IN THE VANDERBILT
description: The late stages of national knockout team championships are almost invariably dominated by experts with impressive reputations and large collections of master points accumulated over many years. But there was a notable exception last week in the Vanderbilt teams, played in Niagara Falls, N.Y.

title: Friday; HIDING OUT AT BRONX ZOO
description: Additions have been made to the Children's Zoo at the Bronx Zoo, but you won't find them without help. They are camouflaged nests for squirrels, robins, blue jays and cardinals, all hidden in trees. Telescopes are provided so youngsters can spot them. The three-acre children's facility -which opens for the season today -encourages youngsters to act like animals. They can climb a giant spider's web, for instance, or escape like a lizard down a slide. Admission to the Children's Zoo is 80 cents for those under 12 and 70 cents for adults, who must be accompanied by a child. Admission to the Bronx Zoo, Fridays through Mondays, is $2.50 for adults and 75 cents for children. Information: 367-1010.

title: Panama Takes Over Canal Zone Policing
description: Panama formally assumed responsibility today for policing the Canal Zone, moving a step closer toward full ownership of the Panama Canal.

title: PUTTING LITIGATION ON A BUDGET
description: Robert Banks, H. Arvid Johnson and Charles Morgan have started a cost-cutting campaign that may mark the end of an era for large corporate law firms.

title: THE BOOKS ISRAEL WON'T ALLOW IN THE WEST BANK
description: To the Editor:

title: REGAN HINTS 9% ARE JOBLESS
description: Unemployment figures to be released Friday could show the nation's jobless rate ''just slightly higher'' than 9 percent, Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said tonight.

title: Giant-Shell Deal
description: Giant Industries said it had completed the purchase of the Cinizia refinery and a related pipeline system from the Shell Oil Company and the Shell Pipeline Corporation. Terms of the purchase were not disclosed. The refinery, 20 miles east of Gallup, N.M., will produce gasoline and diesel fuel and may eventually produce aviation fuel and asphalt, a company spokesman said.

title: PRYOR IN 'SOME KIND OF HERO'
description: AFTER surviving six years in a Vietcong prisoner-of-war camp, Cpl. Eddie Keller (Richard Pryor) of the United States Army comes home to a hero's welcome in Los Angeles. He is interviewed on television, treated kindly by doormen and served champagne on the house. The world adores him.

title: CONGRESS PONDERS BUDGET-BALANCING AMENDMENT
description: Sometime in May the Senate is expected to vote on a proposed amendment to the Constitution that would require a balanced Federal budget.

title: CSX Net Down 45%
description: The CSX Corporation reported today that first-quarter earnings fell 45 percent, to $48.2 million, or $1.16 a share, from record profits of $87.7 million, or $2.14 a share, for the same quarter last year. Revenue was $1.3 billion, down 2 percent from the same quarter in 1981, but transportation revenue of $1.2 billion equaled that of a year ago. CSX said its nontransportation units, especially publishing, natural resources and The Greenbrier, its luxury hotel in West Virginia, ''continued to perform well.''

title: STUDENTS LEARN 'SELF DEFENSE' AT A RIFLE RANGE
description: Louise Sample, 63 years old, put a shotgun gently to her shoulder, pressed her cheek against the stock and let fire with a blast of buckshot that blew a large hole in the paper image of a gunman 25 feet down range.

title: HEAT FROM THE FREEZE
description: President Reagan made clear in his prime-time news conference that he was opposed to the nuclear ''freeze'' that now symbolizes the powerful new anti-nuclear movement. But Mr. Reagan's opposition to the specific proposal is less important than the implicit fact that he's beginning to feel the heat.

title: Business Digest; FRIDAY, APRIL 2, 1982; Markets
description: The stock market rallied briskly, led by energy, technology, glamour and blue-chip issues. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 10.47 points, to 833.24. Big Board volume expanded to 57.1 million shares from 43.3 million on Wednesday. Advances outnumbered declines 1,061 to 377. Analysts said large institutions, on the first day of a new quarter, had committed some of their cash. (Page D1.)

title: PIANO RECITAL: ROBERT BLACK IN PREMIERES
description: SOME compositions have the word ''masterpiece'' written all over them. In every measure - and there are many of them - such works insist on their own profundity, complexity and depth. This attitude was a specialty of the 19th century. But it is worthy of some distrust in its later incarnations. Listening to a ''masterpiece'' is like talking with someone who is always insisting on his irreproachable ''sincerity.''

title: CHINESE FOOD, EAST SIDE TAVERN.
description: Given the growing interest in fish and seafood and the continuing popularity of Chinese cooking, it was probably inevitable that someone would open a Chinese seafood restaurant. The Seafood Room at David K's on Third Avenue near 65th Street, is it, comfortably, spaciously and plushly laid out on the restaurant's street level. Downstairs, David K's continues with its full Chinese menu.

title: Dreyfus case data for sale.
description: WHAT Sotheby Parke Bernet describes as the most important archive of letters and documents relating to the Alfred Dreyfus case ever to appear on the open market is included in a sale next Tuesday at the auction house's York Avenue galleries at 72d Street. Many of the 170 items are from the files of Maitre Labori, the lawyer for Emile Zola and Dreyfus, and were used in the trial at Rennes.

title: RECANTER'S TALE: LESSON IN HUMILITY FOR STATE DEPT.
description: Political considerations, including a desire to help the Secretary of State save face, lay behind the Reagan Administration's ill-fated decision last month to ask a young Nicaraguan to buttress United States assertions of outside interference in El Salvador, according to senior Administration officials.

title: SOVIET PRESS ASSERTS REAGAN IS ON DEFENSIVE OVER ARMS
description: The Soviet press depicted President Reagan today as a man forced by mounting criticism of his arms policies and swelling support for a nuclear freeze to speak out on arms controls.

title: MOTHER AT STORE
description: Four young children, locked in their Harlem apartment alone while their mother went out to a corner grocery store, died last night when flames swept through their bedroom, the police said.

title: OFF OFF BROADWAY UNIT IS CHANGING ITS NAME
description: The Off Off Broadway Alliance, an organization of nonprofit theaters, is changing its name to reflect its changing role.

title: ARGENTINE SUMMONS CABINET TO DISCUSS FALKLAND DISPUTE
description: President Leopoldo Galtieri of Argentina called an emergency meeting of the Cabinet early today amid reports that his forces were poised to invade the Falkland Islands.

title: No Headline
description: Sylvia Frumkin - rapid-fire soliloquy artist, tragicomic spieler and on-again off-again mental patient for 17 years - was being transported in an ambulance to Bellevue Hospital. It was one hospital admission among many, and for a woman whose doctors had likened her to Auntie Mame for her flamboyance, it was just one more acute episode of schizophrenia.

title: FORD BIDS REAGAN TRIM ARMS OUTLAY
description: Former President Gerald R. Ford, an advocate of greater military spending for most of his political career, urged President Reagan yesterday to agree to trim outlays for major new weapons systems by stretching out their procurement schedules.

title: MASON-DIXON MAP FETCHES $360,000
description: The original plan of the Mason-Dixon line was purchased last night for $360,000 at Christie's by Malcolm Forbes Jr. for the Forbes Foundation. It was the highest price ever paid at auction for an American map or any manuscript map.

title: A COTTON TOWN IS BROKE AND ALMOST BROKEN
description: When the first-quarter earnings reports come out in a week or two, it will become clear that the nation's farmers are not buying chemical fertilizers this spring. For the nonce, then, just accept that T.J. Attebury's farm supply store is alive by the slenderest thread.

title: STATEMENT ON REAGAN
description: Following is the text of a statement by Larry Speakes, deputy White House spokesman, after President Reagan's return from a checkup at the Bethesda Naval Medical Center:

title: N.H.L. Suspends Holt
description: Randy Holt, a defenseman for the Washington Capitals, has been suspended for the club's last two games and fined $200. The punishment was imposed by the National Hockey League, which found that Holt had ''physically abused'' a linesman who was trying to break up a fight in a game against the Philadelphia Flyers a week ago.

title: Editor Resigns in Clash On Bad Economic News
description: The editor of a newspaper group in a Detroit suburb said today that he resigned after being told to stop publishing unfavorable economic news.

title: GALA FOR PRINCESS WHO CAME HOME AGAIN
description: The marching band never showed up, the rain frazzled a lot of expensive coiffures, the show at the Annenberg Center of the University of Pennsylvania ran almost twice as long as scheduled and the jammed supper and dancing area would have pulverized sardines. A recipe for disaster, one might say, but somehow a souffle emerged. The evening, as they say in show business, was a smash.

title: CONTROVERSIAL SELF MADE MAN
description: His enemies call him ruthless and his admirers call him tough, but there is little disagreement on one point: Joe L. Allbritton is the archetype of a self-made man.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on March 24 about the first deaf lawyer to argue before the United States Su- preme Court incorrectly identified the developer of a video display screen that was used in the courtroom. It was invented by Translation Systems Inc. of Rockville, Md.

title: NOSTALGIC VISIT TO THE 50'S IN 'DINER'
description: MOVIES like ''Diner'' -fresh, well-acted and energetic American movies by new directors with the courage of their convictions - are an endangered species. They deserve to be protected, not to mention appreciated and enjoyed. ''Diner'' isn't lavish or long, but it's the sort of small, honest, entertaining movie that should never go out of style, even in an age of sequels and extravaganzas. It isn't perfect, mind you, but its very unevenness is part of its appeal. There's an excitement in watching a talented fledgling film maker take chances.

title: APRIL BLOWS IN LIKE MARCH
description: Spring winds swept through the New York metropolitan area yesterday, toppling power lines and overturning an airplane hangar in Morristown, N.J.

title: RIGHTS AIDE A SLAYING VICTIM
description: The body of a 37-year-old official of the National Urban League was identified yesterday by league officials at the New York City Medical Examiner's office, nearly a week after the victim was found bludgeoned to death in an apparent robbery on the East Side.

title: G.O.P. HOUSING PLAN FALTERS IN SENATE
description: Efforts to rescue the ailing housing industry faltered in the Senate today, and leading senators said that the chances for action this year were growing slimmer.

title: MILITANTS TRY TO REACH SINAI BY BOAT
description: Jewish militants opposing Israel's withdrawal from Sinai tried to reach the area by boat today after the army closed it to unauthorized civilians and set up roadblocks.

title: MOSAIC 'HIM AND ME'
description: IN ''Him and Me,'' at the Film Forum, James Benning, one of our more highly regarded experimental film makers, appears to be looking back over his life, from the 1950's to the 80's, recalling it in terms of public events and private sorrows, landscapes, streets, music and colors.

title: F.T.C. Asks Batus For Field Plans
description: Batus Inc., the United States unit of Britain's B.A.T. Industries, said that the Federal Trade Commission had asked for additional information on its proposed $365 million acquisition of Marshall Field & Company, a Chicago-based retailer.

title: ART: MET SHOW EXPLORES OLD SILK ROUTES OF ASIA
description: TWO huge color photographs of mountains in the Hindu Kush of Afghanistan open the show ''Along the Ancient Silk Routes'' at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. One is of a camel train winding its way past a soaring glacier - black specks in blue and white vastness; the other depicts a low rickety bridge with robed figures and a single camel crossing, again dwarfed by snowy slopes.

title: REBEL REJECTS TALK WITH RIGHT
description: The leader of El Salvador's main opposition coalition said tonight that it would not negotiate with a government led by the right-wing Nationalist Republican Alliance, which made significant advances in the Salvadoran elections.

title: Chrysler Layoffs
description: The Chrysler Corporation said it would move the production of rear axles for rear-wheel-drive cars and trucks into a plant that produces engines and drive shafts for the vehicles. As a result, some of the 900 hourly and salaried workers at the Detroit axle plant will be laid off, but others will be transferred to the Mound Road plant in Detroit, where the consolidation will occur over the next 15 months, a company spokesman said. Currently, the Mound Road plant produces only engines and drive shafts for rear-wheel-drive vehicles.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Detroit Edison Co. announced the public offering of 1.6 million shares of $4 series preference stock at $25 a share, to be sold through a Morgan Stanley group.

title: Survivor of Van Crash Leaves Intensive Care
description: The survivor of the collision between a van and train that killed nine young people here on March 14 has regained consciousness, a Nassau Hospital spokesman said today.

title: FORMER ENERGY CHIEF TO HEAD WARREN-KING
description: Charles W. Duncan Jr., who entered the energy business 35 years ago, digging ditches for a pipeline, and became Secretary of Energy under President Carter, has been named president and a principal of the Warren-King Companies, a Houston-based group of energy-related companies with 1981 revenues in excess of $1 billion.

title: Richard Suit Detailed
description: A medical malpractice suit filed on behalf of J.R. Richard states that no palpable blood pressure could be found in the right arm of the Houston Astro pitcher in 1980 less than a week before he suffered a stroke that almost killed him. According to the suit, Richard had been advised by a team of doctors that he could resume light workouts under medical supervision though there was evidence that an occlusion was partly blocking the blood flow to his pitching arm.

title: A Soviet Activist Pleads Not Guilty
description: Ivan Kovalyov, on trial for his human rights activities, pleaded not guilty today to charges of agitating against the Soviet state, dissident sources said. Mr. Kovalyov is a member of an unofficial committee formed to monitor Soviet compliance with rights provisions of the 1975 Helsinki accords.

title: 'THE LONG GOOD FRIDAY,' BRITISH GANG STORY
description: DON'T be flustered by the beginning of ''The Long Good Friday,'' the rough-edged British gangster film that opens today at the Baronet. If you can't make sense of the first scenes, you won't be alone. John Mackenzie, the film's director, has plenty of flair for etching disturbing portraits of rich, modern-day London hoodlums operating in a 30's Chicago style. When one character in the film invokes the St. Valentine's Day Massacre, the reference is a very fitting one. Though its plot contains much that's new, ''The Long Good Friday'' is a swift, sharp-edged gangster story in a classic mold.

title: MUSEUM ADDS HOURS
description: Hours have been extended at the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West and 79th Street, from 10 A.M. to 9 P.M. on Wednesday, Friday and Saturday. On Monday, Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday, the hours are 10 A.M. to 5:45 P.M. There is a suggested admission of $2.50 ($1.50 for children); admission is free Fridays and Saturdays from 5 to 9 P.M. Information: 873-1300.

title: SUMMATIONS SET
description: The defense in the Stouffer's Inn arson and murder trial rested its case today after a forensic scientist testified that he ''could not detect an accelerant in any of five samples'' of concrete floor tested after the hotel fire.

title: 29 Held in Turkey
description: Military authorities arrested 29 people on charges of trying to revive a leftist terrorist gang known as Dev Sol, officials said today. At least 30,000 leftist and rightist activists are in jail awaiting prosecution at military tribunals.

title: AUTHORITY ON ETHICS TAUGHT AT BRANDEIS
description: Henry D. Aiken, a retired professor of philosophy at Brandeis University who was an authority on esthetics and ethics, died Tuesday at Mount Auburn Hospital in Cambridge, Mass. He was 69 years old.

title: A HOMEOWNER'S VOTE FOR AN OIL-IMPORT FEE
description: To the Editor:

title: ARCO Solar Plant
description: ARCO Solar Inc., a subsidiary of the Atlantic Richfield Company, said it plans to build a solar-powered electricity generating station capable of serving 300 to 400 residential customers of the Southern California Edison Company. The photovoltaic system will have a peak output of one megawatt, a tiny fraction of what a typical generating station produces, but it would be three times larger than any existing photovoltaic system. The plant, expected to be operational by year-end, will be built about 100 miles northeast of Los Angeles.

title: RACE FOR GOVERNOR OF HAWAII THREATENS DEMOCRATS
description: The power of the Democratic coalition that has ruled Hawaii since 1963 appears to be seriously threatened this year by a three-way battle for the governorship.

title: DE CHIRICO IS THE STAR IN MODERN'S NEW
description: WING By JOHN RUSSELL

title: 'A LITTLE SEX' PORTRAYS NEW MANHATTAN LOVE STYLES
description: ''A LITTLE SEX'' does have love, laughter, marriage and springtime in its makeup, so why isn't it an airy little romance? This is a movie about how Boy meets Girl, Boy marries Girl, and Boy resolves to have plenty of other Girls, too. That's the funny part. Only after his wife catches him in flagrante delicto does Boy realize that sex with someone he loves is more meaningful than sex with someone he has just met in an elevator. That's the part that's tender, wise, knowing and romantic.

title: IS ACCUSED OVER BANNED PRODUCTS
description: Canada today ordered the expulsion of a Soviet trade representative who it said had tried to obtain high-technology products that the West excludes from trade with the Soviet Union.

title: JAZZ: BOLLING AT TOWN HALL
description: CLAUDE BOLLING, the French pianist and composer, describes his music as ''crossover,'' meaning that it draws on elements of both the classical and jazz sides of the spectrum. Last week, he placed himself in both contexts. On Thursday, he played his ''Baroque Suite for Chamber Orchestra and Jazz Piano Trio'' as part of a concert by the Syracuse Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall, and the next night he was at Town Hall playing with his jazz trio and Hubert Laws, the jazz flutist.

title: PIANO: TONG-IL HAN PLAYS AT Y
description: ONE could not help feeling a sense of wonder at the program that the Korean-born pianist Tong-Il Han offered Tuesday at the 92d Street Y.

title: The U.N. Today; April 2, 1982; SECURITY COUNCIL
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. on complaint by Nicaragua GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: VOLUME UP
description: With institutions committing part of their cash hoard, stock prices staged a brisk rally yesterday led by energy, technology, glamour and blue-chip issues. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 10.47 points, to 833.24.

title: A Honduran Suggests Intervention by the U.S.
description: Honduras, facing ''armed aggression from the Soviet Union by way of Cuba,'' would agree to United States military intervention in Central America if it were the only way to preserve peace, the head of the Honduran armed forces said today.

title: Indifferent Weather, Elusive Trout
description: ROSCOE, N.Y. HERE in the Catskills the weather gods displayed a magnificent indifference toward the April 1 opening of the New York State trout season.

title:
PATENTS;
DNA Technology Used In Endorphin Synthesis
description: Researchers at the University of California in San Francisco have developed a microorganism strain carrying a gene that is capable of directing the synthesis of endorphin, the body's natural tranquilizer. The process is believed to be capable of producing medication that will reduce pain, somewhat as opiate drugs do.

title: DOW ADVANCES 5.33
description: Stock prices moved higher for the second straight session yesterday as institutional investors continued to step up their trading activity. Energy-related and technology issues ranked among the market's best groups. Drug, defense and brokerage stocks also advanced.

title: Around the World; Soviet Dissident Gets 10-Year Sentence
description: A Moscow court today sentenced Ivan S. Kovalyov, 27 years old, a member of the Moscow Helsinki Watch Committee, to five years in labor camp followed by five in internal exile for producing and distributing anti-Soviet material.

title: Royal Charter Returns Home - in a $48,000 Copy; Charter Comes Home
description: A man calling himself ''William Smith'' paid $48,000 for William Penn's copy of the Royal Charter of Pennsylvania Thursday night at an auction at Christie's on Park Avenue.

title: Observer; CHECK IT OUT; by Russell Baker
description: One thing that angers the White House is this charge that President Reagan has no compassion. There is a campaign afoot to illustrate that he does, too, have compassion and in his news conference the other evening Mr. Reagan went out of his way to act and talk like a man with compas-sion.

title: Around the World; U.S. Official Finds No Repression in Haiti
description: The third-ranking official of the Justice Department says he is convinced that there is ''no political repression'' in Haiti.

title: Edwards Offered Post
description: The trustees of the Medical University of South Carolina voted today to offer the presidency of the school to Energy Secretary James B. Edwards whenever he is in a position to assume it. Mr. Edwards took over the Federal department last year with the understanding that his principal job would be to preside over its dismantling. Reports circulated in Washington this week that the Reagan Administration no longer wanted to abolish the department, but Mr. Edwards has said that that will not keep him from leaving Washington this year.

title: JOBLESS RATE ROSE TO 9% FOR MARCH, MATCHING RECORD
description: The nation's unemployment rate rose to 9 percent in March, matching the highest level since World War II, the Labor Department announced today. There were nearly 9.9 million people out of work.

title: DEFICIT MAY GO TO $124 BILLION, LAWMAKERS LEARN IN PRIVATE
description: Congressional leaders are being told privately that even if President Reagan's budget is adopted the Administration expects the 1983 deficit to reach $124 billion, Congressional sources disclosed today. This would be $32 billion more than the Administration estimated eight weeks ago,

title: AT THE HELM IN THE TAX STORM
description: Chiseled in stone above the entrance to the Internal Revenue Service headquarters on Constitution Avenue are the oft-quoted words Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes used in a 1904 tobacco-company collection case: ''Taxes are what we pay for a civilized society.''

title: CHEMICAL WARFARE: MISPLACED EMPHASIS
description: To the Editor:

title: Around the World; Soviet Calls Ottawa Ban On Envoy 'Unfriendly'
description: The official press agency Tass today described the expulsion of a Soviet diplomat from Canada as a provocation and ''an unfriendly act.''

title:
PATENTS;
A Cooling System For Nuclear Reactors
description: A cooling system for gas-cooled nuclear reactors was patented this week for the Department of Energy. Patent 4,322,268 went to Hans H. Amtmann of the General Atomic Company, San Diego, which serves the department as a contractor.

title: Monsanto of Britain
description: Monsanto PLC, the British unit of the United States chemicals producer, said today that it planned to close its low-density polyethylene plant based at Fawley, near Southampton. It said long-term prospects for the product remained poor after two years of considerable losses.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: 5 PRISONERS ESCAPE AT TOMS RIVER JAIL, ONE SEIZED ON STREET
description: Five prisoners escaped from the Ocean County Jail this morning, but one of them was recaptured several hours later on a street in his East Orange neighborhood, officials said.

title: POLICIES OF JUDGE COOKE EVOKE A FIERCE DEBATE
description: Since his appointment three years ago as the Chief Judge of the New York Court of Appeals, Lawrence H. Cooke has evoked fierce debate and controversy throughout the state's legal world.

title:
Patents;
Inventors' Exposition Set in May
description: WASHINGTON THE sixth annual International Inventors' Exposition will be held at the New York Statler Hilton Hotel May 10 through May 14, Harold L. Kleiman, the exposition manager, has announced.

title: Teachers Union Loses Appeals Case on Dues
description: A Federal appeals court yesterday upheld the New York State Public Employment Relations Board's suspension of the right of the United Federation of Teachers to have dues deducted from members' paychecks.

title: CAREY ATTACKS BUDGET APPROVED BY THE LEGISLATURE
description: Governor Carey today assailed the budget approved by the Legislature and said it would cause a deficit of $500 million this year and more than $1 billion next year.

title: Abu Dhabi Oil Price Cut
description: The Abu Dhabi National Oil Company has cut the official Government selling price of its crude oil by 94 cents a barrel, Japanese oil industry sources said today. The sources said Abu Dhabi National's Japanese customers had received notice that the reductions would be retroactive to shipments from March 20.

title: Wickes Seeks Payment Delay
description: The Wickes Corporation, a San Diego-based operator of lumber and building-supply stores, has asked its lenders for temporary relief from its outstanding debt, which calls for a $70 million interest payment on April 30.

title: Reagan to Start Series Of Radio Broadcasts
description: President Reagan will deliver the first in a series of 10 short radio broadcasts at 12:05 P.M. Saturday. The White House said today that the first five-minute speech would deal with economic policy.

title: Bridge: An Author's Mind Strays And He Recalls the Price
description: For many years, the world's most prolific authors of bridge books have been British. The only American with a comparable output is Mike Lawrence, who has won two world titles and a string of national events.

title: AM DECLARES A DEFAULT
description: AM International Inc. said today that it had defaulted on its $115 million credit agreement with 21 banks and that talks to modify the agreement had been suspended.

title: Briton Wounded in Ulster
description: Irish nationalist guerrillas wounded a British soldier today by setting off a mine by remote control as his armored patrol vehicle passed over it near here, the police said.

title: CP Air Jet Order
description: CP Air Ltd., Canada's second-largest airline, said it might ask the Boeing Company to delay delivery of four 767 aircraft already on order until sometime after 1985.

title: FINDING EXPERTS TO CLEAN RARE OLD FABRICS
description: It is hassle enough these days to find a cleaner who will effectively remove the dried hollandaise from your regimental striped tie, the remains of a spilled kir from a cherished Kirman, that daub of chocolate mousse from your white linen Anne Klein.

title: Briefing
description: Graham's Spiritual Trip

title: SOME REFUGEES LOSE U.S. AID
description: Nearly 1,500 Southeast Asian refugees whose Federal support has been cut off lined up outside a welfare agency here today to apply for local relief.

title: Communications Cut With the Falklands
description: The last telex contact between Britain and the Falkland Islands took place early today. After that the line was apparently cut by the invading Argentine forces.

title: Sports People; Hearns Heeds Mother
description: Because Thomas Hearns thinks that mother knows best, his longawaited challenge to Marvin Hagler for the world middleweight boxing championship will take place in the 4,670-seat Windsor (Ontario) Arena, which usually houses minor league hockey, across the river from Hearns's hometown of Detroit. Lois Hearns, the boxer's mother, had grown concerned about the advisability of her son's fighting Hagler, particularly after the champion stopped William (Caveman) Lee in only 67 seconds in his most recent defense.

title:
PATENTS;
Automatic Tourniquet Controlled by Computer
description: An automatic tourniquet for restricting the flow of blood from a wound on an arm or leg was patented this week by Jerome H. Lemelson, president of the Licensing Management Corporation, New York, and Christian Grund, a consultant.

title: 7 DAYS INTO TRIAL, SPY ENTERS PLEA OF GUILTY IN WESTERN BANK THEFTS
description: Christopher Boyce, the convicted spy, pleaded guilty today to robbing eight banks in three Western states. The plea cleared the way for Mr. Boyce to testify for two codefendants, Gloria Ann White and Calvin Robinson, who are accused of helping to plan the holdups after he escaped from the Federal prison in Lompoc, Calif., in January 1980.

title: Briefing
description: Eggs That Go Beep

title: Key Rates
description: Previous Year In percent Yesterday Day Ago PRIME RATE 16.50 16.50 17.00 DISCOUNT RATE 12.00 12.00 13.00 FEDERAL FUNDS 16.00 15.48 15.77 3-MO. TREAS. BILLS 13.20 13.25 13.00 6-MO. TREAS. BILLS 13.05 13.07 12.60 7-YR. TREAS. NOTES 14.23 14.23 13.51 30-YR. TREAS. BONDS 13.60 13.60 12.91 BELL SYSTEM BONDS 16.01 16.03 13.84 MUNICIPAL BONDS 13.83 13.91 10.90 6-MONTH SAVINGS 13.493 CERTIFICATES * * Maximum rate payable by savings institutions Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title:
PATENTS;
For Small Dogs at Play, A Tethered Ball
description: A toy intended especially for small dogs has been invented by Doris H. Topliffe of Tacoma, Wash.

title: LINI DE VRIES
description: Lini Moerkerk de Vries, a public health administrator and teacher, died last Saturday at Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N.J. She was 76 years old.

title: Williams Sets a Priority
description: Sly Williams confirmed today at a news conference that emotional and family stress had taken priority over basketball and were chiefly responsible for his three suspensions by the Knicks this season, the last one for the rest of the season.

title: Briefing
description: The Half-Full Glass

title: DANCE MAGAZINE TO GIVE 4 AWARDS ON MAY 3
description: The Dance Magazine Awards, in their 28th year, will be presented May 3 in New York to four persons. They are Fernando Bujones, principal dancer with the American Ballet Theater; Lee Theodore, foundr of the American Dance Machine, which reconstructs and preserves 20th-century American musical theater dance; Arnold Sophr, director of the Royal Winnipeg Ballet, and Laura Dean, the modern-dance choreographer.

title: 2ND YEAR OF FILM MARKET EVEN BRISKER THAN FIRST
description: The American Film Market is back. For 10 frantic days, independent film companies, from the Dino De Laurentiis Corporation to Serendipity Productions, have been peddling their coming films to buyers from all over the world. They have taken over five floors of the Westwood Plaza Hotel and 18 nearby movie theaters, and are making deals in languages that range from Hebrew to Chinese to Serbo-Croatian. The major Hollywood studios are not taking part, having their own distribution networks overseas.

title: PIANIST: KRAUS PLAYS FIVE FANTASIES
description: Detlef Kraus, a West German pianist who has played here before, has returned to New York for a series of three appearances in Carnegie Recital Hall. The first program was devoted to Beethoven, the second (played last Tuesday and heard by this reviewer) offered fantasies by five composers, and the third, scheduled for next Tuesday, will feature quintets by Schumann and Brahms with the Alard String Quartet participating.

title: Common Market Says It Will Push I.B.M. Suit
description: Europe's top antitrust official said today that the European Economic Community did not intend to drop a major antitrust suit against the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: NEW POLICY WIDENS POLLUTION 'SALES'
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today announced a broad national policy designed to apply market principles to its program to control air pollution. It would greatly expand the ability of companies to buy and sell, or trade, rights to pollute the air.

title: A CITY COMMITTED TO FOSTER-CARE REFORM
description: To the Editor:

title: Around the Nation; Doctor in Philadelphia Arrested in Art Theft
description: A doctor was arrested here today in his seven-room apartment on Rittenhouse Square, where the police said they had found about 100 pieces of artwork, at least 20 of them stolen. The artwork, valued at more than $1 million, included a Picasso painting and a bronze statue.

title: BRANIFF SAYS DEBTS FAR EXCEED ASSETS
description: The Braniff International Corporation, parent of Braniff International Airways, has reported to the Government that its debts last year exceeded its assets by $94.4 million.

title: NEW UNIFORMS--BY DESIGN
description: When Parks Commissioner Gordon J. Davis told Ann Weisbrod, the executive director in charge of training, that it was time for new uniforms for the 2,000 park service workers, Miss Weisbrod paused just long enough to allow a bright idea to dawn.

title: Iran Offers Anti-Israel Plan
description: Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Vellayati of Iran today proposed forming an Islamic army to oust Israel from the Arab territories it has occupied since the 1967 Middle East War. He made the suggestion at a news conference at the end of a five-day visit to Pakistan.

title: U.S. STRESSES NEED FOR 2 PHILIPPINE BASES
description: To underscore the importance of retaining American bases in the Philippines, Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger today toured the Subic Bay Naval Station and Clark Air Base.

title: The Shelter Fraud
description: The Pentagon has already begun to play down its formal claim this week that a multibillion-dollar civil defense program could ''provide for survival'' of 80 percent of the population in a general nuclear war. Still, we have two questions:

title: GALLO, BIGGEST IN WINE, GREW EVEN BIGGER IN 1981
description: Connoisseurs may not take the wines of Ernest and Julio Gallo seriously, but the average American consumer certainly does. The Gallo brothers have tightened their grip on the American wine market anew, producing and selling more than a million cases a week in 1981 and accounting for one of every four bottles of American wine consumed in this country.

title: 5 YANKEE PITCHERS ARE WORRIED; Rawley Trade Worries Some Yanks
description: In the aftermath of the acquisition of Shane Rawley in a trade Thursday night with the Seattle Mariners, several Yankee pitchers pondered their status today, only four days before the season begins.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, APRIL 3, 1982
description: International The Falkland Islands were seized by Argentina after three hours of fighting in which several thousand Argentine troops overcame 84 British marines. The Argentine junta announced that it was in control of the Falkland, South Georgia and South Sandwich Islands. The Falklands, 250 miles off Argentina's southeastern tip, were a British colony since 1832. (Page 1, Column 6.) Britain broke off diplomatic relations with Argentina over the seizure of the Falklands and warned that it was taking appropriate military measures to assert its rights under international law. (1:5.)

title: 23 DIE AS TWISTERS HIT THREE STATES
description: Violent winds roared out of the Rockies and across the Middle West yesterday, spawning more than 60 tornadoes and hailstorms. At least 23 persons were killed by twisters in Texas, Arkansas and Missouri, and hundreds were injured.

title: Black Dance Exhibition Planned Through May
description: ''Black Dance in Photographs: From the Mid-19th Century to the Present'' will open Monday at the Schomburg Center, 515 Lenox Avenue, where it will run through May 28.

title: POOR L.I. SCALLOP CATCH UNSETTLES A WAY OF LIFE
description: The sleek gray marsh hawks have ended their winter migration to South America and returned north to Gardiners Bay at the East End of Long Island. Their return announces the end of the scalloping season, which baymen describe as one of the worst they can remember.

title: The Numbers Game
description: THIS has been a week to remember in college sports. From New Orleans, the stats glittered: 61,612 in the Superdome to watch a 63-62 championship thriller, 29 million television viewers. In the ever-so-important Nielsen Game, during the one-hour time slot when North Carolina and Georgetown went two-on-two against Johnny Carson and Oscar, the margin of victory for heavily favored Hollywood, on a share basis, was only 38-31.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: SMITH PRESSING REAGAN TO OUST COAST ATTORNEY
description: Attorney General William French Smith has recommended that President Reagan dismiss the United States Attorney in San Diego if he refuses to resign for disclosing the identity of a key American intelligence source, Administration officials said today.

title: Gergen Asserts News Media Dwell on Economic Problems
description: David R. Gergen, the White House director of communications, accused the news media today of dwelling on such economic problems as high unemployment and ignoring such strides as the declining inflation rate.

title: EXCERPTS FROM EXECUTIVE ORDER ON SECRECY RULES
description: Following are excerpts from an executive order issued by President Reagan today on the classification of information involving national security: EXECUTIVE ORDER NATIONAL SECURITY INFORMATION

title: Sports People; 2 Islanders Resting
description: Two key Islanders, Bob Nystrom and Denis Potvin, are suffering from injuries and unlikely to play this weekend when the team completes its regular-season schedule.

title: Court Suspends Williams's License
description: Harrison A. Williams Jr., who resigned his Senate seat last month when faced with explusion because of his conviction in the Abscam investigation, was temporarily suspended today from practicing law.

title: Around the Nation; Newspaper Drops Suit Against Georgia Agents
description: Federal District Judge Marvin Shoob has dismissed a suit against the Georgia Bureau of Investigation after The Albany Herald decided that bureau agents had not consciously violated the First Amendment in searching an editor's home.

title: BUILDER BUYS MARX ESTATE IN SCARSDALE
description: The largest privately owned estate in this Westchester County town, a 25-room Georgian mansion on 20.5 acres, has been purchased by a developer who plans to build 29 houses to sell at $450,000 and up.

title: Arthur W. Thomas, 91; Specialized in Colloids
description: Arthur W. Thomas, professor emeritus of chemistry at Columbia University and an authority on colloid chemistry, died March 22 in Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 91 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Report Released On Race-Fixing
description: Prominent jockeys fixed thoroughbred races in New York between 1973 and 1975 but cannot be punished for it because of a lack of cooperative witnesses, according to findings of the State Racing and Wagering Board that were released yesterday.

title: News Analysis
description: With the euphoria of Sunday's large turnout in El Salvador's elections now past, American officials here are confronting an aftermath that could frustrate their hope of bringing a greater measure of democracy to this small and troubled country.

title: METEOROLOGISTS ANALYZE A WILD AND 'CRAZY' WINTER
description: With the rugged and destructive winter of 1981-82 finally ended, at least by the calendar, the nation's top research meteorologists, who admitted that they erred in their winter forecast, met here this week to look for the silver lining.

title: ANIMALS IN NEED OF THE A.S.P.C.A.
description: To the Editor:

title: PRICES, NOT WAGES, MAKE UP LIVING COST
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: In the review of the film ''Cat Peo- ple'' in Weekend yesterday, the musi- cal score was incorrectly credited. Giorgio Moroder wrote the music.

title: Your Money; Plan Now For 1982 Taxes
description: THIS may be the time to be struggling with last year's taxes, but it's also the time to look ahead. What should taxpayers be thinking about now to make things easier next year?

title: HARVESTER, CITING LOSS, SEES A POSSIBLE DEFAULT
description: The financially troubled International Harvester Company said yesterday that it expected to lose $518 million this year and that it could be in technical default on its $4.2 billion loan agreement by the end of the month.

title: REAGAN, IN A PHONE CALL, TRIED TO DETER INVASION
description: President Reagan, in a 50-minute telephone call, tried and failed to persuade the head of the Argentine junta to call off the invasion of the British-controlled Falkland Islands.

title: NETS SET BACK BULLETS ON SHOT BY KING, 98-96
description: If there were any doubts that the drive for the National Basketball Association playoffs had begun, Albert King erased them with resounding force tonight. King gave the New Jersey Nets one of their most important victories of the season, a 98-96 decision over the Washington Bullets at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, with a crashing dunk on an inbounds play with five seconds remaining.

title: FABRIC FUMES IN FIRES
description: THE dangers of toxic fumes emitted by burning upholstery fabrics ando ther furnishings will be studied by the Federal Consumer Product S afety Commission, its chairman announced this week.

title: Around the Nation; Plea of Mental Illnesss Is Ended by Idaho Law
description: Gov. John V. Evans signed into law today a bill eliminating the plea of mental illness as a defense in criminal cases.

title: Landlords Face Court on Alarms
description: Nineteen landlords appeared in Housing Court yesterday to answer charges they had failed to install smoke detectors in their Queens apartment buildings.

title: WINDS HOLD UP SHUTTLE MOVE
description: Preparations for the space shuttle's return to its Florida launching pad were delayed more than 12 hours today by winds as strong as the winds that delayed its landing here.

title: Malfunction Shuts Indian Pt. 2 Plant
description: Consolidated Edison Company's Indian Point 2 nuclear power plant shut down early today because of a malfunction in a water pump, the Westchester County police reported.

title: 9 Arrested Off Sinai Coast
description: Nine people belonging to a group protesting the planned Israeli withdrawal from Sinai were arrested today when they tried to land on the Sinai coast from a yacht.

title: Oil in Gulf of Aden
description: AGIP, the Italian stateowned oil company, said today that it had struck oil in the Gulf of Aden off Southern Yemen. The first well has a capacity of 3,000 barrels a day, the company said.

title: ALBANY APPROVES SALE OF LOW-RATE FLEXINOTES
description: The New York State Legislature yesterday approved the sale of commercial paper and flexinotes, which are short-term securities that the state might issue at lower interest rates than on the notes it has traditionally sold.

title: WHITE HOUSE GETS LETTER HALTED
description: The simmering antagonisms between some Republican senators and the White House flared again this week when Reagan Administration officials forced the withdrawal of a fundraising letter designed to help fill the Senate campaign treasuries.

title: by Frank M. Bryan
description: The town meeting is teetering on the brink of extinction. Here in Vermont, evidence of its jeopardy is everywhere as special interests make ready to pounce on the one power that the meetings have left - the power to coat issues with demoncratic respectability.

title: by Sandro Pertini; Following are excerpts from remarks of the President of Italy, on a visit to the United States, made when he addressed students at The Johns Hopkins University School of Advanced International Studies. They are translated from the Italian by Mario Alfano.
description: Italian terrorism has not been defeated yet, notwithstanding the serious defeats which Italian terrorism is suffering. The terrorist hideouts which have been discovered are very important, as are the weapons which have been found. But for me, the indication that Italian terrorism is about to be defeated is another. The reason is this: The terrorists are talking. Before, they didn't.

title: UNIONS AT NEWS HOLD FIRST TALKS WITH ALLBRITTON
description: Joe L. Allbritton, the Texas financier, met yesterday morning with representatives of the unions at The Daily News for ''initial discussions'' on his negotiations to acquire ownership of the newspaper.

title: FOR THE PART-TIME WORKER, SLIM HOPE, NO CHOICE
description: While the recession forces more and more Americans out of work, a postwar record number of people are struggling half in, half out of the labor force, working at part-time jobs and living on part-time wages because they cannot find full-time work.

title: Going Out Guide
description: YESTERYEAR'S MUSIC

title: Brute Force in the Falklands
description: The Falkland Islands, a cluster of rocky outposts in the far South Atlantic, are peopled mainly by shepherds of British descent. The islands are also a convenient staging point for Antarctic explorers. Their permanent population numbers only in the hundreds, but yesterday they were overwhelmed by thousands of Argentine troops.

title: 4 DRUSES AND 6 ISRAELIS HURT IN SCUFFLES IN GOLAN
description: Four Druse in the Golan Heights were wounded in the legs today by Israeli troops, and six soldiers were slightly injured as clashes erupted over attempts to force the Druse to accept Israeli identification cards after the annexation of the territory.

title: Around the World; Italians Strike to Press For Moves on Economy
description: About 14 million Italian workers staged a two-hour national strike today in what the unions said was a first move to push the Government into taking firm action on economic problems.

title: No Headline
description: Quick cash has long been a specialty of pawn shops, loan sharks and finance companies. But now North Carolina taxpayers have found a new way to raise money in a hurry. In growing numbers, they are selling their anticipated state income tax refunds.

title: Westway, Blocked by a Fin
description: Because he doesn't believe the Army Corps of Engineers has fully explored the problems of striped bass in the lower Hudson River, Judge Thomas Griesa has stopped Westway at the water's edge. With other legal and environmental obstacles cleared away, the Corps owes the city a rapid effort to satisfy this last objection.

title: FRANCE TO CONSIDER ROLE IN ALSANDS FUEL PROJECT
description: France's Minister for Foreign Trade indicated today that France might come to the rescue of the near-moribund Alsands project to mine tar sands for oil.

title: DEAL EMERGING TO KEEP GARDEN FROM CLOSING
description: Even as the circus clowns and acrobats pranced about Madison Square Garden this week, a related balancing act - the complex plan to keep the Garden in New York City - was heading toward its first private performance.

title: Pabst Bids Schmidt Increase Its Offer
description: The Pabst Brewing Company said yesterday that it had instructed management to make a counterproposal of $25 a share to C. Schmidt & Sons, which previously offered to acquire Pabst at $20.50 a share.

title: SATURDAY, APRIL 3, 1982; The Economy
