description: Unemployment rose to 9 percent in March, matching the highest level since World War II. The Labor Department said 9.9 million people were out of work. Several economists said the figures indicated that the economy is still sluggish, delaying hopes for a recovery. Many expect the rate to rise further in the next few months. (Page 1.) The city's jobless rate rose to 10.1 percent. (20.) In addition to the unemployed, more than 5.7 million people hold only part-time jobs. (20.) President Reagan's budget will produce a 1983 deficit of $124 billion, $32 billion more than the Administration estimated eight weeks ago, Congressional sources say they are being told privately. (1.)

title: DR. HARRY OLSEN, ACOUSTIC EXPERT
description: Dr. Harry Ferdinand Olson, an acoustical engineer whose research for the RCA Corporation brought many advances to the recording and broadcasting industries, died Thursday at the Princeton (N.J.) Medical Center. He was 81 years old and a resident of Princeton.

title: IRELAND'S HOPES FOR OFFSHORE OIL STARTING TO FADE
description: For a brief while, that old bromide about Irish luck seemed to be illuminated by a bit of truth. Beneath stormy waters, 125 miles west of Galway, exploration companies encountered oil. Excitement nearly overwhelmed the Irish stock exchange as shares in local companies soared in price.

title: Conrail Track Sold
description: The Consolidated Rail Corporation announced sale of 177.4 miles of its Conrail line in New York for an undisclosed amount to the Delaware Otsego Corporation. Conrail said that Delaware Otsego expects to assume operation of the line about April 8, following Interstate Commerce Commission approval. The sale includes 92.9 miles of line between Binghamton, N.Y., and Utica, N.Y.; 61.7 miles between Chenango Forks, N.Y., and Jamesville, N.Y.; the New York Mills track south of Utica; 6.2 miles of line between Wayne, N.J., and Pompton, N.J., and 13.6 miles between Warwick, N.Y., and Franklin, N.J.

title: Linda Lavin Plans to Marry Again; 'Alice' to Wed
description: One of television's most famous waitresses, ''Alice,'' a widow, has remained unmarried for years, but Linda Lavin, the actress who plays her, is going to try marriage again.

title: I.B.M. TIE EXPLAINED BY BAXTER
description: The Reagan Administration's antitrust chief acknowledged today that a grant from the International Business Machines Corporation had financed part of a year's research he did in the late 1960's. But he denied that the arrangement influenced him to drop the Government's antitrust suit against the computer company earlier this year.

title: PLAN BY CITIBANK POSES RISKS
description: Under a program announced Thursday by Citibank, a customer could lose hundreds of dollars if checks deposited to his account were to bounce, the bank said yesterday.

title: Miss Stacy, at 138, Holds 3-Shot Lead
description: Hollis Stacy shot a sevenunder-par 65 today to take the second-round lead in the $310,000 Nabisco-Dinah Shore women's golf tournament.

title: Ukrainian Boy Denied Bid for Custody Review
description: An appeals court refused today to review its December decision that a Ukrainian boy who ran away from his parents rather than return to the Soviet Union must be returned to their custody.

title: SOCIALIST INTERNATIONAL RIDICULES SALVADOR VOTE
description: The presidium of the Socialist International today ridiculed the elections in El Salvador and issued a statement of support for Nicaragua's Sandinist Government.

title: RANGERS CANCEL DAYTIME SLOT
description: Responding to protests by the Philadelphia Flyers and their own ticket-holders, the Rangers said yesterday that they had decided not to schedule the second game of the National Hockey League playoffs as an afternoon game next Thursday at Madison Square Garden.

title: 2 Held in Labeling Of Kosher Meat
description: Two men were arrested yesterday on charges of branding and selling nonkosher veal as kosher meat, the State Attorney General's office said. A third suspect was being sought.

title: Falkland Islands; History
description: The Falklands, a group of bleak, windswept islands 250 miles off South America's southeast coast, have been a source of contention between Britain and Argentina for 150 years. They were long strategically important as the nearest refuge for ships from the dangerous passage around Cape Horn. Their territorial waters are now considered a likely source of oil and gas.

title: STUDENTS AT PARLEY MOBILIZE AGAINST AID CUTS
description: Ellen Balaguer and Brad Blackwell are soft-spoken young college seniors unaccustomed to a national arena, but they represent a force that has already swayed the powerful House Appropriations Committee to seek more money for students than President Reagan wanted.

title: EL GRECO EXHIBITION OPENS IN MADRID
description: The year of El Greco has begun, and with it another phase in the reconsideration of the 16th-century Cretan painter whose genius was nourished in Italy and came into flower in the Spanish city of Toledo.

title: S.E.C. Studies Chicago Baker
description: The American Bakeries Company, a Chicago-based wholesale baker taken over by a dissident shareholder group after a protracted proxy fight, disclosed that the Securities and Exchange Commission had begun an investigation to determine whether it violated securities laws in connection with required filings or securities transactions since 1979.

title: RULE TYING PUPIL PROMOTION TO READING SKILL STIRS WORRY
description: New York City school officials are increasingly concerned over the fate of thousands of youngsters who may have to repeat the seventh grade several times before raising their reading scores high enough to be promoted.

title: Bloomingdale's
description: Bloomingdale's said it will open its first Florida department store in the spring of 1984 in a new shopping center to be developed near Miami. The 225,000-square-foot, full-line store will be built at The Falls, a shopping center in south Dade County, which will have 65 tenants. Bloomingdale's, like Abraham & Straus, is a store division of Federated Department Stores of Cincinnati.

title: The Final Word on Zsa Zsa Gabor's Age; The Final Word
description: Tired unto tears of having her age reported as being anywhere from 49 to 63, Zsa Zsa Gabor said in Hollywood yesterday, she was revealing the truth by releasing a copy of her birth certificate.

title: Loretta Hines Howard, Artist
description: And Creche Figure Collector

title: New York; THE PLAYBOY TAPES; by Sydney H. Schanberg
description: You've no doubt heard of the landmark Supreme Court case on the Pentagon Papers, New York Times v. U.S. And you've also heard of the Watergate tapes case, U.S. v. Nixon. Well, prepare yourself for another big one - Playboy v. Koch. Or maybe it will be Daily News v. Koch.

title: SHARED PULITZER PRIZE IN 1937
description: Gobind Behari Lal, a Pulitzer Prizewinning journalist and Indian patriot, died of cancer Thursday, a few weeks after writing his last news article. He was 92 years old.

title: Breathing Room for Special Education
description: It may seem mean-spirited for Frank Macchiarola, the Chancellor of New York City's schools, to call for a slowdown in expansion of special programs for handicapped children. But in fact he makes a sensible point.

title: BRIEFS
description: * ARA Services Inc. said that about 1,060,500 shares, or 86 percent of the outstanding common stock of Means Services Inc., had been tendered before the expiration of ARA's cash tender offer.

title: Marguerite Duthuit, a Model In Art of Matisse, Her Father
description: Marguerite Duthuit, daughter of the great French painter Henri Matisse and for many years an indispensable source of information both as to his working methods and as to the whereabouts and authenticity of his huge output, died of a heart attack in Paris on Thursday. She was 87 years old.

title: New Director for the Goddard Space Flight Center; New Goddard Director
description: The director of the National Air and Space Museum, Noel Hinners, has been appointed to become director of the Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Md., effective June 14.

title: Military Analysis
description: It was several thousand Argentines against fewer than 100 Britons yesterday when Argentina seized the Falkland Islands, but an authoritative source in London said Britain had the forces available to make it difficult for

title: MONEY SUPPLY OFF $3 BILLION
description: The Federal Reserve yesterday announced a $3 billion decline in the nation's money supply for the week ended March 24, a largerthan-expected drop that helped lessen concern about large money supply increases that have been predicted for April.

title: Shell to Abandon 2 of 3 Gas Wells
description: The Shell Oil Company said it would cap and abandon two of its three exploratory wells in central Washington after failing to find natural gas in commercial quantities.

title: REAGAN ORDER TIGHTENS THE RULES ON DISCLOSING SECRET INFORMATION
description: President Reagan signed an executive order today giving Government officials broader authority to withhold information from the public on grounds of national security.

title: RECITAL: PRINTED CIRCUIT
description: Paul Galasso's cello works were so warm and amiable when the composer performed them Tuesday night at the Dance Theater Workshop with his group Printed Circuit that the sarcasm, textual provocations and rock intonations that went along with many of them created an ''advanced'' feeling that was unusually engaging.

title: RUTH GIKOW, ARTIST, 67, DIES: CAUGHT THE MOODS OF PEOPLE
description: Ruth Gikow, a painter whose works have been collected by many major museums, died in New York University Hospital yesterday after a long illness. Miss Gikow, who was married to the painter Jack Levine, was 67 years old.

title: AN ANCIENT AND MOST EXACTING CRAFT
description: In a spare, sunlit room the man sits, doing work men like him have done for thousands of years. Outside the city streets are grimy, spotted with trash. The building in which the man sits looks like a hundred other modern buildings, built of brick and glass in square lines, with that odd sense of impermanence typical of the second half of the 20th century.

title: Agreement Ends Case Against 6-Year-Old
description: The case of a 6-year-old girl who faced trial as an adult for hitting another girl with a stick has been resolved by her family's agreeing to pay half the victim's doctor bills, a mediator said today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The British never give orders to anyone to surrender.'' - John Nott, British Defense Secretary. (6:6.)

title: WARSAW PRESSES ATTACK ON SOLIDARITY
description: In the midst of what the Polish Government calls a ''public discussion'' on the future of the trade union movement, the officially controlled press and broadcasting outlets are stepping up a campaign against the suspended Solidarity union.

title: U.S. VETOES RESOLUTIONS AT U.N. ON CENTRAL AMERICA AND MIDEAST
description: The United States twice vetoed Security Council resolutions today, once to protect Washington's policy in the Americas and once to defend Israel.

title: RULE 415 DEBT FILING BY DU PONT
description: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company yesterday became the third major company to register with the Securities and Exchange Commission under new regulations that give corporations quick and easy access into the capital markets without the usual waiting periods.

title: Sorts People; Richard Disabled
description: Major league baseball teams continued trimming their rosters in preparation for the season openers, and among those players cut were some rather familiar names. Perhaps the most prominent was J.R. Richard, who was placed on the disabled list by the Houston Astros and enrolled in a special program designed to help him continue his rehabilitation from a stroke that nearly killed him twoyears ago. ... The Philadelphia Phillies put Tug McGraw, the relief pitcher, on the disabled list and said they would leave him in Florida so that he could work out with the minor leaguers.

title: JAPAN STUDIES OFFERING LOANS TO U.S. BUSINESS
description: The notion of a Japanese program to provide lowinterest loans for American business is apparently receiving serious consideration here.

title: U.S. Navy Plane Lost Over Mediterranean
description: The Navy said today that one of its cargo planes with 11 people aboard was missing and presumed down in the Mediterranean.

title: Sears Loses Patent Suit; Clerk Wins $5 Million In Sears Case
description: A former clerk for Sears, Roebuck & Company was awarded $5 million by a Federal court jury today for a patent violation stemming from the retailer's sale of millions of socket wrenches he designed 18 years ago as a teenager.

title: TROOPER WHO DIED IN CAVE HONORED AT RITES
description: Donald G. Weltner, the Scoutmaster and state police sergeant who died wedged in a limestone cave last weekend, was buried here today under bright blue skies.

title: Court Blocks Broker's Assets
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today obtained a Federal court order freezing the assets of a stockbroker accused of a $22 million stock manipulation scheme.

title: D'AMATO'S VICTORY FOR THE SOUTH BRONX
description: To the Editor:

title: CITY OPERA: A NEW PRODUCTION OF 'I LOMBARDI'
description: The New York City Opera's ambitious cycle of early Verdi operas, while providing us with the opportunity to see some half-legendary works that led up to the mature masterpieces, has not been a series of dizzying successes. Much of the fault is Verdi's, of course, but the City Opera has not been a great help to him. When a work is as weak and uneven as ''I Lombardi,'' for instance, it needs all the help it can get, not only vocally but in stage design, direction and lighting. The ''I Lombardi'' production that made its bow last night hit bottom in design and direction, and the singing was rarely more than acceptable.

title: DECAFFEINATED: SERVING THE BEST
description: The increasing demand for decaffeinated coffee is one of the more noticeable changes in eating habits. Despite that growing demand, envelopes of instant Sanka are often presented with hot water at the end of the meal, even in some of our toniest and otherwise impeccable restaurants. It is much the same problem that faces tea drinkers who rightfully resent being served tea bags in so-called quality restaurants.

title: CAMPBELL'S SOUP -TO-NUTS PLAN
description: ''If you think of the food business as being your desk top, picture a wide segment in the middle that takes up about half of the desk,'' says John Morris, vice president of corporate development at the Campbell Soup Company. ''That's where Campbell is today. What we want to do is get on either side.''

title: Briefing
description: Lockup in High Court

title: Briefing
description: Forward Look in Economics

title: Filmways Loss Is Expected
description: Financially troubled Filmways Inc. disclosed in a proxy statement that it expects to report a ''substantial but still undetermined loss'' for its fiscal fourth quarter ended Feb. 28. In the comparable 1981 period, the company lost $46.4 million and lost $66.3 million in the fiscal year 1981.

title: UNEMPLOYMENT ROSE IN NEW YORK CITY, BUT HELD STEADY IN THE STATE
description: The rate of unemployment in New York City rose from 9.2 percent in February to 10.1 percent in March, the highest since March 1981, when it was 10.6 percent. The rates for both New York State and New Jersey, however, were little changed last month.

title: United Television Stake Is Increased
description: Chris-Craft Industries, a diversified television broadcaster and a producer of plastics, chemicals and pleasure boats, said that it had increased its majority ownership in United Television Inc.

title: Hearing Tuesday In Transit Dispute
description: Arvid Anderson, chairman of the three-member arbitration panel in the transit dispute, announced yesterday that hearings would begin at 10 A.M. Tuesday in the Washington Room of the Sheraton City Squire, at Seventh Avenue and 51st Street.

title: Hologram Show Set
description: Twenty-two children have selected their favorite holograms at the Museum of Holography to be exhibited in ''Children's Choice.''

title: British Video Plant Set
description: The joint video product venture set up by Thorn Emi PLC, the Victor Company of Japan Ltd. and Aeg-Telefunken A.G. will make video cassette recorders in Britain as well as in West Berlin, as previously announced, Thorn said here today.

title: Bonn Official in Moscow
description: Economics Minister Otto Lambsdorff of West Germany met with Deputy Prime Minister Leonid A. Kostandov today in the first high-level contacts between the two countries since the declaration of martial law in Poland on Dec. 13. The Polish crisis and the construction of a natural gas pipeline from Siberia to Western Europe were the chief topics at the hourlong meeting, Mr Lambsdorff said.

title: EUROPEAN ATOMIC ARMS FOES TOUR U.S.
description: A delegation of leaders of the European nuclear disarmament movement, seeking to encourage the same kind of fervent backing that has mounted on the other side of the Atlantic, is nearing the end of a 17-day swing through 50 American cities.

title: Cook Joins Race Against Shapiro
description: Thomas H. Cook Jr., the Mayor of this Essex County community, announced today that he would seek the Democratic nomination for County Executive in the primary on June 8.

title: Around the Nation; Von Bulow Is Rejected In Bid for New Trial
description: A judge today rejected Claus von Bulow's bid for a new trial, saying that the evidence justified his conviction on charges of twice trying to kill his wife.

title: Briefing
description: Who Laughs Last

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Wayne (Tree) Rollins of the Atlanta Hawks was fined $1,500 by the National Basketball Association for elbowing Kenny Dennard of Kansas City in a game on March 24. Rollins, a center, was also assessed an automatic $250 fine when he was ejected and was fined $750 in February for the same offense against Jeff Cook of Phoenix. ... Bjorn Borg, playing his first qualifying match in five years and his first regular competitive match in five months, defeated Paolo Bertolucci of Italy, 7-5, 6-0, in a preliminary match to the Monte Carlo Grand Prix that opens Monday.

title: Donald Luce, Ex-Chief Of a Utility in Newark
description: Donald C. Luce, former president of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company of Newark, died Thursday at his home in Plainfield, N.J., after a long illness. He was 81 years old.

title: RAIDERS EXPRESS INTEREST IN MOVE TO CITY
description: The Oakland Raiders have made a preliminary overture to New York City about the possibility of moving here if they lose their legal battle to move to Los Angeles.

title: SALVADORAN RIGHT SAYS THE CENTRISTS WILL HAVE A ROLE
description: The leader of the extreme right-wing Nationalist Republican Alliance said today that ''we are planning to incorporate'' the centrist Christian Democratic Party in the new Government of El Salvador, but he rejected the idea of retaining the Christian Democratic President of the ruling junta.

title: H.U.D.'S SUBSIDY TO DITY TERMED LATE AND SHORT
description: After a four-month delay, the New York City Housing Authority today received $50 million in operating subsidies from the Federal Government. However, the amount was about 25 percent less than the authority believed it was entitled to.

title: IGOR GORIN
description: Igor Gorin, a baritone who had a long career in opera, radio and television, died March 24 in Tucson, Ariz., where he had been living since his retirement from the concert stage.

title: April Fool's Day Joke Backfires in Athens
description: Greece's state-controlled National Radio Network has been sued and its director has submitted his resignation after an April Fool's Day news broadcast that called for the evacuation of the city center because pollution had reached emergency levels. The broadcast caused serious panic, a Government spokesman said.

title: by George McGovern
description: Ralph Waldo Emerson has assured us: ''A man may love a paradox without either losing his wit or his honesty.'' It is good that we have this assurance because these are certainly days when paradox rules.

title: DALLAS VOTING DISTRICTS IN DOUBT AFTER COURT RULING
description: The May 1 primary election in four Texas Congressional districts has been cast into at least temporary uncertainty by a United States Supreme Court ruling Thursday that overturned the state's latest redistricting plan.

title: Books of The Times
description: Two for Suspense By ANATOLE BROYARD THE ENGLISH LADY. By William Harrington. 408 Pages. Seaview Books. $13.95. CEREMONY. By Robert B. Parker. 182 Pages. Delacorte Press/Seymour Lawrence. $12.95.

title: Lost Off Boston
description: When a World Airways jetliner skidded off a runway into Boston Harbor while landing last Jan. 23, the airline first said all 208 people aboard had got off safely. Within three days the carrier reversed itself.

title: HOW DO THEY SPELL RELIEF? ARBITRATION
description: THIS time two years ago Richard Ravitch, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, was holed up in a midtown hotel, besieged by the press, politicians and the public, trying to end a transit strike that had tied the city in knots.

title: CAMPUS MUSIC EVENTS
description: YOU don't have to be a student to go back to school, and considering the diversity of cultural activity on Connecticut campuses over the next two weeks, music lovers are well advised to do precisely that.

title: West Tops East, 102-88, In College Senior Game
description: Ricky Frazier of Missouri scored 12 of his 15 points in the second half to rally the West team to a 102-88 victory over the East today in the Pizza Hut Basketball Classic.

title: BANGLADESH RULER OFF TO SLOW START
description: Despite all efforts to show that the military takeover on March 24 spells a better future for Bangladesh, there is a growing feeling here that the martial-law administration of Lieut. Gen. H.M. Ershad has had a less auspicious first week in power than many predicted.

title: The Nation; TIme Stands Still For an Assassin
description: As the first anniversary of the attack on President Reagan passed last week, John W. Hinckley Jr., the man who fired the shots, was in a kind of legal limbo, his trial perhaps still many weeks away.

title: PRICES IN BALDWIN
description: To the Editor:

title: A DREAM OF COMMUNITY
description: KIBBUTZ MAKOM Report From an Israeli Kibbutz. By Amia Lieblich. 318 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $16.50.

title: Wendeney Wood Married
description: Wendeney Legendre Wood, daughter of Peter Hodgson Wood of Cross River, N.Y., and Landine Legendre Manigault of Stonington, Conn., was married in Mount Holly, S.C., yesterday to Maurice W. Ver Brugge, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice A. Ver Brugge of San Francisco.

title: OF LIFE AND LOVE--AND TURNING 50
description: ISLID into 50 the other day. The jolt made me realize I wasn't 49 a nymore. Being 49 is having a daughter who cheerfully prepares you f or 50. She reminds you, ''You're going to be an older parent. You g uys were always younger than all my friends' parents, but now you'llb e in your 50's, too.''

title: Sandoval Defeats Petty On a Majority Decision
description: Richie Sandoval of Pomona, Calif., won a majority decision from Harold Petty of Fort Worth today in a 10-round bantamweight bout.

title: EXPLORING UNDERWATER REALMS
description: NEW HAVEN CLEAR, early spring morning light glistened on the water as the research vessel U Conn made her way out of New Haven harbor. The cruise ahead would include activities that demonstrated several aspects of the work of Connecticut's Sea Grant Advisory Service, an agency primarily committed to increasing the state's seafood harvest by exploring the largely unchartered realms of aquaculture and high technology fishing methods.

title: Ideas & Trends; Too Little, Too Many
description: Malthusian prophecies of population growth and consumption rates overwhelming the environment are alive and disconcertingly well. The United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific, meeting in Bangkok last week, traced much of the region's environmental damage to high birth rates and poverty.

title: Bridge; A CINDERELLA STORY
description: In the traditional fairy tale, Cinderella had six remarkable hours that ended, or almost ended, at midnight. In a variation on the Cinderella tale, one that took place at the Spring Nationals in Niagara Falls last month, the time of glory lasted six full days, again ending, or almost ending, at midnight.

title: Salvador Between Right and Wrong
description: Democracies are made, not born, and part of the making, once the people have spoken, is bargaining over who gets what offices. Americans do the people of El Savador no favor by presuming to pick their leaders after last Sunday's stirring evidence that Salvadorans want to determine their own affairs. The whole point of that election was to have El Salvador deal with its own realities.

title: The Region; Gibson and Rival Under a Cloud
description: The damage vandals did to Newark's water supply sistem last summer has been repaired, but the incident continues to make waves for Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson. Last week an Essex County grand jury indicted Mr. Gibson and the City Council President on charges that they put a former city councilman on the payroll as the water system's security chief but didn't require him to show up for work.

title: Presidential Yacht
description: For entertaining foreign dignitaries, soothing testy Congressmen and sheer personal relaxation, the yacht Sequoia had served United States Presidents grandly from Herbert Hoover on. Jimmy Carter ordered her sold in 1977; he said the 104-foot vessel was an ''unjustified and unnecessary frill.''

title: R. L. Keatley Weds Catharine Williams
description: Catharine Davenport Edgar Williams, a reading-skills teacher and a doctoral candidate in the psychology of learning at the University of Hong Kong, was married yesterday to Robert Leland Keatley, editor of The Asian Wall Street Journal in Hong Kong. The Rev. Eric Kvan performed the ceremony in the Anglican Chapel at St. John's College, the University of Hong Kong.

title: Postings; ELEVEN ON 67
description: What is believed to be the first row of townhouses built in Manhattan since the turn of the century is rapidly nearing completion on East 67th Street between Second and Third Avenues.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: ''SPRING Will Be a Little Late This Year.'' ''It Might as Well Be Spring.'' ''Paris in the Spring'' (Tra-La, Tra-La). ''Spring Is Here.'' And let's not leave out ''April in Paris'' (One More Time!!). For most Long Island saloon piano players, ''Spring Can Really Hang You Up the Most'': At least as many songs have been written with spring in the titles or somewhere in the lyrics as there have been about Christmas, and the music makers will be asked to play all the above and many more.

title: OPENING DAY AND ONE THING IS CERTAIN
description: FOR a major league player who played 14-plus years and experienced 19 World Series games, 25 playoff games and three All-Star Games, Openings Days were still the most nerve-wracking experience of them all.

title: Lillian Clark Doubleday Is Betrothed
description: Mrs. Paul J. Chase of Mill Neck, L.I., and Nelson Doubleday of Locust Valley, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Lillian Clark Doubleday, to Newell Bertram Woodworth 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Woodworth of Princeton, N.J.

title: REVERING SUFFERS KNEE STRAIN
description: Dave Revering took his torrid exhibition hitting indoors tonight, but he was also injured on the Superdome's artificial surface.

title: New Jersey Guide; TAIWANESE CIRCUS
description: The magicians, dancers, jugglers and acrobats of the Chinese Magic Circus of Taiwan will perform tomorrow at the State Theater in New Brunswick. The circus is on a 15-week tour of the United States, but tomorrow's performance, which begins at 7:30 P.M., will be the 18-member troupe's only appearance in New Jersey.

title: FROM INDIFFERENCE TO ATTENTION
description: A DOZEN years ago, during the only sabbatical I've had in 30 years of teaching, I tried my hand at writing fiction, to see what would happen. Defoe was 59 when he wrote ''Robinson Crusoe,'' his first novel; I was only 43. My ambition was to achieve a text that would have in it something of the deft ironies of Donald Barthelme, the crazy brightness of Osip Mandelstam and the dark sanity of Kafka.

title: COMPUTERS ALTER LIVES OF PUPILS AND TEACHERS
description: At the Lamplighter School, a private elementary school in Dallas, a 5-year-old was recently overheard speaking disparagingly of a fellow student: ''Jonathan is already 4, and he can't do the computer.''

title: P.L.O. IS SAID TO BE COMMITTED TO LEBANESE TRUCE
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization remains firmly committed to the cease-fire with Israel in southern Lebanon despite the growing impatience of radical factions, Palestinian sources said today.

title: BATHTUBS I HAVE KNOWN
description: RICHARD CONDON is the author of two non-fiction books and 19 novels, among them ''The Manchurian Candidate.'' His newest, ''Prizzi's Honor,'' is being published by Putnam's. By RICHARD CONDON

title:
Numismatics;
A SILVER BULLION COIN?
description: The prospect of an official United States gold bullion coin has caused considerable fanfare - and furor - in recent weeks. Less publicized, but perhaps more significant for the ordinary American, is a parallel proposal calling for production of a silver bullion coin.

title: CHURCHES OFFER EASTER MUSIC
description: day period in the Christian calendar. It commemorates the entry of Jesus into Jerusalem, His death and Resurrection.

title: NOV. 12, 1946: DRIVE-IN TELLERS EVOLVE
description: PROGRESS tickles me. Breakthroughs in the darnedest fields give me goosebumps. Depending on the surroundings, the circumstances and the people with whom I'm sharing a drink I will sing the praises of penicillin or the Boeing 747, the Chipwich or the Zamboni machine.

title: NEW TRIAL SOUGHT IN 1976 MURDER CASE
description: BRIDGETON FOLLOWING a recantation of crucial testimony, public defenders plan to ask the Appellate Division of State Superior Court to approve a new trial for three Bridgeton residents who have spent five years in jail for the murder of a gasoline station attendant during a holdup here in 1976.

title: Major News; Invasion in the South Atlantic
description: For 150 years, London was more amused than interested when Buenos Aires heatedly and repeatedly asserted sovereignty over the Falkland Islands, 5,000 square miles of rocky, wind-blown South Atlantic sheep pasture with possible oilfields off-shore. Last week, Argentina finally got Britain's attention. It sent 4,000 troops to seize the 200 islands (population 1,800 humans and 700,000 mostly absentee-owned sheep) which Britain had ruled since ousting an Argentine garrison in 1833. In brief fighting with 80 defending British marines, an Argentine officer was killed. Argentine newspapers reported continuing scattered resistance by the islanders.

title: Art; FOR THE BOOKSHELF: THE NEWARK MUSEUM DETAILS ITS HOLDINGS
description: NEWARK ON THE surface of things, a museum's publication of a book about its collection is not an extraordinary event, for a number of museums across the country are doing it.

title: TREATING THE LIVER
description: WHEN Jenny's daughter was born with a possibly fatal liver condition, the hospital physician told her to go home without the child and ''begin a new life.''

title: Dance View; THE GREAT GISELLES COMPARED
description: ''There is only one reason why Giselle didn't like Hilarion. I was told it was because he had a red beard.'' That is Alicia Markova's explanation, in the matter-of-fact tone she can make so persuasive, of a crucial plot element in ''Giselle.'' (If Giselle liked Hilarion instead of Albrecht, there would be no plot.) Markova makes her remarks in ''A Portrait of Giselle,'' an unusual film presented by ARTS, the Hearst/ ABC cable channel. She is joined by Galina Ulanova, Tamara Karsavina, Olga Spessivtseva, Alicia Alonso, Yvette Chauvire, Carla Fracci and Natalia Makarova.

title: HARD TIMES FOR NEWSPAPER UNIONS
description: EVERY year the United States Department of Labor ranks the nation's manufacturing employers by the number of jobs they provide. Top place usually goes to steel mills or automobile and auto parts makers. Last year, however, these industries were overtaken by a surprising contender - newspapers - whose payrolls supported more than 432,000 employees.

title: The Region; Westchester Goes Electric
description: When Westchester County proposed two and a half years ago to enter the electricity business, and perhaps ease Consolidated Edison out of it, most voters felt they couldn't afford to. Last week, more than $500 million in rate increases later, the voters seemed to conclude that they couldn't afford not to and approved a more limited proposal by a 5 to 1 margin.

title: Recessionspeak
description: Robust sales and healthy profits speak for themselves; hard times call forth the deepest talents of financial public relations men. This year, more than ever, the evidence is available in the annual reports currently in the mail to millions of American shareholders.

title: Around the World; Mexican Volcano Erupts Again
description: El Chinchonal Volcano hurled rocks, lava and debris for miles tonight in the biggest eruption since the peak in southeastern Mexico turned active in the last week.

title: Couture Beats Berardi To Win Bowling Event
description: Pete Couture defeated Joe Berardi, 240-222, when Berardi left the 10-pin standing in the final frame of the last game today in the $110,000 King Louie Open bowling tournament.

title: MYSTERY DEEPENS AT LOUISVILLE NEW PLAYS FESTIVAL
description: The opening day of this year's Festival of New American Plays at the Actors Theater of Louisville - a 10-event, three-day marathon drawing an international audience of producers, directors, agents and critics - ended with a John Ford double feature, stage simulcra of two of his movie classics, ''The Grapes of Wrath'' and ''The Informer.''

title: PIANIST: BENITA MESHULAM
description: At times during her recital at the 92d Street Y Wednesday night, the pianist Benita Meshulam seemed more a prisoner of the notes than a servant of the music. Despite her evident competence, she was less than persuasive in a program built of works emphasizing delicacy, atmosphere and understatement, largely because she did not seem to know how to bring out what was significant and to subordinate what was clearly secondary.

title: PARADOXES OF BELIEF
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Robert Alter's latest book is ''The Art of Biblical Narrative.'' THE REFUSERS An Epic of the Jews. By Stanley Burnshaw. 444 pp. New York: Horizon Press. $14.95. By ROBERT ALTER

title: DANCE: RIRIE-WOODBURY
description: The Ririe-Woodbury Dance Company came from Salt Lake City to the Theater of the Riverside Church Thursday night with a bag of choreographic tricks. These dancers, under the direction of Shirley Russon Ririe and Joan Woodbury, certainly enjoyed being clever. In fact, kinetic prankishness occasionally made their offerings more shallow than they ought to have been.

title: COUNTY IS SUED ON TAX
description: WHITE PLAINS THE City of White Plains is facing what it calls ''budgetary havoc'' as a result of a new Westchester County law raising the county's share of the sales tax.

title: CALIFORNIA OARSMEN EXCEL AT SAN DIEGO
description: The University of California-Berkeley swept the heavyweight eight-oared events at the ninth annual San Diego Rowing Classic today on Mission Bay.

title: THE NEW ROUNDABOUT ROUTE TO BROADWAY
description: What has happened to the independent producer? The League of New York Theaters and Producers has about twice as many members now as 10 years ago, but this may suggest only that the passion to produce burns as brightly as ever, and not that producing is less hazardous or more fun. It costs far more to produce than it ever did, and because of the risks there is a new route that producers must take to bring a show to Broadway. It begins in the regional theaters or Off Broadway; it winds through agents' offices; it is trod by producers in droves. It has to do with money.

title: 'RESCUE OF THE SEA LAW' FAR FROM COMPLETE
description: To the Editor:

title: COUNTY PLANNING UTILITY AGENCY IN THE WAKE OF BROAD VICTORY
description: WHITE PLAINS SOLID electoral victories for two energy-related referendums last week have cleared the way for county negotiations with Consolidated Edison over distribution of inexpensive power and caused a New Hampshire company to expect to break ground soon in Peekskill.

title: FARM BELT ALLEGIANCE TO G.O.P. APPEARS STILL FIRM
description: The Farm Belt, despite bankruptcies, seed loans at up to 19 percent and corn selling for about $1 a bushel less than a year ago, is showing no convincing signs of a broad revolt against its long-time allegiance to the Republican Party.

title: STATE AIDE, CRITICAL OF POLLUTION BY CITY, SUSPENDED
description: The regional attorney in New York City for the State Department of Environmental Conservation has been suspended after complaining to officials that the agency had failed to halt pollution violations by the city.

title: GANG WARFARE IN NAPLES LAID TO JAILED CHIEF
description: From a prison cell that has been his home for 14 of the last 19 years, not counting the four years he spent in an asylum for the criminally insane, Raffaele Cutolo has reportedly been conducting one of the most murderous gang wars between this city and Salerno.

title: ARGENTINA SAYS IT WILL 'NOT RETREAT' AND BREAKS RELATIONS WITH BRITAIN
description: Argentina said today that it would ''not retreat'' from its seizure of the Falkland Islands from Britain. The Government also announced that it was breaking relations with Britain and ordered British diplomats to leave Argentina by next Thursday, in response to a similar British move Friday. The Economics Ministry announced tonight that it had frozen all British assets in Argentina, hours after London said it would freeze Argentina's assets in Britain.

title: TV View; WHEN A DOCUMENTARIAN TRIES TO PLAY SOCIOLOGIST
description: The documentary mini-series ''Middletown,'' currently being shown on Channel 13 on Wednesday evenings at 9, has been described by its executive producer, Peter Davis, as a collection of ''found dramas.'' In fact, the programs are no more ''found'' than last week's television movie about, say, test-tube babies.

title: Postings; A NORMAL WINTER
description: Remember back in January and February, when the world was locked in an icy embrace and householders and operators of residential property were quaking before the prospect of huge fuel oil bills?

title: FOLK-POP: HAVENS'S 'NEXUS'
description: Hybrids of pop and classical music rarely work outside traditional ''pops'' orchestral settings, and ''Nexus,'' a piece billed as ''a fusion song cycle,'' and based on the songs and poetry of the folkpop singer Richie Havens, is no exception. Given its premiere by the Long Island Chamber Ensemble in Carnegie Hall Wednesday night, this melange of folk songs, recitation and orchestral themes, divided into 12 short movements, proved to be a choppy, pretentious exercise in musical cross-fertilization organized around Mr. Havens's exceedingly naive verses, whose tone of inspirational earnestness is a cut below ''Jonathan Livingston Seagull.''

title: The World; The Errors of Vietnam's Ways
description: Communist regimes usually save their bursts of self-critical candor until after the old guard has safely been changed, but at Vietnam's Fifth Party Congress last week the recriminations just wouldn't keep. Vietnam gets $3 million a day from Moscow, according to Western estimates, but Prime Minister Pham Van Dong said it suffers from shortages of nearly everything - energy, materials, transport, clothing, housing, medicines and even paper.

title:
ECONOMIC AFFAIRS;
LOBBYING:SHAKEDOWN ON CAPITOL HILL
description: THE growing hoards of lobbyists on Capitol Hill armed with campaign c ontributions for members of Congress is more than a political s candal. It is a serious threat to the conduct of United States e conomic policy.

title: The Nation; CHicago Agency Gets Bad Review
description: Chicago has long, and oftentimes accurately, been called the model of political patronage in America. But a recent analysis of the Chicago Housing Authority, calling its primary purpose ''the acquisition of as many Federal Government dollars as possible for the creation of patronage jobs'' and financial opportunity, has drawn charges of ''foul'' from Mayor Jane M. Byrne.

title: BAD APPLES
description: ''We're a victim of our own success,'' said Stan Devaughn, a spokesman for Apple Computer Inc. The victimization of the company that has sold more than 450,000 Apple II personal computers since the model was introduced in 1977, and captured almost a quarter of the bustling home computer market lies in counterfeiting. A handful of Apple II knock-offs has popped up in Asia.

title:
GARDENING;
ROSES: THEIR PROTECTION AND PLANTING
description: WHILE it may be too early to predict the effect of January's severe weather on roses, several growers have reported that the exposed stems of their plants appear to be more severely damaged than usual. It should be the exception in this region if more than an occasional rose is lost during the winter. Healthy, vigorous plants, given protection, should pull through with little damage.

title: Eileen E. Tully Becomes The Bride of Paul Ceglarski
description: Eileen Elizabeth Tully, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel P. Tully of Stamford, Conn., was married there yesterday to Paul Ceglarski, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard S. Ceglarski of Duxbury, Mass. Msgr.

title: Kathy J. McGorty Is Bride In Jersey of John Noonan
description: Kathy J. McGorty, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thaddeus McGorty of Brick Township, N.J., was married yesterday to John D. Noonan, son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Noonan of Mantoloking, N.J. The Rev. Francis McGuire performed the ceremony at the St. Mary of the Lake Roman Catholic Church in Lakewood, N.J.

title: The President, the Poor and the Facts
description: President Reagan did not chide us by name in his news conference last week; he spoke merely of ''an editorial in a paper this morning.'' But it seemed unmistakable from his comments that he was referring to our Wednesday criticism of his deep cuts in programs for children. Unfair, he suggested; if only we would look more carefully we would see he is spending more on such programs.

title: Eastern Conn. Symphony Tosses a Challenge
description: If the 36-year-old Bridgeport Symphony (''The Bridgeport Symphony, a Long-Playing Story,'' March 7) boasts the ''longevity record'' for a symphony orchestra in Connecticut, it has at least one challenger for the same.

title: ROCK: LEON RUSSELL AND BAND
description: In the prime of his career a decade ago, Leon Russell, the Tulsabased pop-gospel singer, composer, arranger and keyboardist, performed with a flamboyance that flirted with self-parody. Blurring the lines between revivalism and rock, Mr. Russell and his entourage made hard, gospel-based rock the center of a floating rock-and-roll party.

title: Caroline Bruzelius to Be Bride May 15
description: Mr. and Mrs. Eugene A. Pharr of Redding, Conn., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Pharr's daughter, Caroline Astrid Bruzelius, to Robert Weldon Wallace, son of Mr. and Mrs. Weldon Wallace of Baltimore.

title: Soccer Opener Put Off
description: The storms that have deluged northern California have forced the San Jose Earthquakes to postpone their North American Soccer League opener. They had planned to play Toronto Sunday, but officials of Spartan Stadium told them that the field was slick and pooled with water. Team officials said they would meet with Toronto officials to reschedule the game.

title: AN EXPERT ON SOUTH AMERICA
description: Junius Bouton Bird, curator emeritus of South American archeology at the American Museum of Natural History, died at his home in the Bronx Friday evening after a long illness. He was 74 years old.

title: Film View; BLAKE EDWARDS-THE PEERLESS FARCEUR
description: Farce is difficult to pin down. ''The Shorter Oxford English Dictionary'' says simply that it's ''a dramatic work (usually short) intended only to excite laughter,'' and ''The Oxford Companion to the Theatre'' defines it as ''an extreme form of comedy in which laughter is raised at the expense of probability, particularly by horseplay and bodily assault.''

title: WHOSE MANDATE?
description: SAN SALVADOR THAT so many Salvadorans voted last Sunday, often at personal risk, was ''a clear indication of a war weariness and a desire for a quick and peaceful solution to the war,'' a university professor here said. That was the most widely held assessment of why they voted. Yet the results of what was probably the country's most democratic election appeared to be more political infighting, more bloodshed and potentially grave obstacles to United States policy in El Salvador.

title: Around the Nation; Early News Program Planned by NBC in July
description: NBC News announced yesterday that it would begin an hourlong early-morning television news program in July. The announcement was made in Dallas by Reuven Frank, president of NBC News, at a meeting of news directors of the network's affiliates.

title: Future Events; Terpsichorean Revels
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.. Fairy Tale Ending April 6-10 - Each year the Blue Hill Troupe, a group of amateur Savoyards, produces a Gilbert and Sullivan operetta for the sheer love of it and the benefit of charity. The 1982 production is ''Iolanthe,'' or ''The Peer and the Peri,'' and its beneficiary the Stanley M. Isaacs Neighborhood Center. In contrast to last year's minimal ''Mikado,'' the production is a lavish one involving a cast of 93, with 19 set changes and 250 costumes. The romantic leads of Strephon and Phyllis will be sung by Winthrop Rutherfurd Jr., a Wall Street lawyer, and Anne Fairbanks, an assistant producer with a communications company. Leslie Mackey, who works for a church pension fund, will portray the ''highly susceptible'' Lord Chancellor. That's typical Blue Hill casting, though, to be sure, most members of the troupe have professional training or previous professional experience to back up their work onstage and behind the scenes. Your best bet is probably April 8, when a 6 P.M. buffet dinner at the Union Club offering such hearty fare as beef Burgundy will precede the 7:30 P.M. curtain at the Hunter College Playhouse, just a hop, skip and a jump away. Proceeds from dinner and the run of the show, including an April 10 matinee, will go to ''Building Futures,'' the Isaac center's youth employment training and placement program. Dinner tickets, $30, from 427-1100.

title: Nuclear Power And Nobel Laureates
description: The writers in ''The Nuclear Debate Goes On'' (Opinion Page, Feb. 28) presented some cogent arguments opposing nuclear power, but they did not take issue with one of the major points made by Herbert Jaffe. In his article he said that an overwhelming number of scientists supported nuclear power, and he cited, in particular, six Nobel Prize winners.

title: No Headline
description: Stephen Klitzman to Wed Justine Lisser

title: REREADING A RADICAL
description: RIPENING Selected Work, 1927-1980. By Meridel Le Sueur.Edited and With an Introduction by Elaine Hedges. Illustrated. 291 pp. Old Westbury, N.Y.: The Feminist Press. Cloth, $14.95. Paper, $7.95.

title: James S. Vick Marries Katherine R. Novak
description: Katherine Rose Novak, a manager with Arthur Young & Co. in New York, was married yesterday to James Stockard Vick, international treasury manager of American Standard Inc. in New York. The Rev. Thomas Buckley performed the ceremony in St. Francis of Assisi Roman Catholic Church in Medford, Mass.

title: CHARLES S. GANOE
description: The writer is an executive vice president of the New York Bank for Savings, the state's oldest savings bank, the nation's second oldest and the creator of the passbook savings account. Ten days ago the pressure of interest rates forced the ''beehive bank,'' as it called itself, to merge with the Buffalo Savings Bank. The following is Mr. Ganoe's account of the bank's final days as an independent entity. --------------------------------------------------------------------- The senior officers of the New York Bank for Savings gathered Thursday, March 18, at the Christ Cella Restaurant on East 46th Street for a surprise dinner to honor Eugene Callan, their chairman and president. Mr. Callan had been told some weeks before that he would be required to resign when the bank's financial difficulties forced it to be merged out of existence. The uncertainty and worry which had dominated our lives for months was forgotten for one night. It was an evening of jokes and frivolity, and Mr. Callan called it his ''firing party.''

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: DANCE Ballet isn't all ''Giselle'' and ''Swan Lake,'' a fact that the Pennsylvania Ballet will underscore when it presents its innovative ''In Celebration of the Woman Choreographer'' on Tuesday, Saturday and next Sunday at the Brooklyn Academy. (A program of works by George Balanchine, Margo Sappington and Jose Limon will be performed on Wednesday, Thursday and Friday.)

title: Susan Shackman, David I. Levine To Wed in June
description: Amy Schreiber Shackman of Baltimore and Dr. Albert B. Shackman of Owings Mills, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Lynn Shackman, to David Israel Levine, son of Dr. Murray Levine and Dr. Adeline Gordon Levine of Buffalo.

title: Executive Weds Constance Hart
description: Constance Colburn Hart, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Hart 3d of Middlebury, Conn., was married yesterday to Robert Walkingshaw 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walkingshaw Jr. of Sewickley, Pa. The Rev. J. Douglas Wigner Jr. performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Woodbury, Conn.

title: U.N. RESOLUTION
description: Following is the text of the resolution on the Argentine action in the Falkland Islands adopted by the Security Council today by a vote of 10 to 1, with 4 abstentions:

title: RESIDENTS DIVIDED ON SEALING CAVE
description: LAFAYETTE TOWNSHIP FOR several weeks, the sounds of tree frogs and blue herons have echoed through the marshy woodlands at Crooked Swamp here, luring groups of spring visitors - science students, Scout troops, spelunkers, amateur anthropologists and naturalists - to an unspoiled environment surrounding New Jersey's largest cave.

title: What's Doing; Richmond
description: SYLVIA COSTEN is an editor on the staff of The Richmond News Leader. BY SYLVIA COSTEN

title:
Stamps;
THE OFFICIAL BIRDS AND FLOWERS OF EACH STATE
description: The official flowers and birds of each of the 50 states are making their appearance April 14 on a setenant pane of 20-cent commemoratives that has been eagerly awaited by many collectors. Their eagerness has been rewarded.

title: Crime Update; POLICE SEEK 3RD SUSPECT IN SLAYING OF AN OFFICER
description: Last Dec. 16, Anthony J. Abruzzo Jr., a 34-year-old New York City police officer, was attending a tree-decorating party with his wife at his in-laws' house in Flushing, Queens. Shortly before 9 P.M., Mr. Abruzzo's father-in-law, Joseph Meheran, pulled into the driveway, after a day at work, and was accosted by three gunmen who demanded his money.

title: Nicaragua Condemns U.S. Veto at the U.N.
description: Nicaragua said today that Friday night's veto by the United States of a United Nations Security Council resolution against the use of force in Central America confirmed its fears of American ''military aggression'' in the region.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: FICTION
description: 1 1 3 THE PARSIFAL MOSAIC, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $15.95.) Through many exploits and hairbreadth escapes, Michael Havelock saves the world from nuclear extinction. 2 2 9 NORTH AND SOUTH, by John Jakes. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $14.95.) The friendship of two wealthy families - one in Pennsylvania, the other in Carolina - is strained by the Civil War. 3 5 10 MARCO POLO, IF YOU CAN, by William F. Buckley Jr. (Doubleday, $13.95.) Blackford Oakes's quest for a mole in the C.I.A. takes him to Russia. 4 3 24 AN INDECENT OBSESSION, by Colleen McCullough. (Harper & Row, $13.50.) A nurse and her charges in a special-care ward of a World War II hospital. 5 4 9 THE DEAN'S DECEMBER, by Saul Bellow. (Harper & Row, $13.95.) During a deathbed vigil in Rumania, a college dean from Chicago realizes some truths about his own land. 6 8 20 SPRING MOON, by Bette Bao Lord. (Harper & Row, $14.95.) Tradition and revolution in modern China seen through the life of an upper-class family. 7 6 9 A GREEN DESIRE, by Anton Myrer. (Putnam's, $14.95.) A woman caught between the clashing ambitions of two brothers during the springtime of this century. 8 7 2 THE MOSQUITO COAST, by Paul Theroux.

title: CAREY JUSTICE PANEL'S PLANS STIR LITTLE INTEREST
description: At a time when prosecutors and the police are looking for ways to imprison more criminals for longer terms, a special commission appointed by Governor Carey has been looking for ways to reduce the number of state prisoners and reduce the length of time they serve.

title: New York Political Notes; MANHATTAN LEADERS STAYING OFF KOCH BANDWAGON
description: Four of the five New York City Democratic leaders - and the most influential upstate county chairman, Joseph F. Crangle of Erie County -are backing Mayor Koch in the Democratic gubernatorial primary against Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.

title: ON THE TURNPIKE: FORGETTABLE SIGHTS
description: THIS is a guide to one of the most-traveled, most-maligned and most-unforgettable stretches of road in America. If you are in one of the 130 million vehicles that will use the New Jersey Turnpike this year, don't groan. Open your eyes and hold your nose.

title: DOCTORS MEET IN ENGLAND ON EFFECTS OF NUCLEAR WAR
description: An international convention of doctors concerned about the effects of nuclear war began a five-day meeting here today with a series of graphic accounts of the devastating power of atomic weapons.

title: IRANIAN PROGRESS IN GULF WAR RAISES NEW FEARS IN AREA
description: Iran's sudden major breakthrough in the long-stalemated war with Iraq is having repercussions throughout the divided and volatile Middle East.

title: Crafts
description: NEWARK TWO exhibitions of folk-art traditions, one alive and well in New Jersey and the other in New Mexico, are on view a few blocks from each other.

title: PAUL CADMUS RETROSPECTIVE IN STORRS
description: STORRS IN the last couple of weeks, business has been unusually brisk at the University of Connecticut's William Benton Museum. And it's no wonder, for the main show, ''Paul Cadmus, Yesterday and Today'' (through May 2), involves the kind of art that people have been wanting artists to get back into for generations.

title: Lisa Noosinow Married
description: Lisa Anne Noosinow and James E. Rule were married yesterday at the Bel Air Hotel in Los Angeles. The Rev. Allyn D. Axelton, a Methodist minister and director of United Campus Ministries at California State University at Northridge, performed the ceremony. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Jerry M. Noosinow of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Mr. and Mrs. Elton H. Rule of Scarsdale, N.Y. The bridegroom's father is president and chief operating officer of the American Broadcasting Companies Inc.

title: Talking; TO PAY OR NOT TO PAY
description: KEY money, furniture money, fixture fees, finder's fees, cash under t he table and other practices, legal and illegal, have become facts o f life in New York City and the amounts people are paying to get t enancy of rental apartments are sometimes staggering.

title: 70 Blacks Mark Anniversary Of Assassination of Dr. King
description: About 70 blacks marched behind a coffin carried by a rickety pickup truck today to commemorate the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: Rockies' Swan Song
description: Peter Gilbert, who wants to be the lame-duck owner of the Colorado Rockies of the National Hockey League, said that his team's game last night against the Calgary Flames would be its last ever played in Denver. ''I just cannot carry the team another year in Denver,'' he said.

title: Canucks 6, Kings 0
description: Darcy Rota scored two second-period goals and Richard Brodeur stopped 23 shots to pace Vancouver, which extended its unbeaten streak to eight games (5-0-3). The Canucks are in a second-place tie with Calgary in the Smythe Division.

title: MEMOIRS OF A MASTER OF SURVIVAL
description: YEARS OF UPHEAVAL By Henry Kissinger. Illustrated. 1,283 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Co. $24.95.

title: UMPIRES COURTED BY NEW ROCHELLE
description: NEW ROCHELLE THE cry of ''play ball'' is less than a month away for the start of the slow-pitch softball season, and officials of the New Rochelle Bureau of Parks and Recreation are actively in search of umpires.

title: Swiss Protest Over Salvador
description: About 2,500 demonstrators demanded today that the Government condemn the Reagan Administration's El Salvador policies. The demonstration in the Swiss capital was organized by leftist political parties, pacifist organizations and the Communist parties of Spain and Italy.

title: DOG-LOVING JUDGE LEADS KENNEL CLUB
description: A JURIST has assumed the leadership of the American Kennel Club. He is William H. Timbers of Darien, the new chairman of the club's board of directors.

title: DANCE: NINA WIENER
description: No matter what time of day it may be for Nina Wiener's audiences, it is usually the cocktail hour in her dances. The works offered on Friday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater by Nina Wiener and Dancers allowed their casts, like habitues of a cocktail lounge, to be world-weary and worldly-wise. Everyone could put on airs and still be charming and could act disillusioned without wallowing in despair.

title: Nancy Porter To Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth L. Porter Jr. of Huntington, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Gibson Porter, to Richard Allen Plumb, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert A. Plumb of Essex, Conn., and Block Island, R. I.

title: ALWAYS IN A RUSH? ASK THE ROBIN WHY
description: ALL of us at various times in our lives question the content of our character, the quality of our existence. This ''soul-searching'' process seeks to fill in a void, and relieve us of an undertaking only the self can achieve. We seek to define this emptiness that reproduces from within, only to find a denial of its existence.

title: BORN UNEQUAL
description: PRINCESS MARGARET A Life Unfulfilled. By Nigel Dempster. Illustrated. 242 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Co. $11.95. By CHARLOTTE CURTIS

title: ENVVIRONMENT ENFORCEMENT CHIEF STRIPPED OF POWER
description: Anne M. Gorsuch, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, whom members of Congress and environmental groups have accused of lax enforcement of the environmental laws, has decided to strip her enforcement chief of his independent powers.

title:
Westchester Youth;
SELF-RELIANCE FOR 'LATCHKEY' YOUTHS
description: FIFTEEN children, 7 to 9 years old, sit on the floor in the story room of the White Plains Public Library listening intently as two counselors from the Renaissance Project, a drug-rehabilitation program, talk about peer pressure and the ways people can feel good about themselves without taking narcotics.

title: FOR SOME SIBLINGS, THE STORK IS FOR THE BIRDS
description: YEAR-OLD Deanna Searle of this Essex County community knows exactly where babies come from. Last fall, she attended the birth of her brother, David, at Clara Maas Hospital in Belleville. Recently, she proudly showed a visitor pictures taken of her in the labor room, pictures of her rubbing her mother's back and offering her ice chips.

title: Phillip W. Kuhn to Marry Candace J. Miller in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Fred Miller of Springfield, Mo., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Candace Jane Miller, to Phillip W. Kuhn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Werner H. Kuhn of New York.

title: NET'S LAST-SECOND VICTORY REFLECTS POISE
description: After the Nets achieved one of their most important victories Friday night, beating the Washington Bullets, 98-96, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, a crowd gathered around a television in their locker room. The set became the focal point of the postgame celebration for good reason.

title: THE GOLD REPORT
description: Last week, the United States Gold Commission issued a report based on more than eight months of study that formally rejected a return to the gold standard. Following are excerpts from the section on domestic monetary arrangements, and comments by commission members. WE considered a number of alternatives that would serve to reintroduce gold into our domestic monetary policy arrangements. The objective would be to improve monetary control through the discipline of gold for the purpose of reducing inflation. Linking changes in the growth rate of money or of some component of money, such as Federal Reserve notes, or of bank reserves, to the change in the gold stock is one approach which was considered for imposing the discipline of gold.

title: Paperbacks:New & Noteworthy
description: century America.

title: Katherine C. Hill To Be May Bride
description: Katherine Cecelia Hill, an assistant professor of English at the C.W. Post Center of Long Island University, plans to be married May 15 to Frederic Alling Miller, public policy coordinator of McGraw-Hill Inc. The ceremony will take place in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church.

title: WESTERN DIVISION; LOS ANGELES DODGERS
description: Tommy Lasorda's usually sunny brow has a couple of furrows, six months after the Dodgers won the World Series: Fernando Valenzuela missed most of spring training in his contract hassle, Steve Garvey wonders when the ownership will discuss his next contract, and age is creeping up on most of the stars.

title: Singapore Government Bans Rev. Moon's Religious Group
description: Singapore has banned the religious sect headed by the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, who is on trial in New York on charges of tax fraud.

title: New Economic System Called for by the Pope
description: Pope John Paul II called today for a global economic order that would assure human dignity and ''just sharing of the property of God'' with special concern for the people in developing nations.

title: Miss Dwyer, Sales Aide Are Married
description: Elinor Chilton Dwyer, a teacher in special learning at the St. Bernard's School in New York, and John Arthur McKenna Jr., a marketing representative for the International Business Machines Corporation in New York, were married yesterday at the Christ Memorial Chapel in Hobe Sound, Fla. The Rev. Dr. Terence Finlay of Hobe Sound, retired rector of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York, performed the ceremony.

title: Scott Runs Fastest Mile, On a Downhill Course
description: In Auckland, New Zealand,the fastest mile run ever timed will never be recognized officially.

title: Travel Advisory; THE ILL-FATED NORWAY, HOT TIME IN HOT SPRINGS; The Norway Cancels Cruises Due to Fire
description: The Norway, formerly the liner France and the world's largest cruise ship, was headed for drydock in Bremerhaven, West Germany, last week seven weeks ahead of schedule. Her series of seven-night spring cruises to the Caribbean out of Miami was canceled after a fire broke out in the auxiliary engine room on March 19, causing damage to the electrical system. It was another in a series of mishaps that has plagued the ship since she became a cruise vessel in 1980.

title: Teen-Age Girl Found Slain
description: Searchers today found the body of Wanda Faye Reddict, 16 years old, who was dragged from her bedroom by an intruder last Sunday. She was the third teen-age girl in this small farming community to be abducted and slain in less than a year. The police said her body was found about 3:30 P.M.

title: A PIANIST WHO WON't RUSH INTO THINGS
description: In a Moscow hotel room late one night in 1970, the young pianist Horacio Gutierrez was awakened by a telephone call from an American he had never met. ''Congratulations,'' the man began. That was how Mr. Gutierrez learned he had won the silver medal at the fourth International Tchaikovsky Piano Competition. He had gone to bed without waiting for the judges' decision.

title: Practical Traveler; WHY THE GREENBACK IS BUYING MORE ABROAD
description: If you can afford the trans-Atlantic air fare - and major increases are under way - you will find that Europe offers some of the best travel bargains this year. In recent months the currencies of Belgium, Denmark, France, Italy and Luxembourg have been devalued. In other countries, among them Spain, Portugal and Britain, market pressures have made the dollar even stronger than it was a year ago, when its value soared.

title: Unanswered Questions On Multi-Town Plant
description: Thank you for the excellent article ''Debate Heats Up as Decision Nears on Multi-Town'' (Feb. 28). The principle of burning garbage as fuel to make steam or electricity is excellent. The Multi-Town Authority package is the problem.

title: A VIEW OF THE INSIDE OF WOMEN'S SHELTER
description: ON a spring morning in northern Westchester the sun is shining, a few brave buds are sprouting and 25-year-old Maria is afraid that the man with whom she has lived for seven years may be planning to kill her.

title: ENGLEWOOD CLIFFS, N.J.
description: ALMOST from the cradle to the grave, Prentice-Hall Inc., the mammothp ublishing combine, pursues the literate, and even sometimes the a lmost-literate, consumer.

title: FINDING THE HOUSE YOU CAN AFFORD
description: By ALAN S. OSER PEOPLE who shop for a home in the counties around New York City thisy ear will have to carry in their minds a concept known to real estates pecialists as ''the affordable house.''

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: JAZZ: ALBERTA HUNTER MARKS HER 87TH BIRTHDAY IN ACTION
description: Alberta Hunter celebrated her 87th birthday Thursday evening in action - out on the floor of the Cookery singing, clapping, punching and talking her way through two one-hour shows just as she does every week from Wednesday through Saturday.

title: PEKING DEBATES TAIPEI FOR THE FIRST TIME SINCE '49
description: For the first time since the Chinese Communists' triumph in 1949, an official delegation of Nationalist scholars from Taiwan debated with a group of Communist historians from mainland China Friday night.

title: Jack I. Poses, Founded Parfums D'Orsay Co.
description: Jack I. Poses, president and founder of Parfums D'Orsay Company, a founder of Brandeis University and a sponsor of the Poses School of Fine Arts at Brandeis, died Thursday at his home in Manhattan. Mr. Poses, who was also a resident of Westport, Conn., was 82 years old.

title: OFFICIAL SALVADOR TALLY GIVES CENTRISTS 24 SEATS
description: The official results of El Salvador's elections were announced today, but political sources said the new Constituent Assembly might not meet until the end of this month.

title: No More Pretending
description: Tired of living in ''sheer, unmitigated fear'' of discovery, Dan J. Bradley astonished associates in Washington last week with the disclosure that he was a homosexual. Mr. Bradley, the departing president of the Legal Services Corporation, announced that he would be leaving for quieter places.

title: College Post Weighed By Secretary of Energy
description: Energy Secretary James B. Edwards is considering an offer to become president of the University of South Carolina Medical School,

title: Jennifer Marks Is Wed
description: At the Chevy Chase Presbyterian Church in Washington yesterday Jennifer Peabody Marks, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lionel Peabody Marks of Larchmont, N.Y., was married to Arthur James Norton, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Russell Everett Norton of Reading, Mass.

title: Around the Nation; Electrical Union Agrees On Concession at G.M.
description: The General Motors Corporation and the International Union of Electrical Workers reached a tentative agreement today on a contract with concessions after 44 straight hours of talks, officials said.

title: KOPPELMAN: SURVIVOR IN A SEA OF CHANGE
description: TWO years after he began government service in Suffolk County and long after many politicians have come and gone, Lee E. Koppelman has emerged as one of the most influential members of County Executive Peter F. Cohalan's administration in Suffolk.

title: Steven Graf Glaser Marries Roxanne E. Edwards
description: Roxanne Elizabeth Edwards, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. Edwards of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married yesterday to Steven Graf Glaser, son of Dr. and Mrs. Peter Glaser of Lexington, Mass. Rabbi David Algaze performed the ceremony at the Hampshire Country Club in Mamaroneck, N.Y.

title: BASEBALL RESILIENCE
description: Most businesses have difficulty getting started again after a major strike, particularly in the midst of a prolonged recession. Most businesses, however, are not a national pastime.

title:
MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW;
Hertz Trio, Ensemble Formed in Canada in '76
description: The Hertz Trio, a Canadian ensemble formed in 1976, made its New York debut Thursday night at the 92d Street Y, playing the Trio in C (Op. 87) by Brahms, Anton Arensky's Trio No. 1 in D minor, and a trio by the contemporary Canadian composer Violet Archer. The group's accounts were idiomatic - the idioms of Brahms and Arensky being fairly convergent -but technically spotty and interpretively slack at a number of points.

title: LEAVING THE KEY
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR A FREE MARKET
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nation; IN CONCLUSION, GIVE ME A BREAK
description: Like most people, members of the United States Senate had taxes on their mind last week. But they did their worrying in public, staging a debate that Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. the majority leader, characterized as nothing less than ''political selfimmolation.''

title: Argentine to Address O.A.S.
description: Foreign Minister Nicanor Costa Mendez of Argentina will address the permanent council of the Organization of American States here on Monday.

title: A TRADESMAN SHUNS FANCY TITLES
description: SOUTHINGTON JOHN CANNING gets mad if you call him an artist. A Scotsman who knows what he is -''a tradesman, thank you very much'' - he has little regard for the species of ''dilettante'' painters, wallpaper hangers and stencilers, the men and women who think all they have to do to decorate a room is to buy a brush and start painting, buy a book and start making wallpaper paste or just buy a stencil pattern and daub away.

title: Shopper's World; PALM BEACH'S BAZZAR FOR BIG SPENDERS
description: MARYLIN BENDER is the author, with Selig Altschul, of ''The Chosen Instrument: Juan Trippe and Pan Am, the Rise and Fall of an American Entrepreneur'' to be published next summer by Simon & Schuster. By MARYLIN BENDER

title: DEATH VALLEY EARNS A MORE BENIGN REPUTATION
description: R.V. DENENBERG is a writer who lives in the Hudson Valley. BY R.V. DENENBERG

title: Stage View; A KNOT OF MYSTERIES, TELLINGLY UNSNARLED
description: I suppose everyone, in his fantasy life at least, enjoys playing detective, and the deep pleasures of playing detective are what make Percy Granger's ''Eminent Domain'' such a fascinating experience in the theater. Let me say quickly that the new piece at Circle in the Square is a somewhat flawed - it might be better to say somewhat incomplete - play, and then let me add that I have seen technically flawless plays that weren't half so interesting.

title: GOLF GROUP WEIGHS A DOGLEG TO ATLANTA
description: TEN years ago, the United States Golf Association, expanding with the times, moved its headquarters from midtown Manhattan to 68 bucolic acres in the Somerset County community of Far Hills.

title: Correspondent's Choice; COUNTRYSIDE FIT FOR A FUTURE KING
description: STEVEN RATTNER is a correspondent in the London bureau of The Times. BY STEVEN RATTNER

title: Topics; O Fortuna
description: We were reading about Mr. and Mrs. Peter McCoy in The Times and couldn't help but think of Carl Orff. Mr. McCoy is now a Commerce Department official after spending a year as head of Nancy Reagan's staff. The McCoys find that ''a certain magic'' is gone; they are no longer in such demand socially.

title: ISLIP OPENS UP CLAM LEASING
description: FOR the first time in 100 years, clams are no longer being mechanically dredged from acreage leased to private companies in the Islip Town portion of the Great South Bay.

title: PARANOIA
description: "The paranoid style in politics'' - that was the phrase used by Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, United States representative to the United Nations, in dismissing allegations that the Administration is working to ''destabilize'' the Sandinist Government of Nicaragua.

title: PUBLIC HELPS WITH BOOK ON TEENAGERS
description: ''WE think of this as a national yearbook,'' Ernie Anastos was saying. ''We want it to look like a yearbook, a family album.'' Mr. Anastos, who is a co-anchorman on WABC-TV's ''Eyewitness News'' program and who lives in Larchmont, was talking about ''Teen-agers, Now and Then.'' Scheduled for publication sometime next year - several major companies are bidding on it - ''Teen-agers, Now and Then'' will be a compendium and comparison of teen-agers' fads, fashions, activities and styles of living from the turn of the century to the present. Primarily pictorial, it will include some text by Mr. Anastos and Jack Levin, a writer and sociology professor at Northeastern University, and an introduction by the model Brooke Shields.

title: Westchester Journal
description: FEW Legislators ever become so closely identified with one issue as did John L. Messina, who died last week. The issue was the Westchester County Airport. He never doubted that the county government's intention was to expand the facility to the detriment of those living nearby, most of whom were his constituents.

title: The Nation; GOod Guys Bad Guys and Useful Guys
description: Although the Intelligence Identities Protection Act is not yet law, it may have already claimed its first victim. William H. Kennedy, the United States Attorney in San Diego, was asked to resign last week because he had publicly confirmed the identity of a key American intelligence source.

title: DRILLING IN PARKS FOR WATER DEBATED
description: OAKDALE A PROPOSAL by the Suffolk County Water Authority to drill for pure water in four state parks in the county is being attacked by environmental groups.

title: ...SOME THINGS ABOUT US OUT HERE IN THE SUBURBS
description: DEAR Mr. Koch: Now I know you keep hoping you've heard the last of this. Lord knows I would too if I were you. And this business about the mail-in coupons, well, it's more than a soul can bear sometimes.

title: Around the World; Pakistan Reports Offer, By U.S. to Station Troops
description: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq said today that the United States offered last year to station troops and arms in Pakistan and that he had rejected the proposal.

title: Bermuda
description: To the Editor:

title: Capitals 6, Maple Leafs 4
description: TORONTO (UPI) - Dennis Maruk scored his 59th and 60th goals of the season to help send Washington to victory. Maruk, fourth among all N.H.L. scorers with 134 points, netted his first goal of the game during a first-period power play at 16:40 to even the score at 1-1.

title: Powerboat Race Won By Woman Driver, 59
description: Betty Cook, 59 years old, won the open class in the Michelob Light 200 offshore powerboat race on Lake Pontchartrain today.

title: DEAR MAYOR KOCH: YOU OUGHT TO KNOW
description: DEAR Mayor Koch: The news has finally reached us out here on Long Island -you've decided to run for the Democratic nomination for Governor of our glorious state. Those of us here on Long Island who have followed your career as our westerly neighbor's chief executive over the last four years or so wish you luck, as you traipse around this state, from City Hall in Manhattan to Town Hall way out here in Hempstead.

title: IN SEARCH OF MIDDLE AMERICA
description: HOMETOWN By Peter Davis. 331 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $14.95. By SUSAN ALLEN TOTH

title: RECYCLING STATUTE IS TESTED IN GROTON
description: ONE midnight recently, Michael McNaughton, a trash hauler who serves Groton, groggily answered his telephone to hear a voice demand, ''What about tin foil?''

title: ALEXANDRA LYDE PLANS JUNE BRIDAL
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jeffrey W. W. Lyde of Lamberhurst, Kent, England, has announced the engagement of their daughter, Alexandra Jane Lyde, to Henry Benson Adriance 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Vanderpoel Adriance Jr., of Shelly Bay, Bermuda.

title: MUSIC GREETS THE EASTER SEASON
description: WITH brass quartets, bell choirs, choruses, organs and vocal and instrumental soloists, churches throughout the Island will offer musical programs starting today to mark the Easter season. Some are part of the regularly scheduled services; others are special concerts. Here is a sampling of these events:PALM SUNDAYNassau County

title: A GUIDE TO SOUTHERN BLOSSOMS
description: REGINALD STUART is chief of the Atlanta bureau of The Times. BY REGINALD STUART

title: Chess; ATTACK AT ALL COSTS
description: There is a type of player burning with such zeal to attack that he cannot stop to enjoy and exploit the fruits of his combination but restlessly seeks to keep the attack going, no matter what ensues.

title: Islanders Triumph; Trottier Scores 50th
description: The Islanders beat the Philadelphia Flyers, 6-3, tonight, to gain a club-record 118 points with one game left in the regular season. It was their 23d consecutive home game without a loss and their sixth victory in eight games with the Flyers, with one tie.

title:
Dining OUt;
ORDINARY ENTRIES, UNUSUAL ENTREES
description: JOINING the increasing number of fine restaurants that continue to establish themselves upcounty is Silvano's (previously Silvano and Edward's) in Somers. Closed briefly for radical reorganization, the restaurant is open again, and under the professional guidance of Silvano Panizzut, the efficient and pleasant dining room staff is an appropriate complement to some very good food. Richard Zinser, a chef of considerable talent and invention, supervises the kitchen, which produces Continental dishes enhanced by touches from the nouvelle cuisine.

title: Council Committees Set Public Meetings
description: The following City Council activities, scheduled for the week of April 5, are open to the public: MONDAY: Committee on Finance, City Hall, 9:30 A.M.
