Committees on Finance and Education meet together, City Hall, 11 A.M. Committee on Health, 250 Broadway, 23d floor, 1 P.M. TUESDAY: Committee on Transportation, City Hall, 9:30 A.M. WEDNESDAY: Committee on Economic Development, City Hall, 10 A.M.

title: THE A B C'S OF PAINTING A PANELED DOOR
description: PAINTING a paneled door is not an especially difficult or tricky job, yet more often than not when a do-it-yourselfer does it, he or she will wind up with a multitude of runs and drips, especially in the lower corners of each panel. In addition, it frequently turns out that there are some spots where paint was not applied at all - but this is not discovered until hours later, after the brushes have been cleaned and everything has been put away.

title: PICTURES OF CHANGE
description: uf718 Coin is the most popular amulet, its value attested through millennia by murder, theft and hoarding. Coins have also been tiny works of art, their luxurious detail carved on metal dies hard enough to withstand the shock of stamping, changed frequently to foil forgers and so precise as to make coins the stop-watches of history.

title: New York Political Notes
description: Decision of Solomon

title: MEDICAID PROGRAM DEFENDED
description: A REPORT to Gov. Brendan T. Byrne last March by the Division on Aging of the state's Department of Community Affairs said that, because of discrimination, ''minority aged, especially blacks, often find themselves on the end of waiting lists for senior housing, while loopholes in Federal legislation allow nursing homes and sheltered-care facilities to deny admission to minority Medicaid patients.''

title: PATRICIA LEE CLOUGH BRIDE OF GIRARD OBERRENDER 3D
description: Patricia Lee Clough, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Richard Clough of Martinsville, N.J., was married last evening to Girard Franklin Oberrender 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oberrender of Ithaca, N.Y., and Bridgehampton, L.I.

title: IN BARREN ICELAND, CULTURE BLOSSOMS
description: One night recently there was a dinner of the Althing, Iceland's Parliament, which was founded in the year 930, and, in keeping with tradition, the Prime Minister spoke in verse.

title: Major News; Staying on the Rocky Road
description: President Reagan maintained last week that he was flexible on the Federal budget, ''not a great stone face,'' and said he would even take a trim or two in proposed Pentagon spending.

title: BRITAIN AND FRANCE PROTEST GREEK MISSILE VIEW
description: Britain and France have protested to Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou of Greece over his recent statement supporting Soviet proposals to freeze the deployment of medium-range nuclear missiles west of the Ural Mountains.

title: UNEMPLOYMENT AT 9%; KEY INDICATORS OFF AGAIN
description: The jobless rate reached 9 percent of the labor force last month, up from 8.8 percent in February. Plant closings and layoffs pushed the rate to its highest level since May 1975. Separately, U.S. Steel, Bethlehem and Wheeling-Pittsburgh announced temporary layoffs of 14,500 workers.

title: IN THE YEAR OF THE FLORIADE
description: R.W. APPLE Jr. is chief of the London bureau of The Times. BY R.W.APPLE Jr.

title: CONGRESS MOVES TO SHIFT JUDICIAL REVIEW STANDARDS
description: Congress, with the support of the Reagan Administration, is moving to change the standards for judicial review of rules issued by Federal agencies. As a result, many analysts believe that it will be easier to challenge Federal regulations in court.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: JOEL: GROWING UP A FARM MAN By Patricia Demuth. Photographs by Jack Demuth. 144 pp. New York: Dodd, Mead & Co. $12.95. (Ages 8 to 12) By SHERWIN D.SMITH

title: Music; YOUNG PERFORMERS IN THE SPOTLIGHT
description: BECAUSE young artists on the way up often need performing outlets more than high fees, the music lover willing to give up the big-name hunt can enjoy excellent local concerts at minimal cost. This afternoon at 3 o'clock, for instance, the pianist Carole Lian plays a free recital at the John Jay Homestead, on Route 22 in Katonah, near Caramoor.

title: Olson Takes Vault Far Below His Goal
description: Billy Olson, America's No.1 pole vaulter, set a meet record at the 55th Texas Relays today, but he fell far short of his goal to become the fourth person to clear 19 feet.

title: Regina Mary Brescia Is Married to David G. Holleb
description: Regina Mary Brescia, an account executive with A.T.&T. in Los Angeles, and David Gene Holleb, an account executive with Bache & Company, also in Los Angeles, were married yesterday in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Alexandria, Va. Msgr. Frank J. Hendrick performed the ceremony.

title: PARK SLOPE
description: THE talk in Brooklyn's Park Slope section these days is of change, o f new people coming in and driving up the price of brownstone housesw ell past the $200,000 mark. But at the same time, there is a r ealization that although some other parts of the city have been all b ut devastated by major upheavals, Park Slope has changed very littlei n recent years.

title: DINING OUT
description: A LOCATION in Levittown notwithstanding, Divino has a great deal in common with restaurants in old Roslyn and Glen Cove, both in its style and its menu. It should prove a welcome addition to this mid-Nassau area.

title: RETURN TO MAURITIUS
description: PHILIP M. ALLEN is a member of the faculty of the University of Dakar. By PHILIP M.ALLEN

title: POPULATION OF CANADA IS SHIFTING TO THE WEST
description: Canada's population is moving westward, weakening the traditional supremacy of Ontario and Quebec in national affairs.

title: L.I. INFLUENCE SALVAGES ITEMS IN STATE BUDGET
description: ALBANY THROUGHOUT the debate on the floor of the State Assembly over the budget last week, Assemblyman Arthur J. Kremer was the man who was constantly called upon to stand up.

title: America's Other Budget
description: William Barry Furlong's excellent article, ''America's Other Budget'' (Feb. 21), which outlined the burgeoning growth of the offbudget credit activities of the Federal Government, unfortunately centers its main criticism of the growth of these activities on their negative impact on interest rates. The extent of the interest-rate impact is questionable and, at any rate, is the least important of a number of very serious drawbacks to the growth rate of off-budget Federal credit.

title: The World; Iran Recoups In Gulf War
description: Iran invited back the Western press last week for an exercise in show and tell. The Islamic Republic would like the world to know that its forces have broken the back of the 18-month-old Iraqi invasion, rolling back Iraqi troops in places to within a few miles of the border.

title: LONDON ORDERING 35-SHIP TASK FORCE TO THE FALKLANDS
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, speaking during the first weekend session of Parliament since the Suez crisis of 1956, said today that the Falkland Islands ''remain British territory'' and ordered a large naval task force to the South Atlantic.

title: Foreign Affairs; THE NUCLEAR DILEMMA
description: After nearly a generation of somnolence, the debate on nuclear weapons has suddenly fully emerged in the U.S. The arguments aren't new. The underlying strategy of using money to buy a doomsday threat instead of manpower for a large standing army goes back to John Foster Dulles's dread promise of ''more bang for a buck.''

title: Around the Nation; New Redistricting Plan In Arizona Is Approved
description: A compromise plan to redraw Arizona's Congressional and legislative boundaries has been approved in Federal court and now goes to the Justice Department for review.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Marty Glickman, a well-known radio and television sports announcer for more than 30 years, will join the staff of WNBC-TV in mid-April. ... The United States Harness Writers Association will honor Alan Leavitt, the president of the Lana Lobell Farms, with the 1982 Proximity Award, the organization's highest honor. ... A $50 million lawsuit filed by Rick Lynch, a former owner of an automobile raceway, against Frank Kush, the football coach at Arizona State University until his dismissal in 1979, has been dismissed in Phoenix. ... Although he has been mentioned as a candidate for several vacant basketball coaching jobs, Nolan Richardson, Tulsa's coach, said yesterday, ''I am 100 percent certain that I will be the head coach at Tulsa next season.''. ... A report in The Montreal Gazette says that the Montreal Alouettes of the Canadian Football League will permit two of their players to leave to play in the National Football League.

title: A 6% Solution
description: To the Business Editor: I humbly offer the following suggestions to the Administration:

title: Neville Dance Company To Mark Anniversary
description: The Phoebe Neville Dance Company will celebrate Miss Neville's 20th anniversary as a New York choreographer with a program of new works and a revival at Larry Richardson's Dance Gallery, 242 East 14th Street, from April 15 to 18 and April 23 to 25.

title: Wine's Half-Acres
description: Terry Robards's article on the Planes' Cayuga vineyard leaves the impression that wine lovers cannot enjoy the tending of vines, crushing of grapes and making of wine unless they choose to venture into the difficult area of commercial production (''The Possible Dream,'' Feb. 7). Anyone with a half acre of tillable land can grow enough grapes to make 300 gallons of wine, or more - enough to provide oneself and many of one's friends with as much wine as they care to drink.

title: REMEMBERING JACKIE ROBINSON
description: Robert Curvin is an editorial writer for The New York Times. By Robert Curvin I was 13 in 1947, the year Jackie Robinson joined the Brooklyn Dodgers and became the first black man to play major-league baseball. We lived in New Jersey at the time, one of a handful of black families in the Italian working-class community of Belleville, near Newark, and in that neighborhood either you were a Yankee fan or you kept your mouth shut. The passion for Joe DiMaggio, the great Yankee center fielder, was fanatical. Tommy Henrich, Charlie Keller, Yogi Berra and Phil Rizzuto were idolized. But not by me. The identification was not there.

title: Astor Castle in South England Goes on Sale for $25 Million
description: Nearly 80 years after his American great-grandfather developed it into one of the great estates of southern England, John Jacob Astor 8th has decided to sell Hever Castle.

title:
Crafts;
AN AMBITIOUS SPRING INVITATIONAL
description: ''INVITATIONAL 1982'' is the name of the current show at the Craftsman's Gallery in Scarsdale, but the title hardly does justice to the size and quality of this ambitious exhibition. The spring invitational show here has been mounted for seven years, and each year it has become more of a challenge to organize, as the number of talented crafts designers grows. The gallery owners, Sybil Robins and Rosanne Raab, have gathered works in metal, clay, glass, wood and fiber -with the emphasis on clay - from more than 40 artists.

title: Around the Garden
description: This Week:

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: PHOTOGRAPHYAs the first crocuses and daffodils appear, the Witkin Gallery is celebrating its 13th anniversary, as well as the season, with an exhibition of pictures of flowers. Most of the pictures are photographs, as befits an institution that for most of its life was devoted exclusively to photography, but there are also some prints and paintings, including a spectacular late 18th-century handpainted engraving published in England by Dr. Robert Thornton (no relation to this writer).

title:
In New Jersey;
'BONUS DENSITY' LOWERS COST OF HOMES
description: IN East Brunswick, N.J., new three-bedroom town houses are availablef or $53,300, with a mortgage interest rate of 6 3/4 percent. How is this possible under current market conditions? The answer is ''bonus density.'' In an area that had been d esignated for three units to the acre, developers may build five u nits as long as one of the additional units is for a low or m oderate income resident. The development, called Colonial Oaks V illage, is part of a 600-acre Town Green Zone in the center of town t hat will be the site of other similar developments as well. .

title: OFFICE HELP SENT TO LOW-RENT SITES
description: IT is the promise of the computer that employees sitting at k eyboards in their own homes could make the back office, with its f loors of clerical and keypunch operators, obsolete.

title: Ellen Weisberg Is Wed To Gary Alan Malasky
description: Ellen Merle Weisberg and Gary Alan Malasky, both of Washington, were married yesterday at the Agudath Sholom Synagogue in Stamford, Conn. Rabbi Joseph H. Ehrenkranz performed the ceremony.

title: 3 Die at Thai Boxing Match
description: Two grenades exploded inside a crowded boxing stadium Friday night, killing 3 people and injuring 61. The police said Commerce Minister Chuan Leekpai and Deputy Communications Minister Veera Musikapong narrowly escaped injury. The police said they believed the attackers were trying to kill a boxing promoter.

title: RULE ON BEER-CONTAINER DEPOSITS IS POSTPONED
description: The State Liquor Authority has put off implementing a proposed rule that would prevent localities from requiring a deposit on nonrefillable beer containers.

title: CABARET: NEWBORN AT JAZZ PIANO
description: Phineas Newborn Jr., is of that breed of jazz pianists who know that, in addition to basic chord structure, the pieces they play also have a melody. He is not reluctant to expose these melodies although, like Erroll Garner and Ahmad Jamal, he does not like to make them too obvious.

title: A NOVEL OF HOPE AND REALISM
description: AH, BUT YOUR LAND IS BEAUTIFUL By Alan Paton. 271 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $12.95. By JOHN ROMANO

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: OFFICIALS in the Village of East Hampton have voted to spend $350,000 toward preserving a historic house on Main Street even while providing space for enlarging an overburdened village parking lot.

title:
MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW;
Alison Hale, Flutist, Offers Martinu Sonata
description: Alison Hale, flutist, made her debut in Carnegie Recital Hall on March 27 with a program featuring sonatas by Telemann, Bach and Martinu. As she admitted at the recital's end, in announcing the encore, her program-opening account of Telemann's Sonata in F minor was a little uneasy; nonetheless, her phrasing and embellishments showed taste, and her articulation was suited to the style.

title: RISKS IN FOREIGN STOCKS
description: WITH Wall Street giving investors fits for nearly a year now, is theg rass any greener in overseas markets? It wasn't last year. The 1981 b ear market, a product of faltering economies, soaring inflation and a strong dollar, trampled stocks in most countries, dampening A merican enthusiasm for overseas investment.

title: SAVING BABIES BEFORE BIRTH
description: As the parent of a hydrocephalic, severely retarded 2-year-old, I want to address the ''in-between'' zone that Dr. Golbus cites as his biggest worry - those cases in which the baby is neither cured nor dies, but sustains a severe handicap. Though the article did mention that a possible side effect of technology is saving a fetus but leaving him brain damaged for life, more attention needs to be given to this subject.

title:
ART;
COLLAGE DEFINED AND REDEFINED
description: SETAUKET IT is only in this century that collage - pasting fragments of paper, cloth and other materials into arrangements or compositions - has been taken seriously as an art form. Before it was legitimized and given its name by the Cubists, collage was a playful pastime, suitable for decorative screens, household ornaments, scrapbooks and valentines.

title: IN ROME, NUNS AS TOUR GUIDES
description: Touring Vatican City and Rome with the Ladies of Bethany is like touring with your favorite aunts - assuming that your favorite aunts are learned, pious, stylish and funny. The Ladies of Bethany are Dutch Roman Catholic nuns. There are 90 of them, engaged in good works in houses from Pittsburgh to Vienna. Four are resident in Rome, at the Foyer Casa Unitas, just around the corner from the bustling and raffish Piazza Navona, where their good works take the form of showing tourists the splendors of the city. None of them wears a habit - they are, in fact, spiffy dressers - and all prefer to be addressed as ''Miss,'' rather than ''Sister.'' They all speak several languages with aplomb and, usually, accuracy.

title: Fashion Design; WHEN THE MOOD STRIKES
description: mon day he physical world in films - the rooms, clothes, trappings that garnishes the action - contributes incalculably to their power. As a general rule, if that world is well made, it is so inseparable from the action that the audience barely notices it; it is usually only when the production is frail - the story slight, the actors weak - that the film maker resorts to ''juicing up'' the look.

title: SAVING BABIES BEFORE BIRTH
description: Intrauterine, prenatal surgery will no doubt bring joy and relief to many parents whose dreams of a healthy baby were formerly unrealizable. But this technological breakthrough is a medical one, not a moral one; the status of the fetus as patient may be different in degree from the status of the fetus of 10 years ago, but it is not different in kind.

title: DON'T BE BLINDED BY THE RISING SUN
description: ALBERT EINSTEIN once mildly chided the public for indulging in what h e called ''boundless admiration.'' He explained that the contrast b etween the popular estimate of his powers and the reality of those p owers was ''simply grotesque.''

title: Nebraska Captures Gymnastics Title
description: Nebraska broke its national scoring record today by seven-tenths of a point and won its fourth straight National Collegiate Athletic Association gymnastics team title.

title: Topics Deflations; Math Myth
description: On the last night of his 20-year-old life, before dying in a duel, the 19th century French mathematician Evariste Galois furiously scribbled outlines of the theories teeming in his mind, breaking off only to scrawl in the margin ''I have not time.'' What he wrote in those last desperate hours, noted the historian Eric Bell, ''will keep generations of mathematicians busy for hundreds of years.''

title: About Westchester
description: ASSEMBLY No. 194 of the Society of American Magicians was meeting, and the word was mum. Like ancient sorcerers engaged in furtive rites, these contemporary wizards were keeping their wonders to themselves.

title: No Headline
description: Herbert Jaffe and Anthony Fainberg, in swallowing the nuclear establishment's myths surrounding radiation and nuclear power and in challenging my statements on the Long Island Opinion Page, have neglected to pursue the facts. Contrary to Mr. Fainberg's trust in Northeast Utilities' claims and Mr. Jaffe's uninformed statement that ''there is no record that Millstone I has added nuclear radiation to the environment,'' the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has reported (in March 1977) that this plant leaked 2,970,000 curies of radioactive gases in 1975 -the largest quantity on record in the United States, before Three Mile Island, of radiation released to the environment by a nuclear plant.

title: The Nation; TUrnabout In Texas
description: Since 1980's census, political parties have been jousting with computer and compass to turn redistricting to advantage. Last week, the United States Supreme Court recalculations reinstated a cherished Republican victory.

title: Mary Jane Spellane Fiancee of Alan Marchisotto
description: Mary Jane Spellane, an assistant secretary of the Chemical Bank in New York, plans to be married next month to Alan Lewes Marchisotto, a lawyer for the Norlin Corporation in White Plains.

title: INEXPENSIVE AND NEW IN RIDGEFIELD
description: RIDGEFIELD LOCATED on the edge of a shopping center along Route 35 in Ridgefield, the Lotus, a new Chinese restaurant, is more inviting from the outside than within. The long rectangular dining room is punctuated with hanging lights, whose thin wood-slated shades look more Scandinavian than Oriental. Pale cream-colored wallpaper simulating institutional tiles does nothing to enliven the room. Empty, the dining room seems bleak and forlorn. Full, the smoke can be intense and the outlets for it seem to be inadequate.

title: Margaret Downs To Wed in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward F. Downs of Bethesda, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Mary Downs, to Harold Fredrick Nelson 3d,, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold F. Nelson Jr. of Fort Wayne, Ind., and Mountainside, N.J.

title: Rodriguez Keeps Title
description: Lucien Rodriguez of France retained his European heavyweight boxing crown Friday, outpointing Mikan Popovic of Yugoslavia in a 10-round fight. The victory improved Rodriguez's record to 32-7-1. Popovic, who settled in Luxembourg after an extensive amateur career in his native Yugoslavia, is 14-2-1 as a pro.

title: MINERS' CHIEF GETS UNCOMMON CAMPAIGN AID
description: In an unusual break with custom, other unions are providing money and kind words to help the campaign of Sam M. Church Jr. for re-election as president of the United Mine Workers of America.

title: Building a Better Rotary Engine
description: ONE of these days, somebody ought to do a novel about a corporation that builds a better mousetrap, has everybody beating a path to its store, and then all but goes broke when the mousetrap turns out to use too much cheese.

title: Ideas & Trends; Giving the Pope His Due
description: After 400 years of estrangement, the idea of reconciliation between the Roman Catholic and the Anglican churches can be touchy. Last week, an international commission of theologians addressed the touchiest issue of all when it said that the Pope had the best historical claim to be the ''universal Primate'' if the two churches reunited.

title: Barbara Hanzel Becomes The Bride of Alan Marks
description: Barbara S. Hanzel, director of planning for the publishing division of ABC Inc. in New York, was married yesterday to Alan D. Marks, an associate in the public finance banking division of Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc. Rabbi Wayne Franklin performed the ceremony in Temple Emanu-El in Providence, R.I.

title: MYSTERIES AND MEANING
description: FICTION AND REPETITION Seven English Novels. By J. Hillis Miller. 250 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $15.

title: CON ED'S DISCOUNTS HELP GENERATE NEW JOBS
description: A supermarket in the South Bronx paid a $4,365 electricity bill last month. It might have paid $5,573, had it not been for a rate reduction of almost 22 percent from Consolidated Edison. A small doll factory in Brooklyn paid $174 instead of the $218 it would normally have been billed, and a Bronx plastics manufacturer whose February electricity bill was supposed to be $48,759 paid $38,913.

title: L.W. KAY 3D, TRADER, TO WED CAROLYN LANG
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Todd Lang of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Caroline Lang, to L. William Kay 3d, son Mrs. Ann Miller of New York and L. William Kay 2d also of Scarsdale. A September wedding is planned.

title:
CAMERA;
TRIPODS AND OTHER SUPPORTS FOR BETTER PHOTOS
Richard Edwin Conn Weds Margaret Elbow
description: Margaret Elizabeth Elbow, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Matthew H. Elbow of Delmar, N.Y., was married yesterday to Richard Edwin Conn of Pleasant Ridge, Mich., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Norman Conn.

title: METS GOING WITH POWER
description: ADD Tom Veryzer, who played shortstop for Detroit and Cleveland for s even years. Add Ron Gardenhire as a rookie shortstop and Charlie P uleo as a rookie pitcher. Subtract Doug Flynn and Frank Taveras as t he double-play combination, Alex Trevino as the No.2 catcher and LeeM azzilli as the switch-hitting hometown hero. Also add George B amberger as manager, subtract Joe Torre and stir vigorously.

title: FOUR NUNS, FIGHTING TO KEEP JOBS, TRY TO TAKE BISHOP TO COURT
description: Collectively, Sisters Honora Reardon, Catherine and Justine Colliton and Mary Rita Furlong have been teaching for more than 100 years, and in all that time, they say, they have observed their own quiet protocol, never even venturing a friendly dinner with a priest.

title: Double Standard
description: To the Editor:

title: HITTING A NEW NOTE
description: GREAT NECK AT the age of 69, at the height of a career that has earned him a prominent place in the top ranks of American composers, Morton Gould is expanding his musical horizons. Today he will make his debut as a narrator, telling the spirited story of Prokofiev's ''Peter and the Wolf'' in a concert to benefit the Great Neck Community School.

title: BARING MUSSORGSKY'S POWER
description: ''Mussorgsky,'' the composer wrote of himself, ''cannot be classed with any existing group of musicians, either by the character of his composition or by his musical views.'' He was nearly right. Modest Mussorgsky was a musical naif, mapping out his own world.

title: THE POSSIBILITIES OF PARENTHOOD
description: SOONER OR LATER The Timing of Parenthood in Adult Lives.By Pamela Daniels and Kathy Weingarten. 366 pp. New York: W.W. Norton & Co. $14.95. By CAROL TAVRIS

title: N.F.L. Presses for Exemption
description: The National Football League is on Capitol Hill, dealing with Congress in hopes of achieving what would be as important for the league as any Super Bowl. The N.F.L.'s aim: exemption of the league from Federal antitrust laws.

title: Paul Alberts, Pianist, In Brahms Intermezzos
description: The ''feeling'' that many listeners hear in music can be an imposed ''feeling'' that distracts rather than illuminates. In Paul Alberts's debut at Carnegie Recital Hall last Sunday afternoon, such ''feeling'' did indeed interfere.

title: Beth Steinberg Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Steinberg of Massapequa Park, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Beth Anne Steinberg, to Robert Gayer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Gayer of Old Bethpage, L.I.

title: Margaret Brown Becomes a Bride
description: Margaret Anne Brown and Joseph Laurence Southard were married yesterday at the Orienta Beach Club in Mamaroneck, N.Y., by State Supreme Court Justice George D. Burchell.

title: Sports of The Times; Yank Relay Team On the Move
description: AS the Yankees await opening day in the 10th year of George Steinbrenner's tyrannical reign, the manager, coaches, players, front-office executives, scouts and all other club employees subject to the principal owner have learned to perform to the accompaniment of a twist to an old refrain:

title: ARGENTINA REJECTS RESOLUTION
description: Argentina today rejected the United Nations Security Council resolution calling for the withdrawal of Argentine forces from the Falkland Islands.

title: Wilkins to Enter Draft
description: Dominique Wilkins of Georgia announced yesterday that he would bypass his senior season and place his name in the National Basketball Association draft in late June, making him the first underclassman to do so this year. Wilkins said he made the decision primarily because of a desire to help his mother financially.

title: FARM MACHINERY DOLDRUMS
description: The slump that began in 1979 among farm equipment manufacturers has continued into its third year, as the impact of high interest rates and declining farm incomes sent sales tumbling.

title: Bruins 5, Nordiques 4
description: QUEBEC (UPI) - Ray Bourque and Peter McNab each scored two goals as Boston ended a three-game losing streak.

title: Theater; 'I DO! I DO!': 50 YEARS IN ONE NIGHT
description: IN December 1966, a musical version of a Jan de Hartog play, ''The Fourposter,'' opened on Broadway and stayed around for 584 performances. ''I Do! I Do!'' co-starred Mary Martin and Robert Preston; like the play from which it was derived, it involved only two characters and never resorted to a telephone to pad out a nonexistent cast. With the superpower presence of Miss Martin and Mr. Preston, not to mention the superb staging of Gower Champion, it needed no outside help.

title: WESTERN DIVISION; OAKLAND
description: What can Billy Martin's scrappy band do for an encore? The A's, after all, won 17 of their first 18 games last year. This year they don't figure to duplicate that remarkable achievement. They do, however, have an excellent chance of repeating their division-winning achievement.

title:
Antiques;
PRINTS, THE 'TELEVISION' FO THE 1800'S
description: WYCKOFF ''IGUESS you could say that prints were the television of the day,'' John Hudzina Jr. said, referring to the 1800's. ''The artists and printers of those days catalogued the customs and life, and conveyed to the people the subjects and events they would never get to see.''

title: Beauty; BEING UNDERWEIGHT CAN WEIGH HEAVILY
description: Growing awareness of the problems encountered by people who are too thin is prompting nutrition experts to develop new treatments.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally for the Metropolitan Area
description: Senate

title: CHIP MAKER'S TALE OF WOE
description: tech company he built into one of the most aggressive, profitable and quality-conscious in California's Silicon Valley is facing its first losses ever, with little relief in sight.

title: AT 29, HE RUNS A COMMODITIES MARKET
description: THE guard at the entrance to Commodity Exchange Inc. had never heard of Alan J. Brody. Mr. Brodyf inds this excusable. As a 29-year-old lawyer with less than five y ears of professional experience, Mr. Brody concedes that he may not h ave the bearing that one would generally associate with the p residency of a commodity exchange. ''But I'm not sensitive to t hat,'' he said recently. ''I don't much care about it one way or theo ther.''

title: Music View; SCHOENBERG'S 12-TONE MUSIC BOTHERS US NO LONGER
description: Time may not heal all wounds or wound all heels but it does bury much musical acrimony almost without a trace. Where have they gone, for instance, all those hot words that were exchanged for a hundred years over the last string quartets of Beethoven? In our own time, amazingly, there still were hard-shell conservatives who regarded them as unplayable and unlistenable.

title: MAILBOX
description: To the Sports Editor: Neil Amdur's article about Texas-El Paso's use of foreign-born students and the coach's questionable practices concerning their track team is very upsetting.

title: THE AILING ECONOMY-DIAGNOSES AND PRESCRIPTIONS
description: AS Congress confronts President Reagan's prescription for economic revitalization, the nation is staggering through one of the worst slumps since World War II. Debate about the nature of Mr. Reagan's remedy is being conducted simultaneously with debate over the structure of the economy itself.

title: TAPES CALLED VITAL IN CASE ON TEAMSTERS' CHIEF
description: More than 2,000 reels of tape recordings containing obscenities, small talk and discussions of apparent criminal conspiracies are at the core of a dispute that could decide a case against Roy L. Williams, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, prosecutors say.

title: STEPHEN PHILLIPS TO MARRY ELIZABETH NICHOLAS IN JUNE
description: The engagement of Elizabeth Jane Nicholas to Stephen Gregory Phillips has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. William M. Nicholas of New Hyde Park, L.I., parents of the bride-to-be.Her fiance is the son of Mrs. William J. Wallace of Seattle and the late Robert L. Phillips Jr.

title: INTEGRITY IS A NEGLECTED WORD IN REPORT
description: The word ''integrity'' appears only once, in the very last sentence, of the 67-page report on fixed races at New York tracks in the mid-1970's that was released Friday by the State Racing and Wagering Board. That is not surprising: After the previous 66 pages, integrity is not a concept that leaps to mind in connection with thoroughbred racing in New York.

title: OPERA: MISS MEIER STEPS IN
description: The Metropolitan Opera's current production of Beethoven's ''Fidelio'' had an unscheduled change of cast Friday evening. Shirley Verrett, the announced Leonore, was ill and her place taken by the American soprano Johanna Meier.

title: Pennant Odds
description: Oddsmakers at the Union Plaza Race and Sports Book listed the 1982 pennant odds as follows: NATIONAL LEAGUE Los Angeles Dodgers 5-2 Houston Astros 5-2 Montreal Expos 14-5 Philadelphia Phillies 7-2 St. Louis Cards 9-2 Cincinnati Reds 4-1 Atlanta Braves 15-1 San Francisco Giants 30-1 Pittsburgh Pirates 30-1 Mets 30-1 San Diego Padres 75-1 Chicago Cubs 100-1 AMERICAN LEAGUE Yankees 2-1 Oakland A's 5-2 Baltimore Orioles 4-1 Milwaukee Brewers 4-1 Texas Rangers 7-1 Kansas City Royals 7-1 Chicago White Sox 7-1 California Angels 8-1 Detroit Tigers 15-1 Boston Red Sox 20-1 Cleveland Indians 20-1 Minnesota Twins 150-1 Seattle Mariners 300-1 Toronto Blue Jays 400-1

title: Bulgarian Sets Lifting Record
description: Blagoi Blagoev of Bulgaria set a world weight-lifting record for the 198 1/4-pound class today by snatching 411 pounds.

title: PRESIDENT DEFENDS HIS ECONOMIC PLAN
description: President Reagan, asserting that the economic program in effect since October ''hasn't really started yet,'' said today that income taxes should not be increased despite the rising budget deficit.

title:
Speaking Personally;
AN ALARMING THOUGHT: A MALFUNCTIONING ALARM
description: AFTER my neighborhood was hit by a particularly severe rash of burglaries, I decided that the time had come to heed the advice of friends and install an alarm system. My friends, who have had one for years, swear by it -and at it, as well, for it frequently rings for no apparent reason.

title: Geoffrey Graham Blum Weds Martha Coburn
description: Martha Anne Coburn and Geoffrey Graham Blum were married yesterday in the First Parish in Weston, Mass., where the Rev. Judy Hoehler and the Rev. Harry Hoehler, Unitarian ministers, performed the ceremony.

title: THE LIFE OF A CLOWN
description: PETER SELLERS The Authorized Biography. By Alexander Walker. Illustrated. 281 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Co. $13.95.

title: Izumo
description: To the Editor:

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Capstone for Capra Frank Capra, now 84, is a Hollywood pioneer who has won three Oscars for having directed ''It Happened One Night,'' ''Mr. Deeds Goes to Town'' and ''You Can't Take It With You.'' His career spans 42 films in 43 years.

title: Robert F. Kennedy Jr.  Weds Law Classmate
description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. married Emily Ruth Black tonight in a Protestant ceremony in the bride's hometown, capping a romance that began when they met at the University of Virginia law school.

title: No Headline
description: With reference to ''Debate Heats Up as Decision Nears on Multi-Town,'' I would like to let off a little steam by commenting on Donald Middleton's position that the critics of this project are ''almost never genuinely involved with environmental concerns.'' Can he tell me who is? The advocates of mighty Multi-Town have still not given the public an environmental impact statement detailing waste water disposal, ash residue disposal and incinerator stock emission control.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: THE FATE OF THE UNIVERSE By Richard Morris. Illustrated. 183 pp. New York: Playboy Press. $12.95.

title: THE DANCE: N.Y.U. ENDS CELEBRATION OF EDUCATION
description: The performance that brought New York University's five-day celebration of ''50 Years in Dance Education'' to a close on Friday at the University Theater seemed itself at least a half-century long. And, with one exception, the ill-programmed concert failed to measure up to the zest and vision of Martha Hill, the director of the Juilliard School's Dance Division and important figure in the development of American modern dance, whom the evening honored.

title: J.P. de Regt Weds Joan I. Reichart
description: Joan Inglis Reichart, a video-software planner for the television division of the General Electric Company in Portsmouth, Va., was married yesterday to John Pieter de Regt, chartering manager of Ogden Marine Inc., a international bulk shipping concern in New York.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''The Falkland Islands and their dependencies remain British territory; no aggression and no invasion can alter that simple fact.''

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: Crime still pays. In these uncertain times, the popularity of the genre of fiction pioneered by Edgar Allan Poe remains constant. During the past year, a score of writers - including such tried and true favorites as John D. MacDonald, Helen MacInnes, Dick Francis, P.D. James and Dorothy Uhnak - have published whodunits that became best sellers. Admirers of such bygone practitioners as Conan Doyle, Rex Stout and Dashiell Hammett hold regular get-togethers. Across the country, 14 bookstores specializing in crime stories are thriving: three are in New York, two in Philadelphia, two in Washington, two in San Francisco, one each in Chicago, Los Angeles, Houston, Providence, R.I., and Boulder, Colo. More and more publishers are strengthening their backlists with series of paperback reprints of memorable mysteries from the past.

title: HOW TV ACCESS FADED OUT
description: WOODBURY IT was called ''Telicommunity Presents,'' and for a while last year, subscribers to cable television in much of Nassau County and part of Suffolk County could see a Hofstra University professor discuss the management of stress, a series about the handicapped or a program about exactly what happens when a child is admitted to Long Beach Memorial Hospital.

title: Pitchers
description: No. 52 Doyle Alexander, throws right, played in 1981 for San Francisco, won 11 lost 7, 2.90 e.r.a.; Expected to join the team in about 10 days, he is a deceptive pitcher. He looks easy to hit, but few do.

title: WHAT DID SARTRE DO DURING THE OCCUPATION?
description: THE LEFT BANK Writers, Artists and Politics From the Popular Front to the Cold War. By Herbert R. Lottman. 319 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $15.95.

title:
GARDENING;
ROSES: THEIR PROTECTION AND PLANTING
description: WHILE it may be too early to predict the effect of January's severe weather on roses, several growers have reported that the exposed stems of their plants appear to be more severely damaged than usual. It should be the exception in this region if more than an occasional rose is lost during the winter. Healthy, vigorous plants, given protection, should pull through with little damage.

title: Washington; THE NEW ABOLITIONISTS
description: President Reagan made a serious effort during April Fool's Week to demonstrate that he understood and sympathized with the people - particularly the young people - who oppose his economic and nuclear policies. But he didn't quite succeed.

title: BOOKS FOR CHILDREN FACE YOUNG CRITICS
description: IT used to be that you couldn't judge a book by its cover. But according to the students at Woodbridge's Ezra Academy, whose classroom reviews of children's books have been collected and published by their school, a book's cover is almost as important as what's inside.

title: Environews
description: OCEAN dumping off New Jersey probably has been responsible for a 50 percent drop in the total weight of fish caught in the Atlantic since the mid-1970's, a marine-conservation official from Sandy Hook has told a Congressional subcommittee.

title: Postings; URBANIST'S DELIGHT
description: Anyone interested in historic preservation, urban design, land use planning, city horticulture and the like should get to know The Urban Center at Madison Avenue and 51th Street. Symbolically situated in a wing of one of the grand old buildings of New York, the Villard Houses, it is the site of free events every week for hundreds of New Yorkers interested in the city's architecture.

title: Squash
description: To the Business Editor: Regarding ''The Executives Who Are Hooked on Squash'' (March 21), please say it isn't true that low-seeded executives are doomed to the bottom rungs of the organizational ladder. I try hard and I really want to win, but my opponents are endowed with better skills - speed, coordination and more solid backhands.

title: Nancy Grummer Married
description: Nancy Louise Grummer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene M. Grummer of Westwood, N.J., was married there yesterday in the Zion Lutheran Church to Gary A. Neuser, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter F. Neuser of Deer Park, L.I. The Rev. Norman Brinkmann performed the ceremony. The bride is with the commodity division of Merrill Lynch International in New York. Her husband is vice president and manager of worldwide distribution for Merrill Lynch International in London.

title: BUDGET ISN'T A DAY LATE, BUT COULD BE DOLLARS SHORT
description: ALBANY THE State Legislature passed a budget on time last week, something it has not done very often in recent years. But it seems to be as uncertain as ever how much New York will raise and how much it will spend in the fiscal year that began last week.

title: William Nix Concert Tonight
description: A memorial concert for William H. Nix, the stage manager and director of the Metropolitan Opera Studio who died last July 25, is to be held at 8 P.M. today at the Mannes College of Music recital hall, 157 East 74th Street. A scholarship fund has been established in Mr. Nix's name to assist young American professional singers. Mr. Nix died of cancer at the age of 48.

title: EXPLORING UNDERWATER REALMS
description: NEW HAVEN Clear, early spring morning light glistened on the water as the research vessel U Conn made her way out of New Haven harbor. The cruise ahead would include activities that demonstrated several aspects of the work of Connecticut's Sea Grant Advisory service, an agency primarily committed to increasing the state's seafood harvest by exploring the largely unchartered realms of aquaculture and high technology fishing methods.

title: DINING OUT IN ASPEN
description: MARIAN BURROS reports on food for The Times. By MARIAN BURROS

title:
Dining OUt;
MAIN COURSES? ONLY A CHOICE OF 73
description: IN MANY ways, it is a typical American-Italian restaurant, one of any number of clones throughout New Jersey. Yet, Le Bistro has an extra nice feel about it. Situated in a semi-residential section of Elmwood Park (formerly East Paterson), the restaurant is crowded and lively most nights, and on Saturdays it is so busy that patrons stand cheek-by-jowl in the bar and foyer waiting to be paged by loudspeaker when a table becomes available. The fact that reservations are not accepted for small parties has something to do with it; also, word is out about the generous quantities of good, southern Italian food that is offered here.

title: FEARS VOICED ON USING DUMP CITE FOR DEPOT
description: Legislators, community leaders and scientists have voiced fears that a former dump in the northeast Bronx that has been approved as a site for a large city bus depot is contaminated by toxic wastes that could prove harmful to garage workers and local residents.

title: SPECIAL GIFT FOR LIBRARY
description: A GIFT to the Pequot Library in Southport of 47 books hand-printed by William Morris, the English designer of the 1890's, will be celebrated with a public reception from 4 to 6 P.M. today. The books will be on display until May 15.

title: CITY OPERA: A NEW PRODUCTION OF 'I LOMBARDI'
description: The New York City Opera's ambitious cycle of early Verdi operas, while providing us with the opportunity to see some half-legendary works that led up to the mature masterpieces, has not been a series of dizzying successes. Much of the fault is Verdi's, of course, but the City Opera has not been a great help to him. When a work is as weak and uneven as ''I Lombardi,'' for instance, it needs all the help it can get, not only vocally but in stage design, direction and lighting. The ''I Lombardi'' production that made its bow last night hit bottom in design and direction, and the singing was rarely more than acceptable.

title: Horses' Rights
description: Its supporters called it a Wagner Act for horses, an allusion to the National Labor Relations Act, which Senator Robert F. Wagner sponsored in 1935. Mayor Koch signed the horse law in August 1981.

title: Jonathan Kibbe, Mary Landergan Set May Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Walter L. Landergan of Lynnfield, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary E. Landergan, to Jonathan Kibbe, son of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Kibbe of Yorktown Heights, N.Y.

title: Editor's Choice
description: Irish writer. THE BRANDEIS/FRANKFURTER CONNECTION, by Bruce Allen Murphy. (Oxford University Press, $18.95.) The political alliance of the two Supreme Court Justices.

title: 'DREAMGIRLS' WAS HIS DREAM
description: As the curtain fell on the opening-night performance of ''Dreamgirls,'' Cleavant Derricks threw his hands up in the air and gave out a cry that sounded at once jubilant and weary. ''Two years!'' he shouted as he ran off the stage of the Imperial Theater and bounded up a narrow staircase to his dressing room. ''Two years!''

title: No Headline
description: Top-seeded Chris Evert Lloyd rallied and defeated Evonne Goolagong Cawley, 5-7, 6-1, 6-4, in a semifinal match tonight and moved into the championship round of the $200,000 Citizen Cup tennis tournament.

title: IN CANADA'S NORTH, ICE IS A BRUTAL FACT OF LIFE
description: It is everywhere in Canada's North, an integral element dominating life like dirt on a farm or cement in a city.

title: CLIFTON DANIEL IS HONORED
description: Clifton Daniel, former managing editor of the New York Times, has been named to the North Carolina Journalism Hall of Fame. Mr. Daniel, 69 years old, is a Zebulon, N.C., native who wrote for The Raleigh News and Observer and The Associated Press before spending 33 years with The Times.

title: The Nation; CIVIL DEFENSE NOTIONS CHANGE BUT THE SKEPTICISM REMAINS
description: Concern over civil defense has faded in and out of American political conciousness for the past 25 years. Last week, for a while at least, it seemed to be making a comeback. The Federal Emergency Management Agency, an organization of 3,000 employees that administers the civil defense program, announced that President Reagan had approved a seven-year, $4.2 billion program designed to ''provide for survival of a substantial portion of the population in the event of a nuclear attack.''

title: TWO POETS
description: THE CHINESE INSOMNIACS New Poems. By Josephine Jacobsen. 79 pp. Philadelphia: University of Pennsylvania Press. Cloth, $9.95. Paper, $4.95. THE COUNTRY BETWEEN US By Carolyn Forche. 59 pp. New York: Harper & Row. Cloth, $11.50. Paper, $5.95.

title: OIL-PRICE DROP PUTS SQUEEZE ON LENDING TO POOR NATIONS
description: WASHINGTON THE moon has its dark side, and so does the slide in world oil prices. Although it has already led to lower inflation in the United States and other oil-importing countries and might help boost them out of recession, the drop in oil prices could also cause further tightening in international lending, especially to the more impoverished countries of the third world.

title: GOTHAM TO AIR FORBES WON
description: Edward Anchel's Air Forbes Won, a son of Bold Forbes who made his racing debut only last month, established himself as a top Eastern prospect for the Kentucky Derby with an impressive victory yesterday in the $84,600 Gotham Stakes at Aqueduct.

title: ON RENTAL HOUSING
description: ON the cover on one of George Sternlieb's recent books, ''The Futureo f Rental Housing,'' is an illustration of a large crystal ball s uperimposed on the facade of a high-rise apartment building.

title: Miss Hallwachs Plans Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Hallwachs of Philadephia have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marianne Jenner Hallwachs, to Joel R. Charney, son of Dr. and Mrs. E. Joseph Charney of Pittsburgh.

title: AMERICA'S OTHER BUDGET
description: As much as it must pain Uncle Sam to borrow money from Wall Street at 15 percent interest and lend it out at 3, he must realize that the I.R.S. borrows from me every two weeks interest free. MICHAEL GALLAGHER Sullivans Island, S.C.

title: AIMING TO AWE, NOT ENLIGHTEN
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Leah D. Frank is a freelance writer with a particular interest in public television. By LEAH D. FRANK

title: HAM(LAMB)AND AN END TO EASTER'S LEFTOVERS BLUES
description: ''THE definition of eternity,'' said one culinary wag, ''is a ham and two people.'' Very soon now, there is bound to be leftover ham from the Easter table. If not ham, then lamb. There are just so many sandwiches you can make, so many omelettes, so many pies, so many croquettes. Then you run out of ideas, and your family runs out of patience.

title: INDICTMENTS CAST A PALL ON ELECTION IN NEWARK
description: NEWARK THE indictments last week of Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson and City Council President Earl Harris by an Essex County grand jury on charges of official misconduct, obtaining money under false pretenses and neglect of official duty have cast a pall over the Mayoral election on May 11.

title: Plan for Industry
description: To the Business Editor: Frank A. Weil's ''Policy for Industry'' (March 28) is a first rate rational approach toward a solution for a serious national deficiency. The increasingly competitive world in which the United States does business and the difficult trade problems existing with its major trading partners have pointed up the need for national long-term industrial planning.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: NEW MUSIC Tuesday night, after a day in which yet another John Cage 70thbirthday marathon will be offered - by the Bowery Ensemble at the Cooper Union from noon to 10 - two major figures of post-Cageian experimental music will combine for a concert as part of the Dance Theater Workshop's prestigious new-music series.

title: Q and A; Co-Op Conversion
description: Question: The owner of the building I live in is trying to convert it to a cooperative, but my neighbor and I don't want to buy. Isn't there a state law that says older people can stay in their apartments as renters even if the building goes co-op? ... M.C.S., Manhattan Answer: A state law allows persons 62 and older to remain as renters as long as they wish in buildings that are converting. In New York City, however, a resident, besides being at least 62, must also have lived in the building at least two years, and the apartment occupants must have a combined income of under $50,000.

title: Japan Cuts Off Soviet Plane
description: Two Japanese jet fighters intercepted a Soviet transport plane that Tokyo said was violating Japanese airspace today west of the southernmost island of Kyushu. The Defense Agency said the plane flew through Japan's airspace for about two minutes above Tori-shima Island and then left without incident.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Backlist best sellers. In the contentious world of books - a world in which booksellers are engaged in constant battle with publishers over such tricky questions as discounts, return policies and freight charges - something quite remarkable is about to happen. Ten days from now, the Association of American Publishers and the American Booksellers Association will jointly start sending magazine and newspaper editors - and of course booksellers - a monthly package of ''Category Paperback Bestseller Lists.''

title: Food; HAM (LAMB) AND AN END TO EASTER'S LEFTOVERS BLUES
description: ''THE definition of eternity,'' said one culinary wag, ''is a ham and two people.'' Very soon now, there is bound to be leftover ham from the Easter table. If not ham, then lamb. There are just so many sandwiches you can make, so many omelettes, so many pies, so many croquettes. Then you run out of ideas, and your family runs out of patience.

title: MORAVIAN EASTER: RELIC OF PAST
description: AS TROMBONES blare German chorales, Protestants from a small denomination will gather at nine places in New Jersey and Staten Island on Easter morning for a service at least 250 years old.

title: REBECCA WEST
description: Leslie Garis writes frequently about the arts. By Leslie Garis My father was quite a lot around when I was small, but I was never allowed to call him Father or Papa or Daddy. He was always H.G. But I knew what he was. And then by the time I was 5 or 6, I began not to know. And I became very anxious to clear up the point, because it struck me that I had only known intuitively -nobody had actually ever said it. So I asked my mother and she said, ''One day I'll tell you. There are reasons why I can't tell you now.'' - ANTHONY WEST, in an interview, January 1982.

title: Sylvia Ripley to Be July Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. S. Dillon Ripley of Washington, New York and Litchfield, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sylvia McNeill Ripley, to Christopher Calvert Addison, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis G. Addison 3d of Washington, Stevensonville, Md., and Sussex Shore, Del.

title: New Psychiatric Ward Will Open at Bellevue
description: Bellevue Hospital will open a new psychaitric ward by September 1984 under an agreement reached by New York City, the state and lawyers for psychiatric patients at the hospital.

title: On Language
description: Publish or Perish KIMBLE MEAD

title: NEW YORK PAYING A PRICE FOR DELAYING REPAIRS
description: For decades, the New York City school system - sometimes seeking to save money, sometimes simply unmindful of a growing problem - postponed regular roof maintenance on some schools, only to discover that resulting leaks had not only damaged walls but also seriously corroded steel underpinnings.

title: Lum Stars in Opener
description: Mike Lum, a former major leaguer, singled home the tying run as the Yokohama Taiyo Whales scored three runs in the bottom of the ninth inning and beat the Hanshin Tigers, 3-2, in their Japanese League baseball season opener today.

title: PORTRAIT OF THE ARTIST AS FACTORY EMPLOYEE
description: THE traditional portrait of the artist as writer shows him or her creating in splendid isolation, far from the madding crowd or the commercial marketplace. Alas, as the death of Harriet Stratemeyer Adams at 89 last week reminded the world of letters, the portrait is not always accurate. Far from pursuing some private muse, the putative author of the Nancy Drew series and other juvenile favorites with brand names such as the Hardy Boys, Tom Swift, the Bobbsey Twins and the Rover Boys presided over what amounted to a small writing factory. Established by her father, Edward Stratemeyer, in 1905, the Stratemeyer Syndicate employed free lance writers to do touch-up work on some stories, or stamp out the bodies of entire books that were published under several pseudonyms used by Mrs. Adams. They sold millions of copies throughout the world.

title: PAMELA SPIEGEL ENGAGED
description: Pamela Sue Spiegel, a freelance television producer, and Arthur David Sanders, a New York lawyer, plan to be married June 6. Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Spiegel of Kings Point, L.I., have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mrs. Irving Sanders of Lynbrook, L.I., and the late Mr. Sanders.

title: EACH PARTY FACES DELEGATE DONNYBROOK
description: HARTFORD FORGET that old Grantland Rice rule of sports that, when the One Great Scorer writes against your name, ''He marks not that you won or lost, but how you played the game.''

title: SUNDAY OBSERVER
description: The Lit'ry Life PATRICK MCDONNELL

title: LET'S EXPLOIT MOSCOW'S WEAKNESS
description: Whether Leonid I. Brezhnev is merely fatigued or near death, it is clear that Soviet leaders have embarked on what may be far-reaching initiatives. His call for a freeze on placing missiles in Europe followed immediately by his appeal for better relations with China may be propaganda or a leader's attempt to take bold initiatives because he realizes little time is left to mark his place in history.

title: RECITAL: KRISTI Bjarnason
description: When the cellist Kristi Bjarnason reached the final half of her concert, presented by Pro Musicis in the Merkin Concert Hall Wednesday night, there were signs of a musical commitment that were missing earlier. In the Second Brahms Sonata (Op. 99) several wellshaped sequences emerged as if they mattered, particularly during the difficult Adagio.

title: JAZZ: TANIA MARIA, PIANIST, VOCALIST
description: On her latest Concord Jazz Record, ''Taurus,'' Tania Maria, a Brazilian pianist and singer, is a very vital and exciting performer. She is a pianist with tremendous drive and a vocalist who communicates as skillfully with humming scat phrases, vocalized lines that have trumpet tones, churrups and whistling as she does with words.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: PLANS and drawings for a proposed $52 million hotel and office complex to rejuvenate downtown Bridgeport were unveiled at a news conference at City Hall last Wednesday, but there was a touch of caution because Bridgeport has seen too many grand plans over the years that never quite materialized.

title: Johns Hopkins Wins
description: Peter Scott scored his fourth goal of the game with 17 seconds gone in overtime to give Johns Hopkins a 13-12 lacrosse victory over Virginia today. Jeff Cook and Mike Donnelly scored three goals each for Johns Hopkins, which is unbeaten in five games.

title: Dream for Sale
description: ''I built my dream house, but my wife didn't like it,'' said Don Kirshner. ''She only wanted a little place.'' So last fall the rock music promoter put the place up for sale: 17 rooms, an indoor disco, two tennis courts, basketball court, pool and etc. on 29 acres in Morris County, N.J. Mr. Kirshner was asking $8.5 million for what was called ''Hollywood country modern.''

title: JAILING DROPPED FOR REPORTER IN MURDER CASE
description: A judge has vacated a jail sentence imposed on a reporter who refused to disclose notes of conversations with teen-agers in connection with a bizarre murder case near here.

title: TIME BANDITS HAUNT COMPUTERS
description: MINEOLA THE computer age is generating a new breed of criminal - time bandits. These high-technology crooks conduct profitable side businesses on other people's computers; they steal trade secrets and embezzle funds. The more skilled among them do it without leaving so much as a trace of an electronic fingerprint.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
BASEBALL: IT'S TOO GOOD TO MESS UP
description: PART of the magic of baseball is reflected in the date of this newspaper. O! how this spring of love resembleth The uncertain glory of an April day. ''Two Gentlemen of Verona''

title: The Morning of Silence On the Railroad Tracks
description: Noise is a necessary part of everyday life. If suddenly it occurs to me that the oil burner hasn't made its customary roar for a long time, I turn the thermostat up a trifle and when the burner kicks on, I'm happy.

title: Appointing a Judge In Nassau County
description: I am writing in my capacity as president of the Nassau-Suffolk Women's Bar Association with regard to Governor Carey's appointment of Abbey Boklan to the position of Judge of the County Court. It now appears that there is a possibility that the Senate Judiciary Committee may hold up what should be routine consent to this appointment. This would be a grave injustice.

title: LESSONS IN DEREGULATION
description: Reese H. Taylor, appointed chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission by President Reagan last year, sometimes finds that visual devices can be helpful in explaining issues of business regulation. Accordingly, in testifying before Congress and in meetings around the country, he has been known to brandish the accompanying illustration, drawn by a staff member to his specifications. The following is Mr. Taylor's narrative analogy, ''The Saga of Mac and Ray.''

title: Debra E. Goldman Engaged to Frederick S. Title
description: Mrs. Harold A. Ackerman of Springfield, N.J., and Samuel Goldman of West Orange, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Debra Ellen Goldman, to Frederick Stephen Title, son of Gerald Title, also of Springfield, and the late Edythe Title.

title: SINAI ISRAELIS LEAVING TRAIL OF MODERNITY FOR BEDOUINS
description: Occupied Sinai - The 15 years in which Israel has occupied Sinai are nothing more than an instant in the long sweep of the desert's history. After Israel's scheduled withdrawal and the Egyptians' return beginning April 25, the signs of an Israeli presence may disappear as thoroughly as tracks in a sandstorm.

title: Headliners; Out of Energy?
description: Energy Secretary James B. Edwards may have, as he said, a ''strong commitment to the Administration and the tasks still before me,'' but it looked last week like he might have an even stronger one to his own future. Mr. Edwards was offered the presidency of the Medical School of South Carolina, a job he has sought, and seemed likely to accept it. If he does, the former South Carolina Governor would be the first of President Reagan's Cabinet members to depart.

title: Nostalgia at Fenway
description: Now that their former stars are truly elderly, the Boston Red Sox have finally decided to stage their first Old-Timers Day on May 1. Heading the list of former Boston standouts are Ted Williams, the six-time American League batting champion, and Joe Cronin, a former shortstop and manager of the Red Sox and a retired president of the American League.

title: Major News; Reagan Opens A Window of Credibility
description: The facts are so complex and the arguments so arcane that the debate over arms control has usually been monopolized by professionals and a few passionately concerned onlookers. But with members of Congress, church leaders and the public in large numbers raising an antinuclear voice, President Reagan last week felt called upon to reassert a hard line.

title: BLEAK PLAY REAFFIRMS A TALENT
description: EAST FARMINGDALE THE Arena Players Repertory Theater is producing Joseph Lizardi's plays, it seems, at the rate of two a year. The last, ''December in New York,'' was a dud. With ''Three on the Run,'' which is on until April 18, Mr. Lizardi is really cooking, full steam.

title: Reading and Writing
description: When I began as a reviewer no one explained to me how one went about writing a review, and I still feel that omission. In the interests of the profession I have prepared a little primer for beginners, based on more than a decade's observation of the field.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:We are planning a trip throughout the United States by trailer. I'd like to know how to find out weather conditions so that we can avoid specific places during such life-threatening situations as tornadoes. - C.C., Plainfield, N.J. Answer:One good general source of information for trip planning is the Weather Almanac, a paperback published in 1979 by Avon Books. If you cannot find it in a local bookstore, send a check or money order for $8.95 ($7.95 plus a dollar for postage and handling) to Avon Books, Mail Order Department, Second Floor, 224 West 57th Street, New York, N.Y. 10019; allow six to eight weeks for delivery.

title: No Headline
description: ABC's ''Wide World of Sports'' lost the video portion of its live broadcast of the Florida Derby only seconds after the horses had left the starting gate Saturday.

title: Performing-Arts Group For Atom Curb Formed
description: Jules Feiffer and five colleagues in the arts - Robert Altman, Harry Belafonte, Jill Clayburgh, Eliot Feld and Harold Prince - have announced the formation of Performing Artists for Nuclear Disarmament. Its purpose, Mr. Feiffer said, ''is to mobilize people in the performing arts to use their skills, talents and public access to halt the ongong drive toward mass destruction.''

title: Sabres 5, Canadiens 4
description: MONTREAL (UPI) - Andre Savard scored a goal with 20 seconds remaining to lift Buffalo and keep alive the Sabres' hopes for homeice advantage in the first round of the playoffs.

title: RETAILING: THE SPECIAL CASE OF MELVILLE CORP.
description: HARRISON, N.Y. NO matter how well the Melville Corporation does in the near or long term, the management of the big shoe and apparel retailer insists that it will adhere indefinitely to its lean corporate staff of only seven executives and a supporting staff of 75. But if Melville's historical record of enjoying a 16 percent annual growth is sustained, that assurance means that by 1987 only seven executives will operate a company with $6 billion in sales.

title: Mariann Dioguardi Married
description: The marriage of Mariann Dioguardi, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William P. Dioguardi of Upper Montclair, N.J., to Thomas P. Higgins took place yesterday in St. Cassian's Roman Catholic Church in Upper Montclair. Msgr. Edward Larkin performed the ceremony. The bride is an account executive with Dancer Fitzgerald Sample Inc., a New York advertising agency. Mr. Higgins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Higgins of Derby, Conn., is an associate with the New York law firm of White & Case.

title: 'BURN-OUT' IS REAL, CRUEL AND TREATABLE
description: To the Editor:

title: EXPOS AND DODGERS SHOULD REPEAT DIVISIONAL TITLES
description: The following National League preview was prepared by Joseph Durso. The order of the teams reflects the predicted order of finish, with the Mets picked for fourth in the East. EASTERN DIVISION MONTREAL EXPOS

title: First Negotiations Held In L. I. Hospital Strike
description: The first negotiations were held yesterday in the bitter 25-day strike by 2,250 employees of the Long Island Jewish-Hillside Medical Center, but both sides said last night that a report of a settlement was premature.

title: SEEDS FOR GARDENS A YEAR-ROUND JOB
description: WETHERSFIELD MOST gardeners come to life in the spring. Enticed by vivid photographs of tomatoes and marigolds, they pore over seed catalogues, debating the merits of pole and bush beans, or of annuals, biennials and perennials.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, APRIL 4, 1982
description: International A large part of Britain's naval fleet has been ordered to the Falkland Islands by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, who told the first weekend session of Parliament since the Suez crisis of 1956 that the islands ''remain British territory.'' Mrs. Thatcher also announced that Argentina's financial assets in Britain would be frozen and other economic sanctions would be imposed. (Page 1, Column 6.) Argentine withdrawal from the Falkland Islands was demanded by the United Nations Security Council. The vote on a British resolution demanding the withdrawal was 10 in favor and Panama against, with the Soviet Union, China, Poland and Spain abstaining. The resolution also calls for an immediate end to hostilities and urges Argentina and Britain to seek a diplomatic solution. The vote came after a debate in which the Argentine Foreign Minister sought to portray his Government's action as that of liberation from colonialism. (1:5.)

title: Pistons 105, Pacers 102
description: John Long scored 25 points and Kent Benson produced 23 as Detroit kept its playoff hopes alive with the victory. Detroit, which snapped a three-game losing streak and raised its season record to 35-40, trails both Washington and Atlanta by 2 1/2 games in the race for the sixth Eastern Conference playoff spot.

title: The Region; For Westway, It's Still Upstream
description: When Mayor Koch and Governor Carey reached accord on the Westway last summer it may have seemed to the highway's proponents that the last big obstacle had been cleared. But in the waters of the Hudson River lurked another, and last week it came to the surface.

title:
The Careful Shopper;
An Unusual Collection Of Discounted Items
description: Closeouts Unlimited, on Central Avenue in Scarsdale, is a place to check periodically because the merchandise changes continuously. Other outlets in the chain are in Peekskill, Poughkeepsie and Port Chester, and all carry a product mix from discounted Easter candies to drills, vises and tools by Buffalo, with quartz watches and refrigerator-storage jars in between.

title: Around the Nation; Savings Banks in 2 Cities Are Rescued by Mergers
description: Federal regulators helped arrange two mergers today, in Philadelphia and Chicago, to rescue savings institutions.

title: Westchester Guide; THE FRENCH CONNECTION
description: The first transatlantic race of tall ships will set sail from La Rochelle, France, at noon on May 15 and is expected to finish in New Orleans around June 17, followed by a three-day celebration commemorating the tricentennial of the exploration of the Mississippi River and the French claim to Louisiana by Robert Chevalier, Sieur de la Salle, who sailed from La Rochelle in 1682.

title: CRIME
description: In the 21 years that Mary J. Latsis and Martha Henissart have been collaborating under the name of Emma Lathen, they have written 19 books on any number of financial topics. (The finance enters because the hero in all of the mysteries is John Putnam Thatcher, the vice president of Sloan Guaranty.) Through the years this writing team has dealt with sales of wheat to Russia, oil, the gold market, mergers, all aspects of banking and, more unexpectedly, dog shows.

title: PROSPECTS
description: The Economy's Trough

title: Jacqueline Neill Collins to Be the Bride Of John Hullar, Consultant, on May 29
description: Jacqueline Neill Collins, an institutional sales associate with the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation's equities division, plans to be married at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More May 29 to John Paul Hullar, a consultant with the advanced underwriting department in the main office of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of New York.

title: Around the World; Namibia Guerrillas Call For International Parley
description: The South-West Africa People's Organization said today that it had called for a new international conference on South-West Africa in an effort to speed up negotiations on the territory's independence.

title: 'Freeze' Proponents Want Quick Fixes
description: The most disturbing aspect about these local nuclear freeze initiatives promulgated by my fellow New Englanders is the intellectual slothfulness with which they approach the subject ('' 'Freeze' Backers Defend Campaign,'' March 21). They mistakingly believe that intensity of conviction is adequate substitution for accuracy in analyses.

title: Luvie Owens Is Bride Of Scott David Myers
description: Luvie Moore Owens, a senior marketing representative of the Northern Trust Bank in Chicago, was married yesterday to Scott David Myers, a senior management consultant with the Arthur Anderson Company in Chicago. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Frank McClain in the Christ Episcopal Church in Winnetka, Ill.

title: REAGAN'S MIDDLE EAST POLICIES DISTRESSING TO AMERICAN JEWS
description: In 1980 a record number of American Jews - 40 percent, according to The New York Times/CBS News poll - voted for the Republican candidate in the three-way Presidential race. By the spring of 1982, the pendulum had swung back. In a Harris Poll released last month, an extraordinary 70 percent of American Jews said they disapproved of the way Ronald Reagan was handling his job.

title: About Books and Authors
description: More Exposure

title: ALLBRITTON IN THE NEWS
description: Joe L. Allbritton (right), a Texas financier with a penchant for buying failing newspapers, last week agreed to buy The Daily News from its owner, the Tribune Company of Chicago. Mr. Allbritton has 30 days to negotiate staff cuts and other concessions with the New York tabloid's unions. If he is successful, he would buy the newspaper and its real estate holdings in Brooklyn and Queens but not the valuable Daily News building in Manhattan. Mr. Allbritton, chairman of the Allbritton Communications Corporation, is a former owner of the defunct Washington Star. Last fall he bought the ailing Trenton Times in New Jersey.

title: Ideas & Trends; More Pollution 'Bubbles'?
description: On the environmental front last week, there were doings and undoings. A coalition of environmentalist groups, shifting their attack from lesser personages to President Reagan, ''indicted'' the Administration in a report for having ''broken faith with the American people on environmental protection.''

title: CONCERT: CALLIOPE SINGERS
description: The lesser known of Bach's two surviving passion settings, the Passion According to St. John, was performed at Alice Tully Hall on Friday night under the direction of Peter Schubert. The performance involved the New Calliope Singers and an orchestra playing period instruments, and featured Lucy Shelton, Kimball Wheeler, Daniel Pincus and David Arnold as soloists in the soprano, alto, tenor and bass arias. The tenor Jon Humphrey sang the part of the Evangelist, Phillip Sneed and Albert de Ruiter the parts of Jesus and Pilate.

title: SYNOGAGUE'S LANDMARK STATUS DEBATED
description: A former synagogue on the Upper West Side is in such disrepair that the Board of Estimate should overrule its designation as a landmark and allow it to be torn down, according to a group that opposed the granting of landmark status to the building.

title: CHANGES PROPOSED IN INSURANCE LAWS
description: TRENDS toward deregulation of major industries at the Federal and state levels could get a boost this month if the Connecticut General Assembly approves a broad new policy designed to change the way the state's Insurance Department oversees personal auto and homeowner policy rates.

title: Food
description: THE CORONATION

title: STRATEGIES FOR THE VATICAN MUSEUMS
description: JAMES McGREGOR is a Rome Prize Fellow in post-classical humanistic studies at the American Academy in Rome. His wife, Ruth Gais, who contributed to this piece, is a classical archeologist. By JAMES McGREGOR

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title:
GARDENING;
ROSES: THEIR PROTECTION AND PLANTING
description: WHILE it may be too early to predict the effect of January's severe weather on roses, several growers have reported that the exposed stems of their plants appear to be more severely damaged than usual. It should be the exception in this region if more than an occasional rose is lost during the winter. Healthy, vigorous plants, given protection, should pull through with little damage.

title: Woody Hayes Drive
description: The trustees at Ohio State University have approved a resolution that will change the name of Stadium Drive, near Ohio Stadium in Columbus, to Woody Hayes Drive. Hayes, who won 205 games against 65 losses and 10 ties in 28 years as head coach of the Buckeyes, was dismissed in 1978 after punching a Clemson player in the final minutes of a game at the Gator Bowl. Officials said they were not sure when the change would become official.

title: CORRECTION
description: A listing of Easter choral programs on Friday incorrectly reported the date of the musical presentation at Marble Collegiate Church. It will at 2 P.M. today.

title: DISKS THAT CLARIFY LOS ANGELES ROCK
description: Los Angeles is still enjoying its latest underground rock explosion, which began around 1978 and which is still largelymisunderstood. The city plays a crucial role in our popular culture, as the center of films, television and pop music. But that centricity provokes its own virulent reactions within Los Angeles and helps explain why the city is perceived in such distorted fashion by the rest of the country, and even by its own pop moguls. What actually happens there is considerably more complex and interesting than simple stereotypes suggest. And a few key records from the younger rock scene can help clarify that complexity.

title: A TOWN GATHERS IN CONCERN
description: WOODSTOCK LAST year voters here used the town meeting to set the tax rate, decide which roads to repair and impose an ordinance limiting public drinking. This year they discussed how to carry out negotiations with the Soviet Union to reduce the risk of war.

title: DEMOCRATS HOPING FOR GAINS IN SPECIAL LEGISLATIVE VOTING
description: In Rochester and some of its suburbs, a political campaign is under way that Democrats hope will strengthen their party's position in the State Senate.

title: DOMESTIC FEUD SHAKES POLITICAL DYNASTY
description: It was a clear case of life imitating kitsch. In a theme common to hundreds of Bombay film melodramas, the proud mother-in-law turned her matriarchal fury on her widowed daughter-inlaw and ordered her out of the house for plotting against the family's interests. The young widow stalked off with her young child insisting that she was being wrongfully accused.

title: LACK OF U.S. FUNDS MAY IMPERIL RUINS
description: Last fall, construction crews clearing a path for a water pipeline through the mountains west of here uncovered ruins that archeologists say may be those of some of the oldest man-made structures ever discovered in North America.

title: CONCERT: BERNSTEIN CONDUCTS
description: Leonard Bernstein led the New York Philharmonic in an unusual and rewarding program of Brahms and Stravinsky Friday afternoon at Avery Fisher Hall. All the pieces except one - Brahms's ''Tragic'' Overture -had close ties to the orchestra.

title: TURKISH CHIEF OUTLINES TENETS OF NEW CHARTER
description: The head of Turkey's ruling National Security Council disclosed the basic principles today of the constitution that is being prepared by the Consultative Assembly.

title: WAS A.F.L.-C.I.O.'S TOP LOBBYIST
description: Andrew J. Biemiller, chief lobbyist for the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and a voice of the national labor movement for nearly a quarter of a century, died yesterday of congestive heart failure at Suburban Hospital in Bethesda, Md. He was 75 years old.

title: 32 DIE AS TWISTERS RIP THROUGH MIDWEST AND SOUTH
description: A string of devastating tornadoes and windstorms, the worst in more than a decade, slashed through at least 15 states from Ohio to Texas late Friday and early yesterday, killing at least 32 persons and injuring hundreds.

title: DESPITE OVERALL CITY JOB RISE, RESIDENTS EMPLOYED FELL IN '81
description: Although payroll employment in New York City increased by 53,000 jobs last year, the number of city residents who held jobs declined by 16,000, according to new government figures.

title: OFFICIALS TAKE LOOK AT PUBLIC EDUCATION
description: A NUMBER of prominent educators, lawyers and government officials met at the Pace University Law School in White Plains last weekend to debate a broad range of issues affecting public education and the court's role in resolving those issues.

title: DEBT HAS OUTGROWN CROPS IN GEORGIA
description: For the last two years drought had parched the thin, sandy soil of southern Georgia, badly hurting the men who cultivate small, diversified farms, 220 acres on the average, that produce tobacco, peanuts, and some cotton, feed grains and livestock.

title: ON COLLEGE POINT
description: To the Editor:

title: SOVIET LEADERS' CLINIC REMAINS UNDER CLOSE GUARD
