description: Policemen continued today to mount watch around the clinic used by members of the Soviet leadership amid indications that Leonid I. Brezhnev may have been admitted there on his return from a trip to Central Asia 10 days ago.

title: STATE BARS STUDY OF COVERT SCHOOL OPERATION
description: The State Commission of Investigation has turned down a request to conduct an inquiry into a covert state operation looking into the New York City school system's practices in hiring teachers for the handicapped.

title: YANKEES GEARED FOR SPEED
description: BOB LEMON, whose job as manager automatically carries with it the a dditional excitement of facing possible dismissal daily, could have c ompany this year. The nonuniformed members of George Steinbrenner's b rain trust could find themselves in jeopardy as the Yankees enter a nother season of potential turmoil on 2 p.m. Tuesday when they play t he Texas Rangers at Yankee Stadium.

title: DEBATE REOPENED ON NEWS REPORTS
description: Remarks by a press aide to President Reagan have rekindled a debate over the accuracy and fairness of news articles about economic problems.

title: Mailbox; Questioning N.C.A.A. Values
description: To the Sports Editor: The day following the article on college athletic cheating and National Collegiate Athletic Association probations (''Problems Are Mounting in N.C.A.A.,'' The New York Times, March 21), I saw on television a rerun of the N.C.A.A. indoor track and field championship. At one point, Ralph Boston interviewed a winning runner from Texas University at El Paso. He was introduced as being ''29 years old and in his fourth year of eligibility at U.T.E.P.'' In the interview, it was clear he could neither speak nor understand simple English.

title: THE FEDERAL RESERVE'S HURTFUL INDEPENDENCE
description: To the Editor:

title: BLACKS AND ALLIES STUDYING POLITICS
description: This time next year, 61-year-old Wilmon Buckley hopes that his name will be among the ranks of this state's elected officials as a supervisor in Simpson County. His only problem, he confides, is that he has no clear idea how to achieve that goal.

title: A U.S. ATTACK ON SMALL-SCALE PUBLIC TRANSIT
description: To the Editor:

title: Art View; PAINTING ATTRIBUTION SPARKS AN UPROAR
description: Dust is still flying in the museum world over the recent ''60 Minutes'' program on CBS-TV, in which a painting by Georges de La Tour at the Metropolitan Museum of Art was branded a fake. Pursuing what he obviously felt was a hot story, Morley Safer, host of this particular segment of the program, produced four English art professionals who attacked the authenticity of ''The Fortune Teller,'' believed to be painted by the 17th-century French artist between 1632 and 1635, and purchased by the Met in 1960 at a cost of $675,000.

title: STAMP ISSUE TO AID SALMON
description: THE suggestion that the United States issue a commemorative stamp paying tribute to the Atlantic salmon has singular merit. The proposal, advanced by Christopher Percy, director of development for the International Atlantic Salmon Foundation, has been submitted to the Postal Service's Citizen's Stamp Advisory Committee.

title:
GARDENING;
ROSES: THEIR PROTECTION AND PLANTING
description: WHILE it may be too early to predict the effect of January's severe weather on roses, several growers have reported that the exposed stems of their plants appear to be more severely damaged than usual. It should be the exception in this region if more than an occasional rose is lost during the winter. Healthy, vigorous plants, given protection, should pull through with little damage.

title: Freedom Is Over
description: Shortly after the Supreme Court last week reversed a lower court's ruling, Federal agents appeared at the home of Dr. Jeffrey MacDonald in Huntington Beach, Calif. The former Green Beret captain, convicted in 1979 of murdering his pregnant wife and their two daughters, had been free since 1980 when an appellate court ruled that his right to a speedy trial had been violated by the Government's delay in indicting him after the Army dismissed charges against him in 1970.

title: ISRAEL'S TIGHTENED OCCUPATION
description: The Israeli Government's ouster of three elected Palestinian mayors from their West Bank posts confirms the end of what Israelis once proudly called a ''liberal'' occupation policy. It also undermines a long-standing United States hope that the mayors might serve as intermediaries between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization in future peace moves.

title: RETURN OF THE BATTLESHIPS
description: The 57,500-ton battleship New Jersey - which blasted 20 Japanese warplanes out of the sky and scarred the beaches of Okinawa and Iwo Jima a generation ago - is rumbling along the Navy's firing range a few miles off the California coast. The time is later this year and the 39-year-old battlewagon is out here to test-fire her heavy-caliber guns. She is making 15 knots, signal flags cracking in the breeze. The decks have been cleared because the blast of a 16-inch gun is enough to blow a man's head off if he is too near the muzzle. Even on the bridge, 35 yards from the closest gun, Capt. William M. Fogarty runs the risk of ruptured eardrums. ''Mickey Mouse ears'' are the order of the day, although old sea dogs are prone to stuff wads of cotton into their ears. Suddenly, a Klaxon sounds the warning - ''Aoo-ga! Aoo-ga!'' The guns are about to fire. Out leap enormous orange balls of flame and mustard-colored smoke. The battleship shudders. Then a thunderclap - more a boom than a bang. A blast of hot air smacks our faces, and the steel casing of the ship's funnel ripples as if it were a sail. From below comes the tinkle of breaking glass -any object not secured is likely to take flight.

title: SEEING THE POPE, TOURING THE VATICAN
description: General audiences are usually held on Wednesdays. During the warmer months they take place in St. Peter's Square (times vary according to season). From November to February they are held at 11 A.M. in the vast new Paul IV audience hall near the south side of St. Peter's. Anyone can attend; there is no dress code, but women should avoid revealing garments.

title: BOARD MEMBERS: WHY THEY SEEK OFFICE
description: Among them, John E. Conlin of Garwood James Hammerstone of Alpha, John Grisso of Winslow and Natalie Waldt of Springfield have spent a total of 80 years on New Jersey school boards. Their record is a far cry from the three years and 11 months that the average school board member serves, but it hasn't stopped them from seeking re-election on Tuesday.

title: No Headline
description: Amid the roar of Reaganomics naysayers, may I suggest that you move Terry Robards's ''The Impossible Dream'' to the editorial page?

title: No Headline
description: Don January, the defending champion, shot a five-under-par 67 today and took a three-stroke lead after three rounds of the $125,000 Michelob Seniors Classic tournament.

title: 3 PROGRAMS CONTINUING CAGE PARTY
description: John Cage's 70th birthday party continues - this week with three evenings of his music at the Whitney Museum. On Thursday, Petr Kotik's S.E.M Ensemble blended the Concert for Piano and Orchestra, the Aria for solo voice and the instrumental piece Atlas Eclipticalis; and as usual, Mr. Cage's music behaved more like an agent than an object.

title: Children's Pay
description: To the Business Editor: Regarding ''Children's Allowances: What the Economists Pay'' (March 14), my economist father, a United States Foreign Service officer, added a foreign exchange twist to his allowance-giving.

title: FAVORED GRITTAR WINS AINTREE
description: Dick Saunders, a 48-year-old amateur, today became the oldest jockey to win the Grand National steeplechase. He rode the 7-1 favorite, Grittar, to a 15-length victory over the Aintree race course's four-and-one-half mile course and 30 fences.

title: GETTING TOUGH WITH DRUNKEN DRIVERS
description: ON the highways and in the General Assembly, Connecticut is mounting its strongest campaign against drunken drivers.It remains to be seen whether the campaign proves effective in stemming the state's death toll due to drunken drivers - about 500 motorists, passengers and pedestrians each year - and the maiming of thousands of others.

title: RANGERS ARE TIED BY WHALERS BUT SAVOR A WINNING SEASON
description: The Rangers, prodded by Coach Herb Brooks, were trying to overcome a case of acute nonchalance tonight as they skated doggedly through their last game of the regular season against the Whalers at the Civic Center.

title: HOBOKEN SCHOOLA: A'S AND F'S
description: HOBOKEN ALTHOUGH politics still plays a large role in Hoboken's school system, George Maier, the Superintendent of Schools, says that he has done his best to get rid of nonproductive workers and transfer teachers to where the need is greatest. Last year, he said, 16 teachers were transferred.

title: CITY NOW AGAINST USING RESERVOIR FOR POWER
description: Reversing a previous position, New York City is now opposing a state Power Authority proposal to build a pumpedstorage power plant at Prattsville in upstate New York that would use water from a city reservoir to generate electricity.

title: The World; Hanging Tough On West Bank And the Sinai
description: The Israeli Government last week enforced its hard line against Palestinian protests in the West Bank and Jewish holdouts in Sinai.

title: Art View; THOSE HEADY YEARS IN PARIS
description: Once upon a time, Europe was wonderland for the visiting American artist. It took forever to get there, but when you finally got off the boat life was cheap, the natives were friendly, and great art fell from the sky. Happy times! Something of their vibration lingers still in the work done in Rome, in Dusseldorf and Munich, and in Paris by one generation after another of visiting Americans. You came for a season, and sometimes you stayed for a lifetime. The European masters were not standoffish. Your compatriots were glad to take your work home as a superior souvenir of their travels. You could winter in big cities and summer in the countryside and never be out of touch with a superior Bohemia. Many an American artist came to fulfillment in conditions such as those.

title: Sound; SONY COOKS UP A TOP TAPE
description: Tape makers literally can't leave well enough alone. Just as tape development had reached the well-enough level, with the better brands sounding very good indeed, some manufacturers seem eager to outdo their own - and anyone else's -achievements.

title: Yale to Require Study Of Foreign Language
description: Members of Yale University's faculty have voted to require undergraduates to study a foreign language, reversing a decision made in the late 1960's and leaving just one Ivy League institution, Brown University, without the requirement.

title: Postings; ORDER OUT OF SPRAWL
description: It is a three-mile stretch of dingy commercial buildings put up at random over the last thirty or forty years, running along the Hempstead Turnpike from Belmont Park to Franklin Square in Nassau County: a grocery store; a social services office; a supermarket, and various vacant and increasingly run-down buildings.

title: FOOTNOTES
description: The influence of British television is strikingly evident on this w eek's best seller lists. "No Bad Dogs," a newcomer to the hard-covern onfiction list (No. 13, is the work of Barbara Woodhouse, a s eptuagenarian English animal trainer, filmed by BBC television, w hose personality and ideas have been aired by many stations in this c ountry.

title: DATA POINT TO RECORD FOR VIOLENT CRIMES
description: ALTHOUGH the total number of major criminal offenses reported in the county appears to have stabilized, incidents of violent crime reached a record level last year, according to preliminary reports from the state's Division of Criminal Justice Services.

title: Wingate's Peltier Relays Star
description: Rain and gusty winds proved no handicap to Dave Peltier of Wingate High School today as he ran the 440-yard anchor leg in 48.7 seconds on the Brooklyn school's winning one-mile relay at the eighth annual Kearny Relays.

title: Around the World; Seoul Holding 9 Suspects For Arson at U.S. Center
description: The police said today that they had arrested a total of nine South Korean suspects in connection with a fire set last month at a United States cultural center in Pusan in which a Korean student was killed.

title: BREAKING SILENCE ON ARGENTINA'S 'MISSING'
description: BUENOS AIRES ARGENTINA has seen thousands of disappearances and assassinations since the military took power six years ago, but the reaction to the latest case was extraordinary. The disappearance and murder a few weeks ago of Ana Maria Martinez, a young pregnant woman and former member of a leftist party, was protested by mainstream civic, political and labor leaders, newspapers, magazines and ordinary citizens - as well as the human rights groups, whose vigil had been lonely. ''The tragic death of Ana Maria Martinez,'' a group of respected attorneys said, ''is a flag that represents the wounds of thousands of unexplained disappearances that suffocate the country.''

title: COMPUTER CRIMINALS: NEW BREED
description: ITEM: Officials of the University of California at Berkeley announced that a group of students had devised a way to tap into the university's computer system and remove, change or destroy information that it contained.

title: Saving Babies Before Birth
description: Robin Marantz Henig has written a fascinating account of new methods to treat the fetus (''Saving Babies Before Birth,'' Feb. 28). But Mrs. Henig has the history a bit wrong.

title: APRIL FOOL--OLD LYME STYLE
description: THE Gazette and The Compass, weekly newspapers serving the Old Lyme area, have been purchased by Tass, the official press agency of the Soviet Union, according to Wednesday's editions of both newspapers.

title: ALL NEW BRUNSWICK IS A STAGE
description: NEW BRUNSWICK BRINGING together four topnotch actors, the Crossroads Theater Company's production of Don Evans's ''A Lovesong for Miss Lydia'' is a funny and somewhat Pinteresque variation on the Big Bad Wolf story.

title: PSEUDONYMS CAUSE A FUROR IN FINNISH POLITICS
description: Finland has long been accustomed to the publication of political articles by writers hiding behind pseudonyms. Many such articles were written by Urho Kekkonen throughout his 45 years in public life, more than 25 of them as President.

title: FROM THE POPE'S WINDOW
description: MALACHI MARTIN has written widely on matters of faith and morals. His most recent works include ''The Final Conclave''; ''King of Kings,'' a recreation of the life of David, and ''The Decline and Fall of the Roman Church.'' By MALACHI MARTIN

title: Ideas & Trends; Step by Step To the Heights
description: Why do some talented people remain just talented, while others shoot right to the top? Nature undoubtedly helps, but it's nurture, according to a University of Chicago study whose findings are now being released, that really does the trick.

title: NEW LIFE AFTER 'THE LAST PICTURE SHOW'
description: William K. Stevens is chief of The Times's bureau in Houston. By William K. Stevens Only the shell of the old picture show still stands. Its projector is long gone, and all the seats and the roof. The ticket window is long since shattered. The crumbling marquee is no more than a graying wooden skeleton, and the light blue paint that once brightened the theater's facade is past peeling. For years, no neon has glowed in the crowning sign that reads, ''Royal.''

title: THE ANSWER WAS: BE A COMPOSER
description: ''ITHINK the first thing I ever wanted to be was statistician for the New York Mets,'' said Daniel Dorff as he recalled his childhood in Roslyn.

title: LAMENT OF THE REAGAN I.R.S.
description: GRADUALLY, in Congressional hearings, internal reviews and independent investigations, a startling truth is emerging here: The Internal Revenue Service, once the most feared of Government agencies, is in danger of becoming something of a paper tiger.

title: Architecture View; The Maturing of Robert Stern; PURCHASE, N.Y.
description: In an interview with Dan Schneider that forms the concluding section of a handsome new book on his work, the architect Robert A.M. Stern says

title: Hempstead Girls Take Class A State Basketball
description: Undefeated Hempstead of Long Island built a 64-59 lead, then held on to earn a 64-63 victory over James Madison of Brooklyn in the Class A championship game of the girls Lucky Thirteen state basketball championships at Union College tonight.

title: The Region; Illegal Spin On Rotating Judgeships
description: Chief Judge Lawrence H. Cooke is generally regarded as New York State's highest legal authority. But last week an appeals court ruled that he ran afoul of an even higher one -the State Constitution - in unilaterally implementing a plan to rotate lower-court judges onto the State Supreme Court in New York City.

title: Kendall Wideman Engaged to Count
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Floyd L. Wideman Jr. of Rumson, N.J., and Palm Beach, Fla., of the engagement of their daughter, Kendall Caroline Bostwick Wideman, to Count Federico Luigi Galdino Pavoncelli, son of Countess Maria Luisa Bruno Pavoncelli of Milan and Count Niccolo Pavoncelli of Rome.

title: WHO WANTS LESS THAN OPTIMAL HEALTH CARE?
description: To the Editor:

title: A CANOE TRIP FROM INN TO INN
description: NARDI REEDER CAMPION is the author of ''Ann the Word: The Story of Mother Ann Lee, Founder of the Shakers.'' By NARDI REEDER CAMPION

title: FIGURATIVE ART SHOW
description: An exhibition of works by American artists focusing on the renewed popularity of figurative art will open Friday and continue through June 9 at the Whitney Museum in Stamford.

title: Dimitri Toufexis, Half Of a Two-Piano Team
description: Dimitri Toufexis, a Juilliard School alumnus who is half of the two-piano team of Toufexis and Ernst and teaches at Moravian College in Pennsylvania, made his New York recital debut in Alice Tully Hall Wednesday night. He played sonatas by Scarlatti and Beethoven, Chopin's Ballade No. 4 and Nocturne in C minor, Liszt's ''Mephisto'' Waltz, Debussy's ''Estampes'' and Larry Lipkis's new ''Waltz-Fantasy.''

title: New Jersey Journal
description: THE board of directors of NJ Transit has put together the last piece of the state's mass-transit puzzle. It voted last week to run commuter trains in New Jersey after Conrail pulls out on Dec. 31.

title: Alan S. Dawes Marries Karen Anne Teshony
description: Karen Anne Teshony, daughter of Mrs. Nicholas William Fenney of Hamden, Conn., and the late Julius George Teshony, was married yesterday to Alan Stuart Dawes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Dawes of Richmond. The Rev. Edward Danks performed the ceremony at the Noroton Presbyterian Church in Darien, Conn.

title: 'FUZZY' ETHICS GET A HARD LOOK IN NORTH SALEM
description: LIKE most towns in New York State, North Salem has a Planning Board composed of five members, appointed by the Town Board to five-year terms. Unlike most other towns, North Salem has just undergone an unusual ordeal of recruitment and replacement in order to arrive at a full Planning Board complement. And of the five members now in office, only one, P. G. Stergianopoulos, its chairman, has been on the board more than three months.

title: CANADIAN BALLET-GUIDED BY A TROIKA
description: Les Grands Ballets Canadiens, which opens Wednesday night at the City Center, is probably one of the few ballet companies in the world to be run by a troika. The Montreal group's official way of referring to its directorate is ''Artistic direction by Colin McIntyre, Linda Stearns and Daniel Jackson'' and the triumvirate's members insist that they are separate yet equal. Miss Stearns supervises the classical repertory, Mr. Jackson supervises the contemporary repertory and, says Mr. McIntyre, ''I look after the administrative repertory; I choreograph the figures.''

title: BASEMENT FARMS PRODUCE BEAN SPROUTS
description: The harvest begins at 3:30 A.M., when a worker yanks back the thick yellow rubber curtain shielding a huge aluminum bin from the light in the basement of the building at 372 Broome Street in Manhattan.

title: The World; U.S. Braces Asia on Arms
description: The guns versus butter debate in the United States last week trailed Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger to Asia, where his pleas for higher military spending got a polite but negative reception.

title: No Headline
description: Doug Padilla upset the world-record holder, Henry Rono of Kenya, and broke the meet record in the 5,000 meters during a driving rainstorm at the Martin Luther King Jr. Freedom Games today.

title: LAW AND ORDER THEN AND NOW
description: ''LAW AND ORDER'' has become an extremely popular catch-phrase these days. While this phrase was popularly associated with the political right in the permissive 1960's and early 1970's, harsh social realities have won this concept many new adherents over the last several years.

title: Joan Gately, S. M. Shapiro Plan Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Gately of Winnetka, Ill., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Joan Henderson Gately, to Stephen Michael Shapiro, Deputy Solicitor General of the United States. He is the son of Samuel H. Shapiro of Northfield, Ill., and the late Dorothy D'Andrea Shapiro.

title: NEW DISPUTES GLUT EUROPE'S FARM AGENDA
description: BRUSSELS THE latest battle to end Europe's perennial farm wars got under way in customary style last week at a meeting here of Common Market leaders. Outside the Community's drab gray headquarters, Belgian riot police battled farmers demanding another big rise in the guaranteed prices - already about twice world levels - the Common Market pays for their produce. Inside, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain locked horns with President Francois Mitterrand of France over the subsidy policy, which has resulted in Britain, a net food importer, bearing a disproportionately large share of Common Market costs. Mr. Mitterrand rejected a compromise under which the Ten would have gradually switched spending away from building butter mountains and filling wine lakes to policies of greater benefit to declining industrial countries. Mrs. Thatcher, in turn, threatened to veto all other Community decisions.

title: No Headline
description: Flying Partner, a long shot, rallied on the outside in the stretch and scored an upset victory in the $271,700 Fantasy Stakes for 3-year-old fillies at Oaklawn Park. Before Dawn, who had won nine of 10 previous career starts and was the 2-5 favorite, was third.

title: EDWARDS, ON 72-210, LEADS BY 3 STROKES
description: Danny Edwards overcame heavy winds to shoot a par 72 and establish a three-stroke lead today in the third round of the $300,000 Greater Greensboro Open golf tournament.

title: BREWERS AND A'S ARE THE CLASS OF AMERICAN LEAGUE
description: The following American League preview was prepared by Murray Chass. The order of the teams reflects the predicted order of finish, with the Yankees picked for second place in the East: EASTERN DIVISION MILWAUKEE

title: PASSOVER: A TIME FOR REMEMBERING
description: THE lamb shanks started me thinking about Passover this year. They were on sale at Gristedes, and right there at the meat counter I had a flash of nostalgia so strong I had to buy one of the neatly packaged bones.

title: ETHNIC SHOWS POPULAR
description: STAMFORD IN the mercurial world of broadcasting, where this year's star is apt to succumb to next year's ratings, radio and television performers rarely voice any displeasure on the air over programming changes involving their shows.

title: PUTTING THE SQUEEZE ON CAR MAKERS
description: IN 1976, the Connecticut Supreme Court, in a case dealing with a determined Fairfield County consumer, put a wall between that consumer and the manufacturer of his new car.

title: RICHARD BURTON AS WAGNER
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Melton S. Davis frequently reports on the arts in Italy. BY MELTON S. DAVIS VENICE After long absences from the stage and screen, punctuated by appearances in mediocre or completely unsuccessful films, Richard Burton at last seems to have his teeth into something significant. He is here making a movie based on the life of Richard Wagner.

title: Pittsburgh Ballet Debut
description: The Pittsburgh Ballet Theater will make its New York debut in performances April 17 and 18 at the Lehman College Center for the Performing Arts. On April 17 at 8 P.M., the company will perform Anton Dolin's ''Pas de Quatre,'' ''Portraits'' and ''Firebird,'' the latter two ballets being new works by the company's director, Patrick Frantz.

title: MISS STACEY'S 71-209 LEADS BY 4
description: Hollis Stacy faltered briefly in the middle of the round but birdied the final two holes to shoot a 71 and take a four-stroke lead today in the $310,000 Nabisco-Dinah Shore women's golf tournament.

title: CO-OPS UPSET FREEPORT
description: FREEPORT THE prospect of converting apartment houses into co-ops is causing concern among tenants in this village, which has one of the largest concentrations of multiple-dwelling units in Hempstead Town. Six apartment-building owners are seeking conversions, and there are reports that others want to follow.

title: 'Lost Hero'
description: To the Editor:

title: TIMELY WRITER WINS
description: Just in case there were any lingering doubts about him, Timely Writer today confirmed that he is the horse to beat in the Kentucky Derby four weeks hence. In what his jockey, Jeffrey Fell, called ''the easiest and the most impressive race'' of the 3-year-old colt's career, Timely Writer stayed closer than usual behind a slow pace, went past Star Gallant with about 150 yards to go, and pulled away to an easy two-length victory in the $250,000 Florida Derby.

title:
ANTIQUES;
NEW HAVEN'S FIRST JEWELER
description: NEW HAVEN TWO rare gold rings made by New Haven's first jeweler, and tied by history to one of this city's founding families -the descendants of Thomas Trowbridge - and to his kinswoman, the colorful Madame Sarah Kemble Knight of Boston, now are part of the collections of the New Haven Colony Historical Society.

title: Ideas & Trends; The Columbia Drops In Later But Greater
description: Neither rain, nor snow, nor gloom of night stayed the space shuttle Columbia from a Monday landing last week. But violent sandstorms did, postponing touchdown and extending the third test flight to eight days. When the hour came - just seconds short of 11:05 A.M. Eastern standard time Tuesday - the sight of the 100-ton glider executing a graceful mid-air turn over the White Sands Missile Range in New Mexico was stunning.

title: WHEN POLITICS INTRUDE INTO PROGRAMMING
description: When the Concord String Quartet plays at Alice Tully Hall tonight, what will not happen is, in its way, as expressive as what will. There are political implications here. This evening brings the third New York installment of the Concord's 10th anniversary celebration. Works by Jacob Druckman and George Rochberg were commissioned and performed by the group for the first two concerts. Tonight's was to have featured a new quartet by Krzystof Penderecki - a piece that has not been written.

title: Italian Culture Official Seized In Currency Transaction Case
description: The police have arrested the director general of Italy's Culture Ministry on charges of illegal currency transactions, the public prosecutor said today.

title: PUBLISHING, AMERICAN STYLE
description: !CLICK SONG By John A. Williams. 430 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $13.95.

title: DON'T RUSH INTO BUYING THAT LITTLE COUNTRY PLACE
description: FOR many New Yorkers, that dreamed-of little place in the country i s a vine-covered cottage in a sun-bathed glen, with a babbling brooka nd a shimmering pond nearby.

title: Zungul Does It Again
description: No one is astonished anymore over the continuing feats of Steve Zungul, the scoring machine of the New York Arrows in the Major Indoor Soccer League. But he surprised even his biggest fans Friday night by scoring three goals in 37 seconds as the Arrows rallied from a 5-2 deficit to defeat the Baltimore Blast, 8-6, at the Nassau Coliseum.

title: ENDANGERED BIRDS: NEW PERIL
description: TRENTON ALTHOUGH several species of birds in New Jersey have been endangered for two or more years, they have not been placed on the state's official list of endangered species because of a paucity of state and Federal funds.

title: CAMPAIGN TO SAVE YONKERS LIBRARY
description: YONKERS AN 11th-hour campaign to save the 79-year-old Carnegie Public Library building in South Yonkers from demolition is gaining momentum, even as the State of New York, its present owner, is preparing to hire wreckers to begin the job.

title: SALE OF N.J. ROCKETS IS LIKELY
description: Ed Tepper, president of the New Jersey Rockets, indicated strongly last week that the Major Indoor Soccer League franchise will be sold and moved, possibly to Atlanta or Minnesota.

title: DETROIT: A SIGN OF THE TIMES
description: DETROIT The billboards along this city's busiest expressways flipped an extra digit on March 26, showing that Detroit had built one million cars so far this year. It was, however, no time for rejoicing. Last year, the million mark was hit exactly one month earlier, and that wasn't exactly a banner production rate either.

title: SOME FLOWERS CAN BE SUCCESSFUL SURPRISES
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Jean S. Wexler is a writer who gardens on Martha's Vineyard. BY JEAN S. WEXLER

title: GETTING A LOAN WHEN YOU'RE JOBLESS
description: IF you've lost your job and need some cash, where can you borrow it?T hat's a tough question in the best of times. But these days, ' 'Everyone is worried about unemployment, and anyone can lose a job t hree months from now,'' said Mary Quinn, director of consumer c redit counseling for the National Foundation for Consumer Credit in S ilver Spring, Md., a nonprofit counseling organization.

title: SCHOOL BOARD ELECTIONS TUESDAY
description: VOTERS in 550 New Jersey school districts will elect school board members and vote on local school budgets Tuesday, but is the fate of the budgets that will be of paramount interest to knowledgeable observers.

title: Headliners; Excessive Punishment
description: By delivering babies in patients' homes, Dr. George A. Wootan caused some controversy in Ulster County, N.Y. But a state order suspending his license last year went too far, the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court decided last week.

title: Rail Museum
description: To the Editor:

title: Brenda L. Marsh Bride Of Steven J. Golembek
description: Dr. Brenda Lee Marsh, a dentist in Manhattan, was married yesterday to Dr. Steven Jay Golembek, an intern in internal medicine at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical College. Rabbi Arnold B. Marans performed the ceremony in the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I.

title: ISRAELI DIPLOMAT SHOT AND KILLED IN PARIS
description: An Israeli diplomat was fatally shot by a young woman today in the lobby of his Paris apartment. No group took responsibility, but Israel said the slaying was the work of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: HAWKS BEAT BULLETS BY 106-101
description: Dan Roundfield scored 33 points and John Drew added 25 to pace the Atlanta Hawks to a 106-101 victory over the Washington Bullets tonight.

title: RYE NECK SCHOOLS: DIFFERENT PRINCIPLES
description: FOR the last five years, no pupil in the Rye Neck Union Free School District with a discipline problem has been sent to a principal's office. There are no principals in the district.

title: HAIG'S QUARREL WITH SALVADOR'S ELECTORATE
description: To the Editor:

title: Alfred B. DelBello In Never-a-Never Land
description: WHITE PLAINS Two propositions he had supported had been blessed by the voters, and Alfred B. DelBello was expanding last week on the ''extremely gratifying'' feeling of victory when the news conference turned to politics.

title: David E. Cutler Will Marry Susan Shellenberger
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. Shellenberger of Framingham, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Grace Shellenberger, to David Eustis Cutler, son of Nancy Eustis Cutler of Arlington Heights, Ill., and Thomas Cutler of Wilmette, Ill.

title: County Theater Fare Is Called Dreary
description: I read the article (''Despite Closing, Hope Is Seen for Equity Troupes in County,'' March 21) about Stephen Rosenfield and his theater totally without sympathy.

title: PARADISE, AUSTRALIAN STYLE
description: HONOUR & OTHER PEOPLE'S CHILDREN Two Stories. By Helen Garner. 156 pp. New York: Seaview Books. $10.50.

title: By ALVIN KLEIN
description: TO observers of the experimental-theater scene, Charles Ludlam has transformed ridiculousness into art. Among other guises, he has appeared in his own plays as a hairy-chested Camille, a fiendish Bluebeard who invents a third gender and a ventriloquist whose dummy really talks back.

title: Soviet Literature
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. STUDY ASSAILS EMBARGO ON CUBA
description: The 20-year-old United States trade embargo against Cuba is forcing Havana deeper into the Soviet camp, according to a study of the Cuban economy prepared for the Joint Economic Committee of Congress.

title: AT PARIS SHOWS, COLLECTIONS WITH A SPECIAL IMPACT
description: The fall and winter ready-to-wear openings, which started with a bang a week ago Friday as Chloe and Emanuel Ungaro introduced well-received collections, continued for another week. But for all practical purposes, the influential showings ended on Wednesday.

title: Politics; SENATE RACE TAKES A FAMILIAR TURN
description: TRENTON THE maneuvering in the race for New Jersey's next full-term United States Senator is settling into a familiar pattern. The Republicans are arguing issues and political philosphy, and the Democrats are looking for someone who can win.

title: LYNN ELLEN IS ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Leon Ellen of Westfield, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Lynn Ellen, to Bruce Howard Goodman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Goodman of Shaker Heights, Ohio. An August wedding is planned. Miss Ellen expects to graduate in May from Vassar College and her fiance will be graduated in June from Dartmouth College.

title: Pennsylvania All-Stars Upset U.S. Squad, 91-85
description: The Pennsylvania All-Stars, led by Clairton's Lloyd Moore and Philadelphia's Seth Greenberg, rallied in the second half to upset the United States All-Star team by 91-85 in the Dapper Dan Roundball Classic Friday night.

title: Feroline Perkins Burrage Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. S. Prentice Porter of Warrenton, Va., have made known the engagement of Mrs. Porter's daughter, Feroline Perkins Burrage, to Thomas Lee Higginson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Higginson of Upper Brookville, L.I.

title: Kentucky
description: To the Editor: No explanation was given for why you ought to be out of the horse business if you are more than 15 miles from Lexington, Ky., in the article ''When the Grass is 'Blue' in Kentucky'' (Travel, March 7). There is a very definite reason for this.

title: Karin Silverstein to Be Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Silverstein of New Rochelle, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Karin Silverstein, to Noe Goldwasser, son of Sarah Goldwasser of Forest Hills, Queens.

title: POP: LAINIE KAZAN, VOCALIST
description: Lainie Kazan is probably not an acquired taste. Either you like the ripely exaggerated style in which she sings at Ibis, at 151 East 50th Street, where she is performed through last night or it makes you cringe.

title: Around the Nation; Overpayments Reported On Medicaid Lab Tests
description: Despite repeated investigations, the Government is still paying millions of dollars more than it should for laboratory tests on Medicaid and Medicare patients, a Federal audit said today.

title:
ON THE ISLE;
HIGH FLIERS
description: If it's spring, it must be time to get out on the beach and, catching a spirited breeze, test those kites you've been accumulating all winter long. So today at noon the Long Island Kitefliers Association will hold an informal kite fly at Jones Beach. Members will meet at parking field 6 and the public is invited, to join in or just watch.

title: Sports of The Times; The Racing Scandal Won't Fade
description: THE parimutuel clerks knew, in the summer of 1974, that something was going on at Saratoga. The clerks would see the same bettors approach the same window and plunk down large sums of money on certain races. According to James Gaffney, who worked there that summer, the clerks would whisper among themselves: ''They are in today. They are making their big bets today.''

title: MAY IS A DANGEROUS MONTH
description: ON the charts of teen-age auto fatalities, the month of May is among the most dangerous periods of the year. That is when the lethal elements of inexperienced drivers, who are inexperienced drinkers, often come together in one of life's adolescent milestones, the high-school prom.

title: Tap-Dance Series Planned
description: The tap choreographer Gail Conrad will present ''tap-dance shorts'' for herself and her sixdancers and five musicians at the Jazz Forum, 648 Broadway, from April 23 to 25 and April 29 to May 2.

title: ( BUDGET STOP AND GO If recent performance is an indication, the economy will never see the record budget deficit predicted for the current fiscal year.
description: The Federal budget posted a $14.8 billion deficit in February, about $1 billion less than the same period a year earlier, according to the Treasury Department's figures. Through the first five months of the fiscal year, the deficit totaled $53.7 billion, or $2 billion less than the total recorded during the October-February period of fiscal 1981.

title: Miss Hines Is Married
description: Patricia Lee Hines and John Stuart Phoenix were married yesterday in the Brick Presbyterian Church, where the Rev. Dr. Herbert B. Anderson and the Rev. Leslie Merlin performed the ceremony

title: Carol A. Simon Plans June Bridal
description: The engagement of Carol A. Simon, an associate with the New York law firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, to Gary W. Kubek, an associate with Debevoise & Plimpton, New York lawyers, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Jack R. Simon of South Orange, N.J., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph Kubek of Cheektowaga, N.Y.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: POP MUSIC The dB's, Pylon, and Pigbag are all rock bands, more or less. They have been lumped together under the largely meaningless rubric ''new wave,'' and they are all performing in the New York area during the coming week. And that is about all they have in common. Their approaches are so disparate, their musical values so distinct, one wonders whether they can all be subsumed under any stylistic heading, even a heading as vague as ''rock.''

title: Follow the Gawker
description: I was entertained by William Safire's ''Traffic Talk'' (On Language, Feb. 28).

title: Gerulaitis and Scanlon Move Into Final
description: Vitas Gerulaitis and Bill Scanlon moved into the final of the $300,000 World Championship Tennis tournament today. Gerulaitis took 2 hours 45 minutes to down Kevin Curren of South Africa, 4-6, 6-4, 7-6, staving off defeat in the third set. Scanlon, a 25-year-old Texan, reached the final of a major tournament for the first time when Pascal Portes of France, his opponent, complained of a foot injury and retired after having dropped the first set, 1-6. On Friday Scanlon upset top-seeded Guillermo Villas of Argentina, 6-4, 6-4.

title: CITY STUDENTS GET A TASTE OF THE LAW
description: For 10 weeks, students at Eastern District High School in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn have been studying divorce law, child-custody rights, tenants' rights and abortion in a socialstudies class called ''Citizen and the Law.'' Attendance is high and interest keen.

title: MAKING 2 OF THE 3 R'S PAY OFF
description: BETWEEN class periods, college students move across the campus from ivy-covered halls to ultramodern buildings, shifting subjects and changing frames of mind.

title: No Headline
description: The attempt to find a moral lesson in the untimely deaths of nine Long Island teen-agers was a heartless indictment of their grieving parents (''In Crash Aftermath, What Checks on Teen-Agers?,'' March 21). Would that we as parents could protect our children from every harm that may come to them! Any parent who tries this learns early on that there are simply no ways that one can do this.

title: Warriors 107 Mavericks 102
description: DALLAS (AP) - World B. Free scored 30 points, 19 in the second half, to lead Golden State.

title: Another Viewpoint On Kidney Transplants
description: ''A New Life, A New Kidney'' (Feb. 28) should be recognized for what it is - a public relations article for Stony Brook University Hospital - rather than for what it pretends to be - the Island's solution for its renal patients. I object to the dubious statistics (more than nine machines service the renal population on the Island) as well as the optimistic tone of the article that views transplantation as a panacea for people with end-stage renal disease.

title: WHITE HOUSE STILL SHAPING TUITION TAX CREDIT BILL
description: Despite President Reagan's support for some form of tuition tax credits for private School students, the Adminstration has not yet reached any decision on when to seek such legislation or what levels of aid should be proposed.

title: Missouri Judge Conducting Hunt for Murderer of Girl, 9
description: A judge who has waged a personal campaign to find the murderer of a 9-year-old girl said Friday he had received dozens of phone calls providing information about the killing.

title: Antiques View; MAJOLICA MAKES A BOLD COMEBACK
description: Majolica - earthenware embellished with brilliant glazes that was popularized first in the Renaissance and revived in the Victorian period - is back in the spotlight.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LOESSER TRIBUTE

title: U.S. AND PANAMA FACE NEW STRAINS
description: A quiet change in leadership in Panama and a controversy here over the appointment of a new United States Ambassador to that country have introduced new uncertainties into relations between the two Governments, according to State Department officials, Congressional aides and Panamanian business leaders.

title: MUTTERING TAKES SANTA ANITA
description: The Tartan Stable's Muttering, given a superb ride by Laffit Pincay, held off a furious closing challenge by Prince Spellbound today and won the $301,300 Santa Anita Derby by a nose.

title: Eddie Albert And Ecotrin
description: As an actor, Eddie Albert has played a bad guy as often as he has a good guy. So you'll have to decide for yourself which role he's playing in the new 30-second commercial for Ecotrin, a safety-coated aspirin that is being advertised to arthritis suffers on television for the first time starting today.

title: WHOLESALE PRICES DIP, POLL SHOWS
description: Wholesale prices for a growing number of products - including aluminum, sugar, gasoline and steel - continued to decline in March, an indication of further weakening in the economy, according to a survey of the nation's purchasing managers.

title: SCIENTISTS ARGUE POTENTIAL HEALTH RISKS OF LOUISIANA NUCLEAR PLANT
description: Southern Louisiana, already plagued by an unusually high cancer rate, can expect an increase in leukemia, lung cancer and other malignancies if a nuclear power plant near New Orleans is allowed to operate, research scientists have predicted.

title: CAMPUS POLITICAL ACTIVITY SHOWS SIGNS OF A SURGE
description: For the first time since nearly a decade ago, when extensive protests against the Vietnam War were convulsing the nation, there are signs this spring of a renewed political activism on college and university campuses.

title: PENGUINS ROUT ISLANDERS, 7-2
description: The Pittsburgh Penguins proved more adept today in a physical game that involved 117 penalty minutes and beat the New York Islanders, 7-2, in their final game of the regular season.

title: BUDGET OUTLOOK BOLSTERS RATES
description: There is little doubt that current and prospective Federal budget deficits are causing interest rates to be higher than they would be if the deficits were smaller.

title: Wolf Trap Amphitheater Is Destroyed by Fire
description: A three-alarm fire fed by strong winds destroyed the amphitheater at the Wolf Trap National Park for the Performing Arts, where entertainers such as Leonard Bernstein, Count Basie and Judy Collins have appeared.

title: The U.N. Today; April 5, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Committee on Nonuse of Force - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: CHIC DISPLAYS TREND TO JAZZ MINIMALISM
description: Chic, the pop-funk disco group, hasn't performed much in the last two years, because its leaders, Bernard Edwards, bassist, and Hile Rodgers, the guitarist, have been so busy producing other acts. This is too bad, because the quintet is one of the most exciting and sophisticated ensembles in all of pop.

title: NEW ZONING PLAN NEEDS A GRANDFATHER
description: To the Editor:

title: A CRITICAL COTERIE ON FOREIGN POLICY
description: In the early 1960's, Senator Paul E. Tsongas worked in an Ethiopian village as a Peace Corps volunteer, and the world has not looked the same to him since.

title: Sonics 140, Nuggets 116
description: SEATTLE (AP) - Jack Sikma, with 29 points, and Bill Hanzlik, with 25, helped Seattle snap Denver's 12-game winning streak and clinch a playoff berth for the Sonics.

title: COSMOS BEAT PERU IN ROUGH GAME, 5-1
description: The Cosmos scored another impressive victory against a reputable foreign opponent by defeating the national team of Peru, 5-1, today at Giants Stadium.

title: H. AUSTIN KAYE
description: H. Austin Kaye, a retired stockbroker for the New York investment concern of L. F. Rothschild & Company, died yesterday at his home in Upperville, Va.

title: No Headline
description: Topics Spirited Activity Elf Policy

title: 2 Lost in Jet Crash Mourned
description: Family and friends gathered Saturday at a memorial mass for a father and son missing and presumed drowned in the crash of a World Airways DC-10 that hurtled into Boston Harbor Jan. 23. The mass for Walter Metcalf, 69 years old, and his son, Leo, 40, both of Dedham, was offered at St. Mary's Church. Their bodies were never recovered from the harbor after the jumbo jet slid off an icy runway at Logan International Airport and bellied into the water.

title: REPORTS OF ARMED IRANIAN EXILES IN EASTERN TURKEY ARE DISCOUNTED
description: Iranian refugees cross daily into Turkey in hopes of getting visas to move on to Western Europe and the United States, but Western intelligence sources here say Iranians have not established any significant paramilitary organization in the country.

title: Seattle Pensioner Hits Slot Machine Jackpot
description: A Seattle man living on a disability pension hit a $400,000 jackpot Saturday, the largest in Las Vegas records.

title: Heaven Better Wait
description: In his wonderful whirlwind visit, Italy's President Sandro Pertini put himself in serious risk of affectionate kidnappings.

title: ACCORD ON A.T. & T. PROVOKES CONCERN ACROSS THE NATION
description: The antitrust agreement between the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the Justice Department has provoked a deep sense of unease across the country.

title: TOM KITE IS SHOOTING FOR THE TOP IN GOLF
description: AUSTIN, Tex. DURING one of this season's Florida tournaments, Tom Kite was asked how he would react if Avis offered him a deal to represent the company on the golf tour. Kite was not offended. Indeed, he found the question amusing.

title: Philip Meister, Helped Start Cubiculo Theater
description: Philip Meister, theatrical director and producer and co-founder of the National Shakespeare Company and the Cubiculo, died after a coronary arrest Saturday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 55 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: BRITONS, FRUSTRATED AND ANGERED, ASSAIL FAILURE TO FORESEE INVASION
description: Argentina's seizure of the Falkland Islands has brought a sense of humiliation and frustration to many Britons for whom the incident has served as a reminder of the decline of Britain as a world power.

title: DESTROYING THE DREAM (2); PHILADELPHIA, April 4 - The psychological phenomenon of denial is familiar to all of us. When some situation, some fact troubles us beyond bearing, we close our eyes to it; we deny its existence.
description: A number of Israel's friends in America are evidently reacting that way to the Begin Government's harsh new policies in the occupied territories. They find the reality so unpleasant that they close their eyes to it. They deny the repression that is taking place; they refuse to see the terrible dangers that Israel is creating for itself.

title: Son of Chief Officer Accused, Iowa Bank Is Ordered Closed
description: A bank in Humboldt was declared insolvent and has been ordered closed after its president's son was accused of using millions of dollars in Government securities held by the bank to manipulate stocks.

title: PUMP FAILURE SHUTS ATOM PLANT
description: The Millstone 2 nuclear power plant shut down automatically today when a pumping system that keeps seaweed from clogging a cooling system malfunctioned, a spokesman for Northeast Utilities said.

title: 76ers DIM KNICKS' PLAYOFF HOPES, 127-106
description: Coach Billy Cunningham refers to Lionel Hollins as ''the least heralded of my starters.'' Julius Erving, Bobby Jones, Maurice Cheeks and Caldwell Jones, the other Philadelphia 76er starters, agree.

title: MUSIC NOTED IN BRIEF
description: We can only hope that Judith Alstadter meant last Saturday's afternoon of Romantic music by women at Carnegie Recital Hall as an excursion along the byways of 19th-century culture, not as a tract on feminine creativity.

title: ORTHODOX JEWS FORM A GROUP FOR SINGLES
description: THEY sat around a library table in an otherwise empty room and t alked about their experiences as Orthodox Jewish singles in New YorkC ity.

title: KHEEL'S TRANSIT JOB WAS KEY IN HIS RISE AS LABOR MEDIATOR
description: A subway conductor is out sick for three days. The Transit Authority sends an investigator, who finds the conductor walking his dog in the park.

title: Again, for the Cameras
description: Like most politicians, President Reagan has an affinity for microphones and cameras. It therefore raised eyebrows last week when the President, appearing in the White House Rose Garden to sign a proclamation designating May as Older Americans Month, strode past a bank of microphones that had been set up on a podium in front of television cameras and went straight to a nearby table to read a prepared statement.

title: 60-SECOND DEBATE
description: With the trustees of the Social Security system warning last week of ''severe financial problems in both the short and the long range,'' the question of cost-of-living adjustments for recipients of benefits is the subject of intense debate. 60-Second Debate Cyril F. Brickfield Executive Director of the American Association of Retired Persons and the National Retired Teachers Association

title: CAPOTE'S MYSTERY
description: Like his nonfiction book ''In Cold Blood,'' Truman Capote's ''Handcarved Coffins'' is an account of a chilling crime - in this case a series of bizarre murders in a small Western town.

title: Zungul Sets Mark For Assists at 53
description: Steve Zungul broke the Major Indoor Soccer League record for assists in a season as he made three and scored five goals as he led the New York Arrows to a 12-3 rout of the New Jersey Rockets today.

title: Half a Taxi Reform
description: ''New York has relatively adequate taxi service.'' So reports Richard Smith, chairman of the Mayor's Committee on Taxi Regulatory Issues. And so his committee assumed in its report, which recommends only modest immediate adjustments in the taxi regulation system.

title: Salt Away More Oil, Quick
description: As motorists know from the price at the pump, the world is temporarily awash in oil. Not since the 1973 oil embargo has there been a better opportunity to funnel some of the surplus into the Louisiana and Texas salt caverns that hold America's strategic petroleum reserve, the first defense against interruptions of imports.

title: Washington Watch; Tax-Leasing Maneuvering
description: leasing issue. Neither has come forward with a specific proposal on how to revise the provisions of the 1981 tax act that made it easy for corporations to buy and sell tax benefits through the leasing of equipment.

title: Lakers 129, Blazers 111
description: Jamaal Wilkes scored 32 points, including 16 in the second period, to lead Los Angeles. Kareem Abdul-Jabbar added 24 for the Lakers, Norm Nixon had 22 and Magic Johnson scored 20 points, had 10 assists and seven steals.

title: Meryl Gittleman Is Bride
description: At Temple Emanu-El in Lynbrook, L.I., yesterday, Meryl Gittleman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Gittleman of Oceanside, L.I., was married to Andrew Perry Kaplan, son of Sidney Kaplan of Hollywood, Fla., and Shirley Kaplan of North Miami, Fla. Rabbi Stuart M. Geller officiated. Mrs. Kaplan is a flutist. Her husband is director of finance for Home Box Office.

title: THE CHIEF JUDGE SHOULD BE A CHIEF JUDGE ONLY
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFING
description: A Guru's Mission

title: SCANLON, IN A FIVE SET FINAL, UPSETS GERULAITIS IN SWITZERLAND
description: Unseeded Bill Scanlon upset Vitas Gerulaitis, 7-5, 7-6, 1-6, 0-6, 6-4, today in the final of a $300,000 World Championship Tennis tournament.

title: EGYPT MOVES TO GET BACK INTO ARAB FOLD
description: Egypt's Ambassador to the United Nations flew to Kuwait today at the head of the first high-level Egyptian Government delegation to visit one of the Arab capitals that broke relations with Cairo in 1979.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Hoechst Corp., Somerville, N.J., has formed three new business groups and named Harry Marty group vice president of the Petrochemicals and Plastics group; George W. Eckelmann group vice president of the Health Care group, and Gerald P. Elden group vice president of the fibers and film group.

title: S News Summary; MONDAY, APRIL 5, 1982
description: International Three Argentine marines were killed in a battle Saturday with a small contingent of British marines at Port Grytviken in the South Georgia Islands, which are in the Falkland group, the Argentine Government announced. Diplomats said that 12 to 20 British marines fought an unknown number of Argentines in the brief fighting. None of the British were killed, the official Argentine report said. (Page A1, Column 6.) Britons are angry and humiliated over Argentina's seizure of the Falkland Islands, creating a a major political crisis for the threeyear old Government of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. Conservative and opposition spokesmen have been unrelenting in their criticism of the Government's failure to anticipate the takeover and in their calls for the resignation of Defense Minister John Nott and, not so severely, of Lord Carrington, the Foreign Secretary. (A1:4-5.)

title: A TRIO OF OCTOGENARIANS WHO IGNORE THE CALENDAR
description: They aren't miracle women. They aren't as spry as they once were, and they don't look 40 or even 50 years old. But as far as the important things in their lives are concerned, age is immaterial. Anna Maximilian Potok, at 84, still guides the prestigious house of Maximilian furs. Alice Neel, 82, needs an eye operation but would rather paint another picture, and Mildred Hilson, who just celebrated her 84th birthday, continues to be one of the most soignee and effective fund-raisers in the city.

title: Commodities; Futures Regulation In Dispute
description: LAWYERS rather than traders continue to generate much of the news in the commodity markets as the debate grows over which Federal regulatory agency should police the rapidly expanding industry, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission or the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: OUTLOOK FOR COLLINS IS STILL UNCERAIN
description: On the last day of spring training, eight weeks after he joined the Yankees in Florida, Dave Collins still did not know today what role he would have with the team.

title:
LE SACRE DU PRINTEMPTS;
Springtime in Montreal. Sap rises in the maples, snows recede from the flanks of Mount Royal, and hope burgeons in the breasts of a million fans of the Montreal Expos - sublime hope, hope impatient with reality, hope oblivious to past disappointment, hope that nurtures faith and gives each season new meaning.
description: Hope, of course, blooms in Cincinnati, in Chicago - even Mets fans can hope. But in Montreal hope joins with exuberant French-Canadian pride to produce language and attitudes found nowhere else in baseball.

title: 'Rapping and Tapping' To Star Jane Goldberg
description: Jane Goldberg will appear in ''Rapping and Tapping'' at the West Bank Cafe (Downstairs), 407 West 42d Street, on April 12, 19 and 26 at 8:30 P.M.

title: Rosalind Rivin Is Bride Of Carl Gary Chernoff
description: At Temple Sinai in Portsmouth, Va., yesterday, Rosalind Rivin, a senior account executive with Leber Katz Partners, a New York advertising agency, was married to Carl Gary Chernoff, senior corporate counsel for the Hertz Corporation. Rabbi Arthur Steinberg performed the ceremony.

title: BOSSY AND TROTTIER: PAIRED FOR SCORING
description: THE scene could be any National Hockey League hotel room from Boston to Edmonton. Bryan Trottier and Mike Bossy are fighting again. It probably sounds like this: ''You did it again.'' ''What?'' ''Left the top off the toothpaste.'' In five seasons of sharing toothpaste on the road - Bossy said Trottier carries the tube -the ''fights'' have been far less frequent than the goals for one of the best combinations in sports history. ''Yeah, we have disagreements some time, husband-and-wife type things, like turning the TV off or the sound down or the lights off,'' said Bossy. ''I wouldn't fight him anyway. He's too strong.''

title: 2 SENATORS DENY SOVIET ARMS LEAD
description: Two Democratic Senators who have often advocated a tough stance toward the Soviet Union said today that President Reagan was wrong when he contended that the Soviet Union possesses superiority in nuclear weapons.

title: STATE TAYLOR LAW DOES MUCH MORE THAN OUTLAW STRIKES
description: To the Editor:

title: TEACHERS OF A TRAFFIC ANARCHY THAT KILLS
description: To the Editor:

title: TO LET ALL CHARITIES LOBBY WITH IMPUNITY
description: To the Editor:

title: AIDES SEE U.S. EFFORT TO AVERT FALKLAND CLASH
description: Administration officials said today that they expected the United States to try to use its influence to produce a diplomatic formula in the next week or so that could avert a military clash between Britain and Argentina over the Falkland Islands.

title: January Is Victor
description: Don January shot a three-under-par 69 today and posted a three-stroke victory in the second $125,000 Michelob Seniors' Classic golf tournament.

title: KOCH'S FUND RAISER GETS EARLY SUPPORT
description: When New York State Comptroller Ned Regan dropped out of the governor's race a few weeks ago, he gave as one reason his inability to compete for campaign funds against Mayor Koch. Now the Mayor's fund raising drive is moving into full swing, and it appears that some of the city's wealthiest and most powerful businessmen are indeed jumping on the Koch bandwagon.

title: 57% IN GALLUP POLL SEE A NEED TO BUILD MORE PRISONS IN U.S.
description: At a time when poll results indicate that nearly half of the American people are afraid to go out alone after dark because of crime in their neighborhoods, 57 percent of the public believe more prisons are needed and 49 percent say they are willing to pay more taxes to get them, according to a Gallup Poll.

title: Jacqueline Burnham Wed To Paul Kurta, Executive
description: Jacqueline Frances Burnham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Burnham of Paramus, N.J., was married yesterday to Paul Mark Kurta, son of Dorothy Saragosey of North Miami, Fla., and Henry Kurta of Seaford, L.I. Rabbi Simon I. Konovich performed the ceremony in the Plaza Hotel.

title: SALVADORAN PRELATE SAYS VOTE REFLECTS A YEARNING FOR PEACE
description: San Salvador's acting Archbishop, Arturo Rivera Damas, said today in his Palm Sunday homily that last Sunday's election was an expression ''of the people's profound aspiration that the violence stop.''

title: NEW BONDS UNCERTAIN
description: Large corporations may or may not take advantage of a hiatus in Treasury note and bond financings by rushing to market their own debt issues. Analysts at Salomon Brothers estimated that only $291 million of new corporate issues were scheduled this week, though a survey of underwriters showed they planned to sell more than that amount.

title: No Headline
description: Harry Sunshine Weds Susan Schwimmer, Teacher

title: JUDGE EXPECTED TO TAKE TESTIMONY IN DISPUTE ON BRINK'S 'INFORMER'
description: A Federal judge is expected to take testimony soon in a controversy over the status of a man who has been identified as both a suspect and a key informer in the Brink's armored-car shoot-out and robbery last Oct. 20.

title: Gillette Set to Promote A New Body Shampoo
description: The latest new-product entry from Gillette's Personal Care division is Bare Elegance, described by the company as a moisturizing body shampoo.

title: Nancy E. Weinberg Wed To James Leonard Burns
description: Nancy Ellen Weinberg and James Leonard Burns, members of the graduating class of the New York University School of Law, were married yesterday at the Sands in Lido Beach, L.I., by Rabbi Arnold Schrater.

title: Celtics 114, Bulls 112
description: BOSTON (UPI) - Larry Bird scored 29 points - 20 in the second half - as the Celtics won their third straight and 21st in their last 22 games.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt STEINBRENNER! By Dick Schaap. 314 pages. Putnam. $14.95.

title: WITH CITY LABOR TALKS NEAR, SPLIT IS DEVELOPING AMONG UNIFORMED SERVICES jobs
description: As contract negotiations are about to begin for New York City's municipal workers, a split is developing in the uniformed services coalition, with sanitation workers likely to bargain separately this year from the police and firefighters.

title: News Analysis
description: With a trip to East Berlin last Monday and an impending trip to Prague, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, is mending official fences that had been badly damaged over the last year and a half.

title: 1,300 People Evacuated After Chemical Fire
description: A fire at a fertilizer plant that spread toxic smoke today over 150 square miles forced the evacuation of up to 1,300 people, the authorities said.

title: Argentine Dies of the Wounds Received in Political Protest
description: One of six people wounded when policemen opened fire on a group of anti-Government demonstrators in the western city of Mendoza on Tuesday has died, a hospital spokesman said today.

title: Census Did Not Include 1.3 Million U.S. Blacks
description: The 1980 census missed counting 1.3 million blacks, but it was a much improved performance over what the agency managed a decade earlier, officials of the Bureau of the Census reported today.

title: WEINBERGER HAILS ASIAN TOUR
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger returned from Asia today and said that he was convinced that he had eased concerns in Japan, South Korea and the Philippines that the United States might reduce its commitment to Pacific security.

title: SWAN: SYMBOL OF A SHAKY STAFF
description: The Mets ended spring training today with a 7-4 loss to the St. Louis Cardinals, who pounded Craig Swan for all their runs in the first three innings.

title: INTERNATIONAL PAPER IN ROUNDTABLE DISPUTE
description: The rumors had it that Edwin A. Gee, chairman and president of the International Paper Corporation, resigned from the Business Roundtable in protest of the group's support of a controversial antitrust bill.

title: MIKE SCHMIDT HAS CREDENTIALS TO RATE WITH BEST
description: MIKE SCHMIDT used to swing and miss so much that one of his Philadelphia Phillies teammates called him ''Ah-tchoo,'' because he made people sneeze from the breezes he stirred.

title: NETS TOP CAVALIERS, 119-109
description: The Nets, who are on the verge of attaining their first playoff berth in three seasons, completed a 6-0 season sweep of the Cleveland Cavaliers, the worst team in the league, with a 119-109 victory today.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: What's a Tar Heel?

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: MOVING TOWARD STOUFFER'S TRIAL VERDICT
description: Almost every day since the Stouffer's Inn arson and murder trial began three months ago, Blanca Marin has been in Westchester County Court, sitting in a front row, watching her husband, Luis.

title: CITY OPERA: 'LUCIA' WITH FLAIR
description: GIANNA ROLANDI gave a riveting account in the title role of Donizetti's ''Lucia di Lammermoor'' yesterday afternoon in the New York City Opera's first performance this season of the production by Tito Capabianco. New to the cast were Barry McCauley as Sir Edgardo of Ravenswood, Brent Ellis as Lord Enrico Ashton and David Eisler as Lord Arturo Bucklaw. Robert Hale sang the part of Raimondo Bidebent, John Lankston that of Normanno and Jane Shaulis that of Alisa.

title: Two Weeks Before Deadline, Half of Tax Returns Are Filed
description: With less than two weeks to the filing deadline, more than half of the nation's taxpayers have already submitted their income tax returns for 1981, the Internal Revenue Service says.

title: Mount St. Helens Erupts, Spewing Ash and Steam
description: Mount St. Helens erupted tonight with a series of steam and ash ''bursts'' reaching as high as four miles above sea level, seismologists and weather officials said.

title: No Headline
description: Question BoxS. Lee Kanner QUESTION: A bowler throws a strike, but then, as he turns around, his foot accidentally touches the foul line and the foul-light flashes. What is the ruling?

title: Debra Joy Tessler Married
description: Debra Joy Tessler, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Marvin Tessler of Little Neck, Queens, was married at Temple Torah there yesterday to Michael Jay Fuchs, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Fuchs of Island Park, L.I. Rabbi Morton Gordon performed the ceremony. The bride is a blood-bank technologist at St. Clare's Hospital and Health Center. Mr. Fuchs is supervisor of the central processing department of the Regency Medical Laboratory.

title: No Headline
description: Dave Anderson Professor Of Hockey

title: GULF NATIONS EAGER FOR CAIRO'S RETURN
description: The Arab Governments of the Persian Gulf are eager to see Egypt resume its tradtional central role in the Arab world once Israel has completed its withdrawal from Sinai on April 25.

title: The Mail Vote
description: The regulation requiring parental notification when girls under 18 ask for prescription contraceptives at Federally funded family planning agencies has provoked a lot of attention - and an extraordinary number of letters. According to a report in The Wall Street Journal, 7,000 are arriving weekly at the Department of Health and Human Services.

title: The Economy
description: Prices of many industrial products continued to fall in March, an indication of further weakening in the economy, according to a survey of purchasing managers. Thirty-three percent of those responding reported lower prices, the most in three decades. (Page D1.)

title: Music: Noted in Brief; Shura Cherkassky Plays Piano Recital at the Y
description: Shura Cherkassky, that tiny wizard of the piano, was at the 92d Street Y on Saturday night to perform some of his musical magic tricks. What other pianist could have passed his hands over the ''Reminiscences de Don Juan'' and brought Liszt's awesome technical problems so completely under his sway? And who else could have evoked with such success the humor needed to divert our attention from Liszt's vulgarities here? Equally baffling was Mr. Cherkassky's domination of Josef Hofmann's ''Kaleidoscope'' - a bizarrely intricate pianistic parlor game meant to be played by only the most advanced of virtuosos.

title: METS UP, NOT YANKS
description: George Vecsey

title: Market Place; Pizza Time: Unproven Idea
description: PIZZA TIME THEATER INC. may be evidence of the fact that a good concept and proven management can overcome the worst of markets. Or Pizza Time Theater may ultimately prove that novelty wears thin.

title: THE LURE, AND LURING, OF SOUTHERN BASS
description: pound largemouth bass hit his surface-swimming plug.

title: RULING RESTORING CONVICTION ENDS EX-ARMY DOCTOR'S NEW LIFE
description: In the 12 years since the deaths by stabbing of Dr. Jeffrey R. MacDonald's wife and children at Fort Bragg, N.C., he has nearly created a second life in southern California.

title: MUDD BOWS AS NBC ANCHOR TONIGHT
description: In the course of a conversation last week, Roger Mudd was asked which network he believed had the strongest evening-news program. ''CBS, probably,'' he replied. ''I just think that even with their losses, the depth of CBS's bench is so much stronger than ABC's or NBC's.''

title: Mrs. Lloyd Victor
description: Chris Evert Lloyd fought off a tenacious challenge and defeated Andrea Jaeger, 6-1, 7-5, today to win the four-player, $200,000 Citizen Cup.

title: FARMER RECALLS BLAZING HIS OREGON TRAIL OF '36
description: There is a faded photograph of Vernon Evans, frozen proudly in the summer of 1936 beside a flivver he put together from old, dead Model T Fords. His aim was to get to Oregon, and it was a long row to hoe, indeed.

title: News Analysis
description: Despite efforts in recent years to reduce the natural tension between law-enforcement officials and intelligence officials, the two still come into conflict.

title: MISS HOLTZMAN DRAWS MIXED REVIEWS ON JOB
description: After three months as Brooklyn's District Attorney, Elizabeth Holtzman sees a variety of ways in which she has bolstered the battle against crime in New York City's most populous borough. They range from stepping up the attack on transit crime and auto thefts to providing pencils for assistant district attorneys who, she says, did not have them.

title: News Analysis
description: Representative James J. Florio's decision not to run for the United States Senate has left the Democratic organization in New Jersey dispirited and unable to focus on a candidate it believes can win in November.

title: Noranda Outlook
description: Noranda Mines issued a pessimistic projection for 1982 1982 in its annual report.

title: NO IMMEDIATE CUTS SEEN IN CAR PRICES
description: Prospective buyers of automobiles are not likely to reap any immediate benefit from the savings that the top two domestic auto makers derive from contract concessions won from the United Automobile Workers, according to company executives and outside analysts.

title: Exxon Talks With U.S.
description: Edward Noble, chairman of the Synthetic Fuels Corporation, said on Friday that his agency would meet with the Exxon Corporation this week to discuss increases in the projected cost of the Colony oil shale project that Exxon sponsors with the Tosco Corporation.

title: Diane Haines Married To Jerry M. Landay
description: The marriage of Diane Burdette Haines, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward B. Haines of Paterson, N.J., to Jerry M. Landay of New York, took place yesterday at the Copper Beach Inn in Ivoryton, Conn. Justice of the Peace Lorraine Wallace of Deep River, Conn., performed the ceremony.

title: WARREN OATES, 52, CHARACTER ACTOR
description: Warren Oates, the character actor who appeared in ''Easy Rider,'' ''In the Heat of the Night'' and ''Dillinger,'' died, apparently of a heart attack, Saturday. He was 52 years old.

title: Canadian Sales
description: Sales by wholesale merchants declined 2.5 percent in January from a year earlier, Statistics Canada said Friday. The agency said wholesale inventories rose 11.5 percent in January from 1981.

title: TIMELY WRITER GETS HIGH DERBY RATING
description: Jeffrey Fell winced at the suggestion that in four weeks he would win the Kentucky Derby aboard Timely Writer in a cakewalk. He has ridden enough good horses who suddenly came up empty, such as It's In The Air, Proud Appeal and Winter's Tale, to know that today's odds-on favorite could be tomorrow's alsoran.

title: KUWAIT'S BUSTLING STOCK SOUK
description: It's called Souk al-Manakh, but it has very little in common with the old Arab markets, the souks of Cairo and Damascus, where jewelers and antique dealers are wedged in between spice and cloth merchants in men sit pensively in cafes looking out into space.

title: VANDALS SET FIRE TO DUTCH STADIUM
description: a fire attributed to vandals caused extensive damage Saturday night to the stadium of the Dutch soccer team, Den Haag.

title: Kennedy Honeymoon; Robert Kennedy Jr. and Bride Off to Caribbean
description: It was a blustery day in Bloomington, Ind., so it seemed natural that the newlyweds would head for a sunny honeymoon in the Caribbean. And that, according to friends, was what Robert F. Kennedy Jr., and his wife, the former Emily Ruth Black, did yesterday following their wedding Saturday night in the bride's home town.

title: Audrey Ingber, Lawyer, Bride of Steven Bender
description: Audrey Helene Ingber, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Ingber of South Fallsburg, N.Y., was married yesterday to Steven Alan Bender, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Bender of Harrison, N.Y. Rabbi Dennis Math and Cantor Ellen Math officiated at the Concord Hotel in Kiamesha Lake, N.Y.

title: Dr. Michael Hindelang; Teacher of Criminology
description: Dr. Michael J. Hindelang, professor of criminal justice at the State University of New York at Albany and founder of the Criminal Justice Research Center in Albany, died March 27 at St. Clare's Hospital in Schenectady, N.Y., of a brain tumor. Dr. Hindelang, who was a resident of Niskayuna, N.Y., was 36 years old.

title: Quiet Diplomacy, Deaf Chile
description: Down in Chile, they just don't get the message. Please make just some little concession to human rights, asks the Reagan Administration quietly, and Chile can be certified as qualifying for renewed American aid.

title: STRIKERS REACH TENTATIVE PACT WITH HOSPITAL
description: A tentative agreement was announced yesterday in the bitter strike by 2,250 hospital workers that has disrupted operations at the Long Island Jewish-Hillside Medical Center for 27 days.

title: Australian Premier Suffers Election Setback
description: Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser suffered a setback Saturday when the opposition Labor Party swept to power in an election in the southern state of Victoria.

title: Sports World Specials; Speaking of Streaks
description: When it comes to winning streaks in basketball, the man who knows a lot is K.C. Jones, who is now in his third year as assistant to Coach Bill Fitch of the Boston Celtics. Jones, a premier defensive guard during his nine years with the Celtics, once teamed with Bill Russell to lead the University of San Francisco to 55 of the Dons' 60 straight victories in the mid-1950's when the school won two consecutive National Collegiate Athletic Association championships.

title: Phelps Proposes Inquiry by I.R.S.
description: Digger Phelps, the Notre Dame coach who recently said that several colleges had illegally paid basketball players as much as $10,000 a year to recruit them, yesterday called for the Internal Revenue Service to investigate college athletics.

title: Rockies Appear Finished in Denver
description: The Colorado Rockies, whose 18-49-13 record is the National Hockey League's worst, scored a 3-1 victory over the Calgary Flames Saturday in what was likely their last home game in Denver.

title: THE FAMED WILL GATHER TO READ THE FORBIDDEN
description: ''Censorship ends in logical completeness,'' George Bernard Shaw once wrote, ''when nobody is allowed to read any books except the books nobody can read.''

title: WEEKEND ERUPTION OF MEXICAN VILLAGE SENDS PEOPLE FLEEING
description: Residents continued to flee the region around the El Chichon volcano today as rocks and ash fell on villages following Saturday night's eruption. There was no information on casualties.

title: STAGE: 'LIVIN DOLLS,' AN IMAGE FROM THE 60's
description: Hard as it is to fathom now, there really was a time when millions of young Americans followed the adventures of Annette Funicello and Frankie Avalon as they cavorted through the sun and song of such kitsch movie classics as ''Beach Party,'' ''Bikini Beach'' and ''Muscle Beach Party.'' The time didn't last long: American International Pictures began throwing its beach parties in 1961 and abandoned them roughly five years later for psychedelia, motorcycles and Peter Fonda. Has life ever been the same since? These days Miss Funicello is to be found on television commercials, no longer a bikini-clad goddess but a proper suburban matron with kids. It's enough to drive her aging fans to drink.

title: KHEEL, FACING OUSTER, STEPS DOWN AS NEW YORK'S TRANSIT ARBITRATOR
description: Contract talks begin this month between New York and its nearly 200,000 municipal workers. Page B4. By MICHAEL ORESKES

title: HIGH WIND RULES DAY IN THE CITY
description: A medley of spring weather - blustering winds, falling temperatures, choruses of somber gray skies and occasional snow flurries - swept over the New York area yesterday, discouraging outdoor play but causing few power or transportation problems.

title: LEBANESE CHRISTIANS SEEK BACKING TO FORCE WITHDRAWAL OF SYRIANS
description: Lebanon's Christian militia forces have opened a new international campaign aimed at forcing the withdrawal of Syrian troops from Lebanon and the disarming of Palestinian guerrillas.

title: 3 ARGENTINES SLAIN AS TROOPS OCCUPY BRITISH OUTPOSTS
description: The Argentine Government announced today that it had overrun the last British military unit in the Falkland Islands and its dependencies as stringent restrictions on the residents of the islands went into effect.

title: BANK-THRIFT LINK IS APPROVED
description: The Federal Reserve Board today approved the first acquisition by a commercial bank holding company of a savings and loan association when it permitted the Interstate Financial Corporation of Dayton, Ohio, to buy Scioto Savings and Loan of Columbus.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Going to the Air

title: CONSUMER PANELS GIVE THEIR VIEWS
description: The subject was hamburger, and the group - a random selection of young married homemakers - said that what they really needed was a way to make ground beef more interesting.

title: Backup End Faces U.S. Drug Charges
description: A 24-year-old reserve defensive end for the St. Louis Cardinals has been charged in a Federal complaint with conspiracy to manufacture and distribute amphetamines.

title: Topping the Oscars
