description: Last Monday, Burt Bacharach and Carole Bayer Sager appeared as part of the collaboration that won an Academy Award for the best song in a film - ''Best That You Can Do,'' the theme from the movie ''Arthur.''

title: PURSUING GENUINE ARMS CONTROL
description: We in the West European peace movement are increasingly convinced that both the American-Soviet exchange about a ''nuclear freeze'' and the negotiations about intermediate-range nuclear weapons that began in Geneva last November are irrelevant to genuine arms control.

title: Richard Pitches
description: J.R. Richard pitched against a major league team for the first time in almost two years today as the Houston Astros beat the Toronto Blue Jays, 3-2, in an exhibition game.

title: Chicago-to-Miami Jet Hijacked to Cuba by 2
description: Two hijackers commandeered a Delta Airlines jet carrying 103 people to Cuba early today, an airline spokesman said.

title: HOW THE RANGERS SUCEEDED
description: The Ranger team that faces the Philadelphia Flyers here in the first round of the Stanley Cup playoffs, beginning Wednesday, is not high-scoring or physically imposing. It has no superstars, has set no league records and has no illusions about itself. The players do not consider themselves the instruments of a destiny that will bring the cup to Madison Square Garden for the first time since 1940.

title: Bridge: 4 Top-Ranked Teams Lose In Grand National Tourney
description: The quarterfinals of the New York Grand National Team Championship began here yesterday afternoon with four top-ranked teams already on the sidelines.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It was a multitalented storm. It did everything it could do to this nation before it left us.''

title: Brezhnev Said to Leave Clinic in Moscow
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, has returned home and is recuperating slowly from an undisclosed ailment that hospitalized him late last month, a Soviet source said today.

title: DID PUBLIC RELATIONS AND WROTE COLUMN
description: Frederick S. Weaver, a politically active Harlem public-relations man who served as the city's Deputy Commissioner of Housing and Buildings under Mayor Vincent R. Impellitteri, died Saturday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived on West 95th Street.

title: Advertising; Behind 2 Account Changes
description: CONTINENTAL AIR LINES is dropping Wells, Rich, Greene, which was notified of the move last Thursday, a day after the carrier got a new board chairman.

title: Patricia Rich Married
description: Patricia Dunham Rich, daughter of Edgar W. Dunham Jr. of Salisbury, N.C., and Jean V. Dunham of Charlotte, N.C., was married yesterday to Michael E. Scudder, son of L. Eloise Scudder of Miami and William F. Scudder of Jackson, Mich. Justice Anthony J. Mercorella of the State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the home of Dr. and Mrs. Nathaniel Miller in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. Previous marriages for the bride, a vice president of S.S.C.&B. Inc. Advertising, and the bridegroom ended in divorce.

title: AGENCY CRITICS SEEKING SIGN OF F.T.C. DIRECTION
description: When President Reagan appointed James C. Miller 3d chairman of the Federal Trade Commission last October there was some concern that the conservative economist's mission was to shut down the agency.

title: BRITAIN ASSERTS IT WILL FIGHT IF PEACE EFFORTS DON'T WORK
description: Defense Secretary John Nott declared today that Britain would fight if diplomatic efforts failed to regain the Falkland Islands from Argentina.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: The Golf Market

title: JAZZ: BOB JAMES AT CARNEGIE
description: To jazz purists, Bob James, the popular fusion composer, keyboardist and arranger who headlined a benefit for jazz radio at Carnegie Hall on Friday, is a symbol of the commercial corruption of jazz-fusion music. And indeed, Mr. James's frothy, formulaic arrangements offer very little in the way of emotional spontaneity or rhythmic excitement.

title: QUICK PROFIT FOR SEEMALA ON FIELD SALE
description: The Seemala Corporation, a subsidiary of Ivan F. Boesky & Company and a leading Wall Street risk arbitrage firm, stands to turn a quick profit on the pending takeover of Marshall Field & Company by Batus Inc. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission last week, Seemala disclosed that it had acquired 9.9 percent of the common stock of Field, or 1,078,200 shares.

title: IN DEFEAT, DEFIANCE
description: Why do you suppose Britain's Lord Carrington, normally so quick to urge accommodation under pressure, was so reluctant to negotiate with Argentina over its newly-pressed claim to the Falkland Islands?

title: Dr. Linda Altman Wed to Physician
description: Dr. Linda Susan Altman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Altman of Tappan, N.Y., was married yesterday in Spring Valley, N.Y., to Dr. Richard Adam Fischer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy Fischer of Merrick, L.I. Rabbi Milton Weinberg, assisted by Cantor Leo Postrel, performed the ceremony at Singer's Hotel.

title: 4 EX-ATTORNEYS GENERAL DENOUNCE BILLS TO BAR COURT-ORDERED BUSING
description: Four former Attorneys General and three former Solicitors General have signed a letter denouncing as unconstitutional two antibusing bills that would severely limit the power of lower Federal courts to desegregate schools.

title: Reds, Orioles Open Today
description: Two astronauts and a new member of the Hall of Fame will be on hand when the baseball season begins today. In the traditional National League opener at Cincinnati, the Reds meet the Chicago Cubs.

title: Righetti Battered Again; Lemon Shows Concern
description: Dave Righetti, the American League's rookie of the year in 1981, completed a miserable spring today as the Texas Rangers battered him for eight runs (six earned) in four and twothirds innings. He wound up the exhibition season having yielded 44 hits, 11 walks and 24 earned runs in 251/3 innings, for an 8.53 earned run average.

title: Bucks 129, Pacers 115
description: MILWAUKEE (UPI) - Sidney Moncrief and Marques Johnson scored 28 points apiece and Pat Cummings added 20 as Milwaukee won its fifth straight game.

title: Flaw in an I.B.M. Computer
description: Divide .1 by 10 and what do you get? The answer is .01. But the new personal computer made by the International Business Machines Corporation in some cases answers .001 - off by a factor of 10.

title: JOHN H. TROLL
description: John H. Troll, a corporate research executive, died Friday of a heart attack at St. Agnes Hospital in White Plains, N.Y., after suffering a seizure while on a flight from Washington. Mr. Troll, who lived in Katonah, N.Y., and had a home in Boston, was 62 years old.

title: SHIFTING TRENDS TRAPPING NEW YORK DAIRY FARMERS
description: Robert Wagner and his sons get up each day at dawn to feed and milk their herd of 137 Holsteins, and each night they repeat the chore. There are no weekends off for the Wagners, who have been dairy farmers in this Rensselaer County community for 27 years.

title: Edwards's 75-285 Wins
description: Danny Edwards shot a front-running round of 75 in strong winds today to score a one-stroke victory in the $300,000 Greater Greensboro Open.

title: Lois Kirkpatrick Is the Bride of Timothy Downing
description: At the First Presbyterian Church in Boulder, Colo., yesterday Lois Marie Kirkpatrick, daughter of Oran Gould Kirkpatrick of Rye, N.Y., and the late Patricia Eintracht Kirkpatrick, was married to Timothy Jackson Downing, son of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Downing of Concord, Mass. The Rev. Kayrene Pearson performed the ceremony.

title: PUBLISHER SUED ON NOVEL CITING CHEMICAL LEAK
description: A writer who says that she and her family were poisoned by gasoline leaking into their water has filed a lawsuit charging that her account of the episode was copied for a best-selling novel, ''Fever.''

title: TEXTBOOKS FOUND TO DISTORT CENTRAL AMERICA
description: What little information is provided about Central America in the books read by schoolchildren in the United States is often distorted and biased, according to a study of 30 books sponsored by the Council on Interracial Books for Children.

title: Gromyko Visits Belgrade In Bid to Improve Ties
description: Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko arrived here today for the first high-level Soviet visit to this Communist country since the death of President Tito two years ago.

title: 3-SHOT TRIUPMH FOR MISS LITTLE
description: Sally Little rallied from five strokes back with a closing eight-under-par 64 today and won the $310,000 Nabisco-Dinah Shore women's golf tournament by three strokes.

title: CITIES FEAR COURT RULING MAY BRING FLOOD OF SUITS
description: City officials across the nation say a Supreme Court decision has made them vulnerable to antitrust lawsuits that could threaten their ability to govern.

title: OIL INDUSTRY FORTUNES FALTER
description: The oil industry has seen bad times before. In 1931, for instance, the price of a barrel of oil in East Texas had fallen to 10 cents, a nickel less than a bowl of chili.

title: LAUDA, DRIVING A McLEAREN, CAPTURES LONG BEACH GRAND PRIX
description: Niki Lauda, driving a McLaren, passed Andrea de Cesaris on the 15th lap today and pulled away to win the Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach, his first Formula One victory in nearly four years.

title: Bonn Invites Reagan To Address Parliament
description: President Reagan has been invited to address the West German Parliament when he visits Bonn in June, Government officials said today. If Mr. Reagan accepts, he would be the first American President to speak in the West German legislature.

title: Kimball Tells Mormons That 'All Is Well'
description: Spencer W. Kimball, the president of the Mormon Church, spoke briefly at the closing session of the church's 152d annual General Conference here today, telling members, ''The church is true and all is well.''

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: TV: TWO NEW CBS SITUATION COMDIES AND INSIDE NICARAGUA
description: ON top of the ratings heap, CBS-TV never stops trying to get better and better - or at least more and more -every day in every way. Tonight the William S. Paley network is introducing two situation comedies. One, ''Report to Murphy,'' finds its fun and games in a metropolitan parole office. The other, ''Making the Grade,'' goes to a contemporary ''Blackboard Jungle'' kind of high school and plays it for laughs.

title: RENEWING OLD TIES: PLEASURES AND PERILS
description: A ''nostalgia trip'' was the way one man described it: looking back on the romantic connections of long ago through the hazy glow of memory. Something as simple as an old snapshot, chanced upon when rummaging through the attic, may be enough to open the floodgates, sometimes mixing desire with memory.

title: IN BRITAIN, THE SPIRIT OF COLONIALISM LINGERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Eubie Blake Fete
description: He was born in Baltimore and he got his start in Baltimore, but there aren't many people left in Baltimore who remember James Hubert Blake as a piano-playing teen-ager at a local pool hall.

title: TWO DELL CO-PUBLISHERS ARE DROPPED
description: Doubleday & Company has notified Seymour Lawrence and Eleanor Friede, both of whom have longtime co-publishing contracts with the company's Dell subsidiary, that it will not renew their agreements when they expire April 30.

title: REAGAN AIDE DEFENDS RECORD IN HOUSE CIVIL RIGHTS HEARING
description: A Justice Department official vigorously defended the Reagan Administration's record on civil rights today in a Congressional forum that is dividing sharply on the issue on party lines.

title: Advertising; The Rome Report to Add Data
description: THE Rome Report of Business Publications Advertising, which comes out twice a year, lists the total pages of advertising run in 500 monthly periodicals and an estimate of their cost, and gives the percentage change from the corresponding period the year before for 45,000 advertisers. And it does that without any help from the individual publishers.

title: PIANO: LOIS SHAPIRO
description: LOIS SHAPIRO performed late sonatas of Beethoven and Schubert on her program at the Merkin Concert Hall Saturday evening, and gave the New York premiere of a work by the composer Arlene Zallman. After opening her piano recital with a sharply profiled account of Ravel's ''Valses Nobles et Sentimentales,'' one in which the piece's concluding pages seemed especially well thought-out, Miss Shapiro offered Schubert's opus posthumous Sonata in A (D. 959).

title: WOLF TRAP THEATER DESTROYED BY FIRE
description: Wolf Trap National Park's performing arts center was destroyed by fire Sunday night, and President Reagan, asserting that ''the show must go on,'' said today that he would do all he could to help rebuild it.

title: No Headline
description: Required Reading Coffee and National Security

title: AH, NOW FOR SOME JOY IN MUDVILLE
description: Baseball is not all physics. There's alchemy too. Before each game, the home plate umpire, behind the closed door of his dressing room, unpacks 72 baseballs and, with his hand, applies to the surface of each a mixture of either water or saliva and a heretofore mysterious substance known as ''Lena Blackburne Baseball Rubbing Mud.''

title: COURT TO RULE ON CLASS A ACTION DISPUTE
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to hear a case that could affect the future course of nationwide consumer class action lawsuits.

title: Davis Successor Named
description: Boston College named a successor yesterday to Tom Davis, its basketball coach who left last month to become the Stanford coach. The position went to Gary Williams, the coach at American University in Washington for the last four seasons, who was an Eagle assistant under Davis in the 1977-78 season and previously served six seasons as an assistant at Lafayette.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I think there has been quite a drumbeat of criticism that has gone largely unanswered by us with regard to some of the programs that I have advocated and, of course, there is the unhappiness that exists for all of us in the present recession.'' - President Reagan. (A8:3.)

title: Sears's Debt Grew in 1981
description: The long-term debt of Sears, Roebuck & Company increased to $5.32 billion at the end of 1981 from $2.97 billion a year earlier, primarily because of an eight-year, $2 billion revolving credit agreement, the retailer said in its annual report.

title: SCHLITZ ASKS COURT TO BLOCK STROH BID
description: The Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company asked a Federal judge today to block a $315 million takeover bid by the Stroh Brewery Company.

title: OLD ROCKET MAKING TOWN'S EYES SORE
description: This town of 600 people in the White Mountains recently held its annual town meeting and tried to thrash out the thorniest issue it has faced in recent memory.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: L.I. Hospital Strike Ends in Settlement
description: Unionized employees at the Long Island Jewish-Hillside Medical Center voted today to end their 27-day strike over the hospital's refusal to recognize District 1199 of the National Union of Hospital and Health Care Employees as bargaining agent for 80 nurses.

title: Second Seagram Post For Miss Cunningham
description: Over the past year, Mary E. Cunningham, a vice president at Joseph E. Seagram & Sons Inc., has been seen at vineyards from the Napa Valley to Bordeaux. When she joined Seagram in 1981, after leaving the Bendix Corporation, she was named vice president for planning and project development and given responsibility for developing a wine-products strategy.

title: Getty Interest
description: The Getty Oil Company said that its Getty Scientific Development Company unit had acquired a 20 percent interest in Synergen Associates Inc., a privately held Boulder, Colo., concern specializing in genetic engineering research. Terms were not disclosed. Getty said that it had also agreed with Synergen on a joint venture to develop microbiological methods to enhance oil recovery.

title: Swiss Say 2 Soviet Diplomats Have Left After Spy Charges
description: Two Soviet diplomats accused of spying have left Switzerland, the Swiss Justice Ministry said today.

title: SCIENCE LIBRARY
description: The Rhythms of Life Edward S. Ayensu and Philip Whitfield, editors. 199 pages, illustrated. Crown Publishers, $35.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate payable by savings institutions. Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Output of Steel Down by 4.7%
description: Steel production fell to 1.675 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, a decrease of 4.7 percent from the previous week's 1.757 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: Penney Rating Raised
description: Moody's Investors Service said yesterday that it had raised the commercial paper rating on the J.C. Penney Financial Corporation to P-1 from P-2.

title: RESENTMENT OF JAPANESE IS GROWING, POLL SHOWS
description: In a reversal of a postwar trend, resentment of the Japanese appears to be growing among Americans. Interviews last week in several communities around the country and a new poll of public opinion commissioned by NHK, the Japanese television network, indicate that there is still a deep reservoir of admiration in this country for the Japanese people as well as respect for Japan's industrial prowess.

title: Grain and Soybeans Up On Falkland Conflict
description: Grain and soybean futures prices advanced on a broad front yesterday as a British naval force sailed toward the Falkland Islands, a British colony that has been occupied by Argentina.

title: ISLANDERS QUIETLY CONFIDENT FOR PLAYOFFS
description: Undeniably the favorite among the 16 clubs that have qualified for the National Hockey League playoffs, which start tomorrow, the Islanders won more games, scored more goals and totaled more points than any edition of the club in the 10-year history of the franchise.

title: HAIG MEETS WITH PEKING OFFICIALS TO DISCUSS ARMS SALES TO TAIWAN
description: In an effort to avoid a deterioration in Chinese-American relations, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. called in the Chinese Ambassador today to urge Peking to accept an American proposal for dealing with the issue of American military sales to Taiwan.

title: Warning by Yamani
description: The world could soon face another energy crisis if oil-consuming nations continued to use their oil stocks at the current estimated rate of about 4 million barrels daily, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, Saudi Arabia's oil minister, said here today. Oil consumption in non-Communist countries in the first quarter of 1982 averaged 47 million barrels a day, Shiek Yamani estimated in a speech to the German Foreign Policy Association. Production averaged 43 million barrels daily, he added, with the difference coming from inventories.

title: 3 in Family Killed In Syracuse Fire
description: Three members of a family were killed today in a fire that raced through their home on Syracuse's southwest side.

title: SETON HALL NAMES CARLESIMO
description: In a move that surprised some and disappointed others, Seton Hall University today named Peter J. Carlesimo its head basketball coach.

title: Miss Redgrave Threatens to Sue
description: Vanessa Redgrave said the Boston Symphony Orchestra should not bow to the pressure of threats by canceling her scheduled performance with the orchestra.

title: Study Sees Aging Population Reducing Productivity Level
description: Production will drop in many industrialized countries after the turn of the century because of accelerating growth in the number of old people, the International Labor Organization predicted today.

title: China Reports Holding Talks With Mongolia on Boundaries
description: China and Mongolia have been holding border talks, the New China News Agency disclosed today. The press agency said a joint boundary inspection commission held its first session in Ulan Bator, the capital of Mongolia, from Feb. 18 to April 3.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bow Valley Industries Ltd., Calgary, Alberta, has appointed G.J. Maier president and chief operating officer.

title: Ashkenazy Stake In Thrift Concern
description: Severyn Ashkenazy, a Los Angeles investor, notified the Securities and Exchange Commission that he owned 9.9 percent of the capital stock of Financial Federation Inc., a holding company for 11 savings and loan associations with headquarters in Los Angeles.

title: KOCH EXPECTED TO CONTROL PARTY DESIGNATION
description: Although his gubernatorial candidacy is less than two months old, Mayor Koch has quickly won so much support among Democratic Party leaders that, barring unforeseen events, he will control the designating meeting of the Democratic State Committee in June.

title: Briefing
description: To Temperance!

title: BABY FORMULA RULES ISSUED
description: The Food and Drug Administration today ordered the infant-formula industry to run frequent tests on the nutritional quality of its products. It said the tests must be made during the manufacturing process and during shelf life to ensure that adequate nutrients are provided.

title: The Taste of Leaves
description: It may sometimes seem that leaf-eating caterpillars attack a tree much as Sherman's army marched through Georgia, destroying everything in their path. But scientists have recently discovered that some caterpillars seem to be finicky eaters and will travel relatively long distances on a tree, sampling as many as 100 leaves before they find one tasty enough to devour.

title: Q&A
description: Q. If, as Science Times said on March 17, the length of day and night can be calculated ''fairly simply'' for any place on earth, please give the formula.

title: U.S. CEASES APPEAL FOR HINCKLEY NOTES, ENDING TRIAL DELAYS
description: The Justice Department said today that it would not seek a Supreme Court review of a ruling barring the use of disputed evidence against John W. Hinckley Jr., who is charged with attempting to assassinate President Reagan.

title: RECORD $3.1 BILLION LOST IN 2D HALF AT THRIFT UNITS
description: The losses of the approximately 3,200 federally insured savings and loan associations reached a record $3.1 billion in the July-December period - more than twice the old record of $1.5 billion set in the first half of the year - the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, which regulates federally chartered savings and loans, reported today.

title: Suit Blaming Tampons For Death Goes to Court
description: Four men and four women were chosen today in Federal court to hear the first suit against the Procter & Gamble Company charging that a woman who used Rely tampons died of toxic shock syndrome.

title: U.S. ATTORNEY IN SAN DIEGO DISMISSED
description: President Reagan today dismissed William H. Kennedy, the United States Attorney in San Diego, for publicly confirming the identity of a key American intelligence source who is the subject of a Federal grand jury investigation.

title: Net May Fall At Goodyear
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company expects a 25 percent drop in first-quarter earnings because of the recession, Charles J. Pilliod, chairman, said today. In the period a year earlier the company netted $43.1 million on sales of $2.2 billion.

title: ARGENTINA SEEKS HEMISPHERE SUPPORT ON FALKLANDS
description: Argentina's Foreign Minister called on nations of the hemisphere today to support what he depicted as a battle against British colonialism in the Falkland Islands, which Argentina seized on Friday.

title: McDonald & Little Ends Ralston Assignments
description: The most interesting thing about the resignation by McDonald & Little, Atlanta, of its three cereal assignments from Ralston Purina last week - with more than $12 million in billings - is that there seems to be no reason for the step. William M. Claggett, vice president, advertising and marketing services at Ralston, said he thought the agency was doing a super job.

title: BACKWARD STEP ON VOTING RIGHTS
description: To the Editor:

title: 'GOLDEN PARACHUTE' FOR OUSTED
description: It's becoming an all-too-familiar saga. The grapevine began to hum last year that the Superior Oil Company was a ripe takeover target. After management began, as one official put it, ''to see its name in print,'' a concerned Superior board approved ''special termination agreements'' sheltering all present and future officers of the company. If outsiders came in, any executive who was shown the door or quit would be consoled with two years' pay.

title: Wickes Sells Part Of Its Golf Unit
description: The Wickes Companies, which has been divesting subsidiaries to raise cash for working capital and to pay off a reported $600 million in loans, has sold a controlling interest in the MacGregor Golf Company to a private investment group headed by Jack Nicklaus, the professional golfer, for $17 million.

title: Chess: Mobility Is Often the Key To the Exchange Sacrifice
description: How much is offered in a positional exchange sacrifice? Usually it will not be attempted unless one gets a pawn in addition to the minor piece for the rook, so the resulting material unbalance will be quite small.

title: WEINBERGER TRIPS ABROAD SET A RECORD
description: When Caspar W. Weinberger flew into Washington at 5:30 Sunday morning, he earned a place in the World Book of Records as the Secretary of Defense who had taken the most foreign trips in his first 14 months in office.

title: Testing Political Waters, 2 Years Ahead
description: It may seem a bit early to start campaigning for the 1984 Presidential election, but don't tell that to Reubin Askew.

title: THE NEW 'DUTCH' REAGAN
description: Just two weeks after his complaint that the press paid too much attention to the unemployed in ''South Succotash,'' President Reagan revived his old radio skills and broadcast a defense of his economic program.

title: Head of Rohr Sees Role as 'Rebuilder'
description: Harry W. Todd is the fifth man in six years to tackle the post of chairman and chief executive of troubled Rohr Industries, a maker of aviation equipment. Profits have been on the rebound, but with cancellations for new aircraft abundant in the foundering airline industry, running Rohr is not expected to become any easier.

title: ANTIMISSILE GROUP IN BONN IS DIVIDED
description: A major rift concerning possible Communist influence developed today among groups opposing NATO's plan for deploying new nuclear missiles in Western Europe.

title: CITY SHOWS ITS DESIGN FOR CENTRAL PARK ZOO
description: The Parks Department made public yesterday its model of the $15 million renovation of the Central Park Zoo - a radical redesign of the present red-brick zoo with its tiny, cell-like cages and limited outdoor spaces.

title: THEATER: 'CATHOLIC GIRLS'
description: THIS year in the theater it has been open season on nuns, priests and Catholic education, with Father Tim Farley proving that the subject has ''Mass Appeal'' and ''Agnes of God'' filling in what ''Sister Mary Ignatius'' failed to explain. Casey Kurtti's ''Catholic School Girls,'' which is at the new Douglas Fairbanks Theater on West 42d Street, is last and, very definitely, least.

title: MAZZILLI IS GIVEN NO. 2 BATTING SLOT
description: With a Mets T-shirt under his sky-blue Ranger uniform, Lee Mazzilli stood alone by the batting cage at Yankee Stadium yesterday watching his new teammates take their practice swings and whispering over and over to himself that ''things will work out, things will work out.''

title: Canada Urges Withdrawal
description: Canada has banned military shipments to Argentina because of its seizure of the Falkland Islands and told Buenos Aires that its forces should be withdrawn immediately, External Affairs Minister Mark MacGuigan said today.

title: Baldrige Sees Company Woes
description: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige predicted today that ''one or two'' major corporations will go bankrupt.

title: LLOYDS BANK LEASES SEAPORT TOWER
description: Lloyds Bank International yesterday signed a multimillion-dollar long-term lease at One Seaport Plaza, the office tower that is to be built at the South Street Seaport. The agreement, city and seaport officials, said, assured completion of the seaport restoration, a complex of shops and restaurants.

title: EDUCATION
description: DR. HARRY LUSTIG, a physicist, is Dean for Science in the College of Liberal Arts and Science at the City College of the City University of New York, a position he has held since 1972. He is also chairman of the educational advisory committee of the New York Academy of Sciences. In this interview with Gene I. Maeroff, an education writer for The New York Times, Dr. Lustig discusses the problems in science and mathematics education and talks of the need for solutions that recognize the interlocking nature of elementary, secondary and higher education. Dr. Lustig was first asked to elaborate on his views, previously expressed, that the science and mathematics teachers entering the profession are at the lower end of the intellectual scale.

title: Search for Woman Called Off at Pond
description: A weekend search of Walden Pond and the surrounding woods near Concord, Mass., for a New Jersey woman missing since last Nov. 28 was called off Sunday after no trace of the woman, Joan Webster, was found.

title: A PEOPLE IMPATIENT WITH ARMS CONTROLLERS
description: To the Editor:

title: MAYOR RECOMMENED THE REMOVAL OF KHEEL
description: Mayor Koch acknowledged yesterday that he had recommended to transit officials that Theodore W. Kheel be removed as the arbitrator in labor disputes affecting the city's subway and bus workers. However, the Mayor rejected Mr. Kheel's assertion that this constituted ''tampering with a quasi-judicial process.''

title: GAZA ATTACK RAISES FEARS OF REPRISAL IN BEIRUT
description: A left-wing Palestinian guerrilla group took responsibility today for a grenade attack against an Israeli patrol in the occupied town of Gaza Sunday, prompting new fears that Israel would carry out a retaliatory raid on Palestinian positions in Lebanon.

title: Market Place; Undervalued RCA Divisions
description: THE RCA Corporation has been active and strong in the last two trading sessions, leading to speculation that a predator could be stalking one of America's most celebrated companies.

title: BRIEFING
description: Political Supermarket

title: REAGAN OPTIMISTIC THAT BUDGET TALKS WILL END IMPASSE
description: President Reagan and Speaker of the House Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. expressed optimism today that the stalemate on the budget for the fiscal year 1983 could be resolved through direct negotiations between the White House and Congressional leaders.

title: Backing for Phelps
description: Muddy Waters, the Michigan State football coach, says he knows of serious recruiting violations, including one school's offer of $6,000 to a player who Waters says spurned the offer and decided to play for the Spartans. Waters made the comments at a news conference called to discuss spring practice and the 1982 season.

title: German Jobless Drop
description: West German unemployment dropped by 123,900, to 1,811,400, or 7.6 percent of the work force, in March, the federal Labor Office said today. The equivalent February figures were 1,935,300 unemployed, a rate of 8.1 percent. The rate in March 1981 was 5.2 percent.

title: SNOW MAY DISRUPT OPENER FOR YANKEES
description: After working in the sunshine longer than any other team, the Yankees are in New York and ready to play. But in the snow? A threat of six or more inches of snow forecast for today placed the Yankees' season opener with Texas in jeopardy. The game, with Ron Guidry set to pitch against Frank Tanana, is scheduled for 2 P.M. at Yankee Stadium.

title: Frank Rising, a Consultant On Labor-Industry Relations
description: Frank W. Rising, a retired labor-management expert, died March 31 in Appleton, Wis., where he had moved last year to be near his daughter. He was 79 years old and had resided for many years in Birmingham, Mich., a Detroit suburb.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: THE free-swimming fashion sharks were everywhere in the fashion sea l ast week, and all of them wanted to know the same thing. How did G iorgio Armani manage to win the cover of Time magazine's April 5 i ssue, and how did Time manage to photograph Mr. Armani's fall c ollection when, at the end of January, he had banned the press from s eeing anything until after April 1? And was it all, some asked, f inally worth it?

title: MASS TRANSIT, NOT WESTWAY, IS THE NEW YORK CITY PRIORITY
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 BRITONS RECOUNT FALL OF FALKLANDS
description: With evident pride and regret only that more resistance was not shown, the ousted British Governor of the Falkland Islands and the commanders of Royal Marines there described today a three-and-a-half-hour battle against Argentine invaders.

title: Harvester Canada Plans Layoffs
description: International Harvester Canada Ltd., a unit of the International Harvester Company, will lay off 80 percent of its 1,800 workers and suspend operations at its agricultural equipment plant here for four months beginning May 31, a company spokesman said.

title: TUESDAY, APRIL 6, 1982; Companies
description: New car sales by the Big Three auto makers rose 26.8 percent in the last 10-day selling period of March, the companies reported. G.M.'s sales rose 53 percent and Ford's 3.2 percent, while Chrysler's fell 7.3 percent. (Page D1.)

title: PANEL URGES ELIMINATING FORMAL TUITION AT CITY U.
description: The elimination of formal tuition at the City University of New York was proposed yesterday by the Committee for Public Higher Education.

title: MEMBER OF TAXI COMMISSION IS INDICTED IN EXTORTION CASE
description: A member of the city's Taxi and Limousine Commission was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of extorting $1,400 from a Police Department detective who had posed as a businessman.

title: Pimlico Investigating Mixup of Two Horses
description: Investigators at Pimlico Race Course refused to comment today on a disclosure that a $12,500 horse had been entered as a $4,000 runner in a race last week.

title: Rozelle Spends 3d Day On Stand at Raider Trial
description: Commissioner Pete Rozelle of the National Football League, testified today that Georgia Frontiere, the Los Angeles Rams' owner, objected to the Oakland Raiders' proposed move to southern California only because the Raiders had not followed league rules.

title: Schmidt Has A Broken Toe
description: Mike Schmidt, the National League's most valuable player the last two seasons, has a fractured toe on his left foot but is expected to be in the starting lineup Tuesday night for the Philadelphia Phillies' season opener against the New York Mets.

title: AVALANCHE VICTIM IS RESCUED
description: A ski-lift operator buried under tons of snow for five days in an avalanche at the Alpine Meadows ski resort was found alive and conscious today. Soon afterward, the body of a seventh avalanche victim was recovered.

title: FALKLAND ISLANDERS' FUTURE
description: The sun has set, the cliche goes, on yet another corner of the British Empire, with Argentina's seizure of the Falkland islands, home to a community of hardworking Britishers for longer than Texas and California have been home to Americans. Of all the claims made by Argentina, none can be more cynical than its pledge to ''guarantee the individual rights'' of the Falklanders whose homeland it has invaded.

title: Delay Sought In I.B.M. Case
description: The Justice Department asked a Federal judge today to delay for one month his hearing into the Government's dismissal of its antitrust suit against the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: GROMYKO, IN 2 DAYS OF TALKS WITH YUGOSLAVS, FINDS RELATIONS GOOD
description: The Soviet Union and Yugoslavia ended two days of talks here today. Yugoslav officials said the two sides had agreed that relations were good but that constant efforts were needed to keep them that way.

title: RECESSION IS LINKED TO FAR REACHING PSYCHOLOGICAL HARM
description: RUMORS fly: An office staff is about to be cut; maybe a plant is closing. Fear spreads throughout the company, accompanied by depression and self-doubt - typical signs of what has come to be known as ''the pink slip syndrome.''

title: Comings and Goings
description: Bjorn Borg, playing in his first tournament after a five-month layoff, defeated Fernando Luna of Spain, 6-4, 6-3, in the first round of the Monte Carlo Grand Prix tennis tournament. ... Phil Sykes, a left wing for North Dakota's national college championship team, signed with the Los Angeles Kings. Sykes, who scored 98 goals in 161 games and was named the most valuable player in the recent N.C.A.A. tournament, was a free agent. ... The shortstop Freddie Patek, a 14-year major league veteran and twice a member of the American League all-star team, was cut by the California Angels. The Angels also released two relievers, Bill Castro and John D'Acquisto, and placed Bill Travers, a left-handed pitcher, on the disabled list. ... Ralph Sampson of Virginia received another honor when he became the first non-senior to win the six-year-old John Wooden Award, given to the athlete designated by the Los Angeles Athletic Club as the college basketball player of the year. ... Bobby Orr, the former Boston Bruin superstar, was among five men designated for entry into Canada's sports Hall of Fame in August.

title: 1,800 Hostages
description: The Empire Needs an Umpire What an odd juxtaposition: a British nuclear fleet has now set off for the far South Atlantic, to avenge an insult to 1,800 British shepherds and fishermen. And what a lesson in the occasional futility of modern armament. Once this menacing armada arrives, what precisely is it to do? Blast the Falklands, and the Falklanders, into smithereens? Fortunately, the stately timetable of naval deployment gives diplomacy a chance. Almost certainly, that diplomacy will have to start in Washington.

title: Loan for Colombia
description: The World Bank said today that it would lend $152.3 million to support a highway construction project in Colombia. The 17-year loan, guaranteed by Colombia, has a 4-year grace period. It will bear an annual interest rate of 11.6 percent, plus a yearly commitment charge of three-quarters of 1 percent on undisbursed balances.

title: Bridge: 4 Grand National Winners Meet in Semifinals in May
description: Four top-ranked teams qualified Sunday for the semifinals of the New York Grand National Team Championship at the New York Hilton Hotel. They must wait seven weeks for further progress, however.

title: Officials Cite Problems In 1980 Census Count
description: The 1980 census did not account for millions of illegal aliens and was afflicted with the same problems of including black people that led to court challenges in the past, officials said today.

title: JUDGE ASSAILS 'SPECULATION'
description: The case of Luis Marin, who is accused of intentionally setting the fire at the Stouffer's Inn that killed 26 business executives, went to the jury today.

title: FLORENCE LE BOUTILLIER
description: Florence Higby LeBoutillier, a charity fund sponsor who had been chairman of campaign drives for the Young Women's Christian Association, died Friday at the Putnam Weaver Nursing Home in Greenwich, Conn.

title: BRIEFING
description: Surprise Programming

title: Saudi Income From Oil Up
description: Saudi Arabia's oil export revenues rose 20 percent last year, to an estimated $101.2 billion, after an increase of 75 percent, to $84.5 billion, the year before, the Saudi Arabian Monetary Agency said today.

title: CITY NAMES MAIN BUILDERS IN TIMES SQ. REDEVELOPMENT
description: Four, and possibly five, major developers have been chosen by New York City and the State Urban Development Corporation as the primary builders for the Times Square redevelopment plan, according to a senior official in the Koch administration.

title: ALBERT NORRIS
description: Albert Norris, who taught Robert F. and Edward M. Kennedy in his 43-year teaching career at Milton Academy, died Wednesday of a heart attack at his winter home in Tampa, Fla.

title: ZACHRY TO FACE PHILLIES
description: The Mets worked out in sunny but cold Shea Stadium yesterday and prepared to open the season tonight in Philadelphia against the twin threats of snow and Steve Carlton.

title: POSSIBLE SALE OF WAIKIKI BEACH SITE REKINDLES RESENTMENT AGAINST U.S.
description: To understand the uproar when the news was reported here in February, imagine that the Federal Government has suddenly asked developers to bid on Central Park, which, let's imagine, the

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Michiko Kakutani A GOOD MAN IN AFRICA. By William Boyd. 342 pages. William Morrow and Company Inc. $14.50.

title: Storer Loan Pact
description: The Storer Broadcasting Company said it had completed a $460 million financing program with the signing of a $325 million revolving credit and term loans arranged through a consortium of 13 banks with the Chase Manhattan Bank as the agent. In February, Storer announced the signing of a $125 million, 10-year term loan with two banks and in January signed a $10 million, three-year loan with another bank. Storer, based in North Miami, Fla., operates television and cable systems.

title: AN INVINCIBLE SAILED OFF IN '74
description: The departure of the light aircraft carrier H.M.S. Invincible from Portsmouth today contrasts strongly with the sailing of a warship of the same name toward the Falkland Islands in 1914.

title: Victoria Demarest, 93, Evangelist and Author
description: The Rev. Victoria Booth Demarest, an evangelist, writer and member of the founding family of the Salvation Army, died Sunday of heart failure at St. Anthony's Hospital in St. Petersburg, Fla. She was 93 years old and lived in St. Petersburg.

title: ATOMIC UNIT REVISED REPORT AFTER REVIEW BY COMPANY
description: Officials of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission altered the conclusions of a safety investigation into a Vermont-based pump company after reviewing a draft of their report with company representatives, according to agency documents and company and commission officials.

title: SOME HISTORY FOR HAIG
description: Alexander M. Haig Jr., a former general now acting as Secretary of State, may know a great deal about military strategy but he doesn't seem to know - or care - much about history.

title: Dow Falls 3.24; Volume Slips
description: Precious-metal issues returned to favor yesterday as stock prices generally eased in moderate trading. After advancing 20 1/2 points last week, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 3.24 points, to 835.33. Volume contracted to 46.9 million shares, as institutional investors cut back their activity. The turnover on Friday, when stocks were climbing, totaled 59.8 million.

title: Magazines for Industry May Be Up for Sale
description: There was a report abroad yesterday that Harcourt Brace Jovanovich is negotiating to buy Don Gussow's Magazines for Industry, with the exception of Glass Industry magazine, which a book publisher is looking to acquire.

title: 7th DEATH IN DESERT EXERCISE
description: A marine participating in the Mojave Desert war games was killed and another injured when a truck overturned at Twnetynine Palms, raising to seven the number of servicemen who have died in the exercise, officials said today.

title: Polish Leader Assures Czechoslovakia on Ties
description: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, assured Czechoslovakia on a visit here today that Poland was once again firmly in the Soviet bloc after the suppression of the Solidarity labor movement.

title: ABBOTT CASE EXPLORING ISSUE OF PROFIT FROM CRIME
description: More than two months after Jack Henry Abbott was convicted of manslaughter in the stabbing of an aspiring actor, Richard Adan, important questions in the case are unresolved.

title: 16 Writers Will Get Arts-Academy Awards
description: The American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters has named 16 writers who will receive awards in literature at the organization's annual ceremonial May 19.

title: DANCE: OBERLIN TROUPE DISPLAYS ITS NEW PIECES
description: THE Oberlin Dance Collective from San Francisco comes to New York with a reputation as one of the leading dance troupes outside the city in the ''postmodern'' genre of experimental dance.

title: WRONGED STATE CONVICTS' HIGH COURT REMEDY
description: To the Editor:

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: HAMILTON, Bermuda
description: A QUIET revolution has begun to reverse the decline of the urban public schools. After more than a decade of plummeting reading scores, alarming truancy and dropout rates, and chaos in classrooms, achievements have begun to climb and discipline is no longer a dirty word.

title: PANEL SAYS NEW YORK STATE FAILED TO CURB REFINER'S WASTE DUMPING
description: New York State failed for two years to curb adequately the dumping and transporting of hazardous wastes by a company believed to have engaged in improper activities, according to a report by a State Senate committee.

title: JUSTICES RESTRICT BIAS CHALLENGES IN SENIORITY SUITS
description: The Supreme Court today made it more difficult to challenge the fairness of seniority systems that have been in place since the Civil Rights Act of 1964 outlawed employment discrimination based on race or sex.

title: SOVIET FOREIGN MINISTRY NOW SAYS BREZHNEV IS ON A WINTER VACATION
description: After a week of unofficial reports that Leonid I. Brezhnev had been hospitalized, the Foreign Ministry's press department called Western news agencies here today with a statement saying that the 75-year-old Soviet leader was on a ''routine winter vacation.''

title: ARGENTINE ACTIVISTS CALL A BRIEF TRUCE
description: Opposition leaders say that although they support the military Government's seizure of the Falkland Islands, their discontent with the junta has not been reduced.

title: REAGAN PROPOSES BREZHNEV JOIN HIM AT THE U.N. IN JUNE
description: President Reagan announced plans today to address a United Nations disarmament conference in New York in June and urged Leonid I. Brezhnev to do the same, setting up an opportunity for the two leaders to meet.

title: JAPANESE-U.S. LOAN PROPOSAL DISCUSSED
description: Zentaro Kosaka, a former Foreign Minister of Japan, said yesterday that any Japanese program to give American businesses access to lowcost money would be a commercial venture and not an aid program.

title: Clabir's 30.5% Of Tandycrafts
description: The Clabir Corporation, a major defense contractor, disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had acquired 30.5 percent of Tandycrafts Inc.'s 3.7 million common shares outstanding and may decide to seek control.

title: Petro-Lewis Seeks Limited Partners
description: The Petro-Lewis Corporation filed with the Securities and Exchange commission for a $1 billion offering of limited partnership interests in certain properties that it had previously acquired from the Hunt family and the Placid Oil Company.

title: STOCKS FALL, POUND DIPS IN LONDON
description: London's financial markets were shaken today by Britain's dispute with Argentina over the Falkland Islands. The London stock market lost more than $4.42 billion in share values, its heaviest one-day loss this year, and The Financial Times Index of 30 leading industrial shares plunged as much as 16.4 points during the day, recovering later to close down 11.1 points, at 559.9.

title: LEAN LINES, LONG AND SHORT
description: The Milan collections for fall and winter were ebullient, as usual, but seemed to be going off in a million directions. London was more laid back and consequently seemed more relevant. Paris was easier to take than usual, the clothes being shown in pleasanter surroundings, but the collections seemed interminable and only one designer, Karl Lagerfeld of Chloe, made any kind of definitive statement that might change the course of fashion in the latter part of this year.

title: Aide Reports Reagan Wrote to 1,000 in '81
description: Presidents get more mail than they can answer, and President Reagan makes a point of personally answering at least 30 letters a week, the head of White House correspondence said today.

title: The U.N. Today; April 6, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee on Enhancing the Effectiveness of the Principle of Nonuse of Force in International Relations - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: U.S.-Soviet Grain Talks
description: American and Soviet officials are talking of holding a meeting to assess grain trade between the two nations, Agriculture Secretary John R. Block said today. The present American-Soviet grain agreement provides for such meetings twice a year - in the spring and in the fall.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF SESSION ON FOREIGN AND U.S. MATTERS
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's news conference in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News.

title: RECITAL: JOSEPH GRADO, TENOR
description: fidelity electronics, sang an all-Italian program in Carnegie Hall Sunday evening, offering songs by Tosti and Cardillo and selections from operas of Verdi, Puccini, Leoncavallo, Cilea and Giordano.

title: CUT OF 1,600 JOBS SOUGHT AT THE NEWS
description: The man who wants to buy The Daily News told leaders of the newspaper's unions yesterday that they would have to give up 1,600 jobs - about a third of the payroll - and accept a wage freeze and a five-year, no-strike contract.

title: BRITAIN DISCLOSES A PROPOSAL FOR ELECTED ULSTER ASSEMBLY
description: The British Government today disclosed a plan for a consultative assembly in Northern Ireland that officials hope will be the first step toward renewed local rule.

title: OFFICIAL IN TEL AVIV THREATENS ACTION AGAINST THE P.L.O. BASES ON LEBANON
description: Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir, speaking at the funeral of an Israeli diplomat slain two days ago in Paris, said today that Israeli forces would strike ''without reservation, without end'' at bases and headquarters of the Palestine Liberation Organization in Lebanon and elsewhere.

title: OIL POTENTIAL IS MINIMIZED AS ISSUE IN FALKLANDS FIGHT
description: Despite years of talk about the oil potential of the Falkland Islands and acrimonious discussions between Britain and Argentina over oil-drilling policy, Government and industry experts tend to minimize the significance of petroleum in explaining Argentina's seizure of the rocky cluster of islands.

title: TV: 'MEDAL OF HONOR RAG' A VETERAN'S PROBLEMS
description: TOM COLE'S ''Medal of Honor Rag,'' tonight's ''American Playhouse'' presentation on WNET-TV at 9 o'clock, was inspired by a true story. Dwight Johnson grew up in a Detroit slum. He was an altar boy. He was gentle, witty and easygoing. Serving in Vietnam, he went berserk and killed several enemy soldiers after discovering the deaths of his buddies in a tank from which he had just been transferred. Back home, he became a hero, complete with a Medal of Honor, but readjusting to normal life proved impossible. He was killed in what apparently was his first attempt at a store holdup.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bank Securities Inc. said it had signed a definitive agreement with Southwest National Corp. to buy Southwest National Bank of Albuquerque for cash and notes totaling $15 million.

title: 3 Players Get Probation
description: Three University of Kansas football players were placed on five years of probation each today for their pleas of no contest to burglary and theft charges.

title: OFFER FOUGHT
description: Conrad M. Black, the multimillionaire Canadian entrepreneur, and his brother, G. Montegu Black, moved yesterday to take control of the beleaguered Hanna Mining Company of Cleveland.

title: CUBS AND ORIOLES WIN
description: Bump Wills and Keith Moreland, both in their first year with the Cubs, hit home runs yesterday to carry Chicago to a rain-shortened 3-2 victory over the Cincinnati Reds in the National League opener.

title: Quakes Hit Central Greece
description: Two moderate earthquakes shook central Greece today but caused no damage or casualties, the Athens Seismological Institute said.

title: SAM COSLOW, 79, SONGWRITER
description: Sam Coslow, a composer, lyricist and publisher who wrote such hits as ''Cocktails for Two'' and ''My Old Flame,'' both with Arthur Johnston, died Friday in Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 79 years old.

title: British Subjects in Argentina Advised by London to Leave
description: The British Government broadcast a radio message tonight advising British subjects to leave Argentina because of the crisis over the Falkland Islands.

title: TV BOYCOTTS (CONT.)
description: Once again, the Coalition for Better Television, the Rev. Donald Wildmon presiding, is calling for a boycott -this time of NBC-TV and its parent corporation, RCA - and once again, broadcasters are crying, Sin! What, precisely, is the sin that this fundamentalist Methodist minister from Tupelo, Miss., is committing when he asks that dislike-minded persons join in not buying the products or services of a conglomerate that he believes excludes ''Christian characters, Christian values, and Christian culture from their programing''?

title: Primaries Ordered Held On Schedule in Dallas
description: A three-judge panel decided today that primary elections will proceed on schedule May 1 in four Dallas County Congressional districts under a plan previously adopted by the panel but rejected by the United States Supreme Court.

title: Space Scientist Resigning
description: Bruce Murray, a space scientist, said Friday that he would step down this year as director of the Jet Propulsion Laboratory here, which handles United States satellite exploration of the planets. He has recently has been involved in guiding the laboratory through a financial crisis caused by cuts by the Federal Government in financing of deep-space exploration. No new director has been named.

title: 'A Good Man in Africa'
description: Morgan Leafy has problems. The First Secretary of the British Deputy Commission in the West African country of Kinjanja, he is being blackmailed by a local politician. His plans to rig the country's elections have somehow gone awry and a coup is slowly brewing. To make matters worse, his black mistress, Hazel, is cheating on him. The luscious Priscilla Fanshawe, daughter of his boss and object of his ambitious lusts, has just announced her engagement to his hated rival. And her father is threatening to dismiss him - unless Morgan can promptly dispose of a smelly corpse, which, according to local beliefs, must be left to rot under the hot African sun.

title: FEDERATED MERGES 2 STORE DIVISIONS
description: Federated Department Stores Inc., the nation's largest operator of department stores, said yesterday that it had merged two of its store divisions - Shillito's in Cincinnati and Rike's in Dayton, Ohio - to cut overhead and increase efficiency.

title: Rise in Soviet Money Supply Called Big
description: M-1, M-2, M-3 and M-anything else are all unknown in the Soviet Union, which does not publish money supply figures and, for that matter, has far different ideas from the West on what constitutes ''money'' anyway.

title: Reason to Cheer
description: When Mike Easler takes his position in left field this season at Three Rivers Stadium, he should have at least 100 fans behind him cheering him on. After all, he's paying their way in.

title: Short-Term Rates Decline
description: Short-term interest rates fell slightly yesterday, while yields on notes and bonds rose marginally. By the end of a very quiet trading session, the rates for outstanding three- and six-month bills had dropped by an eighth of a percentge point or more, to 13.03 percent and 12.92 percent, respectively. The bellwether issue for the long-term bond market, the 14 percent Treasury issue due in 2011, was offered late in the day at 102 14/32 to yield 13.65 percent, down in price by about half a point.

title: SEASON OPENS FOR THE FANS OF BALLISTIC PHYSICS
description: SAN FRANCISCO'S torrential rains delayed it for three days but had little else to do with a historic collision that was to take place in the late afternoon of Oct. 4, 1962, when a sphere approximately nine and one-fourth inches in circumference and possessing enormous kinetic energy came hurtling across the lower atmosphere within sight of 43,852 anxious people and directly toward a man who had spent most of his life as a keen student of the very phenomenon he was now so fearlessly observing.

title: HOUSE G.O.P. LOOKS TO YOUNG STARS
description: When House Republicans looked for new strength for their leadership team at the start of the 97th Congress, they rejected a veteran member as chairman of their Policy Committee and turned instead to Richard B. Cheney, a 41-year-old Representative from Wyoming who was just beginning his second term.

title: NEW CURBS ON TRIAL APPEALS CREATED
description: The Supreme Court today raised new barriers to Federal court suits by prisoners seeking to challenge aspects of their trials as unconstitutional.

title: WHERE MEDICAL CARE IS JUST CATCHING UP
description: To the Editor:

title: New Chief Takes Over At Magnuson Computer
description: Selling products that are compatible with computers of the International Business Machines Corporation is a precarious business, in which a company's fate depends as much on the giant of Armonk as on its own prowess.

title: Fed Weighs Shift on Data
description: Next Monday the Federal Reserve Board will consider several possible changes in its publication of money supply data, according to an agenda for the meeting released yesterday.

title: 11 Americans Killed In Crete Plane Crash
description: All 11 people aboard a United States Navy plane were killed when it crashed into a mountain range on this Greek island, the police said here today.

title: CARRINGTON RESIGNATION TEXT
description: Following is the text of Lord Carrington's letter of resignation as Foreign Secretary, which was sent to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher today and was made public by her office:

title: Comic Dancers Stay On
description: The Bowyer & Bruggeman American Ballet Comedie has extended its engagement at the Space at the City Center.

title: Premium Time on Rikers Island
description: ''I've learned to laugh at their ingeniousness,'' a guard at New York's jail on Rikers Island said recently about the inmates he supervises. But one current form of inmate ingenuity isn't funny; it uses a progressive measure concerning prisoners' rights to tie up the courts and crowd city jails.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BARD IN NEW YORK

title: Edwards Says 'Bad Oil' Could Be in Reserve
description: Up to nine million barrels of low-grade ''bad oil'' could have been pumped into the multibillion-dollar Strategic Petroleum Reserve, the nation's stockpile of crude oil, Secretary of Energy James B. Edwards said today.

title: AFRICAN PARLEY DISRUPTED BY A DISPUTE OVER SAHARA GUERRILLA GROUP
description: Morocco and eight other African countries boycotted a meeting of Organization of African Unity labor ministers here today to protest the presence of a delegation from the Polisario Front guerrilla movement, which is battling Morocco's control of Western Sahara.

title: Business and the Law; Insurance For Past Risks
description: POPULAR wisdom aside, there are times when it does make sense to lock the barn door after the horse is gone. Take the case of a motor oil manufacturer whose product, instead of protecting engines, damages them. The harm is already done, and the manufacturer is faced with a lot of $800 to $1,200 claims. But with a little luck, he can still buy an insurance policy to cover the claims - even though the damage has already occurred.

title: Sports of The Times; Sore Arms and Cold Hands
description: OVER the telephone, the Weather Bureau voice warned of ''winter storm watches'' in the New York area late last night and today. As much as three to six inches of snow were forecast, threatening the Yankees' season opener today against the Texas Rangers at the Stadium, where the venerable clubhouse man, Pete Sheehy, couldn't remember a game ever having been snowed out. But it has snowed at other baseball games in other cities, as several Yankees recalled, some sadly.

title: CBS Wants Cleanup
description: TV is considering an embargo of bouts falling under the jurisdiction of the World Boxing Association, according to Mort Sharnik, boxing consultant for the network.

title: RECITAL: SHLOMO MINTZ, VIOLIN, WITH PAUL OSTROVSKY, PIANO
description: SHLOMO Mintz was at the top of the billing for Sunday's Great Performers concert in Alice Tully Hall, but this was at all times a collaborative effort - Mr. Mintz's exceptional talent as a violinist matched equally by the talents of his pianist, Paul Ostrovsky. Indeed, it was Mr. Ostrovsky's fierce concentration and sense of architecture that gave Beethoven's ''Kreutzer'' Sonata its dramatic underpinning.

title: RANGERS PICK MIO TO FACE FLYERS
description: Ed Mio, who was the third-string goaltender for the Wichita Wind four months ago, is to start in goal for the Rangers tomorrow against the Philadelphia Flyers in the first game of the Stanley Cup playoffs at Madison Square Garden.

title: Two Soviet Diplomats Detained in Bangladesh
description: Two attaches of the Soviet Embassy here were arrested last week while attempting to burn 588 rolls of movie film, according to sources close to Bangladesh security agents.

title: UMPIRES APPROVE CONTRACT
description: Eight hours before they were to yell, ''Play ball,'' major league umpires approved a four-year contract yesterday that will enrich them by an average of 40 percent this year and that should also free the 1982 baseball season of labor troubles.

title: BARBED WIRE CARVES UP TOWN ON GAZA-SINAI LINE
description: Occupied Gaza Strip, March 31 - A chain-link fence, seven feet high and topped by barbed wire, is being erected through the center of this dusty town of 60,000 Palestinian Arabs. It slices across streets, cuts through yards and winds among houses, separating merchants from their markets, farmers from their crops, fathers from their sons.

title: ARSON SUSPECTED AS WOMAN DIES IN BROOKLYN FIRE
description: An elderly woman was killed and eight people were injured in a three-alarm fire that broke out early yesterday in a Lebanese restaurant in Brooklyn and swept through apartments on the floors above.

title: Qaddafi to Visit Greece
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya will make an official visit to Greece soon to discuss relations, a Greek Government spokesman said today. Government sources said Colonel Qaddafi was expected to urge Greece's withdrawal from NATO and the closing of United States bases and to offer Greece investments and a greater share of building industry contracts in Libya.

title: A TIME FOR RELIGION
description: Spring has always been a good time of year in the religious goods business. Churches buy new altar linens to spruce up for Easter, parents and grandparents purchase communion veils and confirmation gifts and families buy Haggadahs and seder plates for Passover.

title: T.W.A. Gets a New Contract With Ogilvy
description: Yes, said William E. Phillips, chairman of Ogilvy & Mather, Trans World Airlines, its client in the financially troubled airline industry, did ask for and get a renegotiated contract with the agency.

title: NEW YORK THREATENED AS SNOWSTORMS BATTER NORTH
description: Winter returned with a vengeance to the northern half of the nation yesterday, packing snows more than 10 inches deep and dropping temperatures from the Rockies to the Middle Atlantic states.

title: STATE APPEALS COURT UPHOLDS EVICTION AT RENT-STRUCK LOFTS
description: The state's highest court has refused to review a lower court decision upholding the eviction of tenants who had been on a rent strike for five years in two buildings in lower Manhattan that had been converted illegally to loft apartments.

title: A.&P. CALLS PENSION SUIT SETTLED
description: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company said yesterday that it had agreed in principle to settle a class action lawsuit brought against its plan to terminate the company's pension program, which had been overfunded by about $250 million.

title: LED NAVY IN CUBAN BLOCKADE
description: Adm. Alfred G. Ward of the Navy, retired, former commander of the Second Fleet and chief of the naval task force in the United States blockade of Cuba in 1962, died Saturday at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Perry Point, Md. He was 73 years old and lived in Severna Park, Md.

title: World Bank Projects
description: The International Development Association will extend credits worth $14 million and $5 million, respectively, for projects in Haiti and the Dominican Republic, the World Bank said today. The bank said the credits, which will be used for road maintenance projects in both countries, will be made in special drawing rights.

title: Columbia U. Trustees Choose a New Chairman
description: Samuel L. Higginbottom was elected chairman of the trustees of Columbia University yesterday, succeeding Arthur B. Krim. Mr. Higginbottom is chairman and president of Rolls-Royce Inc., the American branch of the British automobile concern. Mr. Krim, a lawyer and chairman of the Orion Pictures Corporation, has stepped down after five years as the trustees' chairman, having reached the mandatory retirement age of 72 this month. His successor was elected at the trustees' regular April meeting at Columbia.

title: The Political Toll
description: The rough and tumble of politics may have taken its toll of Boston's city clerk, Barry Hynes. The 47-year-old official, a city employee since 1963, has filed for a disability pension, asserting that he suffers from, among other things, ''nightmares relating to City Council meetings gone out of control.''

title: John G. Peterson, 91; Ex-Chairman of Cargill Inc.
description: John G. Peterson, retired chairman of the board of Cargill Inc., died Sunday at his home here.

title: CONDE NAST ACQUIRES THE TATLER
description: Conde Nast Publications Ltd. today announced the purchase of The Tatler, a British monthly magazine devoted to social news, the arts, features and fashion.

title: LATE-NIGHT NBC NEWSCAST IS SCHEDULED TO BEGIN JULY 5
description: Following the lead of CBS and ABC, NBC has announced plans to introduce a late-night news program this year. ''NBC News Overnight'' will be broadcast after ''Late Night With David Letterman,'' from 1:30 to 2:20 A.M. weekdays and 2 to 3 A.M. Saturdays.

title: MILO O'SHEA: HE OFFERS HIS ACTING AS A PRAYER
description: THE interview was ending and Milo O'Shea looked relieved. ''You know, I'm not comfortable giving interviews,'' he confided as he helped a visitor with her coat in his dressing room. ''I've had interesting roles, but I don't really think I'm that interesting.''

title: STRONGEST MAN SAYS HE'S JUST ORDINARY
description: Anatoly Pisarenko walked onto the stage for the last and most dramatic attempt of the day's weight-lifting competition. His narrow eyes were intense, and he gritted his teeth as he approached the bar that weighed 569 3/4 pounds.

title: Greek President Visits Rome
description: President Constantine Caramanlis of Greece flew into Rome today for a three-day official visit and a meeting with Pope John Paul II.

title: THE TYCOONS' TAX REVOLT
description: Though the dreaded tax deadline is upon us again and the national mood is grim, there is a bright spot in New York. A spark that strikes hope in all of us - as we try to outwit the collectors. A tax revolt that worked.

title: Al Hirschfeld to Get an Elusive Honor
description: He's had one-man shows at several art galleries, and his drawings have appeared in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Museum of Modern Art, the St. Louis Museum of Art, the Cleveland Museum of Art and the Fogg Museum in Boston.

title: B.P. OIL'S LOSS IN '81 WIDENED
description: The B.P. Oil Group, the refining and marketing branch of the British Petroleum Company in Britain and Ireland, announced in London yesterday that a worldwide drop in demand for oil had caused the group to lose $224.3 million in 1981, more than three times the $67.6 million deficit registered in 1980. B.P. Oil also cited a gasolinestation price war among Britain's major oil companies.

title: NUCLEAR TESTING MOVES AHEAD AT YUCCA FLAT AMID QUESTIONS RAISED BY FREEZE
description: MOVEMENT By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD YUCCA FLAT, Nev. OUT among the mesquite, yucca and Joshua trees, here and there on the vast arid landscape, drilling rigs go about their business of penetrating hundreds and thousands of feet into the desert basin. They are opening more holes into which more nuclear weapons will be deposited and then exploded in the continuing effort to understand and advance this awesome technology.

title: Openings
description: April is when blustery, bitter weather is supposed to give way to blossoms and baseball. There's not much yet in the way of blossoms.

title: Traffic Tie-Up In Brooklyn
description: An accident on the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway last evening caused rush-hour traffic to back up where the highway merges with the Gowanus Expressway, the police reported. They said the snarl was caused when a piece of heavy machinery fell off a northbound flatbed trailer just north of the junction at about 4:40 P.M. Two of the three northbound lanes were blocked while emergency crews dismantled the machinery into three pieces. No injuries were reported.

title: AMERICAN'S VENTURE IN SWEATERS BUOYS ICELANDIC EXPORTS
description: There are moments that change a man's life. For Tom Holton, a son of California, the first came when he espied Hanna Johannsdottir, a beautiful Icelandic woman, on the ski slopes near Lake Tahoe, Nev., in 1956.

title: Pabst Reports Profit in Period
description: The Pabst Brewing Company said today that it had a profitable first quarter, with a net income of $1.6 million, or 19 cents a share, compared with a loss of $1.8 million in the same period a year ago. Sales were down.

title: Plane Hijacked to Cuba Returns Safely to Miami
description: A Delta Air Lines jet returned here safely today after being forced to Havana by three men who doused the plane and a stewardess with gasoline.

title: Profit Ratio Fell in Period
description: Manufacturers' after-tax profits averaged 4.3 cents for each dollar in sales in the fourth quarter of 1981, down four-tenths of a cent from the previous quarter and from the similar quarter a year earlier, the Federal Trade Commission reported today.

title: North Carolina Is No.1 In Weekly Lacrosse Poll
description: North Carolina retained its hold on the No.1 spot, and Massachusetts moved into the top 10 Sunday in the United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association weekly coaches' poll.

title: CANOE EXCURSION ON HUDSON ENDS IN DEATH OF 3 BOYS, WITH 4TH LOST
description: Four teen-agers set off on a canoe trip late Sunday in the wind-whipped waters of the Hudson River, pushing off from a lonely pier in this Rockland County community. Today two died after rescue divers found them alive but unconcious. A third was found dead, and the police were searching for the fourth.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on March 31 about Mayor Koch's retreat in his drive to cut tax exemptions in- correctly described the view of Linda Nealon, counsel to the city's Tax Com- mission. She said that a review of non- profit groups had added $97 million to the assessed value of taxable property in the last decade.

title: Kurt Waldheim to Teach at Georgetown
description: Kurt Waldheim, who recently completed a decade as Secretary General of the United Nations, has been appointed distinguished university research professor of diplomacy at Georgetown University in Washington.

title: LITTLE DREXLER SETS DATA STORAGE PACE
description: When Jerome Drexler looks into the burnished surface of a card, disk or tape coated with a material he invented and named Drexon, he sees the dim but unmistakable image of an entrepeneur who believes he has discovered what it takes to cut a billion-dollar swath through the information storage industry.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, APRIL 6, 1982
description: International Britain's Foreign Secretary resigned because of what he said was the ''humiliating affront'' of Argentina's seizure of the Falkland Islands last week. The resignations of Lord Carrington and two of his principal assistants were announced as a large part of the British fleet was on its way to the South Atlantic. Lord Carrington will be replaced by Francis Pym, the Conservative leader in the House of Commons. (Page A1, Column 6.) President Reagan will address a disarmament conference at the United Nations in New York in June, and he urged Leonid I. Brezhnev to do the same to provide an opportunity for them to meet. Mr. Reagan indicated that he was not necessarily proposing ''a full-blown summit conference'' but made a point of saying at least twice, ''I think it would be well if he and I had a talk.'' (A1:3.)

title: REAGAN TELLS OF PLAN TO OPEN U.S. LANDS FOR MINERALS SEARCH
description: President Reagan, expressing concern about the nation's dependence on foreign sources of strategic minerals, announced a new policy today to encourage the development of minerals on public lands.

title: Uranium Venture
description: A Tunisian Chemical Company, Ste Tunisienne des Industries Chimiques Maghrebines, and a French company, Uranium Pechiney Ugine Kuhlmann, a subsidiary of Pechiney Ugine Kuhlmann S.A., have agreed to form a joint venture to produce uranium at a plant to be built in Gabes, Tunisia, a spokesman for the French company said here today. The factory would produce 120 tons of uranium annually in 1985.

title: No Headline
description: An article yesterday on Egyptian relations with other Arab countries incorrectly identified the founding nations of the bloc that professes nonalignment. They are Egypt, India and Yugoslavia.

title: CUBAN CALLS FOR TALKS WITH THE U.S. AND ACCEPTS PART BLAME FOR STRAINS
description: A senior Cuban official said this weekend that ''until recently'' Cuba as well as the United States bore responsibility for the present atmosphere of confrontation, but that his Government was now ready for wide-ranging negotiations and agreements on ''mutual restraint'' with Washington.

title: Text of Carrington letter, page A6.
description: Lord Carrington, the British Foreign Secretary, resigned today because of what he called the ''humiliating affront'' of Argentina's seizure of the Falkland Islands.

title: AUTO SALES BY BIG 3 RISE 26.8%
description: New car sales by the nation's Big Three automobile makers rose 26.8 percent in late March, a rise attributed to consumers anticipating the end of rebate programs.

title: Pemex Loan Canceled
description: The $200 million, two-year Eurocredit for Petroleos Mexicanos, Mexico's state oil company, has been canceled, Banco Nacional de Mexico said here today. The bank, which had been the proposed lead manager, declined comment on why the loan for the oil company, known as Pemex, was dropped. Banking sources, however, said that Mexican finance officials acted to avoid a conflict in the market with the $1.2 billion credit for the National Development Bank, Nafinsa.

title: MAN OF HOUR IN ARGENTINA
description: As he stood on the balcony of the pink presidential palace, tens of thousands of delirious Argentines below chanted his name.

title: Exotic Wagering Bill
description: State Senator John R. Dunne filed a bill in Albany yesterday calling for the abolition of exacta and trifecta wagering at New York harness and thoroughbred tracks.''The continued existence of these forms of wagering jeopardize the very integrity of parimutuel betting,'' the Republican from Garden City, L.I., said.

title: THEATER: BLACK ANGUISH IN 'BROTHERS'
description: THE title characters of ''The Brothers,'' Kathleen Collins's memory drama, are black men who ''should have been born white'' because they ''spent their entire lives trying to jump out of their skins.'' One of them, an undertaker, won his way into political office during the Kennedy era. Another won medals at two Olympics before retiring to his bed at age 27 to begin ''rehearsing his death.'' Another lived the high life until he was caught with his ''hand in the till.''

title: Spinach Versus Zinc
description: Though spinach is a rich source of essential nutrients, especially vitamin A, potassium and iron, this highly touted vegetable also contains a substance called oxalic acid that is in effect an antinutrient. Oxalic acid combines with certain mineral nutrients, in particular calcium and zinc, and prevents their absorption by the body.

title: Niekro Out, Reluctantly
description: Phil Niekro, the Atlanta Braves' knuckleballer and a three-time 20-game winner, was placed on the disabled list with sore ribs and an inflamed Achilles' heel. The move was retroactive to March 31, which means Niekro will not be available until April 21. The 42-yearold right-hander has never been on the disabled list in 17 years with the Braves and did not want to go on it this time, saying doctors told him he could throw again on Thursday and would be able to pitch competitively in a week.

title: Ship's Officer Cleared In Death of Seaman in '81
description: Capt. Lee B. Cargill, the former executive officer of the Navy carrier Ranger, has been acquitted of dereliction of duty and violating orders in the death of a seaman last April 14.

title: American Greetings Net
description: The American Greetings Corporation reported today that it earned $32.8 million last year, up almost 24 percent from profit of $26.5 million the previous year.

title: REDEVELOPMENT IN TIMES SQ. UNLIKELY TILL '84
description: Construction work on the $1 billion redevelopment of Times Square and the West 42d Street area is unlikely to begin before 1984, the Urban Development Corporation, which will manage the project, said yesterday.

title: Waiting in the Wings
description: Last Aug. 29, Cornelius Boza-Edwards of England was scheduled to defend his World Boxing Council junior lightweight championship against Rafael (Bazooka) Limon of Mexico.

title: U.S. Crime Rate Stable, F.B.I. Figures Indicate
description: The United States crime rate leveled off in 1981, according to statistics released today by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: News Analysis
description: Three weeks ago, a civilian wrecking crew of about 40 Argentines landed on the British island of South Georgia to dismantle an abandoned whaling station and hoisted the Argentine flag. On Friday, thousands of Argentine soldiers invaded the British colony of the Falkland Islands, including South Georgia. Today they are digging in as half of the British Navy steams toward the islands.

title: BROWN, GULDEN DEPART YANKEES
description: The blizzard that buried Yankee Stadium beneath more than a foot of snow yesterday forced postponement of the season opener with Texas, but it did not render the Yankees completely idle.

title: Orthodox Girl's View
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: As an Orthodox Jewish girl, I would like to respond to the article ''Jewish Controversy Over Rite for Girls'' which appeared on March 24.
