title: BAPTISTS IN ETHIOPIA DEPRIVED OF CHURCHES
description: To the Editor:

title: Sam Solomon Co.
description: The Sam Solomon Company, a Charleston, S.C., catalogue showroom operator, said that it had agreed to be acquired by Service Merchandise Company in an exchange of stock. Service is the secondlargest catalogue showroom company after the Best Products Company. Solomon had operated under the Chapter 11 provisions of the Federal Bankruptcy Act until last May, when a bankruptcy court approved its debt settlement of $26 million.

title: DEVELOPER SAYS JOB IS EASIER IN U.S. THAN IN EUROPE
description: Few real estate projects in New York City these days can match the controversy generated by the proposed office development at the St. Bartholomew's Church site on Park Avenue. Opponents of the proposed 59-story office tower where the church's community house now stands have promised legal battles that could easily tie up the project for years.

title: Negotiator for Garden Meets With 16 Unions
description: Vincent D. McDonnell, the chief labor negotiator for Madison Square Garden, met for an hour and a half yesterday with the leaders of the 16 labor unions whose members work at the Garden.

title: 5,000 Believed Trapped In Mexican Eruption
description: Clouds of hot ash and debris kept American helicopter pilots from reaching thousands of villagers stranded today on the slopes of El Chinchonal.

title: A CLASH OF FUNCTIONS AT THE APPEALS COURT
description: To the Editor:

title: Ancient Colorado Ruins Are Given a Reprieve
description: The ruins of what archeologists say might have been the oldest structures in North America may be saved from destruction, Government officials say.

title: Home in Indiana
description: If viewers of the current and controversial Public Broadcasting Service series ''Middletown'' find the opening solo cello rendition of ''Back Home in Indiana'' particularly distinctive, there's a good reason for it.

title: Swimming to Record
description: Tracy Caulkins, a freshman at the University of Florida, has already won 35 national swimming titles, only one short of the record held by Johnny Weissmuller, and she is expected to add at least two during the United States short-course championships, which begin today at her home pool in Gainesville, Fla.

title: BEST BUYS
description: IN view of the snowstorm yesterday, it would seem appropriate to discuss chicken soup and rum toddies rather than new potatoes and asparagus. Although the storm has curtailed some arrivals, most fruit and spring vegetables are in plentiful supply.

title: Ortho to Market New Contraceptive
description: The Ortho Pharmaceutical Corporation has received approval from the Food and Drug Administration to market Ortho-Novum 10/11 tablets, the first two-phase oral contraceptive introduced in the United

title: TOUGH PLAYOFF FOR RANGERS AND ISLANDERS
description: The Rangers and the Philadelphia Flyers, who face each other tonight in the first game of their Stanley Cup playoff series, play distinctly different styles of hockey.

title: Borg Status Unresolved
description: The Men's Professional Tennis Council failed today to resolve the question whether Bjorn Borg would have to qualify for Wimbledon, the Grand Slam event he has won five times.

title: British Car Output Up
description: British car production in March rose to 99,000 from 98,000 a year ago and 88,000 in February, according to industry department figures released today.

title: Researchers Honored
description: Dr. Denis Parsons Burkitt and Dr. Michael Anthony Epstein, two British researchers whose work made it possible for scientists to identify the first virus regularly associated with human cancers, will receive the fifth annual Bristol-Myers Award for distinguished achievement in cancer research, it was announced in New York yesterday.

title: Lukens Profit Plunges
description: The Lukens Steel Company announced yesterday that net earnings in the first fiscal quarter of 1982 ended March 20 plunged 36.1 percent, to $958,000, or 18 cents a share, from $1.5 million, or 29 cents a share, in the corresponding fiscal quarter a year earlier. Sales fell 4.6 percent, to $87.1 million, from $91.3 million.

title: 6 Games Postponed; Red Sox in Florida
description: Haywood Sullivan, the executive vice president and general manager of the Boston Red Sox, ordered his team back to its spring training base in Winter Haven, Fla., yesterday after its game with the Chicago White Sox was snowed out in Chicago. A spring blizzard stretching from the Midwest to the Northeast forced the postponement of six games and sent several teams scrambling for alternate workout sites.

title: INTEREST RATES RISE SLIGHTLY
description: Interest rates rose slightly yesterday in light trading as securities dealers in New York and elsewhere closed shop early because of the blizzard.

title: Federal Banking Laws Are Assailed
description: Federal laws restricting interstate banking represent a regulatory intrusion upon the free workings of the marketplace and have prevented consumers from taking advantage of technological innovations in the industry, Attorney General William French Smith said today.

title: WINE TALK
description: Dr. Constantin Frank, wearing a blue suit with a vest, was grasping a bottle of wine and calling for a corkscrew as the dining room at Pierce's 1894 restaurant filled and the noise level rose. All around him were winemakers, restaurateurs and other oenophiles. As usual Dr. Frank was the center of attention.

title: Woolworth Unit Plans
description: F.W. Woolworth & Company Ltd., the British subsidiary of the United States retail chain, is considering the sale of up to 25 stores and an office building, the chairman, Geoffrey Rodgers, said in the annual report released here today.

title: Superintendent Slain At Apartment House
description: The superintendent of an East Side apartment building was shot to death yesterday in the building's lobby by a maintenance man he had dismissed the day before, the police reported.

title: Helen Dodson Hobbs Is Wed to S.T. McKnight 2d
description: Helen Dodson Hobbs, daughter of G. Dever Hobbs of Los Angeles, and Mrs. Dodson Hobbs of Wilmington, Del., was married yesterday to Sumner Thomas McKnight 2d, son of June H. McKnight of Monkton, Md., and the late Henry T. McKnight of Great Falls, Va., and Wayzata, Minn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Mark Harris at the Christ Episcopal Church, Christiana Hundred, in Greenville, Del.

title: 3-Year Pact for Bench
description: Johnny Bench, now the third baseman for the Cincinnati Reds, has signed a three-year contract with the team and vowed to stay with the Reds until he retires.

title: Military Analysis
description: The Royal Navy's task force assembling in the Atlantic west of Gibraltar has two options when it reaches the Falkland Islands - blockade or attack.

title: 0. Belts of Metal
description: One of the paradoxes of fashion these days is that although women have liberated themselves from constraining underpinnings like girdles, they are now squeezing themselves into waist-cinching belts of the sort Moll Flanders might have worn. Most of these are made of leather, but now a designer named Tess Shalom has come up with a rigid belt made entirely of metal. Miss Shalom's belt, cut from hammered brass, is three inches wide and fastens in front with hidden hardware ($125). The designer has also created less dramatic belts that are metal in front but are tied at the back with leather. Her collection, priced from $95 to $150, is in Saks Fifth Avenue's main-floor belt department.

title: SHAPED HISTORIC RULINGS ON RIGHTS
description: Former Associate Justice Abe Fortas, who resigned from the Supreme Court in 1969, died of a ruptured aorta Monday night at his home here.

title: LOANS TO POOR COUNTRIES MAY RISE $500 MILLION
description: The poorest countries may receive an additional $500 million this year in interest-free loans from the International Development Association, an affiliate of the World Bank, the bank reported today.

title: Allied Earnings
description: First-quarter earnings for the Allied Corporation are expected to be down ''substantially'' from last year's $2.33 a share, Edward L. Hennessy Jr., Allied's chairman, told analysts. He said the company was taking steps to cut costs, but did not consider it prudent to cut back spending necessary to finance long-term growth. He said the company would maintain its planned level of capital spending, which was previously announced as $700 million, up from $609 million last year.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bliss & Company, a new international investment banking partnership, will be headed by Richard M. Bliss, former chairman and chief executive officer of American Express International.

title: DICK COLMAN, FORMER COACH
description: Richard W. (Dick) Colman, who coached Princeton's football team to two Ivy League championships and a share of two others, died Monday at the age of 67. He suffered a heart attack in the field house at Middlebury (Vt.)

title: Bank in Iowa Reopened
description: The First National Bank of Humbolt, Iowa, which collapsed after an estimated $9 million in funds had been diverted in what the authorities charged was a stock promotion scheme by the son of its chairman, reopened as the Hawkeye Bank and Trust Company.

title: METROMEDIA IN UNUSUAL FINANCING
description: Metromedia, Inc., the nation's fourth-largest broadcast operation, yesterday announced an unusual plan to raise $450 million, some of which would be used in connection with its pending $220 million purchase of WCVB-TV in Boston.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Sohio Sets Capital Spending for '82
description: The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) has budgeted nearly $3 billion in capital spending for 1982, the company said in its annual report.

title: CAREY IS SEEKING MAJOR CHANGES ON MALPRACTICE
description: Governor Carey is proposing major changes in the state's medical malpractice insurance system, including the creation of a state fund to pay 90 percent of the cost of malpractice awards of between $250,000 and $1 million.

title: Snow Stops Effort To Find Canoeist
description: The search for one of four Rockland County boys whose canoeing adventure on the Hudson River Sunday turned into tragedy was postponed today because of the snow.

title: THE NATURAL PHENOMENON AS A PERSONAL AFFRONT
description: New Yorkers have a tendency to take everything personally, and that includes the weather. In other parts of the world, what took place yesterday would have been called a blizzard, but in New York City, it was characterized as divine retribution, poetic justice and just my luck.

title: 'Perks' Listed By Pennzoil
description: The Pennzoil Company, widely regarded as a takeover target before oil stocks fell out of favor, has granted its top executives not only accelerated severance pay in the event of takeover, but a wide variety of additional ''perks'' having nothing to do with a change in control, a complex proxy statement to stockholders shows.

title: Article 045862 -- No Title
description: A $1 million thoroughbred was killed and four other horses were injured in a barn fire at the Garden State Race Track Monday.

title: Bridge: Herman Filarski Was Star As a Player and Journalist
description: The world of international bridge lost one of its leading citizens last Saturday when Herman Filarski died in the Netherlands at the age of 69. Since World War II, when he learned the game in a German prison camp from which he later escaped, he had been outstanding as a player, a journalist and an administrator.

title: M-G-M MAY SELL VIDEO STOCK
description: The Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Film Company said yesterday that, effective Monday, it would change its name to the MGM/UA Entertainment Company and that it might soon sell stock in an offshoot of the company that is tentatively known as the MGM/UA Home Entertainment Group.

title: LAST BUDGET TALKS BEFORE EASTER RECESS END WITHOUT AN AGREEMENT
description: House Democratic leaders said today that ''everything'' was ''on the table for discussion'' this morning at the last budget meeting with White House aides before Congress's Easter recess.

title: Canada Trade Surplus
description: Canada's trade surplus fell to $951 million (Canadian) in February from a downward revised $1.24 billion surplus in January, Statistics Canada said today.

title: The U.N. Today; April 7, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee on Nonuse of Force in International Relations - 3 P.M.

title: INSURANCE ARRANGED FOR PETS
description: Pet health insurance is coming to New York. Starting April 27, the Frontier Insurance Company will offer dog and cat owners the opportunity to insure their household pets against accidents and illness.

title: ROBERT ALTMAN'S SATIRE 'HEALTH'
description: PICTURE the facade of a once-grand Florida hotel, the vaguely Spanish sort that went up in St. Petersburg in the 1920's - all pinkish plaster, tile roofs, balconies here and there, plus towers that look like an infidel's minarets. The hotel is by the sea, with a swimming pool for those who don't like sand between their toes. Affording minimal shade from the sun are tall, ancient royal palms, no longer in the peak of condition.

title: Stocks Up Moderately as Trading Slows
description: Stock prices rose moderately in slower trading yesterday, with some of the technology and energy issues registering the best gains. The Dow Jones industrial average, which moved in a narrow range throughout the day, closed up 4 points, to 839.33. In the overall market, advancing issues on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered declines by 807 to 603.

title: Hertz Eurobond
description: The Hertz Corporation, the car rental unit of the RCA Corporation, is raising a $50 million, seven-year Eurobond through joint lead managers Salomon Brothers and Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc., a Salomon spokesman said here today. The bond, raised through Hertz Capital, carries a 15 3/4 percent coupon and is priced at par. The bonds are callable at 101 from the fifth year and at 100.5 from the sixth year.

title: Schlitz Profit Up in Quarter
description: The Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company reported yesterday that net income in the first quarter of 1981 more than doubled, to $6.7 million, or 23 cents a share, from $3.1 million, or 11 cents a share, in the first quarter of 1980.

title: Market Place; Perini Urged To Revamp
description: THE Perini Corporation is like the national champion who fails to qualify for the Olympic Games. The fans expected so much more. Perini, a diversified construction company in Framingham, Mass., doubled its earnings in 1981 to $4.55 a share, up from $2.15. But earnings have been erratic over the years, and shareholders have grown impatient that Perini has not capitalized on its vast real estate holdings.

title: STORM CALLED ONLY SMALL THREAT TO BUDS AND MIGRATORY BIRDS
description: The lash of yesterday's blizzard left many gardeners and amateur ornithologists wondering how spring's early plants and the season's first flocks of migratory birds would fare in the snow, wind and cold.

title: DODGERS TOP GIANTS IN 9TH, 4-3
description: Dusty Baker singled with the bases loaded on Greg Minton's first pitch to him in the ninth inning, giving the World Series champion Los Angeles Dodgers a 4-3 victory today over the San Francisco Giants in the opening game for both teams.

title: HAROLD W. STOKE, COLLEGE PRESIDENT
description: Dr. Harold W. Stoke, an educator who served as the president of the University of New Hampshire, Louisiana State University and Queens College in New York, died last Tuesday in Seattle. He was 79 years old.

title: HOPEFUL REMEDIES FOR BREAST AILMENT
description: AS many as half of all women suffer at one time or another from painfully swollen, lumpy breasts, a frightening though noncancerous condition most commonly called cystic breast disease, fibrocystic disease and cystic mastitis. Although the condition is often temporary, disappearing after about three months, many women experience the discomfort and distressing lumps month after month, year after year.

title: PASTA MEASURE, CORER
description: Acouple of quite inexpensive kitchen utensils on the market may seem at first glance to be frivolous but are most useful. One is a plastic disk with holes for measuring the correct amount of spaghetti, a task in which it is easy to make mistakes. The other is a long stainless-steel corer for cucumbers, zucchini and apples; much more efficient than a serrated spoon or the more common short vegetable parer, it doubles as a corer and is excellent for making long holes for stuffing.

title: BRIEFING
description: Rank vs. Standing in Ranks

title: RARE APRIL BLIZZARD PUNISHES METROPOLITAN NEW YORK
description: An unseasonable blizzard whirled about a foot of snow and record cold yesterday into a metropolitan area long wearied of winter. The punishing storm, punctuated by thunder and high winds, bedeviled traffic on New York City streets and country roads, sent schoolchildren and office workers home early, canceled legislative sessions and elections and quite literally nipped spring in the bud.

title: Regan Defends Tax-Cut Plan
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan last night told a group of business executives that any cutback in President Reagan's basic program of tax relief would ''reduce consumer purchasing power'' and delay economic recovery.

title: HOUSE DELEGATION TO VISIT SALVADOR
description: The Reagan Administration has asked a Congressional delegation to go to Central America to assess the postelection situation in El Salvador and to discuss the Caribbean basin development plan with nations in the region.

title: METS SET TO TRY AGAIN
description: The Mets, snowbound in New York, did not even get out of the parking lot in Shea Stadium yesterday while the spring storm postponed their opening game in Philadelphia.

title: One More Time!
description: The lazy are congratulating themselves for not having removed their snow tires, the untidy for leaving their boots in the front hall. The child is making another snowman, the adult another hot toddy.

title: Advertising; Cable TV Sold Door To Door
description: GIVEN the high-technology, two-way cable world in which the people at Warner Amex operate, one might expect them to rely on a sophisticated electronic system when it comes to selling their services.

title: PROMINENT IMMIGRANTS HONORED AT A LUNCHEON
description: The 37 distinguished immigrants had all made it to the United States from such countries as the Soviet Union, Cambodia and Argentina, but more than one-third did not manage to get to the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel for lunch yesterday.

title: WHITE HOUSE HALTS ATTEMPTS TO SHIFT WELFARE TO STATES
description: After months of fitful negotiations with state and local officials, the Reagan Administration has suspended its effort to write legislation transferring welfare and food stamp programs to the states in exchange for a Federal assumption of all Medicaid costs. The transfer is at the heart of President Reagan's ''new federalism'' initiative.

title: FOR EASTER DINNER, FAMILY FAVORITES ARE THE ORDER OF THE DAY
description: EASTER, like other traditional holidays, is usually a time for taking out the old family recipe file and serving what everyone is expecting. For most people it is not a time of experimentation. This Sunday, three cooks who trace their roots back at least as far as the Civil War will be cooking what their families have always cooked on Easter Sunday.

title: BRITISH AND ARGENTINES WELCOME HELP BY U.S., WHITE HOUSE SAYS
description: A White House official said tonight that both Britain and Argentina were agreeable to the idea of talking to the United States about a peaceful solution to the Falkland Islands crisis.

title: Yanks' Opener Set Tomorrow
description: The Yankees have rescheduled their season opener against the Texas Rangers for tomorrow at Yankee Stadium at 2 P.M. Only tickets for yesterday's opener, which was postponed because of the blizzard, will be honored tomorrow.

title: Virgil Thomson Gives Papers to Music School
description: Virgil Thomson, music critic and the dean of American composers, has donated his collection of manuscripts, letters and scores to the University of Missouri-Kansas City Conservatory of Music.

title: EXPANDING THE FRONTIERS OF HOME COOKING
description: A tremendous change in American food tastes has taken place over the past 10 years, amounting to what I consider a gastronomic revolution. It can be seen in the proliferation of gourmet food and kitchen shops, the increase of fine cookbooks, the broadening interest in wine, the surge in the number of first-rate cooking schools, and perhaps most interestingly in the widening scope of what home cooks will tackle in their kitchens.

title: Japan Refuses Canada's Plea
description: Japan does not intend to lower its ceiling on auto exports to Canada during the fiscal year that began April 1, Shintaro Abe, the Minister of International Trade and Industry, said today.

title: PHILARMONIC: MEHTA LEADS CONCERT IN HARLEM
description: THE blizzard took its toll in attendance, but the music went on at Harlem's Abyssinian Baptist Church last night as Zubin Mehta and the New York Philharmonic crowded themselves, some high-powered soloists and a lengthy, gala-style program onto a makeshift stage built over the church's altar. The concert was the third the Philharmonic has given at the 175-year-old congregation, where the late Adam Clayton Powell Jr. was once pastor. The first was in April 1980.

title: SCHOOLTEACHERS FIND A PLACE IN THE ARCTIC
description: From time to time during the school year here, recess is canceled due to polar bears. The huge, powerful animals occasionally wander round town, attracted by the smells of food, dogs and people and by the sight of other creatures also trying to scratch out an existence on the barren tundra of Canada's northern Arcpic countryside.

title: LARGER THAN THE PIPELINE
description: The Reagan Administration ought to soft-pedal its opposition to the proposed Siberian natural-gas pipeline to Western Europe and to view the issue in larger terms.

title: Owners' Profit Motive Raised at Raider Trial
description: One reason the Oakland Raiders did not have a strong case for a move to Los Angeles was that it would ''probably be worth more to the league owners'' to start an expansion team there, Commissioner Pete Rozelle testified today.

title: An Ex-Newspaperman Returns to the Fold
description: Wallace E. Clayton is 61 now and for the last year has been retired from his public relations job with the J. Walter Thompson Company, which he pursued for 29 years, first in New York and then in Detroit. But he never forgot the job that came before the agency one, the job on the staff of The Washington Star.

title: MORE RESIGNATIONS ARE SOUGHT IN BRITAIN
description: Opposition members of Parliament called for more resignations today from the Cabinet of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher over its handling of the Falkland Islands crisis.

title: No Headline
description: The playoff schedule published yesterday for the Ranger-Flyer hockey series incorrectly listed the date of the second game. It will be played at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night.

title: News Analysis
description: Rear Adm. John F. Woodward, the 49-year-old commander of the British flotilla that is steaming south toward the Falkland Islands at 18 knots, has been given no specific orders. The reason is simple: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Government has not decided exactly what it wants the fleet to do. The force is carrying Harrier ''jump jets'' that could bomb Argentina, missiles for use in naval or aerial battles, torpedoes that could sink Argentine ships, amphibious vehicles for a landing in the islands and even 2,000 collapsible cots in case the 1,800 Falklanders are evacuated.

title: BID FOR NEW TRIAL OF SPY IS WEIGHED
description: The attorney for Andrew Daulton Lee, a convicted Soviet spy, said today that he was investigating the feasibility of seeking a new trial for Mr. Lee because of a disclosure that the Mexican official who questioned him after his arrest in 1977 had worked for the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Groundhog Sued
description: As everybody knows, if a groundhog comes out of his hole on Groundhog Day - Feb. 2 - and is not scared back inside by seeing its own shadow, it means there will be an early spring.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Nelson Skalbania, majority owner of the Montreal Alouettes, has issued a statement suggesting that the sale of the Canadian Football League club may be imminent.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: TOUGHER CHECKS URGED TO DETECT FAULTY JET ENGINE
description: Reacting to a series of problems involving the partial disintegration of General Electric jumbo-jet engines, the National Transportation Safety Board yesterday urged that the Government order shorter life spans and tougher interim inspections for the troublesome engine component involved.

title: TASK FORCE REPORTS 8% OF CITY YOUTHS ARE ILLITERATE
description: Nearly 8 percent of the 778,100 youths in New York City between the ages of 14 and 21, both in and out of school, cannot read above a fifth-grade level, according to a report recently issued by the Youth Literacy Task Force.

title: China and Mongolia Complete Border Talks
description: Chinese and Mongolian officials have just ended six weeks of talks on border problems, the first such meeting since the two countries agreed to such discussions in 1964, the New China News Agency reported today.

title: UNSEASONABLE DAY AT YANKEE STADIUM
description: At 6 o'clock yesterday morning, and at intervals through a day of driving snow that postponed opening day, Jimmy Esposito zipped his thin flannel jacket over a pair of sweaters, pulled his baseball cap down to his eyebrows and trekked out to the 3.5-acre playing field at Yankee Stadium to assess the blizzard's damage.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''You were concerned when you had 52 hostages; we have 2,000 hostages down there.

title: Doyle Dane Receives More Borden Business
description: Borden Inc., which returned to Doyle Dane Bernbach 18 months ago after an absence of almost a decade, has just given the agency an additional assignment.

title: Lindner's Hart Stake
description: The American Financial Corporation, which is controlled by Carl H. Lindner, the Cincinnati financier, has raised its stake in Hart, Schaffner & Marx to 9.9 percent, a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed yesterday. John M. Meinert, vice chairman of Hart, said Mr. Lindner had said the acquisition was for investment purposes and that he did not intend to buy more shares in the mens' wear manufacturer.

title: Polaroid Protests I.R.S. Adjustment
description: The Polaroid Corporation said the Internal Revenue Service is seeking $15 million plus interest in additional taxes for the years 1976 and 1977, after reallocating gross income Polaroid received from its foreign subsidiaries.

title: Sports of The Times; The Boys of Winter
description: HE was on the telephone by 10:30 yesterday morning, protesting what he saw and heard outside his window. Since the season ended last October, he had suffered through illness and slow recuperation, boredom and cold weather, just waiting for April 6, for opening day, for baseball.

title: AMERICAN MEDICAL PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including nonrecurring gains of $758,000 or 16 cents a shr for the qr and $688,000 or 15 cents a shr for the yr

title: 22 Appeal Sentences In Killing of Sadat
description: Defense lawyers have appealed the verdicts against all 22 Moslem fundamentalists convicted of complicity in assassinating President Anwar el-Sadat, court sources said today.

title: What's So Funny?
description: On television's ''Taxi,'' Andy Kaufman is the gentle mechanic Latka, an immigrant who speaks an indecipherable language. His offcamera comedy act, however, is a wildly different routine from his TV style, and includes sharp satirical thrusts at a number of targets.

title: The Reluctant Justice
description: ''I did not seek the post of Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States,'' Abe Fortas once testified. ''That was not part of my life plan. ... I dislike being in the position of rejecting a call by the President of the United States to public service. ... He, as is well known, insisted that I do this - that it was my duty to do it.''

title: TEN COMMANDMENTS
description: Do Not talk to Op- Erat- Or While bus is in motion. Signal for Stop. Use cen- Ter door For exit. Wait For light, then Push han- Dle. In emergency, pull pan- El in, Push win- Dow out. No Smo- King. Keep front platform clear. Move to the rear.

title: CALIFORNIA IS FORCED TO DELAY SPRING ATTACK ON FRUIT FLIES
description: Bad weather delayed California's spring offensive against the Mediterranean fruit fly this week, but agricultural officials said their helicopters would resume sorties against the tiny flies early next week.

title: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 7, 1982; The Snow
description: The blizzard led many businesses to shut down early throughout the metropolitan area. Three futures exchanges and a number of securities dealers closed at midday or not long after, although the stock exchanges and the Comex stayed open for a full day, as did many investment houses. Business was all but dead for most retailers, however, and in offices meetings were canceled, travel plans were scrapped and employees were sent home early. (Page A1.) International

title: Stouffer's Jurors Seek Clarifications
description: The jury in the Stouffer's Inn arson and murder trial returned to the courtroom five times today, its first full day of deliberations, to examine evidence, hear testimony read again and have the charges explained.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Citicorp said that an average rate of 14.541 percent was set at the weekly auction of its 91-day commercial paper, down from 14.637 percent last week.

title: CBS Defers Expansion Of News to One Hour
description: CBS announced yesterday that it was indefinitely deferring plans to expand its evening news program from 30 minutes to an hour by next year, apparently bowing to strong resistance from many of its affiliated stations.

title: Careers
description: IT pays for job seekers to be photogenic in these days of the video revolution. In February, for example, Pennsylvania State University announced a major effort for junior-year students in its business program to practice interviewing on videotape before going on job interviews in their senior year. Company recruiters conduct the simulated interviews and the prospective employers get an early look at promising candidates.

title: Oil Reserves Up in Canada
description: Reserves of conventional crude oil in the western provinces of Canada fell last year to about 5.5 billion barrels, equal to about 12 years' supply at current annual rates of consumption, the Canadian Petroleum Association said yesterday.

title: Business Week Seeking Advertisers by TV
description: Business Week magazine is going to be advertising for advertisers for the first time on television beginning tomorrow in New York, Chicago and Los Angeles.

title: BLIZZARD IN NORTHERN JERSEY PUTS OFF SCHOOL-BOARD VOTE
description: An April blizzard dumped up to a foot of snow across northern New Jersey today, crippling roads, forcing widespread school closings and prompting Governor Kean to declare a snow emergency in the state's 11 northernmost counties.

title: DON'T TIE UP BULLETPROOF VESTS WITH RED TAPE
description: To the Editor:

title: KENNEDY URGES END TO FEDERAL RESERVE AUTONOMY
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy urged today that the Federal Reserve Board be made a part of the Treasury Department so that the President had control of and responsibility for its credit policies and the ''soaring interest rates'' that the Senator said were crippling economic growth.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I am fond of most English cheeses and admire, in particular, a double Gloucester that I often use as a substitute in recipes calling for Cheddar cheese. I can't find out the difference between single Gloucester and double Gloucester. Can you also tell me about color of double Gloucester?

title: PAN AM GIVES DETAILS OF ITS CHAIRMAN'S PAY
description: While Pan American World Airways may be operating in the red, its directors have chosen not to be tight-fisted with the man they hope will lead the company to prosperity. When Charles Edward Acker, who was the chairman of Air Florida Inc., switched to the ailing Pan Am last September, he received a salary-and-bonus package that could top $1 million a year by 1985.

title: No Headline
description: The Editorial Notebook By Peter Passell Don't Sell I.R.A.'s Short

title: Student Charged in Slayings
description: A 25-year-old student has been charged with murder and kidnapping in a shooting Monday at Garland County Community College that killed an instructor and another student. Kelvin Love of Hot Springs is to be arraigned Thursday.

title: Michener's Households
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: James A. Michener's piece on having two households (''Denver to Delhi: A Writer's Moves,'' March 17) was thoroughly enjoyable, especially his bald admission of sexism, apparant in the statement that it is much easier for a husband to handle setting up a second home than it is for a wife. But in the next sentence, he goes on to say other than setting up his desk, his wife does all the dirty work of finding the grocery store, filling out forms, getting the water turned on.

title: Stroh Seeking Schlitz Proxies
description: The Stroh Brewery Company, the Detroit-based brewer that is pursuing a takeover of the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company, said it had begun soliciting proxies for the Schlitz annual meeting on April 27.

title: IN IRAN'S WAR, YOUTH AND ISLAM
description: A curious military force of professional soldiers, mullahs, neighborhood militiamen and schoolboys as young as 13, linked by an intense Islamic fervor, broke the long deadlock in the Persian Gulf war by routing entrenched Iraqi troops.

title: BRITAIN BIDS ALLIES PUNISH ARGENTINA
description: Britain asked its partners in the Common Market today to join in banning imports from Argentina, in halting arms sales and in withholding new credits to Argentina to protest the seizure of the Falkland Islands, according to diplomats.

title: Miss Navratilova Wins, Miss Goolagong Injured
description: Trailing by 4-5 in the opening set, Martina Navratilova ripped off nine games in a row and beat Yvonne Vermaak of South Africa, 7-5, 6-0, in the second round of the $200,000 Family Circle Cup tennis tournament today.

title: Ally of Burlington, Vt., Mayor Loses Bid for Chief Alderman
description: After five deadlocked ballots, three Democrats on the 12-member Board of Aldermen joined with five Republicans to elect the first Republican aldermanic president since 1956, defeating Mayor Bernard Sanders' choice for the post.

title: A NIGHT OF TRIBUTES AND A FASHION SHOW
description: FASHION people have a lot of parties. After all, they make the party clothes, and they love an excuse to dress up and see how everyone else is dressed. One of their biggest parties of the year is the Parsons Fashion Critics Awards Show, at which graduating seniors from the Parsons School of Design present a fashion show and get awards from professional designers who worked with them during the year as critics.

title: Brick Building Defies Demolition Attempts
description: Laborers may have done too good a job in the mid-1930's when they built a five-story brick storage facility on the waterfront.

title: RECORD SNOW IN CONNECTICUT HALTS COMMERCE AND TRAVEL
description: Virtually all commerce, government and travel ceased in Connecticut today under the assault of a record snowfall and gale-force winds.

title: Suit Seeks U.S. Release Of Funds for Energy Aid
description: In what they asserted to be the first ''clear'' case of Presidential budget impoundment since the Nixon era, a diverse coalition of members of Congress, individuals and interest groups sued the Reagan Administration today to force the release of $21.8 million to finance the Solar Energy and Energy Conservation Bank.

title: MERCANTILE GETS A NEW PRESIDENT
description: John Elting Treat's first official act as the new president of the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday was to close the exchange early, giving everyone a head start on getting home in the snow.

title: GEN. W.F. BREIDSTER
description: Maj. Gen. Waldemar Fritz Breidster, who was assigned to work with mainland Chinese military forces under Chiang Kai-shek in World War II, died Friday.

title: GRIFFIN BELL SAYS CARTER MADE A 'CRUCIAL ERROR'
description: Former Attorney General Griffin B. Bell's memoirs of the Carter Presidency are about to go to press, and, according to the galley proofs, Mr. Bell thinks Jimmy Carter made a ''crucial error'' by giving Walter F. Mondale, his Vice President, an office in the White House.

title: BALLET: PENNSYLVANIANS OPEN SEASON
description: THE Pennsylvania Ballet opened last night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music with a program entitled ''In Celebration of Women Choreographers'' that consisted nearly entirely of modern-dance works and a ballet of ''third-stream'' inspiration that fused the modern-dance and ballet idioms.

title: Indian Point 2 Back in Service
description: The Indian Point 2 power plant, which was shut down last week because of a pump malfunction in the nonnuclear section of the plant, was back in service today, its operator, the Consolidated Edison Company, reported.

title: BRITISH MARKETS IN TURMOIL
description: London's financial markets continued to reel today from Argentina's invasion of the Falkland Islands last Friday and the subsequent turmoil within the British Government.

title: Addendum
description: Money magazine increasing by 5.3 percent both its advertising rates and circulation base, to one million from 950,000, effective with the July issue.

title: Big Step Forward
description: Playing the sixth friend in a movie about five friends may not sound like a springboard to stardom, but Paul Reiser, who does just that in the new movie ''Diner,'' isn't complaining.

title: UNDER FIRE: A PROVEN, THRIFTY ALTERNATIVE TO ENTERPRISE
description: To the Editor:

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, APRIL 7, 1982
description: International A first nuclear strike by the U.S. will not be renounced by the Reagan Administration, nor will it agree to a freeze of nuclear weapons at present levels maintained by the United States and the Soviet Union, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said. Both positions are necessary to maintain a strong nuclear deterrent force for protecting ''the essential values of Western civilization,'' Mr. Haig said in a speech on nuclear arms policy at a meeting in Washington sponsored by Foreign Policy Association and Georgetown University's Center for Strategic and International Studies. (Page A1, Column 1.) Intense Islamic fervor has apparently given Iranian troops a sense of motiviation and morale that was an important factor in their recent victory that broke the long deadlock in the war with Iraq. The victorious force was made up of professional soldiers, mullahs, neighborhood militiamen and schoolboys as young as 13 years old. ''They ask for martyrdom,'' an officer said. (A1:3-4.)

title: Tooling Reported For G.M. 'N' Cars
description: The General Motors Corporation has begun ordering the tooling and equipment it needs to begin production of a new family of medium-size, front-wheel-drive cars in the 1985 model year, the trade journal American Metal Market reported.

title: GRAIN FARMERS LIKELY TO TRIM CROPS
description: With grain prices still at unprofitable levels and surpluses still crowding the grain elevators, many farmers expect to reduce their plantings in response to the Reagan Administration's program to cut back wheat and corn production.

title: No Headline
description: Transamerica The Transamerica Corporation, a diversified financial services concern based in San Francisco, said in papers filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it owns 24.15 percent of the Hershey Oil Corporation's common stock. The company, which announced its plans to make a $10 million investment earlier this year, said it does not intend to excercise control over the oil company, which is based in Los Angeles. Transamerica purchased 1.2 million shares for $9.9 million in open market transactions during the last two months.

title: THE SNOW BRINGS SKIDS AND SPILLS TO NEW YORK AREA
description: James Miller seemed to be doing something of a war dance in his driveway, kicking up the deepening snow with one foot and then the other, as if angry at the gods. ''I can't even find my newspaper,'' he snapped. ''This is ridiculous.''

title: REPAYMENT BY POLAND POSTPONED
description: Poland and the Western banks to which it owes money signed an agreement in Frankfurt today to delay repayment of $2.4 billion that Poland failed to pay the banks last year. Thus ended a months-long financial tug of war.

title: Misguided Aid for Autos
description: Congress is responding in the wrong way to this year's request from the auto industry - a plea for relief from the Clean Air Act. It has packaged the auto makers' wishes with those of other industries in a bill that environmental groups deride, with some reason, as a wholesale prescription for dirtying the air.

title: AMERICAN GREETINGS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
E.E.C. Seeks Trade Talks
description: The European Economic Community has asked for trade talks with the United States, Japan and Canada before the seven-nation economic summit meeting in June, officials of the community said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a transmission error, an article yesterday on a rocket installed in a New Hampshire community in- correctly identified the hometown of the astronaut Alan Shepard. It is Derry, N.H.

title: TV: MUDD AND BROKAW IN NEW RULES
description: While the network morning news shows continue down the low road of inane chatter and questionable features, the evening newscasts are evidently determined to keep their images on a serious, more dignified plane. NBC News introduced a new anchor team Monday evening and, happily, Roger Mudd and Tom Brokaw were not required to engage in bright banter with a genial weatherman.

title: Washington; 'A MATTER OF HONOR'; by James Reston
description: The British are not very good at holding their empire together, but at least their officials know what to do when they let the side down. They resign in style and retire to their houses in the country.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt IS THERE NO PLACE ON EARTH FOR ME? By Susan Sheehan. Foreword by Robert M. Coles, M.D. 333 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $14.95.

title: Mulvey Follows Code
description: Paul Mulvey says he is still bitter over his demotion to the minor leagues. But he also says he is still playing what he calls ''my bump-and-grind game,'' and will start the American Hockey League playoffs tonight in Rochester with a bruised right hand.

title: Failure to Communicate
description: Les Wallack has resigned as track coach at Rutgers Unviersity after 22 years because of what he called a breakdown in communications. Wallack's resignation came four days after about 60 members of the team boycotted a meet against Seton Hall and Columbia - six members did compete.

title: G.E. NET RISES 5% IN QUARTER; SALES OFF
description: The General Electric Company reported yesterday that the diversity of its product line helped lift net income in the first quarter of 1981 by 5 percent, although revenues slipped 1.2 percent.

title: CONCERT: ST. MATTHEW PASSION PERFORMED BY MUSICA SACRA
description: IT is always a privilege to hear Bach's St. Matthew Passion, but Monday night in Avery Fisher Hall, hearing Richard Westenburg conduct the Musica Sacra chorus and orchestra in the three-and-a-half hour work was something of an honor.

title: Hail Hits Raisin Grapes
description: A weekend hail storm may have ruined 15 to 30 percent of the 1982 raisin grape crop, industry officials said here today. All of the nation's raisin grapes are grown within 35 miles of Fresno. Clyde Nef of the Federal Raisin Administrative Committee estimated the damage at $65 million.

title: Effect of Thyroid Pills
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: In general I admire the common sense of the personal health reports of Jane Brody. However, in the report of March 17 there is a confusing misperception in the case of ''Bob.''

title: IS MOSCOW REDUCING ASSISTANCE TO CUBA?
description: Evidence is mounting that the Soviet Union, which is limited in its ability to extend largess, may be slowing the rate of increase of its economic aid to Cuba.

title: Ford Rebate Plans Extended to June 6
description: The Ford Motor Company, falling into line with the other three domestic auto makers, announced today that it had extended its rebate and two-year free maintenance programs until June 6 and expanded the promotions to include mid-size cars and some trucks.

title: 2 HOFSTRA STUDENTS FILE SUIT OVER U.S. CUTBACKS IN LOANS
description: Two Hofstra University law students filed a class-action suit yesterday on behalf of all current recipients of guaranteed student loans who are adversely affected by Federal cutbacks.

title: Car Sales in Japan Up
description: Japan's domestic sales of passenger cars, trucks and buses reached a record monthly high in March, totaling 529,950 units, up 6.5 percent from a year earlier, the Japan Automobile Dealers Association said today. The association attributed the sharp increase to major passenger car sales campaigns and remodeling. Sales of trucks and buses declined.

title: Gas Imports By Europe
description: A Government-controlled natural gas company forecast today that Western Europe would have to import 47 percent of its gas supplies by 2000, compared with 14 percent in 1980.

title: Text of speech, page A8.
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that the Reagan Administration, determined to maintain a nuclear deterrent to protect ''the essential values of Western civilization,'' would neither renounce a first use of nuclear weapons nor agree to a freeze at present levels.

title: HAIG'S SPEECH ON AMERICAN NUCLEAR STRATEGY AND THE ROLE OF ARMS CONTROL
description: Following is the text of a speech delivered at the International Club by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. before Georgetown University's Center for Strategic and International Studies and made public by the State Department:

title: THE POP LIFE
description: POP history was made recently when the Go-Go's ''Beauty and the Beat'' (I.R.S. SP 70021) became the first No. 1 album ever by a band of women who write their own songs and play their own instruments. Founded in Los Angeles four years ago by the lead vocalist Belinda Carlisle and the rhythm guitarist Jane Wiedlin, the quintet recorded their debut album last spring, and it took more than six months to climb to No. 1, spurred by the success of the hit single ''Our Lips Are Sealed.'' Now, with another single, ''We Got the Beat,'' near the top, and album sales approaching two million, the Go-Go's are the hottest new act in rock-and-roll.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: IN French kitchens the word ''supreme'' has many meanings. One of its primary meanings is to indicate the breast -the choicest part - of poultry, principally chicken. It is also the name of a delicate, subtly seasoned cream sauce using chicken broth as a base.

title: GOLD'S ADVANCE BOLSTERS PRECIOUS METALS FUTURES
description: Prices of precious metals futures continued to advance yesterday behind the strength in the global gold bullion market. Brokers said the buying, much of it from European brokerage houses, easily swept aside periodic bouts of profit taking by American traders, which tended to cause wide price swings during the session.

title: E.E.C. Trade Move
description: The European Economic Community Commission decided today to seek action to curb sales of corn gluten feed from America, in a move that could spark renewed trade tensions, diplomats said. United States sales of the feed to the 10-nation Economic Community amount to about $540 million dollars annually.

title: Nuclear Panel Admits It Mishandled Inquiry
description: Top officials of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission admitted today that they had mishandled an investigation of a Vermont company that makes pumps for nuclear power plants, but they said that no disciplinary action was planned.

title: Knicks Defeated
description: Eddie Johnson, who had 32 points, hit two free throws with four seconds left to give the Atlanta Hawks a 106-104 National Basketball Association victory over the Knicks tonight.

title: Increase in Fighting In Afghanistan Reported
description: The arrival of warm weather appears to have touched off an increase in fighting between Government forces and insurgents in Afghanistan, a diplomatic report from Kabul said today.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: JAZZ HONORS

title: MET OPERA: 'PARSIFAL,' WITH HOFFMANN IN LEAD
description: RICHARD WAGNER'S aim in life was to establish a new religion in which he would serve simultaneously as messiah, pope, chief prophet and court musician. ''Parsifal,'' a summation of these megalomaniacal dreams, is built on a shaky foundation of legends and symbols drawn from Christian and pre-Christian mythology that defies close analysis either as religion or cultural anthropology. It is as if someone were to snip out pages of ''The Golden Bough'' at random and paste them up as an opera libretto. Nevertheless, in a good performance of ''Parsifal,'' Wagner's last opera, inconsistencies and contradictions can evaporate for long stretches of time under the spell of its ruminative music. There are gray-headed citizens who claim to have experienced a ''Parsifal'' or two that transfixed and hypnotized them throughout.

title: WHY THE JAPANESE OUT-TRADE AMERICANS
description: T o the Editor: Ezra Vogel's Op-Ed piece on March 9 (''Japan's 'Concessions' Are Backfiring Badly'') misses the root of the U.S.-Japanese trade problem. True, Japan should remove many non-tariff barriers which now plague those who would sell to Japan, but even with the removal of such barriers the trade imbalance would not be righted.

title: REAGAN RIF EFFECT PUTS BOSSES IN TYPING POOLS
description: When James McHugh typed up a batch of letters the other day, his boss sent them back. ''They were red-penciled,'' said Mr. McHugh unhappily. ''I had to do them over again.'' As a secretary, Mr. McHugh, who once directed a staff of 10 people and administered $27 million in Federal grants, does not know his carbon paper from his Ko-Rec-Type. Yet the Federal Government is paying him $46,000 a year to type.

title: STATE AGENCY BACKS COMPLETION OF WORK FOR 9-MILE PT. PLANT
description: The State Power Commission formally voted today to allow completion of the Nine Mile Point 2 nuclear power plant and approved a plan to penalize the utilities involved for future cost overruns.

title: Dr. Henry Bockus, 86; Led in a Medical Field
description: Dr. Henry L. Bockus, who helped develop gastroenterology as a medical subspecialty, died Saturday at Graduate Hospital of injuries suffered when he was hit by a truck Friday, a spokesman said Monday.

title: HARVESTER: THE CRISIS GROWS
description: For more than two years now, International Harvester has gone from crisis to crisis, publicly playing down the seriousness of each setback and predicting that recovery was only a few months away.

title: KOCH'S BUDGET EXPECTED TO INCLUDE POLICE HIRING
description: Mayor Koch's new budget is expected to include money to replace 1,244 uniformed police officers whose jobs were originally supposed to be left unfilled as they resigned or retired over the next 15 months, New York City officials said yesterday.

title: Tentative Pact Reached In Queens Bus Dispute
description: The Transport Workers Union and four private bus companies in Queens reached a tentative settlement on a new contract last night, according to Walter L. Eisenberg, the contract mediator.

title: Economic Scene; Negotiating On the Budget
description: IT looks as though the impasse between President Reagan and Congress over the fiscal year 1983 budget is soon to be broken. Mr. Reagan and House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. have said that a ''summit'' conference on the budget is in the offing.

title: WAITING FOR H-HOUR; by Russell Baker
description: The last briefing began at midnight. Apparently it will be very bad when we hit the beach. Worse as the day progresses. Our first assault force goes in one hour before dawn. It consists of highly mobile minicam crews, sound men, still photographers, veteran war correspondents and relatives of publishers and network executives who are to get first crack at the island's limited hotel facilities.

title: A NEW VERSION OF HAGGADAH FOR PASSOVER
description: As Passover begins tonight, many Jews across America will be using a new version of the Haggadah during traditional seder festivities to tell the story of the escape of their ancestors from captivity in Egypt.

title: MAN BEHIND THE PLOWS
description: A relentless snow was beating down outside the window of the huge, paneled office of Sanitation Commissioner Norman Steisel yesterday morning. Inside, the blinds were drawn and it might as well have been spring.

title: NO-STAR PARIS CAFE FOR GREAT ARTISTS TO BE
description: Gourmets know Le Grand Vefour, the three-star restaurant overlooking the Palais Royal. Less well known is its no-star neighbor, ''Le Petit Vefour.'' Yet for 50 years artists, writers and musicians from 25 countries have been making their way to this hole in the wall, where they are served four-course meals by members of some of the most illustrious families in France. The price: one franc.

title: Syrian Helicopter Crashes
description: A Syrian military helicopter crashed in the Bekaa Valley today, killing its two-man crew. A communique from the Syrian peace force said the craft had struck a power line.

title: U.S. SCALES DOWN DEMANDS ON MINING OF THE SEA
description: The United States has drastically scaled down its demands and made a critical concession to escape isolation at the global conference writing rules for the world's seas, Western delegates said today.

title: Bridge:; 2 WOMEN AS PARTNERS MADE PERFECT TOURNAMENT SCORE
description: Perfect bowling scores are rare, but perfect bridge scores in tournaments are even rarer. To achieve this a player must win every event for which he or she is eligible, winding up a weekend with at least three titles.

title: PANDICK PRESS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The shr earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split distributed Jan 15

title: Idaho Coach Staying On
description: Calling it a ''good marriage'' of a coach to a school, Don Monson, the Idaho basketball coach, said yesterday that he would be back next year to guide the Big Sky Conference champions for another season. In the last two seasons the Vandals had records of 25-4 and 27-3, won two league titles and made their first appearances in the national collegiate tournament. ... Ray Meyer, coach of De Paul who has won more games than any active coach, said he was leaning toward staying on with the Blue Demons one more season before retiring. ... Ray Carazo stepped down after seven years as basketball coach at Yale. His teams posted a 68-114 record.

title: Comings and Goings
description: E.J. Junior, a linebacker for the St. Louis Cardinals, was among five persons arrested on drug charges in Tuscaloosa, Ala. The 22-year-old player was released on $1,500 bond after being charged with possession of cocaine and marijuana.

title: LION COUNTRY SAFARI INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * AEL Industries has elected to its board Francis J. Dunleavy, a retired vice chairman of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

title: ELECTRO RENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Salvadoran Rebel Snipers Pin Down Troops
description: Guerrilla snipers firing from roofs today pinned down government garrisons in the provincial capital of Usulutan, one of the most fought-over cities of El Salvador's civil war.

title: Priest, Hit With Ice, Robbed in Brooklyn
description: A 45-year-old Roman Catholic priest was hit in the face with a block of ice and robbed by four youths yesterday morning on a Brooklyn street. Last night, two youths were arrested and charged in the assault.

title: Notes on People; Social Security Aide Rewarded for Idea; An Idea That Paid Off
description: It was one of those why-didn't-somebody-think-of-that-before ideas that apparently hadn't occurred to anybody before it occurred to Ted Katz.

title: MGM GRAND HOTELS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
7 KILLED AS A TANKER TRUCK EXPLODES IN TUNNEL ON COAST
description: A gasoline tanker truck exploded in a tunnel early today after colliding with a bus, setting off a fire that killed seven persons.

title: Prudential Quitting Race
description: The Prudential Insurance Company, the major benefactor of the Boston Marathon for the last 16 years, says it will withdraw its participation beginning next year because the event is going commercial.

title: Noguchi Appeals Decision
description: Dr. Thomas Noguchi has appealed his 30-day suspension as chief county coroner, accusing the Board of Supervisors of hypocrisy and ''insidious and frightening improprieties.'' Dr. Noguchi was suspended without pay March 29 on charges of mismanaging the medical examiner's office and of spending too much time on outside projects.

title: SECRETARY OF STATE WILL SOUND OUT BOTH SIDES ON AVERTING HOSTILITIES
description: President Reagan decided today to send Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. to London and Buenos Aires to sound out those two Governments on ways of avoiding a military clash over the Falkland Islands.

title: CONNER HOMES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
description: B-After a loss of $433,000 from interest charges related to settlement of litigation with the I.R.S. C-Net income

title: News of Music; MUSICIANS AND AFTRA TALKING MERGER
description: THE American Guild of Musical Artists is negotiating a merger with the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists. Preliminary talks between the two unions began last summer in Cleveland and have proceeded in earnest since February. Reports are that an agreement will be reached before the end of the year.

title: THE TALK OF CAPITAL HOUSING IS GLUM
description: The housing market in the nation's capital, an escalator to good fortune for most of the past decade, is as depressed these days as a supply-side economist.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We would much prefer a peaceful settlement. We will do all we can to get one.

title: General Foods Sees Profit Dip
description: The General Foods Corporation said that earnings for the fiscal year ended April 3 would be reduced by $1.20 a share as a result of selling its Burger Chef fast-food business and plans to close or sell other restaurants.

title: DISCOVERY OIL LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income; the yr ago results have been restated to reflect the acquisition of the Texo Oil Corp in a merger recorded on a pooling-of-interests basis

title: LUMEN MARTIN WINTER
description: Lumen Martin Winter, a muralist, sculptor, painter and mosaic artist, died of a heart attack Monday at his home in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 73 years old.

title: HUNTINGTON HEALTH SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The yr-ago results have been restated to comply with the retroactive application of F.A.S.B. Statement No 43 regarding compensation absences

title: Heinz Deal In Zimbabwe
description: Heinz Inc., the United States food-processing concern, is close to giving Zimbabwe's twoyear-old Socialist Government its biggest foreign investment in a joint takeover of a local concern, diplomatic and business sources said today.

title: S.E.C. CITES ACCOUNTANT IN SANTA FE INSIDER CASE
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today accused a Seattle accountant of using illegally obtained advance knowledge that the Kuwait Petroleum Corporation planned to buy the Santa Fe International Corporation.

title: THURSDAY, APRIL 8, 1982; The Economy
description: The recession is not over and there is no sign yet of any recovery, the Commerce Department's top economist said. The assessment, by Robert G. Dederick, was one of the most pessimistic so far by the Reagan Administration. He said the jobless rate would continue to rise and by the end of 1982 could exceed 9 percent. (Page D1.) International

title: Excerpts from article, page A14.
description: Four former senior Government officials urged the United States and its European allies today to consider a pledge not to be the first to use nuclear weapons in Europe. To compensate, they recommended the strengthening of the West's conventional forces on the continent.

title: 5 in Family Are Slain; Michigan Boy Detained
description: A mother and her four adopted children were found shot to death in their rural home today, and the authorities said they were holding a 16-year-old boy as a suspect.

title: A NOT-SO-COMIC OPERA
description: Last Friday evening, April 2, the Argentine Embassy in Washington gave a dinner in honor of Jeane Kirkpatrick, the U.S. representative at the United Nations. That morning Argentina had invaded the Falkland Islands.

title: TWO TAMPON TESTS PROVIDE A THREAT
description: Studies done independently by two New York microbiologists offer possible evidence why Rely tampons were associated with a disproportionately high number of cases of toxic shock syndrome.

title: 2 Boeing 757's Ordered
description: Lineas Aereas Costarricenses of Costa Rica has ordered two Boeing 757 airplanes worth about $90 million, Boeing said today.

title: WESTSIDE PANEL VETOES RIVERSIDE PARK RESTAURANT
description: The Parks Department yesterday canceled plans to build a restaurant in Riverside Park at West 79th Street after the local community planning board voted down the controversial proposal.

title: Faint, Late Hope for the Budget
description: President Reagan appears to signal some willingness to meet with Congressional leaders in a budget summit conference. Does that mean he's finally decided to compromise? Tip O'Neill, Speaker of the House, says, ''There really is a possibility that we can work something out.'' Does he know something we don't know?

title: Conoco Oil Well
description: Conoco Inc., a unit of E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, said that a discovery well drilled in the Dutch North Sea flowed 3,228 barrels of oil a day during tests. Conoco said the well, drilled about 20 miles off the Dutch coast in water 115 feet deep, flowed 34 degree gravity oil from a reservoir at a depth of 6,140 feet. The well was drilled to a total depth of 8,300 feet.

title: Phone Rate Rise of 76% Predicted
description: Telephone rates across the nation could rise 76 percent within the next four years because of the combined effects of inflation and deregulation, according to a Government survey released today. Bernard Wunder, the Assistant Secretary of Commerce for communications and information, presented the report at a Congressional hearing here.

title: THE CHILDREN NEED A FRIEND IN CONGRESS
description: To the Editor:

title: ISLANDERS TROUNCE PENGUINS, 8-1, IN PLAYOFF OPENER
description: In a style reminiscent of their last two Stanley Cup-winning years, the Islanders opened the playoffs tonight by routing the Pittsburgh Penguins, 8-1, at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Hawks Win in Overtime, 3-2
description: Greg Fox, a defenseman, scored on a slap shot at 3:34 of sudden-death overtime to give the Black Hawks a 3-2 victory over the Minnesota North Stars.

title: JAPAN CUTTING EXPORT OF CHIPS TO U.S.
description: Japanese semiconductor manufacturers, reacting to American pressure, have begun to voluntarily restrain exports of powerful memory chips that are the building blocks of computers, Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said today.

title: 'ANOTHER FRAUDULENT ELECTION' IN EL SALVADOR
description: To the Editor:

title: Giorgio Tozzi Is Signed For New Prince Musical
description: Giorgio Tozzi, last on Broadway as the star of the revival of ''The Most Happy Fella'' in 1979, has been signed to co-star with George Hearn and Betsy Joslyn in the new Harold Prince production, ''A Doll's Life.''

title: NATIONAL CITY BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard THE FATE OF THE EARTH. By Jonathan Schell. 244 pages. Knopf. $11.95.

title: 12 CHARGED WITH SELLING DRUGS ON UPPER EAST SIDE
description: A dozen people described by the police as major narcotics dealers who operated on the Upper East Side were arrested early yesterday in the Bronx, Queens, Brooklyn and Westchester County, the police said.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, APRIL 8, 1982
description: International Britain threatened to sink Argentine ships that came within 200 miles of the Falkland Islands after dawn on Monday. The announcement was made by the Defense Secretary, John Nott, at the end of a debate in the House of Commons on the seizure of the South Atlantic archipelago by Argentine troops Friday. The disclosure amounted to the imposition of a blockade around the islands. (Page A1,Column 6.) Seeking to avert a military clash in the Falkland Islands, President Reagan has instructed Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. to meet with senior officials in London and Buenos Aires. A State Department spokesman said that the purpose of the trip was to hold ''preliminary discussions'' in both capitals and to offer American assistance in resolving the dispute peacefully. (A1:4-5.)

title: PURCHASE OF LANE BRYANT SET
description: Lane Bryant Inc., the nation's biggest retailer of large-size apparel, said yesterday that it would permit a private investor group led by Wertheim & Company, the investment bankers, to acquire control of Lane Bryant for about $88 million in cash. Control would be obtained by the purchase of the shares held by top officials of the company, but the size of these holdings could not be immediately determined.

title: Police Give Met Gold-Inlaid Pistols
description: The New York City Police Department yesterday gave the Metropolitan Museum of Art two hunting pistols that once belonged to Catherine the Great - even as it checked out a final clue about ownership of the valuable weapons.

title: Sports of The Times; Domeball: It's Not Baseball
description: NOW that a blizzard has temporarily buried baseball as well as much of the nation, it's fashionable to hail domed stadiums as the allweather answer. Even though it was an icy 28 degrees Tuesday night on the streets of downtown Minneapolis, it was a cozy 70 degrees inside the new Hubert H. Humphrey Metrodome, where the Twins were opening their season.

title: Islamic Bank Uses S.D.R.'s
description: The International Monetary Fund announced today that it had authorized the Islamic Development Bank in Saudi Arabia to hold and trade special drawing rights, the asset issued by the I.M.F. for use in the reserves held by governments.

title: Stocks Mixed on Volume Rise
description: The stock market registered a mixed performance yesterday amid heavier trading. The Dow Jones industrial average, moving in a narrow price range throughout the session, closed down 2.48, to 836.85. However, the overall market did somewhat better, with advancing issues on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbering those that declined by 787 to 612.

title: Chrysler Offers Warranty Plan
description: The Chrysler Corporation will offer a free maintenance-warranty program to buyers of its United States-made cars after Saturday, the company's chairman, Lee A. Iacocca, said.

title: JOHN PERKINS, 67, COLLEGE EDUCATOR
description: John A. Perkins, a college educator who was a former president and chairman of Dun & Bradstreet Inc. and a trustee of the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, died Tuesday at Berkeley (Calif.) Hospital. Mr. Perkins, a resident of Berkeley, was 67 years old.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an arti- cle yesterday on American nuclear weapons policy incorrectly described Robert S. McNamara. He retired in 1981 as president of the World Bank.

title: Rolls-Royce Pretax Profit
description: Rolls-Royce, the state-owned aircraft engine company, posted a pretax profit of $31.5 million in 1981, the first time it has been in the black since 1978, Lord McFadzean, the chairman, reported today.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article March 21 about an automobile spray painter who is suing Mercedes Benz of North America and other defendants, citing neurological injuries that he says resulted from paint fumes, incorrectly attributed a contention that the painter may have been ''malingering.'' The assertion, which appears in a court document filed by attorneys for Mercedes Benz, was made by a physician who examined the painter as part of preparation for his lawsuit.

title: Another Mark for Kaat
description: Jim Kaat pitched only long enough to get the last three outs but he made major league history in the season opener for the St. Louis Cardinals Tuesday night. Kaat, at the age of 42, became the only pitcher to have played in 24 major league seasons.

title: MISS TURNBULL UPSET IN 3 SETS
description: She is still only a name, not a number in women's tennis, but Zina Garrison spoke with authority today in the $200,000 Family Circle Cup tournament.

title: Brentano Picks Chairman
description: Francis Oakes Hunnewell, a 43-year-old investment banker, has been named chairman of Brentano's Consolidated Companies, a nationwide chain of bookstores.

title: STUDY SAYS EINSTEIN WAS WRONG ON RELATIVITY
description: Experimental physicists have been trying for years to prove that Albert Einstein's theory of general relativity, the key to modern concepts of gravity and of the structure of the universe, is somehow wrong. Thus far they have had little success.

title: Pabst-Schmidt Talks Snagged
description: The Pabst Brewing Company disclosed that discussions it was holding with C. Schmidt & Sons over Schmidt's previously announced proposal to acquire Pabst for $20.50 a share had encountered difficulties.

title: Gardening; ASSESSING DAMAGE FROM THE BLIZZARD
description: MOTHER NATURE went on a rampage Tuesday and dashed gardeners' hopes of a gentle spring. Record snowfall, as much as a foot in the outer metropolitan regions, winds up to 50 and 60 miles an hour and temperatures down to the teens wreaked havoc.

title: TRIBUNE CO. WARNS UNIONS AT DAILY NEWS
description: The owners of The Daily News said yesterday that they would shut the paper if the man they want to sell it to cannot reach an agreement with the unions on cutting costs. They did not set a firm date for such a shutdown.

title: HAWAII'S ECONOMY IN UNEASY BALANCE
description: While unemployment is up to 9 percent on the mainland, the economy of Hawaii supports its population of almost a million with an unemployment rate of only 5.5 percent.

title: VIOLIN: RALPH EVANS'S DEBUT
description: THERE are so many concerts in New York that a new series is hardly a necessity; increased imagination and concentration would be more welcome than increased quantity. But the weekday matinee audience remained untapped until Merkin Hall began its Tuesday afternoon concert series, and this week Town Hall followed suit with an interesting variation.

title: MOUNTED POLICE UNITS GETTING NEW STABLES NEARER THEATERS
description: After six years of commuting, the Police Department horses that patrol the Manhattan theater district will once again be able to sleep where they work.

title: COMEDY: ARRABAL VIEW OF LEFT-WING DICTATORS
description: FROM his position as a Spanish exile living in Paris, Fernando Arrabal has raised world consciousness about the evils of autocracy, reserving his most invidious antipathy for Franco, as in his devastating play ''And They Put Handcuffs on the Flowers.'' Arrabal is both a satirist and a theater poet, and it is his playfully polemical side that is in evidence in his new work, ''The Extravagant Triumph of Jesus Christ, Karl Marx and William Shakespeare,'' which is in its American premiere engagement at the Intar. Any play by Arrabal is an event, but ''The Extravagant Triumph'' is less than a total success.

title: British Car Sales Up
description: British car sales for March rose 8.4 percent from the 1981 level, to 175,000 units, and increased 42 percent from February 1982, figures from the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders show.

title: EXPERTS TELL HOW TO PICK A FRAME THAT ENHANCES THE PICTURE
description: THE earliest frames were literally part of the picture. Artists in the 13th century hollowed out wood panels and painted in the depressions. The unpainted, raised border formed a natural frame. Today frames are separate objects, but at their best they still seem a natural extension of the pictures.

title: LAID-OFF PILOTS SEEK TO RAISE BUSINESS FOR TWO AIRLINES
description: Wally Majure strode with determination up to the little glass window. ''Hello, I'm Wally Majure,'' he told a woman behind the sevice desk at American Management Associations, a business education group in midtown Manhattan. ''I'm a pilot with Western Airlines, and I'd like to talk to someone who handles your travel.''

title: OUR STYLISH SHUTTLE
description: To the Editor: The logic of your ''Too Fine a Machine'' editorial of March 31 is difficult to follow. ''The shuttle is the wrong vehicle for a small space program,'' you say, ''but since the shuttle exists and works, NASA should be given something to do with it that makes the agency more than a trucker of freight.''

title: HEFNER REFUSED CASINO LICENSE IN ATLANTIC CITY
description: New Jersey's Casino Control Commission ruled today that Playboy Enterprises was unsuitable to operate a casino in Atlantic City unless it severed ties with its founder and principal owner, Hugh M. Hefner.

title: MOSCOW DECLARES STAND IS NEUTRAL
description: After appearing impartial during the early days of the Falkland crisis, the Soviet Union said today that the Argentine action was an outgrowth of Britain's resistance to decolonization.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: AS more and more homeowners and apartment dwellers become do-ityourselfers, sometimes out of necessity, sometimes because they just enjoy doing things themselves, manufacturers continue to introduce tools and home-maintenance products intended to save time and money. Here are some of the new items: For the Chimney

title: CIVIL DEFENSE AGENCY: 'TRYING TO DO SOMETHING'
description: It was midmorning in an elevator at the Federal Emergency Management Agency, and two secretaries were chatting. ''I'm going to pig out tonight on some pizza,'' said one. ''Lots of cheese.'' ''That's what I need,'' said the second dreamily. ''Pizza! Something to look forward to so I don't go crazy in this place.'' The elevator creaked open on the seventh floor, and the two stepped out, their laughter echoing in the hall.

title: PHELPS TO SUSPEND U.S. COPPER OUTPUT
description: The Phelps Dodge Corporation, the nation's second-largest copper producer, said yesterday that it would suspend its domestic copper operations until June 1 and possibly longer because of the depressed copper market. As a result of the move, 3,800 employees will be laid off indefinitely.

title: Queens Bus Lines And Union in Pact
description: A tentative agreement was reached Tuesday between the Transport Workers Union and four private bus lines in Queens.

title: MEN OF FAITH REFLECT ON ANSWERING A CALL
description: The call comes differently to each man, a message surrounded by mystery. For Vincent Keane, it was a quiet voice that he finally decided to answer. For Michael Calvin, it was a persistent summons he could no longer resist. Neither can say why the herald came to them and not to others. It is, they are certain, a divine enigma, one of the Creator's bewildering gifts.

title: HEAD OF WARSAW UNIVERSITY LOSES POST
description: The rector of Warsaw University lost his position today, raising fears in the academic community that martial-law authorities might intrude into university life.

title: Authors of the Article Held High U.S. Posts
description: The article in Foreign Affairs that asked the United States and its European allies to consider renouncing the first use of nuclear weapons was written by four former high-level Administration officials.

title: Wickes Data Are Sought
description: The Allegheny Beverage Corporation yesterday repeated its demand that the Wickes Companies make its financial records available to enable Allegheny to develop a detailed proposal for payment of Wickes's $580 million short-term bank debt. Sanford C. Sigoloff, the new chairman of Wickes, has repeatedly refused to allow the development of such a proposal.

title: OPEC Panel Meets April 20
description: A special committee of four OPEC members will hold its first meeting on April 20 in Vienna to assess conditions in the world oil markets, the official Venezuelan news agency reported today.

title: Options Hearing Asked
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that it had asked the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit in Chicago for a rehearing of a decision affecting options trading by the Chicago Board Options Exchange. The court's decision on March 24 set aside an S.E.C. order approving the options exchange proposal to trade options on mortgagebacked securities guaranteed by the Government National Mortgage Association. The S.E.C. said the ruling had created confusion about the legal basis for options trading in securities.

title: Kings Beat Oilers In Shootout by 10-8
description: Daryl Evans, a rookie playing in only his 14th National Hockey League game, scored two goals and added two assists tonight to lead the Los Angeles Kings to a 10-8 victory over the Edmonton Oilers in the first game of their playoff series.

title: HELEN LAWRENSON, 74, WROTE ABOUT NOTABLE SOCIAL AFFAIRS
description: Helen Lawrenson, whose social observations in books and articles drew widely on her recollections of celebrities and her own adventures, died Monday night at her Chelsea apartment in New York City after an apparent heart attack. She was 74 years old.

title: FIRST BANKERS CORP OF FLORIDA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a tax credit of $119,000; the yr-ago results reflect the acquisition of the Boca Raton National Bank

title: Notes on People; New Dean at Columbia
description: The 11th dean of Columbia College, who will preside over its historic transformation from a 228-year-old undergraduate college for men into a coeducational institution, will be Dr. Robert E. Pollack.

title: INTERNATIONAL LAWYERS STUDY THE MUDDIED WATERS
