description: As Britain and Argentina move closer to what may become open hostilities over the Falkland Islands, and the machinery of international law creaks and groans in an effort to avert it, a few things seem clear to most international law experts.

title: HAIG PLANS MEDIATION TRIPS
description: Britain threatened tonight to sink any Argentine ship that came within 200 miles of the Falkland Islands after Monday morning.

title: Mary Russ Riding High
description: Mary Russ, the first female jockey to lead the rider standing at the Tropical Park meeting at Calder Race Course, hopes to bring her good fortune with her to New York.

title: IN GUATEMALA, THE PEOPLE HAVE LOST AGAIN
description: To the Editor:

title: BALLET: LIVELY FARE BY MONTREALERS
description: LES Grands Ballets Canadiens from Montreal, a company to cheer about, made its last extended New York appearance just as the dance boom was getting under way, which means that a good portion of the new, expanded dance audience, has never seen it.

title: EX-AIDES LINK REP. RICHMOND TO DRUG BUYING
description: Former aides of Representative Frederick W. Richmond have told a Federal grand jury that the Brooklyn Congressman periodically paid them and others to buy him cocaine and marijuana, according to sources familiar with the accounts.

title: Rudy Bond, 68, Actor In Movies and on Stage
description: Rudy Bond, who played the neighbor Steve in the original Broadway and film versions of Tennessee Williams's ''A Streetcar Named Desire,'' died of a heart attack March 29 in Denver. He was 68 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Engineer Found Guilty Of Abusing His Children
description: An aerospace engineer permitted a Superior Court judge to find him guilty of 18 counts of child molestation and sexual perversion Tuesday on the basis of a preliminary hearing.

title: DOW JONES & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The shr earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in Apr 1981

title: METROPOLITAN REGION DIGGING OUT AFTER BLIZZARD LEADS TO 8 DEATHS
description: To the scrape of snow shovels on slushy walks and the whine of reluctant tires on snowbound streets, the metropolitan area began to recover yesterday from the first recorded April blizzard.

title: THE THEATER: PAST RECALLED IN 'MEEGAN'
description: WHAT price the friends of one's youth? Too steep, too steep, according to ''Meegan's Game,'' the play by Elliott Caplin at the Harold Clurman Theater. It is a play about arrested adolescence.

title: FOR SPECIAL OCCASIONS, WHY NOT RENT A CASTLE?
description: IMAGINE a charity ball or a business conference in a setting as gorgeous as the castle in ''Brideshead Revisited.'' Castle Howard in Yorkshire, which played the title role in the television series, is not available, but many other stately homes in Britain can be rented for social or business functions. Sometimes, it's even possible to have the titled owner drop in at the party.

title: Hoechst Plans
description: Hoechst, one of the world's largest chemical companies, announced plans to invest 130 million German marks, or about $53 million, to expand the production capacity of its polyester film-manufacturing subsidiary in the United States. Hoechst, which is based in Frankfurt, said that its plant in Greer, S.C., would begin producing an additional 12,000 metric tons a year of polyester film beginning in early 1984. Most of the increased output is designated for Western European markets.

title: CONSTRUCTION UNIONS JEER G.O.P. CHIEF
description: Richard Richards, the Republican national chairman, offered today to give labor a voice in party affairs but received a hostile reception from delegates to a building trades union conference.

title: BRIEFING
description: Can You Spare the Time?

title: EXCERPTS FROM MAGAZINE ARTICLE ON ARMS POLICY
description: Following are excerpts from an article in the spring issue of Foreign Affairs, the journal of the Council on Foreign Relations Inc,, written by McGeorge Bundy, George F. Kennan, Robert S. McNamara and Gerard Smith:

title: CLASSES AND EXHIBITS IN THE SPIRIT OF SPRING
description: Growing Vegetables in the Big Apple, Cooperative Extension of Cornell University, 2 World Trade Center, Room 5084.

title: Petro-Canada Earnings
description: Petro-Canada, the Government energy group, said today that its 1981 earnings before preferred dividends rose to $203.8 million (Canadian) from $163.8 million in 1980. Daily production last year totaled 11,300 cubic meters of oil and natural gas liquids and 10.7 million cubic meters of natural gas, the company said.

title: Pavel Rotmistrov, 80, Marshal in Soviet Army
description: The Soviet Union today announced the death at the age of 80 of Marshal Pavel A. Rotmistrov, a Soviet armored commander during World War II and a leader in the war's biggest armored battle.

title: PHILADELPHIA DOCTOR SUSPECTED AS THIEF OF TASTE AND DARING
description: To some of his acquaintances here, Dr. Frank Waxman was a caring and successful young doctor. Others also knew him as an art collector of considerable taste and knowledge.

title: Technology
description: TESTS often try to measure how smart people are. But in the future, the tests themselves might be ''smart'' because they will be taken on computer terminals instead of on paper.

title: Home Beat; IN SOUTHWESTERN STYLE
description: IT might have been the blizzard that made the quintet of rooms, part of the ''Focus America: Santa Fe'' promotion at Lord & Taylor, look so sunny.

title: PHILLIPS-VAN HEUSEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: The yr-ago qr net increased by $1,135,000 or 38 cents a shr from difference between estimated interim calculations for the effects of LIFO and the final determination at the end of the yr while or the yr income increased $625,000 or 21 cents a shr from inventory reduction

title: DOMESTIC WORKERS: PAY PROBLEMS
description: ONE of the trickiest issues facing household workers and their employers is how to handle pay and fringe benefits. Does the worker get paid if she misses a day because of the flu? What if she is out of work a month because of an operation? Should the employer provide medical insurance? Pay a Christmas bonus? How much vacation pay, if any, should the worker receive? What if a string of holidays fall on the employee's regular workday?

title: NEW YORK TESTING LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
Allen to Buy Alouettes
description: Some of the confusion surrounding the ownership of the Montreal Alouettes was lifted yesterday with the announcement that a syndicate headed by George Allen would buy the financially troubled Canadian Football League club. But Allen, the president of the team, said that the team's present owner, Nelson Skalbania, must first release the new group from large debts incurred last season.

title: COAST GUARD SEARCHES IN VAIN FOR BOAT AFTER A CALL FOR HELP
description: An extensive Coast Guard air and sea search, begun Tuesday evening after a radio call for help, contended with 60-mile-an-hour winds and high seas but failed to turn up any evidence yesterday that a fishing boat was in trouble 11 miles east of Seaside Heights, N.J.

title: UNITED STATES TRUST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: U.S. Signs Pledge to Aid Three Mile Island Work
description: Officials of the Department of Energy signed an agreement today in Harrisburg, Pa., that formalizes the Federal Government's pledge to remove and dispose of the most dangerous portion of the contaminated reactor at the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant.

title: The U.N. Today; April 8, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee on Nonuse of Force in International Relations - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: Hers
description: NOT too long ago I was writing about the Alice in Wonderland world of high-energy physics, of ''quarks'' and ''gluons,'' particles ''strange'' and ''charmed.'' I asked my friend the physicist how anyone could really believe in such seemingly ephemeral entities, things that no one could ever really see. And he answered: ''In the same way as I believe you're standing in front of me. It all depends on what you mean by seeing.''

title: Alcan Halts Potline
description: Alcan Aluminum Ltd. said that its Australian unit had deferred commissioning a third potline at its Kurri Kurri aluminum smelter in New South Wales because of continuing poor demand for aluminum worldwide. The $155 million facility would have started production at the end of this year or early in 1983, increasing the smelter's rated capacity to 135,000 tons from 90,000. Alcan Australia is 70 percent owned by Alcan, which is based in Montreal.

title: BRITAIN PRESSING U.S. ON FALKLANDS
description: The British Government is applying considerable pressure on the Reagan Administration to provide London with military intelligence and other support for the British flotilla heading toward the Falkland Islands, according to Administration officials.

title: Eastern Commissions
description: Eastern Airlines said yesterday that it would reduce the commission on domestic airline tickets paid to travel agents to 9 percent from 10 percent, effective May 3, to try to cut some of its costs.

title: CHAMBER: FROM MARLBORO
description: A TROUPE from the Marlboro Music Festival offered chamber works by Mozart, Beethoven and Stravinsky at Alice Tully Hall on Monday, combining stylish interpretation with polished performance in a way that left all four of the evening's selections the better for wear. The bulk of the program was devoted to divertimentos for mixed wind and strings by Mozart and Beethoven; Stravinsky's Three Pieces and Concertino for string quartet went between them, placing a crisp 20th-century accent in the midst of some imaginative 18th-century discourse.

title: Track Robbery Wins
description: Track Robbery took the early lead, lost it, but then regained it during a stretch duel with Andover Way to win by a nose in the $268,400 Apple Blossom Handicap for older fillies and mares today at Oaklawn Park. Jameela finished third in the field of six. Track Robbery, a 6-year-old who has been racing in California, covered the mile and a sixteenth under Eddie Delahoussaye in 1:45 1/5 and returned $3.80 for $2 to win.

title: MISSISSIPPI TOWN DIVIDED OVER 2 OUSTED COACHES
description: When two high school athletic coaches disagreed with the school board over how the boys' basketball team should be coached, no one in Mississippi's rural Perry County thought the issue would literally become a Federal case.

title: 3 MEN WHO HOLD KEYS TO A TRANSIT SETTLEMENT
description: Three members of an arbitration panel began this week to hear the proposals of two unions representing the city's 35,000 bus and subway workers. One, Dan Collins, is a twice-a-day subway rider who says he will be looking out for ''the interest and welfare of the public.'' Another, Avid Anderson, a World War II navigator aboard a B-17, believes that public-employee unions should not be allowed to use their power over the lives of the city's residents as a cudgel in negotiations. And the third, Milton Friedman, a professional arbitrator for 30 years, insists that the key to labor-management agreement lies in a painstaking analysis of the issues. Here is a look at the three men and their lives.

title: Critic's Notebook; EDITING AND OTHER FOIBLES OF MOVIES ON CASSETTES
description: TWO weeks ago, I wrote about the wonders of movies on video cassette, saying that this was a way film fans could watch unedited prints of their favorite films at home. Shortly thereafter, I received a dismaying number of telephone calls from people who had bought cassettes that had indeed been edited. Their mistake, like mine, had been to assume that the cassettes, which are not marked as edited, must surely be intact. As it turns out, that isn't always true.

title: GREAT AMERICAN BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Frontier Gives $75,000 Raise
description: Glen L. Ryland, the chairman of Frontier Airlines, has been given a $75,000-a-year raise, according to proxy statements mailed to stockholders.

title: Flyers Defeat Rangers by 4-1
description: The Rangers scored a goal on their first rush at Pete Peeters, the Philadelphia Flyer goalie, last night in the opening game of their Stanley Cup playoff series at Madison Square Garden. The goal, by Eddie Johnstone, came at 3 minutes 10 seconds of the first period and gave New York a 1-0 lead.

title: AN IMPROPER FOCUS ON MIDEAST STRIFE
description: To the Editor:

title: HORIZON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The yr-ago shr earnings have been restated for a 5 percent stock divd as of June 1, 1981

title: GULF AND WESTERN TO SELL CIGAR UNIT
description: Gulf and Western Industries said yesterday that it had agreed in principle to sell its Consolidated Cigar Company subsidiary to MacAndrews & Forbes Group, a Philadelphia-based chocolate producer, for more than $100 million in cash and notes.

title: EUROPEANS VS. JAPAN ON TRADE
description: The European Economic Community formally asked Japan today to make dramatic changes in trade and foreign investment policies. The community outlined some of the steps it thought Japan should take.

title: East Side, West Side
description: Zoning for Light, Air and Lunch

title: MICHEL SEES NEED FOR ADDED TAXES
description: Congress and the White House must agree on significant spending cuts and about $30 billion in tax increases to keep the budget deficit for the fiscal year 1983 below $100 billion, Robert H. Michel, the House minority leader, said today.

title: Nelle Nugent, Producer, Wed to Jolyon Fox Stern
description: Nelle Nugent, the Broadway producer, was married yesterday to Jolyon Fox Stern, president of DeWitt Stern, Gutmann & Co., a New York insurance-brokerage firm. The ceremony was performed by State Supreme Court Justice Theodore R. Kupferman in his chambers.

title: Mandela Is Transferred To a Mainla
description: Nelson Mandela, president of the banned African National Congress, and three other leaders of the organization have been transferred from Robben Island to a mainland jail, the South Africa Press Association reported today.

title: South Yemen Sentences 12 To Death for Sabotage Plot
description: The Supreme Court today sentenced 12 Southern Yemenis to death on charges of engaging in sabotage with the complicity of the United States.

title: Spy's Former Cellmate Freed in Robbery Case
description: A Federal judge dismissed robbery, conspiracy and harboring charges Tuesday against Calvin Robinson, accused of teaching the convicted spy Christopher Boyce how to rob banks.

title: HARRIS STEEL GROUP INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a gain of $221,500 on the sale of shrs of other companies

title: ADJUST TO COMPETE
description: The economic choice facing the United States over the next decade is between protection of the national economy from the international market or rapid adjustment to the new realities of international competition. Either way, government will be actively involved.

title: THE STUDIO HOUSE: NEW TREND-SETTER FROM CLAIFORNIA
description: HOUSES in California have always looked different: somehow more imaginative, more innovative, more interesting than many of their Eastern counterparts. A new, modest kind of structure that has recently grown in popularity there promises to be as influential as one of its predecessors, the California ranch house. It is a small, free-standing structure built on land on which there is already another house. They have their antecedents in the artist's studio, the garage apartment, the gazebo and, perhaps more appropriately, the Victorian folly.

title: PAIUTE OIL & MINING CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a tax credit of $221,000...C-Net loss

title: PROSECUTORS PUT FOCUS ON ESTATE AT MOON'S TRIAL
description: Federal prosecutors presented key evidence yesterday about a $625,000 estate that the Unification Church bought as a residence for the Rev. Sun Myung Moon in Westchester County.

title: Getty Note Offering
description: The Getty Oil Company said today that it planned a $100 million offering of 14 percent, seven-year notes in Europe. The underwriters, it said, are managed by Credit Suisse-First Boston.

title: FREEZER DEFECT RUINS CELL TESTS CONDUCTED ON THE SPACE SHUTTLE
description: A freezer used to store blood samples from an experiment aboard the space shuttle Columbia malfunctioned and caused the specimens to thaw, ruining the test, space officials say.

title: CHARMING SHOPPES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
G.T.E.-Italtel Research Pact
description: The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation said that it had signed an agreement with Italtel, Italy's state-owned telephone company, to conduct research and development of electronic digital telecommunications switching systems.

title: MARIO PRAZ, 85, LITERATURE CRITIC, ESSAYIST AND ART COLLECTOR, DEAD
description: Mario Praz, a critic, essayist and art collector who specialized in the literature of the Baroque and Romantic periods, died here on March 23. He was 85 years old.

title: Mitsubishi Trucks
description: The Mitsubishi Motors Corporation of Japan said today that it will begin production of trucks in Australia at its Adelaide subsidiary later this year.

title: SEOUL ARRESTS PRIEST FOR AIDING A SUSPECT IN ANTI-U.S. INCIDENT
description: A Roman Catholic priest and six lay associates were arrested in Seoul today after a nationwide investigation into the burning of the American Cultural Center in Pusan on March 18.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: CHATTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $68,000 for the qr and $72,000 for the 9 mos

title: PIANO RECITAL: GUTIERREZ
description: THE young pianistic career of Horacio Gutierrez has suffered often from an overabundance of natural resources -an endless capacity for playing incredible numbers of right notes at any speed and evoking almost life-threatening levels of loudness from any keyboard. Such powers have a way of demanding autonomy and then smothering even the best of musical instincts.

title: 'Wrong' to Close
description: ''Maybe I'm Doing It Wrong,'' the musical with songs by Randy Newman, will close Sunday evening at the Astor Place Theater. Directed by Joan Micklin Silver, the play will have run for 33 performances and 12 previews. The cast includes Mark Linn-Baker, Patti Perkins and Deborah Rush.

title: STARS OF TODAY'S COLLEGE LECTURE CIRCUIT
description: in at Democratic National Committee offices at the Watergate complex, how he bugged the warden's office while incarcerated in Danbury, Conn., and how he is now building a new career airing his zealously promilitary views on the college lecture circuit, students and faculty here staged a noisy, angry protest.

title: MORGAN LIBRARY HELPS SAVE THE SPIRIT OF '76
description: In the course of human events, a rare copy of the Declaration of Independence just missed winding up in Japan or England last week. It can now be disclosed that the irreplaceable document was saved from being auctioned off to foreign buyers at virtually the last hour. Instead, it will remain in the United States permanently - at the Morgan Library in New York.

title: ERVING'S 38 SINK NETS
description: The Nets discovered in a 116-113 defeat tonight just how large a difference there is between second and third place in the Atlantic Division. That difference is Julius Erving.

title: Friendly Fire
description: What a peculiar phrase President Reagan uses to describe his distress over Argentina's seizure of the Falkland Islands from Britain. ''We're friends of both,'' he says.

title: WEEKLY PAPERS PUT OUT BY PROFESSIONALS
description: To the Editor:

title: CONNECTICUT PLOWS LEAD WAY BACK TO NORMALITY
description: Connecticut residents, the ungrateful recipients of the greatest snow accumulation from Tuesday's blizzard, returned today to semblances of regular activity.

title: Details of Hertz-Penske Pact
description: A joint truck-leasing venture between the Hertz Corporation and the Penske Corporation will be capitalized at $56 million and will be 65 percent owned by Hertz, the companies announced yesterday.

title: DOCTORS APPEALING FOR A FREEZE IN ATOMIC ARSENALS
description: More than 200 doctors called today for an immediate halt to further deployment of nuclear arms, saying there would be ''no remedy for the foreseeable medical consequences of a nuclear war.'

title: GOOD GUYS, BAD GUYS
description: The argument about how the United States should behave toward friends and foes, and indeed which is which, has broken out of the Washington corridors and gone very public.

title: Ford German Unit Sets Extra Shifts
description: Ford-Werke, the West German unit of the Ford Motor Company, said that it would add eight extra shifts between April 17 and July 10 at its Saarlouis plant to accommodate rising demand for the Escort model.

title: QUICK DEAL SAVES BANK AFTER $16 MILLION LOSS
description: ''A weekend of uncertainty and inconvenience,'' said Joe W. Dodgen, was all this town suffered from the biggest bank looting in Iowa history.

title: Court Rejects Union Charge Of Bias in Election Fund Law
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia on Tuesday upheld the 1976 election law amendments that gave corporate political action committees the right to solicit executive or administrative personnel and their families and rejected a labor union's assertions that the amendment favored corporate committees over similar union committees.

title: Advertising; A Boom In Hispanic Advertising
description: THERE is another boom in the advertising business besides the cable TV boom. And although certainly far less dramatic, it is a fact of life. It is the advertising to the various Spanish communities in the United States, which is growing with the Hispanic population.

title: OIL IMPORT FEE: TALK GROWING
description: The phenomenon of the world oil glut and tumbling prices has been accompanied in recent months by increasing talk about imposing a special tax on imported oil. This idea, which may seem perverse to consumers finally enjoying some relief from rising energy prices, calls for a fee of $5 to $10 for each barrel of crude oil or oil products imported by the United States.

title: Checker Theatens End Of Taxi Manufacturing
description: Checker Motors says it is ending production of its big boxy taxicabs, long a fixture in American cities.

title: STEWART & STEVENSON SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The shr earnings restated for a 3-for-2 stock split

title: THEATER: 'THREE ACTS OF RECOGNITION,' FOREMAN EXTRAVAGANZA
description: RICHARD FOREMAN'S followers won't be surprised by the sights and sounds of his latest extravaganza, the American premiere of Botho Strauss's ''Three Acts of Recognition.'' Entering the Public's Anspacher Theater, one finds all the director's trademarks: fluorescent tubing mounted above an austere modern set; yards of string bisecting the stage; banners containing cryptic epigrams about art. Soon the noise starts up: the rise and fall of distant music, the electronic buzzing that swells to a seat-rattling roar, the periodic blasts of gunfire - or is it backfiring cars?

title: F.C.C. CHIEF ASSAILS 'FAIRNESS' POLICY
description: The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission called on the National Association of Broadcasters today to help him roll back the so-called fairness doctrine and other forms of Government regulation of radio and television broadcasting, which he called infringements of free speech.

title: 'THE STUD FARM'
description: ''THE STUD FARM'' is an impressive, unusual film set in Hungary in 1950, at a time when members of that country's deposed regime have quite literally been sent out to pasture. A number of former army officers now work at breeding horses at the isolated outpost of the title.

title: Tracy Caulkins Equals Weismuller Swim Mark
description: Tracy Caulkins, who recorded the third best time during qualifying heats earlier in the day, came back to win the 200-yard backstroke tonight at the United States Swimming Short Course championships and match Johnny Weismuller's record of 36 individual national titles.

title: Twins Down Mariners
description: Jim Eisenreich's two-run single and Kent Hrbek's bases-empty home run led the Minnesota Twins to a 7-5 victory over the Seattle Mariners tonight. A crowd of only 5,213 was in attendance after a state-record baseball crowd of 52,279 saw the Mariners win, 11-7, Tuesday night in the first regular-season game ever played at the Metrodome.

title: MRS. LLOYD B. TAFT
description: Virginia Stone Taft, the wife of Lloyd B. Taft, an investment banker, died Tuesday at Holmes Hospital in Cincinnati after a long illness. She was 56 years old and lived in Indian Hill, Ohio, a Cincinnati suburb.

title: Notes on People; Man Finds a Fortune but Is Too Honest to Keep It; Rich for a Few Minutes
description: For a few brief shining minutes during Tuesday's blizzard, James Priceman was a multimillionaire.

title: BANKS WILL LINK CASH MACHINES
description: Twenty-six banks around the country, including three of the nation's largest, announced yesterday that they would link their automatic teller operations so that customers could use the cash machines of any of the participants, anywhere in the country.

title: Going Out Guide
description: SPECIAL EYES

title: 7 ILLEGAL ALIENS ARRESTED BY F.B.I. FOR STUDENT LOAN PROGRAM FRAUD
description: A Government investigation into fraud in the federally guaranteed student loan program in the metropolitan area has led to the arrest of several illegal aliens. They were charged with falsifying loan applications in which they claimed to be United States citizens, according to the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Bethesda Navy Hospital Says Accreditation Is in Jeopardy
description: Officials at the National Naval Medical Center, used by Presidents for annual checkups and other needs, confirm that the institution has been threatened with loss of accreditation.

title: DATE SET FOR HINCKLEY TRIAL IN REAGAN ASSAULT
description: A Federal district judge today set April 27 as the trial date for John W. Hinckley Jr. on charges of shooting President Reagan and three other men last year.

title: FOR SOME JURORS IN STOUFFER TRIAL, A CATERD SEDER
description: The third day of deliberations in the Stouffer's Inn arson and murder case was interrupted today so that Jewish members of the jury could celebrate Passover with a seder meal that was brought in to them.

title: Design Notebook
description: AWORKING relationship between artists and architects was once an integral part of the creative process and the cultural environment. In Gothic cathedrals, for instance, one cannot imagine the soaring architecture without the color of the windows or the sculptured iconography. The tradition held firm over the centuries, and no one was busier than Michelangelo working both sides of the arts.

title: Yamani Studies Market
description: Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, Saudi Arabia's oil minister, said today that Saudi Arabia was studying the oil market and would cut oil output below its current ceiling of seven million barrels daily if necessary to defend prices. But, he added, no decision had been made yet. The minister spoke to reporters after he attended a dinner here of the Institution of Mining and Metallurgy.

title: Eruptive Phase Slows At Mount St. Helens
description: Mount St. Helens is still bubbling and spewing gas from its crater, but it has quieted enough to prompt the cancellation of a flash flood watch.

title: SEX BIAS OR CLASH OF CULTURES
description: For Lisa Avagliano, whose case the United States Supreme Court will hear April 26, it seems like a simple matter of justice. Miss Avagliano went straight from college to Sumitomo Shoji America Inc., an American subsidiary of one of Japan's largest trading companies. Starting in 1976, Miss Avagliano earned $170 a week for reading and sorting telexes, sending out estimates and invoices, and doing general secretarial work. It wasn't long before she felt stuck in her job.

title: People
description: * Kenneth H. Lavey named chairman, and Charles A. Rockefeller, executive vice president, of Lavey/Wolf/Swift, a subsidiary of BBDO/Health and Medical Communications.

title: Musselman Is Retained
description: Bill Musselman was retained yesterday as coach of the Cleveland Cavaliers for the 1982-83 season.

title: GAYLORDS, NATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
MACAO, STILL AWAITING 20TH CENTURY, GAMBLES ON
description: The round casino on the first floor of the Lisboa Hotel here is always packed with gamblers. Chinese grandmothers in silk pajamas shuffle across the floor in low-heeled mules carrying green and red plastic bowls filled with pataca, Macao's currency. Carefully dressed Hong Kong businessmen who arrived by hydrofoil from across the Pearl River estuary mingle with the more successful immigrants who walked to this Portuguese territory through the barrier gate from China.

title: Son of Estes Pleads Guilty
description: Thomas Estes, the 43-year-old son of the former president of the General Motors Corporation, Elliott M. Estes, pleaded guilty today to charges of fraud, including misrepresenting his assets and liabilities on a $550,000 bank loan application.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Blocker Energy Corp. said that it had acquired interests in 78 producing wells in Ohio, at a cost of $8 million in cash plus production payments over the next three years estimated at $2.4 million.

title: SNEAD: A MASTER FOR ALL ERAS
description: Sam Snead once told this story: ''It's not true Ben Hogan doesn't talk during a round. He talks to me all the time. He says, 'You're away, Sam.' ''

title: MEXICAN VILLAGERS RETURNING DESPITE WARNINGS ON VOLCANO
description: Hundreds of peasants began walking back to their ash-covered villages today despite Government warnings that the Chichon volcano is still dangerous.

title: Q AND A
description: Q. I live on the sixth floor of an old apartment building, and I seem always to have low water pressure; the building itself is on a high elevation. In the last few cold months, I have noticed that the toilet occasionally burps up a large bubble that gives off a foul smelling gas when it reaches the surface; the bubble is similar to the kind one sees rising in a water cooler. Is this connected to the low water pressure or the cold outside temperature, and can it be corrected? - P.M.R., Brooklyn.

title: MAJOR SHAKE-UP AT SOTHEBY ANNOUNCED
description: A major shake-up in the management of the Sotheby Parke Bernet Group was announced here today. Lord Westmorland, the company's outgoing chairman, said that as a result of the company's current financial difficulties a new management team had been appointed and other steps taken to reduce costs.

title: Notes on People
description: Never Too Late to Quit Never Too Late to Quit

title: COPPER FUTURES SURGE ON PHELPS DODGE MOVE
description: Copper futures prices soared yesterday on news that the Phelps Dodge Corporation, the nation's second-largest copper producer, planned to suspend most of its operations because it had become uneconomical to mine and process the metal at current market prices.

title: JAMAICA'S PREMIER PRAISED BY REAGAN
description: President Reagan began a working vacation in the Caribbean today by hailing Jamaica as proof that democracy and economic development go hand-in-hand and attacking Cuba, 90 miles to the north, for supporting ''a philosophy alien to this hemisphere.''

title: Grenade Wounds a Nun In West Bank Town
description: A nun was critically wounded in a grenade explosion this morning at a Greek Orthodox shrine in the West Bank town of Nablus, the Military Command here reported. A local Arab was also hurt in the blast.

title: PYRAMID OIL CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: The revs figures for 1980 was not reported

title: Chairman at Beeline Adds Two Other Posts
description: It may sound like a long road from banking to selling oil paintings at house parties. But John C. Colman, former executive vice president of the Continental Illinois Corporation and the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, has just become president and chief executive officer of Beeline Inc., which organizes the sales from its headquarters in Bensenville, Ill.

title: EUROPEANS ENDING ARMS TO ARGENTINA
description: France, West Germany, Belgium and Austria banned the sale of arms and military equipment to Argentina today in support of Britain over the Falkland Islands crisis.

title: ARGENTINA FORMS NEW ZONE IN RESPONSE TOP BRITISH MOVE
description: Argentina created a 200-mile defense zone off its shores and around the Falkland Islands today in response to the British threat of a naval blockade of the islands.

title: HANDY PORTABLE LIGHTS
description: FOR those with cars, vans, campers, boats and, yes, airplanes, there is a line of handy, well-designed low-energy halogen spotlights called Mobile Lights by Osram. Each model uses an auto's lighter receptacle or similar outlets.

title: INNIS AND CORE OFFICIAL WIN ACQUITAL ON ASSAULT CHARGES
description: A jury in State Supreme Court in Manhattan acquitted Roy Innis, chairman of the Congress of Racial Equality, and another CORE official yesterday of assaulting a man who had stolen a car radio.

title: MGM Hotels Net Off 37.7%
description: MGM Grand Hotels Inc. reported today that earnings for the second quarter declined 37.7 percent, to $4.3 million, or 13 cents a share, from $6.9 million, or 22 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: Harvester Bank Loan Repaid
description: International Harvester repaid last week a $3.5 million loan to the First National Bank of Commerce of New Orleans, Harvester said today. The New Orleans bank was the only Harvester lender that refused to participate in the troubled company's $4.2 billion debt restructuring that was completed in December.

title: 7 Tracks Call Off Racing
description: Racing at Aqueduct, Meadowlands and five other tracks in the path of Tuesday's blizzard was canceled yesterday. Thoroughbred racing at Pimlico, Keystone, Suffolk Downs, Penn National and Hazel Park was canceled because of track conditions and cold, but harness racing at Roosevelt Raceway, Freehold Raceway and Liberty Bell was scheduled.

title: Mets Select Jones To Oppose Carlton
description: The Mets finally made it through the snow to Philadelphia today, but wintry weather forced their opening game against the Phillies to be postponed for the second straight night.

title: Stake in Bathurst
description: Consolidated-Bathurst Inc., a diversified forest products concern, said that the Associated Newspapers Group had increased its holding in the company's stock to about 15 percent of the total outstanding. As of Feb. 26, Associated Newspapers beneficially owned 3.3 million Consolidated-Bathurst shares, the company said in its proxy statement for the annual meeting. The company did not disclose the value of the holdings.

title: HOW THE N.R.C. PURSUES RISK OF THERMAL SHOCK
description: To the Editor:

title: Batus Offer Oversubscribed
description: Batus Inc. said that its offer to pay $30 each for 8 million shares of Marshall Field & Company had been oversubscribed, despite the withdrawal of about 2.2 million shares before the deadline.

title: Index; International
description: Macao, still awaiting 20th century, keeps gambling A2 Seoul arrests priest for aiding suspect in anti-U.S. incident A4 Around the World A5 4 Western European countries bar arms sales to Argentina A12 Doctors, citing perils of war, urge halt in deploying nuclear arms A13 Government/Politics G.O.P. chairman gets hostile reception at union conference A16 Product safety panel quits effort on aluminum wiring A18 West Side board vetoes Riverside Park restaurant B4 Washington Talk Briefing A20 The depressed state of Washington real estate A20 Civil defense agency preparing for the worst A20 General Around the Nation A16 Iowa bank recovers from big embezzling loss with U.S. help A16 New Midwest snowstorm forming after record April freeze B2 Jurors in Stouffer's arson case are served Passover meal B3 Features/Notes Men in the News: the three transit arbitrators B6 Sports People B16 Going Out Guide C12 Notes on People C22 Issue and Debate: Should we impose a fee on oil imports? D1 PARKING REGULATIONS Because of Passover and the snow, alternate-side parking is suspended in New York City today. All other rules remain in effect. Home Section Home The studio house, new trendsetter from California C1

title: Washington Ballet To Perform in Brooklyn
description: Amanda McKerrow, the first American gold medalist at the International Ballet Competition in Moscow, will star in two New York premieres when the Washington Ballet performs at the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College on April 17 at 8 o'clock and April 18 at 2.

title: Echlin Head Describes Link to Borg-Warner
description: Frank Edward Pilling, 57, the new president and chief operating officer of Echlin Inc., knows all about the ties that bind his company to the Borg-Warner Corporation.

title: U.S. AIDE GLOOMY ON ANY UPTURN
description: The top economist in the Commerce Department, in one of the most pessimistic assessments yet to be offered by the Administration on the economy, said today that the recession was still not over and that there was no indication yet of a recovery.

title: Egypt Is Rebuffed At Kuwait Meeting
description: Syria and Algeria joined the Palestine Liberation Organization today in rejecting an Egyptian proposal for a Middle East settlement based on Palestinian recognition of Israel.

title: Market Place; Western Union Turnaround
description: THE common wisecrack concerning movies with a message is, ''When I send a message, I use Western Union.'' That was a generation ago. Now Western Union sends most of its telegrams to the post office for delivery by the mailman.

title: CONGRESS IS IN DOUBT OVER COST AND NEED IN AIR FORCE BUILDUP
description: After nearly a decade in which the Air Force insisted that it was falling behind the Soviet Union, the Reagan Administration has ordered the service to embark on a major buildup in manpower, fighter planes, bombers and strategic weapons.

title: CARTOON ART FLOURISHING
description: In a society grown more visual and less verbal, political cartooning is steadily emerging as an artistic and political force.

title: HARVARD EASING BUSINESS STUDENT WORKLOAD
description: At the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration, stories abound concerning students who work 20-hour days in a frantic, two-year pursuit of a coveted degree and attractive job offers from major corporations. For the chosen few, however, the road to a $40,000-a-year starting salary may be a little easier.

title: CONSUMER SAFETY PANEL HALTS WIRING CHALLENGE
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission has abandoned a seven-year effort to force the aluminum industry to repair 1.5 million American homes equipped with wiring that may be a fire hazard, officials said today.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Interest Rates Mark Time
description: Interest rates were little changed in quiet trading yesterday, with no new developments to give direction to the financial markets. By late in the day, most short-term rates had increased by less than an eighth of a percentage point, while yields on long-term bonds declined by a few basis points. In the Treasury market, for example, the rate on six-month Treasury bills rose to 13.16 from 13.06 percent, while the price of the 14 percent bonds due 2011 rose to 102 1/4 to yield 13.67 percent compared with 102 1/8 to yield 13.69 a day earlier.

title: CLONING-BOOK SUIT IS SETTLED
description: The author and publisher of a book about an alleged human clone today settled a $7 million suit brought by a scientist who said his reputation had been damaged because his name was used in ''In His Image, the Cloning of a Man.''

title: A.&P. Shift Leaves Key Spot Still Open
description: The Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company shook up its management yesterday, but it has still not yielded an answer to the big question: Who will take the spot left open by the resignation last year of David Morrow as president?

title: German Canal Talks Set
description: Chancellor Bruno Kreisky of Austria will meet the Bavarian State Premier, Franz Josef Strauss, here on April 22 to discuss prospects for completing a canal linking the rivers Rhine and Danube, a statement from Mr. Strauss's office said today.

title: Yanks to Open On Saturday
description: The Yankees postponed their home opener again yesterday, rescheduling it for 2 P.M. Saturday at Yankee Stadium against the Chicago White Sox.

title: Yankees Await Fair Weather
description: While a plow inched around the perimeter of the snowy outfield at Yankee Stadium yesterday, team officials bowed to the results of Tuesday's punishing blizzard and rescheduled Opening Day from today against the Texas Rangers to Saturday against the Chicago White Sox.

title: NEW LAW SWELLS CHICAGO PISTOL REGISTRATIONS
description: Thousands of Chicagoans have been stockpiling and registering pistols in the last few weeks, trying to beat a tough new law that bars the registration of such weapons after Friday.

title: A CENTURY OF SHAKESPEARE IN NEW YORK
description: When John Barrymore climbed into a suit of armor before the battle scene in a 1920 production of ''Richard III,'' he faced a problem. The fight scene called for running and jumping, dipping and dodging, and the armor weighed more than 50 pounds. To make matters worse, he wore a large wad of cloth on his left shoulder to simulate King Richard's humped back.

title: BOBBIE BROOKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
NORTHWESTERN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
DOLE SEES 'HORROR STORY' IN M.T.A. LEASING DEAL
description: Senator Bob Dole, the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, today denounced as a ''horror story'' a $100 million leasing arrangement for New York buses and commuter rail cars.

title: Company News; Ford to Omit Dividend Again
description: The Ford Motor Company's board of directors voted not to pay a second-quarter dividend on common stock - the second consecutive period in which stockholders will receive no bonus.

title: ALLENTOWN, PA. TAKES PRIDE IN MAKING DO WITH LESS U.S. AID
description: It happened about seven years ago, but the residents of Allentown still cite with some pride the title they received for, among other things, a brick-paved mall on their city's main shopping street and the canopies that shade strollers there.

title: Restaurants; Nouvelle cuisine with a new owner.
description: THERE are two basic ways to go into the restaurant business - either start from scratch with a brand-new name and setting, establishing a style and character that reflect the background of the owner or chef, or buy a restaurant that already has a large following and take up where the previous owner left off. Judging by the general lack of success that follows such takeovers, the latter seems to be the more difficult. The new owner must tailor his style and instincts to those of his predecessor, and he may wind up alienating the very customers he hoped to inherit.

title: ADAMS EXPRESS CO reports earnings for As of Mar 31
description: The per shr figures reflect capital gains equal to $1.20 in Feb 1982 and 98 cents in Feb 1981

title: A FANTASY IS A-BUILDING FOR THE REAGAN EGG-ROLL
description: From the attic of a 151-year-old house here come the inspirations that animate Easter, Christmas and Independence Day at the White House. This is where Richard Rovsek thinks.

title: Required Reading A Falklands Lesson
description: Representative Jim Leach, Republican of Iowa, in a statement before the House of Representatives concerning the events in the Falkland Islands. April 5, 1982:

title: Economic Scene; Waiting For Recovery
description: APROVERB among economists goes, ''If you can't forecast accurately, f orecast often.'' And, as the economy continues to slither downward i n the springtime, economists inside and outside the Government have c ontinued to lower their forecasts. Indeed, it now looks as though t he average of economic forecasts has become the latest lagging i ndicator.

title: Holiday Closings
description: In observance of Good Friday, stock and commodity markets will be closed today. Most banks in New Jersey and Connecticut will be closed, but New York banks will remain open.

title: TARDY AND GROUNDLESS ATTACK ON VOTING RIGHTS
description: To the Editor:

title: N.B.A. Fines Mahorn
description: The National Basketball Association continued its campaign against indiscriminate swinging of elbows in rebounding situations by fining Rick Mahorn, a center for the Washington Bullets. The fine against Mahorn, $1,000, was levied for several elbowing incidents during a game against Detroit on March 30. ''The practice of swinging elbows after grabbing a rebound should not be a part of our game,'' said Joe Axelson, the N.B.A.'s director of operations.

title: JONES INTERCABLE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
BRUINS EXTEND LEAD TO 2-0 OVER SABRES
description: BOSTON (UPI) - Barry Pederson, Boston's outstanding rookie, scored three goals and tied two playoff records as he led the Bruins to a 7-3 victory over the Buffalo Sabres and a 2-0 lead in their Stanley Cup series.

title: BRITAIN'S FREEZE DISMAYS BANKERS
description: Britain's freeze of Argentine assets inside British territory has produced confusion and dismay in the international banking system, where America's freeze of Iranian assets in 1979 is still vividly remembered.

title: HOW THE CALL FOR SHIFT IN NUCLEAR STRATEGY EVOLVED
description: The magazine article that has added a new element to the debate over nuclear arms emerged from a series of informal discussions among four former senior Government officials. The article urged the United States and its allies to pledge not to be the first to use nuclear weapons in Europe.

title: REAGAN IN CARIBBEAN, LINKS GRENADA TO MOSCOW
description: President Reagan, opening a four-day stay in Barbados by conferring with five eastern Caribbean leaders, charged today that Grenada had joined with the Soviet Union, Nicaragua and Cuba in attempting to ''spread the virus'' of Marxism in the region.

title: Company News; Schmidt Says Pabst Bid Fails
description: C. Schmidt & Sons Inc., the Philadelphia brewery that bid $168 million to acquire the Pabst Brewing Company, said that it had ''reluctantly reached the conclusion'' that there is ''no likelihood'' of the merger taking place.

title: FRIGITRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Company News; Hercules Units Sold by Witco
description: The Witco Chemical Corporation, a maker of special purpose chemical and petroleum products, said it had sold its Hercules Products and Polymeric Systems divisions to separate companies for undisclosed sums.

title: DARING, OFFBEAT BOOKS AT SMALL-PRESS FAIR
description: The literary community's equivalent of Off Broadway and Off Off Broadway opens for a limited run tonight at 7:30, plays all day tomorrow and closes Sunday evening. It is the annual New York Book Fair, the big show for small presses that is now in its eighth year, and it's all free.

title: Business People; President of PMI Group Renews Company Ties
description: Peter V. Hall, 48, has been named to take office on Monday as president and chief operating officer of the PMI Group, a major private mortgage insurance company based in San Francisco. The position had been vacant.

title: CAR MAKERS MUST HELP STOP CAR THEFTS
description: To the Editor:

title: TV Weekend; SHORTCAKE, SURVIVALISTS, CITY OPERA AND COMEDY
description: TV tonight at 7:30.

title: Company News; BEHIND STROH'S EFFORT TO ACQUIRE SCHLITZ
description: When Peter W. Stroh, president and chief executive officer of the Stroh Brewery Company, graduated from Princeton University in 1951, he wanted to do something adventurous and signed up with the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Dow Advances 6.09; Giant Block Traded; Average Up 4.37 in Week
description: The stock market rose moderately yesterday in accelerated trading in a session highlighted by the second-largest block ever traded on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: GIFTS TO CHARITY RISE 21.3% TO $53.6 BILLION, A RECORD
description: In spite of the nation's economic downturn, individuals, companies and foundations contributed a record $53.6 billion to charitable organizations in 1981, an increase of 12.3 percent, according to the American Association of Fund-Raising Counsel.

title: 7,000 in Massachusetts Are Still Without Power
description: A state of emergency was declared today in this suburb of Springfield in southwestern Massachusetts, and extra police officers were called in to prevent more looting as thousands of residents began a second night without electricity in frigid weather.

title: ART: TWO EXHIBITIONS OF LATE TWORKOV WORK
description: AT first glance the forms in Jack Tworkov's late paintings look like tinted wraiths held in place by lengths of high-tension cable. Structured but not regimented, they present themselves for the most part either as triangles or as irregular quadrilaterals. We sense that a preordained order dictates their size and shape, but we do not see that order as tyranny. These paintings can in fact be read as a metaphor for a society in which everyone gives up something and gets in return a great deal more in the way of mutual tenderness.

title: Searches for Canoeist And Boat Are Ended
description: The Coast Guard called off two searches yesterday, one for a fishing boat believed to have sunk off New Jersey and another for a young canoeist whose body was not recovered with those of his three companions who drowned in the Hudson River.

title: Comings and Goings
description: John Lucas, a guard for the Washington Bullets, missed his third game of the season after failing to join the team for a flight to Indianapolis for a game against the Pacers. When Lucas caught up to the team before the game, he was sent back to the Bullets' hotel by Dr. Edward Houston, the Pacers' physician, who said Lucas had a fever and other complications.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, APRIL 9, 1982
description: International A peaceful end to the Falklands crisis was sought by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., in meetings with senior British leaders, but the Government of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher continued to issue threats against Argentina. On his arrival at Heathrow Airport Mr. Haig conceded that ''the situation is very tense and very difficult'' and he said that he had no ''American-approved solutions in my kit bag.'' (Page A1, Column 6.) The danger of war is waning, according to the Argentine Foreign Minister, Nicanor Costa Mendez, who spoke about the Falkland crisis on his return home from Washington. Nevertheless, there were reports that Argentina continued to pour troops and equipment into the islands. (A1:5.)

title: ALFRED FAIRBANKS
description: Alfred Fairbanks, the British authority on italic handwriting who referred to this script form as ''the dance of the pen,'' died in Hove, Sussex, on March 14.

title: Brenda Benet, Actress, Called Suicide Victim
description: Brenda Benet, an actress who played on the soap opera ''Days of Our Lives,'' shot and killed herself, the police said.

title: Met Museum Rates
description: New suggested-admission rates are in effect at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82d Street.

title: The City; Barnard in Accord With Music School
description: Barnard College and the Manhattan School of Music, neighbors on Morningside Heights, have announced a new program for the 1982-83 school year in which qualified students at each school will be allowed to take classes at the other.

title: RICHMOND IS ASKED BY ESPOSITO TO QUIT FOR THE PARTY'S SAKE
description: The Brooklyn Democratic leader, Meade H. Esposito, yesterday called on Representative Frederick W. Richmond, the subject of a Federal investigation, to ''resign immediately for the good of the Democratic Party.''

title: Academy in Rome Names Investment Banker
description: The American Academy in Rome, a leading international center for advanced independent study in the fine arts and humanities, has elected an investment banker, John W. Hyland Jr., chairman of its board of trustees.

title: HAIG AND BRITONS HOLD 6-HOUR TALKS ON THE FALKLANDS
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. met with senior British officials tonight in his search for a peaceful way out of the Falklands crisis, but the Government of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher continued to issue threats against Argentina.

title: Weekender Guide; Friday; PRAGUE IN TULLY HALL
description: The violinist Josef Suk will play works by two famous Czech forebears when he appears with the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center tonight at 8 and Sunday afternoon at 5 in Alice Tully Hall. Mr. Suk is a great-grandson of Antonin Dvorak and grandson of Josef Suk, the composer whose name he bears. Mr. Suk will be the principal violinist in Dvorak's ''Cypresses,'' joined by Leslie Parnas, cellist; Walter Trampler, violist, and Ida Kavafian, violinist. Performing with him in his grandfather's ''Elegie'' will be Charles Wadsworth, pianist, and Mr. Parnas. Schubert and Haydn are also on the program. Tickets are $10. Centercharge: 874-6770. PARK AVE. RUG SHOW

title: Books of the Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt HEADS YOU LOSE. And Other Apocryphal Tales. By Francis Greig. 210 pages. Crown. $11.95.

title: Index; International
description: Sakharov's wife says he is denied health treatment A2 Crucial sea-law parley opens A3 How the call for nuclear strategy shift evolved A4 Anti-nuclear groups forge a tentative alliance A5 Around the World A7 O.A.S. postpones debate on Falkland crisis A8 Nuclear subs will spearhead British naval force A8 Spain and Britain defers talks over Gibraltar A8 Government/Politics Justice agency ends inquiry on U.S. intelligence chief A28 Senator Weicker opens door to an independent candidacy B2 Washington Talk Briefing A14 Congress: Sluggishness marks both houses pending a budget A14 A priest's ''obsession'' with Asian-American children A14 GOOD FRIDAY Parking - Alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation - Regular collections. Federal, state and municipal offices - Federal offices open; state and municipal offices closed in New Jersey and Connecticut, open in New York. Post offices - Open; regular mail delivery. Banks - Open in New York; most in New Jersey and Connecticut closed. Stock and commodity markets - Closed. Transportation - Regular schedules, some extra cars. Libraries - Open. Schools - Closed.

title: CENTURY BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
SAKHAROV'S WIFE SAYS HE'S DENIED VITAL TREATMENT
description: Yelena G. Bonner, the wife of Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet physicist and human rights activist, said today that Dr. Sakharov had been rebuffed by the Soviet Academy of Sciences in his effort to gain admission to a special sanitarium for treatment of a recurrent heart ailment.

title: Arab Woman Is Killed By Israeli in West Bank
description: A 50-year-old Arab woman was shot and killed by an Israeli soldier today as she approached a military base in the occupied West Bank of the Jordan, the military command said.

title: WASHINGTON SCIENTIFIC (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 14
description: B-After a loss of $12,234 from discontinued operations

title: Advertising; Newsweek Is Adding New College Edition
description: Newsweek, which killed its nine-times-a-year college student demographic edition in January, will begin an entirely new concept next September, a 32-page publication called Newsweek On Campus that will be bound into copies going to 400,000 student-subscribers, and inserted into 425,000 copies of student publications on 55 major campuses.

title: The Evening Hours
description: ACCORDING to the man on the stage of the Pierre Hotel ballroom, a b unch of executives of the National Academy of Television Arts and S ciences sat around a table recently saying, ''Who are we going to dot his year?'' and one of them said, ''Why not Cy Coleman - he plays t he piano, and it will save the cost of a pianist.'' And that, the s tory went, was how Mr. Coleman was chosen to be honored at the s ilver anniversary of the academy's New York chapter earlier this w eek.

title: INTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
SOVERN WILL HEAD CITY CHARTER UNIT
description: Mayor Koch has selected Michael I. Sovern, the president of Columbia University, to head a new panel charged with recommending changes in New York City's Charter, the municipal equivalent of the Constitution.

title: The Great Swap, R.I.P.
description: Though only three months old, President Reagan's ''New Federalism'' seems to have died a swift, merciful death. Merciful, that is, for state and local governments, which stood to lose from the great swap of social programs. And merciful in a larger sense, too, for the President's bold proposal never provoked the high-minded debate that some anticipated and hoped for.

title: PROLER INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Yr to Jan 31
Bequest by Uris Gives Lenox Hill $5 Million
description: The late Harold Uris, a philanthropist and developer of office skyscrapers in Manhattan, bequeathed $5 million to Lenox Hill Hospital, according to his will, which was admitted for probate yesterday in Surrogate's Court in Manhattan. The value of the estate was put at ''in excess of $100 million.''

title: ADMINISTRATION SEEKS EASED RULES FOR INDUSTRIES IN CLEAN WATER ACT
description: The Reagan Administration is proposing 14 changes in the Clean Water Act, among them deletion of the rule that mandatory national standards must be established for treatment of industrial toxic wastes.

title: Fire Safety Program Approved for PATH
description: A $100 million program to improve emergency exits and ventilation in the underground PATH tunnels was approved yesterday, less than a month after the fire that trapped hundreds of commuters and injured more than 70 passengers.

title: FAMILY FARE FOR EASTER IN CITY AND SUBURB
description: Westchester

title: M.T.A. OPEN TO PURCHASING MORE SUBWAY CARS ABROAD
description: The Metropolitan Transporation Authority is negotiating with two more foreign companies to buy subway cars following its purchase last month of 325 subway cars from a Japanese manufacturer.

title: MARINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
A 1960 ROSSELLINI HAS NEW YORK PREMIERE
description: IN ''Era Notte a Roma''(''It Was Night in Rome''), made in 1960, the late Roberto Rossellini was returning to the tumultuous time in recent Italian history - the fall of Mussolini and the last days of World War II - that had provided the material for two of his bestknown works, the neorealistic ''Open City'' (1945) and ''Paisan'' (1946).

title: Auctions; Watches and snuffboxes.
description: BRITISH furnishings dominate sales next week in three major New York auction houses. A sale next Wednesday at 2 P.M. and Thursday at 10:15 A.M. and 2 P.M. at Sotheby Parke Bernet's York Avenue galleries, at 72d Street, offers English and Continental silver watches, precious objects and chess sets. Highlights are a 1927 Swiss watch in a gold case with a tourbillon action, which revolves once a minute, estimated to sell for as much as $55,000; an 1890 Swiss pocket watch with a chronometer action in a gold case by Albert Potter of Geneva (up to $30,000); an 1880 chronograph (stopwatch) with perpetual calendar and moon phases (up to $25,000), and an 1880 French gilt-and-silvered chiming carriage clock with a perpetual calendar (up to $25,000).

title: HUMANITIES CHIEF CALLS PBS FILM PROPAGANDA
description: William J. Bennett, chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities, said today that a documentary shown on public television this week was ''unabashed socialist-realism propaganda'' and not an appropriate project to have received Federal funds. The program was seen Monday night in New York on WNET-TV.

title: ISLANDERS ROMP AND LEAD, 2-0
description: The Islanders again overwhelmed the Pittsburgh Penguins tonight, winning by 7-2 for a 2-0 lead in the three-of-five-game series and continuing to serve notice that they are serious about winning a third consecutive Stanley Cup.

title: Oilers Win on Gretzky Goal in Overtime
description: Wayne Gretzky scored on a 45-foot slapshot at 6 minutes 20 seconds of overtime tonight to lead the Edmonton Oilers to a 3-2 victory over the Los Angeles Kings and even their Smythe Division three-of-five semifinal series at one game apiece.

title: ENERGY REVISIONS PROPOSED IN CANADA
description: The Government has completed introduction of a controversial package of energy legislation designed to encourage and help finance a reduction of foreign ownership in Canada's oil industry.

title: Mark McKee, Financial Aide And Ex-Newspaper Publisher
description: Mark T. McKee, a financial consultant and former newspaper publisher in Michigan, died Tuesday at his home in Oxford, Conn. He was 94 years old.

title: Reagan's Sea-Law Sellout
description: The Law of the Sea conference is an attempt by third-world nations to set up a ''new order'' in the world's production of minerals. Their idea is to subject all exploration and mining of the ocean bottom to international control. Their vehicle would be modeled on OPEC: a cartel capable of price-fixing by enforcing control of mineral production - run by an ''authority'' certain to provide permanent employment for thousands of third-world diplomats.

title: ARGENTINE ASSERTS WAR THREAT FADES
description: Argentina's Foreign Minister said today that ''the danger of war with Britain is fading.'' Speaking at the airport upon returning from Washington, the Minister, Nicanor Costa Mendez, said he was ''very optimistic'' about the chances of a peaceful settlement of the crisis with Britain over Argentina's seizure of the the Falkland Islands, a British colony.

title: STAGE: 'THE EVANGELIST,' MUSICAL BY AL CARMINES
description: AL CARMINES'S new show, ''The Evangelist,'' provides him with a subject that is dear to his musical heart -the religious and romantic fervor of born-again believers. The score is one of the strongest the composer has written in recent years, but the book wavers precariously between ''Elmer Gantry'' and ''Little Mary Sunshine.'' Sometimes there is a twinkle of self-mockery; other times the evening slides into unintentional self-parody.

title: U.S. CONGRESSIONAL GROUP ATTENDS SALVADORAN POLITICAL NEGOTIAIONS
description: After almost two weeks of trying to form a new government, El Salvador's political leaders met again tonight at the United States Ambassador's residence. Also in attendance was an eight-member Congressional delegation that arrived here this morning.

title: METS BEAT PHILS AND CARLTON,7-2, TO OPEN SEASON
description: Delayed for two days by snow and surrounded by 15,345 chilled fans and 50,000 empty seats, the Mets finally opened the season today by surviving the twin rigors of the weather and Steve Carlton and whipping the Philadelphia Phillies, 7-2.

title: WOUNDED DETECTIVE SHOOTS HIS ASSAILANT IN A STREET GUN DUEL
description: A New York City detective and a robbery suspect were wounded last night in an exchange of gunfire on a street corner in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: REPUBLIC RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
FAMILY FARE FOR EASTER IN CITY AND SUBURB
description: Hudson Valley

title: BELMONTE ARRESTED ON ASSAULT CHARGE
description: Eddie Belmonte, a former jockey whose license as an agent was revoked last June when the State Racing and Wagering Board found that he had bribed fellow jockeys to fix races, was arrested yeterday and charged with pistolwhipping another rider who had testified against him.

title: Money Funds Up in Week
description: Assets of the nation's 185 money market funds, including two new broker-dealer funds and a new institutional fund, rose by $2.13 billion in the week ended Wednesday, to a record total of $193.34 billion, according to the Investment Company Institute.

title: Help in Delivery
description: Tom McLaughlin, the head basketball coach at the University of Massachusetts, aided in the delivery of a son during Tuesday's blizzard with the help of a lace from a basketball sneaker to tie off the umbilical cord. McLaughlin and his wife, Debbie, were stranded in their home at Amherst, Mass., and after calling the hospital McLaughlin helped in the delivery of Thomas Jr., who weighed 8 pounds 11 ounces.

title: KEAN SAID TO PICK BUSINESSMAN FOR SENATE SEAT HELD BY WILLIAMS
description: Governor Kean has chosen Nicholas F. Brady, a business executive, to fill the United States Senate seat vacated by Harrison A. Williams Jr., leaders of the New Jersey Republican Party said today.

title: Advertising; Avon Planning Unit To Sell Magazines
description: Avon Products plans to set up a subsidiary called Great American Magazines that will use the company's expertise in direct mail selling it has developed through Avon Fashions to sell magazines.

title: Canada Jobless Rate 9%
description: Canada's unemployment rate surged to 9 percent in March, the highest level since Statistics Canada started keeping records in 1946, the Government announced today. The agency said nearly 1.23 million people were out of work in March, compared with 1.1 million in February, when the unemployment rate was 8.6 percent.

title: Books: A Pop Parable
description: THY BROTHER'S WIFE. By Andrew Greeley. 350 pages. Warner Books. $14.95.

title: HENDERSON PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
WEIS MARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 27
G.M. Closings To Idle 16,100
description: The General Motors Corporation said it will increase closings of its United States car and truck plants next week to five facilities, temporarily idling 16,100 workers.

title: RANGER OIL CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: The yr-ago revs have been restated; results are in U.S. dollars

title: FOUR NUCLEAR SUBS WILL SPEARHEAD BRITISH FLOTILLA
description: The spearhead of the British blockade of the Falkland Islands, which is to begin on Monday, will be formed by four of the Royal Navy's nuclear-powered submarines, military sources confirmed today.

title: 'Worn-Out' Warnings on Cigarettes
description: Some years ago the audience at a screening of an anti-smoking commercial made by an actor with lung cancer was so unnerved by his plight they dove as one for their cigarettes. The response was predictable.

title: Layoffs by Du Pont
description: The Du Pont Company is placing another 120 employees at its textile fibers plant here on alternating work weeks because of depressed demand, the company announced today. The cutback, effective April 19, is scheduled to last for at least six weeks.

title: A WHITBREAD SAILOR RETURNS FROM SEA
description: As we approached the Needles, the spit of land at the tip of the Isle of Wight that marks the entrance to the Solent, it was 10 P.M. and the strong tide was starting to turn against us. Fortunately, the wind had backed to the southwest and risen to 40 knots, giving us a reach down the homestretch in the 27,000-mile Whitbread Round-the-World Race.

title: FAMILY FARE FOR EASTER IN CITY AND SUBURB
description: EGGS will fly at the Bronx Zoo. People will careen in Brooklyn. Eeyore will munch poundcake. Pedestrians will amble. Radio City will simulate dawn. These are a few of the events that will take place this Easter weekend as spring tries to settle in irrevocably.

title: CONCERT: MOZART REQUIEM
description: THERE is a view of Mozart's Requiem that treats it as a dark funerary drama, his final though unfinished opera. This approach was common among an elder generation of conductors, mostly Middle European in origin. One of its more recent proponents was the late Karl Bohm, who could draw out a short silence or simple fermata until the listener had a glimpse of eternity.

title: Market Place; Semiconductor Prospects
description: SEMICONDUCTOR companies today are perceived the way steel companies were 50 years ago. That is, investors do not always differentiate between companies serving quite different markets.

title: Article 052082 -- No Title
description: A unit of Ashland Oil Inc. was fined $6 million today for bid-rigging and other illegal practices involving highway construction projects in North Carolina and Tennessee.

title: INDEPENDENT CANDIDACY POSSIBLE, WEICKER SAYS
description: The fight for the Republican nomination for the United States Senate intensified today with a new suggestion from Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. that he might run as an independent if he were not endorsed by the party's state convention in July.

title: WAITING FOR A BUDGET: THE PACE WOULD SUIT A SNAIL
description: ''That government is best which governs least,'' Henry David Thoreau once wrote, and the second session of the 97th Congress is living up to that maxim.

title: Bridge: Bidding a Successful Slam Can Be Especially Pleasant
description: In a team game it often happens that one team will play, perhaps cautiously, in three no-trump while the opposing pair with the same cards bid, perhaps optimistically, six no-trump. In such circumstances there are four possible combinations of results, only two of which are at all likely.

title: Turk Ends Bucharest Visit
description: Turkey's head of state, Gen. Kenan Evren, left Bucharest today after a three-day visit during which he discussed increased cooperation in the Balkans with the Rumanian President, Nicolae Ceausescu. In a joint statement, the two leaders called for new efforts to transform the Balkans into a ''zone of peace and good neighborliness.''

title: PUBLISHING: AMADO PAYS KNOPF A NOSTALGIC VISIT
description: AFTER attending a recent meeting of Latin American writers in Puerto Rico, Jorge Amado stopped in New York to visit his American publishers and, with his wife, Zelia, to pay a call on Alfred A. Knopf. It was a nostalgic reunion, because Mr. Knopf, the 89-year-old founder of the publishing house that bears his name, first brought the Brazilian writer to the attention of readers in the United States in 1945 by publishing ''The Violent Land,'' a sparse, stark novel about the bloody struggle over Brazil's cocoa lands. Knopf later published many other Amado novels, including the rollicking ''Gabriela, Clove and Cinnamon,'' ''Dona Flor and Her Two Husbands'' (the basis for a Brazilian movie and of ''Sarava,'' the 1979 Broadway musical) and ''Shepherds of the Night.''

title: SNOW MAY BRUSH NEW YORK TODAY
description: New York City may get two to four inches of snow today on top of the amount dropped by Tuesday's freak spring blizzard, according to the National Weather Service. Forecasters said, however, that the storm, if it comes at all, would be much milder than the one that struck Tuesday.

title: A MODEL TORY IN CRISIS ROLE
description: Nearly three years ago, as Conservatives reveled in their election triumph, Francis Pym, their spokesman on foreign policy, looked forward with excitement to becoming Foreign Secretary. Then Lord Carrington made it clear to the new Prime Minister, Margaret Thatcher, that he would accept nothing else. Deeply disappointed, Mr. Pym became Defense Secretary.

title: U.S. DEFICITS: THE FOREIGN INVESTOR'S PERSPECTIVE
description: To the Editor:

title: CHILD-ABUSE STUDY DID NOT TOUCH FOSTER CARE
description: To the Editor:

title: JAPANESE DENY ANY CUT IN CHIP EXPORTS TO U.S.
description: Japanese Government officials and semiconductor company executives said today that the industry in Japan had not begun to voluntarily curb exports of 64K random access memory chips. Nor, they added, is there any plan to do so.

title: Broadway; Ira Levin drama is scheduled for stage in the fall.
description: ''CANTORIAL,'' a new play by Ira Levin, directed by Robert Moore, will go into rehearsal in August, try out at the Colonial Theater in Boston in September and open on Broadway in October. ''I'm gathering the old team - Ira, Bob, Roger Stevens and moi,'' Alfred de Liagre Jr. says. Mr. Stevens and Mr. de Liagre produced ''Deathtrap,'' which Mr. Levin wrote and Mr. Moore directed on Broadway, and which apparently has been helped, not hurt, by the recently released movie. Business at the Biltmore Theater is up. ''Deathtrap'' is a thriller, of course. ''Cantorial'' is more of a drama. It is about a young couple who are converting an abandoned synagogue in SoHo into a home.

title: Giant-Jet Schedules
description: The achievement of the Giants and Jets in reaching the playoffs last season has been reflected in the National Football League's schedule for next season. Each will play two games on Monday nights, a first for both teams, which have never appeared more than once a season in the series televised by ABC for the last 12 years.

title: ALLBRITTON IS SUSPENDING TALKS OVER DAILY NEWS
description: Joe L. Allbritton, who has signed a letter of intent to take over the troubled Daily News, suspended negotiations with the newspaper's unions last night after they expressed interest in talking to Rupert Murdoch, the publisher of The New York Post, about buying The News.

title: The Ultimate Economy
description: The Adams Township School District in upper Michigan has just two schools and only 530 students, but like other school districts around the country, it faces severe revenue cuts next year, and its Superintendent, Gerald Bayer, has been under pressure to trim expenditures.

title: Company News; National Patent Files 4 Lens Suits
description: The National Patent Development Corporation and its subsidiary, NPD Technologies Inc., said they had filed patent infringement suits in four district courts covering soft contact lens patents validated in a recent California Federal court decision.

title: Strike Hurt Attendance
description: After last summer's 50-day baseball strike, 2,500 fewer fans than expected attended each game through the end of the season, according to a survey by two professors at the University of Pittsburgh.

title: TWINS DEFEAT MARINERS, 4-1
description: Gary Gaetti, a rookie third baseman, hit his third home run in three games and singled in another run, and another rookie, Jesus Vega, made two run-scoring singles to lead the Minnesota Twins to a 4-1 victory today over the Seattle Mariners.

title: Iran Says Afghan War Is Close to Its Border
description: A spokesman for Iran's military chiefs of staff said today that Soviet forces were fighting Afghan guerrillas close to the Iranian border, but denied reports that Soviet troops had entered Iranian territory. He made the comments in a telephone interview.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I don't have any American-approved solution in my kit bag.'' - Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., on the Falklands dispute.

title: BRITAIN AND SPAIN DEFERRING GIBRALTAR SETTLEMENT MOVES
description: Spain and Britain agreed today to postpone the opening of the land frontier to Gibraltar and the start of negotiations on the future of the British colony because of the crisis over the Falkland Islands.

title: Pop Jazz; HERBIE MANN ESTABLISHES MUSICAL BASE ON FIFTH AVE.
description: AFTER three decades as a professional musician, Herbie Mann, the jazz flutist, has finally realized the Great American Dream - he can walk to work. Last week, he took charge of the new music policy at Saratoga, a restaurant in the American Stanhope Hotel, 995 Fifth Avenue, opposite the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and just three blocks from his home. He and his musicians will be there 20 weeks a year, and he will bring in other groups to play when he is not on hand.

title: A PENNSYLVANIAN NIGHT OF DANCES BY WOMEN
description: Ballet companies have danced all-Stravinsky programs. They've presented all-Antony Tudor nights. But this weekend the Pennsylvania Ballet will go a step farther. Known as one of the liveliest companies on the ballet scene since Barbara Weisberger founded it in 1963, the Pennsylvania Ballet will uphold that reputation by offering a theme program with a difference. The program, ''In Celebration of the Woman Choreographer,'' will be presented tomorrow at 2 and 8 and Sunday at 2 at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. (Tonight at 8 the company performs works by George Balanchine, Margo Sappington and Jose Limon.)

title: AT YONKERS, HUDSON OF OLD IN PHOTOS
description: The Hudson River begins in a small pond in the Adironacks, Lake Tear of the Clouds, and empties into one of the grandest harbors in the world, New York. Along its impressive way, the river has witnessed much that is important to the nation's heritage. That history, from clusters of immigrants to the mansions of the rich, is represented in small but elegant measure at - appropriately - the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers, in an exhibition of 30 photographs that will be on view, free of charge, until April 18.

title: MARCADE GROUP INC reports earnings for Yr to Jan 30
description: B-After a loss of $859,000 from discontinued operations of a tax credit of $491,000...C-After a loss of $3,908,000 from discontinued operations and a tax credit of $1,146,000

title: Ships Backed Up on Rhine
description: More than 200 ships were backed up today on the Rhine River because of a vessel that sank after its cargo shifted and a fire broke out.

title: BRITISH ZONES' LESSONS
description: .8,2Do not expect too much of enterprise zones. No, that is not a gloomy, self-serving attempt to out-Cassandra Cassandra. It is rather the message from the British experience with this method of urban renewal.

title: SHAWMUT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The yr-ago figures were restated to reflect acquisition of First Melville Bancorp Inc on a pooling of interests basis

title: Intel's Profit Up in Quarter
description: The Intel Corporation, the world's leading producer of microprocessors and one of the leading manufacturers of semiconductor memories, announced yesterday that net income in the first quarter of 1981 more than doubled, to $5.4 million, or 12 cents a share, from $2.1 million, or 5 cents a share, in the first quarter of 1980.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report Tuesday about the Times Square re- development project incorrectly de- scribed the views of Herbert J. Sturz, chairman of the City Planning Com- mission. He said that while suits might be filed by owners of porno- graphic bookstores in the area to stop the project, he believed construction would begin as planned in 1984.

title: WARNER ELECTRIC BRAKE & CLUTCH CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The 1981 results were adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in June 1981 and to reflect a change in accounting for foreign translation

title: Earnings; CHEMICAL BANK UP BY 15.4%
description: The Chemical New York Corporation reported yesterday that its net operating earnings rose 15.4 percent in the first quarter, to $62.2 million, from $53.9 million in the similar period a year earlier.
