Chemical, the nation's seventh-largest bank holding company, was the first of the majors to report first-quarter earnings.

title: Company News; 30% Merck Stake In Japan Concern
description: Merck & Company reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission that on March 31 it acquired 30 percent of the capital stock of Torii & Company, a Japanese drug manufacturer, for about $8 million in cash.

title: Tracy Caulkins Breaks A Weissmuller Record
description: Tracy Caulkins became the nation's top-winning swimmer tonight, surpassing Johnny Weissmuller's total of championships by winning her 37th national title.

title: Brand Drops Suit
description: Jack Brand terminated his lawsuit against the Seattle Sounders and will wait for arbitration in his dispute with the North American Soccer League club.

title: The City; Merchant Accused In Abduction Case
description: The owner of a Manhattan coin shop was indicted yesterday on charges that he was one of four men who kidnapped an elderly jeweler last September. He is also accused of paying an undercover transit officer to rob his shop and to murder his business partner.

title: O.A.S. POSTPONES DEBATE ON CRISIS
description: The Organization of American States postponed a debate on the Falkland Islands today until Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. had a chance to report on his efforts in London and Buenos Aires to bring about a solution.

title: SUN BANKS OF FLORIDA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Pennsylvania's Governor Signs Welfare Purge Bill
description: Gov. Dick Thornburgh signed legislation today putting new limits on cash assistance for people judged able-bodied and creating the state's first ''workfare'' program.

title: POSTAL SERVICE SETS A TRAP TO PROTECT THE UNWARY AD READER
description: The advertisement is enticing: ''Earn $750 a month in your spare time from your own home. Be your own boss.'' A second one begins: ''European Reducing Formula Now Available. Lose Weight Like Never Before.'' The advertisements will begin running in the classified sections of newspapers in West Virginia, Pennsylvania and much of New York state early next week. But those who respond are in for a surprise.

title: RECALL OF CANNED SALMON EXPANDS
description: The Government today expanded its recall of canned Alaskan salmon. The recall now covers eight packing plants and more than 50 million cans that may have defects that can trigger a growth of botulinum toxins.

title: Car Output Off 30.6% in U.S.
description: United States car production in the first quarter fell 30.6 percent from the same 1981 period, to 1.1 million units, the trade paper Automotive News reported today.

title: FAMILY FARE FOR EASTER IN CITY AND SUBURB
description: Long Island

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: DSI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Net loss after a loss of $292,000 from discontinued operations

title: At the Movies; Cat eases job for Malcolm McDowell.
description: IN the new version of that old thriller, ''Cat People,'' Malcolm McDowell turns into a big black cat who kills women and eats portions of them, right after having had a bit of sex with the hapless ladies.

title: Technical Moves Push Financial Futures Up
description: After moving aimlessly all week, prices of financial futures shot upward yesterday in what brokers described as a largely technical move. They noted that many holders of short, or sell, futures in Treasury bonds, bills and Ginnie Mae futures moved to cover their positions before the holiday weekend by buying offsetting contracts. (All commodity markets will be closed today for Good Friday.)

title: INDICTMENTS ILL TIMED FOR NEWARK'S VOTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: RAIN HALTS MASTERS AS ZOELLER POSTS 72
description: The start of the 46th Masters Tournament today proved once again that you can't have everything. The field was there, the spectators were there, the distinguished foreign visitors were there and everything else was in place - except the balmy spring weather that normally envelops a Masters.

title: AN 'EVENT MAKER' CELEBRATES THE SEASON
description: Regardless of rain, snow, sleet, slush or mud puddles, Karin Bacon's Great Egg Event will get under way today at the Bronx Zoo. The egg rolling may have to be done in the parking lot rather than on the lawn, she said, but the weekend parades, pageants, egg decorating and chicken hatching will still go on as scheduled.

title: APECO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: B-After a loss of $476,000 from discontinued operations

title: News Analysis
description: The call Wednesday by four former Government officials for an allied pledge not to be the first to use nuclear weapons in Europe, coming on top of the movement for a freeze on nuclear arsenals, is new evidence that the nation is moving toward the first major debate on nuclear policy in more than a decade.

title: ART: GEORGE SEGAL
description: GEORGE SEGAL is a prolific sculptor, who is close to being an institution. He's been doing more or less the same thing for so long that for the most casual followers of art, a Segal is as instantly recognizable as a familiar landmark. Meanwhile, an idea that seemed poply amusing when it first appeared at the start of the 1960's has since acquired grandeur, and even the purists with misgivings about realism achieved not by modeling but by the shortcut of casts taken from living models are no longer heard from. It was no surprise when the Neuberger Museum in Purchase, N.Y., recently invited its patrons to choose from 44 possible acquisitions, and Mr. Segal's proposed memorial to Franklin D. Roosevelt won, hands down.

title: Spy Denies 2 Associates Helped Him Rob Banks
description: Christopher John Boyce, a 29-year-old convicted spy, testified today that he had no qualms about robbing a number of banks in the Pacific Northwest, but denied that two former co-defendants had any part in the holdups.

title: C.I.A.'s DIRECTOR CLEARED IN FOREIGN AGENT INQUIRY
description: The Justice Department closed the books today on its investigation of William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, concluding that his failure to register as a foreign agent for Indonesia in 1976 did not violate the law.

title: About Real Estate; FOCUS ON LUXURY RENTALS IN MANHATTAN
description: In a period when more and more developers are scorning involvement in even the luxury price levels of the rental housing market to concentrate on cooperative and condominium residences, Donald Zucker is one entrepreneur who unabashedly proclaims the belief that there is a strong market among the affluent for rental apartments.

title: UNITED TELECOMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-After income from discontinued operations of $55,929,000 for the qr and $57,599,000 for the yr; the 1981 periods were restated to reflect company merged on apooling of interests basis

title: ANTI-NUCLEAR GROUPS FORGING TENTATIVE LINKS
description: The European movement that opposes the deployment of new American nuclear missiles in Western Europe and those in the United States who are calling for a freeze in nuclear arsenals have begun to forge a tentative alliance. But significant differences remain in the roots, composition, and tactics of the groups.

title: SCHLITZ LOSES PLEA ON STROH
description: A Federal judge today dismissed an attempt by the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company to block a takeover attempt by the Stroh Brewery Company on antitrust grounds.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Aid Auto Stores Inc., based in New York, said it had agreed to sell its Florida business to Discount Auto Parts Inc., a privately held Florida corporation, for about $1 million.

title: Business People
description: Introducing New Scents At Warner Cosmetics

title: CHEMICAL NEW YORK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The per shr figures reflect a 50 percent stock divd to be paid Apr 15

title: Queen Beatrix to Visit White House on April 19
description: after the shooting had stopped in the American Revolution, John Adams was accepted as a United States envoy by the Netherlands, which thus became the first country to grant official recognition to United States independence.

title: Illustrators' Show
description: Norman Rockwell, Frederic Remington, John Held and Charles Dana Gibson are among the artists whose works are in ''Great American Illustrators,'' an exhibition on view through April 25 at the C.W. Post Center of Long Island University on Route 25A in Greenvale.

title: The Other Balance (1)
description: Secretary of State Haig resorted to verbal overkill when he declared that an American policy of ''no first use'' of nuclear weapons would be ''tantamount to making Europe safe for conventional aggression.''

title: RANGERS WIN, 7-3, TO EVEN PLAYOFFS
description: Midway in the regular season, Mikko Leinonen, the Rangers' 26-year-old rookie from Finland, was distinguished among his teammates only because he could translate into English the thoughts of Reijo Ruotsalainen, the other Finnish rookie.

title: Socal Sees Profit Drop
description: First-quarter profits for the Standard Oil Company of California will be ''down very sharply,'' George M. Keller, chairman and chief executive told a group of journalists in New York City yesterday.

title: LAWYER RULED UNNECESSARY AT A LINEUP BEFORE CHARGES
description: Suspects are not entitled to legal representation at police lineups held before formal legal proceedings are begun against them, the New York Court of Appeals ruled Wednesday.

title: Advertising; Needham Gets Gallo Account
description: AT long last, California's little old wine makers have made up their minds. Eight months after Young & Rubicam resigned a major portion of the E.& J. Gallo Winery advertising account, the client has decided to assign its Premium Wines and Andre Champagne to Needham, Harper & Steers, Chicago, and give a special unnamed assignment to the agency's Los Angeles office.

title: DOMENICI CALLS BUDGET PACT TASK OF O'NEILL AND REAGAN
description: Congressional and White House negotiators have made enough progress toward a compromise budget that they ''could reach an agreement tomorrow,'' Senator Pete V. Domenici, chairman of the Budget Committee, said today. But he said that President Reagan and Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the Speaker of the House, were not yet ''on board.''

title: Javelin Actions Taken
description: A Quebec Superior Court judge today suspended the board of directors of Javelin International Ltd. and named a Montreal lawyer as receiver-manager to supervise the natural resources exploration and development organization for two years.

title: Nigeria Head's Oil Statement
description: The Nigerian news agency today quoted President Shehu Shagari as saying that some international oil companies have reversed their plans to stop buying Nigerian oil.

title: CENTRAL PENN NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
MALL STANDS ALONE IN BROOKLYN 'RENAISSANCE'
description: In October 1969, at the height of his campaign for re-election, Mayor John V. Lindsay unveiled a spectacular plan for the revitalization of downtown Brooklyn. When the campaign ended, most of the plan was forgotten. But one part survives, and some would say thrives. It is the Fulton Street Mall.

title: INTERCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Parley of the Nonaligned Assails the Israelis
description: A conference of foreign ministers from the countries proclaiming nonalignment ended tonight with a sweeping condemnation of Israel and a plea for the United States to review its Middle East policies.

title: U.S. EDUCATION AIDE RESIGNS ABRUPTLY
description: William C. Clohan Jr. resigned abruptly today as Under Secretary of Education, causing a stir in the educational community.

title: Rare Hawaiian Artifacts In Cooper-Hewitt Show
description: An exhibition of more than 300 rare Hawaiian artifacts is on view through May 9 at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum, Fifth Avenue and 91st Street. The show, ''Hawaii: The Royal Isles,'' on tour for the first time outside the Hawaiian Islands, contains objects of ceremony and daily use, paintings, jewelry and clothing that offer insights into the culture and history of the only American state to have emerged from a monarchy.

title: MANY AT G.M. RELUCTANTLY VOTING TO TRADE MONEY FOR JOB SECURITY
description: Hourly workers at the General Motors Corporation appear to be reluctantly approving contract concessions, enticed largely by a desire to protect jobs and maintain labor peace. But strong resistance has been reported at some plants.

title: STAGE: 'SOLOMON'S CHILD,' TALE OF A YOUNG CULTIST
description: ''SOLOMON'S CHILD,'' which opened at the Little Theater last night, isn't the worst production of this limp Broadway season, but it just may be the most pointless. The evening's nonfiction subject - fanatical cults of the Jim Jones ilk - has already been examined ad infinitum in print, movies and television programs. The play's author, Tom Dulack, has nothing new or enlightening to say about this phenomenon and little discernible facility for playwriting. His sole achievement is to provide employment, however temporary, for those good actors John McMartin and Anthony Zerbe.

title: Abitibi, Union End Talks
description: Contract talks have broken down between Abitibi-Price Inc., the world's largest newsprint producer, and the paperworkers' union, opening the way for a strike next month at eastern Canada paper mills, the union said today.

title: THRIFTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
'LUCIA,' LIVE FROM GIANNA ROLANDI
description: Gianna Rolandi is a wonderful, Italianate name for a rising diva. But the woman behind it is an all-American product - born, raised, trained and apprenticed in this country - and one of the new generation of home-grown singers now in such demand in the world's opera houses.

title: Burnham Founder Set to Step Down
description: I.W. Burnham 2d, the easygoing Wall Street investment banker who is known to everyone as Tubby, called a little press conference at his downtown Manhattan office yesterday to announce that at the age of 73, he was stepping down as chairman of Drexel Burnham Lambert, the brokerage firm he started nearly a half-century ago, ''to make room for the younger men.''

title: FAMILY FARE FOR EASTER IN CITY AND SUBURB
description: Connecticut

title: Plea in Cleveland Kidnapping
description: A Mayville, N.Y., woman and her 21-yearold son pleaded not guilty in Federal court Wednesday to kidnapping charges in the 19-month disappearance of a Cleveland girl. Helen Schmidt and Charles Gress are accused of abducting Denise Kay Gravely, 4, who was returned to her mother March 26.

title: LANIER BUSINESS PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 26
U.S. Steel to Freeze Sheet Steel Prices
description: The United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest steel producer, said yesterday that it will freeze the published prices for its entire line of sheet steel products for the remainder of 1982. Sheet steel, used extensively by the automobile and appliance industries, accounts for 40 percent of the company's total steel sales.

title: Sports of The Times; Mets Thrive in the Tropics
description: HERE in the warm-weather port of the Eastern Divison, the sun was shining on the Mets. Never again will people be able to make Philadelphia jokes so recklessly. For the Mets - a team trying to crawl out of its personal Ice Age - Philadelphia turned out to be a health spa.

title: Small Companies Deserve R.& D. Help
description: To the Editor:

title: SECURITY BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
KRUEGER, W A, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
THE BROAD GROWTH AT SYNTEX
description: During the 1960's, when the Syntex Corporation introduced the first oral contraceptives, the company bedeviled Wall Street. Syntex became branded as a ''trading'' stock for speculators in a series of harrowing stock price surges and collapses, including one cycle in which the stock rocketed from a 1963 low of 11 5/8 to 190 1/2 in January 1964, then plummeted to 60 1/8 during the next four months.

title: Braniff Notes Officials' Pay
description: The chairman of the Braniff International Corporation, Howard D. Putnam, was hired away from Southwest Airlines last fall with a three-year contract worth more than $750,000, according to proxy statements filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: HAWKS BEAT STARS, 5-3, AND LEAD, 2-0
description: Denis Savard's goal midway through the third period tonight helped the Chicago Black Hawks defeat the Minnesota North Stars, 5-3, and open a 2-0 lead in their three-of-five-game playoff series.

title: SEAL FLEET INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After net gain from change in accounting; included in net income for the yr ended Dec 31, 1981 is $287,000 from the sale of assets

title: ARGENTINA COVETS THE ANTARCTIC, TOO
description: Argentina's invasion of the Falkland Islands may be seen as part of a larger expansionist ambition aimed in recent years at the Antarctic, with its unexploited riches.

title: Cavendes Bank Stake
description: The Federal Reserve Board has given a go-ahead to a Venezuelan investor's effort to increase his ownership in Florida National Banks of Florida Inc. The board, in a letter made public today, said that C.A. Cavendes and his company, Sociedad Financiera of Venezuela, could increase voting shares in Florida National from 9.9 percent to 24.99 percent.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate payable by savings institutionsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: MILLER, HERMAN, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
description: The shrs outstndg for the 1981 periods were restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stocksplit paid Oct 31, 1981

title: CRUCIAL SEA LAW PARLEY BEGINS AT U.N.
description: The United States and a score of other nations met privately today to begin what are regarded here as the make-or-break negotations at the conference writing rules for the seas.

title: ARMS SALE NON-POLICY
description: In the absence of a clearly defined policy on the sale of conventional arms, the Reagan Administration seems willing to sell more highly sophisticated weapons to a wider variety of countries than any previous administration. A case in point is the pending sale of 24 F-16 fighters to Venezuela.

title: Advertising; Deutsch, BBDO Office Name New Presidents
description: There are new presidents at David Deutsch Associates Advertising and at the Chicago office of BBDO International.

title: Knicks Eliminated as Playoff Contender
description: A little more than five months after they opened the season with hopes of becoming a contender, the Knicks were eliminated from playoff contention yesterday afternoon when they lost by 110-106 to the Boston Celtics before an announced crowd of 11,916 at Madison Square Garden.

title: YANKEES HIT AT WEST POINT
description: With 4,400 cadets gawking, clamoring for autographs and waving napkins in greeting, the Yankees shared a training-table lunch with the United States Military Academy's baseball team today and then worked out in the West Point field house.

title: WORLD BANK INDIA LOAN
description: The World Bank said today that it would lend $200 million to India to help it expand the capacities of its four domestic oil refineries. It said that the loan, repayable in 20 years, included five years' grace and carried an annual interest rate of 11.6 percent. Some of the money for the refineries, two of which are in Bombay, one in Madras and one in Cochin, will be used to install secondary processing facilities to manufacture higher value products from fuel oil, the bank's statement said.

title: A 1945 ARGENTINE HESITATION OVER THE FALKLANDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; ESPN Leaving D'Arcy Agency
description: The Entertainment and Sports Programming Network of Bristol, Conn., a subsididary of Getty Oil, will be leaving D'Arcy-MacManus & Masius, its agency since its inception in 1980, and going to Kurtz & Tarlow.

title: Katherine Rawls, 64, Winner Of 33 U.S. Swimming Titles
description: Katherine Rawls, who had held the record for the most championships by a female American swimmer until last year, died Thursday of cancer.

title: Article 051285 -- No Title
description: Gov. John Spellman, turning aside national security arguments, today rejected a proposal for a port and pipeline to carry Alaskan crude oil to refineries in the Northwest and upper Middle West.

title: FAMILY FARE FOR EASTER IN CITY AND SUBURB
description: New Jersey

title: An Arms Talk Agenda
description: Skeptics think that President Reagan's offer to meet Leonid Brezhnev is meant mainly to calm the fears of war stirred up by American belligerence. But the Kremlin insists that it remains ready to reopen arms control talks. A summit conference can determine whether it is, and also force the Reagan team finally to decide what kind of deal it wants.

title: Military Analysis
description: Iranian forces that are on the Iranian-Iraqi border about 100 miles northeast of Baghdad, Iraq's capital, may be planning a push toward that city, in the view of military analysts in Washington and Western Europe. These forces are in Qasr-i-Shirin, the Iranian border town that the Iraqis captured at the beginning of the war in September 1980 and that the Iranians retook late last year.

title: 4 Electrocuted in Accident
description: Four persons, including a father and his 16-year-old son, were electrocuted Wednesday while trying to install a 42-foot television antenna. A police spokesman said the four were killed instantly when a gust of wind blew the end of the antenna into contact with a live power line.

title: Credit Markets; BOND PRICES REGAIN STRENGTH
description: Government bond prices rose yesterday after two lackluster sessions, while tax-exempt bonds rounded out a brisk three-day rally. The Treasury's 14 percent bond due 2011 jumped 1 5/8 points, to close at 103 28/32 for a yield of 13.46 percent. Coupon issues also moved higher. The 14 3/8 percent seven-year Treasury note, auctioned March 31 at an average yield of 14.42 percent, finished at 101 1/2, up nearly a point, to return 14.02 percent.

title: News Analysis
description: The world's big oil companies and the powerful oil-producing countries are engaged in a major confrontation over prices. The issue is the high price that Nigeria, with the strong backing of other members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, is charging for its oil. The companies, which can buy the same high-quality crude for $4.50 a barrel less than from North Sea producers, are tiring of losing money on every barrel of Nigerian crude they purchase.

title: Advertising; Addendum
description: * Hill and Knowlton has formed a division with headquarters in Los Angeles to handle public relations services in the United States for Japanese companies.

title: Coast Officials Urge Ban On Tankers in Tunnels
description: To prevent a recurrence of the explosion in the Caldecott Tunnel that incinerated seven persons here, politicans demanded today that urgent measures be taken to ban gasoline tank trucks from such routes.

title: A PRIEST'S OBSESSION: 'THESE ARE OUR CHILDREN'
description: The Rev. Alfred Keane still recalls that moment on Christmas Eve, 1970, as he prepared for midnight services in a small parish in the Korean port city of Inchon.

title: 2 SUSPECTS ARRESTED
description: Former City Councilman Matthew J. Troy foiled a holdup at John F. Kennedy International Airport last night by telling three gunmen that he, too, was armed, the police said.

title: CABLE TV INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
RONSON CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-After a loss of $15,768,000 from discontinued operations...C-A fter a loss of $12,347,000 from discontinued operations; the yr-ago results include net sales of $25,411,000 and an operating loss of $834,000 from the company's California subsidiary whose assets were sold on Dec 31, 1980 to the Boeing Co

title: Drums at Soundscape
description: Drum Song, music featuring voice and percussion instruments, will be presented by Bob Moses and his ensemble tomorrow at 9 P.M. at Soundscape, 500 West 52d Street. Mr. Moses, a drummer and composer, will perform with his group - Guillerme Franco, Aujeb Dieng, and Dennis Irwin - and the singer Abbey Lincoln. Tickets are $7 (Theater Development Fund vouchers accepted). Information: 581-7032.

title: CITIBANK ENDS DEPOSIT SURVEY
description: An effort by Citibank to improve its weekly money supply forecast by surveying deposits at about 20 banks across the country has been abandoned, bank officials acknowledged yesterday. They said the plan left it vulnerable to allegations that it would make improper use of the material.

title: PIER 1 IMPORTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: B-Including tax credits of $1,395,000 for the qr and $2,373,000 for the qr and $1,218,000 for the 6 mos

title: TADD DAMERON'S MUSIC, WITH LOVE
description: the list of world-famous modern jazzmen who recorded compositions by Tadley Ewing Dameron goes on and on. But mention Tadd Dameron to many younger jazz fans today and he will be remembered, if at all, as a vaguely familiar name on a record jacket. ''The Fabulous Fats Navarro'' is an album no serious student of post-World War II jazz should be without, but while Mr. Navarro had star billing on the album, in fact he was only the featured soloist. The man who led the bands on that album, and who wrote and arranged ''Lady Bird,'' ''Good Bait,'' ''Our Delight'' and the other celebrated jazz compositions those bands played, was Tadd Dameron.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Company has appointed Alan J. Lipner vice president-taxes.

title: JUSTICE FOR 19 YEARS ON COAST HIGH COURT
description: Former Justice Mathew Tobriner of the California Supreme Court died Wednesday. He was 78 years old. Justice Tobriner, who called his 19 years of service on the court ''the greatest experience of my life,'' retired in January.

title: NOTES ON PEOPLE
description: How Quickly They Forget

title: Advertising; People
description: * Joan Parker, a senior vice president, appointed director of N.W. Ayer's public relations department.

title: DEFENSE ASSERTS MOON'S CHURCH OWNS MANSION
description: Defense lawyers presented testimony and documents yesterday to show that the Unification Church owned the Westchester County residence of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon.

title: BIG BRITISH COMMUNITY IN ARGENTINA IS UNEASY
description: Argentina's large and influential British community is growing increasingly uneasy as the crisis over the Falkland Islands continues.

title: STOUFFER TRIAL JURORS TOLD TO 'STAY WITH EVIDENCE'
description: The judge told the jury in the Stouffer's Inn arson and murder trial today not to speculate or play detective but to ''stay with the evidence'' in reaching a verdict. The jury has been deliberating for four days.

title: GORDON JEWELRY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to give effect to the change to the LIFO method of valuation for some inventories; yr-ago shr earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in Sept 1981

title: Mark Twain School Aide Would Bar 'Huck Finn'
description: An official at a school named for Mark Twain said Wednesday that ''The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn'' was ''racist trash'' and should not be part of the county system's curriculum.

title: United Telecom Net Falls 50%
description: United Telecommunications Inc. reported yesterday that net income in the first quarter of 1982 plunged 50 percent, to $50.9 million, or 64 cents a share, from $101.8 million, or 62 cents a share, in the first quarter of 1981.

title: BURT SHEVELOVE, 66, WRITER AND DIRECTOR, DIES
description: Burt Shevelove, the co-author with Larry Gelbart of the book for the 1962 hit musical ''A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum'' and the director of the popular 1971 revival of ''No, No, Nanette,'' died yesterday in his apartment in London, where he had lived for some 15 years. He was 66 years old.

title: Cafeteria Slips At Big Board
description: While stock market prices advanced yesterday, the fortunes of the New York Stock Exchange dropped a bit, at least in the eyes of the New York City Health Department. The exchange's employee cafeteria turned up on the department's weekly list of restaurants held in violation of the Health Code.

title: Advertising; Mullen Draws Account From a Rival Again
description: James X. Mullen, president of Mullen Advertising, Beverly Farms, Mass., which he founded 10 years ago, has never been inside another ad agency. But that handicap, if it is one, did not prevent his agency from drawing accounts away from two of the hottest shops in town.

title: 8-YEAR-OLD'S BIRTHDAY PARTY IN A COMPUTER CENTER
description: Tracy Pizzo decided that Chunky's Cheese Pizza Parlor was not the place for her eighth birthday party after all. She chose the Future Center of the Capital Children's Museum, where her 13 guests were able to try their hand at the video games on 20 Atari 800 microcomputers.

title: A Record Ace
description: Mancil Davis, the club professional at Woodlands Country Club in Houston, hit an 8-iron shot on the 150-yard sixth hole while giving a lesson and presumed that the shot had carried past the green. But the ball went into the cup on the fly. For the 27-year-old Davis, it was his 41st hole-in-one, and that total tied him with Art Wall as the career leader among professionals.

title: Mexico Says Quake Area Is Still 'Very Dangerous'
description: Officials said today that a ''very dangerous situation'' still existed around a volcano 420 miles southeast of Mexico City and again warned peasants against returning to their farms.

title: Australian Premier Defeats Challenge by a Former Aide
description: Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser turned back a challenge to his leadership today, defeating a former Cabinet Minister, Andrew Peacock, in a special ballot for leader of the governing Liberal Party.

title: COALITION TO PROTEST REAGAN'S POLICIES
description: A coalition of more than 80 national organizations announced today that it would sponsor a grass-roots campaign of marches, demonstrations and other activities to show opposition to President Reagan's domestic policies, especially cuts in the budget for social welfare programs.

title: Gunmen in Ottawa Wound Turkish Envoy
description: Gunmen critically wounded a commercial officer at the Turkish Embassy here today, a Turkish Embassy spokesman said.

title: China Reports Its Oil Reserves
description: The official New China News Agency said today that China had the world's largest oil reserves, between 210 billion and 420 billion barrels. Saudi Arabia has the largest proven oil reserves, more than 160 billion barrels.

title:
PATENTS;
Military Surveillance Methods Are Disclosed
description: Several methods of surveillance were disclosed in patents granted to the Navy this week. One is for the automatic observation from aircraft of man-made objects on the ground.

title: 8,000 G.E. WORKERS STRIKE IN A SUBCONTRACTING PROTEST
description: About 8,000 union workers here struck General Electric's biggest maze of plants today in support of demands that the company stop subcontracting work to factories elsewhere in the United States and in Canada, many of them nonunion.

title: IN NEWARK, A CHURCH, AND MORE, IS GONE
description: They tore down my church in 1980. The memory of my last view of it remains, like the terrible scars left by a wrecking ball, fragmented and painful.

title: FEDERAL CUTS FRUSTRATE 'WORKING POOR' MOTHER
description: When the Federal Government decided to end supplemental welfare and food stamp benefits for many of the ''working poor,'' administration spokesmen promised that budget cutbacks would not affect the ''truly needy.'' There were many days this winter when Jessie Mae Hurst and her two sons strongly disagreed.

title: David Stein, Publisher Of The Riverdale Press
description: David A. Stein, founder and retired publisher of The Riverdale Press and a leader in community affairs, died of a heart attack at his home Thursday. He was 71 years old and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The closeness of the vote makes it clear this was a very difficult and painful step for our U.A.W-G.M. members, yet one taken in an attempt to address our problems in these very troubled economic times.'' - Douglas A. Fraser, president, United Auto Workers, on contract with General Motors. (1:5.)

title: 63,000 DELINQUENT ON STUDENT LOANS
description: A Federal crackdown on doctors, dentists and other professionals who are not repaying student loans on time shows that 63,000 of them are delinquent in paying nearly $31 million.

title: Sports People; Valenzuela to Start
description: Fernando Valenzuela couldn't wait, so the pitcher who won the National League's Cy Young Award and rookie-of-the-year honors last year will make his season debut today, against the San Diego Padres in Los Angeles. Because Valenzuela wanted a $1 million contract and the Dodgers offered only $350,000, he stayed away from spring training and kept in condition by pitching winter ball in Mexico and working out by himself.

title: GIRL'S FIGHT AT GREENWICH HIGH LEADS TO SPORTS BUDGET FAIR TO BOTH SEXES
description: Sixteen-year-old Michele Monahan, to her surprise, has won her 18-month battle against sex discrimination in athletics at Greenwich High School.

title:
PATENTS;
Mobile Beach Chair
description: Adalbert W. Suchy of Yonkers got patent 4,323,260 this week for a beach chair that can be folded into cart form, and can be moved over soft or sandy surfaces with the aid of snap-on tracks.

title: LIM ON TO B E JART, LES GRANDS CANADIENS
description: Repertory may not be everything to a ballet company - dancers count too - but programming does mold a company's image. In this respect, Montreal's Les Grands Ballets Canadiens went seriously downhill Thursday night at the City Center. This second of three programs in a brief season presented Jose Limon's modern-dance work ''There Is a Time,'' Brian Macdonald's ''Double Quartet'' and ''Jeu de Cartes'' and Maurice Bejart's ''The Firebird.''

title: Sports People; Advice to Issel
description: The agent for Dan Issel said he would advise the Denver Nuggets' center to reject a contract offer from the National Basketball Association team and test the free agent market.

title: Around the Nation; Captain of Fishing Boat Guilty of Cruelty to Crew
description: A fishing boat captain was convicted today of violating a 19th-century Federal law against cruelty to seamen by dunking one man overboard and imprisoning five others.

title: FOR QUICK AIRPORT GETAWAYS A SELECTION OF CARRY-ON BAGS
description: The planes fly faster and faster, while the wait for luggage seems to get longer and longer. But passengers are getting smarter, too. More and more people are buying carry-on bags that can be shoved under the seat and carried right off the plane. Stores report that carry-ons constitute the best-selling category of luggage, with soft, lightweight models the most popular.

title: SATURDAY, APRIL 10, 1982; The Economy
description: The Producer Price Index fell 0.1 percent in March, marking the first time in more than six years that it has declined for two consecutive months, the Labor Department reported. The drop in energy prices was even sharper than in the first two months of the year, while food prices reversed course and turned down. Economists saw the latest figures as further evidence of the progress made against inflation. They cautioned, however, that much of the gain is a reflection of the recession, which many think has already touched bottom. (Page 1.)

title: COSMOS OPEN TONIGHT
description: The Cosmos will open their 12th season in the North American Soccer League here Saturday against the Tea Men with five of their best players nursing injuries in New York.

title: GEORGE LEISURE, 92, TRIAL LAWYER, DIES
description: George Stanley Leisure, a founding partner of Donovan Leisure Newton & Irvine, one of the largest law firms in New York, died at his home in Manhattan yesterday morning. He was 92 years old.

title: Go Slow on Ma Bell's Divorce
description: Yet another important voice counsels caution about the terms on which the American Telephone and Telegraph Company is allowed to divest itself of local phone companies. Knowledgeable members of the House have already moved to slow down the divorce approved by the Justice Department. They have now been joined by the Federal Communications Commission, a proven friend of deregulation. The case for caution is impressive.

title: RITA SHANE WITH 'I LOMBARDI'
description: Rita Shane entered the cast of the New York City Opera's budget production of Verdi's ''I Lombardi'' Thursday night at the New York State Theater, and by and large proved a welcome addition.

title: 2 Rookies Excel for Islanders
description: Ed Johnston, the coach of the Pittsburgh Penguins, had enough to worry about today, with his team one defeat away from elimination from the National Hockey League playoffs. The Islanders completely dominated the first two games, outscoring the Penguins by 15-3.

title: WARSAW GROUP
description: The Warsaw Philharmonic Chamber Orchestra, a 20-year-old ensemble led by its founder, Karol Teutsch, came to Carnegie Hall Tuesday night to play a pleasing though conventional program of works for strings. The orchestra was not unfamiliar, having made two previous American tours.

title: O'NEILL GIVES BLESSING TO BUDGET COMPROMISE OUTLINE
description: The Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., has given House negotiators his blessing to go ahead with the details of a budget compromise on the basis of the general outline worked out thus far, Congressional sources said today.

title: Electric Boat Posts Loss
description: The Electric Boat division, a unit of the General Dynamics Corporation, said in its annual report released today that it lost $12.6 million last year.

title: Topics; STRONG SENTIMENTS; A Glorious Phoenix
description: Wolf Trap Farm's Filene Theater, near Washington D.C., has a habit of arising from the ashes. In 1971, just before its debut as a distinguished performing arts center, the theater caught fire, but opened on time.

title: ISRAELI UNITS MOVE TO LEBANESE LINE
description: Senior Administration officials said today that there had been new Israeli military movements near the Lebanese border over the last 72 hours, causing grave American concern about a possible Israeli assault into southern Lebanon.

title: CUBA SILENT ON WHY IT HOLDS EXPATRIATE FROM WEST SIDE
description: A Cuban-born American citizen was arrested in Havana Jan. 31 for unspecified ''subversive activities'' and the State Department says it has been unable to elicit details of charges against him.

title: Penguins Offer Refunds
description: The Pittsburgh Penguins' owner, Edward J. DeBartolo Sr., disgusted with his team's play in the Stanley Cup playoffs, has offered a refund to any fan holding a ticket to Saturday night's game with the Islanders.

title:
PATENTS;
Doorbell for Pets
description: A doorbell for pets was patented this week by Lorin F. Sowards of Brownville, Neb.

title: About New York; OF RABBITS AND OTHER CASUALTIES OF EASTER
description: The rabbits were restless. In the exotic-animal room they moved in their cages, their noses crinkling ceaselessly. No. 2, which had lost No. 1 to a family on Staten Island only the week before, was chewing the paper on the bottom of its cage into pulp. The white rabbit, which had been found hopping aimlessly on a street in Queens and so had no name, was thumping its back legs against the metal bars.

title: Firestone May Seek Hertz
description: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company confirmed reports that it was discussing the possibility of acquiring the Hertz Corporation, the car and truck rental unit of the RCA Corporation, for an undisclosed price.

title: Notes on People; Prince Edward to Teach
description: Prince Edward, the youngest son of Queen Elizabeth II and third in line for the British throne, is going to New Zealand next September to teach school.

title: Beech Aircraft
description: The Beech Aircraft Corporation, a major producer of private and business aircraft, said it planned to lay off up to 600 workers and temporarily shut down parts of its plants in three states to reduce inventories and bring production in line with slow market conditions.

title: Honda Net Off By 20% in Year
description: The Honda Motor Company reported today that its net income fell 20 percent last year, to 24.3 billion yen, or $102 million, even though sales rose.

title: Little 'White House' Battered
description: A Dutch antiwar group attacked a 60-by-20-foot replica of the White House with sledgehammers and spray paint today, but its designer said he would fix the creation he spent 20 years building. The designer, John Zweifel of Orlando, Fla., said: ''Nobody will ever destroy this thing because we'll build it up again. The world can change, but I don't have to change with it.''

title: U.S. APPEALS COURT UPHOLDS CABLE TV ROYALTIES FORMULA
description: A Federal appeals court today upheld the distribution of the major share of cable-television royalty fees to movie makers and television producers.

title: RANGERS AND FLYERS RELYING ON POWER PLAY
description: If the past is prologue, power plays will be crucial when the Rangers and Philadelphia Flyers resume their National Hockey League playoff series in games Saturday and Sunday at the Spectrum.

title: AUTO UNIONISTS NARROWLY FAVOR NEW G.M. PACT
description: Blue-collar workers at the General Motors Corporation have narrowly approved a new labor contract that includes wage and benefit concessions to management.

title: SCM to Drop Typewriter Plant
description: The SCM Corporation said that effective June 30, 1982, it would halt the production of typewriters at its factory in Glasgow, Scotland.

title: A MYTH TERMED JUDICIAL ELECTIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: 46 TRICHINOSIS CASES IN NEW YORK AND RHODE ISLAND TIED TO 2 FARMS
description: Forty-six cases of trichinosis reported late last year in New York City and Rhode Island have been traced to raw or partly cooked pork from hogs purchased at two farms, Federal health officials reported today.

title: A SOFT VIDEO RECORDER MARKET
description: Until recently, Japan simply could not make enough videotape recorders to satisfy the world. Not long after the market had its beginnings seven years ago, the videotape recorder boom was off and going. Led by Matsushita Electric, Sony and the Japan Victor Company, the manufacturers kept adding production capacity at a torrid pace, with an annual doubling of output becoming the norm.

title: POPULAR BANCSHARES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
STADLER AND STRANGE LEAD MASTERS BY 1
description: The unseemly weather that had disrupted the first round of the 46th Masters Thursday improved today, but not enough to help the scores significantly. In place of rain and cold, a brisk breeze blew over Augusta National Golf Club, and a par 144 was good enough to lead after 36 holes.

title: OLD-STYLE RACING THRIVES AT OAKLAWN
description: There is a very profitable race track here that refuses to stay open more than two months a year, where the grandstand admission has remained $1 since 1904, where there is no offtrack betting, no permissive medication, no quinelas, exactas, trifectas or pick-sixes.

title: Bridge: Sam Stayman Now Makes His Points as an Underdog
description: Back in the 50's, Sam Stayman of New York was known both as the inventor of a world-famous convention and for his prowess at the table. He and his teammates won three world titles and several major national championships.

title: 13 U.S. IMPRESSIONISTS IN PARIS SHOW
description: ''Gentle'' is the word Donald MacClelland uses to describe an exhibition of 13 American Impressionist painters that opened last week at the Petit Palais - rather like conducting a California winetasting in Burgundy. Mr. MacClelland, the Smithsonian Institution's curator for traveling shows, organized the show, aimed at demonstrating to France what it had done to the American painters who came over in the 1880's and watched Monet work at Giverny.

title: MONEY SUPPLY UP $900 MILLION
description: The Federal Reserve System announced yesterday that the basic measure of the nation's money supply rose by $900 million in the financial week ended March 31, a modest increase that drew cheers from a number of bankers and economists.

title: Yanks Plan to Open With Doubleheader
description: The Yankees will play baseball in 1982; they are confident of that. They just cannot be certain when. Their opener is now scheduled for tomorrow, the fourth scheduled opener they have had in this six-dayold season.

title: Bullets 114, Bulls 98
description: CHICAGO (UPI) - Spencer Haywood scored 25 points to lead the Bullets to their third straight victory.

title: CORADIAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $491,000 for the qr and $1,903,000 for the yr...C-Including a tax credit of $137,000...D-Net income

title: Nuclear-Plant Plea by U.S.
description: The Justice Department today asked a Federal court to strike down a Washington state initiative requiring voter approval before additional bonds can be issued to complete three nuclear power plants.

title: Bucks 118, Pistons 100
description: Sidney Moncrief scored 35 points, and Bob Lanier had 26 as Milwaukee won its seventh straight game and the 12th in its last 14.

title: London Help Is Sought To Evacuate Falklands
description: A group of Falkland Islanders have asked the British Government to evacuate the local population before hostilities break out there, and Britain has asked the International Red Cross to take ''an interest'' in the fate of the Falkland Islanders.

title: Foremost Sells Dry Milk Unit
description: Foremost-McKesson Inc., a San Francisco-based food producer and distributor of wines, spirits, chemicals, drug and health care products, said it had sold for an undisclosed price its Milkman brand of instant low-fat dry milk, along with a production plant in Loleta, Calif., to Familiar Foods Inc. of the City of Industry, Calif.

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 26.

title: 'DIE ENTF"UHRUNG
description: Various new faces have been slipping in and out of recent Metropolitan Opera performances of ''Die Entfuhrung aus dem Serail,'' and all these cast changes came together Thursday evening at the Met.

title: Around the World; Armenian Terror Group Claims Ottawa Shooting
description: The Armenian Secret Army for the Liberation of Armenia claimed responsibility today for shooting a Turkish diplomat in Ottawa and warned Canadian authorities against taking any action against Armenians in Canada.

title: ATLANTA CHILDREN BLOOM IN NEW CLIMATE OF CALM
description: It is spring in Atlanta and the city is alive with rich bursts of color from dogwoods and azaleas and with the robust laughter of children, a sound all but absent from streets, yards and play lots for the last two years.

title: NUCLEAR SUBMARINES THAT RUN INTO SHIPS
description: To the Editor:

title: HARVESTER CLEARED FOR PHONE SERVICE
description: The International Harvester Company, the financially beleaguered producer of farm equipment and other heavy machinery, received Federal authorization today to enter the interstate long-distance telephone business.

title: TRANSAMERICA REALTY INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: B-Net income after tax credit of $411,000 or 10 cents a shr; Transamerica Realty Investors is managed by Transamerica Realty Services Inc, a subsidiary of the Transamerica Corp, which is listed on the New York Stock Exchange

title: Sports People; Recruiting Dollars
description: Gary Colson, the New Mexico coach, said there was so much cheating in college basketball that he was told one high school player had received $200,000 before signing with a college. He did not name the player or the college, and he said he did not intend to identify coaches who broke rules.

title:
PATENTS;
Treatment Developed To Shrink Tumor's Size
description: A method of cancer treatment was patented this week for Corning Glass Works, Corning, N.Y., by members of its research staff.

title: Issue and Debate
description: AFTER 7 YEARS, PLAN FOR POWER PLANT ON ARTHUR KILL'S S.I. SHORE STILL DISPUTED By PETER KIHSS

title: Credibility Gulch (Cont.)
description: When we left the last episode of ''As the Tape Recorder Turns,'' the missing 13 hours of the Playboy interview were in limbo - with Mayor Koch, behind his legal wagons, refusing to release the complete tapes to a press corps ever bloodthirsty for more of his wisecracks about the boobishness of rural and suburban life that had earlier inflamed the upstate tribes.

title: TULTEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
Sports of The Times; 'I'm Too Good a Player'
description: HE'S only two strokes out of the Masters lead now with 36 holes to play, but yesterday morning Tom Watson stood in the sun outside the Augusta National clubhouse and shook his head.

title: BANK OF COMMERCE (NYC) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The yr-ago per shr earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock splitdeclared in July 1981

title: Pabst Explores Merger Proposals
description: The Pabst Brewing Company is exploring alternative transactions to the $168 million merger proposal it received from the C. Schmidt Brewing Company of Philadelphia, and has told its investment bankers to actively pursue such alternatives, Pabst officials said.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Gerry Cooney sparred yesterday for the first time since Feb. 12, when he tore muscle fibers in his left shoulder. That forced postponement of his Las Vegas, Nev., title fight with Larry Holmes, the World Boxing Council heavyweight champion, from March 15 to June 11.

title: Around the World; Police in Paris Sees Link Among Political Slayings
description: The police said today that tests had established that the same pistol was used here to kill a United States military attache Jan. 18 and an Israeli diplomat last Saturday. They said the weapon was also used in an unsucessful ambush last Nov. 12 against the American charge d'affaires, Christian A. Chapman. Mr. Chapman escaped injury.

title: Around the World
description: A firebomb was hurled at an Israeli army patrol in Bethlehem today and two Israeli girls were injured near the West Bank settlement of Kiryat Arba when Arab demonstrators threw rocks at their bus, Israeli military authorities said.

title: PASTA LOSES HUMBLE IMAGE BUT IS TREATED SHABBILY
description: Now touted for its healthfulness as well as for its esthetic appeal, pasta has undergone a rags-to-riches change of image. Formerly considered a money-saver and a strictly Italian specialty, it is in high fashion, as popular in home-cooking and in expensive takeout shops as it is in all-purpose Continental restaurants and even on the most esoteric nouvelle cuisine menus.

title: RETAIL SALES IN CITY RISE BY ONLY 3%
description: Sales of New York City's big retailers last month increased only 3 percent from March 1981, a spot-check found this week. It was the third consecutive month when average store sales failed to keep pace when adjusted for inflation. Sales for five of the last six months also fell below the approximate 7 percent annual price inflation of typical department store goods.

title: HARRIS BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
East German Aide Is Dead
description: Lieut. Gen. Bruno Beater, the First Deputy Minister of State Security, died today after a long illness, the East German press agency said. He was 68 years old. General Beater, who fought with the Red Army in World War II, was a career officer in the security police and intelligence agency and assumed its second-ranking position in 1964.

title: NATIONAL BANCSHARES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
HAIG, IN BUENOS AIRES, SAYS U.S. TIES WITH ARGENTINA FORM BASIS FOR TALKS
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. arrived here tonight and said the Reagan Administration's improved relations with Argentina were ''a good basis'' on which to resolve the Falkland Islands crisis.

title: THERE'S GOOD NEWS FROM THE 'BABY FRONT'
description: Is the United States afraid of good news? The question seems absurd, yet it must occur frequently to anyone who tries to judge the attention that we, as a nation, pay to good news and bad news.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 16.

title: Leg Injury to Sideline John Henry Until Fall
description: John Henry, thorougbred racing's leading career money-winner and the 1981 Horse of the Year, will be sidelined at least until this fall with a leg problem, it was announced today.

title: HANA MANDLIKOVA IS DEFEATED
description: For Chris Evert Lloyd and Andrea Jaeger, the straight-set victories were routine. But Martina Navratilova needed three sets to subdue Andrea Leand, and Hana Mandlikova was defeated by Mima Jausovec, 7-5, 6-0, in today's quarterfinals of the $200,000 Family Circle Cup.

title: Losing on Exotic Bets
description: It's disgraceful that New York State's Racing and Wagering Board is unable to mete out justice to jockeys it clearly believes to have been fixing horse races. Most of them are still riding high. It's equally dismaying that the state, like the crooked gamblers, has become lovingly dependent on fancy betting practices that are easy to pervert.

title: AN OVERSTATEMENT OF FEDERAL DEPOSIT INSURANCE
description: To the Editor:

title: BRITAIN FEARS TIME IS RUNNING OUT FOR A PEACEFUL FALKLANDS SOLUTION
description: British officials said today that time might be running out for a peaceful settlement of the dispute with Argentina over the Falkland Islands.

title: NEW EGG FOR ARGUING CONDORS
description: Two California condors that lost an egg while fighting over it last month have produced a second one, biologists seeking to save the endangered bird said today.

title: REAGAN WINDS UP TALKS IN BARBADOS
description: For the first time since he arrived in the Caribbean three days ago, President Reagan relaxed at the beach with friends today rather than rushing through meetings.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: ASCENSION ISLAND: A VITAL BIT OF VOLCANIC ROCK
description: The tiny volcanic rock in the South Atlantic called Ascension Island is expected to play a vital role in the Falklands crisis as a staging point for British ships and planes.

title: ON THE INTELLIGENCE BILL'S TIGHTROPE
description: Since Senator John H. Chafee seldom votes with Senate conservatives. his colleagues were surprised when the Rhode Island Republican became the chief author of of a bill strongly supported by conservatives. That measure, which would make it a crime to identify undercover intelligence agents, has stirred up one of the most thought-provoking debates of the current legislative session.

title: MOSCOW SAYS BRITAIN IS THREATENING PEACE WITH FALKLAND FLEET
description: Tass, the Soviet Government's press agency, said today that the dispatch of a British naval force to the Falkland islands had created ''an immediate threat to international peace and security.''

title: Books of The Times; To Be or Not to Be
description: SUICIDE IN AMERICA. By Herbert Hendin, M.D. 252 pages. W.W. Norton. $16.95.

title: TRANSFER PAYMENTS: CUSHION AGAINST DEPRESSION
description: To the Editor:

title: LINDEN, N.J., LOCAL TO CHALLENGE AUTO PACT VOTES
description: Union leaders at the sprawling General Motors assembly plant here, whose members voted overwhelmingly against the new contract approved nationwide, said today that they would challenge the election results.

title: THE REVOLUTIONARY IN EVERY GOOD LAWYER
description: To the Editor:

title: Notes on People; Polish Cellist Is Given Asylum in U.S.; Asylum for Cellist
description: She waited three months, but it was worth it to learn that the United States Government has granted her political asylum, said Cecylia Barczyk, a Polish cellist who defected to this country last December.

title: PHILLIES BEATEN, 2-0, BY ROGERS OF EXPOS
description: Andre Dawson hit a home run in the first inning and Steve Rogers pitched a three-hitter tonight as the Montreal Expos opened their season with a 2-0 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies. The Expos were snowed out twice in Pittsburgh this week.

title: ARIZONA BANK (PHOENIX) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Notes on People; The 10-Year Aftermath of a Wallet's Theft; Theft's Aftermath
description: A Houston accountant maintains that just because his wallet was stolen 12 years ago, he has been forced to sue the Federal Bureau of Identification and the United States Marshal's office for harassing him for a decade.

title: WILFRID PELLETIER
description: Wilfrid Pelletier, the Canadian conductor, died yesterday in New York Hospital. Mr. Pelletier was director of French repertory at the Metropolitan Opera under Edward Johnson's administration, beginning in the early 1930's and continuing until the coming of Sir Rudolf Bing in 1950.

title: News Summary; News Summary; SATURDAY, APRIL 10, 1982
description: International A plan aimed at mending relations with Nicaragua has been submitted by the United States, a State Department official said. However, it depends on the Sandinist Government's stopping support for Salvadoran guerrillas. As described by the official, the plan provides for resumed American economic aid, a pledge of non-intervention in Nicaraguan affairs, and pressure against Nicaraguan exiles plotting to intervene in Nicaragua in return for Nicaragua's cutoff of aid to Salvadoran guerrillas and participation in a limit in Central America on heavy arms and foreign military advisers. (Page 1, Column 1.) High posts for Christian Democrats in El Salvador's new government were demanded by a United States Congressional delegation. Salvadoran political leaders were also told that they must continue the economic and social changes begun by the Christian Democrats if the country is to continue to receive aid from the United States. (4:3-6.)

title: 'IOLANTHE'
description: Part of the charm of Gilbert & Sullivan's ''Iolanthe, or the Peer and the Peri'' lies in the way it repays the Victorian debt to Weber and Mendelssohn, especially in Sullivan's musical treatment of the plot's ''fairy'' motif. There are loving glances at ''Oberon'' and the incidental music for ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' throughout, alongside the familiar formula pieces that make the work as entertaining as any of the pair's other collaborations.

title:
Patents;
Collapsible Respiratory Exerciser
description: WASHINGTON APROFESSOR whose name is familiar to millions as the originator of an emergency treatment for choking victims has invented a collapsible respiratory exerciser that can be carried in a pocket and may be helpful for athletes, joggers and singers.

title: PRODUCERS' PRICES OFF 0.1% IN MARCH FOR SECOND MONTH
description: The Producer Price Index for March fell onetenth of 1 percent from the previous month, the first time in more than six years that this broad inflation measure has declined for two consecutive months, the Labor Department reported today.

title: METS DEFEATED BY CUBS AND JENKINS, 5-0
description: The fourth inning of the first game of the 67th season in Wrigley Field was not a very happy one for the New York Mets. They were pelted by snowballs by some of the fans, and then Bill Buckner hit a two-run home run that eventually won the game for the Chicago Cubs.

title: News Analysis
description: The decision by the Rev. Billy Graham, perhaps the nation's best known religious figure, to address an international conference on disarmament in Moscow next month adds a powerful force to the growing drive by church leaders to end the nuclear arms race.

title: STOUFFER JURY SENDS JUDGE ITS 33RD NOTE
description: The jury in the Stouffer's Inn arson and murder case sent several notes to the judge today, had second thoughts about one and asked for it back, asked for several more hours of testimony to be read to them and then paused so that some members could attend Good Friday services.

title: Tunis Premier to Visit U.S.
description: Prime Minister Mohammed Mzali of Tunisia will make an official visit to the United States on April 29, official sources said today. It will be his first visit to Washington since taking office in April 1980.

title: The City; City Cuts Estimate Of Budget Deficit
description: As a result of improved collection of taxes and other revenues, the Koch administration has significantly lowered its estimate of the deficit it must close to produce a balanced budget for the 1983 fiscal year, starting next July.

title: FALKLAND ISSUE IMPERILS RECOVERY, BRITISH FEAR
description: British economists and Government officials are concerned that the confrontation with Argentina over the Falkland Islands may damage Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's economic strategy just as it is beginning to show results.

title: YOUTHS TO THE RESCUE
description: To the Editor:

title: EX-FOREIGN MINISTER OF IRAN REPORTED SEIZED
description: Iran's former Foreign Minister, Sadegh Ghotbzadeh, long at odds with the country's ruling Islamic fundamentalists, was arrested at his home in Teheran two days ago, relatives reported today.

title: SRI LANKA AMBIVALENT ON HONEYMOON WITH U.S.
description: Three years ago, a senior diplomat at the United States Embassy here complained to a friend that, while he loved living on this island, his work was fairly dull. ''This is the kind of place where you have to wait on line to get your reports onto the back burner in Washington,'' he said. Since then, things have changed.

title: Around the Nation; 16-Year-Old Faces Trial As Adult in 5 Murders
description: Prosecutors said today that they would seek to have a 16-year-old boy tried as an adult on firstdegree murder charges in the slayings of a mother and her four adopted children.

title: Argentine Newspaper Seeks Government Help on Boycott
description: The Buenos Aires Herald appealed to the Government today to intervene in a boycott against it by newspaper distributors who accuse it of being pro-British in the Falkland Islands conflict.

title: JEWELRY INSURANCE BY THE DAY
description: ANYONE who has valuable jewelry might be interested in a per-diem, o ut-of-vault insurance policy. It is designed for people who remove t heir jewels from a bank vault for occasional use. The policy p rovides different rates for jewelry when it is in the bank and when i t is in the owner's possession.

title: BENNETT IS CRITICIZED OVER HIS 'PROPAGANDA' CHARGE
description: William J. Bennett, chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities, who charged that a federally financed documentary on public television about Nicaragua was ''unabashed socialist-realism propaganda,'' was criticized today by his predecessor.

title: Topics Strong Sentiments; Souvenir
description: All of us have succumbed to sentiment - saved the baseball that landed in the bleachers, pressed the first corsage, put away the baby's bootees. But few match the scale of an Army sergeant who hankered for a rocket from the Alabama arsenal in which he once worked.

title: Grain Meeting Set
description: American officials and their counterparts from four other major grain exporters will meet April 22-23 in Ottawa to exchange views on the world grain situation, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: LABOR, AWARE TASK IS TOUGH, SETS OUT TO UNIONIZE HOUSTON
description: In the 1970's, the decade of Houston's most prodigious growth, nearly 700,000 workers joined the labor force here. Most of them did not belong to unions and still do not.

title: Your Money; Declaring Bankruptcy
description: BANKRUPTCY is a frightening word. But for many, out of necessity, it is losing its dread. In rough economic times such as these, more people appear to be contemplating it in the hope that they will be able to win a fresh economic start.

title: The City; Suspect Arrested In Bank Holdups
description: A 32-year-old man wanted as a suspect in 19 bank robberies in New York City since last June 23 was arrested yesterday by detectives on bank stakeout assignments who saw him on a street in lower Manhattan.

title: Index; International
description: In Sri Lanka, uneasiness over honeymoon with the West 2 Plan against first use of nuclear weapons criticized in Bonn 3 Reagan relaxes after two days of Barbados meetings 3 Egyptians have limited success at Kuwait conference 3 Around the World 5 Soviet sees threat to peace in British dispatch of naval force 6 Ascension Island expected to play role in Falklands crises 6 Ex-Foreign Minister reported under arrest in Iran 7 Government/Politics Barry M. Goldwater Jr.'s lead slipping in Senate race 8 Forty-six trichinosis cases are traced to two pig farms 8 Audit finds 63,000 delinquent on $31 million in student loans 10 Agency orders steps to prevent disintegration of jet engines 24 Washington Talk Briefing 10 On the intelligence bill's tight- rope 10 General Around the Nation 8 As fear eases, Atlanta youngsters return to childhood 8 A new spring storm heaps more snow on the Middle West 8 Initiation rite on Easter Eve a sign of faith in Jersey church 25 Stouffer's jury, in fifth day, sends judge 33d note 26 Cuba silent on why it holds expa- triate West Sider 27 PARKING REGULATIONS Because of snow, alternate-side parking is suspended in New York City today. All other rules remain in effect. Arts/Entertainment Parisian show of 13 Impression- ists reveals U.S. psyche 13 Stars named for ''Beyond Ther- apy,'' opening May 24 13 Henry Street Theater stages ''World of Ben Caldwell'' 13 Riverside Church presents ''Spe- cial Evening of Ballet'' 13 An expanded force of Mozartean Players heard 15 Warsaw Philharmonic Orchestra plays at Carnegie Hall 15 Les Grands Ballet Canadiens presents Limon works 16 ''Suicide in America'' by Dr. Her- bert Hendin reviewed 17 Bennett assailed by predecessor on ''propaganda'' charge 43 Court upholds cable-television royalty-distribution plan 43 Industry/Labor Auto union leaders at Linden, N.J., challenge election results 9 G.E. union walks out to protest subcontracting 26 Education/Welfare How the Federal welfare cuts af- fect a working mother 27 Style Carry-on luggage for quick get- aways 44 De Gustibus: Pasta is still treated shabbily 44 Consumer Saturday: Jewelry in- surance by the day 44 Obituaries George Stanley Leisure, noted corporate trial lawyer 28 Sports Nets are beaten by Celtics in Bos- ton, 106-103 19 Stadler and Strange share Mas- ters lead by a stroke at par 144 19 Jenkins and Smith of Cubs stop Mets, 5-0 19 Yankees will try fourth time to open season tomorrow 19 Old-style racing thrives at Oak- lawn 19 Dave Anderson on the Masters 20 Rogers pitches a three-hitter as Expos top Phillies, 2-0 20 Hana Mandlikova ousted by Mima Jausovec 20 For Rangers and Flyers, power play is the key 21 Two rookies excel for Islanders 21 Cosmos open season tonight against Tea Men 21 Features/Notes Going Out Guide 15 Saturday News Quiz 16 Notes on People 17 Sports People 21 Issue and Debate: Power plant plan for Arthur Kill shore 26 About New York 27 News Analysis Kenneth A. Briggs on church in- volvement in arms dispute 3 Editorials/Letters/Op-Ed Editorials 22

title: NICARAGUA IS GIVEN NEW U.S. PROPOSAL TO MEND RELATIONS
description: A State Department official said today that the United States had offered Nicaragua a new plan that would mend relations in return for an end to that country's support for insurgents in El Salvador.

title: AMERICA'S THINKING IS A CITIZENS' JOB
description: To the Editor:

title: Raymond Crowley, 86; Prize-Winning Editor
description: Raymond L. Crowley, an editor whose work helped The St. Louis Post-Dispatch win three Pulitzer Prizes, died Tuesday after a long illness. He was 86 years old.

title: Barrios, 28, Dies Of Heart Attack
description: Francisco Barrios, a former pitcher for the Chicago White Sox, died of a heart attack today in his native city of Hermosillo. He was 28 years old.

title: FRANCHISE TORRENT SLOWING TO A TRICKLE
description: A quarter of a century ago, McDonald's hamburger outlets were snapped up by small entrepreneurs lured by the easy access to cheap money. Both the corporation and the franchisees profited handsomely.

title: Goodrich Selected as Target For Next Rubber Union Pact
description: The United Rubber Workers has announced the selection of the B.F. Goodrich Company as the union's target for negotiating a pattern industrywide contract.

title: NETS DEFEATED BY CELTICS, 106-103
description: The Nets were defeated by the Celtics, 106-103, tonight in a game that clinched the Atlantic Division title for Boston and stalled New Jersey's playoff drive.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: OUT OF RETIREMENT

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday about a postal inspector's plan to combat false ad- vertising quoted him as saying that his decoy ad would appear in The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette. The paper says it had already decided to reject the ad.

title: HAWKS END 76ERS' STREAK AT 5
description: Dan Roundfield scored 21 points and Eddie Johnson 18 as the Atlanta Hawks defeated the Philadelphia 76ers, 103-88, tonight. The 76ers' winning streak ended at five games.

title: WHITAKER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
EGYPT FINDS LIMITED GAINS IN KUWAIT
description: An Egyptian delegation attending a conference in Kuwait of nations that identify themselves as nonaligned received a respectful hearing from Arab and other third-world delegates and was able to tone down but not eliminate criticism of past Egyptian policies, according to reports from the conference.

title: Sports People; Bartow's Pact Extended
description: Gene Bartow, who left U.C.L.A. five years ago to become the first basketball coach at Alabama-Birmingham, has found a home. The college, aware of rumors that Bartow might leave, has extended his contract to 1990.

title: A JERSEY PARISH TO GROW WITH AN OLD EASTER RITE
description: When parishioners at the Most Blessed Sacrament Church here welcome new members at the Easter Vigil service Saturday evening, the traditional sacraments of initiation will reflect a heightened concern for the meaning of membership in the Roman Catholic parish.

title: PETROLEUM & RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for As of Mar 31
description: The assets figures are net assets; the latest period per shr figure assumes full conversion of the convertible preferred stock and after capital gain distribution of $4.88 paid in Feb 1982; the yr-earlier per shr figure is after a capital gain distribution of $2.48 paid in Feb 1981

title: MOZARTEAN PLAYERS
description: Although authentic performance practice is all the fashion these days, the actual live confrontation with familiar music in this ''new'' guise can still shock the ear. An example was provided Tuesday night in Alice Tully Hall, when the Mozartean Players, their forces expanded to a full classical orchestra, presented a Haydn concerto and a concerto and two arias by Mozart.

title: FEDERAL OFFERS 'WORLD OF BEN CALDWELL
description: ''The World of Ben Caldwell'' is far short of its billing as ''a dramatized examination of the absurdity of the American dream and subsequent reality.'' This revue at the Henry Street Settlement's New Federal Theater is a random collage of comedy skits by Mr. Caldwell. The humor is fragmentary, but there is, of all things, a deft impersonation of Richard Pryor by Morgan Freeman.

title: U.S. VISITORS WARN SALVADOR RIGHTISTS ON CENTRIST ROLE
description: A high-level Congressional delegation has delivered a strong message to El Salvador's warring political leaders that they must form a broad-based, moderate government committed to economic and social justice if the country is to continue receiving aid from the United States, according to members of the delegation.

title: YOUNGER GOLDWATER'S INTELLECT AT ISSUE IN CALIFORNIA SENATE RACE
description: Representative Barry M. Goldwater Jr.'s lead in the race for the Republican senatorial nomination in California appears to be slipping in a campaign in which opponents have made Mr. Goldwater's mental prowess a major issue.

title: FLEXTIME ENDED BY HERCULES
description: Hercules Inc., in a move to cut costs, is abandoning both its flexitime program, in which workers could stagger their hours, and its condensed workweek.

title: 2 BONN PARTIES COOL TO BAN ON FIRST USE OF ATOM ARMS
description: Two West German foreign policy experts, representing the governing Social Democratic Party and the Christian Democratic opposition, expressed reservations today about a proposal by four former American officials that the United States should consider renouncing first use of nuclear weapons in defending Europe against conventional attack.

title: POWER AUTHORITY IS DENIED PERMIT TO BUILD A PLANT
description: The State Department of Environmental Conservation refused today to grant a permit to the Power Authority to build a plant upstate that would use water from a New York City-owned reservoir to generate electricity.

title: DRUG AGENCY RECORDS SOUGHT
description: The General Accounting Office has agreed to continue discussions with the Drug Enforcement Administration on access to the drug agency's records, a spokesman for the accounting office said today.

title: Iran on the Rebound
description: In the slow-motion war between Iran and Iraq, there is no American ''side'' and never was. But there are American interests, two of which could confusingly collide as the 18-month conflict nears some kind of climax.

title: The Mushroom Blues
description: Fellow phones, says his name is Mintz, and can he have an appointment. ''You got an image problem, Mintz?'' I ask. My business is solving image problems, you see.

title: 2 STARS NAMED FOR 'BEYOND THERAPY'
description: John Lithgow and Dianne Wiest, who is now appearing as Desdemona in ''Othello'' at the Winter Garden, will star in Christopher Durang's ''Beyond Therapy,'' which will open at the Brooks Atkinson Theater on May 24. The comedy, about some therapists and their patients, was done by the Phoenix Theater last year, with Sigourney Weaver and Stephen Collins in the leads. Mr. Durang has since rewritten it.

title: Around the Nation; Court Rejects Challenge To College's Tax Status
description: Massachusetts' highest court today rejected attempts by the town of Whately to tax Smith College property on the ground that the women's school discriminated against men.

title: Notes on People; New York Banking Aide Considers the Senate
description: New York State's Superintendent of Banks, Muriel Siebert, says she may seek the Republican nomination for United States Senator to oppose the Democratic incumbent, Daniel Patrick Moynihan.

title: C. FRANK REAVIS
description: C. Frank Reavis, senior partner of the New York law firm of Reavis & McGrath, died Wednesday after a short illness at New York Hospital. He was 85 years old and a resident of Manhattan.

title: Sir William Walton Ill
description: Sir William Walton, doyen of British composers, was in ''stable'' condition in a London hospital today, following an exhausting schedule of musical festivities to mark his 80th birthday.

title: CITIBANK SAID TO PLAN BROKER TIE
description: Citibank, the nation's second-largest commercial bank, is planning to enter the stock brokerage business through an arrangement with Quick & Reilly Inc., a large discount brokerage firm based in New York, banking sources said yesterday.

title: Briefing
description: Haig Without Blinders

title: F.A.A. ACTS TO AVERT JUMBO JET ENGINE BREAKUPS
description: The Federal Aviation Administration yesterday intensified its effort to protect jumbo-jet aircraft from engine breakups by ordering American users of a huge General Electric engine to double the frequency of special inspections to detect dangerous cracks.

title: 2 Children Are Freed After an Hour in Safe
description: Two children who had been locked in a safe for 65 minutes in a Dix Hills home were freed today, unharmed, by an expert at opening safes.

title: Private Group Cancels Olympic Coins Contract
description: The commemorative coin program that had been expected to raise at least $200 million for the 1984 Olympic Games in Los Angeles has apparently been ended, the head of the Olympic Organizing Committee said today.

title: The City; Richmond Urged To Leave by Koch
description: Mayor Koch urged Representative Frederick W. Richmond of Brooklyn yesterday not to seek re-election and added that should Mr. Richmond run he would support someone else in a Democratic primary.

title: GOOD FRIDAY OBSERVED IN CHURCHES AND STREETS
description: The suffering of Jesus on the cross was brought home to Good Friday worshipers in the city and across the country yesterday as traditional devotions often focused on contemporary injustice.

title: TRUCK WITH $1 MILLION IN ART IS STOLEN IN SOHO
description: A Chicago art transporter told the police yesterday that his rented truck containing paintings and sculptures valued at more than $1 million was stolen while it was parked overnight in SoHo.

title: Around the World; Plane Crashes on Street, Killing 3 in California
description: A small plane crashed into a busy street this afternoon, killing two men and a teen-age girl aboard the plane but narrowly missing a crowded suburban ice cream parlor where a birthday party was being held.

title: 'SPECIAL EVENING'
description: Tuesday night, the Theater of the Riverside Church offered what it called ''A Special Evening of Ballet.'' Unfortunately, it turned out to be a depressingly familiar sort of presentation.

title: Around the World; Cuban Tourist Flights Halted by Washington
description: The Reagan Administration today halted charter flights to Havana by a Hialeah, Fla., company that had been operating tourist flights to and from Cuba.

title: GERMANS TRY TO REGAIN JAPAN'S TOOL ADVANTAGE
description: Last year Japan moved past West Germany to become the world's second-largest producer of machine tools behind the United States. It was another sign of slippage in a major German export industry often considered a barometer of the country's economic well-being.

title: TWO L.I. THRIFT UNITS MAY MERGE
description: Long Island's two largest savings institutions, Suffolk County Federal and County Federal Savings, are expected to sign an agreement next week to merge, setting up an institution with assets of $2.6 billion. The merger requires Federal approval.

title: TO FIGHT THE RECESSION, A 'HUMAN CAPITAL ACT'
description: America is in the midst of a devastating recession. A dozen or so states have unemployment rates of Depression-era magnitude. Rates of unemployment for blacks and youths are at or near the highest levels ever. Yet the Reagan Administration has done absolutely nothing about putting Americans back to work.

title: Fuji and Boeing Studying Venture
description: Fuji Heavy Industries said it would hold further talks with the Boeing Company on the possibility of jointly developing a new generation 150-seat airliners at an estimated project cost $1 billion.
