title: Orlov, Jailed Soviet Dissident, Is Reported in Failing Health
description: The wife of Yuri F. Orlov, a jailed Soviet dissident, says his health is failing and she has appealed to Leonid I. Brezhnev to reduce his sentence.

title: CAFE MENU TAKES AMBITIOUS TURN
description: THE KITCHEN in Great Neck opened about a year ago as a catering shop. A few tables off to one side also permitted informal cafe dining on the spot - for salads, sandwiches, a slice of quiche, desserts and coffee carried from the counter cafeteria style. Within a few months, the table section evolved into a full-fledged restaurant.

title: Ospreys Home Again
description: Within the last week or two, ospreys have been returning to their nesting sites in New Jersey after their migrations to Florida and other southern climes. State-managed nests for this endangered species generally are in remote marshes, far from where the average person could view them.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: THIS would be the year, David Holahan thought, that everyone would see the annual April Fools' Day joke in his newspapers for the baldfaced tomfoolery it was. After all, he reasoned, who would believe a front-page story ''By John Reed'' that The Gazette and The Compass, which serve the Old Lyme and Mystic area, had been bought by Tass, the Soviet press agency?

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Intent the Key in Seniority Plans
description: A company's seniority system can look discriminatory, sound discriminatory and work to discriminate against the promotion of women and minority group members and still be legal, according to a Supreme Court decision last week. Voting 5 to 4, the Court ruled that even if such a system was adopted after passage of the 1964 Civil Rights Act, which outlawed job bias, it is legal if it was not adopted with the intent to discriminate.

title: In Quest of Carolina Bass
description: pound channel bass alongside for me to net.

title: Resurrection
description: There were landslides in California and floods in the Middle West, freezes in Florida and untimely blizzards all over. But a month or so ago the sun started to hang around a little longer; scilla and crocuses, against all reason, began to shoulder their way out of the mud.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''People's attitudes have changed remarkably in the past week. We are prepared to consider Argentine sovereignty over the islands in return for Argentine agreement to withdraw the troops.'' - Edmund Carlisle of the Falkland Islands. (12:2.)

title: Personal Finance; WHAT TO DO WHEN THE PINK SLIP COMES
description: PHASED OUT. De-Employed. Fired. Call it what you like but it boils d own to being dismissed from your job, and it's happening to more andm ore people these days. Not only is the recession trimming the ranks f rom the executive suite to the secretarial pool, but mergers and a cquisitions are creating a sea of pink slips for executives whose t asks are being consolidated.

title: MORE THAN HONOR AND OIL IN FALKLANDS WAR
description: To the Editor:

title: UTILITY'S RATE RISES CURBED
description: NEWARK IN AN unusual move, the state's Board of Public Utilities, in its order covering abandonment by the Public Service Electric & Gas Company of its Hope Creek II nuclear-power plant, has added a provision restraining the utility from seeking another rate increase until July 1983.

title: Sports People; A Weak Moment
description: His appointment as basketball coach at Wisconsin-Green Bay appeared to be a heady experience for Dick Lien, who was an assistant for two years to Dave Buss before Buss was dismissed. At a news conference, Lien, 39 years old, asked for a glass of water, mumbled a few words and keeled over.

title: HOW ALBANY REACHED A PLAN FOR A CENTER
description: Governor Carey wanted $5 million in state funds to begin construction of a high-technology center at the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in Troy.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Real People

title: WHO SAID THAT MACY (ROSE) NEVER TELLS GIMBEL (JACK)
description: RECENT reports of a lawsuit brought by Gimbels, the department store chain, against the owner of the independent Gimbel & Sons Country Store in Boothbay Harbor, Me., called to mind a similar incident in my family's history.

title:
NEW JERSEY GUIDE;
GRASS'S OTHER SIDE
description: The prose of Gunter Grass took Germany, and then the world, by storm, but how about the flip side of Gunter Grass - Grass the graphic artist, the lithographer, the creator of etchings and prints?

title: Soviet Ship Shadows British Troop Carrier
description: A Soviet ship began shadowing the British liner Canberra today as she sailed toward the Falkland Islands with 2,000 troops on board, a pooled dispatch from a reporter aboard the Canberra said.

title: Rono Outruns Salazar In 10,000-Meter Race
description: Henry Rono of Kenya moved past Alberto Salazar in the final 100 meters today to win an invitation 10,000-meter race in 27 minutes 29.90 seconds.

title: RETURN OF THE BATTLESHIP
description: It is June 1983. The Government of Fidel Castro has been overthrown. A mob gathers outside the northeast gate of the American naval base at Guantanamo Bay - long a source of contention between Cuba and the United States. Insults are shouted at the marines on guard and demonstrators fire shots in the air. At first, there seems little danger of an actual attack. ''Gitmo,'' as the 45-square-mile enclave is known to American sailors, is surrounded by the largest mine field in the world, and air support is only minutes away in Key West. But then aerial reconnaissance reveals disturbing signs. Emplacements for antiaircraft guns and missiles, long abandoned by the Cubans, have been reoccupied, and troop concentrations are forming near Guantanamo.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Consumer Panel Gives Up a Fight
description: The chilling effect of Washington's antiregulatory climate was illustrated by a Consumer Product Safety Commission decision last week. The panel voted not to appeal a Federal District Court ruling that will prevent it from trying to force the aluminum industry to repair homes equipped with aluminum wiring.

title: Barbara R. Boynton to Be Wed in July
description: Mr. and Mrs. William F. Koegel of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Koegel's daughter, Barbara Ruth Boynton, to William Harold Hinman Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hinman of Liverpool, N.Y.

title: The Region in Summary; Deadline Squeeze At Daily News
description: Joe L. Allbritton may take over The Daily News, but the prospective publisher made it clear last week that the burden of cutting costs to save the paper would belong ''very much'' to the newspaper's unions.

title: Cynthia A. Hallenbeck Will Be Bride On Sept. 11 of Douglas Mendel Libby
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alfred M. Hallenbeck of Rochester and Summerland Island, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Ann Hallenbeck, to Douglas Mendel Libby, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold L. Libby of Youngstown, Ohio.

title:
NEW JERSEY GUIDE;
FINALE AT RUTGERS
description: ''H.M.S. Pinafore,'' the classic Gilbert and Sullivan comic operetta, will open Friday in New Brunswick as the final offering in Rutgers University's seven-show season.

title: DOES IT MATTER?
description: WASHINGTON AFTER thirty years of leadership in the development of peaceful uses of nuclear energy, the United States seems to have lost its competitive edge. Increasingly, America's research, development, and sales efforts are being overshadowed by dynamic programs mounted by France, West Germany, Sweden, Japan, and the Soviet Union, leading nuclear experts agree.

title: YOUR HONEST TAXPAYER BEARS WATCHING
description: The national vanity that Americans are honest folks who dutifully file honest tax returns is in jeopardy. When some 95 million returns for 1981 have been filed by midnight Thursday, the Internal Revenue Service estimates that it will be $87 billion short on taxes owed on legitimate income, as against $29 billion for 1973, the first year such statistics were kept. This is the profoundly worrisome aspect of the ''underground economy'' for Treasury officials and members of Congress who fear that tax evasion could become widespread. ''We are not on the edge of a precipice,'' says I.R.S. Commissioner Roscoe L. Egger Jr., ''but unless we move now to turn it around we will create a problem for the future.''

title: BALLET: PENNSYLVANIANS
description: Although the Pennsylvania Ballet has just weathered a financial and directorial crisis, it is dancing very well in its engagement, through today, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Wednesday night's repertory program of George Balanchine's ''Square Dance,'' Jose Limon's ''The Moor's Pavane'' and Margo Sappington's ''Under the Sun'' could even be taken as summarizing the company's admirable artistic policies over the years.

title: COLLEGE FOR THE LEARNING DISABLED
description: Perhaps the most telling statement in Ron Winslow's survey is that only 121 of the nation's institutions of higher learning are aware that they have admitted learning-disabled students.

title: Around the World; Six Die in Indonesia As Volcano Erupts
description: A volcano erupted 125 miles southeast of here on Friday for the second time in less than a week, killing at least six people.

title: THE MANY FACES OF BARLOW RAND LTD.
description: JOHANNESBURG WHEN foreigners take notice of big business in South Africa, their attention is normally drawn to the vast Anglo-American Corporation and its chairman, Harry F. Oppenheimer, whose place in the moneyed portion of this society makes him a one-man aristocracy.

title: SOVIET AIDE IS CAUTIOUS ON SUMMIT TALKS IDEA
description: A senior Soviet official, meeting with a group of visiting Americans, has given a cautious response to President Reagan's proposal for a meeting with Leonid I. Brezhnev in New York during a United Nations disarmament conference in June.

title: Nordiques Lead Series by 2-1
description: Dale Hunter, profiting from his brother's trip to the penalty box, scored two goals in a 72-second span tonight to lead the Quebec Nordiques to a 2-1 victory over the Montreal Canadiens for a 2-game-to-1 advantage in their first-round playoff series.

title: NOBEL LAUREATE
description: To the Editor:

title: Ralph W.E. Jones, 78, Ex-Head of Grambling
description: Ralph Waldo Emerson Jones, who served as president of Grambling University for 41 years, died Friday. He was 78 years old.

title: FATAL HOBOKEN FIRE LINKED TO ARSON
description: HOBOKEN AFTER more than five months of investigation, the Hoboken Police Department believes that it has a suspect in a tenement fire here in which 11 persons died. The fire occurred last Oct. 24.

title: STYLISH SKETCHES
description: QUOTATIONS FROM OTHER LIVES By Penelope Gilliatt. 160 pp. New York: Coward, McCann & Geoghegan. $12.95.

title: Postings; PONDS VS. PUPILS
description: Henry Willets Underhill regrets that he ever agreed to sell 81 acres of a 200-acre Jericho, L.I., farm that his family had held since 1793. Mr. Underhill was persuaded that the scenic beauty of the land would be preserved when it was developed.

title: HORACE SEELY-BROWN, 73, SERVED SIX TERMS AS U.S. REPRESENTATIVE
description: Horace Seely-Brown Jr., a former United States Representative from eastern Connecticut for six terms beginning in 1947, died Friday in Boca Raton, Fla., where he had a winter residence. Mr. Seely-Brown, who also lived in Pomfret Center, Conn., was 73 years old.

title: By Lawernce Van Gelder; Spring Marathon In Paris
description: Anyone who has run the five boroughs in autumn's New York Marathon, who has sampled the traditional springtime agonies of the venerable Boston 26-miler, who may even have flown to Bermuda in January to retrace the equivalent distance of the classic Marathon-Athens trek of 490 B.C. may be looking for new routes to conquer.

title: Connecticut Illustrators To Exhibit Works
description: The work of Connecticut art directors and illustrators in advertisements, on editorial pages, magazine covers and record-album jackets, will be on display at the Museum of Art, Science and Industry in Bridgeport from next Friday through May 2.

title: Kostoff and Miss Cohen Swim to Third Victories
description: Jeff Kostoff and Tiffany Cohen swam to their third victories in distance events in the men's and women's 1,650-yard freestyles tonight in the United States Short Course swimming championships.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, APRIL 11, 1982
description: International A total ban on Argentine imports in Western Europe was voted by the European Economic Community as the deadline for Britain's naval blockade of Argentine shipping off the Falkland Islands approached. The import sanctions, adopted by the 10-member organization in Brussels, were the sternest punitive measures it has taken in its 25-year-history. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: Future Events Dance the Night Away
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.. Brazilian Amethyst April 14 - Amethysts protect against drunkenness, or so the ancients believed. The New York City Affiliate of the National Council on Alcoholism liked the legend enough to name its benefit ball for the gemstone, but still relies on cash in its crusade against alcoholism. The fourth annual Amethyst Ball in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom takes its theme from Brazil, an important source for amethysts. Highlights will include a showing of fashions by Luis de Freitas, a Brazilian designer, and entertainment by Thiago de Mello, & Friends, a Brazilian jazz group. Favors (little packages of coffee) and prizes - a week's vacation for two in Rio de Janeiro and an amethyst-and-diamond ring - continue the theme. Other aspects of the evening, however, will be strictly American. Brooke Shields, the model and actress, is special guest. Tickets, $125.

title: THE 'PEARCHED' VILLAGES OF PROVENCE
description: DOUGLAS C. McGILL is on the staff of The New York Times. BY DOUGLAS C.McGILL

title: REVIVING HISTORIC RECORDING CYLINDERS
description: When and where were the first actual live, off-the-stage opera recordings made? The pre-war Beecham series off the stage of Covent Garden? Those Muck recordings from Bayreuth in the 1920's?

title: THE RETURN OF A ROMANTIC
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- John Gruen, who writes frequently about music and dance, is the author of biographies of Leonard Bernstein, Gian Carlo Menotti and Erik Bruhn. By JOHN GRUEN

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: CLEARER PICTURE EMERGING ON VICTIMS OF CONGRESSIONAL REDISTRICTING
description: After months of negotiations and legal squabbling over how the state should redraw its political boundaries, the Democratic and Republican leaders of the State Legislature have reached roughly the same set of conclusions they had drawn months ago.

title: MORE THAN HONOR AND OIL IN FALKLANDS WAR
description: To the Editor:

title: A COLORFUL SHOW OF CRAFTS IN GREENWICH
description: GREENWICH IF ''Connecticut Choice,'' an invitational exhibition and sale at The Elements Gallery here through April 24 is any indication, crafts art is flourishing in the state. The mixed-media show by 28 Connecticut artisans includes works in clay, glass, wood, metal and fiber. Prices go from $40 for one of Wayne Rundell's melon baskets woven of wisteria runners to $2,250 for ''Tangle,'' a 53 by 46-inch abstract painting on silk by Susan Daniel.

title: Hempstead Recycling: 'Give It a Chance'
description: The Town of Hempstead recycling plant (''Signs Hint at Action on Plant,'' March 14) should be opened forthwith for an extended period, running at full capacity, to determine if there is any significant amount of toxic materials in its stack emissions.

title: AIR FORCE FINDS MECHANICAL FAILURE LED TO CRASHES OF FLYING TEAM
description: The Air Force has concluded that a mechanical failure in one plane, combined with the strict discipline followed by the pilots of three others, led to the deaths of four members of its Thunderbird air demonstration team on Jan. 18.

title: LEBANESE ASKS U.S. AND SOVIET TO BAR INVASION BY ISRAEL
description: President Elias Sarkis met with the Ambassadors of the United States and the Soviet Union today and reportedly appealed for their intervention to stave off a feared Israeli invasion.

title: WHY WE LIVE IN THE MUSICAL PAST
description: We are living in a most peculiar musical age. Musical life is booming, audiences are growing, seasons are expanding, conservatories are turning out virtuosos. In New York, well over a hundred concerts are given every week. There is an extraordinary bustle and whirl in the music world and its accompanying business. But in the midst of all that activity, there is a certain stillness, an immovable center. For our musical life is based upon repetition.

title: Peter Allen to Wed Tracey Anne Baird
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Baird of Los Angeles have announced the engagement of their daughter, Tracey Anne Baird, to Peter Graham Allen, son of Dr. and Mrs. Frederick G. Allen, also of Los Angeles.

title: Miss McInerney To Be the Bride Of Brian O'Hare
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Denis McInerney of Rye, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Kathleen McInerney, to Bernard Francis O'Hare, son of Mr. and Mrs. James O'Hare of Oyster Bay, L.I.

title: KNICKS HAND CAVS 15TH STRAIGHT LOSS
description: Paul Westphal sank a technical-foul shot with 18 seconds remaining for the winning point as the New York Knicks defeated the Cleveland Cavaliers, 117-114, tonight.

title: The Region in Summary; Drug Accusations Add to Pressures Facing Richmond
description: Politicians also are innocent until proven guilty, but they may become unelectable sometime sooner. Last week, amid reports that aides to Representative Frederick W. Richmond told a Federal grand jury that they had bought drugs for the four-term Congressman, he came under increasing pressure to resign.

title: NORTH KOREA IS SAID TO HOLD 105,000 FOR IDEOLOGY
description: South Korean intelligence officials say that at least 105,000 North Koreans are being held in camps for ideological offenders.

title: IMAGINATIVE PROCLAMATION
description: THE GREAT CODE The Bible and Literature. By Northrop Frye. 261 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $14.95.

title: City Hall Notes; MISS BELLAMY NOW TREATED LIKE AN HEIR
description: Only a few months ago, Mayor Koch was saying publicly how Carol Bellamy, the City Council President, was ''a horror show'' who at times did not do her job particularly well. But in recent weeks a certain closeness has developed between the staffs of the two officials, reflecting the fact that Miss Bellamy will become Mayor next January if Mr. Koch is elected Governor.

title: 277 RECEIVE FELLOWSHIPS FROM GUGGENHEIM FUND
description: The John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation has announced fellowship awards totaling $5,070,000 to 277 scholars, scientists and artists chosen from among 3,200 applicants in the foundation's 58th annual competition.

title: Nicole Lewis, J. M. Oakes Will Be Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Roscoe V. Lewis of Stamford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nicole Irene Lewis, to Jeffrey Morton Oakes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Earle D. Oakes of Philadephia.

title: No Headline
description: -Nurses at three hospitals have agreed to a Federal mediator's plan to settle a 90-day strike. The nurses at Good Samaritan, Alexian Brothers and San Jose hospitals voted Friday to accept an average pay increase of 28 percent over 35 months, officials said.

title: WOMEN-ONLY RACE SCHEDULED
description: WHITE PLAINS A WESTCHESTER rarity - a road race for women only -is on the agenda here for Sunday morning, April 25. The four sponsors of ''Women on the Move,'' as the race is named, said they hope the competition will serve to encourage women to become more aware of the need to keep physically fit.

title: Cook Does It All in Lacrosse
description: Of all the players on a lacrosse team, the three attackmen are usually the most spectacular. They are the dodgers, slicing by opponents from behind the goal to fire point-blank shots. They make the split-second passes to open teammates, and they take a thumping from burly defensemen.

title: ONCE UPON A HALESITE
description: TWENTY years ago I moved to Halesite, a little section on Huntington Harbor where Nathan Hale is said to have landed on his way to New York City during the Revolutionary War. On a newspaper page a few weeks ago, I discovered that I don't officially live in Halesite anymore. Along with Rampasture, Flowerfield, Freetown, San Remo, Vernon Valley and a total of more than 30 unincorporated communities on Long Island, Halesite is officially no more.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; There Was Something In the Air
description: Mark Twain once said he counted 136 different kinds of weather in a single New England day. Northeasterners last week may have encountered a 137th - a combination of high winds, subfreezing temperatures, thunder, lightning and at least a foot of snow.

title: Q&A
description: Question:I want to take a white-water trip in late April or early May and would like the names of groups that provide such trips within three to four hours' driving time from New York City. - M.C., New York, N.Y. Answer:Four times a year the Sierra Club puts out a metropolitan regional outings schedule that includes trips in the New York and New Jersey area. Among the outings are hiking, biking and white-water canoeing trips. For a copy of the schedule, a nonmember should send a check or money order for $3 to the Sierra Club, 228 East 45th Street, New York, N.Y. 10017. Members may subscribe to the schedule for $5 a year; for membership information send your name and address to the same address.

title: COMMUNITY'S PRIDE AT EASTER
description: BRIDGEPORT AS most of Connecticut's hundreds of thousands of Protestants and Roman Catholics gather for joyous Easter services and festive dinners today, an often somber Holy Week is beginning for the 300 parishioners of St. Dimitrius Rumanian Orthodox Church here.

title: EDITING THE ANCHOR BIBLE
description: It has been more than 26 years since planning began for the Anchor Bible, an edition in which each book of the Bible is translated and annotated by a different scholar. In 1980 Doubleday & Company, the publisher, said the edition would be completed in 62 volumes. In an interview last month David Noel Freedman, the general editor of the series, mentioned 66. The Joshua volume, published this month, is the 34th to appear, so it may be safe to say the Anchor Bible is halfway home.

title: Soviet Reports Wide Damage In Georgian Republic Floods
description: Record rain and unseasonably warm temperatures have led to flooding in the southern Soviet republic of Georgia, the Communist Party newspaper Pravda reported today. It said more than 300 buildings had been destroyed and some people had been killed and others injured.

title: ...AND SOME APPLAUSE FOR WHAT'S ALREADY RIGHT
description: FOR the last few weeks, the American public has been inundated by a flood of publicity about how corrupt college athletics has presumably become. Almost every day, new and increasingly serious disclosures are headlined. We are bombarded by television, radio, newspaper and magazine reports, all exposing the terrible road down which, we are told, college athletics is traveling.

title: BANGLADESH MILITARY LEADER SAYS HE FEARS SOVIET
description: Lieut. Gen. Hussain Mohammed Ershad, this nation's new military ruler, said in an interview today that he believed the Soviet Union was ''very dangerous.''

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Chicagoans Get Their Last Shot
description: It may be the end of a tradition in Chicago. But then, maybe not. In March, the Chicago City Council approved an ordinance banning the new registration of handguns and requiring owners of registered weapons to renew their applications. Thursday was the end of the grace period before the new law took effect - and the gun business was booming.

title: NEW TRIALS IN TEST MARKETING
description: THE brand managers at XYZ multibillion-dollar packaged-goods companya reconvinced that the company's new product is the best thing since sliced bread. The hotshots on Madison Avenue think they've created an unforgettable advertising campaign. Everybody is keen on sending his particular banner up the proverbial flagpole. But will anyone salute?

title: Sports of The Times; An Amateur Among Masters
description: JUST before he rolled in a 10

title: BLUE NOTE FESTIVAL
description: The Spring Jazz Festival last week at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street, was more than just an attention-getting name. The festival, which runs through today, is notable both because it offers two groups every night instead of the usual one - the Al Cohn-Zoot Sims Quintet and Emily Remler and her trio - and because it is the first major New York booking for Miss Remler, a 24-year-old guitarist who has attracted an unusual amount of enthusiastic attention in the last year.

title: Around the World; Havana-Miami Air Link Temporarily Reinstated
description: More than 2,000 travelers stranded in Havana and Miami because of the Reagan Administration's crackdown on a company operating charter flights between the two cities were today guaranteed passage home.

title: Syria Shuts Iraqi Pipelines
description: Syria halted the flow of Iraqi oil across its territory to Mediterranean terminals today in a further deterioration in relations between the two Arab countries. The step came two days after Syria's announcement that it had closed its border with Iraq, which it has accused of sending saboteurs and weapons into Syrian territory. The closing of the pipelines could cut Iraq's oil exports by as much as half.

title: Q and A; Change in Tenant Status
description: Question: When my husband and I moved into the lower of two apartments in a private house, we received a two-year lease. I am now divorced. The landlord refuses to renew my lease and has requested that I move because he wants a married couple as tenants. Can I be forced out? Also, I learned from Building Department records that the house is listed as a one-family house. Can my landlord evict me if he had no right to rent to me in the first place?...P.G.,Elmont,L.I. Answer: The landlord cannot evict you because your marital status has changed. That would be discrimination based on marital status, which violates state law. If the two-family occupancy is in violation of the Town of Hempstead's zoning law, the landlord would have to stop renting out part of it after you reported the violation. The landlord would not be subject to a penalty unless, after official notice, he continued to operate it as a two-family house.

title: Brazil Stops Cuban Plane
description: Brazilian jet fighters intercepted a Cuban plane over the Amazon basin Friday night and forced it to land at Brasilia.

title: THE HERPES SYNDROME
description: The most important question regarding the herpes epidemic is why it has been permitted to go on unchecked. One sentence in Daniel Laskin's article touched on the answer: ''The nation's research institutes have not done much for herpes victims, either.''

title: GOOD NEWS AND BAD NEWS FOR A CANDIDATE
description: NEWARK FOR Brenda Grier, one of the seven announced candidates for Mayor of the state's largest city, last week was one of those when you win some and you lose some.

title: THE NEW WAY TO BUILD OFFICES
description: FASTER elevators, enhanced security, more flexible air-conditioning s ystems, sprinklers and computerized lobby directories are among the a menities employees will find when their companies move into the n ewest generation of Manhattan office buildings.

title: WILL THEY CLASSIFY EVEN THE ALPHABET?
description: President Reagan has signed a new executive order that vastly increases the power of Administration officials to stamp documents ''classified.'' Intended to protect our country's secrets from falling into enemy hands, this order actually will be used to keep almost everything secret.

title: CRAFTS
description: MORRISTOWN AT THIS time, when many exhibitions are marking the 20th year of the Studio Glass Movement, one that should not be missed is ''American Glass Art: Evolution and Revolution,'' now on view at the Morris Museum of Arts and Sciences.

title: ARCHITECT AND A PAINTER AT THE NEUBERGER MUSEUM
description: PURCHASE TWO shows that are separate enterprises make an irresisitible double bill at the Neuberger Museum of the State University College of New York at Purchase. Works of Robert A. M. Stern and Abraham Walkowitz - the post-Modernist architect schooled at Yale, and the proto-Modernist painter and immigrant from Siberia who lived from 1878 to 1965 - will be showing for several weeks.

title: VACATION PLAN OFFERS OPTIONS
description: NERVOUS is the word for the time-share industry. This is the i ndustry that, for an upfront charge of several thousand dollars and a nnual maintenance fees far lower than the rates at comparable r esort facilities, gives buyers assured weeks of vacation time at a r esort.

title: POVERTY IS MORE THAN BEING FLAT BROKE
description: Peter Townsend, a professor of social policy at England's University of Bristol, has become a key figure in discussions of social policy issues. His latest book, ''Poverty in the United Kingdom,'' proposes a ''deprivation index'' that, Mr. Townsend says, provides a scientific method for measuring poverty. The index is based on a dozen criteria that depart from traditional income-based standards and include such categories as taking yearly vacations and eating cooked meals.

title: Sarah Kahn Is Affianced
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. Ernest Kahn and Virginia Lewisohn Kahn, both of Cambridge, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter, Sarah Elizabeth Kahn, to Gary Allen Freeman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Freeman of Gainesville, Fla.

title: 'BIG BIRD' ENJOYS RESPITE
description: FOR more than a dozen years, Carroll Spinney has been a television and movie star of international renown, collecting acting awards, performing at the White House and cutting two gold records. Yet after 12 years of acclaim, his most ardent fans pass him on the street without a glimmer of recognition.

title: Major News in Summary; Will the Winners Show Restraint?
description: While President Reagan took it easy on a ''working holiday'' in Jamaica and Barbados last week, American diplomats and Congressmen in El Salvador tried to mold a moderate government out of an election that favored the extreme right.

title: Nets Trounce Pacers By 115-86
description: It was as if the Nets, frustrated by consecutive 3-point losses to Philadelphia and Boston this week, were taking everything out on the Indiana Pacers tonight.

title: REAGAN ATTACKS CRITICS OVER CUT IN STUDENT AID
description: President Reagan, in a live fiveminute radio broadcast to the American people, today angrily denounced critics of his proposed cutbacks in the student loan program.

title: Dance View; HONORING YOUSKEVITCH-'A GIVING FROM THE HEART'
description: Strangers venturing near the Drama Department of the University of Texas at Austin between March 25 and 28 might have been amazed at all the kisses and tears there. The kisses were the affectionate pecks with which members of the dance world often greet one another and, although the occasion commemorated a retirement, the tears were tears of joy.

title: WIT AND MELODY ENLIVEN TWO MUSICALS
description: American musical comedy may be an ailing art form, but it is certainly far from dead, judging from the excellent original cast albums of Stephen Sondheim's ''Merrily We Roll Along'' (RCA Red Seal CBL1-4197) and William Finn's ''March of the Falsettos'' on the DRG label (SBL 12581).

title: OVERLOOKED AREA
description: To the Editor:

title: Chartres
description: To the Editor:

title: TURNING POINT FOR BARYSHNIKOV
description: Deborah Trustman writes on the arts and culture. By Deborah Trustman ikhail Baryshnikov waits in the wings, his face expressionless, as if he has shed personality. The asbestos fire curtain closes off the stage for rehearsals in Boston's Metropolitan Center early in the American Ballet Theater's fall tour. At his cue, he leaps diagonally across the stage, spectacularly high, arms and legs parallel to the floor. He comes offstage panting, turns, catches his breath and follows the rehearsal: a new ballet, ''Configurations,'' by the young Singapore-born choreographer Choo San Goh. Baryshnikov has commissioned the ballet for his company, and he has committed his dancers to performing it this season, on the road and during Ballet Theater's New York spring season at the Metropolitan Opera house, which begins next week. The cast of ''Configurations'' includes several promising dancers from the corps de ballet. He wants to watch them work.

title: MORE OFFICERS ARE TURNING IN COLLEAGUES BELIEVED CORRUPT
description: Six New York City police officers have been arrested on corruption charges this year as the result of information provided by fellow officers, and some officials see this as a sign of a growing break in the traditional code of silence within the department that used to mask misdeeds.

title: Catherine Boboly to Be Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul Boboly of Laurence Harbor, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Catherine Marie Boboly, to James Emmett Boardman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Landsdale Boardman of Scarsdale, N.Y., where a June 5 wedding is planned in the Hitchcock Presbyterian Church. Miss Boboly, who is a word processor in corporate services with the Public Service Electric and Gas Company in Newark, and her fiance, who is a programmer with the International Business Machines Corporation in East Fishkill, N.Y., are both graduates of the Rochester Institute of Technology.

title: Physician to Wed Linda Swansburg
description: The Rev. and Mrs. Edward F. Swansburg of Nahant, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Linda Anne Swansburg, to Dr. William Grant Hendren, son of Dr. and Mrs. William Hardy Hendren 3d of Duxbury, Mass.

title: Food
description: Entertaining With Style (outside type)Over the years, personal qualities - beauty, brains, wealth, wit, hard work -have separated the great hosts and hostesses from the crowd.Anne Crutcher is a freelance writer based in Washington. Helen Lawrenson, that frisky 1930's glamour girl, defined a great dinner as one where you can't remember what you had to eat. Without going quite that far, everybody knows food and drink are not the only ingredients of a great party. There are also the people, the setting and the je ne sais quoi.

title: Around the Nation; Chlorine Leak Forces Evacuation of a Town
description: An ''enormously big cloud'' of toxic chlorine gas leaked from a chemical plant in this central West Virginia town today, forcing the evacuation of the town's 1,700 residents and sending 11 people to the hospital for treatment.

title: FRANCE DEBATING STATE TV POLICIES
description: ''Do you expect us to find someone from outer space, perhaps from Mars, to run our television for us?'' Prime Minister Pierre Mauroy demanded to know at a press lunch the other day.

title: ADMINISTRATION SELLING INCREASED NAVY BUDGET AS HEART OF MILITARY STRATEGY
description: The Reagan Administration has proposed to Congress the most ambitious program for naval expansion in the nation's peacetime history as an essential part of the President's plan to project America's military might around the globe.

title: Topics Oil, Ice and Hot Air; A Carter Legacy
description: Oh, all of us critics had a time of it in 1979 when President Carter set his dramatic new energy goal for the country. ''Beginning this moment,'' he said in a televised address on July 15, ''this nation will never use more foreign oil than we did in 1977. Never.

title: IN NASSAU, AN INNER SUBURB PLANS REVIVAL
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I.

title: IN BRITAIN, SOME DOUBTS ABOUT HOW TOUGH TO BE
description: ON-THAMES, England, April 10 - In the Marks and Spencers department store here today, Tony and Olive Williams paused over a rack of women's wool blazers, quickly agreeing that 39.50 was too steep a price. Then the subject of the Falkland Islands came up and the family unanimity vanished.

title: Around the Nation; 25,000 March in Chicago To Protest Arms Race
description: A chanting, sign-waving throng estimated at up to 25,000 people marched through Chicago today, some wheeling babies and leading pets on leashes. In the vanguard were four children carrying the rallying slogan: ''Stop The Arms Race, Save The Human Race.''

title: About Books and Authors
description: The Sense of an Ending

title:
NEW JERSEY GUIDE;
A TRIBUTE TO ISRAEL
description: Two Israeli folk singers will be the centerpiece of a tribute to Israel at the Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. in West Orange Saturday evening. The singers have toured the United States as part of the Israel Folk Company, and when they appeared with that group in New York City in 1971, Howard Thompson, writing in The New York Times, said:

title: IRENA CHOI PLANS NUPTIALS FOR JUNE
description: Dr. and Mrs. Woonsang Michael Choi of Somerville, Mass., and Seoul, Korea, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Irena Sangae Choi, to Bruce Elliot Stern, son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvon Stern of Jericho, L.I.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: cover last year, he has been convicted of a murder he committed in New York while on conditional release from prison.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Safety Net Brooklyn-born Steve Guttenberg, who attended the High School of Performing Arts here for two years, is now a student at U.C.L.A. If he finishes his education as planned, he'll be a dentist in about five years. But, as he points out, the ''glamour and excitement'' of the television-movie business can distract from educational incentives.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Roots of the Troubles The documentary series, ''Ireland: A Television History,'' will begin its 13-week run on Channel 13, Saturday at 8 P.M. This week's segment, ''A Nation Once Again,'' traces the Emerald Isle's history beginning 8,000 years ago and glides through time to 1607, a little beyond the reign of Elizabeth I when Ireland was an English province. The series, which was written and narrated by Robert Kee, will conclude with an examination of Ireland's current problems.

title: WHEN FARMERS ARE HURTING, SMALL TOWNS FEEL THE PAIN
description: As the farmers in Greene County go, so goes the town of Jefferson. And as the agricultural recession deepens, so does the gloom in this once-prosperous central Iowa community that sits among some of the most productive land in the world.

title: Deborah L. Gates Sets Fall Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Gates of Aberdeen, N.J., and Sandesfield, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Leigh Gates, to Mark Maten, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph E. Maten of Ann Arbor, Mich.

title: MICHAEL SPINKS EXPECTS NO TROUBLE IN TITLE FIGHT
description: Until four months ago, the world's two light-heavyweight champions would call each other names when they met. ''Michael Stinks, I mean, Spinks,'' Matthew Saad Muhammad, the World Boxing Council 175-pound champion, would say. ''Your name is Sad Muhammad,'' Michael Spinks, the World Boxing Association champion, would reply. And they would both smile, with visions of $2.5 million purses for a title-unification bout. Now the two will be fighting six days apart, and times have changed since Dwight Braxton knocked out Saad Muhammad for the W.B.C. title last December.

title: Sports People; Herzog Yields a Job
description: Whitey Herzog of the St. Louis Cardinals resigned from one job yesterday but got a raise and a two-year extension on another. Herzog, who has been the manager for the last two seasons and the general manager since the end of the 1980 season, decided to relinquish the general manager's position.

title: SHOW TO FEATURE NATIVE ARTISANS
description: LARGE and small, costly and less so, hewn, carved, turned, painted or otherwise, a vast cornucopia of American decorative art works, made between the 17th and early 19th centuries, goes on display Friday at the Connecticut Spring Antiques Show in Hartford.

title: JILL KAUFMAN ENGAGED TO RICHARD C. WALLER
description: Mr. and Mrs. William E. Kaufman of Armonk, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jill P. Kaufman, to Richard C. Waller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen C. Waller of Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: 'A SOUR LITTLE WAR'
description: The Origins of the Korean War Liberation and the Emergence of Separate Regimes, 1945-1947. By Bruce Cumings. 606 pp. Princeton: Princeton University Press Cloth, $40. Paper, $14.95 Korea The Untold Story of the War. By Joseph C. Goulden. Illustrated. 690 pp. New York: Times Books. $22.50 By John Curtis Perry

title: THE RISE OF A DEMAGOGUE
description: THE LIFE AND TIMES OF JOE McCARTHY By Thomas C. Reeves. Illustrated. 819 pp. New York: Stein & Day. $19.95.

title: Barbara Jo Nocca Becomes Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Felix Nocca of Yonkers have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Jo Nocca, to John Christopher Triplett, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Triplett of Winterset, Iowa.

title: DAMASCENE WARE IN SPAIN'S TOLEDO
description: ROBERT PACKARD teaches humanities at Stevens Institute of Technology. BY ROBERT PACKARD

title: COUNTY AUTHORS CITED
description: The six county authors nominated for the 1982 American Book awards -to be announced April 22 - will be honored at a public reception celebrating National Library Week at 7:30 P.M. Wednesday in the Scarsdale Public Library at Olmstead and White Plains Post Roads.

title: Maria Fiddler Engaged To Walter J. Leukart
description: Capt. Roy E. Fiddler, Merchant Marine, and Mrs. Fiddler of Westport, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Maria Dolores Fiddler, to Walter Jay Leukart, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. Leukart 3d of Columbus, Ohio.

title: WHEN A ZIGZAG IS REALLY A STRAIGHT LINE
description: WASHINGTON IN her stormy first year as head of the Environmental Protection Agency, Anne M. Gorsuch appears to have mastered an indispensable political maneuver - the 180 degree turn. In the past few months, her agency has issued new policies on a host of environmental issues - lifting the ban on burying drums containing liquid toxic wastes, for example, and proposing to drop or relax rules limiting lead in gasoline - only to reverse itself publicly, or to suggest privately that it was having serious second thoughts.

title: Toyota's Edge
description: To the Business Editor: Regarding your article on Toyota, ''The Company That Stopped Detroit'' (March 21), I submit that even if Detroit can overcome the labor ($500) and manufacturing ($1,500) disadvantage per car you quote, it will still be unable to compete against Japan.

title:
GARDENING;
TIPS ON HIRING A LANDSCAPE GARDENER
description: MOST garden writers, including myself, take the approach that the reader will do his own lawn and garden work. That, of course, is not always true, especially in this area.

title: The World in Summary; Ulster Election With a Catch
description: Northern Ireland's Protestants have rejected all suggestions for sharing power with Roman Catholics, so London last week proposed a new tack - sharing without power, through a ''consultative'' assembly for Ulster.

title: JAMAICA, FOR AMERICAN HISTORY
description: GARRY WILLS is the author of several works of history and politics, among them ''The Kennedy Imprisonment,'' just published by Little, Brown. By GARRY WILLS

title: THE CROSSROADS OF THREE FAITHS
description: MALACHI MARTIN's recent books include ''The Final Conclave,'' ''King of Kings,'' a re-creation of the life of David, and ''The Decline and Fall of the Roman Church.'' By MALACHI MARTIN

title: JUDGE RULES REPORTER WAIVED RIGHT TO SILENCE
description: A Superior Court judge has ruled that a newspaper reporter who answered some questions but refused to answer others at a preliminary hearing in a criminal case had automatically waived any right to protect confidential sources or information, otherwise guaranteed by the State Constitution.

title: No Headline
description: I have spent many summers on Fire Island and have clipped many an article about it. The aerial photograph of the island on the cover of March 7 is probably the most wonderful photo of the place that I have ever seen. JOHN C. JANEDIS, New York

title: BRITTANIA WAVES THE RULES
description: The course of empire never did run smooth, but much the hardest part of the perennial old human adventure is bringing it to a conclusion. The French endured two terrible wars, in Indochina and Algeria, before they could be rid of their imperial pretentions. The Portuguese had a revolution. The experience of the British, upon whose overseas territories the sun proverbially never set, has generally been more trying than lacerating, but still the preposterous impasse they have got themselves into over the Falkland Islands is a warning to any aspirant imperialist that in the long run dominion is seldom worth it.

title: RATING LOCAL VISITORS BUREAUS
description: Everyone knows that when you visit Philadelphia for the first time, you go to see the Liberty Bell. When you visit San Francisco you ride a cable car, and in San Antonio you see the Alamo.

title: The Nation in Summary; STrategic Metals And Public Lands
description: Critics who say that the Administration's environmental program was designed to conserve private industry rather than nature were up in arms again last week as President Reagan unveiled his ''national materials and minerals program,''designed to reduce dependence on ''potentially unstable foreign sources'' for strategic metals.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ART Joan Miro will be 89 this month. There will be a major exhibition at the Museum of Fine Arts in Houston, Tex., and coincidentally there will be the inauguration of a large public sculpture in the same expansive city.

title: Prospects
description: Here Comes the Taxman...

title: HEMPSTEAD RE-CYCLING: 'GIVE IT A CHANCE'
description: In reference to the article on the recycling plant, I have attended the meetings of the Town of Hempstead Committee on Solid Waste Disposal as one of the two official observers representing the Salisbury Civic Association in South Westbury.

title: Art View; THE ART OF ITALY TODAY
description: ''Italian Art Now: An American Perspective,'' at the Guggenheim Museum, is a remarkable phenomenon. Where anthologies of recent work from other European nations at the Guggenheim and elsewhere have enjoyed at most a success of politeness, this one includes at least two artists - Sandro Chia and Enzo Cucchi - for whom dealers and collectors all over the world are standing in line. Others in the show may well be in the same position before long. Italian art is in, that is to say, in a way that has not happened for many, many years.

title: '83 RACE TAKING SHAPE
description: STAMFORD MARTY O'MEARA, a Wethersfield businessman who operates two automobile rental agencies in Hartford and who is a director of Connecticut's only greyhound race track, at Plainfield, is anxiously awaiting the start of this season's tuneups for the 1983 America's Cup yachting classic.

title: Models for All Ages
description: I admired the clothes in ''Fashions of The Times,'' (March 7).

title: Paperback Best Sellers; MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: No Headline
description: After reading the March 7 article, I recalled many of our civic association meetings in Lido Beach (we came here in 1953). These meetings were called hurriedly after a storm, and Harold Gates (who is deceased) was the leader in trying to resolve what to do after we lost so much land from our beaches.

title: Stephen Gifford To Wed Lee Peck
description: Mr. and Mrs. William F. Smith of Duxbury, Mass., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Smith's daughter, Lee Canfield Peck, to Stephen Nye Gifford, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen W. Gifford of Dedham, Mass.

title: Passenger Commends 'The Amtrak Way'
description: I am indignant that you should give so much space to Ted M. Levine's March 14 article, ''One Passenger's Raillery Over 'the Amtrak Way.' '' How about another passenger's view?

description: To the Editor:

title: INFORMATION CENTER AIDS PEOPLE SEEKING GRANTS
description: They come singly and in groups, students and artists, scientists and missionaries, all with the aim of obtaining philanthropic grants for their own work or for their organizations.

title: HIS MANY WORLDS INCLUDE SPACE
description: PROFESSION? ''That's a tough question to answer,'' said Jerry Grey of Bridgehampton. ''I call myself an engineer-scientist. But I'm also a professor, a writer, and I do lots of public policy activities - presenting scientific and technical matters and their implications to the public.''

title: Headliners; Oh Yeah?
description: Ever since Einstein knocked off Newton, it seems, scientists have been trying knock off Einstein.

title: A CHEESE IN UPPER-CLASS MOLD
description: STEVEN RATTNER is a correspondent for The Times based in London. BY STEVEN RATTNER

title:
Stamps;
FOR 200 YEARS OF INTERNATIONAL FRIENDSHIP
description: Two centuries ago the Netherlands, then a puissant power in Europe, extended diplomatic recognition to the fledgling United States. The Dutch, who were the bankers of Europe, granted the new nation $1 million in life-giving loans and averted the financial collapse of the struggling republic.

title: M.T.A.-JAPAN DEAL ON 325 SUBWAY CARS IS HEADING FOR COURT
description: The chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and three other officials have been ordered to appear in court on Wednesday to defend their decision to purchase 325 subway cars from a Japanese company.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: FARCE A History From Aristophanes to Woody Allen. By Albert Bermel. 464 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $20.75.

title: CATHLEEN BACICH TO MARRY IN JUNE
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John J. Bacich of B rookfield, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Cathleen anneB acich, to Charles Evan Stewart, son of Mrs. Jennifer B. Stewart of A rdsley-on-Hudson, N.Y., and Charles T. Stewart of New York.

title: Postings; LITTLE CARNEGIE'S LAST PICTURE SHOW
description: The Little Carnegie Theater on West 57th Street gave ''Atlantic City'' a final whirl through its projectors last Sunday night and then, with no warnings or portents, closed. Thus passed one of the city's best-known cinema houses after a run of more than 50 years.

title: Protecting Trees In Babylon
description: I read with interest the letter from A. Roger Yackel of Huntington in the March 21 edition. Mr. Yackel, rightfully, deplores the removal of municipally owned trees and goes on to suggest that an inventory of these valuable resources be compiled by the various towns and villages having jurisdiction over them.

title: NOVELTIES BY CHAMBER MUSIC SOCIETY
description: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center had three charming novelties and one familiar landmark for its audience at Alice Tully Hall Friday night. Josef Suk, the Czech violinist, performed in all this music, and the presence on the program of his grandfather's Elegie for Violin, Cello and Piano and three movements from Dvorak's ''Cypresses'' for string quartet seemed to celebrate his visit.

title: Liverpool Wins by 5-0
description: Liverpool, making a late bid for its fifth championship in seven seasons, routed Manchester City, 5-0, at Manchester today and opened a 5-point lead in the English League soccer standing.

title: SUSAN ALAMO, 56, FOUNDER OF OZARK MOUNTAIN MINISTRY, DIES
description: Susan Alamo, whose preaching to Hollywood street people in 1968 led to establishment of the nationally known Tony and Susan Alamo Christian Foundation, died Thursday at Oral Roberts' City of Faith Hospital in Tulsa, Okla.

title: The World in Summary; China Asks Limit On Taiwan Arms
description: Like Ronald Reagan, Deng Xiaoping is getting flak from his Taiwan lobby. The Chinese leader, who in December 1978 acceded to informal United States ties with the island in return for formal relations with the mainland, has still set no public timetable for Washington to whittle down its one-and-a-half-China policy to one.

title: WHERE GOOD VALUE IS THE DRAW
description: NEW HAVEN IN New Haven, criticizing Leon's is a little like attacking motherhood and the flag. No reservations are accepted at this 30-year-old restaurant, yet night after night the two modest-sized dining rooms are filled and refilled. Diners leaving are forced to exit through the frenzied kitchen because of a waiting line that clogs the narrow entrance.

title: No Headline
description: Let me tell you about two wonderful parents I know. They have four children, two by adoption and two by birth. Their only daughter is 15. One evening about two months ago, they received a telephone call from a woman who claimed to be their daughter's natural mother. It came out of the blue, even though they had talked about searching for her when their daughter was a few years older.

title: Cassettes Provide Guide For Touring Manhattan
description: Walking tours of Lower Manhattan for individuals who wish to go it alone at their own pace rather than in groups have been recorded on cassettes. The routes include descriptions of particular buildings, landmarks and the history of the areas.

title: 5th Ave. Burglar Gets $100,000 in Jewelry
description: A burglar entered a Fifth Avenue penthouse early yesterday and made off with jewelry valued at $100,000, the police said. The occupants of the apartment, Douglas Auchincloss, a former associate editor of Time magazine, and his wife, Lily, were home at the time but were not harmed, the police said.

title: SPRING WHISPERS, 'PROMISES, PROMISES'
description: MY daily walk along a country road began in late February and continues. The road I walk is set high above an ice- and snow-covered reservoir that sends its precious store through massive tunnels and pipes to waiting tanks and taps in a great city. The reservoir is on my left as I proceed west; to the south, and on the slope leading down to the water basin, are strong patient trees: white oak, aspen, white and yellow birch, beech, shag hickory. The trees, aided by strong winds and time have been shedding wood all winter. The discards of many shapes and lengths reach out from the woods like gargoyles, pleading arms or woodland sculpture. I remind myself to return to this place to collect wood for my stove.

title: Beach Erosion And Memories
description: The article on beach erosion (''Fire Island Erosion: New Strategies,'' March 7) alleged that sand dunes 20 feet high are substantial enough to provide protection against severe ocean storm damage. This is not true, and can lend a false sense of security to beachfront dwellers.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THE gypsy moth, which defoliated 850,000 acres in the state last year, is expected to cause comparable damage again this spring. Agricultural experts, predicting a dismal season, also said that there would be fewer Federal subsidies available to help municipalities pay to spray trees to control the leaf-eating pests.

title: DIVERS HAVE OYSTERMEN IN A SQUEEZE
description: Many of the Chesapeake Bay's watermen, a hardworking, outspoken breed, are arguing over a new method of harvesting oysters by diving for them, a procedure viewed as practical by its advocates but as outrageous by those who use older methods.

title: Claudia Angelos Will Be Married
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lewis R. Angelos of Los Angeles, formerly of New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Claudia Angelos, to Raymond F. Healey Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Raymond F. Healey of Upper Montclair, N.J.

title: ARGENTINA SPED PAST THE POINT OF NO RETURN
description: BUENOS AIRES BRITAIN has set a midnight deadline for imposing a naval blockade of the Falkland Islands. A British armada is steaming down the Atlantic. The European Common Market yesterday announced a total ban on imports from and arms sales to Argentina. Argentina has been defeated in the United Nations Security Council. Even fellow members of the Organization of American States appear more embarrassed than impressed by Argentina's seizure of the Falkland Islands 10 days ago.

title: REAL LIFE STRATEGY FOR A FANTASY WORLD
description: GLENN R. SINGER is a staff writer for The Post in West Palm Beach, Fla. By GLENN R. SINGER

title: SCHOOL DISTRICTS WEIGH PROBLEM OF FEWER PUPILS
description: IT is unlikely that county residents have ever heard of the ''East Tuckville'' school district. The name was coined by Dr. Joseph Ventura, Superintendent of the Tuckahoe School District, to represent the hypothetical merging of the Eastchester, Tuckahoe and Bronxville School Districts. He uses it as an example of how educational leaders in those districts could cope with a declining enrollment.

title: Major News in Summary; New War Jitters In South Lebanon
description: Even if an alarmed Reagan Administration hadn't reported portentous Israeli troop movements near the Lebanon border this weekend, Palestinian guerrillas would have had plenty of reasons to fear that Israel's long-threatened strike was coming.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Fine-Print Reading ''I can't remember a more difficult subject to deal with,'' said Daniel O'Connor, Director of Special Programs for NBC News. He was referring to the documentary on the $676-billion insurance business, ''Protection for Sale: The Insurance Industry,'' produced by Tom Tomizawa and Mort Silverstein and reported by Chris Wallace.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption today on the Tele- vision page of the Arts and Leisure section gives the channel incorrectly for a production of ''The Three Sis- ters'' to be shown at 8 P.M. next Satur- day. It will be available on Manhattan Cable's Channel K.

title: CONSUMER RATES
OFFERS POURING IN TO HELP WOLF TRAP
description: Despite a fire that destroyed the stage and auditorium of the Wolf Trap Park for the Performing Arts last week, officials are promising that a full summer schedule of concerts, ballet and opera will be fulfilled. ''We know that we are going to have a Wolf Trap season,'' said Mary-Therese Mennino, director of programming.

title: DEMOCRATS REDISCOVER THEIR POWER
description: WASHINGTON THERE is a change in the political dynamics of Congress, and it was never so noticeable as it was last week. Equally evident, however, were the limits to the shift.

title: RANGERS WIN; PENGUINS TRIUMPH IN OVERTIME BY 2-1
description: Rick Kehoe scored at 4 minutes 14 seconds of overtime tonight to give the Pittsburgh Penguins a 2-1 victory over the Islanders in their first-round National Hockey League playoff. The Islanders lead the three-of-five series, 2-1, with the fourth game set for Sunday night at Civic Arena. If a fifth game is needed, it will be played Tuesday night at Nassau Coliseum on Long Island.

title: RESEARCHERS TRYING TO EASE TOOTHACHE PAINS
description: NEWARK ''DANGLING precariously at the end of every tooth,'' says Frank M. Lapeyrolerie, ''is a large, but highly frightened individual. Dental pain is one of the most intractable pains known to man.''

title: On Defining Issues In Free Counseling
description: Regrettably, Daniel J. Wise's piece concerning the assignment of counsel to indigent matrimonial litigants (''Court Bids Lawyers to Take Cases Free for Poor in Divorce,'' March 21) not only misses the point and quotes me wholly out of context, it paints a portrait not at all reflective of the issues addressed.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Don't Forget The Bananas
description: Aside from the turbulent headlines, what does the average American know about Central America? Not much, judging by a recent New York Times/CBS News poll. It found that many couldn't easily find El Salvador on the map.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
ON PARADE
description: There's more to Easter parading than just showing off holiday finery. In Garden City, where the Easter parade has become a venerable institution, in addition to the customary flora and fauna (yes, bunnies will distribute lollipops), there will be an antique car motorcade and exhibition. Everything gets under way at 1 P.M. today, with the parade proceeding along Franklin Avenue until it reaches Village Hall on Stewart Avenue, where the autos will be assembled for inspection.KRISHNA'S IMPACT

title: CAMPUS AT PURCHASE MARKS 10TH ANNIVERSARY
description: TEN years have passed since the first graduating class left the Purchase campus of the State University of New York, and a multifaceted celebration of that anniversary will begin Saturday afternoon with the formal inauguration of the college's third president, Dr. Sheldon Grebstein.

title:
Economic Affairs;
WHAT'S ALL THE MERGING ABOUT?
description: DURING the last year, the wave of mergers of large corporations r eached a new crest. More than $45 billion of assets were acquired int he process of completing the hundred largest mergers, an amount moret han twice the average of the previous three years of such mergers. T he two largest were the $8 billion purchase of Conoco Inc. by Du P ont, and the $6 billion purchase of the Marathon Oil Company by U nited States Steel. There were seven mergers in which more than $1 b illion of assets were acquired and there were 69 mergers in which m ore than $100 million were purchased.

title: Lizette Smith Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Howard Worth Smith Jr. of Alexandria, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lizette Gordon Smith, to John Francis McGinn, son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. McGinn of Hewlett, L.I. A late summer wedding is planned.

title: Miss Cacace Wed To Terry Pavone
description: Patricia Cacace, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Cacace of White Plains, was married yesterday to Emil A. Pavone 3d, son of Mr. Pavone Jr. of Larchmont, N.Y., and Charlotte Pavone of White Plains. The Rev. Joseph B. Hynds performed the ceremony at Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church in Hartsdale, N.Y.

title: Mailbox; Go, Brooklyn, Beat Everybody
description: To the Sports Editor: Three cheers for the Brooklyn College basketball program. As a Brooklyn College graduate now living in Oklahoma, I eagerly await the Kingsmen's arrival in Division I play.

title: CITY U. REACHES OUT ON TV
description: The City University of New York has begun this semester to offer credit-bearing courses on television in an effort to reach out to groups such as working adults, the elderly and mothers with small children.

title: Strong Quake Hits Greece
description: A strong earthquake, measuring 5.5 on the Richter scale, rocked northeastern Greece today, but there were no immediate reports of damage or casualties.

title: GATHERING THE POETS OF FAITH
description: THE NEW OXFORD BOOK OF CHRISTIAN VERSE Chosen and Edited by Donald Davie. 320 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $24.95.

title: FIRE AND BRIMSTONE CAPATURED ON FILM
description: MORRISTOWN THERE is something pleasing about the idea of a photographer born in a country as flat as the Netherlands specializing in pictures of volcanoes. This is the situation with Mathias Van Hesemans, whose second show at the Woodman Gallery, 8 Dehart Place, will continue through next Sunday.

title: 'CHANEYSVILLE INCIDENT' WINS FAULKNER AWARD
description: ''The Chaneysville Incident'' by David Bradley, a historical novel about 13 escaped slaves who asked to be shot to death by their Northern captors rather than be returned to the South, was named winner of the PEN/Faulkner Award as the best work of fiction by an American writer published last year.

title: Duncan Stearns, Pianist With Unusual Program
description: Duncan Stearns's program Monday night at Carnegie Recital Hall was like some mostly happy throwback to an earlier, more innocent world, one in which pianists routinely chopped up pieces, rearranged them and constructed musical sequences out of snippets. Given the grinding predictability of so much programming today, this proved curiously refreshing.

title:
NEW JERSEY GUIDE;
A LITERARY EVENING
description: Robert Penn Warren - novelist, poet and the winner of three Pulitzer Prizes - will read from his works Wednesday night at the Drew University campus in Madison.

title: Walesa Reunited With Family For Easter at Warsaw Villa
description: Lech Walesa, the union leader, has been reunited for Easter with his wife, Danuta, and their seven children in the villa outside Warsaw where he has been held by the martial law authorities for nearly four months, according to family sources.

title: The Nation in Summary; HArd Hats, Hard Times
description: No poll was needed to catch the political mood in the depressed construction industry last week at an A.F.L.-C.I.O. building trades conference in Washington.

title: A PRIMER FOR DOING BUSINESS IN CHINA
description: MANY American businessmen will have a ''China card'' to play in the d ecade of the 80's as deputy chairman Deng Xiaoping rapidly expands h is nation's trade relations with the West. Whether that card will bea n ace or a deuce depends on how each company plays the game, as w ell as the state of relations between our two countries.

title: IS GOD A FEMINIST?
description: BEHIND the public arguments and fracases over the ordination of women there has appeared, since the late 60's, a flood of feminist religious writing. The authors include men as well as women, academics as well as those animated by a sense of personal religious quest. Some have become important figures in their religions; a few have written themselves right out of their churches. Catholic feminist writers include nuns as well as lay women. The Protestants are mostly theological liberals, but evangelical feminists are also at work. Jews range from the fully Orthodox to the barely observant. Finally, there is a miscellaneous host of witchcraft practitioners, disciples of C.G. Jung and devotees of the philosophy of Alfred North Whitehead.

title: Schedule of Sessions Of Council's Panels
description: The following City Council activities scheduled for the week of April 12 are open to the public: MONDAY: Committee on Rules, Privileges and Elections, City Hall, 10 A.M. TUESDAY: Committee on Finance, City Hall, 9 A.M.; full meeting of the Council, City Hall, 11:30 A.M. FRIDAY: Committee on Public Safety, City Hall, 10 A.M. Committee on Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs, 23d floor, 250 Broadway, 11:30 A.M.

title: Thanks, but No Thanks
description: SETON HALL UNIVERSITY needed Hoddy Mahon. It was the third of November last year when the head basketball coach, Bill Raftery, unexpectedly announced that he was resigning to enter private business. Horace (Hoddy) Mahon - pronounced mah-HON - had been the assistant for the previous 10 years. He had not, as the old exhortation had it, gone west, young Mahon - that is, sought his fortune elsewhere. Being from Newark, Mahon had decided to stay in the area and had left high school coaching to work with Raftery. He had hoped that when Raftery left Seton Hall, he'd take over the head coaching job.

title: Toxicology Symposium
description: A toxicology symposium at Montclair State College next Saturday will discuss mutagenic and carcinogenic factors in the environment.

title: CHARTER IN SEARCH OF A WAY OUT
description: rise towers and glass-and-chrome banks testify to financial roots so strong that they have caused impressive edifices to sprout on otherwise barren and sandy soil. The contrasts vividly color this golden land's business history, a history of booms and busts. And they are perhaps best personified in the form of the Charter Company, a $5 billion oil conglomerate headed by a fifth-generation son of Jacksonville. The company has been both the toast and scourge of Wall Street.

title: The Region in Summary; Plan of Attack On Illiteracy
description: About 60,000 of New York's young people may not be able to read the handwriting on the wall, but it is abundantly clear to the Youth Literacy Task Force. Contending that illiteracy ''is highly correlated'' with crime, unemployment and dependence on welfare, the group last week recommended more reading programs in the city's schools and job training centers.

title: Suns 116, Sonics 99
description: PHOENIX (UPI) - Dennis Johnson's 25 points led a balanced Phoenix attack, ended a three-game losing streak and kept the Suns in the battle for the sixth and final Western Conference spot in the N.B.A. playoffs.

title: Washington; FIGHT OR NEGOTIATE?
description: The basic question in the dispute between Britain and Argentina over the Falkland-Malvinas Islands is whether it should be settled by military means. All other questions are secondary to this, and on this question, Washington is on the side of the British.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS ON THE MILITARY BALANCE IN EUROPE
description: WASHINGTON THE growth of the Soviet nuclear weapons arsenal to ''parity'' with the United States is contributing to a basic re-evaluation of NATO military strategy. Central to this strategy over the years was the presumption that the United States would be prepared to use nuclear weapons first in the event of an overwhelming Soviet conventional attack. As long as the United States was generally believed to have nuclear superiority over the Soviet Union, the threat of using nuclear weapons first was rarely challenged. But now all that is changing. Arguments that were once academic - over whether Washington would actually use these weapons and risk general nuclear war - are becoming of immediate and real importance.

title: Sound; IS COMPLEX DESIGN SWAMPING STEREO?
description: Sometimes I remember sentences out of context, particularly those written by E.B. White, that durable master of intelligent simplicity. In one of his essays, for example, Mr. White explains that things get complicated because because one thing always leads to another. I have forgotten the details of his unquestionably valid argument, but one sentence stuck in my mind: ''I predict a bright future for complexity in this country.''

title: Chess; COMBINATIONS FOR MORE THAN ONE PURPOSE
description: The typical course of a combination, according to the great French master Alexandre Louis Deschapelles, 1780-1847, was ''slam! bang! mate!''

title: 2 PREMIERES GIVEN BY LES GRANDS BALLETS CANADIENS
description: Les Grands Ballets Canadiens from Montreal made a fine comeback Friday night with its third program at the City Center - one that was more substantive than the previous one and even more concerned with novelty than at the opening.

title: Timothy Smith to Wed Kelly Costigan
description: The engagement of Kelly Ellen Costigan to Timothy E. Smith, has been announced by Sarah Anne Friend of La Jolla, Calif., mother of the future bride. Mr. Smith is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Elwin Earl Smith of Darien, Conn.

title: NEED BOREDOM BE SO BORING?
description: BASED upon 14 years of observing the changing social patterns of young people from my perspective as a sociology professor, I would have to say that the most salient characteristic symbolizing a significant contingent of today's youth is the notion of ''boredom'' and their relation to it.

title: That Search For Parking Space
description: Michael Golden (''What's Even More Important Than the Car?,'' Opinion Page, March 7) seems considerably self-absorbed.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: THEATER After nearly two years at the St. James, ''Barnum'' remains a daredevil showbiz stunt - a joyous victory of pure razzmatazz over mind and matter. Although this musical has a neglible book and virtually nothing to say about P.T. Barnum, it usually flies by on the sheer energy of Joe Layton's inventive staging and on the pulsating ragtime melodies whipped up by Cy Coleman.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: DANCE The impact of the social and political changes of the 1960's upon American society are now part of history and it is not remiss to recall that this was a decade of great artistic ferment as well. In this respect, the role played by the Judson Dance Theater in upsetting conventional notions about dance - its performance, its definitions and its creative process -was pre-eminent.

title: CHAMPAGNE & BEER
description: To the Editor:

title: TV View; VARIATIONS ON THE VARIETY SHOW THEME
description: Pity the comedy-variety show. Beginning with Milton Berle and ''Your Shows of Shows'' and ''The Ed Sullivan Show'' in the earliest days of television, it was king of the schedule, pouring forth a stream of whacky sketches and musical production numbers. At one time or another, the weekly series were headed by such superstars as Judy Garland or Frank Sinatra, and by such emerging talents as Lily Tomlin and Richard Pryor. But, perhaps because of over-saturation, the comedy-variety flow gradually became a trickle. Dean Martin and Flip Wilson were among the last entertainers to get good runs out of the format. Today the viewer is left with Barbara Mandrell and, stretching a point, ''Real People.''

title: STORIES OF CHANGE
description: TO SEE YOU AGAIN By Alice Adams. 305 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $13.50.

title: A CASE OF ARSON IS ALSO A CASE STUDY OF ANTI-AMERICANISM
description: a demand no South Korean leader or dissident spokesman has made. Government officials and United States diplomats in Seoul dismissed the Pusan incident as ''an aberration'' by a small group of extremists. But many Korean intellectuals, church leaders and other critics of President Chun Doo Hwan's two-year-old regime said the fire was a sign of growing anti-Americanism. Leaflets distributed at the National University in Seoul last fall also called for removal of the 40,000 United States troops stationed in South Korea, a perennial demand of North Korea's Communist President, Kim Il Sung.

title: IS THIS THE TIME TO BUY A CO-OP?
description: By RALPH BLUMENTHAL THE co-op apartment market of 1982 is not the co-op market of 1979. O r 1981. Or, for that matter, any previous year. Punishing interest rates and softening prices are the overriding facts of life.

title: ASSESSING REAGAN'S DOOMSDAY SCENARIO
description: Rarely, if ever, has the government of a great power proclaimed its vulnerability to devastating attack by a dangerous adversary. Common sense dictates that a moral weakness should not be advertised. Yet that is what President Reagan and his aides have done: They have stated in the starkest terms that soon we shall have no credible deterrent against a Soviet first strike!

title: STUDENT LOANS-WITH PAY-BACK INSURANCE
description: To the Editor:

title: THE EGINTON LOOK
description: All the right equipment was in place at a performance of new works by Meg Eginton on Thursday at Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater. Miss Eginton's ''Bridgedance'' had a stylish Power Boothe set and a vivid, multilayered score by Pat Irwin of the Raybeats.

title: THREAT TO FREE CHOICE
description: A FEW months ago I happened to see on television a public-interest commercial for education. Abraham Lincoln is sitting, hat in hand, in front of the desk of an employment agency counselor. The counselor, after reviewing the folder, says: ''I don't see any formal education listed here, no degree.''

title: Positive Thinking In a Traffic Jam
description: Your articles in the Connecticut Section are excellent - thoroughly enjoyable. How I identify with the umbilical cord of turnpike traffic, or, for that matter, Merritt Parkway traffic (''Morning Soliloquy of a Turnpike Driver,'' March 14).

title: Headliners Funny Money
description: The sins of the son were visited on the father in Humboldt, Iowa last week.

title: North Stars Triumph, 7 to 1
description: Dino Ciccarelli scored three goals to lead the Minnesota North Stars to a 7-1 victory tonight and cut the Black Hawks' lead in the three-of-five first-round series to 2-1.

title: Other Business; PRIVATE VAULTS BANK ON BOOM IN SAFE-DEPOSIT BOXES
description: With waiting lists for bank safe-deposit boxes as long as three to five years, a number of companies are hoping to take advantage of what they see as a potential boom industry. Offering safe-deposit boxes that are not in banks, private vault operators plan to cater to a select group of clients -mostly corporations, attorneys and collectors willing to spend five to 10 times more for boxes than they would at a typical bank.

title: LILCO SEEKS TO PHASE IN SHOREHAM COST
description: OFFICIALS of the Long Island Lighting Company say that they expect to be able to devise a plan under which Long Islanders would not have to pay any more for electricity to cover the $2.493 billion cost of the Shoreham nuclear power plant when it begins operating next year.

title: Mailbox; N.H.L. Needs New Philosophy
description: To the Sports Editor: As a hockey fan of long standing, I read Stan Fischler's article (''Thoughts on Helping N.H.L. Undo Its Siege on Itself,'' The New York Times, March 28) with great interest. Whereas the article was well conceived and quite logical, I felt that his proposals were only part of the solution to making a great game greater.

title: VARIETY OFF PROGRAMS IN WEEKS AHEAD
description: THE next two weeks are shaping up as a veritable culture explosion in Westchester, with at least five orchestral programs on the schedule, not to mention all manner of solo recitals, chamber music programs and even a Zarzuela gala.

title: The World in Summary; Egypt Takes a Step Toward The Arab Fold
description: Egypt's re-entry into other Arabs nations' good graces will likely be by inches. Last week, as the date for reclaiming the last bit of Sinai drew closer, Cairo took the biggest step so far. For the first time since 1979, a high-level Egyptian delegation was openly received in an Arab country that broke relations with Egypt over its peace treaty with Israel.

title:
NEW JERSEY GUIDE;
SHORT COURSE ON A DIG
description: Steven Nicklas, the archeologist who discovered an 18th-century ship buried beneath a Manhattan parking lot, will conduct a short course at Drew University in Madison on how he did it.

title: OFFSTAGE, DANCER SLOWS PACE
description: JERSEY CITY THOMAS EVERET and his wife, Susanna, live in a brownstone overlooking Van Vorst Park and, like their neighbors, they enjoy the 19th-century atmosphere that surrounds the park.

title: Harrington Putnam Jr., Miss McKeever to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Chauncey McKeever of San Francisco have made known the engagement of their daughter, Chauncie McKeever, to Harrington Putnam Jr., son of Mrs. Arthur Crocker of Syosset, L.I., and the late Mr. Putnam. The wedding is planned for May 26.

title: Sports People; Kuhn Tribute to Barrios
