description: ''It is tragic when someone so young and talented, and with so much to live for, loses his life,'' said Commissioner Bowie Kuhn, in comments about Francisco Barrios, who died of a heart attack Friday at age 28 at his parents' home in Hermosillo, Mexico. The righthander, who had pitched for Hermosillo of the Mexican Pacific League during the winter season, played eight seasons for the Chicago White Sox before he was dropped last year.

title: BUDGET ASSISTANCE GRANTED YONKERS
description: The Westchester County Board of Legislators today unanimously approved a $1.1 million aid package that will help the city of Yonkers close a budget gap.

title: LAURIE ANDERSON BETROTHED
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Lester M. Anderson of DeKalb, Ill., of the engagement of their daughter, Laurie Jean Anderson, to Thomas Michael Sprague, son of Mrs. Edmund K. Sprague of Rye, N.Y., and the late Mr. Sprague. Miss Anderson and her fiance are industrial engineers with the Eastman Kodak Company in Rochester.

title: SOME SCENARIOS FOR FALKLAND ISLANDS CRISIS
description: As a British fleet headed toward the Falkland Islands, diplomatic and military scenarios for resolving the crisis proliferated.

title: Arrows Beat Blast, 8-5, As Zungul Gets 4 Goals
description: Steve Zungul scored four goals to give the New York Arrows an 8-5 victory over the Baltimore Blast before a sellout crowd of 11,119 at the Civic Center Friday night.

title: Carole S. Miner Engaged To Joel Steven Schuman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Irvin V. Miner of Roslyn Heights, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carole Stacey Miner, to Joel Steven Schuman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Walter Z. Schuman of Roslyn, L.I.

title: THE LAST RIDE OF AMADO CREDIDIO
description: Two weeks ago the first fatal rider spill at a New York track in 21 years killed Amado Credidio Jr. Following is an account of that day and of how Credidio came to be a jockey on a major American racing circuit. By STEVE CADY

title: BOOK REVIEW
description: April 11, 1982 NONFICTION CHURCHILL AND DE GAULLE. By Francois Kersaudy. 8 CONTROLLING THE BOMB. By Lewis Dunn. 16 FARCE: A History From Aristophanes to Woody Allen. By Albert Bermel. 14 THE FATE OF THE EARTH. By Jonathan Schell.3 GARBAGE IN THE CITIES: Refuse, Reform and the Environment, 1880-1980. By Martin V. Melosi. 14 THE GREAT CODE: The Bible and Literature. By Northrop Frye. 10 KILLING OUR OWN: The Disaster of America's Experience With Atomic Radiation. By Harvey Wasserman and Norman Solomon. 16 KOREA: The Untold Story of the War. By Joseph C. Goulden. 8 LIFE AFTER NUCLEAR WAR: The Economic and Social Impacts of Nuclear Attacks on the United States. By Arthur M. Katz. 16 THE LIFE AND TIMES OF JOE McCARTHY. By Thomas C. Reeves. 9 NUCLEAR CULTURE: Living and Working in the World's Largest Atomic Complex. By Paul Loeb. 16 NUCLEAR WAR: What's in It for You? By Ground Zero. 16 THE ORIGINS OF THE KOREAN WAR: Liberation and the Emergence of Separate Regimes, 1945-1947. By Bruce Cumings. 8 PROTEST AND SURVIVE. Edited by E.P. Thompson and Dan Smith. 16 RADIATION AND HUMAN HEALTH. By John W. Gofman. 16 THE SACRED JOURNEY. By Frederick Buechner. 12 THREE MILE ISLAND: Thirty Minutes to Meltdown. By Daniel F. Ford. 14 FICTION AND POETRY DAMBALLAH. By John Edgar Wideman. 6 HIDING PLACE. By John Edgar Wideman. 6 THE NEW OXFORD BOOK OF CHRISTIAN VERSE. Edited by Donald Davie. 1 QUOTATIONS FROM OTHER LIVES.

title: Business Conditions; SOME STRENGTH IN PROFITS
description: Manufacturing industry earnings were better than average in 1981, despite a second recession in as many years. In its annual survey of more than 1,100 manufacturing concerns, economists at Citibank found that, excluding the oil industry, the average rate of return for manufacturing companies rose to 14 percent last year, from 13.4 percent in 1980, or slighly above the average growth of 13 percent recorded over the last 20 years.

title: HOUSE-HUNTING TIPS
description: How to buy a house will be the subject of a free seminar from 10 A.M. to 2 P.M. Saturday in the White Plains Public Library at 100 Martine Avenue.

title: Naples Gang Member Killed
description: A murder squad from one of the warring underworld gangs in Naples shot to death a rival gang member in a hospital Friday night, the police said today. Antonio Boccia, 28 years old, was riddled with shotgun pellets as he lay in Castellamare di Stabia Hospital, where he was being treated for gunshot wounds from an earlier underworld ambush.

title: Reading and Writing
description: Herbert R. Lottman's new book ''The Left Bank'' reminds us of the time when Americans were infatuated with French literature, an attachment that stretched from Stendhal, Flaubert, Baudelaire and Rimbaud through Proust, Gide, Celine and the Surrealists to Sartre, Camus and the Theater of the Absurd. Now it seems that we hardly read contemporary French poetry or fiction, that we import only a few intellectual fashions, like Roland Barthes, from Paris.

title: Cosmos Win Opener, 3-2, From Tea Men
description: The Cosmos opened their North American Soccer League season and Julio Mazzei began his second stint as the interim coach tonight with a 3-2 triumph over the Jacksonville Tea Men.

title: YANKS TRADE RON DAVIS FOR SMALLEY OF THE TWINS
description: On the eve of their thrice-postponed season opener, the Yankees made a trade yesterday that Ron Davis had expected since last October. They sent Davis, their No.2 relief pitcher, and two minor leaguers to the Minnesota Twins for Roy Smalley, the No.1 shortstop.

title: TURKISH EX-PREMIER IS ARRESTED FOR STATEMENT
description: Bulent Ecevit, a former Prime Minister and leader of the defunct Republican People's Party, was arrested today on charges of ''making false statements against the interests of Turkey.'' He faces a prison sentence of not less than five years if he is convicted.

title: Recession
description: To the Business Editor; What this nation is experiencing, so far, is not ''a plain old, relatively sharp recession,'' as Geoffrey H. Moore contends in, ''It's Just a Recession'' (March 21).

title: Business Conditions; THE TAX BURDEN EASES
description: As the April 15 deadline for filing individual income taxes nears, the beneficial effects of the Administration's tax program are beginning to emerge.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: ALPHONSE CAMERA, who used to paint wigs on President Dwight D. Eisenhower, is in the wholesale automobile business. Joel Sleed, who once told an editor in chief who had said ''I pride myself on my snap judgments'' that ''I think this time your judgment snapped,'' is the travel editor of The Star Ledger of Newark. Jacquie Villa, whose toils in the midnight sun not uncommonly included such paper nightmares by reporters as, ''He was taken a walk when he incountered the alleged prepetator,'' is an editor at a newspaper in Tucson.

title: MORE THAN HONOR AND OIL IN FALKLANDS WAR
description: To the Editor:

title: I am an adoptive mother whose life has been enriched through the experience of parenting each of our three children. It is with respect and concern that I address the feelings of the adoptive parents whose letters were published, with names withheld, on March 21. (The letters were in response to an Opinion Page article by Alison Ward that appeared on Feb. 21.)
description: I relate closely to the depth of love we share for our children, a love expressed in each of the letters. However, I would like to carry my thoughts further than those presented. A growing number of adoptive parents hold views that extend to enfolding birth-parents in our lives as a healthy, realistic approach to raising our children.

title: Janis Rothbard Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harold Rothbard of Interlaken, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Janis Ellen Rothbard, to David Chaskin, son of Mrs. Morton Salsberg of Patchogue, L.I., and the late Herbert Chaskin. A June wedding is planned. Miss Rothbard is director of nontheatrical sales with the New Line Cinema Corporation, where Mr. Chaskin is collections manager of the distribution division.

title: Paperback Talk
description: R.I.P. Ten days ago, in the Belasco Room of Sardi's Restaurant just off Times Square, some 60 persons attended a wake for Fawcett Books, dead at age 32. The sixth largest of the 13 major mass-market paperback houses had been at death's door since January, when CBS Inc., the conglomerate that had owned it for the past five years, arranged to sell its rich backlist to Ballantine Books, the eighthlargest house. Ballantine is owned by the Newhouses, the newspaper, magazine and book-publishing family whose properties include Random House, Knopf and Pantheon. In the past, Ballantine has acknowledged that its backlist is weak; the acquisition of Fawcett's titles will probably lift it to the No. 1 spot in the industry.

title: MAKING HISTORY OR JUST MAKING WAVES?
description: If blood be the price of admiralty, Lord God, we ha' paid in full.

title:
ART;
IMAGES FROM A BRITISH EXHIBITION
description: THE Yale Center for British Art is showing through May 30 ''The Great Exhibition: A Question of Taste.'' The show is devoted to the Great Exhibition of the Works of Industry of All Nations, which opened in 1851 in London's Hyde Park under the sponsorship of Prince Albert and was a notable occasion.

title: HERE COMES LOW-POWER TV
description: WASHINGTON THE Federal Communications Commission, when it approved final rules last month to initiate low-power television stations, created what many experts feel may become a gold rush. For the first time in 20 years, a significant increase in television outlets is possible.

title: MICHAEL LANFHAM PAYS ANOTHER VISIT TO ILLYRIA
description: Michael Langham, former artistic director of Canada's Stratford Festival and the Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis, began his distinguished career in his native England in 1946 with a most unusual production of Shakespeare's ''Twelfth Night.'' ''For some reason, I decided to eliminate all melancholy from the play,'' the 61-year-old director recalled the other day. ''Looking back on it now is slightly embarrassing.'' He simply cut out the offending parts, he says, a decision he can only attribute to his youth.

title: JAPANESE RESIDENTS FIND NEW YORK TO BE JARRING
description: When Joji Aonuma came from Tokyo to work in New York four and a half years ago, he changed his name to George and added a middle initial, J.

title: Around the Garden
description: This Week

title: Darcy Paige Will Be Bride Of Paul Anthony Zaferiou
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Rodney G. Paige of Mamaroneck, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Darcy Paige, to Paul Anthony Zaferiou, son of Mr. and Mrs. Socrates Zaferiou of Blauvelt, N.Y. The wedding is planned for July.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: THE Yeshiva Toras Chaim of the South Shore marked its 25th anniversary week and the third anniversary of the arrival at the yeshiva of a teacher's assistant named Mr. Shamsi. The assistant showed no emotion and made no comments about the anniversary, which is understandable because Mr. Shamsi is a robot.

title: JAMES A. RONAN
description: James A. Ronan, who was the Democratic Party chairman in Illinois from 1952 to 1973, longer than anyone else who held the post, died Friday of pneumonia at Mercy Hospital. He was 77 years old.

title: PLAYWRIGHT'S PATH TO A NEW PREMIERE
description: THOUGH she lives and writes in New York City, the story of Kathleen Betsko, and hopefully her emergence, belongs in large part to Connecticut. It was at the Eugene O'Neill Playwrights Conference in Waterford that what was to become the play ''Johnny Bull'' first began its evolution. And it is at the Yale Repertory Company in New Haven that the play can now be seen in its world premiere, through April 24.

title: BILL EVANS PRESENTS A SOLO RECITAL
description: Formerly of Salt Lake City and now of Seattle, where he directs a company, Bill Evans is an ambitious dancer and choreographer who, last week at the Theater of the Riverside Church, offered two group programs and, on Thursday night, a solo recital of works by himself and other choreographers. But here Mr. Evans's reach woefully exceeded his grasp.

title: THEODORA SKIPITARES
description: Theodora Skipitares is a miniaturist, and watching her table-top performance piece, ''Micropolis, or, Five Portraits and a Landscape,'' at the Performing Garage, we become her Gullivers. As she and two associates present cameo puppet plays on small portable stages, the effect is that of being in an intimate gallery as sculpture secretly comes to life. Sometimes the movement is as minimal as the nod of a head, and at other moments it is an orchestrated mechanization. This hermetic art demands our concentration and earns our attention.

title: The Herpes Syndrome
description: Daniel Laskin correctly focuses on emotional stress as a major precipitant of herpes recurrences, but then dismisses one of the most effective stress-reduction techniques: hypnosis (''The Herpes Syndrome,'' Feb. 21).

title: Major News in Summary; Nuclear Policy Debate Takes Another Turn
description: Proposals for a United States-Soviet nuclear weapons freeze were temporarily shelved last week as Congress departed for Easter recess. But four former senior officials launched a new round in the nuclear debate, contending that the keystone of American defense policy in Europe had become dangerously obsolete.

title:
GARDENING;
TIPS ON HIRING A LANDSCAPE GARDENER
description: MOST garden writers, including myself, take the approach that the reader will do his own lawn and garden work. That, of course, is not always true, especially in this area.

title: COLLEGE FOR THE LEARNING DISABLED
description: As a teacher of dyslexic children, I know that the majority of them can learn to read, write and spell when taught by methods suited to their learning needs. If the schools would address these needs by teaching these children with appropriate methods at the elementary level, many of their learning problems could be prevented. Avoiding academic failure in the early years could prevent many secondary emotional problems and reduce the need for extensive help in college. FLORENCE EICHLER Monsey, N.Y. ------

title: HAMDEN GIVES ITSELF A SPRING FESTIVAL
description: HAMDEN WHEN 10,000 forsythia shrubs burst into bloom here each spring, they signal a cyclical resurgence of civic pride. Keyed to the April flowering of the hardy plant that was imported from the Orient a century ago, the 12th annual Goldenbells Festival will open tomorrow, setting off a three-week celebration of music, dance, drama, art, crafts, sports, forsythia planting and special events in which thousands of residents participate with unabashed boosterism.

title: Design; LIVING IN STYLE
description: onsidering that nearly everyone seems to want a stylish home that expresses a strong personal point of view, it is astounding how few people actually succeed in achieving it. Most ''done'' interiors fall neatly into one familiar category or another - high-tech, international, English country -that are personal primarily to the individuals who first created them.

title: A HISTORY OF MONUMENTS
description: The Parthenon in Athens, the Trevi Fountain in Rome, the figures of Hans Christian Anderson in Central Park and Jacob Leisler in New Rochelle are all monuments that celebrate someone or something at a particular time in history. Claes Oldenburg's ''Giant Clothespin'' in Philadelphia, on the other hand, bespeaks a new attitude toward public sculpture. Mr. Oldenburg, and three other important figures in the art world, will talk about the meaning of monuments in a series of three lectures at the State University of New York at Purchase.

title: Edward William Denton Will Wed Gail Fleckner
description: Mr. and Mrs. William R. Fleckner of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gail Ann Fleckner, to Edward William Denton, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Ridley Denton of San Francisco.

title:
DINING OUT;
THE CUISINE OF PORTUGAL IN YONKERS
description: WELL established near the center of downtown Yonkers, Viriato is a popular neighborhood restaurant offering Portuguese cuisine, a rarity in the county. Bright red tablecloths brighten the homey, somewhat dimly lit dining room with its rustic wood-framed stucco and brick walls.

title: CULTURAL GROUPS NEED NEW IDEAS ON FUND RAISING
description: THE headlines have proclaimed the awesome task that faces virtually all nonprofit organizations today: learning to cope with the severe budget cutbacks on the Federal level. It is predicted that the corporate sector cannot even begin to make up for these dramatic reductions, proclaimed in the name of the ''New Federalism'' and that the days ahead will be dark ones for all cultural organizations, particularly the smallest, the avant-garde and those least capable of self-generated profit.

title: Columbia Oarsmen Win 3d Straight Alumni Cup
description: The Columbia varsity heavyweight crew, after losing an early lead, powered its way past Temple in the final 600 meters and defeated the Owls and Massachusetts Institute of Technology yesterday on a calm Harlem River course.

title: Around the Nation; Californians Are Warned About Flooding Dangers
description: Drenching warm rains fell on California today, causing some mudslides in the San Francisco area and prompting warnings of flooding from the melting of a heavy snowpack in the mountains.

title: MONDALE BACKS 'FIRST USE' OPTION
description: Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale, in an interview published today, endorsed the Administration's refusal to rule out the ''first use'' of nuclear weapons in case of a war in Europe.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Nice Work ... ''There is the drudgery of jobs, but there is the capacity of people to be able to transcend the job they're doing and as a result they give that job an element of craftsmanship,'' says Studs Terkel, the author and more recently, a Chicago radio-show host. One of his five books is ''Working: People Talk About What They Do All Day and How They Feel About What They Do,'' published in 1974.

title: Rally for Pinelands
description: A coalition of environmentalists will hold a rally at the State House on May 1 in an attempt to exact a commitment from Governor Kean to protect the Pine Barrens.

title: Los Angeles Paperboy Slain
description: A teen-age newspaper carrier on his first day on the job was shot and killed Thursday while riding in a delivery truck. The police said that Rodney Green, 18 years old, was in the back of the truck with another Wave Publications carrier when they were confronted by several youths on a street corner in South Los Angeles.

title: FACADE OF 1861 CITY HALL SURVIVES
description: NEW HAVEN EVER since New Haven's imposing brownstone City Hall and annex were torn down in 1976, the 92-foot-wide clock-towered facade that remains facing the green on Church Street has resembled a misplaced stage set.

title: FEWER PROFESSORS ARE GETTING TENURE
description: While Steven Stowe was working on his dissertation and teaching history to graduate students at the State University at Stony Brook in the late 1970's, he looked forward to becoming a full-time member of the faculty and achieving tenure. However, upon graduation he was told that there were no full-time teaching positions available.

title: PUGNACIOUS PARTNERS
description: The relationship between Winston Churchill and Charles de Gaulle had all the ups and downs of a stormy marriage. History was the matchmaker, prompting de Gualle's flight to London in June 1940 with nothing but the clothes on his back. Churchill set the little-known two-star general up in business, giving him the airwaves to broadcast his call to arms, funds to finance his Free French movement, and the official recognition of the British Government.

title:
Camera;
A ROUNDUP OF SUMMER WORKSHOPS
description: With the coming of spring, thoughts naturally turn to summer vacations, and for photographers a worthwhile alternative to the typical vacation could be a summer workshop.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: WHITE PLAINS Cosine, tangent, secant, sine Three point one four one five nine Theta, Delta, Epsilon, Pi We're going to beat you And not even try. THIS is a cheer whose purpose, as these things go, might be considered unusual. No battle cry to crush opponents on the goal line, or wrest from burly hands some kind of ball, this singsong is intended to rouse the powers of intellect and analysis: Admittedly chanted with tongue in cheek, it is used at competitions in mathematics.

title:
Numismatics;
THE NEW ZINC CENT HAS MADE A QUIET DEBUT
description: No news has been good news for the U.S. Bureau of the Mint, at least as far as the new zinc cent is concerned. Three months have passed since the new-style cent began turning up in circulation, and so far it has been almost totally ignored by the general public - to the great relief of the Mint, which had feared the coinage change might trigger widespread hoarding of cents.

title: Dr. John Spera to Wed Margaret S. Ahearn
description: Mrs. John F. Ahearn of Moorestown, N.J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Margaret Shields Ahearn, to Dr. John A. Spera, son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Spera of Newtown, Conn. A May 22 wedding is planned.

title: BLACK FORTUNES
description: DAMBALLAH By John Edgar Wideman 205 pp. New York: a Bard Book/Avaon. $2.95 HIDING PLACE By John Edgar Wideman 158pp. New York: A Bard Book/Avon. $2.95 By Mel Watkins John Edgar Wideman's three previous novels, all set on the lives of c haracters struggling to gain access to America's mainstream or s earching for dignified accommodation to their plight. The first and m ost highly praised book, "A Glance Away" (1967), described a single d ay in the life of a drug addict. "Hurry Home: (1970) was about the a nguish of a black lawyer unable to reconcile his professional p osition with his mixed ancestry and ghetto background. "The L ynchers" (1973) dramatized the frustration and anger of four P hiladelphia blacks who plot to lynch a white policeman in r etaliation for past injustices.

title: Dr. John J. McGowan Is Dead; Teacher of Economics at Yale
description: Dr. John J. McGowan, an associate professor of economics at Yale University from 1965 to 1972, died Wednesday at Emerson Hospital in Concord, Mass., after a long illness. He was 46 years old and lived in Wayland, Mass.

title: Index; International
description: Seoul aides say North Korea holds 105,000 as dissidents 3 Soviet aide comments cautiously on Reagan-Brezhnev meeting 3 Turkish ex-Premier arrested for criticizing military regime 4 Greek Government moving to separate church and state 8 Canada to allow U.S. cruise missile tests over its territory 10 France tries to change its national television system 11 Veil of secrecy is being drawn around British naval task force 12 Salvadoran resentment of foreign reporters is rising 13 Bangladesh leader voices concern over Soviet Union 14 Government/Politics Eleven candidates vie for mayor in District of Columbia 27 Westchester Board of Legislators gives $1.1 million to Yonkers 30 M.T.A.-Japan deal on subway cars is heading to court 31 A look at a proposal's progress in Albany 32 City Hall Notes: Bellamy now treated as heir 33 General Virginia declares moratorium on uranium mining permits 19 Around the Nation 22 An appraisal of downtown Los Angeles's architecture 22 Report says mechanical failure led to Air Force team crash 23 Marine support crews tested in Gallant Eagle exercises 26 Grant information center sees rise in people seeking financing 28 Japanese residents find New York to be jarring 38 277 recieve fellowships from Guggenheim Fund 40 Industry/Labor Apartment workers seek substantial pay increases 30 Education/Welfare ''College bonds'' may provide for loans students 21 Arts/Entertainment Les Grands Ballets Canadiens gives two premieres 46 Chamber Music Society plays three novelties 46 Bill Evans offers programs of solo dances 46 Australian film ''Grendel Gren- del Grendel'' opens 46 Meg Eginton looks back at childhood in dance recital 46 Offers of help pouring in to Wolf Trap 46 ''Chaneysville Incident'' wins PEN/Faulkner award 46 The debuts of young musicians are reviewed 46 Pennsylvania Ballet performs Balanchine's ''Square Dance'' 47 Theodora Skipitares presents evening of miniaturist theater 47 Style Astor castle, steeped in British history 48 Obituaries Horace Seely-Brown Jr., former United States Representative 34 Susan Alamo, founder of Christian foundation in Arkansas 34

title: NEW FILM TALENT ON VIEW
description: A film by a graduate of the state university at Purchase that deals with mother-daughter conflicts, separation and changing family values will be shown at 8:30 P.M. Tuesday as part of the Film Video Workshop's continuing series of screenings showcasing new film-making talent.

title: Apartment Workers Seeking $85 a Week Increase in Pay
description: Employees in rental and cooperative apartment houses in New York City are seeking a pay increase of $85 a week and improved benefits in negotiations for a new contract with the Realty Advisory Board.

title: Foreign Affairs; HUMPTY DUMPTY AGAIN
description: Tremendous tension has built up in Lebanon. A heavy Israeli strike and perhaps a massive invasion is expected any day.

title: Jutland
description: To the Editor:
NIGHT poetry and prose readings in a bookstore on upper Main Street in this historic whaling village have brought the proprietor, Canio Pavone, into conflict with village law.

title: MERGERS ARE THE BETTER CURE FOR AILING THRIFT INSTITUTIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: EXPERTS ASSESS GYPSY MOTH THREAT
description: RESIDENTS in northern parts of the county may get through this spring with a light infestation of gypsy moths. But those who live in the southern areas around White Plains, Scarsdale and Harrison will see their trees defoliated as seriously as last year. Egg-mass counts in these areas are as high 200 or more an acre.

title: THEATER EXPLORES A 'NEED' FOR HEROS
description: PETER JOSYPH is an earnest young writer-actor who takes his art very seriously. Convinced that contemporary drama doesn't celebrate ''what man can be or should be,'' he and four other Long Islanders who feel the same way are determined to break the mold. They have established a new theater company, the Victory Theater, which through original works will attempt to reflect the ''kind of society we live in and offer audiences someone to believe in and look up to.''

title: THEY COMB NEW YORK TO GIVE ITS MOVIES A SPECIAL LOOK
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Don Shewey is a freelance writer with a special interest in the performing arts. By DON SHEWEY

title: SACRED AND SECULAR LOVE
description: THY BROTHER'S WIFE By Andrew M. Greeley. 351 pp. New York: Geis/Warner Books. $14.95. By WEBSTER SCHOTT

title: Zemlinsky Opera Due
description: The Manhattan School of Music will present the American premiere of Alexander Zemlinsky's one-act opera ''Eine Florentinische Tragodie.''

title: ROOKIE OFFICER SHOT IN LEG DURING CHASE OF 2 MEN IN HOLDUP
description: A rookie police officer was shot in the leg last night while chasing two holdup men in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Four Firemen File Suit, Citing Injuries at Blaze
description: Four Newburgh firemen have filed a $6.4 million lawsuit against the owner of a recycling center that, they contend, became a trap when fire broke out there Nov. 1.

title: THE ROAD TO DEVOTION
description: THE SACRED JOURNEY By Frederick Buechner. 112 pp. San Francisco: Harper & Row. $9.95.

title: Bridge; DIAGNOSTIC WIZARDRY
description: Most of us, at one time or another, have heard an acquaintance of limited ability sing the praises of some alleged expert we have never heard of: ''He is a marvelous player. At the first trick he knows every card you have in your hand.''

title: Winifred C. Gass Engaged To Cadet James P. Hogle
description: Mr. and Mrs. Manus M. Gass of River Edge, N.J., and Southampton, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Winifred Caitlyn Gass, to Cadet James Phillip Hogle of West Point, N.Y., son of Dr. and Mrs. Walter R. Hogle of San Diego and Montebello, Calif. The wedding is planned for May 30 in Southampton.

title: Postings; FROM CABINS TO DOMES
description: Prospective buyers of homes in New Jersey who would rather not range all over the state looking for the ideal dwelling have a convenient alternative in the New Jersey Housing Show that opens on Friday. The three-day show will collect under one roof - Asbury Park's Convention Hall - everyone the would-be home buyer might want to consult, from real estate agent to banker to lawyer to insulation supplier to interior decorator.

title: FAITH IN TRADE HOUSES
description: ONLY about 20 percent of the 2,000 to 3,000 religious titles appearing every year are published by general trade houses or university presses. Most religious books are brought out by the publishing arms of churches or independent houses espousing specific religious viewpoints, which together reap the lion's share of the approximately $800,000,000 annual profits. The Southern Baptist Convention (with its Broadman Press) and the United Methodist Church (with Abingdon Press and the Cokesbury retail chain) are the two largest denominational publishers; successful nondenominational houses publishing only religious titles include the evangelical Word Books, Billy Graham's current publisher.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: CONTEMPORARY MUSIC

title: MARINES SHOW THEIR STRENGTH IN TEST OF RAPID DEPLOYMENT
description: When members of the Marine Corps Air Group 70 recently began loading a partly disassembled cargo helicopter onto a huge Air Force transport plane, they reported to their commander, Col. Donald J. McCarthy, that the 17-foot-high helicopter would not quite fit.

title: THE LETTER-GRADE CONTROVERSY
description: year faculty member in the urban affairs department of the State University of New York College at Purchase, recently awarded his first A. That was not because Mr. Robertson is an especially tough marker, but because the college has not given letter grades until this school year.

title: POLE SAYS U.S. FISHING CURBS HURT ECONOMY
description: The suspension of Polish fishing rights in United States waters is expected to reduce Poland's world catch by 25 percent and to cost its struggling economy $60 million to $80 million this year, according to the Polish commercial counselor's office in New York.

title: Best Sellers; FICTION
description: 1 1 4 THE PARSIFAL MOSAIC, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $15.95.) Through many exploits and hairbreadth escapes, Michael Havelock saves the world from nuclear extinction. 2 2 10 NORTH AND SOUTH, by John Jakes. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $14.95.) The friendship of two wealthy families - one in Pennsylvania, the other in Carolina - is strained by the Civil War. 3 7 10 A GREEN DESIRE, by Anton Myrer. (Putnam's, $14.95.) A woman caught between the clashing ambitions of two brothers during the springtime of this century. 4 4 25 AN INDECENT OBSESSION, by Colleen McCullough. (Harper & Row, $13.50.) A nurse and her charges in a special-care ward of a World War II hospital. 5 5 10 THE DEAN'S DECEMBER, by Saul Bellow. (Harper & Row, $13.95.) During a deathbed vigil in Rumania, a college dean from Chicago realizes some truths about his own land. 6 6 21 SPRING MOON, by Bette Bao Lord. (Harper & Row, $14.95.) Tradition and revolution in modern China seen through the life of an upper-class family. 7 9 7 FEVER, by Robin Cook. (Putnam's, $13.95.) Obsessions, personal and professional, possess a cancer researcher.

title: Amy Middendorf Wed to Donald Newton Givler Jr.
description: Amy Middendorf, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. William Middendorf 2d of McLean, Va., was married yesterday to Donald Newton Givler Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Givler of West Chester, Pa. The Rev. Renny Scott performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Apostles in Fairfax, Va.

title: Fashion; WOMEN OF FASHION
description: Personal style is as difficult to stereotype as the women who have it. Not that the ''it'' isn't instantly recognizable. But the ''it'' that elevates one woman above the ordinary may do absolutely nothing for another.

title: AIN THIS DRAMA THE ADVERSARIES ARE DRUGS AND THE NEWBORN
description: Six years ago, Louisa Burns-Bisogno, an Irish-Catholic mother of five, a grandmother of three and blissfully married to a man she unblinkingly calls ''a saint,'' was a high-school teacher in Brewster, N.Y. Then, she says, a strange thing happened. She wrote, produced and directed a 96-character play for her high school's Bicentennial celebration, and decided, almost in an instant, to become a writer. Tomorrow night, the first offspring of that decision, a new television drama starring Vanessa Redgrave and titled ''My Body, My Child,'' will be telecast at 9 on ABC, which, by any reckoning, is hardly a bad start for a 45-year-old beginner.

title: Topics; OIL, ICE AND HOT AIR; Promising Politicians
description: Until the Supreme Court ruled otherwise last week, a candidate for local office in Kentucky could deliver but couldn't promise. The state's corrupt practices act said that candidates may not promise anything of value ''to any person in consideration of the vote or financial or moral support of that person.''

title: MORE THAN HONOR AND OIL IN FALKLANDS WAR
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Slow' Computer
description: There were smiles in many an office when the California Teacher Preparation and Licensing Commission got rid of its $1.5 million computer system 10 years ago. ''It was easier to do it by hand,'' the commission's executive secretary said in January 1972.

title: An Appraisal
description: For a long time the idea of a downtown in Los Angeles was only a bit more plausible than a beach in Omaha or a ski slope in Miami. It existed, mainly in the form of a few bank buildings huddled together at a freeway intersection, but it never seemed to belong to the rest of the city.

title: Lawyer Offers Free Services
description: I have today notified Justice Gagliardi that I am willing to accept assignment of indigent divorce cases and I hope some of my brothers and sisters at the bar will be doing likewise.

title: STEPHEN HOPKINS TO MARRY CYNTHIA J. HEYE ON MAY 22
description: Mrs. Carl W. Heye of Old Lyme, Conn., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Cynthia Johanne Heye, to Stephen Lewis Hopkins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin C. Hopkins of Boonton, N.J.

title: CHOICE FILMS ON TV
description: 'Hound of the Baskervilles'

title: FOREIGN PRESS UNDER ATTACK IN EL SALVADOR
description: Stretched across streets and plastered on cars, banners and stickers admonish reporters: ''Tell the truth. Betray your country, not ours.''

title: A HOW TO FOR GARAGE SALES
description: SEVEN years ago when Sylvia Simmons decided to consolidate three residences (a house on Long Island, a weekend place in Connecticut and an apartment in New York), she moved everything into a home in Wilton and proceeded to hold her first tag sale.

title: EUROPEANS ENDING ARGENTINE IMPORTS IN FALKLAND CRISIS
description: The European Common Market approved a total ban on imports from Argentina today as the hour approached for the imposition of Britain's naval blockade on Argentine shipping off the Falkland Islands.

title: THE TAX MAN HUMAN?  YES, HE CLAIMS
description: DENIS CAHILL loves his wife and three young children. He takes out the garbage, mows the lawn, does odd jobs around the house and coaches youth soccer. He is friendly with his Rockland County neighbors and enjoys watching sports on a Sunday afternoon. Normally, Mr. Cahill doesn't go to great lengths to point these things out. But once a year, especially at this time of year, he likes to mention them and subtly demonstrate that he is an ordinary citizen for whatever good it might do.

title: Phyllis Alpert Lehrer, Old and New on Piano
description: Phyllis Alpert Lehrer's evening of piano music at the Abraham Goodman House last Sunday nicely mixed the old and the new and then offered a few personal touches of its own. Miss Lehrer, who heads the piano department at Westminster Choir College in Princeton, played Bach, Chopin and Schumann but added a brief Toccata by Peter Mennin and then two pieces written expressly for her.

title: PAUL TAYLOR-LOOKING BACK AND AHEAD
description: It was 25 years ago that a young upstart named Paul Taylor stood still and had his company walk through seven dances at the 92d Street YM-YWHA. They performed before a rapidly diminishing audience that later found affirmation of its judgment in a blank review that has become famous in dance history. Today, Mr. Taylor enjoys an international reputation as a master choreographer whose audiences laugh, blanch or grow wide-eyed, at his will, glued to their seats until the curtains fall.

title: DOLE CHALLENGED ON M.T.A. BY GREEN
description: Representative Bill Green has sent a harsh letter to Senator Bob Dole, the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, challenging Mr. Dole's contention that leasing arrangements used by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority were a ''grossly inefficient'' form of Federal subsidy.

title: Richard W. O'Neill, 84, Dies; A Winner of Medal of Honor
description: Richard W. O'Neill, who won the Medal of Honor for bravery as a sergeant in World War I with the 165th Infantry, 42d Rainbow Division, died Friday at Rosary Hill Home in Hawthorne, N.Y. Mr. O'Neill, a longtime resident of Bronxville, N.Y., was 84 years old.

title: 15 Food Places Listed For Health Violations
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 15 food establishments last week for violations of the Health Code. It also named five others that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations and two that were closed for failure to do so.

title: TO BUY FUEL NOW, OR WAIT?
description: EVERY year, as the heating season ends, householders and operators o f residential properties wonder whether they should fill up their f uel tanks at seasonally lower prices or wait until the fall.

title: Around the World; Uganda Is Said to Seize Thousands of Civilians
description: Ugandan security forces arrested about 1,000 civilians in Kampala today, wounding some of them, witnesses in the Ugandan capital said. It was the third mass detention in a month in what the authorities called a drive against anti-Government guerrillas.

title: ZACHRY'S NO-HIT BID IS SPOILED IN 8TH AS METS DOWN CUBS, 9-5
description: In a 1982 debut delayed five days by snow and cold, Pat Zachry came within four outs today of pitching the first no-hit game for the New York Mets in the 20-year history of the club.

title: EX-WAITER CONVICTED OF MURDERING 26 EXECUTIVES IN FIRE AT STOUFFER'S
description: A Westchester County jury found Luis Marin guilty tonight of arson and 26 counts of murder in the fatal blaze at the conference center of Stouffer's Inn on Dec. 4, 1980.

title: A.N. Feick Fiance Of Maile E. King
description: Mr. and Mrs. Philip Lloyd King of Kailua, Hawaii, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Maile Elizabeth King, to Alexander Nichols Feick, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Feick Jr. of New Canaan, Conn. and Stratton, Vt.

title: Mary Hiniker Oestereicher Wed to Oliver LaF. Hamill
description: The marriage of Mary Hiniker Oestereicher, an assistant professor of reading at Brooklyn College, to Oliver LaFarge Hamill, a landscape architect, took place yesterday in St. Paul's Chapel of Columbia University.

title: The Nation in Summary; FAirness Rule Takes Its Lumps
description: From the start, many broadcasters regarded the ''fairness doctrine,'' passed by Congress more than 30 years ago, as manifestly unfair. Now the industry has friends in high places, starting with the Great Communicator himself.

title: FELT CAN BECOME WEARABLE ART
description: LITCHFIELD SOME say Noah invented felt. To insure a comfortable voyage for his four-footed passengers, he covered the ark floor with sheep's wool. The animals, according to legend, trampled the wool, moistened and warmed it, and left behind, when they disembarked, the first felt rug.

title: DEMOCRATS ZERO IN ON TAXES IN KEAN BUDGET
description: TRENTON THE battle of the budget began in earnest last week, as the Democratic leadership of the Joint Legislative Appropriations Committee said it had found ''disturbing inequities'' in Governor Kean's plan to cut business taxes.

title: The Region in Summary; Kheel Makes a Big Give-Back
description: Theodore W. Kheel has settled a lot of disputes in 33 years of arbitrating Transit Authority labor relations, but his own differences with Mayor Koch apparently were non-negotiable. Last week, after the Mayor recommended his removal as transit arbitrator, Mr. Kheel resigned.

title: Caterpillar May Have Caused Rash in 200 School Children
description: The gypsy moth caterpillar, best known for destroying trees, has been tentatively identified as the cause of a rash in more than 200 Pennsylvania children last spring, health officials say.

title: Around the World; Sikh Separatist Is Barred From Visiting India
description: Indian immigration officials refused today to let G.S. Dhillon, a Sikh separatist leader and United States citizen, enter the country. Mr. Dhillon, who had been traveling to a world Sikh conference in the northern state of Punjab, was put on a flight to Hong Kong.

title: A GUIDE TO JERUSALEM'S CHURCHES
description: NITZA ROSOVSKY is on the staff of the Semitic Museum at Harvard and is the author of ''Jerusalemwalks,'' published by Holt, Rinehart and Winston. By NITZA ROSOVSKY

title:
ART;
AMBITIOUS SHOW IN TRENTON
description: TRENTON ALIVELY and interesting exhibition of works by contemporary artists is on view at the Trenton City Museum. The show, which will continue through April 25, is entitled the ''Ellarslie Open'' (for the mansion in Cadwalader Park that houses the museum).

title: Mailbox; Golf Courses Doing Their Best
description: To the Sports Editor: I was very distressed by the recent article on New York City golf courses written by Ralph Monti (''The Special Hazards of New York's Golf Courses,'' The New York Times, March 28). His description of the fifth hole at Douglaston, Queens, is a clear case of inaccurate, misleading and greatly exaggerated reporting, cloaked in humor.

title: Law Student, Miss Gwynne Plan Nuptials
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Samuel C. Gwynne Jr. of Cleveland, formerly of New Canaan, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Grace Gwynne, to Charles D. Cramton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger C. Cramton of Ithaca, N.Y.

title:
MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW;
Marisa Robles, Harpist, With Commentary
description: The noted Spanish-born harpist Marisa Robles made her New York recital debut Thursday evening in Alice Tully Hall, stealing a page out of James Galway's book with her spontaneous asides to the audience and running commentary on the evening's program. As Miss Robles pointed out, the repertory she brought was unusual; some of it was also quite attractive and attractively played.

title: VALENZUELA WORKS 6 AS DODGERS DEFEAT PADRES, 6-0
description: Fernando Valenzuela, showing no ill effects from a 22-day spring holdout, made his season debut today by limiting San Diego to five hits over six innings as the Los Angeles Dodgers defeated the Padres, 6-0.

title: Globe, $7.60, Takes Excelsior
description: Victor (Lefty) Nickerson, the trainer who has been maintaining that Globe can only do his best when raced infrequently, had that belief reinforced at Aqueduct yesterday.

title: VIRGINIA DELAYS PERMITS FOR URANIUM MINING
description: Gov. Charles S. Robb has signed legislation declaring a moratorium until July 1, 1983, on the issuing of uranium mining permits in Virginia.

title: Mid-Manhattan Library Gets Picture Collection
description: The 67-year-old, 2.5 million-item Picture Collection of the New York Public Library has been reopened in new quarters in the Mid-Manhattan Library, at 455 Fifth Avenue, at 40th Street.

title: CONSPIRACY CHARGED
description: Iran confirmed today that former Foreign Minister Sadegh Ghotbzadeh had been arrested. The Teheran radio said that he was accused of plotting to assassinate Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini and the members of Iran's Supreme Defense Council.

title: SO CLOSE, BUT A WORLD APART
description: I STARTED working in Greenwich Village at a time of year when browsing in shops was a pleasure, and I quickly found that doing errands in the city during the week left me extra time over the weekend to relax with my family.

title: Gypsy Moth Spraying Misuse of Public Funds
description: Our congratulations to Joan Lee Faust for a level-headed discussion of the gypsy moth problem in Connecticut this spring (''Gypsy Moths Head East,'' March 28). One hopes this fine account will be read and pondered by our legislators in Hartford who are currently under great pressure to vote $150,000 to assist the towns in spraying chemicals.

title: College for the Learning Disabled
description: Ron Winslow's article ''College for the Learning Disabled'' (Feb. 21) should contribute significantly to the efforts being made to combat the prejudice and discrimination faced by this group.

title: DAMERON RECALLED
description: Tadd Dameron, a jazz pianist who was a pioneering composer in the be-bop era in the late 1940's, died in 1965 leaving a body of work that includes many pieces that have become jazz standards. To celebrate and commemorate Mr. Dameron, the drummer Philly Joe Jones has organized a nine-piece group, Dameronia, devoted to playing Mr. Dameron's repertory.

title: DISNEY'S SPELL WORKS ON GROWN-UPS, TOO
description: MARYLIN BENDER is the author, with Selig Altschul, of ''The Chosen Instrument: Juan Trippe and Pan Am, the Rise and Fall of an American Entrepreneur'' to be published this summer by Simon & Schuster. By MARYLIN BENDER

title: RANGERS WIN; RALLY FROM 3-0 DEFICIT BEATS FLYERS, 4-3
description: An unusual and unlikely hockey justice, or injustice, seemed to prevail at the Spectrum this afternoon, as Cam Connor, a journeyman forward, scored the winning goal for the Rangers against the Philadelphia Flyers with 1 minute 9 seconds to play.

title: TRUCK IS FOUND IN A LOT WITH STOLEN ART ABOARD
description: New York City detectives yesterday recovered a truck filled with more than $1 million in paintings and sculptures that had been reported stolen Friday from a parking space a few blocks away in SoHo.

title: An Open Letter To Governor Kean
description: DEAR TOM:

title: LIVE ABOARD THE INVINCIBLE: PREPARING FOR THE WORST
description: A veil of secrecy is being drawn around the British naval task force as it heads for the South Atlantic and a possible military confrontation with Argentina over the Falkland Islands.

title: SELLER FINANCING: AN ANSWER TO HIGH INTEREST RATES
description: PROBLEM: You put your house up for sale, but everyone who wants to b uy it balks at paying the high interest rates lenders demand on m ortgages these days.

title: Canucks Win, 3-1; Flames Eliminated
description: Dave Williams fired a tiebreaking wrist shot through the legs of the goaltender Pat Riggin at 8 minutes 17 seconds of the final period, helping the Vancouver Canucks to a 3-1 victory and eliminating the Flames from the playoffs.

title: 11 VIE FOR MAYOR IN CAPITAL CONTEST
description: The District of Columbia, once disenfranchised for a century, has fielded no less than 11 mayoral candidates this year, and more may be coming before the filing deadline in July.

title: DOBBS FERRY
description: ON sunny Saturdays in Dobbs Ferry, girls from The Masters School, d ressed by Bean and shod by Bass, stroll down the hill to the Grand U nion and shop for snacks alongside matrons in designer jeans and h igh heels who assess the eggplant with practiced fingers.

title: CONDOMINIUMS CONSIDERED FOR THE SOUND
description: NEW ROCHELLE INSTEAD of children's shovels in the sand around the Beach and Tennis Club on Davenport Neck this summer, there may be builders' shovels. This city is considering a plan for two 15-story condominium buildings, whose 224 apartments would sell for an average of $350,000. Instead of a beach there would be a marina for 48 boats.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: UNTIL recently, the widespread problem with defective and malfunctioning septic systems in the state was called ''New Jersey's dirty little secret'' by the Division of Water Resources of the Department of Environmental Protection.

title: SAMARIANS CELEBRATE SURVIVAL
description: Nablus, Israeli-Occupied West Bank - With the start of Passover last week, a small biblical sect, the Samaritans, performed a rite long abandoned in Judaism: the sacrificial slaughter of lambs.

title:
In New Jersey;
CONVERTING ONE HOME INTO TWO
description: REFASHIONING single-family houses to include separate quarters for g rown children, aging parents or a renter is an increasingly popular s olution to the economic squeeze being felt by many homeowners, many o f whom are locked into their houses because they cannot sell a dvantageously in today's market.

title: CANADA TO ALLOW U.S. TO TEST CRUISE MISSILES
description: Despite strained relations with the United States, Canada has agreed in principle to allow the American cruise missile and other weapons to be tested over its territory.

title: Miss Thompson Will Be Married
description: Mrs. Ronald B. Durning of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Maurice G. Thompson Jr. of Westport, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Louise Thompson, to Christopher Abbott Pope, son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Pope Jr. of New York.

title: Corey Whitman to Wed Hsueh-wei Wang in June
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Cheng-hua Wang of Newton, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter, Hsueh-wei Wang, to Corey S. Whitman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles I. Whitman of Bay Village, Ohio. A June wedding is planned.

title: The Nation in Summary; FEderalism's Biggest Swap Falls Through
description: After President Reagan's ''new federalism'' was greeted with more suspicion than applause, deputy press secretary Larry Speakes redefined it. Mr. Reagan's ''bold new stroke'' became ''a two-way street'' of consultations with the nation's governors. Last week, it was clear that traffic was stuck.

title: ELECTRONIC SOUNDS AT HUDSON MUSEUM
description: YONKERS IN the last decade or so, electronic music has evolved from an expensive, bulky and esoteric study of sonic gadgetry to an accepted, familiar component of much popular music. Only very recently, however, has its technology and marketing advanced to the point where electronic music is beginning to become widely accessible and affordable to the consumer.

title: Sports People; Lakers Seek Sampson
description: Jerry Buss, the owner of the Los Angeles Lakers, says he has made a firm offer involving draft choices to the San Diego Clippers in an attempt to assure the Lakers the draft rights to Virginia's 7-foot-4-inch junior center, Ralph Sampson. The Lakers have the first-round draft choice of the Cleveland Cavaliers, the team with the worst record in the National Basketball Association's Eastern Conference.

title: Photography View; A RENEWED VITALITY IN THE FACE OF ECONOMIC HARD TIMES
description: It is time to declare the photography ''boom'' officially over. The economic hard times that have fallen elsewhere have fallen on photography, too. The watchword for the 80's is retrenchment, and its signs are manifest. The medium's halcyon days in the late 70's were fed essentially by a hothouse investment climate, but today the bloom is off the collecting market place. Auction prices for photographs can charitably be said to have stabilized (or, less charitably, stagnated); Ansel Adams's benchmark ''Moonrise, Hernandez'' has even taken a plunge. A print sales supermarket sponsored by the photography dealers' association last fall in New York failed to meet the expectations of many and barely netted some West Coast entrepreneurs their plane fare home. Corporations, museums and large collectors are still acquiring work, it is true, but the ''little guy'' collector is on vacation.

title:
GARDENING;
TIPS ON HIRING A LANDSCAPE GARDENER
description: MOST garden writers, including myself, take the approach that the reader will do his own lawn and garden work. That, of course, is not always true, especially in this area.

title: Film View; A FEAST OF INTERESTING, ORIGINAL NEW WORK
description: This year - just possibly -may turn out to be one of the best in a very long time in terms of film quality. These are dangerous words to write at any time, especially in April with eight months to go, but there seems to be, at this writing, more interesting, original new work in first-run theaters than at any time in recent memory.

title: POLICE RAID LEADS TO DIPLOMATIC STIR
description: What began in February as a routine police investigation involving a Saudi Prince living here has evolved into a diplomatic stir in which the Prince has been granted immunity from prosecution and is suing the local authorities.

title:
ART;
WHAT THE W.P.A. HELPED NUTURE
description: EAST HAMPTON IN 1936, on the occasion of the first national survey of the accomplishments of the W.P.A. Federal Art Project, the program's national director, Holger Cahill, expressed his pride that ''under government auspices, an opportunity for the development of significant new tendencies has been provided during these crucial times. The outcome is full of promise for the future.'' That his confidence was justified is shown in the exhibition of recent work by distinguished W.P.A. alumni on view through next Sunday at Guild Hall.

title: YOUTH HOMES FEAR AID CUTS
description: WADING RIVER RESIDENTIAL homes that provide remedial services for troubled youths on the Island have been increasing their fund-raising efforts because inflation and cuts in social-services aid have made it more difficult for them to stay financially solvent. Some administrators of these nonprofit residential facilities fear that further budget cuts proposed by President Reagan would force their institutions to close.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Fabienne Serrat, a 25-year-old French ski racer, said in Valberg that she would retire after the slalom compeition there today. In 1974 she was the combined slalom world champion. ... A 52-year-old former nun, Stella Taylor, set an unofficial endurance record by completing a 65-hour swim in a fresh-water pool Friday.

title: The World in Summary; Career Ending or Purge Beginning?
description: The other shoe dropped last week for Henryk Samsonowicz, longtime member of the Polish Communist Party and a prominent liberal. He was expelled from the party two months ago.

title: The Nation in Summary; HInckley Trial Set This Month
description: After months of maneuvering over evidence, April 27 was set as the trial date for John W. Hinckley Jr., charged with shooting President Reagan, White House press secretary James S. Brady and two security men last year.

title: I was sorry, but not surprised, to see the many negative responses by adoptive parents to Alison Ward's article. From the tone of these letters, I have come to the conclusion that no one believes more strongly than adoptive parents that ''blood is thicker than water'' and that the bond between adoptive parents and their children is a weak and fragile thing, easily shattered.
description: Why else would they be so afraid of their children having any contact with blood relatives? Why else would they be so filled with hate, resentment and fear of the original mothers of the children they profess to love?

title: Judith Markowitz Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Morton Cooper of South Orange, N.J., have announced the engagement of her daughter, Judith Ellen Markowitz, to Brian Bedol, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marshall T. Bedol of Shaker Heights, Ohio.

title:
ANTIQUES;
ALL ROADS LEAD TO MORRISTOWN
description: MORRISTOWN ANUMBER of antiques dealers who will be exhibiting at the four-day show that opens Thursday at the National Guard Armory on Western Avenue report that business and prices, despite the recession, are steady and, in many areas, still improving.

title: HOW BIC LOST THE EDGE TO GILLETTE
description: BIC AND GILLETTE are at it again. Like two alley cats, the companiesw on't stop, having battled steadily for six years over the market fort hrow-away pens and shavers. But the heat of the conflict has been r ising of late.

title: Business Conditions; OIL INVENTORY SELL-OFF
description: High interest rates and weak demand forced major oil companies to liquidate inventories at a very rapid rate in the first quarter. Domestic oil companies used up inventories of crude oil and products (excluding the Strategic Petroleum Reserve) at a rate of 785,000 barrels a day, according to statistics from Townsend-Greenspan & Company, the economic consulting firm.

title: Patricia Hoerth Plans June Bridal
description: The engagement of Patricia Anne Hoerth to Edgar George Adams Jr., son of the Rev. and Mrs. Adams of Bala Cynwyd, Pa., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph G. Hoerth of Easton, Conn., parents of the future bride.

title: REBUILDING BEACHES STARVED FOR SAND
description: EATONS NECK FOR decades, the western coastline here has been ravaged by sand erosion, the result of unrelenting storms, overzealous sand mining and some careless technology. Millions of yards of sand have been lost, having left behind shortened beaches that disappear at high tide and battered bluffs that perpetually lose sand and clay to winds and tides.

title: ROBIN SANSON ENGAGED TO HOWARD SHERMAN
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Sanson of Princeton, N.J., and Edgartown, Mass., have announced the engagement of his daughter, Robin Patrice Sanson, to Howard Slan Sherman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard W. Sherman of Cranston, R.I.

title: Poet in Exile
description: After living peacefully in exile in this country for 10 years, Dennis Brutus, the South African poet and scholar, faced deportation last January because of questions about the legality of his visa. A Federal judge in Chicago, after hearing that Mr. Brutus might be a target of assassination in his country because of long opposition to apartheid, gave the poet 20 days to apply for political asylum.

title: George Freeman to Marry Anne Griffith
description: Mrs. Everett C. Furman of Delray Beach, Fla., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Anne Griffith, to George Freeman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Freeman of New York.

title: OIL PRICE DIP SAVED ELECTRIC CUSTOMERS MILLIONS, STATE SAYS
description: Customers of the four major New York State utilities in the metropolitan area were spared $449 million in electricity rate increases last year because of declining oil prices, according to a report issued today by the state's Public Service Commission.

title: ARGENTINE PLEDGES FIGHT IF PROVOKED
description: President Leopoldo Galtieri met with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. for more than two hours today, then told a cheering crowd in front of the presidential palace that Argentina would fight if provoked by Britain.

title: How Much Is Enough?
description: What now passes for a ''debate'' of nuclear strategies is understandably passionate, but it is becoming romantic, confused, even irrelevant.

title: STATE'S GUN LAW: IMPACT AND INTENT UNCERTAIN
description: It was a vivid television commercial -Mayor Koch, walking along a row of empty jail cells and sternly warning: ''If you get caught carrying an illegal handgun, you'll go to jail for one year. No plea bargaining. No judges feeling sorry for you. Just one year in jail.''

title: GREENLAND: NEW FRONTIER FOR TRAVELERS
description: WILLIAM BORDERS is a correspondent in the London bureau of The Times. BY WILLIAM BORDERS

title: Mailbag; ABOUT 'DREAMGIRLS'
description: To the Editor:$

title: PART OF CARGO FOR LIBYA SEIZED IN BROOKLYN IS FREED
description: Part of the $960,000 cargo of water-purification equipment destined for Libya that was seized on the Brooklyn waterfront 16 days ago has been cleared for export by a ruling from the Commerce Department.

title: LONG NIGHTS AND BILL LOGJAM FACE ASSEMBLY
description: WITH the Connecticut General Assembly in its final month of meetings, state lawmakers again are getting ready for the 12-hour days, marathon debates and submarine sandwiches that have become an April rite as common as spring housecleaning. The current legislative session ends May 5.

title: SUN OR SNOW, HARDWOOD CUTTING GROWS
description: WOODBURY DESPITE the blizzard last week that temporarily canceled spring here in the northwest corner of the state, the contrast of the white snow and gray of the barren trees is giving way to muted brown. Soon, all will be green.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Music View; THE CONFLICT FO GOOD AND EVIL IN BOITO'S OPERAS
description: Grand opera is possibly the last artistic arena in which Good routinely triumphs over Evil. Even Hollywood, which used to have self-imposed codes to insure that no picture could end without some assurance that the bad guys would be punished, long ago abandoned any such moralistic stance. Nowadays, the cowboy in the white hat who rides into town on a white horse is as likely to have bank robbery or rape in mind as any nobler aim. And he likely will get away with it, often in lovely color and excruciatingly slow motion.

title: ASPARAGUS MAKING ITS BRIEF, TASTY SPRING APPEARANCE
description: ONE of the great delights of spring is a plate of steaming asparagus dipped in melted butter and eaten with your fingers. Even though asparagus is no longer rare (it is now grown over vast areas in California), it is still a luxury because the season is so short. April and May are the peak months for this delicate vegetable, which is now in the stores in plentiful supplies at reasonable prices.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; The Endellion Strings, A Quartet From Britain
description: A string quartet, if it is to make a significant contribution to the musical scene, should have a character that is far more than the sum of its parts, a style that is both distinctive and compelling.

title: Out West
description: To the Editor: I can only add two points to Phyllis A. Whitney's otherwise excellent article on Sedona, Ariz., and ''Red Rock Country'' (Travel, March 21). The author says she chose the back route via the historic mining town of Jerome rather than take the ''direct'' route from Phoenix to Sedona (Interstate 17 and U.S. 179).

title: A BUDGETARY TUG-O-WAR IN ASSEMBLY
description: HARTFORD SOME of the fiscal and ideological issues that are dividing Connecticut's political candidates in this election year will move to center stage this week as the General Assembly tries to adopt a budget to run state government in the fiscal year starting July 1.

title: BEYOND ANATEVKA
description: AS Tevye, with heavy steps, led his family from its beloved Anatevka, I turned to find my grandmother weeping silently. I felt embarrassed, and was relieved to find her dry-eyed when the house lights came up.

title: A GUIDE TO REPLACING A WALL SWITCH SKILLFULLY AND SAFELY
description: REPLACING an electric wall switch with a new one - which is often necessary because the old one is no longer working properly, or because the homeowner wishes to replace a conventional on-off switch with a dimmer-type switch - is a fairly straightforward job that can be safely tackled by any do-it-yourselfer who follows the commonsense rules that must be observed in any electrical work around the house. (In some communities, local building codes forbid anyone but a licensed electrician to do this kind of work, so if in doubt check with your local building department.)

title: Financial Questions On Equity Season
description: Your article on the Main Street Theater (''Despite Closing, Hope Is Seen for Equity Troupes in County,'' March 21) raised a number of provocative questions.

title: Fell Rides Hostage To an Upset Victory In Arkansas Derby
description: For the second year in a row, Jeffrey Fell is in an enviable position: He is the regular rider for the two hottest Kentucky Derby prospects in the country.

title: HAVING WRIT, THE METER MAID MOVES ON
description: AS a writer, respect for the written word ranks in my estimation along with reverence for those all-American institutions, motherhood and apple pie. I share this philosophical outlook with myriad millions of my fellow beings.

title: BONNELL'S FIFTH HIT LIFTS JAYS OVER BREWERS IN THE 10TH, 3-2
description: Barry Bonnell's single - his fifth straight hit - drove in the winning run in the 10th inning today and lifted the Toronto Blue Jays to a 3-2 triumph over the Milwaukee Brewers.

title: STADLER LEADS IN MASTERS
description: Craig Stadler forged a three-stroke lead in the Masters Championship that appeared comfortable today, and as Jack Nicklaus conceded ''his day is arriving.'' But nine of the world's best golfers are within six strokes of Stadler, and none is about to give up in Sunday's final round.

title: FUGITIVE POLISH LABOR LEADER SEES THREAT TO UNION
description: A prominent Solidarity leader who has eluded capture said today that he believed the authorities were planning to ban the union. So far, Solidarity has been suspended, but not dissolved.

title: Stage View; SURROUNDED BU CREATURES OF HABIT
description: As I sat in two different playhouses on two successive evenings a week ago, a line of dialogue from the faraway past came floating into my head to haunt me. Suddenly I could hear - couldn't get rid of, really - the sound of dear Una O'Connor's light Irish lilt, so at odds with the exasperation and injury that filled her enormous eyes as she shuffled, in housekeeperly fashion, between the needs of nun Ingrid Bergman and young curate Bing Crosby in Leo McCarey's sometimes funny and always foolishly sentimental ''Bells of St. Mary's.'' What she was saying, as she bemoaned the labor of caring not only for the parish priests but also for the good sisters who taught in the convent school was a musically muttered ''Ah, sure, you don't know what it's like to be up to your neck in nuns.'' She pronounced ''nuns'' almost as though it were ''noons,'' which mysteriously made the line sound even tastier.

title: QUESTIONING THE VALUE OF THE UNITED NATIONS
description: Bernard D. Nossiter heads The New York Times's United Nations bureau. By Bernard D. Nossiter Jeane Jordan Kirkpatrick looked up at the General Assembly's electronic scoreboard in puzzled disbelief. Peru had just voted for an Arab resolution that virtually declared Israel an outlaw in the international community -sweeping verbal retaliation for Israel's annexation of the Golan Heights.

title: Postings; BYE-BYE, ZETA, PSI
description: In the 1920's, at the height of their popularity, there were 30 fraternities nestled in rambling structures around the Yale University campus in New Haven. Now there are just three, and the home of one of them, Zeta Psi, is being transformed into apartments.

title: No Headline
description: Many warm ''thank you's'' are to be extended to my old friend, Fred McMorrow, for his article ''The Day the House Went Out to Sea'' (March 7).

title: p.8; WOMEN'S LACROSSE PICKING UP
description: PRINCETON EVERY Sunday, a small band of dedicated women don kilts or warmup clothes to play a game invented by American Indians centuries ago. ''Princeton is the heart of women's lacrosse in central and northern New Jersey,'' said Kim Bedesem, coach of the girls' lacrosse team at Princeton Day School and player-coach of the New Jersey Lacrosse Association.

title: A CONDUCTOR WHO BEATS THE DRUM FOR OFFENBACH
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Mark Steinbrink is a freelance writer with a special interest in the performing arts. By MARK STEINBRINK

title: Sports People; Holmes's Prediction
description: Larry Holmes, the World Boxing Council heavyweight champion, worked out for one more round than he has said he thinks he would need in his title defense against Gerry Cooney June 11 in Las Vegas, Nev. Holmes put on an eight-round exhibition in Cleveland Friday night, then predicted that he would knock out Cooney within seven rounds. ''If it's still going then, I'll walk out,'' Holmes said.

title: I have read the three letters and the article that started the debate. I do not intend to take sides on what seems to be a very heated issue; instead, I would prefer to attempt to act as an intermediary between the divergent forces.
description: Both the article and the letters were obviously filled with a great deal of emotion. There are no rights or wrongs where people's feelings are involved, and a mother's love for her child is truly recognized as the strongest human emotion known. It would be futile to debate whether nature or nurture makes one a ''real'' mother.

title: JAZZ
description: The musical sounds of the 40's - both pop music and jazz - will be filtering through town this week, coming from the horns, the hands and the voices of performers who gave that decade some of its musical flavor.

title: Bea Feitler, Magazine And Book Designer, 44
description: Bea Feitler, a designer of books and magazines, died of cancer in Rio de Janeiro Thursday while visiting her parents. She was 44 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Surgical Death
description: One boy twin was developing normally in the 40-year-old mother's womb. The other, tests showed, had Down's Syndrome, which often results in severe retardation. Dr. Thomas D. Kerenyi and Dr. Usha Chitkara, operating at the Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan, inserted a long needle into the heart of the abnormal fetus and destroyed it.

title: GHETTO IS RECALLED
description: TEANECK IN 1943, as millions of Jews in Nazi-occupied Europe were being loaded onto trains bound for concentration camps, a Torah seized by the Germans from a synagogue in Czechoslovakia was shipped to Prague, there to be preserved for a postwar museum as an example of ''Jewish decadence.''

title: The Fastest Game
description: If P.S. Wood had continued the introductory quotation by William Hazlitt in his article ''The Fastest Game in Town'' (March 7), he would have found that Hazlitt was referring not to the game of racquets, but to handball, or ''fives,'' as it was known in the 19th century. The quotation was actually taken by Hazlitt from an obituary of John Cavanaugh, the greatest fives player of his time.

title: Joy D. Javits To Be Bride
description: Former Senator Jacob K. Javits of New York and Mrs. Javits have announced the engagement of their daughter, Joy Deborah Javits, to David Glenn Romero, son of Elizabeth Fleury Romero of Patterson, La.

title: Topics; OIL, ICE AND HOT AIR; Cold Wars
description: It is not only the weather that has recently turned chilly; consider the language of the day.

title: Musicals at Goodspeed
description: With the glowing exception of the Goodspeed Opera House, I have noticed that regional and community theaters, while having the least to lose financially, tend to be the most conservative in their offerings (''Harvesting Musicals at Goodspeed,'' by Steve Lawson, Feb. 28).

title: WHAT'S NEW UNDER WATER
description: The Sixth Annual Greater New York Underwater Symposium will be held next Sunday in the Humanities Building of the state university at Purchase, at noon and 6:30 P.M.

title: Antiques View
description: There is magic in the lore of Oriental rugs - at least to those who fall under the spell of these weavings. As children we dreamed of exotic lands where golden domes dominated the skyline and palace interiors were lined with color-splashed carpets. And we saw rugs aloft and flying, bearing legendary heroes on great adventures to distant kingdoms. All of us are prey to the charms of these carpets. Indeed, the numbers of fans of such fare are legion and their ranks continue to swell.

title: FOR CONNER, A WEALTH OF CUP DEFENDERS
description: Befitting his stature as America's foremost racing skipper, Dennis Conner is being treated like a king before the defense next year of the America's Cup, yachting's premier prize.

title: Letters; Landmark Benefit
description: To the Editor:

title: Kathleen Griffith Plans Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph N. Corcoran of Elkins Park, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathleen Corcoran Griffith, to John Macauley Keene 3d, son of Mrs. John M. Keene Jr. of Glencoe, Ill., and the late Mr. Keene.

title: BLUE JAY; Cyanocitta cristata
description: Size: 11 to 12 1/2 inches. Color: Upper parts and conspicuous crest, blue; grayish white underparts.

title: Investing; OFF WALL STREET, THEY DON'T LIKE STOCKS
description: IF the theory of investing by contrary opinion holds water, people o ught to be socking away common stocks these days. All across the c ountry, individual investors are snubbing equities -except for e lectric utilities generally - in favor of high-yield, low-risk c ommitments, a check of 16 brokerage branch offices found last week.

title:
Other Business;
ECONOMY PUTS THE BRAKES ON MOTORCYCLE SALES
description: The stagnant economy appears to have done what a generation of nervous mothers was never able to do: cut back sales in the Japanesedominated American motorcycle industry.

title:
GARDENING;
TIPS ON HIRING A LANDSCAPE GARDENER
description: MOST garden writers, including myself, take the approach that the reader will do his own lawn and garden work. That, of course, is not always true, especially in this area.

title: CONSIDER WILD PALNTS AS GROUNDCOVERS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Judy Glattstein is specialist in wild flowers and rock garden plants. BY JUDY GLATTSTEIN

title: WHAT'S DOING IN MONACO
description: PAUL LEWIS is a correspondent in the Paris bureau of The Times. BY PAUL LEWIS

title: COLLEGE FOR THE LEARNING DISABLED
description: Often, the term ''dyslexia'' is used as a catchall phrase to signify a broad range of learning problems.

title: J.E. FEINSTEIN TO WED MARY MARGARET SIMONS
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Simons of Lake City, Minn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Margaret Simons, to Jeffrey Elliot Feinstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Selwyn Feinstein of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y.

title: A LIFESAVING COURSE
description: The American Red Cross Westchester chapter is calling for 500 recruits to learn cardiopulmonary resuscitation in one day. ''Never before has such a large-scale CPR course been attempted in the county,'' according to Red Cross officials, who said that the need for individuals to perform emergency lifesaving procedures is widespread.

title:
Comment;
THRIFT DESTRUCTION
description: SEVERAL months ago, Alan Greenspan, adviser to President Reagan and a former head of the Council of Economic Advisers, o bserved that the thrift industry was a ''ticking time bomb'' in the n ational economy. In recent weeks, the ticking has grown perceptibly l ouder and more ominous. Today, the thrift industry problem t hreatens to undermine the very heart of Reaganomics.

title:
DINING OUT;
A TOUCH OF CLASS IN BASKING RIDGE
description: THE large companies that have relocated within a 20-mile radius of Morristown in the last few years have had a profound effect on the area. House prices have skyrocketed and the countryside has become increasingly suburban, but one of the advantages is that restaurants, like camp followers, go where the action is.

title: UNION RESISTS HEARING
description: LAWRENCEVILLE THE state's Casino Control Commission has scheduled a hearing here on April 26 to determine whether Atlantic City's largest casino-hotel union has ties to organized crime. However, the union, Local 54 of the Hotel and Restaurant Employees and Bartenders International, hopes to block the proceeding.

title: The Week in Business; PRODUCER PRICES DIP AGAIN; THE DEFICIT SWELLS
description: Producer prices fell by a tenth of a percent in March, matching February's decline and marking the first time since 1976 that wholesale prices have been off for two months in a row. Some analysts are lowering their projections on the inflation rate this year to as little as 4.5 percent.

title: PATERSON: PHOENIX IS RISING
description: PATERSON THIS grimy old industrial city has had many ups and downs since Alexander Hamilton planned it as the center of the American silk industry 200 years ago.

title: Jogger
description: To the Editor: Regarding the parent who wrote to Q and A (Travel, Feb. 21) to say that her 16-year-old daughter was visiting Venice, Florence and Rome on a 10-day student tour and wanted to know where to jog, the answer should have been to keep her at home. The money for the trip will be absolutely wasted on a monomaniacal runner for whom one pavement is equivalent to another.

title: French Pastry
description: To the Editor: Mimi Sheraton, the author of ''Le Grand Nosh de Paris'' (Travel, March 21) may know the locations of the best caviar and truffles, but she has omitted a star in the pastry department.

title: Headliners; The Rich Also Serve
description: The disadvantages of great wealth are strictly relative. Take the case of Nicholas F. Brady, who last week was reportedly selected by Governor Kean to fill the Senate seat of Harrison A. Williams Jr. of New Jersey until the November election. The only hitch, according to the family, involved arrangements to put the financier's vast holdings in trust. Mr. Brady, managing director of the investment banking firm of Dillon Read & Company and chairman of Purolator Inc., will presumably have it all worked out so the Governor can formally name him this week.

title: On Language
description: The Meaning of Depression

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS;
description: Louis Eisenberg, a friendly 53-year-old office maintenance worker from Brooklyn, summed up his plans simply when he became the New York Lottery's first $5 million winner last

title: Megan McLeod To Be June Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Louis McLeod of Huntington, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Megan Beth McLeod, to Enrique Hernandez Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hernandez of San Marino, Calif.

title: Andres Brown to Wed Elizabeth C. Disher
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Baxter Disher of Appleton, Wis., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Chapman Disher to Andres Theodore Brown, son of Mr. and Mrs. Adrian T. Brown of Jamaica, Queens, and East Hampton, L.I.

title: W.J. MacNaughton to Wed Miss Hoff
description: Mr. and Mrs. Philip Henderson Hoff of Burlington, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Andrea Clark Hoff, to W. James MacNaughton, son of Mr. and Mrs. D. Roger MacNaughton of Wyckoff, N.J. and East Falmouth, Mass.

title: Ann Appelbaum Fiancee of Rabbi Neal I. Borovitz
description: Mr. and Mrs. Irving Appelbaum of Decatur, Ill., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ann Harriet Appelbaum, to Rabbi Neal Ivan Borovitz, son of Mildred Borovitz of Cleveland, and the late Jerry Borovitz.

title: ATHENS MOVING TO SEPARATE CHURCH AND STATE
