description: Greece's Socialist Government is moving to carry out its pledge to separate church and state and to expropriate the church's unused land.

title: Editor's Choice
description: American's memoir of growing up in two cultures. THE TUGMAN'S PASSAGE, by Edward Hoagland.

title:
CRAFTS;
FROM COMPUTING TO BASKET MAKING
description: AT Incorporated Gallery in New York City, running through April 20, is a show of contemporary basketry by Sheila Benedis of Hastings-on-Hudson. Ten years ago, Mrs. Benedis was a computer analyst who had worked in the computer field for most of her career; she had a master's degree in mathematics but no formal training in art. About five years ago, however, she left her job with a consulting firm and began to use her ''spare'' time, in between raising her son, to take crafts and art-related courses. She studied everything from needlepoint to macrame.

title: Royals 5, Tigers 2
description: John Wathan knocked in two runs, and Tom Poquette scored twice for the Royals. Dennis Leonard, Grant Jackson and Dan Quisenberry combinead to pitch a one-hitter.

title: JOHN B. O'MAHONEY
description: IT is early morning, about 3 A.M. The sound of music and voices from an ongoing party drifts through a residential neighborhood, disturbing a resident who calls the police. Upon arrival, the officer stands at the property line of the party's host, takes a reading on a small device and issues the host a summons. He is in violation of the new local noise ordinance.

title: MISS JAEGER UPSETS MRS. LLOYD IN 3 SETS
description: For only the third time in nine years, Chris Evert Lloyd was beaten in a clay-court tournament today.

title: A HORROR BEYOND COMPREHENSION
description: THE FATE OF THE EARTH By Jonathan Schell. 244 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $11.95.

title: WHEN NANCY DREW'S 'MOTHER' REVEALED THE SECRET OF COOKING UP A MYSTERY
description: PLOT By FREDDA SACHAROW

title: BUFFALO'S UPSWING IS PACED BY SAVINGS BANK
description: Residents here are actually talking these days about something besides the weather, which this month included backto-back blizzards. The newest topic is the Buffalo Savings Bank, now one of the nation's largest such institutions.

title: SENTIMENTAL 'ON GOLDEN POND' POETS AND PARKING STIR VILLAGE; LINDENHURST
description: IT'S taken ''On Golden Pond'' only a couple of years to reverse the route from relative obscurity to severe overexposure. A minor Off Broadway play that tried - and in 1979 twice failed - to succeed on Broadway, Ernest Thompson's overstuffed account of a loving, elderly couple during what may be the last of 48 summers in their Maine retreat was omnipresent in community theaters even before the release of the playwright's vastly superior screenplay.

title: WHAT'S WEALTH? A CUTTING GREEN
description: WHAT is the definition of wealth? To some, it's an Alfa Romeo or a Rolls-Royce. To others, a beat-up, still running, badly used car. To some, caviar and Champagne imported from foreign lands. To others, a crust of bread.

title: Other Business; EASTER TREATS FOR CHOCOLATE MAKERS
description: From dime-store marshmallow chicks to pricey chocolate cottontails, Easter goodies are selling well this year. At Macy's Herald Square store, hundreds of pounds of solid chocolate bunnies and foil-wrapped rabbits, selling at $4.95 a pound, were sold out by midweek at the candy department. Sales clerks also reported a brisk business in imported Easter delicacies -Perugina's $10 to $25 chocolate eggs and $12 ceramic Limoges eggs.

title: A PLAN FOR RIGHTING THE WRONGS OF COLLEGE SPORTS...
description: SINCE commenting on the sins of those connected with college sports programs has become the thing to do, it is sometimes hard for the public to recognize the saints from the sinners. One question that has arisen among that public is this: Why should college athletics be held to higher moral standards than we expect from government or industry? Aren't college programs merely another part of American life?

title: WESTWAY REMAINS A POLITICAL AND LEGAL OBSTACLE COURSE
description: SUPPORTERS of the massive urban highway and development project known as Westway had expected that this would be the year construction would at last begin. Mayor Koch and Governor Carey were seeing eye to eye, engineers and architects were hard at work and a groundbreaking was planned for the spring.

title: 2 SILENT FILMS
description: In its one and only foray into film making, the Yale University Press, publisher of scholarly books, produced a series of 13 silent movies on historic themes in the early 1920's called ''The Chronicles of America.'' Originally shown in commercial theaters and schools, the three-reel prints disappeared decades ago. Recently, Fred Guida, assistant curator of the Yale University film collection, stumbled over a couple of incomplete prints in a New Haven junk shop. Further investigation turned up a dusty but complete set in the Yale archives, one of which, ''The Declaration of Independence,'' will be shown free at 7 P.M. Thursday on a double bill with D.W. Griffith's 1924 epic ''America'' in the Yale University Art Gallery lecture hall.

title: Wildlife Refuge Is Not for Dogs
description: It is unfortunate that the author of the article on the John F. Kennedy Wildlife Refuge (''Nature, Quiet but Wild, Haunts Dunes,'' Opinion Page, March 14) doesn't appreciate exactly what the term ''wildlife refuge'' implies. She opens with a cutesy bit in which a ''a small white dog, tail wagging, runs here and there, sniffing at the frozen ground,'' as if to tell your readers dogs are welcome.

title: ASTOR CASTLE FOR SALE: HENRY VIII SLEPT HERE
description: More than 450 years ago, the moated 13th-century castle that the Astor family has offered for sale for $25 million was the scene of an illicit romance that changed the course of British history.

title: MORE THAN HONOR AND OIL IN FALKLANDS WAR
description: To the Editor:

title: DIFFIDENT MINNESOTAN
description: To the Editor:

title: LACK OF L.I. SUPPORT BLOCKED REGAN BID
description: SEVERAL weeks after his surprise decision to quit the Republican contest for Governor, State Comptroller Edward V. Regan is blaming Suffolk County Executive Peter F. Cohalan for ''unraveling'' his candidacy, a move that helped Mr. Cohalan promote his own bid for Lieutenant Governor.

title: REV. JAMES J. ROHAN
description: The Rev. James J. Rohan, who had been assistant pastor of St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan since 1948, died Thursday at Lenox Hill Hospital at the age of 79.

title: Robert Arrison Will Marry Cynthia Mills Hiatt in May
description: Dr. Harold Hiatt of Cincinnati has announced the engagement of his daughter, Cynthia Mills Hiatt, daughter also of the late Jennie Hiatt, to Robert Thompson Arrison, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Arrison Jr., of Darien, Conn. A May 22 wedding is planned.

title: Arizona Bans Gun Licensing
description: The State House has unanimously approved a bill that would prevent Arizona cities from licensing guns or regulating gun ownership. Representative Bill English, who wrote the bill, said he wanted all control vested in the Legislature because he feared that some cities were leaning toward gun control. The measure now goes to the Arizona Senate for consideration.

title: HOW CANDIDATES COPE WITH CONFUSION
description: WASHINGTON CONFUSION over the state's new Congressional districts - confusion that was not resolved until the United States Supreme Court declined last month to act on a request by New Jersey's Republican Representatives - has played havoc with re-election plans.

title: H.M.S. FURIOUS
description: LONDON WHEN Britain seized the Falkland Islands 149 years ago, it needed only a single sloop. Captain J.J. Onslow of the Clio sailed into the South Atlantic, sent a polite but firm message to Captain J.M. Pinedo of the schooner Sarandi, hauled down the Argentine flag and ran up the Union Jack.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: IN the aftermath of an ill-fated canoing adventure by four Rockland County youths, two teen-agers were pulled unconscious from the Hudson River on Monday and rushed to the Westchester County Medical Center in Valhalla. Despite the efforts made there, however, both victims died.

title: Mailbox; Keep Freshman Off the Varsity
description: To the Sports Editor: In the series on college athletics (''College Sports: Have the Schools Lost Control?'' The New York Times, March 21-24), I remember nothing being said about the very drastic change of a few years back that made freshmen eligible for varsity athletics and thereby overturned a sensible system that had worked well for decades in giving freshman athletes a year without the pressure of varsity competition.

title: The Region in Summary; Charter Revision Gets New Goals
description: When New York City's charter was last revised, in 1977, changes in it were aimed largely at making municipal government more efficient and democratic. Last week Mayor Koch named Columbia University president Michael I. Sovern to head a new Charter Revision Commission whose main task will be to make government legal.

title: Smothered, by a Security Blanket
description: The Reagan Administration is trying to stanch what it calls the ''hemorrhage'' of militarily useful technology to the Soviet Union. But its idea of a tourniquet looks more like a garrote.

title: UTILITIES LEAD OFFERINGS
description: Electric utilities are the largest group of companies that definitely plan to sell debt issues this week. If conditions are favorable, they may be joined by many industrial corporations.

title: Audit on Teapot Dome Said to Find Problems
description: Federal auditors say a company hired to manage an oil reserve at Teapot Dome billed the Government for $5.5 million in costs that were ''ineligible for reimbursement,'' The Denver Post said today.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: A tennis player gets his first serve in and, at the same time, discards the ball he had been holding in his hand. This is distracting to the receiver. Is there a ruling that covers this situation?

title: ARGENTINE OFFICIALS SAY PROSPECTS OF FALKLAND SETTLEMENT ARE DIM
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. traveled to London Sunday with a loose package of negotiating ideas that he hoped would help end the dispute over the Falkland Islands.

title: Former Turkish Premier to Go Before a Military Court Today
description: Former Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit, who was taken from his home Saturday and detained overnight, will face a military court Monday over his contacts with the foreign press, martial law officials said today.

title: MONEY REPORT'S RATE IMPACT
description: Volatile interest rates are unhealthy for the credit markets and the economy, but many analysts believe that tinkering with the weekly money supply announcement will not solve the problem.

title: THE BLUE CROSS BLUE SHIELD WAR ON COSTS
description: T o the Editor: It seems to me that your March 31 article in ''The Price of Health'' series - on health insurance as a contributing cause of rising health-care costs -misinterprets the role of our nonprofit Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans in their relationship with hospitals and doctors, and, especially, the role of the plans as advocates of subscribers and their employers.

title: EASTER: REBIRTH, JOY AND A TOUCH OF SOLEMNITY
description: Carrying a silver cross that glinted in the sunshine and swinging a thurible of incense, clergymen and choir members wound through the ivy-covered front garden at the Church of the Transfiguration at Fifth Avenue and 29th Street. At their feet were signs of springtime rebirth. Daffodils poked their yellow caps through the greenery. Overhead, in a budding tree, sparrows chirped noisily.

title: ST. BART'S TAPS OUT EASTER JOY
description: Bright balloon clusters danced above the elegant pews and the ''Hallelujahs'' were syncopated in St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church on Park Avenue yesterday, where Easter arrived at the 9 A.M. communion service like a gospel jubilee with country-jazz overtones.

title: McNamara Disagrees With Haig on A-Arms
description: Former Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara disputed Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. today on Mr. Haig's contention that the United States would have to triple its armed forces if NATO renounced the first use of nuclear weapons in Europe.

title: BLACK BANK TAKEOVER IS AVERTED
description: Harlem Commonwealth Council Inc. has obtained effective control of the Freedom National Bank, the only black-owned bank in New York, following its purchase of a large block of the bank's convertible preferred stock.

title: 2D MOOSE HUNT IN MAINE PROMPTS EFFORTS FOR BAN
description: Applications have come from as far away as California and Saudi Arabia. Maine's second moose hunt in almost half a century has drawn more than 42,000 entrants willing to pay $5 or $10 for a chance to stalk the biggest game animal in North America.

title: Amend Captures Easter Bowl Title
description: Top-seeded Eric Amend of Rolling Hills Estates, Calif., won the boys' 16 title today in the Olympus Easter Bowl tennis championships with a 7-6, 6-4 victory over Robby Weiss of Northbrook, Ill.

title: Parnassus Performs Stravinsky and Carter
description: Underneath the supposed severity of modernist music, there is a measure of sheer pleasure in playing with conventions and timbres. At the program presented by Parnassus at the Merkin Concert Hall on Saturday night, those elements were evident in Stravinsky's compositions - the Symphonies of Wind Instruments (1920) and the Octet for Wind Instruments (1923, revised 1952).

title: N.H.L. Playoffs; Black Hawks Oust Stars, 3 Games to 1
description: The Chicago Black Hawks eliminated the Minnesota North Stars, who went to the Stanley Cup final series last season, from the Norris Division playoffs with a 5-2 victory tonight.

title: MRS. KIRKPATRICK SAYS FALKLANDS ACCORD IS LIKELY
description: The chief American delegate to the United Nations said today that there was ''a reasonable likelihood'' that Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.'s mission to Britain and Argentina could achieve a diplomatic solution and avoid a clash over the Falkland Islands.

title: Vilas Beats Lendl
description: Guillermo Vilas toppled Ivan Lendl, 6-1, 7-6, 6-3, today in the final of the $300,000 Monte Carlo Grand Prix tennis tournament. It was his first victory over the Czechoslovak after eight straight losses over two years.

title: Index; International
description: Reporter's notebook: Reagan's island in the sun A2 East German pastors protest ban on pacifist badges A3 Japanese upset by U.S. criticism of trade imbalance A4 Around the World A7 British subs thought to have edge if naval clash occurs A8 Pope urges peaceful settlement of Falklands dispute A8 At old outposts of the empire, Britons are stirred A9 Mrs. Kirkpatrick says accord is likely on Falklands A10 Polish primate appeals for national accord at Easter service A11 Washington Talk Briefing A20 The Calendar A20 What they're saying in Washington about Jimmy Carter A20 The fund-raiser - where Congressmen and lobbyists gather A20 General Around the Nation A16 Documentary film stirs furor in Muncie, Ind. A16 Maine's second moose hunts prompts drive to end sport A16 The Region B2 The City B3 Speakers in New York seek help for Ethiopian Jews B3 Couple charged in death of 5-year-old boy B5 Denver seeks to levy taxes on sales of newspapers B7 A look at the influences on Fire Department overtime B8 Study of arrests stresses speed of call to police D9 Health/Science Scientific tests in Alaska to provide light show A17 U.S. tests weather forecasts that stress time elements C17 SportsMonday Baseball: Yankees open season with double loss to White Sox C1

title: A NAMIBIAN TANGLE
description: Among all the failures and frustrations of diplomacy these days, one major diplomatic enterprise has been making headway. That is the effort of five Western powers to bring Namibia to independence - an effort that, if it succeeded, could ease tensions in all of southern Africa.

title: DEFENDANT'S ACCOUNTS CALLED CRUCIAL IN STOUFFER CONVICTION
description: One member of the jury that convicted Luis Marin on Saturday night of arson and murder in the Stouffer's Inn fire indicated today that the panel had decided on the verdict in large measure because of the defendant's own accounts of the events.

title: SPEAKERS AT RALLY SEEK HELP FOR ETHIOPIAN JEWS
description: Fighting back tears, Baruch Tegegne pleaded for assistance. ''I am sure I am a stranger to many of you, as a black and a Jew,'' said Mr. Tegegne, who fled Ethiopia in 1974 and arrived in Israel two and a half years later.

title: RECITAL: JESSYE NORMAN SINGS
description: Jessye Norman's recital at Avery Fisher Hall yesterday afternoon never ventured out of the 19th century, but there was a variety enough in her voice alone to hold our attention.

title: Revival of Arms Pact Sought
description: Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, called today for reviving the second treaty limiting strategic arms, which was negotiated with the Russians by the Carter Administration. Under the treaty, which was never ratified by the Senate, the Soviet Union would have to dismantle more than 10 percent of their missiles or heavy bombers to meet the limitation of 2,250 launchers, Mr. Apsin said, adding that the United States is already below that limit.

title: Foundation Presenting 'Mencken, Nathan, God'
description: ''Mencken, Nathan and God,'' a play written and directed by Sidney Eden will be performed tomorrow through Wednesday at 4 P.M. in the Bruno Walter Auditorium of Lincoln Center Performing Arts Library, at Amsterdam Avenue and 65th Street, and next Saturday at 2:30 P.M. in the Donnell Library, on 53d Street between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas.

title: MICHAEL SPINKS WINNER
description: Michael Spinks, proclaiming ''you haven't seen the best of me yet,'' knocked down Murray Sutherland twice in the eighth round for an automatic knockout today in defense of the World Boxing Association light-heavyweight championship.

title: Maximillian Herzberger Dies; Einstein's Student and Friend
description: Maximillian Herzberger, a student of Albert Einstein's who gained prominence in the field of optics, died here Friday at the age of 83.

title: Publishers Report Advertising Gains
description: Industry organizations from both the worlds of newspapers and magazines have issued positive advertising revenue reports. For the daily papers, the Newspaper Advertising Bureau said that in January, revenues were up 15.2 percent, to $1.3 billion, compared with the same month last year.

title: Safeguard Scientifics Seeks Investor to Avoid Breakup
description: Adolf A. Paier, president of Safeguard Scientifics Inc., sat in the coffee shop of a suburban Philadephia hotel and made a valiant effort to minimize the fact that his company's stock had been manipulated by a broker from Iowa.

title: ROCKET LAUNCHING TO GIVE LIGHT SHOW
description: A broad segment of the Pacific Northwest may get an opportunity to share in an awesome light show when the Poker Flat Research Range sends two rockets into space in the period from Monday to April 26.

title: YANKEES LOSE BY 7-6 AND 2-0 TO WHITE SOX
description: Five days after they were supposed to begin their season, the Yankees finally opened yesterday, and what was the big hurry? The Yankees, thwarted by snow in three previous attempts to open, unveiled their radically altered team at Yankee Stadium, and the debut was a flop. The Chicago White Sox, the only other major league team that had not played any games because of bad weather, swept a doubleheader, winning the first game, 7-6, in 12 innings, and the second, 2-0, in nine.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Return Engagement

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: REAGAN'S ISLAND IN THE SUN
description: In an era when American Presidents have been careful to take American vacations on Colorado ski slopes, California golf courses or Georgia trout streams, President Reagan this week relaxed at a Caribbean oceanfront cottage where the ''Bleep-bleep-bleep'' of tiny tree frogs echoes through the evening air.

title: U.S. STRESSING TIME ELEMENT IN TEST ON WEATHER FORECASTS
description: The National Weather Service is planning to revise its forecasts to give more emphasis to the time that certain weather events are supposed to occur.

title: Historical Society Show On American Bands Set
description: More than 150 band uniforms, pieces of sheet music, programs, posters, photographs, paintings and other memorabilia will go on display July 1 at the New-York Historical Society in ''Oom-Pah-Pah: The Great American Band.''

title: Soviet Police Arrest 12 Moscow Dissidents
description: Twelve dissidents have been arrested by security police in a coordinated series of raids here, dissident sources said today.

title: Mexico to Spend $3.3 Million To Repair Volcano Damage
description: President Jose Lopez Portillo said today that the Government would spend $3.3 million to rebuild houses and reclaim farmland buried by the ash from El Chinchonal, a volcano in southern Mexico.

title: Business Views On Economy
description: Business leaders are pessimistic about the current state of the economy but are expressing confidence in the future, the Conference Board said yesterday.

title: MORE STOLEN ARTWORKS FOUND
description: Twenty-two pieces of art stolen last week from a truck parked in Soho were found in a Lower East Side apartment yesterday, the police said.

title: Chiat/Day Wins Pioneer Account
description: Chiat/Day, Los Angeles, has been named agency for the recently formed Pioneer Electronics (U.S.A.), which resulted from the merger of the Pioneer Corporation of America, based in Long Beach, Calif., and the U.S. Pioneer Electronics Corporation of Moonachie, N.J. Their combined billings are about $9 million.

title: HOSTAGE AND EL BABA REST UP
description: Hostage and El Baba, the heroes of the Arkansas Derby Saturday, stayed behind at Oaklawn Park today while everyone else was getting out of town. With racing in Arkansas having come to an end for 10 months, the backstretch here observed Easter with a commotion of horse vans and travel plans as this town of 38,000 - which was host to an Oaklawn record crowd of 64,318 Saturday - began deflating to its normal size and pace.

title: Sports World Specials; Flip Flops
description: A flip of a coin can often result in an exchange of a quarter or so on a street corner. But where the National Basketball Association is concerned, a toss can involve millions of dollars of profit for the winner.

title: METS SET BACK CUBS, 5-4
description: On the 20th anniversary of their first game and first loss in the National League, the New York Mets defeated the Chicago Cubs, 5-4, today with a heady mixture of second-generation skills.

title: BRAVES BLANK ASTROS TO WIN 5th STRAIGHT
description: Rick Mahler pitched a five-hitter, and Dale Murphy hit his third homer in five games today to spark the unbeaten Atlanta Braves to their fifth victory, a 5-0 decision over the Houston Astros.

title: NCNB Profit Up 9%
description: The NCNB Corporation, holding company for the North Carolina National Bank, reported Friday that net income in the first quarter increased 9 percent, to $14.4 million, or 66 cents a share, from $13.3 million, or 66 cents a share, in the first quarter of 1981.

title: SPEED OF CALL FOR HELP STRESSED
description: The police have little chance of arresting a criminal on the scene unless they are alerted within one minute of the crime, a report prepared for the Justice Department said today.

title: KOCH SEEKS AGENCY REPORTS AS OVERTIME EXCEEDS BUDGET
description: With overtime costs running twice as high as projected, Mayor Koch has ordered the heads of New York City agencies to file reports with him on what they are doing to control those costs. The deadline for the reports is today.

title: The Proboscis in Corporate Tents
description: AMAX Inc., the mining conglomerate, pays former President Gerald Ford $100,000 a year for his services as a consultant. It pays former Defense Secretary Harold Brown $75,000 a year to consult. Such fees are not unusual: many corporations spend heavily for advice from distinguished public figures.

title: VERSATILE CHINAGLIA BOON TO COSMOS
description: Giorgio Chinaglia has the goals to prove his effectiveness around the opponent's penalty area, but this season he has added a new dimension to his game by operating a great deal in midfield for the Cosmos.

title: I.B.M. Wins On 3 Appeals
description: A United States appeals court in San Francisco has upheld the International Business Machines Corporation in an antitrust suit filed by Forro Precision Inc., a small computer components manufacturer.

title: The U.N. Today; April 12, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Council for Namibia - 3 P.M.

title: Easter Services in Beirut
description: Christians flocked to church services here and held the usual Easter processions today despite sporadic explosions and machine-gun fire.

title: 2 ARABS ARE KILLED AS ISRAELI ATTACKS DOME OF THE ROCK
description: An Israeli soldier with an automatic rifle shot his way into one of Islam's holiest shrines, the Dome of the Rock, and sprayed the inside of the mosque with gunfire today, killing at least two Arabs and wounding at least nine.

title: Two Britons Complete Crossing of Both Poles
description: Two British explorers, Sir Ranulph Fiennes, 38 years old, and Charles Burton, 39, planted the Union Jack at the top of the world today after completing the first crossing of both poles in a single, 52,000-mile circumnavigation of the earth.

title: POPE ASKS ACCORD ON FALKLAND ISSUE
description: Pope John Paul II today used his traditional Easter greeting, ''To the City and the World,'' to implore Britain and Argentina to settle their conflict over the Falkland Islands without bloodshed.

title: Premature Publicity for Congressman's Complaint; He Tried to Be Prudent
description: ''Before I go off half-cocked and do something really stupid,'' Representative James V. Hansen wrote in a letter to the Secretary of the Interior, James G. Watt, ''would you please favor me with some of your good counsel concerning this problem?''

title: Resources Council Sees Gains of Clean Air Act
description: Contrary to arguments from its foes, the Clean Air Act has improved both the American economy and the health of the people, an environmental group said today.

title: BRIEFING
description: Judicial Quandary

title: Search Is Ended For Lost Canoeist
description: The search for the body of a teenage boy, missing since April 4 when he and three other youths disappeared while canoeing in the Hudson River, has been called off.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Mary Cantwell CONTROL. By William Goldman. Dela- corte. 305 pages. $15.95.

title: OTHER RELIGIOUS GROUPS JOIN MOON CHURCH IN ITS DISPUTE WITH CITY ON TAXES
description: While the Rev. Sun Myung Moon defends himself against charges of tax fraud in Federal District Court in Manhattan, the religious and political mission of the church he heads is under examination in the New York State Court of Appeals.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Binney & Smith Inc., Easton, Pa., has appointed Joseph R. Petite vice president of finance.

title: BRITISH BLOCKADE AROUND FALKLANDS GOES INTO EFFECT
description: Britain imposed a blockade around the Falkland Islands this morning, ready to sink any Argentine warship that came closer than 200 miles to the disputed archipelago.

title: BRIEFING
description: Falklands Dispatch (1832)

title: 2 Yachts Missing in Race Off North California
description: Coast Guard searchers scanned the waters off Northern California today after a storm for two yachts that failed to return from a 60-mile race. Six sailboats, some battered by the winds and high seas, were found.

title: LIMITED EDITIONS CLUB, ILLUSTRATION OF A COMEBACK
description: The Limited Editions Club is back in business, back in New York, back in the black and again under the firm control of one man. Known for its lavish editions of illustrated classics in the 1930's and 40's, when it had a membership of 2,000 and a waiting list three times as long, the club declined in the last decade to 500 members. It was sold twice, and when it was put up for sale a third time, it was virtually bankrupt. Now its membership is above 1,400 and growing, and its books once again are luxurious volumes illustrated by famous artists.

title: THEATER: FOOTE'S 'ROADS TO HOME'
description: IN ''The Roads to Home,'' the new play by Horton Foote at the Manhattan Punch Line, people are askew - not mightily, but almost parenthetically, tilting, so to speak, coming together at odd angles that aren't quite the proper angles. Mr. Foote's characters are 1920's Texans, and they are neither big town nor small town, nor Old South nor New South, nor Baptist Church nor sin city. In their way, however, they are endearing, and about them Mr. Foote has written a literate, touching play.

title: Ursula Gruber Applies A Linguistic Approach
description: Ursula Gruber of Paris has opened an office in New York, and it has been accomplished by as much promotion as one would expect from a former public relations representative.

title: GROUP FORMS EASTER 'FAMILY'
description: Thirty persons, almost all of them single, jammed into Rita Fliashnick's small studio apartment on West 57th Street yesterday to eat, drink, sing and socialize with other people like themselves who were alone on Easter.

title: White House Tapping 'Annie' for Egg Hunt
description: Annie and Daddy Warbucks from the Broadway cast of ''Annie'' are to preside at the White House Easter egg hunt Monday, when hundreds of children are turned loose in search of thousands of eggs.

title: Havana Cancels Visas Of Cuba-Bound Group
description: The Cuban Government canceled visas for more than 200 American tourists and Cuban expatriates before they were to board a Havana-bound charter jet from Miami, a tour official said.

title: TV: VANESSA REDGRAVE AS A WIFE FACING ABORTION
description: ''MY BODY, MY CHILD,'' ABC-TV's ''Theater of the Month'' presentation tonight at 9 o'clock, was first seriously considered for television a couple of years ago, when it was submitted in a competition organized by the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center in Waterford, Conn. The original play was written by a suburban housewife, Louisa Burns-Bisogno, who decided to become a playwright in her 40's. Although missing the top prize, the piece was optioned by Herbert Brodkin, a television producer with an exceptionally prestigious list of credits.

title: COURTS WEIGH VALUE OF UNWANTED LIVES
description: A small but growing number of lawsuits claiming ''wrongful life'' and ''wrongful birth,'' terms virtually unheard of a decade ago, is stirring concern not only in the medical and legal communities but also among opponents of abortion.

title: DANCE: THE SUSAN SALINGER TOUCH
description: IT seemed appropriate that a cold wind blew through the Bessie Schonberg Theater on Saturday during a program of dances by Susan Salinger. This was a bleak, punchy landscape where aggressively neutered-looking young women paced, tumbled and shoved their way in neat formations across an imaginary plane broken only by transmitters and wires, in a silence disturbed by calm recitations of algebraic theorems. The dancers' only moments of camaraderie occurred as they vied for position on a tightrope.

title: Labeling at Los Alamos Cited in Plutonium Leak
description: Mislabeling of radioactive material at Los Alamos National Laboratory caused a plutonium leak that officials said contaminated 15 people last year, a Federal study reports.

title: U.S.C. Football Is Set for TV
description: Dick Perry, the athletic director at Southern California, acknowledged Saturday that the Trojans' football team will play in televised games next fall despite expected National Collegiate Athletic Association sanctions, according to a published report.

title: RCA SOURCE CONFIRMS FIRESTONE TALKS ON HERTZ
description: A Wall Street source close to the RCA Corporation confirmed yesterday that the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company was a leading candidate to buy the Hertz Corporation from RCA.

title: U.S. TEAM WINS
description: The United States men's and women's 200-meter medley relay teams each posted American record times tonight in a decisive victory over West Germany in a swimming meet at the University of Florida.

title: QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS IN CAREY BUDGET DISPUTE
description: Governor Carey and legislative leaders are locked in a dispute over the state's $27 billion budget. The disagreement has delayed the state's spring borrowing.

title: A Swell Trip
description: There you are, standing on the street corner with the children, your mother and the cocker spaniel. ''We'd better get a Checker,'' you say and start waving.

title: O.& M. Gets Gallo Corporate Business
description: The E.& J. Gallo Winery, in addition to the assignment to Needham, Harper & Steers, Chicago, has also formalized its relationship with Ogilvy & Mather, San Francisco, by announcing that it has become its agency for corporate advertising and promotion of varietal wines and special projects.

title: Saturday: Kings Rally to Win
description: Daryl Evans scored at 2 minutes 35 seconds of overtime Saturday night as the Los Angeles Kings rallied from a 5-0 deficit to score a 6-5 victory over the Edmonton Oilers.

title: U.S.-SOVIET AID IMBALANCE IN THE CARIBBEAN
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LOOKING BACK

title: NATION'S HOG FARMERS REGAINING PROFITABILITY
description: The only bright spot in the gloomy array of farm prices this week was the lowly hog, that most productive of meat-making machines, and highly efficient pork producers like Don Newby were once again seeing profits coming their way.

title: Advertising; New Y.&R.  Unit's Key: Packaging
description: TRY this thesis out for size: The services that provide the nonrational inducements to purchase products will be those that grow the fastest, as constantly improving technology makes easily advertised, exclusive product benefits rare.

title: CALIFORNIA FACING ECONOMIC TROUBLE
description: The combined effects of the national recession and four years of cutting state taxes are causing deepening financial problems for state and local governments in California.

title: Ferruccio Furlanetto In 'I Vespri Siciliani'
description: There were some new and recent arrivals Saturday night in the Metropolitan Opera's ''I Vespri Siciliani'' by Verdi. Thomas Fulton conducted; Ferruccio Furlanetto sang Procida, and Vasile Moldoveanu appeared as Arrigo.

title: Arts Academy in Rome Elects John W. Hylan Jr.
description: The American Academy in Rome has elected its first chairman from the corporate sector. He is John W. Hylan Jr., vice chairman of Warburg Paribas Becker-A.G. Becker, international investment bankers.

title: BENEFIT 'INDEXING' IS FACING SCRUTINY
description: Of all the problems facing Congress in its attempt to write a budget, none are considered more intractable or politically explosive than the automatic cost-of-living adjustments built into Social Security and other Federal benefit programs.

title: EAST GERMAN PASTORS PROTEST BAN ON PACIFIST BADGES
description: A letter read by Protestant ministers at Easter Sunday services in East Berlin and in neighboring areas of East Germany today accused the Communist authorities of alienating young people by refusing to allow them to wear badges and armbands advocating disarmament.

title: MOON IN TOKYO, TIDE IN TEXAS
description: Friction is increasing in the trade relations of Japan, Europe, and the United States, igniting small fires of protectionism that the Administration and foreign governments are trying hard to douse.

title: RELATIONSHIPS
description: IN the eyes of the Internal Revenue Service, Ellen Shall and Steve Kelban are ''married filing j ointly.'' They have a happy marriage, except for certain dark weeks i mmediately preceding April 15. That is when she produces a complete s et of her tax records, in color-coded folders, and he begins r ooting sheepishly in the pockets of his raincoat for his records.

title: FUND-RAISERS FEATURE WALL-TO-WALL LOBBYISTS
description: James Barr is a lobbyist for the Credit Union National Association. He likes to talk to Congressmen. Billy Lee Evans is a Congressman. He likes to get campaign contributions. When James Barr and other lobbyists pushed for a bankruptcy bill last year, Billy Lee Evans, a Georgia Democrat, introduced one. And when Billy Lee Evans asked Mr. Barr to attend his $250-a-head fundraiser the other night, Mr. Barr repaid the favor.

title: West's All-Stars Win Aloha Classic
description: Ricky Frazier of Missouri and Trent Tucker of Minnesota scored 19 points each Saturday night and led the Midwest All-Stars to a 95-90 victory over the South in the final of the 14th annual Aloha Classic basketball tournament.

title: AT EMPIRE'S OLD OUTPOSTS, BRITONS ARE STIRRED
description: Within the pink painted walls of the Muthaiga Club here the other day, they brought out an atlas, first to check just where the Falkland Islands are, and second to plan strategy.

title: Hudson's Bay Rating Cut
description: Moody's Investors Service Inc. said Friday that it had lowered its rating on the senior debentures of the Hudson's Bay Oil and Gas Company to B from A.

title: Dioxin Found In Hooker Landfill
description: Low concentrations of dioxin, a highly toxic component of the herbicide Agent Orange, have been found at an industrial waste landfill on the site of a Hooker Chemicals and Plastics Corporation plant in the Buffalo suburb of North Tonawanda, N.Y., company and state officials reported yesterday.

title: DIPLOMATIC WORLD BANK CHIEF
description: A.W. Clausen's first official act last July 1 was to rearrange the in and out boxes on an outsized desk in a gargantuan office 12 stories above Pennsylvania Avenue.

title: Cuomo Criticizes Koch View on Tax
description: Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo yesterday denounced as ''the worst governmental act I have seen in four years'' a bill to repeal a realestate tax, and again criticized Mayor Koch's support of the measure.

title: Green Jacket For a Walrus
description: JUST as Jack Nicklaus settled into a wooden armchair on the platform in the Masters interview room Saturday, a nearby TV set showed Craig Stadler holing a putt on the 18th green. For the touring pro known as The Walrus, it was his third consecutive birdie in a round of 67 that suddenly gave him a three-stroke lead entering yesterday's final round.

title: Fund-Raising 'Undinner' to Aid Starving Somali
description: Fund-raising dinners are among the most common means of supporting worthy causes, but who ever heard of a fund-raising ''undinner''? That's what Dr. Irma B. Jaffe, a professor of fine arts at Fordham University, has dreamed up to raise money for the starving people of Somalia. Proceeds will be channeled through the United Nations Children's Fund and CARE.

title: OPENER COMES UP HALF EMPTY
description: A mound of soiled snow beyond the outfield fence and a first-ball ceremony honoring the groundskeepers were the only physical reminders yesterday of the blizzard that had delayed the start of the season at Yankee Stadium for nearly a week.

title: Thieves Break Into L.I. Bank And Rifle Safe-Deposit Boxes
description: Thieves broke through the roof of a bank here sometime this morning, cut lines to the telephoneand alarm system and then rifled more than 100 safe-deposit boxes, the police said.

title: Fastener Inquiry Set
description: At the request of the Pentagon, the Department of Commerce will investigate whether imports of Japanese nuts, bolts and other industrial fasteners are undermining an industry the United States needs for its defense, the department said Friday. Special duties on such fasteners expired in January. More than $1 billion worth of nuts, bolts and large screws alone were sold in the United States in 1980.

title: SALVADORAN STATUS QUO
description: To the Editor:

title: News Analysis
description: ''For the first time since the founding of the Federal Republic of Germany, anti-German feelings with deep and farreaching effects are apparent in the United States.''

title: COUPLE CHARGED IN DEATH OF BOY, 5
description: A Queens man and his wife were arrested and charged with seconddegree murder yesterday after the man led detectives to the body of his 5-year-old stepson in a vacant lot in Brooklyn, the Queens District Attorney said.

title: Five-Day Wrecking Operation Finally Brings Down Building
description: On the sixth attempt by a wrecking crew, the brick walls of a cold-storage building came tumbling down Thursday, weakened by 550 sticks of dynamite and finished off by a 2,600-pound steel wrecking ball.

title: MEXICO'S GLOOMY ECONOMY
description: Mexico's confidence in its economic and political system has been badly shaken by the collapse of its currency in mid-February.

title: STAGE: 'PASTORALE,' A FRESH COMEDY
description: AS befits a work titled ''Pastorale,'' Deborah Eisenberg's comedy at the Second Stage is a blast of fresh air. I don't know where Miss Eisenberg comes from - it could be another planet -but she has the most original, not to mention the funniest, new comic voice to be heard in a New York theater since Beth Henley arrived with ''Crimes of the Heart.'' And while it's also true that ''Pastorale'' is slight and imperfect, why not laugh now and think later? Miss Eisenberg's lapses are the forgivable ones of a first-time playwright, and you're going to want to say you knew her when.

title: CAPITAL VIEW: CARTER STILL AN OUTSIDER
description: Former Treasury Secretary John B. Connally was introduced to the Commodity Club of Washington recently as a man who had served every President since Franklin D. Roosevelt except Jimmy Carter. With the mention of Mr. Carter's name, Mr. Connally, a Republican convert under Richard Nixon, tightened his jowls and began vigorously nodding his head. The business group roared with laughter.

title: Civil Rights Leaders Set March for Voting Rights
description: Two civil rights leaders, the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Dr. Joseph Lowery, presented plans today for a five-state march from Tuskegee, Ala., to Washington to urge extension of the Voting Rights Act of 1965.

title: Nighthawks Take 4-Overtime Game
description: It took more than six hours, but Warren Holmes scored at 14 minutes 8 seconds of the fourth overtime period Saturday night to end the longest game in American Hockey League history and give the New Haven Nighthawks a 3-2 victory over the Rochester Americans in their Calder Cup quarterfinal playoff series.

title: WHITNEY COULD LOSE CALDER 'CIRCUS'
description: The Whitney Museum of American Art is in danger of losing ''Circus,'' the major work by Alexander Calder that has long been on loan to the museum, because of tax obligations incurred by the Calder estate to France and the United States.

title: POLISH ARCHBISHOP ASKS FOR ACCORD
description: As Poles celebrated a somber Easter under martial law, the Roman Catholic Primate, Archbishop Jozef Glemp, voiced hope that a reconciliation between the people and their rulers could still be achieved.

title: Thomson Organization To Buy Titsch Titles
description: International Thomson Business Press, a subsidiary of the International Thomson Organization, will be acquiring its 20th trade publication company on April 20.

title: 160 Missing in Burma In Sinking of Ferry
description: More than 160 people were reported missing and presumed drowned today after a ferry capsized near the town of Henzada, sources from the area of the accident reported.

title: ISLANDERS BEATEN
description: The Rangers were outshot, outskated and generally outplayed by the Philadelphia Flyers tonight, but their marksmanship and goaltending were so superb that they won the game, 7-5, and their Patrick Division playoff series, 3 games to 1.

title: MISS NAVRATILOVA TAKES FINAL, 6-4, 6-2
description: ''Who says I can't play on clay?'' Martina Navratilova quipped proudly, after beating Andrea Jaeger, 6-4, 6-2, today in the final of the $200,000 Family Circle Cup.

title: It's One Concert After Another for Kathleen Battle; Busy Season for Singer
description: It's not unusual for good singers to be in great demand, but not many have been as busy this season as Kathleen Battle, who since the end of January has appeared in four operas at the Metropolitan as well as the three-concert Music From Ravinia series at Alice Tully Hall and even found time for the New York Philharmonic's 10,000th concert.

title: JAPAN ATTEMPTS TO HASTEN ECONOMY'S REVIVAL
description: Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki has given his Cabinet ministers three weeks to develop measures for reviving Japan's stagnant economy.

title: Stop Family Trouble Before It Starts
description: In a recent cover story, Newsweek describes the ''feminization of poverty'' - the growing number of poor families headed by women. The trend, underway for more than a decade, helps generate severe social problems, including educational failure, crime and dependency.

title: Football Player Stars in Relays
description: Three days of competition in the 16th Dogwood Relays ended Saturday with almost 2,000 athletes having participated at the University of Tennessee campus.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: Pistons, Playoff Hopes Slim, Top Knicks
description: Kelly Tripucka scored 22 points and John Long added 18 as the Detroit Pistons fought off the New York Knicks, 97-89, tonight and kept alive their faint hope of making the National Basketball Association playoffs.

title: ARGENTINE ANTI-SEMITES
description: Ant i-Semitism in Argentina is like somber background noise: Few pay attention to it, but everyone knows it is there. Many Argentine Jews were, therefore, surprised when, in late February, President Leopoldo Galtieri denounced the desecration of the Jewish cemetery in Mar del Plata, about 240 miles from Buenos Aires. Some think that this may signal a change in policy, but recent measures taken by the Galtieri Government offer little conclusive proof of a real change.

title: JAPANESE UPSET BY CRITICISM IN U.S. OF TRADE IMBALANCE
description: The Japanese are becoming increasingly sensitive to criticism of their surplus in trade with the United States. The Japanese press has been giving front-page coverage to hearings on trade in Congressional committees since early March. The hearings attracted modest attention in the American press.

title: THRIFTIER LIFESAVING
description: To the Editor:

title: Lowell Edwards Dead at 84; Co-developer of Heart Valve
description: Lowell Edwards, the co-developer of a mechanical heart valve that is widely used in open heart surgery, died Thursday. He was 84 years old and maintained residences here and in Santa Ana, Calif.

title: Daryl Sherman, Pianist And Singer, in Village
description: Daryl Sherman has moved into the Music Room of the Horn of Plenty, Bleecker at Charles Streets, where Blossom Dearie, John Wallawitch and Dardanelle have preceded her in cocktail-hour concerts that start at 6:30 P.M. Miss Sherman, like her predecessors, is a singing pianist who also writes songs.

title: MUNCIE FINDS FILM ON STUDENTS A DISTORTED MIRROR
description: With one sociological study or another under way at almost any given time in this ''typical'' Middle Western city, residents have nearly become inured to being scrutinized like laboratory mice.

title: Peking Reports Border Firing
description: China accused Vietnam today of firing on Chinese vehicles near the Yunnan Province border, killing a militia officer. The New China News Agency said Vietnamese troops opened fire Friday on a highway near the border, killing the militiaman, wounding a worker and damaging a car and truck.

title: Bobby Thomson Named 'Sportsman of Year'
description: For 20 years in his hometown of Watchung, N.J., Bobby Thomson has been active with the Watchung Optimists Club, a youth-oriented organization that encourages grade school boys and girls to participate in athletics.

title: People
description: * William K. Hoag has been named a senior vice president and media director of Creamer Inc/New York.

title: Aide to Governor Is Angered By a Report in Boston Globe
description: Gerard Morris, press secretary to Gov. Edward J. King of Massachusetts, says that he and other aides have stopped talking to Boston Globe reporters because of an article the newspaper printed about Mr. King's vacation to Florida, The Globe has reported.

title: Sabres Eliminated by Bruins
description: Peter McNab and Terry O'Reilly scored two goals each tonight as the Boston Bruins beat the Buffalo Sabres, 5-2, to win their Adams Division first-round playoff series, 3 games to 1.

title: MONDAY, APRIL 12, 1982; The Economy
description: Steelmakers are bracing for what may be their worst year since the 1974-75 recession. With the steel market rapidly deteriorating, industry economists now say that shipments in 1982 could drop to 80 million tons, or even lower, from the 87 million tons that had been projected only last January. (Page D1.)

title: Liberia's Leader Lifts Curfew To Mark Anniversary of Coup
description: Liberia's military ruler, Samuel K. Doe, has temporarily lifted curfew restrictions to mark the second anniversary of the coup that brought his People's Redemption Council to power.

title: PRESIDENT AT THE BANK OF COMMERCE
description: Robert R. Brina, 64, has been elected president and chief operating officer of the Bank of Commerce in New York. As president, he succeeds Russell L. Weiss, 51, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer.

title: FOREMOST APPOINTS CHEMICAL UNIT HEAD
description: Barry B. Blocker, 44 years old, has been named president of the chemical group of Foremost-McKesson Inc., based in San Francisco. He succeeds George Ditz Jr., 65, who is retiring as head of the unit, a major chemical distributor and recycler of solvents.

title: FORMER CHIEF OF AMAX RETIRING AS A DIRECTOR
description: Ian MacGregor, the former chief executive officer of Amax Inc., a diversified mining and energy development company based in Greenwich, Conn., will retire as a director in October at the age of 70, according to the proxy statement for the May 6 annual meeting.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: No Consolation

title: ISRAEL'S THREE PROMISES
description: Israel has three promises outstanding, made to its neighbors and its own people.

title: RED SOX SET BACK ORIOLES, 6-0
description: Carney Lansford drove in four runs, and John Tudor pitched a six-hitter today as the Boston Red Sox posted a 6-0 victory over the Baltimore Orioles.

title: Commodities; Protecting Commodity Brokerages
description: PROTECTING the investor-speculator from manipulators and other unethical elements has long been the reason given by the Federal Government why it must regulate all commodity and securities markets, and even the kinds of goods and services traded on these exchanges.

title: THE REGION
description: A police officer was shot today by a gunman firing out of a car, but the officer's bulletproof vest stopped three bullets, the police said.

title: CALIFORNIA'S EDGE ON CLEANING THE AIR
description: To the Editor:

title: DENVER SEEKS TO TAX NEWSPAPER SALES
description: The city of Denver has become the latest battle site in a longrunning war between newspapers and tax collectors seeking to collect on sales of individual copies.

title: SUBS SEEN AS GIVING EDGE TO BRITISH IF CLASH OCCURS
description: Should Argentine naval vessels venture into the 200-mile ''maritime exclusion zone'' around the Falkland Islands, Britain's hunter-killer submarines are likely to have a considerable edge in any encounter, military experts said today.

title: Market Place; Cautious Way To Pick Stock
description: WILLIAM J. RUANE has not changed his basic investment philosophy in 30 years of buying stocks. He finds fewer bargains in stocks now that passive investments yield several times what they once did. Since 1950, for instance, yields on long-term Governments have risen to 14 percent from 3 percent, and those on tax-free municipals have reached 11 percent, up from 1 percent.

title: A RESCUE IN OHIO VIA HABEAS CORPUS
description: To the Editor:

title: News Summary; MONDAY, APRIL 12, 1982
description: International Britain's blockade of the Falklands became effective. Its Navy was ready to fire on any Argentine warship that approached its 200-mile zone around the disputed archipelago. It appeared increasingly unlikely that the Argentine fleet intended to enter the area, where nuclear-powered submarines were stationed. (Page A1, Column 6.) Alexander M. Haig Jr. flew to London from Buenos Aires with some negotiating ''ideas'' as the deadline approached for the British blockade of the Falkland Islands. Argentine officials and foreign diplomats in Buenos Aires were not optimistic about the prospects of a settlement based on the negotiation positions the Secretary of State was taking to London. One includes a simulataneous pullback of the British Navy and a withdrawal of Argentine forces, but only after Britian recognizes Argentine sovereignty. (A1:4-5.)

title: REASONS CITED FOR OVRTIME BY FIRE DEPT.
description: A look at Fire Department overtime, which jumped last year from $25.4 million to $39.3 million and is expected to stay at that level this year, illustrates some of the problems faced by a city agency in controlling such costs.

title: FORECASTS WORSENING FOR STEEL
description: The steel industry is facing a rapidly deteriorating market that may turn out to be the worst in nearly two decades, according to newly revised forecasts.

title: DR. ROBERT HAVEMANN, EAST GERMAN PHYSICIST
description: Robert Havemann, a physicist who was one of East Germany's best known intellectual dissidents, died Friday at his East Berlin home from a heart and kidney ailment, the West German newspaper Frankfurter Rundschau said Saturday. He was 72 years old.

title: Borg Won't Play In French Open
description: Bjorn Borg, a six-time French champion, has decided not to enter the clay-court tournament next month because of a ruling that would force him to go through the qualifying round, his coach, Lennart Bergelin, said today.

title: BRIEFING
description: One More for the Gipper

title: THEATER: 'LETTERS TO BEN,' A MUSICAL
description: TWO years after her husband's death, Beverly Stone is still unable to make an adjustment to single life, and in exasperation she asks, ''How did Alma Werfel Gropius Mahler swing this?'' This is a legitimate question, but Charles Choset, author, composer and lyricist of ''Letters to Ben,'' a new musical at the Theater for the New City, skirts the issue and goes on to another pallid chapter in the life of a wan New York widow.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We decided in the end that he started the fire so he could put it out and be a hero.'' - Anthea Frankl, member of jury that convicted Luis Marin of arson and murder in deaths of 26 at Stouffer's Inn.

title: 2 Missing Atlanta Blacks Not Tied to 28 Others
description: Two young black men disappeared last month, but no evidence links their cases to a string of 28 slayings and disappearances that occurred here in a span of almost two years, the police said today.

title: Police Halt Basque Rallies
description: Policemen fired tear gas and rubber bullets today to break up unau@thorized demonstrations in northern Spain marking Basque Day. About 100 youths barricaded streets in San Sebastian before they were dispersed by the police.

title: BRIEFING
description: Report Card Time

title: A Long Wait and a Long Day
description: EASTER Sunday - six days after the 1982 baseball season began - and the Yankees finally appeared, resplendent in their blue bonnets. After the blizzard and hoarfrost of early April that had kept them underground and under covers, the Yankees were given a weather reprieve. Irving Berlin might have written a sonnet.

title: STADLER DEFEATS POHL IN PLAYOFF
description: Craig Stadler won the 46th Masters today on the first hole of a playoff with Dan Pohl after seeing a sixstroke dwindle to zero on the back nine.

title: AN AMERICAN PRIORITY
description: To the Editor:

title: A MOVEMENT TO DISARM PART OF EUROPE
description: To the Editor:

title: 6 PLACES JOIN U.S. SEVERE UNEMPLOYMENT LIST
description: The Government has designated 1,151 counties and cities as suffering from persistent high unemployment, a move that gives employers there preference for bidding on Federal contracts.

title: ARAFAT, EXPECTING AN ATTACK, SAYS HE WON'T BREAK TRUCE FIRST
description: Yasir Arafat, the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, said today that he expected an Israeli attack ''within hours, maybe 24 to 48 hours,'' but said that Palestinian guerrillas would not be the ones to break the United Nations cease-fire.

title: KNICKS' GAME PLAN: CHANGES FROM TOP TO BOTTOM
description: THE Knicks' loss to Boston at Madison Square Garden the other day made a statistical certainty of what had already seemed virtually certain for weeks: For the fifth time in the last eight seasons, since retirements broke up a rock-solid club that featured Willis Reed, Dave DeBusschere and Jerry Lucas, New York will not be going to the playoffs. This season's failure was particularly disappointing, inasmuch as the team had won 50 games only a year before and had made several player moves during the offseason that were designed to insure playoff contention.

title: Washington Watch; The Battle Over Numbers
description: WASHINGTON MALCOLM BALDRIGE, the Commerce Secretary, is fighting what he concedes is a losing battle to halt dissemination of the ''flash'' change in the Gross National Product usually published around the 20th day of the third month of each quarter.

title: DEBT TO PARAPLEGIC COULD SHUT TOWN
description: This mile-square enclave of mostly Mexican-American heritage, surrounded by the city of Tucson, finds its municipal existence threatened by a debt to one man that is bigger than its annual budget.

title: Philadelphia to Convert Trash Into Electricity
description: Philadelphia will build a $125 million plant to convert municipal trash into steam to generate electricity, Mayor William J. Green said today. The city says it expects to save $210 million in waste disposal costs in the next 20 years by selling most of the steam to the naval shipyard here.

title: AMERICAN SECURITY BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
BRIEFING
description: Not Express Mail

title: MATRIX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: B-After $7,000 loss from discontinued operations

title: FIRST OHIO BANCSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
OPERA: EVE QUELER OFFERS 'NERONE'
description: ARRIGO BOITO'S ''Nerone'' is a legendary monster of an opera that any admirer of the composer would be thankful to hear once. Eve Queler and her Opera Orchestra of New York lured the fabled beast out of hiding Monday night and put it on display at Carnegie Hall in a concert version that evidently was its first American appearance in any form.

title: The U.N. Today; April 13, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee on Non-Use of Force in International Relations - 10:30 A.M.

title: Rapist Gets 7 to 15 Years
description: A man convicted of raping an 11-year-old girl was sentenced today to 7 to 15 years in prison.

title: WESTINGHOUSE ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt TIME FOR FRANKIE COOLIN. By Bill Griffith. 269 pages. Random House. $13.50. THE PATRIOT GAME. By George V. Hig- gins. 237 pages. Knopf. $12.95.

title: BRIEFING
description: Air (Force One) Fares

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I enjoy proving the experts wrong.'' - Nicholas F. Brady, named to be United States Senator from New Jersey. (B5:4.)

title: PITTSBURGH NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The shr earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split

title: Auto Output Is Seen Falling
description: Production of cars in the United States in the 1982 model year will be the lowest in almost 25 years, Ward's Automotive Reports, an auto industry trade journal, said today.

title: URBAN SCHOOLS SHORT OF SUBSTITUTE TEACHERS
description: An unexpected shortage of substitute teachers is troubling schools in New York City and other urban centers around the United States. It is forcing principals to search desperately each day for replacements for absent teachers and it often disrupts the normal education of students.

title: QUIET SENATOR FROM NEW JERSEY
description: At the 1980 Republican National Convention, after Ronald Reagan had been nominated and it was time to pick a running mate, a delegate from New Jersey stepped up to the microphone to announce the state delegation's unanimous support for George Bush.

title: RANGERS FORESEE TOUGHER JOB AHEAD
description: After they clinched their Stanley Cup division playoff round by defeating the Philadelphia Flyers, 7-5, on Sunday night at the Spectrum, the Rangers were more exhausted than elated.

title: EAGLES IN JERSEY ACCEPT LAB-BORN CHICK
description: The small symbol of the Republic is safe now, nestled to the body of its nursemaid 80 feet off the ground in the tower of a pine at the edge of Bear Swamp. Earlier today there was some doubt about their meeting, some fear the one might reject the other. Perhaps even kill it.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Folk Cure For the Seasick
description: Mothers and grandmothers sometimes prescribed ginger tea to settle an upset stomach. Now, the findings of recent investigations into the validity of traditional herbal remedies indicate that our ancestors had the right idea, if not the best way to administer it.

title: ARGENTINA FAVORS PROPOSAL BY PERU
description: Argentina has accepted a Peruvian proposal for a 72-hour truce around the Falkland Islands and is waiting for a British response, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said today.

title: Catholic Church Is Reopened In the Chinese City of Qingdao
description: The Roman Catholic Church of St. Michael in Qingdao, Shandong Province, reopened with an Easter Sunday mass, the official New China News Agency said today.

title: Driver Sentenced In Deaths of Boys
description: On his last working day as a judge, Acting Justice Patrick W. McGinley of State Supreme Court yesterday sentenced one man to 50 years to life for the deaths of two 10-year-old boys last summer and another man to 75 years to life for a 1980 crime spree.

title: MOBILE HOME INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
SKETCHES OF PULITZER PRIZE WINNERS
description: Public Service

title: Metals Prices Weaken In a Lackluster Market
description: Precious metals futures prices retreated yesterday as traders became cautious in the absence of any guidance from the European commodity markets on the Falkland Islands crisis and rising Middle East tensions. The European markets were closed for Easter Monday.

title: RIGGS NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
DIAMOND SHAMROCK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Including an extraordinary credit of $35,548,000 from an exchange of equity for debt...C-After a loss of $9,656,000 from discontinued operations

title: Chrysler's Cash At $900 Million
description: The Chrysler Corporation finished last month with $900 million in cash and marketable securities on hand, the highest end-of-the-month total in its history, officials said.

title: U.S. SEEKS COMPROMISE ON JORDAN ARMS SALES
description: The Reagan Administration is preparing a compromise to the issue of arms sales to Jordan under which the United States would decline to sell mobile antiaircraft missiles or advanced jet fighters but would permit Jordan to buy other newly developed fighters, according to Administration officials.

title: JURY GETS BANK ROBBERY CASE
description: A Federal jury began today deliberating charges that a 42-year-old mother of six helped Christopher Boyce, the convicted spy, plan or commit a string of bank robberies in the Northwest.

title: NORPAC EXPLORATION SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
ABBOTT LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-After foreign currency translation losses of $5,348,000 for the latest first qr and $4,302,000 for the yr ago first qr; the yr-ago shr earnings have been restated for a 2-for-1 stock split effective in May 1981

title: WHIRLPOOL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-After $833,000 loss from discontinued operations

title: New 30-Month Certificate Rate
description: The maximum rate on 30-month certificates will increase today to 14.35 percent from 14.3 percent at thrift institutions, and to 14.1 percent from 14.05 percent at commercial banks, the Treasury Department announced yesterday.

title: IF THERE WERE RATINGS FOR ENVOY SELECTION
description: To the Editor:

title: A KING'S RETURN TO COURT
description: WHEN he first appeared at Wimbledon with his long blond hair, colorful headbands and choir-boy features, Bjorn Borg became the ''teen angel'' to squealingly adoring British school girls. Now that the 25-year-old Swede sits on the fringes of the forest, after a five-month layoff, he is being branded in some quarters of the international tennis kingdom as a recalcitrant Robin Hood.

title: ELEGANCE BACK IN DAYTIME WEAR
description: Judging from New Yorkers strolling uptown, downtown and at various points in between, the odds are very high that the fashionable man this spring will want to look as if he gets his fashion cues from Channel 13 and Hollywood. All of a sudden, it seems, many men are wearing the type of intentionally thought-out clothes that nearly stole the show from the actors in ''Brideshead Revisited'' and ''Chariots of Fire.''

title: BOTSWANA'S BRIGHT PICTURE SHADOWED BY 2 WORRIES
description: It is arid, remote and hugely dependent on transport outlets through white-ruled South Africa, but landlocked Botswana has a lot to show for 16 years of independence.

title: Earth Tremor in Japan
description: An earthquake shook the Japanese main island of Honshu today, registering an intensity of one on the Japanese scale of seven, the Meteorological Agency said. There were no immediate reports of casualties or damage. The epicenter was on the border between Ibaraki and Chiba prefectures.

title: IRVING BANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The yr-ago first qr results include a net gain of $4.8 million on the redemption of certain Penn Central securities

title: E.P.A. CHIEF ASSAILED ON LEAD VIOLATION
description: The Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, Anne M. Gorsuch, privately promised a small oil refinery that it would not be penalized if it violated Federal lead standards, according to sworn testimony in a report by the agency's inspector general.

title: CHILD-FREE LIVING
description: As will happen when a group of older people gets together, conversation on a recent afternoon at the card tables turned to grandchildren.

title: CEDAR RAPIDS FINDS SMALL CONSOLATION IN HARD TIMES: TAX BILLS ARE LOWER
description: The moment of reckoning with the Internal Revenue Service arrives Thursday, and a lot of business people around here are finding that the tax bite is not very painful this year, unfortunately.

title: ADVANCED MICRO DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 28
description: B-Including tax credits of $2.8 million for the qr and $5.6 million for the yr

title: Uniformed Group Seeks 15% Raises
description: Philip Caruso, president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, announced yesterday that the uniformed coalition of city employees would seek an annual pay increase of 15 percent in coming negotiations with the city. The group is also seeking an additional increase of 10 percent over base pay for ''hazardous'' duty, an annual cost-of-living adjustment and fully paid health insurance to meet current medical and surgical costs.

title: BRIEFING
description: Family Finances

title: New Rennoc Head Sees Strong Year for Sales
description: The Rennoc Corporation is a major manufacturer of fabric-based Christmas decorations that was founded in 1954 and entered its present line of business seven years later. Now Donald J. Martin, 53, has joined this producer of Christmas stockings and other ornaments as president, succeeding Richard W. Conner, 58, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer.

title: Ban on Twain's 'Finn' Rescinded in Virginia
description: A superintendent ruled today that Mark Twain's ''The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn'' should remain part of the curriculum of an intermediate school that had banned the book after a committee called it racist.

title: O'SULLIVAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Shr earnings for the latest yr reflect a 25 percent stock divd paid in Aug 1981

title: CACI GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
P.L.O. IS ON ALERT IN LEBANON
description: Palestinian guerrillas remained on alert today, despite reports that Israel had made no decision to invade Lebanon.

title: Suit Is Threatened Over Marijuana
description: A group committed to the relaxation of marijuana laws said Sunday it will ask a Federal appeals court to order Government agencies to release marijuana for medical purposes.

title: BYRD FACING A RE-ELECTION THREAT BY 'SLEEPER' IN WEST VIRGINIA
description: ''I think my opponent should apologize, not to me, but to the people of West Virginia,'' Senator Robert C. Byrd told a cheering meeting of the Ohio County Democratic organization last night. ''If they can drag down the leader of the Senate Democrats, they'll be back to drag you down.''

title: TUESDAY, APRIL 13, 1982; The Economy
description: Retail sales fell 0.5 percent last month, the Commerce Department said, and they are likely to stay sluggish in the second quarter, Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige predicted. The results contrasted with a 2.6 percent rise in February that apparently only temporarily stemmed two previous declines. (Page D1.) February installment debt grew by only $75 million in February as consumers reduced credit purchases because of the recession. The rise, at an annual rate of gain of less than 0.5 percent, compared with an annual growth rate of 6.8 percent a year earlier. (D8.)

title: Dempsey, in Hospital, Is Reported to Be Stable
description: Jack Dempsey, the former heavyweight boxing champion, was listed in stable condition last night after being admitted to the hospital Sunday with an undisclosed ailment.

title: JUDGE REJECTS HIRING OF 'OBSERVERS' AT TEAMSTERS' CONSTRUCTION SITES
description: A Federal judge has overturned an arbitrator's ruling that would have required contractors at city construction sites to hire teamsters' union ''observers.''

title: Salvadoran Refugees Challenge U.S. Stand
description: Lawyers for three Salvadoran refugees seeking political asylum in the United States said at a deportation hearing today that they would raise issues that would challenge the Government's refusal to grant political asylum to most Salvadorans.

title: Chess: A Way to Get Into Trouble And to Avoid Getting Out
description: It has been said that it takes two mistakes to lose a game: the one that got you into trouble and the one that spoiled your chance to get out of it.

title: CAROLINA FREIGHT CARRIERS CORP reports earnings for 12 weeks to Mar 27
NATIONAL STATE BANK (ELIZABETH, NJ) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
FED SHIFT ON MONEY SUPPLY DUE
description: The Federal Reserve Board tentatively decided today to change the way it reports weekly money supply numbers, in an effort to lessen their impact on the nation's financial markets.

title: KHOMEINI FACTION CHALLENGED BY MORE CONSERVATIVE GROUP
description: The Shiite Moslem clergymen around Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, having crushed their moderate, secular opposition, are now themselves coming under sharp challenge from a yet more conservative group of mullahs.

title: Seychelles Sets Trial Date
description: A court in the Seychelle Islands set June 16 for the trial of seven mercenaries, including a woman, who could face the death penalty for treason in a bungled coup last year.

title: ARGENTINE DEBT IN U.S. IS WORRISOME $9 BILLION
description: American banks have more than $9 billion on loan to the Government and residents of Argentina, and a spot-check yesterday showed that many were deeply concerned about the economic effects of Argentina's conflict with Britain over the Falkland Islands.

title: SUBURBAN BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Mexican Sales Of Oil Decline
description: Mexico is struggling to maintain crude oil exports at a million barrels a day despite its recent easing of purchase terms, Petroleum Intelligence Weekly said in yesterday's issue.

title: RAWLEY EXCELS
description: In a game that almost got away from the Yankees despite a 10-1 eighth-inning lead, 14 hits and home runs by Willie Randolph and Dave Winfield, Shane Rawley proved his worth to his new team tonight. Rawley struck out the final two Texas batters to save New York's 10-7 victory over the Rangers.

title: UNITEL VIDEO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
SUITS SEEK ASSETS OF LEWELLYN
description: A number of lawsuits have been filed in an effort to attach the assets of Gary Lewellyn, the 33-year-old fugitive stockbroker. He is accused of having manipulated the stock price of Safeguard Scientifics Inc., piling up millions of dollars in brokerage house debts.

title: SYMPTOMS OF THE 'PALACE MENTALITY'
description: It is called the palace mentality and it affects those who work in America's most exclusive office complex, twisting their personalities while they are there and transforming their lives when they leave. And even now, less than two years after the Reagan Administration moved into those corridors of power, several staff members are wondering whether what they are doing in the White House is worth what the White House is doing to them.

title: O.A.S. UNABLE TO AGREE ON FALKLAND RESOLUTION
description: The Organization of American States failed today to agree on a resolution about the crisis in the Falkland Islands, which Argentina seized from Britain 10 days ago.

title: ONLY PENGUIN OWNER GAVE UP
description: After the Islanders had overwhelmed the Pittsburgh Penguins by scores of 8-1 and 7-2 in the first two games of their first-round playoff series last week, Edward J. DeBartolo Sr., the Penguins' angered owner, refused to attend Saturday's third game, at Pittsburgh's Civic Arena, and offered a refund to any ticketholder who wanted one.

title: RPM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
LENNY BAKER, 37, STAGE ACTOR
description: Lenny Baker, who won a Tony award in 1977 for his performance in the Broadway musical ''I Love My Wife'' and who starred in the movie ''Next Stop, Greenwich Village,'' died of cancer yesterday in a hospital in Hallandale, Fla. He was 37 years old.

title: PROBLEMS REMAIN
description: Hopes for a breakthrough in the Falkland Island crisis faded today when Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said after 11 hours of talks with British leaders that ''a number of substantial difficulties remain.''

title: 3 WORKERS FOR CBS ARE SHOT TO DEATH
description: Three CBS employees were shot to death last night when they stumbled upon the abduction of a woman in a rooftop parking lot on a pier on Manhattan's West Side, the police reported.

title: 2 Win Onassis Awards
description: A French physician who organizes medical relief for victims of international disasters and a Greek archeologist who discovered the tomb of Philip of Macedonia have won $100,000 awards from the Alexander Onassis Foundation.

title: COMMERCE BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
RADIO SOLIDARITY, ON THE AIR, DEFIES POLISH REGIME
description: In a daring act of resistance to the martial law authorities, a clandestine station calling itself Radio Solidarity made an eight-minute broadcast here today.

title: MEDICARE'S DIMINISHING ROLE AS A BILL PAYER
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Akzona Inc., Asheville, N.C., has appointed Thomas C. Arnold vice president and treasurer and Leslie K. Breiland controller.

title: KOCH ATTACKS CUOMO IN A VISIT TO L.I.
description: In one of the strongest attacks on Mario M. Cuomo, Mayor Koch this evening questioned the Lieutenant Governor's record and suggested that Liberal Party leaders allow the two to compete in the party's primary.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation reported yesterday that a broad decline in demand for aluminum resulted in a loss of $24.9 million for the first quarter of 1982, contrasted with earnings of $68.1 million, or $1.60 a share, in the similar quarter a year earlier. Revenues dropped 12.1 percent, to $733.8 million, from $834.4 million.

title: 30 INJURED IN WEST BANK-GAZA VIOLENCE
description: Violent protests erupted in the Israelioccupied West Bank and Gaza Strip today over the rifle attack by an Israeli soldier on Moslems in the Dome of the Rock Mosque.

title: Cable Health Network Salesmen Are Bullish
description: One of the more interesting aspects of the Cable Health Network, a 24-hour-a-day cable programming service that expects to go on line in June, is that the four guys who are selling it to cable system operators and to advertisers came aboard in a package deal, each taking a pay cut in exchange for a piece of the action.

title: CONSOLIDATED PAPERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
REAGAN TO OFFER A PLAN TO PROVIDE TUITION TAX CREDIT
description: President Reagan plans to announce this week that he will soon propose legislation providing tax credits for families whose children attend private or parochial schools, White House officials said today.

title: Batus Is Target Of Complaints
description: Batus Inc., the American holding company for B.A.T. Industries of Britain, said that complaints had been filed against Batus, Marshall Field & Company and the retailer's directors seeking to halt the pending acquisition of Field by Batus.

title: Clarke Is Among Ten Added to Team Canada
description: Team Canada today added 10 National Hockey League players to the squad that will compete in the world championship tournament.

title: Advertising; Pan Am Begins Campaign
description: PAN AMERICAN WORLD AIRWAYS yesterday initiated its huge worldwide advertising campaign intended to introduce itself, with its increased services, as the experienced airline and to pull it out of the red and into the black.

title: FOR MEMBERS ONLY: A $75-A-DAY DEDUCTION
description: Whether you're Representative Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn, who rents a tiny apartment on Capitol Hill, or Representative Stephen J. Solarz of Brooklyn, who lives with his wife and two children in a sprawling suburban home in Virginia, complete with swimming pool and tennis court, income tax time this year may be less painful.

title: BRIEFING
description: Order in the Court

title: Loss Widens at Fannie Mae
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, the nation's largest purchaser of home loans, reported yesterday that its losses in the first quarter doubled, to $42.8 million, from $21.6 million in the similar period last year.

title: The Full Story of Student Aid
