description: ''We haven't cut loans. We've cut the cost to taxpayers of making these loans available.'' That's how President Reagan responded over the weekend to criticism that his proposed cutbacks in college aid might force thousands of students to drop out of school.

title: SPENDING IS BRISK AT WYMAN-GORDON DESPITE RECESSION
description: Executives at the Wyman-Gordon Company still run their old-line forgings business from a warren of small rooms in a low red brick structure built in 1920. This closely held, conservative company does not care to put funds into fancy high-rise offices.

title: NO. 2 MOTOROLA CLOSES THE GAP
description: For as long as many people in the semiconductor industry can remember, Motorola Inc. has played Avis to Texas Instruments' Hertz. No matter how much harder it tried, Motorola has always been a relatively obscure second in worldwide sales to the Dallas giant, which prides itself on having invented the integrated circuit in 1958.

title: ATLANTIC BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
OWNER ATTACKS PLANS
description: The owner of The New York Post, Rupert Murdoch, said yesterday that he would be willing to buy The Daily News in an effort to keep both newspapers publishing. Their present competition, he said, is ''a dance of death which must end with the disappearance of one or both newspapers.''

title: Irving's Earnings Off
description: The Irving Bank Corporation, holding company for the nation's 16thlargest commercial bank, said yesterday that it earned, before securities transactions, $20.5 million, or $2.33 per share, in the first quarter of 1982. This represented a 26.3 percent decline from $27.8 million, or $3.16 per share, earned in the same period last year.

title: HOLDERS MEETING SET ON FLORIDA NATIONAL
description: A Federal District Court ruled today that Florida National Banks of Florida Inc., the target of a two-way takeover contest, must reconvene a shareholders meeting on April 20 because the meeting was improperly ended on Feb. 9 and Feb. 11.

title: IN ARGENTINA, NO SENSE OF A WAR IN THE MAKING
description: Buenos Aires does not have the feel of a city that is about to go to war. Clarin, a tabloid, split its front page today between the news that the Argentine armed forces were ready to ''confront'' the British blockade of the Falkland Islands and a photograph of Guillermo Vilas, the Argentine tennis star, who beat Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia in Monte Carlo.

title: SQUARE D CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The results are restated to reflect the acquisition of Ircon Inc on a pooling of interests basis

title: BUSINESS SCHOOLS CRITICIZED
description: AMERICAN business schools are accused of training too many ''cold'' technicians who know a great deal about corporate strategies but too little about operations in the field where corporations ultimately succeed or fail. Their graduates, it is said, often hurt corporate morale by capturing top management positions denied to people with greater experience down the line.

title: Drug Smuggling Trial Opens for Oil Operator
description: L.J. Balliviero, a prosperous Louisiana oil operator, went on trial today on charges of conspiring to smuggle 185 tons of marijuana into the country through the bayous of southern Louisiana.

title: Oilers Win, 3-2, To Tie Series
description: The Edmonton Oilers staved off playoff elimination tonight, edging the Los Angeles Kings, 3-2, and tying their three-of-five Stanley Cup playoff series at two games apiece behind a goal and assist from Jari Kurri.

title: UNENDING UPS AND DOWNS OVER HEMLINES
description: As the New York designers take the last nips and tucks in the styles for their fall and winter collections, the most important of the year, they are determined to banish hemlines as a touchstone of this or any fashion season.

title: News Analysis
description: The dispute over the Falkland Islands is proving far more intractable than Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. had expected it to be, and there is no assurance that he will be able to find a formula that will avert open hostilities between Argentina and Britain.

title: Chicago Gun Law Spurs Deluge of Applications
description: City workers today began counting and sorting about 15,000 applications from people who want to make their pistols legal under a new city ordinance.

title: Trial Opens in Buffalo Court In Killing of 3 Blacks in 1980
description: The state will produce eyewitnesses and laboratory evidence seeking to link a 26-year-old Army private to three killings of blacks in 1980 in the Buffalo area, a prosecutor said today.

title: DELMED INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a tax credit of $246,000...C-Net loss; the yr ago results reflect an acquisition on a pooling of interests basis

title: MARSHALL & ILSLEY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
KAISER ALUMINUM & CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Including a net gain of $7.3 million or 17 cents a shr from the translation of long-term foreign currency exposures...C-Net income including a net gain of $5.2 million or 12 cents a shr from the translation of long-term foreign currency exposures

title: STATE NATIONAL BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Rose Signs New Pact
description: Pete Rose, closing in on Ty Cobb's major league record for hits, has signed a new contract that will keep him with Philadelphia throughout his pursuit of the mark.

title: McLouth Can Sell Its Trucking Unit
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge allowed the McLouth Steel Corporation to sell its trucking subsidiary to R-W Service System Inc. of Taylor, Mich., for $7 million, an official of the trucking company said.

title: U.S. Agrees to Upgrade Aswan Dam Turbines
description: The United States agreed today to replace and improve the performance of the 12 turbines of the Sovietbuilt Aswan High Dam on the Nile River.

title: CBS-Fox Company Appoints President
description: Stephen Roberts, 43 years old, has been named president of the CBS-Fox Company, the joint venture of CBS Inc. and the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation that was announced in February and is scheduled to be formally instituted early next month. The new partnership, which will have three directors from each concern, will own CBS's 60-acre Studio Center in California's San Fernando Valley, Fox's video cassette and videodisk organization and both corporations' home video efforts.

title: BRIEFING
description: Pushing New Jersey

title: Bread for Garden Circuses
description: Movement at Madison Square Garden these days is not limited to hockey players and trapeze artists. Private management, city government and union leadership have been shifting positions in an effort to save the Garden enough money to persuade the arena's owner, Gulf and Western, to keep the teams playing and the circus in town. Notwithstanding the uncanny talent of the Knicks for dropping games that seem won, the business negotiators may be able to eke out a welcome, if temporary, victory.

title: FOOD STAMPS BILL PROPOSES OPTIONS
description: Jesse Helms, chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee, has introduced a bill to give states the option of using food stamp appropriations for cash grants and other types of assistance instead of food coupons.

title: GOVERNOR VETOES SPENDING LIMIT ON THE WESTWAY
description: A budget restriction that would block hundreds of millions of dollars in financing for the Westway project was vetoed tonight by Governor Carey.

title: CHURCH'S FRIED CHICKEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
MALARIA STILL A WIDESPREAD SCOURGE, BUT HOPE GROWS FOR VACCINE TO DEFEAT IT
description: ALMOST every day, in an old brick building on East 25th Street, research workers sit before microscopes dissecting the salivary glands of mosquitoes.

title: CHILDREN OF DIVORCE GROW UP VOWING 'SAME THING WON'T HAPPEN TO ME'
description: ''MY parents cheated and lied, but I decided never to do that,'' announces a teenager participating in one of several ongoing investigations of divorce. The rapid rise in divorces over the last decade has produced an ever growing number of such experts in marital discord - the children who've seen it at first hand. And many of them, according to the most recent research, declare they will not repeat the mistakes of their parents.

title: Jones Loses Case
description: A San Francisco arbitrator, Sam Kagel, has rejected two grievances that Bert Jones, the Baltimore Colts' quarterback, had filed against Robert Irsay, the team owner.

title: Article 060100 -- No Title
description: A 29-year-old man who was paralyzed when a car in which he was riding crashed into a culvert wall on a state highway was awarded almost $1.9 million today. Judge James C. O'Shea in the State Court of Claims awarded the accident victim, Charles Terwilliger of Kirkwood, $1.5 million for pain and suffering, $325,000 for the loss of potential future earnings and $70,159.96 for medical bills.

title: CONGRESSIONAL INSISTENCE ON A BIG DEFICIT
description: To the Editor:

title: Trade Official To Resign
description: Bill Alberger, chairman of the United States International Trade Commission, today announced his intention to resign effective June 16, opening up a vacancy on the six-member commission during a period of one of its heaviest caseloads.

title: Solving the Rubik's Cube In a Fraction of a Second
description: When children solved the popular Rubik's Cube puzzle in less than a minute, some people thought it could not be done much faster.

title: EX-CURATOR OF NIEMAN FOUNDATION
description: Louis M. Lyons, curator of Harvard University's Nieman Foundation for Journalism for 18 years and a reporter who was a watchdog of the American press, died of malignant lymphoma Sunday at Harvard University's Stillman Infirmary in Cambridge, Mass. He was 84 years old and lived in Cambridge.

title: ISLANDERS' NYSTROM BACK FOR DECISIVE PLAYOFF GAME
description: The Islanders, faced with elimination from the National Hockey League playoffs by the surprising Pittsburgh Penguins, took a calm but serious approach to tonight's deciding game at Nassau Coliseum.

title: FED SEEKS MERGER COMMENT
description: The Federal Reserve Board voted today to call for public comment on the proposed acquisition by the BankAmerica Corporation of Charles Schwab & Company, the nation's largest discount brokerage firm.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Business Day article yesterday about new corporate financing incorrectly stated the rating for the Allied Corporation's $400 million zero-coupon money multiplier notes. They are single-A.

title: THEATER: FRANCISCAN'S 'BELLA FIGURA'
description: JUST when you thought that this theater season had finally reached its breaking point for Roman Catholic plays, along comes ''Bella Figura,'' a new drama by Brother Jonathan, O.S.F., at the Ensemble Studio Theater. But don't ask for deliverance quite yet. If ''Bella Figura'' theoretically resembles its recent predecessors, Brother Jonathan is his own, undogmatic man, and he has written at least half of a lovely work.

title: 16 Enforcers Added
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association has hired 16 retired Federal Bureau of Investigation agents throughout the nation to work part time during the final days of the basketball recruiting season.

title: SCHULMAN, A, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Market Place; Drilling Deals Stress Income
description: ALTHOUGH oil and gas shelters are getting bad reviews, their promoters contend that reports of their demise are premature. The world is in the midst of an oil glut and the pace of exploration and drilling has slowed. Some drilling ventures are in trouble, now that the oil they find brings only $26 a barrel, and while the market for gas is somewhat soft.

title: FMI FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a tax credit of $218,000...C-Including a gain of $44,055 from a credit agreement debt restructure and a tax credit of $2,810,000

title: NATIONAL CITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
CAR MAKERS CREATE NEW INCENTIVES
description: The nation's auto makers, cooling to rebates as a way to stimulate sales in a soft market, are reaching into their bag of marketing tricks for new lures for reluctant buyers.

title: Steel Output Down 7.9%
description: Steel production fell to 1.542 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, down 7.9 percent from the previous week's 1.675 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: Record Eaglet Hatching Is Expected in Maryland
description: Maryland's bald eagles are expected to produce a record number of fledglings this spring, the state Wildlife Administration said today. At least 45 pairs of the majestic birds have been sighted incubating eggs, officials said.

title: REAGAN AND O'NEILL CALLED KEY TO BUDGET PROCESS
description: The private budget negotiations between White House aides and Congressional leaders are scheduled to resume Tuesday, but key figures on both sides said today that a stalemate might persist until President Reagan and Speaker of the House Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. took more active roles in the talks.

title: Childhood Seizures End
description: A 23-year study of children with epilepsy has confirmed that most who are taken off antiseizure medication because they have been free of seizures for at least four years will remain so. Only 41 of 148 children whose medication was stopped later suffered additional seizures, according to a report in the April 8 issue of The New England Journal of Medicine.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: MAN OF JAZZ

title: Bankruptcies in Japan
description: Corporate bankruptcies in Japan reached 17,397 cases in the fiscal year ended March 31, the third-highest level on record, a private credit research agency said today. Although the total represented a 4.5 percent drop from the previous year, the agency said, it was the largest number of filings since 17,987 bankruptcies were reported in 1977 and 18,212 cases in 1980. The amount of liabilities in the latest fiscal year came to 2.456 trillion yen, or $9.9 billion.

title: INVITATION TO GREATER ILLEGAL IMMIGRATION
description: To the Editor:

title: Veteran Gets a Purple Heart, 16 Years After
description: Sometimes the spirit in which an award is given is as important as its substance, says Armand A. Comire, of Danielson, Conn., who received a Purple Heart yesterday, nearly 16 years after being wounded in Vietnam.

title: '81 Losses Fell At Ford Credit
description: The Ford Motor Credit Company, the financing arm of the Ford Motor Company, said today that its 1981 credit losses fell to $67.9 million from $114.7 million in 1980.

title: CHAMBER: FEDER LEADS GOTHAM PLAYERS
description: UNDER the best of circumstances, more than two dozen musicians playing fortissimo in the small-scaled Merkin Concert Hall can sound uninspiring. But on Sunday night, even those ideal conditions did not apply as Edgard Feder conducted the Gotham Chamber Players.

title: Army to Purchase Sikorsky Copters
description: The Army will buy 294 UH-60A transport helicopters from the United Technologies Corporation's Sikorsky Aircraft division over the next three years for $950 million, the Defense Department announced.

title: China Buys U.S. Wheat
description: Grain exporters today reported the sale of another 100,000 metric tons of winter wheat to China for delivery next year. The sale brings to more than 4.6 million tons the volume of American grain that China has agreed to buy during the second year of its long-term grain trade agreement with the United States, consisting of 4.1 million tons of wheat and 546,500 of corn.

title: ISRAEL SEES AN EGYPTIAN DRIFT AWAY FROM CAMP DAVID
description: Israel asked the United States today to intervene against what Israeli leaders regard as a drift by Egypt away from the precepts of the Camp David peace process.

title: 2 MANHATTAN MEN ARE SEIZED IN THEFT OF $1.5 MILLION IN ART
description: Two Manhattan men were arrested last night in connection with the theft of $1.5 million in artworks and the truck where they had been left, the police said. They said that $357,000 in art was also recovered.

title: ISRAELI SOLDIER GAVE LANDLADY A HINT
description: An American-born Israeli soldier slung a rifle over his shoulder Sunday morning as he left the room he had rented for the last few months in West Jerusalem. He told his landlady, Ada Cohen, that he would not be returning ''for a long time.''

title: Three Rome Policemen Wounded by Guerrillas
description: Three policemen were slightly wounded today in a guerrilla attack near the fortified gymnasium in the northern part of Rome where the people charged with murdering former Prime Minister Aldo Moro will go on trial this week, the police said.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: India Lowers Oil Goal
description: India has lowered its oil output target for the year ending March 31, 1983, by 2 million tons, to about 18 million tons, a spokesman for the Oil and Natural Gas Commission said here today. The new target is the equivalent of 360,000 barrels a day, down slightly from last year's estimated production of 360,000 barrels a day.

title: Pabst Vote Is Set Today
description: Shareholders of the Pabst Brewing Company will meet Tuesday to consider whether the current board of directors should be replaced by a group headed by a dissident shareholder, Irwin L. Jacobs of Minneapolis.

title: JEFFERSON'S VISION
description: McLEAN, Va. - It is unfortunate that Thomas Jefferson's birthday, today, is so rarely commemorated, for Americans need to be reminded of the enduring philosophy of that great, many-sided man.

title: THREE NEW 'APOLLO OBJECTS' SIGHTED NEAR EARTH
description: SO far this year, astronomers have detected in the solar system three ''fast-moving objects'' whose orbits cross the orbit of the earth, and a fourth that does not come so close. On Jan. 23, one of the three nearer objects missed the earth by less than 2 million miles, a safe distance but, by astronomical standards, a short one, about 10 times the distance of the moon.

title: MERCANTILE TEXAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The earnings for the 1981 period reflect the acquisition of Greenway Bank & Trust Co and the Citizens National Bank of Greenville on a pooling of interest basis

title: CENVILL DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-There are no yr-ago results because the company started business operations on July 30, 1981

title: Dow Slips 1.62; Defense Group Gains
description: Stock prices retreated slightly yesterday in what analysts viewed as a normal response to a sustained four-week recovery. The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 1.62 points, to 841.32. However, for the first time in a year, the industrials posted gains for four consecutive weeks. The average set its low for this year at 795.47 on March 8. It finished last Thursday, before the Easter holiday weekend, at 842.94.

title: RX FOR POISON: FICTION
description: Hardly a week passes without a newspaper story about the pollution of our air and water by dangerous chemical wastes. Here are but a few recent headlines: ''Guilt Admitted in Toxic Dumping at City Landfills''; ''Panel Says New York State Failed to Curb Refiner's Waste Dumping''; ''New State Rules on Toxic Waste Due on March 9''; ''City Studying Ways to Test for Illegal Waste in Dumps.''

title: 'THE SPECIES WITH MOST AT STAKE IS US'
description: To the Editor:

title: Mild Quake Hits Philadelphia
description: A slight earthquake rattled windows in Northeast Philadelphia and lower Bucks County today, but no injuries or damages were reported, the National Earthquake Information Service said. The tremors registered between 2.5 and 3 on the Richter scale.

title: CHARLES FULLER 'STUNNED' ON WINNING PULITZER
description: Charles Fuller, the black playwright who yesterday won the Pulitzer Prize for drama, said he was ''stunned'' and ''delighted'' by the news, but was quick to add, ''Today is a day of celebration for us.''

title: Bowman Moves Again
description: Scotty Bowman, the Buffalo Sabres' coach and general manager, will shift from coaching to front-office duties again.

title: Phillips, Former Back, Shot and Hospitalized
description: Jesse Phillips, the former New Orleans Saints running back, remained hospitalized under police guard today following an apparent armed robbery attempt in which he was shot and wounded by police.

title: Rex Smith in 'Pirates'
description: Rex Smith will substitute for Patrick Cassidy as Frederick in ''The Pirates of Penzance'' at the Minskoff Theater from tonight through April 25. Mr. Smith was the original Frederick in the production that opened in Central Park two seasons ago, and repeated the role in the film version of ''The Pirates of Penzance'' to be released by Universal next December. Mr. Cassidy pulled a ligament in his leg during the show on Friday while doing a kick in the energetic number ''With Catlight Tread.''

title: 4 Days of Marches Are Ended By West German Missile Foes
description: Four days of marches and demonstrations against the arms race by thousands of participants in several West German cities ended today.

title: STRATHEARN HOUSE GROUP LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 26
description: B-After a special gain of $187,000 or 6 cents a shr...C-Net loss

title: KING RADIO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
SALVADOR POLITICIANS HEATEDLY PICKING NEW TEAM
description: El Salvador's politicians are embroiled in bitter negotiations over who will run the country, and the United States, seeking a government that Congress and the American people will support, is pushing them to come to an agreement that will not exclude the centrists.

title: MAYOR'S AIDES CONCEDE PACE OF REBUILDING LAGS
description: The Koch administration acknowledged yesterday that it would end this fiscal year without committing as much money as it had originally planned to projects to rebuild New York City's deteriorating physical plant. The construction, maintenance and renovation projects involved range from highways and bridges to water mains and sewers.

title: HEART DRUGS POSE PROBLEMS FOR SOME
description: SOME people risk suffering adverse effects from one of the most widely prescribed groups of drugs in the world because of a newly discovered inherited enzyme deficiency, according to several recent reports.

title: Consumer Debt Up Bit In February
description: American consumers took on only $75 million more in installment debt than they paid off in February, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The report offered more evidence of the recession, with Americans reluctant to buy relatively expensive items on credit.

title: Late and Limp on Voting Rights
description: The Reagan Administration says it wants a flat 10-year extension of the Voting Rights Act and calls on critics, for a change, to praise its liberalism. Would that such praise were deserved. The same stance a year ago would have sent thrills through the civil rights movement, allaying some of the distrust felt by many black and Hispanic Americans.

title: 365 New Officers On Subway Patrol
description: The transit police put 365 new officers on subway patrols yesterday in an effort to combat crime, which reached record levels last year.

title: Ravitch Backs M.T.A. Lease Against a Charge From Dole
description: Richard Ravitch, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, said yesterday that Senator Bob Dole was ''wrong on the facts'' last week when he attacked a leasing arrangement under which the M.T.A. plans to buy hundreds of subway cars, commuter railroad cars and buses.

title: OPEC Talks Postponed
description: A new OPEC committee to monitor world oil markets has postponed its scheduled April 20 meeting because some Western oil companies have retreated from their threats to stop buying Nigeria's high-priced oil, the Saudi Arabian News Agency reported today.

title: WARRANTY ACT 'LEMON' TO BE LAW PARLEY FOCUS
description: Rick and Barbara Haas bought a new Chevette in 1977, and almost immediately problems developed with the car's engine, transmission, brakes, suspension, frame and body. It was a lemon.

title: IDEAL 'BACK OFFICE' SITES
description: To the Editor:

title: G.A.O. URGING THE PENTAGON TO PRESS LASER DEVELOPMENT
description: The General Accounting Office urged the Defense Department today to speed development of a ''constellation of laser battle stations in space'' to defend against a Soviet ballistic missile attack.

title: TV: 'WORKING' AND PROPOSED RIGHTS AMENDMENT
description: IN a change of pace, PBS's ''American Playhouse'' series begins singing and dancing tonight at 9 o'clock on WNET-TV. The vehicle is ''Working,'' an adaptation of Studs Terkel's best-selling book. The show had a short Broadway run a couple of years ago and, in a special distribution arrangement, this television version was shown last November on the Showtime pay-cable.

title: Notre Dame Cathedral Fire
description: An exploding aerosol can set fire to a magazine stand in Notre Dame Cathedral today, interrupting a service. Fire brigades quickly extinguished the fire, damage was slight and there were no injuries.

title: TERRAMAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Net loss including $23,000 extraordinary gain for the yr

title: POLICY IS OPEN DOOR AS CHINA OFFICIALLY OPENS CONSULATE IN CITY
description: Ji Lide's invitation was cordial. ''Come at any time - our doors are open,'' said Mr. Ji, China's Deputy Consul General, as his Government officially inaugurated China's Consulate in Manhattan yesterday.

title: Japan-U.S. Gap Widens; Japanese Set Record in U.S.  Trade Surplus
description: Japan's trade surplus with the United States reached a record of $14.42 billion in the fiscal year ended March 31, according to preliminary figures released today by the Finance Ministry.

title: U.S. REQUIRES TOXIC WASTE SITES TO BE INSURED
description: The Environmental Protection Agency said today that an estimated 10,000 hazardous waste facilities would be required to get liability insurance covering property damage and injuries resulting from chemical accidents.

title: Addendum
description: * Bon Appetit magazine increasing its circulation rate base 8.3 percent, to 1.3 million, from 1.2 million, and its advertising rates 16.98 percent, effective with the September issue.

title: TURKISH EX-PREMIER STILL HELD DESPITE COURT ORDER
description: A military court ordered the release today of former Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit, but the Ankara martial law commander refused to free him.

title: Britain's Fist of Sterling
description: Bank power, not the navy, may turn out to be Britain's critical weapon against Argentina's seizure of the Falklands. Argentina's economy is in deep trouble, simultaneously weak and severely inflated. Its debt to foreign bankers stands at $32 billion - greater than Poland's - and it has been growing. If this financial lifeline is severed or even damaged, the Argentine generals may see even more rioting in the streets, as they did just days before the Falklands invasion.

title: THREATS TO 'LIVING DANGEROUSLY' COME TOO CLOSE FOR COMFORT
description: MANILA WITHOUT a warning, Peter Weir, director of ''Gallipoli,'' pulled the crew for his latest film out of the Philippines last week. While filming was proceeding on ''The Year of Living Dangerously'' in a Moslem village in the Quiapo district of Manila, a crew member was slipped a note by a man in the crowd. It said that the production defamed Moslems. If Indonesia would not allow the film - about the final moments of the Sukarno presidency - to be shot in Indonesia, why should Filipino Moslems allow the film to be shot here?

title: Cubs Defeat Mets, 5-4
description: Craig Swan pitched longer today than at any time in the last 22 months when he went six innings against the Cubs. Although he won a round in his comeback, he lost the game when Chicago defeated the New York Mets, 5-4.

title: WESTERN BANK CONCERNS PLAN MARKETING TIES
description: The chief executive of Arizona's largest bank, Valley National, said today that Valley National and five other major Western bank holding companies are planning a combination of services similar to those announced recently by major competitors in the region. The group includes Wells Fargo & Company of San Francisco, one of the largest banking organizations in the country.

title: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
HIGH VOLTAGE ENGINEERING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Q&A
description: Q. If, for some reason, the orbital speed of a planet were to change significantly, what would the effect be on the planet's orbit?

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: SEVEN floors above Central Park South at Sony Inc., Issey M iyake, the 44-year-old Japanese designer who introduced Ultrasuede t o Halston, watched a videotape of his recent Paris show and looked, i n his jump suit, like the most stylish technocrat in New York.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, APRIL 13, 1982
description: International Pessimism on the Falklands crisis increased as Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said after 11 hours of talks with British leaders that ''a number of substantial difficulties remain.'' Mr. Haig delayed until today a flight to Buenos Aires, where he is to resume discussions with Argentine leaders. The main problem appeared to be the insistence by both Britain and Argentina on retaining some element of sovereignty over the South Atlantic islands. (Page A1, Column 6.) Argentina has accepted a proposal by Peru for a 72-hour truce around the Falkland Islands and is waiting for a British response, a spokesman in Buenos Aires said. The official acknowledged that as long as Argentina occupies the islands, which were seized from Britain April 2, any cease-fire or prolonged negotiations would benefit Argentina. (A16:1-2.)

title: Nu-West Plans Sale of Assets
description: Nu-West Group Ltd., a developer and natural resources concern based in Calgary, Alberta, said it planned to sell real estate assets in the United States and Canada valued at about $283.5 million.

title: UNBEATEN BRAVES WIN 6TH
description: Bob Horner and Chris Chambliss hit home runs and Bob Walk and Rick Camp combined on a four-hitter as the undefeated Atlanta Braves beat the Cincinnati Reds, 6-1, tonight for their sixth straight victory.

title: CHEEVER WINS LETTERS MEDAL
description: John Cheever, author of 11 works of fiction since his first book of short stories was published 40 years ago, has been named winner of the National Medal for Literature. The award, which includes $15,000 in cash, is endowed by the Guinzburg Fund in memory of the late Harold K. Guinzburg, founder of the Viking Press.

title: PAULIN, H, & CO LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
Meet Dennis Greco
description: Before he moved to Long Island, the contractor used to get the hairdresser's mail. The lawyer, who was once mistaken for the hairdresser, and the one who works at the South Street Seaport are both left-handed.

title: VETOES BY CAREY SLASH THE BUDGET BY $941 MILLION
description: Governor Carey tonight vetoed $941 million in spending that the State Legislature had approved as part of its $27 billion state budget for this year.

title: FIDELITY SAVINGS SUES U.S. AGENCY
description: In one of the first lawsuits of its kind against a Government agency, the financially troubled Fidelity Savings and Loan Association of San Francisco, the 20th-largest such institution in the nation, is seeking $114 million in damages from the Federal Home Loan Bank of San Francisco. This regulatory institution lends money to savings and loan associations.

title: Taiwan Arms Sales Plan Going to Congress Soon
description: The Reagan Administration will soon give Congress notification of a proposed $60 million sale of military spare parts to Taiwan, a Senate source said today.

title: Surveillance by Police In Chicago Is Attacked
description: The Chicago Police Department was accused today of violating a Federal court order by photographing and filming marchers in a weekend demonstration against nuclear arms.

title: Kenyan, in a Datsun, Wins Five-Day Rally
description: Shekhar Mehta of Kenya held off a late challenge by Walter Rohrl of West Germany and won the five-day Safari auto rally.

title: Weekly in Indonesia Is Closed by Censorship
description: The Government today closed the news magazine Tempo, the last major Indonesian political weekly to survive the press censorship.

title: Delta Town Celebrates Its Bankruptcy Rescue
description: At least 12,000 people crowded onto the grounds of Mound Bayou High School on Sunday to celebrate the rescue of this all-black Mississippi Delta town from bankruptcy.

title: Bridge: Big Bids of Days Gone By Can Lead to Wrong Place
description: If the gods of bridge were to program some celestial computer to keep track of opening bids, they would surely find that one club has the greatest frequency in any standard system. But what about the least frequent? Five no-trump would probably receive the award, with six no-trump and seven no-trump both close challengers.

title: Surprise for Chicken Flies
description: The shotgun pretty well eliminated the old threat of the fox in the chicken coop. Today, the more intractable interlopers in the coops where America's 295 million hens lay eggs are flies. They bother the hens, and bothered hens do not lay as many eggs as unbothered ones.

title: Required Reading Coffee and Security
description: Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, speaking in the Senate on the relationship between the United States and Central American nations. March 25, 1982:

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption Saturday incor- rectly identified J.R. Jayewardene, the leader of Sri Lanka. He is Presi- dent of the country.

title: Kristofferson's Daughter Injured in Crash
description: The singer and actor Kris Kristofferson has canceled a European tour and returned to California to be near his daughter Tracy, who was seriously injured last Friday in a motorcycle accident that also involved Eric Heiden, the winner of five Gold Medals in the 1980 Winter Olympics.

title: 23 Arrested in Naples
description: Italian police arrested 23 people suspected of being Mafia members today in a raid on a gambling hall. The police said they went to the hall looking for Giovanni Sasso, who is wanted for two murders. Mr. Sasso escaped before they arrived.

title: Suffolk's Bottle Law Upheld; To Go Into Effect on April 22
description: Judge Harry Seidel of Suffolk County today lifted the temporary restraining order he had imposed on the county's bottle-deposit law. The judge's action means the law, requiring a deposit on bottles and cans sold in the county, will go into effect on April 22.

title: Laker Bid Rejected
description: Ted Podleski, the general manager of the San Diego Clippers, has turned down an offer that would have assured the Los Angeles Lakers the first selection in the June 29 National Basketball Association college draft. The Clippers, with the worst record in the Western Conference, will be involved in the May 20 coin toss with the Lakers to determine which team gets the first choice.

title: POHL PROVES A POINT IN MASTERS
description: Until Sunday, when he wound up in a playoff with Craig Stadler for the Masters championship, Dan Pohl's one claim to fame was that for two seasons he had been the longest driver on the PGA Tour, averaging 280 yards last year.

title: DORCHESTER GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Jartran Files Debt Restructuring
description: Frank B. Hall & Company, a large insurance brokerage firm, said that its 92 percent owned Jartran Inc. unit, a Miami-based truck leasing concern, had filed for a restructuring of its debt and other obligations with the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Chicago.

title: A-ARMS AND NATO
description: It appears to be open season on proposals to dismantle the foundations of the alliance security policy developed in the post-World War II years. To proposals to forego various United States defense programs or to freeze the present unequal levels of United States and Soviet nuclear forces, there has recently been added a proposal to change our declaratory policy - that is, to announce that we will not be the first to use nuclear weapons.

title: FRISCH'S RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for 12 weeks to Mar 7
description: The shr earnings reflect a 4 percent stock divd paid in Jan 1982

title: THE GROWING IMPORTANCE OF THE FAMILY HISTORY
description: ONE of the most valuable diagnostic procedures doctors can do is free of risks, involves no advanced technology and costs only the time it takes to ask pertinent questions.

title: TOP EXECUTIVE OFFICER IS NAMED BY CAYMAN; Top Executive Officer In Named by Cayman
description: David M. Whitney, 30, has been appointed president and chief executive officer of the Cayman Corporation, an independent energy company whose name will be changed to the Cayman Resources Corporation next Tuesday. He succeeds William T. Ford, 58, who resigned from the Tulsa, Okla., company for personal reasons.

title: AKZONA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Net income; the yr-ago results have been restated

title: OUTCRY OF BOSTON MOTORISTS RELAXES USE OF A 'BOOT' THAT HELD THEIR CARS
description: Among the tight, narrow streets of the city of Boston, finding a place to park, especially a legal place, has never been easy.

title: DESOTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
GENERAL INSTRUMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
FOREST CITY ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including special credits of $672,000 for the qr and $1,087,000 for the yr from the sale of rental properties building...C-Including special credits of $135,000 for the qr and $2,808,000 for the yr...D-Net income; the yr-ago revs have been restated

title: WESTINGHOUSE NET UP 5% IN QUARTER
description: A previously announced decision to terminate efforts to build offshore nuclear power plants and a low tax rate helped lift net income 5 percent for the Westinghouse Electric Corporation in the first quarter of 1982, the company reported yesterday.

title: THE OTHER BALANCE (2)
description: If the United States declared that it would not be the first nation to use nuclear weapons in a future war, would that mean Western Europe would be naked to invasion by overwhelming conventional forces of the Warsaw Pact?

title: COMMERCE SOUTHWEST INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Including a tax credit of $1,026,000...C-Including a tax credit of $1,093,000; the yr-ago results have been restated to reflect acquisitions

title: Note and Bond Prices Gain; 6-Month Bills Yield 12.90%
description: The Treasury sold new three- and six-month bills yesterday at average rates of 12.85 percent and 12.90 percent, respectively, little changed from a week ago, when three-month bills sold at an average rate of 12.89 percent and six-month bills averaged 12.80 percent.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Amarex Inc. said it had agreed in principle to acquire Vanderbilt Energy Corp. of Denver through an exchange of stock with an indicated value of $19 million.

title: BRIEFING
description: Consultant's Delight

title: Synthetic Fuel Aide Leaving
description: The Synthetic Fuels Corporation is about to lose another senior staff member, at least the fourth since the fledgling Government-sponsored agency was formed 18 months ago.

title: Sigma Delta Chi Lists 1981 Award Winners
description: Distinguished Service Awards for 1981 were announced today by the Society of Professional Journalists-Sigma Delta Chi.

title: Salomon Reports 6% Columbia Stake
description: Salomon Brothers Inc., the large investment banking firm, notified the Securities and Exchange Commission that it held 6 percent of the common stock of Columbia Pictures Industries.

title: Phelps Dodge Cuts Salaries
description: The Phelps Dodge Corporation, which announced last week that it was suspending most of its copper-mining operations until at least June 1, said that it had cut salaries for its 6,700 white-collar employees by as much as 8 percent.

title: CEMENT COMPANIES RECESSION VICTIMS
description: Cement has long been derided as the pasty gray material that covers too much of the country's landscape. In the 1960's, families opted for weed-free backyards of cement, architects used it to cut costs on skyscrappers and boat builders molded the heavy mud into yachts.

title: N.F.L. Talks Are Fruitless
description: The Management Council of the National Football League and the Players Association resumed their effort here yesterday to reach a new collective bargining agreement, and the result was the same.

title: SESSIONS, SYLVIA PLATH AND UPDIKE ARE AMONG PULITZER PRIZE WINNERS
description: Pulitzer Prizes were awarded yesterday to an 85-year-old composer, Roger Sessions; to a poet, Sylvia Plath, who, at the age of 30, committed suicide 19 years ago; to John Updike for a novel that was the third in a trilogy, and to a drama by Charles Fuller.

title: RETAIL SALES OFF BY 0.5% IN MARCH
description: The nation's retail sales declined five-tenths of 1 percent in March, the Commerce Department reported today. The new report dashed hopes that the rebound in February sales indicated the recession might be ending.

title: UNITED STATES TRUCK LINES OF DELAWARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec
Kaufman's Stake In Paint Company
description: Kaufman & Broad Inc. said that it had acquired 6.8 percent of the common stock of the Standard Brands Paint Company.

title: AMERICAN FEDERAL SAVINGS AND LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
INTERNATIONAL MULTIFOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: B-Including income of $816,000 for the qr and yr from discontinued operations;yr ago results have been restated

title: NBD BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Talking Business with Senator Richard G. Lugar; Federal Role In Rescues
description: It was not all that long ago, says Senator Richard G. Lugar, that the experts were predicting that neither New York City nor the Chrysler Corporation would ever see 1982 without slipping into bankruptcy.

title: D. ALTMAN DIEHL
description: D. Altman Diehl, a financial consultant and former stockbroker, died Sunday at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 79 years old and lived in Bronxville.

title: CBT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The results were adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split in July 1981 and the yr-agofigures were restated for the poolings of interests method of accounting for two bank acquisitions in early 1982

title: HAIG'S DEPUTY IS SENT TO MIDEAST TO GUARD AGAINST HITCH ON SINAI
description: The United States announced today that it was sending the second-ranking official of the State Department to the Middle East in an effort to insure that, despite last-minute problems, the Israelis will leave Sinai as scheduled on April 25.

title: Theater Wing Seminars Are Beginning Today
description: The American Theater Wing's annual ''Working in the Theater'' seminars on performing, playwrighting and production will be held today, tomorrow and Thursday from 11 A.M. to 1 P.M. at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York, 33 West 42d Street.

title: Nets Get Closer To Berth
description: Ray Williams scored 37 points last night to lead New Jersey to a 104-102 victory over the Knicks at Madison Square Garden that put the Nets on the verge of qualifying for the National Basketball Assocation playoffs.

title: Careers; Marketing Executives In Demand
description: WHILE the Chinese call 1982 the Year of the Dog, for business it might better be called the year of the marketer. A leader in the people-recruiting field - Lester B. Korn, chairman of Korn-Ferry International, a large management recruiting firm - reports what he calls ''a substantial increase'' in demand for marketing executives. About 23 percent of demand in the first quarter of this year has been for marketing executives, up from 17 percent in the period a year earlier, he said. His figures are based on a survey of 750 client companies.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: SHOULD you eat less red meat, fewer eggs and less butter, hard cheese and other foods rich in saturated fats? Should you replace them with chicken (without the fatty skin), fish, beans, polyunsaturated vegetable oils and margarine?

title: Rumanian Leader in Peking
description: Nicolae Ceausescu, the Rumanian President and Communist Party chief, arrived in Peking today and began talks with Chinese leaders that were expected to touch on the question of Chinese-Soviet relations. His first discussions with Hu Yaobang, the Chinese party Chairman, were devoted to bilateral issues, with President Ceausescu briefing his host on Rumania's domestic situation, the New China News Agency reported.

title: WALGREEN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Shr earnings adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective Jan 22, 1982

title: Japan to Buy Iranian Oil
description: Japan will resume importing crude oil from Iran, but only on a noncontract basis, industry sources said here today. Several trading houses are arranging to import two million barrels of Iranian Heavy oil, for shipment in late April or May, at about $26 a barrel, they added. Under the previous contracts, which have been allowed to lapse, Japan last year imported about 140,000 barrels of oil a day from Iran.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: SENSORMATIC ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
CITY WEIGHS $8 MILLION FOR MET MUSEUM WING
description: New York City is considering an $8 million contribution to the Metropolitan Museum of Art to construct its long-planned southwest wing.

title: INTER-TEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
A 'NUCLEAR FREEZE' THAT IS NO SUCH THING
description: To the Editor:

title: COMMODITIES; Bond Futures Slacken During Profit Taking
description: Not unexpectedly, the Treasury bond and bill futures markets eased yesterday after the strong advances of the two preceding sessions. The expected profit taking came after some carry-over buying from Monday petered out about midsession, Chicago brokers said. Overall trading was relatively light, they added.

title: Phone Rate Policy Is Upheld
description: A Federal appeals court today upheld the basic regulatory policy decision that helped produce the largest long-distance telephone rate increase in history last summer.

title: The Mets 20 Years Later
description: SHERMAN (Roadblock) Jones, amid snowflakes, was the starting pitcher for the original Mets in their home opener in 1962 in the old Polo Grounds.

title: City Council Bill Seeks Garden Fund for Sports
description: A bill calling for Gulf and Western Corporation to make available $1 million a year to a New York Sports Fund for every year that the city grants it a real estate tax abatement, was presented to the City Council yesterday for immediate action by Councilman Gilberto Gerena-Valentin (D-Bronx).

title: PACIFIC LIGHTING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Off-Duty Jersey Officer Killed With Own Gun
description: A police officer who removed his gun to adjust his pants while watching television accidentally shot himself in the head and died, officials said today.

title: Lord Greenwood, 70; Was in British Cabinet
description: Lord Greenwood, a former Labor Cabinet minister, died Monday after suffering a heart attack at his home in London.

title: MARRIOTT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 26
SCAN-DATA CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
OFFICER SLAIN IN DISPUTE WITH DETECTIVE
description: An off-duty Transit Authority police officer was shot to death in the Bronx last night in a confrontation with two New York City police detectives that began with a dispute over traffic.

title: ISRAELI ARRAIGNED IN MOSQUE RAID
description: Shouting ''Justice! Justice!'' an Americanborn Israeli soldier was taken into a court here today for arraignment for his rifle attack Sunday at the Dome of the Rock Mosque. The soldier, Alan Harry Goodman, was ordered held for 15 days pending trial on charges of murdering two Arabs and wounding 30 others.

title: THE ONLY GENTLEMAN
description: The question of what books are fit for young eyes has arisen again in the Washington suburbs, where authorities are arguing whether the Mark Twain Intermediate School of Fairfax County should drop Mark Twain's ''Huckleberry Finn'' from the curriculum. My immediate question is, what's it doing in the curriculum in the first place?

title: PEER REVIEW'S CONTRIBUTIONS TO THE CONTROL OF HEALTH CARE COSTS
description: To the Editor:

title: SCM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-After $4 million charge for the closing of a plant and a $2 million tax credit...C-After $1.5 million charge from the closing of a plant

title: Dempsey 'Satisfactory'
description: Jack Dempsey, who was admitted Sunday to the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, had a pacemaker implanted yesterday because, his wife said, his heart was beating ''on the slow side.''

title: WARNER COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
No Headline
description: Schlitz, in documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, said that with Goldman, Sachs & Company, its adviser, it had ''explored the possibility of and in some instances held preliminary discussions with certain other persons.''

title: WESTINGHOUSE CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Q&A
description: Q. I like to use rosemary as a seasoning, but I find the needlelike leaves a bit overpowering, and I cannot find ground rosemary. Is there any special technique for chopping the leaves?

title: 4th SLAYING LINKED TO 3 ON WEST SIDE
description: A witness in a Federal fraud investigation was found shot to death yesterday, and the police said she had probably been slain by the same gunman who killed three CBS employees Monday when they apparently went to her aid in a parking lot on Manhattan's West Side.

title: DELOREAN DOUBTFUL ON BUDGET RENT-A-CAR ACCORD
description: John Z. DeLorean, president of the DeLorean Motor Company, said last night that it is unlikely the company will reach an agreement to lease some of its unsold 1981 inventory to the Budget Rent-a-Car Corporation of America, a deal that would have helped the ailing auto company stay in business.

title: Constantin Warvariv, Ex-U.S. Aide to Unesco
description: Constantin Warvariv, a former United States deputy delegate to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization in Paris, died of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, Lou Gehrig's disease, on April 6 at his home in Silver Spring, Md. He was 57 years old.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: LISTENING to ''The Name of This Band Is Talking Heads'' (Sire), a new live album that chronicles the five-year career of New York's most consistently innovative new-wave rock band, one recalls - with something approaching shock - that many rock critics used to describe the Talking Heads as ''minimal,'' ''arty,'' and ''intellectual.'' It's true that the Talking Heads have always been intelligent and artistically ambitious. But the music that comes blasting off this record, especially the 1977-79 performances from the first of the album's two disks, is hardly an exercise in thoughtful austerity. It is consummately focused and often ingeniously put together. But it is also hard and raw and visceral. In fact, ''The Name of This Band Is Talking Heads'' is one of the most exciting live-rock albums any band has released.

title: Batus Files Field Data
description: Batus Inc. said it had complied with a request from the Federal Trade Commission to furnish more information regarding its proposed $365 million acquisition of Marshall Field & Company.

title: U.S. Reported Willing to Sell Iraq 6 to 12 Transport Planes
description: The Reagan Administration has decided to permit the sale to Iraq of six to 12 Lockheed L-100 transport planes, the civilian version of the C-130, a Congressional source said tonight.

title: No Reorganization Seen at Advent
description: The trustee of the Advent Corporation, a Portsmouth, N.H., maker of stereo speakers and large-screen televisions that has been operating under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code since March 17, 1981, said he had concluded that there is ''no realistic possibility'' for reorganization of the company or other similar financial arrangement that would give any return to its shareholders.

title: OPERA: BOITO'S 'NERONE'
description: ARRIGO BOITO'S ''Nerone'' is a legendary monster of an opera that any admirer of the composer would be thankful to hear once. Eve Queler and her Opera Orchestra of New York lured the fabled beast out of hiding Monday night and put it on display at Carnegie Hall in a concert version that evidently was its first American appearance in any form.

title: RECITAL: MUIR, MISS BLOOM
description: THE Muir String Quartet, winners of the Naumburg Foundation's 1981 Chamber Music Award, joined Sara Lambert Bloom, oboe, and Joaquin Valdepenas, clarinet, in music by Mozart, Bartok and Schubert Sunday evening at Carnegie Recital Hall.

title: ROTHSCHILD CONCERN SELECTS A PRESIDENT
description: Robert S. Pirie, a 47-year-old senior partner in the law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, has been elected president and chief executive officer of Rothschild Inc., the American investment banking firm in New York owned by the French and English branches of the Rothschild family. Mr. Pirie, whose appointment is effective June 1, succeeds Gilbert de Botton, 46, who has been associated with the family for many years and who assumed the position on a temporary basis last July.

title: People
description: * Nan Bedford and May Lou Gorno have been elected partners of Tatham-Laird & Kudner Advertising, Chicago.

title: Utility Stocks Advance Again; Dow Off 0.28; Volume Up
description: With electric utilities continuing to display strength, stock prices generally showed minimal price changes yesterday. Analysts said there was little in the news background to affect the market.

title: 'Israeli Revue' Planned For May 2 at Town Hall
description: ''Israeli Revue,'' starring Mike Burstyn and Shoshana Damari, will play at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street, on May 2, Israeli Independence Day.

title: TOOTH PERIL FOR BABIES
description: Babies who fall asleep while nursing provide ''a perfect breeding ground'' for bacteria that can eat away at their teeth and threaten permanent damage, a dentistry professor warned Tuesday.

title: IF IRAN DEFEATS IRAQ
description: After 19 months of stalemate, Iran appears to be winning its war with Iraq. Recent successes open up the possibility of a turning point, with serious implications for the two belligerents as well as for other countries in the region, and ultimately for the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: BRIEFING
description: Tracking the Joneses

title: INDIAN MUSIC: SPIRITED SAROD
description: RAJEEV TARANATH'S sarod improvisations Sunday at Soundscape mixed the spiritual and the spirited. An afternoon raga began with introspective meditation and proceeded with concentrated vocal variation and discursive phrasing into an exuberant rhythmic celebration.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: It is only in this, the latter part of his life, that Antonio Lopez-Olano has been discovered by social welfare agencies. In theory, his lot has improved enormously: the government benefits, the neat apartment in the housing complex for the elderly, the medical care. In practice, he says he wishes everyone would just leave him alone.

title: RECONTROL AIR FARES
description: Airlines were deregulated in October 1978 on the theory that the industry could function effectively in the free market. Actual experience has exploded that theory. Losses have been heavy, most carriers are seriously weakened, several are near bankruptcy.

title: A Dimmer View of 'Alternative' Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: IN CORREGIDOR, BAD MEMORIES FOR MEN OF THREE NATIONS
description: Leonard Dugan walked briskly to the 10-ton, 12-inch mortar he fired 40 years ago. The tears welled up in his eyes. ''I never thought we would surrender,'' he said.

title: RETURN TO COSTA RICA BY VESCO IS REPORTED DESPITE A 4-YEAR BAN
description: Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive American financier, has reportedly returned illegally to Costa Rica despite a four-year-old ban on his entry into that country.

title: WINE TALK
description: THE sharp decline of the franc against the dollar and an aggressive marketing campaign by French producers and dealers have begun to result in bargain prices for French wines in the United States. Suddenly an array of surprisingly good bottlings from Bordeaux, Burgundy and the Rhone Valley is available in this country at prices ranging from $5 to $10, and occasionally a decent wine can be found for even less.

title: OWENS-ILLINOIS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
BOY, 8, KILLED AS ISRAELIS FIRE TO END GAZA PROTEST
description: An 8-year-old boy was fatally wounded today in the Gaza Strip when Israeli soldiers opened fire after being showered with rocks by Arab demonstrators. Twenty Arabs and four soldiers were reported hurt in the encounter.

title: WARNER UP 57.4% IN QUARTER
description: Warner Communications Inc. reported yesterday that strong earnings gains from the sale of Atari home computers and video games caused net income in the first quarter of 1982 to soar 57.4 percent.

title: CANADA TRUSTCO MORTGAGE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The company s listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchange

title: A TIGHTENING RENT SQUEEZE ON MIDTOWN RESTAURANTS
description: Concern has been expressed in many quarters for the number of retail businesses that have vanished as skyscraping office towers have risen on Manhattan's East Side.

title: HERBST'S, KNOWEN FOR ITS STRUDEL, IS CLOSING
description: Manhattan will lose one of its best-known strudel shops to a 29-story apartment building this week. The 55-year-old Hungarian pastry shop, called Mrs. Herbst's, where three generations of the Herbst family turned 2,000 pounds of apples into strudel each week, is closing its doors Saturday.

title: MITTERRAND IS OFF FOR VISIT TO JAPAN
description: Until recently, France's sales of Perrier to Japan were drastically inhibited by the Japanese requirement that it be boiled. True, French cognac did not have to be boiled, but that, precisely, is the heart of one of the major complaints that President Francois Mitterrand was carrying along as he left today for the first visit ever made by a French head of state to Japan.

title: PRICES EASE FOR ALL MATURITIES
description: After two days of rising prices, the credit markets cooled off yesterday as slight price declines resulted in higher yields for all maturities.

title: Hungarian Plans Bonn Visit
description: The Hungarian Communist Party leader, Janos Kadar, will visit West Germany April 27 and 28, the official Hungarian press agency said today. He will discuss East-West relations and economic issues with Chancellor Helmut Schmidt in Bonn, the agency said.

title: IN THE LORE OF BARBADOS, REDISTILLED RUM
description: In 1650, Richard Ligon returned to England after a three-year sojourn in Barbados and wrote "A True and Exact History of the Island of Barbadoes." The book included a detailed drawing of a sugar mill and a stillhouse, and Mr. Ligon described how "skimmings" were "twice distilled" in the stillhouse. He wrote: "The first time it comes over the helm, it is but small, and is called Low-wines; but the second time, it comes off the strongest Spirit or Liquor that is potable."

title: DANCE: TAYLOR OPENS WITH RARE REVIVAL OF 'ORBS'
description: REVERENT and irreverent, Paul Taylor has always been always so. Many of his new fans will savor this special Tayloresque flavor again in a different peppermint shade with this season's revival of one of his most ambitious pieces, the rarely performed ''Orbs.''

title: YANKEES DEFEAT RANGERS
description: Mike Morgan knew that a steady outing tonight might secure his spot in the Yankee rotation, and the 22-year-old right-hander responded with a strong six and one-third innings in New York's 6-3 victory over the Rangers.

title: COLONIAL COMMERCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a writedown of $1,628,892 for the qr and yr in the carrying value of a mortgage on Atlantic City property and a writedown of $3,434,875 for the qr and yr in the carrying value of an investment in Atlantic City property; Colonial Commercial Corp is a debtor-in-possession and the results include operations of companies in Chapter 11

title: REPUBLICANS WORRY ABOUT ERODING BLACK SUPPORT
description: The Republicans have a problem they never really expected, a problem that makes them uncomfortable and one they don't like to talk about to outsiders because they don't have any quick solutions.

title: VITRAMON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
ISRAEL DENOUNCED BY MOSLEM NATIONS
description: Moslem nations denounced Israel here today for Sunday's killings in the Dome of the Rock, the sacred Islamic shrine.

title: LAWMAKERS AWAY ON FOREIGN TRIPS
description: From Lisbon to Bangkok, members of Congress went off to see the world over the Easter recess. It appears, however, that there was less foreign travel this season than in previous years. Many budget-conscious politicians returned home with the November elections in mind.

title: Ron Franklin Arrested
description: Ron Franklin, who rode Spectacular Bid to victories in the 1979 Kentucky Derby and Preakness Stakes, was arrested with two others yesterday at Keeneland Race Course in Lexington, Ky., and charged with transfer of cocaine.

title: HUFFY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 26
Comings and Goings
description: Jim Bibby, the Pittsburgh Pirate pitcher, will undergo surgery April 22 to correct a problem in the shoulder of his throwing arm. The 37-year-old right-hander has been troubled by a stiff shoulder since the end of the 1981 season and made only three appearances this spring before being placed on the 21-day disabled list on April 2. ... Kirk Gibson, the Detroit center-fielder, rejoined the Tigers in Toronto after doctors examined his sore left knee and said there was no damage. ... Emile Francis, the former New York Ranger coach who is now the president, general manager and coach of the St. Louis Blues, was selected yesterday for induction into the Hockey Hall of Fame.

title: STRYKER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
A 'NUCLEAR FREEZE' THAT IS NO SUCH THING
description: To the Editor: If something is not done to stop the arms race, nuclear war is more a certainty than a probability. I would choose to be in the middle of the first bomb that fell, and I believe it would only be just that those who do nothing to prevent nuclear war should be the survivors. SALLY HOWE LINEWEAVER Northport, L.I., March 21, 1982

title: SCOTTY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 27
PANEL IN COUNCIL APPROVES BOUNDARIES FOR 35 DISTRICTS
description: After raucous debate, a City Council committee yesterday approved new boundary lines for 35 Council districts. Council leaders hope the action, by the Committee on Rules, Privileges and Elections, will permit elections to be held in November.

title: THEATER: JIM SHERIDAN ALONE, WITH 'WAITING FOR BECKETT'
description: WHEN the late Jack MacGowran performed his historic one-man show adapted by the actor from the works of Samuel Beckett it was an exact synchronization of performer and writer and a theatrical incarnation of artistic genius. Among other actors who have specialized one-man performances of Beckett, David Warrilow has come closest to Mr. MacGowran's standard. Jim Sheridan's ''Waiting for Beckett,'' a presentation of the Irish Rebel Theater, is far lower down on the dramatic scale.

title: FOR HORSEPLAYERS WHO CARE TO EAT, THE CARD INCLUDES A MENU
description: IN other, simpler times it was sufficiently satisfying for a horseplayer to have a successful, and therefore guiltless, day at the races, with success measured by whether the bettor won or at least broke even after an eight-race card.

title: 2 SOVIET SUBS REPORTED IN CRISIS AREA
description: Two Soviet submarines are on patrol in the southwest Atlantic as a symbol Moscow's military interest in the confrontation between Britain and Argentina over the Falkland Islands.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * C.I.T. Financial Corp. announced a public offering of $200 million of 15 1/2 percent debentures due in 1987, priced at 99.625 to yield 15.602 percent, and not redeemable before maturity, to be sold through a Dillon, Read & Co. group.

title: Gunmen Reportedly Kill 19 Guatemala Villagers
description: An investigation began today into charges that unidentified gunmen shot to death 15 peasants and burned to death four others inside their huts in a raid on an isolated Indian village.

title: CONROY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
TWO KINDS OF PRESSURE ON TV NETWORKS
description: To the Editor:

title: ECLECTIC COOKING: WHOLESOMENESS FIT FOR THE GOURMAND
description: Many Americans who once spent hours discussing the merits of nouvelle cuisine now seem to be approaching food from a new point of view - as health-food gourmands. They are seeking out the best butter from Normandy or Denmark or Germany and the richest, creamiest goat cheeses with the highest butterfat content, but only if they are ''all natural,'' ''preservative- and additive-free.''

title: New Tax-Leasing Rule
description: Corporations would gain an immediate advantage from the controversial tax-leasing program under a new ruling released yesterday by the Financial Accounting Standards Board. It would allow companies to report the income they earn from selling tax benefits in the year the sale is made, rather than spreading this income over several years as previously proposed by the standards board.

title: DIGITAL RECORDING reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
INTERNATIONAL STRETCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: B-Net income...C-Including an extraordinary credit of $31,000

title: SOUTH AFRICAN INQUEST HALTED BY DISPUTE
description: An inquest into the death of a white trade unionist in the custody of the security police was halted today on its first day by objections from a lawyer for the police to the presentation in open court of an affidavit the dead man signed on the last day of his life.

title: FOR 17 GUITARISTS, THE AWE OF SEGOVIA
description: ON Monday afternoon 10 guitarists - eight men, two women - were gathered backstage at the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium in the Metropolitan Museum of Art. They were waiting to sit at the feet of Andres Segovia, who was giving his first master class in New York. In a master class, even the most brilliant young professional is subject to the criticism of a great master. Thus, all the guitarists were nervous. At least, nine of them were nervous.

title: NORTH AMERICAN PHILIPS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-After $519,000 loss from discontinued operations

title: TOP JUDGE JOINS MAYOR IN CITING GAINS IN COURTS
description: Mayor Koch and the state's Chief Judge reported yesterday that the criminal-justice system was doing a better job of handling ''an explosion of indictments'' in New York City through cooperative efforts begun last year.

description: Previous Year In percent Yesterday Day Ago PRIME RATE 16.50 16.50 17.50 DISCOUNT RATE 12.00 12.00 13.00 FEDERAL FUNDS 14.70 14.33 14.94 3-MO. TREAS. BILLS 12.73 12.70 13.32 6-MO. TREAS. Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Vanessa Redgrave Defends Right to Perform
description: Saying that her goal was to prevent a return to the blacklisting of the 1950's, Vanessa Redgrave, the actress who is outspoken in her defense of the Palestine Liberation Organization, today defended her right to work no matter what her political beliefs might be.

title: New Job for Weinhauer
description: Arizona State University named Bob Weinhauer of the University of Pennsylvania yesterday as its new basketball coach.

title: Koch Aide Elevated
description: For seven weeks, Evan W. Cornog has served as acting press secretary to Mayor Koch. Yesterday the ''acting'' was dropped from the title and Mr. Cornog took over as press secretary.

title: FAB INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
Bombs, Cells and Symbols
description: What do debates over the nuclear freeze and prison construction have in common? Nothing, except that both are heavily symbolized.

title: WHAT PACKAGE LABEL MUST SAY
description: Food packages are subject to much stricter enforcement of Federal regulations than in the past. Twenty years ago it was not uncommon for packagers to use photographic tricks to enhance the appearance of their product - to thicken soup with marbles, for instance, or coat meat with lubricating oil. The Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act prohibits that, and advertisers are careful to display only what the package contains. If garnishes are used they must be described as serving suggestions.

title: RE-ENLISRMENT SURGE IN THE ARMY RESULTS IN STIFFER STANDARDS
description: The Army, faced with an unexpected increase in re-enlistments, says it has toughened its standards so that now commanders will be able to keep only the best soldiers.

title: RAILROAD HALTED BY 8-HOUR STRIKE
description: About 12,000 members of the United Transportation Union went on strike against the Burlington Northern today in a dispute over work rules and wages, but later obeyed a court order and returned to work.

title: Opening of a Salute to Loesser
description: ''Is there something special going on?'' the coatcheck woman wanted to know. ''I've never seen so many people on a Monday night.''

title: BEST BUYS
description: THE average weekly cost of feeding a family of four in New York City rose by $2.01 to $109.34 in the two-week shopping period March 29 through April 9. Shoppers paid $6.15 more for food than in the corresponding period last year.

title: PULTE HOME CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Includes $2,371,000 gain from the sale of mortgage loan servicing by an unconsolidated mortgage banking subsidiary

title: FOUR NUNS LOSE SUIT AIMED AT RETAINING THEIR TEACHING JOBS
description: A judge today ruled against four Roman Catholic nuns who sued their bishop and their school board after being dismissed from their teaching jobs.

title: News Analysis
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin has embarked on a strategy of brinkmanship, both in the process of peace with Egypt and the prospect of war with the Palestine Liberation Organization in southern Lebanon.

title: WEST CHEMICAL PROUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
description: B-Includes tax credits of $176,000 for the latest qr and $162,000 for the yr-ago qr

title: 8 OF FIRST BALCK NAVY OFFICERS HOLD REUNION AT SEA
description: The United States Navy brought them back to sea today, the eight surviving members of ''the Golden 13.''

title: Bridge: Berkowitz and Lilie Gained A Difficult Double Victory
description: The men's team championship and the men's pair championship are among the toughest events in the national calendar. Winning both in the same year has been achieved by four individuals: Sol Mogal, Phil Feldesman and Jeff Rubens, all of New York, and Richard Walsh, a Californian who now lives in Switzerland.

title: REDFERN FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to MAR 31
Tax All Oil, and Natural Gas Too
description: Confronting a budget deficit that may exceed $150 billion next year, Federal policy makers are desperately searching for new sources of revenue. And they are finally looking at a tax on imported oil.

title: FLIGHT TRANSPORTATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
INTERNATIONAL PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Including a gain of $17.2 million or 35 cents a shr, from the sale of tax credits...C-Including a gain of $57 million or $1.16 a shr primarily from major land transactions

title: ISLANDERS OUST PENGUINS ON TONELLI'S OVERTIME GOAL
description: With five-and-a-half minutes to play tonight in the decisive fifth game of their series with the Pittsburgh Penguins, the Islanders trailed by two goals and appeared destined to become another upset victim in this season's topsy-turvy National Hockey League playoffs.

title: U.S. IS GOING AHEAD WITH TAIWAN SALE
description: The Reagan Administration announced today that it was going ahead with the sale of $60 million in military spare parts to Taiwan despite Peking's warnings that this could lead to a "retrogression" in Chinese-American relations.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Jerusalem Nov. 8 on the authorship of the Book of Gene- sis incorrectly reported two state- ments by Moshe Weinfeld, professor of biblical studies at Hebrew Universi- ty. He said that Julius Wellhausen, a 19th-century German Protestant theologian, had hypothesized that cer- tain chapters were written in fifth cen- tury B.C. In a study of the Book of Deuteronomy, Professor Weinfeld argued that two groups of authors were active at the same time, one of whom may have written Deuter- onomy and the other the Books of Le- viticus and Numbers.

title: International Paper, Boise Cascade Plunge
description: The International Paper Company and the Boise Cascade Corporation reported big declines in earnings in the first quarter of 1982, as the recession and its impact on the housing industry continued to depress results.

title: TELEDYNE CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Kenyon & Eckhardt Gets 3 New Accounts
description: Kenyon & Eckhardt's outpost in Boston, the heart of high tech country, has just picked up three pieces of business with collective billings of $2.5 million to $3 million.

title: A BOLD NEW WORLD FOR VIDEO
description: Newspaper excerpts, weather news, economic reports, material for children - a varying, experimental array of written and graphics material - has been flashing onto video screens at 40 homes, a library building and 10 other public sites in the Washington area.

title: Experts Say Taxes Take Smaller Bite in Paycheck
description: Taxes will take a smaller bite out of the American worker's daily earnings this year, economists for a nonprofit watchdog group, Tax Foundation, said today.

title: U.S. BACKS STROH'S SCHLITZ BID
description: The Justice Department gave qualified approval today to a deal under which the Stroh Companies Inc. would acquire 67 percent of the common stock of the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company for $325 million.

title: J. GORDON BASS
description: J. Gordon Bass, a leading figure in the wine and spirits industry for more than half a century, died in Mountainside Hospital, Montclair, N.J., yesterday after a brief illness.

title: SAILOR ON THE SPOT
description: For Britain's navy, the Falkland Islands crisis represents its greatest effort since World War II. For John Woodward, the confrontation constitutes the biggest challenge of his life.

title: JOHN D. TIERNEY
description: John D. Tierney, a former public relations manager for the Caltex Petroleum Corporation and press secretary to two former New York City Mayors, died Monday at home after a long illness. He was 64 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: MOVIE STAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
Economic Scene; The Economist On the Stand
description: HIS brow furrowed with care, his pockets bulging with notes from the interdepartmental meetings he has sat through in the past week, the Economist (a composite figure drawn from interviews with several economists in Government) takes the witness stand and swears to tell the press the truth, the whole truth and nothing but the truth.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary yesterday for Louis M. Lyons, former curator of Harvard University's Nieman Foundation for Journalism, omitted a brother in the listing of survivors. He is Henry E. Lyons of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y.

title: Investors Buy Landmark Stock
description: A group of private investors from Tennessee has agreed to buy $50 million of convertible preferred stock from the Landmark Banking Corporation of Fort Lauderdale, the Florida-based bank holding company announced.

title: CAREY VETOES LEAVE LEGISLATURE STUNNED
description: Governor Carey's vetoes of $941 million in the state's budget - more than twice the amount legislative leaders had expected - left the leaders stunned today and left New York State without a complete spending plan for this year.

title: ARAB NATIONS PLAN STRIKE TO PROTEST KILLINGS IN MOSQUE
description: King Khalid of Saudi Arabia today called on Moslems everywhere to join in a one-day strike Wednesday to protest the violence Sunday at Jerusalem's Dome of the Rock Mosque and to demonstrate support for Palestinians in Israeli-occupied lands.

title: I.R.S. HAIKU
description: Write, sharpened pencils Scratching through tax-night sundown! Sweet eyeglass receipts.

title: Union Breaks Off N.F.L. Talks
description: The players union broke off negotiations with the Management Council of the National Football League here yesterday and filed a complaint with the National Labor Relations Board that centered on a telephone poll of the players being conducted by The New York Times.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, APRIL 14, 1982
description: International Alexander M. Haig Jr. returned to Washington for consultations with President Reagan. United States officials conceded that the Secretary of State's efforts to resolve the Falkland crisis before the British armada reaches the islands nearly collapsed Monday night when Argentina apparently reneged on an understanding with Mr. Haig. (Page A1, Column 6.) The apparent collapse of diplomacy in the Falkland crisis was reported by a spokesman for Britain as Secretary of State Haig interrupted his peacemaking efforts to return to Washington. Mr. Haig said he had ''received some new ideas'' that both sides were studying, but he declined to state the nature or origin of the proposals.(A14:1-2.)

title: MISSISSIPPI FEARS U.S CUTS IMPERIL ITS FISCAL AND RACIAL GAINS
description: With Federal aid declining and the state caught in a deep economic slump, some Mississippi leaders say they fear their state is in danger of falling back into the pattern of poverty and division that prevailed for most of its history.

title: E.E.C. Oil Imports Fall
description: The European Economic Community's oil imports fell 16 percent last year, to 358 million metric tons, or about 2.75 billion barrels, the community's statistics office said today. Oil consumption also dropped, by 8.6 percent, to 418 million tons, or about 3.22 billion barrels, the provisional figures showed. There are about 7.7 barrels of crude in a metric ton.

title: ASTRONAUTS RECOUNT AN 'ADVENTURE OF A LIFETIME'
description: The astronauts who flew the most recent mission of the space shuttle Columbia said yesterday that motion sickness, fatigue and mechanical problems combined to sink their morale on the second day in orbit, but that they recovered and went on to enjoy ''an adventure of a lifetime'' that further demonstrated the new spaceship's reliability and flexibility.

title: M-G-M U.A. SHIFTS OFFICIALS
