description: The M-G-M/U.A. Entertainment Company, which has been plagued by a string of expensive motion-picture failures during the last year, replaced its two senior marketing executives today in a bid to reverse its sagging fortunes at the box office.

title: WHO'S IN CHARGE?
description: The dangers in the dispute between Great Britain and Argentina over the sovereignty of the South Atlantic Falkland Islands should not be minimized.

title: HAIG BACK IN U.S. TO BRIEF REAGAN ON THE FALKLANDS
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. returned to Washington tonight for consultations with President Reagan before resuming his diplomatic mission between Argentina and Britain in an effort to forestall a military clash over the Falkland Islands.

title: Income Rises At 2 Big Banks
description: Marine Midland Banks Inc. said yesterday that its first-quarter operating earnings showed a small gain over 1981, while the Mellon National Corporation said that its income was about unchanged.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: A few years back three young San Franciscans - Candice Loheed, Bean Finneran and Sally Leiter - got into the jewelry business almost by chance. Miss Finneran owned a small kiln and she and her friends started to work with clay, coming up with some amusing notions, such as a necklace that seems to be made of piano keys and others with fruit or animal motifs. They called their company Parrot Pearls, simply because they liked the name. Bergdorf Goodman now has some of the new necklaces: there's one with three parrots perched at the front of bright colored beads ($120) and another that dangles a catch of seven black and white striped fish with green fins ($160). You'll find them in the main floor jewelry department.

title: TOSCO HOLDERS CALL FOR OIL PROJECT END
description: A dissident shareholder campaign in the wake of projected cost overruns is putting pressure on the Tosco Corporation to consider abandoning its stake in the country's most advanced shale-oil project.

title: NATIONAL MICRONETICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 2
U.S. IS SAID TO AID BRITISH FORCES
description: The United States had been providing ''extensive assistance'' to British forces through satellite communications links, weather forecasting from satellite observations, intelligence reports and the supply of jet fuel to the United States base on Ascension Island, which the British have a treaty right to use, according to an ABC News report tonight.

title: POLISH ARCHBISHOP CALLS FOR TALKS
description: The Roman Catholic Church has appealed for talks to end ''the present political impasse'' in Poland. A 10-page letter signed by the Polish Primate, Archbishop Jozef Glemp, was sent to Poland's 27 bishops and to the authorities.

title: ALLBRITTON OFFERS A PLAN TO SHARE NEWS'S PROFITS
description: Joe L. Allbritton, the Texas financier negotiating to acquire The Daily News, has offered News employees a 20 percent share in the paper's future profits.

title: Coliseum Aide Denies Davis Was to Get Fund
description: William Robertson of the Coliseum Commission, who led efforts to bring the Oakland Raiders to Los Angeles, insisted today that $4 million in relocation funds was not intended for Al Davis, the managing general partner, but rather for team employees to compensate for what he called the higher cost of housing here.

title: Plea in Stabbing of Actress
description: A drifter accused of stalking and stabbing the actress Theresa Saldana pleaded not guilty today to attempted murder and assault charges. The suspect, Arthur Richard Jackson, 46 years old, entered his plea at a brief Superior Court arraignment. Miss Saldana, 27, suffered numerous stab wounds in the attack last month outside her West Hollywood apartment.

title: Peter Hager, a Partner With Goldman, Sachs
description: Peter A. Hager, a limited partner of Goldman, Sachs & Company, investment bankers, died of a heart attack Monday in Jersey City on his way from his Manhattan office to his home in Short Hills, N.J. He was 52 years old.

title: BUTCHER & SINGER PICKS ITS CHAIRMAN AND CHIEF
description: Jonathan Butcher, 41, has been named chairman and chief executive officer of Butcher & Singer Inc., the big Philadelphia securities firm co-founded by his grandfather Howard in 1910. As chairman, he succeeds his uncle, W.W. Keene Butcher, who is stepping down at age 65 after seven years in the post.

title: No Headline
description: ''I have a general problem with taxes that don't get paid.

title: Zaire's President and His Young Retinue
description: They've had to replace the elegant Georgian-style mahogany dining room table that seats only 14 with a nondescript banquet model, but nobody at the Waldorf-Astoria was complaining yesterday.

title: 'CHRISTGAU'S RECORD GUIDE'
description: A NUMBER of rock-and-roll reference books have been published in recent months, but one stands out because it is both obsessively complete and caustically outspoken. It is ''Christgau's Record Guide'' (Ticknor and Fields), and in it the longtime rock critic Robert Christgau provides a thumbnail review of every rock album issued in the 1970's, along with lists of his favorite rock records from the 1950's through the 80's and a typically contentious introductory essay.

title: TV: LYNN REDGRAVE IN COMEDY 'TEACHERS ONLY'
description: LYNN REDGRAVE departed from one situation comedy, CBS-TV's ''House Calls,'' reportedly because the producers would not allow her to breast feed her new baby on the set. She is now back in another situation comedy, ''Teachers Only'' on NBC-TV Wednesdays at 9:30, and it would seem that she should come up with another unusual excuse to get out of this one.

title: TEXAS PACIFIC LAND TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Exercise Bicycle Recall Ignored By Thousands
description: Thousands of consumers have not responded to a recall of exercise bicycles, despite the possibility of serious injury if the equipment malfunctions, the Food and Drug Administration said today.

title: BOARD ACTS AGAINST 3 JOCKEYS
description: The State Racing and Wagering Board yesterday ordered three jockeys to show cause why their licenses to ride in New York should not be revoked or suspended for their possible involvement in fixed races in the mid-1970's.

title: Advertising; Harper's To Slash Circulation
description: Troubled Harper's magazine, as part of its search for economic viability, will be cutting its circulation rate base by more than half with its July issue, to 140,000 from 325,000.

title: VAN DYK RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
NEW YORK PENSION SYSTEM CALLED VULNERABLE TO FRAUD ON DISABILITY
description: Inefficiencies and staff shortages have made New York City's largest pension system vulnerable to fraud by workers seeking to retire on tax-free disability pensions, according to the city's Department of Investigation.

title: BOISE CASCADE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
GOING OUT GUIDE
description: CHINA PRINTS

title: CAMBEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
description: B-Including extraordinary tax credits of $42,000 for the qr and $116,000 for the 6 mos...C-Including extraordinary tax credits of $39,000 for the qr and $52,000 for the 6 mos

title: ANOTHER RISE EXPECTED SOON IN THE PRICE OF PEANUT BUTTER
description: Peanut butter does not cost peanuts anymore. But the average national price, which soared last year because of a crop failure, has fallen back in step with inflation, according to a survey conducted by the Peanut Advisory Board, a trade group for growers.

title: Amax Reduces Colorado Mining
description: Amax Inc., the mining and metals producer, said it would begin in early May an additional 20 percent reduction in manpower and production at its molybdenum operations in Colorado. Some 380 employees at the Climax mine and about 230 employees at the Henderson mine will be affected.

title: DAMON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: B-Including a gain of $129,300 for the qr and 6 mos from disposal of discontinued operations

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alberto-Culver Co., Melrose Park, Ill., has named Charles M. Abate vice president, personnel.

title: Edward M. Benford
description: Edward M. Benford, 55 years old of Hawthorne, N.Y., was a manager in the videotape maintenance unit who had been with CBS for 34 years. Mr. Benford, a bachelor, is survived by a brother.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: WHILE working recently on several recipes for shad, I recalled that in my young days as an apprentice chef in Paris, shad, known in French as alose, rarely appeared on menus. If it did, it was almost invariably shad with sorrel sauce. I think I know why. In those days (and I believe this is also true today) boned shad was not widely available in the fish markets of France. I had, to be truthful, never heard of a boned fillet of the fish until I came to this country.

title: ALLIS-CHALMERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Market Place; Pantry Pride: Lure of Losses
description: Pantry Pride is like a reluctant bride with a big dowry who will not wed unless treated in a manner suitable to her station. Thus, the deal this once-bankrupt supermarket chain had struck with Supermarkets General fell through following objections over terms.

title: 28 on U.S. Cargo Plane Believed Dead in Turkey
description: An American C-130 cargo plane carrying 28 military personnel crashed this afternoon on a mountain near Erzincan, 500 miles from Ankara, in eastern Turkey. Sources in the American Embassy here said that although there was no official confirmation, they did not believe anyone had survived.

title: 8 Hurt in School Bus Crash
description: Eight junior high school pupils were injured today when their school bus crashed into the rear of a car, the police said. Two of the children were taken to a hospital after they complained of neck injuries. The others were treated for minor injuries.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Anatole Broyard MOMENTS OF VISION. By Kenneth Clark.191 pages. Harper & Row. $13.50.

title: ONE NEW LOOK: PLAIN AND SIMPLE
description: ONE of the more successful breakfast foods introduced in the past year is Kellogg's Nutri-Grain, a sugarless line aimed at the healthconscious consumer. The cereals, which have won wide acceptance, are also notable for their packages. On the boxes are botanical drawings of the particular grains - wheat, corn, rye or barley - against a white background. The colors are subdued and the lettering is almost austere when seen amid the carnival of colors that is the average supermarket shelf.

title: INCOME SURTAX AND LEVY ON FUELS ARE FOCUS OF BUDGET NEGOTIATIONS
description: A temporary increase in income taxes, perhaps only for taxpayers above some middle-income threshold, and a broad tax on energy have emerged as much-debated possibilities in the secret, three-sided budget negotiations that resumed today.

title: BRITISH OFFICIALS PESSIMISTIC ON U.S. DIPLOMATIC EFFORTS
description: A spokesman for the British Government said tonight that the American diplomatic initiative on the Falkland Islands crisis appeared to have collapsed. But Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said before flying back to Washington that he had ''received some new ideas'' that Britain and Argentina were studying.

title: JOHN GARKLAVS
description: Archbishop John Garklavs, retired prelate of the Midwest Diocese of the Russian Orthodox Church, died Sunday.

title: KITCHEN EQUIPMENT
description: A Spectacular dinner-party dish is pate encased in a light pastry crust with sweeping fluted sides. And it is not as difficult to make as you would think. An essential tool for such a pate is, of course, a mold. Tin molds for this purpose have been used in France at least since the beginning of the 19th century, the time of the great chef Careme, who contributed more than a hundred molds and utensils to the current batterie de cuisine.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch Monday on Bonn-Washington relations incorrectly identified Walter Wallmann, a West German Christian Democrat. He is Mayor of Frankfurt.

title: PRESIDENT WHISTLE-BLOWER AT E.P.A.
description: Hugh B. Kaufman is once again busily biting the hand that feeds him. Mr. Kaufman, who is assistant to the director of the hazardous site control division of the Environmental Protection Agency, is a whistle-blower, one of a tiny minority of Government employees willing to risk their careers to expose what they perceive to be a failure by an administration or agency to serve the public interest. In the past, most of them have paid for their whistling with their jobs.

title: Former Official in Iran May Face Firing Squad
description: Sadegh Ghotbzadeh, the former Foreign Minister of Iran, will face a firing squad if he is convicted of plotting to kill Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, Iran's revolutionary leader, judicial authorities in Teheran said today.

title: BELOW ISSUING HIS FIRST SOLO ALBUM
description: ADRIAN BELEW is the hotshot rock guitarist of the moment. Ever since Frank Zappa plucked the Cincinnati-born guitarist out of a Nashville bar band five years ago, he has been about as busy as any one musician could be, playing lead guitar in the studio and on the road with some of rock's leading innovators - David Bowie, Talking Heads, and most recently the re-formed progressive-rock group King Crimson. Last year he toured with the Talking Heads and then, when they decided to take a vacation from the band and make solo albums, he played on all three of those solo albums. He wrote and sang the lyrics for all the songs on the first album from the new King Crimson, and has recently done the same for a second King Crimson album.

title: GENENTECH TO SELL 6.5% TO CORNING
description: The Corning Glass Works said yesterday that it would buy 6.5 percent of the common shares of Genentech Inc., a leading genetic engineering company, and that the two companies would establish a jointly owned venture to develop enzymes for use in the food processing and chemical industries.

title: ARENTINA WARNS OF WAR TO HOLD ON TO FALKLANDS
description: Argentine officials said today that the Government was willing to make some further minor concessions on administration of the Falkland Islands, but added that the country would go to war with Britain before it would concede sovereignty.

title: GERMAN 'TICKET OF NO RETURN'
description: ''TICKET OF NO RETURN'' ostensibly has a serious subject, but it's really more of a fashion statement than a film. A beautiful, silent, very model-like young woman - the character is called ''She'' in the credits - wanders sullenly through Berlin. She has realized, as the film's very sparing narration tells us, that ''to finally follow her destiny was her sole wish.'' And with this in mind, she has vowed to pursue the life of a drunkard.

title: Procter & Gamble Opens Defense Case on Tampon
description: Procter & Gamble did not immediately remove Rely tampons from the market or issue a warning because preliminary reports indicated that a low risk of toxic shock syndrome was involved, a former company executive testified today.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Continental Steel Corp. said it had agreed in principle to sell its aggregates and construction division for $14 million. The company said it expected to incur a book loss of about $8 million in connection with the sale.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: ARLETTE BRISSON lives in a pleasant apartment building on the Upper East Side and, like most New Yorkers, when she gets into the elevator she exchanges a good morning with her neighbors and not much else.

title: HILTON HOTELS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Including a nonrecurring gain of $1.1 million or 4 cents a shr from the sale of surplus property

title: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 14, 1982; The Economy
description: A temporary income-tax rise, perhaps only for taxpayers earning more than $30,000 or $40,000, and an energy tax were among the proposals considered in budget talks held by House, Senate and Administration negotiators. The talks, which apparently made little progress, were suspended until next week. (Page A1.)

title: EGYPT DENIES ANY VIOLATIONS OF PEACE ACCORDS WITH ISRAEL
description: Egypt has denied published Israeli complaints that it is violating either the letter or the spirit of the Camp David agreements.

title: Phnom Penh Says U.S. Gives Asian Allies Chemical Arms
description: The Vietnamese-backed Government in Cambodia charges that the United States has introduced chemical weapons into Thailand and Pakistan, the Hanoi radio reported today.

title: FOTOMAT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Including a gain of $1.9 million or 21 cents a shr on the sale of capital assets

title: Italian Police Arrest 3
description: Policemen arrested three suspected members of the extreme leftist group called Front Line here Monday, the authorities said today. Arms, documents and leaflets were found during the raid, sources close to the investigation said. They gave no other details.

title: BRENCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-After a loss of $646,000 from discontinued operations

title: Coast Developers Accused by S.E.C.
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it had charged several California real estate developers with securities violations involving a scheme to gain influence in the control of the Financial Federation Inc., a savings and loan holding company.

title: OUSTED AIDE DOUBTS '82 ACTION ON TUITION CREDIT
description: The recently dismissed Under Secretary of Education, William C. Clohan Jr., predicted today that Congress would not act this year on President Reagan's proposal for a tuition tax credit for parents of private school pupils.

title: WOMAN ACCEPTED AS A FIREFIGHTER
description: The name on the Fire Department's roster is ''Jones'' and the firefighter works the hose line for an engine company here. That Jacqueline Jones is the only woman among 647 Newark firefighters seems beside the point to her colleagues, her bosses and the men who trained her to take up her duties.

title: ART LEADERS TELL OF WOES IN BUDGET CUT
description: The cast was first-rate, the hall was a typical Off Off Broadway theater, but the script of this documentary, a work in progress, is unfinished but seems to be veering toward tragedy. The event, which took place yesterday morning, was a one-man Congressional hearing by Representative S. William Green, Manhattan Republican, who heard leaders in the arts describe how they were coping with Federal budget cuts.

title: Pabst Meeting Is Adjourned to April 27
description: The annual meeting of the embattled Pabst Brewing Company was adjourned here today until April 27 to allow election inspectors time to tally the vote in a bitter and apparently close proxy battle.

title: JERSEY'S NEW SENATOR YIELDS BUSINESS TIES
description: Nicholas F. Brady, a 52-year-old Republican who was appointed earlier this week as United States Senator from New Jersey to complete the term of former Senator Harrison A. William Jr., has said that he would resign from all of his business affiliations during his term of office. Senator Brady was appointed by Governor Kean to fill a caretaker role until a new senator is elected in November.

title: INVENTORIES CUT BY 0.4% IN FEBRUARY
description: United States businesses cut their inventories four-tenths of 1 percent in February, the third consecutive monthly decline, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: De Tocqueville on Tape
description: Partly because of his own handicap - he is hard of hearing - Senator Charles H. Percy will soon begin tape-recording Alexis de Tocqueville's 700-page classic, ''Democracy in America,'' for a blind woman.

title: The Talk of Holtsville
description: Shortly before 3 A.M. on weekdays at this time of the year, a heavily loaded 18-wheel van heads south off the Long Island Expressway and lumbers through this small Suffolk County community. Another van rolls through at 6. A smaller truck arrives between 7:30 and 8.

title: SEMICONDUCTOR MAKERS EXPAND RESEARCH FUND
description: To fend off growing Japanese competition, manufacturers of silicon memory chips today announced plans to expand university research spending to $20 million over the next two years.

title: Woman Convicted Of Harboring Soviet Spy
description: A jury late today found Gloria Ann White guilty of harboring a convicted Soviet spy, Christopher Boyce, and helping him plan bank robberies in three Western states.

title: SPENCER COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
CAREY BUDGET VETOS LIKELY TO FORCE TALKS ON TRANSIT PLAN
description: Budget vetoes by Governor Carey may force renegotiation of an intricate transit aid package that was passed last year to preserve the 75-cent New York City bus and subway fare, legislators and aides to the Governor said today.

title: SAGA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 27
HYDROPOWER FOR ALL?
description: To the Editor:

title: Coke Cancels Deal To Get Outlet Co.
description: The Coca-Cola Company has canceled an earlier agreement to acquire the Outlet Company, a Rhode Island-based owner of radio and television stations, the companies announced today.

title: PLAYBOY OFFICERS TO SELL CASINO IN ATLANTIC CITY
description: Playboy Enterprises notified the Casino Control Commission today that it would sell its Atlantic City casino rather than sever ties with its founder and chairman, Hugh M. Hefner, who holds a 66 percent interest in the company.

title: Cuban Official to Visit Paris
description: Vice President Carlos Rafael Rodriguez of Cuba will visit France May 3, the French Government said today. He will be the highest-ranking Cuban official ever to visit to Paris.

title: Iraq Reports Four Violations Of Its Airspace by Syrian Jets
description: Iraq said today that Syrian jets violated Iraqi airspace four times in hopes of diverting Iraq from its war with Iran and forcing it to open a second front against Syria.

title: LET THE PROFIT MOTIVE HELP OUR OIL RESERVE
description: To the Editor:

title: Wing of the Louvre Escapes Fire Damage
description: A fire broke out today in the Pavillon de Flore of the Louvre but firefighters put it out before it could spread.

title: UNITED STATIONERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
FACET ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $626,000 for the qr and $824,000for the 6 mos and tax credits of $234,000 for the qr and $341,000 for the 6 mos...C-After a loss of $67,000 from discontinued operations...D-Net loss after a loss of $247,000 from discontinued operations

title: ONCE HELD BRONX HOUSE SEAT
description: Sidney A. Fine, a former United States Representative and a retired justice of State Supreme Court, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital after a long illness. He was 78 years old and a resident of Manhattan.

title: PENNSYLVANIA REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Feb
description: Results includes gains of $83,000 for the qr and $172,000 for the 6 mos from interest earned on a land loan; also, the 1981 6 mos net includes $103,000 gain from interest

title: West Coast Storm Sets Rain and Snow Records
description: By United Press International A new storm swept down from the Gulf of Alaska yesterday on the tracks of a deluge that sent tons of mud onto California highways and pushed rainfall totals to the highest since 1862.

title: Hotel Companies' Net
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation, citing severe winter weather and the recession, reported yesterday that its first-quarter profit tumbled 18.5 percent, to $21.9 million, or 82 cents a share, from $27 million, or $1.02 a share, in the same 1981 period.

title: OUTSIDE ACTIVITIES AND COLLEGE ADMISSION
description: Outstanding extracurricular activities seldom help students with mediocre grades to gain admission to selective colleges and universities, a recent study indicates.

title: Required Reading Old Antitrust Story
description: Attorney General William French Smith, speaking to the American Bar Association's Section on Antitrust Law, April 1, 1982: There is an old antitrust story concerning one of the ''malefactors of great wealth,'' to use Teddy Roosevelt's words.

title: O.A.S. ADOPTS RESOLUTION EXPRESSING ITS CONCERN
description: After several days of debate and a lastminute attempt by Caribbean nations to insert stronger language, the Organization of American States passed a resolution today expressing its ''concern'' over the Falkland Islands crisis and offering its ''friendly cooperation'' to peace efforts already under way.

title: FAMILY DOLLAR STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
3 TV Networks Boycott Speech by the President
description: Three television networks today boycotted President Reagan's luncheon address to a group of national religious leaders as a protest of new rules on network coverage of the President.

title: Transactions;
description: BASEBALL

title: The U.N. Today; April 14, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee on Non-Use of Force in International Relations - 10:30 A.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: WILLAMETTE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Net income; results reflect a 3 percent stock divd

title: POSTERS HINT AT ANTI-SOLIDARITY DRIVE
description: In what appear to be preparations for new criticisms of Solidarity, the independent labor union, thousands of posters directly attacking Lech Walesa and other union leaders have been printed in Warsaw and, it seems, are awaiting only the right moment to be posted.

title: Mobil May Leave Libya
description: The Mobil Corporation is negotiating a withdrawal from its oil operations in Libya, industry sources said yesterday.John Flint, a spokesman for Mobil, said he could neither confirm nor deny the reports.

title: ENGRAPH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 27
HAIG AND KISSINGER DISPUTED ON TIES TO NIXON 'PLUMBERS
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. was more closely involved in White House wiretaps and the ''plumbers'' operation in the Nixon Administration than he has acknowledged, according to an article in the May issue of The Atlantic Monthly.

title: COMPUTER TASK GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
LIEUT. SMITH, SAMUEL JOHNSON AND THE FALKLANDS
description: To the Editor: From ''The Life of Samuel Johnson,'' by James Boswell: ''In 1771 (Johnson) published another political pamphlet, entitled ''Thoughts on the late Transactions respecting Falkland's Islands,'' in which, upon materials furnished to him by ministry, and upon general topicks expanded in his richest style, he successfully endeavoured to persuade the nation that it was wise and laudable to suffer the question of right to remain undecided, rather than involve our country in another war.$''It has been suggested by some, with what truth I shall not take upon me to decide, that he rated the consequence of those islands to Great-Britain too low.

title: 40,845 SEE METS TOP PHILS IN SHEA OPENER
description: New York got its first look at the recast Mets yesterday, and the Mets responded with dramatic flair: They overcame the Philadelphia Phillies, 5-2, and for the second time in a week defeated Steve Carlton, the leading left-handed strikeout pitcher in baseball history.

title: Nestle's Net Up in 1981
description: Nestle S.A., the food and beverage concern, reported today that its 1981 net income was more than three-and-a-half times its 1980 profit on a 13.3 percent gain in sales.

title: ARCO: IMPACT OF CREDIT BAN New Canaan, Conn.
description: From the perspective of the Atlantic Richfield Company, canceling all three million of its credit cards is a bold piece of corporate marketing strategy. But the view from the pumps of Cactus Arco, on Grant Road, in Tucson, Ariz., is not as sanguine.

title: VERBATIM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 1
Kurtz & Tarlow Named Loewe U.S.A. Agency
description: Kurtz & Tarlow, which became a unit of Geers, Gross Inc., has been named agency for Loewe U.S.A., the recently created division of a 136-year-old leather goods manufacturer and retailer whose shops are well known in Europe and the Far East.

title: Pastime Goes National
description: Three baseball fans are seeking to establish what they think would be a baseball record by attempting to see all 26 major league teams play in one week. Bill Rattray and Joe Hoban of Houston, and Miles Berry of Los Angeles, who are airline employees, completed the fourth day of their expedition on Monday by watching the New York Yankees play the Rangers at Arlington, Tex., after having flown from St. Louis and the Cardinals-Pirates afternoon game.

title: INTERSTATE BAKERIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $587,000 for the qr and $297,000for the 9 mos and tax credits of $63,000 for the qr and $195,000 for the 9 mos

title: Clark Copy Signs China Contract
description: The Clark Copy International Corporation, a small manufacturer of photocopy machines based in Chicago, said it had signed a 20-year contract to manufacture and distribute its plain paper copier and other products in China.

title: Selmon Satisfied
description: Dewey Selmon, whose recent trade from Tampa Bay to San Diego became a focal point in contract negotiations between the National Football League and the Players Association, said he discussed the trade with officials of both clubs before choosing to join the Chargers. Stan White of the Detroit Lions, a member of the players' executive committee, said Monday there would be no collective bargaining agreement reached unless clubs stopped trading away player representatives, and he specifically mentioned Selmon.

title: Betty Blake, Ex-Officer Of the Delta Queen Co.
description: Betty Blake, who was president of the Delta Queen Steamboat Company and later had her own public relations concern, died today of cancer. She was 51 years old.

title: 'High School' Delayed
description: ''Is There Life After High School?,'' the musical which was to have opened tomorrow at the Ethel Barrymore Theater, will open instead on Monday, May 3. The opening was postponed because Melvin Bernhardt withdrew as director and was replaced by Robert Nigro. The show, which has music and lyrics by Craig Carnelia and book by Jeffrey Kindley, has been in previews since March 26.

title: UNITED ARTISTS COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 25
FEDERATED GUARANTY LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Private School Aid Is Still a Bad Idea
description: Perhaps to pacify a constituency that is angered by cuts in college aid, President Reagan is about to propose tuition tax credits for the parents of private-school children. The idea is awful and the timing is worse. Financing private and parochial schools through tax subsidies endangers public education and diverts Federal funds from worthier projects.

title: BANKS FORBIDDEN TO CHALLENGE MONEY FUNDS
description: To the Editor:

title: A DIMINISHING U.S. MINERAL DEPENDENCE ON SOUTH AFRICA
description: To the Editor:

title: OWENS-CORNING FIBERGLAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Net income; prior yr reflects the adoption of F.A.S.B. statement No 52

title: Official for Coliseum Testifies in Raider Trial
description: William Robertson, a member of the Los Angeles Coliseum Commission, testified today that his six meetings in 1979 with Al Davis, the general managing partner of the Oakland Raiders, did not constitute negotiations.

title: CANCELED PROGRAM STIRS PBS DISPUTE
description: A documentary on the insurrection in former Spanish Sahara was broadcast tonight at 8 P.M. on the Public Broadcasting Service television station in New York City, WNET-TV, and a few other public television stations. But PBS did not make the program available to its full network around the country at the same time because of a dispute over its journalistic quality.

title: SOUTHWEST FLORIDA BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
A's 7, Twins 5
description: MINNEAPOLIS (UPI) - Tony Armas hit his second homer of the game, a two-run drive with two out in the 12th inning, to give Oakland the victory. Cliff Johnson singled off Minnesota's Fernando Arroyo (0-1) before Armas connected.

title: AROUND THE NATION
description: Low-fat cottage cheese made by Meadow Gold Dairies was recalled today on Oahu, Hawaii's most populous island. It was the fifth state-ordered recall of a dairy product since March 18 because of pesticide contamination.

title: AM's BRIGHTEST YEARS NOW DIM MEMORIES
description: In 1893, an inventor named Joseph Duncan breezed into Chicago to find his fortune with an automatic addressing machine. He sold a dozen of them in a year's time and was heartened enough to form the Addressograph Company in 1896. Meanwhile, Henry Gammeter had concocted a machine that could duplicate a complete line or a complete page of characters at a single stroke. In December 1902, he formed the American Multigraph Company in Chicago.

title: Market Place; PERT's Fight With Tenant
description: SHAREHOLDERS of Produce Exchange Realty Trust are holding fast, waiting to see how much rent their prize tenant is going to pay. The outcome will determine the value of their infrequently traded shares.

title: TEXAS OIL & GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
McDonnell Given Jet Certification
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said it had received Federal Aviation Administration type certification for its DC-8 Super 71 jet and that first deliveries would be made later this month.

title: 3 EDITORS AT THE TIMES GET NEW ASSIGNMENTS
description: A change of assignments for three editors of The New York Times was announced yesterday by Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, the paper's publisher. Charlotte Curtis, editor of the Op-Ed page since 1974 and an associate editor of The Times, will write a regular column in the news pages starting in June. She will be succeeded by Robert B. Semple Jr., who has been foreign news editor. Mr. Semple's deputy, Craig R. Whitney, will become foreign news editor.

title: DETROITBANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
U.S. JUDGE BARS LANDFILL PROJECT FOR THE WESTWAY
description: A court order prohibiting all work on a Hudson River landfill needed for the Westway highway project was issued yesterday in Manhattan, carrying out a court decision concerning the project's effect on striped bass.

title: TWO ARABS WOUNDED IN MIDEAST STRIFE
description: Two Arabs were reported wounded by gunfire today and at least 10 Israelis were hit by rocks in protests over Sunday's rifle attack at the Dome of the Rock Mosque by an Americanborn Israeli soldier.

title: TITAN GROUP INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes $2,139,000 provision for judgement under appeal and $675,000 gain from disposition of assets...C-Net income including $327,000 gain from dispositionof assets and $13,272,000 gain on restructuring of debt

title: Garden Puts a $60 Top On Holmes-Cooney TV
description: A ticket for the closed-circuit telecast of the Larry Holmes-Gerry Cooney heavyweight title fight June 11 at Las Vegas, Nev., will cost as much as $60, Madison Square Garden said yesterday.

title: NEW JERSEY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
PHILADELPHIA NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
QUENN BEGINNING FOUR-DAY VISIT TO CANADA TODAY
description: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, often accused of being a republican at heart, will greet Queen Elizabeth II in Ottawa Thursday as a loyal, even eager, subject.

title: J.P. MORGAN PROFITS INCREASE 22.5%
description: Despite a $30 million negative swing in foreign exchange income, net operating earnings of J.P. Morgan & Company rose 22.5 percent, to $99.5 million, in the first quarter of 1982, from $81.2 million reported in the period a year-earlier, Lewis T. Preston, chairman, told the bank's annual meeting yesterday.

title: AMERICAN MEN OF 1776 SAID TO HAVE STOOD TALL
description: A Princeton University professor says he does not know why Colonial beds and doors were so small, since early Americans weren't significantly smaller than Americans today.

title: Iranian Leftists Raid Consulate in Geneva
description: Eighteen Iranian leftists ransacked the Iranian consulate in Geneva today and held six officials hostage for two and a half hours before surrendering, the police said.

title: Broker Suspended At Dean Witter
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission charged Ernest E. Suwara, a broker in the Butler, Mo., office of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. with making false statements to induce customers to buy common stock of Victoria Station Inc., a specialty restaurant chain based in Larkspur, Calif.

title: RUBBERMAID INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Helpful Hardware; 2 TOOL CARRIERS
description: THERE are two capacious tool carriers, as handsome as they are practical, now available that permit you to transport your equipment easily.

title: HARLAND, JOHN H, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
NEW ENGLAND MERCHANTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Includes $5,3 million gain from the sale of an aircraft

title: No Headline
description: Vladimir Horowitz, absent from London for 31 years, will give two concerts there next month, in the Royal Festival Hall. The pianist, speaking yesterday at a news conference at his home in Manhattan, said that the first concert, on May 22, would be a benefit at the invitation of Prince Charles. The second concert will take place May 29.

title: REAGAN NAMES PANEL TO CUT DRUNKEN DRIVING DEATH TOLL
description: President Reagan began a highway safety campaign today in an effort to reduce drunken driving. The President established a 30-member commission to work with state and local governments. The panel will be headed by John A. Volpe, a former Governor of Massachusetts who was Secretary of Transportation in the Nixon Administration.

title: Interest Rates Rise Slightly
description: Interest rates rose slightly yesterday as investors remained nervous about rapid money supply growth expected in April. ''The M-1 demon again dominates the near-term market outlook,'' economists at the securities firm of Mabon, Nugent & Company concluded in a recent publication, referring to a basic money supply measure that covers currency and all checking accounts at banks and thrift institutions.

title: LONDON TOLD ISLANDERS FACE NO HARDSHIP
description: In the first official report on conditions in the Argentine-occupied Falkland Islands, a former colonial administrator told the British Government today that the population there was facing no serious hardships.

title: ONE MORE UPSET?
description: SUDDENLY the Stanley Cup playoffs are over in Montreal and Edmonton, but they're really just beginning in New York. For the third time in the last four years, the Islanders and the Rangers will collide, starting tonight at Nassau Coliseum, in a best four-of-seven series. It's known as a divisional final in the new playoff structure but don't be confused. It's still the quarterfinal round for the Stanley Cup itself, the silver chalice that the Islanders should win for the third consecutive year.

title: Hawaiian Haze Tied to Dust
description: Hawaii's skies are hazy this week because of a cloud of volcanic dust, the National Weather Service said, and the condition may last for several days. The dust is suspended about 60,000 feet in the air and is drifting eastward at 40 miles an hour. It may have come from recent volcanic eruptions in Mexico or Indonesia, the Weather Service said.

title: SOUTHERN PACIFIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Includes $2.1 million gain from the sale of Federal income taxes benefits

title: Ex-Mental Patient Is Given 5 Years for Robbery Attempt
description: A former mental patient, Eric Roberts, who held 76 bank customers and employees hostage for seven hours, was sentenced today to five years and four months in prison for the attempted armed robbery of a Davis, Calif., bank.

title: VIEWING YOUR FILM AND TAPE AT LIBRARY
description: In an effort to get more people to use its books and other research facilities, the Brooklyn Public Library has introduced a free program that allows area residents to view and edit their own videotapes, super-eight films and slides.

title: News Analysis
description: Fifteen years ago the nation was engaged in a debate over how poor people should be helped, whether they should be given cash or such noncash benefits as food, medical care and housing, in addition to their relatively meager welfare payments.

title: PETRIE STORES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-After $985,445 capital loss; shr earnings reflect a 3-for-4 stock split on Oct 22, 1981

title: Philippines to Seek Oil
description: The Philippines plans to step up oil exploration and is discussing with contractors possible incentives for drilling, the energy minister, Geronimo Velasco, said today on a Government-sponsored television program. Mr. Velasco said that an average of about 30 wells a year had been drilled in the Philippines between 1973 and 1981. ''We would like to see that momentum increased further,'' the minister added. The Philippines currently produces about 13,000 barrels of oil daily from two offshore oil areas, he said.

title: Contraceptive Clinics Pledge Confidentiality
description: Planned Parenthood said today that it would continue to offer contraceptives to minors in confidence even though the Government said their parents should be notified.

title: NETS WIN AND CLINCH PLAYOFF BIRTH
description: In a season that began with only three victories in the first 15 games, the Nets qualified for their second playoff berth in six seasons in the National Basketball Association by defeating the Washington Bullets, 98-94, before 13,382 fans at Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight.

title: O.& M. to Open Office In Melbourne, Australia
description: Ogilvy & Mather Direct has opened an office in Auckland, New Zealand, and on May 1 will open its 24th outpost, this time in Melbourne, Australia.

title: IDEOLOGY AND IGNORANCE
description: Anyone who wants to know why U.S. foreign policy is up to its neck in disasters these days will find illumination in some recent comments by Jeane Kirkpatrick, President Reagan's Ambassador to the United Nations. She was defending her decision to appear as guest of honor at an Argentine Embassy dinner the night after Argentina invaded the Falkland Islands.

title: ARGO PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
AM FILES CHAPTER 11 PETITION
description: AM International Inc., the old Addressograph-Multigraph Corporation that has been struggling for months to overcome rising debts and continuing losses, announced today that it had filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act while it tried to reorganize.

title: LAW ON REALTY SALE TAX MAY UNDERGO CHANGES
description: A law that would require New York City to return $9 million in taxes to large real-estate developers may be substantially modified, legislative aides said today.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF THE NEWS CONFERENCE HELD BY REAGAN AT THE WHITE HOUSE
description: Following is a transcript of the second of a series of weekly informal question-and-answer sessions with reporters by President Reagan at the White House yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of Cable News Network. Mr. Reagan began with a comment on Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.'s efforts to avert a British-Argentine military clash over the Falkland Islands. Opening Statement

title: INDUSTRIAL NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
ALPINE INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: FLOOR coverings of resilient tile, such as vinyl or vinyl-asbestos, and sheet flooring made of those materials will normally last for many years in the average residence if maintained with reasonable care. However, even the best materials may be damaged by falling objects or by stains that cannot be removed.

title: Southern Pacific Plunges
description: The Southern Pacific Company said today that its first-quarter income plunged 90.8 percent, largely because its rail division was hard hit by a General Motors shutdown of two plants and because costs were high for cleaning up a formaldehyde spill from a railroad tanker.

title: AGAINST I.R.S. AID CUTBACKS. AND TAXES, TOO.
description: Hundreds of thousands of taxpayers will rush to file their 1981 income tax forms at the last minute tonight. In all the furor in Washington over how much to raise taxes, the taxpayers seem to have been left out of the discussion. The disbursement of tax funds - for El Salvador's junta, for the Department of Health and Human Services, for water projects and MX missiles - has come to dominate questions of tax policy, as politicians wrangle over how big the deficit will be and how much must be raised to meet expenditures. The collection of taxes has been ignored in the debate.

title: TOPPS CHEWING GUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
description: B-Includes tax credits of $397,000 for the qr and $1,914,000 for the yr...C-Includes $1,578,000 tax credit

title: NUCLEAR ARMS AND A 'CONSPIRACY OF SILENCE'
description: To the Editor:

title: Benton & Bowles Wins Quincy's Steak Account
description: Benton & Bowles, for seven years the agency for the Hardee's Hamburger Restaurant chain, has been named agency for Quincy's Family Steak House.

title: COLT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 4
description: B-After a loss of $11,520,000 from the operations of the discontinued crucible stainless and alloy division and a tax charge of $39,380,000...C-Net income after a loss of $13,287,000 from operations of the discontinued crucible stainless and alloy division

title: CALIFOLRNIA CONSIDERS NEW JAIL IN MODULAR SECTIONS
description: Officials in Santa Clara County are considering a proposal to build what they say would be the nation's first county jail with a modular design, a procedure that is expected to cut the construction time by as much as two-thirds and also reduce the cost.

title: GRAFTON GROUP LTD reports earnings for Yr to Jan 31
description: B-After a writeoff of $5,398,000 related to an investment of Elks Inc

title: Protestant Militants Seized in Ulster
description: The police arrested five officials of the Ulster Defense Association today and seized submachine-gun parts and more than 1,000 rounds of ammunition in a raid on the Protestant group's headquarters.

title: Bridge:; Perhaps Grandma Knew, But Times Have Changed
description: Many veteran players learned the game from grandmothers who had started with whist, before any form of bridge was current. Whistplaying grandmothers were full of rules of thumb - second low, third high, fourth of your longest and strongest -and so on.

title: MEREDITH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
BANCO DE PONCE (NYC) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
2 Cities to Lay Off Teachers
description: The St. Louis school board voted Tuesday night to lay off 289 teachers at the end of the school year, the city's biggest teacher reduction ever. In Kansas City, Mo., 132 teachers will be laid off by July, city officials announced earlier in the day. Officials in both cities said the layoffs were needed to reduce costs.

title: Panama Asking Talks On British Naval Force
description: Panama, the only Security Council member to support Argentina's seizure of the Falkland Islands, asked today for urgent informal talks among Council members to halt Britain's naval task force.

title: Expos 5, Pirates 4
description: MONTREAL (UPI) - Jerry White hit a pinch three-run homer in the sixth inning to lead Montreal in its home opener before a crowd of 35,941.

title: NAPLES FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (FLA) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 3
RANGERS DEFEAT YANKEES AND PACELLA, 4-1
description: When the Yankees make a one-day stop in Columbus, Ohio, next Monday for an exhibition game against their Class AAA team, John Pacella may be unpacking his bags for a longer stay. Pacella made a move in that direction tonight, when he was the losing pitcher as the Yankees were beaten, 4-1, by the Texas Rangers. In five innings, Pacella yielded four runs, four hits and four walks.

title: India-Japan Car Deal
description: Japan's Suzuki Motor Company and India's Government-owned Maruti Industries signed a preliminary agreement today to build small cars, microbuses and pickup trucks in the Maruti factory outside New Delhi, the Government radio announced. Financial details were not disclosed. The announcement said a formal 10-year agreement would be concluded in June and production would start by the end of 1983.

title: KROGER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
BINKS MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
CORRECTION
description: In some copies yesterday, a sports article about a labor complaint filed by the National Football League Players Association incorrectly identified the Kansas City newspaper that had polled a number of players. It was The Kansas City Times.

title: Alouettes Sale Delayed
description: Jake Gaudaur, the commissioner of the Canadian Football League, has appointed a committee to look into the efforts of Nelson Skalbania to sell the Montreal Alouettes to a group of investors led by George Allen, the team's president. Gaudaur's action, which was taken because of confusing reports out of Montreal as to who already owns which piece of the team, effectively blocks the transfer of the controlling interest until the committee reports to the league next month.

title: Tight Security in Ottawa
description: The police have mounted extra security outside the American, French and Swiss embassies here because they could be targets for Armenian extremists, officials said today. France and Switzerland have arrested Armenians in the past for attacks on Turkish officials. In the United States, an Armenian faces trial for the murder in January of a Turkish diplomat in Los Angeles.

title: GANNETT CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
A-Plant's Reopening Delayed for 2 Weeks
description: The Robert E. Ginna nuclear power plant, which is operated by the Rochester Gas and Electric Corporation, will not be placed back in operation on May 1 as scheduled, a utility spokesman said.

title: Boy vs. Rachmaninoff
description: Mstislav Rostropovich knew Dimitris Sgouros was special, the cellist was saying yesterday, when he first heard about him from friends in Paris. But Mr. Rostropovich, who is also the conductor of the National Symphony Orchestra, didn't know just how special the 12-year-old pianist might be until he was asked what he wanted to play at his American debut tonight during the orchestra's Tchaikovsky festival at Carnegie Hall.''

title: 3 HOUSEMATES CHARGED IN MURDER OF RETARDED MAN
description: One of three defendants charged in the slaying of a mentally impaired 47-year-old man, who had reportedly been a virtual slave for several years, agreed today. to testify for the prosecution.

title: Mets Beat Phillies; Schmidt Out 2 Weeks
description: Pete Rose observed his 41st birthday yesterday at Shea Stadium, played in his 470th consecutive game, got no hits as the rousing Mets sent the Philadelphia Phillies to their fifth loss in six games and then reflected, ''When you lose, it's no fun.''

title: U.S. PROVIDING BRITISH WITH WIDE RANGE OF INTELLIGENCE
description: The United States is providing Britain with political and military information on Argentina from a full range of American intelligence resources, Administration officials said today.

title: Watt Sued on Approval Of a Coyote Poison
description: The Humane Society of the United States filed suit today against Interior Secretary James G. Watt to require him to abandon plans to allow the use of a poison to kill coyotes and to make him prohibit the killing of coyote pups in their dens.

title: Court Refuses to Order Treatment for a Baby
description: The Indiana Supreme Court today ruled 3 to 1 that the parents of an infant born with birth defects could withhold life-sustaining treatment from their 5-day-old son.

title: CENTERRE BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt WATCHFIRES. By Louis Auchincloss. 348 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $13.95.

title: Times Vendor Tells of Threat By 2 Gunmen in Rhode Island
description: The head of the agency that distributes The New York Times in Rhode Island and communities in nearby Massachusetts has told the police that he was threatened by two gunmen, and private security guards have been engaged to protect deliverers of the newspaper.

title: Hartford National Appeals Ruling
description: The Hartford National Corporation, a bank holding company based in Hartford, said it had appealed a Federal court ruling that blocked its planned acquisition of the Connecticut National Bank of Bridgeport, Conn. The appeal was filed in the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in New York.

title: I.B.M. NET GAINED 5.2% IN 1st QUARTER
description: After two quarters of disappointing earnings, the International Business Machines Corporation reported yesterday that net income for the first quarter of 1982 increased 5.2 percent compared with the same 1981 period.

title: STEEL CASE PRESENTED
description: Specialty steelmakers today presented detailed allegations that Britain, France, Austria, Sweden and Italy subsidize exports and called for immediate quotas on the European steel shipments in what they characterized as an issue of survival for the domestic industry.

title: INVESCO INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Yr to Jan 2
HARTE-HANKS COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Witness Calls Doctors 'Biased' on Toxic Shock
description: Dr. James Todd, who first identified toxic shock syndrome, testified today that doctors' biases about tampon use and toxic shock affected the results of a Federal study linking Rely tampons to the disease.

title: WHITE HOUSE HINTS ACCORD ON BUDGET BY TAX SURCHARGE
description: President Reagan said today that he ''was neither ruling out nor ruling in'' an income tax surcharge being proposed in an effort to break the stalemate on the budget for the fiscal year 1983. White House officials also signaled Mr. Reagan's willingness to consider such a tax increase.

title: STROH SAYS IT HOLDS 68% OF SCHLITZ
description: The Stroh Brewery Company of Michigan, the nation's No.7 beer maker, said yesterday that its $325 million offer to buy two-thirds of the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company of Wisconsin had attracted 68 percent of Schlitz's stock.

title: CELANESE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Standard-Coosa To Be Acquired
description: The Standard-Coosa-Thatcher Company, a textile concern based here, said it had reached agreement in principle to be acquired by a group of company executives for $28 million - $1.5 million more than the group offered last month.

title: THEATER: 'STATION J,' 3RD IN NISEI TRILOGY
description: THE Pan Asian Repertory Theater ends its trilogy about the internment of Japanese-Americans during World War II with Richard France's ''Station J,'' playing through Saturday at the 28th Street Playhouse. This is the least subjective of the three plays - each by a different author - but it is also the most theatrically effective, and, acting as director, Tisa Chang has given it the most evocative production.

title: ICN PHARMACEUTICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
MARYLAND NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
CENSUS UNIT'S PLANS TO REDEFINE THE POOR COULD REDIRECT AID
description: The Census Bureau, seeking to redefine who is poor, said today that counting the value of food stamps, Medicaid and other Government benefits would significantly reduce the number of people classified as poor by Federal standards.

title: Q and A
description: Q. I have a wood floor that was originally finished with shellac. I removed all the shellac with a powdered cleaner/bleach that is sold for the purpose, then applied more shellac. However, I used shellac that was old and this has discolored my floor, leaving it blotchy and unsightly. What can I do now to restore it to an even color? - Mrs. R.G., Brooklyn.

title: CITYTRUST BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Including securities gains of $24,000 for the latest first qr and $6,000 for the yr-ago first qr

title: Report Is Inconclusive On Slain Dutch TV Men
description: The Netherlands issued an inconclusive report today on the deaths of four Dutch television journalists killed while accompanying guerrillas in El Salvador last month. The Interchurch Broadcasting Corporation, for whom the four men worked, said it still believed they were killed deliberately.

title: SLAIN WITNESS DID NOT SEEK PROTECTION, PROSECUTOR SAYS
description: The United States Attorney in Manhattan yesterday disputed contentions that a witness in a $6 million fraud investigation had sought protection from his office. The witness, Margaret Barbera, was found shot to death Tuesday in lower Manhattan.

title: HARTFORD VOTES A DRINKING AGE INCREASE TO 19
description: A bill to raise the legal drinking age from 18 to 19 received final approval today from the State House of Representatives. The measure now goes to Gov. William A. O'Neill, who has promised to sign it.

title: NICARAGUA ACCEPTS U.S. PLAN FOR TALKS IN RECONCILIATION
description: The Nicaraguan Government today accepted as a basis for discussions the Reagan Administration's eight-point plan for improving relations between Washington and Managua, according to officials here and in the Nicaraguan capital.

title: John Hancock To Buy Tucker
description: The John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company, of Boston, one of the nation's largest and oldest insurance companies, said it had agreed in principle to acquire the Tucker Anthony Holding Corporation, also of Boston, a regional brokerage firm.

title: 11 Video Machines Seized in Brooklyn
description: The Department of Consumer Affairs - using new enforcement powers against unlicensed businesses for the first time - seized 11 video machines from a game parlor in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn yesterday.

title: FIRST & MERCHANTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
GUNMEN ROB NASSAU HOME OF ART VALUED AT $2 MILLION
description: More than two dozen paintings, including a Picasso valued at $1 million and a Monet valued at $600,000, were stolen by masked gunmen from a secluded house in the Sands Point section of this Nassau County community, the police said today.

title: POP: B-52'S, A 'TACKY BAND'
description: Although the B-52's call themselves ''a tacky little dance band from Athens, Ga.,'' their appearance Monday night at Roseland was still a homecoming. For this group came of age in New York City and counts now as local. The Monday show marked the band's return after a long hiatus and was the first of four nights at the ballroom, the final two being next Monday and Tuesday. The place was packed, in the manner of modern promoters who are not greedy - they would tell you so themselves - but who believe that the vertical bodily compacting generates the only proper rock-and-roll spirit.

title: Hers
description: IHAVE just returned from celebrating the 90th birthday of my grandfather, Clinton Boone Pennebaker, a man who gambled all his life and won. Until not so many years ago, he smoked freely, drank heavily and ate what he liked; much of his comfortable living today comes from winnings in cards, horses and stocks.

title: NEW VARIETY OF PEAR TREE
description: A new slimmer version of one of America's most popular ornamental trees, the Bradford pear, is available to the public this spring for the first time, the Department of Agriculture said this week. The new variety is the Whitehouse pear tree developed at the National Arboretum by William L. Ackerman, a research horticulturist.

title: Astros 2, Dodgers 1
description: HOUSTON (UPI) - Alan Ashby slammed a seventh-inning home run, giving Houston the victory. Ashby's third homer of the season, a line drive into the left-center field seats, came off Burt Hooton (0-1) and broke a 1-1 tie.

title: BRIEFING
description: Cause To Celebrate

title: THREATS BRING POLICE PROTECTION
description: Following Pittsburgh's final playoff game in New York, two Penguin players learned they had been under police protection as a result of telephoned death threats.

title: AVEMCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
INTERNATIONAL MINERALS & CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
RIEGEL TEXTILE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 3
description: B-Includes $6,232,000 gain from an accounting change

title: Loss for Murdoch
description: News International Ltd. reported today a loss of $5.4 million in the six months ended Dec. 31, compared with a profit of $20 million in the similar 1980 period.

title: FIRST EMPIRE STATE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
B.P. MAY SELL ITS SHARE IN A NORTH SEA OILFIELD
description: The British Petroleum Company said today that it was ''in conversation'' with several buyers interested in B.P.'s 15 percent share of the Beatrice oilfield in the North Sea. According to Wood, Mackenzie, stockbrokers, B.P.'s stake in the field could be worth $118 million.

title: Advertising; Warwick Promotes 2 Executives
description: WARWICK, WELSH & MILLER, which will soon change its name to Warwick Advertising, has just promoted the two executive vice presidents who ran the account and creative sides of the agency.

title: Burroughs Offers New Encoder Unit
description: The Burroughs Corporation said it would sell a new document encoder system designed for banks, thrift units and businesses that use high-speed electronic processing.

title: SEVEN PRISONERS KILLED IN FIRE AT JAIL IN JERSEY CITY
description: Seven prisoners were killed here today when an early morning fire engulfed their cellblock on the eighth floor of the Hudson County Jail.

title: PHILIPPINES FINDS A NEW YORK SHOWCASE
description: BLOOMINGDALE'S has featured China and India, Israel and Ireland, to name just a few countries. Now the department store has turned to the Philippines for its latest promotion.

title: IN CELEBRATION OF MACKINTOSH, NEW EXHIBITION IN GLASGOW
description: GLASGOW LIKE many other cities that have lived through a long, sad slide from the eminence and prosperity they enjoyed during and after the Industrial Revolution, Glasgow has begun a counterattack. Known among Britons as a grimy, dilapidated, brawlingly proletarian sort of place, the city would like more people to pay attention to its increasingly flourishing civic and cultural life.

title: Fred H. Klopstock, Ex-Adviser For the Federal Reserve Bank
description: Fred H. Klopstock, a retired adviser with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and a specialist on international finance, died Friday at his home in Manhasset, L.I., after suffering a heart attack. He was 70 years old.

title: Mouse Experiment Ruined
description: Eighteen months of research were ruined when someone opened a biologist's mouse cages at the University of Pennsylvania Medical School. Alicia Dustira, the biologist, said that 546 of the 730 laboratory mice she had raised from birth for experiments in immunology and skin grafts were destroyed last week because there was the possibility that some of the mice were no longer in the right cages.

title: AVANTEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 27
Critic's Notebook; COMMENTING ON MUSIC, OR DETERMINING A CAREER?
description: This writer makes six to seven trips to the concert hall a week and very often isn't sure why. He is always startled, for example, when a press agent thanks him for favorably reviewing one of these events. The uneasy feeling arises that a transaction has been completed between him, the agent and the agent's performer-client and that the critic has unwittingly been the final link in a complex business deal. First, a little promotion and publicity, then some music played, a critic in attendance, and out of this mill grinds the review from which the most benign adjectives are surgically extracted and used to fertilize further promotion, further concerts and more reviews. Thus the critic has shouldered his share of the music profession's burden; and if the printed report has been enthusiastic the artist's career takes a nudge upward. If the review is bad, well, that is an occupational hazard of performing. One tries again.

title: FREE AGAIN, MARIN PLANS TO FIND JOB
description: Because of the crowd, Luis Marin's wife could not take her usual second-row seat in the courtroom here today and had to sit several rows back.

title: NUCLEAR ARMS AND A 'CONSPIRACY OF SILENCE'
description: To the Editor:

title: 4 N.A.D. Cases Result In Action on Ad Claims
description: Four of the 12 cases closed by the National Advertising Division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus in March were concluded when the advertisers either changed the claims or dropped the advertising.

title: STUDY CITES MENTAL-PATIENT LOAD FOR ACUTE-CARE HOSPITALS IN CITY
description: A physicians' group that monitors health services said yesterday that New York State's policy of releasing psychiatric patients from state hospitals and sending them into the community may have led to much ''inappropriate usage'' of acute-care hospitals in Manhattan.

title: Japan to Alter Trade Rules
description: Japan will soon disclose another program to liberalize import restrictions to fend off growing United States and European criticism of Japan's restricted markets, a top Government spokesman said today.

title: Senators Bar Renewal Of a '62 Threat to Cuba
description: The Senate refused today to renew a 20-year-old warning that the United States will use any means, including military force, to keep Cuba from spreading Communism to Central and South America.

title: Gold Rise Forecast
description: Gold prices should bottom out at around $320 an ounce in the third quarter before rising to $350 to $400 by year-end, Gill & Duffus Ltd., a London commodities firm, said today. In a report prepared in anticipation of the new London gold futures market, which opens next Monday, the firm said its price projections assumed that war was avoided over the Falkland Islands.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, APRIL 15, 1982
description: International Britian bluntly warned Argentina not to test the naval blockade imposed within 200 miles of the Falkland Islands by London's nuclearpowered submarines. Amid cheers from all sides in Parliament, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said that ''if the zone is challenged, we shall then take the necessary action.'' She said Britain still sought ''a peaceful solution,'' but the Government took major steps to strengthen its naval and air forces. (Page A1, Column 6.) Alexander M. Haig Jr. described the Falklands crisis as ''extremely dangerous'' and urged Argentina and Britain to show flexibility. The Secretary of State said he would resume his weeklong mission to seek a peaceful settlement by flying to Buenos Aires today. (A1:4-5.)

title: BUTLER MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Net income including a gain of $2,950,000 from the sale of discontinued operations

title: COURT DISCIPLINARIAN WITH CONTROVERSY
description: Judge Lawrence Nicholas Martin Jr. is a quiet jurist, a hard worker and a disciplinarian who ''runs a good courtroom,'' as one colleague put it. But he is also no stranger to controversy.

title: Night Game for Irish
description: Michigan and Notre Dame will play the first night football game ever at the Irish's home field in South Bend, Ind., on Sept. 18, ABC Sports said yesterday. The game will start at 9 P.M., instead of as originally scheduled in the afternoon, under portable lights. ABC will pay $50,000 toward installing the lights.

title:
Home Beat;
24 CHAIRS SHOW OFF CHARACTER
description: FURNITURE is an increasingly popular way for artists to express themselves. And Howard Meister is no exception. A show of 24 of his chairs is now at Art et Industrie, the avant-garde SoHo emporium.

title: STERCHI BROTHERS STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
CAREY OFFERS PLAN TO END BUDGET IMPASSE
description: Governor Carey today proposed a broad plan to resolve the state's budget impasse. It included measures that would give the executive branch authority to put state workers on short time and to withold a portion of the state's aid to local governments in the event of a fiscal crisis.

title: Gold Advances Again, Leading Silver Higher
description: The advance in precious metals futures prices accelerated yesterday with fresh buying in the physical gold bullion markets on both sides of the Atlantic and in Asia. Brokers said it was the strength in gold that pulled up silver and platinum futures prices yesterday.

title: SEAPORT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Includes $48,101 tax credit

title: FORT HOWARD PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
WATT, AFTER YEAR OF BATTLING ENVIRONMENTALISTS, SEES RESPITE AHEAD
description: His missionary zeal is still intact, but after more than a year of continuous combat, Interior Secretary James G. Watt is looking forward to a respite.

title: IMPERIAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Yr-ago results include a gain of $554,000 from the sale of property; shr earnings reflect a 10 percent stock divd to be paid May 7

title: Anti-Marcos Protest
description: As Imelda Marcos, First Lady of the Philippines, opened a promotional display of her country's products at Bloomingdale's yesterday, about 25 Filipinos hanged her in effigy outside the New York department store.

title: Sam Glankoff, Artist; Had Fall Debut at 87
description: Sam Glankoff, an artist who had his first one-man show in 1922 and his second last October because he was shy, died Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 87 years old.

title: CAMERON IRON WORKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
UNION COMMERCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Includes tax credits of $453,000 for the latest qr and $460,000 for the yr ago qr

title: CITIZENS FIDELITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TV: 'NO SOAP, RADIO' COMEDY
description: SAY this for ''No Soap, Radio'': it's different. In the cookiecutter world of situation comedies, the new series, on ABC-TV Thursdays at 8 P.M., is making an almost desperate effort to be zanily unconventional.

title: British TV Takeover Step
description: Robert Holmes a Court, an Australian financier, has won control of one of Britain's largest television and entertainment empires, the Associated Communications Corporation, formerly run by Lord Grade, business sources said today.

title: MORGAN, J P, CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Comings and Goings
description: Now that the Edmonton Oilers have been eliminated from the Stanley Cup playoffs, their star, Wayne Gretzky, will fly to Helsinki, Finland, today to join Team Canada for the world hockey championships. The two-week tournament begins tonight. ... Claudell Washington of the Atlanta Braves will miss three games with a severe bruise after being hit in the head by a pitch from Bob Shirley of the Cincinnati Reds.

title: Doolittle Accepts Award
description: The National Aviation Club presented its 1982 Achievement Award tonight to the Tokyo Raiders, commemorating the 40th anniversary of the B-25 bomber raid on Tokyo in World War II. Gen. James A. Doolittle, retired, of the Air Force, the commander of the raid, now 85 years old, accepted the trophy at a dinner honoring the Raiders, an organization of raid veterans.

title: COLT POSTS LOSS: CELANESE OFF
description: Colt Industries reported yesterday that losses from discontinued operations led to a loss of $25.4 million in the first quarter of 1981, contrasted with earnings of $28.2 million, or $1.01 a share, in the first quarter of 1981.

title: PEKING IN PROTEST ON SALE TO TAIWAN
description: China made a ''strong protest'' today against the Reagan Administration's plan to sell military spare parts to Taiwan. At the same time, however, Peking indicated that it would not retaliate as long as negotiations on the Taiwan arms issue continued.

title: SPRING FREEZES DEVASTATE DEEP SOUTH'S PEACH AND APPLE CROPS
description: Fruit growers and agricultural officials in three Deep South states predicted this week that a pair of early spring freezes would result in the worst peach and apple crop losses in more than a quarter century. In North Carolina, South Carolina and Georgia, grim-faced growers toured their orchards and announced they had been wiped out.

title: REPORT CRITICIZES U.S. POLICY ON ARMS
description: A committee of National Guard officers has recommended a major shift in the nation's philosophy of weapons acquisition, away from complex and highly sophisticated systems and toward greater numbers of simpler weapons.

title: CONGRESS MUST NOT TAMPER WITH TAX INDEXING
description: To the Editor:

title: PROVIDENT NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Bert Jones Seeks Trade
description: Having lost both grievances that he had filed against Robert Irsay, Bert Jones of the Baltimore Colts demanded yesterday to be traded, adding a little more heat to the squabble that has flared between the quarterback and the club owner since last summer. ''Under the circumstances,'' Jones said from his home in Ruston, La., ''I realistically cannot play for them.

title: Dow Declines 2.95, to 838.09
description: Stock prices declined yesterday, although some actively traded issues rose on the strength of improved earnings. Concern over the Falkland Islands crisis was cited by analysts as one reason for the market's modest retreat.

title: Technology; Standards For Pollutants
description: WITH Congress considering major changes in both the Clean Air Act and the Clean Water Act, a number of business and environmental groups have been offering their views on the costs and benefits attributable to Federal environmental laws and regulations. Pollution control technology is bound to become a major issue in the debate.

title: E.E.C.-Brazil Loan
description: The European Economic Community Commission has proposed that the community lend $600 million for the Carajas iron ore mining project in northern Brazil, a commission spokesman said today. The loan, which must be approved unanimously by the Common Market's council of ministers, would go toward the cost of opening up the iron ore deposits, building a 527-mile railway to the port of Ponta de Madeira and fitting out the port, the spokesman said. Total cost of the project is estimated at $4.7 billion.

title: RANGERS AGAIN AN OBSTSCLE TO ISLANDERS' QUEST FOR CUP
description: The Islanders deny that they plan anything special when they play the Rangers, whom they meet tonight at Nassau Coliseum in the opening game of their four-of-seven Patrick Divison final, the third time in four years the teams will have met in the playoffs. ''Emotion is the biggest hurdle we have to face when it's the Rangers,'' said the Islanders' Clark Gillies, who scored 10 goals in the teams' eight regular-season games. ''Especially at the Garden, where the fans can be so boisterous.''

title: Aid by Japan On Computers
description: The Japanese Ministry of International Trade and Industry has authorized the formation of a multicompany research institute to develop a Japanese supercomputer by the 1990's, the Kyodo News Service reported today.

title: Pope Sets Up Texas Diocese
description: Pope John Paul II has established the new diocese of Victoria, Tex., and named the Rev. Charles Grahmann to be its first Bishop, the United States Catholic Conference announced today. Bishop Grahmann, 50 years old, has been an Auxiliary Bishop in San Antonio. His appointment was announced by Archbishop Pio Laghi, the Apostolic bishop in the United States.

title: TRITON GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: B-Includes extraordinary gains of $262,000 for the qr and $260,000 for the 9 mos...C-Including $3,079,000 gain for the qr from the sale of assets and $800,000 extraordinary gain for the 9 mos...D-Net loss; he company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange

title: THURSDAY, APRIL 15, 1982; Companies
description: The Big Three auto makers posted a 16.7 percent drop in new car sales in the first 10 days of April. Chrysler, up 2 percent, was the only domestic manufacturer to have a gain. (Page D1.)

title: Shooting of Officer Defended by Police
description: An off-duty Transit Authority police officer who was fatally shot in the Bronx Tuesday night in a dispute with two New York police detectives first shot at the detectives, a Police Department spokesman said yesterday.

title: ROBERTSHAW CONTROLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
BRIEFS
description: * Affiliated Bankshares of Colorado Inc. said it had agreed to purchase Littleton National Bank of Littleton, Colo., for $13 million in cash, subject to regulatory approval.

title: STRINGS: THOUVENEL QUARTET PLAYS A RECENT KRENEK WORK
description: The Thouvenel String Quartet plays as wide-ranging a repertory as most of its competition, but the four players - Eugene Purdue and Teresa Fream, violinists; Sally Chisholm, violist, and Jeffrey Levenson, cellist - are also Ernst Krenek specialists, of all things, and the second of their two programs this spring, at the Abraham Goodman House Monday night, included Mr. Krenek's most recent essay in the quartet form, the Quartet No. 8 (Op. 233, 1981). The rest of the evening consisted of Ravel's Quartet in F and Brahms's String Sextet in B flat (Op. 18), with Samuel Rhodes and Joel Krosnick, violist and cellist of the Juilliard Quartet.

title: Wickes Halts; Sale Accords
description: The Wickes Companies said that it had terminated previously announced agreements to sell its agricultural division to the Pillsbury Company, and a two-thirds interest in its Red Owl supermarkets and Snyder drugstores to Thorofare Markets Inc.

title: PRIMITIVE DWELLINGS THEME OF EXHIBIT
description: IN spite of limited resources and a lack of sophisticated tools, the builders of homes in primitive cultures managed to deal with their climates. Their discoveries have a renewed relevance in our era of waning resources.

title: Musto and 7 Ask Judge To Nullify Convictions
description: (UPI) - Attorneys for Mayor William Musto of Union City and the seven others convicted with him of racketeering asked today for an acquittal or a new trial, charging errors in jury deliberations.

title: APRIL 1-10 AUTO SALES FELL 16.7%
description: New car sales by the Big Three domestic auto makers dropped 16.7 percent in the first 10 days of April compared with the same period last year, despite extension of manufacturers' rebates and other sales incentives, the companies reported today.

title: Long-Range Optimism On Economy Reported
description: Americans are more optimistic about the long-term, rather than the short-term, effect of the Reagan Administration's economic policies, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: FALKLANDS' 'QUIET TITLE'
description: To the Editor:

title: Inmates in New Cells At Pennsylvania Jail
description: Overcrowding at the century-old Bucks County prison was eased a bit today, as 24 inmates moved into prefabricated module cells.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
