description: * Convergent Technologies Inc., a company that designs and manufactures compact computer systems, said it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to offer 4.4 million common shares to be sold through L.F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin and Hambrecht & Quist.

title: WEINBERGER SAYS SOVIET NOW TOPS U.S. IN MISSILES' ACCURACY OF AIM
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger said today that Soviet intercontinental nuclear missiles had become more accurate than those of the United States.

title: Islanders Looking Ahead
description: A stereo set in the Nassau Coliseum locker room today was playing a tape of Elvis Presley singing ''It's Now or Never,'' but the significance was lost on the Islander players.

title: HAIG STATEMENT ON FALKLANDS
description: Following is a transcript of a statement today on the Falkland Islands dispute by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. that was made available by the State Department: Special to the New York Times

title: ANGELS 4, MARINERS 3
description: Bob Boone's one-out single in the bottom of the 20th inning drove in Don Baylor to complete the season's longest game. The game was begun Tuesday night and was suspended with the scored tied, 3-3, after 17 innings because of the American League's 1 A.M. curfew.

title: INCOMPLETE VICTORY IN THE SOUTH BRONX
description: To the Editor:

title: Crime Chief in South Sentenced for Bribery
description: Carlos Marcello, said by the Federal authorities to be the head of organized crime in New Orleans, was sentenced to 10 years in prison today for a California conviction on bribery charges.

title: Sale of Mirage Jets To India Reported
description: The independent daily Le Monde said today that France had signed a deal with India for the sale of an unknown quantity of Mirage 2000 fighter-bombers, the most advanced French combat jet.

title: Altschiller Obtains Commerce Drug Brands
description: The Commerce Drug Company in Plainview, L.I., has moved its advertising account to Altschiller, Reitzfeld, Solin/NCK.

title: WINTERTHUR IS REPRODUCING ITS ANTIQUES
description: WINTERTHUR, Del. COLONIAL WILLIAMSBURG did it. Historic Charleston did it. Now Winterthur is doing it. The Delaware museum is going into the antiques reproduction business. More than 200 objects from the extensive collection of American antiques acquired by the late Henry Francis du Pont, the museum's founder, are being reproduced under licensing agreements. They will be sold in Winterthur galleries in department and furniture stores across the country, as well as in a gallery on the grounds of the museum.

title: Caterpillar Off 70.2% in Period
description: The Caterpillar Tractor Company said today that depressed worldwide business conditions caused net income to plummet 70.2 percent and sales to drop 10.4 percent in the first quarter of 1982.

title: 'MUDDLE EAST' DANGER
description: A Syrian close to official circles said the other day that he had never seen a time of such dirty politics in the Middle East. The epithet by Ezer Weizman, the former Israeli Defense Minister, of ''the Muddle East'' has probably never been more appropriate.

title: U.S. Information Effort
description: American efforts to counter Soviet propaganda have been a ''modest success,'' and will be expanded in Europe, Charles Z. Wick, director of the United States International Communication Agency, said today.

title: Ontario Hydro Bond
description: Ontario Hydro is raising $150 million in United States currency through a seven-year Eurobond, the lead manager, Deutsche Bank's London branch, said here today.

title: Black Navy Officers Find a Ninth Survivor
description: Eight of the Navy's first 13 black officers gathered for a reunion here this week, thinking they were the only survivors of the original group. Today they found another colleague.

title: KEVIN ROCHE WINS PRITZKER PRIZE IN ARCHITECTURE
description: Kevin Roche, the architect known for such crisp and inventive abstractions in glass and masonry as the Ford Foundation building and the United Nations Plaza Hotel, was named the winner of the $100,000 Pritzker Prize in architecture yesterday. At the presentation ceremonies, in the Whitney Museum, Mr. Roche announced his intention of using the prize money to begin an endowment fund for a chair of architecture at Yale University in honor of Eero Saarinen, the architect with whom Mr. Roche worked closely until Saarinen's death in 1961.

title: NATIONAL CONVENIENCE STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
SETTLEMENT DUE IN ALTON TELEGRAPH LIBEL CASE
description: The Alton Telegraph, a downstate Illinois newspaper that lost a $9.2 million libel judgment in a case widely publicized as endangering press freedoms, has reached a tentative settlement with its creditors.

title: LIBBEY-OWENS-FORD CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
REAGAN HONORS 18 FOR VOLUNTARISM
description: President Reagan is opening the White House Thursday to honor outstanding volunteers and to ''call attention to what can be done through voluntary action.''

title: Conrail Steel Pact
description: The Consolidated Rail Corporation said it had signed a five-year contract with the Bethlehem Steel Corporation to transport coke to Bethlehem Steel plants in a fleet of 350 specially designed rail cars being built by the steelmaker. As part of the contract, Conrail guarantees specific annual utilization levels for the new cars. The accord is expected to generate revenues of about $70 million, Conrail said. also holds 1.6 million of the 21.4 million MacMillan Bloedel shares,

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Air Express International, Stamford, Conn., has appointed Guenter Rohrmann vice president and general manager-North America.

title: Spot Oil Price Rises Slightly
description: Spot crude oil prices edged slightly higher this week partly because of anxiety over tension in the Middle East and the Falkland Islands crisis, market sources said today.

title: Anglican Archbishop Backs Mrs. Thatcher
description: The Archbishop of Canterbury, Dr. Robert Runcie, said today that Britain would have been gravely in breech of its moral duty if it had acted differently in the Falkland Islands dispute.

title: Use of Flash Angers Katharine Hepburn; Flash of Anger
description: One thing Katharine Hepburn won't put up with is ill-mannered people in her audiences. For example, shortly before her play ''West Side Waltz'' ended its New York run, the 72-year-old actress interrupted the performance to upbraid a man in the front row for propping his feet up on the stage.

title: 104 New Products Brought Out in March
description: The 104 new product introductions in March that were tracked by the newsletter Dancer Fitzgerald Sample New Product News were a slight increase compared with the 102 recorded in the same month last year but a drop from the 114 in 1980. For the year so far there have been 277 introductions, compared with 265 last year, but a drop from 278 in 1980.

title: BRITAIN STRENGTHENS ITS NAVAL FORCE WITH MORE PLANES
description: Britain today strengthened the air component of the expeditionary force headed for the Falkland Islands. British military planners said the move would increase the prospect for successful landings in islands should fighting develop.

title: GRACO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
BAXTER TRAVENOL LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Iraq Says Syria Confiscated 200,000 Tons of Its Crude Oil
description: Syria has confiscated 200,000 tons of Iraqi crude oil that was loaded for export through the Syrian port of Baniyas, Iraq said today.

title: MAYFAIR SUPER MARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
Quotation of the Day
description: ''If the zone is challenged, we shall take that as the clearest evidence that the search for a peaceful solution has been abandoned.

title: INDONESIA TIGHTENS CURBS AS TENSIONS GROW IN ELECTION CAMPAIGN
description: For the first time since campaigning began a month ago for the elections of May 4, soldiers and tanks have appeared this week on Jakarta's streets.

title: Braves Win 8th Straight
description: Bruce Benedict drove in the tying run with a double in the ninth, then walked with the bases loaded to force in the lead run in the 10th as the unbeaten Atlanta Braves won their eighth game, a 5-2 decision over the Cincinnati Reds today.

title: PAT FASHIONS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
NEW LINER IN PORT BEARS HOPES OF A BETTER DAY
description: It was not quite like old times when the grand liners formed a majestic skyline of their own on the city's waterfront. But the maiden arrival yesterday of the new Atlantic raised a spray of hope that there would be some resurgence of the port's passenger-ship traffic.

title: EXCERPTS FROM MRS. THATCHER'S TALK
description: Following are excerpts from Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's speech in the House of Commons today, as recorded by The New York Times: Special to the New York Times

title: BANCOKLAHOMA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
SUSPECT HELD IN DEATHS OF 2 U.S. DRUG AGENTS
description: The Drug Enforcement Administration's most sought fugitive, a 40-year-old cocaine trafficker, has been arrested in Colombia in connection with the kidnapping and shooting of two Federal drug agents, the drug agency said today.

title: Sampson's Suitors
description: As things stand now, the San Diego Clippers will have either the first or the second choice in the National Basketball Association's college draft in June, depending on the result of a coin toss next month against the Los Angeles Lakers, who hold a first-round selection of the Cleveland Cavaliers. But now Donald Sterling, the owner of the Clippers, says that he is willing to send three San Diego draft choices and $1 million to Los Angeles for the Lakers' top selection, which would give the Clippers unchallenged rights to the No.1 choice over all.

title: INDIANA NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
THE SQUEEZE ON ARGENTINA
description: Argentina, battered by a severe recession and rampant inflation, is likely to be squeezed further by Britain's economic reprisals against the country.

title: Christopher Kraft to Leave NASA at Year's End
description: Christopher C. Kraft Jr., director of the Johnson Space Center in Houston and one of the guiding figures in the nation's manned space flight program, announced yesterday that he would leave the National Aeronautics and Space Administration at the end of the year.

title: LOSS IN LONDON ART THEFT IS PUT AT $11 MILLION
description: Seven oil paintings were stolen from a private residence here last weekend, and insurers estimated the extent of the loss at $11 million, Scotland Yard said today.

title: Taster's Choice Sets New TV Campaign
description: With the help of the Leo Burnett Company, Nestle is going to put a little romance in the advertising for Taster's Choice freeze-dried coffee. The new theme will bow on network television on Monday, the beginning of the biggest spending ad program the brand has ever had.

title: Image Problem
description: Objections from the National Collegiate Athletic Association have apparently cost Pepper Rodgers, the former Georgia Tech football coach, his job as a commentator for college games to be aired by the Turner Broadcasting System next fall.

title: JUDGE RULES BANKRUPTCY COURT SYSTEM ILLEGAL
description: A bankruptcy judge ruled today in a minor legal case that his court and 219 other bankruptcy courts nationwide were unconstitutional and should be abolished or restructured.

title: Celtics 100, Bucks 91
description: BOSTON (AP) - Boston outscored Milwaukee, 14-2, during the final 3:55. Kevin McHale led Boston with 20 points.

title: A FRESH STORM SWIRLS AROUND HAIG
description: In the Falkland Islands crisis, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. has achieved an objective he has sought since Inauguration Day - he has clearly established himself as the Administration's central and paramount figure on a hot foreign policy issue.

title: Stay Home, Al Haig
description: That curse of modern diplomacy, the jet plane, is spoiling the rhythm of the old-fashioned diplomacy, by gunboat. Whereas Britain and Argentina gave themselves two solemn weeks to contemplate the further loss of life in and around the Falklands, Secretary of State Haig has been tearing around the world as if a holocaust were at hand. He is undoubtedly helpful in probing for compromise, but his frantic shuttle is also provoking rival assertions of mettle. And unavoidably, his active mediation is overdoing America's evenhandedness.

title: CHASE ADDS MORTGAGE BANKING CONCERN
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank announced yesterday that it had agreed to purchase the Suburban Coastal Corporation, the nation's fifth-largest mortgage banking company, for $70 million.

title: Transactions;
description: BASEBALL

title: THOMPSON MEDICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
BLISS & LAUGHLIN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
NASHUA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Prior yr results reflect a change in accounting for foreign currencies

title: REVUE: 'MORE OF LOESSER' STRESSES STAGE WORK
description: THE collection of Frank Loesser's songs that makes up ''More of Loesser,'' the new revue in the King Cole Room of the St. Regis-Sheraton Hotel, suggests the wide range of his output of pop standards, movie songs and Broadway scores - as such songs as ''Slow Boat to China,'' ''Once in Love With Amy,'' ''Abbondanza'' and ''Baby, It's Cold Outside'' are woven through the program. The emphasis, however, is on Broadway, and the cast includes one of the stars of a Loesser Broadway success, Bobby Morse.

title: Food Council's Reply
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: Your March 4 article ''Food Group Offers Safety Guidelines'' does not accurately capture either the spirit of balance and conciliation of the Food Safety Council or the results of its work.

title: Labor Board Upholds Unions On Demands for Safety Data
description: The National Labor Relations Board ruled Tuesday that three companies committed unfair labor practices by denying requests for worker health, safety and medical information.

title: WRITER-DIRECTOR SUES FOR $110 MILLION
description: Robert Towne, writer and director of ''Personal Best,'' has filed a $110 million suit against Warner Bros. Pictures; his executive producer, David Geffen, and Steven Ross, chairman of Warner Communications, for fraud, coercion, defamation and breach of contract surrounding the recently released movie about world-class female track stars.

title: Supervisor Issue Slows American Motors Talks
description: Bargainers for American Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers tried today to resolve a dispute on the ratio of plant supervisors to workers that has delayed agreement on a $150 million employee investment plan.

title: Bulls Beat Knicks
description: The Knicks lost to the Chicago Bulls in the opening round of the National Basketball Association playoffs last season. Both teams were expected tomake the playoffs again this season, but both failed and both are seeking new coaches for next season.

title: RANGERS AGAIN AN OBSTACLE TO ISLANDERS' QUEST FOR CUP
description: The Rangers consider the Islanders the best team in the National Hockey League, regardless of the difficulty the Islanders had in defeating the Pittsburgh Penguins in the first round of the playoffs.

title: HEADED LOOMIS-CHAFFEE SCHOOL
description: Francis Olmsted Grubbs, former headmaster of the Loomis-Chaffee School in Windsor, Conn., died Tuesday in Palm Springs, Calif., after a long illness. He was 74 years old.

title: NO ICONOGRAPHY FOR CASTRO
description: There is something missing in Cuba. It is first sensed at Havana airport and on the long ride into town. It is the pictures of Fidel Castro that are not on the walls; the statues of him that are not in the squares.

title: Gardening; EASY-TO-GROW PLANTS THAT SURVIVE CITIES
description: SOME plants really are easier to grow than others, which is not to imply that they are either ugly or dull. It's just that some species are more tolerant of city growing conditions and will also shrug off insect invasions and disease. The beginning gardener especially will benefit from this selection of low-maintenance trees, shrubs, annuals and perennials. They are all suitable for rooftop or terrace containers or small city yards, and most can be planted as soon as the weather stabilizes.

title: TEMPLE MOUNT SUSPECT RECALLED IN BALTIMORE
description: When the morning services were over and the row of synagogues along Park Heights Avenue here threw open their doors today, the bearded men in dark suits gathered in small groups and spoke of Passover, of the shooting at the Dome of the Rock Mosque in Jerusalem and of a man, Alan Harry Goodman, who grew up just around the corner.

title: FIRST ATLANTA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Yr-ago results have been restated for a 3-for-2 stock split paid in Jan 1982

title: Japanese Gold Find
description: Japan's Metals and Minerals Exploration Agency said today that it had discovered high-grade gold deposits on Kyushu, near other promising deposits found last month by the Sumitomo Metal Mining Company.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption on page 1 Tuesday gave an incorrect reason for holding the White House egg hunt on the Monday after Easter. The event is traditionally held that day.

title: S.&P. CUTS RATING OF BOEING BONDS
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation said yesterday that it had lowered the rating on the Boeing Company's 8 7/8 percent convertible subordinated debentures to A from AA. S.& P. said the rating change reflected the ''deteriorating financial condition'' of the commercial airlines that are the company's major customers, and the ''negative impact on orders for new aircraft.''

title: REAGAN POLICIES BRING A FLICKER OF HOPE FOR DISILLUSIONED BLACKS IN RURAL ILLINOIS
description: After World War II, an increasing number of blacks began to flee Chicago's asphalt for surroundings that reminded them of their past in the rural South. Some settled in this isolated area, 70 miles southwest of Chicago's Loop, which had been home to a few blacks since the Civil War.

title: News Analysis
description: There it was, the ultimate urban nightmare played out for real in a West Side parking lot. Three men, picking up their cars after a day's work at a television network, came upon a woman in distress. A man appeared to be dragging her off. She seemed to be unconscious, or worse.

title: ARGENTINA CONCENTRATES ON A DEFENSIVE STRATEGY
description: With a powerful British flotilla heading toward the Falkland Islands, Argentina has adopted an essentially defensive strategy of exploiting air superiority, access to the front and, above all, time.

title: JUDGE FINDS CASE WAS NOT PROVED
description: Four days after a jury found him guilty of arson and 26 counts of murder, Luis Marin was set free today by a Westchester County Court judge who dismissed the charges and said the prosecution had not proved its case.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: TOURS AND FLOWERS
description: Sunday Walking Tours, Museum of the City of New York.

title: INTERMAGNETICS GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
DOVER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
The U.N. Today; April 15, 1982; ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M.

title: British TV Takeover
description: Robert Holmes a Court, an Australian financier, has won control of one of Britain's largest television and entertainment empires, the Associated Communications Corporation, formerly run by Lord Grade, business sources said today. Mr. Holmes a Court's TVW Enterprises, an Australian television company, now holds nearly 90 percent of A.C.C.'s voting shares following his $108 million bid for the corporation, they said. A.C.C. has a controlling shareholding in a commercial television network in central England and other entertainment and business interests. In addition to his television company, the Australian financier has extensive textile and transportation interests through his Bell group. A rival bid by Gerald Ronson of Heron International, a property company, was withdrawn two weeks ago.

title: NARDA MICROWAVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Includes $501,000 gain from the sale of property

title: Texaco in Nigeria
description: The Texaco Overseas (Nigeria) Petroleum Company will maintain its production of 43,000 barrels a day in Nigeria despite the weak oil market, the OPEC News Agency quoted company sources as saying today.

title: AGAINST I.R.S. AID CUTBACKS. AND TAXES, TOO
description: April is said to be the cruelest month. The 16 million bewildered taxpayers who have called the Internal Revenue Service for assistance since January would understandably concur with that judgment.

title: TANDON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
THE ESSENTIALS FOR MAINTAINING SECURITY AT HOME
description: THE installation of an alarm system is no guarantee of protection against burglary, but most security experts agree that a good alarm system will usually act as a deterrent.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS MACHINES CORP (IBM) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec
description: including provisions of $628,000 million for the latest first qr and $572,000 million for the yr-ago first qr for U.S. federal and non-U.S. income taxes as well as other income of $79 million for the latest first qr and $100 million for the yr-ago first qr

title: By Nicholas Wade
description: The Editorial Notebook Escape From the Titanic, Twice

title: POTLATCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
DECISION DATA COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: B-Including tax credits of $254,000 for the latest first qr and $134,000 for the yr-ago first qr

title: Iowans Seek to Rescind Call for Balanced Budget
description: Twenty-seven state senators, one more than needed for passage, introduced a resolution today to remove Iowa from the list of states calling for a constitutional convention to balance the Federal budget.

title: COLORFORMS' NEW HEAD PLANS EXTENSIVE TRAVEL
description: Androc L. Kislevitz, 30, has been appointed president and chief executive officer of Colorforms, a manufacturer of stick-on cartoon characters and other toy items. He succeeds his father, Harry, 56, who was named to the vacant post of chairman of the Ramsey, N.J., company.

title: MOSLEMS OBSERVE A GENERAL STRIKE
description: At least 15 Islamic countries in Africa and Asia joined today in a general strike in protest against the attack Sunday on the Dome of the Rock Mosque in Jerusalem by an American-born Israeli soldier.

title: TYMSHARE TRIES TO WEATHER PROFIT PINCH
description: For the last 11 years Tymshare Inc. has profited handsomely from the business of selling computer time and software services. But the recession and prospects of increased competition are beginning to trouble the company.

title: A.T.&T. RATE REQUEST TURNED DOWN BY F.C.C.
description: Federal regulators rejected today a bid by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to significantly increase its charge to long-distance competitors for access to local Bell System lines.

title: VIRGINIA NATIONAL BANKSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
SOME AUDIT DATA RULED PRIVATE
description: In an opinion bolstering the confidentiality of accountants' internal documents, a Federal appeals court has denied the Internal Revenue Service access to some work papers of the Amerada-Hess Corporation's independent auditors, Arthur Young & Company.

title: CHILD, 7, DISCOVERED LOCKED IN BASEMENT OF A BURNING HOUSE
description: A frail 7-year-old boy who had apparently been kept locked in a basement was hospitalized in a coma today after being rescued from his empty, burning home, the authorities said.

title: ESSENTIALS FOR SECURITY IN THE HOME
description: IT was a classic case of false security. For years the couple, who lived in a two-bedroom apartment on the Upper East Side, thought that they were safe from intruders. Their top-floor apartment had two sturdy locks on the front door and an imposing steel gate on the fire-escape window.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate payable by savings institutionsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Hess & Eisenhardt Chief Foresees Vehicle Gains
description: The Hess & Eisenhardt Company, founded in 1876 to make horse-drawn carriages and now the manufacturer of armored passenger cars, custom convertibles and executive limousines, has named Louis N. Strike, 36, as president and chief executive officer, succeeding his father, Nicholas, who retired at the age of 65.

title: G.O.P. CONVENTION HEADS FOR DALLAS
description: Departing from the recent pattern of picking national convention sites as much for their political message as for their physical facilities, the leadership of the Republican Party today gave all but final approval to Dallas as the site of its 1984 Presidential nominating convention.

title: ALASKA AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
JOHN BROSNAN, FORMER HEAD OF STATE U. AND REGENTS UNIT
description: John Francis Brosnan, a lawyer and former chancellor of the State University of New York and chairman of the State Board of Regents, died Monday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 91 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Article 064608 -- No Title
description: Being the Mayor of Paw Paw means everything from chasing stray dogs to cutting the grass at the town cemetery. But David Clark never thought the job would also place the survival of the town in his hands.

title: Subsidy Offer To Braniff
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board asked today for public and industry comment by next week on American Airlines' offer to help subsidize Braniff International's losses on its South American routes, the C.A.B. said today.

title: OPERA: GIULINI RETURNS WITH $1 MILLION 'FALSTAFF' IN LOS ANGELES
description: For one golden moment, at least, this opera-starved city has become the center of the opera universe. Tuesday night's performance of ''Falstaff'' with Carlo Maria Giulini conducting did the trick. For a city with its rich musical history, Los Angeles has been strangely reluctant to develop its own opera tradition. Imports from New York or San Francisco have satisfied whatever thirst existed for international-class performances. However, the Los Angeles Philharmonic persuaded Mr. Giulini, its music director, to return to conducting live opera after 14 years of concentrating on his symphonic career. Mr. Giulini, whom many regard as the greatest conductor of Italian opera in our time, led the first of eight performances of Verdi's last opera at the Music Center, an event that reminded any who may have forgotten that the ideal of ensemble opera can be realized in this world when everyone involved cares enough.

title: SORG PRINTING CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
A Way Out of the City Council Crisis
description: The New York City Council, clinging to the life raft of legitimacy, urgently needs to be rescued. Although its members' terms expired on Jan. 1, they hang on because the Justice Department refused to pre-clear elections on new district lines. Then blacks and Hispanics challenged the constitutionality of at-large Council members on grounds of unequal representation. Two Federal courts have upheld the challenge.

title: SLATER ELECTRIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: B-Includes $8,000 extraordinary credit

title: Bonn in Bid to Brezhnev
description: West Germany called on Leonid I. Brezhnev today to accept President Reagan's invitation to meet during a special United Nations General Assembly on disarmament in June and July. Lothar Ruhl, a spokesman, said the West German Government ''believes that such talks, which it has urged for a long time, will be very important in securing peace and furthering progress toward mutual disarmament through negotiation.''

title: Mistrial or New Judge Is Sought by Penthouse
description: Penthouse magazine asked the California Supreme Court today either to declare a mistrial in its $522 million libel case or remove the trial judge for having prejudged the evidence.

title: ARGENTINA IS GIVEN A BLUNT WARNING BY MRS. THATCHER
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher bluntly warned the Argentine Navy today not to test the blockade imposed within 200 miles of the Falkland Islands by the British nuclear-powered submarines.

title: NEW FIDELITY SAVINGS EMERGES FROM ASHES
description: Government regulators said today that they had transferred the assets of the Fidelity Savings and Loan Association, which was placed in receivership Tuesday, into a new Federally chartered entity to be known as Fidelity Savings of San Francisco.

title: No Headline
description: Carnegie Hall will present a spring festival of 17 concerts from June 2 to June 17 to be called ''Serenades.'' Eleven concerts in the main hall and six ''Perspective'' concerts in the Recital Hall will feature works by Haydn, Beethoven and Bach, and will celebrate the centennial of Igor Stravinsky's birth.

title: CRISIS ATTRACCTS CROWD TO COMMONS
description: For the House of Commons, the Falkland Islands crisis today produced the largest assemblage of members, reporters, distinguished guests and onlookers in recent memory, a swirling mass of humanity brought to life precisely at 2:35 P.M. when the resonant Welsh tones of George Thomas, the Speaker, boomed ''The Prime Minister.''

title: AGENCY CRITICIZED FOR RULE CHANGES ON LEAD IN GAS
description: The Environmental Protection Agency was accused today of consulting only with the oil and lead industries, and not with health specialists, before proposing changes in the rules limiting lead in gasoline.

title: Financial General Picks 3 Top Officers
description: Following the acquisition of about 95 percent of Financial General Bankshares Inc. by a group of Arab investors, its reorganized board of directors elected new officers to the top three positions yesterday. Robert G. Stevens, a 51-year-old banker, was appointed president and chief executive officer, while two national political figures - Clark M. Clifford, 75, and Stuart Symington, 80 - were named chairman and vice chairman, respectively.

title: ARGENTINA DEFIES BLOCKADE, IT SAYS
description: The coast guard announced today that two of its patrol boats defied the British blockade of the Falklands on Tuesday, racing across to the islands 250 miles off the Argentine coast.

title: E.E.C. TO EMBARGO ARGENTINE IMPORTS
description: The European Economic Community overcame lastminute hesitations and agreed today to enforce a one-month ban on Argentine imports, effective Friday, to protest Argentina's occupation of the Falkland Islands, officials of the community reported.

title: HAIG, CALLING CRISIS DANGEROUS, IS OFF AGAIN TODAY
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. described the Falklands crisis today as ''exceptionally dangerous'' and said both Argentina and Britain would have to show flexibility if a peaceful solution was to be achieved.

title: CBS Down 16% In 1st Quarter
description: CBS Inc. reported yesterday that first-quarter net income declined 16 percent, to $14.2 million, or 51 cents a share, from $16.9 million, or 60 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenues for the quarter, however, rose 3 percent, to $1.01 billion, from $981.3 million in the first quarter of 1981.

title: POLISH PRIMATE PLEDGES TO WORK FOR A NATIONAL ACCORD
description: The Primate of Poland said today that the main concern of the Roman Catholic Church was to work actively for a national accord.

title: SERVICO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Includes gains of $9,116 for the qr and $284,557 for the yr from the cumulative effect on prior yrs of recognizing compensated absences...C-Includes $128,245tax credit

title: STUDY CASTS DOUBT ON THEORY ON BLOOD SUGAR AND FATIGUE
description: About one-third of a group of people who for prolonged periods performed exercise similar to that experienced by marathon runners developed low blood sugar, but that did not cause them physical harm or affect their endurance, according to a study reported yesterday.

title: HAIG SEES WHITE HOUSE 'SNIPING' IN DISPUTE OVER USE OF PLANE
description: Aides to Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. today accused the White House of ''sniping'' at Mr. Haig because of a disagreement over which plane he should have used at the start of his diplomatic mission on the Falkland Islands crisis last week.

title: Brent's New Chairman Sees an End to Oil 'Glut'
description: Walter B. Ruck, 51, has been elected chairman of Brent Petroleum Industries, an oil and gas exploration and services company with interests in mining. He was succeeded as president at the Calgary, Alberta, company by William J. Gordica, 49.

title: Jockey Dies in Workout
description: Burleigh Turetski, a 34-year-old jockey, died after he was thrown from his horse today during a workout at Los Angeles County Fairgrounds. Poppa's Pet, a 2-year-old quarterhorse, veered and charged into the rail, unseating the jockey. Turetski was rushed to Pomona Valley Community Hospital, where he died of cardiac arrest 45 minutes after the accident.

title: Mead's Profit Drops by 54%
description: The Mead Corporation, a diversified forest products and packaging concern, said today that its firstquarter profit fell 54 percent from a year earlier, as its key markets struggled under the economic recession.

title: NICARAGUAN LEADER WHO QUIT LAST YEAR DENOUNCES EX-ALLIES
description: Breaking nine months of silence, Eden Pastora, one of the most popular leaders of the Nicaraguan revolution, criticized the Sandinists today for the direction they have taken their revolution.

title: Sports People; Nehemiah to Join 49ers
description: Renaldo Nehemiah, who holds the world record of 12.93 seconds in the 110-meter high hurdles, has tried out as a wide receiver with eight pro football teams in the last month. Now the San Francisco 49ers want him, and apparently Nehemiah is convinced that as a wide receiver he could certainly do worse than working for Coach Bill Walsh, the architect of the 49ers' pass-oriented offense.

title: Fidelity Savings Takeover Quest
description: The Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation carried forward today the unprecedented task of trying to find one or more bidders to lift the newly created Fidelity Savings of San Francisco out of receivership.

title: Canadian Bankruptcies
description: The number of Canadian companies declaring bankruptcy in the first quarter rose 33 percent, to 2,720, from the comparable quarter a year ago, the Consumer and Corporate Affairs Department reported today. Monthly figures released by the department showed there were 1,002 business bankruptcies in Canada in March, bringing the quarterly total to 2,720.

title: No Headline
description: Book: The Stars' Rabbi By Richard F. Shepard THE RABBI ON FORTY-SEVENTH STREET. By Ann Birstein. 179 pages. Dial. $13.95.

title: QUEEN IS IN CANADA TO PROCLAIM NEW CHARTER
description: Queen Elizabeth II arrived in her Canadian dominion today to preside over the transition of constitutional power from London to Ottawa.

title: A BUSY LIFE FOR ITALIAN CENTENARIAN
description: GIUSEPPE PREZZOLINI turned 100 years old on Jan. 27, yet he still writes several reviews and articles a month for European newspapers and magazines. Indeed, according to those who know him best, the Italian-born scholar who now lives in Lugano, Switzerland, is as intellectually alert and curious as when he was at Columbia University, where he taught Italian for more than 20 years before retiring in the 1950's.

title: VICTIM IN JAIL FIRE ADMITTED LIKING TO PLAY WITH MATCHES
description: Hudson County officials said today that the fire that killed seven inmates at the Hudson County Jail on Wednesday had started in a cellblock that housed an inmate who had admitted that he played with matches.

title: DOUBTS VOICED ON SHOREHAM A-PLANT
description: More than 300 people gathered in a Suffolk County office building Wednesday night to tell three Federal officials what they think about the Shoreham nuclear power station.

title: The Bureaucracy; IN THIS TOWN, THE CURRENCY IS POWER
description: ''Those who talk about power are those who lack it themselves,'' mused Thomas L. Hughes, president of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, when asked to talk about what most people in this town talk about.

title: 'THE HAPLESS CREWS AT RIKERS ISLAND'
description: To the Editor:

title: U.N. CHIEF SHUNNING ACTION THAT MIGHT HURT HAIG EFFORT
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar defended his passive role in the Falkland Islands crisis today and said he did not want to take any step that would undermine the ''admirable'' mediation efforts by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.

title: HAROLD T. TOAL
description: City Manager Harold T. Toal, a Miami Beach employee since 1965, died of cancer today at Mount Sinai Medical Center. He was 59 years old. Mr. Toal came here from Providence, R.I., as director of the Miami Beach Development Commission. He leaves his parents, who live in Rochester, N.Y., and two sons, Mark and Tim.

title: BRUINS, CANUCKS AND HAWKS WIN
description: Ray Bourque fired a 30-foot wrist shot from the slot past Dan Bouchard, the Quebec goalie, with 55 seconds left in regulation tonight to give the Boston Bruins a come-frombehind 4-3 victory over the Nordiques in the opener of their quarterfinal Stanley Cup series.

title: FRIDAY, APRIL 16, 1982; The Economy
description: U.S. industrial output fell 0.8 percent in March, providing further evidence that the recession was still in progress and affecting all areas except military and aerospace goods and autos, the Federal Reserve reported. Saying the economy was ''dead in the water,'' Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan urged a compromise in budget talks, noting that would provide a signal to the market that would send rates down and spur a revival. (Page A1.)

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, APRIL 16, 1982
description: International Egypt has pledged to withdraw ''within a few days'' the troops it stationed in Sinai that Israel says exceeded the limits permitted by the peace treaty, according to Defense Minister Ariel Sharon. In addition, he said, a senior Egyptian Army officer is to arrive in Israel today to discuss ways to halt the infiltration of arms by the Palestine Liberation Organization through Sinai into the Gaza Strip. (Page A1, Column 6.) Egypt carried out the executions of five Moslem fundamentalists convicted in the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat only hours after a clemency plea was rejected by his successor, Hosni Mubarak. (A1:5.)

title: Noguchi Demoted by County
description: Dr. Thomas Noguchi, the Los Angeles County coroner, was demoted today to ''physician specialist,'' effective April 28, after a meeting with the County Board of Supervisors. The coroner said he would appeal to the Civil Service Commission. He was suspended for 30 days, effective March 29, amid allegations that he had mismanaged his office and sensationalized autopsies of celebrities, most recently those of the actors William Holden and Natalie Wood.

title: Thrift Unit Merger on L.I.
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today that it had approved the merger of County Federal Savings and Loan Association in Rockville Centre, L.I., into the Suffolk County Federal Savings and Loan Association of Centereach.

title: Chock Full o'Nuts: Finkelsteins' Stake
description: Jerry Finkelstein, a 65-year-old New York political figure and businessman, and his son James, publisher of The National Law Journal, have increased their holdings in the Chock Full o'Nuts Corporation to 6.6 percent from 5 percent, and say they are seeking a meeting with the company's management.

title: A Judge's Doubts, and Courage
description: Higher courts will say whether Judge Lawrence Martin was correct to set aside a jury's arson-murder verdict in the case of the Stouffer's Inn fire in Westchester County. Given his doubts about the sufficiency of the evidence against a defendant charged with causing 26 deaths, the judge acted with principle and courage. The prosecutors are irresponsible to suggest otherwise.

title: French Defer Guerrilla Trial
description: A Paris criminal court judge today postponed the trial of two guerrilla suspects whose arrest had provoked threats of reprisals by the international guerrilla known as Carlos. The judge said a strike by prison guards prevented the appearance of the defendants, Bruno Breguet of Switzerland and Magdalena Kopp of West Germany, and he postponed the trial by one week.

title: TEXAS INSTRUMENTS SLIPS 19% IN QUARTER
description: Texas Instruments reported yesterday that first-quarter earnings dropped 19 percent compared with the similar period last year and that additional layoffs would occur in the second quarter.

title: A 44% GAIN BY RCA IN QUARTER
description: The RCA Corporation yesterday reported a 44 percent rise in firstquarter earnings, to $60.5 million, after an extraordinary gain of $29.1 million from the sale of several units. Without that gain, the company would have had a 25.2 percent earnings decline.

title: MIDTOWN THEATERS SURVEYED FOR LANDMARK DESIGNATION
description: New York City landmarks officials, wary of repeating the controversy over the demolition of the Helen Hayes and Morosco theaters, are surveying virtually every theater in midtown Manhattan to determine which should be preserved.

title: TAKING CONTROL AT BURLINGTON
description: Like many of the new generation of chief executives, Richard M. Bressler starred first as a financial specialist and then took the reins as a division head and a corporate planner before reaching the top.

title: Mary W. Taylor Is Dead at 68; A Former Lawyer for N.L.R.B.
description: Mary Walker Taylor, a former lawyer for the National Labor Relations Board in New York, died Tuesday at New York Hospital. She was 68 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Air Forbes Won Listed As Favorite in Wood
description: Air Forbes Won, a maiden six weeks ago who is now considered to be the top New York prospect for the Kentucky Derby, will face 11 rivals in the Wood Memorial at a mile and an eighth tomorrow at Aqueduct.

title: FESTIVAL: TCHAIKOVSKY
description: IT is difficult to imagine just how Mstislav Rostropovich and the National Symphony came to decide that New York needed a big dose of Tchaikovsky just now, but they did, and Tuesday night the Washingtonians' four-concert series began at Carnegie Hall. Because the American Council for the Arts had taken the concert for a benefit, the event was rather festive.

title: 'A Little Kind of Low Chuckle'
description: Not content with describing ''The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn'' as ''racist trash,'' John Wallace, an administrator at the Mark Twain Intermediate School in Fairfax, Va., added that anyone who taught the book was racist too. Speaking for the school's Human Relations Committee, he asked that it be removed from the curriculum.

title: S.E.C. CITES FRANKLIN MINT INSIDER SALES
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today disclosed charges that the chairman and several top current and former officials of the Franklin Mint Corporation had used inside information to trade in the company's stock.

title: News Analysis
description: For several days this week, the Organization of American States - 30 nations spread across two continents and several seas - struggled to respond in a unified way to the possibility of armed conflict in the Western Hemisphere.

title: Security Pacific Up 7%
description: The Security Pacific Corporation, the parent of Security Pacific National ank, today reported first-quarter earnings before securities transactions of $52.6 million, up 7 percent from the $49.2 million posted a year ago. Per-share earnings were $1.77, unchanged from a year ago because of the recent issuance of convertible debentures. Net interest income for the quarter was $265.1 million, up 12 percent from a year ago.

title: Shots Injure Two Boys Bicycling in the Bronx
description: Two boys were shot and wounded yesterday while riding their bicycles along a street in the University Heights section of the Bronx, the police said.

title: 12 WORKERS DIE IN COLLAPSE OF UNFINISHED BRIDGE RAMP
description: Two sections of an unfinished bridge crashed 50 feet to the banks of an industrial canal here today, killing 12 construction workers.

title: For Children; Music and Stories
description: 1633. STORY TIME, informal readings, Saturday and Sunday at 3 and 4 P.M., Children's Bookshop, Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82d Street. Pay-what-you-wish. Information: 879-5500. Sail Around Manhatan CIRCLE LINE SIGHTSEEING YACHTS, three-hour cruise around Manhattan, passes historic sights, landmarks and bridges. Vessels leave from Pier 83, foot of West 43d Street. For a brochure, call 563-3200.

title: RUSSIAN: 'AUTUMN MARATHON'
description: ''AN AUTUMN MARATHON'' is a comedy - a Russian comedy, a sad comedy, a comedy neither frivolous nor flighty. It is about an eternal triangle, remarkably chaste, and the man at its apex. If this were an American film, it would star George Segal, consumed with manic despair. The hero here, however, is resigned; think of him as subliminally miserable. The film, which won the Grand Prize at the San Sebastian Festival, opens today at the Embassy 72d Street Cinema. It has its moments.

title: Mostly Mozart Names Schwarz Music Director
description: Gerard Schwarz, music director of the Y Chamber Symphony and the Los Angeles Chamber Orchestra, has been named music adviser to the Mostly Mozart Festival. Mr. Schwarz is working with William Lockwood, Lincoln Center's director of programming, in deciding Mostly Mozart's future repertory and in engaging its conductors.

title: Around the Nation; Federal Judge Rejects Mobile's Election System
description: A Federal judge today threw out this city's at-large system for electing city officials, saying it discriminated against blacks.

title: 'WRONG IS RIGHT,' GLOBE-HOPPING THRILLER
description: NOTHING in the career of Richard Brooks, who has made good if stolid films -''Blackboard Jungle,'' ''Elmer Gantry'' and ''In Cold Blood'' - as well as some that weren't so hot - ''The Brothers Karamazov,'' ''Bite the Bullet'' and ''Looking for Mr. Goodbar'' - is preparation for the wholehearted mess of his latest production, ''Wrong Is Right,'' which opens today at the Loews Astor Plaza, Tower East and other theaters.

title: SAXON INDUSTRIES FILES CHAPTER 11
description: Saxon Industries, a paper products and photocopier manufacturer, filed for financial reorganization yesterday under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, a Saxon official said.

title: Boy Found in Burning House Conscious Again After Coma
description: A 7-year-old boy who was rescued Tuesday night from his burning home, where he had apparently been been kept locked in the basement, regained consciousness from a coma today, a hospital spokesman said, but was reported in serious condition.

title: BAKER DUBIOUS ON CURB IN SOCIAL SECURITY INCREASE
description: Howard H. Baker Jr., the Senate majority leader, expressed reservations today about proposals to reduce automatic increases in Social Security benefits, one of the major elements in the budget negotiations between White House aides and Congressional leaders.

title: WHAT THE SQUEAL RULE WILL BREED
description: The fertilization of pine cones is complex; the process for producing sea horses requires a remarkable degree of male-female partnership; and slugs, snails and earthworms, being hermaphrodites, are tortuously self-involved. But human reproduction is simplicity itself - which is why celibacy is the only sure-fire contraceptive.

title: STOCKS UP, LED BY COMPUTERS
description: Computer and semiconductor issues led the stock market in a modest advance yesterday as investors focused on earnings. Analysts gave part of the credit for improved prices to Wednesday's surprise report of higher quarterly profits for International Business Machines.

title: ANTISOCIAL YOUTHS
description: While no one has a proved solution for dealing with antisocial youngsters, some of the pieces of the solution are known but have not been assembled. The problem is not lack of knowledge but rather lack of money.

title: ON STATEN ISLAND, MOTHERS WORRY ABOUT TOXIC DUMP AND AILMENTS
description: The stench hit the Staten Island neighborhood in January. Rita Jones and Linda Fishkin remember reeling with nausea. Sharon Edwards says that she could not breathe and that she quickly pulled her children into the house.

title: Briefing
description: In the Pink

title: Required Reading Matter of Sovereignty
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, in a speech before the Senate concerning a resolution of the Falkland Island crisis, April 13, 1982:

title: Addenda
description: * Rapp & Collins, direct-marketing subsidiary of Doyle Dane Bernbach, is opening a West Coast office in Los Angeles.

title: MORTON TO BUY ITS STOCK FROM RHONE
description: Morton-Norwich Products Inc. announced today that it had reached a tentative agreement with Rhone-Poulenc, the French-owned pharmaceutical concern, to buy back 2.8 million shares of Morton-Norwich common stock for $135 million and to settle litigation involving the two companies.

title: OCCUPATION 'TAXES'
description: To the Editor:

title: Twins 11, A's 5
description: MINNEAPOLIS (UPI) - Kent Hrbek hit his fifth home run of the year in a three-run sixth inning and Randy Johnson added a three-run shot, his fourth hit of the day, in a six-run eighth inning for Minnesota.

title: Around the World; Warsaw Campus Upset Over Rector's Dismissal
description: Students and lecturers at Warsaw University halted classes for 15 minutes today and signed petitions in their first protest against the ouster of the school's popular rector, Henryk Samsonowicz.

title: A-BOMB NURSERY TALES, RACCOONS AND IRELAND
description: THIS week's presentation on public television's ''Matters of Life and Death'' series tonight at 10:30 on Channel 13, WNET-TV, offers an unusual angle on the subject of nuclear destruction. Narrated by Martin Sheen from a script by John Crowley, ''No Place to Hide'' goes back to the height of the cold war years of the 1950's, to see what kind of official government information the public was getting about the fearful new weapons the United States had unveiled at Hiroshima and Nagasaki in 1945.

title: World Air Loses Plea
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board today denied a request by World Airways that the agency impose restrictions on fare discounting. World has been one of the leading discounters but now finds that prices have fallen to the point of being uneconomic.

title: U. S. Requests Military Aid Of $275 Million for Pakistan
description: The Reagan Administration asked Congress today for an initial $275 million to start its five-year $3.2 billion arms sales to Pakistan to help it ''resist great pressures from the Soviets in Afghanistan.''

title: 'It's a Wonderful Sport'
description: ''T HIS ain't a crazy world?'' said Freddy Menna, the fight manager. ''I had a guy once come to me, he was fantastic, he was beautiful, one of the most gorgeous builds in the world - and the world's a pretty big place. He'd pound his chest, 'I'm Tarzan.' And in the gym he was rough. Oh, boy, I've got the next heavyweight champeen on my hands. So I take him down to Scranton for his first fight. The bell rings, he takes one step and goes down. He wasn't even hit. He fainted.''

title: New Air Math: 2 - 1 = 2
description: Can airline competition ever benefit from the withdrawal of a competitor? Yes, say Braniff and Pan Am in an application to consolidate their Latin American services. The Departments of Transportation and Justice agree, and, with some hestitation, so do we.

title: Notes on People; Proud Michigander
description: The Columbia space mission, the colonel was saying, ''has been an opportunity for all of us as Americans to fly our colors around the world, to demonstrate our will to be first and No. 1.''

title: Profits Scoreboard
description: See accompanying notes for special items. (Loss)

title: Berger, Stone & Ratner And Now, McCaffrey
description: There has been no acquisition and no merger, but William C. McCaffrey, former chairman, president and creative director of the William McCaffrey Inc., agency, has joined Berger, Stone & Ratner, along with some of his former employees and clients.

title: Head of Newpark Unit Focuses on Cleaning Up
description: Last year Newpark Resources, a major oil services concern based in Metairie, La., established Newpark Waste Treatment Systems as a subsidiary to neutralize and remove byproducts of the oil and gas drilling process. Now that the unit is operational, C. Alvin Wentz has joined Newpark Waste as president.

title: PHILLIES BEAT METS IN 13TH, 8-4
description: Yesterday's game at Shea Stadium was not the prettiest one the Mets have played in their new era of pride and power. They fought back twice to stave off the defeat, but in the end, too many misplays, too many walks and a ball hit too far by Luis Aguayo proved too much.

title: LEBANON'S SHIITES
description: The long quiescent Shiite Moslem community in Lebanon - the largest religious sect there, comprising about 30 percent of the population - is increasingly asserting itself in determining the country's future, as fighting yesterday in Beirut indicated.

title: Notes on People; Two at a Time
description: Since he came to New York in 1978, Zubin Mehta has worn two hats or, as it were, waved two batons - as the conductor of the New York Philharmonic and as the conductor of the Israel Philharmonic.

title: BACK TO BASICS IN MIDTOWN MANHATTAN
description: To the Editor:

title: BIG TOP COMES TO THE AID OF CALDER'S LITTLE TOP
description: Three unicyclists, four clowns, two showgirls in sequins and towering feathered headdresses and a 2,000-pound elephant gathered at the Whitney Museum yesterday to open a fund-raising campaign to save ''Circus,'' a group of small sculptures by Alexander Calder on loan to the museum since 1970.

title: AN ISRAELI INITIATIVE FOR PALESTINIAN MODERATES
description: To the Editor:

title: Yanks Gripe Less, Accept Platooning
description: The pitching coach of the Yankees, who is the author of a master's thesis on the effects of platooning, was not at all troubled by the murmurs of discontent from players benched because of the system.

title: Portuguese Chief in Angola
description: President Antonio Ramalho Eanes flew today to Angola to begin a four-day state visit to the former Portuguese colony, now a Marxist nation propped up by Cuban troops and Russian and East German technicians and advisers.

title: REAGAN OPPOSED TO BILL FOR MORTGAGE SUBSIDY
description: Samuel R. Pierce Jr., the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, said today that the Reagan Administration would oppose Congressional efforts to provide substantial subsidies for mortgage interest to people trying to buy homes.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We're in a very steep recession at this point, and the economy is dead in the water.'' - Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan. (A1:1.)

title: SHORT-TERM RATES INCREASE
description: Short-term interest rates rose while yields on notes and bonds declined yesterday, and dealers said the small, divergent changes reflected technical factors and not any fundamental change in the investment climate.

title: MOSCOW SAYS U.S. IS SEEKING TO ACQUIRE BASE IN FALKLANDS
description: The Soviet Government's press agency Tass said today that an American proposal for joint administration of the Falkland Islands by Argentina, Britain and the United States was a ruse to establish an American foothold in the South Atlantic.

title: Around the World; South African Expects To Confer With Kaunda
description: Prime Minister P.W. Botha said in Parliament today that he was likely to hold talks in the near future with President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia. The South African leader gave no indication of when or where the meeting would take place, saying details would be announced at an appropriate time.

title: Transactions;
description: COLLEGES

title: 'SMASH PALACE' OPENS SERIES
description: THE ''New Directors/New Films'' series - which looks as if it will be particularly strong this year - gets off to a wonderful start with ''Smash Palace,'' Roger Donaldson's brisk, believable account of a marital breakup in New Zealand. An earlier film of Mr. Donaldson's, ''Sleeping Dogs,'' had its premiere in New York recently, and it demonstrated much the same command and crispness that distinguishes ''Smash Palace.'' (The film opens commercially April 30 at the Paris Theater.)

title: BONN AIDE UPHOLDS ATOM-ARMS POLICY
description: Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher made clear today that the West German Government wanted no part of a proposal by four former American officials calling on the Atlantic alliance to consider a policy of not being first to use nuclear weapons in the event of a Soviet conventional attack in Western Europe.

title: AUDITORS ASSAIL NAVY YARD PARK IN A NEW REPORT
description: Two years after a city audit uncovered ''widespread fraud and mismanagement'' at an industrial park on the site of the former Brooklyn Navy Yard, a new audit has found questionable contract awards and other unremedied problems at the park.

title: A BALLET COMPANY NEW TO NEW YORKERS
description: There has been so much interest in this city in dance from outside New York that it may come as a surprise to local audiences to discover that there's any dance west of the Hudson that they haven't seen. There is, however, and New Yorkers will get a chance to see a whole new company tomorrow and Sunday, when the Pittsburgh Ballet Theater makes its New York debut at the Lehman College Center for the Performing Arts.

title: LOUIS DE GUIRINGAUD, 71, FOREIGN MINISTER OF FRANCE IN 1970'S
description: Louis de Guiringaud, Foreign Minister in the late 1970's under President Valery Giscard d'Estaing, committed suicide in his Paris home today, the police said. He was 71 years old.

title: URGES RESTRAINT
description: President Reagan urged President Leopoldo Galtieri of Argentina today to show flexibility and restraint in the Falkland Islands crisis and help spare the Western Hemisphere a conflict that ''would be a tragedy and would leave a bitter legacy.''

title: 'MASTER HAROLD' BY FUGARD DUE AT LYCEUM MAY 4'; 'Master Harold' by Fugard due at Lyceum May 4.
description: IT is not entirely certain yet, but it is as certain as these things can be. Athol Fugard's ''Master Harold ... and the Boys,'' which received such stunning reviews when it had its world premiere at the Yale Repertory Theater last month, will open at the Lyceum Theater on May 4. It will be directed by Mr. Fugard, and it will star Zakes Mokae, Danny Glover and Lonny Price. Mr. Price, who was on Broadway only briefly in ''Merrily We Roll Along,'' will replace Zeljko Ivanek, who was Master Harold, or Hally, in the Yale production. Mr. Ivanek is making a movie.

title: MET OPENS JEWEL BOX OF OLD MASTERS
description: PEOPLE who think that the great age of old-master collecting is over should go along to the Metropolitan Museum and see the Dutch 17th-century paintings from the collection of Mr. and Mrs. Edward William Carter, which is on view through June 20. The Carter collection is no more than 15 or so years old, but it is thoughtful, strange and touching beyond all expectation.

title: Madrid Plot Suspect Freed
description: One of 32 military men charged with attempting to overthrow Spain's constitutional monarchy last year was ordered released today because of pretrial time served. The order by the Supreme Council of Military Justice said Capt. Francisco Ignacio Roman of the Civil Guard was entitled to provisional freedom because he had already been held for two-thirds of the 18-month prison term the prosecution seeks for him.

title: Money Fund Assets Slide
description: Assets of the nation's 185 money market funds fell $1.06 billion in the week ended Wednesday, to $192.29 billion, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: Army Awards Two Contracts For Copter Amid Price Debate
description: The Army today awarded the first contracts for production of the new antitank Apache helicopter, whose cost has aroused strong objections in the Senate Armed Services Committee.

title: White Sox Win Fifth In Row, 8-4
description: Steve Kemp hit a two-run homer, and Jim Morrison broke an 0-for-13 slump with a two-run double today to lead the Chicago White Sox to their fifth straight victory, an 8-4 decision over the Boston Red Sox.

title: Smith Barney Arab Bid
description: Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, a leading Wall Street investment banking firm, is negotiating with Arab investors interested in purchasing a major stake in the 108-year-old company, a Middle Eastern source reported yesterday.

title: ART PEOPLE
description: A FLAP over the purchase of two high-priced works of art has slowed an ambitious public art program in Miami, pending an official review. At issue are a $285,000 mural by James Rosenquist chosen for a concourse of Miami's airport used by Eastern Airlines and a $500,000 commission to Beverly Pepper for a sculpture that would stand at the entrance to the seaport.

title: COPPOLA, HEAVILY IN DEBT, DECIDES TO SELL STUDIO
description: Struggling under a double burden of millions of dollars in bank debt and the box-office failure of his newest movie, ''One From the Heart,'' Francis Coppola, the Academy Awardwinning writer and director of the ''Godfather'' movies, has finally made the painful decision to sell his Hollywood studio.

title: SPORTS NEWS BRIEFS
description: Lanny Wadkins shot a five-under-par 67 and opened a two-stroke lead today in the $350,000 MONY-Tournament of Champions.

title: Deaths of Two Children Are Termed Homicides
description: The unrelated deaths of two children last month were ruled homicides yesterday, and three adults were charged, the police said. The New York City Medical Examiner's office said both children had been beaten.

title: Notes on People; Farewell to No. 24
description: According to Glenn de Moss Wolfe, who operates a motel in the Mojave desert town of Blythe, Calif., he is an ordained Baptist minister, a lawyer, a pilot and a cosmetologist. He is also, according to the Guinness Book of Records, the most-married and divorced man in the monogamous world.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: ''THERE'S two kinds of films,'' says Bob Hoskins. ''High grade films, and Lew Grade films.'' Mr. Hoskins made ''The Long Good Friday,'' the film at the Baronet, in which he plays a king of the London underworld, for Lord Grade's company. Later, various Grade executives became nervous about Mr. Hoskins's cockney accent - they wanted to redub his lines, using a more genteel actor - and about the movie's violence. ''They were frightened about the Irish element, too,'' Mr. Hoskins says. ''They said, 'You can't let the I.R.A. win.' I said, 'You want a gangster to win?' ''

title: Pacers Defeat Hawks
description: Butch Carter scored 14 of his careerhigh 20 points in the second quarter to lead the Indiana Pacers to a 108-102 victory over the Atlanta Hawks tonight. Carter came off the bench to make all seven of his shots in the second quarter, giving Indiana a lead which it never relinquished. Indiana's final home game of the season drew only 4,852 fans - the Pacers' smallest crowd of the season.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard THE PORTAGE TO SAN CRISTOBAL OF A.H. By George Steiner. 170 pages. Simon & Schuster. $13.50.

title: Friday; REVELS FIT FOR A SUN KING
description: The Festival of the Enchanted Island isn't a celebration of Manhattan. It's a three-day event named after an extravaganza given by Louis XIV in 1664, and it opens tonight at 8 in Symphony Space, Broadway and 95th Street, with music, dance and theater from the court of France's Sun King. The festival is a collaboration of the New York Consort of Viols, Music for a While, Sachiyo Ito and Company, and Courante, a new dance company. Tomorrow night at 8, the program will contrast court dance, music and ritual of 18th-century France and Okinawa. On Sunday at 3 P.M., 14th-century fare: music and verse of Guillaume de Machaut. Tickets for each performance: $7.50 and $10. Reservations: 864-5400. Tonight's program will be repeated Sunday at 7 P.M. as a benefit for the performing groups, followed by supper at the French Embassy. Tickets: $50; information: 724-3105. NEW MUSICALS IN SOHO

title: L.I. Comedy and Music
description: ''An Evening of Comedy and Music'' with Myron Cohen and Jan Peerce will be offered this weekend at the Westbury Music Fair on Rush Hollow Road in Westbury, L.I. Besides the comedian and the former Metropolitan Opera tenor, the show features Claire Barry, singer, and Paul Pincus and his Klezmer Trio.

title: News Analysis
description: From the beginning, Governor Carey's aides promised that this year's budget battle would be different from all others. They were right.

title: Around the World; Visit to China Keeping Rumanian Leader Busy
description: Nicolae Ceausescu, the Rumanian leader, conferred today with Hu Yaobang, the Chinese Communist Party chairman, on the third day of an official visit.

title: Essay; ON DINNER PARTIES
description: What if Fate had denied me the coveted role of political essayist, and assigned me instead to cover Washington dinner parties for the Home-Living-Food-Fashion-Style section? Here are some notes hastily scribbled after a couple of social occasions.

title: UKRAINIAN RETURNS TO THE U.S. TO FIGHT FOR CUSTODY OF SON
description: Michael Polovchak returned from the Soviet Union Wednesday to resume his attempts to regain custody of his 14-year-old son, Walter.

title: Raytheon Gains 8.5%
description: The Raytheon Company, the producer of military and civilian electronics and Beech aircraft, reported yesterday that first-quarter earnings rose 8.5 percent, to $79.4 million, or 94 cents a share, from $73.2 million, or 88 cents, a year earlier. Raytheon said its sales in the quarter were $1.42 billion, up from $1.31 billion the previous year.

title: BRITISH DOUBT ARGENTINA WILL RISK CLASH
description: The Defense Ministry said today that two Argentine destroyers had left their home ports and others were preparing to sail, but it expressed doubts that they would challenge the British naval blockade of the disputed Falkland Islands.

title: Economic Scene; Political Unrest And Violence
description: IS there a common cause of the outbreak of political trouble and actual or threatened violence in so many scattered theaters - between Argentina and Britain over the Falkland Islands, between Israel and the Arab states over the West Bank and the Palestine Liberation Organization bases in Lebanon, in El Salvador and elsewhere in Central America, in Poland and elsewhere in Central Europe, between China and the United States over Taiwan, and, most seriously, in the resumed cold war and threatened nuclear arms race between the United States and the Soviet Union? Is the common cause of the political troubles world economic disorder, with military adventuring the common but dangerous solution?

title: FASHION AVE. AND BROADWAY MEET
description: There were not as many year-round tans as there might have been in years past. And, even though it was the first important daytime affair of the spring season, only four women wore hats. Still, everyone agreed that the luncheon given yesterday for Ethel Merman in the roof garden of Lord & Taylor was something of a landmark. For, to those who spend a good part of their days juggling their date books while their Adolfo suits are being cleaned, it signified the first combined luncheon/fashion show in recent memory in which the clothes were actually modeled by society women, a tradition at its peak in the late 1940's.

title: David Crosby Charged
description: A felony drug charge of cocaine possession was filed Wednesday against the rock singer David Crosby, who was arrested Tuesday at his nightclub dressing room. The authorities said laboratory tests indicated that officers had confiscated a quarter-gram of cocaine.

title: AETNA TO BUY GEOSOURCE IN A $638 MILLION DEAL
description: The Aetna Life and Casualty Company, the nation's largest publicly held insurance company, announced yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Geosource Inc., a Houston oil service company, in a stock transaction valued at $638 million.

title: SONNY TERRY AND BROWNIE MCGHEE AT OTHER END
description: SONNY TERRY and Brownie McGhee, who are appearing at the Other End on Bleecker Street through Sunday, have been performing together since 1939 -probably longer than any working blues or folk duo or group. But their story isn't one of close, undying friendship, as one might suppose. Mr. Terry, the harmonica player and singer, and Mr. McGhee, the guitarist and singer, are staunch individualists whose partnership has been marked by feuds, splits, and reunions.

title: CITY OPERA: TRUSSEL IN 'L'AMORE EI TRE RE'
description: JACQUE TRUSSEL, who had originally been scheduled to sing the role of Avito in the New York City Opera's production of ''L'Amore dei Tre Re,'' finally entered the cast after a period of illness for the final two performances of the opera during the spring season.

title: LAWMAKERS DOUBT FAST PASSAGE OF TUITION CREDIT
description: In light of the budget crisis, President Reagan's proposal for tuition tax credits stands virtually no chance of passage in this session of Congress, most lawmakers from both parties agreed today.

title: Bridge: A Player Can Be the Victim Of His Own Great Wealth
description: If some highly radical government put its multimillionaires in a tax bracket higher than 100 percent, they would suffer from what the French call ''un embarras de richesse.'' Something similar can happen at the bridge: A player can find himself with an excess of high cards.

title: ISRAELI SAYS EGYPT AGREES ON 2 ISSUES TIED TO SINAI EXIT
description: Defense Minister Ariel Sharon said today that Egypt had pledged to withdraw ''within a few days'' the military forces in Sinai that Israel said exceeded the limits permitted by the peace treaty. Egypt had denied that it had more troops in the area than the pact permitted.

title: Around the Nation; Atlanta Slayer Is Found To Be Legally Indigent
description: Wayne B. Williams, convicted of killing two of 28 young blacks slain in Atlanta over a two-year period, was declared indigent today and will be provided free legal service for his future appeals.

title: Jersey Schoolboy Wins Twice in Rutgers Relays
description: Bob Lutkewitte of Christian Brothers Academy of Lincroft, N.J., yesterday became the first schoolboy in the East to surpass 60 feet in the shot-put and 200 feet in the javelin at the same meet on the opening day of the Rutgers Relays.

title: GRAHAM OPENS ANTINUCLEAR CRUSADE
description: In the fieldhouse of a working-class university in downtown Boston, on the first truly brilliant spring day New England has seen this year, the Rev. Billy Graham began what aides say is the most ambitious crusade of his long career.

title: A COMMITTEE IS NOT WHAT CHILDREN NEED
description: To the Editor:

title: 'TAP DAY': FADING BIT OF OLD YALE
description: Sometime today, 15 Yale University juniors answered knocks at their doors to have a visitor declare: ''Skull and Bones. Accept or reject?''

title: Blue Circle-Kilgore Deal
description: Blue Circle Industries said today that it had offered to acquire the Kilgore Ceramics Corporation, a privately held company in Texas, for approximately $12.5 million. Kilgore, a ceramic sanitary ware manufacturer, had pretax profit of $2.2 million on sales of $20 million in 1981. Blue Circle said its Armitage Shanks-Kilgore Inc. subsidiary had established an acrylic bath plant at its factory near Johannesburg, South Africa, and was considering expanding into other areas of the world.

title: UNSURPASSED MEDICAL DEVICE: A DOCTOR'S BRAIN
description: To the Editor:

title: Douglas Fraser, Author On Columbia Faculty
description: Douglas Fraser, professor of art history and archeology at Columbia University and an authority on the art and architecture of Africa and Oceania, died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital after a long illness. He was 52 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Nigerian Oil Output
description: Nigerian oil production in the first 10 days of April was steady at about 930,000 barrels a day, the same as in March, official sources said here today. The sources said that they expected average daily production in April to be just under the million-barrel-a-day mark.

title: Boeing Brazil Sale
description: A Brazilian airline, VASP, has agreed to buy 13 Boeing 737-300 twin-jet airliners at a cost, including spare parts, of about $350 million, according to industry sources. The sale must be approved by the Brazilian Government, but the sources said that no hitch was expected.

title: TOXIN FOUND IN HUMANS YEARS AFTER FEED MIX-UP
description: Ninety-seven percent of the residents of Michigan were estimated to have retained residual levels of the toxic chemical PBB in their bodies five years after some livestock feed was inadvertently contaminated with it in 1973, a long study by scientists from the Environmental Sciences Laboratory of the Mount Sinai School of Medicine has concluded.

title: JOHN DAY
description: John Day, an artist, died yesterday in the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 49 years old. Mr. Day's paintings have been exhibited in the Museum of Modern Art, the Brooklyn Museum and the Whitney Museum of American Art. He was a professor of art at William Paterson College in New Jersey. Mr. Day was born in Boston and is survived by his mother, Josephine Day of Waterford, Conn., and his brother, Michael Day of Ann Arbor, Mich.

title: The U.N. Today; April 16, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meeting of parties to the Con- vention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Award Upheld On Johnson
description: A Federal judge in Minneapolis has refused to overturn a $170.4 million jury verdict against Johnson & Johnson. The jury decided in July that Johnson & Johnson had bought an innovative electronic pain-killing device -the transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulator, or TENS - in order to suppress it, thereby protecting the market for its own Tylenol line, the nation's most popular pain killers.

title: REAGAN IS ASSAILED IN SEVERAL CITIES
description: A coalition of organizations opposed to Federal cuts in social programs began a three-day ''spring offensive'' against the economic policies of President Reagan today with a series of demonstrations, teach-ins and vigils in several cities.

title: Yale Gets Grant for Holocaust Library; Yale Gets Revson Grant For Holocaust Library
description: A $300,000 grant from the Charles H. Revson Foundation has been awarded to Yale University for a permanent archive of videotaped and filmed accounts of the Holocaust from American and European survivors of the World War II attempt to destroy the Jews of Europe.

title: CHARGE IN JERSEY AT COIN PHONES GOING UP TO 20 CENTS
description: Pay-telephone calls in New Jersey, which have cost 10 cents for 28 years, will cost 20 cents in about two weeks. The increase is part of an $85.9 million rate increase granted yesterday to New Jersey Bell by the State Board of Public Utilities. New Jersey will thus join 27 other states in charging more than a dime for calls from pay phones. At present, the charge is 25 cents in nine states, 20 cents in 15 states and 15 cents in three states. New York and Connecticut are among the 22 states in which the cost remains 10 cents.

title: AMERICAN REGIONAL, INDIAN TRADITIONAL; American regional, Indian traditional.
description: MUCH is heard these days about the emergence of a new American cuisine, an innovative combination of our own regional cooking with Continental influences. Anyone who doubts that such a cuisine can enjoy high-fashion status, should visit Texarkana, a two-month-old restaurant on 10th Street, in premises formerly occupied by Peter's Backyard. Texarkana, with its adobe peach walls and courtyard atmosphere, is owned by Abe De La Houssaye, who has already attracted a casually stylish crowd that gathers at 9 P.M. and later.

title: Transamerica Net Falls 21.9%
description: The Transamerica Corporation, a diversified financial and consumer services concern, said today that first-quarter profit fell 21.9 percent, to $44.9 million, or 70 cents a share, from $57.5 million, or 88 cents a share, in the period a year ago.

title: INDUSTRIAL OUTPUT DECREASED IN U.S. BY 0.8% IN MARCH
description: The nation's industrial output fell eighttenths of 1 percent in March, further confirming that the recession is not over yet, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: 5 SADAT ASSASSINS EXECUTED IN EGYPT
description: Five militant Moslem fundamentalists convicted of the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat were executed early today only hours after a clemency plea was rejected by Egypt's new President, Hosni Mubarak.

title: Alcoa and Reynolds Off Sharply in Quarter
description: Two of the nation's largest aluminum companies reported yesterday that they had sharply lower first-quarter earnings compared with the same period last year.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ''H OW does one get to have pink hair?'' a partygoer asked the British clothes designer Zandra Rhodes the other evening. Miss Rhodes was resplendent in a diaphanous gown of red silk, with a large red silk rose at her right shoulder, red lipstick and bright pink hair steaked with purple, and was obviously enjoying the double takes she caused. ''By dyeing it,'' she said. ''But first you bleach it white. I like it because there's really no upkeep. Every two months I have it bleached and dyed. Do you like the pink color?''

title: Sports People; An Old-Timer Says No
description: It has been five years since Dom DiMaggio visited Fenway Park, where he once played center field for the Boston Red Sox, and it may be many more years before he finally makes an appearance. DiMaggio, who has turned down an invitation to be at Fenway on May 1 for the annual old-timers game, is still piqued over a remark reportedly made by Jane Yawkey, the widow of Tom Yawkey, the club's owner, when the team was up for sale in 1977. Mrs. Yawkey, who was told at the time that DiMaggio was interested in buying the Red Sox, is said to have replied, ''Over my dead body.''

title: Around the Nation; Baby Dies as Lawyers Pressed Plea on Feeding
description: A severely retarded infant died tonight as lawyers prepared to ask a United States Supreme Court Justice to order the boy kept alive against his parents' wishes.

title: U.J.A. AND ISRAEL BOND LEADER
description: Henry Montor, a leader in the establishment of the United Jewish Appeal and a founder of the Israel Bond Organization, died yesterday of leukemia at Hadassah Hospital in Jerusalem. He was 76 years old and had lived for the last 25 years in Rome and Jerusalem.

title: A TAYLOR PREMIERE
