description: THERE is more than meets the eye in ''Lost, Found and Lost,'' Paul Taylor's latest dance work, but there is so much to meet that the result is more of a visual confrontation than a casual theatrical encounter.

title: TITANIC SURVIVOR JOINS A LOST FATHER
description: 130, off Newfoundland, April 15 - The last time Frank Goldsmith saw his father, the man was standing behind a barrier silently watching his son climb up the tilting deck of the Titanic toward one of the last lifeboats in the starlit cold of April 15, 1912.

title: Grumman Closing Its Dormovac Unit
description: In a move to eliminate a money-losing subsidiary, the Grumman Corporation announced that it was terminating its Dormavac unit, which makes containers for long-term vacuum storage of perishables at low temperatures.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate payable by savings institutionsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: ELI LILLY, GRACE UP
description: The Allied Corporation announced yesterday that net income in the first quarter plunged 25 percent as sales edged up 1.9 percent. Allied, with headquarters in Morristown, N.J., said that net income in the latest three months dropped to $63 million, or $1.38 a share, from $84 million, or $2.23 a share, in the first quarter of 1981. Sales edged up 1.9 percent, to $1.61 billion, from $1.58 billion.

title: SANDINIST PLURALISM?
description: The Sandinists who led the overthrow of Anastasia Somoza Debayle took power promising free elections and a rapid transition to pluralist democracy. Since taking control of Nicaragua, however, they have ignored these promises in favor of consolidating power by increasingly arbitrary means. The distinction between the Sandinists' promise and performance, however, appears to have escaped the Socialist International, which recently praised the regime for its ''commitment'' to pluralism and democracy. Such praise is ill-deserved. Yet there remains a fragile hope for democracy if the Sandinists can be induced to honor their commitment to free elections.

title: Advertising; Diners Club Drive for Affluent
description: NOW that it has Citicorp to play its Daddy Warbucks, Diners Club can afford to raise its voice in the credit card marketplace, where the heavy emphasis these days is on making card holders of the affluent business travelers and their carefully cultivated expense accounts.

title: PABST VIOLATED PACT, ARBITRATOR DECIDES
description: The Pabst Brewing Company violated its labor agreement with brewery workers when it closed its Peoria Heights, Ill., facility, a New York arbitrator has found, and he has directed the company to reopen the plant or negotiate a settlement of all claims with the union.

title: Borg Says He Will Skip Wimbledon Tourney
description: Bjorn Borg, a five-time Wimbledon champion, said today that he would not play in that tournament because he does not want to play in a qualifying event.

title: POSTHUMOUS PENSION
description: To the Editor:

title: WEEKS PASSES A RANGER TEST
description: The last time and the only time Steve Weeks had played in a National Hockey League playoff game had been last season, for 14 minutes against the Los Angeles Kings in the third period of a game the Rangers had virtually won.

title: 'IOLANTA,' A RARE TCHAIKOVSKY OPERA
description: Those for whom the title ''Iolanthe'' stirs up memories of Gilbert and Sullivan could be in for a musical revelation tonight. As an offering in their four-day Tchaikovsky festival at Carnegie Hall, Mstislav Rostropovich and the National Symphony will bring New York listeners a different ''Iolanthe'' - Tchaikovsky's ''Iolanta'' -in a concert performance this evening at 8. ''Iolanta'' is Tchaikovsky's last opera, one of the best-kept secrets in his canon. If the reaction to the National Symphony's recent performances in Washington is any gauge, tonight's account could be one of the season's musical windfalls.

title: ANIMAL TRAINERS ARE UNSUNG STARS OF THE BIG TOP AT THE GARDEN
description: The circus is in town, and that means elephants that dance the Highland Fling, tigers that leap through flaming hoops, camels that kneel, poodes that do back flips and at least six horses that allow stunt riders to do all sorts of stunts on their backs.

title: WORLD BANK'S HEAD IMPLICITLY CRITICIZES REAGAN AID POLICIES
description: In a complaint implicitly directed at the Reagan Administration, the president of the World Bank spoke today of a ''tragic'' failure by Western governments to meet development aid commitments designed to alleviate suffering in the so-called third world.

title: HOPES FOR REBIRTH OF SOUTH BRONX RISE AT BUILDING ON THE CONCOURSE
description: The Concourse Flatiron Building, a symbol of the problems and potential of the South Bronx, was dedicated yesterday as an apartment residence for people with low or moderate incomes.

title: In the Nation; THE OTHER BALANCE (3)
description: Why do Western leaders insist that the United States maintain the option of using nuclear weapons in order to prevent or repel an invasion of Western Europe by the Warsaw Pact?

title: BRIEFS
description: * Boeing Co. said it had increased its revolving bank credit agreement to $3 billion from $2.25 billion.

title: JOS. SCHLITZ ACCEPTS STROH OFFER
description: The Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company yesterday gave up its opposition to a takeover by the Stroh Brewery Company and agreed to be purchased by the smaller brewery for nearly $500 million in cash.

title: Around the World; Iran Legislator Accuses Ghotbzadeh of a Plot
description: Teheran newspapers quoted a member of the Iranian Parliament today as having said that former Foreign Minister Sadegh Ghotbzadeh had planned to blow up Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's house with rockets.

title: Indians 8, Brewers 1
description: CLEVELAND (AP) - Bert Blyleven, who has been troubled with tendinitis in his right elbow, threw seven innings of two-hit ball in his regular-season debut as Cleveland defeated Milwaukee. Blyleven retired the first 13 hitters before Ben Oglivie doubled in the fifth, scoring one out later on Don Money's single up the middle.

title: Notes on People; Aid to Cancer Patients
description: Four years ago he was told he had inoperable lung cancer and there was nothing that could be done to save him. Two years ago, after spending a fortune finding and getting the best care possible, Richard A. Bloch was told the cancer was in complete remission and that he had no more to fear from the disease.

title: EMILY REMLER, NEW GUITAR VIRTUOSO, AT BLUE NOTE
description: EIGHT years ago Emily Remler was picking out rock tunes on a single string of a guitar. She had never heard any jazz, she couldn'tread a note of music and had no particular interest in being a musician. Today she is being hailed as one of the major jazz stars of the 1980's, a guitarist of unusual authority and individuality.

title: Sports People; Arcel Honored
description: The trainer Ray Arcel and the late Mike Jacobs, a colorful promoter of the 1930's, were among four men voted into the Boxing Hall of Fame by a committee of sportswriters. Also named were Harry Jeffra, who won the world bantamweight and featherweight championships four decades ago, and Jack Blackburn, who trained Joe Louis when he was heavyweight champion.

title: 2 INDICTED FOR MURDER OF JUDGE
description: A narcotics smuggler and a hired killer, both already in prison, were indicted in Texas today on charges of murdering the Federal district judge who was scheduled to preside over a drug case against them in 1979.

title: A FRENCH CRIME MELODRAMA
description: ''GARDE A VUE'' could euphemistically be called a psychological thriller. It could more accurately be called a slow, claustrophobic crime melodrama with a lot of talk.

title: Tigers 4, Blue Jays 2
description: DETROIT (UPI) - Lou Whitaker broke a 2-2 tie with a run-scoring single in the sixth, and Enos Cabell hit his second run-scoring single an inning later in Detroit's home opener.

title: ONCE AGAIN, THEY'RE ASKING: WILL KENNEDY RUN?
description: It is as though 1980 and all those caucus and primary defeats in the snows of Iowa and New England never happened.

title: MORE HEUBLEIN STOCK BOUGHT
description: The General Cinema Corporation raised teh ante in its stock battle with Heublein Inc., announcing that it has acquired another 456,900 shares of the Farming, Conn., food and beverage company.

title: HISTORY IS REVISED A BIT FOR NEWEST GREEN BOOK
description: For the record, it's known as the Official Directory of the City of New York, but the only ones who call it that are the same people who insist on telling tourists how to get to the Avenue of the Americas.

title: HATE GENERATION
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Stock Exchange has elected to its board Abraham A. Ribicoff, currently special counsel to the law firm of Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hays & Handler and former United States Senator and Governor of Connecticut.

title: U.S. SHIFTS ON SOVIET GAS LINE
description: The Reagan Administration has decided to avoid further conflict with European allies over a Soviet natural gas pipeline and will seek instead to establish ground rules for East-West trade at an economic summit meeting June 4, Administration officials said today.

title: Sports People; Cosmos' Bogicevic Back
description: Vlado Bogicevic of the Cosmos, the North American Soccer League's career leader in assists, has recovered from a sprained right knee that kept him out of action for a month.

title: Union Pacific Off 38.1%
description: The Union Pacific Corporation said yesterday that its firstquarter earnings and sales fell from last year because the recession had reduced railroad traffic and cut into refinery operations.

title: FILM SERIES PUTS SPOTLIGHT ON NEW WOMEN
description: DIRECTORS By LESLIE BENNETTS

title: CITY OPERA: 'GEROLSTEIN'
description: GEROLSTEIN may sound like a tonic for old folks, but don't believe it. It acts more like a sleeping pill. Which is to suggest ever so gently that the New York City Opera's new production of ''The Grand Duchess of Gerolstein'' makes an evening's visit to Offenbach's mythical principality seem like a week in the Land of Nod.

title: FRENCH 'DIVA' OPENS AT THE PLAZA
description: ''DIVA'' is an empty though frightfully chic-looking film from France. Though it means to be a romantic suspense-thriller, it has the self-consciously enigmatic manner of a high-fashion photograph, the kind that's irresistible to amateur artists who draw mustaches on the perfectly symmetrical faces of pencil-thin models in sables.

title: SLAIN WOMAN HAD IDENTIFIED HER EMPLOYER AS FRAUD KEY
description: The controller of a Manhattan diamond company who was murdered this week identified her employer as the originator of a $6 million fraud at the company.

title: STATES HEEDING PLEAS TO STRENGTHEN LAWS ON DRUNKEN DRIVING
description: Amid rising public concern over the tens of thousands of deaths and injuries caused each year by drunken drivers, states from Maine to California are imposing tough new penalties, raising the legal drinking age or making it easier to obtain convictions.

title: G.M. Aids Loss-Ridden Opel
description: Adam Opel A.G., the struggling West German unit of the General Motors Corporation, said today that losses rose in 1981 and that G.M. had lent it the equivalent of $530.9 million last year.

title: SHIITE MOSLEM AND LEFTIST FIGHTING SPREADS IN LEBANON
description: Shiite Moslem militiamen and armed leftist groups fought until dawn here today in the worst outbreak of hostilities in a year.

title: St. Cecilia's 'Israel'
description: Handel's ''Israel in Egypt'' will be performed by the St. Cecilia Chorus and Orchestra tomorrow night at 8 in Carnegie Hall, Seventh Avenue and 57th Street.

title: ART: FROM JAY COOGAN, SCULPTURAL PERSONALITIES
description: MATISSE may have been the last artist who strove to please. But since his famous 1908 statement about making art that would soothe, like ''a good armchair,'' the drive has been in the opposite direction. Artists, whether motivated by concern for the public's mental hygiene or by an insatiable need for instantaneous response, have been impelled to confuse and to mystify or in one way or another to sock it to their audience.

title: RANGERS DEFEAT ISLANDERS, 5-4, FOR a 1-0 LEAD IN SERIES
description: A 59-foot goal by Reijo Ruotsalainen with 118 seconds left gave the Rangers a 5-4 victory over the Islanders tonight in the opener of their quarterfinal National Hockey League playoff series at Nassau Coliseum.

title: DEMOCRACY IS OBSESSION OF BANNED SEOUL POLITICIAN
description: Kim Young Sam, banned from national politics by President Chun Doo Hwan, is moving to reorganize his shattered New Democratic Party in apparent defiance of the South Korean authorities.

title: MOST OF ARGENTINE FLEET IS REPORTED TO LEAVE PORT
description: Argentina's only aircraft carrier and most of the rest of its fleet reportedly put out to sea today from a port 800 miles north of the Falkland Islands.

title: 'PRE-RETIREMENT' COMMUNITY IN JERSEY
description: The sociological forces that have led to the development of what are known as retirement communities, those homogeneous enclaves built exclusively for the elderly, are well known, particularly to Herbert E. Wishnick, a New Jersey-based developer. Since 1965 Mr. Wishnick's company, Crestwood Village Inc. of Whiting, N.J., has built several retirement communities with a total of more than 9,000 units throughout the Northeast and Middle Atlantic States.

title: Market Place  Robert Metz
description: OPPENHEIMER & COMPANY, the securities firm, has come up with a surprising expression of Wall Street opinion on Reagan economics. A polling of 138 money managers yielded an emphatic consensus that ''the Reagan politics are salutary.''

title: Sports People; Wagner Fills Posts
description: Wagner College has filled two positions formerly held by P.J. Carlesimo, who resigned recently to become head basketball coach at Seton Hall. Walt Hameline, Wagner's football coach, has been named athletic director, and Neil Kennett, formerly assistant basketball coach, has been promoted to head coach.

title: SEES NO HARM TO PUBLIC EDUCATION
description: President Reagan proposed legislation today to give income tax credits to families that pay tuition to private elementary and secondary schools.

title: CAPITAL'S NATIONAL THEATER IS INDEFINITELY CLOSING
description: The National Theater, in the midst of a clash with the Shubert Organization and facing a dispute over an adjoining construction project, will close indefinitely early next month and will lay off virtually all its staff of 100 people.

title: THEATER: 'JOHNNY BULL'
description: NEW HAVEN IN ''Johnny Bull,'' Joe Malenko, a G.I. stationed in Britain in 1959, brings a peace-bride home to his coal mining family in Willard Patch, Pa. His tyrannical father takes a look at the pert blonde bird and assails her as a ''Johnny Bull whore,'' simultaneously casting aspersions on her nationality and her morality.

title: JOURNEY TO MARCO POLO'S TIME THROUGH COSTUMES
description: Politicians, movie actors and leaders of industry shielded their eyes from the glare of flashbulbs and the sparkle of costumes Wednesday night at the Textile Museum here.

title: A RICH NEW MINE RUNS INTO THE DIAMOND SLUMP
description: The potential for disappointment seemed minimal when the geologists and mining engineers from De Beers Consolidated Mines, the South African diamond concern, ran feasibility studies on a flat, arid savannah here that was sparsely covered with thorn bushes and cattle.

title: Penn Central's Net Gains 57%
description: The Penn Central Corporation, a diversified energy and manufacturing concern, said yesterday that its first-quarter profits rose 57 percent, in part reflecting the inclusion of earnings by GK Technologies, which Penn Central acquired at the end of last year's first quarter.

title: A GRAND NAME FALTERS
description: But it was Mary, Mary, Long before the fashions came, And there is something there, That sounds so fair, It's a grand old name. By JOYCE PURNICK

title: DAVIS AIMS TO UNTANGLE BOXING CAREER
description: The gold medal is gone, too. On the day he stood before a Manhattan news conference and accused his managers of mishandling his boxing career, Howard Davis Jr. returned home to Dix Hills, L.I., and found his pregnant wife, Gina, rushing out of a neighbor's house next door. His wife had arrived only minutes before with their 10-month-old son. The front door was broken, the back door was open. She looked inside, saw the disarray and rushed to the neighbor's house to telephone the police. Davis got there before they did.

title: ABBOTT IS SENTENCED TO 15 YEARS TO LIFE IN SLAYING OF WAITER
description: Jack Henry Abbott was sentenced yesterday to a minimum of 15 years and a maximum of life in prison for killing a waiter in the East Village last summer.

title: FABLED STONES UP FOR SALE; Fabled stones up for sale.
description: JEWELS and clocks formerly owned by European and American aristocrats are among the highlights of next week's auctions at Christie's, Park Avenue at 59th Street, and Sotheby Parke Bernet, Madison Avenue at 76th Street. The star of Christie's auction next Tuesday at 10 A.M. and 2 P.M., is the Emperor Maximilian diamond, a cushion-cut stone of 41.94 carats with a strong blue fluorescence. Maximilian, the brother of the Hapsburg Emperor Franz Josef of Austria, was Emperor of Mexico from 1863 to 1867, a reign that ended before a Mexican firing squad. His young wife, Carlotta, returned to Europe and went mad after failing to persuade Napoleon III to keep troops in Mexico. The diamond was sold to help pay her medical bills some time before her death in 1927.

title: LIVELY COMPETITOR TO THE OLD DE KOONINGS
description: IT is possible to take Willem de Kooning for granted. It is also possible to say that he has gone off, gone down and fallen apart. Behind his every exhibition, after all, there stands the competition. The competition in this case is not the work of other living painters. It is the record of de Kooning's own long career. Of how many painters now living can it be said that they renewed the idea of figure painting, renewed the idea of landscape painting and made for themselves a new and enduring abstract idiom?

title: 6 ARAB YOUTHS AND ISRAELI SOLDIER HURT IN PROTESTS
description: Six Palestinian youths were shot and wounded today in the Gaza Strip, and an Israeli soldier was hurt in the leg by a stone as demonstrations continued over the shootings Sunday by an Israeli soldier on the Temple Mount in Jerusalem.

title: PACE OF TALKS QUICKENS FOR BUILDING EMPLOYEES
description: The pace of negotiations between the owners of rental and cooperative apartment houses in New York City and their building employees quickened yesterday. Both sides pressed efforts to reach an agreement before contracts expire at midnight Tuesday.

title: Borg Declines to Play At Wimbledon in 1982
description: Bjorn Borg, the 25-year-old five-time Wimbledon champion from Sweden, confirmed today that he would not play in this year's tournament ''as a matter of principle.''

title: CHINA TERMS RELATIONS WITH U.S. AT CRITICAL STAGE
description: The Chinese Government warned today that Chinese-American relations remained at a critical stage over the Taiwan arms issue and that it was possible that they could worsen.

title: LENOX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
DECEPTIVE MESSAGE OF FELONY STATISTICS
description: To the Editor:

MEREDITH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
SILTEC CORP reports earnings for Sales
description: B-Net income after $285,000 loss from discontinued operations

title: FLEET WITHIN WEEK OF THE FALKLANDS
description: The vanguard of the British battle fleet is less than a week's sailing time from the Falkland Islands, military sources indicated today.

title: ISC SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 25
INGREDIENT TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
BRITISH COLUMBIA FOREST PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
U.S. Aide Arrives in Cairo
description: President Reagan's special envoy in the negotiations for Israel's final withdrawal from the Sinai Peninsula arrived in Cairo from Israel today.

title: BILL TO PERMIT TV CAMERAS AT TRIALS WINS SUPPORT
description: Court administrators, prosecutors and news organizations yesterday supported a proposal to allow cameras into New York State's courtrooms on an experimental basis. But the use of cameras was opposed by some lawyers' groups.

title: WORCESTER BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Consumer Saturday; A CAUTION ON EASY CREDIT CARD
description: ''MAJOR credit cards available without a credit check,'' one of the many advertisements appearing in newspapers around the country says. The offer may seem irresistible to people who have difficulty obtaining credit cards. The offers are also deceptive, according to the United States Postal Service, the New York State Attorney General's office and the Better Business Bureaus in New York and other cities.

title: Soviet Jew, 18, Is Arrested In His 2d Red Square Protest
description: An 18-year-old Soviet Jew chained himself to a fence around St. Basil's Cathedral in Red Square today and held up a sign demanding permission to immigrate to Israel. The police quickly seized him.

title: 586 ARE ARRESTED ON DRUG CHARGES IN WEEK'S RAIDS AT PUBLIC AREAS
description: A special unit of the Police Narcotics Division made 586 arrests on drug-related charges this week in a series of purchases and raids in parks and other public areas of Manhattan, the police said yesterday.

title: Leaders Picked to Head Wolf Trap Fund Drive
description: Leaders from business, political and civic circles have been named to head efforts in the Washington to raise $17.5 million to rebuild the Wolf Trap Center for the Performing Arts.

title: Hinckley Now Denying He Aimed at President
description: John W. Hinckley Jr. has asserted that he was not aiming at President Reagan when he shot him nearly 13 months ago but was trying to hit his limousine, the Government disclosed tonight.

title: MEN'S STORES BATTLING BACK
description: In the last few years, discounters, rising clothing prices and higher operating costs have put new pressure on traditional men's wear merchants that do not want to cut prices to attract business.

title: HORIZON BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
SAFETY-KLEEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 27
description: B-Includes $1,029,000 gain from stock appreciation rights...C-Includes $975,000tax credit and has been restated to reflect a change in accounting for foreign currency translation

title: ZIEGLER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
MITEL CORP reports earnings for Yr to Feb 26
NORTHWEST NATURAL GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Lieut. Col. R. T. Coulson Marries Helen McMaster
description: Helen Margaret McMaster, business manager of the Cox Newspapers in Washington, was married yesterday to Lieut. Col. Robert Theodore Coulson, U.S.A. District Court Judge Daniel Fairfax O'Flaherty performed the ceremony in his chambers in Alexandria, Va.

title: INTERSTATE POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
SALEM CARPET MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
TRANSAMERICA INCOME SHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Reagan's Tax Return Indicates a $14 Refund
description: President and Mrs. Reagan reported earnings of $418,826 in 1981 and paid almost 40 percent of that in Federal income taxes, their joint return showed today. Among the Reagans' deductions was $5,930 for gowns that Nancy Reagan gave to museums.

title: AMALGAMATED SUGAR REFINING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
MERCK DIPS 1.8%
description: The Control Data Corporation reported yesterday that net income in the first quarter of 1982 slipped 5 percent, while revenues rose 8.6 percent.

title: INTERFIRST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The results reflect the 1981 mergers accounted for on a pooling of interests basis

title: HAIG HAS DAY OF TALKS WITH ARGENTINES
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. met with Argentine officials for most of the day today in renewed efforts to head off war between Britain and Argentina over the Falkland Islands.

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 13.

title: NATIONAL CENTRAL FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Including securities gains of $13,000 for the latest first qr and securities losses of $34,000 for the yr-ago first qr

title: TPC COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
De Gustibus; WHEN BUYING FOOD, REMEMBER GEOGRAPHY
description: One of the most neglected aspects of choosing fresh foods wisely might well be termed the geography of quality. Rarely is the public given qualitative guidelines on the differences between products grown in various parts of the country and the world.

title: WILSON BROTHERS reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
MEDICAL COVERAGE AND THE ELDERLY
description: To the Editor:

title: LITTLE, ARTHUR D, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 2
SUCH ORDINARY PEOPLE, SUCH SINGULAR PAIN
description: Hugs and kisses all around. A peck on the cheek, a pat on the shoulder. First names and close acquaintance. The room faces a grimy red-brick wall; ''LAW OFFICE'' it says in faded block letters on the windows across the way. The red chairs are arranged in a neat circle. The pain, and the violence, are like a noxious gas in the square, dull room.

title: DETECTOR ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31

PATENTS;
Atari Improves Method Of Video Display
description: Atari Inc. of Sunnyvale, Calif., which manufactures video games and home computers, received a patent this week for improved methods of generating moving objects on a video display screen. David R. Stubben and Lyle V. Rains obtained patent 4,324,401.

title: OMNICARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The 1981 earnings are on a proforma basis

title: RECITAL: TRIOS BY BEETHOVEN
description: On the solid assumption that Beethoven's trios are a noble contribution to the literature, even if only one of them carries the title ''Archduke,'' the Kalichstein-Laredo-Robinson Trio has undertaken a complete cycle of the works at Lincoln Center this season. The second of the cycle's three programs was heard Tuesday in Alice Tully Hall; it offered one fairly familiar work and three glimpses, spanning 20 years, into the less-well-known part of Beethoven's output.

title: REAGAN SEES TALKS ON BUDGET NEARING A 'CLIMACTIC' STAGE
description: President Reagan said today that his Administration's budget negotiations with Congress were ''approaching a climactic stage,'' and he promised a ''constructive and conciliatory spirit'' in deciding whether to compromise on his economic program.

title: ARGENTINE OFFICIALS WARN OFF A NEW SOVIET INFLUENCE
description: Apparently troubled by Argentina's international isolation over its seizure of the Falkland Islands, officials here have started warning in private that the confrontation with Britain is offering the Soviet Union an opportunity to extend its already considerable influence on Argentines.

title: ONE-DAY TRANSIT STRIKE SURPRISES BOSTON
description: A surprise one-day transit strike began at 5:15 o'clock this morning, as the first train stood poised to roll out of Ashmont Station to head for downtown Boston on the Red Line. John Moran, a barn captain and union representative, waved a hand and yelled to the motorman, ''Nobody's going out!''

title: MUBAREK LETTER REASSURES BEGIN ON SINAI PULLOUT
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin received a letter today from President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt and was officially described as satisfied and pleased by the message.

title: MITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Omnicare Inc.  Client Cutback
description: Omnicare Inc., a supplier of specialized medical services to hospitals, said that its major customer, American Medical International Inc., will not renew 14 contracts with Omnicare that are due to expire later this year.

title: UNICOA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
CURB ON HONG KONG'S TEXTILES
description: Textile industry and Government officials here have canceled one of Hong Kong's more prestigious export promotions, the 14-year-old Ready-to-Wear Festival, which has traditionally been aimed at Western markets. Textile and apparel makers now plan to look more to the market in Japan, which does not restrict clothing imports.

title: AMERICAN NUCLEAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Books of The Times; Resisting the 'Best'
description: THE RANDOM REVIEW, 1982. Edited by Gary Fisketjon and Jonathan Galassi. 317 pages. Random House, $14.50. Ballantine paperback, $3.95.

title: NEW YORK CAN BE THE WORLD HIGH-TECH CAPITAL
description: To the Editor:

title: Donahue Will Interview For ABC's Late News
description: Phil Donahue, whose interview program is seen on 217 television stations, will appear in a regular feature of a late-night newscast of ABC News beginning in October. The announcement was made by Roone Arledge, president of ABC News and Sports, and Walter Bartlett, whose Multimedia produces and syndicates Mr. Donahue's program.

title: MERCHANTS NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Operating loss...C-Net loss

KAISER CEMENT & GYPSUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31

title: LYNCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $5,000 for the latest first qr and $48,000 for the yr-ago first qr

title: 100,000 on Strike in Spain
description: More than 100,000 workers went on strike today to demand greater Government investment in the northern Spanish region of Asturias, union spokesmen said. Virtually every sector of production was affected, especially mining and steel.

title: 43.3% Gain For First Chicago
description: The First Chicago Corporation said yesterday that its net operating earnings rose 43.3 percent, to $33.1 million, or 83 cents a share, in the first quarter of 1982, from $23.1 million, or 58 cents a share, in the 1981 period.

title: Around the World; 2 British Explorers Stranded in Arctic
description: Two British explorers attempting to be the first to circle the earth by both polar caps are stranded in the Arctic with only four days' rations, according to a radio report received in London today.

title: NEW LOOK AT STOPPING NUCLEAR WAR
description: Roger C. Molander was still a card-carrying member of what is known in this town as the ''arms control community'' when he attended a meeting at the Pentagon that helped change his life.

title: A Bargain Beauty
description: TWO years ago, Edward Anchel learned that sometimes it pays to arrive unfashionably early. It was the first night of the Keeneland summer yearling sales in Lexington, Ky., and most of the well-heeled buyers and agents were still sipping drinks near the outdoor walking ring or handing their car keys to the valet attendants as the first few horses went through the selling ring.

title: Teacher of the Year
description: A solid crystal apple for the Teacher of the Year was presented to Bruce Brombacher, a 33-year-old Vietnam War veteran from Upper Arlington, Ohio, who gave up a promising scientific career to go into teaching.

title: TRANE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
GIRARD CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
CONSOLIDATED OIL & GAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
DAVIS IN A COMEBACK, OUTPOINTS CRUZ
description: There were times last night, said Howard Davis Jr., ''it felt like I was in a different world.'' There were flashes, he said, of what it used to be, when he believed no boxer in the world could beat him. But for most of the 10 rounds, Davis struggled with himself in scoring a unanimous decision over Angel Cruz at the Felt Forum.

title: GUARDSMAN CHEMICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
PLANTERS NATIONAL BANK & TRUST CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
WANTED: PHILOSOPHER OF CORRECTION
description: Prisons have fascinated the thinkers outside them. ''While we have prisons,'' George Bernard Shaw said, ''it matters little which of us occupies the cell.'' Fyodor Dostoyevsky wrote, ''The degree of civilization in a society can be judged by entering its prisons.''

title: THE ILIAD AND THE ODDITY
description: Everything fades. You can forget your own shoe size, your parents' ZIP code, the capital of Missouri. But try forgetting commercials soldered to your synapses: Mr. Whipple and the Charmin, the Esso tiger in your tank, Brooke's Calvins, Robert Young's Sanka prescriptions. Memory's runny sieve has special repositories for these. We can all play about a thousand feet of celluloid over in our minds, and most of it contains commercials.

title: SOCIETY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Watson Leads by 1
description: Tom Watson shot a four-under-par 68 today to take a one-stroke lead at 137 midway through the $350,000 Tournament of Champions.

description: B-After a securities gain of $4,000 and loss from discontinued operations of $118,000

title: 2 GAZA STRIP ARABS KILLED BY ISRAELIS
description: Two Palestinian Arabs were killed and at least 13 wounded by gunfire today as worshipers coming out of mosques in the Gaza Strip and the West Bank attacked several small patrols of Israeli soldiers, an army spokesman reported. No soldiers were reported injured.

title: BRT REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: B-Net income including extraordinary income of $240,794

title: SOUTH CAROLINA NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
FARMERS SEEK ANY WAY TO RAISE THEIR EXPORTS
description: With American grain and soybean supplies at record levels and prices depressed as a result, farmers are clutching at any chance to increase exports of these commodities.

title:
NOTES ON PEOPLE;
I.R.S. Spurns Corn
description: With the Federal income-tax filing date now past, there comes a story from Dayton, Ohio, about Ralph Dull, a farmer who tried to pay his tax bill with a truckload of corn from his 1,000-acre farm in Brookville.

title: C. Y. TUNG, OWNED A SHIPPING EMPIRE
description: C.Y. Tung, who controlled one of the world's largest shipping fleets, died Thursday of a heart attack. He was 71 years old.

title: U.S. AND SOVIET RESUMING TALKS ON GRAIN SALES
description: Under pressure from farmers, the Reagan Administration has agreed to hold talks with the Soviet Union on grain sales, the first since the imposition of martial law in Poland last December.

title: LOST 1953 MAYORAL RACE
description: Harold Riegelman, who served New York for more than 60 years in various health, housing, financial and cultural organizations, but failed in his campaign for Mayor in 1953 against Robert F. Wagner, died yesterday at New York Hospital after a brief illness. He was 89 years old and lived in Manhattan and Chappaqua, N.Y.

title: Sports People; Al Davis Testifies
description: Al Davis, owner of the Oakland Raiders, testified in Federal District Court in Los Angeles yesterday that the original lease with the Oakland Coliseum was for five years with a series of three-year options at the $26 million stadium. Letters were introduced by the Raiders' attorney, Joseph Alioto, to show that the Coliseum had increased its demands to a 10-year lease with payment of 10 percent of the gross.

title: Around the World; Iran Opens Assault On Kurdish Militants
description: Iranian Government forces backed by helicopter gunships and heavy artillery have launched a major offensive against Kurdish rebels in the western part of the country, Kurdish sources said today.

title: NETS ROUT CELTICS, IMPROVE PLAYOFF SPOT
description: The playoff-bound New Jersey Nets added what Ray Williams called ''another of our little miracles'' to their season tonight. They overwhelmed the Boston Celtics, 113-96, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, giving Boston, the best team in basketball, its worst loss of the season.

title: 'A BAD RAP'
description: To the Editor:

title: SUNAIR ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
HERITAGE BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Factory Utilization Resumes Decline
description: Manufacturers operated at 71.4 percent of capacity last month, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, down from a revised 72 percent in February. It was the seventh drop in factory use in the last eight months.

title: Around the Nation; Woman Wins $700,000 In Polio Vaccine Case
description: A drug company that manufactures polio vaccine has been ordered to pay $700,000 to a woman who contended she was paralyzed after her daughter was vaccinated with live virus.

title: Triton Option Sold to Reliance
description: The American Financial Corporation, which is controlled by Carl H. Lindner, a Cincinnati financier, said it had sold an option to buy a 22 percent interest in the Triton Group to the Reliance Group Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of Reliance Group Holding Inc.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Bill Shoemaker may have found his Kentucky Derby horse. After winning the Forerunner Purse at Keeneland on Linkage, Shoemaker said he was impressed by the horse's performance and would know more after the Blue Grass next Thursday. ... Ira Matthews, a former star kickreturner for the Oakland Raiders, was among eight free agents who signed with the Green Bay Packers. ... Rick Wise, the 37-year-old right-hander who has a 188-181 career mark in 18 major league seasons, was waived by the San Diego Padres. The Padres chose Wise in the sixth round of the free agent re-entry draft in 1979 and signed him to a five-year pact.

title: Getty Oil Expands Issue
description: The Getty Oil Company said today that its subsidiary Getty Oil International (Caribbean) N.V. would increase its planned sale of 14 percent, seven-year notes outside the United States to $125 million from $100 million, because of market conditions.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, APRIL 17, 1982
description: International British warships are on schedule on their journey to the Falkland Islands and are less than a week's sailing time from the islands. Sources in London said that the last units of the task force - made up of about 25 ships - had left their rendezvous point off Ascension Island, in mid-ocean between Africa and South America, early Thursday, following ships that had left Monday or Tuesday. (Page 1, Column 1.) Britons deeply resent the way the United States has dealt with the Falklands crisis. The Argentines also have been critical of the United States, believing that it was favoring Britain. But many Britons have been offended by what they feel is the lack of more overt support by senior American officials, including President Reagan and Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. Perhaps the strongest resentment has been directed at Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the United States delegate to the United Nations, who attended a dinner a the Argentine Embassy in Washington on April 2, the day the Falklands were seized by Argentina. (1:2-3.)

title: BANK OF VIRGINIA CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
PERMITS UP
description: New housing starts rose 2.5 percent in March, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 947,000 units, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: CHARGES WEIGHED FOR PARENTS WHO LET BABY DIE UNTREATED
description: Prosecutors said today that they might file charges against the parents of a retarded infant who died at Bloomington Hospital after the parents, with a court's approval, denied him food, water and medical aid.

title: PEACEFUL SOLUTION URGED BY REAGAN
description: President Reagan pledged again today that the United States would do ''everything possible to head off hostilities between Great Britain and Argentina'' over the Falkland Islands.

title: FLAGSHIP BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
SOUTHEAST BANKING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
FILM: 'NEIGE,' CHRISTMAS FAIR AND SOME PIGALLE CHARACTERS
description: ''Neige'' (Snow), the first feature to be directed by the actress Juliet Berto and Jean-Henri Roger, who was a member of Jean-Luc Godard's Dziga Vertov group, is an actorly sort of movie in the manner of something by John Cassavetes. Though it is far more tightly written and edited than a film by Mr. Cassavetes - indeed, it looks almost too slick and professional for its own good - ''Neige'' is full of meaty roles for actors and is not overly encumbered by a story that might get in their way.

title: RANGERS OFFER NO EXCUSES BUT VOW TO COME BACK
description: The Rangers had no alibis tonight after they were routed, 7-2, by the Islanders in the second game of their Stanley Cup playoff series at the Nassau Coliseum.

LOMAS & NETTLETON MORTGAGE INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
FOR SANDINISTS, AN EX-ALLY'S CHALLENGE
description: The denunciation of the Nicaraguan Government by one of its revolutionary heroes could signal the creation of a new center of opposition to the Sandinist regime, according to diplomats, Congressional aides who specialize in the area and Central American politicians here.

title: PENN CENTRAL NAMES PRESIDENT-CHIEF EXECUTIVE
description: The Penn Central Corporation yesterday named the chief executive of its key energy subsidiary to be its next president and chief executive officer.

title: FEDERAL DOUGH, COLLEGE LOAF
description: Reducing Federal financial aid to college students could help many young lives, I think, by making potential students think hard about going to college and considering alternatives to formal education. I say that because of my experience, just a few years ago, as a student receiving lots of Federal aid.

title: ACCIDENT INSURANCE COVERAGE: SOME PROS AND CONS
description: The policies are sold in machines at airports, by direct mail and through newspaper advertisements as well as by insurance agents. They are bought by people who worry that they might break a leg on a skiing vacation, that their children might be injured in a schoolyard or that the plane they are taking might crash.

title: Argentine Herald Strike Ends
description: The Buenos Aires Herald, a 106-year-old English-language daily, won a battle today as distributors ended a five-day strike that had sharply reduced its circulation. The newspaper La Prensa had argued in an editorial that the strike was besmirching Argentina's reputation abroad.

description: Yr-ago results reflect the adoption of an accounting change for foreign currency translations

title: U.S. ASKS STROH TO SELL ONE OF SCHLITZ'S PLANTS
description: The Justice Department went to court today to require the Stroh Brewery Company to sell off one of the brewing operations of the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company in return for antitrust approval of their merger agreement.

Belfast Policeman Dies
description: A policeman shot in an ambush died in a Belfast hospital today, authorities said. Sgt. David Brown was shot when he drove into a dead-end street April 1 to pick up a cleaning woman to take her to the police station where both worked.

description: Batus Inc., the American arm of B.A.T. Industries of London, said yesterday that it had reached an agreement with the staff of the Federal Trade Commission that settles the agency's investigation of Batus's continuing acquisition of Marshall Field & Company. The action was seen as clearing the way for Batus to acquire the Chicagobased retail chain.

title: Sports People; Minor League Magic
description: Whether the Mets truly have the magic back is a question whose answer will have to await the steamy days of July and August. But Darryl Strawberry, the outfielder from Los Angeles who was chosen No.1 in the amateur draft two years ago, is already working some magic for their Texas League farm club at Jackson, Miss.

title: Military Analysis
description: Any fighting between Britain and Argentina over the Falklands is likely to focus at the start on the islands' only airstrip, with British aircraft attempting to knock it out, military experts here and at NATO headquarters in Brussels say.

title: AMERICAN INCOME LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
COLLEGES COMBAT COMPUTER ABUSES
description: At universities around the country, administrators are becoming concerned that computers, now an everpresent teaching tool, are becoming the vehicle for high-speed plagiarism and vandalism.

title: SYSCON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: B-After $400,000 loss from contract litigation

title: Irene Krugman Dead; Environmental Artist
description: Irene Krugman, a sculptor known for environmental works, died of cancer Thursday at her home in Morristown, N.J. She was 56 years old. Mrs. Krugman, whose work was concerned with spatial relationships, created environmental installations -both for indoor and outdoor sites - that made the viewer aware of their interior space as well as their relationship to surroundings. Her work is in the permanent collections of the Newark Museum, the New Jersey State Museum and the University of Notre Dame.

title: A FUTURISTIC WORLD OF SCENTS
description: Happy, nostalgic, carefree, romantic - just decide the mood you're in or the mood you'd like to be in. Then pull out a cassette, put it on the machine and the room will be filled with -what? The answer today would probably be music. The answer a few years from now, according to Annette Green, may very well be fragrance.

title: Transactions;
description: BASEBALL

title: Canucks, Led by Hlinka, Top Kings, 3-2
description: Ron Delorme checked Larry Murphy of Los Angeles along the boards early in the third period, took the loose puck and fed Gary Lupul for the winning goal in a 3-2 victory for the Vancouver Canucks in the first game of the divisional final Thursday night.

title: FIRST PENNSYLVANIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31

PATENTS;
Virus for Vaccination Incubated in Living Cell
description: A method of preparing a living virus to be used in vaccination for mumps was patented this week.

title: REGAL-BELOIT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Your Money; Employees Get More Benefits
description: AT the Phillips Petroleum Company, every dollar an employee decides to save is matched by a 50-cent company contribution to his thrift plan. Sound good? It gets better. When stockholders meet at the end of April, they are expected to approve a plan that would match employee savings dollar for dollar. In addition, the funds in the thrift plan are not taxed as they accumulate and receive favorable treatment at termination.

title: Briefing
description: Freeze Testing Grounds

title: OPERA: 'GRAND DUCHESS OF GEROLSTEIN' REVIVED
description: Gerolstein may sound like a tonic for old folks, but don't believe it. It acts more like a sleeping pill. Which is to suggest ever so gently that the New York City Opera's new production of ''The Grand Duchess of Gerolstein'' makes an evening's visit to Offenbach's mythical principality seem like a week in the Land of Nod.

description: President Reagan's spokesman did not try to defend him today when a reporter questioned the accuracy of a Presidential assertion that Britain once hanged people for carrying guns in the commission of crimes.

Spain Honors Paley

title: WAS DEPUTY FOR EISENHOWER
description: Gen. Thomas T. Handy, who served as Deputy Chief of Staff to Gen. George C. Marshall and Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower in World War II and later as commander of all American troops in Europe, died Wednesday at Brooke Army Medical Center in San Antonio, Tex., after a long illness. He was 90 years old.

title: Babette B. Ashby Dies at 55; An Editor With Family Circle
description: Babette Brimberg Ashby, an editor for Family Circle magazine, died of cancer Tuesday at North Shore University Hospital, Manhasset, L.I. She was 55 years old and lived in Port Washington, L.I.

UNITED JERSEY BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
RULE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28

ON FLOTILLA: JAZZ MIXES WITH DRILLS;
The Observer, London
description: It had been another pleasant evening: dinner, followed by a Royal Marine band concert. As the last notes died away, Col. Tom Seccombe, the commander of the military forces aboard this British troopship, rose to say a few words.

title: A Costly Budget Fracas in Albany
description: No mere observer can fully grasp all the motives in Albany's newest budget fracas, but the main issues seem clear. New York's legislators amended Governor Carey's budget to increase spending on programs their constituents like - mainly aid to education and assistance to local governments -and without raising taxes.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American First Corp. and San Diego Bancorp said they had reached an agreement in principle for American First to acquire First Affiliated Securities Inc., a securities broker-dealer subsidiary of San Diego Bancorp, on undisclosed terms.

title: PACT HALTS A REVAMPING OF RULES ON STRIP MINING
description: The Interior Department signed a binding agreement with the National Wildlife Federation today that would halt pending changes in rules controlling strip mining until the environmental effects of the changes could be assessed.

title: CONCERT: GERMAN HERITAGE
description: At Avery Fisher Hall on Monday evening, Rohan Joseph and the American Philharmonic Orchestra mined that seemingly inexhaustible lode, the 19th-century Austro-Germanic repertory, for their eighth concert of the season. The program, which opened with Weber's overture to ''Der Freischutz'' and was brought to a close by a performance of Bruckner's Symphony No. 6 in A, marked the New York debut of the Sri Lankan-born pianist Malinee Peris, who joined Mr. Joseph and the orchestra in Beethoven's ''Emperor'' Concerto.

title: The U.N. Today; April 17, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Conference on Law of the Sea - 10:30 A.M., 3 P.M. and 8 P.M.

title: NEW ENGLAND ELECTRIC SYSTEM reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day yester- day incorrectly reported the interest rate for one-year tax-exempt savings certificates. The current rate is 10.16 percent, rising to 10.37 percent tomor- row.

title: TROUBLE IN CITY BUDGET SEEN BY FINANCIAL CONTROL BOARD
description: The staff of the State Financial Control Board, which must pass upon New York City's budget, has told the Koch administration that it may withhold its full endorsement this year, largely because of uncertainty created by the budget conflict in Albany.

title: 3 Men Arrested In Bronx Shooting
description: Three Bronx men have been arrested on assault and drug charges in the shooting of two boys in the University Heights section of the Bronx, the police said.

title: Around the Nation; 7 Houston Policemen Dismissed in Beatings
description: Seven police officers were dismissed and six were supended without pay today for harassing and beating several hotel guests after an election night party, the authorities said.

title: GORMAN-RUPP CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
TRANSCRIPT OF REMARKS BY REAGAN ON BUDGET
description: Following is a White House transcript of remarks by President Reagan to editors and broadcasters from the Southeast today:

title: Gunman Robs Catholic Rectory
description: A gunman who said he had killed three people herded a priest, his visiting sister and a nun into the kitchen of a church rectory on East 12th Street yesterday before fleeing with about $120 and two watches.

title: CONCERT: PIANIST, 12
description: Mstislav Rostropovich, always with an eye for the dramatic, disrupted his Tchaikovsky Festival with the National Symphony in Carnegie Hall Thursday night to present the American debut of a 12-year-old Greek pianist, Dimitris Sgouros. The revised program began with an impassioned, idiomatic, excellently played account of the Tchaikovsky ''Manfred'' Symphony and concluded with Rachmaninoff's Piano Concerto No. 3.

U.S. COURT BARS UNION FEES FOR SOME NONUNION WORKERS
description: A Federal appeals court ruled today that in the 20 states where compulsory unionism is outlawed unions cannot insist on contract provisions that require payment from nonmembers.

title: TEXAS AMERICAN BANCSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
U.S. HANDLING OF FALKLAND CRISIS STIRS DEEP RESENTMENT IN BRITAIN
description: The handling of the Falkland crisis by the United States Government has provoked deep resentment in Britain. The Argentines have also been critical of the United States, charging that it was favoring Britain. But a broad cross section of Britons have been offended by what they feel is the lack of more overt support by senior American officials, including President Reagan and Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.

title: Sports People; Athletic Academics
description: Admissions standards at Michigan, which has a solid reputation for academics as well as athletics, are sometimes lowered to help in the enrollment of athletes from high schools, Cliff Sjogren, the university's admissions director, acknowledged. Mr. Sjogren was responding to a series of articles in the student newspaper, The Michigan Daily, which cited school records showing that eight student athletes, five of them football players, had been accepted with below-average scores in the Scholastic Aptitude Test and that two of the youths had compiled high school averages of less than C. The newspaper quoted the football coach, Bo Schembechler, as saying, ''The university is obligated as a public institution to provide opportunities for young people from all backgrounds.'' And Mr. Sjogren said that ''there have to be some compromises'' to achieve athletic and academic excellence. ... Del Shankel, the acting athletic director at Kansas, said that ''an internal review'' had failed to produce evidence warranting a full investigation into possible football recruiting violations. School officials had acknowledged that the National Collegiate Athletic Association advised them of a possible inquiry.

title: FIRST OKLAHOMA BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
THE CITY
description: City police officials and the Federal Bureau of Investigation yesterday established a special unit to investigate the slayings this week of a witness in a Federal inquiry and three CBS employees. An F.B.I. official, Kenneth Walton, said the agency had assigned several agents to work with detectives ''for the duration of the case.''

title: Around the Nation; Investigation Reopened In Doctor's Murder Case
description: New evidence in the murder case against Dr. Jeffrey MacDonald has prompted the Federal Bureau of Investigation to reopen the investigation at the request of a retired agent acting as an independent investigator in the case, the authorities said today.

title: WEST UPSET BY REAGAN PLAN TO SELL SOME FEDERAL LANDS
description: A Reagan Administration plan to help reduce the national deficit by selling Federal lands to private bidders threatens to ignite a new controversy over public land policy in the West.

title: BANKS OF IOWA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Canada Bank In Fraud Case
description: The Bank of Nova Scotia, a multinational lender that is one of Canada's five largest financial institutions, has been charged with seven counts of fraud in connection with the liquidation in 1976 of a western department store chain based in Regina, Saskachewan.

title: METS BEATEN BY 4-3 ON OLIVER'S HOMER
description: Al Oliver sent a message to his lawyer last night: Now you can talk to the Montreal Expos about that new contract. Oliver, who would have been a Yankee if Oscar Gamble had been willing to become a Texas Ranger again, provided the lawyer, Howard Mandell, with some bargaining power for those negotiations by hitting a ninth-inning home run that gave Montreal a 4-3 victory over the Mets at Shea Stadium.

title: Dow Rises to 843.42, A 10-Week High
description: Stock prices rose yesterday in stepped-up trading to finish at their best levels in 10 weeks. A strengthening bond market was cited as one reason for the advance. Newly announced takeovers sent two issues sharply higher.

title: Julie Mendoza Married
description: Julie Alma Mendoza, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin C. Mendoza of New York and Locust, N.J., was married in the Cosmopolitan Club yesterday to David Joseph Pavlucik, son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew J. Pavlucik of Stratford, Conn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Robert F. Pitcock, a Dutch Reformed minister.

title: BRAUN ENGINEERING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Layoffs at VW in U.S.
description: Volkswagen of America Inc. said today that it will close its only American car and truck assembly plant, in Westmoreland, Pa., for two weeks starting Monday, laying off 4,000 workers. A company spokesman said that the plant, which is operating this week, will be closed to reduce inventories. VW already has 900 employees on indefinite layoff.

title: 'DIRTY POWER' FELLS COMPUTERS
description: Shortly before 8 o'clock one night recently, the voltage in Con Edison's power lines serving the West Side of Manhattan dropped to 5 percent of normal levels for a fraction of a second. Most people in the area noticed only a flickering of lights, but for some the effects were more lasting.

title: PORTEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
BRUINS ROUT QUEBEC TO LEAD SERIES, 2-0
description: Barry Pederson scored twice in a threegoal second period and Rick Middleton added a goal and three assists tonight to lead the Boston Bruins to an 8-4 rout of the Quebec Nordiques and a 2-0 lead in their Stanley Cup quarterfinal playoff series.

title: No Headline
description: Scott May scored 7 of his 11 points in the fourth quarter tonight and sparked the Milwaukee Bucks to a 112-99 triumph over the Knicks. New York, which fell to 33-48, was led by Bill Cartwright's 19 points. Cartwright left in the fourth quarter after he chipped a tooth in a scramble for a loose ball.

title: RAINIER BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
DENT BENCHED
description: Bad weather and bad feelings continued to hound the New York Yankees tonight as they opened a weekend series with Ron Guidry defeating the Detroit Tigers, 10-2, but with Bucky Dent benched and angered.

title: Around the World; 2 Whites Added To Zimbabwe Cabinet
description: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe added two new whites to his Cabinet today and promoted loyal members of the opposition party in order to strengthen national unity.

title: Article 070751 -- No Title
description: The president of the New York Public Library was standing at his desk, routinely going through his mail one recent morning, when he came across an enclosure that made him sit down, stupefied.

title: HOME FOR THE HOMELESS
description: It was a typical night in a small overnight shelter that a group of us operate in Brooklyn. It's called Christian Help in Park Slope, and although the all-volunteer staff includes the unchurched and Jews and self-proclaimed agnostics, and its location on dingy Fourth Avenue is hardly in the poshest section of the neighborhood, the shelter night after night provides food and lodging for a dozen of that newly discovered and publicized group, the homeless. Some stay with us but a night, others for weeks.

title: STAGE: THE ACTING COMPANY PERFORMING 'TWELFTH NIGHT'
description: Ten years old, the Acting Company, an offspring of the Juilliard Theater Center, remains a youthful troupe, annually replenishing itself with new talent. As has become customary, the company includes New York as a brief stop in its valuable nationwide touring, and is now in residence with a two-week two-play season at the American Place Theater. Through this weekend, the Acting Company is offering ''Twelfth Night,'' to be replaced next week by ''The Country Wife.''

title: FIRST SECURITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
UNION PLANTERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Sports People; 49ers Sign Nehemiah
description: As expected, the Super Bowl champion 49ers held a news conference in San Francisco to announce that they had signed Renaldo Nehemiah, the world-record hurdler, to a four-year contract worth a little more than $500,000. Nehemiah, who is 23 years old, has not played football since he graduated from Scotch Plains (N.J.) High School five years ago.

title: Billy Joel Recovering
description: Billy Joel, the rock singer and songwriter injured in a motorcycle accident on Long Island Thursday, was reported in ''quite good'' condition yesterday after major surgery at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center in New York.

title: MONEY SUPPLY UP $7.1 BILLION
description: The Federal Reserve late yesterday announced a $7.1 billion increase in the basic money supply for the week ended April 7, a large gain that was at the upper end of economists' forecasts.

title:
Patents;
Drying Up Of Water Measured
description: WASHINGTON AN evaporimeter, which measures the speed of evaporation of water and other liquids, was patented this week for the RCA Corporation. Its potential applications are in meteorology, agriculture, control of water reservoirs and the protection of moisture-sensitive books and antiques in libraries and museums.

title: BRANIFF DEAL IS SET BACK BY C.A.B.
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board today rejected a request that it give prompt approval to an agreement that would permit Pan American World Airways to lease Braniff Airways' Latin American routes for four years.

title: CROCKER NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Around the Nation; Two Air Force Officers Retire After Losing Jobs
description: Two officers were relieved of their command at Keesler Air Force Base for ''bad judgment,'' it was announced today.

title: Bennington Elects
description: Bennington College, the 600-student liberal arts college in Vermont, got its eighth president yesterday. The board of trustees elected Dean Michael K. Hooker, of Johns Hopkins University, to succeed Joseph S. Murphy.

title: Gypsum Layoffs
description: The National Gypsum Company said it will lay off 435 of the 625 workers at its Huron Cement division here, beginning next week, because of a continuing slump in the nation's construction industry.

title: SOO LINE RR CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
RLC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
F.T.C. MOVES TO CLOSE FOUR REGIONAL OFFICES
description: To comply with the Reagan Administration's budget reduction proposal for next year, the Federal Trade Commission voted unanimously today to close four of its 10 regional offices.

title: EASTERN CHURCHES TO OBSERVE EASTER
description: For Eastern Orthodox Christians, yesterday was Good Friday. It marked the beginning of solemn observances preceding the triumphant festivities if Easter Sunday for Eastern Orthodox Christians.

title: New York; YOU CAN'T WRAP FISH WITH TV
description: The survival of The Daily News has become a big story in this town. The accounts in print, on radio and on television of the corporate/union struggle over its fate have taken on a cliff-hanging quality as the putative April 25 deadline approaches. The consumers of these daily battle stories have a right to ask: Is it that important? Are we in the journalistic community breathing hard merely because something we don't like, something that makes us nervous, is happening inside our fraternity? Does it matter if The News folds or are we inflating the importance of a newspaper to the city it serves?

title: AN H.U.D. SURRENDER TO AMERICA'S HOUSING PROBLEMS
description: To the Editor:

title: FIRST CITY BANCORPORATION OF TEXAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect acquisitions on a pooling of interests basis

title: BOXER'S DEATH REVEALED
description: Fred Bowman, a 25-year-old lightweight boxer who had been comatose for 13 months as a result of injuries he suffered in a bout here, died March 23, a funeral home in Youngstown, Ohio, and his trainer reported today.

title: OLD STONE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $485,000

title:
PATENTS;
Hosiery Repair Kit To Eliminate Runs
description: Janice L. Crandall and her husband, Richard W. Crandall, who live in Chicago, were granted a patent this week for a hosiery repair kit.

title: IMPERIAL CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Italy Upsets U.S. Team In World Hockey, 7-5
description: Italy, a newcomer to the world hockey championships, upset the United States team today, 7-5. An empty-net goal by Dave Tomassoni with 10 seconds left insured the victory.

title: PASSPORT TRAVEL INC reports earnings for Yr to Nov 30
SATURDAY, APRIL 17, 1982; International
description: The U.S. agreed to hold grain talks with the Soviet Union next month. The talks, sought by American farmers, would be the first since martial law was imposed on Poland last December. While the Administration called the talks ''routine,'' two Farm Belt Senators said the meeting would be a step toward longer-term sales. (Page 1.) U.S. farmers, who have watched record crops and large stockpiles erode their incomes, are seeking any chance to raise exports. (32.)

title: CELANESE CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-After a loss of $276,000 from discontinued operations; the company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges

title: A TOWN VOTES TO REMAIN ONE
description: Longtime residents of this community failed Thursday in their bid to vote it out of existence in an effort to keep it from being taken over by the disciples of an Indian guru, but most of the ballots were immediately challenged by the county election supervisor.

title: NAMIBIAN GUERRILLAS MAKE DEEPEST RAID IN MORE THAN A YEAR
description: The insurgent South-West Africa People's Organization, which appeared to have been crippled by repeated South African assaults on its bases in Angola, has carried out its deepest and most effective raid into the disputed territory known as Namibia in more than a year.

title: 'THE AMATEUR,' COLD WAR HUNT
description: Movies that sneak into town without advance screenings don't ordinarily amount to much. But ''The Amateur,'' which opened yesterday at the Criterion Center and other theaters, is better than one might expect. As cold-war thrillers go, this is an efficient and enjoyable one, with a good cast, a clever if overburdened plot, and a stylish brand of mayhem. The final shootout, for example, takes place in a warehouse full of mirrors and crystal chandeliers. Another scene is set in a bar that has an underwater view of a swimming pool.

title: STRUTHERS WELLS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: B-Includes $16,182 extraordinary gain...C-Includes $382,790 gain from discontinued operations

title: Around the Nation; Ukrainian Boy Files Suit To Block Return Home
description: A lawyer for a 14-year-old Ukrainian youth filed a lawsuit today in Federal District Court asking that the youth's parents be barred from forcing him to returning to his homeland.

title: SOUTH CAROLINA ELECTRIC & GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
VARCO INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
IN SINAI, A DEFIANT FEW AWAIT INEVITABLE BULLDOZERS
description: Occupied Sinai, April 15 - Amid pain and defiance, Israel is dismantling its presence in the last area of the Sinai Peninsula still under its control, in preparation for returning it to Egypt in 10 days.

title: FIRST INTERSTATE BANK OF CALIFORNIA reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: First Interstate Bank of California is the largest subsidiary of First International Bancorp, which has 21 affiliate banks in the 11 Western states

title: CON ED SEEKS 12 PERCENT INCREASE AND END OF HIGHER SUMMER RATES
description: A $475 million rate increase - raising the average monthly electric bill by $5.33 in New York City and by $7.88 in Westchester County - was requested yesterday by the Consolidated Edison Company.

title: Briefing
description: In the Beholder's Eye

title: Tax Relief Offered To French Business
description: As it approached the anniversary of its first year in power, France's Socialist Government sought help from the business sector today by proposing a huge tax cut intended to stimulate investment and revive the economy.

title: CITY ADVISES PUBLIC NOT TO EAT SALMON FROM 7 3/4-OZ. CANS
description: Health officials in New York City and Connecticut yesterday advised people not to eat any Alaskan salmon from 7 3/4-ounce cans. They acted after doctors in Hartford said that a 68-year-old woman who apparently ate such salmon had contracted botulism.

title: ISLANDERS DEFEAT RANGERS BY 7-2 AND TIE SERIES AT 1-1
description: The Islanders regained their championship form tonight and routed the Rangers, 7-2, at Nassau Coliseum. The victory evened their Stanley Cup quarterfinal series at one game apiece, with the third and fourth games of the four-of-seven series scheduled for Madison Square Garden Sunday and Monday nights.

title: SOME TRUCKING CONCERNS RENEGE ON INCREASES IN TEAMSTER CONTRACT
description: A continuing business slump in the unionized trucking industry is leading some companies to renege on an agreement to give members of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters a scheduled cost-of-living raise.

title: EPSCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Unusual Elections
description: Besides chill winds, snow and thunder, this unusual spring brings New Yorkers four unusual elections to fill vacancies in the State Legislature. Voting takes place on Tuesday; on Wednesday the winners are expected in Albany, where without so much as a beginner's manual they may play an important role in 1982's Battle of the Budget.

title: Article 071315 -- No Title
description: The American General Corporation of Houston yesterday offered $1 billion in stock for the NLT Corporation of Nashville, an insurance company that owns Nashville's Grand Ole Opry.

title: Concert to Benefit School
description: Randy Weston, the pianist, and Leon Thomas, the singer, and other artists will perform in concert tomorrow from 2 to 6 P.M. at the High School of Music and Art, on Convent Avenue at West 135th Street. This second annual fund-raising program will benefit Mwamko wa Siasa, a pan-African oriented school at 261 West 136th Street.

title: 2 Face Prison for Oil Bribery
description: Two men face prison terms for bribery in the operation of the Teapot Dome Federal Oil Reserve. Fredrick R. Williams, a former purchasing agent for the company that operates the reserve, was sentenced Wednesday to 30 months for accepting bribes and was placed on probation for conspiring to take bribes. A Federal District Court jury later convicted Douglas E. Rawson of conspiring with and bribing Mr. Williams.

title: HEAD OF L.I.R.R. EXPECTS FARE AND SERVICE TO RISE
description: Robin H. H. Wilson has been president of the Long Island Rail Road, the nation's largest commuter line, since August. The 45-year-old Mr. Wilson, who was born in Dublin, Ireland, was educated at Cambridge and Harvard Universities. He was an executive at Trans World Airlines for more than a decade before he replaced Francis S. Gabreski, who had complained that the president of the L.I.R.R. had ''all of the responsibility but none of the authority'' for railroad decisionmaking.

title: GIBSON, C R, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
CHASE MANHATTAN BANK (NYC) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Results reflect foreign currency translation losses of $3.8 million in the latest first qr and $333,000 for the yr-ago first qr

title: OFFICER KILLS A YOUTH ON IRT HE SAID DIDN'T HEED ORDERS
description: A 19-year-old youth was shot to death by a plainclothes transit police sergeant on a Bronx subway train Thursday night. The transit police said yesterday that the youth had ignored several commands to ''freeze'' and that he appeared to have been reaching for a gun.

title: CONTROL DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Can Congress Really Regulate?
description: Like many Americans, Representative Elliott Levitas of Georgia is unhappy about Federal regulatory commissions. ''The question is,'' he says, ''who is going to run the country - the guys you elect or the guys you don't elect.'' His Congressional colleagues apparently agree and are moving, with little dissent, to a broad new curb on the commissions.

title: LEHRMAN PLACES 1981 NET WORTH NEAR 25 MILLION
description: Lewis E. Lehrman, candidate for the Republican and Conservative nominations for Governor of New York, put his net worth yesterday at almost $25 million.

title: Around the World; India to Start Producing Plutonium
description: India is preparing to begin reprocessing atomic waste at a plant designed to produce weaponsgrade as well as fuel-grade plutonium, the Government announced today.

title: Briefing
description: Capitalism's Edge

title: Disturber of the Press
description: Those whom the gods disfavor they call an ''institution.'' Louis Lyons, the longtime curator of Harvard's Nieman Foundation, earned that dubious cognomen.

title: BLUES STOP BLACK HAWKS TO TIE SERIES
description: Wayne Babych broke a 1-1 tie early in the second period leading the St. Louis Blues to a 3-1 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks to even their quarterfinal series at one game apiece. The series will resume at Chicago Sunday night.

title: INTERMAGNETICS GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: B-Including a tax credit of $26,995...C-Net income

title: FALCONBRIDGE COPPER LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Global Motion Sickness
description: Queen Elizabeth flew to Canada, Secretary of State Haig flew back and forth across the Equator and President Reagan flew to Barbados and back. While there, the President swam with Claudette Colbert and made a speech about college education, strongly hinting that he was for it.

title: CASCADE NATURAL GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
IPCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Including extraordinary tax credits of $672,000 for the qr and $1,481,000 forthe 9 mos...C-Including extraordinary tax credits of $583,000 for the qr and $1,366,000 for the 9 mos and extraordinary net gains n the sale of land of $62,000 for the qr and $322,000 for the 9 mos

title: Pepsico-Whitbread Pizza Hut Deal
description: Pepsico Inc. said it had entered into a joint venture with Whitbread & Company, a major British brewer, to increase the number of Pizza Hut restaurant outlets in Britain.

title: VICTORIA BANKSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The yr-ago net er shr reflects a 20 percent stock divd paid in Dec 1981

title: Elinor McVickar Dies; Harper's Bazaar Editor
description: Elinor Guthrie McVickar, an editor at Harper's Bazaar and a consultant to cosmetics companies, died Thursday at Doctors Hospital after a short illness. She was 80 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Bridge: Argentines Beat the British
description: In a More Peaceful Arena By ALAN TRUSCOTT

title: BAYBANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
KOPPERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
MERCANTILE BANKSHARES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
CHART HOUSE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
SALVADOR GETS RIGHTS LESSON FROM THE U.S.
description: Maj. Roger D. Slaughter, wearing his black beret with its red ranger flash, tapped his pointer against the chart listing the do's and don'ts of gaining the support of people in a fight against guerrillas.

title: Headliners; Not Stopping the Presses
description: The staff of The Alton Telegraph in Illinois was breathing again last week with word that James C. Green, a local contractor, would settle for less than his $9.2 million libel judgment against the paper. Not that the paper had libeled him in print.

title: AIR FORBES WON CAPTURES WOOD
description: Air Forbes Won, a handsome colt who began his career only six weeks ago, wore down Shimatoree with a stretch drive that was more taxing and less impressive than anyone had expected to win the $175,200 Wood Memorial by a neck yesterday at Aqueduct.

title: MORE PAC'S
description: To the Business Editor: Professor Bergmann says that PAC's ''formed by special interests ... are multiplying as fast as cockroaches in a dirty kitchen,'' and she supposedly proves her point by citing the total number of PAC's now in existence.

title: Federal Unions Don't Grow
description: The number and percentage of nonpostal Federal employees who were represented by unions remained virtually the same last year, the Government reported this week.

title: Crime; by Newgate Callendar
description: Since 1974, Elmore Leonard has been writing unusually well-crafted crime books set in his hometown of Detroit. He is not, apparently, a prolific novelist; his latest book, SPLIT IMAGES (Arbor House, $12.50), is only the fifth since ''Fifty-Two Pick-up'' eight years ago.

title: Maura Loughlin Engaged to John Carley
description: Dr. and Mrs. L. Leo Loughlin of Santa Clara, Calif., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Maura Ann Loughlin, to John L. Carley, son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Carley of Dallas, formerly of Stamford, Conn. An Aug. 28 wedding is planned in Santa Clara.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: THE controversy is continuing over the application of carbaryl, a pesticide manufactured by the New Jersey-based Union Carbide Company, to control gypsy moths.

title: Ideas and Trends; by Eva Hoffman and Margot Slade; Prize-Worthy Winners of The Pulitzers
description: The young and tragic, the old and scholarly, the middle-aged and middle-class. Last week's winners of Pulitzer Prizes in poetry, music and fiction were studies in contrasts.

title: David Mackay Coit Marries Margaret G. Richards
description: Margaret Gracie Richards, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Thorpe Richards of Annapolis, Md., and Alexandria, Va., was married yesterday to David Mackay Coit, son of Charles Armistead Coit of Portland, Me., and Mrs. Eileen Pyle Coit of Falmouth Foreside, Me. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Richard Landis at St. Anne's Episcopal Church in Annapolis.

title: NEW SENATOR LEARNING ROPES
description: WASHINGTON By States News Service

title: Europe in Bloom
description: To the Editor: Though it was interesting to read about British gardens, in the articles, ''Spring Preview: Europe in Bloom'' (Travel, March 14), I think your readers could find a comprehensive listing in the publication, ''Historic Houses, Castles and Gardens in Great Britain and Ireland,'' available for $4.75, plus $1.50 postage, from the British Travel Bookshop, 680 Fifth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10019. The book describes the gardens, their locations, seasons and hours, the fees charged, and how they may be reached by rail or motor coach. HELEN M. FRANC New York

title: The World; by Barbara Slavin and Milt Freudenheim; Solidarity Speaks Again
description: Radio Solidarity burst upon Warsaw's airwaves and the Polish consciousness last week. In an eight-minute broadcast, the clandestine station urged Poles to keep struggling for the release of detainees and ''the restoration of human dignity.''

title: 'WORKSHOP' BOOKS FOR THE PHOTOGRAPHER
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Lou Jacobs Jr. is a freelance writer who often contributes to this section. By LOU JACOBS JR.

title: REPUBLIC AIRPORT RUFFLES NEIGHBORS
