description: EAST FARMINGDALE SINCE 1969 Republic Airport has been under the wing of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, and disgruntled neighbors say that they have had to live with heavy tax losses, day-and-night airtraffic noise and fears for their personal safety. Now, there is a move in the State Legislature to make a change in the airfield's controls, and the residents are hoping it will help them.

title: ARGENTINE-RUSSIAN TRADE IS SURGING AS SOVIET TAKES 77% OF CROP EXPORTS
description: The Soviet Union's support for Argentina's position in the Falkland Islands crisis has focused attention on the close trade relationship that has emerged between the two countries over the last two years.

title: Free Agents In the N.B.A.
description: Sam Pellom; BOSTON - Eric Fernsten; CHICAGO - Ricky Sobers, Coby Dietrick; CLEVELAND - Keith Herron, Lowes Moore, Cliff Robinson, Bill Robinzine, Kevin Restani, Brad Branson, Phil Hubbard (option); DALLAS - Wayne Cooper; DENVER - T.R. Dunn, Dan Issel, Cecil Hordges, Kiki Vandeweghe, John Roche; DETROIT -John Long, Steve Hayes, Edgar Jones, Jeff Judkins; GOLDEN STATE - Bernard King; HOUSTON - Moses Malone, Mike Dunleavy, Major Jones, Elvin Hayes, Calvin Garrett, Bill Willoughby; INDIANA -Johnny Davis, Don Buse, Louis Orr; KANSAS CITY - Ernie Grunfeld.

title: USE OF TOXIC WASTES IN GAS AND HEATING OIL SUSPECTED
description: Federal and state investigators are looking into reports that significant amounts of heating oil, diesel oil and gasoline have been adulterated with toxic chemical wastes before being sold to consumers in the New York metropolitan area.

title: THE ROLLER-COASTER ART DECO MARKET
description: The ups and downs in auction sales of Art Nouveau and Art Deco material have been among the most dramatic registered in art sales in recent seasons. Over the last decade the highest price ever paid at auction for a Louis Comfort Tiffany lamp rose from about $25,000 to $360,000, a phenomenal escalation. Then, 18 months ago, the auction market for such wares began to experience reversals. Sales of virtually every category of early 20th-century decorative arts - from turn-of-the-century Tiffany lamps through 1920's Rene Lalique glass vases - weakened. Problems deepened a year ago and by last November, three of New York's top auction houses had experienced difficulties -either the goods did not sell or prices had plummeted.

title: The Region; by Richard Levine, Carlyle C. Douglas and William C. Rhodes; MUrdoch Wants To Dance, Too
description: As the field of choices narrows, so does the distance between The Daily News and extinction. The Tribune Company of Chicago, which owns The News, last week rejected an offer by Rupert Murdoch, the owner of The New York Post, to negotiate for The News. Mr. Murdoch, who put The Post's losses at close to $20 million last year, proposed putting both newspapers under common ownership with the unions agreeing to immediate cost cuts equal to operating losses.

title: NEW HAVEN'S BIRTHDAY
description: New Haven's 344th birthday will be celebrated Friday through Sunday with such traditional whoop-de-do as a Revolutionary War encampment, concerts, sports events and a fair, plus some nontraditional events that include a human chess game with Mayor Biagio DiLieto and A. Bartlett Giamatti, president of Yale University, as opposing kings. Costumed students will portray the other pieces in the game, which is to begin at 1 P.M. Saturday at the Cross Campus area.

title: Marcia M. Palmer, Nurse, Wed to Dennis Lee Lane
description: Marcia Merrick Palmer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David R. Palmer of New York and Mashpee, Mass., was married yesterday to Dennis Lee Lane, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond D. Lane of Dayton, Ohio.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Carol Zeavin, Violinist, In a Varied Program
description: Carol Zeavin, a young violinist from Los Angeles now active in New York's chamber-music life, showed energy, musical intelligence and a serviceable technique in her recital in the Abraham Goodman House Thursday night. Bach's E major Duo Sonata was graceful and ardent in its Adagio and brightly articulate elsewhere.

title: LIFE IN THE DELTA: THE LIVING IS EASY FOR A WORLD THAT SHRUGS AT CHANGE
description: In her novel ''Delta Wedding,'' Eudora Welty describes through the eyes of a 9-year-old girl how it was to enter the Mississippi Delta in 1923, aboard a train called ''The Yellow Dog'' that chugged through the hills:

title: COW POWER IS USED TO MAKE ELECTRICTY
description: NEW MILFORD COWS eat corn and make milk. But along the way, each produces 18 tons a year of manure, a smelly substance that can pollute streams and ground water.

title: SUNDAY OBSERVER
description: Ball of Wax

title: YOU'VE GOT TO HAND IT TO THEM
description: When I was growing up in the Middle West, there were no workmen, exactly. Instead, there were specialists who came over to the house and solved problems. In our elaborate household, these specialists were perhaps more important than anyone else. Their arrivals were heralded; they always came in the front door and were always addressed as ''Mr.'' And, somehow, they always had the time to explain their methods to the curious children who hung around them.

title: SCREAMS, THEN SEA'S SILENCE, STILL HAUNT 5 SURVIVORS OF TITANIC
description: Out of a night so cold that ice crystals formed ''whiskers around the lights,'' as old sailors put it, over the dark waters and across 70 years, the screams still haunt these five survivors, aging men and women for whom the nightmare of the sinking of the Titanic is endless.

title: HOW THEY'RE DOING IN MUNCIE, IND.
description: MIDDLETOWN FAMILIES Fifty Years of Change and Continuity. By Theodore Caplow, Howard M. Bahr, Bruce A. Chadwick, Reuben Hill and Margaret Holmes Williamson. 443 pp. Minneapolis: University of Minnesota Press. $16.95.

title: BOWLERS FIND LEAGUES TO SPARE
description: YEAR-OLD Joey Ciciola, his T-shirt proclaiming him the ''World's Greatest Bowler,'' smiles broadly. He has just rolled a spare, knocking down all 10 pins in two tries. As he returns to the scoring table, his father (and bowling teammate) congratulates him with a hearty hand slap.

title: REAGAN SAYS THAT PEACE DEPENDS ON SUPPORT FOR U.S. ARMS BUILDUP
description: President Reagan said today that ''nuclear war cannot be won and must never be fought'' but that peace depended on public support for a continuing American military buildup.

title: THE NEW YORK TIMES MAGAZINE / PART 2 APRIL 18, 1982
description: 17 MAKING OVER Why People Are Investing in: Remodeling * Redesigning * Redecorating By George O'Brien Soaring interest rates and inflation have quite literally hit home. As a result, traditionally mobile-minded Americans are staying put and making do - creatively.

title: Other Business; EMPLOYMENT: MANY ARE LOOKING AHEAD
description: ''Open your door to a better life,'' proclaims a brochure for Job World, one of dozens of agencies catering to Americans seeking employment abroad. ''These exciting overseas opportunities may be the way to make and save a fortune.''

title: Stage View; PLAYWRIGHTS NEED TO BE NURTURED; by Walter Kerr
description: I'd like to call your attention to an infamous, or at the very least exceedingly shortsighted, sentence you may easily have missed. It turned up in several daily newspapers recently at the tag end of an item announcing the closing of a certain Broadway show. I'm not going to bother giving you its title or the names of the people involved with the enterprise because titles and names aren't of the essence here. A commonplace attitude is.

title: Katherine Meade Plans June Bridal
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Meade of Wassaic, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Katherine Ruth Meade, to James C. Tanner Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Tanner of Pawling, N.Y.

title: THE DANCE: PAUL TAYLOR PRESENTS VARIETY OF 'PROFILES'
description: Paul Taylor has been producing exciting new dances for so long now that one gets used to a certain amount of razzle-dazzle at every performance. But two works new to the Paul Taylor Dance Company's spring repertory at City Center, performed Thursday, were reminders of how quietly powerful a choreographer he can be.

title: The Region; by Richard Levine, Carlyle C. Douglas and William C. Rhodes; Older Is Wiser, Hartford Hopes
description: After walking a wobbly line on the issue for 10 years, Connecticut last week took a firm stand on teen-age drinking. By a 104-to-40 vote, the House of Representatives followed the Senate's lead and approved a bill to raise the legal drinking age from 18 to 19 on July 1. Gov. William A. O'Neill has promised to sign it.

title: Collioure
description: To the Editor:

title: China's Air Line
description: To the Editor:

title: IT'S EARLY TO COLLEGE UNDER BENEFITS RULE
description: OAKDALE ANNE BALFOUR laughed as she recalled that in the space of five hours on March 31 her daughter, Deborah, was suddenly transformed from a typical, if bright, high school junior to a registered college freshman ready to begin classes at Dowling College here on April 19.

title: 'IT'S A MUSICAL AND F.D.R. SINGS IN IT'
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Mike Nichols, the theater and film director, is one of the producers of the musical ''Annie.'' By MIKE NICHOLS

title: OFTEN, IT PAYS TO GO BANKRUPT
description: As the news reports bombard us with the recurring theme of rising and spreading business failures, the word ''bankruptcy'' relentlessly creeps into the vocabulary. And just last week, a proud old name in American business - Addressograph-Multigraph, now called AM International - did what many corporate executives dread. It filed for protection under the nation's bankruptcy law.

title: Jamaica
description: To the Editor: Letter-writer Edith Selig's experience with a guide at Dunn's River Falls (Travel, March 14) so closely paralleled our own that I am compelled to give additional words of warning. v. e vacationed in Jamaica a few weeks ago, and heeding advice to hire a guide, we accepted the offer of a man who was waiting at the bottom of the road to Dunn's River Falls.

title: New York Times Magazine April 18, 1982
description: William Safire 12 On Language Sluff It All Off Russell Baker 24 Sunday Observer Ball of Wax Zbigniew Brzezinski 28 The Failed Mission The inside account of the attempt to free the hostages in Iran. Fox Butterfield 32 How the Chinese Police Themselves Visitors to China often remark with surprise that it doesn't seem like a police state.

title: Bilingual Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Aspirin Diet Is Found To Slow Cancer in Rats
description: Tests with rats showed that simple aspirin slowed the growth of liver cancer without the sometimes painful and toxic side effects of chemotherapy, a research team reported Friday.

title: Around the World; Turkish Chief Reiterates Pledge of Democracy
description: Gen. Kenan Evren, head of Turkey's military junta, said again today that the armed forces would return Turkey to a parliamentary democracy. But he said the army would not permit political activities until a new constitution was approved by a referendum and election and political bills were enacted.

title: AMERICAN JEWS AND THE HOLOCAUST
description: *Copyright 1952 by W.H. Auden. From ''W.H. Auden Collected Poems,'' edited by Edward Mendelson. Reprinted by permission of Random House Inc.Lucy S. Dawidowicz is the author of ''The War Against the Jews 1933-1945.'' Her most recent book is ''The Holocaust and the Historians.'' By Lucy S. DawidowiczThe mass and majesty of this world, all That carries weight and always weighs the same Lay in the hands of others; they were small And could not hope for help and no help came. ...* - W.H. AUDEN

title: About Time
description: A recent story about the Naval Observatory's frustrations with timekeeping confirms a bar-stool theory of relativity: nobody has ever known exactly what time it is.

title: Ellen Goodwin Harwood Has Nuptials
description: Ellen Goodwin Harwood, daughter of Mrs. Richardson Harwood of Natick, Mass., and the late Mr. Harwood, was married yesterday to Grant Bennet-Alder, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Bennet-Alder of Tucson, Ariz. The Rev. Robert W. Ihloff performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Natick.

title: FOR THE WORLD'S LARGEST LIBRARY; by Samuel A. Tower
description: The Library of Congress, which began as a service to the members of Congress and still continues to serve that role, also serves as a national library for all the people of the nation and as a repository of the history, culture, attainment and aspirations of America. It is the largest library in the world.

title: MEDICAID PAYMENTS: 2 VIEWS ON THE SYSTEM
description: This concerns the article by Caren Goldberg regarding physician experience with Medicaid payments for those people who were deemed eligible for such payments by the state. Prior to the institution of Electronic Data Systems Corporation, in November 1981, payments for the Department of Welfare were sporadic and in some instances took as long as six months. Those of us who take care of people who are entitled to Medicaid and welfare payments had become accustomed to the delays and nonpayments.

title: Singer's Translators
description: To the Editor:

title: Stores Checked in City For Suspected Salmon
description: New York City Health Department inspectors began checking the shelves and storerooms of 1,100 grocery stores in the city yesterday in an effort to help retailers identify cans of Alaskan salmon that might be contaminated with botulism.

title: FIRE DEPT. DECREASES RESPONSE TO ALARMS AT THE TRADE CENTER
description: The New York City Fire Department has reduced the number of companies that respond immediately to automatic alarms at the World Trade Center.

title: Topics; TERMINOLOGY, TERMINATIONS; Resignation Reversed
description: Last year Brenda Grier, a member of the Newark School Board, refused to vote for Dr. Columbus Salley, who was selected to administer the city's schools. She charged that Mayor Gibson had improperly interfered in the selection.

title: R.A. Semeraro Weds Dana Stambaugh
description: Dana Underwood Stambaugh and Richard Anthony Semeraro were married yesterday in the Grace Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. Harold Barrett, the rector, performed the ceremony.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: THE PURSUIT OF LOVE & LOVE IN A COLD CLIMATE, by Nancy Mitford. (Vintage, $2.95.) These two sly, witty comedies of manners about the English country gentry during the 1920's are the basis of the currently popular PBS television series. ''The Pursuit of Love'' (1945) centers on Linda Radlett's search for romantic love in all the wrong places, while ''Love in a Cold Climate'' (1949) tells of Polly Hampton's eagerness to forgo her inheritance for the man of her choice. In a foreword, Jessica Mitford, sister of Nancy Mitford (1904-73), attests to the faithfulness of the novels to the lives of their family and friends.

title: ESTEE LAUDER: THE SCENTS OF SUCCESS
description: Blue is the color of the headquarters of the Estee Lauder group, from the midnight blue elevator banks to the blue walls, blue carpets and blue-and-white overstuffed sofas of the reception area. Blue is the personal trademark of Estee Lauder, as pink was Elizabeth Arden's. And just as surely as Mrs. Lauder has nailed her color to the company's mast, she has stamped her personal imprint on the group, by some measures the most successful cosmetics company in the United States.

title: Self-Searching In Israel
description: Michael Elkins's sensitively written article on Israel's inner conflict prompts me to respond (''Self-Searching in Israel,'' March 7). Last summer we took our children to Israel for the first time.

title: Mrs. Gandhi in Saudi Arabia
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India arrived here today at the start of a four-day official visit. Mrs. Gandhi will go to Riyadh Sunday to meet King Khalid and other Saudi leaders for talks expected to focus on economic ties.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
JOFFREY WEEKEND
description: Making a long weekend out of their visit to Long Island's East End, the Joffrey II dancers (with Ron Reagan) will appear at Southampton College's Fine Arts Theater on Friday at 8 P.M. and at Guild Hall's John Drew Theater in East Hampton on Saturday at 8:30 P.M. and next Sunday at 2:30 P.M. For ticket information, call 283-4000 in Southampton and 324-4050 in East Hampton.

title: Children's Books
description: LIVES OF THE ARTISTS By M.B. Goffstein. Unpaged. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $8.95. (All Ages) By SELMA G.LANES

title: The World; by Barbara Slavin and Milt Freudenheim; Ecevit Back Behind Bars
description: Bulent Ecevit, a former Prime Minister of Turkey who won't stop speaking out, spent 60 days in prison earlier this year for criticizing martial law. Last week, he was locked up again and the Ankara martial law commander ignored a military court's finding that there was insufficient evidence to hold him.

title: THE SPELL OF THESE STONES
description: Few marks left by ancient man have crazed so many as the vast stones surviving from the Stone Age, some rough, some carved, standing alone or in circles, or balanced on giant pedestals. Found in Europe, the Americas, Asia, Africa, Easter Island and other islands, they have inspired fantastic theoretical wars among archeologists, astronomers and historians, and have been delved into, moved, defaced, plundered and sometimes worshiped by enthusiasts trying to prove they were Druid temples, astrological clocks, tombs or gods.

title: STOKOWSKI'S LEGEND - MICKEY MOUSE TO MAHLER
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Abram Chasins is the author of ''Leopold Stokowski, A Profile,'' which will be published in October by E.P. Dutton By ABRAM CHASINS

title: Officials Report 3 Dead In Separate Bronx Fires
description: Two children were killed in a Bronx apartment yesterday by a fire that officials termed suspicious. In an apparently unrelated blaze, firefighters found the charred body of an unidentified man believed to be in his 20's when they responded to a brush fire in Van Cortlandt Park, near 252d Street, in the Bronx at 9:10 A.M.

title: Rocket Crashes in Alaska
description: A rocket equipped to study forces that create the aurora borealis, or northern lights, crashed three minutes after takeoff in Alaska, a launching official said. But another rocket on the same mission was successfully launched an hour later Thursday night by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

title: Camera; POINTERS ON TAKING PICTURES AFTER DARK; by Joseph Williams
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Joseph Williams is a copy editor in the National News Department of The Times.

title: Building Triumph
description: To the Editor:

title: Prospects; Another Dip in G.N.P.
description: Private analysts say that this week's first official G.N.P. estimate may show that the Government's economists were quite prescient when they said in March the economy fell 4.5 percent last quarter.

title: A STARK POLITICAL FABLE OF SOUTH AFRICA
description: WAITING FOR THE BARBARIANS By J. M. Coetzee. 156 pp. New York: Penguin Books. Paper, $3.95.

title: SUBMARINE PIONEERS HONORED
description: HACKENSACK ON MAY 17, 1897, a small cigar-shaped vessel slipped into the murky waters of the Arthur Kill, off Elizabeth. It dived, surfaced, dived again and continued on its maiden voyage.

title: JULIE A. KISER IS BETROTHED TO RICHARD H. WALDMAN
description: Mr. and Mrs. Julian A. Kiser of Indianapolis have announced the engagement of their daughter, Julie A. Kiser of Chicago, to Richard H. Waldman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward S. Waldman of Greenwich, Conn.

title: SINGING COWBOYS RIDE THE COMEBACK TRAIL
description: Singing cowboys, those yodeling, rough-riding, gun-toting heroes of the Old West, seem to be staging a comeback. Last week, Columbia Records introduced a ''Columbia Historic Edition'' series that includes newly assembled album collections of old favorites (and some previously unreleased recordings as well) by Gene Autry, the Sons of the Pioneers (with Roy Rogers), the Texas honky-tonk singer Lefty Frizzell, and two pioneers of the country-jazz hybrid called western swing, Spade Cooley and Bob Wills.

title: ARBOUR'S STRATEGY STIRS SUTTERS TO ACTION
description: Al Arbour plays no favorites. In his constant pursuit of excellence this season, the Islanders' coach dared to bench Denis Potvin for two games when the team captain and three-time Norris Trophy defenseman made some costly errors.

title: JOHN G. WILCOX TO MARRY LESLIE HARLOW SEPT. 11
description: Mr. and Mrs. Albert Lewis Harlow of Fairfield, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Leslie Marie Harlow, to John Griffin Wilcox Jr., a son of Mrs. John Griffin Wilcox of Jamesburg, N.J., and the late Mr. Wilcox.

title: Dispelling Menstrual Myths
description: As a feminist counselor, columnist and woman who knows too well the impact of premenstrual syndrome, I was delighted to see Robin Marantz Henig's discussion of a topic that has been taboo for too long (''Dispelling Menstrual Myths,'' March 7). We feminists admit the possibility that our menstrual cycles influence our moods and actions.

title: Catherine Collins Is Married to Jonathan W. Skipp
description: Catherine Thorpe Collins, daughter of Paul Herbert Collins and Kitty Bob Hyatt Collins, was married yesterday to Jonathan William Skipp, son of Dr. Francis E. Skipp and Marjorie LaPorte Skipp. Both families are of Cocoanut Grove, Fla., where the Rev. Warren C. Skipp, uncle of the bridegroom and an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony in the garden of the Monroe estate, a historic site.

title: MAKING OVER MAGICIANS AND MATERIALS
description: Because of prices that have gone through proverbial roof, most people are sticking to the homes they have. But this is no reason to ignore changing living needs.

title: U.S. SUES UNION IN TEST CASE
description: NEWARK LOCAL 560 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters has been chosen by the Department of Justice as the first target for a new method of rooting out union corruption.

title: SETON HALL WINNER IN 3 RELAYS
description: Seton Hall won three events, but Al Oerter and Benn Fields drew the individual attention today at the eighth annual Rutgers Relays in the Rutgers Stadium.

title:
Other Business;
PRODUCTIVITY: QUALITY CIRCLES FOR SUPERMARKETS
description: Broken eggs, wasted meat, wilted vegetables - these are the special nightmares in the 28,680 supermarkets across the country that haul in sales of $171.6 billion each year but rely on a razor-thin 1 percent to 2 percent of gross sales for net profits.

title: Children's Books
description: KIMAKO'S STORY By June Jordan. Illustrated by Kay Burford. 42 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $6.95. (Ages 7 to 10) By BRENDA WILKINSON

title: 47 Atomic Power Sites Warned on Bolt Defect
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has warned operators of 47 atomic power plants that bolts in some of their facilities may be corroded and could cause leaks of radioactive water.

title: A PARADOX IN MONTCLAIR
description: MONTCLAIR BECAUSE the recent paintings of Jack Roth, which are on view at the Montclair Art Museum until May 9, are beautiful, they raise some interesting questions about where we are in the world of art at the moment.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
VISITING PSYCHIATRIST
description: In his only New York area appearance this year, Viktor E. Frankl, the noted Viennese psychiatrist, will lecture at the C.W. Post Center's Concert Theater on Tuesday. Dr. Frankl, whose ''Man's Search for Meaning'' has sold more than two million copies in the United States, will speak at 8 P.M. at the Brookville campus. Tickets are $5; $2 for non-Post students; admission is free for the college's students and staff. For reservations, call 299-2233.

title: Business Conditions; LYING INDICATORS
description: In economics, some statistics indicate, but just as many obfuscate. And some mean nothing at all. The problem has always been to differentiate among the three. Now, to make matters easier, two Wall Street economists have come up with a new award.

title: A DINNER THEATER ANALYZES SUCCESS
description: ELMSFORD WHILE the last several years have seen the disappearance of two Actors' Equity operations, the Main Street Theater of White Plains and the Westchester Regional Theater of Harrison, a dinner theater in the county continues to prosper.

title: SEMINAR ON FURNITURE
description: John Stair, who directs Sotheby Parke Bernet's restoration shop in Manhattan, will conduct a seminar, ''The Care of Fine Furniture,'' Thursday at the Snug Harbor Cultural Center on Staten Island. The seminar, which begins at 7 P.M., opens a three-day conference on ''Restoration and Preservation Technology.''

title: Follow-Up on the News; Buying Funerals
description: A new law adopted by New York City in August 1981 was designed to protect consumers in their dealings with funeral homes because, in the words of the law's sponsor, Councilman Henry J. Stern, ''aside from a house and a car, a funeral is the single most expensive purchase that many people make.''

title: MORRISTOWN IS HOPEFUL OF SETTLING ZONING RIFT
description: MORRISTOWN A PROPOSAL by Planned Parenthood of Northwest New Jersey to move into a building a block from where it is now has taken on epic proportions in the last 11 months as the organization has sought to rebut allegations that it is undermining the morals of young people.

title: SOME SIMPLE AND QUICK WAYS OF EATING MEATLESS
description: EVEN those who do not consider themselves vegetarians -and that is most of us - will, once in a while, have a meatless meal. More and more, people are saying they can't eat as much meat as they used to. The idea of a big juicy piece of roast beef no longer sends shivers of delight from their heads to their stomachs.

title: Sports People; First Times Out
description: Amid controversy over sponsorship for next year and indications that the 86th race may be the last one to start on a Monday, two first-time starters were the favorites as a field of more than 7,600 prepared for tomorrow's Boston Marathon. Alberto Salazar won his only two previous marathons, both in New York, and set the world record of 2 hours 8 minutes 13 seconds last October.

title: Dance; THE 'NEW' PROFILE OF BALLET THEATER
description: Mikhail Baryshnikov is now in his second year as director of American Ballet Theater. This year, many said, would indicate his real strengths and weaknesses as a director and suggest a company profile. But a quick scan of the repertory and casting for Ballet Theater's eight-week season at the Metropolitan Opera House reveals no immediate truths about the ''new'' Ballet Theater. Stars like Alexander Godunov and promising youngsters like Susan Jaffe will share the opening night program tomorrow. There's drama from Kenneth MacMillan, abstraction from Choo San Goh and a romp from Lynne Taylor-Corbett, with new company productions ranging from George Balanchine to Merce Cunningham and revivals of ballets that helped to identify Ballet Theater under the previous direction of Lucia Chase and Oliver Smith.

title: MUSIC: TCHAIKOVSKY OPERA 'IOLANTA'
description: Mstislav Rostropovich has been sometimes criticzed for the narrowness of his repertory and his supposed lack of technical skill as a conductor. But the man has a mission, which is to bring Russian music to the West, and at least in that music he conducts with both authority and a passionate intepretive insight that transcends mere facility.

title: Follow-Up on the News; TV Live Crime
description: In one of the more ambitious television surveillance programs in the country, Miami Beach began last November to mount 120 camera boxes on traffic signal poles along a three-mile stretch. By monitoring the street scene, the police hoped to foil would-be rapists, muggers and robbers.

title: Editor's Choice
description: life L.A. lawyer. THE FATE OF THE EARTH, by Jonathan Schell.

title: WHY WOMEN DOMINATE MODERN DANCE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Roger Copeland teaches at Oberlin College and is co-editor of the anthology ''Dance Theory and Criticism'' to be published by Oxford University Press later this year. By ROGER COPELAND

title: OLD STURBRIDGE: PAST IS PRESENT
description: SHERRY MARKER is a writer who lives in Northampton, Mass. BY SHERRY MARKER

title: Around the Nation; Public Transit Service Resumes in Boston
description: Service resumed today on the city's bus, subway and trolley lines as officials considered taking disciplinary action against some members of the Carmen's Union, which staged a one-day wildcat strike.

title: HOW THE CHINESE POLICE THEMSELVES
description: Copyright c 1982 by Fox Butterfield. Reprinted by permission of Times Books, a division of Quadrangle/The New York Times Book Company.

title: A MEMO BY MARCOS WORRIES HIS FOES
description: When President Ferdinand E. Marcos returned in late March from a six-day visit to Saudi Arabia, he found the National Assembly in heated debate over what would happen in the event of his death.

title: Miss Emmons Becomes Bride
description: Constance L. Emmons, daughter of Mrs. Philip L.R. Du Val and Peter B. Emmons, both of New Canaan, Conn., was married there yesterday to Timothy M. Brown, son of Mrs. Randolph F. Brown and the late Mr. Brown, also of New Canaan. The Rev. T. Guthrie Speers Jr. performed the ceremony in the First Presbyterian Church.

title: LITERARY SWITCHBOARD
description: RICHARD A. By Sol Yurick. 446 pp. New York: Arbor House. $14.95.

title: Business Conditions; TRADE: A HIDDEN THORN
description: While some analysts attribute the ongoing recession to the continued slump in key industries like autos, housing and steel, the real reason may lie elsewhere.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; William Waters Plays Various Guitar Works
description: The most difficult aspect of music, Pablo Casals once said, is not the notes but the spaces between them. It is there, too, that the guitarist William Waters seemed most uncomfortable in Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night.

title:
Economic Affairs;
PUT A TAX ON OIL POLLUTION
description: Oil consumption is financial pollution. When someone buys a gallon of gasoline or heating oil, he imposes an economic cost on the nation. Such activity is financial pollution because it imposes an extra social cost, or premium, on the nation that is not borne by the person who burns the fuel.

title: FINDING THE RIGHT ARCHITECT
description: Anyone who thinks that the way to renovate painlessly is to hire an architect might want to think again. An architect, no matter how clever, efficient or well-meaing, cannot eliminate the agony from renovation any more than a doctor by his brilliance and skill can expunge the trauma from surgery. Renovation is time-consuming, expensive, frustrating, risky and messy. Architects can do little to soften these facts.

title: RESERVE PROPOSED FOR RAIN FORESTS
description: A Smithsonian Institution biologist who has studied the world's tropical forests for the last 15 years has proposed a novel plan to preserve a portion of the rapidly diminishing rain forests, which contain about half the earth's plant and animal species.

title: SENTIMENTAL EDUCATION
description: THE CRYING HEART TATTOO By David Martin. 330 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $14.50.

title: TOP TEEN-AGERS FINDING PROBLEMS
description: MORE and more, teen-agers are taking over sports to the point where 2 0-year-olds who have never been champions are dismissed as over the h ill. And in reaching the top, many of these athletes say that the p ressures that supposedly endanger them often do not exist or are s elf-created, that the enemy usually is not the pressure from others b ut from themselves.

title: Headliners; Abbott's Sentence
description: He was the ''jailhouse author'' who, after a life in prison, was released, then convicted in January of manslaughter in the death of Richard Adan, a New York actor and part-time waiter.

title: GREECE WANTS BRITISH TO RETURN ELGIN MARBLES
description: Melina Mercouri, the actress who is now the Greek Minister of Culture, recently issued a strongly worded demand that Britain return the Elgin Marbles, taken from the Acropolis at the start of the 19th century.

title: A Disgruntled Chinese Enters American Embassy in Peking
description: A Chinese man jumped over a wall and entered the United States Embassy today to complain about a visa problem.

title: No Headline
description: WATER pipes that bang or knock every time a faucet is turned off, or that make hammering noises when a washing machine or similar water-using appliance is in use, not only are a nuisance, but also can lead to a breakdown in one or more pipes and fittings if the problem is not corrected in time.

title: MIND THE ECO-SYSTEMS
description: To the Editor:

title: A STEAKHOUSE WITH THE RIGHT FORMULA
description: GREENWICH MANERO'S must be doing something right. This year marks its 40th anniversary in its original location. Although it has expanded, it remains the same unpretentious family-oriented place it has been for years. (Westport's Porky Manero's restaurant is related, but has separate management.)

title: IMPROVISING IN ART AND LIFE
description: SEEING IS FORGETTING THE NAME OF THE THING ONE SEES A Life of Contemporary Artist Robert Irwin. By Lawrence Weschler. Illustrated. 212 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $14.95.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICE
description: EARLY MUSIC For those whose tastes run to ''early'' music - music, that is, written at least a century before the concert hall became the major musical institution - there are at least two concerts being offered Sunday. None is given in a concert hall, and each is of interest.

title: COUNTRY: ASLEEP AT THE WHEEL
description: A mixture of high-stepping Texas swing, boogie-woogie, and roadhouse honky-tonk has been the stock in trade of the country band Asleep at the Wheel for 10 years. and at the Lone Star Cafe, where they appeared Tuesday and Wednesday, the band, whose membership has fluctuated between 6 and 11 - it's now an actet - played a typically diverse set that included a Bob Wills medley, a rousing "Route 66" and a recent Rosanne Cash hit, "My Baby Thinks He's a Train," which was written by Leroy Preston, a former member of the band.

title: Persistent Rent Increases
description: Question: I live in a four-unit building in Manhattan. The landlord has raised the rent 25 percent a year over the last four years. Do I have any recourse?...R.M.,Manhattan Answer: Because your building has fewer than six apartments, you are not covered by rent stabilization. However, if the building was erected before 1947 and you occupied the apartment before June 1971, you are protected by rent control and the increases are illegal. Controlled rents may not rise more than 7 1/2 percent a year. If the apartment is not rent-controlled, the landlord can raise the rent by as much as he wants, and you are not likely to get any satisfaction by taking the matter to court. Without some form of rent regulation on an apartment, the courts have been reluctant to stipulate the rent a landlord can charge.

title: IDEOLOGICAL CLASH DUE AT PARTY CONVENTION
description: West Germany's Social Democrats tomorrow open a week-long party congress in Munich that may challenge fundamental policies of Washington's strongest continental ally. Helmut Schmidt has threatened to quit as Chancellor if the party reverses its backing for NATO nuclear missile plans. Yesterday, at least 20,000 people attended a rally in Munich to protest the missile deployment.

title: CLASSIFYING GENETICS RESEARCH: MOSCOW'S LEAD
description: To the Editor:

title: THE RETURN OF THE GYPSY MOTH
description: AUTHORITIES on the subject of the gypsy moth seem to feel that there will be no significant collapse in the population of this pest in the near future, although there may be seasonal ups and downs from one area to another. It would appear likely that the areas that experienced severe damage last year can look forward to a similar experience this year and that adjacent areas will see an increase in damage from the spillover.

title: Future Events Out Every Evening
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated. A Half Century April 21 - Eubie Blake, Cy Coleman, Bobby Short, Burton Lane and Betty Comden and Adolph Green are among those participating in an evening of cabaret entertainment to benefit the Billy Rose Theater Collection of the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center. The collection, an invaluable source of theater lore, is celebrating its 50th anniversary. Former Mayor John V. Lindsay and Tammy Grimes will introduce the acts in the library's main gallery from 6 to 9 P.M. There'll also be hors d'oeuvres and an open bar. Tickets, $50.

title:
DINING OUT;
NEW ROLE FOR AN OLD TENNIS CLUB
description: THE impressive white-clapboard building with Palladian windows and a circular driveway formerly was a tennis club known as the Elizabeth Town and Country Club. And it still has the gracious space of days gone by, what with its large rooms, high ceilings and red-and-green clothed tables placed a civilized distance apart.

title: The Wrong Way to Tax Energy
description: It now seems clear: any deal between Congress and the President to cut the 1983 deficit will include an energy tax. That is certainly welcome news. It would both ease the nation's fiscal pains and reduce dependence on foreign energy imports. What is not welcome is the lack of open discussion of the form the tax will take.

title: THE ALTERNATIVE TO ARMS CONTROL
description: While anyone in his right mind is in favor of nuclear disarmament, I am skeptical of the capacity and willingness of governments to achieve it in any fundamental measure. The skepticism is based on the history of disarmament in our century - a long, painful, repeatedly frustrated, always futile effort. Disarmament is ''a mirage and a will-o'-the-wisp,'' concluded Salvador de Madariaga, of Spain, chairman of the League of Nations Disarmament Commission and Disarament Conference. No person has ever been better qualified to judge. Persistent failure of an endeavor should cause it to be re-examined, not continued forever in the same manner. Another way must be found to control nuclear war, not necessarily ruling out disarmament, but laying a new foundation for nonbelligerent coexistence. This may be the time to seek it out because a new element has entered the situation - an impelling fear.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;
'TREASURE HUNT' UNCOVERS A BOUNTY
description: ROSLYN HARBOR WHEN Thomas A. Saltzman and Constance Schwartz, curators of ''The Collections of Long Island: A Century of Change'' -which opens Tuesday at the Nassau County Museum of Fine Art here -pulled up in front of a simple house on the South Shore a few months ago in search of art, they thought they had come to the wrong place. On what they call a ''treasure hunt,'' traveling all over the Island to solicit works for the exhibition, the two had been to lavish estates that yielded expected priceless paintings and sculpture.

title: MILWAUKEE BOYCOTT PROTESTS DELAY BY A JUDGE
description: Since April 1, 18-year-old Kimberly Lacy has been picketing Milwaukee's downtown Gimbels and Boston Store and the Capitol Court Shopping Center. She wears a blue T-shirt saying ''Justice for Ernie Lacy'' and passes out leaflets saying ''A Price Must Be Paid for Injustice.''

title: Nets Clinch Fourth; 52 for Ray Williams
description: In more ways than one, it was a fitting end to a surprisingly successful regular season. With time expiring and the New Jersey Nets leading the Detroit Pistons handily tonight, Ray Williams, weary after a career-high scoring performance, received the ball at midcourt from Buck Williams. He took a few steps and heaved the ball. As the buzzer sounded, the ball zipped through the net, giving Williams 52 points for the night.

title: Made in Japan With Quality
description: THE question is, how does Japan do it? Take any two cars, one American and one Japanese, and the import is likely to seem better assembled. The trim will be more perfectly matched. The mileage will be better. And paradoxically, the performance often will be better as well.

title: Children's Books
description: MARKED BY FIRE By Joyce Carol Thomas. 172 pp. New York: Avon/Flare. Paper, $2.25. (Ages 12 and Up) By ALICE CHILDRESS

title: Watson Wins in Diving
description: Dan Watson of Cambridge, Mass., won the men's 10-meter platform event and Wendy Wyland of Mission Viejo, Calif., won the women's competition today in the U.S. indoor diving championships.

title:
DINING OUT;
VICTORIAN GREETING IN HISTORIC AREA
description: SPARTA, a small strip of Ossining that hugs the Hudson River, dates back to 1742. The neighborhood holds a small but historically interesting sampling of residential architecture from Colonial times to the present. In these calm streets, Dudley's, painted quite purple, glows a conspicuous, assertive welcome.

title: IN TOKYO, THE ADS ARE OCCIDENTAL
description: Tokyo - It qualifies as one of the minor ironies of business in Japan. The market here may still be off limits for any number of Western products. But for Westerners themselves, or to be more precise, their images, it is wide open. From subway posters to fashion magazine covers to television ads, the Western faces hawk Japanese products to Japanese consumers.

title: A DOCUMENTARY MASTERFULLY UNGARBLES THE PAST
description: The first striking thing about ''Ireland: A Television History,'' a 13-part television series currently on WNET/Channel 13 Saturdays at 8 P.M., is its remarkable clarity as Robert Kee, the writer and narrator, sets about ''ungarbling the past'' in an effort to disclose the root causes of the island's long-lived ''troubles.'' The second is that the project is a co-production of the British Broadcasting Corporation and Ireland's Radio Telefis Eiran (RTE).

title: The Week in Business; INDUSTRIAL OUTPUT DOWN AS RECESSION DRAGS ON
description: Industrial production fell eight-tenths of a percent in March, indicating that the recession is not likely to be over soon. Factories operated at 71.4 percent of capacity last month, the seventh drop in usage in the last eight months.

title: THEATER: 'LIVINGSTONE AND SECHELE' AT QUAIGH
description: There are layers in ''Livingstone and Sechele,'' which is having its American premiere at the Quaigh Theater. David Pownall, the British author, peels them away - not the way you peel an onion, but the way you unravel a mystery, with a wink here and a leer there, until finally we see the culprit, or, in Mr. Pownall's play, the deus ex machina. He is Sechele, the king of an African tribe being ministered to by the celebrated Dr. Livingstone. Mr. Pownall has written a play about colonialism and Christianity, and it is both sad and witty.

title: CONCERT: A TRIBUTE TO ROBERT MILLER
description: There were no eulogies to lengthen the nearly five-hour musical tribute to Robert Miller at Symphony Space Wednesday night, only a brief thank you at the start from Allan Miller, one of the space's artistic directors, to Milton Babbitt, Mario Davidovsky and Victoria Miller for their help in making the evening possible. The rest was music, much of it by composers with whom the late Mr. Miller was associated during his career as a pianist specializing in the contemporary repertory. The performers were in many ways Mr. Miller's musical kinsmen - soloists and ensembles that have also specialized in the contemporary literature. Indeed, the whole production bore a striking resemblance to a Dixieland wake, though the expression was admittedly a bit more cerebral.

title: Dzhabar Rasulov, 68; Regional Soviet Leader
description: Dzhabar Rasulov, a prominent Soviet political leader in Central Asia who served in several Soviet administrations, died April 4 of a heart attack, according to Soviet newspapers received in New York. He was 68 years old.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
LESSONS OF HISTORY AND HERITAGE
description: WHEN my mother fled Germany in 1936, settling first in Italy and then in France, she did not understand why her family was being persecuted; she was too young. Like most children, however, she accepted dislocation and change with relative equanimity, learning Italian and then French, relinquishing old friends and making new ones, taking hatred, persecution and fear almost for granted. Through a combination of foresight and good fortune, she and her parents survived the Holocaust. They were propelled by historical forces much greater than individual will, forces that determined not only her ultimate national allegiance but the identity of her children.

title: B.G. Clary Fiance Of Mary L. Hunt
description: Dr. and Mrs. George R. Hunt of Mahtomedi, Minn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Louise Hunt, to Bradley Grayson Clary, son of the Rev. and Mrs. S. Grayson Clary of St. Paul, where the Rev. Clary is rector of St. John the Evangelist Episcopal Church.

title: Around the Nation; Russian Boy Sees Father But Wants to Stay in U.S.
description: A 14-year-old boy who ran away rather than return to his Soviet home had a cordial but ''not very emotional'' visit with his father when the two met for the first time since July, the boy's lawyer said today.

title: U.S. CALLED INSENSITIVE TO EUROPE ON A-ARMS
description: During most of last year the United States Government ''was not adequately sensitive'' to the effect that its discussion of limited nuclear war was having on European public opinion, according to a report by the staff of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
HAPPY LIBRARY WEEK
description: Traditionally the cultural centers of suburbia, area libraries are putting a special effort into their programming this week in celebration of National Library Week. Among the special free events scheduled are a performance of music and dance of ancient Mexico and Peru by the Cantores Trio today at 3:30 P.M. at the Harborfields Library, 31 Broadway in Greenlawn, followed by a Mexican dinner and fiesta featuring the apprentice company of Ballet Hispanico of New York at 7:30 P.M. Friday (tickets $15; 757-4200).

title: Fare of the Country; YOGHURT: TURKISH DELIGHT
description: MARVINE HOWE is The Times bureau chief in Ankara. By MARVINE HOWE

title: Rhodes Procedures Are Called Biased
description: There seems to be a tone of surprise in Priscilla Van Tassel's article on the Rhodes Scholarships (Feb. 28) that Princeton University is sending more candidates than other colleges.

title: Around the Nation; Texas Officers Acquitted In Drowning of 3 Youths
description: An all-white jury today acquitted three former Limestone County officers in the drownings of three black teen-agers who were in custody when a boat capsized on a Texas lake.

title: WHAT TO DO IF SERVICE WORKERS STRIKE
description: The tenants of some 2,300 rental and cooperative apartment houses in New York City are faced with the possibility of a strike this Wednesday (4/21) if negotiations on a new contract between Local 32B-32J of the Service Employees Union and the Realty Advisory Board are not successful. The current contract expires at midnight Tuesday.

title: The Region; by Richard Levine, Carlyle C. Douglas and William C. Rhodes; A Nice Budget While It Lasted
description: For the first time in recent years the New York State Legislature passed a budget before the fiscal year began April 1, but some of it didn't stay passed for long. Using 187 vetoes, Governor Carey last week slashed $941 million from the plan.

title: NOTES: THE PHILHARMONIC REACHES OUT
description: The New York Philharmonic's fifth annual Radiothon, the orchestra's largest annual fund-raising event, is scheduled to begin this Friday. The weekend radio marathon will be carried over WQXR (96.3 FM, 1560 AM), which is donating 60 hours of continuous air time to the project. It will be broadcast live from the Adagio Cafe in the west lobby of Avery Fisher Hall. The goal of this year's Radiothon, which ends at 9 P.M. on April 26, is to surpass last year's contributed total of $357,100.

title: TIGERS TOP YANKS; JOHN IS POUNDED EARLY IN 5-3 LOSS
description: Tommy John, who is usually one constant in the Yankees' gyrating world, lost today for the second time this week as the Detroit Tigers scored early and went on to a 5-3 victory.

title: 4 SLAIN EXECUTION-STYLE IN A CONNECTICUT RAMPAGE
description: A 42-year-old Connecticut man, apparently distraught over a divorce, went on a rampage in West Hartford early yesterday and killed his former wife and her boyfriend, mother and daughter in a series of execution-style shootings, the police reported.

title: HOW TO HOOK YOUR OWN SPOUSE
description: I go to bed with Ed Zern and wake up with Nelson Bryant. With careful planning, Jacques Cousteau can claim some middle hours. The simple explanation - I'm married to a fisherman - not an ordinary fisherman ... a fly fisherman.

title: Elizabeth Kilcullen Is a Bride
description: The marriage of Elizabeth Kilcullen, an associate with the New York law firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell, to Addison Lanier 2d, an associate in the corporate finance department of Salomon Brothers, the investment and securities firm, took place in St. James Episcopal Church in New York yesterday. The Rev. James A. Hanisian and the Rev. David B. Wayne performed the ceremony.

title: WOOL FESTIVAL IS ON TAP NEXT WEEKEND
description: KINGSTON IN THE parlance of sheep farmers, spring is shearing and lambing time, and the Walkers of WoodsEdge Farm here are celebrating with a ''wool-away'' festival next Sunday.

title: WATER QUALITY FOUND BETTER FOR NIAGARA
description: After a five-month study conducted last year on the presence of chemical substances in the environment of the Niagara Frontier area of New York, the Environmental Protection Agency has concluded that water and air quality there have ''improved markedly.''

title: Photography View; EVE SONNEMAN'S EXPLORATIONS; by Andy Grundberg
description: Eve Sonneman's photography is widely shown, collected, published and admired, but it repeatedly has been scourged by reviewers with a relentlessness not ordinarily encountered in art criticism. Her pictures have been characterized as amateurish, formless and mystifying. She has been called a careerist, a lazy photographer. Why, we might ask, does she arouse such vituperative passions in some, while enjoying the appreciative responses of others? Why do her photographs, and her success, remain both enigmatic and annoying to many eyes?

title: Reading and Writing; Personals
description: I'm puzzled by the people who describe themselves and their needs in the Personal columns of The New York Review of Books. Seldom has such an attractive and accomplished group struck such a melancholy note. For beneath their brave insouciance, their professed pleasure in literature, music, conversation, wining, dining, hiking and biking, I sense an unspoken sadness. Culture, it's clear, has disappointed them: it's not enough.

title: S. Ann Stuart Is Bride Of Kerry B. Fitzpatrick
description: S. Ann Stuart, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John S. Stuart of Hethersett, England, was married there yesterday to Kerry B. Fitzpatrick of East Windsor, N.J., son of Muriel K. Rose of Frederiksted, St. Croix, the United States Virgin Islands, and the late John A. Fitzpatrick Jr. of Sea Girt, N.J. The Rev. Michael Sexton performed the ceremony in St. Remigius Anglican Church.

title: THE POET WOULD HAVE BEEN ANGRY
description: THE LETTERS OF ALFRED LORD TENNYSON Volume I. 1821-1850.Edited by Cecil Y. Lang and Edgar F. Shannon Jr. 366 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The Belknap Press of Harvard University Press. $30.

title: An Unshifted Stride May Have Lost It
description: The margin between Air Forbes Won and Shimatoree in yesterday's 58th running of the Wood Memorial at Aqueduct was an elongated neck, and it could easily have been the cost of Shimatoree's unchanged leads.

title: THE DANCE: PHOEBE NEVILLE PRESENTS HER NEW 'PALANTIR'
description: Phoebe Neville has long been one of the most distinctive voices in modern dance today. She explores her universe - a private, but immediate place - slowly and with apparent sureness, sledom betraying that universe. It is dark there, but clear, a place for ritual and magic reduced to their most simple terms.

title: A PRIMER FOR WATCHING TV
description: According to recent Nielsen figures, the average American child spends 26 hours a week watching television, more time than is spent in school. Yet, surprisingly little guidance is available to youngsters on how to watch selectively, intelligently and critically.

title: Carter Is Said to Seek Active Role in Mideast
description: Former President Jimmy Carter says he may travel to the Middle East to join negotiations on Palestinian autonomy in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, according to an interview in the joint Sunday editions of The Atlanta Journal and The Atlanta Constitution.

title: FOR LOVE AND MONEY
description: PRIZZI'S HONOR By Richard Condon. 316 pp. New York: Coward, McCann & Geoghegan. $13.95.

title: Linda Ruth Brett Is Bride In Jersey of John R. Dorf
description: At Union Congregational Church in Upper Montclair, N.J., yesterday Linda Ruth Brett and John Randall Dorf, 1981 graduates of Lehigh University, were married by the Rev. Yorke Peeler Jr.

title: Out West
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed reading the article on Sedona, Ariz., and ''Red Rock Country'' (Travel, March 21). Two years ago we took the same road from Phoenix to Sedona, visiting Flagstaff, Sunset Crater, the Grand Canyon and finally Monument Valley.

title: THE FAILED MISSION
description: It has been almost two years since the bold, ambitious attempt to rescue the American hostages in Teheran collapsed in flames on a bleak stretch of Iranian desert. Here, in the first account by a key participant, Zbigniew Brzezinski, President Carter's national security adviser, tells of the months of secret planning, meticulous preparation and spirited debate that led to the rescue attempt.

title: Australia
description: To the Editor: In Susan Heller Anderson's ''Around The World In 80 to 92 Days'' (Travel, March 7), the city of Auckland is erroneously placed in Australia. Having been there recently, I can safely state that it is still 1,000 miles east of Australia.

title: CHAMBER PROVIDES JOB DATA
description: SALARIES and wages continued to rise in the county last year, and secretarial positions remained the major job category, according to a survey recently released by the County Chamber of Commerce in White Plains.

title: CITY HEALTH AGENCY LISTS 33 FOOD PLACES FOR CODE VIOLATIONS
description: The New York City Department of Health released the names of 33 food establishments last week for violations of the city's health code.

title: Thailand Said to Be Planning Amnesty for 55,000 Prisoners
description: Thailand is expected to proclaim an amnesty early next month for more than 55,000 prisoners to mark the bicentennial of the start of the Chakkri dynasty, officials said today.

title: SEASON BEGINS TO WIND DOWN WITH SPECIAL EVENTS
description: LAST night, the Meriden Symphony paid tribute to Edwin Gerschefski, by playing his ''Nocturne'' and receiving from the Meriden-born composer a tape library of his recent works.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
ON THE RUN
description: If it's spring - and the calendar insists that it is - it must be time to get those running shoes out and on Saturday take to the sands of Jones Beach for the Fifth Annual Natural Light-Long Island Ocean Run. There will be two heats - a 10-mile run starting at 10 A.M. and a 50-mile jaunt beginning at 10:30 A.M. - and registration fees, which will benefit the National Kidney Foundation, are $5 in advance or $6 on Saturday. For information, call 669-1000.

title: POLL SEES NEW LAG BY REAGAN
description: A majority of the American public would not like President Reagan to run for re-election, according to the latest Gallup Poll, but the poll's respondents say they think he will do so just the same.

title: Dance View; AN ADVENTUROUS CANADIAN COMPANY
description: Les Grands Ballets Canadiens from Montreal has come and gone and one hopes the company will return again. Its standard of dancing is always respectable, at times excellent. If it isn't a great company, it is creatively, one of the few seen hereabouts that does not seem to be suffering from hardening of the toe shoes. That is, it seems willing to court risk as well as success.

title: 'THEY DON'T WEAR BLACK TIE,' FROM BRAZIL
description: At the beginning of the Brazilian film "They Don't Wear Black Tie," a middle-class boy and girl are making plans to live happily ever after. Maria (Bete Mendes) is pregnant by the handsome young Tiao (Carlos Alberto Ricelli), and that helps accelerate their plan to rush into marriage. Everything looks rosy. "They Don't Wear Black Tie" is an extremely successful politically aware drama about how the bloom falls off the rose.

title: Two Police Officers in Crash Accused of Drinking on Duty
description: Two police officers whose squad car sideswiped a parked vehicle during a chase were suspended without pay yesterday on charges that they drank on duty, a police spokesman said.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Parsnip 'Peril'
description: Parsnips dangerous to your health? Researchers at the Federal Department of Agriculture's toxicology laboratory in College Station, Tex., reported last August that they had found substantial amounts of psoralens in the root vegetable.

title: GOUDY TYPE DISPLAY
description: A small but important collection of the typography of Frederic W. Goudy, the noted American type designer and printer who died in 1947, has been donated to the Hiram Halle Library in Pound Ridge and will go on permanent exhibition today in celebration of National Library Week.

title: CORRECTION
description: One of the photographs accompanying a Westchester Weekly article last Sunday about the State University of New York at Purchase was incorrectly captioned. It showed the headquarters of Pepsico, where part of the yearly Summerfare festival, sponsored jointly by the corporation and the college, is held.

title: POLISH FILM SCHEDULED
description: ''Man of Marble,'' a two-and-a-half-hour work by Andrzej Wajda, the Polish film maker, can be seen on the Princeton University campus tomorrow through Friday.

title: BATHROOMS COME INTO THEIR OWN
description: WHEN homeowners talk about remodeling their houses these days, many t end to pay increasingly more attention to one area that never used t o come in for much thought: the bathroom.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: In a poll of National Basketball Association players conducted by The Sporting News, Moses Malone of the Houston Rockets was named the player of the year and Isiah Thomas of the Detroit Pistons was selected as rookie of the year ... Sam Nassi, owner of the Indiana Pacers, who underwent open-heart surgery Tuesday in Encino, Calif., was reported in serious but stable condition. ... Marvin Johnson of Indianapolis and Eddie Mustafa Muhammad, both former lightheavyweight champions, will fight May 14 in Buffalo as part of the card on which Sugar Ray Leonard will defend his world welterweight title against Roger Stafford.

title: NEW ROGET'S ELIMINATES 'SEXIST' GROUPINGS
description: A new edition of Roget's Thesaurus, the 130-year-old book of synonyms and antonyms, eliminates categories its editor says are sexist, biased, prejudiced, illiberal and narrowminded.

title: BAILEY TRIAL FOR DRUNKEN DRIVING FILLING COURTROOM
description: In a reversal of roles, F. Lee Bailey, the Boston lawyer, is the defendant in a trial on charges of driving while intoxicated.

title: GREEKS ASSERT U.S. AGREED TO 2 TERMS
description: Before the Greek-American negotiations on American bases broke down here last June, the United States is said to have agreed that as part of a settlement it would pledge to oppose any use of force between Greece and Turkey.

title: Julie Landau Married To Michael D. Schaff
description: Julie Ellen Landau, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marc Landau of White Plains, was married there yesterday to Michael David Schaff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel Schaff of Elkins Park, Pa. Rabbi Maurice Davis performed the ceremony at the Jewish Community Center.

title: Wadkins Leads by 2 on 68-207
description: Lanny Wadkins had six birdies over his last nine holes and scored a four-under-par 68 today to take a two-stroke lead after three rounds of the $350,000 Tournament of Champions.

title: Cubs 10, Pirates 2
description: PITTSBURGH (UPI) - Larry Bowa drove in three runs, and Bill Buckner and Leon Durham knocked in two each to lead an 18-hit offense that lifted Chicago to victory in a game delayed twice by rain.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Raija Roivainen, Mezzo, In Russian-Finnish Bill
description: The Nordic temperament, as seen from these more temperate climes, is brooding, melancholic and introverted. When Raija Roivainen, a Finnish mezzo-soprano, made her debut Monday in Carnegie Recital Hall singing works primarily drawn from Russian and Finnish repertory, the temperament was very much in evidence, along with a refined dramatic and musical sense.

title: MARATHON RUNNER REACHES CROSSROAD
description: HUNTINGTON PETER McNEILL finished first in last year's Long Island Marathon, and he is generally recognized as one of the elite among local competitive runners. Despite his acknowledged prowess, he still shares a problem common to other Island long-distance runners this time of year. After running in tomorrow's Boston Marathon, he must decide whether to compete in the Long Island Marathon on May 2, and, if he does, whether he will be able to give it his all.

title: Around the World; 59 More Officials Dismissed in Poland
description: Poland's martial law regime has dismissed 59 officials for improper execution of duties, inability to carry out assignments, breaking laws and in some cases drunkenness, the official press agency P.A.P. said today.

title: The Region; by Richard Levine, Carlyle C. Douglas and William C. Rhodes; STouffer's Fire Jury Persuaded, But Judge Isn't
description: A jury may have convicted him, but Luis Marin, the 26-year-old former waiter accused of setting a fire at Stouffer's Inn that killed 26 people, wasn't proven guilty. So ruled Westchester County Judge Lawrence N. Martin Jr. last week as he set aside the verdict and set Mr. Marin free.

title: A SUNNY POINT ON THE HORIZON
description: PLAINFIELD CHIP away the bleak surface that has encrusted the country's greenery this spring and you will unearth a peppy and harmless little jape entitled ''Sky Lines.''

title: SECRETARY RESISTS BID TO USE EMERGENCY FARM FUND
description: Despite increasing pressures from farm state Congressmen, Agriculture Secretary John R. Block has again declined to open a $600 million emergency credit fund to bail out farmers already deeply in debt and unable to borrow more from regular sources.

title: Percentage of Gross Heads the Issues
description: In The New York Times poll of National Football League players, the issues of free agency and retirement benefits were cited in importance just behind the percentage-of-gross proposal. The latter is the key demand upon which the players' union has built its case for a new collective bargaining agreement with the N.F.L. Management Council, the negotiating arm of the league.

title: DANCE: JUDSON THEATER REMEMBERED
description: The organizers of a surprisingly refreshing program called "Judson Dance Theater Reconstruction" know that you can't go home again. Instead, they have tried to re-create that home if ever so briefly - even if it was a home these same young organizers never knew.

title: Robin Leah Liebmann To Be Wed in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Liebmann of Baldwin, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Robin Leah Liebmann, to Barry G. Simonson, son of Dr. and Mrs. Alan Simonson of Woodmere, L. I.

title: YALE PROFESSOR PROTESTING FEDERAL RULE ON GRANTS
description: In a protest against a Federal regulation, a Yale University professor has refused to sign a required report documenting his work on a project receiving a Federal grant.

title: IN ISRAEL, NEW ANXIETIES SHARPEN OLD SUSPICIONS
description: JERUSALEM PRIME Minister Menachem Begin and his key Cabinet ministers took Israel and the rest of the world on a roller coaster of apprehensions last week about the peace process with Egypt. They began with warnings that Egyptian actions might provoke Israel into reconsidering the final pullout from Sinai next Sunday and ended with expressions of confidence that all would be well.

title: KOCH, ON L.I., TESTS HIS SUBURBAN VIEWS
description: POLITICALLY rooted in New York City, Mayor Koch offered a preview of his suburban campaign style and substance as he sought the support of Nassau and Suffolk Democratic politicians last week.

title: Mary Guthrie Hilliard Is Wed
description: Mary Guthrie Hilliard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Henning Hilliard of Louisville, Ky., was married yesterday to Orme Wilson 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilson Jr. of New York, Washington and White Post, Va. The Rev. Stephen R. Davenport performed the ceremony in St. Francis-in-the-Fields Episcopal Church in Harrods Creek, Ky.

title: Mailbox; RENAMING FANS
description: To the Sports Editor: Dave Anderson is quite wrong, it seems to me, when he writes that the television contract recently signed by the National Football League ''proved again that the fans are the game'' (''The Fans Are N.F.L. 'Game,' '' The New York Times, March 28). It is not ''the fans'' but the customers who are the game.

title: PROBLEMS PERSIST AT U.S.PRISON
description: DANBURY THERE were fire extinguishers, but the prisoners did not know how to use them. There was an emergency fire hose, but the guards did not know it, and the inmates could not use it because it was in a locked cabinet.

title: OUTGOING, RETIRING PAPERBOY RECOLLECTS
description: Dear Customer, I am sorry to say that I am leaving my position as your paperboy, effective Saturday, Feb. 27, 1982. I have enjoyed the last three years, and I surely will have many pleasant memories to treasure in the future. Thank you for being the people you are and making those years an enjoyable experience. Your Paperboy, Michael Brophy By BETSY BROWN

title: PENETRATING THE PENTAGON
description: RICHARD HALLORAN is a reporter in the Washington bureau of The Times. BY RICHARD HALLORAN

title: Hiking in France
description: To the Editor:

title: HOLES IN GROUND TO CONTINUE BROADWAY RUN A BIT LONGER
description: The tens of thousands of pedestrians and motorists who each weekday since January have detoured around a hole in the ground at Seventh Avenue and 49th Street in the theater district face at least several more weeks of inconvenience.

title: B.D Marren Jr., Seane Donohue Have Nuptials
description: Seane H. Donohue and Bernard D. Marren Jr. were married yesterday in the Roman Catholic Church of the Transfiguration in Tarrytown, N.Y. The Rev. Robert M. O'Connell of New York performed the ceremony and the Rev. Normand J. Godin celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: MANY VINES GROW QUICKLY FOR FLOWERING SCREENS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Theodore James Jr. is a writer who gardens on eastern Long Island. BY THEODORE JAMES Jr.

title: Malone Heads List Of 63 Free Agents
description: Gavin P. Maloof owns the Houston Rockets, a team his father left to him when he died in November 1980. Now the 27-year-old Maloof faces a multimillion-dollar problem: How to keep Moses Malone with the Rockets and at what cost.

title: BREZHNEV OFFERS TALK WITH REAGAN IN EUROPE IN FALL
description: The Soviet Government's press agency Tass quoted Leonid I. Brezhnev tonight as having rejected President Reagan's suggestion that they hold informal talks in June in New York during a United Nations disarmament conference. Mr. Brezhnev proposed instead that they hold a full-fledged summit meeting in October in either Finland or Switzerland.

title: ELECTED HONDURAN GOVERNMENT'S PROBLEMS MOUNT
description: When elections last January led to the installation of this country's first civilian Government in a decade, Hondurans were hopeful that social and economic changes would soon bring an improvement in the quality of their lives.

title: A RIDE INTO GREEK HISTORY
description: PAUL ANASTASI reports for The Times from Athens. By PAUL ANASTASI

title: IN DEFENSE OF A DEDICATED TRASIT TAX
description: THE March 28 Opinion Page article by Richard C. Leone, the former State Treasurer, opposing a dedicated tax for transportation misses the point. It is true that there are competing voices for fewer funds, that welfare, Medicare, food stamps, education, programs for the handicapped are - all of them - important.

title: Topics; Terminology, Terminations; A.C.R.O.N.Y.M.
description: Finding convenient names for public causes becomes steadily harder. Initials once sufficed, but over the years, many combinations have been taken (A.A.A., A.B.A., A.C.A., A.D.A. and on, into the B's).

title: PHILHARMONIC: VIVALDI 'FOUR SEASONS'
description: Those who complain about stereotypical orchestral programming will take solace from this week's New York Philharmonic subscription programs. Zubin Mehta has reduced his forces to chamber-orchestra (in one case, chamber-music) proportions, and programmed a fresh early-20th-century concert, one that suggests the links between the varied forms of interwar neo-Classicism.

title: Headliners Give Him an 'A'
description: At age 89, Andres Segovia, the premier classical guitarist, is nothing short of indefatigable.

title: SURVEY THREATENS TITLE TO WESTERNERS' HOMES
description: Howard Coday is 64 years old, retired and moves a bit more slowly than he once did. He is ''stove up pretty bad with arthritis since '74,'' he says. For him and his wife, Irene, the cottage they have owned for 10 years in the high mountains at the edge of the national park here has been a quiet retreat.

title: Personal Finance; WHY SHARED MORTGAGES ARE HARD TO GET
description: When they were introduced a couple of years ago, shared appreciation mortgages seemed both a long overdue innovation for the struggling residential mortgage industry and a welcome chance for first-time buyers to enter the housing market.

title: Letters; In New Canaan
description: To the Editor:

title: Tara Beauregard Is Bride in Capital Of John Van Husan Whitbeck, Lawyer
description: Tara Maria Michelle Beauregard, daughter of Mrs. William H. Crocker and Henry G. Beauregard, both of Washington, was married there yesterday to John Van Husan Whitbeck, son of Mr. and Mrs. Brainerd H. Whitbeck of New York. Msgr. John J. Murphy performed the ceremony in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church.

title: John C. Gamble Fiance Of Kaja-Anne Jezycki
description: Mr. and Mrs. Leo J. Jezycki of Tuxedo Park, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kaja-Anne Jezycki, to John Charles Gamble, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Gamble of Wilson, N.Y.

title: CAR REPORTED STOLEN EVERY FIVE MINUTES ON NEW YORK STREETS
description: Every five minutes a motor vehicle is reported stolen in New York City in what the authorities say is now a multimillion-dollar-a-year underground business.

title: Suzann Weithas Wed To John J. Cahill Jr.
description: Suzann M. Weithas, a marketing assistant for the Mennen Company in Morristown, N.J., was married yesterday to John J. Cahill Jr., portfolio manager for the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation in Princeton, N.J. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. William Kokozka at the Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church in Rumson, N.J.

title: No Headline
description: Robin Marantz Henig's article brought to mind a report I encountered while writing a book on American women pilots during World War II. The report, ''Medical Considerations, Women Auxiliary Service Pilots (WASP) Program,'' was prepared for the United States Air Surgeon in 1945 and details the research and findings of a remarkable study of women conducted at the all-female pilot training base, Avenger Field, in Sweetwater, Tex.

title: Dealing With Mobil
description: To the Editor:

title: Policeman Is Killed in Spain By Basque Guerrillas' Attack
description: Basque terrorists fired a rocketpropelled grenade into a police armored vehicle today, killing one officer and wounding six others, the police said.

title: Cabaret Night to Benefit Rose Theater Collection
description: The 50th anniversary of the New York Public Library's Billy Rose Theater Collection will be celebrated next Wednesday from 6 to 9 P.M. with cabaret entertainment in the main gallery of the Lincoln Center Library-Museum. Former Mayor John V. Lindsay and Tammy Grimes will be hosts of the benefit for the collection.

title: J.F. Montaigne, Laurie Hays Wed
description: Laurie Hays, a reporter for The Times-Picayune/The States Item in New Orleans, and Joseph Fenwich Montaigne, a reporter for The Philadelphia Inquirer, were married yesterday in the First Presbyterian Church in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Richard Stearns performed the ceremony.

title: Ideas and Trends; by Eva Hoffman and Margot Slade; The Other Side Is Also Worried
description: The antinuclear chorus, until now heard mostly in the United States and Western Europe, has been joined by some surprising voices. Choosing the occasion of Easter Sunday services, Protestant ministers in East Berlin and surrounding areas read a letter protesting a ban by the East German authorities on badges and armbands advocating disarmament.

title: What's Doing; SINGAPORE
description: PAMELA G. HOLLIE is a New York Times correspondent based in Manila. BY PAMELA G. HOLLIE

title: Massachusetts Tuition Rise
description: The Board of Regents has approved a 10 percent tuition increase for out-of-state students at Massachusetts public colleges and universities.

title: Paperback Best Sellers; MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Wingate High Captures Big Apple 1,600 Relay
description: Trevor Parris, Richard Doughlin, Edwin Worrell and Dave Peltier of Wingate High captured the 1,600-meter relay in 3 minutes 19.1 seconds yesterday in the Mobil Big Apple Relays at J.F. Kennedy High School, the Bronx.

title: ABC Equipment Fails During Reagan Talk
description: ABC Radio lost its transmission of the first 32 seconds of President Reagan's nationwide address yesterday when an amplifier failed in the network's control room in New York.

title: CRAFTS
description: LAKEWOOD AN OPULENT estate built by a railroad magnate will be the setting on April 30 for ''Crafts: Getting Your Act Together,'' a daylong conference designed to set craftspeople on a professional track.

title: Norman Mailer And Rebecca West
description: Having read that Rebecca West thinks I'm ''a terrible bore,'' I tried to recall the few hours we spent together one afternoon in 1961 or 1962, and have come to the conclusion that I must have been tiresome indeed, since Dame Rebecca (no doubt in desperation) began to describe the habits of former lovers to me - needless to say, they were all rich, or powerful and famous, and one was marked as unforgettable but repulsive: ''like an electric eel'' (''Rebecca West,'' by Leslie Garis, April 4). I can never know how much I bored her, but, be certain, she sure amused me.

title: Saad Muhammad Wins Bout
description: With a touch of gentleness, Matthew Saad Muhammad returned to the ring today and stopped Pete McIntyre, a former sparring partner, at 2 minutes 28 seconds of the second round.

title: GOT A SECOND? SORRY, THAT'S TOO LONG
description: At a technical conference in Phoenix, Ariz. last week, Bell Laboratories scientists made an announcement of some scientific significance: The researchers had created a 30 femtosecond flash of laser light.

title: PRESIDENT'S TROUBLES BEGIN TO LOOK INFECTIOUS
description: Republican leaders gathered here last week to plan a gala 1984 national convention. They went to parties, played poker and heard with gratification that there were so many eager Republicans in the area that all 162 members of the national committee could have a car and a volunteer driver for the convention.

title: SCHMIDT FACES TROUBLE IN PARTY TALKS
description: The Social Democratic Party begins a weeklong convention in Munich on Monday that carries the possibility of new problems for the Government of Chancellor Helmut Schmidt and for NATO security policy.

title: CHANGE OF BATON AT OPERA
description: THE arias, couplets and ensembles sung out front remain constant, but behind the scenes at the Nassau Lyric Opera, the motif is change. This afternoon's performance of Rossini's ''The Barber of Seville,'' which will be conducted by Robley Lawson at the C.W. Post Concert Theater, will mark a threefold finale: the windup of the company's sixth season, Mr. Lawson's farewell appearance as chief conductor and the end of his tenure as the organization's artistic director - a position he has had since the company was founded in 1975. Tomorrow night, the board of directors will vote on his replacement.

title: Bset Sellers; FICTION
description: 1 1 5 THE PARSIFAL MOSAIC, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $15.95.) Through many exploits and hairbreadth escapes, Michael Havelock saves the world from nuclear extinction. 2 2 11 NORTH AND SOUTH, by John Jakes. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $14.95.) The friendship of two wealthy families - one in Pennsylvania, the other in Carolina - is strained by the Civil War. 3 3 11 A GREEN DESIRE, by Anton Myrer. (Putnam's, $14.95.) A woman caught between the clashing ambitions of two brothers during the springtime of this century. 4 6 22 SPRING MOON, by Bette Bao Lord. (Harper & Row, $14.95.) Tradition and revolution in modern China seen through the life of an upper-class family. 5 5 11 THE DEAN'S DECEMBER, by Saul Bellow. (Harper & Row, $13.95.) During a deathbed vigil in Rumania, a college dean from Chicago realizes some truths about his own land. 6 4 26 AN INDECENT OBSESSION, by Colleen McCullough. (Harper & Row, $13.50.) A nurse and her charges in a special-care ward of a World War II hospital. 7 7 8 FEVER, by Robin Cook. (Putnam's, $13.95.) Obsessions, personal and professional, possess a cancer researcher.

title: WILTON OPENS HOUSING PROJECT
description: DESPITE critics who fought the concept for a decade, Wilton's first subsidized housing project for the elderly, Ogden House, has opened its doors. Though the official opening is set for today, the project's 84 apartments are already occupied.

title: ADVOCATE PRAISED
description: ELECTRICITY rates in New Jersey may be the highest in the nation, but New Jerseyans still have the best customer advocate, according to consumer advocates from New Jersey, Connecticut, New York and Texas.
