title: BRITISH INDICATE HAIG'S MISSION IS GOING BADLY
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher returned to London from her country residence tonight amid signs that Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig's attempt to mediate the Falkland Islands crisis was going badly.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Sunday about the City University of New York's new credit-bearing courses on television incorrectly reported the network on which ''Sunrise Semester'' appears. The production is a joint effort by New York University and WCBS and is shown by WCBS-TV.

title: QUEEN, IN OTTAWA CEREMONY, GIVES CANADA ITS CONSTITUTION
description: Queen Elizabeth II, in a ceremony in Ottawa that was marred by rain and ''the regretted absence'' of Quebec, formally transfered constitutional power from Britain to Canada today.

title: SLUFF IT OFF
description: Estee Lauder, the cosmetics firm, advertises its ''Almond Clay Pack'' with this copy: ''The clarifying facial that facilitates sluffing from within.'' Another mask, it is claimed, ''sluffs, softens, smooths ... .''

title: The World; by Barbara Slavin and Milt Freudenheim; China Bites a Few More Bullets
description: Once again, the United States and China have averted a crisis in relations without resolving their fundamental differences over Taiwan. Last week, the Administration formally notified Congress of its intent to sell $60 million in military spare parts to Taiwan.

title: GLEN COVE AWAITS A BUSINESS CENTER
description: GLEN COVE THE City of Glen Cove, formerly dependent on Federal resources for its 16-year-old downtown urban renewal project, is using a combination of public and private money to finance $27 million in new construction and provide what officials hope will be the project's commercial anchor.

title: LIVELY PRODUCTION OF A TIRING TALE
description: ''PIPPIN'' was a Broadway smash hit in 1972. What made it so was the dazzling staging and choreography of Bob Fosse. The book, performed without intermission, became a wearying affair as the story line progressed. Bob Fosse, however, created one brilliant number after another and kept electrifying the audience, if not quite distracting them completely from the tiring tale of Pippin, Charlemagne's first-born son. What I learned from the show was to beware of musicals that are performed without intermission. The reason usually turns out to be that customers were walking out during previews of the show.

title: 'NEW FEDERALISM' IS CONSIGNED TO COOLIDGE
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN has paid homage to Calvin Coolidge as his philosophical preceptor, although the two men are inherently unalike in temperament and personal behavior. But the philosophy of our 30th President, which should be relevant now only as a basis for historical perspective, has indeed been reborn in the proposals of our 40th President - under the illusory standard of the ''New Federalism.'' The time has long passed for such a political delusion to have even a remote possibility of addressing contemporary problems of 20th-century America.

title: TROUBLE WITH MEN
description: NELLIE WITHOUT HUGO By Janet Hobhouse. 192 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $12.95.

title: RITES OF SPRING FOR BEACHGOING SINGLES
description: ALL right, class, prepare for a social-studies lesson. Now that a contractor has been chosen to build Long Island's largest garbagerecycling plant on the Pilgrim State Hospital grounds and local residents have filed suit to block the construction, it seems an appropriate time to examine the governmental process involved in bringing the project this far.

title: Sound; HOW TO KEEP A TAPE DECK HALE AND HEARTY; by Hans Fantel
description: Europeans used to quip that in America people trade in their cars when the ashtrays are full. Even in more abundant times, this overstated the case. Still, the jibe holds a nugget of truth. The notion of maintenance comes hard in a country where things are easily replaced.

title: A Stark Political Fable of South Africa
description: Agreat commanding subject haunts the South African imagination, yet this subject can also turn into a kind of tyranny, close, oppressive, even destructive. Imagine what it must be like to live as a serious writer in South Africa: an endless clamor of news about racial injustice, the feeling that one's life is mortgaged to a society gone rotten with hatred, an indignation that exhausts itself into depression, the fear that one's anger may overwhelm and destroy one's fiction. And except for silence or emigration, there can be no relief.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Barry Goldsmith, Piano, Tackles Problematic
description: Barry Goldsmith, the pianist who made his debut in Carnegie Recital Hall Wednesday night, seems to have a taste for problematic music. The first portion of his program consisted of Shostakovich's Prelude and Fugue in E minor, Beethoven's Opus 111 Sonata and Schumann's ''Humoresque,'' and before he allowed himself Chopin (the Barcarolle) and Albeniz (three excerpts from ''Iberia'') in the second, he played Schoenberg's Opus 33 pieces.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: INFLATION HURTS, BUT DEFLATION COULD BE WORSE
description: Not so many months ago, when prices were bounding relentlessly ahead, consumers and politicians came to share the view that inflation is, economically and socially, the country's No. 1 enemy.

title: Around the Garden
description: This Week:

title: Dr. Amy J. Gittell Planning Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Gittell of Forest Hills, Queens, and Sag Harbor, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Amy Jacobs Gittell, to Thomas Clark Gallagher, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Gallagher of Waddington, N.Y. The wedding will take place on May 29 in Sag Harbor.

title: Albany Notes; TAX BREAK FOR CONGRESS HELPING LEGISLATORS, TOO
description: For large numbers of taxpayers, this week was not a pleasant one. But thanks to Congress, New York State legislators got a special break that made April 15 less onerous. It may also have turned the act of filing a tax return into an easy way to make several thousand dollars.

title: The Nation; by Michael Wright and Caroline Rand Herron; All Right, So He Was Off by A Few Months
description: Even good soldiers can whistle a happy tune for only so long before their jaws grow tight. Barely two months ago, Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan was speculating that by late spring the economy would come ''roaring back.'' Last week, Mr. Regan declared that the economy was ''dead in the water.''

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
LONG ISLAND PREMIERE
description: ''A Sea Symphony,'' Ralph Vaughan Williams's musical setting of the poetry of Walt Whitman, will make a debut on the Island next weekend in a joint concert by the Huntington Chorale and the Nassau Symphony Orchestra. The Friday performance is at Berner High School on Carman Mill Road in Massapequa; Saturday's concert is at Huntington High School on McKay Road. Both performances are at 8:30 P.M. For ticket information, call 598-3376 or 271-8423.

title: A NEW SEASON A NEW GENERATION
description: IT was a day of firsts for me. In the morning, I noticed the first green blades of hyacinth, tulip and daffodil along my front walk. I nodded my head at the new generation of plants as I recognized their distinctive leaves. They peered out over the brown leaf-mulch to bask in their first spring sunshine.

title: More PAC's
description: To the Business Editor: It was with some amusement that I read Barbara R. Bergmann's article, ''Lobbying: Shakedown on Capitol Hill'' (April 4). A firsttime reader could assume that the ''bad guys'' in American business had invented the PAC's (political action committees), and they are now about to prostitute the integrity of our political system.

title: MUSICAL CHAIRS, PLAYED TO A POLITICAL BEAT
description: TRENTON IT ISN'T where Republicans in New Jersey stand these days that is making news. Instead, it is where they sit. Nicholas F. Brady has traded his seat on Wall Street for a leather chair in the United States Senate, and two Republican Representatives are seeking seats in new districts in an effort to beat the carefully designed Democratic gerrymander of the state's 14 Congressional Districts.

title: Tolls Rise Tomorrow For Several Crossings
description: Higher tolls for several Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority crossings go into effect at 12:01 A.M. tomorrow.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Miss Holmes, A. B. See 3d Are Married
description: Elizabeth Milburn Holmes and Alonzo B. See 3d, both long-range financial planners with Texas Instruments in Dallas, were married yesterday at the Grace Episcopal Church in Munroe, La. The Rev. Robert Hargrove performed the ceremony.

title: Braves Equal Mark With 10th Straight
description: Bob Horner hit a two-run double in the first inning tonight to help the Atlanta Braves defeat the Houston Astros, 2-1, and tie the National League record for consecutive victories at the start of a season.

title: MUSIC: CONSORT OF VIOLS REVISITS VERSAILLES
description: The New York Consort of Viols turned Broadway and 95th Street into a little bit of Versailles Friday night. The place was Symphony Space, but the costumes, the music, the dancing and the narrations were drawn from 17th-century France and the court of Louis XIV.

title: Foreign Affairs; A BLEAK CAIRO SPRING
description: There is every reason to expect the orderly return of the Sinai to Egypt as scheduled on April 25. But it isn't going to be the halcyon, hopeful signal that was planned as the beginning of the end of the Arab-Israeli conflict.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
SOME FOLKS
description: ''The World of Folk Music on Long Island'' focuses on the multitalented Oscar Brand today at 7:30 P.M. The second of four concerts sponsored by the Town of Hempstead, the performances are at East Meadow High School on Carmen Avenue, and tickets are $1.50.

title: U.S. PANEL LAUDS NUCLEAR-SHUTDOWN ACTIONS
description: Federal investigators studying the tube rupture that forced the shutdown of an upstate New York nuclear plant said today that the plant's operators performed during the emergency better than they had thought, but still might not have prevented possible damage to the reactor.

title: DEMONSTRATION IS SET
description: ELIZABETH THE ashes have long since been swept away, but the fiery images remain vivid for thousands of Elizabeth residents. At dusk on Wednesday, some 200 members of a community group will gather, as they did last year, to light candles and rekindle memories of the Chemical Control Company explosion that spewed a giant cloud of toxic smoke over the city on April 21, 1980.

title: JOBLESS RATE TIED TO BIG WORK FORCE
description: President Reagan has suggested that the recession is not as deep as indicated by the latest unemployment rate, asserting that one factor involved in that rate is the great increase of people entering the labor market, especially women.

title: THE FALKLAND STAKES ARE HIGH FOR WASHINGTON TOO
description: WASHINGTON AS the British flotilla steamed toward large Argentine forces encamped on the Falkland Islands, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. pressed hard last week for a diplomatic settlement. In Washington, where many officials had viewed the distant conflict as a kind of comic opera, the mood grew sober. The stakes for the United States and for Britain and Argentina, it became clear, were far higher than had been imagined.

title: Promotion of Arts In Schools Gratifying
description: Efforts of the Council for the Arts in Westchester to promote interest in the arts by improving how they are presented in the schools (''Educators Examine Programs on Arts,'' March 21) are very gratifying to those professionally involved. I think this has become a problematic area because current criticism fails to recognize that varying stylistic emphasis on two different components of major works of art form the basis of appeal to different sections of the community.

title: About Books and Authors; Scholars May Scream
description: AFTER four decades of editing the likes of T.S. Eliot, Flannery O'Connor, Isaac Bashevis Singer, Elizabeth Bishop, Robert Lowell and Bernard Malamud, Robert Giroux is about to have a book published next month under his own name: ''The Book Known as Q: A Consideration of Shakespeare's Sonnets'' (Atheneum).

title: DEMAND GROWS FOR FOOD TO THE NEEDY
description: FROM North Canaan in the northwest corner of the state to Stafford in the northeast, from places as diverse as New Canaan and Willimantic, free food is being provided to thousands of needy residents. A variety of institutions and programs, such as churchsponsored soup kitchens, private and public social-service agencies and a Federal surplus-cheese giveaway is responsible for this growing trend.

title: A Scenario for A Depression
description: It is ironic that Benjamin Stein unintentionally completed the circle of Herbert Hoover's logic in ''A Scenario for a Depression'' (Feb. 28). He began with Mr. Hoover's reluctant acceptance of the financial community's wisdom that it was the deficit that was straining the financial markets and that tax increases would restore the health of the economy. Mr. Stein suggests rather casually that the theories of the supply-siders, the Keynesians and the monetarists no longer work, or are no longer relevant. Then he concludes with the suggestion that we are on uncharted waters, that experimentation is too dangerous and that we should wait until we return to familiar territory.

title: THE ONES WHO ALWAYS SAY HELLO
description: ON these pages recently there was a spate of articles by Long Islanders about the virtues of Long Island living. Some spoke about the physical beauty of the Island; others spoke broadly about the Long Island life style. All were well-thought-out pieces. Each reflected a tendency on the part of Long Islanders to be defensive about the way we live.

title: Avoiding the Trap
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. ENVOY, IN CAIRO, CONFIDENT ON SINAI
description: President Reagan's special envoy to the Middle East said today he was confident that Israel's final withdrawal from the Sinai Peninsula would take place a week from Sunday as stipulated in the Camp David peace treaty.

title: THE RETURN OF THE GYPSY MOTH
description: AUTHORITIES on the subject of the gypsy moth seem to feel that there will be no significant collapse in the population of this pest in the near future, although there may be seasonal ups and downs from one area to another. It would appear likely that the areas that experienced severe damage last year can look forward to a similar experience this year and that adjacent areas will see an increase in damage from the spillover.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: THERE were no drawn swords, no battle cries, no bagpipe tattoos when representatives of the Bells and Irvings met at Sunnyside last week. Instead, there was a toast of Scotch whisky and a promise to formally conclude a conflict that had become something of a tradition.

title: by Sylvia Plath
description: Las t night I felt the sensation I have been reading about to no avail in James: The sick, soul-annihilating flux of fear in my blood switching its current to defiant fight. I could not sleep, although tired, and lay feeling my nerves shaved to pain & the groaning inner voice: Oh, you can't teach, can't do anything. Can't write, can't think. And I lay under the negative icy flood of denial, thinking that voice was all my own, a part of me, and it must somehow conquer me and leave me with my worst visions: having had the chance to battle it & win day by day, and having failed.

title: PLAYERS WOULD BACK A STRIKE
description: There is strong support for a strike among the professional football players, according to a poll taken by The New York Times. Of the 1,558 players on the National Football League's 28 team rosters, 758 responded and a majority indicated support for a strike.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: A Dancer for All Mediums

title: ART CRITIC ASSAILED AND LAUDED FOR VIEWS
description: The integrity of David L. Shirey, as demonstrated in ''What It Is Like to Be an Art Juror,'' reinforces my admiration for this sensitive critic.

title: MAKING OVER
description: WHY PEOPLE ARE INVESTING IN: REMODELING * REDESIGNING * REDECORATING

title: BY JOHN B. FORBES
description: HEMPSTEAD EVERY Sunday in the spring, a dedicated band of women don kilts, grab lacrosse sticks and spend hours at Hofstra University playing a game invented by the American Indians.

title: Transactions; HOCKEY
description: ST. LOUIS (NHL) - Recalled Bob Sirois, a goalie, from Milwaukee of the International League and Jim Pavese from Sault Ste. Marie of the Ontario Association.; COLLEGE

title: DREDGING ISSUE SPLITS THE SOUND
description: AMID sighs of relief and howls of protest, the Corps of Engineers, New England Division, has designated an open-water disposal site in Long Island Sound off Stamford. The sighs come from the permit holders in Mamaroneck, N.Y., who have been waiting to receive the goahead to dredge for more than a year. Their relief is also shared by the users of other small, largely recreational ports in Westchester and Fairfield Counties where maintenance dredging is needed to retain port and marina viability.

title: Jane Shenan to Be Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Shenan of Allenhurst, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Jane Michele Shenan, to Peter J. Hughes, son of Mrs. Honora Rogers Hughes of West Orange, N.J., and the late Peter Hughes. A September wedding is planned.

title: STEPPING THROUGH THE RUINS
description: THIS JOURNEY By James Wright. 91 pp. New York: Random House. Cloth, $10.50. Vintage. Paper, $5.95. THE PURE CLEAR WORD Essays on the Poetry of James Wright. Edited by Dave Smith. 260 pp. Urbana: University of Illinois Press. $18.95. By EDWARD HIRSCH

title: HOW WORKERS SAVED THEIR JOBS
description: WHEN General Motors announced in August 1980 that it would either sell or close its Hyatt bearings plant in Clark, more than 1,500 union members and their families suddenly confronted the specter of unemployment and all that follows in its wake: alcoholism, broken families, disrupted neighborhoods and communities, rising crime rates and a general malaise in both human and economic terms.

title:
MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW;
KERNS-ABRAMS DUO, FLUTIST AND PIANO
description: The Kern-Abrams duo, consisting of Sharette Kern, flutist, and Daniel Abrams, pianist, played music of Haydn, Chopin, Bach and Henri Dutilleux in their New York debut Friday night at Carnegie Recital Hall. The pair also offered two works by Mr. Abrams, one a suite entitled ''Jaz-zonata,'' the other a fantasia for flute and piano on Weber's opera ''Der Freischutz.''

title: Five Andean Nations Pledge To Trade More With Argentina
description: Five South American countries said today that they would step up trade with Argentina to help it overcome the economic boycott imposed by the European Economic Community.

title: SCHOOL ON SATURDAY? FOR JAPANESE, YES
description: ACOWBELL clanged through the halls as Masako Odani's fourth-graders scurried to get into their seats before their teacher got to the classroom. But a teacher's aide was already scurrying around the room trying to get to these desks before the pupils did, so she could tape the desk tops shut, as a precautionary measure..

title: U.S. TO STUDY BREZHNEV'S CALL FOR SUMMIT MEETING
description: The White House said today that it would study Leonid I. Brezhnev's proposal for a summit meeting in the fall, but said that President Reagan still hoped the Soviet leader would come to New York in June for an initial meeting.

title: Travel Advisory; LIVERPUDLIAN ECOES, WHEELS IN COLORADO; Touring The Beatles' Liverpool
description: Many's the tourist who has fashioned his travels in the footprints of his idol - Sherlock Holmes's London, Scarlett O'Hara's South, Hamlet's Denmark. To such geographic lodestones can now be added the Liverpool of the Beatles - a metropolis associated with John Lennon's birthplace, Paul McCartney's school, George Harrison's house, Ringo Starr's local pub and such songs as ''Strawberry Fields'' and ''Penny Lane.''

title: NO EXHIBIT FOR STATE AT THE WORLD'S FAIR
description: THERE won't be a ''Better Yet Connecticut'' exhibit at the 1982 World's Fair that begins next month in Knoxville, Tenn. State officials determined that such an exhibit, selling items bearing Connecticut's official tourism slogan, would be too expensive.

title: FINALE AT RUTGERS
description: ''H.M.S. Pinafore,'' the Gilbert and Sullivan comic operetta that opened Friday in New Brunswick, is the final offering in Rutgers University's seven-show season.

title: CHICAGO MAYOR RELAXES PUBLIC HOUSING FEUD
description: The dispute between Mayor Jane M. Byrne and Federal officials over what the officials call the confused and patronage-ridden administration of public housing here appears to have subsided after a proposal by the Mayor for reorganizing the executive level of the Chicago Housing Authority.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
ARBOR DAY
description: It's time for Arbor Day observances on the Island and though you don't necessarily have to plant a tree, you can mark the occasion at the Environmental Centers of Setauket-Smithtown, which have scheduled a full weekend of events. At 10 A.M. Saturday at Sweetbriar Farm, Landing Road in Smithtown, there will be a ''preserve walk,'' followed by a planting ceremony (they'll plant Newtown Pippen apples in honor of the species developed on the Island in the early 1700's) at 1:30 P.M.

title: CAN 42ND STREET REGAIN ITS SHOWBIZ GALMOUR?
description: Behind the sleaze and hustle of West 42d Street lies one of the city's most extraordinary - and untapped - cultural resources: nine famous old legitimate theaters, their glory days long forgotten and their handsome facades obliterated by Kung Fu billboards.

title: 2 Named for Atlanta Appeal
description: Alvin Binder, the lawyer who defended Wayne B. Williams in his trial for the murders of two Atlanta blacks, was appointed along with an Atlanta lawyer Friday to handle Mr. Williams's state-financed appeal. Mr. Binder and Lynn Whatley were appointed by Judge Clarence Cooper of Superior Court, who on Thursday declared Mr. Williams indigent and therefore eligible to use public funds in his appeal. He was convicted Feb. 27.

title: APPEALS COURT REJECTS SUIT ON FALL AT SEAPORT
description: A worker who was injured on a ship has lost an attempt to obtain damages for his accident because the vessel was permanently docked at the South Street Seaport Museum.

title: GUIDEBOOKS TO ALMOST EVERYWHERE
description: RICHARD EDER is chief of The Times Paris bureau. By RICHARD EDER

title: MITTERRAND STRESSING JAPANESE TECHNICAL TIES
description: During a visit to Japan this week, President Francois Mitterrand of France was offered mostly what one Japanese Government official described as ''tea and sympathy and politesse.''

title: LEONARDO'S CODEX DAZZLES FLORENCE
description: For the last two months, about 3,000 people a day, and twice that number on Saturdays and Sundays, have been paying about $2 admission to peer intently at 72 pages of yellowed paper covered with mirror-image writing in brown ink and illustrated with many scientific drawings on practical hydraulics in the margins.

title: SAFETY-DEVICE FAILURE IN G.M. BUSES INJURES 3
description: A safety device on the rear doors of some of the city's new General Motors buses has malfunctioned in the last few weeks, causing minor injuries to three passengers, a spokesman for the Transit Authority said yesterday.

title: A PIP OF A 'PIPPIN' IN BRIDGEPORT
description: ''PIPPIN'' was a Broadway hit in 1972. What made it so was the dazzling staging and choreography of Bob Fosse. The book, which was performed without intermission, became a wearying affair as the story line progressed. Mr. Fosse, however, created one brilliant number after another and kept electrifying the audience, if not quite distracting it completely from the tiring tale of Pippin, Charlemagne's first-born son. What I learned from the show was to beware of musicals performed without intermission. The reason usually turns out to be that customers were walking out during previews of the show.

title: STATEWIDE FOOD BANK IS BEING PLANNED
description: A COALITION of New Haven community groups is about to start an ambitious project to establish a statewide food bank to provide nonprofit organizations with food to feed Connecticut's poor.

title: THE BEARD FAD MAY BE FACING A BLANK FUTURE
description: ''I am certainly not going to shave now.'' - Paul S. Finot, a political science teacher, on being removed from his teaching duties at John Muir High School in Pasadena, Calif., because he had grown a beard during his summer vacation, September 1963. ''Beards, like above-the-knee skirts, are becoming more a fashion and less a measure of social defiance.'' -Leonard Sandler, on behalf of the New York Civil Liberties Union, in its successful defense of the right of Abe Dweck, a Transit Authority employee, to wear a beard on the job, December 1967.

title: No Headline
description: Michael Elkins asks: ''What has happened to the Zionist dream?'' Perhaps the dream started to turn into a nightmare when the Government of Great Britain abrogated the promises made in the Balfour Declaration; or when no attempt was made to save the lives of six million European Jews; or when the remnants of the Holocaust were blockaded from entering Palestine; or when the world community failed to come to Israel's aid during four Arab attempts to drive her into the sea; or when the nations of the world stood by during years of P.L.O. terrorist attacks on women and children; or when the United Nations lost the very morality which is the reason for its existence; or when her best friend, the United States, decided to supply her sworn enemies with every conceivable weapon to destroy her. I would suggest that the Zionists have to sleep with one eye open, and under that condition, dreaming becomes quite difficult. ALBERT ESTEROW, Fresh Meadows, N.Y.

title: FOOD
description: TURNING OVER A THOUSAND NEW LEAVES With this uncomplicated preparation for puff pastry, haste no longer leads to waste.

title: BOMB UNIT REMOVES OLD DYNAMITE STICKS AT E. 51ST ST. HOUSE
description: A number of buildings on East 51st Street were emptied of their residents for an hour yesterday afternoon while the police bomb squad removed several sticks of old dynamite from the home of a recently deceased Army colonel and explosives expert.

title: REMOVING A RESIDUE OF THE HOLOCAUST
description: IBELONG to a minority within a minority. I am the daughter of survivors of the Nazi Holocaust. I am also Jewish. There has always been a gulf between Holocaust survivors and other Jews. In that gulf are guilt, remorse, accusations, fear and bottomless sorrow. In the last few years, that gulf has been narrowing.

title: CUBANS TO PERFORM
description: A two-hour production by Teatro Escambray, a 28-actor troupe from Cuba, will be the highlight of Latin American Week at Rutgers-Camden, a five-day event that starts tomorrow. The Cubans will perform at 8 P.M. Wednesday at the College Center, Fourth and Penn Streets.

title: THE FAR WEST VILLAGE
description: ''W AY out west of Hudson Street'' is how Greenwich Villagers, viewing the world from their expensive little Bohemia, used to think of the cheaper dockside quarter to the west.

title: Miss Rochford, Paul Vineis Wed
description: Christine Jane Rochford and Paul Jonathan Vineis were married yesterday in Alexandria, Va. The Rev. Dr. Lewis Morgan performed the ceremony in the Trinity United Methodist Church.

title: U.S. SEEKS OUSTER OF MAYOR MUSTO
description: NEWARK DEFENSE attorneys for Mayor William V. Musto of Union City and Government prosecutors traded court motions here last week. The defense called for a new trial, while the United States Attorney's office demanded the immediate incarceration of the Mayor and four co-defendants on the grounds that they had strong ties to organized crime and were a threat to the community.

title: WASTE PAPER RECYCLING PLAN PRESSED BY ENVIRONMENTALISTS
description: Citing environmental benefits, community service and added revenue as incentives, a private environmental group in New York is seeking to expand its efforts to recruit major businesses to conserve waste paper for recycling.

title: Rutgers Law Dean Accused of Dishonesty
description: I read Dean Simmons's (Rutgers University Law School) letter on the Opinion Page of March 7, and I accuse him of not being totally honest in his reply to the angry parent of a student rejected by the Admissions Committee.

title:
ANTIQUES;
BARRACKS THAT ANTEDATS KILROY
description: TRENTON TRENTON BARRACKS, constructed in 1758 to house British troops during the French and Indian War, is the only one remaining of five such barracks in the state. However, the word barracks seems forbidding for the gracious fieldstone building and its long, sheltering wooden porches.

title: U.S. ENVOY GETS MIXED REVIEWS IN MOROCCO
description: When Richard M. Nixon arrived for a recent visit, the United States Ambassador gave a dinner in his honor, with the 23-year-old son of the late Shah of Iran seated next to him.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICE
description: THEATER In ''Pastorale,'' at the Second Stage, one meets a first-time playwright, Deborah Eisenberg, who goes her own, merry way. Miss Eisenberg's characters are disconnected 1960's dropouts at loose in 1980's New England, and she has captured their loopy language and often affectless manners without making concessions to any other reality.

title: The Nation; by Michael Wright and Caroline Rand Herron; It's Really Tough All Over
description: Beyond their membership in the union, rich California and poor Mississippi have never had much in common. Now, though, with tax revenues declining and Washington turning increasingly tight-fisted, officials in Sacramento and Jackson are struggling with roughly equal lack of success against fiscal and economic difficulties.

title: Susan L. Avitabile Becomes Bride of Richard Gula
description: Susan L. Avitabile, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George P. Avitabile of Torrington, Conn., was married yesterday to Richard W. Gula, son of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Gula of Middletown, Conn. The Rev. Peter J. Gomes, Plummer Professor of Christian Morals at the Harvard Divinity School, performed the ceremony in the Memorial Church at Harvard University.

title: THE BOSTON MARATHON RUNAROUND
description: Jock Semple has been involved with distance running since he was a teen-ager in Scotland. For the last 53 years he has been involved with the Boston Marathon, first as a competitor, now as a trainer and for the last 29 years as co-director of the race, to be held tomorrow.

title: '84 Olympics on Schedule
description: Everything is on schedule for the 1984 Summer Olympics in Los Angeles and tickets will go on sale next spring, Harry Usher, the executive vice president of the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee, said today.

title: CARDINALS 6, PHILLIES 0
description: Joaquin Andujar pitched a three-hit shutout, and St. Louis reached Steve Carlton for five early runs as the Cardinals defeated the Philadelphia Phillies today, 6-0, for their seventh straight victory.

title: RONI L. SCHERMAN ENGAGED
description: The engagement of Roni L. Scherman to Stuart M. Stein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin M. Stein of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Delray Beach, Fla., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Emanuel Scherman of North Woodmere, L.I.

title: TO ADD OR NOT TO ADD
description: By Paul Goldberger A decade ago, the most talked-about house addition in architectural circles was a white, machinelike object that had been tacked by the architect Michael Graves onto a rather banal suburban house in Princeton, N.J. The Benacerraf house project, as the addition was known, bore little if any relationship - conscious or unconscious - to the house of which it was a part. In fact, it is no exaggeration to say that the original house and the Graves addition had nothing at all to do with each other.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: IRVINGTON IT was a little after 3 P.M., and classes were letting out. Henry, who is 14, had just come from a room where he and the others had been reading aloud an adaptation of Charles Dickens's ''Oliver Twist.'' Now he was talking to a visitor, explaining that in the reading he had taken the leading role.

title: 91 Law Officers Slain on Duty In '81 Held Lowest on Record
description: Ninety-one law-enforcement officers were killed in the line of duty in 1981, the lowest total in the 11 years that statistics have been kept, the Federal Bureau of Investigation has reported.

title: Catherine Anne Lee Bride Of Mark A. Schmid in V.I.
description: The marriage of Catherine Anne Lee, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Burt Lee of White Plains and St. Thomas, V.I., to Mark Alan Schmid took place yesterday. Lieut. Col. Frederick Q. Lawrence of the Army Chaplain Corps, retired, performed the ceremony at the St. Thomas Yacht Club.

title: DANCE: ZERO MOVING TROUPE, MERGING ARTISTIC TENDENCIES
description: Philadelphia's Zero Moving Dance Company, which came to the Theater of the Riverside Church Thursday night, is an unusual group. Directed by Hellmut Gottschild, a pupil of Mary Wigman, the German Expressionist choreographer, it derives from a dance tradition comparatively little known in America.

title: VIOLINIST: ROSAND'S TCHAIKOVSKY
description: By EDWARD ROTHSTEIN In Tchaikovsky's Violin Concerto the solo instrument often acts like a representative of the orchestra itself, whipping passions to climaxes so 100 other players can take off, until the violin is ready to drive forward once again.

title: Leaden Minds, Leaden Hearts
description: We carry in our bodies 100 times more lead than did our premetalworking ancestors. The health cost of this burden appears increasingly serious: pre-school children are particularly at risk, and recent research strongly indicates, though it cannot yet prove, that even the minutest quantities of lead can cause subtle forms of mental damage from which children may never recover.

title: THE SPIRIT OF NEW YORK
description: American designers are plunging into their fall collections pursued by problems. On the brink of the year's most important showings -beginning tomorrow in New York City - they are dealing with deeper matters than the depth of a hemline or the placement of a waistline. Fresh from a season when designer clothing finally felt the falloff in sales that has affected the retail business in general, designers share -via sales figures - the nation's unease about the economy. Making matters worse, they must contemplate the inevitable escalation of production and fabric costs, and the consequent necessity of elevating their own price tags even higher. Additionally, all designers are now acutely aware of the growing fashion independence of American women, who may not always be sure of what they want, but are most definite about what they do not.

title: SCHOOL-AID TALKS TIE UP $13.2 MILLION
description: ALBANY FOR months, school districts have been closely following the barrage of studies, proposals, computer printouts and polemics on how to allocate New York State's hefty contribution to its schools.

title: PERPLEXITY IN REYKJAVIK
description: In the darkest days of World War II, a number of bridge-playing sailors suffering across the Atlantic on convoy duty had a pleasant surprise when they reached the storm-buffeted port of Reykjavik. They received a warm welcome from the bridge enthusiasts of Iceland, of whom there was an abundance.

title: Cathy Ann Gilpin To Be June Bride
description: Mr, and Mrs. Carl M. Gilpin of Weston, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cathy Ann Gilpin, to Michael Roman Worchesek, son of Capt. Robert R. Worchesek, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Worchesek of San Diego.

title: Music View; THE MET OPERA SEASON WAS NOT BAD, BUT . . .
description: This has been a classic ''yes, but'' season for the Metropolitan Opera. Looking back at the seven-month 1981-82 schedule, which concluded with last night's performance of ''Fidelio,'' we find those two painful but useful words cropping up again and again. Consider, as the season in microcosm, that famous opening night when boos greeted Renata Scotto before she could sing a note of her opening aria, ''Casta diva.'' That lack of elementary fair play ranked as one of the season's low points, particularly since not only Miss Scotto but the conductor and the other two principal singers were appearing in their roles for the first time with the Metropolitan. Yes, but ...when all that is taken into account the fact remains that Miss Scotto went on to sing poorly in a punishing role that she should not have been allowed to attempt at this stage of her career. Critical chivalry, sadly, must in this instance bow to reality.

title: BEST FILMS ON TV
description: Regrettably, three of the week's best films on television - ''Freud,'' ''Lonely Are the Brave'' and ''Apartment for Peggy'' - have been slotted after 2 A.M. Who cares? Possibly the great majority of New Yorkers who sleep at night and work by day will care. If they do, maybe they will squawk. And then perhaps station schedulers will wake up. Nonetheless, some welcome spring fare is on hand.

title: Mary Crane, Whitney Tilt Are Married
description: Mary Stuart Crane, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Carey Crane of Riverside, Conn., was married yesterday to Whitney Curtiss Tilt, son of Albert Tilt 3d of Tetonia, Idaho, formerly of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Cornelia Murray. The Rev. Melvin Schlacter performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn.

title: THE 'RIP-OFF FOR THE RICH' IN SEA LAW DRAFT
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Differences persist. They always will.'' - Queen Elizabeth II on Quebec's refusal to support constitutional amendment process. (8:1.)

title: Article 071599 -- No Title
description: Eastern Airlines has agreed to pay $65,000 in an out-of-court settlement to 23 women who charged that because of their age they were not hired as flight attendants.

title: OPERA: 'I VESPRI SICILIANI'
description: The Spanish soprano Angeles Gulin made her Metropolitan Opera debut Thursday night as Elena in the company's final performance this season of Verdi's ''I Vespri Siciliani.'' There was some excitement in her voice - a dramatic quality she could turn on and off - but from the technical and musical standpoint, her singing exhibited a number of shortcomings.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, APRIL 18, 1982
description: International Buenos Aires was gloomy over the prospects for averting hostilities with Britain over the Falkland Islands as Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and Argentine officials met to discuss the crisis. Senior Argentine officials and foreign diplomats doubted that a ground for compromise would be found. Argentina was adamant in its refusal to settle for anything less than full sovereignty over the Falklands. Mr. Haig ''still doesn't believe that we are willing to go to war over the principle,'' an Argentine official said. (Page 1, Column 6.) A country weekend was cut short by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, who returned to London when it seemed that Secretary of State Alexabder M. Haig Jr.'s attempt in Buenos Aires to mediate the Falklands crisis was foundering. Mrs. Thatcher's re-turn to London was not linked to any new development, an official spokes-man said, but other sources said she felt a major turning point was ap-proaching. (1:5.)

title: HISTORY AS A DISAPPOINTMENT MACHINE
description: SHIFTING INVOLVEMENTS Private Interest and Public Action. By Albert O. Hirschman. 138 pp. New Jersey: Princeton University Press. Cloth, $14.50. Paper, $5.95.

title: GUIDEBOOKSCITY OF RAFFISH SURPRISES
description: THOMAS THOMPSON is the author of ''Blood and Money'' and ''Serpentine.'' ''Celebrity,'' his first novel, has just been published by Doubleday. By THOMAS THOMPSON

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: THE appointment of Assemblyman Joseph M. Reilly as Nassau County General Services Commissioner was not as routine as it might have appeared in the press release last week.

title: PIANO: PETER KATIN, BACH TO BRAHAMS
description: Peter Katin, the British pianist, played Bach, Liszt, Chopin and Brahms on Monday in Alice Tully Hall. Mr. Katin was usually at odds with his material here. His personality occupied an interpretive world of order, neatness, correct manners and good sense; and for a pianist of such self-possessed sanity this was a program too rife with latent manic qualities.

title: Carol E. Goulian To Be June Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Levon Goulian of New Milford, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carol Ellen Goulian, to John Bassett Moore Place 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Place of San Francisco, formerly of New York. A June wedding is planned.

title: RITES OF SPRING FOR BEACHGOING SINGLES
description: ''FIRE ISLAND/Ocean Beach. Oceanfront 4 BR house with large sundeck, May-Sept. shares open for friendly people 25-35, at good prices.'' The ad ran in the paper on a Wednesday. By Friday, 22 persons had called - 19 of them females. The males who were organizing the group house were thrilled; now, they thought, they could be picky in their choice of the women who would be signed up for the summer. The female members of the group, including me, kept anxiously asking, ''It's going to be half and half - right?''

title: ATLANTIC CITY WOOS ORIENTALS
description: ATLANTIC CITY THE gambling casinos here are sending representatives to Chinatowns across the country with a sales pitch designed to attract a growing market of Oriental bettors.

title: SUMMERFARE HOPING TO SET A TRADITION
description: BORROWING a page from the television industry's script, the county's largest arts festival will usher in its five-week summer season by rerunning one of its most successful offerings.

title: The Region; by Richard Levine, Carlyle C. Douglas and William C. Rhodes; THe Bunny Stays But Hefner Goes
description: The Playboy Casino in Atlantic City will still have many of the familar symbols, but not perhaps the ultimate one. Under an agreement approved last week by the New Jersey Casino Control Commission, Hugh M. Hefner will not be in charge.

title: Penn's Varsity Wins In Childs Cup Regatta
description: The Penn varsity heavyweight crew combined a powerful start and a strong sprint at the finish to defeat Princeton and Columbia and win the 68th annual Childs Cup regatta yesterday on the Harlem River.

title: DEFENDER OF THE FAITH
description: Last July, Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan was looking ahead. The President's spending cuts had been approved by Congress and the three-year tax cut was nearly assured.

title: Fair Grounds Assails Governor of Louisiana
description: An attorney for the Fair Grounds race track charges that Gov. Dave Treen strong-armed the Louisiana State Racing Commission into voting Friday to bar horsemen from racing horses at tracks they own.

title: U.N. Envoy Arrives in Kabul Seeking 3-Nation Negotiation
description: A United Nations special envoy, Diego Cordoves, who is seeking a negotiated solution to the Afghanistan conflict, arrived in Kabul today and had talks with Foreign Minister Shah Mohammad Dost, the Kabul radio reported.

title: The World; by Barbara Slavin and Milt Freudenheim; Jerusalem Attack Echoes Through The Arab World
description: Like a spark in dry tinder, the shooting rampage by an Israeli soldier last Sunday at Islam's third holiest site inflamed Arab opinion and led to more clashes between Israeli forces and Palestinians in Jerusalem, the West Bank and the Gaza Strip. By the week's end, dozens of people were injured and five Arabs were dead - two killed on Jerusalem's Temple Mount, site of the Dome of the Rock mosque, and three, including an eight-year-old boy, fatally shot by Israelis subduing rock-throwing protesters in Gaza.

title: U.S. ENDING AID FOR TRAINING AT MENTAL UNIT
description: TWO months after the county took over the Mental Retardation Institute in Valhalla, to save the nationally recognized program of mental-retardation services, from possible disbandment because of financial problems, the Federal Government has decided to discontinue a yearly training grant that accounts for nearly 20 percent of the institute's funds.

title: Vince Lombardi's Widow
description: Marie Lombardi, widow of Vince Lombardi, the Green Bay Packers football coach, died today at John F. Kennedy Hospital. She was 66 years old. Mrs. Lombardi had been ill with a lung infection for about two months, said her son-inlaw, Paul Bickham.

title: 'BUNGLED' ROOSEVELT I. HOUSING TO BE REPAIRED
description: A 1,000-unit Roosevelt Island apartment complex whose construction seven years ago was ''bungled,'' according to a state housing official, is about to undergo $5.5 million in repairs for defects. Neither the owner nor the sponsoring state agency, the Urban Development Corporation, will accept responsibility.

title: NEW VIRTUOSI FESTIVAL
description: The 1982 New Virtuosi Festival, at 8:30 each evening from Thursday through Sunday and on May 1 at Real Art Ways in Hartford, will feature five musicians who have pioneered in the development and commissioning of new works for their own instruments. As Joseph Horowitz said in The New York Times in a 1980 review of an avantgarde concert by one of the virtuosi participants, ''Virtually any instrument can be made a star, given a sufficiently spectacular practitioner and a supply of pieces designed to ferret out untested techniques for plucking, bowing and blowing.''

title: PHOTOS FROM A LINER STUDIED IN CBS SLAYINGS
description: Detectives began examining photographs yesterday taken by passengers on a cruise ship in the hope that some of the pictures might provide clues to the slayings last week of three CBS employees and a woman they apparently had tried to help.

title: An Ulster Farmer Is Wounded And Then Killed by 4 Gunmen
description: Four gunmen wounded a farmer from ambush today, then shot him dead as he tried to crawl away from them, authorities said. The gunmen apparently believed he was a part-time soldier, but he was not, authorities said.

title: Biggs Advances to Final On a Quick Knockout
description: Tyrell (Tyrone) Biggs of Philadelphia has advanced to the final of the United States Amateur Boxing Championships after taking only 41 seconds of the first round to stop Lionell Washington Friday night in the semifinals of their superheavyweight bout.

title: Miss Greenwald, Christian Albert To Wed Aug. 28
description: Dr. and Mrs. Willard F. Greenwald Jr., of North Haven, Conn., and Arlington, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Anne Deacon Greenwald, to Christian Edward Albert, son of Mrs. William H. Winters Jr. of Quogue, L.I., and the late Carl Albert.

title: FROM HERE TO HIGH TECH
description: Eavesdrop on the shoptalk of musicians and you often hear them discussing the ''personality'' of their instruments.

title: DRAMA: 'YOSSELE GOLEM' IN ITS WORLD PREMIERE
description: ''Yossele Golem,'' by Dan Horowitz, an Israeli dramatist, having its world premiere at La Mama E.T.C., is billed as a ''poetic drama,'' which means that it is open to many interpretations, and in this avant-garde production it is not difficult to formulate them.

title: HOLLY WHITCOMB WRIGHT BRIDE OF ROBERT S. PHELPS
description: Holly Whitcomb Wright and Robert Stephen Phelps were married yesterday in St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York by the Rev. Kenneth Swanson.

title: SCULPTOR RATED 'R'
description: WASHINGTON By States News Service

title: Practical Traveler; AIR-FARE OPTIONS ON THE ATLANTIC RUN
description: Despite substantial increases by major airlines in trans-Atlantic fares, bargains abound for this spring and summer if you know where and how to find them.

title: Military Analysis
description: British military leaders are now coming to grips with what is perhaps the most important and least spectacular question of the Falkland Islands operation: What happens if nothing happens? In other words, what do the British do if the Argentine Navy does not challenge the 200-mile blockade around the Falklands, the air force confines its operations to flying cover over Argentine ports and the Falkland garrison concentrates on building shelters and laying mines.

title: Miss Bush Is Engaged To Teacher
description: Vice President and Mrs. George Bush of Washington have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dorothy Walker Bush, to William H. LeBlond, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard K. LeBlond 2d of New Canaan, Conn.

title: by Jean Mayer
description: Since World War II, the United States has been the world's bulwark against famine. In the eyes of many foreigners, and in those of many Americans, this has made up for the shortcomings they have seen and see in our foreign policy. But now we have turned our back on America's humane values and on the poorest of our neighbors. Engulfed in a wave of Social Darwinism, America devotes only 0.27 percent of its gross national product to food and development aid in comparison to France's 0.62 percent, West Germany's 0.43 percent, Canada's 0.42 percent, and Britain's 0.34 percent.

title: Art Critic Assailed And Lauded for Views
description: With great expectation, I visited the Summit Art Center on the final day of its annual juried exhibition. I had submitted a painting, as I sometimes do, and it was rejected, as they sometimes are.

title: THAIS CELEBRATE MONARCHY AS SYMBOL OF UNITY
description: Thais happily splashed each other with water this week to mark the start of the traditional Thai New Year. Since the beginning of the month, they had been celebrating the 200th anniversary of Thailand's Chakkri dynasty of kings, and while technically it is being observed through 1982, its most spectacular features are on the wane.

title: Elizabeth Ann Leyda Wed
description: Elizabeth Ann Leyda, a business sales representative for the Liberty Mutual Insurance Company in Denver, was married yesterday to O. Waring Mellick Jr., a sales representative in Denver with Coastal Plains Inc. of Dallas, a power transmission and gearing company. The Rev. Monroe Osborne performed the ceremony in the Broadway Baptist Church of the American Baptist Convention in Denver. The bride is a daughter of Mrs. Paul Leighton Leyda Jr. of Denver and the late Dr. Leyda, who was a surgeon. Mr. Mellick is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mellick of Greenwich, Conn.

title: Ideas and Trends; by Eva Hoffman and Margot Slade; Roche's Prize, And Saarinen's
description: If the master is known by the quality of his students, then two architects were honored last week when Kevin Roche won the $100,000 Pritzger Prize.

title: A BETTER PROGRAM OF CARE FOR THE TERMINALLY ILL
description: To the Editor:

title: HEALTH CARE UNITS WILL LOSE U.S. AID
description: The Reagan Administration is ending Federal grants and loans to organizations that provide health care to groups of people for a flat fee paid in advance.

title: Charles Hoxie, 70, Manager For Private Security Service
description: Charles E. Hoxie, the former Middle West regional manager of Burns International Security Services Inc., the private protection company, died Friday at his home in St. Louis, Mo., after a heart attack. He was 70 years old.

title: Around the Nation; Arizona Town Votes To File for Bankruptcy
description: The city council voted Friday to authorize the financial reorganization of this town of 6,500 people under protection of Federal bankruptcy law because of a $3.6 million judgment the town says it cannot pay.

title: Sports People; Lessons for Gretzky
description: Yesterday was a day off for the eight teams competing in the world hockey championships in Finland. But it was also a day of reflection for Wayne Gretzky, the scoring star of the National Hockey League who has been quiet in two international games.

title: Nazis and Homosexuals
description: To the Editor:

title: Silbersteins Excel
description: Competing for the second time this year as a brother team, Dave and Dan Silberstein of North Rockland (N.Y.) High School won the two-man shot-put and placed fourth in the two-man discus throw at the 28th Iona Relays today at Fairleigh Dickinson Univerity.

title: VARIATIONS ON A SPANISH THEME
description: A SUBTLE adjustment in the name has signaled a radical change at Granados in Glen Head, formerly Meson Granados. Visually the restaurant is the same, telegraphing the Spanish theme with heavy beams, white stucco walls, some wrought iron and paintings of lacedraped senoras. The difference in management only becomes evident once the food is served. It is prepared with far less finesse than in the past.

title: NEW CHARTER PANEL HAS A HEAPING PLATE
description: ''When government gets too big, too bulky, too unwieldy, it can't respond in time to do much good,'' the Bronx resident told a panel of government officials. ''Like the dying dinosaur, whose body thrashed about long after its pea-sized brain ceased functioning, our huge city is slowly dying, but the brains in City Hall have still not received the message.''

title: MOTHER IS SEEKING TO REGAIN SON, 4, FROM EX-BABY SITTER
description: Brenda D. Smith, a disabled, unemployed high school dropout, has lost custody of her 4-year-old son. He now lives with a woman who was his baby sitter while his mother convalesced from an automobile accident.

title: Mailbox; RECOGNIZE MARIS
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: MEDAL CELEBRATES PHILADELPHIAS'S BIRTHDAY; by Ed Reiter
description: The City of Philadelphia is in the midst of its 300th birthday celebration and The Franklin Mint is striking the official medal for the Century IV Celebration. The company will furnish all examples at well below cost to maximize the city's profit from their sale, which will help finance the tercentenary program.

title: LOUISE COHALAN TO BE WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Conway Cohalan of Loch Arbour, New Jersey have announced the engagement of their daughter, Louise Juliet Cohalan, to John Philip Bosmans, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Bosmans of Oakhurst, N.J. Miss Cohalan, a nurse in the emergency ward at Bellevue Hospital in New York, is a granddaughter of the late New York State Supreme Court Justice and Mrs. Denis O'Leary Cohalan of New York. Mr. Bosmans is a partner in Brown & Bosmans, a carpentry contracting company in Ocean Township, N.J.

title: 2 Elderly Women Slain In Apartment Attacks
description: An 86-year-old Manhattan woman and an 82-year-old Bronx woman were found slain in their apartments yesterday afternoon in separate incidents, the police said.

title: U.S. AIDE IS WOUNDED IN BEIRUT
description: An assistant military attache at the American Embassy in Beirut was wounded in the shoulder today by a sniper who fired at his car near the ''green line'' dividing Beirut, an embassy spokesman said.

title: N.F.L. Is Playing Politics
description: ''D ANGLING'' is the word used by Commissioner Pete Rozelle of the National Football League. As worms to gaping fish, Rozelle dangles possible new franchises and Super Bowl games to Representatives and Senators in order to hook them in the muddy waters of Capitol Hill.

title: BUDGET DATES SLIDE BY
description: At the time, the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974 seemed a triumph of legislative self-discipline. Now the budget process has again become an untidy game, as recent history demonstrates (see chart: reading left-to-right, it's a chronology of developments according to fiscal year; top-to-bottom, it tracks events by calendar year and shows that Congress must often simultaneously align one year's budget with reality while planning for the next). Designed to bring order to decisions on how much Government should spend and how much revenue it should raise, the process instead pushes politicians to set precise ceilings on future outlays based on imprecise predictions. Still, most analysts say, any process is better than none. Here is how it was intended to work: Fifteen days after Congress convenes, the President is required to present his blueprint for the fiscal year beginning the next Oct. 1. By April 15 (last Thursday) House and Senate Budget Committees are to have presented theirs (they didn't). By May 15, a First Concurrent Budget Resolution, on which both houses agree, should be voted. It sets limits for general categories of spending - ''Military,'' ''National Resources'' and so on. Authorizing committees then try to cram dozens of specific programs under each ceiling; meanwhile, appropriations committees earmark funds for them. Inevitably the sum total of the appropriations exceeds the First Resolution's targets. The Second Resolution, due 16 days before the fiscal year starts, was intended to provide for ''technical adjustments,'' factoring in inflation, say, or providing for natural disaster cleanups.

title:
ART;
EVOKING PARIS IN A PERIOD OF CHANGE
description: WHAT more appropriate subject could there be than Paris for April exhibitions? Two of this month's shows focus on Parisian themes, examining both the city itself and its unique ambience as interpreted by its resident artists of the 19th and early 20th centuries.

title: JOHN H. BERG TO MARRY DURRELL GODFREY IN MAY
description: Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Godfrey of Orient, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Durrell Hay Godfrey, to John Hendrickson Berg of New York and East Hampton, L.I., a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. William Berg of Brooklyn.

title: BOOK REVIEW
description: April 18, 1982 NONFICTION BEYOND GREED. By Stephen Fay. 26 DIANA COOPER. By Philip Ziegler. 16 ESSAYS ON CHINESE CIVILIZATION. By Derk Bodde. 7 HOW I COMMITTED SUICIDE: A Reverie. By C.L. Sulzberger. 16 L.A. FREEWAY: An Appreciative Essay. By David Brodsly. 11 THE LETTERS OF ALFRED LORD TENNYSON: Volume 1. 1821-1850. Edited by Cecil Y. Lang and Edgar F. Shannon Jr. 14 THE LIFE AND TIMES OF GRIGORII RASPUTIN. By Alex de Jonge. 32 LIGHTNING BIRD: The Story of One Man's Journey Into Africa's Past. By Lyall Watson. 18 MEGALITHOMANIA. By John Michell. 35 MIDDLETOWN FAMILIES: Fifty Years of Change and Continuity. By Theodore Caplow, Howard M. Bahr, Bruce A. Chadwick, Reuben Hill and Margaret Holmes Williamson. 11 SCIENCE IN TRADITIONAL CHINA: A Comparative Perspective. By Joseph Needham. 7 SEEING IS FORGETTING THE NAME OF THE THING ONE SEES: A Life of Contemporary Artist Robert Irwin. By Lawrence Weschler. 3 SHIFTING INVOLVEMENTS: Private Interest and Public Action. By Albert O. Hirschman. 9 TOLSTOY IN THE SEVENTIES. By Boris Eikhenbaum. 14 TOLSTOY IN THE SIXTIES. By Boris Eikhenbaum. 14 FICTION AND POETRY C.B. GREENFIELD: NO LADY IN THE HOUSE. By Lucille Kallen. 20 THE CRYING HEART TATTOO. By David Martin. 12 A LIVING DOG. By Peter Somerville-Large. 20 THE MAN OF GLASS. By Donald Zochert. 20 THE MOORSTONE SICKNESS. By Bernard Taylor. 20 NELLIE WITHOUT HUGO.

title: TO FINANCE A HOME, YOU MUST SHARE LENDER'S RISK
description: As spring takes hold in the metropolitan region, thousands of families will be seized by the seasonal compulsion to search for a new home.

title: Around the World; Guatemalan Bishops Say 200,000 Have Fled
description: Roman Catholic bishops say that political violence in Guatemala has driven at least 200,000 peasants into neighboring Central American countries.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: WHEN Governor O'Neill called a press conference for last Monday afternoon, reporters looked forward to the event with special anticipation. It wasn't because there was a burning topic to discuss; in fact, the press conference had not been called for any particular reason. And it wasn't because this was to be an open, ask-whateveryou-want press conference, although this was Mr. O'Neill's first such event since taking office 14 months ago.

title: I.R.S. Adjunct
description: To the Business Editor: This is a proposal that would hold down Government spending, yield billions of dollars in extra tax revenue and would not cost the honest taxpayer one penny.

title: TAX SEMINAR
description: A seminar on the benefits of the Economic Recovery Tax Act of 1981, describing tax incentives for the rehabilitation of old buildings for commercial purposes, will take place from 7:30 A.M. to 7:30 P.M. Friday at the Connecticut General Life Insurance Company, Bloomfield.

title: Architecture View; A HOMAGE TO THE SKYSCRAPER
description: If there is any encouraging sign in American architecture right now, it is that certain ideas which seemed somewhat radical just a few years ago - and were the exclusive province of a group of noncommercial, ''high design'' architects - have begun the great journey into the rest of the culture. I am speaking most particularly of the tendency away from the austerity of orthodox modern architecture and toward an architecture that re-uses historical forms, accepts the possibility of ornament, and emphasizes the relationship of a building to its neighbors.

title: Nonfiction in Brief; by Frances Taliaferro
description: HOW I COMMITTED SUICIDE A Reverie. By C.L. Sulzberger. 216 pp. New Haven and New York: Ticknor & Fields. $11.95.

title: VETOES LEAVE SCHOOL FUNDS TIED UP IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY FOR months, school districts have been closely following the barrage of studies, proposals, computer printouts and polemics on how to allocate New York State's hefty contribution to the state's schools.

title: A Downtown Library Planned for Yonkers
description: In response to the article on April 4 (''Campaign to Save Yonkers Library''), having to do with the downtown branch of the Yonkers Public Library:

title: FORMER AFRICAN COLONIES RETAIN STRONG FRENCH TIES
description: When Graham Greene toured a part of West Africa in the 1930's, his journey took him across the border between Liberia and what was then the French colony of Guinea. As Mr. Greene recounts the story, the Liberians did not call their neighbor ''Guinea,'' but ''France,'' so pervasive was French colonial influence.

title: THESE NICE NOISES FROM CUBA COULD BE A SIGNAL OR JUST STATIC
description: It may be one of those moments in history that great leaders grasp to reshape the future, or it may be just another series of misleading blips on a cloudy Central American radar screen. But in the last two weeks, Cuba and Nicaragua have been sending signals that could indicate willingness to begin serious talks with the United States. The Reagan Administration has been listening and responding, but it remains skeptical.

title: Other Business; ADVERTISING: LET YOUR FINGERS DO THE CLIPPING
description: Fingers walking through the Yellow Pages could do with a pair of scissors this year. In the 1982-83 editions of Bell System telephone books, some of the ads are clip-out coupons.

title: RELOCATED BAYWAY: A DEAD END
description: ELIZABETH WHEN Mary Zack watched the recent television film ''Love Canal,'' she recalled, she cried and said to herself, '' 'Mary, there could be another Love Canal right in your backyard.' ''

title: Borg Sought by W.C.T.
description: The $500,000 Tournament of Champions, which opens at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills May 2, is trying to persuade Bjorn Borg to enter, Bob Thompson, the tournament director, said yesterday.

title: OF JEFFERSON, MADISON AND BUDGET DEFICITS
description: To the Editor:

title: Pavarotti Will Sing With Contest Winners
description: Luciano Pavarotti, the tenor, will join winners of the Opera Company of Philadelphia-Luciano Pavarotti International Voice Competition in Puccini's ''La Boheme'' and Donizetti's ''L'Elisir d'Amore'' this spring at Philadelphia's Academy of Music.

title: ELECTROGRAPHY SHOW
description: Electrography: art produced technologically from photographs with the aid of inks and photocopying equipment, will be on exhibition through May 9 at the Creative Arts Workshop, 80 Audubon Street, New Haven. Tom Norton, its creator, will lead a workshop for 20 illustrators and graphic designers from 10 to noon today, focusing on the commercial possibilities of the new technique.

title: WHY EGYPT REGARDS THE WITHDRAWAL AS OVERDUE
description: CAIRO ''W HAT do you think will happen after April 25?'' an Egyptian asks his friend. ''April 26, of course, what else?'' is the reply. The dismissive joke about the implications of Israel's final withdrawal from Sinai is meant to convey nonchalance about the forthcoming milestone in Middle East history. Like most political jokes, it is both true and false. If withdrawal comes on schedule, it will not have the intense emotional overtones for most Egyptians that it is already having for Israelis. But if Israel, at the last moment, decided not to withdraw, Egyptians almost certainly would explode in anger of such dimensions that it might sweep the Mubarak regime out of power, touch off new religious violence and bring a reversal of the country's foreign alignments.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICE
description: JAZZ Anthony Braxton and Muhal Richard Abrams have been two of the most ambitious jazz composers and instrumentalists of the past two decades. Mr. Braxton, a formidable alto saxophonist, also plays every other member of the saxophone family and a variety of flutes and other woodwinds. He has written music for standard jazz quartet and big band, for various chamber orchestras, and for massive groups of four, six, eight, and even a hundred symphony orchestras. Needless to say, most of these latter work have yet to be performed. Mr. Abrams, a pianist, is somewhat older than Mr. Braxton but has been associated with him since the mid-60's, when they were both early and important members of the Association for the Advancement of Creative Musicians, a Chicago black musicians's cooperative.

title: 4 in Canadian TV Crew Are Held by Argentina
description: Two Canadians, an American and an Argentine interpreter working for Canadian television were reported today to have been arrested for filming near an air base in southern Argentina.

title: Ideas and Trends; Eva Hoffman and Margot Slade;
description: When a big fish swallows a small fry, that's just the laws of nature. When the world's largest pharmaceutical company stifles a small outfit after having promised to nurture its growth - that, a Minneapolis jury decided, is a violation of antitrust laws.

title: ARMS CONTROL DRIVE TO OPEN
description: Fasts and prayers for peace, bicycle marathons, a ''Run for Your Life'' race, teach-ins and a ''dance for disarmament'' will be held in the next week as part of a nationwide campaign, beginning Sunday, to alert Americans to the dangers of nuclear war.

title:
GARDENING;
THE RETURN OF THE GYPSY MOTH
description: AUTHORITIES on the subject of the gypsy moth seem to feel that there will be no significant collapse in the population of this pest in the near future, although there may be seasonal ups and downs from one area to another. It would appear likely that the areas that experienced severe damage last year can look forward to a similar experience this year and that adjacent areas will see an increase in damage from the spillover.

title: KIM KUBILIUS WILL BE BRIDE OF JOHN HENNINGSEN JR.
description: Leonare Ann Kubilius of Stamford, Conn., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Kim Patricia Kubilius, to John T. Henningsen Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Henningsen of Rye, N.Y.

title: RESPONSES TO A CO-OP CONVERSION
description: MANY New Yorkers are finding ''red herring'' announcements in their m ailboxes these days. They are the first notices that the owner of a r ental apartment building is planning to convert it into a c ooperative or a condominium.

title: IF WATER PIPES BANG, INSTALL A DEVICE TO EASE THE PRESSURE
description: WATER pipes that bang or knock every time a faucet is turned off, or that make hammering noises when a washing machine or similar water-using appliance is in use, not only are a nuisance, but also can lead to a breakdown in one or more pipes and fittings if the problem is not corrected in time.

title: Mansion of Offices
description: Only a few of the turn-of-the-century mansions that once were homes for such families as the Mellons, the Vanderbilts and the Rockefellers and that helped give the Morristown area of New Jersey its reputation as a center for gracious living have survived the economic pressures of modern development and the energy crunch. One of the grandest of them all is the crenelated old house of Edward P. Meany, a lawyer who helped to organize the American Telephone & Telegraph Company. The house is on Madison Avenue in Convent Station, a locality just east of Morristown.

title: REGAN'S INNER CIRCLE
description: WASHINGTON There are those who are close to Donald T. Regan, the Treasury Secretary. But, insiders at Treasury say, there is no one official that the Secretary regularly turns to for advice.

title: THE CHINA THE WEST KNEW NOTHING ABOUT
description: SCIENCE IN TRADITIONAL CHINA A Comparative Perspective. By Joseph Needham. Illustrated. 134 pp. Hong Kong: The Chinese University Press. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $12.50.

title: DEBATE TAKES NEW TURN
description: HARTFORD CHALLENGING an opponent to a debate is one of the oldest ploys in political campaigning, and it is being used again in most of the major election campaigns in Connecticut this year.

title: RASPUTIN, WARTS AND ALL
AGRICULTURAL ZONING FACING COURT TEST
description: THE legitimacy of agricultural zoning, a controversial method of preserving farmland that essentially prohibits subdividing it beyond a certain point and restricts its use to farming, will be tested in State Superior Court this summer.

title: No Headline
description: THE exhibition pace at the Hudson River Museum is getting quite hectic these days. On hand now is a show of Jacob Lawrence paintings (through May 9) and, to be covered at a later date, a retrospective by the photographer Eve Sonneman. There is also a video performance by David Behrman and Paul de Marinis that invites viewer participation.

title: FEMINISM TAKES ALL KNOWLEDGE AS ITS PROVINCE
description: How did the growing power of city councils, rather than tradesmen's guilds, make it easier for women to enter the labor force in Renaissance Tuscany? How did Queen Elizabeth's cult of chastity reinforce patriarchal structures in Renaissance England? How did having Queen Elizabeth as premier reader affect Spencer's rhetoric in ''The Faerie Queene''?

title: Business Conditions; PAPERBOARD OUTPUT LAGS
description: After declining steadily through the second half of 1981, production and shipments of paperboard - useful indicators of economic activity - are showing few signs of a rebound in what generally is the start of a busy season for manufacturers.

title: REDEFINING POVERTY: SOME INTERESTING BUT LOADED CHOICES
description: Almost since the War on Poverty began in the 1960's, there has been a dispute about whether the Government was winning it. If anything, last week's Census Bureau report on ways of counting who's poor demonstrated how difficult the question is to answer.

title: Q and A
description: Question:I want to go to the Middle East next year. Can you tell me what the best months are, from the point of view of weather, for Israel and Egypt? I am available from November through April. - E.J.H., New York, N.Y. Answer:Israel's weather during December and January can vary from cold with rainy squalls - even occasional snowfalls - in Jerusalem and northern Israel to much milder weather in the Negev, the desert in the southern part of the country.

title: Reader Comment; IN DEFENSE OF PAC'S
description: To the Business Editor: Barbara R. Bergmann's ''Lobbying: Shakedown on Capitol Hill'' (April 4), does not reflect the devotion to scholarly accuracy and impartiality that many people expect from academia.

title: JAPAN, MEET WOODY ALLEN
description: TOKYO After nearly a decade, foreign celebrities are no longer the advertising novelty they once were. In the last year or so, Japanese advertisers have grown picky. Not just any famous foreigner will do.

title: HE DREW FROM HIS BOYHOOD TO MAKE 'DINER'
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Stephen Farber is a freelance writer based in Los Angeles. BY STEPHEN FARBER

title: The World; by Barbara Slavin and Milt Freudenheim; The Queen Cuts Canada's Strings
description: Britain has long been willing to sever the last colonial ties to Canada, but as in the Falklands, the local population has been the obstacle. In Canada's case, the 10 provinces had been unable to agree on a new constitution to supersede the made-in-Westminster British North America Act of 1867.

title: HOLOCAUST PROGRAMS PLANNED
description: IN COMMUNITIES throughout the state, memorial programs will be held this week for the 11 million civilians, including six million Jews, who were killed by the Nazis.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THREE prominent business executives, Peter Dugan, Michael McGrath and Joseph A. (Bo) Sullivan, and a Montclair lawyer, Raymond R. Connell - all good friends of Governor Kean - have organized a charitable extravaganza to help the widow and three young children of Philip Lamonaco, the much-decorated state trooper who was slain on Interstate 80 last December.

title: MARKET SOUGHT FOR LOCK
description: PUSH buttons are a part of today's home comforts. If, for example, you want to call a friend, you can tap a push-button phone. If you need to do your tax returns, a push-button calculator comes in handy. And now, push buttons can be a part of your home security system.

title: STUDY SHOWS BLACKS CLOSED LEARNING GAP
description: Black children closed the gap on whites in educational achievement tests in the 1970's, a new study of national test results shows. The relative improvement, the study's author says, may be tied to blacks' increased motivation to succeed.

title: Sports People; Top Players Back Borg
description: The world's two top-ranked men's singles players both have come to the defense of Bjorn Borg, who announced Friday that he would not play this year at the Wimbledon tournament that he has won five times.

title: Canal Cruises
description: To the Editor: The comment on the Mid-Lakes Navigation Company cruises in the Q & A column (Travel, March 14) states that the price on the Erie Canal and Finger Lakes cruises includes ''meals and cabins.'' Actually, there are no cabins; overnight accommodations, which are included in the fare, are at motels and hotels along the way. We have taken several of the canal trips and recommend them highly, especially the one from Syracuse to Buffalo. WILLIAM KINGSBURY Moorestown, N.J.

title: TAX BREAKS ON OLD HOUSES
description: DESPITE the attractiveness of the Federal Government's new tax incentives for the rehabilitation of old or h istoric structures, many property owners are not taking advantage oft he benefits because of the complexity of the provisions.

title: CORRECTION
description: Correction In a beauty article on April 4, the Magazine inadvertently estimated the number of people who are underweight in this country, citing the book ''Food, Nutrition and Diet Therapy.'' The passage actually cited referred not to the number of Americans underweight, but to that category of the population that is ''15 to 20 percent or more below the normal accepted weight standards.''

title: W. HARTFORD ATHLETE IN THE BIG LEAGUES
description: year-old catcher from West Hartford, was so impressive during the recent spring training session that he was kept with the club when the Atlanta Braves returned to their home base. In the last two decades, it's been relatively rare for a product of Connecticut's diamonds to gain a berth on a big league squad.

title: White Sox Win 2 And Stay Unbeaten
description: The unbeaten Chicago White Sox won their sixth and seventh games of the season tonight by sweeping a doubleheader from the Baltimore Orioles.

title: The Nation; by Michael Wright and Caroline Rand Herron; Reagan's Bow to Private Schools
description: The Reagan Administration continues to be consistent in its commitment to private enterprise, even in education. In Chicago last week the President outlined his promised legislation to give income tax credits to families whose children attend non-segregated private elementary and secondary schools.

title: Topics; TERMINOLOGY, TERMINATIONS; Proud Mary
description: A Mary of our acquaintance, who was named after her mother who was named after her aunt who was named after her mother and so on right into Eden, is not taking the toppling of her name from New York City's Top Ten at all well. It is now number 37, down there in the cellar with Katherine and Margaret (her children) and Esther (her aunt).

title: Renee Miller Married
description: Renee Miller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Miller of Fort Lee, N.J., was married yesterday to Judd Pillot, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Pillot of Haworth, N.J. State Supreme Court Justice Maxine Duberstein performed the ceremony at the Harkness House in New York. The bride is a multimedia producer for Comart Aniforms, producers of corporate audio-visual productions in New York, where Mr. Pillot is a television producer for A.H. Perlmutter Inc.

title: Barbara Butt Has Nuptials
description: Barbara Elder Butt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph L. Butt of East Brunswick, N.J., and Peter Trowbridge Gill, son of Mr.and Mrs. Robert Lee Gill of New York, were married yesterday in St. Vincent Ferrer's Roman Catholic Church. The Very Rev. Michael Trainor performed the ceremony.

title: Record Baptist Collection
description: Southern Baptists have given $47,185,970, a record, to the Lottie Moon Christmas offering for mission operations, surpassing last year's collections by almost $3 million. The report on the mission fund was presented Wednesday at the semiannual meeting of the Southern Baptist Foreign Mission Board here. In other business, Gene W. Triggs, vice president of the Mississippi Chemical Corporation of Yazoo City, Miss., was elected chairman of the foreign mission board.

title: THE NEW 'INFORMATION POLICY' MEANS A LESS INFORMED PUBLIC
description: In the years after Watergate, when Congress moved to install a new openness in Government, secrecy became almost a synonym for evil. Many hands made efforts to open the file drawers of Government. But as the 10th anniversary of the ''third rate'' burglary at the Watergate complex approaches, there is agreement and some worry that the pendulum is swinging back.

title: IN DEFENSE OF ANGER ON ABORTION ISSUE
description: ON March 30, some men sat behind their desks, looked us in the eye and coolly told us that they would sign our death warrants. No, we are not sitting convicted of coldblooded murder, and the men are not judges sentencing us. They are state legislators, and we are women (mostly) who had come to Albany to plead that abortion remain legal. It was the annual Albany lobbying day of the Westchester Coalition for Legal Abortion.

title: MONITERING THE FLIGHTS OF WILD BIRDS
