description: FAIRFIELD CLUTCHING a copy of the Audubon Field Guide to North American Birds in one hand, a camera dangling around his neck, 13-year-old Kenneth Croll of Fairfield gently stroked the head of the small, wild songbird that was about to become an unwitting participant in a scientific study.

title: 2 Jersey Nuclear Plants Are Closed by Problems
description: Two of the three nuclear generating plants in New Jersey shut down automatically when they developed problems today. The third plant was already out of service.

title: SUZANNE MICELI ENGAGED
description: Announcement has been made of the engagement of Suzanne Annette Miceli, daughter of Mrs. Lee Robison and Joseph Miceli both of New York, to Stanley Berrie, son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Berrie of Brookville, L.I. A June wedding is planned. Miss Miceli is national retail sales manager for Evyan Perfumes Inc., of which her mother is executive vice president. Mr. Berrie is president of Naomi Manufacturing Inc., jewelry designers, in New York.

title: AN AUTISTIC CHILD IN BARCELONA
description: ''Mater Amatisima,'' written and directed by a talented new Spanish director named Jose A. Salgot, is as obsessive as the horror story it tells about a pretty, intelligent, unmarried young woman, Clara (Victoria Abril), and the autistic child who comes to absorb her life. The setting is modern Barcelona, a place of high-rise apartment blocks, computerized industry and severely efficient clinics, but the film's antecedents are in the work of Edgar Allan Poe.

title: HONOLULU MOST COSTLY, WITH NEW YORK THIRD
description: A survey of 25 major metropolitan areas in the nation shows that Honolulu, Anchorage, New York, Boston and Washington are the most expensive places for a family of four to maintain a moderate standard of living, the Government has reported.

title: A WOOD BURNER'S SPRINGTIME CELEBRATION
description: THAT applause we hear is for the shoots of crocuses. Now we listen intently for the snap of sails on Long Island Sound. We eagerly anticipate the bouquet of dogwoods and forsythias. Springtime in Connecticut. Ah!

title: ARGENTINA GLOOMY ON ACCORD AS HAIG CONTINUES TALKS
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. held further meetings today with Argentine leaders seeking to avert hostilities with Britain over the Falkland Islands, but senior Argentine officials and foreign diplomats were gloomy about the possibility of a breakthrough.

title: RETIREES RESTORING WARPLANES
description: GARDEN CITY ''THEY'RE a very young group of older people,'' said Jake Bussolini, director of business operations for the Grumman Aerospace Corporation. He was talking about the 35 members of the company's Retirees' Club, aged from the late 60's to the advanced 70's, who have been engaged during the last several years in rehabilitating World War II aircraft and lunar modules for display in exhibitions.

title: SOLAR UNITS AIDING VALLEY'S POOR
description: Residents of the San Luis Valley are turning to the sun and their own handicraft for a cheaper form of power.

title: BUSINESSES SEEKING ENERGY ECONOMIES
description: WHIPPANY WHILE the Board of Public Utilities and the state's utilities cautiously tiptoe into experiments with energy conservation, some New Jersey businesses already are taking giant steps.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
COMPOSERS ALLIANCE
description: Members of the Long Island Composers Alliance will be busy this week showcasing their efforts. Today at 7:30 P.M. at the C.W. Post Center's Great Hall in Brookville, the works of Irwin Swack and Gary Washington will be featured, and on Saturday at 8 P.M. at the Nassau County Museum of Fine Art, Northern Boulevard in Roslyn Harbor, music by Arline Diamond, Herbert Deutsch, Herbert Feldman, William Goldberg, Marga Richter, Avraham Sternklar and Serge Suny will be performed. Both concerts are free.

title: NOTEBOOK: AFTERMATH OF THE MARIN TRIAL
description: SOME trials have dramatic endings, but few have two dramatic endings. That was the case with the Stouffer's Inn trial, however. On a Saturday night, just a week ago, the jury said Luis Marin was guilty. On Wednesday, Judge Lawrence N. Martin Jr. said he was not.

title: HAMPSHIRE COLLEGE RECEIVES $5 MILLION GIFT FROM FOUNDER
description: With its apple orchards and spacious fields, Hampshire College has always been well endowed by nature. But the 12-year-old institution was operating without much of a financial cushion until it announced that it had received a $5 million bequest, tripling its endowment.

title: by A. Esmat Abdel Meguid
description: The coordinating bureau of the non-aligned movement held a meeting in Kuwait from April 5 to 8 in support of the Palestinians. I had the honor to represent Egypt, my country, at this meeting, where I outlined my Government's position on the question of Palestine.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
ARCHITECTURAL SPLENDOR
description: For its annual foray into updating relics of the Island's architectural past with contemporary room settings, the Designers' Showcase starts a six-week stand at the former Gould-Guggenheim estate at the Sands Point Park and Preserve with a champagne preview today from 1 to 5 P.M. On Monday, ''Castles on the Sound,'' which benefits the North Shore Child Guidance Association, will start its regular run and will be open from 10:30 A.M. to 4 P.M. weekdays and from noon to 5 P.M. weekends and Memorial Day. Regular admission is $6; the preview will be $35. For reservations, call 883-6900.

title: THE CITY OF ANGELS AND AUTOS
description: L.A.FREEWAY An Appreciative Essay. By David Brodsly. Illustrated. 178 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $17.95.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: IN more than a few 19th-century novels, mothers warned their daughters of the evils of the city, which would inevitably sap their moral fiber, undermine their ethical underpinnings, take advantage of their innocence and drop them in the gutter in a blizzard.

title: Mailbox; A FITTING SALUTE TO CREDIDIO
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: DAILY NEWS TALKS TO BE SPEEDED UP
description: Bargainers for the unions at The Daily News and for Joe L. Allbritton, who is seeking to acquire the newspaper, say they intend to speed up their negotiations to meet a deadline next Sunday for an agreement on contract concessions to save the threatened newspaper.

title: JOHN G. PARSONS TO MARRY KATHRYN POND MCCARTHY
description: Mr. and Mrs. Warren Bjorklund of White Bear Lake, Minn., have announced the engagement of her daughter, Kathryn Pond McCarthy, to John Geddes Parsons, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harris B. Parsons of Barrington, R. I.

title: HELPING PARENTS TALK TO CHILDREN
description: ''IT was the letter from India that did it,'' said Adele Faber of Roslyn. The time was two years ago, and she and Elaine Mazlish, her Roslyn neighbor and collaborator, were already receiving appeals from readers to write a sequel to ''Liberated Parents/Liberated Children,'' their successful, award-winning 1974 book on dealing with children.

title: CAMPAIGNING REPUBLICANS ASSERTING INDEPENDENCE
description: Representative Jim Coyne was working his way through a shopping mall in this Philadelphia suburb, grabbing hands and greeting potential voters, when he was approached by Ron Rita, a young student. Mr. Rita asked if the Congressman was going to support more cuts in student aid programs.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ART One of the great pleasures of living in New York is that we see Saul Steinberg's cartoons almost as soon as they get off the press. Steinberg has a way with words, and a way with people, and a way with architecture, and when the three of them get to pull in the same direction they put us in a good humor for the rest of the day.

title: Shopper's World; BOSTON'S FAVORITE BARGAIN STORE
description: DEBORAH BLUMENTHAL is a writer who lives in New York. BY DEBORAH BLUMENTHAL

title: Index; International
description: Schmidt party's congress may raise new problems for him 3 U.S. envoy, in Cairo, says he is confident on Sinai exit 3 New edition of Roget's Thesaurus curbs ''sexist'' categories 4 Around the World 5 Mitterrand, in Japan, stresses high-technology industries 7 Memo by Marcos sets off Asem- bly debate over succession 9 Greece demands Britain return the Elgin Marbles 10 Greeks say U.S. agreed on 2 key demands in base talks 11 Thailand celebrates a birthday and the traditional New Year 13 Honduras is losing faith in U.S. as problems mount 14 U.S. envoy gets mixed reviews in Morocco 16 Display of Leonardo de Vinci's codex dazzles Florence 17 Soviet-Argentine trade has surged in last two years 18 Government/Politics Block resists moves to use fund for emergency farm loans 22 Costliest cities are Honolulu, An- chorage and New York 23 Reagan Administration is halting aid to prepaid health programs 26 Chicago Mayor offers plan to reorganize housing authority 27 Moderate Republicans assert in- dependence from Reagan 40 Gallup Poll reports most see a Reagan 1984 candidacy 40 Albany Notes: tax break for Con- gress to help legislators, too 64 General Multibillion-dollar system pro- posed to preserve rain forests 19 Milwaukee stores boycotted over police brutality issue 28 Around the Nation 30 The Mississippi delta: A world that shrugs at change 30 Allbritton and Daily News unions to speed up talks 41 Arts/Entertainment Angeles Gulin performs in 'I Ves- pri Siciliani' 65 New York Consort of Viols revis- its old Versailles 65 Philadelphia's Zero Moving Dance Company performs 65 'Yossele Golem,' world premiere of Israeli's play 65 Peabody award won by cable TV program 66 Aaron Rosan plays Tchaikovsky' Violin Concerto 66 Mstislav Rostropovich presents Tchaikovsky's opera ''Iolanta'' 66 'Mater Amatisima,' Spanish hor- ror story, opens 66 Judson Dance Theater Recon- structions offered 66 The debuts of young musicians are reviewed 66 Country band Asleep at the Wheel appears at cabaret 66 Peter Katin, British pianist, gives recital 67 Phoebe Neville offers a new dance work, ''Palantir'' 67 ''Livingstone and Sechele'' is staged at Quaigh Theater 67 Style The beard fad may be facing a blank future 68 News Analysis Drew Middleton on British Navy's outlook in Falklands 18

title: THE JERUSALEM OF DAVID
description: Hills and sparkling domes, sound of the marketplace at the gates of the Old City, monotonous, melancholy sing-song voices from houses of study, homeless beggars, newly arriving pilgrims - the human tumult made of so many religions, so many nations, so many memories: Jerusalem holds you and never eases its grip. No other city in the world exerts such a hold on a visitor. You plunge into it as into a poem, you depart reluctantly and with a sad heart.

title: WHERE ALCOHOLICS CAN FIND HOPE
description: Garden City East Veronica, a 42-year-old widow, had been drinking steadily for 15 years. During that time her longest sobriety was os sic months' duration. "The court had me up for child neglect," she said recently. "I had to sign my children over to foster care. I'm grateful to be here."

title: HOW THE POLL WAS CONDUCTED
description: The New York Times poll of members of the N.F.L. Players Association was conducted by telephone during a four-day period that began last Monday using telephone numbers obtained for 1,500 of the 1,558 players on league rosters.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF STATEMENT BY PRESIDENT
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's radio broadcast address from Camp David yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News:

title: RESOLVED: MOTHER-IN-LAW DAY AND PEACH MONTH COST PLENTY
description: Each year, members of Congress introduce hundreds of resolutions praising such things as peaches and patriotism, bald eagles and ballet.

title: Robert M. Norris Dies; Expert in Foreign Trade
description: Robert M. Norris, former president and a director of the National Foreign Trades Council, died yesterday at his home in Sneden's Landing in Palisades, N.Y. He was 72 years old.

title: Fire Truck Accident Disrupts L.I.R.R. Shea Stadium Runs
description: A 25-ton fire engine dispatched to put out a small blaze at an IRT subway station fell through an adjoining wooden boardwalk used by Long Island Rail Road passengers, forcing the L.I.R.R. to suspend service to the station.

title: SUNDAY DRIVERS GO BUGGY RIDING
description: TAKING a Sunday drive doesn't necessarily involve the automobile. For members of the Connecticut Valley Driving Club it means getting out the old horse and buggy and bowling along country dirt roads as far away as possible from the fumes and noise of modern-day traffic.

title: TWO DECADES OF A RUSSIAN GIANT
description: TOLSTOI IN THE SIXTIES By Boris Eikhenbaum. Translated by Duffield White. 255 pp. Ann Arbor: Ardis. $25.

title: PAMELA SIMMONS PENN WILL BE BRIDE
description: Dr. Vivian-Sue Penn of Cranbury, N.J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Pamela Simmons Penn, to William Christian Morine, a son of John P. Morine of Malden, Mass., and West Bath, Me., and the late Donna T. Morine of Arlington, Mass., and West Bath, Me.

title: Around the World; Police in India Kill 2 In Riot Over Language
description: The police shot and killed two rioters and wounded two others today in Bangalore after a movie star spoke to a crowd about language rights, authorities said.

title:
CAREFUL SHOPPER;
Serving White Plains The French Way
description: La Gourmandise, opened four years ago at Maple and Mamaroneck Avenues in White Plains, has established itself as a source for fresh daily office snacks a la Fran,caise. The eclairs and the Napoleons, with either custard or whipped cream and raspberries, are 90 cents each; the plain croissants are 65 cents, but when filled with apricot or chocolate are 75 cents; with almond they are 85 cents, and with ham and cheese are $1.25. Kiwi or strawberry tarts are $1.15, just reduced from the winter price of $1.30; large apple turnovers are 75 cents, and brioche are 60 cents.

title: By JOHN RATHER
description: EAST HAMPTON TWO months after the fact, a surprise decision by the Town Board to abolish the Town Planning Department remains a pre-eminent issue among residents in this area, where land use is a primary civic concern.

title: ALBANY CONDUCTING RENTAL BIAS INQUIRY
description: THE State Attorney General, Robert Abrams, is investigating rent discrimination against families with children on Long Island, as well as elsewhere in the state, where the housing squeeze has hit singleparent families particularly hard.

title: PEABODY AWARD WON BY CABLE TV PROGRAM
description: For the first time in its 42-year history, the George Foster Peabody Broadcasting Award has gone to a program made for cabletelevision distribution rather than network.

title: AN EMPIRE IN BLACK BUSINESS
description: Last week, Travers J. Bell Jr., chairman and founder of the only black-owned New York Stock Exchange member firm, lost in his attempt to take control of the Freedom National Bank, the only black-owned commercial bank in New York. Mr. Bell, who is 42 years old, vows to continue the battle, but even if he fails, Mr. Bell is building a growing financial empire that stretches from Brooklyn to Africa.

title: QUESTIONABLE COUNSELORS OF 'NO FIRST USE'
description: To the Editor:

title: SEA-ANIMAL CENTER IN FINANCIAL STRAITS
description: ATLANTIC CITY UNLESS government or private financing is obtained in the next several months, the Marine Mammal Stranding Center, which tries to save dolphins, sea turtles and other animals, and does research on the causes of their deaths, will close.

title: Run It Down The Flagpole, Says London
description: Argentina's blue-and-white striped flag still flew over the Falkland Islands last week, but for 200 miles around, British nuclear-powered submarines apparently ruled the waves. Except for a dash by two small patrol boats to the Malvinas, as Argentines call the islands, Buenos Aires let the blockade go untested. The Argentine fleet put to sea but did not initially sail into Britain's no-go zone.

title: CAMPUS ACTIVITY TURNS TO POLITICS
description: THE days of the Vietnam War, the civil rights movement and largescale student activism supposedly ended more than a decade ago. At Wesleyan University, that spirit lives on for many students.

title: DAFFODIL SOCIETY SHOW
description: The New Jersey Daffodil Society's eighth annual Standard Flower Show will be held next Saturday at the Presbyterian Church hall on Sycamore Avenue in Shrewsbury.

title: No Headline
description: In his book ''The Dental Physician,'' Dr. Al Fonder found that a 99 percent correlation exists between women who suffer from excessive menstrual problems and women who also suffer from temporomandibular joint problems. The temporomandibular is that joint found in front of each ear and one can feel it in motion when one opens or closes one's mouth. Dr. Fonder found that women suffering from such disturbances who also have severe menstrual problems have found the menstrual problems improve or disappear completely when the temporomandibular problem is corrected. JAN WADE GILBERT, D.M.D., Lynbrook, L.I.

title: SRI LANKA PUTS MODERN TWIST IN ANCIENT EPIC
description: A committee of scholars, appointed and paid for by the Government, has recently extended Sri Lanka's 1,500-yearold epic to cover the period 1936 to 1957 so that such developments as air conditioning and aluminum cans are now rendered in the same kind of verse used to chronicle the succession of ancient kings and the evolution of Buddhist traditions on the island.

title: Chess; HOW TO MAKE USE OF AN ADVANTAGE
description: There is a lot to be said for aiming toward positions where one feels at home rather than aiming toward advantageous positions in general. Having the advantage is no advantage if one does not know what to do with it.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Film View; ROBERT ALTMAN-AN ENDANGERED SPECIES
description: What are we going to do about Robert Altman? It's difficult to talk about him without making him sound like some sort of household problem, like waxy buildup or clogged drains. He's an essential part of the American film scene that requires constant care. Left unattended, he goes wrong. Carried away by his own enthusiasm, he spends too much money on the sort of movie that can't possibly recoup its investment, or too much time on small details while losing sight of the overall project.

title: NEW LOOK IN POETRY READINGS
description: MIXING verse and video, a series of three poetry readings has been drawing audiences - afterward refreshed by wine and cheese -to cultural and historic sites around the state.

title: SILVER LINING WITH CLOUD
GASOLINE TAX REVENUE IS A SLOW, RELUCTANT TRICKLE
description: When gasoline prices were going through the roof, and the profits of oil companies likewise, state officials eyed ''big oil'' as a source of badly needed funds. But falling prices, combined with cheating at the pumps, thorny litigation and Federal tax changes, have turned a vision of vast new revenues into a reality of diminishing returns.

title: TIGERS TOP YANKS; SWAN IS EFFECTIVE FOR FIVE INNINGS
description: When Tim Raines tried to steal second base in the first inning yesterday and Craig Swan didn't get hurt, it was a good sign for the Mets.

title: CUBAN-AMERICAN BEING HELD BY HAVANA RELEASED TO U.S.
description: A Cuban-born American citizen who was held in a Cuban jail for 11 weeks for unspecified ''subversive activities'' has been released and returned to the United States following protests from the Reagan Administration and 26 Congressmen.

title: 2 NEW YACHTS MAKE A SPLASH
description: Smash, splash. Judy Conner, wife of the syndicate helmsman, Dennis Conner, cracked the champagne bottle across the bow of the sleek, white 12-Meter yacht, previously known as Hull No. 34, christening her Spirit of America.

title: FROM MAGAZINES TO MUSEUMS
description: BROOKVILLE DO you remember her, the Gibson Girl, with her valentine lips, self-possessed nose, sophisticated eyes and nipped hips? Or the young housewife by Christy, the flawless embodiment of the American feminine ideal? And do you recall the rotund postmen, the robust mechanics and the rapt young boys intensely listening to war stories told in a garage by a young marine recently returned home?

title: AGE NO BARRIER FOR MODELS
description: MODELING is a profession that has been dominated by young women, such as Brooke Shields and her peers. But some Connecticut women are becoming part of a growing industry trend; they are middle-aged models.

title: Up to 40% of Big Fires Set, Insurance Researchers Say
description: A 12-state study of large fires in 1980 indicates that, depending on the type of building and insurance policy involved, arson was responsible for 11 percent to 40 percent of the blazes.

title: THE RETURN OF THE GYPSY MOTH
description: AUTHORITIES on the subject of the gypsy moth seem to feel that there will be no significant collapse in the population of this pest in the near future, although there may be seasonal ups and downs from one area to another. It would appear likely that the areas that experienced severe damage last year can look forward to a similar experience this year and that adjacent areas will see an increase in damage from the spillover.

title: Weber Captures First Pro Bowling Tourney
description: Pete Weber won his first tournament as a professional today when he turned in three-game total of 674 to defeat Pete McCordic in the $100,000 Greater Hartford Open tournament.

title: BATTERY PARK CITY: THE NEWEST PRESTIGE ADDRESS
description: BY fits and starts, Battery Park City is emerging along the Hudson R iver near the southern tip of Manhattan as New York's premier new h ousing and commercial development.

title:
ANTIQUES;
DESIGN OF CARD TABLES STUDIED
description: NEW HAVEN FOR what is probably the first time, a detailed computer study of a particular American furniture form has been completed and used to analyze work by specific cabinetmakers and their colleagues in various regions along the Atlantic Coast.

title: CAPTURING GERSHWIN'S GENIUS
description: On Nov. 1, 1923, a singer named Eva Gauthier, who was a contemporary-music specialist, gave a recital in New York's Aeolian Hall, which was the Alice Tully Hall of its day. Her program included Bartok, Hindemith and Schoenberg. It also included a selection of songs from American musical revues by Irving Berlin, Jerome Kern, Walter Donaldson and George Gershwin, accompanied by Gershwin himself, shy and awkward and earnest at the piano.

title: Ideas and Trends; by Eva Hoffman and Margot Slade; Gorsuch Promise Raises Questions
description: Was it legal? Apparently. Was it proper? Some think not. On Dec.11, representatives of Thriftway Company of New Mexico told Anne M. Gorsuch, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, that their company faced financial ruin if it could not add more lead to gasoline than is allowed under the Clean Air Act. Mrs. Gorsuch responded by giving ''her word on nonenforcement'' if the small oil refinery violated the Federal lead standards, according to a report last week by the E.P.A.'s inspector general, Matthew Novick.

title: LAROUSSE'S DICTIONARY IS SMART AND CONCISE
description: If there is such a thing as a work of reference that I cannot read through, I have yet to find it. Catalogues, timetables, chronicles of alumnus and alumna, Companions and Concordances of every kind - all are a joy to me. As for dictionaries of painters and painting, I bite into them the way jackal bites into gazelle.

title: Martin Evans Weds Margaret Harwood
description: Margaret Kidder Harwood, a vice president and account supervisor at Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, a New York advertising agency, was married yesterday to Martin Frederic Evans, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Evans of Nashville. The Rev. Philip B. Roulette performed the ceremony in the Immanuel Episcopal Church in Glencoe, Md.

title: FUTURISTIC AIR TRAFFIC CONTROL SYSTEM PRESSED AS ANSWER TO NEEDS OF NATION
description: Pilots and air traffic controllers should be able to perform their jobs with greater ease, economy and safety, Federal officials say, if the Government is able to win Congressional backing for a sweeping modernization of today's air traffic control system.

title: Clash in Zimbabwe Reported
description: A Zimbabwean soldier has been killed and three were wounded in a clash with dissident troops loyal to the opposition leader Joshua Nkomo. The Zimbabwe national press agency, quoting ministers in Prime Minister Robert Mugabe's office, said today that the rebels were former guerrillas from Mr. Nkomo's forces who had deserted from the national army.

title: COSMOS' BOGICEVIC RETURNS TO LINEUP
description: The Cosmos begin their sixth North American Soccer League season at Giants Stadium against the Tampa Bay Rowdies Sunday afternoon.

title: Claire Picone Is Married To Richard F. Powell 3d
description: Claire Theresa Picone, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence A. Picone of Edison, N.J., was married yesterday to Richard F. Powell 3d, son of Mrs. Richard Powell Jr. of Metuchen, N.J., and the late Mr. Powell. The Rev. Ronald Parker of St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Bound Brook, N.J., performed the ceremony at the Plainfield (N.J.) Country Club.
Size: 16 to 25 inches long, including a 7 1/2- to 10 1/2-inch tail.

title: Sports of The Times; The Voices Only Denis Potvin Hears
description: THE moment Denis Potvin skates onto the Madison Square Garden ice tonight, the Islander defenseman will be greeted by the unkind voices of the Ranger loyalists who love to hate him.

title: A Tardy Tax Report?  Don't Worry, but ...
description: If the income tax filing deadline caught you behind by a day or two, don't worry too much: The Internal Revenue Service says you probably will not be punished.

title: LOSS OF AID FOR ISABELLD UNSETTLING BROOKHAVEN
description: UPTON INSIDE a cavernous building where scientists are struggling to manufacture the vital components for the Brookhaven National Laboratory's troubled $465 million nuclear accelerator, an overhead crane with a capacity of 15 tons swung into action one afternoon last week. Clanking and swaying, the pulley hoisted its 15-foot-long payload, carried it across the room and lowered it over a nearly identical twin.

title: Washington; PROTEST OR DEBATE?; by James Reston
description: One of the many questions about the future of nuclear weapons is whether the people of the United States and the other allied nations will get enough facts on this immensely complicated military and moral issue for the searching inquiry the subject requires. In short, will it be decided by government decision, by public education or by political demonstrations.

title: Investing; BUYING A PIECE OF A SHOPPING CENTER
description: Limited partnerships used to mean oil wells, especially in the days before supply caught up with demand. But there are limited partnerships that invest in other ventures - like shopping centers - and the returns sometimes can be stunning.

title: FEELINGS RUN HIGH ON CASINO-BUS PLAN
description: ATLANTIC CITY APLAN to regulate the hundreds of buses that bring gamblers to this resort city each day produced both lively support and heated opposition at a public hearing last week.

title: Artists' Conference On A-War Tomorrow
description: A weeklong conference sponsored by Artists Against Nuclear Madness will open Monday evening with a program of talks by Colleen Dewhurst, Jane Alexander, Michio Kaku, Daniel Berrigan, Alice Neel and Jules Feiffer.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Bus Hunt
description: The never-ending search for the perfect bus for New York City's crowded, bumpy streets turned global last year. Hino Motors of Japan offered two samples in June: a compact model with cushioned seats and double-width rear doors.

title: INTEREST HIGH IN SPECIAL ALBANY RACES
description: Democrats in the Ninth Assembly District in southwestern Suffolk County have received letters and phone calls seeking their support in Tuesday's special election for the Assembly. The letters were prepared at a storefront office on Lark Street in Albany, and some of the calls came from a union headquarters on Park Place in Manhattan.

title: OF ADOLESCENTS
description: WOULD teaching young people how to drink have a sobering effect on our teen-agers? Or would a statewide program of education on alcohol abuse be a vain attempt to stem the flood of teen-age drinking that increasingly alarms parents, educators, the police, doctors and government officials - in fact, all of society?

title: WOMEN'S LACROSSE GAINING
description: TWO years ago the Westchester Women's Lacrosse Association was nearly dead, and few outside the tight community of women's lacrosse would have mourned its passing. But now a band of determined women, some from Westchester County and Fairfield County and others from New York City, grab lacrosse sticks each weekend and undergo the rigorous training necessary to build the stamina and skill for tournament play.

title: ANCIENT AND MODERN JUDAIC LANDMARKS
description: MOSHE BRILLIANT is on the staff of The Times bureau in Jerusalem. BY MOSHE BRILLIANT

title: Medicaid Payments: 2 Views on the System
description: This responds to the article entitled ''Medicaid's Bureaucratic Blockade'' by Caren Goldberg, in the issue of March 21. In the article, Mrs. Goldberg describes problems that she has had in receiving payment for Medicaid patients. Because of her concern with the provision of services and her sensitivity to the needs of Medicaid patients as well as the fact that she feels that she and her husband can no longer accept new Medicaid patients, I feel that another perspective may be helpful.

title: LENDL GAINS 15TH FINAL IN ROW
description: Top-seeded Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia gained his 15th consecutive tournament final today with a 6-3, 6-2 victory over Ecuador's Andres Gomez in the $300,000 World Championship Tennis Tournament.

title: SCIENCE IN PURSUIT OF HEALTHIER MOUTHS
description: ''THERE'S a lot more to dental decay than just a sweet tooth,'' said Dr. Michael C. Alfano, director of the Oral Health Research Center at the Fairleigh Dickinson University School of Dentistry.

title: INDIA CHOOSES FRENCH JET OVER A SOVIET PLANE
description: The French Defense Ministry announced today that India would buy 40 Mirage fighter-bombers and had taken an option to purchase 110 others.

title: Paperback Talk; by Ray Walters
description: The Yank at Penguin. What ever became of Peter Mayer, who was often called the most dynamic and innovative paperbounder on Publishers Row during the 13 years he spent building Avon Books from a midget into a giant mass-market house and the two years in which he revitalized a stagnating Pocket Books?

title: TRANSIT USERS DENOUNCE SYSTEM AT 'ACCOUNTABILITY SESSION'
description: More than 500 irate subway and bus riders packed into the auditorium of a West Side school yesterday to give low ratings to the city's transit system at the Straphangers Campaign's second annual ''accountability session.''

title: Beer in Prague
description: To the Editor: Henry Kamm has made a common error regarding the alcoholic content of European beer in his article ''Prague's Foamy Delights'' (Travel, March 14). The concentration of solids in unfermented beer is measured in degrees Plato or degrees Balling and is expressed on most European beer labels as oP.

title: Crime Victims Week Is Set
description: President Reagan on Thursday proclaimed the week of April 19 as Crime Victims Week, saying, ''Innocent victims of crime have frequently been overlooked by our criminal justice system.''

title: California
description: To the Editor: I would like to add one more delight to the list of wines, bread and cheeses listed in the article ''What's Doing in Sonoma'' (Travel, March 28).

title: THE RETURN OF THE GYPSY MOTH
description: AUTHORITIES on the subject of the gypsy moth seem to feel that there will be no significant collapse in the population of this pest in the near future, although there may be seasonal ups and downs from one area to another. It would appear likely that the areas that experienced severe damage last year can look forward to a similar experience this year and that adjacent areas will see an increase in damage from the spillover.

title: REFINERS SPLIT OVER RULES ON LEAD IN GASOLINE
description: The petroleum refining industry has showed that it is divided over proposals by the Environmental Protection Agency to rescind, relax or otherwise change rules limiting the lead content of gasoline.

title: WHY JEWS WORRY
description: Dear Cousin, I am writing to you - a leader of an important Jewish organization - because I'm worried. So is every Jew I know. Israel appears to be hurtling toward disaster, and the Diaspora is not far behind, with anti-Semitism increasing alarmingly. Many Israelis are publicly searching their souls, but American Jews are largely silent. Where are their voices?

title: EXPERTS AGREE KOCH PICKS JUDGES IMPARTIALLY
description: In the more than four years Mayor Koch has been making judicial appointments, he has kept his pledge to erase politics from the system, both critics and admirers say.

title: Mets Are Beaten by Expos, 7-6
description: Despite three two-run homers, two by Dave Kingman and another by George Foster, the Mets lost by 7-6 to the Montreal Expos at Shea Stadium yesterday.

title: K. Switzer Is an Old Boy
description: IF it hadn't been cold and snowy in Boston 15 years ago, Kathy Switzer might not be a television commentator at the Boston Marathon today. She would not have become one of the historic figures in America's most famous road race - like the two unrelated John Kelleys, or like Will Cloney and Jock Semple, the two officials who tried to take away her numerals in 1967.

title: HAIG, IN ARGENTINA, CITES OBLIGATIONS OF U.S. TO BRITAIN
description: Secretary of State Alexander M.Haig Jr., in remarks here apparently aimed at exerting pressure on Argentina in the Falkland Islands crisis, reaffirmed Sunday that the United States had longstanding obligations to Britain.

title: TOLERANT GUARDIANS OF OUR ENVIRONMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: TEACHING CLILDREN CHILD CARE
description: A scruffy blond-haired doll that had seen better days lay snugly wrapped in a green and white patterned quilt on a long metal table in the science laboratory at the Weston Middle School. In a few moments the doll would be picked up and burped, tossed over a shoulder, rocked back and forth, and generally treated like a baby.

title: A MOVEABLE 'DOOMSDAY' FOR SOCIAL SECURITY
description: To the Editor:

title: CARDS TOP PHILLIES FOR 8 STRAIGHT
description: Since the Atlanta Braves and the Chicago White Sox have yet to lose a game this season, the 9-3 record compiled by the St. Louis Cardinals may seem comparatively modest. But the last eight victories have come in succession, and five of them have been by the margin of one run, as was yesterday's 6-5 triumph over the Philadelphia Phillies in 11 innings at St. Louis.

title: SYRIAN-IRAQI WAR OF NERVES HEATING UP
description: The war of nerves between Syria and Iraq intensified over the weekend, with Syria calling for the overthrow of the Baghdad Government and Iraq vowing to organize an Arab economic boycott of the Damascus regime.

title: British Troops and Scientists From Falklands Are Deported
description: British marines and scientists deported early today by Argentina to Uruguay walked on the beach and played with a soccer ball but made no comments to the press.

title: BARBARA L. ARNSTEN IS MARRIED TO SETH ROSENZWEIG
description: Barbara Louise Arnsten, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Percy S. Arnsten of Maplewood, N.J., was married yesterday to Seth Edward Rosenzweig, son of Dr. and Mrs. Leonard Rosenzweig of Freeport, L.I. Rabbi Stephen Pearce performed the ceremony at the Unitarian House of Worship in Summit, N.J.

title: Favored Perrault 3d to Lemhi Gold
description: Lemhi Gold outraced the heavily favored Perrault in the stretch and pulled away to a decisive sevenlength victory today at Santa Anita in the 43d running of the $300,000 San Juan Capistrano Handicap.

title: SUSAN MAYERS MARRIED
description: The marriage of Susan Mayers of Stamford, Conn., to Harold Silverman of Norwalk, Conn., took place yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Emil Levin, parents of the bride, in Beechhurst, Queens.

title: McCarey Wins
description: Kevin McCarey, a former all-American at Villanova who is now with Athletics West in Eugene, Ore., ran away from the field of 620 to capture the Long Island Road Runners Club Half Marathon today.

title: JOYCE GOLDKLANG MARRIED TO ROBERT WAYNE BELLISH
description: Joyce Debra Goldklang, a daugher of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Goldklang of Hackensack, N.J., was married yesterday to Robert Wayne Bellish, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Bellish of the Bronx. Rabbi Eugene J. Lipsey performed the ceremony at Temple Emanuel in New Hyde Park, L.I.

title: Group Seeks U.S. InquiryIn 3 Texas Drownings
description: A spokesman for the Comanche Three Committee, a group that had sought felony charges in the drownings of three black youths in police custody, said Saturday that he would continue to push for a Federal investigation after the three officers involved were acquitted.

title: Youth, 15, Held In Two Murders
description: A 15-year-old youth has been charged with the murders of two elderly women who were robbed and slashed to death, one last week and the other last year, in their neighboring apartments in upper Manhattan, the police reported yesterday.

title: Noble Nashua 4th
description: Noble Nashua, considered the top older horse in the East, shocked most of the 21,185 bettors at Aqueduct yesterday by finishing last in a field of four in the $81,750 Bold Ruler Handicap.

title: OUTDOORS: DEEPLY INVOLVED IN THIN-WATER FISHING
description: water that barely comes to the knees - are as nervous as a teen-ager on his first date. The fish move up current out of the deep, green channels, and across the shallow flats where they root for bottom-dwelling invertebrates. The angler often has only one or two chances to cast his bait, lure or fly to them. The presentation must be near-perfect or the prey will be spooked, will hurtle away across the flat, its departure marked by a lengthening furrow.

title: Talks Resume Today On L.I.R.R. Contract
description: The management of the Long Island Rail Road and 15 of the commuter line's 17 unions planned to resume contract talks today.

title: American Symphony Celebrates Stokowski
description: The American Symphony Orchestra celebrated Leopold Stokowski's 100th birthday at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon. Stokowski founded the orchestra in 1962 and guided its fortunes for 10 years.

title: H. E. IVES WEDS SHELLEY MARDER
description: Dr. Shelley Ruth Marder, a research fellow in the rheumatology division at the San Francisco General Hospital of the University of California, was married yesterday to Dr. Harlan Eliot Ives, a research fellow in nephrology at the H. C. Moffitt Hospital of the University of California in San Francisco. Rabbi Mayer I. Perelmuter and cantor Judith Rowland performed the ceremony at the Hampshire House in New York.

title: TV: 'A MIDSUMMER NIGHT'S DREAM'
description: In a preface to tonight's presentation of ''A Midsummer Night's Dream,'' on WNET-TV at 9, Jonathan Miller, the producer, explains how it is still difficult for any director to tackle the play in the wake of Peter Brook's memorable 1970 stage version, which amounted to a ''preemptive strike of excellence.'' Mr. Brook, inspired by the artificiality of Persian theater, placed the play in a starkly white and bare gymnasium, pushing aside traditional sets and props so as to concentrate soley on the poetry. The result was indeed extraordinary.

title: PHOTOS FROM ANGKOR, THEN AND NOW
description: As part of a campaign to dramatize the need to preserve the magnificent ruins of the vast temple-city of Angkor in Cambodia, a beautiful and moving exhibition of more than 50 photographs has gone on display in the lobby of the United Nations General Assembly Building. The exhibition is moving for what it shows about the past and present - the past glory of Angkor, one of the archeological and artistic treasures of the world, and its current state of disrepair after a decade of war and neglect.

title: Paper Says It's a Boy
description: The Princess of Wales isn't expected to give birth until July, but that hasn't kept a London newspaper from reporting that the royal offspring will be a boy.

title: Bangladesh Ousts 18 Officials And Recalls 15 Ambassadors
description: Martial law authorities have recalled 15 ambassadors, including envoys to the United States and the Soviet Union, and have dismissed 18 senior domestic officials, the state-controlled press said today.

title: Little Radiation Danger Seen In Virginia Nuclear Plant Fire
description: No appreciable amounts of radiation escaped in a fire at the Surry nuclear power station, but it will take another day to determine exact levels of radiation leakage, a Nuclear Regulatory Commission spokesman said today.

title: MUSIC NOTED IN BRIEF
description: Frans Brueggen, John Gibbons and Anner Bylsma divided their talents between the 17th and 18th centuries Saturday at the Metropolitan Museum. There was a host of 17th-century Italian pieces, and these, along with a Telemann Trio Sonata in B flat, benefited especially from beautifully coordinated performances.

title: Peru Denounces Embargo
description: President Fernando Belaunde Terry of Peru said today that the European Common Market's trade embargo on Argentina was an attack on all Latin America. Peru and other nations in the Andean Pact said Saturday that they would increase trade with Argentina to offset the embargo, imposed bcause of Argentina's seizure of the Falkland Islands.

title: CAIRO AFFIRMS VOW ON PEACE PROCESS
description: President Reagan's special envoy to the Middle East met today with President Hosni Mubarak and said the Egyptian leader had affirmed that the Camp David accords were ''the only existing basis'' for peace in the Middle East.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BASKIN'S ART At age 15, Leonard Baskin, in the Federal Art project at the Educational Alliance, was sculpting a 250-pound block of marble he had found along the East River. This year, when turns 60, Mr. Baskin is still sculpting and painting with the same zeal he manifested as a Brooklyn boy of 1937.

title: Washington Watch; Money-Short Tax Court
description: WASHINGTON ''THERE really wasn't anything else we could do,'' said Charles S. Casazza, chief clerk of the United States Tax Court, describing efforts to save a little money by canceling all trial sessions for April and the first week in May.

title: WOMEN EMPLOYED BY WOMEN
description: THE last time Patricia O'Connor was looking for a job, the i nterviewer at an employment agency said, ''I have the perfect p osition for you.'' Then he paused and added, ''Oh, but it means w orking for a woman, and you wouldn't want that.''

title: MARCY ABELOW A BRIDE
description: Marcy J. Abelow, a daughter of Asher B. Abelow of Valley Stream, L.I. and the late Mrs. Abelow, was married yesterday to Stefan H. Ensler, a son of Adele Ensler of New York and the late Leon Ensler.

title: FRAN BLECHMAN, EXECUTIVE, BRIDE OF ALAN H. BERNSTEIN
description: Fran R. Blechman, a vice president and industry specialist for Merrill Lynch Pierce Fenner & Smith, and Alan H. Bernstein, coordinator of child care recruitment and training for the Jewish Board of Family & Children's Services, were married yesterday at the Harmonie Club in New York. Rabbi Jon Haddon performed the ceremony.

title: CITY OPERA: GRACE BUMBRY IN 'MEDEA'
description: CHERUBINI'S ''Medea'' is not a repertory opera and never will be, simply because sopranos come along only rarely who are both singers enough to handle its vocal gymnastics and actresses enough to chill the blood with its tale of inexorable horror. Eileen Farrell was singer enough in her heyday, but she never attempted the role on the stage, and a few other sopranos have been theatrically plausible in the role, including Marilyn Niska in the New York City Opera's production in the 1970's. But ''Medea,'' for most people, probably has meant Maria Callas. She defined and delineated the term singingactress in her portrayal of Cherubini's deranged sorceress, as recordings can testify.

title: GRAPHIC EVIDENCE IS HINCKLEY ISSUE
description: As John W. Hinckley Jr.'s trial for shooting President Reagan and three other men approaches, Judge Barrington D. Parker is considering whether to prevent the victims from testifying and to bar use of dramatic evidence showing how Mr. Hinckley shot them, and the nature of their injuries.

title: CABARET: SINGER-VIOLINIST
description: The Art Deco surroundings, the portraits of old film stars that line the walls and the synthetic glitter that twinkled through the restaurant and cabaret at 349 West 46th Street when it was Ted Hook's OnStage have all been expunged, replaced by a simple black-wall setting now that it has become Van Buren's. But the structure remains the same.

title: Charles Dodge Directs Synthesized Sounds
description: Charles Dodge, director of the Center for Computer Music at Brooklyn College, transforms ordinary talk with a synthesizer. His compositions playfully toy with sounds of speech, tease them, twist them and toss them about with acrobatic virtuosity.

title: SPECIAL $1 MILLION BONUS FOR GRACE'S TOP OFFICER
description: J. Peter Grace, 68-year-old chairman, chief executive officer and unquestionably the person in charge at W.R. Grace & Company, was given a $1 million ''special bonus'' last year, according to the proxy statement for the diversified corporation's annual meeting on May 10.

title: Padres 9, Dodgers 3
description: SAN DIEGO (AP) - Terry Kennedy hit a two-run double, and Broderick Perkins tripled in two more runs to highlight a seven-run eighth inning as San Diego completed its first four-game sweep over Los Angeles since 1969.

title: SIR WILLIE MORRIS, A DIPLOMAT
description: Sir Willie Morris, a retired British diplomat, died last Tuesday in Oxford, England, after a brief illness. He was 63 years old and a resident of Oxford.

title: Market Place; Art of Picking Growth Stocks
description: ''EMERGING growth stocks,'' those venturesome vehicles of Wall Street, have taken their lumps lately, along with many largecapitalization issues. Several brokerage firms have tailored their current selections in small stocks to the changing market and economic environment.

title: 215 Seized in Indian Rioting
description: The police rounded up more than 215 people as ''antisocial'' elements today in Bangalore after a day of fierce riots - fought over a language issue - in the southern city and the nearby town of Chitradurga. Two rioters were shot to death by policemen Saturday in Chitradurga while rock-hurling demonstrators burned several vehicles and attacked airline offices, movie houses and stores in Bangalore.

title: DEATH BY CIGARETTE FIRE: A SOLUTION DEBATE
description: It will not be easy to watch the New York City Fire Department's new public service message - a message delivered by a woman whose family perished and who was disfigured in a fire that started when her husband fell asleep while smoking a cigarette.

title: AMERICAN ROLES DURING THE HOLOCAUST
description: Add to the growing list of films about the Holocaust Laurence Jarvik's ''Who Shall Live and Who Shall Die,'' a spare, unadorned 90-minute documentary. The film examines the roles played by members of the United States Government and by American Jewish leaders in the efforts to save European Jews from extermination in Nazi concentration camps nearly 40 years ago.

title: Protests in 2 Swiss Cities
description: The police detained 50 young people who participated in weekend rock-throwing demonstrations or unauthorized protests against the governmment in Zurich and Basel.

title: SAHARAN REBELS WARN WASHINGTON THEY MAY TURN TO SOVIET FOR ARMS
description: The Polisario Front, which has been fighting Morocco for for control of Western Sahara, has warned the United States that it might seek weapons from the Soviet Union if Washington continues to step up military assistance to Morocco.

title: A Correction
description: The sports section of Sunday's editions of The Times incorrectly listed a scheduled telecast of last night's Ranger-Islander game at Madison Square Garden. WHT will televise Islander home playoff games only.

title: ISRAELI IN MOSQUE CASE DECIDES TO CHANGE LAWYERS
description: The American-born Israeli Army recruit accused of last Sunday's murder on the Temple Mount in Jerusalem today dropped his court-appointed counsel and agreed to be defended by an attorney hired by Rabbi Meir Kahane, the Jewish Defense League leader.

title: TEACH THEM WELL-AND EARLY-HOW TO READ
description: To the Editor:

title: BRINK'S SUSPECT MAY WIN RELIEF ON PRISON CURBS
description: A Federal magistrate has recommended that a hearing be held on whether Katherine Boudin, one of the suspects in the Brink's armored car robbery in Rockland County last October, should be held in less restrictive custody.

title: AUTO SUPPLIERS SEEK WORKER CONCESSIONS
description: The nation's auto parts suppliers, taking their cue from the Big Three auto makers, are also asking the United Automobile Workers union for wage and benefit concessions.

title: PRISONER, 38, DIES AFTER SCUFFLE
description: A 38-year-old prisoner died Saturday after a scuffle with guards at the Great Meadow Correctional Facility in Comstock, N.Y., corrections officials said. Yesterday prisoners were kept locked in their cells, except when seeing visitors, and conditions were described as ''subdued.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There is something positive, which is the fact that negotiations continue.

title: JEWISH PROTESTERS EVICTED FROM SINAI
description: The Israeli Army began evicting Jewish protesters from one of the northern Sinai settlements this morning as Israel's two chief rabbis pleaded with other militants not to carry out their threats to commit suicide.

title: Shoot-Out With Einstein in Arizona
description: Some bold physicists at the University of Arizona say they are 95 percent certain that they have disproved Einstein's theory of general relativity. Fat chance.

title: DEL WEBB ARIZONA UNIT NAMES NEW TOP OFFICER
description: George Reeve, 42, has been named president and general manager of the Del E. Webb Development Company, which manages the Sun City and Sun City West resort retirement communities in Arizona. The unit, which is owned jointly by the Del E. Webb Corporation and the J.G. Boswell Company, had been headed on an acting basis by Joe Aubin, 56, who resigned to pursue other interests.

title: Bridge: Karp's Top-Seeded Team Wins in White Plains Play
description: For the leading players of New Jersey and Westchester County, and some other parts of New York State, there was some crucial action over the weekend in White Plains. Thirty-two teams, qualified from local preliminaries, were vying for the district grand national title.

title: Rangers 9, Brewers 6
description: MILWAUKEE (UPI) - George Wright, a rookie, hit a three-run homer to cap a four-run Texas rally in the eighth inning that handed Milwaukee its fifth straight loss.

title: Republicans Stay Away From Watt Appearances
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt came here this weekend to help Republicans raise funds at a dinner and reception. But seven leading Republican officeholders found it impossible to attend.

title: Charles Siragusa, Ex-Agent; Took Action Against Luciano
description: Charles Siragusa, former head of the Illinois Legislative Investigating Commission who tried for years to get evidence that would put the underworld leader Charles (Lucky) Luciano in jail, died Thursday after a long illness. He was 68 years old.

title: Two Children's Operas Presented in Brooklyn
description: The Brooklyn Philharmonia presented two children's operas by American composers Saturday afternoon at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The first, Edward Barnes's ''The Frog Who Became a Prince,'' raised questions about what children's opera really is.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Comic Relief

title: A DRAFT ISN'T NEEDED
description: The All-Volunteer Force was created in 1973, but the issue of how to man our military has not died. Despite the success of the All-Volunteer Force, there are still many people calling for a draft to strengthen our national defense.

title: BRIEFING
description: It was a great cloning of the anchor baritones, a scene to rival the flappings and twitterings at Capistrano as the White House invited a large group of news broadcasters from out-of-town stations to come on the grounds, meet the President, and feel free to use the ultimate backdrop in broadcast journalism. The lawn by the North portico, usually restricted to Sam and Judy and Bill, quickly was swarming with a covey of two dozen TV newscasters and their crews who separately framed their local talent against that marvelous house. It was a display of stand-up magenta blazers and authoritative warblings that had tourists gawking from the other side of the White House fence.

title: Fishing Boat Sinks Off Dublin; Crewmen Blame a Submarine
description: A fishing boat capsized and sank today in the Irish Sea after being dragged two miles by what its crew said was a submarine.

title: Market Place; Holly Sugar's Unclear Future
description: WILL Holly Sugar be sold? It's hard to say, but the idea has come up repeatedly. Whenever it does, the impact is stunning and speculators have a field day.

title: RAY WINFIELD SMITH, 85, SPECIALIST IN ANCIENT GLASS AND EGYPTOLOGY
description: Ray Winfield Smith, an authority on ancient glass and Egyptology who directed a project at the University of Pennsylvania to recreate visually an Egyptian temple of the 18th dynasty Pharaoh Ikhnaton, died Saturday at the Tremont Health Care Center in Houston. He was 85 years old.

title: No Headline
description: The Reagan Administration's military policy is ''not coherent.'' Raising the military budget while slashing social programs ''makes no sense.'' Such multibillion-dollar programs as the MX missile are ''a complete waste of money.''

title: SUSPECT IN SLAYING OF 2 IDAHOANS CAPTURED BY F.B.I. AFTER SHOOTOUT
description: A nationwide, 15-month search for a man suspected of killing two Idaho game wardens ended tonight in a shootout with Federal Bureau of Investigation agents, according to Joseph Yablonski, special agent in charge of the bureau's Las Vegas office.

title: FEW INTERNSHIPS THIS SUMMER
description: Every summer, first-year business students abandon classrooms for junior managerial posts at major companies. This year, however, many may be lifeguards.

title: From Dream Into Reality
description: FROM the moment Shimatoree was foaled, the dream began, the dream that this might be a Kentucky Derby horse. Until he arrived in this country 15 years ago, Shimatoree's owner, Dr. Rif'at Hussain, a 38-year-old plastic surgeon from Pakistan, had never even heard of the Kentucky Derby, but soon he did. Four years ago he purchased a mare, Tudor Twist, for $500 at the Keeneland Sales and the dream began. Saturday the dream was being led into the paddock at Aqueduct for the $175,200 Wood Memorial as the trainer Dick Dutrow, in a blue blazer and red striped tie, bent to talk to the jockey Jeffrey Fell, in red and yellow silks.

title: Angels 5, Twins 2
description: Don Baylor hit two homers, including a two-run blast to cap a four-run first inning, and Geoff Zahn pitched a six-hitter in California's sixth consecutive triumph.

title: SOVIET DECREE ON SEA MINING SEEN AS PROD TO U.S.
description: The Soviet Union issued a decree today empowering Soviet enterprises to engage in deep-sea mining. In so doing, Moscow served notice on the United States that Soviet concerns were ready to challenge American companies if the Reagan Administration continues to block an international seabed agreement.

title: Release the Haitians
description: For months, in some cases a full year, the United States has ''detained'' undocumented Haitian migrants. Imprisoned is more like it; some are in fact housed in prison cells. But unlike prisoners, the Haitians do not know when their sentences will end. Once, this detention policy was justifiable. Now, after so many months, it has started to smell: like the detention of Japanese-Americans in World War II; like racism; like cruelty.

title: A Union Man
description: To hear Leon J. Davis tell it, life as a union leader has been a series of small encouragements and one giant achievement - organizing the nation's hospital workers.

title: TIE COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
CANUCKS WIN IN OVERTIME, LEAD 2 TO 1
description: Colin Campbell, a defenseman who did not score during the regular season, got his second goal of the game from the left point 1:23 into overtime tonight and gave the Vancouver Canucks a 4-3 victory over the Los Angeles Kings and a 2-1 lead in their Smythe Division playoff series.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, APRIL 19, 1982
description: International Longstanding obligations to Britain on the part of the United States were reaffirmed in Buenos Aires by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. in remarks apparently aimed at exerting pressure on Argentina in the Falkland Islands crisis. There were signs that his talks with Argentine leaders were becoming increasingly strained, and he suggested that both sides put off for now the problem of dealing with the crucial issue of sovereignty over the islands. (Page A1, Column 6.) Phone calls from 10 Downing Street to colleagues were made by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher as anxiety increased over the continuing deadlock in the peace negotiations in Buenos Aires. The Prime Minister's urgent calls were the second time in 24 hours that she had asked for opinions of Cabinet members on the Falkland Islands crisis. (A1:3-5.)

title: Russians Deride Reagan On Nuclear Weapons
description: The Soviet Union said today that President Reagan tried to defuse America's growing antinuclear movement in his weekend radio address but that ''nobody will be misled.''

title: Queen Ends Canadian Visit
description: Queen Elizabeth flew home to London today, confident that Canada's new Constitution would strengthen the unity of the nation of 24 million people despite angry rumblings of secession from Quebec.

title: Candy Young Wins Hurdles
description: Candy Young won the women's 400-meter intermediate hurdles in the 28th annual Iona Relays in 59.5 seconds today, defeating Stephanie Vega by a tenth of a second. The two athletes, however, were not nearly so close in their opinion on who won the race.

title: Zimbabwe's Capital To Be Renamed Harare
description: Zimbabwe, celebrating its second anniversary of independence, announced today that in honor of the occasion, the name of Zimbabwe's capital would be changed from Salisbury to Harare, after a 19th-century tribal chief. Officials said they expected the change to be ratified by the Salisbury City Council next month.

title: CABARET: TERRY BURRELL
description: TERRY BURRELL has everything a great cabaret performer should have, including an act. Miss Burrell, a Trinidadian whose theatrical background has included ''Eubie,'' ''Bubbling Brown Sugar'' and ''The Wiz,'' is appearing at Sweetwater's through Saturday.

title: Bomb in Madrid Knocks Out Phones
description: About 375 pounds of explosives that authorities said they believed had been set by Basque guerrillas destroyed a major telephone exchange in Madrid early today, slightly injuring several people and cutting phone service to more than half a million customers.

title: STRONGER U.S. POLITICAL PARTIES URGED
description: Both politics and government in this country have been undermined by a weakening of the major political parties in recent years, according to a group of social scientists, government officials and politicians. They proposed a number of ways to strengthen the parties.

title: Advertising; Tic Tac's Turnaround
description: ONE of the most difficult chores in marketing, if not the most difficult, is the product turnaround, especially when a brand has lost much of its distribution. That's what makes the tale of the terrific Tic Tac revival so impressive.

title: COMMODITIES
description: FUTURES contracts, which are promises to buy or sell underlying goods, are not the only items traded on commodity exchanges. The price of seats, or memberships, in these private institutions usually serve as an indicator of the economic health of a market's ''products.''

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Air Products and Chemicals Inc., Allentown, Pa., has elected to its board Edwin A. Gee, chairman and chief executive officer of the International Paper Company.

title: DEMOCRATS WHO BACKED REAGAN AWAIT FIRST TEST
description: ''I like Gramm because he won't let them run him,'' said Homer Reagan, a retired postal worker with only minimal regard for the man in the White House who has the same last name.

title: THE EVEN HAND
description: At the two places in the world where war threatens to break out, the United States is striking the pose of evenhandedness. In each case, we have a staunch democratic ally on one side of a dispute, and on the other an authoritarian regime with close economic ties to the Soviet Union. A question arises: When is the even hand the best hand for the United States?

title: Stamina in Doubt On Air Forbes Won
description: Air Forbes Won, who ground out a desperate victory Saturday by a neck in the Wood Memorial, was up and around his stall at Aqueduct yesterday morning. Everything was intact except, perhaps, his aura of invincibility. The unbeaten colt notched his fourth victory and will be flown to Churchill Downs today to begin preparing for the Kentucky Derby May 1. But he was so hard-pressed to win that the depth of his talent appears questionable.

title: NICARAGUA PRESSES U.S. TO CONFER IMMEDIATELY
description: Nicaragua is urging the United States to open negotiations immediately, saying that the presence of a United States destroyer off the Nicaraguan coast has introduced a new threat to its security.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: With a runner on second, the pitcher starts his delivery motion and the runner attempts to steal third. The pitcher, picking it up quickly, throws to third base in front of the runner. Is this legal or a balk?

title: SONIA LANDAU IS MARRIED TO JOHN CORRY
description: Sonia Landau, a member of the board of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, and John Corry, a cultural news reporter for The New York Times, were married yesterday at the Carlyle Hotel. State Supreme Court Justice Theodore R. Kupferman performed the ceremony

title: Nordiques Conquer Bruins in Overtime
description: Wilf Paiement scored on a 20-foot wrist shot at 11 minutes 44 seconds of overtime tonight to give the Quebec Nordiques a 3-2 victory over the Boston Bruins in the final series of the Adams Division. The Nordiques now trail, two games to one.

title: 'Street Crime' Category Said to Remain Stable
description: Violent crimes by assailants who did not know their victims continued to occur at an ''exceedingly stable'' rate in the 1970's despite increasing fears of street crime, the Justice Department reported today.

title: CULT OPPONENT ON TRIAL IN OHIO KIDNAPPING CASE
description: Ted Patrick, known for his efforts to make young people renounce religious cults, has gone on trial here in the kidnapping of a teen-ager who, according to her parents, was led into lesbianism through mind control.

title: GAINS FROM SALVADOR LAND DISTRIBUTION DISPUTED
description: Agricultural production has declined substantially on the largest farms that the Government expropriated and converted to peasant cooperatives, according to the findings of a private university group here.

title: DETECTIVE ENJOYS FAME AS MODEL FOR WHODUNIT
description: Judy Roberts tucked a revolver in her evening bag the other night and went out to a glittery dinner party at a downtown restaurant.

title: Skidmore Student Kills Self
description: A student at Skidmore College committed suicide by pouring gasoline over herself and lighting it, officials said today.

title: BORG, DISPLAYING OLD FORM, TOPS VILAS IN TOKYO FINAL, 6-1, 6-2
description: Bjorn Borg demonstrated today that his return to competitive tennis after a five-month layoff may not be as difficult as his rivals undoubtedly had hoped. Borg overwhelmed Guillermo Vilas in straight sets, 6-1, 6-2, and won the $250,000 Suntory Cup men's tournament.

title: LISA DENHOLTZ MARRRIED TO MICHAEL A. SILBER
description: Lisa Rachel Denholtz, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Melvin Denholtz of Livingston, N.J., was married there yesterday to Michael Adam Silber, son of Dr. and Mrs. Austin Silber of Englewood, N.J. Rabbi Peter Kasdan performed the ceremony at Temple Emanu-el.

title: ISRAELI POLICY ON ID CARDS ENRAGES GOLAN'S DRUSE
description: Since the annexation of the Golan Heights last December, the Israeli authorities have been locked in an angry political struggle with the 12,500 Arab Druse residents of the territory, and no early resolution is in sight.

title: WALKER IS DOUBTFUL FOR NETS' PLAYOFFS
description: Even with Ray Williams's 52-point performance and a 147-132 triumph Saturday night over the Detroit Pistons in Pontiac, Mich., the New Jersey Nets were not a happy group after the game.

title: Indians 8, Royals 2
description: CLEVELAND (AP) - Toby Harrah got three hits, including his fourth home run, and Alan Bannister highlighted a four-run first inning with a two-run double for Cleveland.

title: LUCY MILLS TOWNSEND BRIDE OF WALTER E. IRVING 2D
description: Lucy Mills Townsend, daughter of Mrs. Louis Busch Hager of New York and Lyman Bass Townsend of Pittsford, N.Y., was married at the Mashomack Club in Pine Plains, N.Y., yesterday to Walter Edward Irving 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. James E. Irving of Kent, Conn. Town Justice George L. Tenore of Pine Plains performed the ceremony.

title: RE-SLICING CORPORATE TAX PIE
description: Some of the most fiscally aggressive states in the country are scheduled to do battle before the Supreme Court today against some of the largest corporations in the world over a method of taxation that has already caused some foreign governments to threaten retaliation against American businesses.

title: KENNETH MACDONALD, EX-MEMBER OF NEW JERSEY CASINO COMMISSION
description: Kenneth N. MacDonald, a former vice chairman of the New Jersey Casino Control Commission, died of stomach cancer Saturday at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital. He was 59 years old and lived in Haddonfield, N.J.

title: DR. MARC EHRICH WEDS RACHEL MARLENE BARATZ
description: Rachel Marlene Baratz, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Baratz of Paradise Valley, Ariz., was married there yesterdsay to Dr. Marc Ehrich, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Ehrich of Westfield, N.J. Rabbi Elliot Marmon, assisted by Cantor Barry Caplan, performed the ceremony at Har Zion Congregation.

title: DARTMOUTH TACKLES STUDENT DRINKING
description: The student is being recorded on videotape. He is supine on the grass of the campus quadrangle outside his fraternity house. It is Sunday, the morning after a night of drinking. His speech is unclear. He has been violently ill, remembering only that he had begun drinking early Saturday evening. He has barely recovered. He may have had a good time, a very good time, he says.

title: PLASTIC PRODUCERS MAKE BID FOR TRADITIONAL PAPER MARKET
description: First, you have to get your terms right: If it's brown paper, it's a bag, and if it's opaque plastic with looped handles, it's a sack. Manufacturers of both are quick to make the distinction.

title: RECOVERY PROSPECTS FOR CHIPS
description: The semiconductor industry is showing signs of emerging from its protracted slump. Industry executives and analysts say that new orders are at the highest level in nearly two years, excess prouction capacity is diminishing and soft prices have firmed a bit.

title: LEFT BEHIND BY THE HEALTH-CARE REVOLUTION
description: To the Editor:

title: News Analysis
description: As Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. continued his mediation effort over the Falkland Islands, it was becoming clear how little leverage the United States has to move Argentina toward a compromise with Britain.

title: Taiwanese Wins
description: Ai-Yu Tu, a 27-year-old Taiwanese professional, rallied from two strokes back with a one-under-par 73 today to win the $93,117 Mitsukoshi Ladies Open golf tournament. She had a 54-hole score of 217.

title: Continental Air Choooses Keye
description: Continental Air Lines, Los Angeles, is moving to Keye/ Donna/Pearlstein, the only truly local shop among the six competing for the account. The airline's last billing figure was about $16 million, making it the biggest account the 12-year-old agency has ever won.

title: BRAVES WIN RECORD 11 IN ROW
description: The Atlanta Braves tied the major league record for victories at the start of the season and broke the National League mark with their 11th in a row today as Biff Pocoroba pinch hit a two-run double in the eighth inning for a 6-5 victory over the Houston Astros.

title: ISLANDERS TOP RANGERS IN OVERTIME, LEAD SERIES, 2-1
description: The Rangers played their best game of the Stanley Cup playoffs at Madison Square Garden last night, but the Islanders played their usual excellent game and won, 4-3, after exactly three minutes of overtime.

title: MISS WHITWORTH WINS RECORD 82d EVENT
description: Kathy Whitworth won the Women's International golf tournament by nine strokes today, tying the Ladies Professional Golf Association record for career victories that was held by the legendary Mickey Wright.

title: CIRCLE REP'S DIRECTOR, CITING EXHAUSTION, TO TAKE A SABBATICAL
description: By ELEANOR BLAU After 13 years as artistic director and guiding force of Off Broadway's Circle Repertory Company, which he helped to found, Marshall Mason has decided to take a sabbatical of at least a year and probably two, starting Sept. 30. ''I was so exhausted and had a feeling the exhaustion was terminal,'' he explained the other day. ''I'm not ill,'' the 42-year-old director added, ''but in their 40's people drop dead of heart attacks.''

title: Khomeini Hints At Discord in Military
description: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini hinted today at discord among the military. At the same time, Iran's main opposition group reported an ''uprising'' at Teheran's largest army base.

title: PEOPLE
description: * Bernie Dowling named senior vice president, controller, at J. Walter Thompson U.S.A. Inc.

title: IN BUFFALO, THE SURVIVAL OF DARWIN
description: Charles Darwin died on April 19, 1882, and 40 free-thinking philosophers and scientists who held a symposium here this weekend agreed that 100 years later a lot of unfinished business remained.

title: FRANCE UNEASY WITH IMAGE OF AFRICA'S GENDARME
description: An image evoked by mentioning the French presence in Africa is this: the sky over some dusty mining town deep in Africa's heart fills with parachutes, and swarthy legionnaires descend on rebel hordes, routing them and saving a dictator.

title: BRIBERY INQUIRY AT DAIMLER
description: A West German prosecutor said today that offices of Daimler-Benz, the West German auto maker, were searched and bank accounts of Arab auto dealers were frozen in an investigation of Daimler export officials suspected of having taken bribes and evading tax payments in connection with deliveries of trucks to the Middle East.

title: Mariners 4, A's 3
description: SEATTLE (AP) - Richie Zisk tied the score with a leadoff home run in the ninth, and Todd Cruz delivered the game-winner with a single to pace Seattle.

title: M.T.A. Approves Rail-Car Purchase
description: The purchase of 186 additional electric commuter rail cars from the Budd Company of Philadelphia for the Long Island Rail Road and the Harlem and Hudson lines has been approved by the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: Mime Troupe to Open Musical Spoof May 16
description: The San Francisco Mime Troupe will open its ''Factwino Meets the Moral Majority'' on May 16 at the Fashion Institute of Technology Amphitheater, at 227 West 27th Street.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Mikan's Garden Memories

title: LARRY BROWN PUTS HIS WINNING TOUCH ON NETS
description: ASUCCESSFUL coach stands out in a crowd. His face is not haunted with dark lines of defeat and the disappointments of the past. Instead, it glows with contentment.

title: MEMORABILIA OF BING CROSBY'S HOUSES WILL BE SOLD
description: A warehouse full of artifacts and memories from the life of Bing Crosby, and a simpler time in America, will be placed on an auction block next month.

title: SECRET ADMIRERS
description: Sports World Specials Secret Admirers

title: F.B.I.-City Effort On Crime Urged
description: New York City Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire suggested yesterday that a joint effort by the city police and the Federal Bureau of Investigation be mounted to combat organized crime. Mr. McGuire said he had discussed the proposal with Federal authorities.

title: SALAZAR HEADS BOSTON FIELD
description: Neil and Dan Sheehan of Brooklyn stretched their weary legs across two wooden barriers near the Prudential Center finish line for Monday's 86th Boston Marathon.

title: JAPAN PLACES MARKET ABOVE PROFITS
description: In Japan, which is viewed as a model of capitalist vigor, profit can be a dirty word. ''Profit in Japan is not really a good word,'' said Akio Mikuni, an independent corporate financial consultant to many Japanese companies. ''High profits just lead to pressure from workers to increase wages and from consumers to reduce prices. Why report high profits?''

title: BURLESON OUT
description: The California Angels placed Rick Burleson on the disabled list today, and he is expected to be out for the season after exploratory minor surgery disclosed a tear in the rotator cuff in his right shoulder.

title: TAX REFUSAL COMPLETES PRELATE'S MORAL JOURNEY
description: Last Thursday, Raymond G. Hunthausen, the Archbishop of Seattle, filed his Federal income tax return and deliberately held back $125. It was a milestone on a personal journey begun 37 years ago when the bombing of Hiroshima and Nagasaki left a young seminarian despondent and bewildered.

title: RAYCHEM CARVES A PROSPEROUS NICHE
description: Sometimes, a new technology can pleasantly surprise even those with high hopes for it. Paul M. Cook was convinced by his work for the Atomic Energy Commission almost 30 years ago that radiation chemistry -in particular, bombarding plastics with radiation - could produce unusual and useful materials.

title: HOLZMAN SAYS GOODBYE AFTER FINAL LOSS
description: Red Holzman said goodbye for the season, and maybe for good, as coach of the Knicks today. The goodbyes came after the Boston Celtics, who finished atop the National Basketball Association regular-season standing with a 63-19 record, overwhelmed the Knicks, 119-99, at Boston Garden.

title: Cosmos Defeat Rowdies
description: The Cosmos played well for only the first half in their North American Soccer League home opener today, but the Tampa Bay Rowdies were equally ineffective in the second half and the Cosmos emerged with a 2-0 victory at Giants Stadium.

title: IMPROVEMENT CITED IN CITY HEAT AID PROGRAM
description: In a winter made even longer by the blizzard that swept through the New York metropolitan region two weeks ago, two predictions made last fall by the man responsible for the city's heat-emergecy effort seem to have been realized.

title: BAKER VOICING HOPE OF GAINING ACCORD ON TAX SURCHARGE
description: Howard H. Baker Jr., the Senate majority leader, said today that he was encouraged to believe that President Reagan would accept an income tax surcharge being proposed in an effort to break the stalemate on the budget for the fiscal year 1983.

title: Transactions;
description: COLLEGE WOOSTER - Al Van Wie announced retirement as head basketball coach.

title: Voting Rights Marchers To Head for Washington
description: Demonstrators who traveled across Alabama for 13 days in support of voting rights are to set out Monday for Washington in an effort to assure the strengthening of the Voting Rights Act of 1965.

title: ISLANDERS' BOURNE FINALLY FINDS NET
description: Before last night's game, you had to check the bottom of the scoring lists to find Bob Bourne's name. In seven playoff games this season, the Islanders' speediest skater had no goals and just two assists, not the kind of statistics that help win Stanley Cups.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: WADKINS POSTS 3-SHOT VICTORY ON 280
description: Lanny Wadkins rolled in a 40-foot birdie putt on the 17th hole and finished with a one-over-par 73 today to win the $350,000 Tournament of Champions by three strokes.

title: MRS. THATCHER CONSULTS URGENTLY WITH COLLEAGUES
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher consulted with colleagues by telephone tonight as anxiety mounted here over the continuing deadlock in peace negotiations in Buenos Aires.

title: GAYLORD HARNWELL PHYSICIST AND PRESIDENT OF PENN, DIES
description: Dr. Gaylord P. Harnwell, an atomic physicist and educator who led the University of Pennsylvania in 17 years of postwar growth, died early yesterday at his home in Haverford, Pa., after a lengthy illness. He was 78 years old.

title: Transit Subsidy Is Not So Horrible
description: Senator Bob Dole says the New York Transit Authority's technique of using tax subsidies to reduce the cost of new buses and rail cars is a ''horror story.'' And a good point lurks behind that hyperbole. Because the subsidy is indirect, only 60 to 70 percent of it actually benefits transit. But for beleaguered commuters in New York and elsewhere, 60 or 70 percent is surely better than the alternative: nothing at all.

title: A Thai Proposal
description: The Prime Minister of Thailand, Gen. Prem Tinsulanonda, is a 61-year-old bachelor with no known romantic attachments. But now, it seems, he does have prospects.

title: MEPHISTO'S WALTZ
description: The price of ambition is a familiar theme in literature. But no novelist's imagination has outdone the reality of Henry Kissinger in the Nixon White House. So one feels after reading a devastating new account of those years.

title: To the Editor: A news story published April 9 under the headline, ''Gifts to Charity Rise 12.3% to $53.6 Billion, a Record,'' overlooks perhaps the most significant factor contributing to that increase - the new tax law.
description: The Economic Recovery Tax Act of 1981 reduced the maximum tax rate on an individual's income from 70 percent to 50 percent, starting Jan. 1, 1982. Therefore, any tax deduction for charitable contributions made before that date would have the ef-fect of reducing the income-tax liability of a ''top bracket'' individual by 70 cents per contributed dollar, as opposed to a 50-cent reduction after that date.

title: NASA Is Reorganizing Shuttle's Management
description: The space agency has announced plans to reorganize its space shuttle management to prepare for operational satellite-launching flights of the re-usable craft.
