title: G.M. Officers Miss Bonuses
description: For the first time since the General Motors Corporation introduced a bonus plan in 1918, top executives at the No.1 American auto maker have not received bonuses for two consecutive years, the company said.

title: AUTO UNION REACHES A TENTATIVE ACCORD AT AMERICAN MOTORS
description: The United Automobile Workers reached a tentative agreement today with the American Motors Corporation on an employee investment plan, the union and company announced.

title: COMPANIES PLAN FEW NEW ISSUES
description: Corporations remain reluctant to sell long-term debt at current interest rates, as shown by this week's light volume. Only five of their issues are scheduled for public sale. Although the volume of corporate note and bond offerings could increase quickly, the total volume already scheduled for the next four weeks is a light $1 billion, according to Salomon Brothers.

title: DANCE: TAYLOR REVIVES 'ESPLANADE'
description: By offering a repetition of ''Arden Court'' and the season's first performances of ''Esplanade'' and ''House of Cards'' on Saturday night at New York's City Center, the Paul Taylor Dance Company reminded audiences that Mr. Taylor has not only made dance history, but he has also often looked back on dance history.

title: NEGOTIATIONS ON JAPANESE AID TO SEOUL SEEM NEAR IMPASSE
description: Japan and South Korea appear to be moving toward a deadlock on a Korean request for $6 billion in aid. Finance Minister Michio Watanabe said Friday that Tokyo could not pledge more than $800 million in official development aid to Seoul for the South Korean long-term development plan, covering the period from 1982 to 1986.

title: BORROWERS HELP KEEP RATES HIGH
description: The unusual volume of short-term borrowing by business has helped keep interest rates high, but with the economy in a recession some analysts expect weaker credit demands to help reduce interest rates.

title: COWBOY CULTURE YIELDS, EVEN IN THE HEART OF TEXAS, TO UN-CHIC BUNNY HOP
description: You suspected that Texas Chic had begun to pale when the fiddlers and guitarists at Cotton-Eyed Joe's, a countryand-western honkytonk on Houston's West Side, forsook the Texas Two-Step for the Bunny Hop.

title: Heating Oil Prices Spark Inquiry Bid
description: City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin has asked the United States Attorneys in Manhattan and Brooklyn to investigate possible ''pricefixing or restraint of trade'' by retail dealers in home heating oil.

title: LAG IN HOSPITAL CITED IN PSYCHIATRIC TRANSFERS
description: One-fifth of the beds for psychiatric patients in New York City's overcrowded acute-care municipal hospitals are being taken up by patients waiting many weeks for transfers to more appropriate and cheaper care elsewhere.

title: WHITE SOX CAPTURE 8TH WITHOUT A LOSS
description: Although bad weather forced the postponement of four opening games for the Chicago White Sox, the rest and accompanying frustration may have made them a little more determined to succeed when their season finally began. Yesterday, they used some aggressive base-running and a throwing error by Rick Dempsey of Baltimore to down the Orioles, 6-4, at Comiskey Park in Chicago.

title: MONDAY, APRIL 19, 1982; The Economy
description: The semiconductor industry is cautiously optimistic amid signs that it is emerging from a long slump. Orders are at a two-year high, excess capacity is shrinking and prices have firmed somewhat recently. But further improvement is tied to an upturn in the nation's economy. (Page D1.)

title: WHEN BARGAINING BECOMES BEGGING
description: To the Editor:

title: Intruder Kills 2 In Jersey Home
description: A gunman broke into a home here, killed a man and his 3-year-old daughter and critically wounded the man's wife in an apparently unprovoked attack, authorities said today.

title: Red Sox 4, Blue Jays 3
description: BOSTON (UPI) - Glenn Hoffman led off the ninth with a triple and scored on Jerry Garvin's wild pitch to give Boston the victory. After Hoffman tripled into the right-field corner off the loser, Roy Lee Jackson (2-1), Garvin came in and intentionally walked the pinchhitter Tony Perez. With a 1-2 count on Rick Miller, Garvin let go a wild pitch, and Hoffman came home with the winning run.

title: YANKEES, RIGHETTI LOSE TO TIGERS, 5-2
description: The Yankees scored some small successes on a sunny afternoon in Tiger Stadium today: In their eighth game, Willie Randolph supplied the team's first stolen base of the season. And Roy Smalley, batting .172 as the offensive foil to Bucky Dent, hit his first home run.

title: Giants 4, Reds 2
description: Reggie Smith and Darrell Evans each had home runs for San Francisco.

title: BARBARA SEAMAN REWED
description: At the Park Avenue Synagogue yesterday Barbara Seaman, author and co-founder of the National Womens Health Network, was married to Milton Forman, president of Toltec Fabrics Inc. Rabbi Judah Nadich officiated.

title: Pope Visits Bologna, Prays for Bomb Dead
description: Pope John Paul II, in a visit to this Communist-run city, prayed at Bologna's train station today for the 85 victims of ''that horrible massacre'' caused by a terrorist bombing in August 1980.

title: Peace March in Italy Draws Over 100,000
description: More than 100,000 people in this northern city marched to oppose nuclear weapons in a demonstration sponsored by the Italian Communist Party, the police said today.

title: U.N. Envoy Heads for Teheran For Talks on Afghan Problem
description: Diego Cordoves, a special United Nations envoy, left Kabul, the capital of Afghanistan, for Teheran today on the last leg of a tour to discuss the chances of a negotiated solution to the Afghan problem, the Kabul radio said.

title: The U.N. Today; April 19, 1982; ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL
description: Meets at 10.30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Steel Output Up in Week
description: Steel production was 1.57 million tons last week, up 2 percent from the previous week's 1.54 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: Hat's Off to Film Maker - and That's the Problem
description: It was, the film maker Norman Jewison was saying yesterday, just a blue baseball cap he bought in the mid-1960's to shield his eyes from the sun while he was directing Steve McQueen in ''The Thomas Crown Affair.''

title: POLICE RESUME NIGHT PATROLS ON SUBWAY TRAINS TONIGHT
description: Beginning tonight, after a two-year hiatus, transit police officers will once again patrol most subway trains each night between 8 P.M. and 4 A.M.

title: A FORMER PARTNER IS LEAVING SOLOMON
description: Richard G. Rosenthal, 40 years old, one of Wall Street's bestknown arbitragers, has resigned as a managing director and member of the executive committee of Salomon Brothers, the big investment banking concern, which has $719 million in total capital.

title: Debray, the Leftist Theorist, Visits Nicaragua for France
description: President Francois Mitterrand's special adviser on Latin American affairs, Regis Debray, arrived here today for a four-day visit.

title: Geo Publisher Move
description: After only eight months as publisher of Geo magazine, T. Swift Lockard is moving upstairs to the job of vice president and assistant to Cleon T. Knapp, chairman and chief executive of Knapp Communications. Geo was acquired in September by Knapp from Gruner & Jahr, its West German publisher-founder, which poured millions into unsuccessful attempts to make it the hit it is in both Germany and France.

title: U.S. Team Loses 3d Straight Game
description: The United States hockey team led twice before wilting in the third period and losing, 4-2, to Finland today, taking its third straight defeat in the World Hockey Championships.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard GROUP PORTRAIT. JOSEPH CONRAD, STEPHEN CRANE, FORD MADOX FORD, HENRY JAMES AND H.G. WELLS. By Nicholas Delbanco. Illus- trated. 224 pages. Morrow. $11.50. THE ENGLISH POETS OF THE FIRST WORLD WAR. By John Lehmann. Illus- trated. 144 pages. Thames & Hudson. $17.95. AWRITING student once told me that not only would he prefer not to m eet a great writer, but he also didn't even want to read a great b ook. He was afraid of being influenced, compromised in his splendid s ingularity. In our innocence, we like to think of the writer alone, a n imperial self, bearlike or tubercular in a cave or a garret, e xorcising dybbuks and eating mice. We ought to know better. Writers r ead all the time and find one another, either by accident or on p urpose; they swap manuscripts and sexual partners; they bear c hildren and grudges. Solitude has little to do with originality.

title: RULING DUE IN PENTHOUSE CASE IN BIAS CHARGE AGAINST JUDGE
description: The libel suit by La Costa Resort against Penthouse magazine is scheduled to go to the jury this week. In its closing days the trial has acquired a new issue - an allegation by Penthouse that the judge hearing the case is so biased against it that the magazine is exposed to ''the risk of a ruinous judgment.''

title: LILCO USES ADS TO BRING CASE TO PUBLIC
description: The Long Island Lighting Company, aware from surveys it has conducted that its customers think electric bills are too high, has embarked on an intensive advertising campaign that will attempt not only to explain its rates but also to personalize its image.

title: Policeman Killed, Another Is Held
description: A Roselle Park policeman was shot to death during a party for a fellow officer who was about to enter the Army, authorities said today. The officer for whom the party was being held was charged with aggravated manslaughter in the killing.

title: PRESIDENT IS NAMED AT NEW HORIZONS FUND
description: Edward J. Mathias, 40, has been named president of the T.Rowe Price New Horizons Fund, a mutual fund with about $840 million worth of assets under management that specializes in small, emerging growth companies. He succeeds Thomas C. Barry, 38, who resigned to pursue personal business interests.

title: Waltrip Captures 3d Nascar Event
description: Darrell Waltrip regained a lost lap on a caution flag in the late stages of the Northwestern 400 today to win his third race this season on Nascar'S Grand National circuit.

title: Cubs 5, Pirates 1
description: PITTSBURGH (AP) - Leon Durham hit a three-run homer in Chicago's four-run third inning, pacing Ferguson Jenkins and the Cubs. The Cubs took a 1-0 lead in the first inning off Eddie Solomon (0-2) when Bump Wills walked and came around on consecutive singles by Ryne Sandberg and Bill Buckner.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Peak Performance

title: Elections Today to Fill 5 Seats in Legislature
description: Special elections will be held today to name five new members of the New York State Legislature - a State Senator each in Nassau County and Rochester, and Assemblymen in Brooklyn, the Bronx and Suffolk County. The polls will be open from 6 A.M. to 9 P.M.

title: 7 WEST EUROPEANS DETAINED IN SOVIET
description: A group of seven foreigners in Red Square attempted today to unfurl a hand-lettered banner with the Russian words for ''Bread, Life and Disarmament,'' but their project was cut short by the K.G.B., the state security police.

title: DAVIDSON INSPIRES RANGERS
description: It was definitely a gamble by the Rangers, but for half the game last night at Madison Square Garden, it was working. Starting in goal was John Davidson. Because of an injury, Davidson had appeared in only one game this season, but now he was inspiring his teammates toward what he hoped would be a victory to tie the quarterfinal series with the Islanders at 2 games apiece.

title: TURKISH POLICY ON IRANIAN REFUGEES' ACTIVITIES
description: To the Editor:

title: UNION CARBIDE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
MA BELL'S FAULTY PROPOSED BILL OF DIVORCEMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: WELDED TUBE OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: VECTOR GRAPHIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 1
TAX PANEL FOCUSES ON SALES EXPENSES
description: Congress was told today that some husbandand-wife teams in the direct sales business report a few hundred dollars of sales on their tax returns and list many thousands of dollars of so-called business expenses as deductions against other income.

title: REALIST INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
XIDEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
American Ballet School
description: The School of American Ballet will present its 17th workshop performances at the Juilliard Theater, 144 West 66th Street, on May 1 at 8 P.M. and May 3 at 4 and 7.

title: STUDY INDICATES INTERFERON MAY SPREAD SOME CANCERS
description: Interferon, a substance under study as a possible cancer treatment, in some circumstances may increase the ability of cancer cells to spread into normal tissue, according to research described at a biological meeting.

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: A major crisis developed today among members of the Philippine Supreme Court as a result of the upgraded bar examination of the son of one of the justices.

title: Abscam Legal Defense Fund For Williams Nears $200,000
description: Contributions of $22,097 in the first three months of the year to the legal defense fund of former Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. have brought the total amount raised close to $200,000, a new report showed today.

title: Pope's Trip to Britain In Doubt if War Starts
description: Britain's leading Roman Catholic churchman said today that Pope John Paul might cancel his planned visit to Britain next month if war breaks out over the Falkland Islands.

title: Difference of Opinion
description: While Lynn Swann of the Pittsburgh Steelers criticized Ed Garvey, executive director of the National Football League Players Association, and said he would not go out on strike, Art Kuehn of the Seattle Seahawks lashed out at two teammates who said publicly they would not support a player strike this season. Kuehn said the stand taken by Jim Zorn and Steve Largent, who oppose strikes on religious grounds, ''hurt the union.''

title: Daihatsu Accord
description: The Daihatsu Motor Company said today that it had contracted to supply 20,000 automobile engines in 1982 to Nuova Innocenti, an Italian auto maker based in Milan. The accord, for 1,000-cubic-centimeter engines, replaces a contract formerly held by Britain's state-owned auto maker, BL Ltd. Terms of the accord were not disclosed.

title: Jack Dempsey Released
description: Jack Dempsey, who was admitted to New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center on April 11, was discharged yesterday. The 86-year-old former heavyweight champion had a pacemaker implanted last week because of a slowing of his heartbeat. ... On May 2, the day after the Kentucky Derby is run in his home town, Louisville's most famous heavyweight since Muhammad Ali will defend his United States Boxing Association title against Jimmy Young. But Greg Page, who has won all 18 of his pro fights, 16 by knockout, will do his fighting in Atlantic City, the promoter Don King announced.

title: Formula for Disbursing Vocation Aid Attacked
description: The New York State formula for aiding vocational high schools shortchanges New York City by $18 million, according to a study released yesterday by the Educational Priorities Panel, a coalition of 25 civic groups.

title: MIDLAND-ROSS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Includes gain from royalties on an iron ore reduction process equal to 6 cents a shr

title: Soviet Announces Launching Of Research Station, Salyut 7
description: The Soviet Union launched a research station, Salyut 7, into a near circular orbit around the Earth today, according to a report in Tass, the Government's official press agency.

title: B.N. Net Off 58.2%
description: Burlington Northern Inc., citing the recession, poor weather and ''exceptionally strong'' earnings a year ago, said today that its first-quarter profit tumbled by 58.2 percent, to $37.6 million, or 95 cents a share, from $90 million, or $2.33 a share, a year earlier. Revenue fell slightly, to $1.1 billion from $1.2 billion. Rail operating income declined 53 percent, to $57.4 million for the first quarter, on revenue of $920 million.

title: J. GEORGE HARRAR, PAST PRESIDENT OF ROCKEFELLER FOUNDATION, DIES
description: Dr. J. George Harrar, a retired president of the Rockefeller Foundation and a biologist who led the foundation's agricultural research that helped produce the so-called Green Revolution, died Sunday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 75 years old.

title: EX-U.S. ATTORNEY CURRAN IN RACE FOR GOVERNOR AS REPUBLICAN
description: Paul J. Curran, formerly a United States Attorney and chairman of the State Investigation Commission, said yesterday that he would run for Governor of New York.

title: MONSANTO CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Required Reading; 'Unmistakable' Bias
description: Robert W. Edgar, Democrat of Pennsylvania and chairman of the Northeast-Midwest Congressional Coalition, speaking before the House Budget Committee. March 22, 1982:

title: JAPAN'S FUJITEC: A MOVE TO U.S.
description: As Shotaro Uchiyma sees it, a truly global company ought to be run from New York City - the financial and information capital of the world, he says.

title: Mehta to Get Award
description: Zubin Mehta, music director of the New York Philharmonic, will receive the Concert Artists Guild Award at the guild's 31st awards ceremony on April 28 at 5:30 P.M. in the Corinthian Room of the New York Sheraton. Since 1951, the guild has assisted emerging artists by sponsoring New York debuts and other concerts.

title: POP GUITARIST: MIKE OLDFIELD
description: instrumentalist who is best known for ''Tubular Bells,'' part of which became the theme for ''The Exorcist,'' made his United States debut Sunday at the Ritz leading a virtuosic seven-piece ensemble. Though Mr. Oldfield has never been able to match his success with ''Tubular Bells'' in the United States, he has enjoyed a huge European following, particularly in Germany.

title: Union Carbide Net Off
description: The Union Carbide Corporporation, noting its key markets have been hard hit by the recession, said today that its first-quarter profit fell 49 percent from a year earlier.

title: HEARTBREAK HILL MAKES RUGGED MARATHON TEST
description: Here in Newton, and in all the towns west of Boston along the marathon route, this day begins each year in the kitchen with the scent of carved roast beef and ham, the gentle crackling of lettuce leaves and the sound of mustard jars being unscrewed.

title:
FALKLANDS AND THE U.N.;
CAMBRIDGE, Mass. - Within a few days, young Britons and Argentines may start killing each other. It is high time to get to work on a cease-fire resolution for the contested islands, whether they are called the Malvinas or Falklands.
description: The unwillingness of both Britain and Argentina to reach agreement while the British fleet sails southward is to be expected. It is not only that mediation is difficult for a Secretary of State who speaks officially, may look coercive, and represents the United States with all its political concerns and inhibitions. So long as Argentina and Britain do not face a fading opportunity to say ''yes,'' the arguments for each to say ''no'' to any proposal are persuasive: ''It is less than we want.'' ''If we act tough, we may get more.'' ''By saying 'no' we keep our options open.'' And, ''If the worst comes to the worst, we can always accept these terms later.'' Faced with such a choice, why say ''yes''?

title: ANTITANK AND ANTI-NUKE
description: Is the tank, introduced in World War I and the dominant land weapon of World War II, obsolete already? And if so, might that help in the prevention of nuclear war?

title: KNOXVILLE RACING TO MEET MAY 1 DEADLINE FOR FAIR
description: Sparks sputter from the torch of a bearded welder on scaffolding. A steamroller presses onto fresh asphalt. In one blue-sided pavilion, a Japanese technician is applying his screwdriver to a tiny fragment on a gigantic, constantly changing, computerized panel. In another, a Chinese is checking the contents of a large wooden crate.

title: Judge Rescinds Ruling On Hinckley Trial Jury
description: Reversing an earlier decision, a Federal District judge decided today that the jury would not be sequested in the forthcoming trial of John W. Hinckley Jr. for attempting to assassinate President Reagan.

title: DATA GIVEN IN NEW WAY
description: The Census Bureau today instituted a new method of reporting the first findings from its decennial survey of the American population's detailed characteristics.

title: Migrant Boss Sentenced To 2 Years in Slave Case
description: A migrant crew leader, one of four men accused of working a man to death, was sentenced today to two years in prison after pleading guilty to a lesser charge of conspiring to enslave migrants.

title: IDAHO OFFICIALS WRESTLE WITH DEATH ROW PROBLEMS
description: With the population on death row growing at the rate of one new inmate a month, officials at the state penitentiary here have been working overtime in recent weeks to put new life in the death law.

title: Goodyear Net Off 19.6%
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company announced today that first-quarter profits fell 19.6 percent, to $45.6 million, or 63 cents a share, from $56.7 million, or 78 cents a share, in the 1981 quarter.

title: Violin Recital Looks At Baroque Spiritualism
description: The violinist Evan Johnson gave an unusual glimpse of a Baroque spiritual world Sunday afternoon at the Church of the Transfiguration, playing Heinrich von Biber's ''Mystery Sonatas.'' The composer wrote 15 sonatas and a passacaglia illustrating the mysteries of Jesus's life.

title: 42 SOUTH KOREAN CHRISTIANS ASK RECALL OF 2 TOP U.S. AIDES
description: South Korean Christian leaders urged the Reagan Administration today to recall the two top American officials here, because of ''increasing anti-American feeling.''

title: BIRTH CONTROL: 4-DAY PILL IS PROMISING IN EARLY TEST
description: A new birth control pill which women could take for four days at the end of each monthly cycle, instead of for three weeks as at present, has been devised by a leading French biochemist.

title: U.S. LIVING STANDARD FOUND HIGHEST
description: The United States had the highest standard of living among industrialized countries in 1980 and, as a result of the strength of the dollar on foreign exchange markets, very nearly the highest prices, according to a study of 15 nations.

title: NO STRANGER TO THE HIGH COURT
description: He was the first black accepted on the Harvard Law Review, the first to serve as a clerk to a Supreme Court Justice, the second to serve on a President's Cabinet and the first to reach the top of the corporate legal establishment.

title: 'GAMES OF COUNTESS DOLIGEN'
description: ''THE GAMES of Countess Dolingen'' (''Les Jeux de la Comtesse Dolingen de Gratz''), a first feature directed by Catherine Binet, is a handsome, baffling film that communicates not through reason or through any consistent, linear narrative, but through an association of images and emotions. Like some dreams, it is immensely vivid while it is happening -sometimes seductive and soothing and sometimes nightmarish. When it's all over, one recalls a pleasurable experience without having a clue to what really was going on.

title: CENSUS DATA SHOW GAINS IN HOUSING AND EDUCATION
description: In all states, for the first time, more than half of those over 25 years old have completed at least four years of high school.

title: Arts Seminar to Explore Direct-Mail Marketing
description: A two-day seminar on direct-mail marketing for the arts will be given tomorrow and Thursday at Theater Row, 42d Street between 9th and 10th Avenues, sponsored by the Alliance of Resident Theaters.

title: BIOLOGIST AWARDED $600,000 FOR CANCER STUDY
description: For outstanding research on the genetics of human cancer, Dr. Michael Wigler of the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory on Long Island has been awarded a grant of $600,000, the American Business Cancer Foundation announced today.

title: WESTERN UNION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Includes $4.2 million gain from consumation of agreements for the sale of communications satelite capacity

title: Halt to Fidelity Sale Sought
description: The former management of the Fidelity Savings and Loan Association of San Francisco, which was ousted last week as a result of the failure of the thrift institution, asked a Federal court in San Francisco today to block the intended sale of the institution.

title: STORAGE TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Nets' Cook Assumes Key Role
description: When the Nets' training camp opened last fall, Darwin Cook was just one of many young hopefuls looking for a place in Larry Brown's backcourt.

title: Liberalism and the Chinese Bedroom
description: Something like 1984 already seems well entrenched in China. Fox Butterfield's illuminating report Sunday in The New York Times Magazine documents the chilling extent to which all daily life is monitored. An engineer avoids telling anything personal to people at his workplace, knowing that workers can be ordered to tell whatever they know about each other. Local street committees can search one's house at any hour. And probably the most chilling aspect of social control is one with an American echo.

title: Rockets' Hayes Upset
description: The Houston Rockets are evidently ready for the National Basketball Association playoffs. As they did last season, when they upset the Los Angeles Lakers, San Antonio Spurs and Kansas City Kings to reach the finals, the Rockets got the final playoff berth and will open tomorrow night at Seattle in a three-game series in which the SuperSonics have the home-court advantage.

title: Rasmussen to the Bench
description: There will be a changing of the guard on the Jets this year, according to Bob Fry, the offensive line coach.

title: NEW GELCO HEAD SHUNS 'IVORY TOWER' MANAGING
description: Morton L. Zalk, 61, has been elected president and chief operating officer of the Gelco Corporation, a leasing and transportation services company with headquarters in Eden Prairie, Minn. As president, he succeeds N. Bud Grossman, the 59-year-old founder of the corporation, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer.

title: REAGAN APPOINTS AIDE AS MINORITY LINK
description: President Reagan, in a shift of policy on minority affairs, today appointed a black special assistant, Melvin L. Bradley, to represent the interests of minorities in the White House.

title: Cattle on Feed Rise
description: The number of cattle fattened in feedlots prior to slaughter April 1 rose 2 percent from a year earlier for the first year-to-year rise in four years, the Agriculture Department said today. Cattle and calves on feed in 13 states totaled 8.82 million head. The figure was 2 percent less than two years ago.

title: RICHARD JAMIESON
description: Richard Jamieson, an actor who last year appeared in George Farquhar's ''The Recruiting Officer'' at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, died last Thursday in Burlington, Vt.

title: No Headline
description: GIBSON POWERS TIGERS

title: MINISTRIES OF ECONOMICS
description: As increasing financial hardship is met with diminishing Federal welfare programs, residents are turning to the churches of this city for help.

title: Court Approves Lehigh Plan
description: The Lehigh Valley Railroad Company, which sought shelter under the Federal Bankruptcy Act in 1970, has been given approval for a revised and amended plan of reorganization.

title: REPUBLICANS SAY A KEY IS 'JOHNNY LUNCHBUCKET'
description: As the House of Representatives returns tomorrow from its Easter recess, it is appropriate to remember the maxim of Speaker of the House Thomas P. O'Neill Jr.: ''All politics is local.''

title: INTERDISCIPLINARY COURSES ARE TRIED IN SOME COLLEGES
description: WHEN Morris Dickstein, a member of the English department at Queens College, decided to offer a course about the 1960's, he thought it would be a mistake to treat the heat and fervor of the decade only through its literature without giving equal attention to its sociological significance.

title: Choreographer Gets a Lesson in Brazilian Law
description: Because the two countries have no extradition treaty, Brazil has become a favorite haven for those seeking to avoid prosecution in the United States.

title: NEW YORK STATE ELECTRIC & GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
A Near Blizzard Strikes In the Northern Plains
description: The Winter of 1982 stubbornly clung to the Northern Plains yesterday, whipping up near-blizzard conditions in the Dakotas, burying parts of Minnesota, Michigan and South Dakota under nearly a foot of snow and coating roads in Wyoming and North Dakota with ice.

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart in Metropolitan Report on April 5 showing New York City's cost for wages and benefits of employees in 10 major jobs included several inac- curacies.

title: MURPHY MOTOR FREIGHT LINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
By Theodore W. Libbey Jr.; Music for a While Salutes Machaut
description: As part of a weekend festival of early music at the Symphony Space, Music for a While offered a program devoted to the verse and music of the 14th-century French composer Guillaume de Machaut on Sunday afternoon. The staged presentation, which purported to be an allegorical dramatization of Machaut's life, was entitled ''La Fontaine Amoureuse'' and featured as its final part ''Le Lai de la Fonteinne,'' the composer's tribute to the Virgin Mary.

title: PENNSYLVANIA BANKS SET MERGER ACCORD
description: Two of Pennsylvania's largest bank holding companies, the Pittsburgh National Corporation and the Provident National Corporation, said today that they had agreed in principle to merge.

title: SYMBOL TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Martin Marietta Off
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation, a manufacturer of cement, aerospace and aluminum products, among others, today reported a first-quarter earnings slide of 60.2 percent.

title: SPRINGS MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Cobb Stops Shelburg
description: Randy (Tex) Cobb stopped Jeff Shelburg at 2:17 of the seventh round in their scheduled 10-round heavyweight bout tonight.

title: NOW IN NEW YORK, FALL SHOWS OPEN
description: For the next two weeks New York becomes the center of the fashion world. Willi Smith opened the fall fashion season yesterday morning with a lively showing in his new quarters off Seventh Avenue. He was followed every hour on the hour by other designers' openings. Before the month is over, several hundred collections will be unveiled - in showrooms, in auditoriums of the two prominent fashion schools in the area, the Parsons School of Design and the Fashion Institute of Technology, and in a few hotels and discotheques.

title: Commodore Move
description: Commodore International introduced three new personal computers, which its chairman, Irving Gould, said would sell for far less than comparable products on the market and would be shipped by September.

title: CHOCK FULL O'NUTS RESISTING MOVES BY FINKELSTEIN
description: Chock Full o'Nuts may be known, as the advertising jingle says, for its heavenly coffee, but some Wall Street investors seem to feel that the quiet little company is also real estate rich.

title: GREYHOUND DEFENDS AIDE'S AUTO PURCHASES
description: The Greyhound Corporation said yesterday that the president of its Greyhound Rent-a-Car Inc. subsidiary committed no impropriety by purchasing more than 600 automobiles for his unit last year from a Miami dealership that is 50 percent owned by his son.

title: Tribute to Dr. King Set For Sunday in Bronx
description: A tribute to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. will be presented Sunday at 2 P.M. by the Church of Christ the King and Caribbean House. There will be an ecumenical observance at the church at 1345 Grand Concourse, between West 169th and 170th Streets.

title: TANDY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
PENNWALT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-After $6,064,000 loss from discontinued operations and $16,295,000 gain from an accounting change

title: Pacific Atoll Landowners Ask U.S. To Halt Tests
description: The landowners of Kwajalein atoll in the Marshall Islands, where the United States has tested long-range ballistic missiles for nearly 20 years, demanded today that the tests be halted pending a referendum on whether the operations should continue.

title: Woman and Black Named For Shuttle Missions
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced yesterday the crews for the seventh, eighth and ninth space shuttle missions. They include the first woman to fly an American space mission and the first black astronaut.

title: ELECTRO-POP: PETE SHELLEY
description: rock hits of the last several months with ''Homosapien.'' Produced in a synthesized electro-pop style that could scarcely be more removed from the Buzzcocks's hard-edged punk, the song is one of the wittier pop expressions of the confusion that exists between people and computers.

title: 219 Nuclear Protesters Get Fines or Jail Terms
description: Almost four years after they were arrested for blocking access to the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant, 219 people were sentenced today to either spend 10 days in jail or pay a $300 fine.

title: ISLANDERS WIN, 5 TO 3, TAKE 3-1 LEAD OVER RANGERS
description: The Islanders and the Rangers played a swift and hectic Stanley Cup playoff game at Madison Square Garden last night, and when it was over the Islanders had won for the third time in the series, 5-3.

title: PHILIP MORRIS CLIMBS BY 22.9%
description: Philip Morris Inc. reported yesterday that net income in the first quarter of 1982 climbed 22.9 percent, while revenues increased 11.2 percent.

title: Black Hawks Top Blues, Take 3-1 Lead
description: Denis Savard scored three goals tonight to lead Chicago to a 7-4 victory over the St. Louis Blues, giving the Black Hawks a 3-1 lead in their quarterfinal playoff series.

title: For $2.7 Million, CBS Gets Cuisine Magazine
description: That which was supposed to happen, happened. CBS Inc. has acquired Cuisine Magazine - for $2.7 million.

title: POSTAL SERVICE'S POWER TO SET NEW MAIL RATES IS CONTESTED
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide how much flexibility Congress intended to give the United States Postal Service in setting postal rates for different classes of mail.

title: Prosecutor Closes Case In Death of Indiana Baby
description: The Monroe County prosecutor, Barry Brown, said today that he would not file charges in the death of a week-old deformed baby who was denied nourishment and medical treatment at the parents' request.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: BY Thursday it was official. The fashion epidemic that started one m onth ago in Milan and then traveled to London and Paris finally hit N ew York. More foreign fashion journalists arrived than many had seena t other American collections and a press service center was set up a t 552 Seventh Avenue, near 40th Street, to help out-of-town r eporters file their stories.

title: CHAMBER: PIANIST PLAYS TRIO
description: THE Polish-born pianist Artur Balsam made his debut Sunday with the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, anchoring trios by Haydn and Beethoven on the society's final subscription program of the season at Alice Tully Hall. The afternoon's lengthy offering included the Quintet for Clarinet and Strings in B minor (Op. 115) by Brahms and a suite for piano and winds written in 1940 by the French composer Florent Schmitt.

title: MA BELL'S FAULTY PROPOSED BILL OF DIVORCEMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: MEDIA GENERAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
MUSICAL: 'FIVE POINTS' TELLS A BIT OF BLACK HISTORY
description: life figures who dominated it. Though conceived as a light entertainment, ''Five Points'' is no exception, at least in principle. This musical's hero is William Henry Lane, who, under the nickname Juba, was a pivotal figure in the history of jazz dancing in the 19th century.

title: RECESSION PRESSES WASHINGTON STATE
description: With umemployment in this state at 13 percent and a budget delicately balanced by a sales tax on groceries, Gov. John Spellman of Washington believes conditions may get worse.

title: Rowntree Mackintosh
description: Rowntree Mackintosh is continuing to explore possibilities for expansion in the United States and has reorganized its American operations to help its efforts, Kenneth Dixon, the company's chairman, said in the annual report. The company recently dropped a takeover bid for Huntley & Palmer Foods after a higher bid from Nabisco Brands Inc. and referral of the offer to the Monopolies and Exchange Commission.

title: TWO MEN ARE FACING KIDNAPPPING CHARGES AS WOMAN IS FOUND
description: A woman who said she was abducted in Ohio scrawled ''I am a kidnap victim'' in lipstick on a service station bathroom in Alabama and eventually escaped from her two male captors by running her car into a fence, the authorities said today.

title: TRITON ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: B-Includes $55,000 extraordinary gain

title: PACIFIC SCIENTIFIC COO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
PERCY BOAS
description: Percy Boas, a former cotton broker, died Friday at his home in Manhattan.

title: Business and the Law; If a Product Is Defective
description: IF you are injured by a defective product, and you sue the manufacturer, chances are that the lawyers who work on your case will get seven dollars for every six that you recover.

title: BANKAMERICA HAS 3.5% GAIN
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation reported yesterday that its firstquarter net operating earnings soared 58.1 percent from the level a year earlier, while the BankAmerica Corporation reported a rise of only 3.5 percent.

title: PICCADILLY CAFETERIAS reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Prost Awarded Victory
description: The Appeals Tribunal of the International Auto Federation has disqualified the first two finishers in the March 21 Brazilian Formula One Grand Prix - Nelson Piquet of Brazil and Finland's Keke Rosberg - because the cars did not satisfy Formula One minimum weight regulations. The decision, which cannot be appealed, was taken following protests raised by the French and Italian auto sport federations on behalf of the Renault and Ferrari racing teams. The victory now goes to France's Alain Prost, who finished third.

title: Braniff Comment
description: Braniff International said it would consider negotiating for airlines other than Pan American World Airways to fly its South American routes, following a Civil Aeronautics Board decision last Friday not to grant interim approval of Pan Am's takeover of these routes. Braniff said it was disappointed with the decision and still believed its agreement with Pan Am was valid. It said the agreement with Pan Am would have given it breathing space to overcome its current economic difficulties.

title: U.S. Sextet Defeated By Czechoslovakia, 6-0
description: Czechoslovakia beat the United States, 6-0, today in the world hockey championship.

title: UNITED TECHNOLOGIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Includes $66,600,000 gain from an accounting change

title: Chess: 2 Americans Tie for First At Indonesia Tournament
description: The First Lady Tournament held in Surakarta and Denpasar, Indonesia, was a triumph for the grandmaster Walter Browne of Berkeley, Calif., and the international master Ronald Henley of New York, who shared the $27,500 first prize. Each scored 17 1/2-7 1/2.

title: 20,000 Join a Fascist March In Madrid Backing Argentina
description: About 20,000 Spaniards, their right arms raised in the fascist salute, marched through Madrid tonight, chanting their support for Argentina's invasion of the Falkland Islands.

title: PIANO: AX PLAYS HAYDN
description: EMANUEL AX'S recital Sunday night at Carnegie Hall marked the continuing progress of a distinguished young pianist. Occasionally, Mr. Ax's fingers overpowered his ear and created half-intelligible blurs of velocity, but those occasions were few.

title: MUSHROOM SPORES SUSPECTED AS CULPRIT IN ALLERGIC REACTIONS THAT BAFFLED
description: SPECIALISTS By BAYARD WEBSTER

title: American Home Gains
description: The American Home Products Corporation said yesterday that its first-quarter profit was up 13.8 percent, to $145.1 million, or 93 cents a share, from $127.5 million, or 81 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales rose 6 percent, to $1.11 billion, from $1.05 billion. The company's products include prescription drugs and packaged foods.

title: HAIG ENDS TALKS WITH ARGENTINES ON A SOMBER NOTE
description: Warning that ''war in the South Atlantic would be the greatest of tragedies and that time is indeed running out,'' Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. flew to Washington from Buenos Aires tonight after talks on the Falkland Islands crisis.

title: Boldirev Helps Canucks Gain 3-1 Lead
description: Ivan Boldirev scored a pair of goals and assisted on another tonight to lift the Vancouver Canucks to a 5-4 victory over the Los Angeles Kings and a 3-1 lead in their playoff series. The fifth game will be played Wednesday in Vancouver.

title: PARKER-HANNIFIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Q&A
description: Q. What would be the results if a nuclear bomb hit a nuclear power plant? Would the effects be multiplied? Radiation increased? Explosive force magnified?

title: 12 Killed at Indonesian Rally
description: Twelve people were killed and at least 130 were injured in a stampede at a political rally in South Kalimantan, a police spokesman said today. He said the stampede took place on Sunday as supporters of the opposition Moslem United Development Party rushed to leave a crowded stadium in Kalimantan, the Indonesian part of Borneo.

title: CHILEAN CABINET IS DISMISSED
description: President Augusto Pinochet, his country in deep recession and his economic policies beset by critics, dismissed all 16 members of the Cabinet today.

title: APPLE ENDS COMPUTERLAND TIE
description: Apple Computer Inc. announced yesterday that it had terminated its central buying agreement with Computerland, the nation's largest chain of computer stores. Apple said it was acting in an attempt to gain control over the location of retail outlets carrying its products.

title: UPDIKE AND KIDDER WIN AMERICAN BOOK AWARDS
description: John Updike and Tracy Kidder, both of whom won Pulitzer Prizes last week, were among the winners in the literary categories of the 1982 American Book Awards.

title: U.S. COURT TO PICK A MASTER TO REDISTRICT NEW YORK STATE
description: A special Federal court declared yesterday that it would appoint someone to develop reapportionment plans for New York State's Senate, Assembly and Congressional districts because the State Legislature had failed to adopt the necessary plans.

title: Britons Set Up Everest Camp
description: A British expedition has established its base camp at 21,000 feet in an attempt to climb the unscaled east side of Mount Everest, the world's highest peak, according to a report received here today.The six-man team set up the camp April 4, the report said.

title: Miss Ruiz Held For Larceny
description: Rosie Ruiz, who two years ago was the first woman to finish the Boston Marathon, but was disqualified a week later when it was determined that she had not run the full 26 miles 385 yards, was arrested in New York on charges of larceny and forgery yesterday, a half-hour before the annual race.

title: ARGENTINA'S REACH FOR THE SANDWICH ISLES
description: To the Editor:

title: LOWENSTEIN, M, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
THE TELLING CUTS IN STUDENT AID
description: To the Editor:

title: SALVADOR ASSEMBLY MEETS FOR FIRST TIME
description: El Salvador's new Constituent Assembly held its first session today, dispatching its initial work with a speed and unanimity that, officials acknowledged, is unlikely to last for long.

title: MORE FUNDS ARE SOUGHT FOR VOICE OF AMERICA
description: The International Communication Agency, saying that the United States was ''waging a war of ideas with our adversaries,'' asked for more funds today for broadcasts to the Caribbean, Asia and Africa.

title: Where Tokens Can Be Bought
description: Bracing for another traffic jam at tollbooths for bridges and tunnels leading into Manhattan this morning, the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority advised that ''the more people that use tokens, the better the traffic is going to flow.''

title: Islanders, Mets Sign Pay-TV Agreements
description: SportsChannel, a New York-New Jersey pay cable-television network, said yesterday it had signed a 30-year agreement with the Islanders to televise home and road games.

title: Peru Treasures Recovered
description: The police have recovered part of a collection of gold and silver treasures stolen from the National Archeological Museum last November, police sources said today.

title: DON'T DEPORT ETHOPIANS
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service last fall began to notify thousands of Ethiopians on voluntary-departure status that unless they left the country before Nov. 30, deportation proceedings would begin. The change in policy, the Service said, resulted from ''stabilization of conditions'' in Ethiopia. That assessment, the State Department's, is not shared by the refugees, who claim they risk persecution because of political and religious beliefs and ethnic origins.

title: Gold and Silver Futures Show Substantial Drop
description: Precious metals futures prices crumbled yesterday in the largest one-day decline since late last September. Although the market had expected gold and silver prices to decline for both fundamental and technical reasons, many brokers and traders said they were surprised by the size of the losses.

title: Borg Advances
description: Bjorn Borg won his first-round qualifying match today in the $370,000 Alan King tennis tournament, a Grand Prix hard-court event.

title: In Talk, JWT Officials Skirt Computer Issue
description: Considering all the troubles the JWT Group has had with its finances, due to the much-publicized computer irregularities in its syndication unit, members of the New York Society of Securities Analysts showed little interest in the matter when the holding company's management made a lunchtime presentation yesterday.

title: MARTIN MARIETTA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
RESERVE OIL & MINERALS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
ILLINOIS TOOL WORKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Including a net gain of $1,277,000 on the sale of an interest in a Japanese affiliate

title: WESTERN PACIFIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Includes $933,000 gain from the sale of marketable securities and $660,000 charge from the discontinuance of certain activities

title: BALLET: FANS ATTRACTED BY PITTSBURGH TROUPE
description: THE Pittsburgh Ballet Theater, which made a New York debut Sunday afternoon and Saturday night at Lehman College's Center for the Performing Arts, attracted an unusually large audience.

title: BLAST INJURES 7 IN SHIPYARD
description: Seven persons were injured today by an explosion aboard the Navy frigate Garcia, which was being overhauled at the General Shipyard on Boston Harbor, the authorities said. Three sailors and an employee of the General Ship Corporation suffered minor injuries. Another General Ship worker was admitted to Massachusetts General Hospital, Navy spokesmen said.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Aluminum Company of America, Pittsburgh, has elected Robert F. Qlagle treasurer.

title: MCLEAN TRUCKING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-After $1,017,500 loss from discontinued operations for the qr and $1,136,597 gain from discontinued operations for the 9 mos and $4,456,199 charge for the 9 mos

title: POST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
The U.N. Today; April 20, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets on question of Palestinians at 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: SUBTLE SHIFTS IN IMAGE FOR THE PRESIDENT
description: A casual invitation to President Leonid I. Brezhnev and a Presidential radio talk emphasizing peace. The promotion of one black to a significant White House post and the appointment of another to the Presidential staff. Willingness to consider an income surtax on upper-bracket Americans in the budget negotiations and a personal appearance at a Chicago parochial school.

title: SEA GALLEY STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Peavey to Merge With Conagra Unit
description: A merger between two food processing concerns, the Peavey Company of Minneapolis and a subsidiary of Conagra Inc. of Omaha, was announced jointly by company officials. The deal is valued at about $175 million.

title: BOSTON INVESTORS CONTESTING LICENSE
description: An investor group of prominent Boston-area residents is contesting the right of the New England Television Corporation to receive a license for WNAC-TV, following the Supreme Court's refusal yesterday to hear the appeal of RKO General, which lost the right to operate the station in a decision by the Federal Communications Commission.

title: HIGH COURT TO RULE ON TAX STATUS OF RACIALLY BIAS PRIVATE SCHOOLS
description: Ending months of uncertainty, the Supreme Court announced today that it would decide, after all, whether racially discriminatory private schools are entitled to Federal tax exemptions.

title: SHARED MEDICAL SYSTEMS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
WESTERN MARINE ELECTRONICS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
NBI INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
U.S., LINKING CUBA TO 'VIOLENCE,' BLOCKS TOURIST AND BUSINESS TRIPS
description: The United States announced new restrictions today that will have the effect of banning tourist and business travel to Cuba after May 15.

title: Alfalfa and Immune Disease
description: Research in monkeys has revealed that a substance in alfalfa seeds and sprouts can cause a syndrome identical to the serious immunological disease, systemic lupus erythematosus (also called SLE or lupus).

title: TENNANT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
S.E.C. ACTS IN INSIDER NAVY CASE
description: In an unusual action against a Government employee, the Securities and Exchange Commission accused a Navy procurement official today of using inside information to trade in the stock of a company he helped get a naval contract.

title: PONDEROSA SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 25
description: B-Includes $1.9 million gain from the purchase of tax benefits...C-Net loss

title: 100 YEARS AFTER DARWIN'S DEATH, HIS THEORY STILL EVOLVES
description: IT has been a century since the death of Charles Darwin, and the mere mention of his name still manages to excite controversy. Just as Bishop Samuel Wilberforce condemned Darwin's theory of evolution when ''On the Origin of Species'' was first published in 1859, so today religious fundamentalists continue to challenge Darwinian theory and support instead divine creation.

title: NEWS BLACKOUT ON SINAI EVICTIONS STIRS ISRAELI PROTESTS
description: As intensive diplomatic negotiations continued today between Egypt and Israel on putting their peace treaty into effect, the Israeli army moved in force into northern Sinai and began evicting Jewish protesters from the settlements in the area.

title: Women's Film Festival Will Run May 12-18
description: Women Make Movies Inc. will present 36 films from nine nations in a festival from May 12 to 18 at the Film Forum, 57 Watts Street. The second festival is, according to its sponsors, the largest women's film festival in the United States.

title: 2 MAN GARBAGE CREWS AGREED ON FOR THE CITY
description: New York City and the leadership of the sanitation workers' union announced an agreement yesterday to replace all three-man sanitation crews with two-man crews. They would work on trucks that now use three men, as well as trucks that were specifically designed for reduced crews.

title: WHEELABRATOR-FRYE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Restated to reflect the discontinuance of Pullman Transportation Co and FirstGreatwest Corp

title: RALSTON PURINA CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $600,000 for the qr and $3.1 million for the 6 mos

title: Davis Cites Warning To Owners of Illegality
description: Al Davis, owner of the Oakland Raiders, testified today that National Football League team owners were warned by a lawyer for the league more than three years ago that a rule restricting the movement of franchises was illegal.

title: 'Family Event' for Columbia Journalism Review
description: It was going to be, Osborn Elliott was saying, ''a nice spoofing event, a family event.'' In this case, it was the family of the Columbia Journalism Review, gathering at the Princeton Club last night for a double event - a celebration of the publication's 20th anniversary and a retirement party for Edward W. Barrett, who started the magazine in 1962.

title: PHILIP MORRIS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-After $10 million reduction in earnings from the adoption of F.A.S.B. Statement No 52 for foreign currency translation

title: 10 Arrested by Italian Police As Urban Guerrilla Suspects
description: The police said today that they had made 10 arrests and discovered a hide-out in Padua in their continuing offensive against the left-wing Red Brigades urban guerrilla group.

title: Loss for Great Western
description: The Great Western Financial Corporation, the parent of the nation's second-largest savings and loan association, said today that it lost $14.6 million in the first quarter, a sharp reversal from its 1981 first-quarter profit of $841,000, or 4 cents a share. It attributed the loss to stubbornly high interest rates.

title: NATIVE OF HUNGARY IS JAILED IN SOUTH ON SPYING CHARGES
description: Otto Attilla Gilbert, a native of Hungary, was arraigned here today on charges of conspiracy to commit espionage. The Federal authorities say he tried to buy national defense secrets from a Hungarian-born United States Army warrant officer stationed at Fort Gordon.

title: National Medical In Acquisition
description: National Medical Enterprises said that it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire the privately held First Washington Group Inc., a 13-state psychiatric hospital chain, in a transaction valued at $100 million.

title: DUTCH QUEEN IN U.S. TO MARK 200 YEARS OF CLOSE RELATIONS
description: President Reagan welcomed Queen Beatrix of the Netherlands to the White House today, praising the longtime alliance between the Dutch and American peoples.

title: TINY FISH LOOMS LARGE IN EVOLUTION DEBATE
description: DEVILS HOLE, Nev. IN water warm and tranquil, where their ancestors were stranded long ago by the vicissitudes of nature, here in a remote desert spring and nowhere else in the world, some tiny fish live under circumstances that would have entranced Charles Darwin.

title: Financial General Control Claimed
description: After a lengthy battle to gain control of Financial General Bancshares Inc., a group of Middle Eastern investors announced yesterday that, as a result of a successful tender offer, they now control about 96 percent of the company's outstanding common.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''People are ready to kill us. I've never seen the traffic like this.

title: SOME CHEMICALS FOUND IN THE HUMAN BRAIN ARE ALSO PRODUCED BY ONE-CELLED
description: ANIMALS By HAROLD M. SCHMECK Jr.

title: SHUE GOES TO BAT FOR HAYWOOD
description: Gene Shue made an unusual request recently. The Washington Bullets' coach wrote to members of the Professional Basketball Writers' Association, who vote for the postseason awards, asking that they consider designating Spencer Haywood ''comeback player of the year.''

title: INTEREST RATESS FALL SHARPLY
description: Interest rates fell sharply yesterday as traders and investors showed their optamism that a budget compromise and various technical factors would soon push down interest rates even further.

title: American Express Gains
description: The American Express Company said yesterday that its first-quarter profit rose 8.3 percent from a year earlier, mainly on improved earnings by its travel-related operations such as the American Express charge card.

title: Disarmament Rally Gets Backing From a Concert
description: Rallies can be expensive: Organizers need telephones and copying machines, speakers need sound systems, marchers need buttons and banners.

title: LITTON PRESIDENT HAS HOMECOMING
description: Eight years after he left Litton Industries to run a small semiconductor company, Orion L. Hoch, 53 years old, will come home to Litton to become president and chief operating officer, succeeding Fred W. O'Green, 61, who will remain chairman and chief executive officer.

title: Judge Drops Charges In Portman Protests
description: To applause and cheers of ''bravo,'' Judge Bernard J. Fried of Manhattan Criminal Court dismissed trespass charges yesterday against 165 theater people and supporters arrested during a protest March 22. They were trying to prevent the razing of the Helen Hayes and Morosco Theaters, the destruction of which would make way for the construction of the Portman Hotel.

title: Theory on Harsh Winter
description: A relatively tiny but persistent decrease in the amount of solar energy reaching the earth's surface in 1980 and 1981 may have helped cause this year's unusually severe winter, a senior scientist at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory at the California Institute of Technology suggested yesterday.

title: Church Dedicates Organ At David Higgs Concert
description: The Park Avenue Christian Church presented an organ concert Sunday afternoon as part of a series dedicating its Holtkamp organ. The organ, nestled beneath the church's turquoise Tiffany glass east window, is a three manual instrument with mechanical key action, electric stop action and four divisions.

title: INFLATION'S WITHDRAWAL PAINS
description: For more than a decade, America has railed against inflation. Now it is subsiding and business, to its dismay, is discovering that lower inflation is bringing problems as well as benefits.

title: BRITISH SAY PLAN FALLS SHORT OF DEMANDS
description: The British Government said tonight that at first sight the new proposals for easing the Falkland Islands crisis submitted to it by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. did not meet its requirements.

title: RELUCTANT BUT GRATEFUL LYNCH WARMS UP TO JOB IN MET BULLPEN
description: Less than a month ago, with his spring training earned run average at 5.79, Ed Lynch realized that he would be on his way back to the minor leagues unless he first accepted Manager George Bamberger's decision to put him in the Mets' bullpen, and then excelled at his new job.

title: South Tucson Seeking Time on Damage Award
description: The City of South Tucson asked for a 30-day grace period today to work out a way to pay a $3.6 million damage award to a former police officer while delaying filing for financial reorganization.

title: UNION CAMP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
VOLUME GROWS
description: The stock market continued to advance yesterday in accelerated trading with some of the stocks that responded to specific news developments registering the largest price moves.

title: Brandt Asks Party Unity For Social Democrats
description: The Social Democratic leader, Willy Brandt, opened a national party congress today with an appeal for party unity and a call for disarmament.

title: WESTWAY: THIRD RATE COVER UP
description: Those who are still advocating the building of the lavish $4 billion, 4.2-mile superhighway-waterfront scheme known as Westway have been nervously trying to dismiss the recent Federal court decision as a technical hitch about environmental concern over striped bass that can be swiftly addressed and swept aside.

title: SOUTHAM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Includes $2,463,000 special gain

title: NCR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
NUCLEAR ARMS CAN BE A VOLATILE TOPIC FOR CLERGY
description: When the Rev. Jerry Carter steps into the pulpit of Asbury Methodist Church in Livermore, Calif., he preaches to a congregation made up largely of employees of a nearby laboratory that designs nuclear weapons.

title: BRIEFING
description: D.A.R. Invites Miss Price

title: TWO BRONX HOSPITALS WIN GRANTS TO CONSOLIDATE SERVICES FOR YOUTH
description: Two Bronx hospitals were among 20 recipients of $12 million in grants designed to consolidate medical services offered to young people. The awards were announced yesterday by the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation.

title: MILITANTS WAIT FOR AUTHORITIES TO MOVE
description: Occupied Sinai, April 19 - All night long and through the morning and the long afternoon, the squatters who want to dissuade the Israeli Government from returning this town to Egypt next Sunday waited for the army assault to dislodge them.

title: APARTMENT WORKERS SET FOR WALKOUT
description: The leader of the union representing employees at rental apartment houses and cooperatives in the city said yesterday that the workers were prepared to strike tomorrow unless there was an agreement on a new contract by midnight tonight.

title: Justice Dept. Checking Possible Klan Violence
description: The Justice Department's civil rights chief said today that Ku Klux Klan activity was increasing and that the department was conducting at least nine investigations of suspected Klan violence.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Susan Bolotin PRIZZI'S HONOR. By Richard Condon. 316 pages. Coward, McCann & Geoghegan. $13.95.

title:
NOTES ON PEOPLE;
Walt Rostow Shows Off His Musical Talent
description: He was national security adviser to Presidents John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson and has taught economics and history at Columbia, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Oxford and Cambridge. That's been the public side of Walt W. Rostow.

title: News Analysis
description: When Mayor Koch was asked one day last week what effect the budget impasse in Albany would have on New York City, he talked a good deal about how the state was required to have a budget and said that he was confident it would eventually have one. In short, by his own admission, the Mayor did not say very much.

title: CABARET: CHRIS CONNOR SINGS NUMBERS FOM KENTON DAYS
description: IN keeping with the practice at Michael's Pub in recent years of building performers' programs on a theme - often the work of a specific songwriter - Chris Connor, who sang with Stan Kenton's band for six months in 1953, did a program called ''Kenton on My Mind'' last week at the East 55th Street restaurant.

title: TV: ANN BEATTIE STORY ON 'AMERICAN PLAYHOUSE'
description: IN the current issue of The Dial, a public-television monthly magazine, literary critics were asked what they might expect from a play written by the novelist Ann Beattie. James Atlas answered, ''Laconic people talking in a depressed and guarded way.'' That very aptly describes much of ''Weekend,'' the ''American Playhouse'' presentation on WNET-TV at 9 o'clock this evening.

title: TOUGHER BAIL LAW NOT USED SINCE PASSAGE, STUDY SHOWS
description: The state's strict new bail law, which went into effect more than eight months ago, has never been invoked by any of New York City's five district attorneys, according to a private study scheduled for release today.

title: HONEYWELL ALSO UP
description: Three major computer companies reported higher quarterly earnings yesterday, with one, the Tandy Corporation, the nation's largest manufacturer of personal computers, reporting a gain of 30.1 percent.

title: State Offering Lottery On 'Instant Baseball'
description: New York State officials have announced an ''instant baseball'' lottery game to coincide with the recent opening of the baseball season.

title: HANDICAPPING THE HANDICAPPED IN SCHOOL
description: To the Editor:

title: SALAZAR WINS FASTEST BOSTON MARATHON
description: Capping a memorable duel in the sun, Alberto Salazar outkicked Dick Beardsley in the final 50 yards today and ran the fastest Boston Marathon ever, 2 hours 8 minutes 51 seconds.

title: Horse Found to Run Under a False Name
description: Maryland racing stewards ordered a purse redistribution today after having heard evidence about three races in which a colt had run under the name of a lesser competitor from the same barn.

title: LIFEMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Bridge: Stauber's Team Advances To Grand National Finals
description: One of the country's strongest bridge teams survived in Grand National Knockout play in White Plains over the weekend, along with a giant-killing quartet.

title: HAIG REPORTED SHORT OF GOAL AS HE LEAVES BUENOS AIRES
description: Administration officials said today that Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. had left Buenos Aires with some movement from the Argentine side, but not enough progress to assure an early resolution of the dispute between Argentina and Britain over the Falkland Islands.

title: TUESDAY, APRIL 20, 1982; Markets
description: Interest rates fell sharply. Optimism over a budget compromise, plus technical factors, indicate to traders and investors that rates will slide. But yields remain high: The 14 percent bonds due 2011 rose a point and a half, to 106 3/4, for a yield of 13.07 percent. (Page D1.)

title: U.S. ARMY INQUIRY ABSOLVES ADVISERS
description: The Inspector General of the United States Army has investigated charges that American military advisers witnessed the torture of two young Salvadorans in January 1981 and found the account untrue, according to the American commander in El Salvador at the time.

title: Israeli Labor Minister Is Convicted of Theft
description: Israel's Minister of Labor, Welfare and Immigrant Absorption was convicted today of theft from a charitable fund that he headed when he was Mayor of Ramle, before joining the Government.

title: Special Election Choices
description: In the New York metropolitan area, four seats in the State Legislature will be decided today in special elections.

title: GAF GETS $9.5 MILLION IN KODAK SUIT
description: In a settlement that clears up the last of the major antitrust actions filed against the Eastman Kodak Company during the 1970's, the photography giant agreed yesterday to pay the GAF Corporation $9.5 million and to drop a claim that GAF violated licensing agreements.

title: New Yorkers to Dance In July Festival in Italy
description: Twelve dancers from the High School of Performing Arts have been invited to perform at the 1982 Festival of Two Worlds at Spoleto, Italy, on July 15, 16 and 17.

title: GIBSON ASSETS HE'S NOT GUILTY IN PLEA TO JUDGE
description: Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson and City Council President Earl Harris, who are opponents in a heated mayoral campaign here, pleaded not guilty today to charges that they bilked the city out of more than $115,000 by creating ''no show'' jobs for a former City Councilman.

title: Outside Magazine Uses R.J. Reynolds Concept
description: Donald E. Welsh, creative thinker and publisher of Outside magazine, was fairly quick to see the possibilities for his publication - dedicated as it is to rugged travel - and R.J. Reynolds Tobacco's Camel Expeditions promotion, now in its second year.

title: Bankruptcies Up 50%
description: The number of United States businesses that failed in the first 14 weeks of this year is up 50 percent from the same period a year ago, according to Dun & Bradstreet, a leading financial reporting service. During the first 14 weeks of this year, 6,205 companies failed. That includes only those companies that owed money to creditors when they went under.

title: Bank Interest In Holly Sugar
description: Michael S. Buchsbaum, the chairman of the Holly Sugar Corporation who heads a group considering buying the company, said the Republic Bank of Texas had indicated it was interested in leading a bank group to provide financing of the purchase and working capital.

title: TRAFFIC JAMMED AT NINE CROSSINGS IN NEW YORK CITY AS TOLLS INCREASE
description: Traffic moving into and out of Manhattan backed up for miles yesterday as higher toll charges went into effect at nine bridges and tunnels in New York City. Motorists waiting on long lines fumbled and grumbled, searching for change and tokens.

title: The Puffs From Havana's Cigar
description: First, the hard-nosed interpretation of Cuba's unexpected pitch for better relations with the United States: It's a trick and a trap. Fidel Castro doesn't really mean it when his agents express a desire to ''talk'' with Washington, admit to having smuggled arms to Central America and disapprove of the Soviet interventions in Poland and Afghanistan.

title: U.S. IS LOOKING TO THE HONDURANS TO HOLD THE LINE
description: With leftist revolutionaries ruling Nicaragua and Marxist guerrillas vying for power in El Salvador and Guatemala, the United States seems anxious to convert Honduras into a buffer against the spread of Communism in Central America.

title: AMERICAN WAY OF HOUSING CHANGING AS NUMBER AND COST OF UNITS INCREASE
description: In direct response to powerful social and economic forces that have scattered the American population over the last decade and fragmented families, the kinds of dwellings Americans inhabit have changed substantially, according to the census report made public today.

title: NATIONAL MINE SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 26
Metromedia Sets Beep Purchase
description: Metromedia Inc., the nation's fourth-largest broadcast operation, announced that it had agreed in principle to acquire Beep Communications Systems for an indicated value of $9.6 million, or $6 a share.

title: A Breakdown at CERN
description: An important experiment that could verify a central theory of elementary particles has been delayed several months by a recent accident at the European Organization for Nuclear Research (CERN) at Geneva. The institution's proton synchrotron was contaminated with dust during servicing operations.

title: Sports of The Times; First Lady of Pro Football
description: IN other years, Red Grange, George Halas and Art Rooney had been the celebrants of the Super Bowl ceremonial coin toss. And when Marie Lombardi was selected for that role at Super Bowl XV in New Orleans, she was asked what her late husband would have thought about it.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article April 12 on the Limited Editions Club gave an incorrect date for the death of the founder, George Macy. He died May 20, 1956.

title: WALBRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
ROHM & HAAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Includes $4.4 million gain from the sale of operations from the company's oiland gas properties

title: Rubber Workers Reach Model Pact at Goodrich
description: The United Rubber Workers reached a tentative agreement with the B.F. Goodrich Company today on a contract with cost-of-living adjustments but no general wage increase for three years.

title: Advertising; Thomson's Philosophy
description: TODAY, International Thomas Business Press will complete its acquisition of Titsch Publications, a dynamic Denver based publisher in the leisure technology field. That is one of the six areas where the two-year-old Thomson Organization subsidiary is determined to become a major force and is spending $100 million a year for five years to insure it.

title: NORDIQUES WIN, 7-2, EVEN SERIES AT 2-2
description: The Stastny brothers, Peter, Marian and Anton, each scored a goal tonight to lead the Quebec Nordiques to a 7-2 rout of the Boston Bruins that tied their quarterfinal playoff series at two games apiece.

title: TRANSIT AUXILIARY POLICE PATROL BRONX AND BROOKLYN STATIONS
description: By day they lead disparate lives. Robert Lang dispenses pipe fittings, bath fixtures, circuit breakers and mops in the Co-op City maintenance stockroom. Rosetta Watts monitors insurance commissions at Frank B. Hall & Company near Wall Street. Luis Rivera sits in class, finishing his last year at Theodore Roosevelt High School. Noreen Kelley feeds data into the computers of the New York City Finance Department. And James O'Connor patrols the floors of the National Bank of North America.

title: U.S. to Pay $138 Million To Banks on Polish Aid
description: The Commodity Credit Corporation will soon pay American banks an additional $138 million as a reimbursement for federally guaranteed loans to Poland that are overdue, a Commodity Credit Corporation official said today.

title: Enoxy Acquisition
description: Enoxy Chemicals S.A., a joint venture of Italy's state-owned energy company, Ente Nazionale Idrocarbi, and the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, has agreed in principle to buy International Synthetic Rubber Company, an Occidental spokesman said here. International Synthetic, which produces synthetic rubber, is currently owned by a consortium of tire manufacturers that includes Dunlop Holdings, Firestone and Goodyear. The spokesman gave no financial details of the deal, but said that final arrangements should be completed by early May.

title: A JERSEY MAN IS HELD FOR POLICE QUESTIONS ABOUT CBS SLAYINGS
description: A 46-year-old Keansburg, N.J., man was arrested in Kentucky yesterday on a forgery warrant, and the New York City police said he would be questioned in the slayings last week of a Federal witness and three CBS employees.

title: COMPUTER SOFTWARE FOUND WEAK
description: AN expert examination of the teaching materials, or software, available for the programming of educational minicomputers has found most of them boring and pedagogically flawed.

title: HOSPITAL INDUSTRY PROPOSES FIXED PAYMENTS FOR MEDICARE PATIENTS
description: The hospital industry called today for a new system of Medicare reimbursement under which hospitals would receive a standard payment, set in advance, for each elderly patient regardless of length of stay or illness.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Automatic Data Processing has acquired the Houston and San Antonio data processing operations of Computer Statistics Inc. for an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: CONNECTICUT SENATE TO ACT ON BUDGET
description: The State Senate is scheduled to take up the expenditure portion of the $3.19 billion state budget on Tuesday, completing the most important task of the General Assembly's waning session.

title: A NEW LOOK FROM JAPAN
description: More than 700 people attended the showing last Thursday night of the new fall collection of Yohji Yamamoto, a relatively unknown Japanese designer who received enthusiastic reviews for his collection in Paris recently.

title: BRITISH COMING FOR 83' ARTS FESTIVAL
description: A dazzling display of Britain's cultural vitality is to fill many of New York's performing halls and museums next April for ''Britain Salutes New York,'' the city's first international arts festival. Lincoln Center, Carnegie Hall, the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Museum of Modern Art, Town Hall and the Morgan Library are among the sites where the four-month festival will take place.

title: PUBLIC RADIO IN DEAL TO SEND DATA TEXT
description: National Public Radio, facing a sharp reduction in Federal funding, said today that it had agreed to form a joint venture with a private corporation to transmit digital information to homes, offices and businesses.

title: WHITE HOUSE AND CONGRESS AGREE ON DISCRETIONARY SPENDING FREEZE
description: White House aides and Congressional leaders have tentatively agreed on a freeze on discretionary nonmilitary spending that would yield savings of more than $30 billion over three years, according to Democrats and Republicans. But the negotiators seeking a budget compromise remain far apart on whether to increase taxes and curb benefit programs.

title: ALEXANDER REJOINS YANKS AS A STARTER
description: Doyle Lafayette Alexander rejoined the New York Yankees today after five years on three other teams and promptly became the No.4 man in the pitching rotation and the No.1 man in a series of decisions that could further recast the team.

title: IDEAL TOY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: B-Includes tax credits of $4,847,000 for the qr and $6,703,000 for the yr...C-Net loss

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SEE IT NOW

title: Power Agency Upheld On Its S.I. Newspaper
description: There is no legal bar to the State Power Authority's publication of a newspaper to rebut what it called unfair reporting by The Staten Island Advance, Attorney General Robert Abrams said yesterday.

title: Attorney General Gets A Second Dining Room
description: Attorney General William French Smith has installed a second private dining room on the fifth floor of the Justice Department.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum RateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellweather issues

title: Passing the School Buck
description: Even Congressional friends of President Reagan's tuition tax credit plan admit that it hasn't a prayer of enactment this year, given the staggering Federal deficit and lukewarm support for the idea. But politics ought not to obscure serious questions about the merits of the plan.

title: UNIROYAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
STALEY, A E, MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
NATIONAL HOME CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Includes $943,000 ain from the purchase of $1,700,000 face 4 percent convertible subordinated

title: PYM TO COME TO U.S.
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, expressing serious reservations about the latest Falkland Islands peace plan, announced today that Foreign Secretary Francis Pym would go to Washington on Thursday with a set of counterproposals.

title: Carey and Legislature Seek a Budget Accord
description: Governor Carey and legislative leaders agreed today to make a final effort at ending the impasse over the state budget.

title: North Sea Oil Find
description: The state-owned British National Oil Corporation, operator for the Halibut Group, said today it had found oil at its 211/18a-24 well, in the northern section of the British sector of the North Sea, adjacent to the Norwegian median line.

title: TESTS ON HUMANS
description: Press reports, some sensational, of lapses in the protection of human subjects in cancer research have generated anxiety in patients and resentment in medical centers.

title: Key Rates
description: Previous Year In percent Yesterday Day Ago PRIME RATE 16.50 16.50 17.50 DISCOUNT RATE 12.00 12.00 13.00 FEDERAL FUNDS 14.18 14.87 15.88 3-MO. TREAS. BILLS 12.31 12.49 13.62 6-MO. TREAS. BILLS 12.59 12.79 13.64 7-YR. TREAS. NOTES 13.71 13.72 13.95 30-YR. TREAS.
