title: CBS EDGES ABC IN SEASON'S RATINGS
description: In a television season during which the overall audience for the three networks dropped substantially, CBS-TV won a narrow victory over ABC in the prime-time audience-popularity ratings race, according to figures released yesterday by A .C. Nielsen.

title: FOSTER, L B, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Including a nonrecurring gain of $3.8 million from the sale of fixed assets of Beall Pipe Inc

title: Cypriot President Says He'll Seek Re-election
description: President Spyros Kyprianou of Cyprus said today that he would seek re-election and that he had received the support of the nation's major Communist party.

title: ARMATRON INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $452,000 for the qr and $501,000 for the 6 mos...C-Including tax credits of $255,000 for the qr and $260,000 for the 6 mos and income of $1,449,000 for the 6 mos from the settlement of litigation

title: INQUIRY IS STARTED ON RIG THAT SANK
description: In the stormy early morning hours of Feb. 15, the Ocean Ranger, the world's largest floating drilling rig, sank in the Atlantic 175 miles off Newfoundland, with the loss of all 84 of its crew and all the logs and records that might explain what took it down.

title: ISLANDERS WARY OF LETDOWN
description: The Islanders will be at Nassau Coliseum tonight, holding a 3-1 lead in their four-of-seven-game National Hockey League playoff series with the Rangers and needing only one victory to move into the conference final.

title: Sheboygan Factory Burns
description: A raging fire fed by chemicals destroyed a block-long furniture factory and injured 12 people Monday. The fire, whipped by winds and fed by volatile chemicals stored in the building, leveled the four-story Thonet Industries building, built in 1888. Most of those injured were treated and released.

title: TERMINAL DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
INCREASE TAKES TOLL ON TOLL TAKER, TOO
description: More than 3,000 left hands reached out to give money to James Denig yesterday during his 7 A.M.-to-3 P.M. shift at a Queens-Midtown Tunnel tollbooth and, for the first time in two years, he found he could do nothing by rote.

title: 13 Are Named as Outstanding Mothers; Outstanding Mothers
description: Twelve of the 13 women named yesterday to this year's ''Outstanding Mothers Honors List'' are more or less well known, but the exception, Joanne Sheptock of Peapack, N.J., also has a claim to fame. She is the mother of 29 children, 22 of them adopted.

title: CHEMED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $1.9 million for the latest first qr and $2.8 million for the yr-ago first qr

title: LIED RECITAL: PETER SCHREIER
description: THE East German tenor Peter Schreier made his Metropolitan Opera debut 15 years ago, and has been an honored performer on both the operatic and recital stages worldwide even longer. But New York had to wait until last night for his local lieder-recital debut, which took place at Carnegie Hall before a large and warmly appreciative audience.

title: Ankara's Shame
description: It is fairly obvious what Turkey's generals want from Bulent Ecevit, who was three times Prime Minister and is his country's bestknown democrat. They want him to say everything's been dandy in Ankara since the junta dissolved Parliament in 1980.

title: YANKS VANQUISH CHICAGO
description: The latest product of the Yankees' game of musical lineups needed time to warm up in the sub-40 degree weather tonight. But once the players in the new lineup got hot, they were torrid.

title: PAMOUR PORCUPINE MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
AVANT-GARDE: 2 'VIRTUOSI'
description: ''NEW virtuosity'' is a concept that has been used in contemporary music for at least 15 years to describe the techniques developed by modern instrumentalists and the music composed to exploit those techniques. Monday night, the Kitchen presented the first of two programs of a ''New Virtuosi Festival'' that also involves concerts in Hartford and Baltimore, devoted to the work of four American instrumentalists who have explored such virtuoso effects. The performers were Joseph Celli, oboist, and Stuart Dempster, trombonist.

title: WINE TALK
description: IT was extremely sweet, tasting of nectarines and honey, with the concentrated flavor imparted by a mold called Botrytis cinerea; and it was very rare, a reminder of a different world of wine, where sweetness is the goal regardless of the American inclination to reject whatever is not dry. The wine was a Kasteler Schlossberg Silvaner Trockenbeerenauslese 1976, and its complex name alone would be sufficient to deter all but the most devoted oenophile.

title: COURT RULES BOYCOTT OF SOVIET'S CARGOES VIOLATED LABOR LAW
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that the International Longshoremen's Association violated Federal labor law by refusing to handle Soviet cargo in American ports in protest against the Soviet Union's intervention in Afghani-stan.

title: SANDWELL & CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: Comparable results for the yr earlier were not available because the company changed its fiscal yr end from Aug to Dec

title: A Correction
description: A recipe in The Living Section April 7 for lemon meringue pie omitted a line. In step 3, it should have said to stir in lemon juice, rind and butter after cooking the egg yolk and cornstarch mixture over boiling water for three minutes.

title: Concertgebouw Tour To Run Sept. 18-Oct. 9
description: The Concertgebouw Orchestra of Amsterdam under its music director, Bernard Haitink, will begin a United States tour Sept. 18. The tour is part of the celebration of the 200th anniversary of the opening of diplomatic relations between the United States and the Netherlands, the longest unbroken and peaceful relationship the United States has enjoyed with any nation.

title: AN INDIAN IMPORT, 'MY SON, MY PRECIOUS'
description: IMAGINE a very simple, heartfelt but threadbare ''Kramer vs. Kramer''-like story set in a remote corner of India. ''My Son, My Precious'' is something along these lines, and something genuinely and effortlessly touching. As an extremely modest, small film, it may not have much future outside the ''New Directors/New Films'' series in which it is being shown. But as festival selections go, this is a rewarding one.

title: ART: FROM THE BEST OF DUTCH WORKS
description: ''DUTCH PAINTINGS From the Mauritshuis'' at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, which will open Friday, is a model of its kind. The scale is right - just 40 paintings. The choice is right. The uncluttered installation is right. The famous names are right - Rembrandt, Vermeer, Ruisdael, Hals, Jan Steen, Gabriel Metsu, Terbrugghen, Carel Fabritius. The Rembrandt ''Susanna,'' the Vermeer ''Head of a Girl'' and the Ruisdael ''View of Haarlem'' are three of the best pictures ever painted, and they look their best in the National Gallery.

title: INDUSMIN LATD reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
SIMONE ALIBERT SMITH
description: Simone Alibert Smith, honorary chairman of the Committee of French-Amerian Wives, a New York organization, died Monday at a nursing home in Litchfield, Conn. She was 87 years old and lived in Bordeaux.

title: COOPER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $3,522,000; yr-ago results have been restated to include the acquisition of Crouse-Hinds on a pooling of interests basis

title: THEODORE D. STARR
description: Theodore D. Starr, an investor who lived in Water Mill, L.I., and Palm Beach, Fla., died on April 13 in Palm Beach.

title: Singer Leaves Hospital
description: A follow-up: The rock singer Billy Joel, who broke his right wrist and left thumb in a motorcycle accident on Long Island last week, has been released from a Manhattan hospital and given a good chance of a full recovery.

title: Labor Dept. Assailled On Union Embezzling
description: The president of the Sheet Metal Workers' International Association is demanding an explanation from the Labor Department for what he terms its lax handling of an embezzlement case involving officials of a union local.

title: OVERHEAD DOOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Manila Pan Am Strike
description: More than two-thirds of Pan American World Airways' local employees went on strike today, forcing the closing of two ticket sales offices but otherwise causing no serious disruption of the carrier's operations, Pan Am said.

title: Dancer Fitzgerald/N.Y.  Announces Promotions
description: Gary M. Susnjara, 42 years old, has been named president of Dancer Fitzgerald Sample/New York as the parent company decides to stress the fact that it is, according to Peter F. McSpadden, the new chairman, ''probably one of the largest single advertising resources in the city.''

title: STILL IN SAIGON' CLIMBING
description: ''PEOPLE said it would either be a hit or a real dog,'' Dan Daley said this week about ''Still in Saigon,'' the song he wrote last May about a Vietnam veteran's unbearably intense memories of combat. This year, the Charlie Daniels Band recorded the song, and four weeks ago it entered the singles charts at No. 75. This week, it is No. 33, with intense sales action and airplay reported.

title: ATHLONE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
APPLIED MAGNETICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $83,000 for the qr and $545,000 for the 6 mos and a gain of $9,493,000 for the qr and 6 mos on the sale of Geo Space Corp; shr earnings reflect a 5 percent stock divd paid Mar 12

title: BELO, A H, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
DENNISON MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Yr-ago results have been restated for an accounting change

title: Cards Re-Sign Gray
description: Mel Gray, who has caught passes in 117 straight National Football League games, has signed a one-year contract with the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: JOSTENS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
ISRAELI PLANES ARE ATTACKED BY MISSILES
description: Israel announced today that one of its planes, flying over the Golan Heights, had been fired on Monday by a missile launched from Syrian territory.

title: SAN JOSE WATER WORKS reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
WAENING THE BODY FROM DEPENDANCE ON CAFFEINE
description: OF the nation's three most popular nonprescription mood-altering drugs - alcohol, nicotine and caffeine -only alcohol and nicotine are universally recognized as potential health hazards. But as suspicions mount about the adverse health effects of caffeine, millions of Americans are trying to diminish or eliminate entirely their dependence on this artificial mental and physical stimulant.

title: AMERICAN ELECTRIC POWER CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
DONALDSON LUFKIN & JENRETTE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
14 Greek Tourists Are Killed In Sinai Desert Bus Accident
description: A total of 14 Greek tourists were killed and 34 others were injured in a bus accident today in Sinai, a Greek Embassy spokesman said.

title: REPUBLIC STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
UNIROYAL HIGHER
description: The Dow Chemical Company, following a pattern of weakness in the chemical industry caused largely by the strengthening of the dollar abroad, reported yesterday that earnings in the first quarter of 1982 dropped 14.4 percent from the 1981 quarter, while revenues slipped 4.1 percent.

title: FALKLAND MISSION: HAIG'S LONG DAYS IN ARGENTINA
description: For almost four days, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. was doggedly persistent, at times even pleading, in his negotiations here to find a way to avert a war over the Falkland Islands, according to Argentines present.

title: Polish Leaflet Reports Nationwide Strikes
description: An underground leaflet made available today reported that there were nationwide strikes and demonstrations last week to protest martial law and that dissenters plan an expansion of a clandestine network called Radio Solidarity.

title: Hawaii Concern's Milk Is Banned on Airlines
description: The Food and Drug Administration announced today that it had banned a dairy company's milk from use on airline flights from Hawaii to the mainland and United States territories because the milk contained unacceptable levels of a pesticide.

title: KENNAMETAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Sam Steinberg, 85, a Peddler At Columbia for Generations
description: Sam Steinberg, who for more than 40 years sold candy bars and his own cardboard paintings on the Columbia University campus, died Sunday at Misericordia Hospital in the Bronx.

title: 2 Big Corporations Plan 'Golden Parachutes'
description: Two major corporations, the American Broadcasting Companies and the United Technology Corporation, disclosed information about ''golden parachutes'' for their top executives.

title: THE DISPUTE OVER THE S.E.C.
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission, entrusted with regulating the nation's financial markets, is caught in a heated debate over what role it should play as an enforcement agency.

title: PRESIDENT APPEALS TO FALKLAND FOES TO SHOW RESTRAINT
description: President Reagan appealed to Argentina and Britain today to show restraint in their dispute over the Falkland Islands. He also urged the Organization of American States to delay any action on the crisis so long as the United States was engaged in trying to bring about a peaceful solution.

title: WNCN Studio Opening With 4 Hours of Music
description: A four-hour broadcast featuring Aaron Copland, Ned Rorem, Ruth Laredo, Jens Nygaard, Eugenia Zukerman and Beverly Sills can be heard tonight from 7 to 11 o'clock on WNCN-FM. The concert celebrates the opening of the station's performance studio, which will present musical events beginning May 2 with a 12-hour benefit for the New York City Opera.

title: F.C.C. ASKS FOR BELL ACCORD REVISION
description: On the last day for public comment on the antitrust settlement between the Justice Department and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the Federal Communications Commission proposed today a major amendment that would permit Bell's 22 local operating companies to engage in a variety of unregulated businesses once they are divested.

title: Vandals Burn Dais in Wales
description: A dais being built for Pope John Paul II's expected visit to Cardiff was burnt down by vandals, the police said today.

title: GENERAL TELEPHONE & ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Q&A
description: Q. I have a recipe for a Christmas bread that calls for two tablespoons of granular yeast. A well-known author of books on bread states that one ounce of granular yeast equals two tablespoons. It is clearly printed on the best-known brands of yeast that one envelope contains a quarter of an ounce. If one envelope contains a quarter of an ounce and if, as the author states, I need two tablespoons to make an ounce, I would need four envelopes. Is this true? And can you tell me the equivalent of compressed yeast (a yeast cake) when substituting granular yeast?

title: Gerardo Roxas, Party Leader In Philippines, Is Dead at 58
description: Gerardo Roxas, president of the Philippines Liberal Party and a longtime critic of President Fernando E. Marcos, died last night at the age of 58.

title: COMINCO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
FIRST BOSTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
NORTON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
SARGENT-WELCH SCIENTIFIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Includes $38,000 gain from discontinued operations

title: Chairman Leaves G. Fox for Filene's
description: Michael Babcock has resigned as chairman of G. Fox & Company, a Hartford department store group owned by the May Department Stores Company, to become president of Filene's, the Boston-based department store group. He will assume his new post May 3.

title: BRAVES WIN 12th STRAIGHT TO SET RECORD
description: When Joe Torre was dismissed as manager of the Mets on the last day of last season, he was asked if he'd ever consider managing again.

title: RICHARD JAMIESON
description: Richard Jamieson, an actor who last year appeared in George Farquhar's ''The Recruiting Officer'' at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, died last Thursday in Burlington, Vt.

title: THEATER: STRINDBERG'S 'GHOST SONATA'
description: ''GHOST SONATA'' begins with an image of selflessness - a student has heroically rescued a child from a collapsing building - and it ends with a vision of Arnold Boecklin's spectral painting ''Island of the Dead.'' Moving from life to death, Strindberg tells a mordant, mystifying tale of deceit, guilt and vengeance.

title: CONSOLIDATED FREIGHTWAYS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $13,000

title: Advertising; Yago Aims At Beer Market
description: RATHER than trying to take on Riunite, the wine that dominates the field in both sales and advertising, Yago SantGria, using a tonguein-cheek approach, is going to try to cut a wedge out of the beer market.

title: U.A.W. to Oppose Bonuses at G.M.
description: The United Automobile Workers said it would oppose improvements in a bonus plan for top General Motors Corporation executives when they are presented at the auto maker's annual shareholders' meeting on May 21.

title: POET AND PLAYWRIGHT WAS 89
description: Archibald MacLeish, distinguished poet, playwright, statesman and man of letters, died last night at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston, which he entered March 20 for treatment of an undisclosed illness. He was 89 years old and had lived in Conway, Mass.

title: John H.H. Phipps, 77, Active Conservationist
description: John H.H. Phipps, a conservationist who was chairman of the John H. Phipps Broadcasting Stations Inc. in Tallahassee, Fla., died Monday at Tallahassee Memorial Regional Medical Center. He was 77 years old and lived at his farm, Ayavalla, in Tallahassee.

title: Architect's Award
description: In 1975, at the height of a distinguished architectural career, Philip C. Johnson underwent triple coronary bypass surgery. Some feared that Mr. Johnson, whose designs include the Museum of Modern Art Annex and the New York State Theater in Lincoln Center, might have to retire because of his heart condition.

title: WRONG 'BUCKET' FOR CITY'S $8 MILLION
description: To the Editor:

title: DIEBOLD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
BULLETS SUBDUE NETS BY 96-83 IN PLAYOFF OPENER
description: Like vultures, the Washington Bullets hovered above the floundering Nets tonight, waiting for them to expire. Then they devoured them.

title: House Panel Adopts a Plan To Extend Clean Air Deadline
description: In a critical vote on renewal of the Clean Air Act, the House Energy and Commerce Committee decided today, 22 to 19, to reject an industry-backed plan to give states until 1993 to meet air pollution standards.

title: IN IVORY COAST, PALACE ON 8-LANE ROAD TO NOWHERE
description: They say there are more streetlights in this ''village'' of 15,000 than there are in the Ivory Coast's capital of Abidjan with its population of 1.5 million.

title: BRITISH AMBASSADOR: DAYS IN CRISIS
description: Chuck telephoned Nicko the other afternoon. They talked about Al. ''Hello, Chuck, I haven't any developments,'' said Sir Nicholas Henderson to Senator Charles Percy, referring to the Falkland Islands crisis. The two men chatted briefly about the peace-making efforts of Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.

title: Astronaut's Mother Dies
description: Graveside services were scheduled today for Ruth C. Crippen, the mother of Robert Crippen, an astronaut. Mrs. Crippen, 67 years old, died Saturday in this community north of Houston. She ran a tavern here for nearly 40 years.

title: SHORTER CITY LABOR PACTS ARE ADVISED BY ROHATYN
description: Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, suggested yesterday that New York City depart from recent tradition and seek one-year, rather than two-year, settlements with municipal labor unions in this spring's negotiations.

title: CONGRESSMEN, RETURNING, REPORT VOTERS WANT BUDGET COMPROMISE
description: House members returning to Washington today from the Easter recess brought a message from the voters back home: Find a budget compromise that will reduce the deficits projected by President Reagan's plan and provide some relief from high interest rates.

title: A MATTER OF INTEGRITY
description: To the Editor:

title: TIDEWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
SPRING FEVER; (Concerning the Inescapable Corniness of Love)
description: For crying out loud, the cliches tumble thick and fast here among the romantics: I find I'm ankle high knee deep up to my waist and in over my head in words I knew I'd never use. Yet the sun does, truly, break through the, dammit, clouds when I see you. You do, forgive me, make the gray sky blue. Your absence from the room makes me delirious anticipating your arrival or return. I am, inanely so, in love with you.JUDY TILLINGER

title: Judge Stops Sanction of Fight
description: Tony Ayala Jr., the undefeated junior middleweight contender, won a major decision in United States District Court today when Judge Herbert J. Stern issued a permanent injunction preventing the World Boxing Association from sanctioning a title bout Saturday between Davey Moore, its 154-pound champion, and Charlie Weir of South Africa.

title: AMID HARDSHIP, ISLAMIC ZEAL STILL GRIPS IRAN
description: Powerful mullahs riding in bulletproof Mercedes limousines with smoked windows, followed by carloads of armed guards. Fifteen-year-old boys volunteering to walk across Iraqi mine fields. Long lines forming before six o'clock in the morning for scarce, rationed food. Political graffiti scrawled on walls around the city: ''Death to women whose heads are uncovered!''

title: North Sea Platform
description: The British National Oil Corporation has ordered detailed engineering designs from Brown & Root for the second platform at its North Sea Beatrice Field, a statement by the oil company said. A spokesman for the state-owned company said tenders for platform construction would be sought around July, with production due to start early 1984. The field, which is to cost more than $1 billion to develop, will build up to peak output of 60,000 barrels daily after the plaftorm is put on stream.

title: SOVIET SPACE STATION LAUNCHED, POSSIBLY TO AWAIT FRENCHMAN
description: The Soviet Union launched a new unmanned space research station Monday in preparation for what is expected to be a joint French-Soviet mission this summer.

title: CONROCK CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Hertz Vice Chairman Moves to Rival Avis
description: Joseph V. Vittoria, 46, will be trying harder as he moves from the Hertz Corporation, where he has been president and then vice chairman, to the Avis Rent A Car System as executive vice president for sales and marketing. Avis, with 26 percent of the market and a subsidiary of Norton Simon Inc., is No.2 in the car rental business behind Hertz, which accounts for about 40 percent.

title: Catching Up to Bench
description: It is beginning to appear that Johnny Bench will be doing more catching for the faltering Cincinnati Reds in the next few weeks than he had anticipated. The 34-year-old star demanded last year that he catch no more than twice a week, so as to save his body the continual pounding that playing the position entails.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, APRIL 21, 1982
description: International President Reagan urged Argentina and Britain to show restraint in the Falklands dispute, and he appealed to the Organization of American States to delay any action in the crisis as long as Washington was trying to bring about a peaceful solution. The O.A.S. council voted 18 to 0, with the United States abstaining, to convene a foreign ministers' meeting Monday to consider collective action against Britain. (Page A1, Column 4.) Britain expressed deep reservations about the latest Falklands peace proposals and said that Foreign Secretary Francis Pym would fly to Washington tomorrow with counterproposals. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher made the announcement at a tense and crowded session of the House of Commons. (A14:3-6.)

title: Donaldson Rises 42%
description: Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. reported yesterday that its earnings for the first quarter of 1982 rose 42 percent, to $3.4 million, or 27 cents a share, from $2.4 million, or 25 cents a share, in the same period last year. Revenue increased 63 percent, to $104.4 million, from $63.9 million. The company said its higher earnings were a result of continued cost reductions and strong performances in areas including investment management and banking.

title: LAWSON & JONES LTD reports earnings for Yr to dEc 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $532,000 for the latest yr and $1,482,000 for the previous yr

title: TIMEX PLANS COMPUTER TO RETAIL AT ABOUT $100
description: The Timex Computer Corporation, an affiliate of the company that introduced the world's first inexpensive wristwatch, yesterday introduced the first personal computer to retail at around $100.

title: TIMKEN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
LONE STAR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
G.A.O. STUDY FINDS MANY YOUTHS FAILING TO REGISTER FOR DRAFT
description: An increasing number of 18-year-old men are failing to register for the draft, according to a study released today by the General Accounting Office.

title: McLouth to Seek Asset Sale Delay
description: The troubled McLouth Steel Corporation will ask its secured creditors to extend the steelmaker's June 18 deadline to sell, merge or surrender its assets, according to its chairman, R. Milton Deaner.

title: How To Fill and Heat Burritos
description: It is almost impossible to give exact measurements for filling flour tortillas to prepare burritos. It is a question of judgment, depending on the size of the tortillas, which may range from 6 to 12 inches.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: based performance artist, made the surprise hit record of last year. Her ''O Superman,'' originally recorded for Manhattan's One Ten label, became a top five hit in Britain and generated so much interest in Miss Anderson's work that Warner Bros. signed her to a recording contract. And now we have ''Big Science,'' which includes ''O Superman'' and is Miss Anderson's first Warner's album - for that matter, her first album for anybody.

title: ISTVAN SZABO's 1976 'BUDAPEST TALES'
description: IN Istvan Szabo's allegorical film ''Budapest Tales,'' most of the characters speak in capital letters about Life, Love and the Need to Keep Calm while hitching a ride on the tram of Adversity. There is, in fact, a tram that is a central element in the story plus a few other symbols, including a trapped fish and a caged bird, that are fellow travelers accompanying the human passengers as they Press On.

title: CHEMINEER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 2
LAWYERS CHALLENGE CURBS ON TRAVEL TO CUBA
description: Civil liberties lawyers today questioned the legality of the Reagan Administration's new effort to ban business and tourist travel to Cuba. Two groups said they might file a suit to block the restrictions.

title: SCOTT PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Includes $4,534,000 pretax gain from the sale of investment tax benefits; yr-ago results restated for the adoption of foreign currency accounting rule

title: Tadzhikistan Leader Named
description: The Communist Party of Soviet Tadzhikistan has named Rakhman Nabiyev as its First Secretary, replacing Dzhabar Rasulov, who died earlier this month, the official Tass press agency reported today. Mr. Nabiyev was premier of Tadzhikistan, a predominately Moslem Central Asian republic bordering Afghanistan and Pakistan, Tass reported.

title: DEMOCRATS PUSH HARTFORD BUDGET THROUGH SENATE
description: Democrats today pushed a $3.19 billion state budget through the Connecticut Senate and onto the desk of Gov. William A. O'Neill, who is expected to sign it.

title: WINE IMPORTS CAPTURE MORE OF U.S. SALES
description: Imported wines achieved a new level of popularity in the United States in 1981, accounting for a record 22.6 percent of the American market, according to a statistical analysis of wine sales in this country. The marked share held by imports grew from 21.3 percent in 1980 and was more than double the 10 percent recorded in 1970, according to Impact, a newsletter that reports on trends in the beverage industry.

title: Republic Steel Reports a Loss
description: The Republic Steel Corporation said today that it had a net loss of $28.5 million in the first quarter, in contrast to a profit of $32.6 million, or $2.01 a share, a year before. Sales fell 20.8 percent, to $880.5 million, from $1.1 billion.

title: JORGENSEN, EARLE M, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Briefing
description: For Armchair Admirals

title: DUQUESNE LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Nuclear Plant Construction
description: Despite many delays, up to 30 nuclear power plants could be completed in the next two years, the staff of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission estimated today.

title: TIMES PLANS NATIONAL EDITION ON COAST FOR 13 STATES IN WEST
description: The New York Times will begin printing its national edition in California in August, Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, the paper's publisher, announced yesterday. He said the operation would provide same-day distribution to major cities in 13 Western states.

title: Market Place; Casino Stocks' Latest Trend
description: WHEN stock market speculators gather to swap tales of derring-do, they're apt to dwell fondly upon the wild ride of gambling issues in the late 1970's.

title: MERRILL LYNCH & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
U.S. VETOES REBUKE TO ISRAEL
description: The United States vetoed a Security Council resolution today that condemned the Easter Sunday killings in the Dome of the Rock mosque in Jerusalem.

title: BEVERLY ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
SENATE TV BACKERS LOSE VOTE
description: Supporters of putting the Senate on television failed to even win a majority today in their first attempt to end a filibuster.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: 1. Life-Jacket Chic The French designers Marithe and Francois Girbaud get many of their ideas from the fads young people wear on the streets of Paris. But their newest brainstorm came during a plane trip, when they were amused by the graphics on the card that explains the use of life preservers. So the Girbauds made a jacket of white cotton, reproducing the instructions, in various languages, on the lining. The ''life jacket'' has a hood, a front zipper and windbreaker pockets. It's being made in this country by Complements Sportswear and is priced at $150 at Diddington's, at West Broadway and Prince Street in SoHo.

title: Ralph Edsell Jr., Ex-Counsel To State Assembly Speaker
description: Ralph J. Edsell Jr., who had been chief counsel to Joseph F. Carlino, former Speaker of the Assembly and Nassau County Republican chairman, died of a heart attack Friday in Orlando, Fla. He was 58 years old and lived in Islamorada, Fla.

title: CBS to Market Bally Games
description: A CBS Inc. unit will market home versions of the Bally Manufacturing Company's video games that will be compatible with other best-selling home video games, the companies said.

title: U.S. SEEKS TO IMPROVE TIES WITH GUATEMALA
description: The Reagan Administration indicated today that it hoped to establish a ''closer, more collaborative'' relationship with the conservative military regime that seized power in Guatemala last month.

title: NORTHROP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
GOULD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''I think the economy is now poised for a recovery. I know of nothing that would be a greater tonic for the economy right now than for the Congress and the White House to come together on a plan that would lower the deficits and create new jobs.''

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ALL ABOARD

title: Walt Disney Net Down
description: Walt Disney Productions said today its second-quarter profits fell 22 percent on a 5 percent increase in revenues compared with the same quarter last year. Net earnings dropped to $21.64 million, or 65 cents a share, from $27.63 million, or 84 cents a share, a year ago, the company said. Revenues climbed to $247.6 million, from $235 million in the comparable quarter last year.

title: SCHMIDT WARNS PARTY ON FREEZE OF NATO ARMS
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, addressing a convention of the Social Democratic Party, warned advocates of a nuclear freeze today that its enactment in Europe would amount to accepting the ''unbelievable Soviet armada that is aimed at us.''

title: TASK FORCE URGES AID FOR STATE RACING INDUSTRY
description: New York State's racing industry, beset by declining attendance and increases in operating costs, will continue to suffer financial losses over the next five years unless Governor Carey and the Legislature act to provide assistance, according to a joint legislative task force. The losses, the task force said, will afflict nearly every racing operation in the state.

title: Alan Dugan Receives Shelley Poetry Award
description: Alan Dugan has received the Shelley Memorial Award from the Poetry Society of America.

title: DENTISTS LEAVE 'ELM STREET' FOR MALLS L.I.
description: To the dismay of the dental profession, most people do not take very good care of their teeth. The dentists are not just concerned about cavities and crowns: They are worried because dentistry got only about $15 billion of the $247 billion spent on total health care last year.

title: UNITED MCGILL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
INFOTRON SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31

title: GERMANS TO TAP ARCTIC GAS
description: Two West German and two Canadian companies have agreed to form a joint venture to develop, liquefy and ship natural gas from the Canadian Arctic to Western Europe, one of the West German partners said today.

title: WEINBERGER SEES FLEXIBILITY ON MILITARY SPENDING
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger, speaking in New York last night, said for the first time that the Reagan Administration's $160 billion military budget might have to be cut this year.

title: ELLIS FOR FALL: GOOD AND NOT SO GOOD
description: PERRY ELLIS fans will be glad to know that his crunchy tweed jackets and cable-knit sweaters are as comfortable and foreverlooking as they've always been. His tartan plaids are livelier and his coats more handsome than ever. Everything is a bit longer for fall and winter: the sweaters, the coats, the jackets.

BEEHIVE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Mar
RAYPAK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31

EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * A.H. Belo Corp., Dallas, has elected to its board Thomas B. Walker Jr., a partner in Goldman, Sachs & Co.

title: A Look at Metromedia
description: Metromedia Inc., which carries the highest price tag of any stock on the Big Board, traded Monday at a record price of 215 before closing at 208, up 3 points. Shares of the nation's fourth-largest broadcast operation moved one point higher yesterday, to 209.

description: 1 pound flour, about 3 1/4 cups 1/2 cup solid white vegetable shortening or lard Salt to taste, if desired 1 cup warm water (slightly hotter than lukewarm but not unpleasantly hot to the touch).

description: B-Includes $49,000 tax credit

title: JERSEY'S PUBLIC SERVICE ASKS REDUCTION IN ELECTRIC RATES
description: The state's largest utility asked the Board of Public Utilities today for a $186 million reduction in electricity rates for its customers.

title: BRADY TAKES OATH AS JERSEY SENATOR
description: In a brief ceremony on the Senate floor, Nicholas F. Brady was sworn in today as a Republican Senator of New Jersey. His old friend, Vice President Bush, administered the oath.

title: Gretzky Player of Year
description: Wayne Gretzky, the sensational Edmonton Oiler center who set National Hockey League records for goals and points in a season, has been named the Sporting News's player of the year, for the second straight season, in a poll of N.H.L. players. Gretzky was named on 262 of the 283 ballots.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Le Anne Schreiber THE JOURNALS OF SYLVIA PLATH. Foreword by Ted Hughes. Ted Hughes, consulting editor, and Frances McCul- lough, editor. Dial. 370 pages. $16.95.

title: Bridge: Knowing Pattern of Cards Comes Easily to an Expert
description: One basic advantage that the expert has over lesser lights is that he has a deeply rooted awareness of distribution. The common patterns are so ingrained that he rarely has to count up to 13.

title: CORRECTION
description: A brief article yesterday on an award of the Concert Artists Guild gave the name of the recipient incorrectly. He is Avery Fisher. The award will be presented next Wednesday by Zubin Mehta.

title: LONG ISLAND LIGHTING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
New Chilean Cabinet Is Expected Tomorrow
description: President Augusto Pinochet said today that he would name a new Cabinet Thursday to replace the 16 ministers he dismissed Monday.

title: VERMONT AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Yr-ago shr earnings reflect a 15 percent stock divd declared in Nov

title: DANCE: BALLET THEATER OPENS WITH 'WILD BOY'
description: IT was a good opening. The American Ballet Theater returned to the Metropolitan Opera House on Monday night for an eight-week season, and the spirit was definitely up.

title: Nissan to Introduce New Economy Car
description: The Nissan Motor Corporation displayed a new front-wheel-drive small car called the Sentra that is estimated to get 43 miles a gallon in city driving and 58 miles a gallon on the highway.

title: REAGAN VOWS TO GO 'EXTRA MILE' TO GET ACCORD ON BUDGET
description: President Reagan pledged at a news conference today ''to go the extra mile'' to compromise with Democrats on his budget as White House and Congressional negotiators sought to narrow their differences on a package to hold the Federal deficit at $95 billion next year.

title: TIMELY WRITER IS OUT OF DERBY
description: Timely Writer, who had been favored to win the Kentucky Derby on May 1, was declared out of the race after undergoing emergency abdominal surgery here late today. Veterinarians rated the colt's chances for survival as ''fair to good'' but said that he would not be able to race again for several months, if it all.

title: A GUIDE TO CHOOSING A RIPE PINEAPPLE
description: ALTHOUGH finding a good melon is generally considered a difficult and chancy proposition, it is child's play compared to the odds one is up against when buying fresh pineapple. That stately leaf-crowned, prickly-skinned fruit with its luxurious, juicy, sweet-sour interior, offers few dependable outward clues to its inner condition, even now at its peak season.

title: INTERNATIONAL THOMPSON ORGANIZATION reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-After a loss of $13 million from discontinued operations and an extraordinaryloss of $35.5 million

title: HOME FOR ACTORS RAISES $750,000
description: Some $750,000 of the $2 million needed to build a nursing home for the Actors' Fund of America has been raised. Most of the money is from the ''Night of 100 Stars'' in February at Radio City Music Hall, and $52,000 is from people who used American Express credit cards.

title: NEW YORK TIMES reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Includes $3,834,000 gain from equity in earnings of associated companies...C-Includes $4,766,000 gain from equity in earnings of associated companies

title: TV: FOR BARYSHNIKOV, IT'S A HOLLYWOOD NIGHT
description: MIKHAIL BARYSHNIKOV has used television well in his ascent to superstardom. He has recorded a few ballet programs for public television. He did ''The Nutcracker'' for CBS-TV. His ''Baryshnikov on Broadway'' special deservedly won a slew of awards. And now, in the same showcase vein, he is starring at 10 o'clock tonight on CBS in ''Baryshnikov in Hollywood.''

title: PEOPLES RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 28
ABOUT NEW YORK
description: Donna Valentine runs a one-room school on the first floor of Madison Square Garden, with a shabby little blackboard and a standing scale in one corner that is generally used to weigh boxers.

title: Northern Trust Purchases Seen
description: The Northern Trust Corporation, Chicago's fourth-largest bank, said it intends to acquire an undisclosed number of suburban Chicago banks later this year, and is now negotiating with several institutions.

title: AMSTED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
RIVAL MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
THE CAFFEINE CONFLICT-WHERE DOES IT STAND?
description: UP, once known as the Uncola, recently began an advertising campaign designed to convince the public that its lemon-and-limeflavored beverage is preferable to other soft drinks because it does not contain caffeine. Understandably, this has upset the manufacturers of Coca-Cola, Pepsi-Cola and Dr Pepper, which do contain caffeine. They contend that 7-Up's advertising campaign is based on unsubstantiated health concerns. The dangers of caffeine, they argue, have never been proved.

title: CITY OFFICIALS ASSESS MONDAY'S ; CHAOS
description: As traffic jams eased yesterday, officials at the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority reflected ruefully on what they might have done to prevent Monday's snarls at nine bridges and tunnels where tolls were increased.

title: METS AND SCOTT STOP CUBS, 3-2
description: Despite Joel Youngblood's first home run of the year and Mike Scott's second solid pitching effort in the Mets' 3-2 victory last night over the Cubs, Manager George Bamberger was still not ready to make final decisions about his right-field situation and his pitching rotation.

title: DENNY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Shr earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid Apr 1

title: EMULEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
PHILLY JOE JONES SALUTES DAMERON PROPERLY
description: A LITTLE more than a week ago, the jazz drummer Philly Joe Jones presented a special program of music by the late Tadd Dameron at Lush Life, the new Greenwhich Village jazz club. Mr. Dameron, a composer and arranger who was most active in the late 40's and early 50's, has always been a kind of shadowy figure in jazz history. But at Lush Life, Mr. Jones recreated the nine-piece band Dameron led in the early 50's, a band Mr. Jones originally played in, and the music and its composer sprang vividly to life.

ELECTRONIC DATA GETS ARMY CONTRACT
description: The Army announced yesterday that it had awarded to the Electronic Data Systems Corporation a 10-year contract to install and operate what will be one of the Government's biggest data processing networks. The contract's value is estimated at $656 million.

title: Knight-Ridder Declines
description: Knight-Ridder Newspapers Inc. said today that first-quarter earnings fell 26.7 percent while revenue increased 7.2 percent.

title: '61 BORDEAUX RATES HIGH AUCTION PRICE
description: A 12-bottle case of Chateau Lafite-Rothschild 1961 brought $2,800, and a single bottle of Beaulieu Vineyard Private Reserve Georges de Latour cabernet sauvignon 1947 brought $420 at a wine auction conducted last weekend in Chicago by Christie's.

title: WHY ISRAEL BANS SOME ARAB BOOKS
description: A 12-year-old pupil studying in the Gaza district before June 1967 undoubtedly would have encountered in his Egyptian junior high school textbook this sentence: ''The Arabs will never cease striving for the destruction of Israel.''

title: A Return for Ongais
description: Danny Ongais, who was seriously injured in a crash during last year's Indianapolis 500, is scheduled to return to Indy-car competition this Sunday at the Atlanta International Speedway. The recuperated driver started his comeback earlier this year in selected GT sports car events. ... David Pearson, who has been on a two-year sabbatical from Grand National racing, has signed to drive a car sponsored by Chattanooga Chew chewing tobacco and the Carolina Tool Company. Pearson will drive a Buick, owned by Bobby Hawkins, in five to seven races.

description: Yr-ago results reflect the adoption of F.A.S.B. Statement No 52

title: Palestinian Goes on Trial For '79 Bombing in Israel
description: A Palestinian extradited from the United States went on trial today on charges that he planted a bomb that killed two Israeli boys and injured 36 people. Ziad Abu Eian, 23 years old, faces life imprisonment if convicted on murder charges in the May 1979 bombing in the Galilee town of Tiberias.

description: B-Includes $9,516,000 gain from the repurchase debt

description: THE fans will chant, ''Nineteen-forty'' tonight at the Nassau Coliseum, and they will chant it again next season whenever the Rangers visit the Islanders. The Rangers are not going to win the Stanley Cup this year, either.

Arco Cuts Plans
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company, the nation's seventh-largest oil company, said it will reduce its projected $5 billion capital spending program this year by 10 to 15 percent.

title: GIRLS' SCHOOL AIDE SLAIN IN EAST SIDE
description: The 31-year-old business manager of an East Side girls' school was found stabbed to death in his apartment on East 19st Street, the victim in a robbery-murder, the police said.

description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: A caption in Metropolitan Report on Monday under a picture of a ceremony at Temple Emanu-El referred incorrectly to events in Warsaw during World War II. The ceremony marked the April 1943 Ghetto uprising by Jews, which was suppressed by the Nazis.

title: Boise Cascade Off 85.3%
description: The Boise Cascade Corporation, a leading forest-products company, reported today that first-quarter profit plunged 85.3 percent, to $5.5 million, or 21 cents a share, from $37.5 million, or $1.40 a share, a year earlier. Sales fell 9 percent, to $714 million, from $784 million.

title: 2 Airlines Seek Braniff Routes
description: Two Miami-based airlines, Eastern and Air Florida, said that they had approached Braniff Airways about its money-losing South American routes.

title: Mugger Robs Wife of Cuomo
description: A mugger stole a purse containing $250 and credit cards from Matilda Cuomo, the wife of Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, on a deserted street in Queens Monday night.

description: The multimillionaire owner of the Edmonton Oilers hockey team was rescued by the police tonight from a gunman who had held him captive in his home for nearly 12 hours.

description: Apartment house owners and union employees ''stopped the clock'' at midnight last night and agreed to continue into the morning efforts to reach a new contract.

title: Milwaukee Aide Declares Inner City Rat Alert
description: The City Health Commissioner, saying that he feared an ''explosion'' of the rat population, has declared an emergency in a 900-block section of the inner city, where one out of every 10 homes is believed infested with the rodents.

title: NEW JERSEY MAN IN THE CBS CASE AGREES TO RETURN
description: A New Jersey man said by New York City police officials to be implicated in the slayings of a Federal witness and three CBS employees waived extradition yesterday in Frankfort, Ky., and agreed to return to the city.

title: ARGUMENTS RISE ON WEATHER BOSTON MARATHON SHOULD GO PRO
description: The debate over whether the Boston Marathon should retain its amateur status or offer prize money and accept large-scale sponsorship involves more than tradition.

title: Soy Protein Drink Is Reported To Reduce Cholesterol Levels
description: A soy protein drink can lower high cholesterol levels, a study completed recently at the University of Western Ontario shows. High cholesterol is a major factor in heart disease.

description: POLITICSTo the Editor:

title: Washington Post Up 183%
description: The Washington Post Company reported today that its profit for the first quarter of 1982 was $5.1 million, nearly triple the amount for the same period in 1981.

American League Wilcox Hurls One-Hitter
description: Milt Wilcox pitched a one-hitter as the Detroit Tigers walloped the Kansas City Royals, 8-0. Glenn Wilson was the batting star, cracking two doubles and droving in two runs.

description: WHILE the three-cornered battle over the 1983 budget is being waged by President Reagan and the Democrats and Republicans in Congress, the first salvos in the 1984 Presidential campaign are sounding.

description: An Israeli Cabinet minister who was convicted on Monday of theft of public funds announced today that he intended to resign from the Government but that he would retain his seat in Parliament.

description: President Reagan today renewed his invitation to Leonid I. Brezhnev to meet with him in June at the United Nations. Mr. Reagan said that such a meeting would not preclude a summit conference at a later date, as proposed Saturday by the Soviet leader.

description: An explosion ripped apart a grain elevator today, throwing debris up to a mile away, and the police said five people were missing.

description: President Reagan keeps trying to charm Britain and Argentina into a compromise over the Falkland Islands, as if there was no difference between the aggressors and the defenders. But there is a problem beyond the Falklands.

title: 3D-RANKED EAGLEBURGER SHIFTED TO STAGE CENTER
description: When Queen Beatrix of the Netherlands came over to the State Department for a long-planned official luncheon on Monday, her host by default was neither Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., who was in Buenos Aires trying to avoid war in the South Atlantic, nor Deputy Secretary Walter J. Stoessel Jr., who was in Cairo trying to seal the Egyptian-Israeli peace treaty. Rather, it was the No. 3 man in the department, Lawrence S. Eagleburger.

Farmers Set Crop Cutback
description: Grain, cotton and rice farmers have agreed to leave idle this summer 79 percent of the 226 million acres usually planted in corn, wheat, cotton or rice, the Agriculture Department announced today.

title: RULE TO LESSEN CITY BACKLOG OF FELONY CASES INVALIDATED
description: A State Supreme Court justice has declared unconstitutional a rule governing adjournments in felony cases in New York City. The rule, established by the state's top court officials last month, prohibits adjournments without the permission of a designated administrative judge.

title: Virginia M. Maynard, Lawyer And Civic Leader in Brooklyn
description: Virginia M. Maynard, a lawyer and a leader in Brooklyn civic and charitable affairs, died last Wednesday at her home in Brooklyn. She was 89 years old and also had a home in Westhampton Beach, L.I.

title: Raider Juror Dismissed For Reading Newspaper
description: A juror was dismissed today from the panel in the Oakland Raiders' antitrust suit against the National Football League because he had read a newspaper, contrary to the judge's instructions.

title: REAGAN AD STAND GAINS
description: In a surprise reversal, the three major advertising associations told a House subcommittee today that they now supported the Reagan Administration's proposal to limit the Federal Trade Commission's authority to regulate deceptive advertising.

title: MAYTAG CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Philippine Kidnappers Killed
description: Soldiers killed four kidnappers and rescued a 16-year-old girl who had been held for 25 days on the southern island of Mindanao. The Philippine News Agency said today that two kidnappers were killed Sunday when the girl was rescued and that two others died in an encounter Monday.

title: What the L.E.A.A. Elephant Learned
description: The Law Enforcement Assistance Administration, which expired this month, had run through 14 years, five Presidents and $7.7 billion. While it earned a reputation as a bureaucratic white elephant, it was also sadly misunderstood.

description: History Inter-American Treaty of Reciprocal Assistance, also known as the Treaty of Rio or the Rio Pact. Signed on Sept. 2, 1947, in Rio de Janiero after an Inter-American Defense Conference addressed by President Harry S. Truman.

description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin said today that news coverage of the Israeli withdrawal from northern Sinai this week was being restricted as part of efforts to ''prevent bloodshed'' in the area.

description: The largest star in our Milky Way galaxy may be nearing the end of its life and could blow up any time, astronomically speaking, producing a burst of light equal to the illumination from billions of suns, astronomers said today.

description: One of the chief pleasures of cooking, it has always seemed to me, is the opportunity it offers to experiment, by changing a known quantity into something with a different textures and flavor.

description: It is one of America's more subtle ironies that the new telecommunications revolution, even as it offers the technological means to a more united, active, communicative citizenry, appears to be reinforcing the country's most fractious, privatistic tendencies.

title: CONGRESS AND PRESIDENT LEAD HOLOCAUST MEMORIAL SERVICES
description: Congress and President Reagan led the nation today in commemorating the six million Jews who were victims of the Nazi Holocaust nearly four decades ago.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Beverly Enterprises, responding to an announcement by the Justice Department challenging the company's proposed purchase of Mediplex, a Flowood, Miss., nursing-home owner and operator, said that the parties had agreed to a restructured acquisition plan.

title: SPEED SKIERS DEFYING GRAVITY
description: Scott McKinney has climbed high mountains, tamed wild horses, meditated while hang-gliding and schussed down glaciers. He has also skied 125.77 miles an hour, a distinction no one else can claim.

title: TENTATIVE ACCORD REACHED ON SEA'S RESOURCES
description: Delegates writing a treaty for the seas achieved a significant breakthrough today when they tentatively agreed on a plan to divide the mineral wealth of the oceans.

title: A CHILEAN MILITARY ATTACHE FALSELY ACCUSED
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Cats,' a Hit in London, Sets Broadway Dates
description: ''Cats,'' a musical by Andrew Lloyd Webber based on T.S. Eliot's ''Old Possum's Book of Practical Cats,'' will begin previews Sept. 23 at the Winter Garden Theater and open Oct. 7.

title: KITCHEN EQUIPMENT
description: Buffet dinners are fun to plan. For one thing, there are limitless possibilities for decorating food and combining different dishes for the table. But a major drawback with this kind of entertaining is finding plates and platters that are big enough to hold the food. Most often, guests try to pile helpings on plates that are too small, or they end up standing in line several times over in order to be able to sample all the dishes. At last I have found an attractive plate that is the perfect size for a buffet. It measures just over a foot across - like the oversized plates used for nouvelle cuisine - and is made of cream-colored ceramic glazed stoneware. In spite of its size, the plate is not heavy. Besides its ample girth, the thing I like most about this plate, which is made for Lee Bailey housewares at Henri Bendel is its plainness. I have never cared much for patterned dishes, no matter how beautiful the design. A swirl of colors and shapes detracts from the look of the food and quarrels with the colors of the vegetables and sauces. This dish is completely unadorned, and is appealing both for its classic simplicity and roominess. As a matter of fact I like it not only for buffets, but for regular meals as well.

title: TURN BACK CLOCK ON DAYLIGHT TIME
description: IF you were told that there is a custom among us that is suspect in its origins, inequitable in its application and unsound in its philosophy - and yet, for all that, acquiesced in with hardly a murmur -could you name it? Could your mind sift through the haystack of practices that only pretend to such distinction (the cocktail hour? the income tax? the expense account lunch? the Presidential primary?) and find the needle I have in mind? Could you, in other words, come up with the villain of this piece, the usage that for half the year tyrannizes us like a king with no clothes on?
''The President has taken the first step. He has admitted the need for change.

title: MOST RATES CONTINUE TO FALL
description: Interest rates continued to decline yesterday in all sectors of the credit markets except long-term bonds, where prices fluctuated widely but closed virtually unchanged.

description: A judge barred the Federal Government yesterday from paying $90 million to New York State for the acquisition of land from New York City to build the Westway highway project.

title: EUROPE'S STAGGERING GIANTS
description: When West German businessmen talk about the country's chemical business these days, they often express fears that such industry giants as Hoechst, BASF and Bayer could well go the way of Europe's moribund steel companies.

TRADING ACTIVE
description: Stock prices fell moderately yesterday in continued active trading as profit taking erased some of the market's recent sharp advances. The Dow Jones industrial average ended the session down 5.52 points, to 840.56. Since March 8 the blue-chip barometer had risen about 55 points, which was its largest sustained advance for a fiveweek period in several years.

title: Space Flight
description: New York City stands to lose 700 jobs to Albany because the state's Medicaid Management Information System is afraid it may lose its lowrent quarters. Someone is giving up a little too easily on useful jobs.

title: DAVID ROSENTHAL, 84, REAL ESTATE INVESTOR AND BENEFACTOR, DIES
description: David Rosenthal, a real-estate entrepreneur, a former leader in the dress industry and a philanthropist, died Sunday in Good Samaritan Hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 84 years old and had homes in Palm Beach and Manhattan.

title: A True Friend of the Court
description: The Supreme Court's choice of William Coleman Jr. to argue against tax exemptions for racist schools is superb, even though the occasion for inviting him is deplorable. His very presence in the case is a rebuke to the Reagan Administration. When has it ever been necessary to go outside the Justice Department for a civil rights champion?

title: CHICAGO WINS INDEX FUTURES BID
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission today approved a proposal by the Chicago Mercantile Exchange to trade futures based on Standard & Poor's Composite Index of 500 stocks.

title: New Foundation Aide
description: Alberta Arthurs, the president of Chatham College in Pittsburgh, has been named director of humanities by the Rockefeller Foundation. In her new position, which begins in September, Mrs. Arthurs will administer a fellowship program that distributes $3 million a year in the humanities, one of the New York-based foundation's eight program areas.

title: ALBERT W. DEANE
description: Albert W. Deane, the former manager of the department of censorship and editing of the Paramount Pictures Corporation, died last Thursday at a retirement home in Maplewood, N.J., to which he had moved last year from New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 85 years old.

description: Dick Stockton toppled Bjorn Borg, 7-6, 1-6, 6-2, today in the second round of qualifying for the $370,000 Alan King-Caesars Palace Tennis Classic.

description: LONG ISLAND CITY, a predominately industrial area in Queens bordering the East River, has for years been characterized as on the verge of revitalization,

description: Jewels and clocks formerly owned by European royalty and American aristocrats sold yesterday for well above Christie's most optimistic expectations, indicating that the jewelry market may be enjoying a resurgence.

description: Murray L. Weidenbaum, the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, today dismissed as mistaken the forecasts that the Federal budget deficit this year may be $30 billion or more below the $100.5 billion projected by the Reagan Administration.

description: Linda Yang

description: West Germany today sharply criticized a British television documentary that said that Bonn had provided Argentina with technology to make an atomic bomb.

PUBLICATION OF CLASSICS SERIES BEGINS
description: The first four volumes of the Library of America, part of a remarkable publishing project that began more than 20 years ago as a vision for preserving America's literary heritage, are on their way to the nation's bookstores.

title: ISRAELIS APPROVE SINAI WITHDRAWAL
description: Israel's Cabinet voted unanimously today to withdraw from Sinai on Sunday, as required by the peace treaty with Egypt. Hours after the decision, the army moved against militant Jewish protesters in the northern Sinai town of Yamit, evicting them by force.

title: ISRAELI JETS BOMB LEBANESE VILLAGES HELD BY THE P.L.O.
description: The nine-month-old cease-fire between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization was shattered today as waves of Israeli planes attacked guerrilla positions south of Beirut hours after an Israeli soldier had been killed by a land mine in southern Lebanon.

title: SuperSonics 102, Rockets 87
description: SEATTLE (UPI) - Gus Williams scored 23 of his 27 points in the second half and the SuperSonics took command in the third quarter tonight to win the first game of their two-of-three mini-series.

title: Owens-Illinois Changes Management Structure
description: Owens-Illinois Inc., a major packaging producer with headquarters in Toledo, Ohio, divided its business into two parts in 1976 and named separate presidents and chief operating officers for domestic and for international operations. Now it is changing that structure and giving those same senior executives titles refecting overall corporate responsibilities.

title: Sports People; Cousineau to Oilers?
description: He was the first player selected in the 1979 National Football League draft, but he spurned an offer from the Buffalo Bills and instead signed for three years with Montreal of the Canadian Football League. Now, Tom Cousineau has taken the first step toward playing in the N.F.L. by signing an offer sheet with the Houston Oilers.

title: TOLEDO EDISON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Rare Bird's Eggs Watched
description: Two Siberian crane eggs are being incubated by American cranes and scientists say they are hoping for the second successful hatching of the nearly extinct bird in captivity. The International Crane Foundation said Tuesday that the eggs were laid last week.

description: Peter Stastny had two goals and an assist, and John Garrett turned in a strong performance in goal tonight as the Quebec Nordiques scored a 4-3 victory over the Boston Bruins and took a 3-2 lead in their Stanley Cup playoff series.

title: DROP IN U.S. ECONOMY CONTINUED, AT RATE OF 3.9%, IN FIRST QUARTER
description: The gross national product, the country's broadest measure of economic activity, fell at a 3.9 percent annual rate in the first quarter, confirming that the recession continued through March, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: JUSTICE FREEZES CHURCH'S FUNDS HELD IN 4 BANKS
description: Eight New York bank accounts belonging to the Life Science Church were frozen yesterday as part of a continuing Federal and state investigation into whether religion is being used as a cover for tax evasion.

title: Letter: On Urban Policy A Local Plan for Enterprise Zones
description: To the Editor:

description: The Hartford National Corporation reported yesterday that it had net income of $4.1 million for the first quarter of 1982, up a slight 2.5 percent from the $4 million posted a year earlier.

description: A jury acquitted F. Lee Bailey today of drunken driving. It ruled that the well-known lawyer from Boston was guilty only of passing a stop sign.
