THE PUBLIC'S MESSAGE TO ARMS
description: CONTROLLERSTo the Editor:

title: GAMES THAT WAR-GAMES PEOPLE PLAY
description: For the strategic planners in the Reagan Administration who are paid to think the unthinkable, word games often substitute for war games as ways to amuse themselves and maintain their sanity.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Campbell Soup Co. said that its Campbell Soup Overseas Finance unit had signed areeements for two Eurobond issues that will be guaranteed by the parent.

title: The Voice of a Man
description: ''Poems are speaking voices,'' Archibald MacLeish said in an essay on Robert Frost. ''And a poem that is hard to get rid of is a voice that is hard to get rid of.

title: Big Waldenbooks Insert Is Set for Newsweek
description: The great celebration at Newsweek last night was over getting selected as carrier for two 34-page Christmas catalogues for Waldenbooks - a $2 million-plus marketing project by the Carter Hawley Hale subsidiary.

title: Aaron Recalls Contentment and Slights
description: His career records as one of the most talented men who ever played baseball have long since been written into the books - home runs, total bases, extra-base hits, runs batted in, games played and atbats, among others. And throughout the 23 seasons that Hank Aaron spent in Milwaukee, Atlanta and then back in Milwaukee, his hallmark was always steadiness. There was rarely anything flashy about The Hammer, who played off-off-Broadway while such as Mays, Snider and Mantle drew the spotlight in New York and on the Coast.

title: Vida Barrera Weaver Is Dead; Wife of Syndicated Columnist
description: Vida Barrera Weaver, wife of the syndicated columnist Peter Weaver, died of cancer Tuesday. She was 57 years old.

title: MARGARETHE VON TROTTA STUDIES SISTERS AGIAN
description: MARGARETHE VON TROTTA'S third film, ''Marianne and Juliane,'' has a good deal in common with her second, ''Sisters, or the Balance of Happiness.'' In an interview, Miss von Trotta explains that she was just finishing work on her screenplay for ''Sisters'' when the idea for this film, with its similar subject, presented itself.

title: WYNN'S INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Syntex Unit's San Jose Plant
description: The Syntex Corporation, a diversified pharmaceuticals and agribusiness concern based in Panama, said its Syntex (U.S.A.) unit would build a $500 million pharmaceutical plant in South San Jose, a city of 670,000 at the south end of San Francisco Bay.

title: DURABLE ORDERS UP BY 1.9%
description: New factory orders for durable goods rose 1.9 percent in March, making it the first time since last summer that such orders have risen for two consecutive months, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: STEVENS MAY ASK SENATE TO CUT TROOPS IN EUROPE
description: A debate on the military budget was widened today with discussion of whether the United States should consider withdrawing some troops from Europe, a step that Senator Ted Stevens, the assistant majority leader of the Senate, said he might propose.

title: MORTON TO PROCEED WITH SALE OF UNIT
description: Morton-Norwich Products said it would proceed with the sale of its pharmaceutical division to the Procter & Gamble Company for $371 million in cash.

title: Kissinger Calls Report About Nixon a 'Myth'
description: Henry A. Kissinger, the former Secretary of State, has denied a published report that he once said former President Nixon, as a result of excessive drinking, would be incoherent if awakened at night.

title: TYPISTS COMPETE IN KEYBOARD SPEED
description: THERE wasn't a quick brown fox or a lazy dog in sight but there were several thousand frenzied fingers at the Halloran House on Tuesday as 300 secretaries and typists who work in the New York area competed in the regional type-off for the World's Fastest Typist Contest.

title: Net Rises 3.3% At Lockheed
description: The Lockheed Corporation yesterday reported earnings of $37.5 million, or $2.18 a share, up 3.3 percent from $36.3 million, or $2.33 a share, in the first quarter of 1981.

title: KOCH TAKES HIS GUBERNATORIAL CAMPAIGN UPSTATE
description: Mayor Koch, saying he would ''lead in a way that puts aside divisions,'' traveled across New York State today in what he called the formal start of his campaign for the Democratic nomination for Governor.

title: LYDALL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
A .22-CALIBER SHELL FOUND IN VAN IS LINKED TO SLAYINGS IN CBS CASE
description: A preliminary examination indicates that a .22-caliber shell casing found in the van of a New Jersey man was fired from the same gun that killed a Federal witness and three CBS employees, Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire disclosed last night.

title: NORTHWEST TO SEEK 20% OF OIL PRODUCER
description: Northwest Industries, a Chicago-based conglomerate, announced yesterday that it had acquired a 9.7 percent interest in the Pogo Producing Company, a Texas oil and gas exploration concern, and that it intended to acquire as much as 20 percent.

title: Son Admits Theft Of $104,000
description: A 24-year-old Freeport man accused of a $104,000 spending spree with money from his parents' safe pleaded guilty today to second-degree grand larceny in Nassau County Court.

title: NORTHWEST INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
U.S. CHARGES FILED AGAINST 3 IN BRINK'S ROBBERY
description: Three men were indicted in Manhattan yesterday on Federal charges that identified them as armed participants in the Brink's robbery that led to the killing of two policemen and a guard on Oct. 20 in Rockland County.

title: Pabst Proxy Suit
description: Irwin L. Jacobs, the leader of a group of dissident shareholders of the Pabst Brewing Company, announced that his group had filed suit Tuesday against Pabst and Torray Clark & Company, a Maryland investment advisory concern, in the United States District Court in Delaware, alleging violations of Federal securities laws and Delaware state law. The suit seeks to enjoin the counting of about one million shares voted by Torray Clark's clients in favor of Pabst's management at a recent proxy meeting. Mr. Jacobs' group, which controls 16.3 percent of Pabst's voting shares, has been trying to disqualify from the counting more than 12 million shares controlled by Torray Clark.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, APRIL 22, 1982
description: International The truce in Lebanon was shattered as Israeli jets bombed Palestinian guerrilla positions south of Beirut hours after an Israeli soldier was killed by a land mine in southern Lebanon. Lebanese Government sources said at least 23 people had been killed in the raid. Two Syrian MIG-23's were shot down by Israeli planes. (Page A1, Col. 6.) Washington urged the P.L.O. not to retaliate against Israel for the bombing raids in Lebanon in an effort to avert a breakdown in the nine-month-old cease-fire negotiated by the United States. Officials confirmed that President Reagan had reassured Israel that, in return for its withdrawal from Sinai Sunday, Washington would maintain Israel's military superiority over the Arabs. (A15:1.)

title: PENGO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Unsettling the I.B.M. Case
description: Not long after the Justice Department wearily dropped its 13-yearold antitrust case against the International Business Machines Corporation, there arose suggestions that the Assistant Attorney General for antitrust, William Baxter, might have had a conflict of interest in the matter. He stoutly denies it and bitterly protests the way the I.B.M. trial judge, David Edelstein, raised the question last month.

title: SAUNDERS LEASING SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
SHORT-TERM RATES IN DECLINE
description: Short-term rates declined yesterday, but longer-term yields rose, reflecting the widespread expectation of stable or lower short-term rates in coming weeks. But the outlook for long-term rates is less certain.

title: LAWMAKERS VOICE DISMAY OVER INMAN
description: Congressmen on both sides of the aisle and at each end of the political spectrum reacted with dismay today to the sudden resignation of Adm. Bobby R. Inman as Deputy Director of Central Intelligence.

title: Bridge:
description: L.I. Regionals to Start Off With an Unorthodox Twist By ALAN TRUSCOTT

title: SEARS CLIMBS 35.2% IN FIRST QUARTER
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company, which aggressively diversified outside the retailing area last year, reported yesterday that it had a 35.2 percent rise in net income in the first quarter, but not as a result of the new financial services or real estate brokerage businesses that it had recently acquired.

title: Sumitomo Chemical Net
description: The Sumitomo Chemical Company today announced a 72.7 percent drop in consolidated net income for all of 1981, to $995.8 million, from $3.6 billion a year earlier, on sales of $2.86 billion, down 3.3 percent, from $2.95 billion in 1980. It cited sluggish demand for petrochemical products and a decline in product prices.

title: Bridgestone Tire
description: The Government will pay 1 billion yen, or about $4.1 million, in overseas investment insurance to the Bridgestone Tire Company, whose joint venture project in Teheran was seized by the Iranian authorities, Bridgestone officials said.

title: PUBLIC SERVICE CO OF COLORADO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
LABOR'S BUSINESS
description: Times are changing in labor-management relations. Unions that traditionally chose to stay out of management's prerogatives now realize that the quality of management is labor's business, too.

title: Citicorp Board Inquiry
description: In response to lawsuits against some officers of Citicorp, the company's board has begun a review of a 1978 study by the bank's outside counsel about the legality of certain foreign exchange transactions, according to Darwin E. Smith, chairman of the board's audit committee and chairman and chief executive officer of the Kimberly-Clark Corporation.

title: A.T.& T. HOLDERS GET FIGHT TALK
description: Charles L. Brown, chairman of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, urged more than 5,000 shareholders attending the company's annual meeting here today to continue lobbying against a proposed House bill that A.T.& T. has said would place undesirable restrictions on it after divestiture of its local operating companies.

title: FAILURE OF TOXIC WASTE REGULATION IS CHARGED
description: Millions of tons of hazardous wastes not regulated by the Government are discharged into the environment each year, creating a serious public health problem, witnesses testified today at a Congressional hearing.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: CONSERVATIVE MOOD AT FURNITURE SHOW
description: HIGH POINT, N.C. BUYERS had a lot more on their minds than furniture as they attended the semiannual furniture market here. For one thing, because of the decrease in home starts, furniture sales have been lagging and the buyers have been looking for ways to entice people to replace what they already own.

title: CORRECTION
description: A news item in Notes on People yesterday about the composer Arthur Schwartz omitted the name of the lyricist for the songs ''Dancing in the Dark,'' ''That's Entertainment,'' and ''You and the Night and the Music.'' He is Howard Dietz.

title: GOODY PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Boat Overturns; Two Are Rescued
description: A small sailboat, buffeted by high winds, overturned yesterday in the Hudson River near Battery Park, but the two persons aboard were rescued by a passing tugboat, authorities said.

title: Sperry Introduces New Product Aid
description: Sperry Univac, a division of the Sperry Corporation, introduced a computer-aided design and manufacturing system that it said would enable manufacturers to take a product from design through production using one common data base on one computer system.

title: HEAVY SNOWS IN THE WEST STIR HOPE AND FEAR
description: Atop Galena Summit, 26 miles north of here, the county snowblowers are still working Highway 75, cutting back the sheer 15-foot cliffs of snow that line the approach to the pass like the walls of a tunnel.

title: METS TRIUMPH, 7-4
description: Ron Guidry continued to prove his boss wrong tonight, pitching a sizzling three-hitter as the Yankees beat the Chicago White Sox, 1-0. Guidry retired 15 consecutive batters in one stretch and 24 of the last 25 he faced, and he struck out nine batters while walking only one.

title: Shevelove Memorial Set
description: A memorial service for Burt Shevelove, the writer and director, will be held Tuesday in the Booth Theater at 5:30 P.M. Mr. Shevelove was co-author with Larry Gelbart of the book for the hit musical ''A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum.'' He died in London on April 8.

title: Samuel Shulsky Dead at 75; Writer of a Financial Column
description: Samuel Shulsky, a former New York newspaperman and syndicated financial columnist, died yesterday in Silver Spring, Md.

title: INLAND STEEL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Stroh's 'Survival' Bid
description: The Stroh Brewery Company was forced to acquire the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company to survive amid consolidation in the beer industry, Stroh's president said today in his first public comments on the takeover.

title: INCO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
OPEC SAYS PRODUCTION DECLINES
description: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is producing only 15.85 million barrels of oil a day, more than a million barrels below the group's official ceiling, its president said yesterday. The announcement suggested that OPEC might be succeeding in its campaign to curb output substantially, exerting upward pressure on prices.

title: CONSERVATIVE 'PUBLIC INTEREST' FIRMS EMERGE
description: It used to be that just about all the people who called themselves public interest lawyers in this lawyers' town tended to be civil rights activists, environmentalists and earnest young liberals who pounded away at the Establishment and big business in the name of consumers, poor people and minorities.

title: Surprise Party
description: Another opera buff got a pleasant surprise on his 47th birthday at the State House in Trenton.

title: FALKLANDS AND THE LAW
description: To the Editor:

title: Braves Get 13th On Hit in 9th
description: Claudell Washington's two-run single with two out in the bottom of the ninth inning lifted unbeaten Atlanta to a 4-3 decision over the Cincinnati Reds tonight.

title: SCHOOLS FIND MATH JOBS HARD TO FILL
description: Unable to compete with higher salaries offered by industry, school districts in the New York area are finding it increasingly difficult to recruit mathematics and science teachers. As a result, they are hiring hundreds of unqualified teachers to take over these subjects.

title: 76ERS WIN AS DAWKINS GETS 27
description: Any doubt that Darryl Dawkins was ready for the playoffs faded quickly tonight at the Spectrum. Dawkins, the 6-foot-11-inch, 250-pound center, scored 27 points, made 12 of 17 shots from the field, grabbed nine rebounds and blocked nine shots in helping the 76ers to a 111-76 rout of the Atlanta Hawks. The 76ers took a 1-0 lead in the two-of-three-game Eastern Conference series. The second game will be played Friday night in Atlanta. A third game, if necessary, would be here Sunday.

title: REYNOLDS, R J, INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Includes $2 million foreign currency translation gain...C-Includes $3 millionforeign currency translation gain

title: TIMELY WRITER OUR OF DANGER
description: Timely Writer's greatest triumph came this morning, 11 days earlier than expected. It happened at 7:30 in the receiving barn of a surgical clinic on the outskirts of town. The victory was not certified with a gold julep cup from the Governor of Kentucky, but with a weary smile from a veterinarian who needed a shave and some sleep.

title: NATIONAL DISTILLERS & CHEMICALS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Includes gain equal to 35 cents a shr from the sale of shrs of Mallinckrodt Inc to Avon Products Inc; 1981 results restated to reflect the change in method of computing and accounting for unrealized foreign currency adjustments

title: SHORTAGE OF ARMS, TROOPS AND FUNDS COMPLICATES JOB AHEAD FOR THE ARMY
description: The mission of the Army is simple to state, but complex to carry out: The Reagan Administration is asking it to create, from threequarters of a million men and women, a flexible, high-technology force prepared to fight in desert, jungle or forest.

title: THURSDAY, APRIL 22, 1982; The Economy
description: The continuing recession caused a 3.9 percent drop in the G.N.P. in the first quarter, after a 4.5 percent drop the quarter before. The stagnation was attributed to inventory reduction. (Page A1.)

title: Reagan Goes Riding
description: President Reagan took the afternoon off today and went horseback riding at the Marine Corps Base at Quantico, Va. The President, in riding breeches and a yellow shirt, was accompanied by his chief of staff, James A. Baker 3d.

title: NEW HAMPSHIRE BALL BEARINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
'VULNERABLE' AREA OF BRONX FIGHTS CLOSING OF BANK
description: For three and a half hours, leaders of a neighborhood in the Northwest Bronx squared off against the giant Citibank corporation in a hearing before Federal bank regulators.

title: Basques Say They Mounted Wave of Bombings in Spain
description: Basque separatist guerrillas took responsibility today for a recent string of shootings and bombings in Spain as the Government rejected direct negotiations with them.

title: TASS ATTACKS SCHMIDT SPEECH
description: The Soviet press agency Tass today criticized a speech Tuesday by Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany, describing it as extremely contradictory and full of ''rude and unseemly'' attacks on Moscow.

title: 2 KOREAS BLAME EACH OTHER FOR SKIRMISH
description: North and South Korea blamed each other today for an exchange of gunfire across the demilitarized zone early this morning.

title: APARTMENT PACT GRANTS WORKERS INCREASE OF $65
description: A threatened strike that might have curbed services for as many as a million New York City tenants was averted early yesterday when apartment-house owners and the union representing their employees agreed on a new three-year contract.

title: QUOTRON SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
NUCLEAR WEAPONS ARE THE
description: ENEMYTo the Editor:

title: Maine Mansion the Prize In an Essay Contest
description: FOXCROFT, Me., April 21 (AP) - A 20-room Victorian mansion is being offered as the prize in an essay contest sponsored by the owner. The participants, who pay a $50 entry fee, must write 125 words on ''Why I want to win a big old house in Maine.''

title: LEASE A PUPIL
description: To the Editor:

title: SALVADOR ARMS FLOW CONTINUES, ENDERS SAYS
description: Thomas O. Enders, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, told a House subcommittee today that Nicaragua was ''engaged in a campaign of destabilization'' in El Salvador. He said ''substantial levels'' of arms were continuing to enter that country.

title: SEARS ROEBUCK & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
BANKERS' GAMBLE WITH LOANS ABROAD
description: To the Editor:

title: TIMEPLEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $55,000 for the qr and $268,000 for the 9 mos...C-After a loss from discontinued operations and disposal of discontinued operations of $427,000

title: REGENCY ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
PAINE WEBBER DROPS 36.2%
description: The E.F. Hutton Group Inc. and Paine Webber Inc., two of Wall Street's largest investment concerns, posted sharply reduced quarterly earnings yesterday - in line with a 33.6 percent drop reported Tuesday by Merrill Lynch & Company, the industry leader.

title: Advertising;  How 2d Agency Sells Itself
description: DENISE T. DAVIDOFF, president and chief executive of Shailer Davidoff Rogers, is at long last going to take advantage of the fact that her 15-year-old Fairfield, Conn., agency is in the midst of what has become a great concentration of corporate headquarters.

title: People
description: * John Conti has been named president of John G. Murray Advertising.

title: STAUFFER CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
PHIBRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Borden Net Climbs 8.1%
description: Borden Inc. reported today that first-quarter profit rose 8.1 percent from a year earlier, but more than half of the earnings came from the sale of three Pepsi-Cola franchises and disposition of other operations, offseting a sharp drop in chemical division income.

title: FOR STORING WINTER THINGS; by Barbara L. Isenberg and Mary Smith
description: THE annual rites of spring - getting out lightweight clothes and storing woolens, boots and other winter paraphernalia - are under way. The Jensen-Lewis Company, 89 Seventh Avenue (15th Street), has a new group of organizers designed to make the job easier.

title: INTERPACE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $646,000 or 16 cents a shr

title: Harvester to Have Only a Single Agency
description: Financially harassed International Harvester, Chicago, has merged all of its marketing departments and is screening seven agencies to see which one will be its sole agency.

title: PAN AM'S SURVIVAL STRATEGY
description: The big push that could determine its survival has begun at Pan American World Airways. A major ad campaign to lure people to its international destinations is now in place as are many union concessions that should enable the carrier to increase its operations by 12 to 15 percent without raising costs.

title: THAIS TO PRESS ATTACKS ON GUERRILLAS
description: Despite Government casualties of at least 40 dead and more than 200 wounded in the last two months, the military commander of Thailand's mountainous southern peninsula insists that he will ''destroy'' this region's Communist Party of Thailand and banish its ''dark influence'' permanently.

title: WYMAN-GORDON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 3
WOMETCO-CABLE TV INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 27
description: B-Includes $299,000 tax credit...C-Includes $382,000 tax credit

title: LOCKHEED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-After a loss of $16.6 million from discontinued operations and an extraordinary gain of $22.8 million from the exchange of preferred stock for debentures

title: Dr. Nelson B. Sackett, Gynecologist, Is Dead
description: Dr. Nelson B. Sackett, a gynecologist and obstetrician and a specialist in gynecological cancer, died of a heart attack Tuesday at New York Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: IN CHAOS, ISRAEL'S SOLDIERS PRY RESISTERS OUT OF SINAI
description: Occupied Sinai, April 21 - Amid scenes of hysteria and random violence, Israel today began the evacuation and destruction of this town, founded eight years ago.

title: MIRRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-After $222,000 loss from discontinued operations

title: STEELMET INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
INTERLAKE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Mary Hornaday Dies, Former Monitor Writer
description: Mary J. Hornaday, a former correspondent for The Christian Science Monitor who was the first woman to serve as acting president of the Overseas Press Club, died Tuesday in Riverdale, N. Y. She was 76 years old.

title: METICULOUS JUDGE IN WESTWAY CASE
description: In his nearly 10 years on the Federal bench in New York City, Thomas P. Griesa has presided over many dramatic cases. There have been celebrity contract disputes, a challenge by drug addicts to a hiring ban by the Transit Authority, the conviction of Frank Tieri as the boss of a Mafia family, the fraud conviction of Michele Sindona in the collapse of the Franklin National Bank and the Socialist Workers Party's nine-year-old, $40 million lawsuit against the Federal Government.

title: REICHHOLD CHEMICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Includes $485,000 foreign exchange gain...C-Includes $742,000 foreign exchange gain and has been restated to reflect a change in accounting for foreign currency translation

title: METROMEDIA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Includes $4,617,000 gain on disposition and retirement of debt

title: COURAGE IN HARD TIMES
description: When Abe Fortas died on April 5, people inevitably thought about his service on the Supreme Court and his forced resignation. But there is reason to reflect on his earlier years as a lawyer, and especially on his performance at a bad time for law and public life in this country. That was the era of Senator Joe McCarthy.

title: STOCKS POST MODERATE GAINS
description: The stock market posted a moderate advance yesterday in active trading. The Dow Jones industrial average, which moved in a narrow price range throughout the session, closed up 2.86 points, to 843.42. Advancing issues on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered stocks that declined by 841 to 598.

title: HARRIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 26
description: Results for the latest 9 mos have been restated for an accounting change; results for the yr-ago 9 mos include a gain of $12.2 million from the sale of an investment

title: GARY LEWELLYN BANKING AFFAIR LEAVES IOWA TOWN UNFAZED
description: There is a curious lack of anger in this town toward Gary V. Lewellyn, the 33-year-old Des Moines stockbroker who is charged with embezzling money from the First National Bank where his father, Clifford, was president.

title: SERVICE MERCHANDISE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
PROTECTING OUTDOOR FURNITURE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Michael Varese restores furniture for antiques dealers and collectors. By MICHAEL VARESE

title: National Futures Picks First Chief
description: Robert K. Wilmouth, the 53-year-old president of the Chicago Board of Trade, has resigned to become the first president and chief executive officer of the National Futures Association. The association is the self-regulatory group for the futures industry and is expected to be formally established, following the passage of appropriate Federal legislation, on Oct. 1.

title: Polish Communist Party Ousts 44,500 Members
description: The Polish Communist Party said today that it had suspended or expelled 44,500 members in March for showing indifference to the party's activities.

title: WOODSTREAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
ANTIQUES, ORCHIDS AND HOUSE TOURS
description: Fort Greene House Tour, departing from Williamsburg Savings Bank, 1 Hanson Place, Brooklyn, 643-1603.

title: A POOR CASE FOR GIVING AMTRAK MORE TAXPAYER DOLLARS
description: To the Editor:

title: PENTHOUSE TRIAL IS GOING TO JURY
description: The $522 million libel suit by the resort La Costa against Penthouse magazine is scheduled to go to the jury Thursday.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard SKETCHES FROM LIFE. The Early Years. By Lewis Mumford. Illustrated. 500 pages. Dial. $19.95.

title: Spanish Court Rejects Appeal By a Paper Barred From Trial
description: The military court hearing evidence against 33 defendants accused of trying to overthrow the Government 14 months ago rejected the appeal of an editor today.

title: BESIEGED HOMEOWNERS APPEAL ON ASSESSMENTS
description: They crowded onto the plastic chairs on the second floor of the old Municipal Building in Brooklyn yesterday, clutching slips of paper with the block and lot numbers of their properties. They were homeowners, and they wanted to get something back from the city.

title: CONCERT: OZAWA LEADS BOSTONIANS IN BERLIOZ REQUIEM
description: WHEN Vanessa Redgrave's well-publicized views on the Palestinian question aroused opposition recently in Boston, the Boston Symphony decided bow to the protests and cancel its performances of Stravinsky's ''Oedipus Rex'' in which the actress had been scheduled as the narrator. In that work's stead, Seiji Ozawa decided to program the Berlioz Requiem, hardly a piece that can be thrown together at a moment's notice, but one that the orchestra's music director and his musicians know intimately and have performed with distinction in the past. Last night, in the wake of several Boston performances, Mr. Ozawa took Berlioz's massive work to Carnegie Hall and set the august walls trembling with acoustical - and, more importantly, musical - excitement.

title: S.&P. FUTURES ARE TRADED
description: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange today began trading in futures based on Standard & Poor's Composite Index of 500 stocks in what securities and commodities traders believe is an additional move toward merging the two industries.

title: Bolivia Sets Elections in 1983 For a Constituent Assembly
description: President Celso Torrelio announced today that elections for a constituent assembly would be held in the first half of 1983.

title: FORMER PRESIDENT OF MET MUSEUM
description: Roland L. Redmond, a lawyer and former president of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, died Tuesday at his home in Tivoli, N.Y. He was 90 years old. At his death, he was counsel to the law firm of Carter, Ledyard & Milburn, with which he had been associated since 1919.

title: Soviet Six Beats U.S.; 2 Players Are Ejected
description: The unbeaten Soviet Union scored its fifth victory of hockey's world championship tournament today, beating the United States, 8-4, in a game marred by 48 penalty minutes and the ejection of one player from each team.

title: MINNETONKA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Addendum
description: Shaw Elliott Inc. has changed its name to Hirsch Elliott Inc.

title: CONCERT: GERSHWIN SALUTE
description: ALONG with other composers influenced by jazz, blues and song, George Gershwin combined traditions of popular and high culture. They touched again briefly Monday night as the National Orchestra of New York presented a ''Gershwin Celebration'' in Carnegie Hall, conducted by Mitch Miller.

title: 'COMPUTER KIDS' MASTER SKILLS AS BASIC FOR THEM AS READING
description: ''WE'RE used to it, that's all,'' said 16-year-old Alla Roytberg. ''I guess, to many of us, it's completely ordinary, like television.'' ''Among some adults, there's fear of it, I suppose,'' said Brett D'Ambrosio, who recently turned 15. ''It's the fear of the unknown. It's a natural fear, but there's really nothing to be afraid of.''

title: BUDGET VIEWS PUT IN FOCUS BY 5 SENATORS
description: As the budget negotiations between Republican and Democratic Congressional leaders and White House officials inch their way forward, the Senators from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut have been hearing a chorus of voices from their home constituents.

title: HAWAIIAN ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Including a gain of $2.8 million from a change in the billing system

title: Honeywell's Stake In French Unit Cut
description: Honeywell Inc., a leading computer maker, said it had reached agreement in principle to sell more than half of its stake in a French affiliate following a slide in the unit's profit and the threat of French nationalization.

title: STONE & WEBSTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
SANTA FE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for QTr to Mar 31
City's Reservoirs Now at Capacity
description: After nearly two years of warnings about drought conditions and the importance of water conservation, New York City's upstate reservoirs are filled to capacity, the city's Department of Environmental Protection said yesterday.

title: Arts and Letters Group Gives Annual Prizes to 5
description: The American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters has conferred its annual arts prizes on two painters, Michael David, 27 years old, and George McNeill, 74, and three sculptors, Nizette Brennan and Alan Motch, both 31, and Manuel Neri, 51.

title: OF SEX AND LIBERALS
description: Why do liberals panic when faced with certain aspects of sexuality and social mores? Mention the word ''chastity'' and they get all nervous and giggly. This, at least, has been a common response to the Reagan Administration's proposal requiring parental notification when adolescents obtain prescription contraceptives from federally funded clinics. Demographic evidence may suggest that reducing the extent of adolescent sexual activity, not sex education or contraceptives, is the key to controlling teenage pregnancies. Yet the idea that public policy might be designed to inhibit adolescent sexual activity is something liberals cannot discuss calmly; it is easier to huff about Moral Majoritarians. Has some profound liberal taboo been offended?

title: Hitachi Robot
description: Hitachi Ltd. said it had developed a new industrial robot with twice the memory capacity of a conventional machine.

title: Going Out Guide
description: GRAND AFFAIR

title: News Analysis
description: Representative Tom Bevill of Alabama emerged from a meeting of House Democratic leaders today and said, ''The country is in bad shape. They've agreed on that.''

title: NETS TRY TO AVERT FAST EXIT
description: Less than 24 hours after his 4-for-19 shooting performance, Ray Williams was blue, even down to his shoes, while his Net teammates practiced yesterday.

title: RANGERS THANKFUL FOR LUCKY BOUNCES
description: There was no jubilation in their dressing room tonight after the Rangers had avoided elimination from their Stanley Cup playoff series with the Islanders.

title: DANCE: TAYLOR'S TROUPE WITH 'MERCURIC TIDINGS'
description: TO suggest that Paul Taylor's ''Mercuric Tidings'' just sings is not quite right. It is a dance work that bursts seemingly into song. If no sounds other than portions of Schubert's first two symphonies rise from the pit, music and dance are so closely entwined here that they are one.

title: PROGRAM OF TOURS SET IN PHILADELPHIA
description: Philadelphia Open House, a series of 28 events and tours of the neighborhoods and suburbs of William Penn's 300-year-old ''green country towne,'' is scheduled from April 30 through May 9. Sponsored by 19 different organizations, most tours are limited in size, some as small as 100 people, and reservations are recommended.

title: Custodian Admits Burning of Temple
description: A careless janitor who tried to disguise his role in a synagogue fire by painting a swastika outside the burning building pleaded guilty to arson today.

title: MARY KAY COSMETICS reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
SHORT INTEREST ON BIG BOARD RISES TO RECORD LEVEL
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest jumped by 8.9 million shares, in the month ended April 15, to a record 94.6 million.

title: Q & A
description: Q. During this past winter I encountered problems with heavy snow accumulating on the roof, resulting in a great deal of water damage in one room. The roof is only a few years old, and I can see no signs of a leak. I have been told that this is inevitable when heavy snow accumulates. Is this true, and if so what can be done to prevent it? - A.E.F., Lancaster, Pa.

title: SUBURBANITES PICK FAVORITE HOME STYLES
description: If the typical middle-class suburbanite had as wide a choice as he wanted, what style would he select for his home? In 18 months of studying the housing-style preferences of homeowners in suburban tracts, Scott A. Kinzy, an architect and assistant professor of design at the State University of New York at Buffalo, discovered that modern and contemporary houses rank at the very bottom of the range of styles; nearly half the homeowners instead chose a ''farm'' or a Tudor house as their favorite.

title: Phibro Down 27.9% in Quarter; Reynolds Declines Slightly
description: The Phibro Corporation reported yesterday that a weak commodities market caused net income in the first quarter of 1982 to drop 27.9 percent, while revenues increased 4.2 percent.

title: NONPARTISAN TALKS URGED BY BUSH
description: Vice President Bush said today that the Reagan Administration ''welcomes the emergence of the nuclear freeze issue in the national political debate'' but urged that the debate be conducted in a ''statesmanlike'' and nonpartisan manner.

title: Technology; Overcoming Data Barriers
description: TO-COMPUTER conversation represents the world's most modern form of communications. Already it is playing an important role in international commerce in such areas as banking and air traffic control. Multinational corporations keep track of their farflung operations with computers and, increasingly, employees of such companies stationed in one nation can draw data out of a computer in another.

title: THE TRAGEDY OF TIMING
description: The state of Israel, soon to celebrate its 34th year, has a history of unrelieved drama, sometimes triumphant, often deeply painful, always changing. When I arrived in the middle of the 1948 war, the first people I met after an arduous journey were three soldiers.

title: 'IRON LADY' DISPLAYS GIFT AT RECEPTION
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher took a bit of time away from the crisis that has dominated her life for nearly three weeks to play hostess Tuesday night at a long-planned reception for businessmen at 10 Downing Street.

title: Cavendes Stake In Florida Bank
description: Following an extended series of court battles in a struggle over who may acquire Florida National Banks of Florida Inc., one of the bank's major stockholders, C.A. Cavendes Sociedad Financiera, a Venezuelan investment group, purchased about 10 percent of Florida National's shares at $26 a share from another Venezuelan holder, the Cisneros Group.

title: Iraq-Japan Oil Halt
description: Iraq has told Japanese refiners and importers that it will suspend crude oil shipments to Japan until further notice because of the closing of oil pipelines through Syria, industry sources here said.

title: Hers; by K.C. Cole
description: AFRIEND of mine does the most marvelous things with shadows. On a sunny day, he'll lift his hands high above his head and make holes in the spaces between his crossed fingers. On the ground below, we can see shimmering images of the sun created as light passes through the holes. These are the same sun images we see when sunlight filters through the irregular spaces between the leaves of a tree, leaving overlapping round images - like scattered gold coins - on the ground.

title: FILM: 'MAX FRISCH,' A DOCUMENTARY
description: ''MAX FRISCH: Journal I-III,'' a Swiss documentary feature written and directed by Richard Dindo, exemplifies the sort of painstaking, uncritical, single-minded scholarship that often has the effect of obscuring its subject rather than illuminating it. The subject here is Max Frisch, the German-Swiss diarist, novelist (''Man in the Holocene'' and ''Montauk'' among others) and playwright, perhaps best known in this country for his furiously comic ''The Firebugs.''

title: German Auto Output
description: West German motor vehicle production rose by 15 percent in the first quarter, to 1.15 million units, from a million vehicles a year ago, according to an industry association report today. Production in March rose 16.4 percent, to 427,700 vehicles, from 367,393 in February.

title: OVER 1,000 LEFT HOMELESS BY FIRE IN ANAHEIM, CALIF.
description: Hundreds of apartment units were destroyed and more than 1,000 people were left homeless by a fire that devastated four square blocks of this suburb of Los Angeles before dawn today.

title: CALVIN KLEIN' RECIPE FOR SUCCESS
description: WHEN Calvin Klein was moving swiftly up the fashion ladder a dozen years ago and was asked the reason for his success, he said, ''I try to make clothes women like to wear.''

title: U.S. SAYS MEDIATION IN CRISIS CONTINUES
description: Senior Administration officials sought today to counter views in Congress that mediation efforts in the Falkland Islands dispute had failed and that the United States should now side with Britain against Argentina.

title: PROCTER & GAMBLE ORDERED TO PAY $300,000 IN TOXIC SHOCK CASE
description: A Federal jury today found the Procter & Gamble Company liable for the death from toxic shock syndrome of a woman who used its Rely tampons. It ordered the company to pay her husband $300,000 in actual damages.

title: DEMOCRATS PRESS REAGAN ON BUDGET
description: House Democratic leaders insisted today that President Reagan would have to take the initiative in approving a budget compromise before it would be considered by Congressional Democrats.

title: CITY'S BUDGET FURTHER THREATENED BY LATEST WESTWAY COURT RULING
description: A court order barring the Federal Government from paying out $90 million for the Westway project threatens to throw New York City's 1983 budget more out of balance than it already is, city officials said yesterday.

title: City Loses Appeal Of Solicitation Ban
description: A Federal court ruled yesterday that New York City went too far when it issued a total ban against the solicitation of money in its 41 welfare centers.

title: Coastal Denied Award Rehearing
description: The Coastal Petroleum Company reported that a Federal Appeals Court denied its request for a rehearing of a recent United States Circuit Court ruling vacating a $20 million verdict that Coastal had obtained from the Mobil Oil Corporation.

title: Market Place; More Glamour In Health Care
description: SOME years ago, Avon Products and Revlon Inc. were among the darlings of Wall Street in the glamorous business of cosmetics. Their profits rose, and so did their stock prices.

title: CHAMBER: MUSIC AT Y, WITH NEW ACOUSTICS
description: THE 92d Street Y has installed a new acoustical shell in its Kaufmann Concert Hall, and the results were pleasantly apparent in the Chamber Music at the Y concert given on Tuesday night.

title: Inquiry Hears of Deaths Of Oil Rig's Crew in Boat
description: A damaged lifeboat carrying eight or nine crew members of the oil rig Ocean Ranger capsized as they lunged for a line from a rescue vessel, Federal investigators were told today.

title: FEW BALLOT ON SCHOOLS IN SUBURBS
description: The people who walk into Steven A. Janett's real-estate office here usually have three questions in mind: Are the streets safe? What are the chances of resale? And what's the quality of the school system?

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: The International Amateur Athletic Federation Council, ending its five-day meeting in Kingston, Jamaica, imposed an 18-month suspension on Lindy Haglund, the Swedish spinter, and named Canberra, Australia, as the host city for the 1985 Track and Field World Cup as it ended its five-day meeting in Kingston, Jamaica. Primo Nebiola of Italy, the Federation's president, said Miss Haglund was being penalized for using anabolic steroids at a track meet in Sweden last year, but added that the athlete was ''mistakenly'' given the drug by her coach. ... Perry Turnbull, the St. Louis Blues left wing, will undergo surgery Monday to repair a severed tendon in his right leg, suffered when he was cut by a skate last Thursday in a playoff game against Chicago.

title: Accounts
description: * World Book/Childcraft International to McCann-Erickson, Chicago. * The New York Stock Exchange Index to FCB/Corporate.

title: Jessie Cox, an Owner Of Dow Jones Concern
description: Jessie Bancroft Cox, a major stockholder of Dow Jones & Company, the financial publishing concern, died in New York on Tuesday. She was 73 years old and lived in Cohasset, Mass.

title: Hearings Are Ordered On Players' Complaints
description: The New York regional director of the National Labor Relations Board issued a formal complaint today and ordered hearings after the National Football League Management Council had refused to supply the players' union with copies of the league's television contracts and all standard player contracts.

title: CRYPTOGRAPHERS READY TO RESIST SMOTHERING
description: To the Editor:

title: VORTEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
INMAN TO LEAVE HIS C.I.A. POST AFTER CONFLICTS
description: Adm. Bobby R. Inman, who took positions on intelligence and foreign affairs that often brought him into conflict with Reagan Administration policy, has decided to resign as Deputy Director of Central Intelligence, the White House announced today.

title: TAX ON VIDEOTAPING IS URGED
description: Representatives of the entertainment and electronics industries told the Senate Judiciary Committee today that the owners of home videotape recorders should not be branded as criminals for duplicating copyrighted television programs.

title: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: CANADA'S ISOLATED NORTH
description: ''Attention,'' the airport sign warns, ''The Hand That Feeds Could Get Eaten.'' And there is a large picture of a large polar bear who bears no resemblance whatsoever to his friendly southern cousin, Smokey.

title: New Marine Bank Chief Foresees Expansion
description: John R. Petty, 52, president of the Marine Midland Bank, has added the title of chief executive officer of the New York institution. He succeeds Edward W. Duffy, 55, who remains chairman of the bank, as well as chairman and chief executive officer of its holding company, Marine Midland Banks Inc. Mr. Petty is also president of the holding company, whose assets at the end of 1981 amounted to $18.9 billion.

title: BRIEFS
description: * AeroMech Airlines, based in West Virginia, said the Civil Aeronautics Board had designated it a small regional airline, replacing its former status as a commuter airline.

title: Hesburgh Nears Record
description: Some people collect stamps, some coins. Others collect matchbooks, antiques or bottles. The Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh, president of the University of Notre Dame, collects honorary degrees, and he is about to set a record.

title: U.S. URGES P.L.O. NOT TO RETALIATE FOR ISRAELI RAIDS
description: The United States urged the Palestine Liberation Organization today not to retaliate against Israel for bombing raids in Lebanon.

title: DRAMATIC ACADEMY WILL HEAR PLUMMER
description: Christopher Plummer, co-star with James Earl JOnes in ''Othello,'' will speak Tuesday at the 96th graduation ceremonies of the American Academy of Dramatic Arts in the Winter Garden Theater.

title: SAL CABLE COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Comptek Forms Legal Service Unit
description: Comptek Research Inc., a Buffalo-based supplier of hardware and software computer systems for lawyers, said it had turned its office automation division into a separate corporation, to be known as the Barrister Information Systems Corporation.

title: BRIEFING
description: Museum Tableau

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary of Burt Shevelove on April 9 incorrectly identified the au- thors of the screenplay of ''A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum.'' It was by Melvin Frank and Michael Pertwee, who adapted it from the play by Mr. Shevelove and Larry Gelbart.

title: Hawaii Milk Distributor Challenges Court Ban
description: Hawaii, Hawaii's largest milk distributor, today sought a restraining order against a state order that bars it from processing any milk produced on the island of Oahu because of pesticide contamination.

title: Blues Subdue Hawks in Overtime, 3-2
description: Bernie Federko took a centering pass from Joe Mullen and scored at 3:28 of overtime, giving St. Louis a 3-2 triumph over the Chicago Black Hawks and keeping the Blues alive in their Stanley Cup quarterfinal series.

title: Sports People; Wisconsin Spurned
description: Jerry (Ice) Reynolds, the former basketball star from Alexander Hamilton High School in Brooklyn, says he will give up his attempt to enroll at Wisconsin and attend Louisiana State instead. Reynolds, a 6-foot-8-inch forward, was recruited by the former Wisconsin coach, Bill Cofield, but could not play because he never received a high school diploma.

title: EFFECTS OF STOUFFER'S VERDICT ON LAWSUITS HELD MINIMAL
description: Legal sources agree that the recent reversal of Luis Marin's arson and murder conviction in the Stouffer's Inn fire will have a minimal effect on civil suits seeking damages.

title: RANGERS WIN AND CUT ISLANDERS' LEAD IN SERIES TO 3-2
description: The Rangers staved off elimination from the Stanley Cup playoffs tonight by outworking the Islanders Nassau Coliseum and beating them, 4-2.

title: HELEN OF TROY (CO) reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
USAIR reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Includes $4.9 million pretax operating loss and $27.2 million pretax gain on the sale of tax benefits

title: AMERICAN AIRLINES REPORTS A DEFICIT
description: American Airlines yesterday reported a net loss of $41.6 million for the first quarter, in contrast to a profit of $3.9 million, or 3 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: LEUKEMIA OUTBREAK IN FAIRHAVEN, MASS., PROMPTS STATE STUDY
description: A state health investigator today began interviewing families of seven young leukemia victims, looking for clues to the higher-than-normal incidence of the childhood disease in this community of 16,000 people.

title: GOLDEN NUGGET INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
N.H.L. Playoffs; Canucks Top Kings And Clinch Series
description: Darcy Rota scored a pair of second-period goals and Richard Brodeur continued his outstanding play in goal to to lift Vancouver to a 5-2 victory over the Los Angeles Kings tonight that gave the Canucks the Smythe Division title.

title: U.S. Aides Expect Spy Case In South to Go to Grand Jury
description: The case against a 50-year-old man accused of spying for Hungarian military intelligence will probably go before a Federal grand jury this week, the authorities said Tuesday.

title: Bond Issue for Prison Urged in Jersey Study
description: Construction of a new 1,000-bed state prison should be financed through a state bond issue of up to $100 million, a legislative report urged today.

title: Pilot Lands Safely On Road In Jersey
description: A pilot helping fight a forest fire safely landed his single-engine plane on the westbound lane of Interstate 195 today, authorities said.

title: IN BUENOS AIRES, THE EUPHORIA'S OVER
description: In the first days after Argentina's invasion of the Falkland Islands, the weather was fine and the nation jubilant. But, after Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. left without settling the dispute, rain fell on Buenos Aires, and people began to realize that there might be war.

title: TANDYCRAFTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,588,000 for the qr and $1,818,000 for the 9 mos and $6,100,000 extraordinary gain for the qr and 9 mos from an insurance settlement...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $273,000for the qr and $455,000 for the 9 mos

title: P.L.O. SUGGESTS IT WILL HONOR TRUCE
description: A ranking official of the Palestine Liberation Organization said today that the P.L.O. was maintaining its side of the cease-fire in Lebanon despite Israel's latest air attack. But he warned that if Israel struck again, the P.L.O. was likely to fire back across the border.

title: Nigerian Import Curb
description: President Shehu Shagari of Nigeria has announced drastic curbs on imports in a bid to forestall an economic crisis touched off by falling oil revenues. In a nationwide television and radio broadcast on Tuesday, President Shagari said imports of a wide range of goods produced in Nigeria would be restricted, imports of all motor vehicles would be suspended entirely and all capital projects not already under way would be deferred. Declining oil revenue has cut the Government's revenue forecast for this year, to $13.3 billion from $17.3 billion, he said.

title: THE PLUSES AND MINUSES OF IVY AND OTHER VINES
description: Has the era of ivy-covered walls ended? The recent announcement that Harvard University is having its brick walls stripped of their traditional leafy greenery raises the question for home gardeners.

title: Jimmy Carter to Teach at Emory
description: After spending more than a year working on his memoirs, Jimmy Carter has apparently had enough of the solitary professional life. Beginning in September, the former President announced yesterday, he will make periodic forays from his study in Plains, Ga., to serve as a visiting professor at Emory University in Atlanta.

title: CORRECTION
description: The signature in yesterday's article ''Tests on Humans'' should have been Morris B. Abram.

title: Fire Dept. Allowed To Hire 60 Men
description: The city's Fire Department, which has been ordered to appoint 45 women as firefighters once it devises a new physical test, will be allowed to hire 60 men to keep staffing from dropping below a safe level, a department spokesman said yesterday.

title: Mortgage Aid Bill Is Backed
description: A Senate committee today approved a bill to provide substantial Government mortgage subsidies for low- and moderate-income families despite signs that the Reagan Administration would oppose any such moves as too costly.

title: EDNA CLARK, 96, AVON HEIRESS AND DEVELOPER OF FOUNDATION
description: Edna McConnell Clark, an heiress to the Avon Products cosmetic fortune who used her wealth to establish one of the country's leading private foundations, died yesterday at her summer home in Woods Hole, Mass. She was 96 years old.

title: MINE SAFETY APPLIANCES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
INCO REPORTS A LOSS
description: Two large metals companies yesterday reported sharply lower profits while a third company reported a loss for the first quarter of this year compared with the first three months of 1981. All of the metals they produce - steel, nickel and aluminum - have been battling a difficult market for more than a year. Kaiser Steel

title: NEW VIRTUOSI: 2 AT FESTIVAL
description: THE flutist Robert Dick and the percussionist Jan Williams were featured in the Kitchen's ''New Virtuosi Festival'' Tuesday night. In their solo performances, each virtuoso used ''new'' techniques applied to ''new'' expressions.

title: POPE & TALBOT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''The argument has been, co-opt the left before it's too late. That analysis has been proven incorrect, but another has been proven right - that is, that if only given the opportunity to choose, Central Americans will choose democracy over authoritarianism, and reform over revolution.'' -Thomas O. Enders, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs. (A6:3)

title: News Analysis
description: Just before Governor Carey broke off negotiations with the Legislature over the state budget last month, he spent hours negotiating amiably with the legislative leaders. So pleasant were the discussions, in fact, that the Assembly Speaker, Stanley Fink, returned to his office and told his aides about how forthcoming Mr. Carey had been.

title: U.S. SAYS TALKS WITH CUBA ARE STILL POSSIBLE
description: Administration officials said today that lines of communication were still open to Cuba and that the Administration remained ready for discussions, despite its actions and statements about Cuba.

title: WALL STREET REACTION: IT CAN HAPPEN AGAIN
description: Wall Street executives, clearly embarrassed by the most daring stock-kiting scheme in years, suggested yesterday that it could happen again because of the way the industry operates.

title: The Rio Pact Indeed
description: Argentina has invoked the wrong treaty at the wrong time to promote the illusion that all Latin American nations support its seizure of the Falklands. They don't, and some that do serve only their own territorial ambitions. By appealing to the Rio Pact against intrusion into the hemisphere, the Argentine generals choose the semblance of diplomacy over the real thing.

title: Iranian Dissident Cleric Under Guard at Home
description: A leading Iranian dissident cleric, Kazem Shariat-Madari, has been placed under armed guard at his house ''so that people don't attack him,'' the Speaker of Parliament, Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani, said today on the Teheran radio.

title: TRIAD SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
INTERNATIONAL KING'S TABLE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 3
HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: THERE are probably dozens of woodworking joints that are used by professionals, but many of these take a great deal of skill and experience to complete properly and some call for the use of tools that many do-it-yourselfers are not likely to own.

title: BRITAIN DRAWS UP 3-STEP PEACE PLAN ON THE FALKLANDS
description: Britain has decided to propose a three-stage plan for settlement of the Falkland Islands crisis that might include only a relatively brief return to British administration, Government sources reported today.

title: The U.N. Today; April 22, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. on Palestinians.

title: ROGERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 4
Moscow Backs the West On Nuclear Talks Plan
description: In a surprise last-minute reversal, the Soviet bloc today joined the West and nonaligned nations in backing a proposal to have a special working group try to break an impasse on talks on a nuclear test ban, Western diplomats said.

title: MCNEIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Includes gain on the sale of facilities and operating losses on discontinued operations...C-After loss from discontinued operations

title: HEXCEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Including a gain of $607,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change; yr-ago results have been restated to include operations of Seal Sands Chemical Co Ltd

title: Sports People; Angels Get Kelleher
description: In need of a backup shortstop, the California Angels have purchased Mick Kelleher from Detroit for an undisclosed amount of cash. Kelleher will play behind Tim Foli, who became the No.1 shortstop after Rick Burleson suffered a shoulder injury that will sideline him for the season.

title: RAMTEK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-After $216,000 loss from discontinued operations

title: TEXAS POLITICS: GAME PLAYED WITH A NAME
description: Buster beat Babe the last time and now Bill wants the job. Or, as they put it on the ballot, J.E. (Buster) Brown defeated A.R. ''Babe'' Swartz for the State Senate here in 1978 and is opposed this year by W.J. Bill Blythe Jr.

title: TALKED-ABOUT BUT NEVER-SEEN THEATER CHARACTERS
description: IHAVE a splendid idea for a play, and because it isn't proper for a critic to collect theatrical royalties on the side, it's hereby offered, gratis, to any blocked dramatist in need. Naturally, when this opus appears on Broadway, a donation must be made in my name to the Actors Fund.

title: BALLET THEATER: 'BILLY,' 'SYLPHIDES' AND 'FANCY'
description: IT was a real ''American Ballet Theater'' night Tuesday at the Metropolitan Opera House, when the company performed three of the ballets most closely associated with its history.

title: TORY URGES G.O.P. IN MICHIGAN TO BE PATIENT
description: A member of the British Parliament's Conservative majority went to bat here Tuesday for a conservative Republican candidate for the United States Senate, urging patience and fortitude upon local Republicans who might have begun to worry about President Reagan's economic policies.

title: STAGE: ACTING COMPANY REVIVES 'THE COUNTRY WIFE'
description: THE Acting Company's production of ''The Country Wife'' at the American Place Theater begins deceptively with a macabre image, as if the director, Garland Wright, were preparing for a black mass. The lodgings of that notorious counterfeit castrato, Horner, have been seemingly decorated for a funeral. Horner himself is sleeping under a sheet on a coroner's table, and in the background there is a skeleton serving as a coat rack.

title: Brady Back Home
description: James S. Brady, the White House press secretary, was back home yesterday after spending 21 days in George Washington University Hospital for treatment of a blood clot in his left leg.

title: ARGENTINE PLANE IS REPORTED TO CIRCLE BRITISH FLEET
description: An Argentine Air Force reconnaissance plane circled Britain's powerful naval task force in the South Atlantic today, apparently pinpointing the size, speed and position of the flotilla, according to reports received from the fleet.

title: DANCE: JUDSON REVISITED WITH LIBERTIES TAKEN
description: STRICT historical accuracy was stretched a bit Sunday night at St. Mark's Church-in-the-Bowery. The program was part of the series of Judson Dance Theater Reconstructions. Yet, although the first dance event at the Judson Memorial Church was held in 1962, the concert included works from 1957 and 1960, and some of the works choreographed after 1962 did not receive their premieres at Judson.

title: ARGENTINA'S PRESIDENT TO FLY TO FALKLAND ISLANDS TODAY
description: President Leopoldo Galtieri will fly to the disputed Falkland Islands on Thursday, the Argentine Government announced today.

title: STYLISH PARK SEATING FOR A SPRING GARDEN
description: THE Italians have their paved city piazzas, the French their more formal plazas under a canopy of trees and the English their squares, small green gardens surrounded by town houses. All are public places in which to stroll or sit and enjoy the view. By the late 18th century, as cities expanded, many erstwhile private estates became municipal properties - vast parks with impressive vistas open to the public.

title: UNIONS AT THE DAILY NEWS STUDY SEPARATE PROPOSALS BY ALLBRITTON
description: Leaders of the 11 unions at The Daily News yesterday reviewed their separate offers from Joe L. Allbritton, the Texas financier who is trying to acquire the newspaper.

title: ROTELCOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
FUGITIVE BROKER SURRENDERS
description: Gary V. Lewellyn, a fugitive stockbroker charged with embezzlement and stock manipulation, surrendered here today, ending a three-week hunt by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Alfa Romeo Cites Gain
description: Alfa Romeo S.p.A. has achieved a 28.2 percent increase in productivity in the last few weeks, helped by a 13.7 percent cut in its work force, Ettore Massacesi, chairman, said today.

title: HUTTON, E F, GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Service to the Law
description: In his years as a lawyer and judge, David W. Peck apparently impressed a lot of people, enough anyway to light up the grand ballroom of the Pierre Hotel with glowing praise Tuesday night as he received the New York Legal Aid Society's Servant of Justice Award.

title: 'CREDITWATCH' IS POSTED ON STATE'S BONDS
description: Standard & Poor's Corporation, the bond rating service, today issued a ''Creditwatch'' on New York State securities. The watch is a warning to investors that the status of the bonds is uncertain.

title: New Publisher Named At Geo Magazine
description: To replace T. Swift Lockard, who has moved up to vice president and assistant to the chairman of Knapp Communications, Harry Myers is being brought in to be publisher of the struggling Geo magazine.

title: AUTHOR LOSES COURT RULING
description: A Federal judge has ruled that a corporation has a strong constitutional right under the First Amendment to criticize a book that was written about it.

title: HOOVER UNIVERSAL reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
WASTE MANAGEMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
TROOPS ACCUSED OF KILLING 48 IN SALVADORAN VILLAGE
description: Forty-eight members of an extended family that lived in this secluded hillside hamlet of mud huts were reportedly killed this week. According to villagers who said they had seen at least some of what happened, Salvadoran Government soldiers did the killing.

title: SOUTH AFRICA TIED TO ABORTIVE COUP
description: A former South African intelligence operative is reported to be disclosing to his captors in the Seychelles details of South African Government involvement in a bungled coup there in November.

title: Queen Beatrix Addresses A Session of Congress
description: Queen Beatrix of the Netherlands told a joint session of Congress today that nothing is more important to her people than an agreement on a ''balanced, controlled reduction of arms on all sides.''

title: VELO-BIND INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Includes investment spending as well as results of the first settlement from Minnesota Mining & Mfg Co as a result of a successful patent infringement litigation...C-Includes $213,000 tax credit

title: E.P.A. Said to Violate Dow Chemical's Rights
description: The Environmental Protection Agency violated constitutional protections against illegal search and seizure when it had aerial photographs taken of a Dow Chemical Company facility without a warrant, a Federal district judge has ruled.

title: TIR-CONTINENTAL CORP reports earnings for As of Mar 31
TO MAGAZINE FOUNDER, CAPITAL DOESN'T FUNCTION WELL
description: There are only two jobs in Government that Charles Peters would take: the Presidency of the United States or the top spot at the General Services Administration.

title: STANADYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
U.S. EXPECTS MANY CITIES TO JOIN TAX-BREAK PLAN
description: Samuel R. Pierce Jr., the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, predicted today that hundreds of cities would apply to have areas designated for a Federal program to relieve poverty and high unemployment. Under this program, businesses could obtain tax relief and take advantage of other incentives for investment.

title: RULE ON FUND RAISING BY SECTS IS OVERTURNED BY HIGH COURT
description: The Supreme Court ruled today, 5 to 4, that states cannot regulate fund raising by religious groups in ways that burden some groups more than others.

title: VIRGINIA ELECTRIC & POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
PHILADELPHIA URGED TO REJECT EVACUATION PLAN
description: About 40 speakers representing medical, educational, scientific and religious organizations told a sympathetic City Council committee today that it would be futile to spend money on a plan to evacuate residents in a nuclear attack.

title: State Rests Case In Buffalo Killings
description: The prosecution rested its case today in the trial of an Army private accused of killing three blacks in the Buffalo area in the fall of 1980.

title: Sports of The Times; Series Too Short
description: AS the New Jersey Nets' starting team was about to leave the bench Tuesday night for the opening tap in the mini-series playoff against the Washington Bullets, Coach Larry Brown stared at Buck Williams, the rookie forward.

title: METS TRIUMPH, 7-4; Five Runs in 8th Make Swan Victor
description: Craig Swan earned a 7-4 victory -his first since June 11, 1980 - over the Chicago Cubs last night with a one-inning relief appearance in a game that the Mets salvaged with a five-run eighth inning at Shea Stadium.

title: HANDCRAFTED MODERN FOLK ART
description: UNTIL four years ago Nancy Gardner Thomas was a secretary in a hospital. Then a friend encouraged Mrs. Thomas, a craftsman in Virginia, to make a small wooden bird.

title: ESSEX BANCORP (LYNN, MASS) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PAINTER OF ABSTRACTS OF ANDES CHILDHOOD
description: Maria Luisa Pacheco, a Bolivian-born painter who had lived in the United States since 1956, died of a brain tumor Wednesday night at her home in Manhattan. She was 62 years old.

title: FIRST MISSISSIPPI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,499,000 for the qr and $1,512,000 for the 9 mos...C-After a loss of $7,071,000 from discontinued operations

title: A PARADISE OF ORCHIDS BLOOMING IN THE BRONX
description: Thousands upon thousands of orchids are in bloom at the Enid A. Haupt Conservatory of the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx, ranging from about a 16th of an inch to nine inches across. They are orange, yellow, red, brown, white, purple, pink and many hues and tints in between and they are all part of ''Orchid Paradise in the Big Apple,'' an unusual show that is housed in the central showroom or Topiary House and three pavilions of the large conservatory.

title: COLORADO NATIONAL BANKSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The per share figures reflect a 15 percent stock dividend paid in February 1982

title: The Coal Parasites
description: Coal exports are good for America, generating billions in revenue. And they are good for our European allies, reducing dependence on Mideast oil and Soviet natural gas. The future of coal exports now seems so bright that American ports and railroads are gearing up to double the trade over the next decade. Enter the parasites.

title: SCHLUMBERGER LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CLEVELAND-CLIFFS IRON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-After a writedown of $2.9 million for holdings of common and preferred stock of McLough Steel Corp and certain McLouth obligations...C-Net income

title: SOUTH GEORGIA: FORBIDDING BATTLEFIELD
description: The island of South Georgia, where the Argentine takeover of the Falklands began, has become the focus of speculation as the place where the British effort to recapture the islands may also begin.

title: LINKAGE CAPTURES BLUE GRASS
description: Linkage took a giant step into the Kentucky Derby picture today with a dazzling 5 1/2-length victory in the $195,285 Blue Grass Stakes at Keeneland Race Course. But now the question is whether his trainer, Henry Clark, will allow the colt to run in the May 1 race at Churchill Downs.

title: CHROMALLOY AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-After a loss of $2,890,000 from discontinued operations

title: 'Medea' a Family Affair
description: The Broadway revival of ''Medea,'' which begins previews at the Cort Theater on Tuesday, will be very much a ''togetherness'' affair. Four married couples are involved in the production.

title: A SPORTSWEAR COLLECTION WITH A NEW DESIGN
description: It is becoming increasingly apparent as the fall fashion openings reach their midway mark that a mastery of tailoring is a designer's biggest asset. A little imagination and an eye for color are, of course, also useful. But as clothes come in closer to the body and lose their free-flowing, formless look, it is absolutely necessary to understand the nuances of cut and construction so they do not look as if they were made of cardboard or, worse yet, cast iron.

title: BRITISH AIDES' COMMENTS CAUSE WIDE PUZZLEMENT
description: Seemingly contradictory comments by ranking officials have created widespread puzzlement here and abroad about Britain's strategy in the Falkland Islands dispute.

title: BONN PARTY SHUNS CALL FOR A-FREEZE
description: The Social Democratic Party, meeting in a national convention, rejected a call today for an immediate nuclear moratorium with the specific intention of halting preparations for the deployment of American medium-range nuclear missiles in Western Europe.

title: I.T.T. Fights Bell On Rate Request
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation said it had asked the Federal Communications Commission to deny American Telephone and Telegraph Company's request to double charges for connecting non-Bell long-distance telephone service to local Bell operating companies.

title: LEAKS AT GRAND CENTRAL SHUT AREA NEAR LOCKERS
description: Falling plaster and dripping water, which commuters using Grand Central Terminal have had to dodge, forced the closing yesterday of a waiting area and the terminal's only locker room.

title: ACCEPTANCE OF SURTAX IS HINTED
description: Without committing President Reagan, Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan hinted broadly today that the Administration would accept a temporary surtax on upper-income taxpayers as part of a budget compromise with Congress.

title: FIRES ENGULF 5,000 ACRES IN THE JERSEY PINELANDS
description: Three forest fires broke out in southern New Jersey yesterday afternoon, engulfing more than 5,000 acres of pinelands in flames, officials said.

title: CANADIANS WARMLY WELCOME FRENCH PREMIER
description: The French Prime Minister arrived here today for a six-day official visit that is expected to widen France's interest in Canada beyond Quebec.

title: MEXICO TO CUT OIL EXPORTS
description: Mexico City, April 22 (AP) - Mexico, reacting to the glut of oil on world markets, said today that it would cut oil exports by 250,000 barrels, to 1.25 million barrels a day.

title: STANDARD OIL CO (INDIANA) reports earnings for Qtr to March31
RATES MIXED IN UNCERTAINTY
description: Interest rates were mixed yesterday, and market participants said uncertainty about the course of the economy and private credit demands, the size of Federal budget deficits and monetary policy were keeping rates from moving much from current levels.

title: MILTON BRADLEY CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A WORKABLE ALLIANCE: DEVELOPMENT AND PRESERVATION
description: In Greenwich Village the Federal Archives Building, a huge and splendid example of the 19th-century Romanesque revival style, is being developed into a mixed-use structure combining space for retail shops, offices of community groups and 354 cooperative apartments.

title: Wrong Valve Opened Days Before Rig Deaths
description: Nine days before the world's largest oil rig, the Ocean Ranger, sank in a storm, killing all 84 crew members, the drilling rig's captain accidentally opened the wrong valve and caused the platform to tilt, a drilling foreman testified today.

title: BRALORNE RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
TELECO OILFIELD SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: B-Includes $374,000 tax credit and share earnings reflect 2-for-1 stock split in April 1981

title: SCHOOLS' LOWLY SUBS To the Editor:$
description: Gene Maeroff's news article in The New York Times of April 13, ''Urban Schools Short of Substitute Teachers,'' came as no surprise to me. And the shortage he described applies to suburban as well as urban schools.

title: The Economy
description: Donald T. Regan hinted at possible acceptance of a surtax on upperincome taxpayers as part of a budget compromise. But the Treasury Secretary worded his statement carefully, and did not say that President Reagan agreed with the idea. (Page D1.) Budget negotiators took a new tack: setting only basic targets for spending and taxes for the coming fiscal year, and leaving the politically difficult details to Congress. (A1.)

title: UNION ADVISERS INVITED TO POLISH TALKS
description: Nine advisers and lawyers for the Solidarity union who are not in detention have been invited to join in an officially sponsored conference Friday and Saturday on ''the future of the trade union movement'' in Poland.

title: AUCTION SET FOR MOTEL WHERE DR. KING DIED
description: The Lorraine Motel, where the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated on April 4, 1968, will be put up for auction at noon next Tuesday if a loan payment cannot be met.

title: BANCORP OF PENNSYLVANIA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Denmark Will Open a Center In '83 for Victims of Torture
description: The Danish chapter of Amnesty International, the human-rights group, said today that Denmark will open the first international rehabilitation center for torture victims.

title: Rabbi Perilman Commemorating Ordination
description: ''The crowds are overwhelming,'' the visitor from North Carolina was saying in New York City yesterday, but not, he acknowledged, entirely unfamiliar.

title: DELTA AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
STANDARD OF INDIANA GAINS 24.7%
description: The Standard Oil Company (Indiana), the nation's-fifth largest oil concern, said yesterday that its net income for the first quarter rose by 24.7 percent while the Standard Oil Company (Ohio), ranked No.14, said its profit for the quarter fell by nearly 13 percent. The two were the first of the big oil companies to report results for the period.

title: PHOENIX STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: B-Includes $365,000 extraordinary gain; C-Net loss
