MOTOROLA INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BRIEFS
description: * American Can Co. said it had entered into an pact with United Coconut Planters Bank of the Philippines to form United Philippine Can Co.

title: OAKITE PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Latest quarter results include Epic Chemicals Inc which was acquired in January

title: The U.N. Today; April 23, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets on Palestinian question at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: MEDGAR EVERS COLLEGE PROTEST GROWS
description: The takeover by students of the office of the president at Medgar Evers College in Brooklyn this week was the culmination of weeks of protest. Students and faculty members say it is symptomatic of larger problems that have wedged a wall of animosity between many of them and the president.

title: FALKLANDS: 'I ATTACK, YOU CAN NEGOTIATE'
description: To the Editor:

title: Allen Quits Alouettes
description: After only three months as president and chief operating officer of the Montreal Alouettes, George Allen resigned yesterday, saying that the uncertain financial condition of the club made it impossible for him and a group of other investors to exercise their option to purchase it. ''On Feb. 16, 1982,'' Allen said, reading from a prepared statement, ''I entered into an option agreement with Nelson Skalbania to buy the Alouettes.

title: Shell Canada Ends Tie With Nova
description: Shell Canada and Nova, an Alberta corporation, said yesterday that they will end their plans for joint ownership of several projects planned or under construction in Alberta.

title: THE BOOM IN ARTHRITIS DRUGS
description: Ever since Indocin, the first modern prescription drug for arthritis, was introduced in 1965 by Merck & Company, there always seems to have been room for new entrants.

title: 'SEE WHAT I HEAR'
description: ''IF You Could See What I Hear'' is an interesting movie to hear about, even if it isn't so very interesting to watch. It's the story of Tom Sullivan, a blind young man whose handicap, if the film is to be believed, is as important a source of practical jokes for him as it is a source of trouble. Twice during the course of the film, we watch Tom drive a car filled with some of his most trusting and good-natured buddies. When the police nab him for this, he simply explains that he's blind, and everybody has a good laugh. Laughs like this abound in ''If You Could See What I Hear,'' which opens today at the RKO National Twin and other theaters,

title: SMITH INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March31
ST REGIS PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PUBLISHING: AFTER 60 YEARS, DAUBER & PINE IS LOSING ITS PINE
description: AFTER 77 years as a bookseller, 90-year-old Nathan S. Pine, a New York institution, has called it quits. ''I thought I'd walk out of the store before I'm carried out,'' he said in his rich, vibrant voice. ''Besides, it's about time to find out who and what I am.''

title: EXPERT SAYS SOVIET MAY LOFT LASER GUN BUT DOUBTS EFFECT
description: The chief of Air Force research and development said today that the Soviet Union could launch a laser antisatellite weapon in the next five years but contended that it would be ''ineffective'' except as a political and propaganda weapon.

title: ARIZONA PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
CROSS, A T, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
MILWAUKEE FIGHTS TO END RAT INFESTATION
description: The yard behind Ina Fisher's red and white house is fenced and kept neatly trimmed and spotless. But the houses and yards next door, and the alley behind her home, are filled with the litter and refuse on which rats thrive.

title: NATIONAL CAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
G.& W. Stake In Hammermill
description: Gulf and Western Industries said that it now owned 588,000 shares, or 7.1 percent, of the Hammermill Paper Company. In filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, G.& W. said that the total included 113,400 shares acquired on the open market betwen Feb.23 and April 14 for about $2.9 million, financed by general corporate funds.

title: MEM CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SPS TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Weekender Guide; Friday; TOTEM POLES ON 73D ST.
description: All forms of life - humans, birds, insects - are equal yet unique parts of a balanced and beautiful universe. That is the belief reflected in American Indian totems and effigies on exhibit today through May 29 at ACA American Indian Arts, 25 East 73d Street. Among the objects are totem poles and ceremonial masks from the Northwest Coast, a Zuni fetish of a buffalo carved almost 600 years ago, Navajo rugs depicting supernatural beings and bowls dating from the year 1000 decorated with whimsically stylized humans and animals. A free slide lecture comparing symbols and totems in European and American art will be offered at noon and 5:30 P.M. today by Dr. Robert W. Venables, a curator at the Museum of the American Indian. Admission is free. BRECHT'S 'EDWARD II' ON 86TH ST.

title: MISSOURI PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Money Fund Assets Drop
description: Assets of the nation's 190 money market funds declined for the second consecutive week, dropping $483 million in the week ended Wednesday, to $191.8 billion, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN OFFERS HIMSELF IN DEAL FOR 'COLOREDS'
description: The Rev. Allan Hendrickse is prepared to serve as the thin edge of the wedge for racial and constitutional changes in South Africa: provided, that is, Prime Minister P.W. Botha finally offers people of mixed race, known here as coloreds, a political deal that is at least halfway plausible.

title: FRACAS: WHITE HOUSE AND PACKWOOD
description: The Republicans are brawling like Democrats these days, or, perhaps, like characters in a Saturday morning movie serial. Whatever their role model, the continuing battle between Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon, chairman of the Republicans' Senate Campaign Committee, and various aides, allies and defenders of President Reagan is growing more intense and providing the capital with a lively spectacle.

title: AAV COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Polaroid Off 80% in Quarter
description: The Polaroid Corporation, which last fall announced a large reduction in its work force to cut costs, reported yesterday that earnings fell 80 percent for the quarter ending March 31.

title: Lloyd's and Argentina
description: Lloyd's of London, the international insurance concern, has severed all insurance business with Argentina, a Lloyd's spokesman said today. David Larner said Lloyd's underwriters stopped writing insurance for Argentine companies on April 3.

title: CHICAGO & NORTHWESTERN TRANSPORTATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 3
description: B-Including a pretax gain of $17 million from the sale of a Chicago passenger terminal...C-Net income

title: Official Says Nostalgia For Detente Hurts U.S.
description: The Reagan Administration considers detente to be dead, but ''nostalgia'' for that policy of relaxation with the Soviet Union lingers and is harming the allied defense effort, a Pentagon official said today.

title: Gunman Gets $75,000 From 34 in Restaurant
description: A gunman entered the Amalfi Restaurant at 16 East 48th Street last night, announced a holdup and took $75,000 in cash and jewels from 33 customers and the restaurant's manager, the police said.

title: INTERTHERM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Results for the latest first qr include a gain equal to 2 cents a shr from foreign currency translations

title: Prafulla Mukherji, 97; Research Metallurgist
description: Prafulla C. Mukherji, a retired research metallurgist and a leader in Indian intellectual and political affairs in the United States for several decades, died Wednesday at Brookdale Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 97 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: BRINK'S CASE DEFENDANT SAYS HE WAS BEATEN IN JAIL
description: A defendant in the Oct. 20 Brink's robbery testified yesterday that he had been repeatedly beaten at the Rockland County Jail after his arrest.

title: DANCE: BALLET THEATER IN ASHTON'S 'RENDEZVOUS'
description: ONE of the most valuable acquisitions that the American Ballet Theater's artistic director, Mikhail Baryshnikov, made for the repertory last year was Sir Frederick Ashton's early ballet, ''Les Rendezvous.''

title: Walker of Nets Hopes to Play
description: At 5 feet 10 inches and a sturdy 172 pounds, Clarence (Foots) Walker, the valuable point guard of the Nets, is not especially equipped to be a gifted rebounder. In fact, he averaged less than two rebounds a game this season.

title: STANDARD MICROSYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
NUCLEAR ARMS PROTESTS GROW IN USUALLY PRO-MILITARY SOUTH
description: In a region long recognized as conservative, intensely patriotic and pro-military, Jesuits and Junior Leaguers, pediatricians and politicians, scientists, soldiers and students are beginning to emerge in a broad-based and growing movement against the use or buildup of nuclear weapons.

title: Pop Jazz; MCLAUGHLIN AT CARNEGIE: JAZZ AND CLASSICS MEET
description: ''THERE may be a crisis in the music business,'' the guitarist John McLaughlin said when he arrived in New York the other day to prepare for his concert at Carnegie Hall tonight, ''but there's no crisis in music.''

title: Auctions
description: AMERICANA sales continue this weekend and next week at Sotheby Parke Bernet's galleries with American Indian art, folk art and manuscript and printed materials.

title: U.N. DRIVE OPENS TO EXPEL ISRAELIS
description: Radical Arab nations and the Palestine Liberation Organization have begun their most determined effort so far to expel Israel from the General Assembly.

title: Francis Seeks Return
description: Russ Francis, the former all-pro tight end who retired from the New England Patriots last year, has reportedly had second thoughts. Newspaper accounts in Boston say that Francis wants to play again but also wants to pursue a career as an actor and has therefore asked the Patriots, who retain rights to him, to trade him to a team on the West Coast.

title: GENERAL HOST CORP reports earnings for 12 weeks to Mar 20
TWO ENCOUNTER RADIATION
description: Two workers were slightly contaminated today by airborne radiation detected on the third floor of the Duane Arnold nuclear power plant near here, company officials said. Horace Webb, vice president for corporate affairs at the Iowa Electric Light and Power Company, said non of the radiation escaped outside. The workers were not identified.

title: OLIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Gretzky Scores Twice As Canada Tops U.S.
description: Wayne Gretzky scored two goals and set up two others today, helping Team Canada to a 5-3 victory over the United States at the world hockey championships. The loss relegated the Americans to the B pool in the tournament.

title: NORTHWEST BANKCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
U.S. Requests More Aid For Morocco and Tunisia
description: The Reagan Administration asked Congress today for sharply increased military aid for Morocco and Tunisia, nations that it described as ''strategically located countries facing threats in a volatile part of the world.''

title: STANDARD MOTOR PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
OMARK INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
THE U.S. HANDICAP IN GLOBAL BUSINESS
description: To the Editor:

title: CLOW CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
by Nic E. Wiehahn
description: Before 1979, South Africa's labor legislation and practices portrayed, among other features, two negative characteristics: discrimination on the basis of race, color, and sex; and, paternalism. After 1979, thing began to change.

title: TIGERS DEFEAT YANKEES AND JOHN
description: Tommy John's record is not too healthy, but he is, and that's more than many of his teammates can say. John pitched well last night for the second time in three starts, but he suffered his third loss as the Detroit Tigers trimmed the Yankees, 3-1, for their sixth consecutive victory. Jack Morris, who beat John in his ineffective outing last Saturday, held the Yankees to six hits, only one after the fourth inning. Chet Lemon hit a tworun homer in the third inning.

title: Weber Skis 109 M.P.H.
description: Austria's Franz Weber zipped down Velocity Peak at 109 miles an hour today during the first day of eliminations at the 1982 Camel International Speed Skiing Championships. Weber, who has won here the last two years, finished his second run one m.p.h. faster than Paul Buschmann of Tahoe City, Calif. Steve McKinney of Olympic Village, Calif., the world recordholder at 125.77 m.p.h., was third at 107 m.p.h.

title: TEXTRON INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: B-Includes $300,000 gain from discontinued operations

title: STANDARD REGISTER CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results for 1981 restated to reflect a change in accounting for vacations

title: CEMETERY UNION CALLS STRIKE AT 12 SITES IN NEW YORK AREA
description: Four hundred gravediggers and groundskeepers went on strike yesterday at 12 nonsectarian cemeteries in the metropolitan area. Sam Cimaglia, president of Local 365 of the Service Employees International Union, said it was a selective strike that would affect only about 60 burials a day. But he warned that the walkout might be expanded next week to Jewish and Catholic cemeteries if a mediation session scheduled for next Monday failed to ease the deadlock.

title: Coffee Makers Reduce Prices
description: The nation's major coffee producers have cut their wholesale prices as much as 10 cents a pound, effective immediately. But it will take two months for lower consumer prices to show up at supermarkets.

title: LIMAN PANEL'S SENSIBLE REMEDIES FOR PRISON OVERCROWDING
description: To the Editor:

title: BOTTLE BILL WALK ENDS WITH RALLY IN ALBANY
description: Two columns of tired but exuberant marchers converged here today to proclaim the virtues of a 5-cent deposit on bottles and cans sold in New York State.

title: GAF CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Including a tax credit of $1.1 million and a gain of $5.3 million from discontinued operations which includes a reversal of $7.1 million reserve less a related $2.7 million tax credit for royalties established in 1977 that are no longer required as a result of the recent dismissal of a pending Eastman Kodak patent suit against GAF...C-Including a gain of $761,000 from discontinued operations

title: EMHART CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-After a foreign currency translation loss of $22.7 million; yr-ago results have been restated to reflect the adoption of an accounting change for foreign currency translations

title: REDS WIN AND END BRAVES' STREAK AT 13
description: Atlanta's record streak at the start of the season came to an end after 13 victories when the Reds beat the Braves, 2-1, tonight. Bruce Berenyi and Tom Hume of Cincinnati combined to stop Atlanta on six hits.

title: GULFSTREAM BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Carson Contests Charge
description: The day after he was arrested last February and charged with driving while under the influence of alcohol, Johnny Carson sounded apologetic when he recounted the arrest on his television show.

title: GOULD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Including a gain from discontinued operations of $4.3 million; sales for the latest first qr include $14.5 million from the company's French battery subsidiary previously accounted for under the equity method; yr-ago results have been restated to include operations of American Microsystems Inc, acquired in Feb 1982 corrected from Wednesday's editions

title: GULF CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
MISS CULLINANE WINS CLOSE 3,000 METERS
description: Sande Cullinane of Falmouth, Mass., and Suzanne Girard of Johnson City, N.Y., are 19-year-old sophomores at North Carolina State, good friends on and off the track. Today, the friends became very close rivals in the college women's 3,000-meter run in the 88th annual Penn Relays.

title: MONTANA-DAKOTA UTILITIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PRESTON TRUCKING CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
In the Nation; REPEATING THE PAST; by Tom Wicker
description: Sometimes this seems to be an Administration without a memory, fated to repeat a past of which it's unaware. In his ''new federalism'' proposals, for instance, President Reagan apparently did not grasp the historical fact that many of the programs he wanted to turn back to the states had been developed at the Federal level precisely because the states could or would not take on such tasks.

title: CURTICE-BURNS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 26
Ogilvy & Mather Unit Gets Chemlawn Billing
description: Ogilvy & Mather Direct Response, the Ogilvy & Mather International subsidiary with 25 offices worldwide, has just landed the account of the Chemlawn Corporation, Columbus, Ohio, whose $9 million in current billings makes it the biggest account ever landed by the five-year-old agency.

title: MEI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MASCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
DONNELLEY, R R, & SONS reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
MACMILLAN BLOEDEL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
DYCO PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Mail by Wire To Continue
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia has refused to stop the Postal Service's new electronic mail service, E-COM, which began operations last Jan. 4.

title: CULBRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Including a tax credit of $1,856,000...C-Including a gain of $54,527,000 on the sale of proprietary medicine business

title: COMSHARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Net loss after a loss of $2,204,400 from idscontinued operations...C-After a loss of $2,441,400 from discontinued operations

CONSOLIDATED FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 27
SPECTRADYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: 1981 share earnings and shares outstanding restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in July 1981

title: A CHEKHOVIAN IDYLL
description: AMONG the leisurely pleasures of Nikita Mikhalkov's ''An Unfinished Piece for Player Piano'' are the ensemble acting of an excellent cast and the extraordinarily enterprising approach taken by this pre-eminent Soviet director. The film, only very loosely based on the early Chekhov play ''Platonov,'' is perhaps even closer to Chekhov than Chekhov was. Mr. Mikhalkov, who is also the director of ''A Slave of Love'' and ''Oblomov,'' uses this as an opportunity to capture, even embroider, the spirit of a Chekhov story. He succeeds to a remarkable degree.

title: MIDCON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''I will not disguise from you that there are real difficulties and real obstacles.'' - Francis Pym, British Foreign Secretary, discussing Falklands crisis. (A1:4.)

title: SOUTH JERSEY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
G.M. BACKS DOWN ON EXECUTIVE BONUS
description: The General Motors Corporation, bowing to an angry protest from the United Automobile Workers, has agreed not to pay its executives the bonuses they might qualify for under a proposal made by the company late last week.

title: CABOT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
61 East Germans Fled in '81
description: Sixty-one people fled across the fortified East German border to West Germany last year, 10 more than in 1980, a West German report said today. The annual border police report said that 193 more East Germans had reported to West German border authorities and had asked to stay in the West. It said that 45 people had crossed the border from west to east but that most of them were mentally disturbed or drunk.

title:
Decision File;
Smugglers Endanger Sky Over Florida
description: The airspace over South Florida is cut up by so many dare-devil pilots smuggling drugs into this country that the Federal Aviation Administration says the Florida sky now poses a safety hazard for legitimate private planes.

title: Judge Backs Thrift Unit Dissidents
description: Votes cast on Monday by a dissident shareholder group seeking control of Financial Federation Inc., the nation's 25th largest savings and loan organization, will temporarily be allowed to stand, a Federal judge ruled today.

title: Neeskens and Durgan To Miss Chicago Game
description: Johan Neeskens and Jeff Durgan will not play against the Sting in Chicago Saturday, Coach Julio Mazzei said today.

title: VOLCKER URGES CUT IN DEFICIT
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, yesterday renewed his call for sizable reductions in the projected Federal budget deficits beginning in the fiscal year 1983. To be adequate, he said, the reductions would have to exceed $100 billion a year.

title: DOW CORNING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
PRIME COMPUTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Robert W. Lundeen, 60 years old, has been named chairman of the Dow Chemical Company, effective in July. He will succeed Earle B. Barnes, who will retire from the Midland, Mich., corporation at the mandatory retirement age of 65. Paul F. Oreffice, 54, continues as president and chief executive officer, a post he has held since 1978.

title: Bonn Aide Offers to Quit
description: Hans Matthofer, West Germany's Minister of Finance and a key aide to Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, has offered his resignation for reasons of health, a source close to both men disclosed today. But Mr. Matthofer reportedly told Mr. Schmidt that he would stay on at the Chancellor's insistence.

title: Sports of The Times; Cam Connor Takes a Giant Step
description: WHEN the New York Giants were catching the Brooklyn Dodgers late in the 1951 baseball season, the Giants made a show of standing around the batting cage and smiling a lot at the Dodgers, just to make the point that they were alive and well and living at Coogan's Bluff.

title: FEDERAL-MOGUL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
COMMONWEALTH EDISON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
FARMER BROS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Stock-Index Futures Suit
description: The Commodity Exchange in New York said yesterday that, despite a lawsuit by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, it would begin trading Comex 500 stock-index futures as soon as it receives approval from the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

title: Japan to Allow Marines To Return to Iwo Jima
description: The Japanese Government overruled local objections today and decided to allow military maneuvers by 800 United States marines on Iwo Jima, scene of a World War II battle in which more than 25,000 troops were slain, official sources said.

title: African Nations Discuss Crisis Within O.A.U.
description: A special three-day meeting of the Organization of African Unity convened here today with a warning by President Daniel arap Moi of Kenya that the O.A.U. was drifting apart because of the admission of a guerrilla movement.

title: SUN CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: B-After $776,000 loss from discontinued operations

title: Turnaround Expert To Be Saxon Head
description: William J. Scharffenberger, fresh from serving as president of the Continental Steel Corporation until it emerged last month from reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, has now been named president of Saxon Industries, which filed for Chapter 11 last Thursday.

title: BRADY, AS SENATOR, TO USE TALENTS AS BUSINESSMAN
description: Nicholas F. Brady accepted the rare invitation to become a United States Senator from New Jersey after persuading himself that he could do as well in politics as he has done on Wall Street.

title: Give the Gun Law a Fair Test
description: ''You'll go to jail for one year. No plea bargaining,'' Mayor Koch warned two years ago in publicizing New York's new handgun law. But today only about half of those convicted of carrying loaded unlicensed guns in New York City go to jail for the supposedly mandatory year.

title: SCHLUMBERGER UP 30.7% IN 1st PERIOD
description: Schlumberger Ltd. reported yesterday that strong gains by its oilfield services group caused net income in the first quarter of 1982 to soar 30.7 percent, while sales increased 13.1 percent.

title: ASSOCIATED COCA-COLA BOTTLING CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-After a charge of $503,000 from an accounting change

title: CBS UNIT OFFERS $58 MILLION FOR MAKER OF RUBIK'S CUBE
description: The Ideal Toy Corporation, one of the industry's most profitable companies last year on the strength of its popular Rubik's Cube, announced yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by the toy division of CBS Inc. in a transaction valued at about $58 million.

title: SUMITOMO BANK OF CALIFORNIA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CONSUMERS POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
TIGER INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: B-Net income which excludes extraordinary gains of $9.4 million from the sale of a Boeing 747 and Tiger's mortgage insurance subsidiary

title: TAX DEAL TO KEEP THE GARDEN OPEN
description: Madison Square Garden will remain open, with $1 million more in tax abatements than had been discussed during long negotiations, New York City officials said yesterday.

description: B-Includes $6,229,000 extraordinary credit from an accounting change

title: COWLES COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
ENTEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
DRUMS, SPEAKERS AND A 'DIE-IN' TELL NEW YORKERS OF NUCLEAR ARMS PERIL
description: With guitar, saxophone, tambourines and drums providing a compelling beat, the singers belted out their message: ''If you love your baby, if you love your friend, you know this arms race has got to end.''

title: St. Regis Off 61%
description: The St. Regis Paper Company reported yesterday that profit in the first quarter was down 61 percent to $19.4 milllion, or 56 cents a share, from $49.8 million, or $1.44 a share, in the period a year before. St. Regis, a manufacturer of forest products, said sales fell 9.8 percent to $672.2 million from $745.3 million.

title: REEVES BROS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 3
DeLorean Acts to Free Its Inventory
description: The DeLorean Motor Company said yesterday that new financial arrangements had been completed to free its United States inventory of automobiles, frozen since March by its largest creditor, the Bank of America.

title: SIMMONDS PRECISION PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MIO STAYS CALM AND SAVES THE RANGERS
description: Ed Mio, whose goaltending insured the Rangers' survival playoff victory over the Islanders, said today that he expected to be calm Friday night in the sixth game of the series at Madison Square Garden.

title: JACOBS ENGINEERING GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
HAIG SAID TO ASSERT CASTRO IS ANGUISHING ON OFFER FROM U.S.
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. was reported tonight to have told a group of Massachusetts businessmen that Fidel Castro was ''anguishing'' over an offer by the United States that would cause the Cuban leader to sever his links with the Soviet Union and ally Havana with the West.

title: SIMON, NORTON, INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: B-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $18,553,000 for the quarter and $21,234,000 for the 9 months; C-After $1,241,000 loss from discontinued operations for the 9 months

title: Essay; IS CASTRO CONVERTIBLE?; by William Safire
description: The C.I.A. has come up with an exciting modern method of briefing President Reagan about foreign leaders: the motion picture. Before a visit to the U.S. by Israel's Menachem Begin, the C.I.A. produced a psychological profile in the form of a film documentary for the President's top-secret viewing that was the pride of the agency's film division.

title: P.L.O. SAID TO BAR REPRISAL FOR RAID
description: Yasir Arafat, the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, has decided for the time being not to retaliate for Israel's air strikes on Wednesday against guerrilla positions in Lebanon, according to P.L.O. officials.

title: PHELPS DODGE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mach 31
description: B-Net income including $4.1 million dividend from Southern Peru Cooper Corp

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: BEVERLY Sills was comparing notes with Albert Hudes on their f avorite tear-jerkers. ''La Boheme,'' said Mr. Hudes, who is directoro f development for the New York City Opera. ''I feel cheated if I d on't cry on cue. The cue for me is in the third act when Mimi says s he's leaving Rodolfo.''

title: BRIEFING
description: 'Women Prefer Democrats'

title: DELTA AIR HAS FIRST LOSS IN A QUARTER SINCE 1957
description: Delta Air Lines reported yesterday that it had a loss of $18.4 million for its third fiscal quarter, ended March 31, the first quarterly loss for the airline since 1957.

title: Discussions At Braniff Continue
description: Braniff International, which had hoped to consummate a deal by this weekend to lease its South American air routes for urgently needed additional cash, said yesterday that ''we will do our best to continue to fly'' while negotiations continue.

title: MARYLAND MAY OVERTURN A SUBURBAN BOARD ON SHIFTING OF STUDENTS
description: The school board in Montgomery County, Md., was told today that its plan to close a number of predominantly nonwhite schools and alter the attendance boundaries of others was ''unreasonable and arbitrary'' and unfair to nonwhite children.

title: Submarine Saves Refugees
description: A United States submarine, the Indianapolis, has rescued a boatload of Vietnamese refugees in the Gulf of Siam, the United States Embassy here said today. An embassy spokesman said that the submarine came upon about 30 refugees in a small craft Wednesday and took them to the Thai port of Sattahip. The submarine had been on its way to a port call at the beach resort of Pattaya in Thailand.

title: PACIFIC RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Eastern Pilots Accept Pact
description: Eastern Airlines pilots have accepted a twoyear contract that calls for a one-year wage freeze and continues their participation in a wage contribution plan for five years.

title: HOMESTAKE MINING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
CHAMPION PARTS REBUILDERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Metropolitan Baedeker; MONTCLAIR, FOR ANTIQUES IN A HISTORICAL SETTING
description: WHEN you come to see the Vernon ''Mona Lisa'' at the Montclair Art Museum in New Jersey, make plans to stay awhile; Montclair is a town of quiet pleasures.

title: SMITHKLINE BECKMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: 1981 results have been restated for a merger with Beckman Instruments Inc accounted for under a pooling of interest method

title: BREZHNEV AT RALLY, SCOTCHING 4 WEEKS OF MYSTERY AND RUMOR
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev appeared at a nationally televised Kremlin rally today, ending a four-week absence from public view during which Moscow was swept by unconfirmed reports that he had been hospitalized.

title: Goodrich Pay Cuts
description: Some 2,000 workers at a B.F. Goodrich Company plant in Akron will be asked to accept a pay cut to $11.41 an hour in exchange for guarantees that the plant will stay open for three years, Goodrich and the United Rubber Workers said.

title: by F. Andy Messing Jr.
description: In Washington, hundreds of defense experts have been spending countless hours debating how to use defense dollars to rejuvenate our conventional and nuclear forces. While this thinking is necessary to develop a proper mixture of deterrent powers, a crucial element is missing from our formula but not from Soviet strategy - the ability to conduct efficient irregular warfare. By irregular warfare, I mean unconventional warfare, limited conventional military actions and reactions, and anti-terrorism.

title: MEANS SERVICE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Includes a capital gain equal to about 8 cents a shr from the sale of some routes in Ohio and a charge equal to 12 cents a shr from the impact of stock appreciation rights

title: Premieres on 67th St.
description: The Canticum Novum Singers will offer two world premieres in a program of 20th-century American music tomorrow night at 8:30 at Abraham Goodman House, 129 West 67th Street.

title: WHEN AIRLINES FAIL IN THE FREE MARKET
description: To the Editor:

title: HEALTH GOODS PLANTIFFS WIN
description: Grand Rapids, Mich., April 22 (AP) - The American Hospital Supply Corporation of Evanston, Ill., the nation's largest manufacturer and distributor of health care products, tried to monopolize the market for medical and surgical supplies, a Federal judge ruled today.

title: Market Place; Disappointing Cooper Profits
description: COOPER INDUSTRIES, which is both a machinery and oil services company, has traditionally traded at the relatively low share prices accorded machinery companies.

title: NATIONAL EDUCATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Dataproducts President Will Also Become Chief
description: Charles A. Dickinson, the 58-year-old president of the Dataproducts Corporation, a major manufacturer of computer printers, has been elected to the additional post of chief executive officer. He succeeds Graham Tyson, 59, who will continue as chairman of the company, which has headquarters in Woodland Hills, Calif.

title: KEYSTONE CONSOLIDATED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-After a loss of $568,000 for the qr on the devaluation of the Mexican peso and an extraordinary creidt of $1,342,000 for the 9 mos...C-Net income

title: ISRAEL BULLDOZES HOMES AS PROTESTERS SING ANTHEM
description: In a combined operation involving troops and firemen, Israeli forces this morning overpowered the main center of resistance to the evacuation of the Sinai town of Yamit.

title: JOHNSON CONTROLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
2 Die in Illinois Tank Blast
description: An oil storage tank at the Tri-Central Marine Terminal exploded today, killing two welders and injuring another worker. The explosion, near a ship canal west of Chicago, tore a hole in the roof of the tank and touched off a fire that threatened other tanks at the terminal, some of which contained highly flammable naphtha, sheriff's police said. The fire was quickly brought under control, a police spokesman said.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, APRIL 23, 1982
description: International Salvadoran rightists took control of the new Constituent Assembly, blocking the centrist Christian Democrats from all key legislative posts. The right-wing coalition elected Roberto d'Aubuisson, head of an ultra-rightist party, to be president of the assembly, and elected right-wing candidates to the nine other leadership positions. The action followed reports that a coalition of the centrists and a conservative party, backed by the military, planned to name a moderate as provisional President. (Page A1, Col. 6.) U.S.-British talks on the Falklands were held for four hours in Washington. Foreign Secretary Francis Pym said that he and Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. had made ''a useful start'' in discussing the latest ideas for resolving the British-Argentine dispute. There was surprisingly little sense of crisis surrounding the meeting even though the British flotilla was believed to be only a few days away from the islands. (A1:4.)

title: Allegheny Up by 59.9%
description: Allegheny International, a diversified manufacturer of speciality metals and consumer products, reported today that earnings for the first quarter increased 59.9 percent, to $31.5 million, or $1.87 a share, from $19.7 million, or $2.13 a share, in the 1981 first quarter. During the period the average number of shares increased to 10.8 million from 7.4 million.

title: ALLEGHANY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Including an extraordinary gain of $5 million

title: JUDGE MAY PERMIT HINCKLEY TRIAL VIDEOTAPE
description: Federal District Judge Barrington D. Parker said at a hearing today that he would probably allow the prosecution at John W. Hinckley Jr.'s upcoming trial on charges of shooting President Reagan and three other men to show television videotapes of the shootings.

title: Economic Scene; The Economy As Theater
description: THE lines separating politics, economics and theater have become increasingly blurred in the Reagan era. Since Washington has borrowed so liberally (and conservatively) from Hollywood, turnabout would be fair exchange. Here are a few scripts that might appeal to the movie industry: 'Dead in the Water'

title: STAGE: AT ROUNDABOUT, 'THE BROWNING VERSION'
description: THE once-tattered reputation of Terence Rattigan has risen so steadily, both in London and New York, since his death in 1977 that critics are no longer needed to plead his cause. As it's now clear, Rattigan's best plays are his best defense - they're almost foolproof. Last season, the Roundabout Stage Two proved this conclusively with its bristling revival of ''The Winslow Boy.'' Last night, the case was made again at the same theater with a generally excellent staging of an even better Rattigan play, ''The Browning Version.''

title: HONDA ENDS OPPOSITION TO AUTO UNION'S EFFORTS
description: The Honda Motor Company, the first Japanese company scheduled to open an auto manufacturing plant in the United States, will no longer resist organizing efforts by the United Automobile Workers, industry sources said.

title: News Analysis
description: By publicly raising objections to the CBS News documentary ''People Like Us,'' the Reagan Administration has highlighted again a continuing controversy over the ''fairness doctrine,'' the rule that has required broadcasters to provide a reasonable amount of time for opposing viewpoints on important issues, as a condition of being licensed to use the public airwaves. The irony of the Administration's position is that the Administration is on record as supporting the repeal of many Federal regulations, including the ''fairness doctrine.''

title: CIPHER DATA PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Net loss after a loss of $5,000 from discontinued operations

title: POLAROID CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SECRET PLEAS ACCEPTED BY U.S. ATTORNEY IN CITY
description: At least 75 Federal defendants, and probably more, were permitted to enter guilty pleas in secret proceedings in Manhattan over the last two years in Federal judges' chambers. The practice is considered even by Justice Department officials to be unusual and perhaps contrary to Federal guidelines.

title: HARTFORD CLASSES DRAW STUDENTS FROM SUBURBS
description: Students from suburban high schools are being drawn to a troubled inner-city school through a magnet program that is designed to provide better education in a desegregated setting.

description: BASEBALL

title: Advertising; Chewing Gum for The Rich
description: IMAGINE a Danish company with enough nerve to export chewing gum to the home of Wrigley's, Adams and Beech-Nut. Why the next thing you know some Japanese company will try exporting autos to the home of General Motors, Ford and Chrysler. Or some French company will be sending water to the home of the Mississippi.

title: Spies, Trust, Men and Laws
description: Bobby Inman's explanation for quitting as number two man at the Central Intelligence Agency is probably as accurate as a top spy's can be in public. He says he wants to run something, start a new career, educate his teen-age sons. If that were all, there would be ample cause to regret the loss of brains, talent and tact from an agency that can never have enough of those assets.

title: 15,000 EXPECTED TO TAKE A LEISURELY 5-BOROUGH BIKE RIDE
description: LED by 200 Dutch sailors, some 15,000 bicyclists in orange vests will trace a great loop through the city on Sunday. They won't be competing, just ambling along, free of intrusions from motor vehicles, in the sixth annual Five Boro Bike Tour, sponsored by American Youth Hostels and Citibank.

description: A right-wing coalition took control of the leadership of El Salvador's new Constituent Assembly tonight, locking the centrist Christian Democrats out of all key legislative positions.

description: CAN a French-Canadian girl find true happiness living with a reformed gold miner near Lover's Rock in Kootenay Pass, Saskatchewan, Canada? Can Hard-Boiled Herman, a pistol-packing overweight innocent, be a successful clothing designer after his wisecrackin' wife sells her frontier saloon? Can a Royal Canadian Mountie really get his man, when his man has been framed by a lascivious Indian woman out to protect herself?

Hungarian Is Indicted On 4 Counts of Spying
description: A Federal grand jury indicted a 50-year-old Hungarian today on four counts of espionage. The indictment charges that Otto Attilla Gilbert tried to buy classified military information from an Army warrant officer and that he conspired with two other Hungarians to obtain the information and deliver it to Hungarian agents.

title: PLASMA-THERMINC reports earnings for Qtr to March31
OIL STOCKS HELP DOW CLIMB 9.70
description: Energy stocks rallied yesterday to lead the market to its highest level in 12 weeks. Trading was heavy. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 9.70 points, to 853.12. This marked its best closing since 871.10 on Jan. 29. The Dow ended last year at 875.

title: INMAN RESIGNATION TIED TO DEBATE ON WIDENING INTELLIGENCE ACTIVITY
description: An intense debate in the Reagan Administration over the possible reorganization of counterintelligence operations led indirectly to the resignation of Adm. Bobby R. Inman as Deputy Director of Central Intelligence, senior Administration officials said today.

title: Criticism From Soviet
description: Yuri Titov, president of the International Gymnastics Federation, is the latest in what is becoming a long list of athletic officials in the Soviet Union who have criticized the Los Angeles organizers of the 1984 Olympics. In an interview with the national daily Sovietsky Sport, Titov said that, with the Games only two years away, ''There is still no clarity, just a smokescreen of promises and assurances.'' Titov said that what he had been able to establish, and what is making him unhappy, is that gymnasts at the Games, instead of having a tunnel between the warm-up hall and the site of the actual competition, ''would have to walk several hundred yards under the open sky;'' that the organizers have not yet specified the type of mats to be used in the competition, and that the training halls are scheduled to be opened only a few days before the Games.

title: Roadblock to Halt Drugs Creates Anger in Florida
description: Residents of the Florida Keys are angry over a roadblock set up to catch aliens and drug smugglers, and one of them went to court in a futile effort get it abolished.

title: HISTORIANS FIND THEY'RE SOUGHT BY U.S. BUSINESS
description: Historians and business executives might seem an unlikely match, but the companies are providing a home for many of the 10,000 persons who have earned their Ph.D.'s in history in the past decade.

title: AMERICAN PRECISION INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
W.B.A. Drops Sanction Of Moore-Weir Bout
description: The World Boxing Association, complying with a court order issued in the United States, today withdrew its sanction for a junior-middleweight title bout between Davey Moore, the champion, and Charlie Weir.

title: CESSNA AIRCRAFT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
BUILDINGS PACT TO FORCE RISES IN RENTS IN CITY
description: There was general agreement yesterday that Wednesday's settlement with building service workers would result in higher rents for New York City apartments. But the size of the increases will be uncertain until the city's Rent Guidelines Board sets the levels of rent adjustment later this year.

title: TALKS OVER COSTS FOR DAILY NEWS ARE BROKEN OFF
description: Talks on cutting labor costs at The Daily News were broken off abruptly yesterday afternoon. The unions said they wanted to bargain over a wage freeze and a five-year contract, proposals that the man who wants to own the paper is demanding as nonnegotiable items.

title: STAR SUPERMARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ART: TWO GROUP SHOWS
description: OF two noteworthy figurative groups on show this week, one spans the years 1932 to 1982 and celebrates the golden anniversary of the Midtown Galleries, 11 East 57th Street. In the other, the artists are generally younger and their work is recent, marking a decision on the part of the gallery, the Coe Kerr, 49 East 82d Street, to include more contemporaries in a stable that previously was strongest in artists of the 19th and early 20th centuries. Each exhibition is interesting enough in its own right, but taken together they report sharply and disconcertingly on the way tastes have changed in the last half-century.

title: KAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
BRITON AND HAIG IN 'USEFUL START' ON THE FALKLANDS
description: Britain's Foreign Secretary, Francis Pym, said after a four-hour meeting today with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. that they had made ''a useful start'' in discussing the latest ideas for resolving the Falkland Islands dispute.

title: TV Weekend; CARTOONS, TOURS AND 'NEIGHBORHOOD'
description: ''JOKEBOOK,'' a new limited-run series beginning on NBC-TV tonight, is stuffed with cartoons and is being presented at the early hour of 8 o'clock, but it is not just for the kiddies. Produced and directed by William Hanna and Joe Barbera, whose own animation credits include ''Smurfs'' and ''The Flintstones,'' the anthology is offering a wide range of material from international sources.

description: B-Including an extraordinary credit of $202,000...C-Including income of $9,295,000 from discontinued operations; yr-ago results have been restated to reflect discontinued operations

Walter Wilson Dead; With Morgan Stanley
description: Walter W. Wilson, a former partner of Morgan Stanley & Company, the investment banking concern, died Wednesday at his home in Rye, N.Y. He was 78 years old.

title: 2 SYRIANS OUSTED
description: A powerful car bomb tore through a crowded street in central Paris at rush hour this morning, killing a young woman and injuring 46 people. The French Government, in a statement four hours later, expelled two Syrian diplomats and recalled its ambassador from Damascus for consultation.

title: CUBA BRIEFLY HOLDS 3 AMERICANS ON BOAT
description: Miami, april 22 (UPI) - A cuban gunboat seized a 40-foot sailboat with three United States citizens aboard Wednesday and released them later in the day, officials said.

title: GUN IN C.B.S. KILLINGS SOUGHT IN CREEK
description: Police divers searched a narrow tidal creek here today for the handgun used to kill a Federal witness and three CBS employees in Manhattan last week.

title: MIKE AUGUSTYNIAK'S SOLITARY STRUGGLE
description: Mike Augustyniak's opponent these days is not a beefy linebacker or defensive lineman but instead a tension spring. The spring provides resistance as Augustyniak, wearing a harness that is attached to it by a rope, engages in running exercises.

title: WHERE YOU CAN SEE AMERICA'S 'MONA LISA'
description: WHAT does the mini Art Museum in Montclair, N.J., have in common with the mighty Louvre in Paris? Well, for the next two weeks, the ''Mona Lisa.'' Starting tomorrow, and through May 9, the museum in Montclair will show what's known as the Vernon ''Mona Lisa,'' a version of the Leonardo painting that has been in this country since the 18th century. Its owners, descendants of William Henry Vernon, an American swell who brought the work back from Paris in 1797, are convinced that their ''Mona Lisa'' is not only a Leonardo, but an even earlier Leonardo than the one that hangs in the Louvre. The claim is not given credence by Louvre officials, however, nor are Leonardo scholars rushing to embrace the Montclair ''Mona.''

title: SIFCO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Means Plans Sale
description: Means Services Inc., the largest commercial laundry service business in the Middle West, said it was selling three of its 26 processing plants to satisfy the Justice Department's objections to a proposed merger with ARA Services Inc. of Philadelphia. The Justice Department had said that it would challenge the proposed acquisition, having identified three areas of competitive overlap between ARA's Aratex division and Means.

title: PACIFIC LUMBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
B.T.U. FEE, YES-OIL FEE, NO
description: To the Editor:

title: LARGE VOLCANIC CLOUD COULD CHANGE CLIMATE
description: A cloud of volcanic debris stretching 13,000 miles across two oceans has the potential to alter the earth's climate, atmospheric scientists say.

title: At the Movies
description: HOLLYWOOD DURING a spring that has been described by most movie distributors as ''chilly,'' ''Porky's,'' ''Chariots of Fire'' and ''On Golden Pond'' are the sunny exceptions. ''Porky's,'' a raunchy tale of sexobsessed high-school boys, has taken in more than $53 million at the box office in one month. ''On Golden Pond'' is closing in on $94 million, while ''Chariots of Fire,'' winner of the Academy Award as best picture of 1981, has earned $39 million.

title: American League; Brewers 7, Blue Jays 0
description: MILWAUKEE (AP) - Home runs by Ben Oglivie, with one on, and Cecil Cooper, with the bases empty, supplied the power behind Mike Caldwell's four-hitter for Milwaukee.

title: COAST COUNTY HAILS RETURNING NIXON
description: Entering to the strains of ''Hail to the Chief,'' former President Richard M. Nixon made a nostalgic return to his native Orange County Wednesday night.

Knight-Ridder In Affiliated Tie
description: Affiliated Publications and Knight-Ridder Newspapers Inc. have signed an agreement that could lead to marketing a home information system, called Viewtron, in Boston, both companies announced.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Jim Bibby, the Pittsburgh Pirates' sore-armed pitcher, underwent surgery yesterday for the removal of bone fragments and the repair of a minor problem with the rotator cuff in his right shoulder.

title: Restaurants; by Mimi Sheraton; Under the bridge and at stage center.
description: THE two restaurants reviewed today have much in common. Both owe their interest and their following to their location, and in both the kitchens attempt to prepare many complicated, trendy dishes that are well beyond the skills of the staff. Considering the desirability of their settings - the River Cafe has a knockout view of the New York skyline from the Fulton Ferry landing, and O'Neal's Times Square has proximity to the theater district - both chefs would do well to follow Escoffier's advice to keeps things simple.

title: GLOBAL MARINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
M-A-COM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
Rain Puts Off Golf
description: Showers soaked the Lakewood Country Club course today, forcing postponement of the first round of the New Orleans Open golf tournament 97 minutes after it had started. The first round is now scheduled to be played on Friday, the second on Saturday and the third and fourth on Sunday.

title: STANLEY WORKS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
STOCKMAN HEARD, NOT SEEN, AS JAMES BAKER RISES
description: In this city's timeless preoccupation with the political pecking order, the old hands keep an eye on public appearances for clues to real influence at the pinnacle of Government.

title: FOR CAROLYN ADAMS, FAREWELL TO PAUL TAYLOR
description: Choreographers need bodies on which to set their dances. If they are lucky, they find dancers who are intelligent as well as physically adept. And if they are very lucky, they find a dancer devoted enough to stick with them through both lean and splendid years, becoming so responsive that words are almost unnecessary during the creation of a dance.

title: CABINET UNIT ASKS NEW WATER RULES
description: The Cabinet Council on Natural Resources and the Environment sent President Reagan recommendations today for changing the Clean Water Act, including changes in a requirement that industries treat toxic wastes before dumping them into municipal sewer systems.

title: ART: EDWIN DICKINSON, ENIGMATIC, UNFORGOTTEN
description: ''If you can't place him, show him the door'' may be standard practice in some restaurants, but it is a very bad principle in art history. There is nowhere in particular that we can place Edwin Dickinson, who was born in 1891, died in 1978 and who is now the subject of a retrospective exhibition at the National Academy of Design on Fifth Avenue at 89th Street. Yet a major painting by Dickinson, once seen, is hard to forget.

title: Chrysler Gains Cited
description: Lee A. Iacocca, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, said today that his company was in ''good shape'' after its financial difficulties and could earn $150 million this year if the recession ends. Chrysler does not need to use any more of the Government-guaranteed loans authorized by Congress in 1979, he told the House Subcommittee on Economic Stabilization.

WHITE HOUSE ASSAILS CBS NEWS, BUT A BID FOR REPLY IS REJECTED
description: The Reagan Administration, angered at what its officials called a ''misleading'' portrayal of its economic policies on a CBS News television documentary Wednesday night, asked the network today for a half-hour in prime viewing hours ''to present our side of the story.'' title: Ulster Nail-Bomb Wounds 2
description: Two civilians were wounded early today by a guerrilla nail-bomb probably aimed at security forces, the police reported. No group took responsibility for the bomb, which exploded in a garbage can, but police sources blamed the Irish Republican Army.

title: CONCERT: MEHTA LEADS A WAGNER POTPOURRI
description: WAGNER programs that consist of unrelated chunks torn from the body of that composer's operas turn up at orchestral concerts less frequently now than they once did. Perhaps modern audiences, weaned on complete performances of the Ring, both recorded and live, no longer need to hear this music played in digest form. No one who wants Wagner today has to be satisfied with samples.

title: Senators Press for Data On Cost of B-1 Bomber
description: Four Senators asked Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger today to release figures on the cost of the B-1 bomber program, and one of them angrily asserted that the Pentagon was ''stonewalling'' Congress on the issue.

title: DANCERS TO WATCH AS SEASON BLOSSOMS
description: HERE'S to dancers, not just to the bright young things and the international razzle-dazzlers, but to the performers who really make the dances go. This particularly busy weekend some of the best of these performers are appearing - in ballets, modern dances and ethnic celebrations throughout the city. All very different, they bring more than technique to bear on every phrase and gesture. They create an unmistakably personal vibrancy on stage - they make you watch them.

title: Davis Permitted Rule He Seeks to Overturn
description: Al Davis, the managing general partner of the Oakland Raiders, admitted under cross-examination today that he never tried to change the rules that govern teams moving from one city to another. He is now challenging those rules in an antitrust suit involving an effort to move his Raiders to Los Angeles.

title: Brooklyn Store Thieves Shoot Off-Duty Officer

title: A 15-QUARTET SALUTE TO SHOSTAKOVICH
description: NOWHERE are the unhappinesses of 20th-century life more eloquently chronicled than in the 15 string quartets of Dmitri Shostakovich. The earlier quartets are never far from the destruction and death of World War II; the last four confront dying in more personal and more anguishing ways. The 15th, indeed, is a solemn and fantastic procession of six adagio movements - in its way, an elaborate funeral march that the composer seems to be writing for himself.

title: SCREEN: UPDIKE ADAPTED
description: WHY, you may well ask, is a television film adapted from John Updike's stories about the Maple family opening today at Cinema II? According to Zoetrope Studios, which is releasing ''Too Far to Go'' as a theatrical feature, this film is being rescued from its undeserved obscurity.

title: Businessman Goes to Jail For Dumping Chemicals
description: BARRE, Pa., April 22 (UPI) - The president of a defunct New Jersey concern today became the first businessman to be jailed for criminal violation of Pennsylvania's environmental laws. He was also fined $760,000.

title: Broadway; Angela Lansbury returns in comedy next season.
description: the screenplay of ''Prince of the City'' and the play ''The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie,'' to name only two. Mrs. Allen has adapted ''Potiche'' by Pierre Barillet and Jean-Pierre Gredy (''Cactus Flower'' and ''Forty Carats'' were based on Barillet-Gredy plays; Mrs. Allen adapted ''Forty Carats''), retitled it and set it in a Massachusetts town an hour out of Boston. It is a comedy.

title: Creeping Socialism?
description: Craig Morton, the Denver Broncos' quarterback, said that the National Football League Players Association's demand for a fixed percentage of the clubs' gross revenues amounted to ''socialism'' and that as a result he could not support a strike over the issue. ''I think it's really wrong, against American tradition,'' said Morton, who participated in a player strike in the summer of 1974, when the issue was free agency. ... Kirby Criswell, the Cardinal defensive end arrested in St. Louis earlier this month on a charge of marijuana possession, was indicted there yesterday by a Federal grand jury, which accused him of conspiring to manufacture and distribute amphetamines.

title: ADAC LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Net loss including tax credits of $123,000 for the qr and $360,000 for the 6 mos

title: FOOD INDUSTRY'S MIDDLEMEN
description: It is Monday morning. The supermarket has been depleted by weekend shoppers, and the battle for territory is renewed. In the frozen food section of a Manhattan A.& P. at 68th Street and Broadway, Martin Chambers and Pat Smith are busily restacking the Buitoni and Sara Lee, making sure that Stouffer's and Pepperidge Farm do not encroach on their turf.

title: GALTIERI, IN THE FALKLANDS, STRIKES A CONCILIATORY NOTE
description: On his first visit to the Falkland Islands since Argentine troops seized them three weeks ago, President Leopoldo Galtieri sounded a conciliatory note toward Britain today while insisting that his country would fight to hold on to the archipelago.

title:
Patents;
Improved Medical Scanner
description: WASHINGTON AN improved scanner for physicians to use in ultrasonic examination of patients was patented this week for the New York Institute of Technology, Old Westbury, L.I. The inventor is William E. Glenn, director of the institute's Science Center in Dania, Fla.

title: Sports People; Traveling Man
description: The Buffalo Bills of the National Football League have called a news conference for today in which they are expected to announce that they have acquired the rights to Tom Cousineau, a free-agent linebacker. He played the last three years with the Montreal Alouettes of the Canadian Football League.

title: The Talk of Princeton University
description: Oh, that campus life. Days of toil, moments of bliss. The bell atop Nassau Hall summons the lingerer to class. The sun warms the crews on Lake Carnegie and draws sweetheart and suitor to the grass of Cannon Green. At Prospect Garden, lectures are alfresco, the afternoons thick with Shakespeare, perhaps Swift. And in the building called West College, James Wickenden braces for the worst.

title: David Mason, Leading Player; Of Bridge in New York Region
description: David Mason, a leading contract bridge player in the New York area, died Thursday of cancer at Beth Israel Hospital in Newark. Mr. Mason was 59 years old and lived in Maplewood, N.J.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "While the patient has not been cured, the inflation fever is way down" - Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics. (1:5)

title: ISRAELIS BURY A SETTLEMENT IN SINAI SAND
description: By nightfall the town of Yamit had been ground into the desert and covered over with its sand. All but about 20 of those who had made a desperate stand against the return to Egypt of the last sector of Sinai under Israeli control were carried, shouting at soldiers, into buses that took them across what will again become an international boundary next week. The rest have promised to leave Sunday.

description: Leaders of the country's state legislatures authorized their representatives today to bargain with the Federal Government about the possibility of the states' taking over the nation's biggest welfare program, Aid to Families with Dependent Children.

description: Swine influenza killed a 4-year-old Nevada girl in February, Federal epidemiologists said yesterday. But, in reporting the case, the investigators also said that the girl's death had been an isolated instance and that there was no danger of an epidemic.

description: ''When I talk to them,'' Debbie Julich explained, ''they say, 'Debbie, what do you want me to do?' And I tell them, 'Be nice, do something.' It usually works because they know I knew what the answers could be on the other side, how I as a buyer would defend.''

title: IN NIGHT COURT, THE PLOT NEVER CHANGES
description: The Manhattan Night Arraignment Court, known to law enforcement personnel and felons alike simply as Night Court, is one of the great shifting immutables in this town. Like Grand Central Terminal or cocktail party conversation, the ingredients are always changing, yet the whole always remains the same.

WISCONSIN LEADER RULES OUT 2ND TERM
description: Gov. Lee Sherman Dreyfus said today that he would not seek a second term. The Republican Governor's announcement stunned party leaders and supporters who had expected him to run again. Mr. Dreyfus said that he was bowing out of politics to ''return to private life.''

title: U.S. IS REMAINING ADAMANT AS DETAINED HAITIANS PRESS APPEALS FOR ASYLUM
description: Once in a while a letter of anguish makes its way out of one of the detention facilities for Haitian refugees, as this one to President Reagan did a few weeks ago:

title: Around the World; Austria Says U.S. Agrees To Take Polish Refugees
description: Interior Minister Erwin Lanc said today that the United States had agreed to help Austria resolve its Polish refugee problem by accepting 1,000 of the Poles every month.

No Headline
description: Mexico's former security chief, who came to the United States to file a libel suit over a magazine article that said he was involved in a stolen car ring, was arrested tonight on charges stemming from the operation.

title: Anaconda Closing
description: The Anaconda Minerals Company will abandon its huge Berkeley Pit copper mine here, lay off 270 workers in Butte and delay the reopening of a Utah mine, the company said today. Frank Gardiner, manager of Anaconda's copper operations, told a news conference that the work force at Butte would be reduced to about 800.

title: CLOROX CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Danish Ballet to Open At the Met on June 15
description: The Royal Danish Ballet will open June 15 at the Metropolitan Opera House for two weeks, its first visit to New York in six years. The company will present ''A Folk Tale,'' ''Napoli'' (Act III) and ''Kermess in Bruges,'' three ballets from its repertory by August Bournonville, the 19th-century choreographer and company balletmaster.

description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect the merger of JMR Instruments Inc during fiscal 1981

title: U.S. Proposes a Limit On Back Pay for Bias
description: The Reagan Administration moved today to limit back pay awards to workers subjected to employment discrimination by Government contractors.

title: Books of The Times; The Ordinary People
description: COLLECTED STORIES. By V.S. Pritchett. 520 pages. Random House. $20.

description: B-Includes $246,355 capital gain; C-Includes $108,266 capital gain; D-Not reported

title: PRICE DROP SPELLS RELIEF IN MINNEAPOLIS SUBURBS
description: The office staff at the Richville Bank and Trust Company held an employee relations meeting with management the other day. They wanted the price of a cup of coffee made in the office to be dropped a dime, to 15 cents.

title: DeLorean Deal
description: The DeLorean Motor Company announced that it had reopened its car processing centers, allowing 600 luxury sports cars to be shipped to dealers. John Z. DeLorean, chairman of DeLorean Motor, said that the decision to resume the shipment of new cars resulted from a series of new developments, including an inventory refinancing agreement reducing the company's indebtedness to the Bank of America and the signing of an agreement with the receiver now controling the manufacturing plant in Belfast, Northern Ireland.

title: Issue and Debate; DRIVE TO FREEZE U.S. AND SOVIET NUCLEAR ARSENALS
description: This week, it is estimated, a million Americans attended seminars, debates, films and other activities designed to alert citizens to the perils of nuclear war. The events, the largest and most publicized to date, were sponsored by Ground Zero, a nonpartisan organization.

title: ORDER OF COURT SENDS HINKLEY TO HOSPITAL FOR DIAGNOSTIC TESTS
description: John W. Hinckley Jr., who is accused of shooting President Reagan and three other men last year, underwent diagnostic tests at Johns Hopkins University Hospital in Baltimore tonight, a hospital spokesman said.

title: 'Cast of Characters' To Recall Ruth Draper
description: Ruth Draper, whose one-woman shows were highlights of the American theater of the 1930's and 40's, will be impersonated by a young actress, Patrizia Norcia, in ''Cast of Characters,'' opening May 5, at the Cherry Lane Theater.

title: REVLON INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The earnings in the latest quarter include a 19 cents nonrecurring charge per fully diluted share arising from the previously reported settlement of a patent suit concerning contact lenses

description: B-After a reserve of $400,000 for current and future expenditures related to a plant closing; C-Net income

title: EXPOS TOP METS IN 9YH, 5-4
description: Another day, another one-run ball game. The Mets, who have seen seven of their first 14 games decided by a single run, were beaten in the ninth inning today, 5-4, when, with the score tied and one out, Al Oliver slapped a single up the middle and sent Rodney Scott home from third.

title: Pittston Buys Burlington Unit
description: Burlington Northern Inc. and the Pittston Company said they had reached a definitive agreement for the sale of Burlington Northern Air Freight Inc., a Burlington subsidiary, to Pittston for $177 million in cash. The transaction is scheduled to be completed on May 3.

TOPPS & TROWSERS INC reports earnings for Yr to Jan 31

Pay Trade Subsidies to End Them
description: Does President Reagan have a soft spot for business? Not according to companies that depend on the export of big-ticket items like commercial aircraft, electrical generators and railroad cars. They see the Administration's effort to reduce loans by the Government's Export-Import Bank as a cynical attack on ''fat cats'' that will cost thousands of jobs.

title: MONEY SUPPLY OFF $1.9 BILLION
description: The Federal Reserve late yesterday announced a $1.9 billion decline in the nation's basic money supply that surprised many traders and economists, who were expecting an increase of about $1 billion.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Wednesday on the launching of a Soviet space laborato- ry, Salyut 7, incorrectly listed the likely members of the first crew.

title: CENTRAL ILLINOIS PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
U.S. FALKLAND PLAN GETS ICY RESPONSE
description: The United States has presented Britain with a set of new proposals to avert a conflict over the Falkland Islands, but a British source said tonight that they were ''unsatisfactory'' from his Government's point of view.

title:
PATENTS;
Method to Reduce Color Printing Costs
description: A method patented this week for the Cymaticolor Corporation, Edison, N.J., is expected to bring the cost of four-color printing close to that or black and white. Patent 4,325,631 was obtained for the company by Francis E. McCullion Jr., a vice president and director.

title: Elmer Ward, Founder Of Palm Beach Clothes
description: Elmer L. Ward Sr., founder, former president and board chairman of Palm Beach Inc., a major clothing manufacturer, died Thursday at his home in Kennebunk Beach, Me. Mr. Ward, a former resident of Boston and Cincinnati, was 84 years old.

title: Kadar to Visit West Germany
description: Janos Kadar, the Hungarian Communist Party chief, will visit West Germany next week in the first trip to the West by a Soviet bloc leader since martial law was imposed in Poland on Dec. 13. The visit Tuesday and Wednesday will take place at the invitation of Chancellor Helmut Schmidt.

title: WATSON IS TRADED
description: The Yankees traded Bob Watson to the Atlanta Braves yesterday, and before he left Yankee Stadium he noted that ''if this team ever gets the right combination of whatever they're looking for, they're definitely going to hurt some people.''

title: ENVIRONMENTAL AGENCY CHIEF SAYS CRITICS ARE POLITICALLY MOTIVATED
description: Anne M. Gorsuch, the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, charged today that attacks by environmentalists on her policies were politically motivated efforts to do in the Reagan Administration.

title: Canada Technicians to Stay
description: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau rejected opposition demands today that Canada recall its nuclear technicians from Argentina, whose nuclear ambitions have drawn new attention because of the Falkland Islands crisis. Seventy-one Canadian technicians are helping build a Canadian-designed nuclear reactor at a site 120 miles from Buenos Aires.

title: McLouth Drops Retirees' Benefits
description: The McLouth Steel Corporation, the nation's 11th-largest steel company, which is operating under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, says it is dropping health and life insurance benefits for its 1,000 retirees because it has no choice under an agreement with its creditors.

title: OCCIDENTAL PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NEGOTIATORS BACK SHIFTING OF TAXES TO SOCIAL SECURITY
description: White House and Congressional budget negotiators tentatively agreed today to earmark specific taxes, such as those on tobacco and liquor, to aid the faltering Social Security System, Republican and Democratic aides familiar with the negotiations said.

title: W.B.A. Granted Stay, Backs Moore-Weir Bout
description: The World Boxing Association, in a reversal of its action a day earlier, yesterday sanctioned the Davey Moore-Charlie Weir bout as a title fight after having won a stay of a Federal court injunction. The bout between the two junior middleweights is scheduled for today in Johannesburg.

title: Lisa McCormick Married
description: Lisa McCormick, a model and daughter of John McCormick and Mrs. David Jessell, both of London, was married there yesterday to Nicholas Tiffany Love, an actor and son of Kennett Love and Mrs. Robert Morgan, both of New York.

title: INMAN LOSS RAISES FEARS IN CONGRESS
description: A conservative Republican member of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence said today that the ability of Congress to act as a check on the activities of intelligence agencies had been imperiled by the resignation of Adm. Bobby R. Inman as Deputy Director of Central Intelligence.

DEEP- SEA LIFE FLOURISHING ON VOLCANIC ENERGY
description: Probing a thicket of black geysers erupting from the lightless sea floor 8,600 feet beneath this ship, biologists in a three-man submarine are exploring a new world of living organisms dependent not on sunlight but on volcanic energy gushing from deep within the earth.

title: SHERRITT GORDON MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange

title: Sports People; Pacers Staying Put
description: Sam Nassi, the owner of the Indiana Pacers, said he expects his team to remain in Indianapolis next season. Nassi, speaking from Encino Hospital in California where he had an aortic valve replaced, said he had no plans to fold the Pacers, who completed their sixth National Basketball Association season with a 35-47 record. The club's average home attendance of 7,758 ranked 19th in the 23-team league and was down 2,300 from the previous season.

title: Sports People; Ray Meyer Returning
description: Ray Meyer will return to De Paul next season for his 41st year as head basketball coach. But he will have to do without Terry Cummings, a junior who yesterday announced that he would be available for the National Basketball Association draft. At a news conference in Chicago, Meyer, 68 years old, said he would return for at least one more season. Cummings. who averaged 22 points and 11 rebounds a game last season, said he found the decision to turn pro difficult, but ''there are more important things than education, like family.''

title: FLAMBOYANT BOXER SHOWS A NEW IMAGE
description: Johnny Verderosa's motorcycle is for sale. ''The first $1,750 takes it,'' said the undefeated fighter from Staten Island. ''I don't even like it anymore. It scares me.''

description: The International Harvester Company, the financially troubled manufacturer of farm and construction machinery, is seeking changes in its $4.2 billion debt restructuring agreement in an effort to avoid default, company sources acknowledged today. Analysts predicted that the restructuring would be accomplished.

title: MRS. THATCHER VISITS THE NAVY'S COMMAND CENTER
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher spent two hours at the Royal Navy's underground command center outside London today as a mood of expectancy gripped the British capital.

MALAY COALITION WINNING BY LANDSLIDE VOTE
description: The National Front of Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad was headed for a landslide victory today after most of the ballots had been counted from Thursday's general election.

title: ARGENTINA SAYS 2 BRITISH WARSHIPS HAVE VIOLATED ITS ZONE OF DEFENSE
description: Argentine officials said tonight that two British warships violated the Argentine defense zone today by moving to within 50 miles of the sparsely inhabited Falkland Islands dependency of South Georgia.

title: ILLEGAL RADIO OPERATORS TRANSMITTING REGULARLY
description: The disk jockey flipped a couple of switches, pulled on his headphones and twirled a small black knob. In defiance of Federal law, radio station WBUZ-FM went on the air.

description: A Venezuelan company that is a key player in the multifaceted battle to obtain control of the Florida National Banks of Florida Inc. has announced that it has sold 565,000 of Florida National shares, representing 7.5 percent of the total outstanding, to the Southeast Banking Corporation.

title: BIG 3 AUTO SALES UP 8.3% LED BY 15.5% G.M. GAIN
description: On the strength of a 15.5 percent increase in car sales by the General Motors Corporation, sales by the nation's Big Three auto makers rose 8.3 percent in the middle 10 days of April compared with the same period last year, the companies said today. It was the highest sales increase this year.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, APRIL 24, 1982
description: International Violation of Argentina's defense zone by two British warships was reported by Argentine officials. The ships were said to have moved to within 50 miles of the sparsely inhabited Falkland Islands dependency of South Georgia. The Argentine press agency Telam quoted a Government official as saying that an attack on South Georgia, 800 miles east of the Falklands, was ''imminent.'' The officials said the ships' movements were a violation of the Rio Treaty and that the Government had filed a protest with the Organization of American States. (Page 1, Columns 2-3.) U.S. Salvadoran policy will not change despite the right-wing coalition's control of the new Constituent Assembly, Ambassador Deane R. Hinton said. He said that the Reagan Administration's support of the Salvadoran Government ''will continue in any case'' and that he ''would certainly hope'' that Congress will not suspend economic and military aid to El Salvador as a result of the Assembly vote. The vote placed the chamber under the control of Roberto d'Aubuisson, an extreme rightist, and excluded members of the centrist Christian Democratic Party. (1:1.)

DANCE: AMERICAN BALLET IN PAUL TAYLOR'S 'AIRS'
description: ''Airs'' is one of the happiest recent additions to the repertory of the American Ballet Theater, which performed the Paul Taylor work Thursday in the Metropolitan Opera House. Who would have thought that ballet dancers would have taken so well to the unballetic flow of ''Airs''? But watch Christine Spizzo, with her clear attack and phrasing, and the adaptations of the classically trained body to those abrupt shifts in direction and dynamics become apparent and exciting. And the dance becomes new, as so often happens when a different group of dancers perform a familiar work.

title: RELIGIOUS GROUP PROXY POWER
description: Groups of religious shareholders that monitor corporate responsibility have for years found it difficult to convince companies to take them seriously. Many executives have simply ignored their requests for information, and because their shareholder petitions have rarely won many proxy votes, companies more often than not have never tried to negotiate settlements.

SATURDAY, APRIL 24, 1982; The Economy
description: Consumer prices fell 0.3 percent in March, the first decline in almost 17 years. Lower fuel and housing prices accounted for most of the drop. The downward trend has been sharper than expected, but most economists do not expect it to last. (Page 1.) Prices in the New York-Northeastern New Jersey area fell 0.8 percent, the sharpest drop in 33 years. (1.) The Administration sees the decline in prices as its first clear economic victory, but critics say the cost in unemployment and lost production has been too high. (1.) The slowdown in inflation will keep the rise in Social Security benefits effective July 1 to 7.4 percent, or about $27 a month. (48.)
