De Gustibus; A REAL BARBEQUE IS HARD TO FIND
description: Although authenticity of preparation is a less important consideration than how a dish winds up tasting, occasionally a misnomer can lead to wrong expectations, and therefore, disappointment. As American regional cooking begins to gain status, it is inevitable that ''barbecue'' will become a popular word on menus. Yet little of the meat and poultry sold as barbecue in New York is truly that at all. Pallid imitations cooked in gas or electric broilers and ovens that do do not barbecue anything are being served up in restaurants all over town. Delicious though these broiled and roasted impostors may be, they are not barbecue, not even if they are marinated, basted and accompanied by a typical sweetsour-pungent barbecue sauce.

The police recovered $24,000. Mr. Clohessy was a security guard at the plant at the time of the robbery. ... Two men were critically wounded in a shootout with the police in Brooklyn, after they had robbed Waldbaum's supermarket at Kings Highway and Nostrand Avenue in the Sheepshead Bay section at about 7 A.M. and attempted to flee with two employees as hostages.

title: THE ART OF TEACHING SCIENCE
description: Dr. Thomas is carrying owls to Athens in suggesting that science teachers impress upon their students the paradoxes and mysteries of contemporary physical and life sciences. Quite the contrary. These students need reason to hope for the advancement of knowledge to save them from their increasing skepticism and mysticism. DALE E. BURRINGTON Professor of Philosophy Hartwick College

title: LONG SENTENCES SOUGHT FOR REPEAT OFFENDERS
description: Jackson Monroe Martin slumped in his chair and stared at the floor. He could not believe he had just been sentenced to 99 years in jail for indecent exposure.

title: In the Arts: Critics' Choices
description: PHOTOGRAPHY To most viewers of photography, Richard Prince's new photographs (at Metro Pictures, 169 Mercer Street, through Saturday) will seem disorienting. They are large (30 by 44 inches) pictures of blackand-white figures set against nebulous, hotly colored backgrounds.

title: SIMS OF TEXAS WILL BE MADE THE NO. 1 CHOICE BY PATRIOTS
description: The National Football League's annual draft of college players will begin at 10 A.M. on Tuesday, and there will be no hesitation about the first selection. The New England Patriots, who had the poorest record in the league last season and therefore gained the right to the first choice, will take Ken Sims, the defensive tackle from Texas who has already visited Boston as a guest of the team, signed autographs and given interviews.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; America Gets Painted by The Numbers
description: Like a snapshot of a family picnic, a national census can reveal things that are startling and familiar. The Census Bureau made public last week its findings from the ''long form'' completed in 1980 by one out of five Americans. Among the features of this eclectic family: For the first time, a majority over the age of 25 in every state have finished high school; after declining every decade since 1920, foreign-born residents are on the rise again; and Americans would much rather drive alone to work than use public transportation (and would almost rather walk). No one will be surprised that overall income gain since 1970 was slight, that family size shrank and that fewer people live in their native states.

title: Durbin Captures Title In Firestone Bowling
description: Mike Durbin won his second bowling title in the $200,000 Firestone Tournament of Champions with a 233-203 victory today over the defending champion, Steve Cook.

title: YOUNG BUT NOT INNOCENT
description: In 1957, the year my library card was upgraded to Y.A., ''drugs'' meant penicillin, ''grass'' was something you mowed to pad your allowance, and when you wanted to read about sex, you climbed up to a top shelf and filched ''Lady Chatterley's Lover.'' A ''Young Adult'' novel in those days provided a firmly edited version of reality, with ethical and romantic dilemmas scaled down to our budding comprehension and our treasured innocence. The best ones did this without condescension, and without leaving the reader feeling that something was missing. Out of limited materials, they created complete, dignified novelistic worlds.

title: Cheryl A. Morgan Engaged to Harold G. Albert Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jesse J. Morgan Jr. of Miami and Harwich, Mass., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Cheryl Ainley Morgan, to Harold Godfrey Albert Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert of Upperco, Md.

title: CYNTHIA ANN RIHA MARRIED
description: Cynthia Ann Riha, daughter of Broydon Riha and Mrs. Pat Riha, both of Santa Rosa, Calif., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Lehman Leedy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold J. Leedy of New York.

title: 'DANCE CRAZE'
description: The sloppy but cheerful ''Dance Craze,'' which opened Friday at the Eighth Street Playhouse, is a concert film devoted to the musical hybrid known variously as ska, or two-tone, or rock steady. The English bands featured here owe a lot to reggae - the best-known British band rockers playing anything of this sort are the Police, who do not appear in ''Dance Craze'' - but have added a thing or two of their own. Flat tops. Checked jackets. Persistent hopping, preferably from one foot to the other. An overall spirit of jubilation.

title: REDUCTION IS SEEN IN HEART DISEASE
description: LIVING in Connecticut may increase the life expectancy of residents by four to five years, according to new figures from the state's Department of Health Services. Health officials attribute this to the reduced risk of cardiovascular disease and stroke believed to be the result of a statewide program on hypertension.

title: The Nation in Summary; WElcome to Ground Zero, All You Folks
description: 'Ground zero' is the spot directly under a nuclear bomb explosion. For the last seven days, a nationwide series of lectures, debates and entertainments called Ground Zero Week tried to educate people about what might happen near such an unfortunate place.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Lifting the Lid On Secret Pleas
description: The payoff is usually information. The cost is secrecy. But in spite of the constitutionally questionable nature of the procedure, at least 75 defendants in Federal trials were permitted to enter guilty pleas in judges' chambers in Manhattan during the last two years, it was reported last week.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I've never dealt with an industry that has more pervasive corruption than the construction industry.'' -James F. McNamara, director of Mayor Koch's Office of Construction Industry Relations. (1:2.)

title: AN EYE FOR THE FINEST OF FOLK ART
description: Thomas G. Rizzo lived surrounded by stark, stunning portraits of other people's ancestors, a half-dozen folk-art landscapes and several remarkable weathervanes. Until his sudden death at 53 years of age last November, his home, high above Manhattan's East River, was a repository for his folk-art collection which he acquired over more than 30 years, always judiciously editing his possessions with the aim, eventually, of keeping only museum-quality works.

title:
DINING OUT;
A SPANISH SURPRISE IN RAHWAY
description: EL BODEGON in Rahway will come as something of a surprise to those who are accustomed to the noisy and colorful Spanish restaurants in Newark. The decor here is attractively subdued. The walls in the small dining room on the first floor are of weathered barn siding, and old wooden beams traverse the stuccoed ceiling.

title: Other Business; A REPUBLICAN SETBACK IN HOTELKEEPING
description: WASHINGTON Last September, a group of wealthy Republican businessmen, all socalled ''Eagles'' who contributed more than $10,000 each to the Republican National Committee, swooped into the capital, plucked the Embassy Row Hotel out of the doldrums for $14 million and vowed to transform it into a ''five-star hotel'' within a year. It was to be a place where their Republican confreres and visiting political luminaries could gather.

title: ENCOUNTER WITH FATE ON THE ISLE OF RHODES
description: GEORGE VECSEY is a sports columnist for the New York Times. BY GEORGE VECSEY

title: BARS IN FIREHOUSES FAN BITTER DISPUTE
description: GREENWICH SOME long-standing friction between the 60 paid firefighters and 600 volunteers in this town has escalated into a confrontation over complaints by the firefighters of drinking in the firehouses by the volunteers.

title: Patricia Blessington, Brian Heneghan Wed
description: Patricia Ann Blessington, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Blessington of Cos Cob, Conn., was married yesterday to Brian Patrick Heneghan, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Heneghan of Duxbury, Mass. The Rev. Vincent O'Connor performed the ceremony in St. Catherine of Siena Roman Catholic Church in Riverside, Conn.

title: AFTER CAMP DAVID, THE ROAD TO PEACE IS STILL TREACHEROUS
description: WASHINGTON CELEBRATING was muted today as the last Israelis withdrew from Sinai, marking 37 months since the peace treaty with Egypt was signed. The early euphoria after the first Arab-Israeli peace treaty was sealed in Washington had long since dissipated, but it still retains enormous political and military importance.

title: TENNIS, EVERYONE? BUSY SEASON AHEAD
description: White Plains It is the time of year when students of the lob, forehand and backhands are flocking to the 464 public tennis courts in the country. Circuit play is scheduled to begin on about three dozen of these courts this weekend in the Westchester County Tennis League, with about 20 men's teams competing. On Tuesday the league's 52 women's units will swing into action.

title:
IN UTAH, 'THE SCHOOL OF THE FUTURE';
PROVO, Utah
description: IN the summer of 1976 Dustin and Nancy Heuston sat in their cottage in Waterford, Vt., and put the finishing touches on a comprehensive plan for ''the school of the future,'' a dream they had nourished for years that would match students and microcomputers in an effort to profoundly change the course of public education. Last September that dream came alive here in an experimental, private school that already has a student body of 120, from kindergarten through fifth grade, and a growing waiting list. And according to Mrs. Heuston, who is headmistress of Waterford School, ''we're not talking about just an add-on. We're talking about a brand-new delivery system.'' It is this, she says, that distinguishes Waterford's approach from other more fragmented attempts at introducing technology in the classroom.

title: LOVE WITH COMPLICATIONS
description: LAST RESORT By Scott Sommer. 240 pp. New York: Random House. $12.50.

title: DESPITE SALVADORAN VOTE, THE KILLINGS ARE CONTINUING
description: On the outskirts of the capital on the lower slopes of the lush green San Salvador volcano, a moonscape expanse of lava rock has become a dump for human refuse and humans.

title: Agriculture Secretary Backs Cash Aid Plan in Puerto Rico
description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block said Friday that he had approved Puerto Rico's plan to start a program of assistance in cash to replace food stamps, effective July 1.

title:
A CRAFTSMAN AIDS DISABLED CHILDREN;
WHITE PLAINS
description: NILS HILL is an artist who saw a job to be done, and now makes his living by doing that job. The 32-year-old sculptor and painter moved to Ossining two years ago from Manhattan and was hired as a teacher's aide by the Southern Westchester Bureau of Cooperative Educational Services to work with severely handicapped children at the bureau's Rye Lake campus in White Plains. Assigned to the classroom with the youngest children, he spent his days changing diapers, helping children feed themselves and assisting youngsters who hadn't learned to walk yet.

title: Suns Win Series
description: Walter Davis scored 30 points and Dennis Johnson 26 tonight as they led the Phoenix Suns to a 124-119 victory over the Denver Nuggets in the third and deciding game of their opening-round playoff series. Phoenix will play the Los Angeles Lakers, who drew a bye in the opening round, in a four-of-seven-game Western Conference semifinal series that will begin Tuesday night in Los Angeles.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
FRIENDS FOR 200 YEARS
description: True friendship needs no ceremony, William Shakespeare once observed, but public displays of affection on suitable occasions can serve to reinforce the ties that bind. The United States and the Netherlands are dramatizing that point as they celebrate the 200th anniversary of their friendly diplomatic relationship, and numismatic items figure prominently in the observance.

title: Martha S. Mihaly Is Bride Of James Manning Black
description: Martha Sue Mihaly, daughter of Mrs. Mary Mihaly of Roanoke, Va., was married yesterday to James Manning Black, son of Prof. and Mrs. Cyril E. Black of Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Henry B. Luffberry performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Lutheran Church in Washington.

title: Nets Facing Many Decisions
description: Not long ago, Coach Larry Brown was eating shrimp in a Boston restaurant while digesting the season. His New Jersey Nets were in a furious race for a berth in the National Basketball Association playoffs.

title: KINGS PARK
description: ON March 2, the Kings Park, L.I., school board voted to close one ofi ts four elementary schools, signaling a new phase in the history of t he small North Shore village.

title: Prospects
description: The Price of Deflation

title: BONN PARTY'S FISCAL PLAN MAY SHAKE COALITION
description: West Germany's stubborn recession emerged as a major issue at the Social Democratic Party's five-day convention here this week.

title: Deirdre Kelly Will Be Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henry Arthur Kelly of Southport, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deirdre Claire Kelly to Michael Dent Moore, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Maxwell Moore of Fairfield, Conn.

title: Television Week
description: Back to Basics What is classical animation? According to Don Bluth, a former Disney Studios animator, it's what the old Disney Studios produced: ''A style of animation that allows you to watch without becoming tired from a profusion of bright colors and that has no extremely wiggly lines which you can't really believe in.''

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: In a poll of National Football League players, Lawrence Taylor of the Giants was named the National Conference rookie and linebacker of the year. He was honored Friday at the annual National Football League Players Association charity awards dinner in Washington.

title: Peking Establishes a Society To Study Social Psychology
description: PEKING. April 24 (Reuters) - China established a society today for the study of social psychology, like most social sciences a subject banned as bourgeois during the Cultural Revolution.

title:
TV VIEW;
INGRID BERGMAN'S GOLDA MEIR--A REMARKABLE PORTRAYAL
description: Film biographies are notoriously celebratory. There is the occasional exception - for instance, the gory portrait of Idi Amin currently being shown in movie theaters. But the average product, especially on television, runs to carefully calculated inspirational drama, from ''The Missiles of October,'' with its hero-worship portraits of John and Robert Kennedy, to ''Ike,'' with its macho depiction of a tough Dwight D. Eisenhower, played by Robert Duvall, of all people.

title: A LOOK AT JAPAN CHANGED HIS LIFE
description: WHEN William Pickens 3d, fresh out of the University of Vermont in 1958 with a Bachelor of Arts degree and a Reserve Officers Training Corps commission as a second lieutenant, finished his initial training on active duty and prepared to ship out, two destinations confronted him: ''It came down to a choice of Japan or Biloxi for me.''

title: STORIES OF TRADITION AND TODAY
description: TWO TRUTHS IN MY POCKET By Lois Ruby. 137 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $9.95. (Ages 12 and Up) By JOHANNA KAPLAN

title: SCIENTISTS FOCUS ON PINELANDS
description: CHERRY HILL ATEAM of 30 government and academic scientists, some from as far away as California, made recommendations at meetings here last week that could substantially influence development in the Pine Barrens, the country's first National Reserve.

title: HOSPITAL ZONING AND THE 'DOMINO EFFECT'
description: MANHASSET THE curtain will rise this week on another act in a drama whose plot illustrates the complications of land-use decision-making on the Island.

title: THE VILLAGE IMPROPER
description: ILIVE within the city limits of Yonkers - actually, right on the edge of its boundary line. However, because of my close proximity to another village and because our mail is routed through that village's post office, our mailing address bears the name and zip code of a very affluent, small southern Westchester town.

title: Topics Modern Times
description: Upscale Gum

title: A FEW WORDS ON CHOOSING YOUR DICTIONARY
description: When you set off on a college education, of course a general dictionary should go along. But which one? Here are some pointers to help you choose.

title: METS ENDURE ON RUN IN 7TH, 1-0
description: ''It's just incredible, these one-run games,'' Manager George Bamberger said today after the Mets had played a onerun game for the eighth time this season and the fifth straight time against the Expos. The Mets won this one, 1-0, on a seventh-inning double by John Stearns that scored Gary Rajsich.

title: Business Conditions; SERVICE STATION SQUEEZE
description: With consumption and prices falling at the same time, gasoline service stations are finding themselves in an increasingly difficult situation. Last month, filling station sales declined 8.4 percent from February levels, to a seasonally adjusted $7.7 billion.

title: NEW HOPE FOR THE ABANDONED TENANT
description: SUDDENLY, your rent check is going to the city instead of your l andlord. It's not that the building is so bad, but financing costs a nd soaring fuel bills cut the landlord's chances for a profit and h e abandoned his building to the city.

title: YONKERS COMPANY PLANS EXPANSION
description: Yonkers The Excelsior Transparent Bag Corporation, a large packaging concern on the Hudson here that began more than 40 years ago in a two-car garage, is embarking on a $1.2 million expansion project.

title: CONSUMER RATES
by Glenn Seaborg
description: CONTROLLING THE BOMB Nuclear Proliferation in the 1980s.A Twentieth Century Fund Report. by Lewis A. Dunn. 209pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. Cloth, $21. Paper, $695.

title: THE CALM WATERS OF ANNAPOLIS
description: FRANCIS X. CLINES is a correspondent in the Washington bureau of The Times. By FRANCIS X.CLINES

title: Carol A. Rooney, James Flanagan Will Be Married
description: Mr. and Mrs. Francis Charles Rooney Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carol Anne Rooney, to James Michael Flanagan, son of Mrs. John Joseph Flanagan of New Vernon, N.J., and Cotuit, Mass., and the late Mr. Flanagan.

title: FACTORY OUTLETS: BARGAINS TO BOOT
description: BURLINGTON THEY step off the buses in a steady stream, people with pockets full of cash and empty shopping bags. Many have traveled 100 miles or more - the buses come from Virginia, Washington and upstate New York - and for many it is the third or fourth trip.

title: Business Conditions; GROWTH IN ADVERTISING
description: Gross income from advertising revenues rose 23 percent worldwide last year from 1980 levels, to $3.9 billion on billings of $14.8 billion, in spite of a worsening recession in Europe and large currency devaluations in Latin America, according to a recent survey of international conditions conducted by Advertising Age, the trade publication. The survey, which is conducted annually, includes figures from more than 800 advertising agencies in 72 countries.

title: Sports People; Second Thoughts
description: Since Southern California football was placed on three years' probation by the National Collegiate Athletic Association Friday, one of its top recruits was having second thoughts about a letter of intent he signed to attend the school. James FitzPatrick, a lineman at Beaverton (Ore.)

title: A ROMANTIC AT THE KEYBOARD
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Allan Kozinn writes frequently about music and musicians. BY ALLAN KOZINN

title: JERUSALEM, HOLY CITY OF ISLAM
description: SARI NUSEIBEH, who lives in the Old City of Jerusalem, is a professor of philosophy at Bir Zeit University on the West Bank. By SARI NUSEIBEH

title: BUSINESS STUDENTS GO ABROAD
description: block manufacturing business, begun by her great-grandfather. ''Americans have traditionally been ignorant of foreign cultures and business customs,'' she said. ''I think this has affected our business success.''

title: Two of A Kind
description: As the mother of fraternal twin girls, now 27 years old, I must admit the first few months were overwhelming (''Bringing Up Two of a Kind,'' by Kay Mussell, March 14).

title: 11TH HOUR FOR THE BUDGET MAY LAST A LONG TIME
description: For a month now, rank-and-file members of Congress have been in the odd position of restaurant patrons waiting for the chefs to finish haggling over the dinner menu. Last week, negotiators for the White House and the Congressional leadership appeared to be narrowing their differences on ways to revise President Reagan's 1983 budget. But it remained unclear whether Congress had the stomach for the three-year, $425 billion plate being readied for its table.

title: PIANIST FINDS OUTLET IN OTHER ART FORMS
description: Artistic people are often blessed with multiple talents," said Nicholas Flagello of White Plains. "They then enrich their major occupations by enjoying the release of practicing another art form." The American-born concert pianist, conductor and composer also holds doctorates in music and in psychology and is a painter.

title: A PASSENGER REACTS TO A DEATH ON THE TRACKS
description: ONE night recently, the Conrail train in which I was riding -the 6:20 Croton-Harmon out of Grand Central - ran over someone somewhere between stations in the Bronx.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: DOBBS FERRY UNTIL now, Radio Station WDFH - 91.3 FM - lacked one major element: listeners. Broadcast from an upstairs bedroom of a small, Tudor-style house on Brookside Lane here, it reached on its ultralow power only the handful of individuals who happened to tune in from within a half-mile radius. Recently, though, that changed, when WDFH made its move into substantially larger territory, if not the big time.

title: About Books and Authors; Gobbledygook and Mangled Syntax
description: THE AMERICAN BOOK AWARDS ceremony at Carnegie Hall this Tuesday will be less suspenseful than usual, because for the first time the winners have been announced in advance. And the ceremony is almost certain to be more low-key than in some years past, 1974 for example, when a streaker (remember them?) enlivened the proceedings by racing through Alice Tully Hall at Lincoln Center shouting, ''Read books! Read books!'' and the poet Peter Orlovsky, in accepting Allen Ginsberg's award for poetry, read a lengthy denunciation of American Government policy by Mr. Ginsberg.

title: Betsy Callicott and William Goodell, Lawyers, Will Be Married on June 19
description: Betsy Mercer Callicott and William Rice Goodell, 1980 graduates of the Washington and Lee University School of Law, plan to be married June 19 at the Whitehaven Presbyterian Church in Memphis.

title: A POLITICAL EDUCATION
description: THE KESTREL By Lloyd Alexander. 244 pp. New York: E.P. Dutton. $10.95. (Ages 10 to 14) By GEORGESS McHARGUE

title: COMPUTER SCHOOLS MULTIPLY
description: AT the Children's Computer School on Manhattan's West Side, Caleb is the only pupil in attendance on a rainy, windy Saturday afternoon. Wearing his cowboy T-shirt, jeans and scuffed sneakers, he is 10 years old, the average starting age at the school.

title: TREATING YOUTH CONFIDENTIALLY
description: WOODMERE ''I'M here for birth control,'' she said, ''because of a recent extremely upsetting incident. My friend had to have a pregnancy test. No, my parents don't know I am here - basically because I don't really talk to them.''

title: Right to Liberty
description: ''People can commit rapes and murders and be let out of jail in 10 or 15 years. Here's a guy who steals six candy bars, and he spends 35 years imprisoned.''

title: RED SOX DEFEAT BLUE JAYS, 8-7
description: Carl Yastrzemski capped a five-run fifth inning today with a three-run homer, the 430th of his career, to lead the Boston Red Sox to an 8-7 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays.

title: A VIRGIN ISLAND OF THEIR OWN
description: acre dot on the map of the Sir Francis Drake Channel between the Atlantic Ocean and the Caribbean Sea, but to the Tonkonogys, who divide their ''mainland'' time between two other islands, Manhattan and Long Island, the lush, volcanic tropical isle represents every romantic notion that Mr. Tonkonogy ever acquired in his youth.

title: TOO MANY STYLES ENCIRCLE 'THE FIGURE'
description: GARDEN CITY ALTHOUGH it is no longer in the firehouse, the gallery at Nassau Community College has kept the name of its first home. The Firehouse Gallery's new quarters, in a robin's-egg-blue building on the south campus, functions better as an exhibition space, with fabric-covered panels and track lighting to enable a more professional-looking presentation.

title: Key West, in Protest On Aliens, 'Secedes'
description: Residents of Key West, angry at the Federal Government for what they called its cumbersome efforts to control illegal immigration, ''seceded'' from the United States Friday and briefly established ''The Conch Republic.''

title: THE NUCLEAR DEBATE: ADDITIONAL VIEWS
description: Samuel Korman, in his letter to the editor on ''The Nuclear Debate Goes On,'' states that it ''presented some cogent arguments opposing nuclear power, but they did not take issue with one of the major points made by Herbert Jaffe ... that an overwhelming number of scientists supported nuclear power.''

title: Business Conditions; MANUFACTURING GLOOM
description: So far, continued health in the nation's service sector has prevented the current recession from surpassing its two most recent predecessors in depth or duration. According to the Bureau of Economic Analysis, real output has fallen 2.1 percent in the downturn that began last July, compared with a decline of 2.6 percent during the short but steep recession of 1980 and a 4.8 percent drop during the five-quarter decline of 1974-1975.

title:
GARDENING;
WHAT TO PLANT, ANNUALS OR PERENNIALS?
description: SOME disagreement exists among flower enthusiasts as to which requires the least work to grow, annuals or perennials. Those who champion perennials point out that they do not require replanting each year as do annuals and insist that that alone is sufficient backing for their argument.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
CHIMPS AND MUSIC
description: Dr. Jane Goodall, the anthropologist who won fame with her television studies of chimpanzees, will be at C.W. Post Center's Concert Theater today to discuss these creatures ''In the Shadow of Man.'' Accompanied by recent slides and new film, the lecture is at 4 P.M. and tickets are $8.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: PRESENT and former inmates at the Hudson County Jail are disputing the official version, given by the County Prosecutor, of the fire in which seven inmates died two weeks ago, according to Howard Moskowitz, a lawyer for the American Civil Liberties Union.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Prepayment for Medicare Bills?
description: Apparently responding to the Administration's pressure to cut health-care costs, the American Hospital Association last week proposed a ''prospective reimbursement'' system of payments for Medicare, the Federal health insurance program for the elderly and some disabled.

title: Letters; On Landmarking
description: To the Editor:$

title: Padres 6, Braves 4
description: ATLANTA (UPI) - Gene Richards and Juan Bonilla raced home on a throwing error by the Atlanta pitcher, Rick Camp, in a four-run, eighth inning outburst as San Diego won its 10th straight.

title: THE MAN WHO'LL BE THE FIRST SELECTION
description: Long before Ron Meyer was hired as the head coach last Jan. 15, the decision had been made in the New England Patroits' front office. Ken Sims would be the team's first choice in this year's draft. Because the Patriots hold the No.1 selection this year, Sims will be the first of 334 players chosen on Tuesday when the National Football League's annual selection process of the best college seniors begins.

title: LOW PRIORITY IS PUT ON THE DEFENSE OF SOUTH GEORGIA
description: The Argentine military command appears to have abandoned the idea of staging a serious defense of South Georgia, a distant, glacier-covered dependency of the Falkland Islands.

title: Mary K. Johnston, C. V. Jordan Wed
description: Mary Kathryn Johnston and Charles V. Jordan were married yesterday in the garden at the home of the bride's grandmother, Mrs. James E. Gibson, in Winston-Salem, N.C. The Rev. Charles E. Shannon, a Methodist minister, and the Rev. Francis Ellsinghorst, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: BELONS: A BRETON GIFT
description: FRED FERRETTI is a reporter for The New York Times. By FRED FERRETTI

title: SCHOOLS ENTER THE COMPUTER AGE
description: LAST fall Dan McKechnie, a 26-year-old teacher in Irvine, Calif., took out a personal loan of $15,000 to buy his sixth-graders two computer keyboards, six monitors, one printer, two disk drives and $10,000 worth of software. Now Mr. McKechnie moonlights as a video producer to pay back his loan.

title: NEW HAVEN'S 'AMALFITANIS' KEEP TIES TO ITALY
description: ''This was one of my Dad's favorite pictures,'' Agnes Laudano said. She was holding a large, framed photograph of a monk sitting beneath the arbor of a hotel. ''Dad died at 96 and had this as a memento. He was born there.''

title: Future Events From Art to Zippers
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.. A Ducal Treat April 28 - The Duke and Duchess of Roxburghe and the Duke and Duchess of Wellington will grace the Victorian tea dance that B. Altman & Company is giving on its furniture floor to introduce the Baker Furniture collection of reproductions from the stately homes of England and Scotland. The Roxburghes will feel right at home, with reproductions of five pieces from their castle on display. The party, from 6:30 to 8:30 P.M., will benefit the Victorian Society Scholarship Fund. Tickets, $75 each, $125 a pair, from 620-2418.

title: TIGERS BEAT YANKEES, 7-2
description: The Detroit Tigers, the hottest team in the American League, staged a multifaceted show at Yankee Stadium yesterday. They unleashed a three-homer barrage against Doyle Alexander, and they punctuated their 7-2 victory over the Yankees with an incident involving their manager and their star player that was reminiscent of the Reggie Jackson-Billy Martin drama in Boston five years ago.

title: GUIDELINES FOR LEADING A CHILD INTO THE WONDERS OF SPEECH
description: THE study of normal language development became a science barely two decades ago, but already investigators have a deep perception of what happens as children learn to talk. The dominant role in teaching the child is played by the parent.

title: HARLEM YOUTH PROGRAM SEEKS TO GROOM LEADERS
description: Every Wednesday after closing hours, the Chemical Bank branch at 124 West 125th Street in Harlem opens its doors to young people from 10 to 17 years old who want to transact business.

title: BY STUART TAYLOR
description: When John W. Hinckley Jr. goes on trial Tuesday for shooting President Reagan and three other men, the "insanity defense" will, in a sense, go on trial with him.

title: Umpire Misses Game
description: Bill Haller, an umpire who was injured in a collision at home plate Friday night, missed the game yesterday between the Detroit Tigers and the Yankees.

title: Television Week
description: Depicting Golda ''We prevailed in the thick of all kinds of things,'' said Alan Gibson, director of the two-part television film ''A Woman Called Golda,'' the story of Golda Meir, the late Israeli Prime Minister. A reluctant Ingrid Bergman had to be convinced that she was ''perfect'' for the title role, Mr. Gibson said.

title: Two South African Soldiers Are Captured in Zimbabwe
description: Two white South African soldiers wanted in connection with a murder in South-West Africa have been captured trying to enter Zimbabwe, Minister of State Emmerson Munangagwa said today.

title: PIER AREA ON WEST SIDE CALLED VITAL TO SURVIVAL OF STRIPED BASS
description: For reasons that lie partly in temperature conditions and food availability and partly in the unknowns of a life process that requires more study, the striped bass that play an important role in the lucrative North Atlantic fishing ground are believed to need the pier-line area along Manhattan's West Side to survive the winters in the first year or two of life.

title: RUTGERS MOUNTING A HUMMEL FESTIVAL
description: NEWARK IN A musical celebration of international importance, Rutgers-Newark is mounting a festival of works by Johann Nepomuk Hummel, a student of Mozart's who lived from 1778 to 1837.

title: THE ART OF TEACHING SCIENCE
description: The reason why science is ''the shrewdest maneuver for discovering how the world works'' is that it is essentially Darwinian. It constructs new understanding on a growing and experimentally refined foundation of earlier experience, ''the so-called basics.''

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Cargo Is Cargo, Says the Court
description: In two cases last week, the Supreme Court reaffirmed old principles by not making new distinctions. The Justices decided unanimously that the International Longshoremen's Association violated Federal labor law when it refused to handle Soviet cargo protesting the Soviet Union's invasion in Afghanistan.

title: SUMMING UP
description: Copyright c Theodore H. White. This article is excerpted from Theodore H. White's ''America in Search of Itself: The Making of the President, 1956-1980,'' which will be published next month by Harper & Row. A Cornelia and Michael Bessie Book.

title: PACT STRIPS CONVICTS IN TEXAS OF SUPERVISORY POWER
description: Prisoners in Texas will be stripped of supervisory control over other convicts and more guards will be hired to handle the job under an agreement announced in Federal District Court.

title: CHINESE ARMY'S QUEST FOR EGGS CREATES ECOLOGICAL NIGHTMARE
description: From a cluster of bleak islands in the South China Sea comes word of a beleaguered unit of Chinese soldiers locked in bitter ecological combat over a flock of chickens.

title: URGENT TALKS HELD BY BRITISH CABINET ON FALKLAND CRISIS
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's select crisis Cabinet Saturday night held its longest meeting since the Argentine invasion of the Falkland Islands, after the return of Foreign Secretary Francis Pym from two days of talks in Washington.

title: Secrecy Upheld in Deal Related to Bank's Close
description: An appellate court has rejected the use of the Freedom of Information Act to make public a settlement related to the closing of the Franklin National Bank.

title: India's Satellite Is Repaired
description: Engineers have successfully corrected a malfunctioning communications antenna aboard India's first operational satellite, launched here April 10. The $130 million weather and communications satellite, Insat 1, developed antenna problems the day after it went into orbit. Without the antenna, it would have been almost useless.

title: Around the Nation; Inspector Saw Trouble Before Bridge's Collapse
description: A Federal inspector has said he became uneasy about how a highway ramp here was being built a month before it collapsed, killing 12 workers.

title: Armed Bandits in India Rob Train Passengers of $100,000
description: Armed bandits robbed passengers on an express train today of at least $100,000 in cash and valuables, railroad authorities said.

title: Sports People; Stepien Sues Paper
description: Ted Stepien, owner of the Cleveland Cavaliers of the National Basketball Association, has filed a $2 million lawsuit against The Cleveland Press and a reporter, Doug Clarke, who recently wrote a column that Stepien says was false and defamatory.

title: PATTERN OF SUMMER SHARING IS CHANGING
description: IMPELLED by the rising cost of summer rentals, many people who neverw ould have considered sharing a house are finding that they enjoy it.A mong them are older couples, single parents with children and e stablished professionals and business people, both singles and c ouples.

title: THE COMPLETE ILLUSTRATOR
description: ANNO'S BRITAIN By Mitsumasa Anno. Illustrated. Unpaged. New York: Philomel Books. $10.95.

title: PHYSIOLOGY OF GETTING HOOKED ON JINGLES
description: To the Editor:

title: HOW TO CHANGE THE PAST
description: CONTROL By William Goldman. 305 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $15.95. By EVAN HUNTER

title: Ugandan Stops Foe in 3d
description: There was no way a gentleman could refuse such warm invitations. So Cornelius Boza-Edwards, the polite boxer, obliged Johnny Verderosa's wide-open chin by knocking him out today. The end for Verderosa, the previously undefeated United States Boxing Association junior lightweight champion, came at 1 minute 38 seconds of the third round.

title: BOOKS GOOD FOR LOOKING
description: IN deciding whether to purchase a given book, readers seldom ask themselves, ''Would I go back to read this volume again and again?'' But somehow we all tend to make stiff demands of picture books; we ask not simply that they entertain us once (most can), but that they promise pleasure in frequent rereadings. That's where so many of the current crop fall down.

title:
THE CAREFUL SHOPPER;
Shop Opens New Outlet Across the Street
description: Just looking has been in Katonah for 15 years, but about two months ago its sister store, Just Looking Too, opened diagonally across the street in a shop four times the size of the original. The new store incorporates the original store's shoe department - including purses and briefcases - and the lingerie department. Everyting is discounted 20 to 40 percent, with periodic 50 percent markdowns on special promotions.

title: MADRID'S FLEA MARKET
description: ROBERT PACKARD is a writer who lives in New York. By ROBERT PACKARD

title: INFLATION WIPED OUT GAINS IN EARNINGS IN 70'S
description: Inflation wiped out virtually all the gains that American families achieved through higher earnings in the 1970's, while the distribution of income became slightly more unequal, according to the Census Bureau.

title: MIDWIVES SEEK GREATER ROLE
description: AS THEY marked National Nurse-Midwifery Week with exhibits and educational programs last week, New Jersey's certified nurse-midwives were still seeking a larger role in the state's health-care system.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: NATIONAL DEFENSE, by James Fallows. (Vintage, $4.95.) In what our reviewer Martin F. Nolan described as ''spare, controlled prose unencumbered by liberal cant,'' The Atlantic Monthly's Washington correspondent, James Fallows, analyzes the shortcomings of our defense system, shows the technical, bureaucratic and often psychologial sources of these shortcomings and proposes options to reflect the domestic and international realities of the 80's. ''Prudent soldiers and thoughtful citizens,'' Mr. Nolan said, ''should arm themselves with a copy.''

title: TACTICS AND STRATEGY IN HOUSING
description: THE New Jersey Supreme Court, in its recent decisions in the Mount Laurel and Oakwood at Madison cases, has issued a clarion call to major landowners, developers and public-interest groups to institute litigation against local land-use ordinances in the name of affordable housing.

title: Reagan to Address Chamber
description: President Reagan will speak to the United States Chamber of Commerce at its annual meeting Monday morning at Constitution Hall, the White House announced Thursday. Asked to describe the subject of Mr. Reagan's speech, Larry Speakes, a White House spokesman, said the President would ''tell them how it is.''

title: MOYNIHAN DECLARES FOR SECOND TERM
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan announced his candidacy for a second term yesterday, declaring that his polls show him to be the ''most approved-of public figure in the State of New York.''

title: Pirates 8, Cubs 5
description: CHICAGO (AP) - Dave Parker's run-scoring double keyed a two-run seventh inning that helped Pittsburgh overcome a five-run deficit. The Pirates broke through for three runs in the fifth, added another in the sixth on Dale Berra's first homer and finally went ahead in the seventh.

title: Catharine Stevenson Is Bride of Jeffrey C. Sturgess
description: Catharine Morley Stevenson, director of equity investments at the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York, was married yesterday to Jeffrey Charles Sturgess, director of retail marketing at Actmedia Inc., an advertising sales company in New York. The Rev. W. Chave McCracken performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Cleveland Heights, Ohio.

title: CAMPUS NARCISSISM AND LOST VISION
description: WALKING through a suburban high school or college campus in Connecticut, one notices two rather large subgroups among the students - the cowboy and the preppy.

title: AMERICAN PL EIADE
description: WALT WHITMAN Complete Poetry and Collected Prose. ''Leaves of Grass'' (1855). ''Leaves of Grass'' (1891-92). ''Complete Prose Works'' (1892). Supplementary Prose. Edited by Justin Kaplan. 1,380 pp.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; 400 More Cases On Rely Tampons
description: Deciding who won last week in a product liability case involving Rely tampons depended on your point of view. Michael Kehm said he won, since a Federal jury in Iowa held Procter & Gamble liable for the death from toxic shock syndrome of his wife, Patricia, a Rely user, and awarded him $300,000 in damages. Mr. Kehm traced his wife's death to Procter & Gamble's continued promotion of Rely, despite evidence in the summer of 1980 linking it to toxic shock.

title: SHE SHELVES SEASHELLS
description: WHENEVER Lynn Nathansen was sick as a child, her mother would take an old wooden box out of the closet. The box was filled with shells from the South Pacific.

title: The Nation in Summary; THe Buck Stops There
description: After months of silence, the United States Supreme Court announced last week that it would decide whether racially discriminatory private schools are entitled to Federal tax exemptions, and appointed William T. Coleman Jr., former Secretary of Transportation and a prominent Washington lawyer, to argue a legal position abandoned by the White House.

title: On the Waterfront
description: To the Editor:

title: WELCOME AND INVITING CHANGES
description: RIDGEFIELD OVER the years, the quality of dining at The Inn at Ridgefield has been something of a roller coaster ride, full of ups and downs. It is a pleasure to be able to report that currently The Inn is on an upward curve, a welcome change from just two or three years ago. A change in personnel occurred two years ago and the current chef, Raymond Peron, knows what he is doing. This shows in most appetizers, many entrees and all desserts.

title: Cordelia Robb Bride of John R. Fell Jr.
description: Cordelia Reid Robb and John Ruckman Fell Jr. were married in Mill Neck, L.I., yesterday at the home of Mrs. Cornelius J. Reid, mother of the bride. The Rev. Bruce A. Rodgers of St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church performed the ceremony.

title: Anne Thompson Wed to Steve Kunin
description: Anne Thompson, daughter of Margaret K. Thompson of Pleasantville, N.Y., and Edward T. Thompson of Bedford, N.Y., was married yesterday to Steve Kunin, son of Ralph Kunin of Los Angeles, and the late Sylvia Kunin. The Rev. Sydney Wilde-Nugent, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at the Cosmos Club in Washington.

title: CONCERN OVER CULTS PROMPTS PROGRAM
description: A growing concern about the activities of cult groups has prompted organizations in the state and in the county to stress the need for informational efforts directed toward parents, students and professionals in the field of social welfare. At least five programs have been scheduled for the next month at three different sites in the county.

title: ANNA SOKOLOW IS 'NOW'
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Aaron Cohen is a freelance writer with a special interest in dance BY AARON COHEN

title: 'MALOU,' BY JANNINE MEERAPFEL
description: The values of ''Malou,'' the first feature to be written and directed by Jeanine Meerapfel, a German film maker, reveal themselves unexpectedly, much like those of a friendship with someone who initially seems demanding and self-centered but whose genuine decency and intelligence become evident with time. The film will be shown today at the Festival Theater at 8:30 P.M. and tomorrow at 6 P.M. in the New Directors/New Films series.

title: Prentice-Hall
description: To the Business Editor: I read with interest ''Cradle to Grave With Prentice-Hall'' (April 4). For two years I worked as an editor at one of the ''three small book subsidiaries'' that the publisher sold in 1981 - Winthrop Publishers Inc., a publisher of college textbooks in Cambridge, Mass.

title: A FLAVOR THAT'S 'SOUTHERN ITALIAN'
description: COULD you guess that Villa D'Ric in Syosset is an Italian restaurant? The word ''villa'' is the clue. ''D'ric'' is more difficult to place. It might be Esperanto. Actually, it is a composite of the first names of the owners, Dominic and Ricky.

title: BRIDGEPORT ANGLERS FEAR PIER'S DEMISE
description: BRIDGEPORT EVERY morning at 7, Skirmantas Rastas turns his 1974 Dodge off Exit 29 from the Connecticut Turnpike onto Seaview Avenue and follows the signs to what was once an amusement center in the east end of this old factory town.

title: FATE OF AREA REPRESENTATIVES AWAITS REDISTRICTING OUTCOME
description: WASHINGTON EVERYONE is running, but no one knows where. Everyone knows when, but no one knows against whom. The rules are clear but the boundaries are not.

title: Headliners; Executive Suite
description: Knowing glances were passed last week when it was announced that Mary E. Cunningham, an executive for Joseph E. Seagram & Son Inc., and William M. Agee, chairman of the Bendix Corporation, plan to marry.

title: CRITICS OF AID TO SALVADORANS PLAN NEW FIGHT
description: Congressional critics of continued military aid to El Salvador say that after Thursday's victory by rightists in the newly elected Salvadoran Constituent Assembly, they will renew their efforts to tie the aid to an end to the Salvadoran civil war.

title:
DEBUTS IN REVIEW;
Kathryn Master, Era Trio and Laura Oltman
description: Works of the 20th century were featured with varying degrees of frequency and success on three programs at Carnegie Recital Hall during the past week; all three marked the New York recital debuts of the participants.

title: NEGOTIATIONS ON SALE OF NEWS STALEMATED AS DEADLINE NEARS
description: Negotiations for the sale of The Daily News remained stalemated yesterday. ''There's absolutely no movement whatsoever, behind the scenes or in front of the scenes,'' said Theodore W. Kheel, adviser to the paper's 11 unions.

title: TOY THERAPY, SWEDISH STYLE
description: EVANSTON, Ill. IN a simple storefront here reposes an inventory of very special toys: puzzles, for example, with large wooden handles on each piece for those who have difficulty moving their hands; a wooden cart that cannot be overturned, for children who cannot walk without support; a large soft, spongy ball with a beeper in it for those who could not tell where it was if they could not hear it.

title: HAIG SAID TO BE CONVINCED BRITAIN WILL USE FORCE IF NEGOTIATIONS FAIL
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. was reported today to be convinced that Britain would use military force in the next few days if there was no progress in his new talks with Argentine officials on the Falkland Island crisis.

title: HAWAIIANS TRY TO STOP SHELLING OF SACRED ISLAND
description: Native Hawaiians who have been trying for years to halt the bombing of the island of Kahoolawe have been joined by Greenpeace, an environmental organization, in protests against a five-nation military exercise centered on the island.

title: Foreign Affairs; ISRAEL'S JOYLESS PEACE
description: The eve of Israel's second full withdrawal from Sinai, this time in peace with Egypt, is a moment of questions without answers. The simple, almost apologetic ceremonies scheduled Sunday are a symbol of the wary uncertainty.

title: Best Films on TV
description: 'In Old Chicago' This is a big, booming eyeful of Americana with the frontier thrust of an emerging metropolis, a viable plot about politics and the love of a rogue and a singer, and a disaster spectacle of a finale. ''In Old Chicago'' (1938), an immensely entertaining movie, will be broadcast Thursday at midnight on Channel 9.

title: GIVER NOT TAKER OFF-LIMITS
description: HARTFORD ON the surface, Connecticut has gone beyond some other states in identifying and restricting the lobbyists who flock to the State Capitol each day the General Assembly is in session.

title: THEATER PATRONS AND WHAT THEY WANT
description: The recent letter in your section from John Curran expressing his lack of sympathy about the closing of the Main Street Theater arouses conflicting emotions in me; I operate The Theatre Place in Pleasantville. We are a dinner theater, and we offer mostly the tried and true. But this is not because we choose to. It is because the audience for what he calls "new, innovative" and risk-taking theater is small - frighteningly small, I might add. For every Mr. Curran, there are hundreds and hundreds of theater patrons who want what they know. Is that really bad?

title: TAKING UP WHERE JANE AUSTEN LEFT OFF
description: THE SEMI-ATTACHED COUPLE AND THE SEMI-DETACHED HOUSE By Emily Eden. 543 pp. New York: Virago Modern Classics/The Dial Press. $7.95. By PHYLLIS ROSE

title: The Nuclear Debate: Additional Views
description: Both sides of the nuclear power controversy have been hurling numbers at each other on the Long Island Opinion page. Miriam Goodman, after her numbers were shot down by Anthony Fainberg, aimed a salvo of 2,970,000 curies at me. That number, she says, is the number of curies of radiation released by Connecticut's Millstone No. 1; the largest release of nuclear radiation on record in the United States before the Three Mile Island accident.

title: AN ISSUE OF LITERACY
description: WITH the introduction of low-cost microcomputers, the growth of educational software and a grass-roots demand among parents, students and administrators for computer education, thousands of schools throughout the United States have purchased computers and designed curricula to help students become ''computer literate.'' But for many in the educational community, the term ''computer literacy'' is still a hazy cognitive challenge, a term clouded not only by classroom inexperience with computers, but also by a continuing debate about what constitutes an appropriate standard for those skills.

title: News Summary; News Summary; SUNDAY, APRIL 25, 1982
description: International The British Cabinet was summoned to an urgent meeting by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher after the return of Foreign Secretary Francis Pym from talks in Washington with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. over the Falkland Islands. Despite Mr. Pym's report of a ''bit of progress,'' British officials cautioned that Britain and Argentina were still far apart from a negotiated solution to the crisis. A warning, which was communicated privately to Argentine officials through the Swiss Embassy in Buenos Aires, was issued to all Argentine ships and planes by the British Defense Ministry to stay away from the British fleet in the South Atlantic or risk an ''appropriate response.'' (Page 1, Column 6.) U.S. failure in mediating the crisis over the Falklands would result in American support of Britain, Reagan Administration officials said. They stressed that this was the consensus in the White House and State Department, but that President Reagan had made no formal decision and had set no time limit for breaking the deadlock. Officials said the support would include United States participation in an embargo on Argentine goods, but would not include use of American military forces. (1:4-5.)

title: CHINA UNLEASES A CAPITALIST TOOL
description: When Pepsi-Cola's bottling franchise in Hong Kong shut down last year, the corporation looked at the cheaper wages, rents and taxes just across the border in China and decided to spend $5.5 million to relocate here.

title: FOOD
description: GRINDING IT OUT

title: Yale Crew Wins Cup
description: Yale's heavyweight crews won four of the five races on the Harlem River yesterday, including the featured varsity Blackwell Cup event, in a triangular regatta with the University of Pennsylvania and Columbia.

title: JOB JITTERS: CAMPUS AILMENT OF THE 80's
description: LAST fall I was stricken with a strange illness. These are the earliest symptoms I noticed: - During an art history exam, I could not recall the name of ''The Scream,'' Edvard Munch's painting of a lone, terrified man. I called it ''Ten Minutes Till the Job Interview.''

title: Brewers 4, Rangers 1
description: Pete Vuckovich hurled a three-hitter and Roy Howell slugged a two-run homer to lead Milwaukee.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: THE State Senate last week passed and sent to Governor O'Neill a $3.19 billion budget for the 1982-83 fiscal year beginning July 1. Debate was relatively quiet, although Republicans, led by Senator Philip S. Robertson of Cheshire, attempted to reduce spending, repeal the unpopular unincorporated business tax and also repeal the levy on oil companies that operate in Connecticut, which was approved in 1980.

title: ELDERLY TAKE TO CAMPS
description: ''EVERY room faces the sky, and in the summertime the trees are just all over the place,'' says Gloria Stone, a 73-year-old legal secretary from Manhattan. ''I call this my country home.'' Although she has traveled throughout the United States and Europe, for the last three summers she has returned to Star Lake Lodge in Bloomingdale, N.J., near Paterson.

title: The Region in Summary; Is There Life Beyond Limbo?
description: The on-again, off-again negotiations to save The Daily News were on-again and off-again last week, leaving the nation's largest general interest newspaper and 4,000-plus employees facing perhaps the final deadline.

title: LOW-KEY CEREMONIES SET FOR SINAI TRANSFER TODAY
description: The Government of President Hosni Mubarak today predicted a smooth final withdrawal of Israel's presence in Sinai Sunday as Egypt's black, white and red flag is raised at Rafa, in northern Sinai, and at Sharm el Sheik on the peninsula's southern tip.

title: PIECES SACRED AND SECULAR
description: A TREASURY OF JEWISH LITERATURE From Biblical Times to Today. Edited by Gloria Goldreich. 243 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $13.50. (Ages 12 and Up) By SAUL MALOFF

title: ART SAMPLER
description: ONE of the stars of the recent juried exhibition at the Summit Art Center was Irmari Nacht, whose provocative entry was a series of jute- and sisal-wrapped cylinders with intriguing geometric designs on them.

title: TRACING THE STORY OF JEWISH PIONEERS IN 'THESE LITTLE VILLAGES'
description: RIVERHEAD AT the turn of the century there were several hundred Jews living in eastern Long Island. Following the same routes taken by other immigrant groups who had left the crowded slums of New York in search of better lives among the Yankee Long Islanders, they toiled in small factories in Setauket and Sag Harbor; farmed in Moriches and Calverton; fished in Greenport, or traded in their peddler's packs for general stores.

title: CAN THE GOVERNMENT PROMOTE CREATIVITY-OR ONLY ARTISTS?
description: IF the White House has its way, one-third fewer Federal dollars will go to the arts in 1983 than two years ago. The Week in Review asked three experts - Daniel J. Boorstin, a historian and the Librarian of Congress, Arlene Goldbard, co-director of the Baltimore-based Neighborhood Arts Programs National Organizing Committee, and Frank Hodsoll, chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts - to talk about cultural policy. Excerpts of their discussion with Caroline Rand Herron, an editor of The Review, and Irvin Molotsky, an editor in the Washington bureau of The New York Times, follow.

title: KOCH AND CUOMO ASK TO BE LIBERAL PARTY NOMINEE
description: Each depicting himself as probable winner of a Democratic primary, two candidates for Governor of New York -Mayor Koch and Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo - asked the Liberal Party yesterday for its nomination.

title: 200 YEARS OF FINE POTTERY
description: STEVEN RATTNER is a correspondent in the London bureau of The New York Times. By STEVEN RATTNER

title: OPERA BUFFA: 'GIARDINIRA' AS WRITTEN
description: In composing ''La Finta Giardiniera,'' an opera buffa whose title means ''the pretend garden-maid,'' the 18-year-old Mozart had to deal with a libretto that ranks among the lamest farragos ever committed to print. That he handled the task triumphantly should surprise no one; what has stood in the opera's way for the last two centuries is the fact that the original score of the first act disappeared around the time the opera was recast as a German Singspiel, with spoken dialogue in place of the recitatives.

title: THE MAGICAL MYSTERY OF THE LIBERAL ARTS
description: AS a 9-year-old, I was introduced to a marvelously magical world when I began to study under a leading teacher of stage magic and sleight of hand. That childhood love of the mystery and entertainment surrounding the modern magician has not diminished in the heart of this college president four decades later.

title: NEW RITZ-CARLTON OFFERS LUXURY ON SMALLER SCALE
description: Two years ago, John Bennett Coleman purchased the 260-room Navarro Hotel on Central Park South for $15 million. By the time he is finished with its renovation, he will have put $25 million more into it. But, he says, it will have been worth every penny because, by September, he will have quietly transformed the stodgy, and largely ignored, Navarro into the new Ritz-Carlton Hotel.

title: April 25, 1982
description: NONFICTION A, B, SEE! By Tana Hoban. 38 THE ADVENTURES OF MARCO POLO. By Demi. 33 ALL THE COLORS OF THE RACE. By Arnold Adoff. 49 ANNO'S BRITAIN. By Mitsumasa Anno. 46 APRIL FOOL. By Mary Blount Christian. 42 THE BEDSPREAD. By Sylvia Fair. 38 BEN'S ABC DAY. By Terry Berger.48 BEN'S DREAM. By Chris Van Allsburg. 46 BIRDS. By Arnold Adoff. 37 THE BROOKLYN BRIDGE: They Said It Couldn't Be Built. By Judith St. George. 33 A CAT'S TALE. By Rikki Cate. 42 CHUCKIE. By Nicki Weiss. 48 COMMANDER TOAD AND THE PLANET OF THE GRAPES. By Jane Yolen. 45 THE DARKANGEL. By Meredith Ann Pierce. 35 DAYS ARE WHERE WE LIVE. Compiled by Jill Bennett. 37 EULALIE AND THE HOPPING HEAD. By David Small. 45 A FARMER'S DOZEN. By Sandra Joanne Russell. 48 THE FIRST TULIPS IN HOLLAND. By Phyllis Krasilovsky. 38 FOX AND HIS FRIENDS. By Edward Marshall. 42 THE GIRL IN THE GRASS. By David Roth. 44 GOOD AS NEW. By Barbara Douglass. 48 GOOD NIGHT, MR. TOM.

title: Paperback Talk
description: A matter of concern. During the week just past, two giants of Publishers Row have been zealously stuffing the racks with copies of two original paperbacks dealing with a subject that Americans in the past have shown a reluctance to read or even think about:

title: ISRAELI PRIEST TRYING TO CLOSE A RELIGIOUS GAP
description: "In the heart of every Christian who has read the New Testament and the bible there is a spontaneous tenderness for the Jewish people," said the Rev. Marcel J. Dubois, a Dominican priest from France.

title: DEATH VALLEY
description: To the Editor: R. V. Denenberg's article on Death Valley makes the traveler want to get out his maps and head for Furnace Creek, Stove Pipe Wells, Scotty's Castle, Bad Water and Dante's View. It also makes us who were part of the largest contingent ever to visit Death Valley, yearn to write the chapter, ''Mojave Revisited.''

title: DUE-ON-SALE MORTGAGES MAY NOT BE
description: IF you are trying to sell your house and you have an old, l owinterest mortgage, you probably think that a buyer cannot assume t he mortgage if there is a ''due-on-sale'' clause written into the c ontract. The clause clearly says the lender can demand immediate p ayment of the entire debt if the house is sold. The mortgage is t hus nonassumable, right?

title: With an Eye On Elections
description: As members of the House straggled back into Washington last week after a two-week Easter break, it might have been understable if a few hadn't bothered unpacking.

title: ROMANTIC PIANO-MUSIC DISKS
description: Every generation has its handful of distinctive piano soloists, but ours is notable for its seemingly endless flood of competent ones. These less glittering figures also demand their time before the recording microphone, and some of the results are here in this assortment of Romantic piano music. Claudio Arrau is the one really distinguished name here. Otherwise, these new releases show consistent technical virtuosity, occasional distinction but mostly, an honorable adequacy.

title: T.J. Ondrey Weds Anne E. Conley
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More yesterday Anne Esther Conley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Agnew Conley of New York and Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla., was married to Thomas Joseph Ondrey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Thomas Ondrey of Burton, Ohio. Msgr. Thomas P. Leonard performed the ceremony.

title: Red Rock Country
description: To the Editor: Phyllis A. Whitney feels sorry ''for all those motorists rushing by on the highway'' in her article ''Southwest: Red Rock Country'' (Travel, March 21) but in her haste she herself missed one of Arizona's fascinating treats not far from Sedona. This is Montezuma Castle, the well-preserved prehistoric cliff dwelling of 12th-century Indians.

title: DE KOONING HAS MEETING WITH QUEEN
description: Queen Beatrix of the Netherlands, on the last day of her visit to the United States, called on the reclusive Dutch-born artist Willem de Kooning yesterday to look at some of his paintings. For the occasion, Mr. de Kooning flew in by helicopter from his home in East Hampton, L.I., in one of his rare visits to New York City.

title: OSPREYS ON THE WING
description: THE osprey, an endangered species in New York State for the last decade, has rebounded dramatically on the Island's East End, one of two areas in the state where osprey nests were once relatively common.

title: No Headline
description: Carolyn Rossi, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dante Rossi of St. Thomas, V. I., was married in New York yesterday to James Mason Copeland, son of Helen Mason Copeland of Charlotte, N.C., and the late Herbert J. Copeland. The ceremony was performed in the Manhattan Church of the Nazarene by the Rev. Orville Jenkins Jr. and the Rev. William Weber. The bride is executive producer of the Lambs' Theater. Mr. Copeland is with the architectural firm of Croxton Collaborative in New York.

title: R. M. Brown 3d to Wed Miss McIntire
description: Mrs. Rita I. McIntire of Westport, Conn., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Sharon Lynn McIntire, to Ralph Manning Brown 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. R. Manning Brown Jr. of Princeton, N.J.

title: 'I LOVE YOU,' STORY OF A BRAZILIAN ROMANCE
description: It cannot be said that Arnoldo Jabor's ''I Love You'' is a frivolous film, although some extra levity undoubtedly would have helped. Certainly the film's earliest, half-factitious section is its best, as the sultry Maria (Sonia Braga) arrives at the ridiculous apartment of Paolo (Paolo Cesar Pereio). Maria has been jilted and so has Paolo, and they are ready to embark upon a long and acrobatic tryst - more about that later. Right now, a few words about Paolo's apartment are in order.

title: SHELTER SERVES NEEDY IN STAMFORD
description: STAMFORD FRANK MARZULLO'S is a success measured in misery. People come to the Community of St. Luke here, which Mr. Marzullo directs, because they are hungry, homeless or both. The Community houses and feeds them, sells them clothing and food at reduced prices, even arranges to send their children to summer camp.

title: BUSH VISITING SEOUL AMID WORRY OVER ANTI-U.S. ACTS
description: Vice President Bush, the highest official of the Reagan Administration to visit South Korea, arrived here this morning amid increasing expressions of concern in Korea about growing anti-American sentiment.

title: ON LANGUAGE
description: More Important(ly)

title: MYTHS, HONOR AND MACHISMO AT STAKE IN THE FALKLANDS
description: Spanish conquistadors named this land Argentina, ''land of silver.'' While they found little treasure, the name somehow remains apt. The society they founded in the 16th century is still based more on what a leading Argentine sociologist called ''myths and magic'' than on law and morality. This is central to the Argentine national character and helps explain why Argentine forces boldly seized the Falkland Islands from Britain three weeks ago and now are poised to defend it against a British battle fleet.

title: GRAHAM BLENDS PREACHING WITH APPEAL FOR PEACE
description: As the Rev. Billy Graham goes from one college rostrum to another in his current tour of New England, he often speaks of a personal ''pilgrimage'' that has led him to regard the ending of the arms race as ''my No. 1 social concern.''

title: POLISH POSSIBILITIES
description: THE POLISH AUGUST The Self-Limiting Revolution. By Neal Ascherson. 320 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $14.95.

title: Beth Crandall Becomes Bride Of James Barnes
description: Elizabeth Alice Crandall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Wilson Crandall of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., was married yesterday to James Douglas Barnes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul McClung Barnes of Milwaukee. The Rev. Robert W. Hare performed the ceremony in the Presbyterian Church in Scarborough, N.Y.

title: DEMOCRATS FAVORED IN THE HOUSE, POLL SHOWS
description: The public remains intent on voting for Democrats over Republicans for the House of Representatives by very large margins, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: OUR SCHOOLS: WHY THEY DON'T TEACH
description: ONE can hardly get through the paper - let alone the day - without wondering what has happened to our schools. In the cities nearly half the youngsters are dropping out. In the suburbs they stay, but seem to learn less and less as scholastic aptitude sags everywhere. Nobody seems to know why.

title: SCHOOLS ENTER THE COMPUTER AGE
description: TECHNOLOGY has always been an important element in how and what people think and how they communicate. In ''The Republic,'' Plato spoke of the effects of the development of writing on memory and other thinking skills associated with the oral tradition. The invention of movable type put the Bible within the reach of the common man and permanently altered the religious views of Europe.

title: THE ARISTOCRATIC CAULIFLOWER
description: all members of the cabbage family -go wonderfully with plain roasted meats. And now that spring lamb is in season, it is a perfect time for them. A mixture of all three makes a beautiful presentation for a dinner party, the cauliflower whole in the center and the other vegetables arranged around it.

title: BROOKS PLEASED WITH RANGERS
description: The Rangers had just been eliminated from the Stanley Cup playoffs Friday night by losing, 5-3, to the Islanders when two unpredictable events occurred.

title: DR. NATHAN ZION
description: Dr. Nathan Zion, a dentist who practiced in Passaic, N.J., for 50 years, died yesterday morning at New York University Hospital of heart failure.

title: by Roger B. Swain
description: Roger B. Swain is science editor of Horticulture Magazine and author of ''Earthly Pleasures: Tales From a Biologist's Garden.''

title: DENISE O'TOOLE BETROTHED
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. John J. O'Toole of Elizabeth, N.J., of the engagement of her daughter, Denise Marie O'Toole, to James J. Mulhearn of Bronxville, N.Y., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. James Mulhearn of Brooklyn. A June wedding is planned. Miss O'Toole is a daughter also of the late Mr. O'Toole.

title: Around the Nation; New Knoxville Evictions Expected as Fair Nears
description: Officials here say they expect new evictions because a judge has barred the city from punishing landlords who evicted tenants in a fever of expectation of money from tourists who would visit the coming World's Fair.

title: Bathtubs, Etc.
description: To the Editor:

title: BUDGET CUTTING: DOESN'T SUCCESS COUNT
description: AS the budget cuts become a reality, I have begun to wonder whether usefulness or success is a factor in determining whether a Federal program is to continue. Upward Bound at Stony Brook has been in existence for 16 years and has helped more than a thousand young people from low-income families finish high school and prepare for college.

title: USING RECORDS TO SAMPLE NEW MUSIC
description: Contemporary music is in a fragmented but exciting state, and to appreciate the excitement, a concertgoer must confront the fragmentation. That is not always easy, with different kinds of music presented all over town, advertised in different places and appealing to widely varying sociological swatches of the populace.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
THE HIGHWAY WAS HIS LIFE...AND DEATH
description: IT WAS on a dreary Monday afternoon in December that the wire services sent out a report that a New Jersey state trooper had been gunned down, gangland style, on busy Interstate 80.

title: Judaica Museum to Open
description: The Judaica Museum will open next month on the campus of the Hebrew Home for the Aged, at 5901 Palisade Avenue, in Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: John Kunstadter Jr. Weds Miss Mather
description: Melissa R. Mather, an assistant treasurer at the Bank of New York, was married yesterday to John W. Kunstadter Jr., an assistant manager with Citibank's international services division. The Rev. Ralph Ahlberg, assisted by the Rev. William Nye, performed the ceremony in the Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims (Congregational) in Brooklyn Heights.

title: PLAYHOUSE JOB OPENINGS
description: For the first time in its 52-year history, the Westport Country Playhouse will pay three production assistants and one wardrobe supervisor $1,000 each for the season, beginning June 21 and closing Sept. 4.

title: EASING A COMPANY'S RISKS OVERSEAS
description: WASHINGTON NOT that it craves anonymity, but the Overseas Private Investment Corporation ''is probably one of Washington's best-kept secrets,'' or so acknowledges Craig A. Nalen, the marketing man that President Reagan picked as its helmsman last June.

title: CAMPUSES REFLECTING RISING JAPANESE INFLUENCE
description: THE impact of things Japanese on American society has never been more powerful, and that impact is spreading rapidly across American campuses. Because many college and university officials believe that their students' success as businessmen, lawyers and engineers depends on their understanding and in some cases borrowing of Japanese methods and philosophies, Japanese studies are becoming an important part of the curriculum of American schools.

title: 'BEFORE I GO I HAVE SOMETHING TO SAY'
description: GOING back to childhood, that overcharted landscape of the past, I find too many scenes and stories that instruct me on why I've become a writer - odd encounters with language in a mixed neighborhood, mostly working-class, where by a mere inflection of ''Hello'' you could tell that the pert young widow had lost her beau, the Montours were coming up in the world this week, the Drews had not paid their grocery bill.

title: ATLAS ON BIRD BREEDING IS PLANNED
description: SHARON THE hills below a soaring turkey vulture echoed with the honks of Canada geese staking out nesting territory on Bog Meadow Pond at the Sharon Audubon Center.

title: 2 RARE U.S. POSTAGE STAMPS SET RECORD PRICE AT AUCTION
description: Two rare United States postage stamps, an ''Upside-Down Jenny'' and a 19th-century stamp showing Columbus doing a headstand, fetched the highest prices ever for American stamps at an auction held here yesterday at the Plaza Hotel - $180,000 each.

title: THE DRILL FOR VISITORS AT WEST POINT
description: JAMES FERON is chief of the Westchester bureau of The Times. BY JAMES FERON

title: AIDING STUDENTS, A LIFELONG INTEREST
description: NEW HAVEN BOTH were teachers in their younger days and they continue to believe fervently that youngsters from poor families with a wish for learning deserve to be helped.

title: No Space Shuttle Delay Seen Despite Explosion of Engine
description: The explosion of a $30 million main space shuttle engine while it was being tested should not affect scheduled shuttle flights, a space agency official says.

title: Roderick Newbold Ryan Weds Sara S. R. Ballantine
description: Sara Streit Riker Ballantine, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Percy H. Ballantine of Andover, N.J., was married yesterday to Roderick Newbold Ryan, son of Mrs. Martin K. Richards of New York and Southampton, L.I., and William A.K. Ryan of St. Michael's, Md. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. George Poffenbarger at the Christ Episcopal Church in Newton, N.J.

title: 'Orphan' Horses
description: When the Federal Bureau of Land Management said last July that it was raising the fee to adopt Western wild horses and burros, some animal lovers saw it as a death sentence.

title: THE TALLEST ON LONG ISLAND
description: The 360-foot-high Health Sciences Center on the campus of the State University of New York at Stony Brook is generally acknowledged to be the tallest building on Long Island. But nothing is ever that simple.

title:
Economic Affairs;
THE FAMILY: ANOTHER SAFETY NET
description: TWENTY years ago, when full employment implied an unemployment rate o f around 4 percent, a 9 percent rate would probably have caused p olitical turmoil and marching in the street. Currently, a 9 percent r ate is causing our leaders political problems, but not as much as w ould be expected when record numbers of individuals are unsuccessfuli n their search for work.

title: THREE FOR THE ROAD
description: ''On my thirteenth birthday my father called me a slut once too often, my dog was hit by a car, and I lost my virginity -what was left of it.'' With this zinger of an opening sentence TO TAKE A DARE (Harper & Row, $10.50) stakes its claim to be this season's most talked about ''Young Adult'' novel -sure to scandalize many parents at the same time that it hooks a large audience of worldly wise teens. At age 12, heroine Chrissie Perretti is already aspiring to be the ''Punk Queen'' of her neighborhood; at 13, she runs away from home. But far from hitchhiking her way to perdition, Chrissie somehow manages to transform herself into an unusually mature young woman. At age 16 she's working hard to establish a career as a chef and set down roots in an Arkansas resort town.

title: YEARS AGO IN RUSSIA
description: WHY THERE IS NO HEAVEN ON EARTH By Ephraim Sevela. Translated from the Russian by Richard Lourie. 205 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $11.50. (Ages 12 and Up) By WALLACE MARKFIELD

title: Images of India
description: As the publisher of Clark Worswick's books on the history of photography in the Far East, I am offering some facts to place in better perspective Fergus Bordewich's article ''India's Embellished Images'' (March 14). Without gainsaying Mrs. Gutman's efforts, the ''spadework that redeemed a brilliant art from the seeming cultural slag heap of the colonial age'' was surely done first by Mr. Worswick, a photohistorian who was curator of ''The Last Empire,'' an exhibition at the Asia Society in 1976, which brought to public attention photographs by indigenous Indian photographers and was reviewed enthusiastically in this newspaper. Mr. Worswick's book, ''Princely India,'' described the work of Lala Deen Dayal, court photographer to the Nizam of Hyderabad.

title: MANY UNUSUAL FERNS WILL GROW IN GARDEN SHADE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Dr. John T. Mickel is senior curator of ferns at the New York Botanical Garden. By JOHN T. MICKEL

title: PRIVATE SCHOOLS GET LOAN AID
description: AS tuition costs increase rapidly and a record number of applicants attempt to squeeze into private schools, more than $1.5 million in grants to be used for loan programs for lower- and middle-income families will be given to Connecticut schools over the next seven years.

title: Whale Watching Off Cape Cod
description: In the Atlantic Ocean, just north of Provincetown, Mass., lies the Stellwagen Bank, a prime feeding ground for the great denizens of the sea.

title: Vermont Governor Vetoes Bill To Raise Drinking Age to 19
description: Gov. Richard A. Snelling has vetoed a bill to raise the drinking age in the state to 19, saying he could not support ''laws of passion'' that did little to solve problems.

title: U.S. TIES WEST GERMANY, 5-5
description: Aaron Broten scored with 2 minutes 30 seconds to play today to give the United States a 5-5 tie with West Germany and its first point in the World Hockey Championships.

title: STUDENTS: SMITTEN BY BIG BUSINESS
description: COLORED rejection letters cover the walls of a fourth-floor dormitory at Wellesley College in Wellesley, Mass. At Brandeis, in Waltham, Mass., students search their mailboxes three times a day awaiting job offers. Over lunch, Brown students in Providence, R.I., compare perquisites and the tans they got during trips for interviews at corporate home offices. And at M.I.T. in Cambridge, seniors debate the merits of designing guided missiles or video games for the nation's high-technology companies.

title: Nonfiction in Brief; by Robert M. Kaus
description: THE WHOREHOUSE PAPERS By Larry L. King. 290 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $14.95.

title: Carole Shortt Is Married to Robert Carl Johnson 2d
description: The marriage of Carole Ann Shortt, daughter of Robert J. Shortt of Middlebury, Conn., and the late Bernadette Miscavage Shortt, to Robert Carl Johnson 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Johnson of Woodbury, Conn., took place yesterday in St. John of the Cross Roman Catholic Church in Middlebury. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John G. Fanning, assisted by the Rev. John E. Doran, cousin of the bridegroom.

title: RENEE BOGART TO BE MARRIED
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Carl F. Bogart of Stamford, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter Renee B. Bogart, to Marylou Gjessing of Thousand Oaks, Calif., and Peter La Salandra of Windsor, Conn. A July 3 wedding is planned in New York.

title: CATS AND DOGS
