description: In the opening picture in Peter Spier's RAIN (Doubleday, $10.95) a girl and her younger brother, a dog and cat play in a backyard garden, and a cloud appears as a gray smudge in the corner. On the next page, raindrops fall, and the cat is the first to take cover.

title: CAN NEW ZEALAND RIVAL AUSTRALIA FOR MOVIE HONORS?
description: ''You must understand,'' says Roger Donaldson, the 36-year-old New Zealand filmmaker, ''that in New Zealand there was no way you could go to any film school. There was no way you could learn about filmmaking. The only way to learn was to do it.''

title: MIND OVER BLATHER
description: I'm not exactly crazy about flag-waving, but there are certain things I think every American has a duty to do. This is why every year I set aside three nights to watch the Miss America contest, the Academy Awards and the Super Bowl.

title: EX-RELIEF AIDE TO CHRONICLE CAMBODIA KILLINGS
description: Gregory Stanton remembers when the compulsion began. He was conducting relief work in Cambodia in 1980 and he met a teen-age boy. The boy told Mr. Stanton how two others of his age, members of the Pol Pot forces, had forced him to watch as they killed his parents. ''And as he told me this,'' Mr. Stanton said, ''he began to cry.''

title: Best Films on TV
description: 'Staircase' and 'Memory'

title: WHERE THE ACCENT IS ON NEW PLAYS AND PLAYWRIGHTS
description: The setting is the second floor of an underheated building on the far West Side of Manhattan. A dozen people are gathered on a frigid winter afternoon to discuss a play. The group - actors, directors and other playwrights - has just ended a workshop production of the new script, and its members are sharing their thoughts with the playwright. Nearly all of them preface their remarks with encouragement and then go on to say things that would make a critic wince. The playwright seldom responds. He listens, jots down notes, gulps coffee. Everyone shivers. Typically, the spotlight at Ensemble Studio Theater is on the playwright.

title: Peace for Sand
description: True to its word and interests, Israel pays Egypt the final installment of Sinai sand today. With this second evacuation in 25 years, it buys a promising state of peace with its most formidable neighbor. But not peace of mind.

title: 8 Tons of Marijuana Seized
description: A Coast Guard cutter intercepted a 65-foot-yacht off the Dominican Republic Thursday night and seized about 8 tons of marijuana, according to a Coast Guard spokesman.

title: HEATING UNIT CAN COOL
description: NOW that the cold weather is finally gone (we hope), most homeowners will soon be shutting down their central heating systems and will start thinking about ways to keep the inside of the house cool.

title: JOHN CARDINAL CODY, HEAD OF ARCHDIOCESE IN CHICAGO, IS DEAD
description: John Cardinal Cody, the Archbishop of Chicago, died early this morning at Northwestern Memorial Hospital. Paramedics summoned to the Cardinal's North State Parkway residence at about midnight took him to the hospital emergency room. He died at 12:19 Central time.

title: Correction
description: To the Editor:

title: CANADIAN DOCTORS DEMAND MORE PAY
description: Medicare, Canada's publicly financed comprehensive health system, is once again being battered by thousands of angry doctors agitating for higher incomes.

title: TWO OF A KIND
description: My twin girls were also born in 1977. However, that is the only similarity I share with Mrs. Mussell. I not only had the twins, but also a 3-year-old son.

title: Velasquez Scores On Andover Way
description: Aware that Andover Way has a tendency to loaf when leading, Jorge Velasquez gave his mount no such opportunity in the $110,000 Top Flight Handicap for fillies and mares at Aqueduct yesterday.

title: Best Sellers; FICTION
description: 1 THE PARSIFAL MOSAIC, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $15.95.) Through many exploits and hairbreadth escapes, Michael Havelock saves the world from nuclear extinction. 2 NORTH AND SOUTH, by John Jakes. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $14.95.) The friendship of two wealthy families one in Penneylvania, the other in Carolina-is strained by the Civil War. 3 TWICE SHY, by Dick Francis. (Putnam's $13.95.) A greedy gang at large in the world of horse-racing and computer programming. 4 CELEBRITY, by Thomas Thompson (Doubleday, $17.95.) A crime committed in their boyhood come back to haunt two young men. 5 THY BROTHER'S WIFE, by Andrew M. Greeley. (Warner/Gels, $14.95.) Two brothers, a priest and a senator, each in his own way love the same woman. 6 SPRING MOON, by Bette Bao Lord. (Harper & Row, $14.95.) Tradition and revolution in modern China seen through the life of an upper-class family. 7 AN INDECENT OBSESSION, by Colleen McCullough. (Harper & Row, $13.50.) A nurse and her charges in a special-care ward of a World War II hospital. 8 A MOTHER AND TWO DAUGHTERS, by Gail Godwin.

title: NOMINATION DRIVE PRESSED ON COAST
description: Two months of campaigning that included a $700,000 splurge on television commercials in the Los Angeles area have revitalized Lieut. Gov. Mike Curb's campaign for the Republican nomination for Governor.

title: MONTCLAIR TO HONOR TV PIONEER
description: MONTCLAIR WHEN a group of scholars, government officials and scientists gathers at Montclair State College Saturday, it will do more than commemorate the 30th anniversary of the first instructional telecast on the East Coast.

title: SHORT-CIRCUITING THE SHORT SKIRT
description: Some like them short, to be sure. And with summer approaching, a skirt on the high side would seem the logical choice. But, at about a three-to-one ratio, women shopping in New York stores have been opting for the opposite, selecting skirts with hemlines that hang anywhere from mid-calf to a few inches above the ankle.

title: NAMIBIA CHURCHMEN ARE PESSIMISTIC ON TALKS
description: A group of visiting church leaders from South-West Africa said in New York last week that they were not optimistic about the international talks on independence for the territory.

title: Sports People; It's Marvelous, Really
description: The name on the world middleweight boxing champion's robe is official: Marvelous Marvin Hagler. Named Marvin Nathaniel after his birth in Newark May 23, 1954, Hagler had the name legally changed Friday in Plymouth (Mass.)

title: CRACKS IN THE WALL OF KHOMEINI'S POWER
description: For more than three years, the centripetal force holding together the swirling factions of revolutionary Iran has been the mystical, charismatic personality of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. The underlying political question has always been, what will happen when the 82-year-old imam dies?

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: HUNTINGTON is the first town on Long Island to be designated ''Tree City U.S.A.'' by the National Arbor Day Foundation. The award, co-sponsored by the National Association of State Foresters, the United States Forest Service and the National League of Cities and the United States Conference of Mayors, will be presented to Supervisor Kenneth C. Butterfield on Friday, the 100th anniversary of Arbor Day.

title: No Headline
description: Bonnie L. Sloan, a sales representative in New York with Catalina, a sportswear manufacturer, was married yesterday to Charles Peck, national accounts manager with Trans-Ocean Import Company, a rug importer in New York. Rabbi Gunther Hirschberg performed the ceremony at Stouffer's Inn of Westchester, in White Plains, assisted by Rabbi Seth Bernstein and Cantor Ephram Biran. The bride is a daughter of William B. Sloan of Albany and the late Thelma Sloan. Mr. Peck is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Malvin R. Peck of New York.

title: OPERAS: ZEMLINSKY AND OFFENBACH
description: We have seen fitful signs in recent years of an Alexander von Zemlinsky revival, and the latest manifestation was the American premiere Thursday night of his 55-minute one-act opera ''Eine Florentinische Tragodie'' at the Manhattan School of Music. The second repeat performance will be presented this afternoon. The opera is preceded by Offenbach's early one-act comedy ''Le Mariage aux Lanternes.''

title: HIGH SCHOOLS HIRE NEW COACHES: FOR THE S.A.T.
description: LATE one recent afternoon, as their classmates drifted off home, to after-school jobs or to team practice sessions, 17 11th-graders gathered in a classroom at Rodger Ludlowe High School in Fairfield, Conn., to begin six weeks of intensive preparation for next month's Scholastic Aptitude Tests.

title: PONDERING REAL CONCERNS OF THE 1950'S
description: Though by my count it has no more than three certifiable belly laughs, which average out to one every 33 minutes, and not quite enough filthy chuckles to fill the spaces between the belly laughs, ''Porky's,'' Bob Clark's rowdy teen-age sex comedy, deserves attention, if only because it's on the point of becoming one of this year's major box office hits. Don't be fooled by its perfect grooming and neat table manners - it's ''The National Lampoon's Animal House'' of 1982.

title: QADDAFI WILL VISIT GREECE THIS WEEK
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, is making an official visit to Greece on Friday in an attempt to establish a bridge with Western Europe and to blunt American efforts to isolate him internationally.

title: NEW PROGRAMS OFFERED FOR DIABETICS
description: Since the discovery of insulin 60 years ago, diabetes has been perceived as a disease that is easy to control. But according to Dr. Michael Bergman, director of a new diabetes program at the County Medical Center, the incidence of the illness in this country is increasing.

title: COMPACT SPACES FOR COMPACT CARS
description: It may seem perverse to shoppers who have bent fenders, dented doors and chipped paint squeezing into standard 9-foot-wide parking spaces in shopping malls, but a recent study recommends narrowing the spaces to 8 feet 5 inches. What may seem even more perverse to shoppers who have circled and recircled mall parking lots looking for an empty space is the same study's companion recommendation that mall operators also cut the number of parking spaces.

title: Cat Asthma
description: Many people can't stand cats. They wheeze, cough and get watery eyes when they go near a cat. In August 1979, two Boston physicians patented a remedy for this asthmatic reaction: an extract made from cat dandruff that was injected into the sufferers.

title: MARCHES AGAINST BUDGET CUTS BEGIN PROTEST WEEK
description: The All People's Congress began a week of demonstrations against cuts in social programs by the Reagan Administration with protest rallies and marches today here and in 103 other cities.

title: Jill Vorenberg Plans Wedding
description: James Vorenberg, dean of the Harvard Law School, and Mrs. Vorenberg, of Cambridge, Mass., have announced the engagement of Mr. Vorenberg's daughter, Jill Vorenberg, to Rodney Bruce Alberts, son of Marian J. Alberts and Raymond Alberts, both of Kansas City, Mo.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:I have been told it is possible to rent a houseboat and tour the Thousand Islands. Can you tell me where to find information on this subject? - R.A., Matawan, N.J. Answer:One source of houseboat rental and related tourist information is the Thousand Islands Bridge Authority and Thousand Islands International Council (Box 428, Alexandria Bay, N.Y. 13607, 315-658-2281 or 315-482-2501). The council has a list of houseboat marinas and other tourist accommodations on the Canadian and on the American sides of the St. Lawrence River. The season for houseboating lasts from mid-May to mid-September. Rentals run from $250 to $800 a week and include all gear, but neither food nor crew. Reservations should be made as soon as possible since many houseboat vacationers return year after year.

title: Crude Victory Over Inflation
description: Though it means only that a dismal economic situation has become a little less dismal and though White House exuberance over the announcement rings false, there is still reason to cheer the news that the Consumer Price Index actually dropped in March at an annual rate of 3.3 percent.

title: ANALYSTS WEIGH IMPACT OF MERGER ON L.I. BANKING
description: IN the aftermath of the merger of Long Island's two largest savings and loan institutions, financial analysts and others in the the banking industry disagree on what the federally sanctioned change will mean for banking on the Island.

title: THE STUDENT'S TANGLEWOOD
description: IN the late 1940's, some 30 years before Charles Strouse would enchant theatergoers with the music for ''Annie,'' he was writing classical music under the watchful eye of Aaron Copland as a scholarship student at the Berkshire Music Center at Tanglewood. When, in 1960, he had his first big hit with ''Bye Bye Birdie,'' he returned his scholarship money. ''Being accepted there was one of the greatest thrills of my life,'' he recalled. ''I was pleased to have been able to repay them.''

title: Hawaii Dairy Operating Again After Clearance on Pesticide
description: Meadow Gold Dairies-Hawaii, which was ordered to halt most of its production after a pesticide was discovered in products made from raw milk, has agreed to conduct new tests and will be permitted to resume full production, state officials say.

title: The World in Summary; Cuba May Be Seeing Fewer Americans
description: The Reagan Administration seems undecided whether Fidel Castro's Cuba is ripe for cuffing or conversion.

title: ADAPTING 'SHOGUN' FOR THE CLASSROOM
description: FOR many Americans, the sole source of information about Japanese culture is ''Shogun,'' the historical novel that became the basis for a widely viewed television mini-series.

title: Harvard Beats Navy
description: Harvard's varsity lightweight crew defeated Navy today, taking the Haines Cup for the 17th time in 19 years.

title: Jazz Festival Time In New Orleans
description: There are festivals - and there are festivals so extensive that they breed a festival within the festival. Take, for example, the 13th annual New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival that begins Friday and continues until May 9.

title: FORMER P.O.W. WHOSE WIFE TOOK $121,998 REJECTS $38,449
description: When Col. Fred V. Cherry of the Air Force, a decorated fighter pilot, was released in 1973 after more than seven years as a prisoner of war in North Vietnam, he came home to find that his wife, who had deserted him, had been paid a total of $121,998 by the Air Force - his salary, his subsistence allowance, his flight pay and his savings.

title: HAVLICEK TO SPONSOR SPORTS FOR YOUTHS
description: For 16 seasons, John Havlicek played a brand of nonstop professional basketball that earned him the title of "The Man in Motion." Now the retired Boston Celtic is scoring points in the county by sponsoring a major running event and creating a summer basketball program for 500 youngsters.

title: Miss Reiss, Claude Sloan Are Married
description: Catherine Mary Reiss, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Paul J. Reiss of Bronxville and Lake Placid, N.Y., was married yesterday to Claude Coleman Sloan, son of Mrs. Harold M. Jones and the late James T. Sloan Jr., both of Richmond. The ceremony was performed in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Bronxville by the Rev. James C. Finlay, president of Fordham University.

title: GRADUATES' GUIDE TO APARTMENT HUNTING
description: THERE was a time, once, when looking for that first apartment in NewY ork had a real romance about it. It was a rite of passage between c ollege and the adult world. It was My Sister Eileen and little b asement apartments in Greenwich Village. It was sunny Upper West S ide rooms with high ceilings and moldings or East Side high rises f ull of bright-eyed secretaries, trainees in Brooks Brothers suits a nd doormen (in deference to Mom).

title: RESISTING THE PITCH
description: JOCK AND JILL By Robert Lipsyte. 153 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $9.50. (Ages 12 to 15) By JOHN LEONARD

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Testing 'Natural' Abortion Drug
description: ''It's like a morning-after pill, only many mornings after,'' said Dr. Sheldon Segal, director of population sciences at the Rockefeller Foundation. He was referring to a drug developed in France which, taken four days at the end of the month, seems to terminate early pregnancies through a process resembling natural abortion.

title: Karen Cooney Is Bride Of Judson H. Thuerk
description: Karen Lynn Cooney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Cooney of Wilton Conn., and Judson Hugh Thuerk, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh D. Thuerk of Easton, Conn., were married yesterday in St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Wilton. The Rev. J. Stephen Jacobs performed the ceremony.

title: Music View; THE ENSEMBLE'S THE THING
description: Do you know what ''ensemble'' means? Of course you do. An ensemble is any Easter outfit that costs more than $50, or possibly the threepiece rock group that played at your cousin Eddie's wedding. In everyday use, the word passes as common coin, without causing much confusion. However, ensemble is one of those double-edge words - ''dynamic'' is another - that vaguely suggest something or other to the man in the street and something else, something more precise, to a musician. The lingo of any trade, profession or calling has many such twin-bladed words. When a musician speaks of good ensemble he refers to the kind of relationship among performers that the better string quartets develop, an understanding so close that the group seems to breathe in and out together, one in which individual egos lose themselves in the effort to make something irreducibly, mysteriously whole out of a collection of spare parts. Musicians of the worthwhile sort value this experience so highly that the idea of ensemble takes on an all but mystical quality for them.

title: ''The Refused''
description: To the Editor:

title: THE ART OF TEACHING SCIENCE
description: Technical jargon is another hindrance to the development of popular interest in science.

title: The World in Summary; Malaysia 2-M's Return to Power
description: Malaysian Prime Minister Datuk Seri Manathir Mohamed and his deputy, Datuk Musa Hitam, used their first nine months in power to seize the high ground in the country's ethnocentric and religiousoriented politics. Their tactics paid off last week as their coalition of 11 Malay, Chinese, Indian and tribal parties won a landslide victory in parliamentary and state elections.

title: ALGERIAN SUPPORTS BETTER TIES TO U.S.
description: A close aide to Algeria's President said this week that the Government was ready for a ''new phase'' of cooperation with the United States and wanted improved relations.

title: The World in Summary; Waiting, Hurrying
description: The Administration also appears to be in no hurry to open negotiations with Nicaragua.

title: Westchester Court Choice
description: Governor Carey has nominated Francis Nicolai to fill a vacancy in the Westchester County Court.

title: BACKERS OF COAST CORONER RALLY TO HIS DEFENSE
description: Politicians and celebrities are rallying in support of Dr. Thomas T. Noguchi in his heated public battle to retain his job as the medical examiner of Los Angeles County.

title:
STAMPS;
ONE ISSUE FOR CONSUMERS, ANOTHER FOR THE FAIR
description: The United States is issuing a 20-cent stamp on Tuesday urging Americans to spend wisely and save money; then on Thursday it is issuing a block of four 20-cent commemoratives for a World's Fair where they will be able to spend money in all kinds of ways - including a ride on the world's largest ferris wheel and learning all about energy.

title: ROMANTIC EDENS
description: Rosamond Bernier will give an illustrated talk at 8 P.M. Wednesday at Prospect Hill School, at Clay and Washington Avenues in Pelham, on the subject of "Art and the Garden," ranging over venturies of romantic Edens created by Bramante, Raphael, Poussin, Watteau and Monet.

title: Waiting for Godot And the L.I.R.R.
description: The L.I.R.R. and gefilte fish: They both smell! The former always, and the latter only after sudden blasts of hot air from defective heater-blowers in exposed platform waiting-shelters perched three stories above street level.

title: TWO OF A KIND
description: That was a good article on twins. I, too, have always been fascinated with multiple births and was guilty as charged when I used to see twins in Central Park.

title: THEATER: 'ETHAN FROME' IS REVIVED
description: The difficulty of transferring a literary classic to the stage is fully evidenced in the dramatization of ''Ethan Frome,'' revived at the Long Wharf Theater. The Edith Wharton novel is as bleak and as beautiful as the wintry New England landscape that is its setting. While some of the author's novels, such as ''The Age of Innocence,'' are filled with vivid characters and dramatized conflicts, ''Ethan Frome'' is a story about people of rigid taciturnity and stoicism. Character arises from unspoken words and the measured lyricism of Mrs. Wharton's prose.

title: Mary M. Mannix Is Engaged
description: The engagement of Mary Margaret Mannix to Mark H. DeBlois has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. John F. Mannix of Wilton, Conn., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. DeBlois Jr. of Pawtucket, R.I.

title: Miss Dugdale Is Betrothed To a Sculptor
description: Mr. and Mrs. John F. Dugdale of New York and Locust Valley, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Juanita Bet Dugdale, to Don Justin Meserve, son of Mrs. Edgar Saunders of East Dennis, Mass., and Walter L. Meserve of Fallston, Md.

title: Recent Sales
description: Pompton Plains $112,000 6 Abby Lane *2*4-bedroom, 3-bathbi-level, new construction; *2*2-car garage, septic tank; taxes $2,200 Kinnelon $147,900 712 Orchard Road *2*5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath ranch, 16 years old; fireplace, *2*family room, new furnace and kitchen; taxes $2,900 North Haledon $125,000 57 Brookside Terrace *2*3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath ranch, 7 years old; central air- *2*conditioning, deck off kitchen; taxes $2,269 Little Falls 80 Kingwood Drive *2*2-bedroom, 1-bath Cape Cod, 34 years old; *2*enclosed porch, fireplace; taxes $1,305 Wayne $143,000 24 Chopin Drive *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath bi-level, 10 years old; *2*underground sprinkler, family room, fireplace; taxes, $2,744 Clifton $102,000 14 Joyce Lane *2*3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath split-level, 20 years old; *2*central air-conditioning, underground sprinkler; taxes $1,500 OTHER AREAS Baldwin, L.I. $141,500 515 Foxhurst Road *2*6-bedroom, 3-bath Colonial, 20 years old; eat-in kitchen, finished *2*basement, fireplace, in-ground pool, patio; taxes $3,700 Bayport, L.I. $68,000 647 Middle Road *2*3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath Colonial, 100 years old; 3/4 acre, *2*eat-in kitchen, fireplace, open porch, patio; taxes $3,000 Bronxville, N.Y. $203,500 73 Summit Avenue *2*8-room, 2-bath stucco Tudor/Norman, *2*62 years old; terrace, playroom; taxes $3,503 Wilton, Conn. $238,500 2 Bald Hill Place *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, Colonial, 11 years old; *2*1.9 acres, river front, waterfalls on property; taxes, $2,755

title: MAJORITY FROM FORD'S MAHWAH PLANT STILL JOBLESS
description: For the first time in 34 years, Eugene Pfeiffer cannot find a job. ''I've been working since I was 12,'' he said. ''It gives a man a very disgusted feeling to know that he's really out there looking, and it's just closed doors no matter where you go.''

title: HOW SCHOOLS USE THEM
description: school teachers, recently conducted a survey among readers to find out how many schools were using computers and for what purposes. The responses, from more than 4,000 teachers, librarians and school administrators, disclosed a high interest in computers among all three groups.

title: The World in Summary; Schmidt Sways Bonn Socialists
description: The specter of death and taxes seems to be everywhere this spring, not least of all in West Germany, where Helmut Schmidt weathered a testy conclave last week of his Social Democratic Party.

title: by Jeremy Bernstein
description: THE EDGE OF INFINITY Where the Universe Came From and How It Will End By Paul Davies. Illustrated, 194 pp. New York: Simon and Schuster, $13.50.

title: Chess; WHEN ONE OF THE BISHOPS IS IMMOBILIZED
description: It doesn't take much to make a bishop bad - one of its own key center pawns immobilized on a square of the same color as those on which the bishop travels is enough.

title: No Headline
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bryce Glover of Portland, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Beth Glover, to Dr. Kevin Shannon of Dallas, son of Mr. and Mrs. Matthew A. Shannon of Tarrytown, N.Y. The wedding is planned for June. Miss Glover is a buyer of women's sportswear for Joske's of Dallas and Dr. Shannon is in pediatics residency training at the Parkland Memorial Hospital and the Children's Medical Center in Dallas.

title: AIR AND SPACE IN COLORADO
description: WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT is chief of the Denver bureau of The Times. BY WILLIAM E.SCHMIDT

title: OLYMPIC COINS: HOW TO HELP THE ATHLETES
description: PERHAPS the trouble with Peter Ueberroth, the president of the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee, is that he predicts miracles and then produces them. When he took office, Ueberroth said that the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee, the non-profit California corporation responsible for conducting the 1984 Olympic Games, ''will not receive any public funds from Federal, state or local governments'' and that the 1984 Los Angeles Games will be the first Olympic Games in history to be financed solely by the private sector.

title: NETWORKS UNCERTAIN ON RADIO AUDIENCE FOR REAGAN'S TALKS
description: Network radio officials said today they could not estimate how large an audience has been tuning in to President Reagan's weekly radio addresses to the nation.

title: SPACE ODDYSEY IN ALABAMA
description: REGINALD STUART is chief of The Times bureau in Atlanta. BY REGINALD STUART

title: A TOAD TO KISS?
description: The last time I went to a bookstore to buy a children's book, I read through the first few pages of dozens of volumes, most of them boring. I finally decided that if the books I looked at didn't amuse me, they certainly wouldn't be able to hold the attention of my 6-year-old niece, and I ended up buying her a chemistry set instead. Authors should realize that giving animals the power of speech or dressing a badger in a frock does not a children's book make. Books with toads as their central characters have special problems, since to my mind it is nearly impossible to think of a toad as anything but a wart donor, an appetite deterrent or something you kiss in hopes that it will turn into a princess.

title: The Week in Business; FIRST QUARTER'S ECONOMIC DECLINE IS 3.9%
description: The economy declined at a rate of 3.9 percent in the first quarter. The drop was largely because of inventory liquidation, the Government said. The economist Henry Kaufman predicted that improvement would start soon but might not last into next year.

title: VIDEO ART'S GURU
description: D.C. Denison is a staff writer for The Boston Phoenix. By D.C. Denison

title: Dance View; PITTSBURGH'S BALLET COMPANY FAVORS DANCE-DRAMA
description: The last time we saw Ruth Page's ballet, ''The Merry Widow'' in New York was at a historic performance at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in 1962. No company in the city was willing to give Rudolf Nureyev any New York exposure -he had not even been out of Russia for a year then - and it was the Ruth Page Ballet that came from Chicago to provide him with the showcase.

title: Major News in Summary; Silver Clouds, Dark Linings
description: Last week's inflation report was striking, so striking that for a moment the White House ignored one of the few still undisputed economic rules. Deputy press secretary Larry Speakes cheerily claimed credit for the dramatic drop, by 3.3 percent at an annual rate, of consumer prices in March - down for the first time since 1965 and the most since 1953. It was, he said, ''because of our consistent economic policy, which has cut the rate of increase in Federal spending, and our policy of nonintervention in the marketplace.''

title: Headliners; A Lot for a Little
description: While some might accuse F. Lee Bailey of overkill, the flamboyant defense lawyer said he was only protecting his reputation. Mr. Bailey, who was acquitted on drunken driving charges in San Francisco last week after a 12-day jury trial, said he spent at least $100,000 on the case. Mr. Bailey said that the costs covered the expense of a private investigator and two defense lawyers who attacked the credibility of the arresting officer. ''This matter has serious consequences for someone in my business,'' said Mr. Bailey, who finally was fined $50 for running a stop sign. ''I'm concerned that this officer, who is dangerous and has a bad record of striking people, is walking around this city with a pistol,'' he said, adding that his case was a blow for ''the little man.''

title: NEW METHOD TO REDRESS TAX CASES
description: HOMEOWNERS who believe their tax assessments are too high now have a new way to seek relief: they can go to a small claims court. This approach does not require a lawyer and the only cost is a $25 filing fee.

title: LE CORBUSIER'S CHANDIGARH
description: BARBARA CROSSETTE is a reporter in The Times Washington bureau who spent six months in India teaching at Punjab University on a Fulbright Fellowship. By BARBARA CROSSETTE

title: Clare Sogorka, Hayes Clark Wed
description: Clare Sogorka, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Michael Sogorka of Point Pleasant Beach, N.J., was married there yesterday to Hayes Braden Clark, a senior analyst with the corporate planning department of Philip Morris Inc. in New York. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Timothy Lyons in St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church.

title: N.Y. REDRISTRICTING STALLS DESPITE COMPUTER'S PUSH
description: Computers are supposed to work magic, but they have proven no match for the witchraft involved in reapportionment. The process of drawing lines on maps to form boundaries for State Senate, Assembly and Congressional districts is without question one of the most political tasks that the Legislature has confronted - for months. It is also very difficult, because of a variety of arcane requirements in the state's Constitution.

title: The Nation in Summary; ZOnes of Doubt On Reagan Plan
description: The linchpin of President Reagan's program to revitalize the economy also holds the key to his plan to reinvigorate the cities. Last week, at a Senate hearing on the Administration's proposed enterprise zones -forms of free-market frontiers in decaying urban neighborhoods where taxes and regulations are cheap -the argument echoed that supply-side incentives alone won't turn the economy's engine.

title: IN NEW YORK, A ZEST FOR LEARNING IS IGNITED
description: SEVERAL times a week, two teachers in the Joan of Arc junior high school on Manhattan's West Side unlock a door on the fifth floor and wheel out four personal computers. Two were bought by the school district, one was given as payment for the school's role in a computer company's advertisement and the fourth is on loan from the New York Academy of Sciences.

title: Las Vegas Gets Plan For Crime Testimony
description: This gambling resort has instituted a new program under which private enterprise will join the public prosecutor in bringing back tourists whose testimony is valuable in criminal cases in which they were victims.

title: A WESTCHESTER MIX IN THE SOUTH BRONX
description: THREE years ago, a college in Westchester County set up a campus not far from a college in the South Bronx, and the college in the South Bronx was none too pleased. The suburban college was part of a private women's school established by an order of Roman Catholic nuns and situated in New Rochelle. The college in the South Bronx, a branch of the City University of New York, was a bilingual institution born of the civil rights movement of the 1960's and set up to serve the poor, Hispanic population of the blighted New York neighborhood.

title: 'THE WRITER IS THE FORGOTTEN MAN'
description: ''Itook my two-year-old son, Benny, to the circus the other day,'' Budd Schulberg said, ''and I was watching those acrobats standing on each other's shoulders. There on the bottom was a strong-necked fellow with 18 people standing on his shoulders. If he hadn't been standing there, everybody on top of him would have fallen down. He looked as if he felt he wasn't getting quite enough credit.''

title: Dr. Christina Mora Married to Dr. Scott Goldstein
description: Dr. Christina Theresa Mora, a staff physician at Doctors Hospital in New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Scott David Goldstein, a senior resident in general surgery at Lenox Hill Hospital in New York. Rabbi Ferenc Raj of the Progressive Shaari Zedek Synagogue in Brooklyn performed the ceremony at the Jewish Center in Princeton, N.J.

title: CORRUPTION IS CALLED A WAY OF LIFE IN NEW YORK CONSTRUCTION INDUSTRY
description: Tainted Industry Construction in New York First of three articles BY MICHAEL ORESKES

title: Robert George Petitt Marries Anita Fiskio
description: Anita Mesek Fiskio, an assistant vice president of the Connecticut Bank and Trust Company in Hartford, was married yesterday in the First Congregational Church in Lyme, Conn., to Robert George Petitt, president of the Northeast Bank in Sanford, Me. The Rev. John Thursby performed the ceremony.

title: Joelle M. Kayden Becomes a Bride
description: Joelle Moira Kayden, daughter of Dr. Gabrielle Reem Kayden and Dr. Herbert J. Kayden of New York and Bedford Hills, N.Y., was married yesterday to Paul Wesley Killian, son of Dr. Camille Killian Parker and the late Dr. Edgar W. Killian of Logansport, Ind. Rabbi David Greenberg performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents in Bedford Hills.

title: NEW PRINCIPALS IN 'THE WILD BOY'
description: A return to American Ballet Theater's tradition of well-varied mixed bills has been signaled this last week and Friday night's at the Metropolitan Opera House was again a good combination. An all-new principal cast made its local debut in Kenneth MacMillan's ''The Wild Boy,'' a happy cast change took place in Sir Frederick Ashton's ''Les Rendezvous'' and last year's staging of excerpts from ''Raymonda'' by Mikhail Baryshnikov, was led grandly by Martine van Hamel and Kevin McKenzie in its first performance of the season.

title:
ANTIQUES;
GLITTER AND GLEAM IN WESTPORT
description: WESTPORT ONCE again the Fairfield County Hunt Club glitters with collections of silver and pewter and fine porcelain and pottery, displayed against a background of both painted and waxed 18th- and 19th-century furniture. The glitter and gleam mark the l8th-annual Southport-Westport antiques show, open today from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. The show, with 72 dealers participating, is a benefit for the Near and Far Aid Association.

title: LOUIS LYONS IN 'SCOUNDREL TIME': A CASE IN POINT
description: To the Editor:

title: HIGH-TECH HANDICAPPER NO THIEF, JUDGE SAYS
description: A person who takes advantage of his employer's computers for personal work has not violated any law, a Criminal Court judge in Brooklyn has ruled.

title: HUDSON POLITICIANS GET TOGETHER FOR A FIRST HURRAH
description: JERSEY CITY THE Democratic leaders of Hudson County staged an old-fashioned political ''unity'' meeting in City Hall last Thursday. It was the kind of gathering at which the names of Frank Hague and John V. Kenny were invoked and tales of their political prowess recalled.

title: CITY COUNCIL MEETINGS SCHEDULED THIS WEEK
description: The following City Council activities scheduled for the week of April 26, are open to the public: MONDAY: Committee on Finance, 23rd floor, 250 Broadway, noon; Committee on Transportation, 23rd floor, 250 Broadway, 1 P.M.; Committee on Rules, Privileges and Elections, City Hall, 2 P.M. TUESDAY: Full Council meets, 1.30 P.M., City Hall. WEDNESDAY: Commitee on Environmental Protection, City Hall, 10 A.M.; Committee on Housing and Buildings, City Hall, 1:30 P.M. THURSDAY: Committee on Health, City Hall, 10 A.M.; Commitee on Youth Services, City Hall, 1:30 P.M. FRIDAY: Committee on Consumer Affairs, City Hall, 10 A.M.; Committee on Economic Development, City Hall, 10 A.M.; Committee on Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs, 23d floor, 250 Broadway, 11:30 A.M.

title: BUILDING, BREAKING AND OPENING THE EAST
description: THE BROOKLYN BRIDGE They Said It Couldn't Be Built. By Judith St. George. Illustrated. 125 pp. New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons. $10.95. (Ages 11 and Up)

title: DERBY TRIAL STAKES IS WON BY 56-1 SHOT
description: Star Gallant fell from the top flight of serious Kentucky Derby candidates today in the Derby Trial Stakes, and Royal Roberto showed he might be a serious factor in the race next Saturday. But both of them finished behind a 56-1 shot who is not even nominated for the Derby.

title: Sarah Lawrence Starts A Fund-Raising Drive
description: Sarah Lawrence College officially opened a seven-year campaign yesterday through which the small liberal arts institution seeks to raise $30 million by 1989 to finance a variety of educational and capital objectives.

title: Haig Greets Tunisian
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. met Prime Minister Mohammed Mzali of Tunisia today when he arrived at Andrews Air Force Base for a one-week official visit.

title: Topics; MODERN TIMES; Playing Soldier
description: No, this picture isn't a fake, and those children really are being trained by a Green Beret in Honduras.

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as wella s in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Topics; MODERN TIMES; Invited Computers
description: Some landmarks loom so large you walk by without noticing. Take two recent mileposts of the computer age. One is the estimate that the population of computers is about to reach 5 billion, outnumbering humans.

title: THE SALT THAT SEASONS SPEECH
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR IN 1925, when Harriette Valentine came east as a bride to the house here that had been in her husband's family since the early 1800's, she was struck by the unusual character of the language spoken by the natives of what was then still a sleepy little coastal village. Raised in the Far West, Mrs. Valentine had never before heard expressions such as ''drunk as a coot'' or ''all decked out.''

title: Reds 3, Astros 2
description: HOUSTON (AP) - Dave Concepcion and Johnny Bench drove in firstinning runs with a double and single to lead Cincinnati. The Reds got to the Astro starter Bob Knepper (1-2) for all three runs.

title: Crime; by Newgate Callendar
description: In 1978 William DeAndrea made an auspicious start with ''Killed in the Ratings,'' which won him an Edgar. That novel introduced Matt Cobb, the vice president of special projects and general troubleshooter at a television network in New York, hired to keep things running smoothly, avoid scandal and solve any loose murders that happen to be committed.

title: HOW COMPANIES SHOULD USE THEIR CASH
description: Being "cash-rich" is sometimes considered a negative for a business, somehow suggesting that management does not know how to put the money to work. A pile of cash, it is said, may make one vulnerable to a takeover; at the very least, a hoard may look unbusinesslike.

title: ELDERLY TENANTS HAVE SPECIAL NEEDS
description: THE elderly woman had seemed fine a few weeks earlier. But suddenly she started to deteriorate. She was not able to clean her apartment or look after herself personally. There was even danger of an accidental fire while she was trying to cook a meal.

title: Military Analysis
description: The complexity of the tactical problem facing Rear Adm. John F. Woodward is gradually being recognized in London as the British task force he commands plows through the South Atlantic toward the Falkland Islands.

title: TANDEM COMPUTERS: NO RECESSION HERE
description: going manner and country drawl, has always seemed the hayseed who came to the Silicon Valley from Texas and outsmarted the local talent. Mr. Treybig's company, Tandem Computers Inc., was founded six years ago and is selling its machines now at an annual rate of $300 million, a performance that outpaces even Tandem's famous computer-manufacturing neighbors.

title: TOLLAND'S REPORT GETS AWARD
description: THE spired, colonial-style building that adorns the cover of the Town of Tolland's annual report is vintage New England. The darkshuttered, white clapboard building is identified on an inside page as the former Tolland County Courthouse, constructed in 1822, now a National Historic Landmark and present site of the town's public library.

title: U.S. SEES A RISING SOVIET PERIL IN ASIA
description: Senior American diplomatic and military officials in the East Asian and Pacific region, meeting in Hawaii this week, stressed the common interests of China, Japan and the United States in countering what the officials said was a growing Soviet threat in the area.

title: ARGENTINA DEFENDS ITS RIGHT TO KEEP AN EYE ON FLOTILLA
description: The military junta, declaring that the crisis in the South Atlantic was ''reaching intolerable limits,'' Saturday night rejected London's warning that Argentine planes and ships stay away from the British fleet that is approaching the Falkland Islands.

title: THE PAYOFF: FROM THE SIMPLE TO THE MOST SOPHISTICATED
description: Payoffs can take many forms in the construction industry. At the simplest level, cash changes hands, assuring that the work moves along.

title: Major News In Summary; Both Sides Seem Poised to Fight Over Falklands
description: British and Argentine forces came within shooting distance in the stormy South Atlantic last week as hopes dwindled that American diplomacy could resolve the Falklands crisis peacefully.

title: by Sally Ogle Davis
description: Sally Ogle Davis is a Los Angeles based writer.

title: APRIL IS BOWING OUT WITH A PLENTITUDE OF CONCERTS
description: THE concert season traditionally tails off dramatically in May and, as if to accentuate the point, this last Sunday in April is awash with fine music of many persuasions. Lovers of choral music are particularly lucky since two major county groups are offering fascinating combinations today: the Ossining Choral Society at 3:30 P.M., the Taghkanic Choral at 8 P.M.

title: Around the Garden
description: This Week:

title: TOURISM SPARKS A DEBATE
description: WHETHER to use state tax revenues to promote local tourism is the question that is prompting some heated discussion this month in Connecticut towns from Salisbury in the northwest hills to Stonington in the southeast.

title: Sports of The Times; Reggie Jackson's Stadium Scenario
description: TUESDAY night, Reginald Martinez Jackson will return to Yankee Stadium with a halo on his cap and drama on his mind. What he likes to call the ''magnitude of me'' will be wearing his familiar 44 on a red-and-blue trimmed California Angels uniform instead of on Yankee pinstripes. No matter what develops, Yankee Stadium has never been the stage for this scenario before: the return of a former Yankee folk hero in another team's lineup while still a headline celebrity.

title: CRAFTS
description: PRINCETON IN TAPESTRIES currently on view at the Henry Chauncey Conference Center, Lore Lindenfeld of Princeton has posed a two-sided problem that relates both to the woven surface and to illusionary space.

title: A NEW BRIDLE TRAIL IS OFFICIALLY OPENED
description: TALK in equestrian circles in the state recently has been centered on the new trail from Willimantic to Putnam intended specifically for horseback riders. The bridle path was dedicated yesterday morning.

title: Dr. Dennis Penzell to Wed Joan Rolland in November
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alan J. Rolland of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Joan Carol Rolland, to Dr. Dennis Penzell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Penzell of Massapequa Park, L.I.

title: GUN CURBS STIR ANGER IN THE WEST
description: Charles Burgess slammed his hand on the hood of his pickup truck and, almost in a shout, annnounced that no one was going to take his guns away from him.

title: FOR TOYS, TRY SCHOOL STORES
description: BEYOND the big discount toy stores along the highways, beyond the toy sections of department stores, and beyond the trendy toy boutiques lies the little-known world of school-supply stores, where nursery schools, kindergartens and discerning parents buy playthings of quality and enduring value.

title: CARDS TAKE THEIR 12TH IN ROW
description: The free-swinging St. Louis Cardinals continue to take the season one game at a time, and that suits two former Phillies, Lonnie Smith and Dane Iorg.

title: No Headline
description: Ann Failing Abernathy of Tarrytown, N.Y., and Lant Salsbury Abernathy of Mount Kisco, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sue Ann Abernathy, to Edward Thomas Melvin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward T. Melvin of Toms River, N.J. A June wedding is planned. The future bride is a commercial banking officer with Marine Midland Bank, N.A., in New York. Mr. Melvin is vice president of Adams & Porter Inc., insurance brokers in New York.

title: Reading and Writing; SEDUCTION
description: Seduction, which has figured in many great novels, may be disappearing from serious fiction, and not everyone will be sorry to see it go, for it has sometimes carried an unpleasant connotation of a man manipulating a woman's emotions. Seduction implied that she didn't know her own mind or self, or that she lacked the moral courage to make a decision. There was the suggestion too that men were the bold agents of romantic anarchy and women the timid conservators of conventional morality - a view that may never have been accurate and certainly is not now.

title: Cold War
description: To the Editor:

title: POSTINGS
description: Ever wonder what it is like to live in a solar house? Next Sunday, in Westchester, owners of eight ''climate-responsive'' houses will tell.

title: THEATER FAMILY PLAYS MANY ROLES
description: LYNBROOK ''I WON'T speak to you until it's quiet.'' The bearer of the ultimatum is Barbara Schaap, conducting her customary precurtain crash course in theater etiquette - she calls it her ''commercial'' - before a capacity audience that, at a recent matinee, included an overflow of youngsters and a smattering of adults.

title: NEW MAN ON CAMPUS: THE EFFICIENCY EXPERT
description: FACED with soaring inflation and sharp cuts in Federal aid, colleges and universities have been increasing their efforts to gain better management and financial-planning techniques. Such efforts are becoming especially visible at private institutions, which have not had to answer to cost-conscious state legislators. Last year, for example, Columbia University hired Maurice Feigenbaum, formerly director of operations for New York City, as its first director of internal management.

title: George Jarvis Coffin 3d Marries Susanne Madeira
description: Susanne Claypoole Madeira, daughter of Mrs. Rufus C. Finch Jr. of New York and Harry R. Madeira of Haverford, Pa., and Northeast Harbor, Me., was married yesterday to George Jarvis Coffin 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Coffin Jr. of Eden, N.Y. The Rev. Timothy Pickering performed the ceremony in the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Bryn Mawr, Pa.

title: THE ETERNAL TRIANGLE, RUSSIOAN-STYLE
description: A GREAT LOVE By Alexandra Kollontai Translated and introduced by Cathy Porter 156 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Co. $12.95 cloth, $4.95 paper.

title: In the Arts: Critics' Choices
description: JAZZ Duke Ellington's birthday, April 29, has been a focus for celebrations involving his songs and compositions for many years, long before his death in 1974. Since his death, St. Peter's Church, which has a rehearsal room named for Mr. Ellington, has had a celebratory program of his music each year on his birthday.

title: THE ART OF TEACHING SCIENCE
description: Dr. Thomas's focus on the nature and manner of science education makes it clear that we will not solve this problem simply by ''throwing money at it.'' The facts are that we must first identify the specific problems as well as the means to stimulate an interest in science, and to raise scientific competence.

title: U.S. INVESTIGATING DIALYSIS PROGRAM
description: Federal prosecutors in New York State are investigating the federally financed program that provides dialysis treatment for patients whose kidneys are irreparably damaged.

title: THE NUCLEAR DEBATE: ADDITIONAL VIEWS
description: In Miriam Goodman's reply to Anthony Fainberg's letter on the question of nuclear power, she once again takes up the tactic of vituperation when her incorrect assertions are unmasked. She originally distorted statistics to try to show that Millstone 1 had caused a local increase in cancer rates.

title: Queens Man Arraigned In 2 Girls' Kidnapping
description: A 49-year-old Queens man, who the police say had forced two teenage girls to engage in prostitution, was arraigned yesterday on charges of kidnapping, rape and promoting prostitution.

title: DEFENSE RESTS IN CASE OF MURDERED BUFFALO BLACKS
description: The defense, after just two days of testimony, rested its case Friday in the second-degree murder trial of an Army private accused of killing three black men.

title: Washington; THE POLITICS OF A-BOMBS
description: One of the major problems for both the Democrats and Republicans over the next couple of years will be how to keep the control of nuclear weapons from becoming a partisan political issue in the elections of 1982 and 1984.

title:
NOTES ON MUSIC;
THE EMPIRE BRASS
description: In a concert at the Cloisters today, the Empire Brass Quintet plans to offer music of the Middle Ages and Renaissance and, for the first time since the Naumburg Award-winning group began to play there, transcriptions of works by several Baroque composers, among them J.S. Bach. The inclusion of Baroque music on the program is evidence of what members of the group describe as their dedication to ''keeping the repertory growing,'' and also of the players' enthusiasm for the Cloisters' unique acoustics.

title: LATIN NATIONS SEE PARALLELS IN CRISIS
description: Argentina's claim to the Falkland Islands has attracted the support of all the Latin nations of South America, most of whom have longstanding territorial disputes among themselves.

title: Sound; LOUDSPEAKER MYTHS EXAMINED
description: The annual herring catch in Newfoundland is closely correlated to the number of illegitimate births in North Dakota. Also, it has been rigorously substantiated that if, during an eclipse, you beat a tomtom long enough, the sun will come out. We have a tendency to draw conclusions from things of this sort.

title: Miss Berke Wed To V.L. Devlin
description: Leslie Christine Berke, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Berke of New York, was married yesterday to Vincent Louis Devlin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis O. Devlin of South Portland, Me. The Rev. Thomas Dix Bowers performed the ceremony in St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church.

title: IMAGES OF INDIA
description: Fergus Bordewich's intriguing article on vintage photography in India describes royal hunting photographs in which the animal victims are arranged as if they were alive. It may be of interest to know that Indian hunters still posed with their lifelike - but quite dead -quarry until recent years, when the hunting of India's rapidly diminishing game was legally prohibited.

title: ISRAELI ARCHEOLOGISTS END 12 YEARS OF WORK IN SINAI
description: While modern Israeli settlements were being demolished and buried in the sand dunes of northern Sinai this week, the remains of ancient civilizations on the peninsula were undergoing last-minute excavations by a team of a Israeli archeologists.

title:
GARDENING;
WHAT TO PLANT, ANNUALS OR PERRENIALS?
description: SOME disagreement exists among flower enthusiasts as to which requires the least work to grow, annuals or perennials. Those who champion perennials point out that they do not require replanting each year as do annuals and insist that that alone is sufficient backing for their argument.

title: Miss Brown Is Affianced
description: Announcement has been made by Peter Megargee Brown and Carroll Williams, both of New York, of the engagement of their daughter, Andree deRapalyee Brown, to Wayne Herkness, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lindsay C. Herkness Jr. of Philadelphia.

title: CLAIRE E. FRENIERE TO BE JUNE BRIDE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henry F. Freniere of Franklin, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Claire Elizabeth Freniere, to Robert William Klein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert R. Klein of Huntington, L.I.

title: MUGGING ANTICRIME PROMISES
description: The Administration promised to give priority attention to violent crime and assigned a blue-ribbon task force to write the ''script,'' but there is no money to produce the ''play.''

title: The Region in Summary; Westway Hits Cash Barrier
description: Someday, perhaps, Westway will ease New York's traffic flow. Last week, the highway-cum-urban development project threatened to do the opposite to the city's cash flow as Federal Judge Thomas P. Griesa barred Washington from sending $90 million in Westway aid to Albany.

title: NARROWING THE PUBLIC-PRIVATE SCHOOL GULF
description: THERE isn't much good news in Detroit these days, but William M. Washington, principal of that city's Cleveland Middle School, believes there is some.

title: NEGLIGENCE SUITS AND AWARDS INCREASING
description: MINEOLA SPURRED by a higher rate of serious accidents, liberalized laws and aggressive advertising campaigns by lawyers seeking clients, the number of personal-injury suits has steadily been increasing on the Island. The trend is highly satisfactory to specialists in negligence law but is a matter of concern for the insurance companies that must pay the cost of successful claims; the increase is also presenting problems for court administrators.

title: FORUM TOPIC: HUMAN RIGHTS
description: ''The Artist and Human Rights'' is the subject of a public forum scheduled for tomorrow at 8 P.M. in Cooper Union Hall, at 41 Cooper Square, featuring the sculptor Tomas Concepcion and his life-sized ''prisoner sculptures.''

title: DEFENDANT FREED IN ABDUCTION CASE
description: Ted Patrick, known for his efforts to make young people leave religious cults, was found not guilty Friday night in a case prosecutors contended stemmed from an attempt to sway a 20-year-old woman from lesbianism.

title:
NUCLEAR ABC IN THE SCHOOLS;
BOSTON
description: SIXTEEN high school seniors sit in a circle in Dr. Robert McCarthy's class at Brookline High School, listening intently and responding readily to questions that would pose a challenge to most scholars and politicians.

title: SOVIET INDUSTRY REPORTS A POOR FIRST QUARTER
description: Soviet industry is off to one of the poorest first-quarter starts in years, according to first-quarter results published today, indicating that 1982 growth targets may be out of reach.

title:
ANTIQUES;
LOOK WHAT'S GOING TO BE ATOP THE PALISADES
description: ALPINE WHAT is described as a one-day extravaganza of antiques and crafts will be held Saturday at the State Line Lookout on the Palisades Interstate Parkway here. The site, just south of the New York border, is a wooded area with views of the Hudson River.

title: A NEW MAESTRO FOR SYMPHONY
description: ''I AM elated and very proud, '' says Paul Dunkel, the newly appointe d music director of the White Plains Symphony . ''I've always wante d to have an ongoing association with a major orchestra, and I would compare this one favorably with any in the country.''

title: Just Testing
description: To the Business Editor: Your excellent article on test marketing, ''New Trials in Test Marketing'' (April 11), neglected to mention the one, single most important reason for its continuing expansion: It effectively relieves management of the need to be responsible.

title: Chief of Federal Agency Links Terrorists to Drug Smuggling
description: The chief of the Drug Enforcement Administration said Friday that terrorist organizations around the world were financing themselves by selling illegal drugs.

title: In the Arts: Critics' Choices
description: ART Until recently, no one knew that Jean Lipman, the art collector, exhibition organizer, writer and editor, was also a painter. For more than 30 years, she has been taking off, in oils and other media, on the work of other artists; mainly folk painters and Alexander Calder.

title: OPERA: WOLF-FERRARI'S 1906 'I QUATTRO RUSTEGHI'
description: Ermanno Wolf-Ferrari's ''I Quattro Rusteghi'' of 1906 is one of those operas that crops up periodically -Laszlo Halasz did the American premiere with the New York City Opera in 1951, and the Manhattan School of Music revived it a few years ago -but deserves a more secure spot in the repertory. Every time it appears, critics praise it to the skies and audiences enjoy it, and then it disappears again.

title: Around the World; Angola Sentences 5 to Die For Aiding the Rebels
description: The Angolan Government has sentenced five people to death and jailed 13 others for collaborating with rebels fighting the Marxist regime, the Angolan press agency reported today.

title: N.A.S.L. IS LIKELY TO OUST WOOSNAM
description: A majority of the club owners of the North American Soccer League has voted to remove Phil Woosnam as commissioner of the league, according to executives who attended an owners' meeting in Chicago March 16 when the decision was reached.

title: THE PRE-DERBY PARTIES START ON A FAST TRACK
description: The clock was creeping toward midnight Thursday night, and the tables, with their salmon-pink flowers and eye-catching salmon-pink ruffled cloths, were deserted.

title: COMEDY, HIGH AND LOW
description: A GOOD MAN IN AFRICA By William Boyd. 342 pp. New York: William Morrow. $14.50.

title: Sports of the Times; MERRICK SAVES FACE ON 30TH BIRTHDAY
description: HE knew it was his birthday, but he had no idea of the present waiting for him in a practice rink on Long Island. Wayne Merrick, one of the least-known players on a team struggling for its third straight Stanley Cup, had reached the dangerous age of 30 by the time he skated out to practice on Friday morning.

title: FINAL ACCORD SEEN UNLIKELY AT BUDGET TALKS TODAY
description: A key negotiator in the budget talks between the Reagan Administration and Congress said today that he expected no final agreement out of a negotiation session scheduled for Sunday.

title: Mariners 3, Twins 2
description: SEATTLE (AP) - Todd Cruz, Julio Cruz and Dave Henderson hit home runs with the bases empty to provide all the Seattle runs.

title: DOVER SEEKS TO UNDO YEARS OF DECLINE
description: DOVER DOWNTOWN Dover, at one time the thriving commercial hub of western Morris County, is taking its first steps to rebound from years of neglect and decline. Since last fall, eight 19th-century buildings once doomed to the wrecker's ball have undergone extensive transformation into bright new condominium apartments and offices.

title: RESTORING THE PUBLIC LIBRARY TO ITS ORIGINAL SPLENDOR p.1
description: When the main building of the New York Public Library on Fifth Avenue was designed in 1897, its very purpose was something new: Libraries were mostly the private preserves of an educated class, not places for the general public at all. The civic leaders who thought New York should have a great library - who were moved in part by the example of Boston, whose great McKim, Mead & White-designed library had opened on Copley Square in 1893 - hardly thought of themselves as radicals, of course. Their goal was not so much bringing books to the masses as it was confirming their city's might. The library, like an art museum, was part of a larger vision of civic grandeur and civic order.

title: Metropolitan Museum
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art is introducing a series of Spanish lecture programs in various galleries for New York's Hispanic-American population, beginning next Saturday and continuing through June 26.

title: THE FALKLAND CRISIS AND THE REAGAN FLAW
description: The imbroglio over the Falkland Islands reveals a major flaw in the Reagan Administration's policy toward the third world. It demonstrates that the centerpiece of American policy - an invitation to friends and clients to put aside parochial feuds and join a ''strategic consensus'' directed against Moscow - has little hope of success. Nor can our interests in the developing world be dealt with simply by extending a warm hand to whomever would be our friend while readying a Rapid Deployment Force for emergencies created by those who would not. What is lacking in American policy is a willingness to address problems internal to the third world - territorial claims or regime changes - that can only serve Moscow's interest.

title: COULD A REVIVAL OF HUMMEL'S MUSIC BE AT HAND?
description: Last year it was Salieri's turn, and suddenly, thanks to Peter Shaffer's Broadway play ''Amadeus,'' that once-popular, longforgotten composer was suddenly in the news. The play even sparked something of a Salieri revival.

title: Headliners Won for the Road
description: If the noblest goal of long-distance running is the sublimation of pain through endurance, Alberto Salazar has become the sport's chief apostle.

title: Prince Marks Raid on Nazis
description: Prince Philip of Britain attended ceremonies today marking the 40th anniversary of a British raid against a Nazi naval base in this French port. The Prince, husband of Queen Elizabeth II, arrived on a special flight from London, while 132 former British soldiers and sailors who participated in the 1942 raid arrived aboard the royal yacht Britannia.

title: REPAIR CREWS FILLING A RECORD 200 MILLION POTHOLES IN NATION
description: The severe cold weather may be gone, but motorists are still feeling the results every time their cars hit a pothole. And this spring there a record number of potholes - 200 million of them.

title: THE TROUBLE WITH ITALY
description: DONALD E. WESTLAKE is a novelist who lives in New York. His latest book, ''Kahawa,'' has just been published by Viking. By DONALD E.WESTLAKE

title: California Crew Wins
description: California held off a late surge by Washington and won a 2,000-meter varsity crew race by a second today. The winner's time was 5 minutes 42.3 seconds.

title: The Region in Summary; Everybody Cleans Up
description: In measuring productivity, three minus one equals $18.3 million. That's how much New York City stands to save each year as a result of an agreement last week to reduce all three-man sanitation crews by one worker.

title: Luxury Living On a Barge
description: As Peter Paul Rubens once said, ''It is not important to live long, but to live well.'' Some people may disagree with the first part of that statement. But all who cherish the second will be happy to know that were the great Flemish painter alive today - he died, by the way, in 1640 at the age of 62 - he would have no need to venture far from home to unite theory with practice.

title: ANACONDA CLOSING OPEN-PIT COPPER MINE AT BUTTE
description: The era of copper's dominance of the economy of Montana came to a symbolic end Friday as the Anaconda Copper Company announced it was closing the Berkeley Pit at Butte, one of the world's largest open-pit copper mines.

title: A WOMAN OF THIS CENTURY
description: HANNAH ARENDT For Love of the World. By Elisabeth Young-Bruehl. 563 pp. New Haven and London: Yale University Press. $25.

title:
Camera;
BOOKS THAT CAN HELP IN SELLING STOCK PHOTOS
DINNERTIME BOXING A HIT IN BRIDGEPORT
description: BRIDGEPORT WHEN three Bridgeport businessmen announced last month that they were joining forces to bring professional boxing back to the city in April and charge $65 a ticket, the local reaction was that the fight show would be dealt a black eye.

title: Protest by Drivers Hurts Grand Prix
description: An international racing tribunal has changed the procedure for weighing Grand Prix cars after they race, and the immediate result is the smallest field for a world championship Formula One race in almost 30 years. Only 14 cars will take the green flag for today's San Marino Grand Prix in Imola, Italy.

title: WHO DRINKS BLOOD?
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Ian Burgess is an author and student of children's books. BY IAN BURGESS

title: E.P.A. AIDE DECRIES SOME CRITICISM
description: THE new regional administrator of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency, Jacqueline E. Schafer, has cautioned that the agency could find itself in a ''crisis of confidence'' if environmentalists go too far with their attacks on it.

title: KEEPING TIME IN BEDFORD
description: saving time, Dennis Dix of Bedford will climb the ladder to the 19th-century clockworks in the Sutton Clock Tower. Holding a flashlight, he will pull a pin on a dial, disengaging the gears, and with one revolution of the dial, he will move the hands on the wooden clockfaces forward the requisite one hour.

title: Terrence Brown Marries Catherine Simms Citarella
description: Catherine Simms Citarella, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael G. Citarella of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Terrence C. Brown, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Brown of Jackson Heights, Queens. The Rev. Robert Hickey performed the ceremony in the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church.

title: WHEN GOVERNMENT LOVES INFLATION
description: To the Editor:

title: Music View; PAUL MCCARTNEY'S LATEST IS EXQUISITE BUT FLAWED
description: Paul McCartney was ''the cute Beatle.'' He was also the Beatle who wrote ''Yesterday'' and ''Eleanor Rigby,'' ballads that transcended the popularity of this most popular of all rock groups and became standards, recorded by artists of every stylistic persuasion. And although it's been well over 10 years since the breakup of the Beatles, Mr. McCartney's image hasn't changed much - to the public at large, he's still the cute, consummate pop tunesmith.

title: A PROGRAM TO HONO STATE'S SUFFRAGIST PIONEERS
description: IN 1918, Edna Purtell of West Hartford, a militant suffragist, went to jail in behalf of the National Women's Party. A fiery speaker, she continued her political activities working for the LaFollette campaign in 1924 and later became a state labor investigator, leading the campaign to end child labor in Connecticut.

title: FOR BORG, CHOICES TO BE MADE
description: Bjorn Borg says he is very stubborn, even around his wife, Mariana. Gemini people are stubborn, he says. ''That's why I've been so successful in tennis,'' Borg says, his left hand leaning thoughtfully on his forehead. ''If I want to do something, I'm telling myself, 'O.K., I'm going to do it.' Like the qualifying. If I believe in something, I'll stick to it. Or if I would like to have something, if I have to do something for it, I'll work for it.''

title: IN OHIO, THE ENEMY IS JAPAN
description: NILES, Ohio JAMES L. DANIELL, the president of RMI Titanium, has no affection for the Japanese. ''They shot me down twice in the war,'' barked the former Navy officer, who lost two ships to Japanese shelling during World War II. ''I'd hate like hell to get shot down in peacetime.''

title: Carry-On Bags
description: To the Editor: My brother and I are international cabaret artists and are constantly faced with baggage problems, whether traveling domestically or to the far reaches of the Orient. One such problem we consistently experience is the dimensional uncertainty of carry-on baggage which must fit under the seat.

title: Ann Hamilton Is Wed To Edwin S. Myers Jr.
description: Ann Amanda Hamilton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Felix Conway Hamilton of Coral Gables, Fla., was married yesterday to Edwin S. Myers Jr. of New York. The Rev. Woodrow W. Hasty performed the ceremony at the Plymouth Congregational Church in Coconut Grove, Fla.

title: LYNDHURST TO REOPEN ON LIMITED BASIS
description: Describing Lyndhurst as "one of the two three crown jewels of the National Trust system," John Frisbee, director of properties for the trust, visited the Tarrytown mansion last week. Speaking at an informal briefing on new plans and programs for the National Historic Landmark, Mr. Frisbee announced that Lyndhurst would be open to the public on a limited basis this summer.

This is, however, a fairly recent phenomenon. Really workable systems of color photography were not developed until 50 or 60 years after the introduction of black and white photography. It was even later, in the 1930's, that the familiar modern forms came on the market. However, color was desired from the very beginnings of photography, and so color photography has a history of early attempts, obsolete processes and pioneering successes that is fascinating and not very well known.

title: THE SOCIAL CONSEQUENCES BEYOND SCHOOLS
description: LAST month Apple Computer Inc. offered to give Apple II microcomputers to each of the more than 82,000 public elementary and secondary schools in the United States, provided Congress liberalizes the Federal tax laws governing the donation of educational materials. Dubbed the ''Kids Can't Wait'' program by the manufacturer, the proposal has already gained more than 5O Congressional sponsors and brought an ''avalanche of inquiries and interest from all kinds of institutions,'' according to Apple's vice president, Frederick M. Hoar.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Amade 3 Play Haydn On Old Instruments
description: Monday's concert by the Amade Trio in the Abraham Goodman House was a debut only in the strictest sense. Sonya Monosoff, violin, John Hsu, cello, and Malcolm Bilson, fortepiano, are all established early-music players, so the freshness of this concert had to do with instruments, not with musicians.

title: IN ISRAEL, DREAMS OF PEACE SEEM HOLLOW AFTER SINAI
description: By tonight, nothing in the Middle East should be quite the same as it is this morning. Israel completes its withdrawal from Sinai today, returning the final swath of desert wilderness to Egypt, relinquishing a vast territory twice the size of Israel itself. The concession is deep, probably more extensive than any ever made by a country in a comparable position of military strength. It fulfills a commitment undertaken three years ago, at the signing of the peace treaty between Israel and Egypt, in the hope that it would change not only the face of the Middle East, but eventually the underlying dynamics that have brought only war to the region for the last generation. And so today should be a landmark. The question is whether it will also be a turning point.

title: 76ERS ELIMINATE HAWKS BUT LOSE HOLLINS
description: The Philadelphia 76ers came away from their two-game opening-round playoff series with three victories and one loss.Two victories came on the basketball court against the Atlanta Hawks and the other in a Hawk protest that was denied. The 76er loss was of Lionel Hollins, the starting guard, for today's opener of the National Basketball Association Eastern Conference semifinal series against the Milwaukee Bucks and perhaps for the rest of the playoffs.

title: by Peter Andrews
Mailbox; Raised to Root For the Mets
description: To the Sports Editor: My father was a fan of the New York baseball Giants. Although he lived in the Bronx, home of the Yankees, Dad regularly traveled across the river to root for his favorite team.

title: SCHOOLS WEIGHING MERIT OF SABBATICALS
description: GEORGEANN GILLESPIE attended graduate school in the summer and at night, and had already matriculated when she applied for a sabbatical leave from Burr D. Coe Vocational and Technical High School in East Brunswick, Middlesex County.

title:
GARDENING;
WHAT TO PLANT, ANNUALS OR PERRENIALS?
description: SOME disagreement exists among flower enthusiasts as to which requires the least work to grow, annuals or perennials. Those who champion perennials point out that they do not require replanting each year as do annuals and insist that that alone is sufficient backing for their argument.

title: Imperfect Advice
description: ONE rule that an angler should always follow - unless catching fish is irrelevant -is to do what the local experts recommend. Observing this single precept will save many blank days, although it will occasionally let one down, something I was recently reminded of when fishing for largemouth bass on Florida's Jackson Lake.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: THE Indians played lacrosse. Indians lived on Long Island. Hence, Long Island has a great lacrosse tradition because the Indians played the game.

title: Carolina Wins 20th Straight
description: North Carolina, master of the fourcorner slowdown strategy in basketball, survived a one-corner slowdown today in lacrosse. The top-ranked Tar Heels broke a 7-7 tie with three straight goals in the fourth period for an 11-8 victory over No.8-ranked Washington and Lee.

title: U.S. General Sees Dividends Gained From the Vietnam War
description: The United States gained strategic political dividends from the Vietnam War by ''holding the line for 10 years against Communist expansion,'' Gen. William C. Westmoreland said today.

title: DANCE: WASHINGTON BALLET IN BROOKLYN
description: The musical scores dominated the evening last Saturday, when the Washington Ballet returned to the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College.

title: WINE
description: THE BLIND LEADING THE ... Geppetto's Italian Cafe is tucked into the corner of a sprawling shopping center surrounded by acres of asphalt-covered parking spaces in Suffern, N.Y., a northern suburb of Manhattan. A back room of the establishment is the frequent setting for tastings attended mostly by members of the wine trade. Sixteen wines are always on the agenda, and the tastings are punctuated by commentary and quips that become more inspired as the palates become more lubricated.

title: The Wrong Town
description: To the Editor:

title: Around the World; Vietnam Shuffles Cabinet In Move on Economy
description: Vietnam has shuffled its Cabinet to change the country's economic leadership, the Vietnam press agency said today.

title: KEVIN M. MARRIMAN TO MARRY ELIZABETH S. PHILLIPS
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Phillips of Glen Ridge, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Shepard Phillips, to Kevin Michael Marrinan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Joseph Marrinan of Crestwood, N.Y.

title: Orioles 7, White Sox 4
description: BALTIMORE (AP) - Eddie Murray's second home run of the game, a three-run shot in the seventh inning, helped Baltimore snap its ninegame losing streak.

title: Television Week; WAY OUT WEST
description: In the finale to this season's "In Performance at the White House" series, viewers will have the opportunity to see and listen to the country-music concert that was taped March 7 for President and Mrs. Reagan - on sunday at 10 P.M. on Channel 13. The country-music star Merle Haggard and the young fiddle champion Mark O'Connor played for the Reagans and their guests at a ranch that adjoins theirs in California's Santa Ynez Valley. Mr. Haggard sang a mixture of drinking songs, ballads and socialcommentary songs, including such foot-stomping, patriotic numbers as "Okie From Muskogee" and "Are the Good Times Really Over?"

title: Vanna Borden Married To Nino Rafael Acuna
description: The marriage of Vanna Maria Borden, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Borden of Rumson, N.J., to Nino Rafael Acuna of New York, took place yesterday in the First Alliance Church in New York. The Rev. Eugene McGee performed the Protestant ceremony.

title: HERE'S AN ARRESTING WORK IN PROGRESS
description: As I sit down to the typewriter, there is talk of extending the run of ''Bella Figura'' beyond today's scheduled closing. If it should continue its performances at the tiny second-floor Ensemble Studio Theater on West 52d near Eleventh, I urge you to grab a taxi and a shoehorn and try to get in. If it shouldn't, I'd jot down the title, which you are likely to forget until you've seen the play, against some future moment when it will surely reappear. I urge you to these things for two reasons. The play is worth the energy it takes to find it: affectionate and disturbing in almost equal portions. And because it is imperfect its author, Brother Jonathan, O.S.F., patently needs audiences to help tell him where its final shape lies. At present some of its values lie glittering on the surface; and some of its gold is still hidden. Cooperative digging is the next order of business.

title: ISLANDERS GET A REST, FINALLY
description: And on the 18th day, the Islanders rested. For the first time since the start of the National Hockey League playoffs, the Islanders had a day off, thanks to Friday night's 5-3 victory over the Rangers at Madison Square Garden. The victory gave them the quarterfinal series, 4-2, and three days to prepare for the semifinals, which begin Tuesday night at Nassau Coliseum.

title: POLICE IN CBS CASE SAY TESTING OF SLUGS WILL GO INTO WEEK
description: No results are expected until tomorrow or Tuesday in ballistics tests on a .22-caliber shell casing and 10 spent slugs found at the home of Donald J. Bowers, the police said yesterday.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
CELEBRATING SPRING WHEN WE WERE YOUNG AND INNOCENT
description: A HUNDRED years ago, or so it seems, when we were all young and innocent, we regularly celebrated two delightful holidays every spring. But I've just noticed that they're largely extinct now. They didn't die dramatically, by decree or common consent; they just slowly ebbed away while no one was looking.

title: COAST FIRE PROMPTS MOVE TO RESTRICT SHINGLES
description: In the aftermath of the worst fire in Orange County's history, legislation has been proposed that would restrict the use of wooden roof shingles that are not fire-retardant. The shingles were a major contributor to the rapid spread of the blaze, according to the Anaheim City Fire Department.

title: ZONING DECISION LOOKED TO FOR PRECEDENT
description: ADECISION expected this summer on the legality of agricultural zoning in New Jersey may be the most publicized legal ruling in Hunterdon County since Bruno Richard Hauptmann was convicted of kidnapping and murdering Charles A. Lindbergh Jr. in 1935. The case, in which Bethlehem Township is being sued by the Grand Land Company over a 1979 agricultural zoning ordinance designed to protect dwindling farmlands, is being heard in Superior Court in Flemington.

title: REP. JOHN M. ASHBROOK OF OHIO DIES AT AGE OF 53
description: Representative John M. Ashbrook of Ohio, a strongly conservative Republican voice in Congress for 21 years and a candidate for the Senate this year, died yesterday at a hospital in Newark, Ohio, after suffering massive internal bleeding. He was 53 years old.

title: HOW TO BREAK OFF THE MOMENTUM OF THE NUCLEAR ARMS RACE
description: Everyone understands that nuclear weapons are the most deadly things ever invented by man. If they were ever to be used, the chances are overwhelming that they would be used in great numbers. And that would mean the slaughter of innocents in the hundreds of millions, the end of Western civilization, perhaps even the end of a livable world.

title: DALLAS
