description: THE Lamplighter School here has bright open classrooms, 413 students ranging in age from 3 to 9, goats named Maxine and Laverne, a cat named Bubblegum and 50 Texas Instruments 99/4 computers.

title: The Region in Summary; Balanced Budget Or Juggling Act?
description: Although Gov. William A. O'Neill liked what he saw in the $3.19 billion budget the Connecticut Senate passed last week, Republican leaders insisted that, with a built-in deficit of perhaps $100 million, there was less to it than met the eye.

title: OPPOSITION PARTIES IN INDIA JOCKEY FOR POSITION
description: A month before key elections are to be held in four Indian states, the leaders of the fragmented opposition factions are flirting and feuding with each other in the hope of establishing advantageous coalitions.

title: KNOXVILLE UNVEILS ITS WORLD'S FAIR
description: WENDELL RAWLS Jr. is a correspondent in the Atlanta bureau of The Times. By WENDELL RAWLS Jr.

title: Television Week
description: A Look at the Saudis ''We went into some of the most remote parts of the kingdom where most Saudis don't even go, where very few had been. We brought back footage from those places which to date have been unheard of.''

title: 'RUBELLA BULGE' OF THE 60'S REACHES THE COLLEGES
description: MORE than 8,000 children born deaf as a result of a rubella epidemic, known as the ''rubella bulge,'' that swept the country between 1963 and 1965 are about to reach college age. In consequence, enrollment in programs for the handicapped is expected to nearly double from the approximately 5,500 deaf students currently in postsecondary programs nationwide, according to the Department of Education's Office of Special Education.

title: WHAT CABLE OFFERS CHILDREN
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Alexis Greene is a freelance writer who frequently reports on children's television programming. By ALEXIS GREENE

title: LeRoy Attaway Jr.  Weds Robyn Gill
description: Robyn Worth Gill, a graphic designer with the Associated Merchandising Corporation in New York, was married yesterday to LeRoy Banks Attaway Jr., the editor of Boating magazine in New York. The ceremony was performed at the Fourth Presbyterian Church in Chicago by the church's pastor, the Rev. Dr. James Flemming and the Rev. Bliss Williams Browne of the Trinity Episcopal Church in Chicago.

title:
DEBUTS IN REVIEW;
Yuli Turovsky, Cellist, Of the Borodin Trio
description: The cellist Yuli Turovsky, one of the members of the Borodin Trio, made his New York recital debut in the Merkin Concert Hall Thursday, accompanied by the pianist Luba Edlina, another of the trio's members. Mr. Turovsky's program included Schumann's ''Fantasiestucke'' (Op. 73) and sonatas by Kodaly, Beethoven and Shostakovich.

title: STATE SEEKS LIMITS ON RADIOLOGY UNITS
description: RADIOLOGISTS are expressing concern over a proposal by the State Health Department to close or reduce services at more than half of the 18 hospital-based therapeutic radiology units on Long Island.

title: ARGENTINA ACCUSES 3 BRITISH REPORTERS OF ESPIONAGE
description: The Argentine authorities have accused three British journalists of espionage. The charges, made on Friday in the city of Ushuaia on Tierra del Fuego, represented the most serious development in friction between the ruling military and the foreign press corps that has arrived in Argentina to cover the Falkland Islands crisis. The military has detained at least seven other foreign correspondents in the last two weeks.

title: Indian Country
description: To the Editor: Though William E. Schmidt's article on the Southwest's ''Indian Country'' (Travel, March 21) says that the Meteor Crater in Arizona is millions of years old, it is only about 25,000 years old. The crater is an example of the fact that dramatic events still happen occasionally in the solar system. JAY M. PASACHOFF Director, Hopkins Observatory, Williams College, v. illiamstown, Mass.

title: Sports People; Browns Get Cousineau
description: Tom Cousineau, a top linebacker in Canadian pro football, will open the 1982 National Football League season in the uniform of the Cleveland Browns. Cousineau, an all-American from Ohio State, was drafted No.1 in 1979 by the Buffalo Bills, but chose to play instead for the Montreal Alouettes.

title: Virginia Mariani Will Be Married
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harry F. Mariani of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., and Warwick Parish, Bermuda, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Virginia Anne Mariani, to J. William Foster, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joe S. Foster of Knoxville, Tenn.

title: Charles Gifford Weds Jerrilynn Dodds
description: Jerrilynn D. Dodds, assistant professor in the department of art history and archeology of Columbia University, was married yesterday to Charles Augustus Gifford, an architect with the New York firm of Hardy Holzman & Pfeiffer. The Rev. Lucia Ballantine performed the ceremony in Grace Episcopal Church in New York.

title: THE ARCHITECT AS ARTIST
description: The New York City apartment as a showplace for important architecture is a fairly recent phenomenon. During the past decade or so, serious architects have been spurred by the lagging economy to turn their hands to interior renovation, and many inhabitants of boring, boxy rooms have gained mightily in the process. Typically, the apartment-dwelling client who hires an ''important'' architect is a patron of the visual arts, seeking, in addition to interesting architecture, a flattering background for a collection of paintings and sculpture.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: THE INS AND OUTS OF CHARTERS
description: If all goes according to plan, cut-rate charter flights will carry tens of thousands of Americans to Europe and back this year. The operators insist that the outlook is bright and that they can save a traveler hundreds of dollars to some destinations. Experience has shown, however, that it pays to tread cautiously with charters and make sure you understand the rules.

title: COMMUNITY MOURNS THE LOSS OF ITS VOICE
description: MOUNT HOLLY IN A three-quarter-page advertisement on Feb. 4, The Herald, long a weekly newspaper here and known for many years as The Burlington County Herald, announced:

title: OPERA: 4 NEW TO 'BOHEME
description: Some new voices appeared Friday night in the New York City Opera's current production of Puccini's ''La Boheme.'' Two young American sopranos, Catherine Lamy and Wilhelmenia Fernandez, sang Mimi and Musetta.

title: Personal Finance; THE CASE FOR DISABILITY INSURANCE
description: MANY people think that once they have purchased a policy on their l ife, they have completed their insurance program. But what happens i f they are disabled by an accident or illness? Their income will p robably plummet at the same time they face high medical bills and e xtra expenses. And the odds on being disabled for an extended periodb efore the usual retirement age of 65 are certainly greater than the o dds on dying before that age.

title: North Koreans Detain Japanese Fishing Boats
description: North Korean patrol boats captured five Japanese fishing boats in the Yellow Sea today, but later released three of them, the Japanese Coast Guard said.

title: Domitilla Enders, C.J. Kennan Wed
description: Domitilla Elena Enders and Christopher James Kennan were married yesterday in St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church in Niantic, Conn. The Rev. Dennis Jarry performed the ceremony.

title: Inuit Art
description: To the Editor: The Shopper's World article, ''A Toronto Specialty: Eskimo Stonecut Prints'' by R. V. Denenberg (Travel, March 14), was extremely informative, but we would like to tell your readers that it will not be necessary to travel to Toronto to view Inuit prints.

title: UNEMPLOYED PROFESSIONALS FIND THEIR BELIEF IN THE AMERICAN DREAM FADING
description: After 29 years at his company Hollis Smith felt secure. He had done all the things society had demanded and in return had landed a prestigious job. He bought a house in the suburbs and two cars and by all appearances Mr. Smith's life stood as proof that the American dream was alive and well.

title: GREENED BUILDING
description: Green is for plants and green also is for money, and that is why the 12,500 square feet of greened space created at 277 Park Avenue by Chemical Bank seems an especially appropriate symbol for the bank's world headquarters building.

title: YOUNG SUICIDES-TRAGIC AND ON THE INCREASE
description: Suicide, as the ultimate act of self-destruction, raises fears about the psychological and social well-being of any society. Suicide among a society's young is particularly fearsome, for it seems to threaten survival itself. So, when the alarm sounded several years ago on a steeply rising suicide rate among America's young people, concern heightened among specialists and an anxious public.

title: Royals 5, Indians 1
description: Paul Splittorff and Dan Quisenberry combined on a five-hitter and John Wathan smashed two key hits for Kansas City.

title: BUILDING, BREAKING AND OPENING THE PAST
description: MOST kids I know love facts - ''Is it true? Did it really happen?'' they'll ask - but not so many have a taste for history. Which is no surprise, since understanding the long ago requires an imaginative leap that few books help them make; most writers of history books for children get tangled up in facts, trying either to force-feed them or to hide them under layers of sugar-coating. And facts are ornery; I saw that again as I read these three new books about Marco Polo's travels to China seven centuries ago. Facts are a lot like seeds, evidently: they just lie there, inert, until someone with the proper feeling for them, and a sense of audience, comes along to garden them. But then, what green things can happen!

title: CLASSES HELP STUDENTS CREATE AD PORTFOLIOS
description: On Madison Avenue, where the revolving door turns quickly, beginners in advertising often feel they need only one piece of luggage to succeed: a portfolio or ''book'' of ad campaigns.

title: Township Group No Relation to PAF
description: To clear up a bit of misinformation in ''It's Ridiculous - as It Should Be'' (April 4): Charles Ludlam is described as ''a member of the Township Theater Group, which ultimately became PAF Playhouse.'' This is incorrect.

title: Around the World; Court in Turkey Rejects Ex-Premier's Appeal
description: A military court has rejected an appeal by former Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit for his release from jail on bail pending trial, defense lawyers said today.

title: Angels 4, A's 2
description: The left-hander Geoff Zahn pitched his third straight victory and Fred Lynn scored two runs as California posted its eighth straight triumph at home.

title: ECLECTICISM IN JERSEY CITY
description: JERSEY CITY AN INTERESTING and ambitious art exhibition that does not quite come off is on view at the Jersey City Museum. The trouble is the light. I saw the show, ''Painterly Landscapes,'' on a brilliantly sunny spring day, and there was simply too much light from the skylight.

title: Diane Dracos Married To Jeffrey L. Gendell
description: Diane Elizabeth Dracos, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Frank Jonathan Dracos of Stroudsburg, Pa., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Lund Gendell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald S. Gendell of Cincinnati. The ceremony was performed in St. Bernadette's Roman Catholic Church in Canadensis, Pa., by the Rev. Edward R. Scott.

title: Investing; TIMING YOU MOVE BACK INTO STOCKS
description: WHEN should an investor move into the stock market to try to exploitt he arrival of better times? Having decided when, what stocks should h e buy? Varied suggestions are being put forward on Wall Street thesed ays, some of them contradictory, and the leitmotif is caution.

title: The Region in Summary; For Governor, A Big Field Gets Bigger
description: Time may not be on the side of Paul J. Curran, the former United States Attorney who belatedly began his campaign for New York's Republican gubernatorial nomination last week, but demographics might be.

title: ELISE ANN WEIL ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Weil of White Plains, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Elise Ann Weil, to Stephen Jay Cohen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Cohen of Philadelphia. Miss Weil is an account supervisor with Lois Pitts Gershon Inc., a New York advertising agency. Her fiance is director of news for KNXT-TV in Los Angeles.

title: COSMOS BEAT STING FIRST TIME SINCE '77
description: In a matchup of last year's Soccer Bowl participants, the Cosmos ended several years of frustration against the Chicago Sting with a 3-1 victory before a crowd of 16,149 at Comiskey Park today.

title: Other Business; IN BASEBALL CARDS, TOPPS STILL LEADS THE LEAGUE
description: For more than two decades, it was easier to find an underpaid free agent than a trace of competition in the flourishing baseball card industry. The Brooklyn-based Topps Chewing Gum Company put them out, and that was that.

title: THE OTHER DARWIN: SCIENTIST AS MORAL MAN
description: In the course of his life and works, Charles Darwin, who died 100 years ago last week, administered a great shock to man's ego, displacing him from the company of angels and establishing his continuity with the other animals. Darwin modestly asserted that he had ''two distinct objects in view: firstly to show that species had not been separately created, and secondly, that natural selection had been the chief agent of change.''

title: WEAKFISH; Cynoscion regalis
description: Size: Averages 16 to 24 inches and one to five pounds.

title: AFTER BOBBY INMAN, WHITHER THE C.I.A.?
description: According to the current incumbent, William J. Casey, to be successful the Director of Central Intelligence must maintain good relations with four groups: his own staff, Congressional oversight committees, senior government officials who receive intelligence data and friendly foreign intelligence services. By that measure, Mr. Casey said recently, his own performance should be considered good.

title: THE NEW WRITER VS. HOLLYWOOD
description: ''It was an art in which words were subordinate to images, where personality was worn down to the inevitable low gear of collaboration,'' wrote F. Scott Fitzgerald of screenplay-writing. And yet ''as long past as 1930, I had a hunch that the talkies would make even the best-selling novelist as archaic as silent pictures...there was a rankling indignity, that to me had become almost an obsession, in seeing the power of the written word subordinated to another power, a more glittering, grosser power.''

title:
PERSPECTIVES;
WELCOME TO DISASTER HIGH
description: OUR school opened in 1976. Bicentennial excitement. Promises. And a new hope that filled us with great expectations. One of us was a 12-year-old student beginning junior/senior high school; the other a young teacher retreading a career at a model school-of-the-future in suburbia. Disaster seemed unlikely.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: U.S. IS SAID TO PLAN AID TO GUATEMALA TO BATTLE LEFTISTS
description: The United States has decided to end a four-year freeze on arms sales to Guatemala after signs that a coup last month improved human rights conditions, according to Administration officials.

title: Around the World; French Office in Beirut Is Damaged by a Bomb
description: A bomb exploded today outside the Beirut office of Agence France-Presse. There were no injuries. The explosion caused heavy damage to the building, which also houses the French television network office.

title: Andrew Scott Parets Marries Amy Nan Sherman
description: Amy Nan Sherman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norton L. Sherman of Newton Centre, Mass., was married yesterday to Andrew Scott Parets, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Parets of La Jolla, Calif. Rabbi Bernard Mehlman performed the ceremony at the Belmont (Mass.)

title:
GARDENING;
WHAT TO PLANT, ANNUALS OR PERRENNIALS?
description: SOME disagreement exists among flower enthusiasts as to which requires the least work to grow, annuals or perennials. Those who champion perennials point out that they do not require replanting each year as do annuals and insist that that alone is sufficient backing for their argument.

title: CONNORS ADVANCES TO LAS VEGAS FINAL
description: Outplayed in the first set, Jimmy Connors rebounded for a 4-6, 6-2, 6-1 victory over Sandy Mayer today and a berth in the final of the $370,000 Alan King Tennis Classic.

title: 'CITYSTEADING' IN EAST ORANGE
description: NINE years ago, William S. Vogel moved his insurance company from N ewark, where it had been situated for more than 30 years, into n earby East Orange so he could expand his operations. The business g rew, and once again he looked for more room. The suburbs beckoned.

title: Other Business; HARLEY GEARS UP FOR NEW MARKETS
description: For over eight decades, Harley-Davidson has been the best-known - and since 1948 the only -name in American motorcyles. For Hell's Angels and other easy riders, the big bikes are the final word in macho.

title: LISBON LOOKS BACK TO '74 REVOLUTION
description: On Sunday, Portugal marks the eighth anniversary of the military coup that led to sweeping liberal changes, but there is not expected to be any major celebration.

title: JEWISH DAILY FORWARD: SURVIVOR AT 85
description: In the composing room, ancient Linotype machines clatter, spitting out lines of type in hot lead. The characters are those of the Hebrew alphabet, and the paper being printed is written in Yiddish.

title: SOMETHING EASY TO READ
description: The theory is simple: Give a child something easy to read -and he will. But the so-called ''easy readers,'' designed to lure 6-to-9-year-olds, are so patronizing and formulaic that they are (to use the favorite term of literary criticism among the group at which they are aimed) BOR-ing.

title: MICE IN MACY'S
description: THE GREAT RESCUE OPERATION By Jean Van Leeuwen. Illustrated by Margot Apple. 167 pp. New York: The Dial Press. $9.95. (Ages 7 to 11) By DORIS ORGEL

title: Choosing a Lawyer
description: Question: How does one choose a lawyer when one's building has been presented with a red herring (a formal declaration of a developer's plan to turn a building into a cooperative)? What does one look for? ... E.A., Manhattan Answer:An individual or a group should choose a lawyer in the same way it would choose any other professional. Consult other professionals, members of cooperative boards and people who have been through cooperative-conversion attempts. Then select the most experienced lawyer you feel comfortable with.

title: RECITAL: MUSIC CONSORT
description: The New Music Consort's evening at Carnegie Recital Hall Thursday offered two premieres, works by two of American music's familiar names and then a brief look backward to the endings of the Romantic era.

title: RECREATING A FAMED CONCERT
description: When Paul Whiteman presented a concert by his orchestra at Aeolian Hall on the afternoon of Lincoln's Birthday in 1924 (and in 1924 that still meant Feb. 12), he called it ''An Experiment in Modern Music.'' What he hoped to do was to point up the worthiness of jazz as a music, to show that it had both immediate validity and a future. In a program note, Whiteman's manager, Hugh C. Ernst, wrote that Whiteman intended to indicate ''the tremendous strides which have been made in popular music from the day of the discordant Jazz, which sprang into existence about 10 years ago from nowhere in particular, to the really melodious music of today, which -for no good reason - is still called Jazz.''

title: Researchers Advise Caution In Prenatal Exam Technique
description: Doctors should limit their use of ultrasound examinations of unborn babies until there is proof there are no harmful long-term effects associated with the technique, a medical journal has advised.

title: DERAILMENT BY A PRO
description: Avexing problem in American tournaments for many years has been the subject of professionalism. Can experts make a living in tournaments that do not offer prize money? And how, if at all, should their activities be controlled?

title: CENSUS FINS THAT NEW YORK'S POT IS STILL MELTING
description: The New York metropolitan area is home to more foreign-born people than to people born in other parts of the United States, new figures from the 1980 census show.

title: MURDEROUS ENTERTAINMENT
description: TWICE SHY By Dick Francis. 307 pp. New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons. $13.95.

title: Multimillion Goof
description: Overly generous Social Security checks were cranked out last month for 2,000 retired people - each check about $5,000 too high.

title: BIRD DOES THE BEST HE CAN
description: ONE of the best players in the National Basketball Association, and, arguably, one of the finest of all time, has r ecently been a second-string player with the Boston Celtics.As the Celtics open defense of their N.B.A. championship against t he Washington Bullets this afternoon, Larry Bird will play, and playa great deal, but possibly not right away. Two months ago, Bird was ar egular, but an injury put him on the sidelines for five games. When h e returned, the Celtics were in a winning streak, and Coach Bill F itch decided not to alter the starting lineup. Bird, who earns $ 650,000 a year, did not flinch. There has been, according to o bservers and statistics, little appreciable difference in his play.

title: MINISTER CALLS REAGAN'S TUITION PLAN DIVISIVE
description: A Baptist minister said last week that tuition tax credits for parents of pupils in private schools would be unconstitutional and religiously divisive.

title: CONCESSIONS BY UNIONS PROMPT WORRIED DEBATE
description: The American union movement is facing an important new challenge as it accedes, in industry after industry, to employers' demands for concessions on wages, benefits and work rules, labor experts say.

title: Around the Nation; 50 Arrested in Riot At Boston Rock Concert
description: A riot erupted at a Boston University rock concert today and about 100 police officers broke up a crowd of almost 600 people, arresting 50.

title: CONCRETE CANOES TO VIE
description: Engineering students from 10 colleges will compete Saturday in the annual Concrete Canoe Race Festival in Echo Lake Park, Westfield. The festival's organizers expect thousands to watch as the students paddle madly around a 700-yard triangular course from 10 A.M. to 3 P.M. The event is free.

title: JOIN THE ARMY AND EARN THAT SHEEPSKIN
description: WHEN Nicholas Tenerelli quit community college for financial reasons, he joined the Navy knowing that it would pay most of his tuition. Last month, he received his bachelor's degree in occupational education from Southern Illinois University. He earned some of his credits by taking courses from professors who drive hundreds of miles on weekends to teach at Great Lakes Naval Training Center near Chicago, where he is stationed. But most were earned in other ways.

title: TRANSLATOR AT HOME IN IBSEN'S UNIVERSE
description: For Rolf Fjelde, translation is an art and a discipline that enables him to synthesize many interests: intense love of language, a background steeped in poetry and a deep involvement in world literature and drama. As a translator of the major works of Henrik Ibsen for the last 20 years, Mr. Fjelde knows well the unusual challenges and rewards of slowly chipping away at a text a few lines at a time.

title: CAN BRAVES DO WHAT THE BROWNS DID?
description: CYNICS say the Atlanta Braves aren't good enough to win the pennant, even with their record winning streak. But worse teams have used a fast takeoff to glide in first. Hark back to the wartime season of 1944 and the St. Louis Browns.

title: IN THE WAKE OF WAR
description: THE REFUGEE SUMMER By Edward Fenton. 261 pp. New York: Delacorte. $10.95. (Ages 12 and Up) GOOD NIGHT, MR.TOM By Michelle Magorian. 318 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $11.50. (Ages 12 and Up) By SELMA G.LANES

title: FUND-RAISING CONCERTS BRING OUT THE STARS
description: ''MAY is a perfumed word,'' said Longfellow. ''It means youth, love, song.'' Judging by the Connecticut music calendar, it also means an assortment of delights. On the very first night of the merry month, there are two all-star fund-raising benefits, one to further the activities of the Shoreline Alliance for the Arts, the other for the University of Connecticut Health Center Children's Cancer Fund.

title: COLLEGES OFFER MORE BAD NEWS FOR THE POOR
description: THREE ominous responses to the problem posed by drastic reductions in Federal aid to education were reported last winter: Wesleyan University's decision to modify its ''need blind'' admissions policies to favor those who can pay for college, Harvard's announcement that it will give greater emphasis to achievement-test scores over aptitude tests in considering applicants, and the fact that state colleges and universities are reducing their remedial programs and becoming more selective in admissions. All three actions put a new limit on access to higher education.

title: HOW THE BANKS ARE SQUEEZING SMALL BUSINESS
description: MANY of the country's small businesses are recounting experiences similar to that of Utility Industries of Somerdale, N.J. ''If we borrow, it's two or three percentage points above the prime rate, while big companies borrow well below the prime,'' said Wiley J. Pickett, owner of the $500,000-a-year company, which makes devices to pull cables through conduits. ''Not that I'm complaining about what big business gets. It's what small business doesn't get,'' Mr. Pickett added.

title: In the Arts' Critics' Choices
description: FILM A week before the Film Society of Lincoln Center holds its gala tribute to Billy Wilder, there'll be another tribute of sorts at Carnegie Hall Cinema. Overlooked Wilder films (''The Private Life of Sherlock Holmes,'' ''Kiss Me, Stupid'') will be represented, as well as successful ones (''The Fortune Cookie,'' ''Irma La Douce'').

title: Comment; MA BELL SPEAKING
description: The following are excerpts from a speach given by Charles L. Brown, chairman of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, at the company's annual meeting held last week in Baltimore.

title: BEGINNINGS AND ENDINGS
description: CHILDREN are immortal. A child will describe in lurid detail the number and circumstance of his or her vomitings, yet the child has no conception of what illness is.

title: Index; International
description: Bush arriving in Seoul amid con- cern over anti-Americanism 3 U.S. aides see growing Soviet threat in Asia and Pacific 3 Broad survey of genocide in Cam- bodia is planned 4 Around the World 5 Soviet industry records poor first quarter 6 Schmidt party's economic plan may shake governing coalition 7 Algerian calls for better relations with the United States 9 Visiting Namibian churchmen pessimistic about talks 10 Qaddafi to make official visit to Greece 11 Israeli archeologists wind up Sinai excavation program 12 Canadian doctors agitating for higher salaries 20
