''I Love You'' opens at Baronet 71 A restored Mozart opera ''Giardi- niera'' is staged 71 Ballet Theater changes princi- pals in ''Wild Boy'' 71 Style Pre-Derby parties start on a fast track 72

title:
DEBUTS IN REVIEW;
Pianists, Seunghee Kim And Steven Silverman
description: Three pianists performed at Carnegie Recital Hall in concerts April 17, two as recitalists and one as an accompanist. The programs of both the recitalists, Steven Silverman and Seunghee Kim, marked their New York debuts.

title: Black Female Artists To Present Exhibition
description: The fourth Exhibition of Black Women Artists of Brooklyn and Environs will be at the Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church, 85 South Oxford Street, in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn, through May 2. More than 200 works by 53 artists are on display.

title: REGION'S TAXES CROSS BORDERS AND AIMS
description: Motorists waiting on toll lines at Port Authority bridges and tunnels often find themselves staring at billboards proclaiming, ''One Region, Indivisible.'' Except for those bridges and tunnels, though, regionalism in the New York area seems in scarce supply. Nowhere is this more evident than in the levying of taxes.

title: WINNERS OF $1,000 MERIT SCHOLARSHIPS NAMED
description: A total of 1,800 high school seniors from throughout the country have been named winners of $1,000 scholarships in the 26th annual competition sponsored by the National Merit Scholarship Corporation.

title: LITTLE BIG MAN
description: ON By Thomas J. Dygard. 221 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $8.50. (Ages 12 to 16) By ROBERT E.HOOD

title: The World in Summary; Enter Brezhnev, Impassively
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev has ended four weeks of speculation about his whereabouts. The 75-year-old Soviet leader last week walked onstage at the Moscow Palace of Congresses and thus dispelled rumors that the stroke he is believed to have suffered was fatal.

title: WICKES COMPANIES SEEK DEBT SHELTER
description: The financially ailing Wickes Companies, one of the nation's biggest retailers, sought relief from its debts today by filing here for protection under Federal bankruptcy laws.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN PHILADELPHIA
description: WILLIAM ROBBINS is a correspondent for The Times based in Philadelphia. By WILLIAM ROBBINS

title: The Art of Teaching Science
description: Poets and philosophers should join scientists in being thankful for Lewis Thomas (''The Art of Teaching Science,'' March 14).

title: BOARD FEUD THREATENS G.O.P. USE OF MAJORITY
description: He has said he might leave Republican ranks, although other Republicans tend to dismiss that as a threat, and he had hinted that he might not join in appointing a successor to the late John L. Messina of Port Chester, thus maintaining the Republicans' inability to utilize their majority role.

title: HALT THE ABUSE OF HABEAS CORPUS UNLIMITED
description: To the Editor:

title: Best Films on TV
description: Triple-Header Saturday is a film bonanza - five good ones in a row, starting with two early-afternoon bargains - ''Man of a Thousand Faces'' at 1 P.M. on Channel 9 and ''The Return of Frank James'' on Channel 5 at 3 P.M.

title: A MAJOR GAIN FOR THE DISABLED
description: year-old student who has been deaf since childhood, has become so adept at using the computers at the Mill Neck Manor School for the Deaf that she earned college credits in computer programming last summer at Southampton Community College on Long Island.

title: A RAINBOW FOR A HEART
description: IWAS driving my 7-year-old daughter to school when she gasped and s aid, ''Oh, no! I forgot something. Turn around, Mom. We have to go b ack.'' ''What is it?'' said I. ''Your math homework?''

title: Terese B. Bienfait Becomes a Bride
description: Terese Brent Bienfait, an assistant in the American decorativearts department of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, was married yesterday to John Poor Townsend Blake, a statistical analyst in New York.

title: Vermeer
description: To the Editor:

title: VERSE FIRST, POETRY NEXT
description: BY current consensus, verse is a type of poetry with definite boundaries of form, whose subject matter is either frothy or funny or both. In other words, it is not to be taken as seriously as ''real poetry.'' ''The Princeton Encyclopedia of Poetry and Poetics'' hasn't the audacity to blurt out that piece of news. Webster's Dictionary says only that poetry has ''a quality that stirs the imagination'' and ''a quality of spontaneity and grace'' and that verse may be ''distinguished from poetry especially by its lower level of intensity.''

title: THERE'S A LIMIT IN RENT FOR STORE SPACE IN CO-OPS
description: SUPPOSE you own a cooperative apartment on Lexington Avenue and you learn that the building's street-floor s hops are paying only $25 a square foot rent while comparable space n ext door is going for $50. Before you condemn your co-op board for m alfeasance, you ought to familiarize yourself with Section 216 of t he Internal Revenue Code.

title: Rain Postpones Moore Fight
description: The World Boxing Association juniormiddleweight title fight between Davey Moore, the champion, and Charlie Weir, ranked fourth, was postponed today until Monday because of rain.

title: VAMPIRE ON THE MOON
description: THE DARKANGEL By Meredith Ann Pierce. 223 pp. Boston: Atlantic-Little, Brown. $11.95. (Ages 12 and Up)

title: MARGIOTTA ALLY MIFFED OVER POST
description: MARVIN MIDDLEMARK is a businessman who is one of Joseph M. Margiotta's closest friends. He was one of the few friends to show up faithfully every day at the county Republican leader's mail-fraud and extortion trials last year. They lunched together practically every day during the trials.

title: REAGAN HOPEFUL RATES WILL DECREASE
description: President Reagan, in his fourth weekly radio address, said today that he thought interest rates could come down soon because of certain harbingers around the nation.

title: REDISCOVERING AN OBSCURE VIRTUOSO
description: The story of Charles-Valentin Alkan's death is one of those possibly apocryphal tales that gives us some insight into his life as well. The 19th-century virtuoso pianist and composer was a neighbor and friend of Chopin, was admired by Bulow, and was said by Lizst to have ''the finest technique I have ever known.'' That worldly figure died in 1888 at the age of 74, when a bookcase fell on him. He was reaching for a volume of the Talmud kept in a privileged position on the top shelf.

title: U.S. IS EXPECTED TO SUPPORT BRITISH IF HAIG MEDIATION PROVES FRUITLESS
description: With time apparently running out on Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.'s efforts to mediate the Falkland Islands crisis, high-ranking Administration officials say his failure to make real progress soon would be expected to result in American support for Britain over Argentina.

title: THERE IS MORE O THE GAME THAN JUST WINNING IT
description: ''YOU got ears, kid? I told you to use your elbows under those boards. You let me worry about the refs. You're out there to win a ball game, idiot! Now sit out!'' An angry coach screams. A frustrated boy tries to hide his tears from his teammates. The boy is 12 years old.

title: U.S. LOSING ITS LEVERAGE IN SALVADOR
description: After nearly a month of bickering, cajoling and subtle threats, the new Government of El Salvador began to take shape last week. But it was not the shape that Washington or its beleaguered allies, the Christian Democrats, had hoped for.

title: FREEZE NOW-BUILDUP (IF CALLED FOR) LATER
description: To the Editor:

title: Fastest 3,200-Meter Relay to Villanova
description: Villanova, stung Friday when it lost the race it had dominated in the Penn Relays, struck back today. The Wildcats won three of the day's seven championship relays, capping their haul with a spectacular victory in a spectacular 3,200-meter relay.

title: THE WATCH GENERATION
description: To the Editor:

title: SETTLEMENT ENDS MINE DUMPING SUIT
description: One of the nation's longest environmental and public health lawsuits has ended with an agreement by a mining company to pay $1.84 million to Duluth, Minn., and three other communities.

title: ABOUT THE BASICS OF FUND RAISING
description: Barbara Hammond ("Cultural Groups Need New Ideas on Fund Raising," Opinion Page, April 11) begins by describing the financial crisis that now afflicts nonprofit organizations, and then goes to the haphazard thinking about the role of public funds that helped bring on a "crucial time."

title: ARENA TRIES TO KEEP THE PEACE
description: EAST RUTHERFORD AT 4 o'clock on a cold winter morning, John Dispenziere and a buddy, Patrick Doyle, two 18-year-olds from Pine Brook, pulled into the parking lot of the Brendan Byrne Arena.

title: Major News in Summary; Israel Moves On Two Fronts
description: Israel last week kept its word on peace and war. As promised, it proceeded toward the return today of the last slice of the Sinai, dispatching 7,000 soldiers to forcibly evacuate 1,200 angry holdouts who tried to obstruct the transfer to Egypt.

title: L.I. SPEAKERS BACK TOUGHER DRUNKEN-DRIVING BILLS
description: Helen LaPenter took time off today from her job as a clerk in the Nassau County District Court to tell a State Assembly hearing why she thinks New York's penalties for driving while intoxicated are not harsh enough.

title: ART: SOME FINE PLUMAGE
description: GREENWICH THE Bruce Museum could not have begun the spring season more auspiciously than with its present show of bird paintings and prints. That these are by Roger Tory Peterson, or, to use the nom de plume the ornithologist takes when on location, King Penguin, makes the occasion even more special.

title: BEHIND THE PLAYBOY DECISION
description: ATLANTIC CITY EXECUTIVES of Playboy Enterprises have expressed bewilderment over the state Casino Control Commission's denial of a gambling casino license in a split decision on April 7.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: THOUGH winter's chill is still upon the water of Mamaroneck Harbor, the county has decreed that swimming there is forbidden until further notice. So are the summertime joys of wading, water skiing and scuba diving. The reason is a broken sewage pipe from which "treated waste water water" is leaking.

title: UNIONDALE TAKES TITLE IN 1,600
description: ''We won this one for Mr. Krauser,'' Brian Cotton shouted today after Uniondale High of Long Island scored an upset victory in the school 1,600-meter relay championship at the Penn Relays.

title: Mailbox; Inside Baseball And Domeball
description: To the Sports Editor: In his column of April 8 (''Domeball: It's Not Baseball''), Dave Anderson criticizes domed ball parks for destroying baseball by transforming it. He specifically assails artificial turf for destroying the sacrifice bunt.

title: A STROLLER'S TOUR OF THE CITY
description: LESLIE BENNETTS, a reporter on the metropolitan staff of The Times, lived in Philadelphia for 12 years. By LESLIE BENNETTS

title: LINDA M. CERRO WILL BE MARRIED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gregory Cerro of West Sayville, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Linda Martha Cerro, to Robert W. Landau, son of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Landau of Bethesda, Md.

title: Czech Player May Be Defector
description: Peter Ihnacak, a member of the Czechoslovak national hockey team, was reported to have defected today and might be headed for the Quebec Nordiques of the National Hockey League.

title: TOOL ORDERS FELL 61.2% IN MARCH
description: New orders for machine tools continued to slide in March, and industry analysts now say that orders this year will slip below the depressed levels of last year.

title: Reynolds to L.S.U.
description: Jerry (Ice) Reynolds, 6-foot-8-inch basketball star at Alexander Hamilton High School in Brooklyn, New York, has signed a letter of intent to attend Louisiana State, Coach Dale Brown said today. He had been recruited by Wisconsin, but failed to meet academic requirements.

title: U.S. Steel Layoffs
description: The United States Steel Corporation said Friday that it had furloughed 180 workers from its Fairfield facility, cutting the total work force to about 4,000, almost half of its 1978 production level of more than 8,000.

title: NO. 3 C.I.A. OFFICIAL CALLED AS LIKELY SUCESSOR TO INMAN
description: President Reagan plans to appoint John N. McMahon, executive director of the Central Intelligence Agency, to the No. 2 job in the agency, replacing Adm. Bobby R. Inman, who resigned last week, intelligence sources said today.

title: YANKS DISMISS LEMON AND NAME MICHAEL MANAGER
description: Despite his avowal that Bob Lemon would manage the Yankees for the entire 1982 season, no matter what the team's record, George Steinbrenner dismissed Lemon yesterday for the second time in three years. Gene Michael, whom Steinbrenner dismissed as manager last September, will replace Lemon only 14 games into the season.

title: MEHARRY MEDICAL COLLEGE OF NASHVILLE FIGHTS VANDERBILT FOR HOSPTIAL RIFGTS
description: Meharry Medical College, which has trained almost half the nation's black physicians and dentists, is waging a battle to survive that has led to a clash with Vanderbilt University, its much larger and predominantly white rival across town.

title: Penn Central Settlement
description: A shareholder group that blocked the Penn Central Corporation from a $1.4 billion takeover of Colt Industries last fall will be paid $975,000 in settlement of $1.8 million in expenses, Penn Central told stockholders in proxy materials for the May 20 annual meeting. Among the group were Howard Terry, a director, and representatives of the Hunt brothers.

title: People
description: * John H. Horne named general manager of Kenyon & Eckhardt's New York office.

title: THE IRAQI GOVERNMENT IS NOT FALTERING
description: To the Editor:

title: Soft Morning Wins Bouwerie
description: Soft Morning beat the favorite, Pay or Play, by a neck in yesterday's seven-furlong $57,000 Bouwerie Stakes at Aqueduct. There was a nine-minute delay before the result was made official because of a general stewards' inquiry prompted by some heavy traffic on the run through the backstretch.

title: French Prime Minister Visits Quebec for Talks
description: The French Prime Minister, Pierre Mauroy, flew to the predominantly French-speaking province of Quebec, the second leg of a six-day visit to Canada.

title: LEGISLATURE IS READY TO TRY OVERRIDING CAREY ON BUDGET
description: With negotiations between the legislative leaders and Governor Carey near collapse, the State Legislature prepared over the weekend to try overriding at least a share of Mr. Carey's $900 million in budget vetoes.

title: DEFAULT GIVES CONNORS FINAL
description: Jimmy Connors won the $60,000 first prize in the Alan King Tennis Classic today when Gene Mayer retired in the first set of the final with a severe ankle sprain.

title: LYMAN H. BUTTERFIELD, EDITOR OF THE ADAMS PAPERS
description: Lyman Henry Butterfield, a historian who edited the landmark Adams Papers and a former director of the Institute of Early American History, died at New England Deaconess Hospital in Boston yesterday after a long illness. He was 72 years old and lived in Cambridge, Mass.

title: TIMES SQUARE: WRONG SPOT FOR A COOL BILLION
description: To the Editor:

title: PUBLIC SHELTERS IN CITY DRAWING YOUNG AND ABLE
description: With conditions improving at New York City's public shelters for the homeless, officials say the shelters have begun attracting hundreds of people who might otherwise remain in other housing.

title: MUSIC: SHEENA EASTON
description: highland-lassie image for all its considerable charm. But when she sang, Miss Easton, who has enjoyed several big United States hits, including ''Morning Train'' and ''For Your Eyes Only,'' became an ordinary, cosmopolitan pop soprano - piercingly direct in her attack and somewhat thin in timbre.

title: THE CLASHES OVER DOCUMENTARIES ON PUBLIC TV
description: In recent weeks, as public television has reached into controversial areas of News Analysis American life and United States foreign policy, there has been an increase in the tension between the officials who run public television and the Government that in large measure supports it.

title: Soviet Six Beats Canada for Title
description: The Soviet Union fought off a challenge and defeated Canada, 6-4, today to capture its 18th world hockey championship.

title: TEXTS OF ARGENTINE AND BRITISH STATEMENTS
description: Following is the text of an Argentine Government statement yesterday in Buenos Aires on the military action in South Georgia, as translated by The Associated Press, and the text of a British Government statement read later in London by Defense Secretary James Nott: Argentine Statement

title: 24 Concerts Scheduled For Season at Caramoor
description: The Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts will begin its summer festival June 26 in Katonah, N.Y. The festival will present 24 concerts on the 117-acre Caramoor estate.

title: Military Analysis
description: Britain's recapture of the port of Grytviken on the Falkland Islands dependency of South Georgia combined the element of surprise with thorough reconnaissance, according to NATO analysts here.

title: FOUR RESOLUTE MEN
description: Israel's final withdrawal from the Sinai put so much strain on all parties that its completion brings a feeling of relief rather than celebration. But it is a profound achievement, and it should be recognized as such: a reason for hope in what has for so long been the tensest region of a tense world.

title: BOB LEMON'S 14-GAME YEAR
description: IT was cruel and it was ugly: all the talk about Bob Lemon being given a full year to manage the Yankees, a last hurrah with dignity and patience. ''There will be no change this year,'' Steinbrenner said last Dec. 9. ''I wouldn't care how the team is doing. I'm not going to make a change in 1982 unless it's dictated by something other than how the team is doing.''

title: Shields Is Winner
description: Jim Shields of Woodside, Queens, former star at William and Mary College, won the Manufacturers Hanover Queens five-mile run at Flushing Meadows Park yesterday.

title: Suns Win Series
description: Walter Davis scored 30 points and Dennis Johnson 26 Saturday night as they led the Phoenix Suns to a 124-119 victory over the Denver Nuggets in the third and deciding game of their opening-round playoff series. Phoenix will play the Los Angeles Lakers, who drew a bye in the opening round, in a four-of-seven-game Western Conference semifinal series that will begin Tuesday night in Los Angeles.

title: Thousands Turn Out To Greet British Ship
description: A crowd estimated by the police at about 15,000 turned out in bright sunshine to welcome the Queen Elizabeth 2 after an Atlantic crossing that followed the course of William Penn's voyage of 1682.

title: OUTDOORS: NORTHEASTERNERS READY FOR SHAD TO RUN
description: NORTHEASTERNERS with a yen to go shad fishing this spring have had to postpone their excursions for, on the average, 10 days or two weeks.

title: FEWER VIETNAMESE REACH THAI COAST
description: Vietnamese ''boat people'' have been arriving on the southern coast of Thailand in markedly smaller numbers this year than in the first three months of last year or the year before, according to a field officer here for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees.

title: SHORTCUT TO RETARDING SOVIET TECHNNOLOGY
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A review last Tuesday of the City Opera production of ''Medea'' incorrectly reported Eileen Farrell's performance history in the title role. She sang the role in San Francisco in September 1958.

title: McEnroe in Final
description: John McEnroe will try to become the first three-time winner of the World Championship Tennis title when he meets Ivan Lendl Monday night.

title: DELAYS AHEAD ON CONRAIL LINE
description: Starting Monday, riders of Conrail's Upper Harlem line will be asked to make concessions to progress during off-peak hours on weekdays. They will find that the line has become a combination train-and-bus shuttle at those times.

title: MAKE NEW YORK GROW WHERE IT NEEDS TO GROW
description: To the Editor:

title: Mariners Win, but Perry Misses 299th
description: Todd Cruz's leadoff home run in the bottom of the 11th inning, his fourth hit of the day, gave the Seattle Mariners a 5-4 victory over the Minnesota Twins today.

title: Brewers 11, Rangers 6
description: Cecil Cooper drove in three runs with two doubles and a single, and Rollie Fingers pitched two scoreless innings of relief for Milwaukee.

title: Royals 6, Indians 3
description: KANSAS CITY (AP) - Lee May and George Brett hit homers, leading Kansas City to a sweep of the three-game series. May, who had not hit a homer since July 1980, pounded a pitch from Bert Blyleven (2-1) over the left-field fence in the fifth.

title: SENATOR JACKSON SEES PRESSING NEED FOR EXPANDED U.S. SOVIET HOT LINE
description: Senator Henry M. Jackson urged the United States and the Soviet Union today to establish a jointly manned communications center to ease what he called a growing concern that a nuclear war might be touched off by accident.

title: CAIRO HAS HIGH HOPES FOR THE FUTURE OF SINAI
description: Before Israel captured the Sinai Peninsula in the 1967 war, the vast desert's relationship to Cairo was as remote as Alaska's to New York City.

title: Sports World Specials; Moore's Opinions
description: Bobby Moore of Britain remembers when his country won the World Cup soccer tournament in 1966. After England defeated West Germany, 4-2, in overtime at Wembley Stadium in London, Moore was voted the player of the tournament and a few years later was described by Pele, Brazil's incomparable offensive star, as ''the world's greatest defender.''

title: Orioles 2, White Sox 1
description: BALTIMORE (AP) - Rick Dempsey hit a two-run homer, and Dennis Martinez won for the 11th straight time at Memorial Stadium. It was only the seventh victory on a Sunday for the Orioles in 22 attempts over two seasons.

title: DANCE: GREENHOUSE ENSEMBLE
description: IS it possible that choreographers can approach their art too thoughtfully? In its 10 years of existence, the Greenhouse Dance Ensemble has proved to be a modern-dance group of taste and intelligence, and its concert Saturday at the Theater of the Riverside Church was no exception. But seldom did one have a sense of choreographers engaged in the physical immediacy of their dance.

title: CENSUS HELPS CITY PLAN NEEDS
description: Drawing on the results of the 1980 census, the New York City Planning Commission has projected in its annual report the requirements and priorities for maintaining New York's roads, sewers, bridges and other basic needs for the next decade.

title: DANCE: MMD, WITH TANAKA
description: A DANCER joined two musicians in the hourlong choreographic jam session presented Wednesday night at the Japan Society by a trio called MMD. Taking its name from the first initials of its members - Min Tanaka, dancer; Milford Graves, percussionist, and Derek Bailey, guitarist -MMD appears to strive for a vitality akin to that of a good jazz combo. And its three members are certainly accomplished in their fields. But what made their event puzzling rather than invigorating was Mr. Tanaka's performing manner.

title: The U.N. Today; April 26, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets on Palestinians at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: That Time of Year Again at an Illinois Museum
description: For those who had trouble remembering to set their clocks ahead an hour for daylight time, take the example of William Andrewes, who heads the Time Museum in Rockford, Ill., where he is in charge of 2,500 rare timepieces. Mr. Andrewes, who is 32 years old, has the twice-yearly chore of changing the time on about 75 of them. Actually, he doesn't consider it a chore at all.

title: 2 in the Hall Of Clutter
description: IN those years, boxers trained for a big New York fight out in Pompton Lakes, N.J., at Doc Bier's place, a big, white colonial house surrounded by several small cottages. After dinner, the trainers Ray Arcel and Jack Blackburn, who were often there with various fighters, would sit under the trees and talk until the mosquitoes chased them inside. Sometimes they would talk about finding the heavyweight champion. And then one day Ray Arcel happened to see Jack Blackburn in Chicago.

title: Reds 4, Astros 3
description: HOUSTON (UPI) - Dave Concepcion's sacrifice fly in the top of the 10th inning brought in Ed Milner with the winning run. Milner reached first on an infield hit when Randy Moffitt (0-1) of Houston mishandled a dribbler down the third-base line.

title: No Headline
description: Faced with unplayable, marshlike conditions, PGA Tour officials reduced the New Orleans Open at the rain-plagued Lakewood Country Club from 72 to 54 holes today and hoped for one day of dry weather.

title: BARBARA BUSH: CHEERING ON THE REAGAN TEAM
description: She doesn't prance around with pompoms or kick up her heels, but Barbara Bush is one of the most vocal cheerleaders on Ronald and Nancy Reagan's team.

title: PENTAGON AIDE FACES OUSTER OVER DISCLOSURE
description: The Reagan Administration has begun proceedings to dismiss a Pentagon official who is accused of unauthorized disclosure of secret information to Congressional officials and the news media, according to Administration officials.

title: MUSIC: SHOSTAKOVICH STRING QUARTETS
description: WE live in a time in which Beethoven cycles of every sort have become a commonplace. There will be a Brahms ''celebration'' next season at Carnegie Hall, and Lincoln Center offers us ''Mostly Mozart'' year after year. But comprehensive looks at 20th-century masters are more infrequent. Promotors can adduce box-office resistance to modern music, but there are certain composers whose work is assured of a place in the affections of posterity. With them, one can only ascribe the lack of present-day performances to a collective failure of nerve by promoters, performers and public alike.

title: American Hospital To Appeal Ruling
description: The American Hospital Supply Corporation of Evanston, Ill., said Friday that it would appeal the decision of a Federal judge who ruled that it had tried to monopolize the market for medical and surgical supplies.

title: PROS LIKE LOOKS OF 2 PENN STATE GUARDS IN DRAFT
description: Sean Farrell would like to be a Houston Oiler and block for Earl Campbell. Mike Munchak can see himself as a Chicago Bear, opening paths for Walter Payton. Both comprehend that one or the other but not both can become a Seattle Seahawk.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: Cousineau Signs Rich Browns' Pact
description: Tom Cousineau says he is happy to be back in Ohio and eager to play for the Cleveland Browns.

title: FORT GREENE'S DWELLERS CELEBRATE ITS TREASURES
description: Fresh lumber was being carried into brownstone basements and power tools were droning out open windows in Brooklyn's Fort Greene section yesterday as residents and visitors strolled the sunny streets, at once celebrating historic treasures and current creative vitality.

title: Argentine Submarine Was Once U.S. Vessel
description: The Santa Fe, the Argentine submarine attacked by British helicopters today, was commissioned by the United States as the Catfish in 1945 and was sold to Argentina in 1971, according to Jane's Fighting Ships, a standard reference book of the world's navies.

title: Snead Duo Wins
description: Sam Snead and Don January didn't let the Legends of Golf Tournament get away from them again today. Snead and January took the $100,000 first-place prize by 12 strokes - ending two years of frustration in which they had faded on the final round.

title: 2 DAYTON PAPERS TO JOIN STAFFS
description: Dayton's two large daily newspapers will combine their editorial staffs as part of a reorganization to cut costs, the publisher has announced.

title: Washington Watch; Rumania Loan Payment Claim
description: WASHINGTON A second Government agency, the Export-Import Bank, has been asked for reimbursement of federally guaranteed or insured loans to Eastern Europe.

title: Harvard Scores
description: Harvard's heavyweight crew won its 20th straight Compton Cup today, defeating Princeton by four lengths on the Charles. M.I.T. was third. Harvard covered the 2,000 meters in 6 minutes 10.4 seconds. The Crimson also won the junior varsity race, and Princeton took the freshman event.

title: NO STRAIGHT AND NARROW LINE FOR FALL
description: Anne Klein's designers, Donna Karan and Louis dell'Olio, based their fall collection on the bathrobe. Ronaldus Shamask was concerned with medieval monks' robes. Harriet Winter devised new ways to design coats, and Vera Maxwell found a new source for prints in workshops connected with the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

title: MONDAY, APRIL 26, 1982; The Economy
description: The depressed economy slashed corporate profits in the first quarter. Hardest hit were the auto, steel, airline and other cyclical industries. Although banks profited handsomely from high interest rates, brokerage houses heavily dependent on retail trade showed large declines. (Page D1.)

title: Edward Carroll Plays New Trumpet Music
description: Edward Carroll, a fine trumpet player and deft programmer, divided his Saturday afternoon at the Metropolitan Museum of Art between new music and the Baroque. The newer pieces never added up to much; but except for William Kraft's boring and blatant ''Encounters III,'' with Gordon Gottlieb, percussionist, the other entries - Tomasi's ''Semaine Sainte a Cuzco,'' with the organist William Whitehead, David Short's ''Colloquio'' and Richard Moryl's ''Rainbows,'' both with Cameron Grant as pianist -consistently entertained.

title: C.A.B. Official to Be A Dean at Carnegie
description: Elizabeth E. Bailey, the 43-year-old vice chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, will resign in the summer of 1983 to become dean of the Graduate School of Industrial Administration at Carnegie-Mellon Univesity in Pittsburgh.

title: REQUIRED READING
description: Bush on Arms

title: TINY COPIER MAKER TAKING A BIG STEP IN DEAL WITH CHINA
description: In the copier industry, dominated by giants, Otto A. Clark and his company, the Clark Copy International Corporation, are minuscule: Clark Copy has only 23 employees and 300 stockholders. Total sales last year barely exceeded $1 million, and it spent only $1.2 million on research and development.

title: ARGENTINES EXPRESSING SURPRISE AND BITTERNESS
description: Argentines received the news today of the British attack on South Georgia Island with disbelief. The news spread slowly, building through the day, with announcements from London of British successes followed several hours later by communiques from the Argentine military junta that their soldiers were bravely fighting on.

title: Dodgers' Guerrero Accused by Fan
description: Pedro Guerrero, a Los Angeles Dodgers outfielder, was cited on a charge of battery today by the police, who acted on the complaint of a baseball fan who said that Guerrero had struck him with a clod of dirt.

title: Lewis Runs 10.09, Wins 100 Meters
description: Carl Lewis ran the fastest 100-meter race of the year, and Kellie Cathey set an American women's record in the 10,000-meter run at the Mount San Antonio College Relays today.

title: Nakajima Winner
description: Tsuneyuki Nakajima, six strokes in front at the start of the round, scored a five-stroke victory today in the $150,000 Dunlop International Open golf championship.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: With runners on first and second and one out, the batter hits a fly to the infield. The umpire signals an infield fly, but the ball strikes the pitcher's rubber and bounces foul between home and third base. What is the ruling?

title: ALLBRITTON ACTS TO EXTEND TALKS ON DAILY NEWS
description: Joe L. Allbritton, the Texas financier who is trying to acquire The Daily News, asked the present owners yesterday for more time to negotiate cost cuts with the paper's unions.

title: Schmidt and Genscher Discuss Cabinet Changes
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt met with Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher today to discuss planned Cabinet changes in their increasingly strained coalition Government, officials said.

title: Big Insurance Broker Picks Top Officers
description: At Johnson & Higgins, a large New York-based insurance brokerage concern, Edwin L. Knetzger Jr., 57, has been elected president. He succeeds Robert V. Hatcher Jr., 51, who was named chairman, while continuing as chief executive officer.

title: SYRIANS ACCUSE OTHER ARABS OF PLOTS AS SIGNS OF EGYPT'S RETURN INCREASE
description: As Israel returned the last of Sinai to Egypt today, the official Damascus radio warned that the move ''opened the door to a new phase of plotting'' against the Arab confrontation states.

title: DEUS EX MACHINA
description: When a robot at a Tasmanian industrial plant was out for servicing and repairs, its everyday jobs - the most unpleasant in the plant - suddenly became an immediate human responsibility. In no time, workers sent it a ''get well'' card.

title: Nuclear Devices Tested In Nevada and Siberia
description: A nuclear device was set off 1,890 feet underground at the Nevada Test Site today by British and United States scientists. The blast was code-named ''Gibne'' and had a yield of 20 to 150 kilotons, a maximum equivalent of 150,000 tons of TNT.

title: HAIG MISSION THROWN INTO DOUBT BY ARGENTINE'S STATEMENT ON TALKS
description: Future American mediation efforts in the Falklands crisis were thrown into doubt tonight when Argentina's Foreign Minister asked for a postponement of a meeting with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and later said Argentina had suspended talks because of Britain's military action in South Georgia.

title: Red Sox 5, Blue Jays 4
description: TORONTO (AP) - Rick Miller doubled home the tiebreaking run with one out in the 12th for Boston. Glenn Hoffman led off the Red Sox 12th with a single to center and was sacrificed to second.

title: RELATIONSHIPS
description: THE idea was inspired by the recurring bitter arguments between two p rofessors in the same department at the University of Massachusetts.A lthough the two needed to be able to communicate for the smooth o peration of the department, and both claimed to want to, their d iscussions invariably wound up in ego-scarring verbal duels.

title: Crimes Against Criminal Law
description: For 16 years, Congress has been struggling to turn thousands of confusing, inconsistent and obsolete criminal statutes into a modern criminal code. It's badly needed: a rational, accessible volume that sets forth the purpose and reach of Federal power, arranges crimes and punishments according to severity and reduces offensive sentencing disparities.

title: Canoeing New York
description: As an eager 5-year-old, David Hearn was taught by his father, a government geologist and a canoeing enthusiast, to use a paddle on a trip down the upper Missouri River in Montana. ''Son,'' he was told by his father, Carter, ''this is one of the finest sports ever created by man. You keep at it and someday, who knows? You might take part in an Olympics.''

title: O'LEARY'S SACRED COW
description: As a former flack, I doffed my hat in reverent wonderment at all that Jeremiah O'Leary has been able to do for his client.

title: ABRAMS SAYS HERTZ WILL MAKE REFUNDS TO SOME CUSTOMERS
description: The Hertz Corporation has agreed to pay $100 to $150 to certain customers who have had accidents since July 1, 1980, after taking out collision insurance on their leased cars.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt POKER FACES: The Life and Work of Professional Card Players. By David M. Hayano. 205 pages. University of California. $17.95.

title: STEINBRENNER'S MANAGERS
description: Ralph Houk - Resigned Sept. 30, 1973. Bill Virdon - Hired Jan. 3, 1974.

title: Commodities; Futures Innovation In Chicago
description: SELF congratulation always attends the opening of any new commodity market, and there was plenty of it on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange last Wednesday, when trading began in its Standard & Poor's 500 stock-index futures.

title: MISS SHEEHAN WINS
description: Patty Sheehan sank a two-and-a-halffoot putt for par on the fourth playoff hole today and defeated Kathy Postlewait in the championship round of the $150,000 Orlando Lady Classic golf tournament.

title: Market Place; Saxon Seeks Silver Lining
description: SAXON INDUSTRIES' current popularity as a trading vehicle appears to reflect conjecture that Saxon, like some companies in the past, may eventually emerge from receivership as a valuable property.

title: METS LOSE, 5-2, AS SCOTT IS POUNDED EARLY BY EXPOS
description: The New York Mets finally ended their string of one-run games against the Montreal Expos today with a 5-2 loss. Montreal clustered its runs in the first four innings, and the Mets, again without Dave Kingman's bat, lacked a counterpunch. Kingman, out with a spiked toe, was ready to provide ninth-inning help as a pinch-hitter, but never got the chance.

title: BOSTON STUDY CALLS FOR SHIFTS IN THE EDUCATION OF WORKERS
description: A study of education and the future labor market here has concluded that schools will have to shift from narrow vocational training toward producing workers with greater versatility in mathematics and language.

title: 'SILHOUETTES,' ROMANCE
description: ''SILHOUETTES,'' the new film at the Eastside Cinema, tries ever so hard to be charming, and sometimes it almost succeeds. After all, how far wrong can you go with sunny Sorrento, a June-December romance, no sex or violence (well, just the tiniest bit of sex) and a male lead who never stops smiling? The male lead is George David Weiss, who has been lyricist, composer or both for a great many popular songs - ''Lullaby of Birdland,'' ''Mr. Wonderful'' and ''Rumors Are Flying,'' to name only a few - and is also the co-author of the screenplay for ''Silhouettes.'' He plays a composer of popular songs who has fled New York when rock barbarians take over the music business. In Sorrento, he gives piano lessons and stares from his balcony at the Bay of Naples. It is lovely.

title: JEWS URGED TO OPPOSE NUCLEAR WEAPONS RACE
description: The biblical story of Noah and the flood and the remembrance of the Nazi Holocaust were key images invoked at a conference in Manhattan yesterday as Jews were called on to oppose the nuclear arms race as a matter of faith.

title: Cubs 5, Pirates 3
description: CHICAGO (AP) - Larry Bowa's two-run double highlighted a four-run fourth inning as Chicago ended a four-game losing streak. Keith Moreland doubled with one out in the fourth, and Jody Davis drew a walk off Rick Rhoden (0-2).

title: KEY WEST'S ABANDONED NAVY BASE STIRS AGAIN
description: The old, sun-bleached Navy base here, abandoned by the Defense Department in 1974, has stirred back to life as a key headquarters for United States forces in the Caribbean and Central America.

title: The Begins' Message To Mrs. Sadat
description: Following is the text of a telegram sent today by Prime Minister Menachem Begin and his wife, Aliza, to Jihan el-Sadat, widow of President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt, and made public here by the Government: Dear Mrs. Sadat: Our hearts, Madame, go out on this day to you and the children and grandchildren. Anwar Sadat, of blessed memory, should have been with us to see the glory of his efforts to make peace and achieve reconcilation between the good peoples of Egypt and Israel.

title: Moore to Defend Crown Tonight
description: Delayed by rain and beset by legal entanglements, the World Boxing Association junior middleweight title fight between Davey Moore and Charlie Weir is scheduled to take place Monday night.

title: Hungary Chief to Visit Bonn
description: Janos Kadar, the Communist Party chief, leaves Monday for a three-day visit to Bonn, becoming the first Soviet bloc leader to visit a Western nation since Poland imposed martial law Dec. 13.

title: Bell Begins New Push For Executone Phones
description: Ma Bell being everyone's favorite whipping girl - or at least one of them - it will not be surprising to see her starring in print ads and radio commercials that are intended to get business executives to install Executone phone systems in their offices to cut their phone bills.

title: IN SOUTH KOREA, SMOKE OF ANTI-AMERICANISM
description: For years as Pentagon spokesmen sought to justify defense budgets on Capitol Hill, they would point with pride to South Korea as the one country ever ready to accept American troops. Now with the burning of the American Cultural Center in Pusan on March 18, the United States is confronted with anti-Americanism unparalleled in the 100 years since it opened diplomatic relations with Korea.

title: ICEBERG PATROLS SEE A DEADLY BEAUTY
description: 130, off Newfoundland, - ''Oh, they're out here all right,'' Lieut. Frank Sturm shouted over the roar of the plane's engines. ''The trick is to find them before they find someone. And this is looking to be a real busy year.''

title: WICKES'S BIGGEST TASK: DEALING WITH SUPPLIERS
description: Last Friday evening, top executives of the Wickes Companies, one of the nation's largest retailers, gathered at the plush Century Plaza Hotel in West Los Angeles to discuss the company's shaky finances.

title: Ashkenazy Evokes The Demons of Spring
description: Vladimir Ashkenazy's performance Saturday night at Carnegie Hall was an evocative venture into the grotesque. It began with Scriabin - six tiny pieces from Opera 51 and 56 flittering and oozing like sinuous insect life, and then the Sixth Sonata, with its dabs of sickly sweetness, its disintegrating elusiveness and its vague sense of evil.

title: DR. ELLEN BETH WOLFSON IS WED TO NEIL GROBERG
description: Dr. Ellen Beth Wolfson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Wolfson of New York, was married at the Harmonie Club yesterday to Neil Groberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Groberg of New York and North Miami, Fla. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel performed the ceremony.

title: Fallout Impact Disclosed In Akron and Albany
description: Sometime between 1951 and 1962, this city and Albany, N.Y., were pelted with radioactive rain from a contaminated cloud drifting east from a Nevada nuclear testing site, it has been disclosed.

title: HOWARD WEAVER, A YALE DEAN
description: Howard Sayre Weaver, a former dean of the Yale University School of Art and a director of the Media Design Studio at Yale, died Friday at his home in Guilford, Conn., after a long illness. He was 57 years old.

title: WELLS FARGO PLANS CUTS TO RAISE PROFIT
description: Wells Fargo & Company, the nation's 12th-largest banking organization, has decided to cut back on its overall activities and concentrate on California and other Western states, according to its chairman, Richard P. Cooley.

title: Images of High School
description: ''Is There Life After High School?'' which is previewing on Broadway, is about people in their 30's looking back. The musical is not designed to appeal especially to the current crop of high-school students, but it has been getting an interesting reaction from some of them.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Stock Exchange appointed Lee J. Cutrone vice president, securities division, and William D. Strauss vice president, finance division.

title: SCHOLARS DEBATE TRUTH ABOUT TRUTH
description: ''The discovery of lying was one of the great joys of my life,'' confessed Dr. Willard Gaylin to a gathering of scholars seeking the truth about truth.

title: OPERA: GIANNA ROLANDI IN 'ARIADNE'
description: NOT many operas in the standard repertory are more difficult to cast and produce successfully than ''Ariadne auf Naxos.'' If you will recall, that would-be gentleman Jourdain commissioned an opera seria and an opera buffa for the same evening's entertainment but decided to expedite matters by ordering both to be performed simultaneously. The ramifications of this, both in the onstage drama and in what opera people think of as real life, are naturally enormous.

title: PEKING TO SET UP PILOT PROGRAM TO REHABILITATE THE HANDICAPPED
description: The Chinese Government plans to set up a pilot program in modern rehabilitation medicine after a lecture tour here by one of the world's leading specialists.

title: TV: IAN MCKELLEN PLAYS SHAKESPEARE ON PBS
description: IAN McKELLEN is not exactly a household name in American television homes. The British actor does not enjoy the popularity here of, say, Laurence Olivier or Benny Hill. Yet, he is considered by many to be one of the most distinguished performers of his generation. Theater audiences were able to appreciate this claim because of the Broadway production of ''Amadeus,'' for which his portrayal of Salieri won a Tony award. Now, on a national public-television scale, on WNET-TV at 9 o'clock this evening, he is being given a very special showcase in ''Ian McKellen Acting Shakespeare.''

title: UNDER THE SUN OF SPRING, BICYCLES, BASEBALL, MIMES AND JUST STROLLING
description: Yesterday, when the long-lost sun had warmed the sidewalks on West 86th Street, Marian Ekberg stepped out from her room with her cane for the 80th spring of her life. She caught her breath at the sight of the concourse of people, with strollers and picnic baskets in hand, headed toward Central Park.

title: SONICS OUST ROCKETS
description: The Seattle SuperSonics, led by Jack Sikma's 30 points and 17 rebounds, scored a 104-83 victory over the Houston Rockets today to capture their Western Conference opening playoff series, 2 games to 1.

title: I.M.F.-MOROCCO ACCORD
description: The International Monetary Fund has completed negotiations with Morocco on a multimillion-dollar financial package that is likely to be formally approved Monday, monetary and diplomatic sources said Friday. The sources estimated the size of the one-year agreement at about $400 million and said it was reached after complex and sensitive negotiations.

title: Quake Jolts Eastern Turkey
description: A mild earthquake shook several provinces in southeastern Turkey but caused no injuries or property damage, the local authorities reported today. They said the quake lasted at least seven seconds Saturday night. A spokesman for the Istanbul-based Kandilli Observatory said the tremor registered 3 on the Richter scale.

title: BRIEFING
description: Thinking of Leaving

title: WHITE HOUSE BUDGET SESSION AGAIN FAILS TO MAKE PROGRESS
description: Budget negotiators held another round of inconclusive talks at the White House today, with hopes of a compromise with President Reagan still unfulfilled.

title: OPINIONS ARE MIXED IN ANTINUCLEAR DRIVE'S IMPACT
description: Representative Timothy E. Wirth, a Democrat who represents Boulder, home of the University of Colorado, assessed as ''wonderful'' the weeklong series of lectures, films and entertainment in his district focusing on the perils of nuclear war.

title: SURVIVORS RUN FOR THE ROSES
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky. WHAT began on winter and spring nights of 1979, when 34,497 thoroughbred mares delivered foals who might have run in this year's Kentucky Derby, is reaching its conclusion this week amid only one certainty: the best of that generation will not be running for the roses.

title:
MUSIC NOTED IN BRIEF;
McKee and Miss Woods Sing 'Gerolstein' Leads
description: The New York City Opera's fifth performance of Offenbach's ''The Grand Duchess of Gerolstein'' went smoothly Saturday evening with new singers in three of the principal roles. It was hard to believe that the production had not been designed around two of them.

title: DARING PIRONI BEATS FERRARI TEAMMATE
description: Didier Pironi defied Ferrari team orders and engaged his teammate, Gilles Villeneuve, in a series of duels on the final laps today and won the Grand Prix of San Marino.

title: Parker-Hannifin Names Successor to a Parker
description: Paul G. Schloemer, 53, has been appointed president of the Parker-Hannifin Corporation, a major manufacturer of fluid power products for business and industry, effective July 1. He will succeed Patrick S. Parker, 52, who remains chairman and chief executive officer of the company, whose headquarters are in Cleveland.

title: STICKING POINTS IN THE DISPUTE
description: Between Governor Carey and the legislative leaders lies a gap of about $650 million. The question that is keeping New York budgetless is whether the plan approved by the Legislature last month is in balance.

title: Steel Union Charges Bonn
description: Eleven specialty steel companies and the United Steelworkers union have charged that steel from West Germany is being dumped in the United States at prices below the cost of production.

title: Mother Teresa, in Japan Visit, Says Abortion Harms Peace
description: Mother Teresa, the Nobel Peace Prize winner, said today that ''abortion is destroying the home, and destroying the home will destroy peace among nations.''

title: Smithsonian Requests An Asia-Africa Museum
description: WASHINGTON (AP) - The Smithsonian Institution has asked Congress to authorize a $74 million underground museum in Washington as a showcase for art from Asia and Africa.

title: RECESSION PUTS PROFITS IN A SLUMP
description: The slumping United States economy severely depressed the earnings of a broad variety of American companies during the first quarter, according to reports issued thus far.

title: Vornado Loss Widens
description: Vornado Inc., the operator of the defunct Two Guys discount store chain, reported Friday that it had a loss of $56.1 million for the fiscal year ended Jan. 30, compared with a loss of $3.56 million in the prior year. The deficit includes a loss of $62.4 million from the closing of all the Two Guys stores, compared with a loss of $5.06 million from discontinued operations the year before. Earnings from continuing operations, which include the real estate and merchandising businesses, were $6.3 million, or $1.18 a share, up from $1.5 million, or 28 cents a share, the year before.

title: SINAI PENINSULA: THE YEARS OF CONFLICT
description: 1948. Israeli troops, pursuing retreating Egyptian forces, captured parts of northeastern Sinal, including Abue Aweigila, Kusseima the approaches to El Arish. Israel withdrew after pressure from the United States and threats of military intervention by Britain.

title: 3 KEY AIDES RESHAPE WELFARE POLICY
description: Hardly any issue has caused President Reagan more political difficulty than his domestic social policy, with its sharp reductions in Federal benefit programs.

title: MOYNIHAN AFTER ONE TERM: THE PROS AND CONS OF INDEPENDENCE
description: In a hotel ballroom in New York the other day, a thousand people listened in engrossed silence as Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan delivered a nine-page treatise on the merits of American government and the principles of the founding fathers. Along the way, the Senator found reason to touch on nuclear war, the Middle East, the Atlantic alliance and Argentina.

title: 2 Killed, 1 Burned In Brooklyn Fire
description: Two people were killed and one critically burned when a fire roared through a building in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn shortly before noon yesterday, the Fire Department reported.

title: WINNING IMAGE IN ITS TRICENTENNIAL GIVES PHILADELPHIA REASON TO CELEBRATE
description: This city, it seems, still clings to the memory of the night when its townspeople went mad. It was a night when the dark and stolid statue of William Penn, still seeming to brood over the city he fathered 300 years ago, looked out from the City Hall tower upon the bedlam reigning in celebration of the Philadelphia Phillies' victory in the World Series.

title: So Close to Top
description: The intestinal surgery that was performed on Timely Writer last week, eliminating the probable favorite from the Kentucky Derby and the other two Triple Crown races, reminded some race track aficionados of another pre-Derby favorite who was forced to miss thoroughbred racing's biggest attraction because of an injury.

title: Angkor Lives
description: Out of the Cambodian jungle comes the good news that the great temples of Angkor survive. The ruin has been battered by gunfire, gnawed by looters and ensnared by vines, but after 12 years of civil war, aerial bombardment and invasions, it is essentially intact.

title: Bekins Buy-Out
description: The Bekins Company said Friday that a leveraged buy-out of the company by two of its directors had been discussed, but that both sides had agreed to terminate negotiations.

title: 76ers Win, 125-122, as Erving Scores 34
description: There were flying dunks, scoop shots, reverse layups, offensive tip-ins and even a few ordinary jump shots in Julius Erving's repertory today.

title: Struck by Javelin, Girl, 17, Dies
description: A high school girl from Tolna died Saturday from injuries suffered when she was struck by a javelin during a track and field meet.

title: SERIES TO NORDIQUES
description: Dave Pichette, a defenseman, scored the winning goal in the third period as the Quebec Nordiques defeated the Boston Bruins, 2-1, tonight to capture their Adams Division playoff series by 4 games to 3.

title: Bodies Found After Blast
description: Volunteer firefighters today recovered three bodies from a huge mound of corn and concrete left when a grain elevator exploded, killing five men. No official cause of the blast here has been announced, but Fire Chief Norman Elgan and others have said the cause was most likely grain dust ignited by a spark.

title: THEATER: 'PAPER FLOWERS,' IN ENGLISH AND SPANISH
description: IN 1970, Egon Wolff, a chemical engineer in Chile who became one of the better-known playwrights in Latin America, wrote a drama called ''Flores de Papel.'' Its treatment of cultural class conflict appears to have made it something of a staple, and it can now be seen, in Spanish as well as English, at the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater.

title: FOR PROBLEM TEEN-AGERS: LOVE, TOUGHNESS
description: ''The main thing Toughlove does is give parents back some of their self-esteem,'' said Frances Mollin of Glen Cove, L.I. ''It keeps us from weakening. It gives us the courage to continue to take a stand and stick to it.''

title: Y.& R. Coast Unit Gets Suzuki Motorcycles
description: The U.S. Suzuki Motor Corporation, the marketer of Japanese-made vehicles, has slipped its motorcycle account to Young & Rubicam, Los Angeles, from Eisaman, Johns & Laws.

title: JETS SEEKING BACKUP HELP
description: Perhaps the wistful way Joe Walton, the offensive coordinator of the New York Jets, described his corps of receivers was a clue to their coming draft:

title: IN QUIET CORNWALL, BRITONS ARE UNEASY OVER NEWS
description: The news of the British invasion of South Georgia reached the tranquil, isolated southwest corner of England at sundown.

title: SURTAX PLAN DRAWS BROAD CRITICISM
description: The proposed three-year surtax on upper-income taxpayers, which the Reagan Administration and Congressional leaders seem willing to accept as part of a budget compromise, is coming under fire from conservatives and liberals.

title: U.S. PROMISES MAJOR EFFORT ON PALESTINIAN AUTONOMY
description: President Reagan assured Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel and President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt today that the United States was ''firmly committed to further progress'' in carrying out the unresolved part of the Camp David agreements dealing with self-rule for the Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: American Motors Pact Approved by First Local
description: A contract calling for workers to invest part of their wages in the American Motors Corporation's product development program has been approved by the first of three locals to vote on it.

title: STAGE: 'BAGS,' A STREET-PEOPLE MUSICAL
description: ''BAGS'' is a musical that seems to be trying to be an American ''Threepenny Opera.'' Its characters are New York City's street people, primarily its bag ladies, and its focus is a battle to save the city's old brownstones from being torn down to make way for highrise apartments.

title: The District Dance in New Jersey
description: New Jersey Republicans are still trying to throw out a Congressional district map approved by the Democrat-controlled Legislature. The state's seven Republican representatives are urging Gov. Thomas Kean, a fellow Republican, to invoke a Federal statute that would permit an at-large election if no constitutional district lines have been drawn. Such tactics would only further confuse voters, for no good public purpose.

title: 1,000 Salmon Cans Suspect in City
description: New York City's check of Alaska salmon in 7 3/4-ounce cans has turned up more than 1,000 such containers in 1,100 stores canvassed by Health Department inspectors, Bruce Berent, a department spokesman, said yesterday. Some of the cans are suspected of containing defects that could have allowed botulism toxins to develop.

title: RICHARD ATKINS MARRIES JOANNA PANG, A DANCER
description: Joanna Pang, a television actress and dancer, was married yesterday in Livingston, N.J., to Richard Atkins, a television producer. Superior Court Judge Murray Simon of Essex County, N.J., performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. S. Stephen Atkins.

title: EGYPT'S FLAG RAISED AT 2 SITES IN SINAI
description: After being kissed by dignitaries, a huge Egyptian flag was unfurled today and raised to the top of a 40-foot flagpole on a promontory overlooking the Red Sea. Hundreds of onlookers cheered and chanted as nearly 15 years of Israeli occupation of the vast Sinai peninsula came to an end.

title: BALLET THEATER: MISS VAN HAMEL INJURED IN 'JARDIN'
description: ONE of those sad but increasingly common events in the life of a dancer took place again Saturday afternoon, when Martine van Hamel of the American Ballet Theater suffered an on-stage injury.

title: CHICAGO LEADER WAS 74
description: John Cardinal Cody, the Archbishop of Chicago and spiritual leader of about 2.5 million Roman Catholics in the metropolitan area, died of heart failure shortly after 12 A.M. today. He was 74 years old.

title: THRIFTY MATERNITY CARE
description: To the Editor:

title: Swiss State Retains Male-Only Electorate
description: The all-male electorate of Switzerland's least populous canton decided overwhelmingly today to continue denying women the vote in town and cantonal elections.

title: 2 Off-Duty Officers Injured in Scuffle
description: A police officer was shot and another officer was clubbed on the head with a baseball bat early yesterday in a scuffle with teen-agers at a Queens fast-food restaurant, the police said.

title: 34 KILLED IN BLAST AT ITALIAN EXHIBIT
description: An explosion and a flash fire ripped through an antiques exhibition here today, killing at least 34 people and injuring dozens of others, the police said. Many jumped from the roof of the four-story building onto mattresses piled up below.

title: UNUSUAL U.S. TRADE SITUATION
description: Rarely is the United States thought of as a country reliant on foreign trade, the way Japan is, or many European countries. But, in recent years, American companies have looked more and more to foreign markets, and greater numbers of foreign companies have entered the American market.

title: BRITAIN REPORTS TROOPS SEIZE KEY HARBOR ON SOUTH GEORGIA AFTER FIRING ON ARGENTINE SUB
description: Argentina said early today that British forces had "apparent initial success" in their assault on the remote South Atlantic island of South Georgia.

title: PERSSON REJOINS ISLANDER LINE TOMORROW
description: When the Islanders took to the ice yesterday at the Cantiague Park rink in Hicksville, L.I., they still didn't know whether they would be facing the Boston Bruins or the Quebec Nordiques in the semifinal round of the National Hockey League playoffs, which starts tomorrow night at Nassau Coliseum.

title: EGLEVSKY BALLET: VILLELA AMERICANA
description: THE Eglevsky Ballet Company championed American music Saturday night by offering an Americana program at Hofstra University's John Cranford Adams Playhouse in Hempstead, L.I. Some of the ballets were as jolly as Fourth of July picnics. Thus, while Milton Kaye played ragtime piano music, dancers gave classical steps jazzy accents in Edward Villella's ''Legs of Lamb.'' And in his ''Prelude, Fugue and Riffs,'' to Leonard Bernstein, they cavorted like classically trained hepcats.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, APRIL 26, 1982
description: International Britain made its first military move to regain control of the Falkland Islands with the recapture of the principal port on South Georgia, which is about 800 miles east of the Falklands, and which, like the Falklands, was occupied by Argentine forces three weeks ago. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and Defense Secretary John Nott announced in London that the Argentine troops on South Georgia had surrendered after a two-hour battle. The British forces, Mr. Nott said, were landed by helicopter and supported by a number of warships. (Page A1, Column 6.) Argentina waged a last-ditch fight against a British naval bombardment and helicopter assault on South Georgia, the Buenos Aires authorities said. Without admitting that either of the two defended positions of Grytviken and Leith Harbor on the glacier-covered island, a series of communiques from the military junta appeared to preparing Argentines for the news that the first battle for the Falkland Islands had been lost. One of Argentina's four submarines was crippled by British helicopters, military sources said. (A1:3.)

title: CELTICS ROUT BULLETS IN OPENER BY 109-91
description: In the shadows of 14 championship banners swaying overhead in crusty old Boston Garden, the Celtics overwhelmed the Washington Bullets, 109-91, before a sellout crowd of 15,320 today.

title: RESEARCHERS CORRECT DEFECT IN A HUMAN GENE
description: Scientists have created and transmitted artificial genetic instructions to correct the behavior of a defective human gene that causes an incurable and often fatal blood disease.

title: An Appraisal
description: Nothing seems to frighten civic-minded residents of Denver more than the suggestion that the explosive growth of their city in the last few years has made it resemble that other energy boom town,

title: MITTERRAND ASSAILS U.S. CRITICS
description: President Francois Mitterrand of France was quoted today as saying that ''it is just too bad'' if the Reagan Administration does not like his policies in Central America.

title: ADMINISTRATOR TO FILL POST TILL POPE PICKS A SUCCESSOR TO CODY
description: A temporary administrator will be elected Monday by the city's top-ranking Roman Catholic priests to oversee church affairs until Pope John Paul II appoints a successor to John Cardinal Cody.

title: Bridge: Bob Yellis and Teammates Win L.I.'s Knockout Title
description: Knockout team events are usually designed so that the length of matches increases as the final approaches. The Long Island Regional Knockout Championship, which ended Saturday at Hofstra University in Hempstead, L.I., was an exception. Matches in the early rounds were a full session of play until three teams remained unbeaten. This would normally call for a two-session final, but one session was deemed sufficient by the organizers, increasing the element of luck in the result.

title: 10.4% British Inflation Rate
description: Britain's annual rate of inflation continued to fall in March, reaching the equivalent of 10.4 percent - the lowest level in three years, the Government announced Friday.

title: Ballesteros Wins
description: Severiano Ballesteros shot a four-underpar 68 today and won the $90,000 Madrid Open golf tournament by a shot. Jose Canizares, who started the final round two shots ahead, carded a 71.

title: Diners Club Will Use SSC&B Outside U.S.
description: Diners Club International, which has its domestic advertising done by Doyle Dane Bernbach, has decided on using SSC&B:Lintas for the rest of the known world.

title: Angels 5, A's 1
description: Bobby Grich drove in three runs with a double and a single, and Brian Downing hit his seventh homer of the season to help California sweep the three-game series. The Angels extended their home record to 9-0 this season.

title: FALKLANDS DEAL TO SAVE LIVES AND 'HONOR'
description: To the Editor:

title: Expos Cut Office
description: Rowland Office, signed by the Montreal Expos as a free agent to a long-term $1 million contract in 1979, was cut from the roster today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are not retreating from Sinai. We are demonstrating our desire to move forward toward peace.''

title: Advertising; Computers And a Beer For Ally
description: ALLY & GARGANO, the creator of the award-winning Federal Express campaign and other memorable work, will be adding its combat skills to the booming battle of the microcomputers.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: FAMILY CIRCLE

title: CARDS' 12-GAME WINNING STREAK SNAPPED BY PHILS
description: The Mets are off to a good start this season, thanks in large part to astute work by Frank Cashen, the general manager, and George Bamberger, the new field manager. But the men they replaced are also happy in their work, albeit in different settings.

title: ANALYSTS WATCH DEBT QUALITY
description: Volatile interest rates have taught investors about the risk of changing prices on notes and bonds, and analysts are now warning that the economic recession is introducing the additional risk that borrowers may have a hard time repaying their debt.

title: Giants 6, Dodgers 3
description: SAN FRANCISCO (UPI) - Jeff Leonard's first career grand slam capped a five-run eighth-inning rally that sent Fernando Valenzuela to defeat. San Francisco snapped a five-game losing streak and Los Angeles had its four-game winning streak ended.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Consumer Saturday column on the Style page incorrectly reported the time and day for two workshops sponsored by New York City's Depart- ment of Consumer Affairs. The work- shop for the disabled will begin at 1 P.M. Tuesday. The workshop for the elderly will begin at 9:30 A.M. Thurs- day.

title: Donaldson in Coast Fight
description: A money manager for Los Angeles County has accused a broker for the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation, the brokerage concern, of repeatedly placing unauthorized trading orders for nearly $11 billion in Government securities for the county.

title: NEW YORK BANK PROFITS LEAD
description: Most of the leading banks in New York reported strong net operating earnings in the first quarter, while earnings remained under pressure at the big California banks, a compilation of the results shows.

title: Corporate Gifts to the Arts Encouraged
description: Several organizations concerned with support for the arts have announced ceremonies and programs to encourage individual and corporate donations.

title: 3 Sonatas Featured In Recital by Perahia
description: There was a reflective and introverted intelligence to Murray Perahia's piano performances yesterday in Alice Tully Hall. The voices in Schubert's Sonata in G (Op. 78) were carefully defined and shaped; the textures of J.C. Bach's Sonata in C minor (Op. 5, No. 6) were sensitively balanced.

title: Leave School 'Gates' in Place
description: In the simplest sense, the promotional ''gates'' adopted by New York City's schools obviously work. The policy of not promoting students who don't meet reading requirements in the fourth and seventh grades kept back 17,500 students last fall. But some school officials now are dismayed at the prospect that many will fail the tests again and languish a second year at the same level.

title: ASHBROOK DEATH LEAVES SENATE RACE IN DOUBT
description: The death Saturday of Representative John M. Ashbrook, the leading Republican candidate for the nomination to run against Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, a Democrat, has left Ohio's political situation in doubt.

title: STUDENT SCORES RISE AFTER NEARBY SUBWAY IS QUIETED
description: Fifteen times during each school day, an IRT subway train would rumble and screech past Public School 98, near the northern tip of Manhattan. In classrooms facing the elevated tracks, all work would stop until the train barreled by.

title: RODERICK O'CONNOR WEDS LISA MARRANO IN BRONXVILLE
description: At St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Bronxville, N.Y., yesterday Lisa Marie Marrano, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leon D. Marrano Jr. of Rye, N.Y., was married to Roderick O'Connor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick O'Connor of Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. Russell Sloan performed the ceremony and concelebrated the nuptial mass with the Rev. Ernest Riordan.

title: NEW CORPORATE ISSUES REMAIN LIGHT
description: The volume of new corporate note and bond financings remains light, with only $640 million scheduled for offering this week. Of that total, the amount of cash actually raised will be far less, since the new issues include $375 million of zero-coupon notes.

title: LIFELINE FOR OIL RIGS: PLANES RACING ARCTIC SPRING
description: The huge plane sat at the end of the runway, straining at its brakes. The roar of its four powerful engines billowed out across the barren tundra. Its strong wing lights sparkled off the blowing snow and frozen mud stretching for over a mile ahead. Capt. Spike Sheret was about to go to work.

title: Player Asks Trade
description: Lemar Parrish, cornerback for the Washington Redskins, has asked that he be traded because of what he said was a personality conflict with the defensive coordinator, Richie Petitbon. Parrish, 34 years old, is a 12-year National Football League veteran.

title: Royal Birth: Palace or Hospital?
description: There's a bit of a stir developing in Britain, at least in some newspapers, over where the new royal child is to be born. The Princess of Wales is due to give birth about July 1, and there are reports that the Princess and her husband, Prince Charles, would like to have the child delivered in a hospital.

title: News Analysis
description: There is a new banner flapping in the breeze above Beirut's once fashionable Hamra Street warning all who pass under that there is ''no place for traitors and weaklings in the ranks of the Palestinian revolution.''

title: FELL STOIC OVER TIMELY WRITER
description: Last Saturday afternoon, when Jeffrey Fell should have been in Kentucky riding the Derby favorite Timely Writer in the one-mile Derby Trial, he sat in the jockeys' room at Aqueduct answering a letter of commiseration from a fan. The fan was lamenting Timely Writer's intestinal surgery earlier in the week, which forced the horse's withdrawal from the Derby and the Triple Crown series.

title: A RUNNING BACK IS GIANTS' PRIORITY
description: The Giants, in their dramatic rise from a 4-12 record in 1980 to 9-7 and the playoffs in 1981, more or less filled every pressing roster need except one. They hope to rectify that tomorrow in the first round of the National Football League draft.

title: IRREGULARITIES IN CONCRETE INDUSTRY INFLATE BUILDING COSTS, EXPERTS SAY
description: Tainted Industry Construction in New York Second of three articles. BY SELWYN RAAB

title: GREECE SEEKS TO ASSURE ALLIES ON NATO AND COMMON MARKET
description: Greece's Socialist Government, which won a sweeping electoral victory six months ago with a program for radical change, is now seeking to improve its strained relations with its Western allies, particularly the United States.

title: SOME O.A.S. DELEGATES SEE ARGENTINA'S HAND IMPROVED
description: On the eve of a meeting of the Organization of American States meeting here on the Falkland Islands crisis, Latin American diplomats said today that Argentina's hand in the debate might have been strengthened by Britain's assault on South Georgia.

title: Thrift Merger In Chicago
description: Chicago Federal Savings and Loan Association, with assets of about $600 million, said late Friday that it had filed an application with the Federal Home Loan Bank Board to merge with three smaller thrift institutions based in Chicago. The merger, if approved, would make the new institution the fifth-largest savings and loan in Illinois, with an estimated $1.23 billion in assets.

title: MAKE NEW YORK GROW WHERE IT NEEDS TO GROW
description: To the Editor: The Fifth Avenue Association agrees with your editorial, that the Board of Estimate should approve the proposed new midtown zoning district - but with several modifications. The absence of a ''grandfather clause'' will unquestionably doom several building projects now in the planning stages, and one of these projects has been approved by the board and the City Planning Commission.

title: TV: MARIE OSMOND AND DEBBY BOONE
description: THEY'RE pulling out all the stops on NBC this evening, with a special about the Osmond family and a special about Debby Boone. The first show is by far the more astonishing, for all sorts of reasons. It's a lucky girl -isn't it? - who gets a chance to play her own mother in a drama about how her parents fell in love.

title: Bush Visits Army Units Stationed in South Korea
description: Vice President Bush watched American soldiers at this forward base today prepare to patrol the Demilitarized Zone between South Korea and North Korea.

title: ISRAELI COMPLETES PULLOUT, LEAVING SINAI TO EGYPT
description: In a somber mood, Israel withdrew the last of its soldiers from the Sinai peninsula today, leaving the desert wilderness to Egypt as provided by the first treaty of peace between Israel and an Arab country.

title: WESTERN DEMOCRATS SEEK TO BLEND ENERGY AND ENVIRONMENTAL NEEDS
description: Democrats and the Rocky Mountain West can prosper together by pressing forward on energy development, but at a measured rather than headlong pace, leading Democrats from several states agreed at a conference here this weekend.

title: Cody Leaves a Letter Forgiving His Critics
description: John Cardinal Cody left a letter to be read after his death in which he said he forgave his critics but warned that God would not be so forgiving.

title: American Philharmonic To Open With Wagner
description: The 1982-83 season of the American Philharmonic Orchestra, led by Rohan Joseph, will open Sept. 19 in Avery Fisher Hall with a Wagner program in which Birgit Nilsson will be the soloist. The rest of the season will consist of four Sunday matinees and eight Monday evenings, all at Fisher Hall.

title: RICHARD L. MONTAIGNE
description: Richard L. Montaigne, a realtor for more than 50 years, died Thursday at Kings Highway Hospital Center in Brooklyn after a short illness.

title: Orantes Triumphs
description: The veteran Manuel Orantes won the $100,000 British clay-court title today with a 6-2, 6-0 victory over a compatriot, Angel Gimenez, then lashed out at the Spanish Tennis Federation.

title: GEO INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ROBERTSON, H H, CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
POWER TEST CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
ARGENTINE CROWD SHOUTS DEFIANCE
description: They gathered again today in the Plaza de Mayo, not to cheer a victory but to let off patriotic emotions after a defeat.

title: Newsprint Rise Put Off
description: Citing poor market conditions, major newsprint producers in both Canada and the United States said yesterday that they had deferred a 5 percent price increase to their United States customers until June 1. But, an analyst said, the price increase could be delayed even longer unless United States publishers began using up their substantial inventories of newsprint, stockpiled in expectation of a strike this spring by paperworkers in eastern Canada.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Manfred Winkelhock of West Germany was disqualified yesterday from the San Marino Grand Prix at Imola, Italy, in which he had finished sixth on Sunday. Race officials said Winkelhock's British-built ATS car had been found to be 4.4 pounds under the minimum weight requirement.

title: REAGAN LANDS SMALL BANKS FOR INIATIVE
description: President Reagan today praised the volunteer spirit of several small banks in Indiana and Ohio for sharply lowering interest rates on automobile loans in an effort to bolster local economies.

title: FOE OF CORRUPTION WINS 2.5 MILLION IN LOTTERY
description: A Bronx construction worker who drove himself deep into debt during the last four years fighting corruption in his union won $2.5 million in the New York State Lottery yesterday.

title: Former Turkish Premier Is Arrested Again
description: Bulent Ecevit, the former Prime Minister, faced charges today of defying a military order against political statements.

title: Bad News for Brown
description: The news was not all good last weekend for Dale Brown, Lousiana State's basketball coach. About the same time that Jerry Reynolds, the star from Alexander Hamilton High School in Brooklyn, signed a national letter of intent to attend L.S.U., Brown learned that Leonard Mitchell, a 6-foot-7-inch junior who was a starter last season, had undergone surgery on the elbow of his right arm. Mitchell, a right-handed shooter, slipped Saturday while wrestling with his brother at their home in Martinsville, La. Dr. Ricardo Leoni, who performed the surgery, said that damage to a nerve was extensive and that Mitchell would need three to six months of rehabilitation.

title: FABLE FROM LEFT FIELD
description: Once upon a time, in a kingdom not so far away, there was a great battle, called an election, for the office of Supreme Governor. In the preliminaries, two candidates vied for the Democratic Party nomination.

title: FOSTER WHEELER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Revenue figures represent earned billings

title: Bronx Man Guilty In Murder Retrial
description: A 28-year-old Bronx man whose 1977 sentence of 15 years to life for rape and murder had been reversed on the ground that his confession was coerced was convicted in a retrial yesterday in State Supreme Court in the Bronx.

title: FRANK COPPOLA, MAFIA LEADER
description: Frank Coppola, who was charged with directing a vast drug trafficking ring that operated between Italy and the United States, died today. He was 83 years old.

title: Houston Farewell?
description: Calvin Murphy says he may have played his last game for the Houston Rockets, who were eliminated by the Seattle SuperSonics Sunday in the opening round of the playoffs. ''If they didn't use me this year,'' said the 34-year-old Murphy, who has spent 12 years with the Rockets, ''they sure aren't going to use me next year.

title: TREASURY BACKS DISCLOSURE BILL
description: The Treasury Department gave its support today to a Senate bill that would require more reporting to the Internal Revenue Service of payments to millions of ''independent contractors,'' including sales representatives, real estate brokers, insurance agents, some physicians and other persons who are not employees.

title: Assistant to Cody Is Chosen As Temporary Administrator
description: Msgr. John Richard Keating, an assistant to the late John Cardinal Cody, was chosen today to administer the Archdiocese of Chicago temporarily.
