title: WAS ACTRESS IN 'BRIEF ENCOUNTER'
description: Dame Celia Johnson, best known for her role in the movie ''Brief Encounter,'' died of a stroke today at her home at Nettlebed, near Oxford. She was 73 years old.

title: EFFORT TO CURB WORLD'S FLEETS DROPPED AT SEA-LAW PARLEY
description: A crisis that threatened to wreck the Law of the Sea Conference was averted tonight when Rumania and 29 third world nations abandoned a proposal that would have restricted the world's fleets.

HINCKLEY TRIAL OPENS TODAY IN WASHINGTON WITH SANITY AT ISSUE
description: On the eve of John W. Hinckley Jr.'s trial in the shooting of President Reagan and three other men, a prosecutor told the judge today that Government psychiatrists do not believe Mr. Hinckley was so mentally ill at the time that he was not responsible for his actions.

description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher suggested strongly today that further British military action in the Falkland Islands crisis might be imminent and warned that ''time is getting extremely short'' for further diplomatic initiatives.

description: Argentina's military rulers conceded today that British forces had captured two principal bases on South Georgia Island, and military sources said there would be no major attempt to expel the invaders.

description: The disappearance of a prominent literary journalist Sunday night has added to the growing fears that France may be facing its most serious terrorist challenge in years.

description: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang said today that a major Government reorganization would be announced shortly, completing the first stage of his plans to streamline the nation's 20-million-member bureaucracy.

description: A 45-day election campaign is ending under the watchful eyes of Indonesian troops, who have largely kept political rallies and parades under control.

title: Tainted Industry Construction in New York Last of three articles.
description: The following article is based on reporting by Leslie Maitland and Michael Oreskes and was written by Mr. Oreskes. At least 18 law enforcement agencies are involved in investigating corruption in New York City's multibillion-dollar construction industry, but key prosecutors agree that they are doing less than they would like to do about the problem.

description: The state of Washington filed suit against the Northern Tier Pipeline Company and the Federal Government today, seeking repeal of Federal permits issued for a $2.7 billion oil pipeline.

title: THE LATEST 'MONSTER CLOUD': AWESOME BUT NOT DANGEROUS
description: THESE were no ordinary storm clouds. Moving in from the west across the Belize-Mexican border, they rapidly covered the entire evening sky. They were a strange yellow-gray, billowing and soaring awesomely like thunderheads, though not organized into a clearly defined storm.

House Acts on Ashbrook
description: The House today called off its Wednesday session to allow members to attend the funeral of Representative John M. Ashbrook, Republican of Ohio, who died of internal bleeding. The 53-year-old lawmaker collapsed Saturday at his Johnstown, Ohio, office and died about 90 minutes later. A large delegation of House members is expected to attend services at 1 P.M. Wednesday at the Johnstown Baptist Church.

title: Polaroid Rating
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation said that it had lowered its rating of the Polaroid Corporation's senior notes to A from A+, because of increasing competition in the instant photography and film equipment business. ''Polaroid is basically a one-product company,'' said Ken Bann, the rating officer who handles Polaroid for the rating firm, ''and that product is suffering from increased competition that we expect will get stiffer in the next few years.''

title: WASHINGTON LUMBER SPURS CONTRACT BATTLE
description: WOOLLEY, Wash. -Small lumber mills that harvest much of Washington's Douglas fir, hemlock and red cedar are now embroiled in a contract dispute that has put the industry and state goverment at odds with local communities.

title: Federal Judge Assails Supreme Court Rulings
description: Recent United States Supreme Court decisions have extended constitutional protection and Federal authority far beyond their proper bounds, Judge Robert Bork of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia has said in an unusual criticism by a sitting Federal judge.

title: TUESDAY, APRIL 27, 1982; Companies
description: Eastern Airlines won tentative C.A.B. approval to take over Braniff's Latin American routes for at least a year, beginning June 1. Eastern originally offered to pay Braniff $30 million to lease the routes for six years. Braniff had asked the board to allow either the Eastern plan or an earlier one from Pan Am. (Page A1.)

title: AZTEC EXHIBIT HEADED THIS WAY
description: THE American Museum of Natural History will become the first museum in the United States and only the third outside Mexico to exhibit artifacts from what is believed to have been the main ceremonial center of the Aztec empire. The exhibit, called ''Aztec Mexico: Discovery of Templo Mayor,'' will be held from July 27 to Oct. 6 and represents the museum's major summer offering.

title: MONEY MANAGEMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
D' AMATO SEES G.O.P. IN TOUGH RACES
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato said yesterday that the combination of strong Democratic candidates for Governor and Senator and the nation's depressed economy could severely handicap statewide Republican candidates this year.

title: JERALD GRAVE
description: Jerald Grave, head of the musicology department of the Eastman School of Music in Rochester, died Thursday. He was 40 years old. Dr. Grave published many scholarly articles, including contributions to the New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians, and reconstructed an American Colonial opera, ''The Disappointment,'' which was performed in Washington in 1976 and was recorded.

title: 'Missing' Woman Found in Hospital
description: A 13-state missing-person alarm for a frail, 73-year-old woman was canceled by the police last night after she was located at a hospital in Brooklyn. She had been taken there 10 days earlier, after a car accident cut short her drive to see friends on Long Island, who reported her missing.

title: CHARGES DROPPED IN DEATH OF BLACK IN MILWAUKEE
description: The remaining charges against members of the Police Department were dismissed today in the case of Ernest Lacy, a 22-year-old black who died while in custody last summer.

title: BUSH, IN SEOUL, HINTS OF TRIP TO PEKING
description: Vice President Bush said today that he might visit China during his tour of Asia and the Pacific.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: KILLING the Department of Education is turning out to be harder than its would-be pallbearers imagined. Neither outright abolition, originally pledged by President Reagan, nor transformation into a foundation for educational assistance, favored by T.H. Bell, the Secretary of Education, now seems imminent. Congress appears in no mood to rescind what it so recently created.

title: Article 095300 -- No Title
description: A $3 million gift to help replace Columbia Univerity's deteriorating 54-year-old Baker Field football stadium with a new concrete structure was announced by the university yesterday. The new stadium will be on the same site at the northwestern tip of Manhattan, 218th Street and Broadway.

title: Journal Plans European Edition
description: The Wall Street Journal will publish an international edition in Europe, starting early next year, Dow Jones & Company, which issues the newspaper, announced yesterday.

title: REVERE COPPER & BRASS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
EX-WHITE HOUSE AIDE RATES REAGAN
description: After years as one of Washington's most politically effective advisers to Republican Presidents, Bryce N. Harlow is on the outside looking in, from the vantage point of his retirement home in a quiet valley near Harpers Ferry, W. Va. There, the Potomac River flows near his cottage, far distant from another stretch of the Potomac that he crossed daily to serve as an aide to Dwight D. Eisenhower and Richard Nixon and later as an adviser to Gerald R. Ford.

title: SOVIET SEES DANGER IN DISPUTE
description: The Soviet Union said tonight that more fighting in the Falkland Islands dispute between Britain and Argentina would pose ''great danger'' - especially to ''those who provoke'' it.

title: STYLES SHE'D WEAR HERSELF
description: Carolina Herrera, the South American socialite turned fashion designer, presented her new fall collection last Thursday at the New York Public Library and, by any reckoning, it was a success. For, little more than a year into her career, Mrs. Herrera seems to have proved that she can unerringly make the kind of smartly tailored day wear and extravagant evening clothes that members of the international set cannot live without.

title: APPEAL ON RADIO MUSIC IN STORES IS DECLINED
description: The Supreme Court refused today to review a ruling that could require many small retail establishments in the New York area to pay royalties for the right to keep a radio turned on for background music for their customers.

title: DEMOCRATS AT ODDS OVER BUDGET NEGOIATIONS
description: At a meeting of House Democratic leaders last week, Representative Jim Wright of Texas proposed a statement expounding the party's view on the budget negotiations with the White House. One part of the draft asserted that ''the bulk of the revenues'' needed to reduce the current deficit should not come from cuts in Social Security benefits.

title: Tell Argentina the Hard Truth
description: If Argentina were a democracy, its present Government would by now have resigned or faced impeachment over the Falklands dispute. Its people have been misled by their non-elected junta on every salient point. Britain really wasn't supposed to resist seizure of the islands ... the world was expected to shrug ... and in the event of an uproar, well, Argentina would pull out its troops for a token few months, as long as everyone accepted that its flag was there forever.

title: MELVILLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Ex-Editor's Offer
description: Last year, Michael Balfe Howard created a stir in Denver when he disclosed that the reason he had been dismissed as editor of The Rocky Mountain News the year before was a cocaine habit that had cost him $6,000 a week and led to several suicide attempts.

description: To the Editor:

title: 'PRIVATE' DEATH
description: There is a baby girl in a New York hospital with the kind of birth defects for which there is no help. Her parents, doctors and nurses are waiting for nature to take its course, but so far nature has not been kind. Meanwhile, they look for a place in which she can live in warmth and peace. When she sickens, as is inevitable, no extraordinary means will be used to save her; when she dies, her friends will know as much relief as grief. But for the few months that are her life she will have been treated with courtesy, acknowledged as a human being. Another baby was born two weeks ago in Indiana. He had a incomplete esophagus, which is operable, and Down's syndrome, the consequences of which are impossible to estimate at birth. Nature took its course very quickly - he died in six days - but with considerable help. At his parents' request, the infant wasn't fed. The decision, the family lawyer said, was "a private matter." Why private? Had that baby been normal, his death by starvation would have been a public concern. But becausehe had been inadvertently robbed of perfection, he was deliberately robbed of life. His flaws somehow canceled out his rights. Two county courts and the Indiana State Supreme Court appear to have agreed: they declined to force his parents to feed "Infant Doe." But if children have a chance to live, shouldn't they get it, whether or not their parents are willing? And if they haven't a chance, like that little girl in a New York hospital, shouldn't they be allowed to leave this world in their own good time? Whether to carry a fetus to maturity is still, and should remain, a women's choice.

Salute to Goodman
description: His father was a railroad man with a passion for playing the saxophone, often in the kitchen, with a Benny Goodman record in the background.

description: The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees has been forced to assume direct control of the Central American refugee program in Honduras because of bitter squabbling over politics and religion among local voluntary agencies.

description: British military officials reported today that South Georgia Island did not come entirely under British control until 10 o'clock this morning after considerable additional fighting during the night.

title: NORTHWEST AIRLINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BELL PLANS SHELF RULE STOCK SALE
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it plans to sell up to 10 million shares of newly issued common stock under the Securities and Exchange Commission's experimental shelf rule. Instead of selling all the new stock at once through a syndicate of underwriters, as has been traditionally done, A.T.&T. will be able to sell the shares in parcels from time of time through underwriters, broker-dealers or directly to institutional investors. If all the new shares are sold, the $500 million to $600 million raised would help finance capital spending by A.T.&T., whose ability to borrow money is being restricted by the pending divestiture of its operating companies. An S.E.C. spokesman, Chiles Larson, said that A.T.&T. was perhaps the first company to register for the sale of stock under the S.E.C.'s Rule 415, which took effect in March on a nine-month experimental basis. Other companies have registered to sell bonds and other debt offerings under the ruling, which is expected to dramatically transform the investment banking business by giving large corporate clients the flexibility to market securities without investment bankers as intermediaries.

title: IN FLIGHT MOVIES UPDATE CONTENT AND EQUIPMENT

And, because the average passenger is 20 years older than the average moviegoer, often the movies that sell best at 30,000 feet are movies that have failed at the box office because they did not appeal to the young audience. Last year, they included ''The Competition,'' ''Paternity,'' ''Continental Divide,'' ''The Mirror Crack'd,'' ''Victory,'' ''Rollover'' and ''Raise the Titanic.''

title: ISRAEL AND THE PHALANGE
description: It is unlikely that Israel will launch a major military strike to liquidate the Palestine Liberation Organization in Lebanon unless it can count on its uncertain ally, the 22,000-member Maronite Catholic Phalangist militia, to enter the fray. But that depends on who prevails in the Phalangists' power struggle - its 82-year-old founder, Pierre Gemayel, who is edging away from relations with Israel, or his son, Bashir, the charismatic 34-year-old militia chief, who leans toward establishing an Israeli-backed Christian state.

title: Harvester Loan Plan Revisions

The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company is the lead bank in the pact. Earlier it was reported that the revisions had been approved by nearly one-half of Harvester's lenders. Mr. Anderson said he did not expect the bank to have large losses on its loans to Harvester, but he declined to disclose the size of its Harvester loans.

title: TV: 3-PART DOCUMENTARY EXAMINES SAUDI ARABIA
description: Osman Linjawi, a Saudi businessman garbed in a ghutrah, the traditional draped headgear, and seated by a swimming pool, tells the television reporter that his Western friends once thought of Saudi Arabia as a land of camels, tents and harems. Now, he continues, they imagine a land of private jets and banks.

title: NL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Sports of the Times; Taking the 'Man' Out of Manager
description: WHEN he changed Yankee managers before, George Steinbrenner was always up front. But judging by his disappearance this time, even he is apparently ashamed of how he has turned what was once baseball's best job into its worst embarrassment.

title: MCDONALD'S CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results for the latest period reflect the adoption of FASB Statement No 52 regarding foreign currency translations; Year-ago results have not been restated to reflect this change

title: RTE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Hakuhodo of Japan, SSC&B-Lintas in Pact
description: Hakuhodo, second in size among Japanese agencies only to Dentsu, and SSC&B-Lintas, one of the worldwide networks of agencies in the Interpublic Group of Companies, have signed a 10-year agreement that will give the Japanese access to full service at SSC&B-Lintas's 48 offices in 38 countries and will include a limited exchange of personnel.

title: THE $90 BILLION FRAUD
description: To the Editor:

title: RECITAL: A TRIBUTE TO CHOPIN
description: FOUR laureates of the Warsaw International Chopin Competition, all Polish-born, shared the stage Sunday in a tribute to Chopin at Carnegie Hall. The program, which consisted of brief recitals by Halina Czerny-Stefanska, Barbara Hesse-Bukowska, Adam Harasiewicz and Tadeusz Kerner, gave each pianist the opportunity to perform an extended work in company with a sampling of shorter ones.

title: WHERE THE TECHNIQUE OF PLASMAPHERESIS HAS BEEN TRIED
description: Plasmapheresis, a modern version of bloodletting, has been used to treat at least 50 ailments. Many attempts may prove worthless, but scientists deem further investigations warranted, and a sampling of disorders for which it has been tried follows:

title: BLOODLETTING IS REVIVED FOR A WIDE VARIETY OF MODERN ILLS
description: IN a return to the Hippocratic practice of bloodletting, once believed to purge the body of bad humors and to restore the vigor of life, doctors in many countries now are bleeding patients to treat a myriad of disorders. The widely varying results have led to many medical controversies about the practice, which is costly and timeconsuming, yet has saved lives. Some estimates foresee hundreds of thousands of these procedures being done annually by mid-decade at a cost of billions of dollars.

title: WILLIAMS COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Virginia Slims Back in Tennis
description: Virginia Slims, which during the 1970's was instrumental in making women's tennis a leading professional sport, announced yesterday that it would return as sponsor next January.

title: Polish Prelate Meets Pope on Prisoner Issue
description: Archbishop Jozef Glemp of Poland, expressing concern about the situation in his country, met Pope John Paul II today to discuss the church's campaign to free 3,000 prisoners held by Warsaw's martial-law Government.

title: EVOLUTION OF A LEANER A.& P.
description: On a recent Sunday morning, the small A.&P. store in Queens looked a bit disheveled. Several fluorescent bulbs were out, leaving part of the store in near darkness. Stock was strewn haphazardly along the aisles as clerks replenished shelves.

title: KOLLMORGEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SQUIBB CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: B-Including income of $1,166,000 from discontinued operations; Squibb said thatresults for the 1981 quarter have been reclassified to reflect the sale of company's confectionery business and restated for the adoption of FASB No 52 on foreign currency translations retroactive to Jan 1, 1981

title: LYNCH COMMUNICATION SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
KYLE TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
A Voting Rights Letter for Congress
description: We have always, as you know, falsely pretended that our main purpose was to exclude the ignorant vote when, in fact, we were trying to exclude not the ignorant vote, but the Negro vote. ... At present, the masses of the colored race are indifferent to the right to vote and still more indifferent to the right to hold office. By adopting remedial measures now we shall cause no discontent, because of the present apathy of our colored citizens. This is fully recognized by all statesmen.

title: SOUTHWEST FOREST INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
UNLIKELY LEGAL PATH TO FALKLANDS PEACE
description: To the Editor:

title: .22 CASING FOUND IN JERSEY TIED TO GUN IN CBS KILLINGS
description: A .22-caliber shell casing found last Friday in the garage of a Keansburg, N.J., man was fired from the same gun used to kill four people in New York City on April 12, police sources disclosed yesterday.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF STATEMENT BY MRS. THATCHER
description: Following is a transcript of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's statement to the House of Commons today reporting the capture of the Argentine-occupied island of South Georgia:

title: Bridge:; A Message to 3 Members; Of Solodar Team: You Won
description: Those who win major team championships are normally aware of the fact within two or three minutes of the last card being played, but that was not the case Sunday night.

title: U.S. STRESSES RISKS OF CREDIT TO SOVIET
description: The Soviet Union is facing a growing shortage of hard currency that could bring as many risks for creditors in a few years as Poland presents now, a Commerce Department official warned today.

title: NEWPARK RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: B-After $293,000 loss from discontinued operations

title: Two Airlines Report Losses
description: Northwest Airlines reported a loss of $17.9 million in the first quarter yesterday, and Western Airlines said it had an operating loss of $6.4 million. Both carriers cited lower passenger revenue attributed to the recession and fare wars.

title: UNION OIL CO OF CALIFORNIA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Ad Courses Accredited At Missouri University
description: The advertising courses at the University of Missouri have been re-accredited, Roy Fisher, dean of the School of Journalism, announced today.

title: FLIGHTSAFETY INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TOSCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: B-Including a tax credit of $17,061,000; C-Net loss after a tax credit of $8,036,000

title: 'Small Savers' Rate Off
description: The maximum interest rate on new 30-month savings certificates, known as ''small savers certificates,'' fell slightly, to 14.1 percent, for thrift instititions and 13.85 percent at commercial banks. The rate, which changes today, had been 14.35 percent at thrift institutions and 14.1 percent at commercial banks for the last two weeks.

title: Nettles Fractures Thumb
description: Graig Nettles, the Yankees' third baseman and captain, fractured a bone in the thumb of his left hand in Sunday's game against the Detroit Tigers and is expected to be sidelined four to six weeks.

title: Conservatives Victors In Saskatchewan Vote
description: The Progressive Conservative Party scored a stunning upset in Saskatchewan's general election today, ending 11 years of rule by the socialist New Democratic Party.

title: Nancy Reagan Visits Coast
description: Nancy Reagan traveled to Los Angeles today to start sorting through household items that have been in storage since she and President Reagan moved to the White House. Mrs. Reagan's press secretary, Sheila Tate, said she would stay at the Beverly Wilshire Hotel until Friday, then fly to Knoxville, Tenn. She is to be joined there Saturday by the President, who will be visiting the World's Fair.

title: SALVADORAN GENERAL TRIED TO PICK THE PRESIDENT, RIGHTEST CHIEF SAYS
description: The head of El Salvador's extreme rightist party, the Nationalist Republican Alliance, bitterly accused one of the top military leaders today of trying to force the Constituent Assembly to elect a centrist as the country's provisional President.

title: Ryan Breaks Slump, 6-2
description: Nolan Ryan of the Houston Astros gave up only four hits and stopped the St. Louis Cardinals, 6-2, tonight for his first victory of the season after four losses. Ryan struck out five and walked two.

title: NEW KOPPERS CHIEF FOCUSES ON MARKETS
description: Charles R. Pullin, 58 years old, has been elected chairman and chief executive officer of the Koppers Company, a diversified engineering and construction enterprise with $2 billion in sales last year. He succeeds Fletcher L. Byrom, 63, the outspoken statesman of American business and champion of capitalism.

title: REPUBLIC AUTOMOTIVE PARTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Associated Dry Goods Corporation's $200 million of zero-coupon notes due in 1983-89, to be offered through a Lehman Brothers group, has been priced to yield from 14.45 to 15 percent.

title: BOEING DOWN 57.6% AS BUYERS CUT BACK
description: The Boeing Company reported yesterday that a sharp cutback in commercial airline deliveries, among other factors, caused net income in the first quarter of 1982 to plunge 57.6 percent on a 13.7 percent decline in sales.

title: ST JOSEPH LIGHT & POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SERVICEMASTER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split effective May 29, 1981

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: SCHLICHTER INTERESTS COLTS
description: Art Schlichter, the Ohio State quarterback and one of the select candidates for today's opening rounds in the National Football League's annual draft of college seniors, went through a 90-minute workout yesterday in the campus field house for two Baltimore Colt coaches.

title: Telecom Unit Files Under Chapter 11
description: The Telecom Corporation, a Houston-based company that derives most of its income from Spector Red Ball, its trucking subsidiary, said that the trucking line would seek protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Is there any evidence showing that prolonged consumption of sugar leads to physical addiction?

title: CITY STORES LOST
description: The City Stores Company, the operator of the W.& J. Sloane furniture store chain, said yesterday that it lost $15.9 million in the fiscal year ended Jan. 30, more than double the loss of $6.57 million before an extraordinary credit in the previous year. Sloane lost $5 million in its continuing operations in the latest fiscal year compared with $6 million the year before, the parent company said.

title: LA BARGE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ROCKWELL INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Family Weekly Head To Retire in June
description: Morton Frank, who sold the Family Weekly newspaper supplement to CBS Consumer Publications in 1980, will retire in June as chairman and publisher to be replaced by Patrick M. Linskey, former ad director who has been president and associate publisher since last year. Mr. Frank, 69 years old, will be chairman emeritus and a consultant to CBS.

title: CARNEGIE SETS '82-83 SEASON
description: Carnegie Hall's 1982-83 season will include a ''Brahms 150th birthday celebration,'' the 20th anniversary season of the American Symphony, a Beethoven piano sonata cycle from Alfred Brendel, a concert performance of Wagner's ''Das Rheingold'' with Georg Solti and the Chicago Symphony and a Rossini cycle of three concert-opera performances with Marilyn Horne.

title: TREAT SS-16 WARNINGS WARILY
description: The growing momentum of the nuclear-freeze movement is drawing strenuous counterattacks from the hawks. President Reagan asserts that there can be no freeze while the Soviet Union possesses ''a definite margin of superiority.'' And Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. says that ''a freeze at current levels would perpetuate an unstable and unequal military balance.'' This position reflects an official renunciation of the underlying principle of the strategic arms limitation agreements: the assumption that both superpowers enjoyed rough equivalence in strategic nuclear weaponry.

title: P.& G. Gains 15.1%; Rockwell Up 2.4%
description: The Procter & Gamble Company reported yesterday that net income in its third fiscal quarter of 1982, ended March 31, rose 15.1 percent, while sales increased 4.7 percent.

title: Developer Expects Interest Default
description: The South Atlantic Financial Corporation, a Miami-based real estate development company, said it would default on the interest payment due May 1 on its $1.7 million in outstanding subordinated debentures. In February, the company defaulted on both principal and interest on $16.9 million in outstanding debentures.

title: BLASS, SANT'ANGELO LIGHTS UP NIGHTS
description: The emphasis was on evening clothes as yesterday's fall and winter fashion openings unfolded, and from the look of the designs on the runway, it will be no time for mournful dressing and simple spaghetti dinners. The clothes are on the spectacular order, and they tend to glisten and glow, baring a good deal of skin along the way.

title: HAIG DECLARES U.S. REDOUBLES EFFORT
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. told the Organization of American States today that the United States was ''redoubling'' its efforts to find a solution to the Falkland Islands dispute, which he said had reached a critical point.

title: SEAWAY MULTI-CORP LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-After special gains of $124,563 for latest year and $275,635 for earlier period; the company is in arrears on preferred share dividends

title: Ford Plant Plans
description: The Ford Motor Company said it would spend $50 million to tool up a suburban Detroit auto plant beginning late next year if the auto maker's management approves plans for a line of front-wheel-drive cars to be introduced in the mid-1980's. The Sterling Heights transmission and chassis plant employs some 1,500 hourly workers and another 250 salaried employees.

title: General Cinema's Heublein Stake
description: The General Cinema Corporation said it had raised its stake in Heublein Inc. to 14.3 percent, or 3.1 million shares, continuing a bidding war that began in February, when General Cinema disclosed its purchase of a 9.7 percent stake in Heublein.

title: CUT RATE TOKENS-FOR DRIVERS ONLY
description: To the Editor:

title: Ailing Kingman to Play
description: Noting that ''you can't take Dave Kingman's bat out of the lineup for two days and not miss him,'' Manager George Bamberger of the Mets said yesterday that Kingman would play tonight when the team plays the Padres in San Diego. Kingman will play with his left baseball shoe cut open on one side to expose his injured big toe, which was spiked during a game against the Expos on Friday.

title: C.I.A. EXPERT FOR INMAN POST
description: John N. McMahon, who was chosen today by President Reagan to succeed Adm. Bobby R. Inman as Deputy Director of Central Intelligence, probably knows more about the operations of the Central Intelligence Agency than anyone else in Government. In a 31-year career there, Mr. McMahon has been a generalist among intelligence specialists, holding senior management posts in all major divisions of the agency, including stints as head of operations and chief of analysis.

title: KRATOS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results for the latest first quarter reflect operations of Keuffel & Esser Co, a recent acquisition, from Jan 1, 1982 after deducting a charge of $1,270,000 for imputed interest cost required for purchase accounting treatment; year-ago results reflect the adoption of FASB Statement No 52 regarding foreign currency translations

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bank of New York has elected Eric S. Salat, Richard W. Dodd, Dennis Hodne and Louis A. Rivera vice presidents.

title: JOB SWEEP OF ALIENS
description: Swooping in as workers began morning shifts, Federal immigration agents apprehended nearly a thousand illegal aliens yesterday at job sites around the nation in what the Government said was an effort to recapture higher-paying jobs for unemployed American citizens.

title: J.K. LANDAUER, ARMS EXPERT
description: Joseph K. Landauer, an expert on arms control and on the assessment of the nuclear potential of other nations, was killed in an automobile accident Sunday afternoon. He was 54 years old.

title: Backer & Spielvogel Assigned Raintree Line
description: Backer & Spielvogel, which already does the Lestoil advertising for the Noxell Corporation, yesterday was assigned its Raintree Skin Care Line, that was introduced by SSC&B.

title: NICHOLS, S E, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Net loss; C-Net income

title: PROCTER & GAMBLE CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Moynihan Supports Britain
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan said today that the United States should stand behind Britain in its dispute with Argentina over the Falkland Islands. ''We should let Argentina know that we'll support our NATO ally,'' the New York Democrat said at a campaign stop here.

title: UNITED INDUSTRIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The share earnings are adjusted for a 10% stock dividend paid in February 1982

title: New Cray Line
description: Cray Research Inc. introduced a line of large-scale computers that it said would have up to five times the capability of its existing product, the Cray 1S. The new system, which will sell for $11.4 million to $14.5 million, consists of two computer processors, each faster than the single processor in the Cray 1S. Cray ''supercomputers'' are used mainly for specialized scientific applications in nuclear weapons research, weather forecasting and oil exploration.

title: LET THE CONSTITUTION ORDER THRIFT IN GOVERNMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: GIDDINGS & LEWIS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FOOTBALL SUCCESS FORMULA: RECRUIT A PHILOSOPHER
description: Ralph Waldo Emerson didn't like crowds. ''Whom God hath put asunder,'' he protested, ''why should man join together?'' It follows, one might presume, that this apostle of serenity and self-reliance would have cared not a fig for football - in which a mass of men are brought together to pile on top of one another, while another mass cheers them on.

title: MORRISON-KNUDSEN CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Ferdy J. Tagle, a Printer, 82; Led a New York High School
description: Ferdy J. Tagle, a former principal of the New York School of Printing, a New York City high school, died Saturday at Lake Wales (Fla.) Hospital. He was 82 years old, and lived in Lake Wales and New Milford, Conn.

title: Storm Kills 12 in India
description: Twelve people were killed and 50 injured in a storm in part of northeastern India, the United News of India reported today. The storm, with winds up to 75 miles an hour, damaged hundreds of homes in Assam state Sunday, the news agency said.

title: Conagra's Option For Peavey Stake
description: Conagra Inc., the Omaha-based food processing company that last week said it would merge one of its subsidiaries with the Peavey Company, another food processor, said it had aquired the option to buy 18.5 percent, or 1,084,000 shares, of Peavey's common stock.

title: FINANCE UNITS BRING G.M. PROFITS
description: The General Motors Corporation reported net income of only $128 million for the first quarter of 1982 and said the profit came from financing auto loans rather than from making cars and trucks.

title: Chess:
description: A Scraggly Defense Gets Grandmaster Into Trouble By ROBERT BYRNE

title: Zambian Sentenced as Spy
description: Webster Lumbwe, 31 years old, a former Zambian intelligence agent, was sentenced to 20 years in prison today after his conviction on charges of spying for the United States Central Intelligence Agency.

title: HIGH COURT TO REVIEW TENNESSEE BANK TAX
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a state can tax the income earned by banks on interest from United States bonds, Treasury notes and other Federal obligations.

title: EASTERN WINS BID ON BRANIFF ROUTES
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board tonight approved on an interim basis a plan by Eastern Airlines to take over most of the Latin American operations of Braniff Airways starting June 1.

title: 4 PRINCIPALS EXPANDING REAL ESTATE PARTNERSHIP
description: A new real estate partnership has been established bearing the names of Marvin Davis, 56-year-old Denver oilman and owner of the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation; Myron M. Miller, 50, a Denver developer; Thomas J. Klutznick, 43, former chairman of the Urban Investment and Development Company, and Gerald S. Gray, 53, chief financial officer of the Davis Oil Company.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Saturday on the effects of lower inflation rates bore an incorrect dateline and misidentified a bank. The article was sent from Richfield, Minn. The bank is the Richfield Bank and Trust Company.

title: Jersey Banks Set Merger
description: Two southern New Jersey banks with combined assets of more than $835 million have approved a merger, according to the boards of both banks.

title: LUBRIZOL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SIERRA RESEARCH reports earnings for Qtr toMarch 31
SINGER CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: B-After a loss of $17.8 million from discontinued operations and a gain of $18.9 million on the repurchase of bonds; C-Including income of $200,000 from discontinued operations

title: MICHIGAN NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SCHMIDT PLANS MOVES TO PERK UP CABINET
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, apparently in an attempt to give a sense of new activity and ideas to his Government, will announce Cabinet changes, including a new Finance Minister, in the next few days.

title: Doyle Dane Officer's Look at Cable TV
description: The latest weighty tome from an ad agency on the subject of cable TV is a contribution from Doyle Dane Bernbach's W.S. (Jay) James, a vice president for video technology/programming.

title: MOLECULAR GENETICS, FOCUSING ON AGRICULTURE, TO GO PUBLIC
description: Apparently hoping to benefit from being the first biotechnology company focused on agriculture to sell stock to the public, Molecular Genetics Inc. announced yesterday that it planned to offer 900,000 shares - some 20 percent of the company's stock - in late May or early June.

title: National Medical Adds Two Units
description: National Medical Enterprises Inc., a Los Angeles-based hospital management company, said it had acquired two companies, Professional Pulmonary Services Inc., of Shenandoah, Iowa, and Oxygen Therapy Systems Inc., of New Orleans, for an undisclosed amount.

title: MAGIC CHEF INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
LOMAS & NETTLETON FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GILBERT ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The net income for the latest first quarter includes a gain equal to 9 cents a share on the sale of a portion of the business operations

title: JUDGE OFFERS SETTLEMENTS FOR EVERS COLLEGE SIT IN
description: A judge proposed a settlement last night in an effort to end a sitin by students at Medgar Evers College in Brooklyn. The terms of the proposed settlement, which were not made public, were offered by Justice William Bellard of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn to administrators of the college and representatives of the students occupying the offices of the college's president and registrar. Both sides were directed to return to court today with their response to the judge's proposals.

title: INFORMATICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Advertising; Magazines' New View Of Art
description: OBSERVERS of the magazine industry were quick to realize that the goings on at Hearst Magazines over Connoisseur magazine were out of the ordinary. Isn't the usual tactic of that operation to bring out a new publication as an annual and then if it makes a hit on the stands take it a biannual, increasing the frequency as consumer demand required until the monthly stage is reached?

title: ISLANDERS BRACE FOR NORDIQUES
description: ''Unpredictable'' is how Coach Al Arbour of the Islanders described the Quebec Nordiques, the club the two-time defending Stanley Cup champions face in the National Hockey League playoff semifinals, starting tonight at Nassau Coliseum. Arbour could have used the same adjective in describing how his team usually performs against the freewheeling Nordiques.

title: COMMUTER'S SCULPTURE
description: Every weekday morning, the island of Manhattan is set upon by two million people, a force twice the size of the one that invaded Normandy on D-Day in what was then called the greatest movement of men and materials in history. It is anyone's guess what it would have been called if the Allies had taken public transportation. Or if they had had to line up for miles to pay tolls. Perhaps they would have just blown the toll booths sky high. By bus, by train, by Chevy, Ford and Toyota, soldiers in today's commuting army inch their way into the city each morning, surrendering their territory to Manhattan residents in the evening and attacking again at sunrise. One corporate transportation study asserted that New York commuters arrived at work with the equivalent of "battle fatigue." George Segal sees something heroic in all of this, and has created a monument ot these heretofore antiheros, a sculpture entitled "The Commuters." It was unveiled Thursday at the Port Authority Bus Terminal in midtown. "These are long-suffering people," Mr. Segal explained, "good and decent people, who are sacrificing for a better life for their families than in the harsh and often dangerous city. I have a high regard for them." The sculpture does not glorify them, however. It depicts three commuters, in bronze with a white graffiti-resistant patina, at a bus departure gate.They standon the floor, not a pedestal. There is no look of rugged determination of their faces, no wings on their heels.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, APRIL 27, 1982
description: International Further British military action in the Falklands may be imminent, according to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. She also warned that time was running out for new diplomatic initiatives. She told Parliament that Britain's recapture of South Georgia, 800 miles east of the Falklands, had been completed without British casualties and with serious injury to only one Argentine. She said Britain had not fired first and pledged that the 200 Argentines in custody would be quickly sent home. (Page A1, Col. 6.) Argentina's rulers conceded that Britain had retaken the two main bases on South Georgia Island, and military sources said there would be no attempt to expel the British. The informants said that Argentine forces would wait for the British flotilla to come closer to the Falklands before mounting an assault. (A12:1-4.)

title: News Analysis
description: Sunday's withdrawal from Sinai has left Israel in a testy mood. The compromise in the south has reinforced a toughened posture on other fronts, especially toward the Palestinian Arabs in Lebanon and the West Bank. A period of tension is foreseen, with the risk of war across the Lebanese border remaining high.

title: Police Search for 5 Men In Brink's Bank Theft
description: Five men armed with automatic weapons and rifles stole an estimated $200,000 from a Brink's armored truck parked in front of a shopping mall bank today and fled in a stolen van, the police said. No shots were fired and no injuries were reported.

title: Tandy-Memorex
description: The Tandy Corporation said it had received notice that the Federal Trade Commission would take no action to block Tandy's acquisition of the Consumer Products division of the Memorex Corporation. Garland Asher, Tandy financial planning director, said the definitive agreement with Memorex would proceed, with completion planned by June 30, the end of the company's fiscal year.

title: UNION OIL CLIMBS 9.1%
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company, the nation's seventh-largest oil company, yesterday reported a profit increase of 4.6 percent, to $385.4 million, or $1.53 a share, in the first quarter of 1982, from $368.3 million in the comparable 1981 quarter.

title: U.S. TO BUY IRAN OIL AT LOW PRICE
description: The Government has signed an agreement to buy bargain-priced Iranian oil for its Strategic Petroleum Reserve, thereby opening the United States market to Iran's oil for the first time since shortly after the American hostages were seized in November 1979.

title: MOORE KEEPS TITLE BY KNOCKOUT IN 5th
description: Davey Moore of New York knocked out Charlie Weir of South Africa in the fifth round tonight and retained his World Boxing Association junior middleweight title.

title: PEERLESS MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Haig And Watergate
description: A close reading of Seymour Hersh's startling article in The Atlantic Monthly is almost as damaging to Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. as it is to Henry Kissinger, upon whom it is focused.

title: FRACTUED ANKLE ENDS HOSTAGE'S CAREER
description: It was 12:56 P.M. today when Chris McCarron crouched closer to Hostage's billowing brown mane and clucked into his ear, the jockey signaling the colt that it was time to pick up the pace of his final workout for the Kentucky Derby. Hostage immediately lengthened his stride, putting the force of his 1,300 pounds on the skinny ankles that carry a sprinting thoroughbred to a speed of 40 miles an hour.

title: BUDGET MEETINGS STALL ON DEMAND FOR TAX PROMISE
description: The Reagan Administration is demanding that Democratic Congressional leaders guarantee that there will be no vote to repeal the third year of the tax cut enacted last year, but the Democrats are refusing, those who are close to the budget negotiations disclosed today.

title: 'FEDERALISM' SWAPS DEFENDED
description: A senior White House official said today that President Reagan still wanted Congress to enact his ''new federalism'' proposals this year, while another official said the Administration might be willing to keep food stamps as a Federal program.

title: KEAN SEEKS FUNDS FOR 2 NEW PRISONS
description: Governor Kean proposed today that the New Jersey prison system be doubled by 1988 to keep pace with dramatic increases in the prison population caused by tough new sentencing laws.

title: AVANT-GARDE: BIG SOUND IN JAZZ STYLE
description: MUHAL Richard Abrams led a 20-piece band Saturday at the Symphony Space in the last of four Composers' Concerts sponsored by the Kitchen. The compositions by Anthony Braxton and Mr. Abrams that were presented on the four nights ranged from structures for triggering and shaping improvisations to pieces that were entirely written out, but Saturday's program was squarely in the jazz tradition.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Filtrona Corp. said it had agreed in principle to acquire Dollinger Corp. through a $36-a-share tender offer for that company's 236,016 outstanding common shares. The transaction is valued at $8.5 million.

title: Southeast Banking
description: A group of Florida investors said they had acquired 947,700 shares, or 5.6 percent, of the Southeast Banking Corporation, the state's largest banking institution. The investment group is headed by Samuel Adler, a south Florida builder-developer. The investors said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that the purchases were for investment, and that while more purchases were planned, ''we have no present intention to seek representation on the board of directors.''

title: PINKERTON'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Orphan, 9, Killed As Gun Discharges
description: A 9-year-old orphan was shot to death yesterday afternoon in Brooklyn when a handgun being taken apart by his cousin discharged, striking the boy in the head, the police said. The cousin was arrested and charged in the shooting.

title: The U.N. Today; April 27, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Preparatory Commitee for the Sec- ond Special Session of the General As- sembly Devoted to Disarmament - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Antitrust Suit Filed In ARA Means Bid
description: The Justice Department filed a civil antitrust suit today to prevent the nation's second-largest textile rental service company from acquiring its largest Middle Western competitor.

title: Ion Engines Tested in Space
description: Over the last 11 years a 20-foot-long spacecraft has been circling the earth, logging 1.6 billion miles, and on command firing its engines in an experiment to determine the efficiency and reliability of a new type of space propulsion - ion-electric propulsion. As tests were brought to an end this month, engineers at Lewis Research Center in Cleveland reported that the ion engines were capable of reducing the cost and extending the useful lifetimes of future space vehicles.

title: NORFOLK & WESTERN RY CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
THE DOCTOR'S WORLD
description: UNTIL fairly recently, establishing the dose of prescribed drugs was a crude art. The human dose was based largely on the overall impressions that physicians derived from their everyday experience of treating patients as well as from extrapolations to humans of tests on animals.

title: No Headline
description: The Yankees lead all teams with nine players, including two shortstops, Bucky Dent and Roy Smalley, on the ballot for the All-Star Game, the commissioner's office said yesterday.

title: WARNACO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect adjustments resulting principally from the adoption of FASB Statement No 52 regarding foreign currency

title: DOW ADVANCES 3.42, to 865.58
description: The stock market's six-week rally continued yesterday as prices ended moderately higher in active trading. The Dow Jones industrial average, which has risen almost 65 points since March 12, advanced 3.42 points yesterday, to 865.58. Stocks that rose in price on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered stocks that declined by a 9-to-5 ratio.

title: LATE SELLING REVERSES PRECIOUS METAL GAINS
description: A late burst of selling erased modest early gains in silver and gold futures yesterday. Brokers described the trading in precious metals and most other commodity markets as trendless, attributing the early advances of 10 cents an ounce in silver and $10 an ounce in gold to the heightening of the Falkland Islands conflict.

title: WOOSNAM DISCOUNTS MOVE TO REPLACE HIM
description: Phil Woosnam, reacting to a report that a majority of the North American Soccer League's owners had voted to remove him as commissioner, yesterday characterized their decision as merely ''a plan to split the responsibilities of the league office between the commissioner and another person, who would handle business matters, including television.''

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday incorrectly reported the Syntex Corporation's plans to develop a site it owns in San Jose, Calif. A corrective article appears on page D16.

title: FOUNDATION LEADER ASKS CHURCH COOPERATION
description: Since he became president of the Council on Foundations in March, Dr. James A. Joseph has been traveling around the United States like an old-time circuit rider, pleading the cause of philanthropy.

title: GREAT LAKES CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A Dropout Graduates, 80 Years Later
description: When Jesse Byam went back to high school in Madison Heights, Mich., a couple of years ago, she never gave any thought to getting a diploma.

title: Oil Rig's Inspection Was Reportedly Overdue
description: The oil drilling rig Ocean Ranger was more than six weeks overdue for a safety inspection when it sank in a storm, killing all 84 crew members, a Coast Guard officer testified today.

title: Japan Fishing Rights Cut
description: In its first formal trade-related sanction against Japan, the Reagan Administration today placed restrictions on Japanese fishing rights.

title: Volcano Blankets Tokyo With Dusting of Ash
description: Mount Asama, 7,626 feet high and 200 miles northwest of the capital, erupted for the first time in nine years today, sending a a lead-gray column of smoke into the sky and blanketing most of metropolitan Tokyo with fine volcanic ash.

title: JETERO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NOTES ON FASHION
description: Some said it was clearly a case of international knock off, with Calvin Klein freely adapting Karl Lagerfeld, Perry Ellis adapting Thierry Mugler and Anne Klein Laura Biagiotti. Others complained that there was simply no direction. The more open-minded hailed the wealth of options. No matter how the American fall collections were described by observers last week, one thing was clear. The fashion message from Seventh Avenue has changed completely and, most likely, irrevocably from last fall. Gone are the voluminous shapes, the sweeping design gestures, the sea of shawls. Gone the softness and playfulness. Gone, too, the cropped pant.

title: TRANSCON INC reports earnings for Qtr to March31
Virginia Prison Officials Fined on Inmate Safety
description: A Federal District judge found nine current or former Virginia prison officials in contempt of court today and fined them for failing to segregate dangerous prisoners.

title: COOPERATION GROWS BETWEEN YALE AND CITY TEACHERS
description: THE Gothic stone walls that buffer the campus of Yale University from the rough and tumble city of New Haven, barriers that often seem psychological as much as physical, are becoming increasingly less forbidding to at least one group: local public schoolteachers.

title: INCENTIVES TO SPUR VOLUNTEER WORK STUDIED IN ALBANY
description: Faced with Federal cutbacks in social programs and requests by President Reagan for citizens and private groups to expand their charitable efforts, the state is considering creating a wide range of incentives to encourage volunteer work in both the public and private sectors.

title: COUNTERTENOR HARDSETY
description: THE countertenor Rodney Hardesty divided his program Sunday evening at the Abraham Goodman House's Merkin Concert Hall between music of the 17th and 18th centuries, most of it English, and contemporary offerings by English-speaking composers. If the English language was the reason that things held together, Mr. Hardesty worked like a poet to see that there was also a rhyme every few settings, offering a piece drawn on the words of John Donne by Pelham Humfrey and one by Priaulx Rainier some three centuries later, or answering Henry Purcell's elaborate third setting of ''If Music Be the Food of Love'' with Richard Cumming's lively ''Feste,'' a collection of songs written for a 1963 production of Shakespeare's ''Twelfth Night.''

title: Hoch Wins on 70-206
description: Scott Hoch, shooting a two-under par 70 for a total of 206, held off the first-round leader, Bob Shearer, and Tom Watson today to win the New Orleans Open by two shots. Rains caused the event to be reduced to 54 holes.

title: Another MS Virus?
description: Scientists at Baylor College of Medicine in Houston have found a virus in the spinal fluid of four patients with disease of the central nervous system. Three suffered from from multiple sclerosis (MS), a crippling disease that affects more than 200,000 Americans, while the fourth had a distinctly different and less common disease of the nervous system called amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.

title: MICHAEL SAYS HE'LL PRESENT 'POSITIVE' ATTITUDE TO PLAYERS
description: Amid persistent expressions of confusion among the players, Gene Michael resumed his role as Yankee manager yesterday. ''I don't know that they're in turmoil,'' Michael said at a Yankee Stadium news conference, addressing the issue that has been a prime topic of discussion among the players recently.

title: WILLIAMS, W W, CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Surgery Performed
description: Rick Burleson, the California Angels' shortstop, has undergone successful surgery to repair a tear in the rotator cuff of his right shoulder. ''The surgery went well,'' said Dr. Lewis Yocum, the club orthopedist, who performed the two-hour operation.

title: KOREAN KILLS 62 IN DRUNKEN SPREE
description: At least 62 people were killed by a drunken policeman who went on an eight-hour shooting spree through several villages in South Korea before blowing himself up with a grenade, the police said today.

title: MORE ARMS AID SOUGHT FOR ASIA
description: The Reagan Administration pressed Congress today for more arms aid to South Korea and Thailand, citing what it called a growing Soviet-supported military threat to those countries.

title: Dow Off 8.08 on Profit Taking
description: Stock prices tumbled yesterday as profit taking and disappointing results of first-quarter corporate earnings erased some of the market's sharp gains posted during its recent six-week rally.

title: ALBANIA, OBJECT OF AMNESIA
description: Albania, the least known European country, could be the setting of a drastic change in the East-West balance of power. Albania's strategic value, though virtually forgotten in the West, is fully understood by Moscow. At the nexus of Yugoslavia, Greece, and Italy, Albania with two excellent deepwater ports, at Vlore and Durres, dominates the Balkan peninsula and the entry to the Adriatic Sea. The Italian coast is only 50 miles away, across the narrow Strait of Otranto.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LITTLE ITALY

title: BEGIN ASKS SETTLEMENTS VOW
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin said today that he would press for a parliamentary resolution barring future Israeli governments from concluding peace treaties that require the dismantlement of Israeli settlements.

title: News Analysis
description: What appears to be a struggle for political power in El Salvador between the center, represented by the Christian Democrats, and the right, represented by four conservative political parties, is something both far more complicated and possibly far more dangerous.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption on the front page yesterday misidentified Costa Rica's representative at the Washington meeting of the Organization of American States. He was Foreign Minister

title: Sugar Prices Decline On Import Quota Plans
description: World sugar futures prices weakened yesterday as investors braced for restrictive import quotas and other measures that the Administration is expected to take to bolster the depressed domestic sugar market.

title: Courtroom Reference
description: A social association between a baseball player and a man who was murdered in an organized-crime shooting has been brought out in a Federal criminal trial of seven men in Philadelphia. The player, Jay Johnstone, formerly with the Phillies and now with the Los Angeles Dodgers, was linked with the late Frank Sindone by a tape recording made by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in 1977 and played in court Monday. Yesterday The Philadelphia Daily News reported that Johnstone had dined with Mr. Sindone after games and quoted the player as saying: ''I knew the guy.

title: Conrail Pares Quarterly Loss
description: The Consolidated Rail Corporation said today that it lost $25.7 million in the first quarter, the smallest loss for that period in the railroad's six-year history.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: IN the fourth century B.C. Hippocrates described a disease characterized by erosion and scarring of the skin on the face. Many centuries later physicians named it lupus (Latin for wolf) because they thought the lesion Hippocrates described resembled the bite of a wolf.

title: BRACES FOR A BRITISH ASSAULT
description: The Argentine junta today rejected a request by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. to return here to to continue his efforts to mediate the Falklands crisis. The Argentine armed forces braced for what officials said might be a British assault against the disputed islands in the next two days.

title: Baltimore Aide Is Indicted
description: Walter S. Orlinsky, president of the Baltimore City Council, was indicted today on 12 counts of mail fraud, wire fraud and extortion in connection with a scheme to award city contracts in return for money.

title: EXCERPTS FROM HAIG'S SPEECH ON FOREIGN POLICY
description: Following are excerpts from an address by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. to the annual meeting of the United States Chamber of Commerce here today as provided by the State Department: Special to the New York Times

title: BEGIN SAYS HE THREATENED TO DELAY SINAI PULLOUT
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin said today that he had personally warned Egyptian leaders that Israel would consider delaying its withdrawal from Sinai by a month or more unless what Israel said were Egyptian violations of the peace treaty were corrected.

title: THE THEATER: CHAIKIN'S 'ANTIGONE'
description: AS staged by Joseph Chaikin at the Public Theater's Martinson Hall, ''Antigone'' is a classic, all right - a classic howler. The laughs begin as the lights go down, when we hear a strangled, offstage scream that sounds like an outtake from a grade-Z horror movie. The climax comes roughly 70 minutes later when the wizened old chorus leader surveys the wreckage of the house of Oedipus and asks, in a Mel Brooks accent, ''Whoever thought it would come to this?''

title: SEOUL IS STUNNED BY POLICEMAN'S SLAYING OF 56
description: For eight hours beginning last night, a drunken South Korean policeman stormed through a southern farm community killing at least 56 people and wounding 37 others, and a stunned national Government sought today to find out why no one could stop him.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Jimmy Connors, who won the Alan King Tennis Classic Sunday in Las Vegas, said he might play for the United States in the Davis Cup quarterfinals against Sweden July 9-11 in St. Louis. ''I like playing Davis Cup but I don't want to commit to it every time,'' Connors, ranked third in the world, said.

title: WORRY OVER ARGENTINE LINKS
description: As the Falkland Islands crisis worsens, American companies, which have doubled their investment in Argentina since the mid-1970's, have become increasingly concerned about their operations in the Latin American country.

title: WILDLIFE GROUP SUES TO BAR A MAJOR SALE OF U.S. COAL LEASES
description: The National Wildlife Federation sued Interior Secretary James G. Watt today to block what would be the largest sale of Federal coal leases in history.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Arizona Public Service Co. said it plans to offer two million shares of a new series of cumulative $25 preferred stock near the end of this week.

title: Advertising; Potential Of Lists Is Growing
description: JACK OLDSTEIN isn't a silver-lining specialist. He just sounds that way. ''In this economy there is a potential,'' he said the other day. ''People are out of work, so you sell them correspondence courses to improve themselves. That's the way it is; as one situation cuts back another grows. And this is the greatest time to gear up for the explosion that's coming.''

title: BBDO Net Up 10.3%
description: BBDO International yesterday was the first of the publicly held agencies to announce first-quarter earnings. Revenues gained 11.8 percent over the comparable period last year, to $47.2 million from $42.2 million. Net income was up 10.3 percent, to $3.2 million, or $1.15 a share, from $2.9 million, or $1.06 a share.

title: STEVENS GOES OUTSIDE FAMILY FOR PRESIDENT
description: Harry M. Stevens Inc., the big sports concessionaire founded in 1887 and run by third- and fourth-generation members of the Stevens family, has named the first nonfamily member as president.

title: TWO SWIFT RUNNERS SELECTED BY GIANTS
description: The Giants, 25th in rushing and 28th and last in total offense last year, tried to remedy those situations in a hurry yesterday in the National Football League draft. On the first two rounds, they chose Harold (Butch) Woolfolk of Michigan and Joe Morris of Syracuse, two swift, durable and productive 22-year-old running backs.

title: FOREIGNERS REPORTED ABROAD
description: A Chinese jetliner reportedly carrying foreign tourists on a flight from Canton crashed near the southern city of Guilin on Monday, killing all 112 people aboard.

title: RACE LURING UNKNOWN
description: With so many of the top 3-year-old colts sidelined with injuries, horses that had never been considered Kentucky Derby possibilities seem to be arriving by the hour at Churchill Downs for Saturday's race.

title: Auto Gains Predicted
description: The president of the Ford Motor Company, Donald E. Petersen, said that he expected a gradual recovery in auto sales during the second half of 1982.

title: The Concrete Conspiracy
description: A New York Times series on corruption in New York's construction industry demonstrates starkly that everyone pays as construction costs rise to replace funds drained off by collusion, conspiracy and crime. The inflated costs push up mortgage and rent payments. The problem deserves urgent government attention.

title: THEATER ROW PLANNING A FESTIVAL
description: To celebrate its continuing development, Theater Row - 42d Street between Ninth and 10th Avenues - will hold a festival from June 2 to 27.

title: AT A QUEENS FACTORY, THE WORD ON PRICES
description: If you want to know the Way Things Are in this city, in these United States, you might as well go to Flushing, Queens, and drop in on the people at the Angler's Company Ltd. They will tell you.

title: U.S. JUDGE TELLS JERSEY TO MOVE INMATES IN A JAIL
description: A Federal judge today ordered the state to remove its prisoners from the Union County Jail by July 1 because overcrowding had produced conditions ''so degenerative and so unhealthy as to be constitutionally impermissible.''

title: Mondale Says It's a Mistake For the U.S. to Stay Neutral
description: Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale said today that it was a mistake for the United States to remain neutral in the dispute between Britain and Argentina over the Falkland Islands.

title: HIGH COURT BACKS JUDICIAL DISCRETION IN NAVY TARGET PRACTICE
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that a Federal appellate court erroneously barred the Navy from using a Caribbean island off Puerto Rico for target practice.

title: TV-ILL PREPARED FOR 'NARROW-CASTING'
description: To the Editor:

title: AT LONG LAST, LEBANON'S SHIITES TAKE A STAND
description: To the Editor:

title: Jets Pick Crable, a Linebacker
description: After years of having had the dubious luxury of high draft choices, the Jets drafted 23d yesterday because of their successful season of 10 victories, five losses and a tie. They made Bob Crable, a middle linebacker from Notre Dame, their top selection.

title: Careers; Disposing Of Toxic Wastes
description: THE Battelle Memorial Institute of Columbus, Ohio, a major independent research institute, calls disposal of toxic wastes a critical growth area. As a result of a survey, it found that most companies have limited staff training programs for handling wastes. Battelle wants to fill the gap.

title: ISLANDERS BEAT NORDIQUES BY 4-1 IN PLAYOFF OPENER
description: After struggling through their first two playoff series, the Islanders insisted that if they could just play their game, they would be all right.

title: HIS PEERS GET A FIRST LOOK AT HINCKLEY
description: The people who would judge John W. Hinckley Jr. looked to the right, to the courtroom's side door, and he came forth today, flanked by security guards, still showing the clean-cut, youthful, slightly anxious gaze that has puzzled the nation since he shot President Reagan 13 months ago.

title: MILES DAVIS RECORDING OF HIS CONCERT RIGHTS A WRONG
description: T'S always interesting to hear a live album recorded at a concert one attended, if only as a challenge to the memory. When the concert was as controversial as last summer's Kool Jazz Festival performances by the influential jazz trumpeter Miles Davis, his first New York concerts in almost five years, the release of a live album takes on even more importance. ''We Want Miles'' (Columbia), a new double album, was recorded in Boston and Tokyo as well as at Mr. Davis's two Kool concerts in New York. But it offers a consistent sound and approach, and a chance to re-evalute a new band and musical direction that seemed to this reviewer and a number of others to be somewhat lacking in substance when Mr. Davis returned to the stage last summer.

title: Market Place; Realty Trust's Profitable Plan
description: ''IF Arab oil producers could tolerate cold weather, New Plan Realty Trust might not be so successful in its quest for upstate shopping centers,'' says William Newman, chairman of the real estate investment trust that is based in New York City.

title: TRYING TO SOLVE THE BOTULISM MYSTERY
description: ON March 31, Ida Smith was admitted to a hospital in Hartford, paralyzed and unable to speak. The diagnosis was a stroke. Not until almost two weeks later, when a series of tests failed to show stroke damage, did the doctors consider another diagnosis: botulism. The misdiagnosis is not surprising. In 1981 there were only 28 reported cases of botulism in the United States. Most doctors have never seen a victim of the deadly food poisoning.

title: Politician and Driver Slain by Naples Terrorists
description: Red Brigades guerrillas killed a Christian Democratic politician and his driver today in their first major action since the kidnapping of Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier of the United States.

title: Chock Full o'Nuts Seeks Acquisitions
description: The Chock Full o'Nuts Corporation said it would consider being acquired by another company or seek its own acquisitions in an effort to thwart the advances of Jerry Finkelstein, a New York publisher who recently acquired 6.1 percent of the company's stock.

title: Excerpts from speech, page A12.
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that, with the Soviet Union entering a period of leadership change, the United States faced ''a historic opportunity'' to influence future Soviet actions by making clear to the Kremlin leaders ''the benefits of greater restraint.''

title: The U.N. Today; April 28, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets on question of Palestinians - 10:30 A.M.

title: EXXON NET DOWN 22.5% IN QUARTER
description: The Exxon Corporation, the world's No.1 industrial company, said yesterday that its net income, hurt by the worldwide oil glut, fell 22.5 percent in the first quarter. This contrasts with an average 20 percent rate of annual growth in Exxon's earnings since 1975.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Saturday about a confer- ence at Brooklyn College on Arts in Transition erred in reporting the com- ments of Leonard Fleischer of Exxon on support of the arts. He said that in 1970 United States corporations con- tributed slightly more than 1 percent of their pretax net profits and that in 1981 the share of all private giving to the arts (including that of individuals, corporations and foundations) was slightly below the 1979 and 1980 fig- ures.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate.

title: Court Backs Railroad on Credit Rule
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that a railroad that violates Federal credit rules in delivering freight does not forfeit its right to be paid for the shipment. The decision, which overturned a ruling by a Federal appeals court, was a significant legal victory for the nation's railroads.

title: INDIANA BANKER RECEIVES PRESIDENTIAL PAT ON BACK
description: Larry D. Summers, president of the Plainfield First National Bank and Trust Company, Plainfield, Ind., missed an important telephone call last Wednesday. President Reagan had phoned to congratulate him on First National's move to slash interest rates on auto loans to 12.75 percent from more than 16 percent.

title: PIANO RECITAL: MISS RICH
description: ELIZABETH RICH'S piano recital in the Abraham Goodman House Monday evening addressed the music of Beethoven and its influence on the generation that came immediately after him. From Beethoven himself there were the Sonata in A (Op.101) and ''An die ferne Geliebte'' with the tenor Constantine Cassolas.

title: READY FOR READING ON SCHOOL DAY ONE
description: To the Editor:

title: Telling Stories
description: It takes nerve for President Reagan, of all people, to accuse someone else of being anecdotal. So for the White House to protest Bill Moyers's CBS special on Reaganomics suggests that the program must have stung. It should have. Though not wholly accurate in detail, its general point was sound: the President's budget policy is pushing many people out of work and into the welfare net - and pushing others, who cannot work, out of the net.

title: Required Reading; A Lawyers on Lawyers
description: Lloyd N. Cutler, former White House counsel, on the legal profession, during a lecture at Emory University: Japan has only 10,000 lawyers, or one for every 10,000 people. Western Europe averages one lawyer for every 1,500 people. We have over 500,000 lawyers, or one for every 450 people. We Americans have more faith in laws, regulations and litigation to solve social and economic problems, whether national or personal, than any society on earth. And that is why one in every 450 of us, one in every 200 in the work force, is a lawyer. I once made a calculation that in the District of Columbia, one in every 30 people gainfully employed is a lawyer.

title: THE THEATER: 'BEST ALL AROUND,' COMPETITION FOR TEEN-AGERS
description: IN Marsha Sheiness's ''Best All 'Round,'' a coupla white chicks sit around talking. At the Perry Street Theater, the setting is Corpus Christi, Tex., the time is the 1950's, and the talk is girlish and oh-so-familiar. Michael Lee (Nina Levine) is shy and a bit slow with the boys, while her best friend, Nickie (Lisa Reed), is fast in several senses of the word. She even speeds when she borrows Michael Lee's car to meet her date at a local burger stand.

title: JORDAN AND MOROCCO CONGRATULATE EGYPT
description: Two leaders of Arab countries that severed diplomatic ties with Egypt because of the peace treaty with Israel have sent President Hosni Mubarak messages of congratulations on the restoraton to Egypt of Sinai.

title: FEAR OF DRIVING IT'S NOT UNCOMMON
description: TEN years ago Esther Tuchman, her husband and four children moved from a garden apartment in Bayside, Queens, to a spacious house in Scarsdale. The move seemed ideal, but as it turned out life became tougher for Mrs. Tuchman, for she is one of a number of people who, in a society heavily dependent on the automobile, is afraid to drive.

title: Bulova Consolidation
description: The Bulova Watch Company, controlled by the Loews Corporation, has consolidated its advertising at Doyle Dane Bernbach, which was already doing the advertising for the Bulova brand. Now the agency has been assigned the Accutron Swiss Watch, Caravelle watches and Bulova clocks that have been at Scali, McCabe, Sloves.

title: KEAN FORGIVES FINES IMPOSED IN WATER CRISIS
description: Governor Kean forgave nearly $9 million in fines for violations of water- rationing regulations yesterday, as drought emergencies in northern New Jersey and the Delaware River Basin were formally ended.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'm not starving myself or anything. I'm just making a living.

title: REAGAN LIKELY TO SEEK NEW FARM PRICE SUPPORTS
description: The Reagan Administration is expected to call for changes in farm price support programs that could raise domestic sugar prices as much as 4 cents a pound and lower retail dairy prices slightly. The moves are certain to anger either consumers, producers, farm state Congressmen, or some of this country's allies.

title: Rev. David J. Fant Dies at 85; Led a New York Bible Society
description: The Rev. David J. Fant, retired executive secretary of the New York International Bible Society, died last Friday at his home in Riverdale, Ga. He was 85 years old.

title: LeFante Enters Race For Senate in Jersey
description: Joseph LeFante, a former Representative, Assembly Speaker and Community Affairs Commissioner, said today that he would seek the Democratic Party's nomination in the June 8 primary for a seat in the United States Senate.

title: Securities Firm Is Sued
description: Los Angeles County is suing a New York investment firm for reportedly investing $11 million of its public funds in Federal securities without county authorization.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Anatole Broyard Soon To Be Immortal. By Ellen Alexander Conley. 216 pps. St. Martin's Press. $13.95.

title: PANEL DELAYS ACTION ON VOTING RIGHTS ACT AS COMPROMISE IS SOUGHT
description: Lawmakers searched for a last-minute compromise on extending the Voting Rights Act today as the Senate Judiciary Committee postponed consideration of the legislation until Wednesday.

title: WILSONS SEE LONG ROAD FOR WOMEN
description: WHEN the sisters Ann and Nancy Wilson rose to prominence in the mid-1970's with their rock group Heart, very few women were singing and playing hard rock. Heart's music, which has been consistently popular with radio programmers and record buyers, had its softer, acoustic side. But onstage and on many of their records, Nancy Wilson played biting electric guitar while Ann shouted out lyrics in a strangled scream that recalled Led Zeppelin's Robert Plant, one of her formative influences along with black rhythm-and-blues.

title: WINE TALK
description: One of the more extraordinary tastings ever conducted in North America took place here over the weekend when the wines of the great Chateau Cheval Blanc, in 36 vintages dating back to 1911, were evaluated by a group of expert palates from all over the country. One basic conclusion was that Cheval Blanc, a richly flavored Bordeaux that lacks the fame of Lafite, Latour and some other chateaus, deserves to be on the same exalted level.

title: INMAN CALLS U.S. INTELLIGENCE 'MARGINALLY CAPABLE'
description: United States foreign intelligence is ''marginally capable'' of meeting ''the problems we are going to face in the 1980's and 1990's,'' Adm. Bobby R. Inman said in a speech here today at the American Newspaper Publishers Association convention.

title: ALPHA FLOYD TO PERFORM IN SALEM CHURCH SERIES
description: Alpha Floyd, the soprano, will be one of a group of soloists in a performance of Verdi's Requiem at 5 P.M. Saturday at Salem United Methodist Church.

title: BERT JONES SENT TO RAMS, FRANCIS TO 49ERS
description: The opening of the National Football League's draft was embellished yesterday by the trading of four prominent veterans - Bert Jones, Mike Barber, Russ Francis and Tim Fox - to go with the usual mix of predictable and unpredictable selections.

title: BROADCAST LOBBYIST TO RESIGN BY 1983
description: One of Washington's best known lobbyists, Vincent T. Wasilewski, announced yesterday that he would resign as president of the National Association of Broadcasters after 17 years in the post.

title: Governor for Speeders
description: ''It's become almost routine,'' William R. Siebert, the head of the Oregon state police administrative division, said of Gov. Victor L. Atiyeh's volunteer work in law enforcement. ''He's picked up drunken drivers, speeders and people that are crazy in traffic, just weaving in and out.''

title: Haitians End Hunger Strike
