description: The last four hunger strikers of a group of 38 Haitian women who had been fasting to protest their incarceration at a refugee camp ended their strike Monday, Federal officials reported. The women began their strike 11 days earlier in the hope of gaining their freedom.

title: REFORM IS URGED IN MILITARY BUDGET PLANNING
description: Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, former Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, urged Congress today to order fundamental reforms in how military budgets are prepared because ''there is no way for Congress to know whether the budget is adequate, excessive or insufficient.''

title: Family Affair at Medgar Evers
description: When we read about the sit-in at Medgar Evers College, a two-year unit of City University in Brooklyn's Crown Heights section, we wondered if perhaps it was a harbinger of new campus protests. The answer is no. The Medgar Evers protest is essentially a family affair.

title: G.& W. Raises Stevens Stake
description: Gulf and Western Industries said that it had increased its holdings in J.P. Stevens & Company, the textiles concern, to 19.32 percent through the acquisition of 193,500 shares for about $3 million.

title: Rail Consolidation
description: The Norfolk and Western Railway Company and the Southern Railway Company announced that the consolidation of the two companies into the Norfolk Southern Corporation would be effective on June 1.

title: Fraser Plea To Japanese
description: Japanese auto makers enjoy a significant labor cost advantage over their rivals in the United States, and Douglas A. Fraser, president of the United Automobile Workers union, is trying to close the gap. Mr. Fraser is in Japan, urging Japanese auto workers to demand higher wages.

title: FELIX GREISSLE, 87, EX-EDITOR OF MARX MUSIC CORPORATION
description: Felix Greissle, former editor of the E.B. Marx Music Corporation and a friend and student of Arnold Schoenberg, died Monday in Manhasset, L.I. He was 87 years old.

title: Spain's Coup Defendants Face 30-Year Sentences
description: The prosecution refused today to reduce charges of military rebellion against 33 men accused in last year's attempted coup in Spain and requested 30-year prison sentences for the three main defendants.

title: Canada Defeats Czechs By 4-2 in World Hockey
description: Dino Ciccarelli of the Minnesota North Stars and Bob Gainey of the Montreal Canadiens scored third-period goals today to give Team Canada a 4-2 victory over Czechoslovakia in the World Ice Hockey Championships.

title: A SUPREME WINE THAT'S COSTLY INDEED
description: The wines of Chateau Cheval Blanc are among the most expensive in the world, with older vintages that have achieved the status of collector's items particularly costly. At a Christie's wine auction in Chicago on April 17, a magnum, equal to two bottles, of Cheval Blanc from the famous 1947 vintage brought $620.

title: AT HARLEM SCHOOL, THE BASS BRAVURA OF THE TUBA
description: ''Have you ever heard a lovesick elephant?'' Harvey Phillips asked the group of children clustering around him yesterday. As the children slowly shook their heads, Mr. Phillips raised his tuba and produced the sweet, mournful bass sounds of the second movement of ''Effie the Elephant,'' the opening number of his concert for young students at the Harlem School for the Arts, at 645 St. Nicholas Avenue.

title: MUSIC: THE SUFI DERVISHES
description: ANNUALLY since 1978 the priests, chanters, musicians and dancers of the Sufi dervishes of the Halveti-Jerrahi order from Istanbul have presented their communal ceremony of the ''dhikr'' at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. So popular have these admission-free mystical Islamic cermonies become, and so magnetic seems the order's leader, al-Hajj Sheikh Muzaffereddin Halveti al-Jerrahi, that a mosque for the order has been established in SoHo, reflecting the strong appeal that this particular sect has for the city's artists.

title: U.S. Trade Deficit Rose To $2.6 Billion in March
description: The nation's merchandise trade deficit rose to $2.6 billion in March as a surge in imported automobiles offset a decline in foreign oil purchases, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: HOME CANNING: CARE MUST BE TAKEN
description: BECAUSE most cases of botulism are caused by improper home canning, it is essential to follow directions from an authoritative source. The Department of Agriculture is one of the most reliable.

title: Afghan Gets Diplomatic Post
description: Mohammed Sakhi Daneshjo has been named Afghanistan's Deputy Minister for Foreign Affairs, Western diplomats said here today. Mr. Daneshjo, a career diplomat, was Director for Political Affairs in the Afghan Foreign Ministry.

title: TEACHER CONVICTED IN SEX CASE
description: A Superior Court jury here today convicted a Leonia schoolteacher of one count of sexual assault on a fourth-grade pupil.

title: TV: NEW YORK POLICE IN 'QUESTION OF HONOR'
description: ''A QUESTION OF HONOR,'' a three-hour television movie on CBS tonight at 8 o'clock, was adapted by Budd Schulberg from a book called ''Point Blank.'' Written by Sonny Grosso and Philip Rosenberg, the book was based on the true story of a New York policeman they chose to call Joe DeFalco. Mr. Grosso was a personal friend of DeFalco and, in fact, got him a bit part in ''The French Connection.'' Mr. Grosso had figured prominently as a law enforcer in the story that inspired the film.

title: MRS. KIRKPATRICK, THE U.S. AND THE FALKLANDS
description: To the Editor:

title: O.A.S., BY 17-0, CALLS FOR A TRUCE IN THE FALKLANDS
description: The Organization of American States passed a resolution early this morning calling for a truce in the Falkland Islands and the withdrawal of British and Argentine forces.

title: 'TIME IS RUNNING OUT'
description: Everybody keeps saying that ''time is running out'' for a peaceful settlement of the Falkland Islands dispute. But the Reagan Administration keeps using up the time that's left by tossing the problem to the United Nations, which has no power to deal with it.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, APRIL 28, 1982
description: International Britain will invade the Falklands this week unless an unexpected diplomatic breakthrough occurs, according to authoritative Government sources. Aides to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said they saw no evidence of diplomatic progress. The Times of London reported that an advance detachment of British troops had landed in the islands. (Page A1, Column 6.) Argentina rejected a U.S. request for Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. to return to Buenos Aires to continue his efforts for a settlement of the Falklands crisis. Argentines braced for a British assault against the disputed islands. (A18:1-2.)

title: BRIEFING
description: Scooped by Scoop?

title: A PAN FOR CARMELIZING
description: CARAMELIZING sugar for sauces and desserts is a simple process, but it works so fast that before you know what has happened the sugar may have burned and the saucepan is ruined.

title: SALVADOR EXPANDS ASSEMBLY'S POWER
description: El Salvador's rightist-controlled Constituent Assembly voted itself broad powers Monday night to organize the Government and control the nation's laws.

title: CITY COUNCIL APPROVES PLAN FOR NEW DISTRICT BOUNDARIES
description: After much wrangling, the City Council yesterday passed new boundary lines for 35 districts. Council leaders said they hoped the new lines, which must be signed into law by Mayor Koch and approved by the United States Justice Department, would lead to Council elections in November.

title: Dodgers Waive Goltz
description: Dave Goltz, the right-handed pitcher who signed a six-year contract worth $3 million with Los Angeles two years ago, has been placed on waivers by the Dodgers for the purpose of giving him his unconditional release. The Dodgers must pay Goltz the remaining $1.5 million on his contract, for the 1983, 1984 and 1985 seasons.

title: BATTLE RAGES OVER COINS FOR '84 OLYMPICS
description: Congressmen who sometimes despair of their ability to affect the great issues of the day may be taking some comfort these days from the efforts of Representative Frank Annunzio. The Illinois Democrat, who heads the usually obscure Consumer Affairs and Coinage Subcommittee, is proving that one person among 435 can indeed make a difference.

title: News Analysis
description: Now that Mayor Koch has made it amply clear that he no longer wants his job, the line of people who might run next year to succeed him is beginning to sprawl across the steps of City Hall and beyond.

title: 19 Injured in German Blast
description: An explosion injured 19 people at the giant Bayer chemical plant, the police said today. The cause of the explosion Monday night was not immediately known. A spokesman for Bayer said the blast caused ''considerable.''

title: Enough Traveling
description: For the last 20 years, they have been traveling more than 100,000 miles a year, to more than 1,500 cities and towns, to give their concert of songs from the American musical theater. Now after 20 years on the road, Earl Wrightson and Lois Hunt will be back giving the program in New York City on Sunday at the Kaufmann Concert Hall of the 92d Street Y.

title: Q&A
description: Q. G.K. Chesterton wrote the following: ''The lady, though lofty, was quite gracious, however, and offered the visitor a small glass of Port wine and a slice of seed-cake, in the manner of everybody's most ancient great-aunts.'' What is a seedcake?

title: 250 More Are Arrested In Crackdown on Aliens
description: By The Associated Press Immigration officers in New York and Houston arrested about 250 suspected illegal aliens yesterday in the second day of a nationwide crackdown aimed at aliens who work in well-paying jobs that could be held by United States citizens.

title: Boston Takes 8th in Row
description: Carl Yastrzemski drove in two runs with a single in the first inning and set up the lead run with another hit in the fifth tonight as the Boston Red Sox beat the Kansas City Royals, 7-5, for their eighth consecutive victory.

title: Official Tells of Policy On Parole for Sirhan
description: Former state policy virtually forbade a denial of a parole date for Sirhan B. Sirhan, the assassin of Senator Robert F. Kennedy, an official testified today before a special parole hearing.

title: LAWYER AND EX-HEAD OF RIFLE ASSOCIATION
description: Woodson D. Scott, a retired New York lawyer and a former president and director of the National Rifle Association, died Monday at Stamford (Conn.) Hospital. He was 82 years old and had lived in Stamford since moving from Manhattan 13 years ago.

title: Long-Term Rates Up Slightly; 6-Month Bills Are at 12.52%
description: Uncertainty about Federal Reserve monetary policy, the size of Federal budget deficits, and the course of the economy continued to plague participants in the credit markets yesterday.

title: THREE VIEWPOINTS FOR FALL
description: THOSE who think of fashion as an art form had a chance to indulge their fancy Monday evening when Michaele Vollbracht, who made his reputation as a fashion illustrator, hired the Beacon Theater on Broadway at 74th Street to stage his fashion show. The crowds outside suggested the opening night of a significant theatrical event. There were tickets and ticket-takers and ushers inside who guided the audience to their seats and handed out programs detailing four fashion acts.

title: MARKET CHALLENGES FOR LASERS
description: The recent push on Capitol Hill and in the Defense Department for laser weapons to be used in space has been greeted without enthusiasm at the headquarters of Coherent Inc., one of the nation's leading laser manufacturers.

title: Hats Off! Or On?
description: Capt. Simcha Goldman of Los Angeles has won his yearlong fight to wear a yarmulke while on duty in the Air Force. Judge Aubrey E. Robinson Jr. of Federal District Court in Washington ruled on Monday that an Air Force regulation barring the yarmulke, a skullcap worn by some Jews as a sign of respect to God, was unconstitutional.

title: COCA-COLA ADVANCES BY 2.1%
description: The Coca-Cola Company reported yesterday that net income in the first quarter edged up 2.1 percent, held back partly by a decline in orders for soft drink syrup.

title: MGM Grand Swap
description: MGM Grand Hotels Inc. reported that 8.1 million of its shares had been tendered to date as part of the company's recapitalization plan. Under terms of the exchange offer, which was made on Monday, one share of a new issue of series A redeemable preferred stock, redeemable at $20 a share, is being issued in exchange for each share of common stock that is tendered. Kirk Kerkorian, the principal stockholder of MGM Grand and his wholly owned Tracinda Corporation, tendered 5 million of the aggregate number of shares, MGM said.

title: Texaco Policies Cited by Holders
description: Texaco Inc., at its annual meeting here, answered criticisms of its business interests in South Africa and its policy of discounting employees' lump-sum pension payments. A representative of the United Church of Christ and several shareholders voiced their objections to the company's business interests in South Africa while employee-stockholders objected to the pension policy.

title: Schmidt Appoints Lahnstein To Post of Finance Minister
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt received approval today from his Social Democratic Party for a series of Cabinet shifts, including the naming of Manfred Lahnstein to the post of Finance Minister. Mr. Lahnstein, the former chief of Mr. Schmidt's chancellery, replaces Hans Matthofer, who, because of health reasons, requested a less-taxing Cabinet post. Mr. Matthofer was named Postal Minister.

title: A NEW BONNIE RAITT IS BACK WITH NEW BAND
description: BONNIE RAITT and her new band were at the Palladium Sunday night, playing rock-and-roll. Like Nancy Wilson of Heart, Miss Raitt used to be more than a little self-conscious about letting go onstage, and after her show she said she still wondered what her fans would think when she cuts loose with a screaming electric guitar solo, and punctuates it with expressive body English.

title: NORDIQUES AREN'T DISCOURAGED
description: After the Nordiques lost the opener of their Stanley Cup semifinal series to the Islanders tonight, the Quebec players and their coach, Michel Bergeron, noted that losing the first game of an important series was nothing new to them.

title: POST-NUCLEAR 'ROAD WARRIOR'
description: NEVER has a film's vision of the post-nuclear-holocaust world seemed quite as desolate and as brutal, or as action-packed and sometimes as funny as in George Miller's apocalyptic ''The Road Warrior,'' an extravagant film fantasy that looks like a sadomasochistic comic book come to life.

title: Bridge: Bridge World's Quiet Man Is Mourned by Colleagues
description: In the 60's and early 70's a quiet man regularly upset players with national reputations in major New York team competitions, demonstrating that loud voices and large egos are in no way essential for success at the bridge table. He was David Mason of Maplewood, N.J., who died last week, mourned by all in the bridge world. He had served the Greater New York Bridge Association in many capacities, including that of president.

title: Soviet Pentecostalists Say Family Was Beaten
description: The Soviet Pentecostalists who have taken refuge at the United States Embassy here said today that their brothers and sisters in the Siberian city of Chernogorsk were badly beaten recently when they staged a demonstration to demand their emigration.

title: ACCEPTING SCIENTIFIC IDEAS
description: It is very tempting to make fun of scientists, now departed, who have made fools of themselves by rejecting scientific theories whose validity now seems obvious.

title: LARGE BAKERY PROPOSES MOVE TO CITY
description: American Bakeries Inc., the country's fourth-largest commercial bakery, says it will move its corporate headquarters from Chicago to Queens if New York City can meet its financial demands.

title: A Suspect in Murder Makes $500,000 Bail
description: A 43-year-old woman who was indicted and jailed in the shooting death of her father, from whom she stood to inherit hundreds of millions of dollars, was released on $500,000 bail yesterday, according to Edward Hershey, a spokesman for the Department of Correction. A certified check for the bail was presented to the Correctional Institution for Women at Rikers Island, he said.

title: BIRTH-CONTROL RULE MAY BE MODIFIED
description: The Reagan Administration's proposal to require notification of parents when minors receive contraceptives at clinics that receive Government funds may need refining so it will not be an undue burden on the clinics, an official of the Department of Health and Human Services said this week.

title: SONG: PRADA, AS TROUBADOUR
description: MOST of the Spanish songs sung by Amancio Prada at the Spanish Institute Monday night were his own settings of classic ballads and contemporary lyrics. But Mr. Prada's musical illuminations of texts going back to 11th-century Galician troubadour songs had the aura of authenticity.

title: U.S. TALKING TO BOTH SIDES IN FALKLAND CRISIS
description: Administration officials said today that the United States was in close consultation with the Argentine and British Governments over the Falkland Islands crisis, but they acknowledged that Argentina was still refusing to take part in Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.'s mediation efforts.

title: SPRIG
description: ''The begiddig of Sprig'' says the Caladar; ''It's dot eddy such thig'' says by dose. We've had that sabe argubet year after year Far back as by bebory goes. I adbit I adbire your blossobs, although I dote sbell their perfube, But, oh how I wish you would brig be sub tissue Idstead of the flowers that bloob! MARION ROSETTE

title: BUSH TO VISIT CHINA FOR TALKS TO INCLUDE TAIWAN ARMS ISSUE
description: The White House announced today that Vice President Bush would visit China for talks early next month that will include an effort to resolve the dispute over American arms sales to Taiwan.

title: Nippon Steel Contract
description: The Nippon Steel Corporation said today it had signed a contract with the Reed Tubular Products Company of the United States to establish a specialized tool joint manufacturing and drill pipe processing company here next month. The joint company, called the Reed Nippon Corporation, will be capitalized at one billion yen with Reed taking 49 percent and the remaining 51 percent to be shared by Nippon Steel with 34 percent and its subsidiary the Nippon Steel Metal Products Comapny with 17 percent. Production will start in 1984 at an annual rate of 10,000 tons initially.

title: Daisy G. Lawrence, 81, First Girl Scout in U.S.
description: Daisy Gordon Lawrence, the first American Girl Scout, died Monday at a nursing home in Seattle at the age of 81. A former resident of Danbury, Conn., and New York City, she had moved to Seattle five years ago.

title: J. Carroll Bateman, 64, Dies; Head of Insurance Institute
description: J. Carroll Bateman, former president of the Insurance Information Institute, died Saturday at Jefferson Memorial Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 64 years old and lived in Butler, N.J.

title: SINAI: 'A TRIUMPH OF HOPE OVER HISTORY'
description: To the Editor:

title: REFINANCING WOES CALLED A THREAT TO FUTURE OF CITY'S RENTAL HOUSING
description: Problems in mortgage refinancing have become a threat to the future of New York City's rental housing, according to real estate experts. Mortgages generally made for 10-year terms are coming due on existing properties, and they must be renewed at much higher rates. In many cases lenders want most of the principal repaid when the loan is renewed - and in a few cases paid off entirely.

title: SUPREME COURT HEARS CASE ON CHILD-PORNOGRAPHY LAW
description: An assistant Manhattan district attorney told the United States Supreme Court today that a 1977 New York State law barring the use of children in pornography had been intended to ''protect children from abuse'' that left a ''profound adverse effect, both physical and mental.''

title: CUSTODY FIGHT AN ORDEAL FOR UKRAINIAN'S PARENTS
description: Had he been a French or German citizen returning home from the United States with his children, Michael Polovchak would not be embroiled in the battle he has fought with the Illinois and Federal authorities for the last two years to regain custody of his 14-year-old son, Walter, the Ukrainian parent said here today.

title: RELIGIOUS LEADERS OPEN DRIVE TO AID THE POOR
description: A group of about 50 religious leaders and theologians began a campaign today to persuade Congress to maintain a number of domestic programs in the budget for the next fiscal year.

title: VOTERS SURPRISE SASKATCHEWAN
description: For the first time in its 77-year history as a Canadian province, Saskatchewan, in the heart of the country's wheat belt, elected a majority Conservative government on Monday night.

title: JAY VELIE
description: Jay Velie, an actor and singer whose Broadway career covered more than 50 years, died Thursday of congestive failure at his home in Larchmont, N.Y. He was 89 years old.

title: Pabst Says It Won In Proxy Dispute
description: Directors nominated by the Pabst Brewing Company were narrowly elected over a dissident slate following a recent proxy battle, Pabst announced at its reconvened annual meeting. But the dissidents vowed to seek a new election.

title: LES DAMES D'ESCOFFIER DINE FESTIVELY
description: BOTH the ''premiere assiette,'' Le Consomme de Canard de Barbary, and its successor, Le Supreme de Saumon au Coulis d'Ecrevisses, had been consumed, helped along by a perfectly beautiful, dry and grassy 1979 Pouilly Fume from Domaine des Chailloux, when Irena Chalmers rose to greet her sister members of Les Dames d'Escoffier and to preside over the induction of six members.

title: National Football League Draft; FIRST ROUND
description: 1, New England, Kenneth Sims, de, Texas; 2, Baltimore, Johnnie Cooks, lb, Mississippi State; 3, New Orleans, used first round selection last year by picking quarterback Dave Wilson of Illinois in the supplemental draft; 4, Cleveland, Chip Banks, lb, Southern California; 5, Baltimore, from Los A ngeles, Art Schlichter, qb, Ohio State; 6, Chicago, Jim McMahon, qb, Brigham Young; 7, Seattle, Jeff Bryant, dt, Clemson; 8, Minnesota, Darrin Nelson, rb, Stanford; 9, Houston, Mike Munchak, g, Penn State; 10, Atlanta, Gerald Riggs, rb, Arizona State; 11, Oakland, Marcus Allen, rb, Southern California; 12, Kansas City, from St. L ouis, Anthony Hancock, wr, Tennessee; 13, Pittsburgh, Walter Abercrombie, rb, Baylor; 14, New Orleans, from Green Bay through San Diego, Lindsey Scott, wr, Georgia. 15, Los Angeles, from Washington, Barry Redden, rb, Richmond; 16, Detroit, Jimmy Williams, lb, Nebraska; 17, St. Louis, from Kansas City, Luis Sharpe, t, U.C.L.A.; 18, Tampa Bay, Sean Farrell, g, Penn State; 19, Giants, Butch Woolfolk, rb, Michigan; 20, Buffalo, from Denver, Perry Tuttle, wr, Clemson; 21, Philadelphia, Mike Quick, wr, North Carolina State; 22, Denver, from Buffalo, Gerald Willhite, rb, San Jose State; 23, Green Bay, from San Diego, Ron Hallstrom, t, Iowa; 24, Jets, Bob Crable, lb, Notre Dame; 25, Miami, Roy Foster, g, Southern California; 26, Dallas, Rod Hill, db, Kentucky State; 27, Cincinnati, Glen Collins, dt, Mississippi State; 28, New England, from San Francisco, Lester Williams, dt, Miami (Fla.). SECOND ROUND 1, Baltimore, Leo Wisniewski, dt, Penn State; 2, San Francisco, from Baltimore, William (Bubba) Paris, t, Michigan; 3, New Orleans, Brad Edelman, c, Missouri; 4, Cleveland, Keith Baldwin, de, Texas A&M; 5, Tampa Bay, from Chicago, Booker Reese, de, Bethune-Cookman; 6, Seattle, Bruce Scholtz, lb, Texas; 7, Baltimore, from Los Angeles, Rohn Stark, p, Florida State; 8, Oakland, from Houston, Jack Squirek, lb, Illinois; 9, Atlanta, Doug Rogers, de, Stanford; 10, Oakland, Jim Romano, c, Penn State; 11, St. Louis, David Galloway, dt, Florida; 12, Minnesota, Terry Tausch, t, Texas; 13, New England, from San Diego through Green Bay, Robert Weathers, rb, Arizona State; 14, New England, from Washington through San Francisco, Andre Tippett, lb, Iowa. 15, Detroit, Bobby Watkins, db, Southwest Texas State; 16, Pittsburgh, John Meyer, t, Arizona State; 17, Houston, from Tampa Bay through Miami and Los Angeles) Oliver Luck, qb, West Virginia; 18, Giants, Joe Morris, rb, Syracuse; 19, Kansas City, Calvin Daniels, lb, North C arolina; 2 0, Philadelphia, Lawrence Sampleton, te, Texas; 21, Buffalo, Matt Kofler, qb, San Diego State; 2 2, Washington, from San Diego through Los Angeles, Vernon Dean, db, San Diego State; 23, Denver, Orlando McDaniel, wr, Louisiana State; 24, Jets, Reggie McElroy, t, West Texas State; 25, Miami, Mark Duper, wr, N.W. Louisiana; 26, Dallas, J eff Rohrer, lb, Yale; 27, Cincinnati, Emanuel Weaver, dt, South Carolina; 28, New England, from San Francisco, Darryl Haley, t, Utah.

title: REAGAN TO ENTER TALKS ON BUDGET AS NEGOIATIONS REACH AN IMPASSE
description: President Reagan asked the Democratic leader of the House and the Republican leader of the Senate today to join him Wednesday on Capitol Hill in a personal effort to achieve a budget compromise.

title: CHINA'S PROPOSED CONSTITUTION OFFERS BIG CHANGES
description: China made public a proposed new constitution today that would change its commune system dramatically, formally end the right to strike and set a 10-year limit on the tenure of top officials.

title: People
description: * Carl Carey named vice president and general manager of WNBC-TV.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Accu Test Systems, Houston, announced that Louis W. Storms Jr. had been named acting president and chief executive officer, following the resignations of Lester Straughn, chairman, and Gary R. Lawrence, president and chief operating officer.

title: ABC's Profit Climbs by 89.1%
description: The American Broadcasting Companies, citing the strength of television operations, said yesterday that its first-quarter profit surged 89.1 percent, to $24.2 million, from a year earlier.

title: ARTICHOKES: TURNING OVER A NEW LEAF
description: PERHAPS it is nothing more than unbridled enthusiasm for globe artichokes, but each year at this time I feel that the latest harvest is fleshier and better than ever. There is definitely a hierarchy among greens - who could contemplate okra or cabbage in sophisticated realms? - and if I should rank them, artichokes would certainly be at the top of the list.

title: Control Data Adds Computer Line
description: The Control Data Corporation introduced a new family of large-scale computers that it said would offer the widest range of computing power of any system in its history.

title: MAINSTREAM STYLE WITH PERSONAL STAMP
description: THEIR names may not be quite as household as those of Blass, Klein and Halston. But that did not stop such lesser-known designers as Mary Jane Marcasiano, Julio Espada and Koos van den Akker from presenting fall collections last week that bear the personal stamp of their design visions without leaving the mainstream of current fashion.

title: Real Estate; The Shift In Taxation For Transit
description: THERE will be more money for mass transit in New York City as a result of a change in real estate taxation, according to authoritative accounts.

title: Economic Scene; Grim Reality Of the Budget
description: THE grim reality needs to be faced: The budget is out of control. Unless President Reagan makes a remarkable deal with Congressional leaders in a meeting with them today, the nation faces a string of the biggest deficits in its history. And, if nothing dramatic is done now, those deficits will climb in the next few years, weakening the national economy.

title: EASTERN GIVES BRANIFF $11 MILLION FOR ROUTES
description: Frank Borman, chairman and president of Eastern Airlines, said yesterday that Eastern had paid Braniff Airways an initial $11 million to lease Braniff's Latin American routes. He predicted that the new routes would be profitable enough to earn back that down payment by the end of the year.

title: Ford's Minicar
description: The Ford Motor Company has indefinitely shelved its plans to market a minicar carrying the Ford nameplate, according to American Metal Market's Metalworking News, an industry trade journal. The publication said plans for selling the car in the United States foundered on difficulties between Ford and its Japanese partner, the Toyo Kogyo Company, which makes the Mazda line of vehicles. A Ford spokesman, Bill Peacock, said the company would not comment on the report.

title: RECESSION IS CITED
description: The Xerox Corporation yesterday reported a 23.3 percent drop in its first-quarter net income that it said was caused by the recession. Earnings fell to $109.5 million, or $1.29 a share, from a restated $142.7 million, or $1.69 a share, in the comparable 1981 period, the copier and computer maker said.

title: SAUDIS SAID TO PRESS THEIR PEACE PLAN
description: Saudi Arabia has been talking to other Arab governments in an effort to organize a meeting of Arab heads of state that would approve the ''Fahd peace plan'' as the Arab alternative to the Camp David accords, a top Palestine Liberation Organization official said today.

title: ST. PAUL VOTERS VETO CABLE TV SYSTEM RUN BY CITY
description: Voters overwhelmingly defeated a proposal today for the city to run its own cable television system. With all 161 precincts reporting, the tally was 23,796 votes against the proposal and 13,459 for it, or 64 to 36 percent. The city has 157,000 registered voters.

title: ONE-HOUR NEWSCASTS BACKED IN POLL
description: JUST two months after Group W Broadcasting released a study showing that a majority of television viewers opposed expansion of the network news to one hour, NBC yesterday released its own poll aimed at demonstrating that most viewers were receptive to an expanded onehour national newscast.

title: SENATORS BALK AT HELICOPTER'S RAPID COST INCREASE
description: In the mid-1970's Congress agreed to an Army request for a new attack helicopter, a sleek weapon designed to fight day or night, to hurl missiles against enemy tanks in Europe and possibly the Middle East. Its cost was put at about $5 million per aircraft.

title: RULES BENT FOR JAMAICA, HELPING U.S. INDUSTRY
description: President Reagan's expressed wish to transform Jamaica into an economic showplace of the Caribbean has prompted three Federal agencies to waive laws and bend rules, thereby providing more than $100 million to bolster the Jamaican operations of leading American aluminum companies.

title: U.S. STEEL'S EARNINGS SLIDE 70.5%
description: The United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest steel producer, reported yesterday that its first-quarter earnings plunged 70.5 percent, to $79.9 million, with most of the profit coming from the Marathon Oil Company, which U.S. Steel acquired after a long takeover battle.

title: SCIENTISTS URGE MORE EFFORT TO CUT ATOM RISK
description: Declaring that science offers ''no prospect'' of defense against nuclear war, the National Academy of Sciences called on American and world leaders today to intensify ''with a sense of urgency'' their efforts to reduce the risk of nuclear war and the spread of nuclear weapons.

title: Outrage at U.S.C.
description: James H. Zumberge, president of the University of Southern California, says he thinks the National Collegiate Athletic Association was ''unreasonable, inequitable, wholly unjustified'' and ''vindictive'' in its penalties against the U.S.C. football team, and that he is considering filing a lawsuit against the association. The N.C.A.A. prohibited Southern Cal from playing bowl games in the next two academic years and from appearing on television in 1983 and 1984. Mr. Zumberge estimated that the penalties would cost U.S.C. more than $1 million and said that U.S.C. opponents would suffer heavy losses because of the television ban.

title: THE HISTORY OF BOTULISM
description: BOTULISM is an often-fatal disease of the nervous system of humans and other mammals that was first recorded in Europe in 1735 and that was suspected of being associated with a German sausage. It was named after the Latin word for sausage, ''botulus.''

title: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 28, 1982; Companies
description: Exxon reported a 22.5 percent drop in first-quarter net income because of the worldwide oil glut. The company's earnings had been growing at an average rate of 20 percent since 1975. Exxon also registered a 10.6 percent decline in revenue. Three other big oil companies' earnings were also down for the period, Socal's by 65.5 percent, Gulf's by 11.9 percent and Shell's by 4.4 percent. (Page D1.)

title: Borg-Warner
description: The Borg-Warner Corporation said it had agreed to acquire Burns International Security Services, a security guard concern based in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., for $82.5 million in cash. Burns, which employs 36,000 personnel worldwide, had revenues last year of about $240 million. Borg-Warner, a diversified heavy manufacturing concern based in Chicago, reported revenues of about $2.7 billion in 1981.

title: DREXEL ORDERED TO PAY MERRILL LYNCH IN HIRINGS
description: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. has been ordered by a New York Stock Exchange arbitration panel to pay Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc. damages of $250,000 for improper recruiting practices.

title: Executive Post For N.A.S.L.
description: The North American Soccer League's 28-man board of directors voted unanimously in Chicago yesterday to appoint sometime soon a frontoffice executive with the title of chief executive officer who will work with Commissioner Phil Woosnam.

title: BALLET: CYNTHIA GREGORY'S 'SWAN'
description: THERE were times when a performance of ''Swan Lake'' invariably grabbed the viewer by the throat, and just as invariably that performance used to be by Margot Fonteyn and Rudolf Nureyev with Britain's Royal Ballet.

title: Addenda
description: * Albert Jay Rosenthal & Co., Chicago, has acquired Fran Wollack and Associates.

title: Boston Stock Exchange
description: James E. Dowd has resigned as president of the Boston Stock Exchange after 13 years. The resignation of Mr. Dowd, 59 years old, was announced yesterday by Charles J. Mohr, chairman of the exchange, but had been tendered at the exchange's April 22 board of governor's meeting. About 80 issues are traded only on the Boston Stock Exchange.

title: NEW BID EXPECTED FOR LANE BRYANT
description: A new bidder is preparing to outbid a private investor group headed by Wertheim & Company for control of Lane Bryant Inc., the nation's largest retailer of extra-size apparel, Wall street sources said yesterday.

title: Reader's Digest Ending Its Families Magazine
description: The Reader's Digest Association announced yesterday that it is ending its Families magazine with the June issue because it has just not been able to reach its sales goals.

title: BRITAIN REPORTED READY TO INVADE ISLANDS THIS WEEK
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has decided to invade the Falkland Islands this week unless there is a sudden and unexpected diplomatic breakthrough, authoritative Government sources reported today.

title: Afghan Rebels Reported To Inflict Heavy Losses
description: Afghan insurgents inflicted heavy losses on Soviet and Afghan Government troops in two separate battles on April 19 near Kabul, the Afghanistan capital, western diplomatic sources said here today.

title: SOLDIER GUILTY OF 3 KILLINGS IN BUFFALO
description: A 26-year-old white Army private accused of murdering four blacks and a dark-skinned Hispanic man in shooting and stabbing attacks here and in New York City was convicted of three of the killings today.

title: IDAHO POTATO PANEL COMBATS LABEL PROBLEM
description: The Idaho Potato Commission is asking the United States Customs Service to block imports of Canadian potatoes said to be mislabeled with the Idaho-potato trademark.

title: N.B.A. Fines 3 Players
description: Wayne (Tree) Rollins of the Atlanta Hawks and two Philadelphia 76ers, the guard Lionel Hollins and the center Darryl Dawkins, were fined $5,500 by the National Basketball Association for excessive violence in the first-round playoff game between the teams last Friday in Atlanta.

title: JACKSON STARS AS ANGELS WIN
description: Reggie Jackson, last seen in a Yankee uniform Oct. 28, returned triumphantly to Yankee Stadium last night. Gene Michael, last seen in a Yankee uniform Sept. 5, did not.

title: PAINO RECITAL: JOSEPH SMITH
description: THE recital by Joseph Smith, a pianist, at Alice Tully Hall Monday night was a bit like a hothouse plant: it grew, through delicate stages, into something quite cultivated and attractive and free of even the slightest hint of rugged beauty. The aroma of such creations can be seductive, even if it is rarely as heady as that of wildflowers.

title: Lifeboats for Oil Rig Inadequate, Inquiry Told
description: A damaged lifeboat found with 20 bodies still strapped inside was evidence that the oil rig Ocean Ranger's lifeboats were not strong enough to withstand rough weather, Federal investigators were told today.

title: Military Analysis
description: British operations against the Argentine garrison in the Falkland Islands would appear likely to follow a strategy known as indirect approach. Senior military sources at present rule out a direct assault on Stanley, the capital, and its airfield, the two centers of Argentine defense. The prospect of steadily deteriorating weather in the South Atlantic east of the islands has convinced North Atlantic Treaty Organization military analysts that the British task force has discarded the idea of using its frigates and destroyers to enforce a blockade. With that option gone, Rear Adm. John F. Woodward, the force commander, faces the difficult but not impossible task of launching a large-scale landing.

title: Old '44' Returns
description: AT 3:30 yesterday afternoon, under the threatening sky, Reggie Jackson came out of the visitors' dugout at Yankee Stadium to take batting practice. He was carrying his familiar black bat and wearing his familiar mustache, but the uniform was not the customary one.

title: Fewer Job Offers Found For Graduating Seniors
description: College seniors are getting fewer job offers, but starting salaries have risen despite the recession, according to a survey by the College Placement Council.

title: ASPIRIN LINKED TO CHILDREN'S DISEASE
description: There is growing concern in the medical profession about a link between aspirin and a rare but sometimes deadly children's disease called Reye's Syndrome.

title: Boyce to Plead Guilty To Five More Holdups
description: Christopher Boyce, the convicted spy who has already pleaded guilty to eight bank robberies, has agreed to plead guilty to five more holdups committed while he was a fugitive, prosecutors said today.

title: Official at Hospital Accused of Perjury
description: The director of purchasing at the Baptist Medical Center in Brooklyn has been indicted by a grand jury in Brooklyn on perjury charges, the state deputy attorney general for Medicaid fraud control announced yesterday.

title: 17 on School Bus Injured in Jersey
description: Seventeen elementary-school students suffered minor injuries today when their school bus skidded off a wet road, the police reported.

title: LYNNE R. STEINMAN
description: Lynne R. Steinman, an assistant to Borough President Anthony R. Gaeta of Staten Island, was killed Monday in a three-vehicle collision on I-95 in Teaneck, N.J. She was 38 years old and lived in Todt Hill, S.I.

title: Let the Bankruptcy Law Alone
description: Swept along by energetic credit-industry lobbying, the Senate may soon pass a broad and misguided law sharply limiting access to the nation's most popular form of personal bankruptcy.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: AFTER more than 40 years in food preparation, I still get enormous pleasure from the creation of new dishes, especially those that turn into an adventure. Many of the traditional classics of the French kitchen, such as coulibiacs and country pates and tripes a la mode de Caen may be turned out, but there is more fun when I have to adapt or create something.

title: Execution in Caviar Scandal
description: The Soviet Union has executed a former official reportedly arrested in connection with a caviar scandal. The Communist Party newspaper Pravda said today that the executed man, former Deputy Fisheries Minister Vladimir I. Rytov, had been executed for bribery while in office.

title: CANUCKS BEAT HAWKS IN SECOND OVERTIME, 2-1
description: Jim Nill's rebound goal at 8 minutes 58 seconds of the second overtime gave the Vancouver Canucks a 2-1 victory tonight over the Chicago Black Hawks in the opening game of their four-of-seven-game Stanley Cup semifinal series.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Is Seeking Prison-Death Inquiry
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has asked Governor Carey to appoint a special prosecutor to investigate the recent death of a prison inmate who had charged that officials were trying to kill him because of his civil-rights activities.

title: Cannon Mills' Chief Resigns
description: Otto G. Stolz, 40 years old, has resigned as chairman, president and chief executive officer of the Cannon Mills Company, effective May 30.

title: 1. Bag for Weekend Gear
description: A ragbag used to be a receptacle for scraps of fabric. Now what one designer calls a ''rag bag'' is something else. It is a soft drawstring bag made of rags, big enough to accommodate all the gear one needs for a weekend. Jill Krasner, a Maryland craftsman, weaves the body of her bags from cotton rags like the ones grandmother used to turn into rugs. She gets pleasantly hazy color effects. Then Miss Krasner adds tops of calico prints and clothesline rope as drawstrings. The bags are $65 at To Boot, 100 West 72d Street.

title: Lawyer Seen As Candidate For S.E.C.
description: James C. Treadway Jr., a 38-year-old Washington lawyer, emerged yesterday as the leading candidate for a seat on the five-member Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: No Headline
description: LAKERS DEFEAT SUNS BY 115-96 IN OPENER

title: Accounts
description: * Venture magazine to Catania, Mackie Advertising for trade and promotional advertising.

title: JAZZ FESTIVAL TO REUNITE 3 OF GOODMAN QUARTET
description: The 1982 Kool Jazz Festival-New York, which until last year was known as the Newport Jazz Festival, will open June 25 and run for 10 days and nights, through July 4.

title: Bank Aide Urges G.P.U. Assistance
description: Bankruptcy is a ''distinct possibility'' for the General Public Utilities Corporation unless an agreement is worked out soon to finance the cleanup of Pennsylvania's crippled Three Mile Island nuclear reactor, a Chemical Bank executive said.

title: SIFTING OF JURY PANEL BEGINS AT HINCKLEY TRIAL IN CAPITAL
description: The laborious process of choosing a jury for the trial of John W. Hinckley Jr., who shot President Reagan and three other men almost 13 months ago, began today in Federal District Court here.

title: JUDGE BARS $17 MILLION IN PLANNED WESTWAY SPENDING BY STATE
description: More than $17 million in projected state expenditures over the next 12 months for the Westway highway project were barred last night by Judge Thomas P. Griesa of Federal District Court in Manhattan. At the same time, the judge approved state payments of $13 million for projects well under way or completed.

title: Charles Fuller Honored
description: Charles Fuller, author of ''A Soldier's Play,'' currently at Theater Four, received the Theater Club's annual award yesterday for the best play by an American. Mr. Fuller, who recently won the Pulitzer Prize for his play, received the Theater Club medal in a ceremony at the Women's National Republican Club, 3 West 51st Street. Previous winmners of the award, established in 1926, include Elmer Rice, Maxwell Anderson, Moss Hart, Robert Sherwood, Arthur Miller, Neil Simon and, last year, Lanford Wilson.

title: Pinter Enigma
description: ''The Hothouse,'' a play by Harold Pinter that seems to deal with the goings-on in a state-run institution someplace, is scheduled to begin previews on Friday. While the company was getting the production into shape, someone asked Arthur Cantor, the producer, what the title meant.

title: ARABS EASE U.N. ATTACK ON ISRAEL
description: Arab nations, under pressure from other third-world countries, today abandoned their plan to expel Israel from the General Assembly.

title: News Analysis
description: After five weeks of difficult but preliminary negotiations between White House and Congressional leaders on the budget for the fiscal year 1983, a critical moment has arrived for President Reagan and his economic program, and possibly for Republican political fortunes in next fall's elections.

title: Amdahl Contract
description: The Amdahl Corporation, a leading manufacturer of large-scale computers, said it was awarded a contract valued at $45 million, the largest in its history, to deliver 20 computer systems to the United States Army. Amdahl said it will act as a subcontractor under a contract awarded to the Electronic Data System Corporation.

title: ANOTHER WASHINGTON: THE JURY ROOM
description: There is another Washington behind the familiar facade of Presidential comings and Congressional goings. It is the real, sometimes violent, city that flourishes almost unseen by visitors and unknown to many Washingtonians.

title: Cemetery Workers Accept Arbitration
description: Cemetery workers and their employers reached agreement early yesterday on a procedure for arbitrating their contract dispute, averting a threatened walkout at cemeteries throughout the metropolitan area.

title: UNIT OF MAGNETISM SAID TO BE TESTED
description: The long-sought magnetic monopole, a particle that is the basic unit of magnetism, has reportedly been detected in an elaborate, high-technology experiment at Stanford University in California.

title: WRONG-LAW SENATOR
description: To the Editor:

title: MORGADO FOUND WITHIN THE LAW IN BUYING HOUSE
description: A state ethics committee has found that Robert J. Morgado, Governor Carey's chief aide, did not violate state law when he purchased a $281,000 house last year from a developer who does business with the state.

title: PADRES BEAT METS, STREAK AT 11
description: The San Diego Padres extended their winning streak to a club-record 11 games tonight with an 8-5 triumph over the New York Mets. It put the Padres into first place in National League West, ahead of the slumping Atlanta Braves, who have lost five straight after having won their first 13 games of the season.

title: HARVESTER TO MODIFY DEBT PACT
description: The International Harvester Company, the financially troubled manufacturer of farm and construction machinery, said today that it had obtained its lenders' consent to modify a $4.2 billion debt restructuring agreement and thus avoid technical default.

title: Reliance Acquires Triton Option
description: Reliance Group Holdings, a New York-based investment concern with interests in real estate and insurance, said it had acquired an option to purchase 22.07 percent of the Triton Group, another New York real estate invesment firm, for about $7 million.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: DO children believe that Trix cereal actually contains fruit? Action for Children's Television, the consumer group that lobbies for better children's television programming and against deceptive commercials aimed at children, has filed a formal complaint with the Federal Trade Commission charging that General Mills, maker of the cereal, is ''engaging in unfair and deceptive trade practices with respect to the promotion of its breakfast cereal Trix.''

title: This Year's Media Day Was Poorly Attended
description: The attendance at Media Day, sponsored yesterday by the American Association of Advertising Agencies, made its own statement. About half of last year's 340.

title: TRACK STAR CONVICTED IN RAPE, STABBING CASE
description: Adrian Ward, who set three Maryland scholastic track records and won a full scholarship to Villanova, was convicted of raping and stabbing a 41 year old woman in her home here.

title: Willie Ritola, 86, Track Star; Won 5 Olympic Gold Medals
description: Willie Ritola, a five-time Olympic gold medalist in the 1920's and the winner of 18 American championships in distance running, died Saturday at the age of 86.

title: A SOUTH AFRICAN NANNY
description: As a white child growing up in South Africa, I had a rather troubled sense of my uniqueness -and a black male nanny.

title: Sports of The Times; Billy Smith's Eye Is on Another Cup
description: BILLY SMITH leans forward anxiously as the tiny object flicks across his field of vision. At the last possible second, he reaches out with his thumb and presses a button.

title: Air Florida Holds Controllers To Blame for Potomac Crash
description: Air Florida has filed a suit charging that air traffic controllers at National Airport were responsible for the Jan. 13 crash of one of its jetliners into the icy Potomac River.

title: CLARINETIST: STOLTZMAN GIVES RECITAL
description: RICHARD STOLTZMAN'S clarinet recital last night at Carnegie Hall was dedicated to Benny Goodman, the man who made the place safe for clarinetists before the young recitalist was born. Aptly, Mr. Stoltzman dedicated the program to his instrumental idol in a modest little speech that bowed to the ''first man to perform American jazz and European classical music with equal artistic quality.''

title: HIGH TOLL IS FOUND IN HEART DISORDER
description: A newly reported statistical study of a heart rhythm abnormality called atrial fibrillation shows that it was associated with a death rate that was about double that of those in the study who did not develop the disorder.

title: HOW TO GROW HORNS
description: Menachem Milson, 49, used to be the mild-mannered professor he looks. He taught Arabic literature at Hebrew University. With blue eyes and a trim figure, he has something of Paul Newman's clean handsomeness. Now, he is the number one demon of Palestinian Arabs.

title: Justice Marshall Backs
description: State Districting Order

title: DOW DECLINES BY 4.86, TO 852.64
description: Lower corporate profits for an array of industries continued to depress stock prices yesterday. The lack of any apparent progress on a budget compromise between the White House and Congress was also a negative factor.

title: Woman and 2 Men Slain in the Bronx
description: The bodies of a woman and two men were found by the police in a Bronx apartment yesterday afternoon, apparently the victims of drugrelated killings that took place last weekend. The woman's 2-year-old daughter was alive and unharmed in the apartment.

title: CHEATING ON EXAMS IS CHARGED IN REPORT ON THREE MILE ISLAND
description: Two former shift supervisors at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant should face criminal charges for cheating on examinations, a judge charged today in a special report to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

title: MAY OFFERS A WEALTH OF HOUSE TOURS AND DESIGNER SHOWCASES
description: Besides the Kips Bay Boys' Club Show House, which opens this week, there are many other designer showcases and house tours taking place in the next month. All of the tours are self-guided, with maps, and go on rain or shine. Showcases

title: Means-ARA Tie Is Proceeding
description: A Federal District Court in Columbus, Ohio, denied the Justice Department's request for a temporary restraining order that would have barred the nation's second-largest textile rental service company from acquiring its largest Middle Western competitor.

title: WOLF TRAP PLANS FULL SEASON
description: The Wolf Trap Park for the Performing Arts announced today that it would mount virtually its complete season this summer under an aluminum-and-vinyl covering known as a sprung structure.

title: Gardening; City Gardener
description: Move Plants Now As plants in the small city garden mature, the original design may need to be altered. Don't be afraid to move shrubs or smaller trees that have outgrown their space. Transplanting them in early May will enable them to begin establishing new roots before summer's heat. Prepare the new soil area in advance, trim back all branches by half, water the plant well and dig up as much of the root ball as possible using a sheet or plastic to help hold the mass together. Once the plant is transplanted, keep the soil evenly moist for about a week, then feed with a highly diluted solution of any all-purpose watersoluble fertilizer; if signs of wilt persist, trim the branches back further.

title: Cities Service Mine
description: The Cities Service Company is considering whether to curtail or halt production at its coppermining complex near here after failing to find a buyer for the facility, the vice president of the company's metals division, C.T. Brown, said today. The property was placed on sale last May. Cities Service said at the time that it sought the sale to obtain capital for other business opportunities.

title: ARGENTINA REFUSES BAIL TO 3 BRITISH JOURNALISTS HELD AS SPIES
description: Three staff members of London newspapers who have been imprisoned in Argentina since April 13 were denied bail today, according to officials at the newspapers here.

title: Business People; CHANGES AT J.C. PENNEY RAISE SUCCESSION ISSUE
description: The horse race for succession to the top management of the J.C. Penney Company, the nation's third-largest general merchandise retailer, became a bit clearer yesterday.

title: Company Earnings; MOBIL OFF 49.1%; SUN UP 3.3%
description: Continuing the trend of depressed earnings reports by major oil companies, the Mobil Corporation yesterday reported a 49.1 percent drop in its first-quarter profit, citing a sharp downturn in its foreign energy operations because of the oil glut.

title: GENERAL ELECTRIC
description: The chairman of the General Electric Company told shareholders that one of the company's biggest opportunities would be in the area of factory automation. He described this as a "$20 billion to $30 billion mega-market that we see ahead for reindustrializing America." John F. Welch Jr., the chairman, also said that the country's diversification would help its financial performance in the future.

title: M-G-M Unit Chief
description: Cy Leslie, 59 years old, a former president of CBS Video Enterprises, has been named chairman and chief executive officer of the M-G-M/U.A. Home Entertainment Group, a newly formed part of the M-G-M/U.A. Entertainment Company.

title: Myers Chief Quits Over Cost Plan
description: The president and chief executive officer of the L.E. Myers Company in Chicago resigned because of a disagreement with the board on its decision to step up a cost reduction program.

title: CONCERT: HARLEM PIANO TRIO
description: THE genre of music in which the Harlem Piano Trio specializes - ''third-world classical music'' - is not really a genre at all. It is not music deriving from the third world or influenced by music of Africa, Asia or South America. Tuesday night at the Symphony Space, it was defined as music in the European classical tradition by ''third-world community artists'' -blacks, Hispanic people, women and Orientals.

title: B.A.T. Profit Up 55.1%
description: B.A.T. Industries, a tobacco and retailing conglomerate, said today that its 1981 profits rose 55.1 percent, largely because of foreign exchange gains. The company said that $184 million of its $369 million pretax gain was attributable to favorable foreign exchange transactions. B.A.T. said net earnings rose to $653 million from $421 million in 1980.

title: El Salvador's Army Said to Suffer Losses
description: A military spokesman said today that guerrillas had inflicted ''numerous'' casualties on 4,000 Government troops in heavy fighting in Morazan Province.

title: Union Carbide
description: Shareholders of the Union Carbide Corporation approved a resolution to double the authorized shares of the company's common stock to 180 million and to increase the authorized shares of preferred stock to 25 million from 10 million. The shareholders voted on the stock increases at the company's annual meeting in Hartford.

title: PRO-HITLER RALLY FAILS IN MOSCOW
description: In a land where unsanctioned demonstrations are all but unknown and ''fascism'' ranks among the vilest terms, a group of young Russians tried last week to hold a rally marking Hitler's birthday.

title: ASSESS STEREO SOUND BEFORE UPGRADING SET
description: EVER since car makers hit on the notion of the annual model change, planned obsolescence has been a standard marketing aid. The idea, of course, is to make the owner of last year's model feel stodgy and out of fashion so he'll rush out and buy the very latest.

title: Office and Mission Targets of Bombs
description: Pipe bombs exploded outside the Fifth Avenue office of Lufthansa Airlines and the Iraqi Mission yesterday but caused little damage and no injuries, the police said.

title: DANCE: 'MIZU' EXPLORES SOME LINKS TO POETRY
description: THREE interesting ways of combining movement with poetry were explored in ''Mizu: A Collaboration in Word, Sound and Movement'' Tuesday night at St. Mark's Church-in-the-Bowery.

title: U.A. AGENCT ASSERTS SOVIET SOLD $9.6 BILLION IN ARMS IN '79
description: The Arms Control and Disarmament Agency said today that the Soviet Union exported $9.6 billion in military equipment to other countries in 1979, as against $5.1 billion in United States deliveries.

title: Liar's List
description: Inspired by Columbia University's recent symposium on truth, a friend of ours has found a game that's more fun than calorie counting or discount shopping. She lists the day's lies.

title: Celebrities to Participate In Soviet Jewry March
description: Gregory Peck, Helen Hayes, Tony Randall, Richard Dreyfuss, Paul Simon, Joseph Papp and Elizabeth Swados are among the celebrities who will take part in Sunday's 11th Solidarity March for Soviet Jewry, sponsored by the Greater New York Conference on Soviet Jewry.

title: POLITICS AND GOD'S 'PROPHETS'
description: Those who speak in the name of God have the hardest time learning that politics is the art of compromise. Politics involves give-and-take: You win some, you lose some. The prophets of God who are too sure of themselves expect only to take, to win.

title: Cubs 6, Reds 0
description: CHICAGO (UPI) - Dickie Noles allowed only one hit, a leadoff single by Eddie Milner in the fourth inning, in pitching his first career complete game and leading Chicago over Cincinnati. Noles (3-2) faced 30 batters. Milner reached base twice, drawing a walk with two out in the ninth. The only other Cincinnati player to reach base was Cesar Cedeno, who drew a lead-off walk in the eighth after Noles had retired 12 straight batters. Noles struck out seven in pitching his first shutout. It was also the first complete game by a Chicago pitcher since Mike Krukow beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 14-0, last Sept. 27. Steve Henderson had a two-run triple in a three-run fifth inning off Tom Seaver (0-3) and Jerry Morales added a two-run triple in the seventh to pace Chicago's attack.

title: NANCY'S CLOTHES, CHAPTER 18
description: Nancy Reagan's dresses, Chapter 18: Have the First Lady's clothes been sewn illegally? If so, did Adolfo know about it? Why did the New York authorities raid a certain Queens garment factory? Does Mrs. Reagan care? And just who is Ruth?

title: COLLAPSE OF TALKS TO PUT STRAIN ON BUDGET PROCESS
description: With the collapse of the bipartisan budget negotiations between Capitol Hill and the White House, the task of putting together a budget next year falls to the leaders and committees of Congress.

title: Stroh-Schlitz Deal
description: The Stroh Brewery Company of Detroit announced that it had purchased 19.25 million common shares of the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company under its initial tender offer, which expired on April 15.

title: U.S. Team Meets Hussein
description: A United States military mission led by Assistant Secretary of Defense Francis J. West Jr. met today with King Hussein of Jordan, officials said, but no details were made public. The mission arrived here late Tuesday night.

title: O.A.S. BACKS ARGENTINA ON SOVEREIGNTY
description: The Organization of American States gave final approval today to a resolution supporting Argentina's claim to sovereignty over the Falkland Islands. The measure also called on Argentina and Britain to agree to a truce and withdraw their forces from the area.

title: SENATORS DEBATE ATOMIC WASTE BILL
description: The Senate took up legislation today that would establish a national policy for storage and disposal of nuclear wastes, but the proposal encountered staunch resistance from senators whose states are likely to be chosen for burial sites.

title: Wickes Petitions
description: The Wickes Companies said it had filed additional petitions for relief under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws for its Howard Brothers Discount Stores unit, two of Howard's wholly owned subsidiaries and two credit units. Wickes, a major retailer, sought protection from creditors under Chapter 11 last Saturday. The company, which has $2 billion in debts, said that it had filed for the additional relief in Howard's case because of ''precipitous actions by a few trade creditors, in particular a levying and seizing of goods.''

title: Books of the Times; Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt LINCOLN'S QUEST FOR UNION. Public and Private Meanings. By Charles B. Strozier. 271 pages. Basic Books. $17.50.

title: Business People; U.S. STEEL NAMES A VICE CHAIRMAN
description: W. Bruce Thomas spent his 30th anniversary at the United States Steel Corporation yesterday celebrating his appointment to the post of vice chairman of administration and chief financial officer. The 55-year-old lawyer moved up from executive vice president of accounting and finance.

title: SPECIAL EDUCATION NEEDS DEDICATION AT THE TOP, NOT A 'PAUSE'
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR SOME, HARD TIMES LIMIT COLLEGE DREAMS
description: Here at South Commack, a large suburban high school where college has always been synonomous with sacrifice, more students than ever are planning to say no this year to elite private colleges and register instead at public institutions.

title: Students Reject Move By Judge to End Sit-In
description: Students occupying the president's office at Medgar Evers College in Brooklyn yesterday rejected a judge's proposal to end the eightday sit-in.

title: Big Apple Circus Sets Schedule for Summer
description: The Big Apple Circus, whose European-style one-ring show is presented in a 1,600-seat traditional big-top tent, will perform in four boroughs this summer.

title: 10,000 Cambodian Refugees Due for Resettlement in U.S.
description: More than 10,000 Cambodian refugees in camps run by the United Nations in Thailand will be resettled in the United States in the next few months, an American Embassy spokesman said here today.

title: Gene Klein Stricken
description: Gene Klein, the owner of the San Diego Chargers, was taken to a local hospital today after suffering chest pains. He was admitted to to Scripps Memorial Hospital, where he was listed in stable condition. Klein, who is 61 years old, suffered a heart attack last May 28 while testifying at the Raiders anti-trust trial.

title: Home Improvement
description: THOUGH washerless faucets do not need repairs as often as old-style compression faucets, which have washers, even the newer type will eventually start to wear and leak or drip when shut off as tightly as possible.

title: W.C. TOWNSEND, BIBLE TRANSLATOR
description: W. Cameron Townsend, who helped translate the Bible into many languages, died Friday at a hospital in South Carolina just across the state line from his home in Waxhaw, N.C. He was 85 years old.

title: Royals 8, Red Sox 5
description: BOSTON (UPI) - Hal McRae of Knasas City drove in five runs with a homer and a double tonight to help snap Boston's eight-game winning streak.

title: Hers
description: PETER RICHARDS is a San Francisco artist who works in a science museum. When Peter isn't running the Exploratorium's artist-inresidence program, he's studying the science of waves and eddies and natural cycles to create artworks that are really performances where nature plays the most important part. When he strings fishing lines of chemiluminescent light in San Francisco Bay to show the play of wind and tide and water, he explains that he's using light to frame nature. But is this science? Or is this art?

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allied Corp., Morristown, N.J., has named Daniel P. Burnham vice president and controller. * AVX Corp. has appointed Robert B. Welsh vice president-finance.

title: TRADITIONAL TASTE TAKES HOLD AT THE KIPS BAY SHOW HOUSE
description: the mansions in which interior designers display their talents - are a telling barometer of the design profession at a given moment. The Kips Bay Boys' Club Decorator Show House '82, one of the most prestigious, is no exception.

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart on Sunday gave an incorrect figure for the University of Central America's estimate of the number of civilians killed in El Salvador in 1981. The correct figure is 13,229.

title: JUDGE TO APPOINT MASTER FOR CARE OF THE RETARDED
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that New York State was failing to comply with reforms pledged in 1975 in care for the mentally retarded. He said he would name a special master at state expense to supervise the reform program.

title: ITINERANT PAINTER RIDES THE WEST BY BIKE
description: SAN FRANCISCO DRESSED in a multizippered black flight suit and beret, the itinerant artist Larry Boyce is becoming a familiar, even a conspicuous, figure here and in 100 other Western cities.

title: News Analysis
description: The confrontation last week between the United Automobile Workers and the General Motors Corporation over the company's plan to improve executive payments has become a central issue in discussions of labor's wage concessions to corporations.

title: 'ARREST,' SECRET POLICE
description: ''THE ARREST'' carries the following disclaimer: ''The country, events and characters in this film are fictional. Any resemblance to any country's reality is purely coincidental.'' In other words, this will either be a film that's perfectly transparent in its political references, or one that bears no resemblance to real events at all.

title: SOVIET MARKS SRI LANKA TIES
description: Andrei A. Gromyko, the Soviet Foreign Minister, has called for closer political and economic relations with Sri Lanka and restated Soviet support for turning the Indian Ocean into a demilitarized zone. The comments by Mr. Gromyko, made at a reception yesterday in honor of the visiting Sri Lanka Foreign Minister, Abdul Cader Sahul Hameed, were summarized by the Soviet press agency Tass.

title: MAJORITY OF WIRE TAPS WERE IN NEW YORK, JERSEY AND FLORIDA
description: More than half the wiretaps in the United States last year were conducted by the authorities in New Jersey, New York and Florida, a Federal agency has reported.

title: Core Detroit Complex Sold
description: Five core buildings of the $357 million Renaissance Center project in downtown Detroit are being sold, Henry Ford 2d, a prime mover for the project, announced today. The price was not disclosed.

title: SETH THOMAS CLOCKS WILL MOVE TO GEORGIA
description: The Seth Thomas clock factory will leave Thomaston, the town named after it, to merge with a Westclox plant in Georgia, the president of Seth Thomas said today. The 169-yearold company, together with Westclox, forms the General Time Corporation. According to the Seth Thomas president, H. Spence Warren, the move is necessary to keep Seth Thomas competitive.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Exercise is the only thing that really keeps your mind clear when you get older.

title: FEDERAL GRAND JURY INVESTIGATING DEATH OF MISSOURI 'BULLY'
description: A Federal grand jury investigating the death of Kenneth Rex McElroy, who was shot last July as a crowd gathered around his pickup truck in the town of Skidmore, Mo., is trying to learn if public officials conspired to violate the man's civil rights, a Justice Department lawyer said today.

title: IRA CORN JR., EXECUTIVE AND BRIDGE DEVOTEE, IS DEAD
description: Ira G. Corn Jr., a Dallas industrialist and corporate executive whose passion for the game of bridge led him to organize and finance the first full-time professional bridge team, died of a heart attack yesterday morning at the Baylor University Medical Center in Dallas. He was 60 years old and lived in Dallas.

title: ARAB PROTESTS ERUPT IN OCCUPIED AREAS
description: Widespread violent demonstrations broke out today throughout the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip with Palestinian teen-agers taking to the streets to stone Israeli vehicles and soldiers.

title: EUROPE'S MOOD CHANGES AS MORE ACTION LOOMS
description: For the rest of Europe, the rationale for the gradual progress of the British fleet toward the Falkland Islands has always been similar to the rationale for a nuclear deterrent: the point was not to use it.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Detroit Lions have offered Coach Monte Clark a new multiyear contract that would reportedly pay $250,000 a year. The old contract, for five years, expires after next season. ... Dan Issel of the Denver Nuggets has backed away from a threatened confrontation with the National Basketball Association by deciding to wait until after the playoffs to seek offers as a free agent. League rules require that a prospective free agent wait until after the championship round before declaring, but Issel has a clause in his Denver contract that allowed him to do so on May 6.

title: BELLAMY REPORT CRITICIZES CITY'S OUTPATIENT CLINICS
description: The quality of ambulatory health care provided to millions of New Yorkers was sharply attacked yesterday in a study of outpatient clinics made by the office of City Council President Carol Bellamy.

title: Strikers Beat Cosmos on Deflected Kick
description: The Cosmos, uncoordinated on attack and disorganized on defense, were defeated by the Fort Lauderdale Strikers, 2-1, tonight. It was the Cosmos' first loss after three victories this season in the North American Soccer League.

title: ARGENTINES HIRE U.S. LAWYERS
description: Two lawyers from a prominent New York firm, one of them a former Treasury Department official who helped administer the seizure of Iranian assets two years ago, have been retained by Argentina's central bank to help with financial problems arising from the Falkland Islands crisis.

title: CORRECTION
description: The advertising column in Business Day last Monday incorrectly credited the creation of the advertising campaign ''Put a Tic Tac in your mouth and get a bang out of life.'' It was by Chalek & Dreyer.

title: Gasoline Stocks Decline as Oil Imports Rise
description: Gasoline supplies continued to decline last week, dropping nearly 4 million barrels, but they remained within the Department of Energy's average range for this time of year, the American Petroleum Institute, an industry trade group, reported yesterday.

title: ARBOUR SEES ROOM FOR IMPROVED PLAY
description: Coach Al Arbour wants the Islanders to show some improvement for tonight's second National Hockey League playoff game against the Quebec Nordiques at Nassau Coliseum. That may sound surprising since New York captured the opener of the four-of-seven-game semifinal series, 4-1, and outplayed the Nordiques in virtually every department.

title: FOR NORMALIZING RELATIONS WITH HANOI
description: There is an increasing chorus of opinion calling for a reappraisal of the United States' relations with Vietnam. A number of American visitors have come away with the impression that the Vietnamese want to strike a deal with the United States. While they do not defend Vietnam's record on human rights, they say that it is no worse than that of many of America's staunch allies. In fact, normalized relations could go far toward ameliorating Vietnam's protection of human rights, the heart of the problem being its treatment of members of the old, United States-backed regime.

title: Advertising; New TV Campaign For Pathmark
description: Pathmark supermarkets and Venet Advertising, for 14 years one of the more productive and creative partnerships in marketing, will preview a new TV campaign tonight on New York and Philadelphia TV stations that reach all of the chain's five-state marketing area.

title: Drop at Times Mirror
description: The Times Mirror Company said today that its first-quarter profit fell 23 percent, mainly because of a loss in wood-products operations, to $20.2 million, or 59 cents a share, from $26 million, or 76 cents, a year earlier.

title: CAREY AND KEAN WILL CREATE PANEL TO STUDY PORT AUTHORITY
description: In their first formal meeting as Governors, Hugh L. Carey and Thomas H. Kean agreed last night to establish a panel to examine the overall operation of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. In the past, disagreements flared between former Governor Brendon T. Byrne and Mr. Carey over Port Authority issues, including the sale of the World Trade Center, the fare on the PATH lines and increases in the tolls on the Hudson River crossings.

title: HELPRIN WINS FICTION PRIZE
description: Mark Helprin, author of ''Ellis Island and Other Stories,'' has been named winner of the Jewish Fiction Prize for 1982 conferred by the Jewish Welfare Board's Book Council. The National Jewish Book Awards are now in their 33d year.

title: WOMAN MINERS SEEK DAMAGES IN HARASSMENT SUIT
description: Darla Baker says that before she started working in the Appalachian coal fields five years ago she was warned that she would be harassed by male miners. Today she says such warnings were understatements.

title: JUDGE BIDS POTENTIAL JURORS 'CLOSE YOUR EYES' TO NEWS ON HINCKLEY
description: Federal District Judge Barrington D. Parker instructed potential jurors today to ''close your eyes, close your ears'' to news reports about the trial of John W. Hinckley Jr.

title: U.S. Suspends Rights Review For Arms Sales to Argentina
description: Since the Falkland Islands crisis, the Reagan Administration has suspended consideration of human rights certifications for Argentina and Chile that would be needed before either country could receive American military aid, officials said today.

title: Judge Sets New Date for Trial Of Teamsters Union President
description: A Federal district judge today postponed until September the bribery-conspiracy trial of Roy Lee Williams, the president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, and four other men.

title: Key Rates
description: Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Watson's Perspective
description: Bob Watson, traded to the Braves by the Yankees last Friday, two days before Bob Lemon was discharged as manager, was asked in Atlanta what effect he thought the dismissal would have on his former teammates.

title: A Man of Few Words
description: In his nine years as chief spokesman for the United States Supreme Court, Barrett McGurn, who announced his retirement last week, has earned a reputation for reticence. It has been suggested that his favorite response to inquiries, ''I won't have anything on that,'' be inscribed on a rubber stamp.

title: A Loss in '81 For Peugeot
description: The Peugeot auto group said today that it would post a consolidated loss of more than 2 billion francs, or $324 million, for 1981 because of a sharp rise in financing charges and the costs of restructuring overseas operations. That would be a 33 percent increase from Peugeot's 1980 loss of 1.5 billion francs, which is equivalent to $243 million.

title: BUDGET TALKS END WITHOUT ACCORD: REAGAN VISIT FAILS
description: Negotiations between President Reagan and Democratic Congressional leaders over how to control the deficit fell apart this afternoon in disagreement. Participants in a three-hour meeting in the Capitol said there was now almost no chance that the budget stalemate could be resolved through a bipartisan compromise.

title: Home Beat; THE LATEST IN DOLL FURNITURE
description: THEY'RE not exactly what you would call avant-garde, but they are fairly contemporary. Scaled one inch to the foot, the miniatures made by Minis by Me, a Malverne, L.I., company, are based on the lifesized furniture in the homes of the concern's two partners, Elaine Fleischman and Marilyn Davidson.

title: IC Industries Buys Underwood
description: IC Industries announced an agreement to buy the William Underwood Company of Westwood, Mass., a specialty foods distributor. Terms of the cash transaction were not disclosed.

title: PHILIPPINES FACING LANGUAGE PUZZLE
description: At the turn of this century, a shipload of American missionaries came to the Philippines to teach Filipinos the English language. Today, that heritage is disappearing.

title: PROCESS MAY TAKE A YEAR OR MORE
description: Officials of New York State and the Army Corps of Engineers said yesterday that new studies would be conducted to assess how much environmental damage would occur if the Westway highway project was built.

title: BAR LEADER ASSAILS MOVES TO STRIP COURTS OF POWERS ON SOCIAL ISSUES
description: The president of the American Bar Association warned today that efforts in Congress to strip the Federal courts of jurisdiction over school desegregation, abortion and other issues ''threaten the rights of all of us.''

title: Ex-Convict Confesses Boy's Slaying in 1975
description: A member of a white racist prison gang who underwent a religious conversion has confessed the slaying of a black teen-ager that had gone unsolved for more than six years, the police say.

title: Advertising; Budget Rent A Car Sues Hertz for $10 Million
description: Budget Rent A Car, charging that its comparative advertising efforts were sabotaged by Hertz (also known as No.1), filed a $10 million suit in Federal District Court in Chicago on Tuesday.

title: ABC and CBS to Air Reagan Budget Talk
description: Both the ABC and CBS television networks said last night that they planned to broadcast President Reagan's defense of his budget at 8 o'clock tonight.

title: STUDENT LOAN CUT IS DROPPED
description: The Department of Education has dropped plans to make it more difficult for commuting college students to qualify for Federal grants this fall, Representative Paul Simon of Illinois said today.

title: PROTESTER ENDS HIS FAST A WINNER AND A LOSER
description: A hunger strike, a rare form of protest in this city of expense-account lunches, ended today, and Mitch Snyder, 57 pounds lighter after 63 days of refusing food, was feeling as hurt as he was hungry.

title: Military Analysis
description: British military analysts say Britain's difficulties in enforcing the air and sea blockade of the Falklands, which is scheduled to begin Friday, will be many and varied but not as great as the problems Argentina will face in trying to break it.

title: JUDGE BARS ORDINATION TAX-GAIN DEAL
