description: The Life Science Church, which promises adherents tax benefits for accepting ordination, has been enjoined from selling its ministerial credentials.

title: THE RETURN OF PRESS SECRETARIES
description: Following are excerpts from the White House transcript of the daily briefing last Friday when Larry Speakes, deputy press secretary, invited six former Presidential spokesman to return to the White House to joust with reporters, producing much laughter.

title: Q & A
description: Q. I want to remove a foil-back wallpaper from my bathroom. It covers part of each wall as well as the entire ceiling.

title: A PLAN FOR NAMIBIA WORTH BALKING AT
description: To the Editor:$

title: MISS HEFNER IS PRESIDENT AT PLAYBOY
description: Playboy Enterprises, the entertainment and communications company, announced today that Christie Hefner, a vice president of the company, had been promoted to president. She replaces Derick J. Daniels, who has resigned.

title: 'A SLAP IN THE FACE'
description: WERE it not Armenian, and perhaps if it did not incorporate a very chaste bordello into its story line, ''A Slap in the Face'' would never have turned up at the New Directors/New Films series, where it was shown earlier this week. It will open tomorrow at the Embassy 72d Street theater. This isn't a bad film, but it's a primitive one; it has the plainness, if not quite the simplicity, of a folk tale. Waiting for its charms to manifest themselves isn't a futile task, but it's one that requires some forbearance.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on the Washington Talk page March 11 incorrectly described the status of children of Isabel Letelier, widow of Orlando Letelier, the former Chilean Ambassador to the United States. Mrs. Letelier has been declared persona non grata by the Chilean Government, but her children have not.

title: Rise in Profit At Matsushita
description: The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, Japan's fifth-largest industrial concern, said today that first-quarter profit and sales each rose 9 percent from a year earlier.

title: Tosco Holder To Continue Fight
description: Kenneth M. Good, the Colorado land developer seeking to oust the management of the Tosco Corporation in a proxy fight, says that a Government agreement to continue loan guarantees for Tosco's shale oil project has not changed his position.

title: Crying 'Spy' in Argentina
description: Argentines don't like their country to be portrayed as brutal and lawless, a place where justice is arbitrary and prisons are horrible. But those are pretty good descriptions of what the Argentine junta has done to three accredited British journalists: slammed them into tiny cells, denied them bail and charged them with espionage.

title: Jazz History Is Subject Of a Traveling Show
description: The history of jazz in music, dance and drama is the subject of a 35-day, 20-city show, ''Jazz Is,'' sponsored by R.J. Reynolds Industries. The 25-member cast and crew are students and graduates of the North Carolina School of the Arts.

title: CONCERT: 'MICROTONAL' BY NEWBAND
description: IN Charles Ives's ''Three Quartertone Piano Pieces,'' a piano is tuned a quartertone flat and played together with a standard instrument. Sunday night in the Symphony Space, in a program of ''microtonal music'' presented by Newband, the juxtaposition of these two incompatible tonal tunings was plangent, rubbery and iconoclastic.

title: THE STAGE: JUILLIARD THEATER STUDENTS PUT ON 'LOVE'S LABOR'S LOST'
description: IN the program for the Juilliard Theater Center's current repertory season of two classics and two new Australian plays there are individual photographs of the members of the company, all of them fourth-year drama students. They look like fresh-faced youngsters in any college yearbook. However, on stage in Michael Langham's production of ''Love's Labor's Lost,'' with the addition of whiskers, wigs and costumes, most of them are unrecognizable. In performance they are transformed into a semblance of an Elizabethan acting company - green but determined.

title: Greece Says Qaddafi Calls Off Planned Visit
description: The Government announced today that Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, had postponed an official visit that was to have begun Friday.

title: The U.N. Today; April 29, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Preparatory Committee for the Sec- ond Special Session of the General As- sembly Devoted to Disarmament - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: U.S. AGENCY SETS GAS PRICING STUDY
description: The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, in a move that could lead it to raise sharply the price of natural gas, voted today to conduct a four-month market examination to determine whether Federal controls have kept the price of so-called old gas too low.

title: ASPIRATIONS OF A PARK AVE. ATRIUM
description: The greenhouse, open to the public, is filled with tropical trees. In all, it contains 46 kinds of plants. Page C3. By PAUL GOLDBERGER An Appraisal

title: THEATER: 'TEACH ME HOW TO CRY'
description: ''TEACH ME HOW TO CRY'' is a flawed play; the production at the Equity Library Theater is flawed, too. It doesn't matter. ''Teach Me How to Cry,'' by Patricia Joudry, is a sugarplum of a work, rich with small insights and full of bittersweet truth. Yes, it is sentimental, but the sentimentality is more hard-nosed than treacly, and the play is a rewarding evening of theater.

title: Heating Oil Futures Post Moderate Gain
description: After a day of extremely nervous trading, heating oil futures prices closed moderately higher yesterday. The nervous and confused activity was attributed to anticipation of the weekly statistics of the American Petroleum Institute, which are issued after the close each Wednesday.

title: ARGENTINES STUDY A U.S. PEACE PLAN
description: With the British task force approaching its battle station off the Falklands, the Argentine junta today overrode earlier official statements that the latest United States peace plan was unacceptable and announced that it was under study.

title: Earnings; KODAK PROFIT SLIDES 27.2%; BUSCH, PEPSICO GAIN
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, the world's leading producer of photographic equipment, reported yesterday that depressed economic conditions worldwide, the strengthening of the United States dollar and start-up costs for new products combined to depress net income in the first quarter of 1982 by 27.2 percent on a 2.6 percent decline in sales.

title: Talks Seeking Alsands Deal
description: William Daniel, the president of Shell Canada Ltd., said today that he did not rule out the possibility of extending the April 30 deadline for an agreement on the Alsands project.

title: Business People; ZENITH CHIEF EXECUTIVE ADDS CHAIRMANSHIP
description: Revone W. Kluckman, 53, has been elected chairman of the Zenith Radio Corporation, succeeding Joseph S. Wright, 72, who is retiring. Mr. Kluckman will continue as president and chief executive officer.

title: MAYOR REQUESTS INQUIRY BY STATE ON CONSTRUCTION
description: Mayor Koch called on Governor Carey yesterday to appoint a special state prosecutor to investigate corruption in the construction industry.

title: REPORTERS ARE DIVIDED ON ROLE IN STATE SHOW
description: A group of political reporters in an organization called the Inner Circle have agreed to provide the entertainment for a "New York State Salute to the Media" organized by state officials.

title: Lights Out for Cubs
description: A bill to bar the Chicago Cubs from playing baseball at night at Wrigley Field, sponsored by Representative Ellis B. Levin, Democrat of Chicago, was passed by a committee of the Illinois Legislature and sent to the full House. The legislation was prompted by the sale of the of the Cubs by the Wrigley family to the Tribune Company, owner of The Chicago Tribune, and speculation that the new owners want to introduce night baseball in the park.

title: JUDGE BARS COMEX CONTRACT
description: The Commodity Exchange of New York, which had planned to begin trading futures contracts based on Standard & Poor's Composite Index of 500 stocks Thursday, was thwarted today when a Federal judge issued a temporary restraining order on a copyright suit by S.& P.

title: New Advice Is Offered To Would-Be Rescuers
description: Rescuers administering mouth-to-mouth resuscitation are customarily warned to clear the victim's throat so that the patient does not choke.

title: Aliens Crackdown Pressed
description: Federal agents arrested hundreds of suspected illegal aliens in nine cities yesterday, continuing a crackdown that critics have denounced as ''racist scapegoating'' designed to divert attention from unemployment. In Washington, an Immigration and Naturalization Service spokesman said the weeklong ''Operation Jobs'' was a success with more than 2,500 people already taken into custody.

title: Advertising; Addenda
description: * Sport magazine increasing its advertising rates 8 percent, effective with the September issue.

title: Justice Department Opposes New Special Prosecutor Law
description: A spokesman for the Justice Department told senators today that the department was opposed to extending the law that requires appointing a special prosecutor to investigate politically sensitive cases.

title: A Vietnam Memorial To Be Built in Albany
description: The site for a state memorial to victims and veterans of the Vietnam War was announced today. John C. Egan, State Commissioner of General Services, said that a courtyard in the Empire State Plaza in Albany had been set aside for the monument.

title: METS END PADRES' STREAK, 5-4 IN 15
description: It took the struggling Mets 15 innings, but they finally ended a 10-game losing streak at Jack Murphy Stadium tonight. Mookie Wilson, who has hit in 13 straight games, tripled to lead off the 15th and scored on Bob Bailor's sacrifice fly for a 5-4 victory over the San Diego Padres.

title: TEXAN IS ELIMINATED AS BIDDER FOR NEWS, PAPER'S OWNER SAYS
description: The owners of The Daily News announced yesterday that all discussions on its prospective sale to the Texas financier Joe L. Allbritton had been ''terminated.''

title: NICARAGUA: OUR ILLEGAL 'OPTIONS'
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; Accounting Change Helps Interpublic Net
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies, thanks to a new accounting practice that went into effect Jan. 1, showed sharply higher earnings in the first quarter compared with the 1981 period.

title: 10 TEACHERS OUSTED IN 50's GIVEN RESTITUTION FROM CITY
description: Thirty years after the first of them were discharged for refusing to answer Senate questions about their political affiliations, 10 New York college teachers or their estates received voluntary restitution yesterday from the city.

title: News Analysis
description: As Argentina braces for hostilities with Britain, President Leopoldo Galtieri and the junta appear to be leading a nation united over holding the Falkland Islands but profoundly divided over other political issues.

title: Advertising; New Finish To Strong Beginning
description: THE question of how to top winning advertising is a troublesome one for ad agencies. No one wants to mess up a good thing. The way that the Advertising to Women agency has solved the problem is just to add a new ending to a winning beginning. The brand involved is the Jean Nate After Bath Splash and line from the fragrance division of Charles of the Ritz. The first commercial created for it by the agency four years ago increased unit sales 33 percent the first year and retail sales to $65 million from $32 million in four years.

title: FILM: 'ONE NIGHT STAND,' ROMANCE-CUM-THRILLER
description: ''ONE NIGHT STAND'' is an unpleasant Canadian romance-cum-thriller about two peppy, overbearing people who meet in a disco and immediately develop the kind of awful intimacy that, under other circumstances, might take years. A lonely and much too vivacious woman named Daisy (Chapelle Jaffe) picks up a penny-dreadful street singer, Rafe (Brent Carver), who looks a little too much like her brother.

title: Robert Eckenrode Dies at 55; Was Amtrak Vice President
description: Robert T. Eckenrode, a group vice president for finance and administration with Amtrak and former executive vice president and chief financial officer for the American Stock Exchange, died of cancer Tuesday at his home in Alexandria, Va. He was 55 years old.

title: CAREY AND ANDERSON SUBMIT PLANS TO END BUDGET IMPASSE
description: Governor Carey and legislative leaders held an extraordinary meeting early today to discuss proposals designed to break the monthlong impasse on the state's $27 billion budget.

title: Text of O.A.S. resolution, page A19.
description: The United States made an urgent appeal today to Argentina and Britain to accept a new set of American proposals for averting a major military confrontation over the Falkland Islands.

title: Technology
description: MANUFACTURERS of brand name items, from Levi's blue jeans to Cartier watches, have found that their products are sometimes counterfeited, resulting in lost revenues and the sale of substandard goods to consumers.

title: ISRAEL PEACE MEDAL IS CAUSE FOR A PARTY
description: SENATOR BARRY GOLDWATER didn't manage to get there, but Abba Eban did. So there was nary a murmur of disappointment among the 1,450 guests in the New York Hilton's grand ballroom Tuesday evening.

title: Huffy Assets Sale
description: The Huffy Corporation of Dayton, Ohio, said it had sold the assets of its automotive products division to the Dyson-Kissner-Moran Corporation for an undisclosed amount of cash ''substantially in excess'' of the division's book value. Huffy said it had decided to sell the division because it did not have long-term high-growth potential.

title: U.S. Reaches an Accord With Turkey on Security
description: The United States and Turkey announced today that they had reached agreement on the need to develop fully Turkey's security potential, calling it ''an increasingly vital factor for enhancing regional stability and peace.''

title: Thayer to Head Whitney Corp.
description: Walter N. Thayer, a long-time associate of the late John Hay Whitney, was elected yesterday to succeed him as chairman and chief executive of the Whitney Communications Corporation, publisher and operator of cable TV systems.

title: Study of Youths' Fitness Finds Wide Deficiency
description: Fewer than half the children in America are able to meet physical fitness standards that should be attainable by the average healthy youngster, a study of test results showed today.

title: 11 AWARDS GIVEN BY SOCIETY OF MAGAZINE EDITORS
description: Newsweek magazine and The Atlantic each won two of the 11 National Magazine Awards presented yesterday by the American Society of Magazine Editors.

title: BANK'S GREENHOUSE OPENS TO THE PUBLIC
description: ABLOCKLONG three-story greenhouse filled with large tropical trees opened to the public this month at 277 Park Avenue, the new world headquarters of Chemical Bank.

title: OTHER ISRAELI VOICES
description: In the wake of the final Sinai withdrawal the Government of Israel has hardened its already tough position on the West Bank and Gaza. In those occupied territories, it says, there will be no withdrawal in exchange for a secure peace; Israel will go on absorbing the territories and their 1.3 million Palestinian inhabitants.

title: FORD TRIMS ITS DEFICIT IN QUARTER
description: The Ford Motor Company today reported a loss of $355.4 million in the first quarter, much of it the result of taxes paid by its profitable overseas subsidiaries.

title: Reagan Will Address Parliament in Bonn
description: President Reagan will address the West German Parliament in Bonn and visit West Berlin during a nineday trip to Europe next month, the White House announced today.

title: CURFEW IS LIFTED
description: The Polish Government announced tonight that it had ordered the release of 800 internees and that a number of martial law restrictions, including the nationwide curfew from 11 P.M. to 6 A.M., would be lifted beginning Sunday.

title: Rubber Workers Sign Tentative Master Pact
description: Negotiators for B.F. Goodrich and the United Rubber Workers signed a tentative master contract agreement tonight, clearing the way for a vote by union members.

title: Myslinski Retiring
description: Casimir Myslinski has announced that he will retire as athletic director after 14 years in which he helped to turn the University of Pittsburgh into a nationally ranked football power. The 62-year-old Myslinski will leave June 30 under an early-retirement incentive program. No successor has been announced.

title: GEOFFREY BEANE AT HIS TOP FORM
description: THOUGH there have been other good fashion collections shown this season, Geoffrey Beene's was the first great one. Every so often a designer puts together a collection of clothes that sums up the temper of the times and the way women think of themselves. This was one of those occasions.

title: COOPER-HEWITT, PARSONS OFFER MASTER'S PROGRAM
description: The Cooper-Hewitt Museum and the Parsons School of Design will offer a new program, a master's degree in the history of decorative arts, beginning in September.

title: Music for the Occasion
description: Some of the dance world's livelier wits got together on Monday night to celebrate with Alwin Nikolais, the multimedia dance choreographer, as he was presented with the 31st annual Capezio Dance Award in a ceremony at the Juilliard School.

title: House Panel Narrowly Votes A Limited G.I. Education Bill
description: A subcommittee of the House Armed Services Committee has narrowly approved a watered-down education provision of the G.I. Bill of Rights in the face of opposition by the Reagan Administration to any new benefits.

title: BLUEGRASS: MCLAIN FAMILY GIVES CARNEGIE HALL CONCERT
description: PHYLLIS GEORGE BROWN, the wife of Gov. John Y. Brown of Kentucky, introduced the McLain Family Band's concert at Carnegie Hall Monday night. The McLain family apparently performs at many official functions when they aren't playing or presenting bluegrass festivals on their farm near Berea, Ky.

title: REORGANIZATION SET AT BRITISH AIRWAYS
description: In a tacit admission that bigger and newer is not always better, British Airways today announced a reorganization that would partially split the carrier into operating groups resembling the separate companies that existed a decade ago.

title: Rhodes Bars Senate Race
description: Gov. James A. Rhodes reiterated today that he will go into private business when his term expires in January, ending speculation that he might seek the Republican nomination for the United States Senate. State law bars him from running for Governor this year.

title: NEXT TIME START DAYLIGHT TIME ON TIME
description: To the Editor:

title: WORKS OF 3 CRAFTSMEN ON DISPLAY AT GALLERY
description: WORKS of three artists have been brought together at the current show at Convergence Gallery, 484 Broome Street. Although each creates in a different medium, all three make highly personal statements.

title: Gardening; COUNTRY GARDENER
description: Flowers Perennials: Finish planting, preferably on cloudy days. Set out new plants after soil has been prepared with additional compost and enriched with 5-10-5 fertilizer. Water in well. Finish dividing late-blooming perennials such as phlox, mums, daisies and sunflowers. Annuals: Set out hardy ones first: calendula, pansies, strawflowers, pincushion flower and larkspur; sow seeds of bachelor buttons, sweet alyssum, sweet peas and poppies. Wait until later in the month to set out tender ageratums, verbenas, zinnias and marigolds. For shady nooks set out started tubers of caladiums and tuberous begonias. Apply mulches to flower beds to keep moisture in and weeds out.

title: A Ford in Their Future
description: The Detroit Red Wings were put on the auction block two months ago by Bruce Norris, whose family has owned the club for half a century. Now a syndicate including a member of another prominent family has expressed interest in purchasing the franchise.

title: Nuclear Cleanup Plan Called Most Equitable
description: Pennsylvania officials have said that utility customers nationwide would each pay less than $1 to decontaminate the crippled Three Mile Island nuclear plant under a cleanup bill studied by Congress.

title: Company News
description: The NLT Corporation, an insurance company, said that its directors had rejected a $1 billion takeover offer by the American General Corporation.

title: JOB DISABILITY: LAWSUITS RISE
description: Edward Blankenship had been working at the Cincinnati Milacron Chemicals plant, mixing dimethyl tin-dichloride, for about six months when he and his wife began to notice that his personality was changing.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Electric Power Co. shareholders approved a proposal to increase the number of authorized common shares to 200 million from 175 million.

title: Construction Contracts Up
description: Contracts for new construction in March rose 8 percent, to $13 billion, from the level of the previous month, the F.W. Dodge division of the McGraw-Hill Information Systems Company said yesterday. But it added that the numbers did not reflect an upturn in the building industry.

title: Going Out Guide
description: MOZART'S INSPIRATION

title: Standard Zoning for Grandfathers
description: New York's Board of Estimate today gets its chance to vote on the major amendment to the Zoning Resolution proposed by the City Planning Commission. Builders would be restricted to smaller buildings on the major sites in midtown Manhattan if the Board approves, which it would be commendably wise to do.

title: Bounty of Jazz
description: Jazz blends easily among the generations even if it is sometimes a room away. Take, for example, Tuesday night at Michael's Pub, where the schedule for the Kool Jazz Festival New York, the newer name for the Newport Jazz Festival, was announced.

title: DANCE: MUNA TSENG TROUPE
description: SUNDAY afternoon's program by Muna Tseng and Dancers at the Theater of the Riverside Church contained all sorts of works. But Miss Tseng was most choreographically convincing in ''Dance for Music,'' a study in pure motion to an electronic score by Laurie Spiegel. Its pulsations enlivened four immobile women, set them swaying and prompted them to let the sways take off into skips as their shoes pattered in a percussion obbligato on the floor.

title: Israeli Moves Censured By General Assembly
description: The General Assembly condemned Israel today for what it called repression of Palestinian Arabs and rebuked the United States for supporting Israel.

title: Firm to Assist In Conrail Sale
description: The Transportation Department has chosen Goldman, Sachs & Company, the New York investment banking firm, to assist in the Government's sale of Conrail. The sale is expected to involve some of the highest fees paid to investment houses in Wall Street's history.

title: Bridge: The Seamon Family Hopes It Started a Winning Habit
description: Family teams have often done well in major competitions, but it is doubtful whether any of them has ever matched a recent performance of the Seamon family of Miami Beach.

title: C.I.A. REPORT TELLS OF LOSING SECRETS
description: A United States intelligence report says secret information passed by a radar engineer to a Polish spy involved such key American weapons systems as the B-1 bomber and the radar-evading Stealth bomber.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, APRIL 29, 1982
description: International Britain stepped up military pressure on Argentina with an announcement that it would impose a total air and sea blockade around the Falklands, effective tomorrow. British officials confirmed that small troop units had been put ashore in the islands to prepare for the large-scale invasion expected soon. The two countries weighed a last-minute American peace plan that was considered unlikely to win acceptance in London or Buenos Aires. (Page A1, Column 6.) Argentina overrode statements issued earlier in Buenos Aires that the latest American peace plan was unacceptable and announced instead that it was under study. Meanwhile, the ruling military junta sought to prepare Argentines for war. (A14:1.)

title: Company News; Dow's Book Digest
description: Dow Jones & Company announced that it would cease publication of Book Digest magazine, which it acquired for over $10 million in 1978.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN-ZAMBIAN MEETING SET
description: Prime Minister P.W. Botha will meet President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia on Friday, his first direct meeting with a prominent African leader,

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE

title: 'Little Gloria' Planned For 4-Part NBC Series
description: Bette Davis, Angela Lansbury, Maureen Stapleton, Glynis Johns, Martin Balsam, Barnard Hughes, Ken Howard and John Hillerman will head the cast of ''Little Gloria ... Happy at Last,'' a four-hour NBC-TV series based on the 1934 child-custody case involving Gloria Vanderbilt.

title: FLAMES OF ISLAMIC FERVOR UNSETTLE NIGERIA'S NORTH
description: The students at Bayero University here held a demonstration recently to commemorate Iran's Islamic revolution. Among the slogans they painted on campus buildings was one that read, ''Down with the American system.''

title: Financial General
description: The American Stock Exchange is considering delisting Financial General Bankshares because 96 percent of its shares outstanding have been obtained by an investor group as a result of a tender offer, according to Jack Beddow, senior vice president of the bank holding company. Trading in the company's stock was halted yesterday, pending the outcome of an inquiry into how many minority shareholders remain. Mr. Beddow said it was possible the information would be submitted this week.

title: CANADA HAPPY WITH FRANCE'S BALANCING ACT
description: Prime Minister Pierre Mauroy has returned to Paris, leaving Quebec with a promise that France will never abandon it and will remain at its side ''whatever the ways it may choose to affirm its identity.''

title: A PLAN FOR NAMIBIA WORTH BALKING AT
description: To the Editor:

title: Bache Loses Webb Suit
description: The widow of Del Webb has been awarded $418,000 in a Federal suit accusing the brokerage firm of Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Inc. with mismanaging her investments.

title: Sirhan a Terrorist Plotter, Parole Panel Is Told
description: Two former convicts pictured Sirhan B. Sirhan as a terrorist hit man plotting the death of Senator Edward M. Kennedy and the theft of plutonium for Libya, a state parole board was told today.

title: Fedmart Retail Chain
description: The Fedmart Corporation, a privately held chain of discount stores owned by the Hugo Mann interests of West Germany, said that its board had decided to discontinue all retail operations ''as soon as practicable.'' The company said that the decision was based on ''current economic conditions, more viable alternative forms of investment opportunities and intensified competition.'' Wall Street sources have indicated that Fedmart is negotiating to sell about 35 of its store sites in California to the Dayton-Hudson Corporation of Minneapolis, which plans to merge them into its Target discount store division.

title: LEFTISTS HIJACK PLANE IN HONDURAS
description: Five leftists hijacked a domestic airliner today with 48 people aboard, including 15 Americans. They threatened to kill an executive of a United Statesowned banana company unless the Honduran Government paid a $1 million ransom and freed 52 people whom they identified as political prisoners.

title: GULF STILL SEEKING TO BUY OIL CONCERN
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation has disclosed that it is still interested in buying an oil company, almost a year after it arranged a $6 billion bank credit so that it would be ready if a takeover candidate appeared.

title: U.N. Rights Aide Forced Out
description: Theo van Boven, a Dutchman whose appointment as head of the United Nations human rights division has not been renewed, said today that Argentina ''took the lead'' in forcing him out of his post. Mr. van Boven, 47 years old, a former Dutch Foreign Service official, leaves the job on Friday at the end of a five-yearappointment.

title: WALL STREET ECONOMISTS WARY ON BUDGET SNAG
description: Wall Street executives said last night that President Reagan and Congressional Democratic leaders would continue to seek a budget compromise despite the impasse that developed yesterday.

title: TEXAS DEMOCRATS GIRDING TO UNDO '78
description: When William P. Clements Jr. shocked the Democrats into disarray four years ago by being elected the first Republican Governor of Texas since Reconstruction, he galvanized his party and propelled the state toward what some analysts believe is two-party status.

title: The Police Blotter
description: One of two armed men who tried to seize a rack of dresses on Seventh Avenue in the garment district was apprehended shortly before noon yesterday after accidentally shooting himself in the groin as he was pursued by four garment workers. The suspect - Francisco Oriano, 21 years old, of the Bronx, was charged with wounding James Nelson, 58, of Mount Vernon, who was pushing the dress rack.

title: M.T.A. LINKS NEW SUBWAY CARS TO U.S. TAX AID
description: The chairman of New York's Metropolitan Transportation Authority said today that if Congress repealed a public transit tax-leasing provision, he would recommend that the M.T.A. cut its order of new subway cars.

title: BULLETS' 3-POINTER BEATS CELTICS
description: Frank Johnson of the Bullets is listed at 6 feet 3 inches tall. He appears small amid the taller players who dominate the sport.

title: TEXT OF O.A.S. RESOLUTION ON THE FALKLAND ISLANDS
description: Following is the text of the resolution on the Falkland Islands adopted by the Organization of American States today by a vote of 17 to 0, with 4 abstentions:

title: Continental Steel Shifts
description: Thomas I. Sigler, who helped nurse ailing Penn-Dixie Industries through a period in Chapter 11 bankruptcy from which it emerged a month ago as the Continental Steel Corporation, will add to his current title of president the post of chief executive officer of the steel company. He assumed the post vacated by William J. Scharffenberger, vice chairman, who resigned to become president of Saxon Industries. At the same time it was announced that Howard R. Hawkins, a board member, has been elected chairman of the company, which has headquarters in Kokomo, Ind.

title: NURSING HOME OFFICIAL FACES CHARGES
description: The director of New York State's largest association of private, profit-making nursing homes was arrested yesterday. He was charged with conspiring with others to blow up a union trailer during a 1980 strike and then submitting the $5,000 payoff for Medicaid reimbursement.

title: AN OLD ALLY IS EASED OUT BY SCHMIDT
description: Since Monday, Chancellor Helmut Schmidt has been officially involved in realigning his Cabinet. Way down at the bottom of the list of changes is the replacement of the Government spokesman, Kurt Becker, by Klaus Bolling, a former spokesman for the Chancellor who 16 months ago was sent to East Berlin as Bonn's permanent representative in East Germany.

title: PIANO RECITAL: GLORIA SAARINEN
description: GLORIA SAARINEN, a Canadian pianist, brought a diffuse program to the Merkin Concert Hall Tuesday evening, along with a Bosendorfer that seemed too big for her technique. The result was a recital whose appeal fluctuated according to its content and to Miss Saarinen's ability to meet the technical demands imposed by the pieces.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * City Investing Company filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission 1.5 million common shares that may be offered by the First Boston Corporation as selling shareholder.

title: Nuclear Freeze Called Unsound U.S. Strategy
description: A nuclear weapons freeze and a policy of ''no first use'' of such weapons are seductive to a growing number of Americans but are unsound strategies for preventing war, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff said today.

title: 'Films From Vienna' To Begin on Sunday
description: A festival of ''Films From Vienna'' will be held at the Carnegie Hall Cinema, Seventh Avenue and 57th Street, between next Sunday and May 15, designed to show Austria's contribution to international cinema.

title: Critic's Notebook
description: SOMETIMES you can understand things while they're taking place before your very eyes, right up there on the stage. Sometimes, to understand things, you have to wait until you get home, where you can either brood about them or maybe go to your bookshelves and look them up. And sometimes you never get to understand things at all.

title: South Korean Shootings Lead Minister to Resign
description: President Chun Doo Hwan appointed Ro Tae Woo, a close friend, Home Minister today after Suh Chung Hwa resigned.

title: Fruit Fly Battle in California Reported to Be Almost Over
description: The $100 million, two-year battle against the Mediterranean fruit fly in California appears to be almost over, the head of the eradication program said Tuesday, but future infestations by the pest are inevitable.

title: Where Is the Real Defense Debate?
description: Pre-emptive warfare: Defense Secretary Weinberger now seeks to fend off more serious assaults on his huge budget by acknowledging that the rise in military spending might have to be slowed. With debate stuck at that level, the deeper questions are ignored: Is the overall strategy coherent? Are the forces and weapons necessary?

title: Credit Markets; U.S. NOTE PRICES FALL SLIGHTLY
description: Prices of Treasury note issues fell slightly late yesterday after negotiations for a budget compromise broke down and after the Treasury announced plans to sell $5.25 billion of new three-year notes next Tuesday and $4 billion of 10-year notes next Wednesday.

title: REAGAN VISIT FAILS; News Analysis
description: Barring some unlikely reversal, the collapse of President Reagan's bid for a budget compromise with Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the Speaker of the House, has set the stage for a combative session of Congress and a sharply partisan election campaign.

title: BRITAIN IMPOSING BLOCKADE ON ALL SHIPPING AND FLIGHTS NEAR FALKLANDS TOMORROW
description: Britain announced today that it would impose a total sea and air blockade around the Falkland Islands on Friday. The announcement of the 200-mile blockade, which applies to all ships and planes, civilian and military, of all nations, came as both countries weighed a last-minute peace plan submitted by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.

title: Advertising; JWT Group Loses $47,000 in Quarter
description: The JWT Group, which for the years 1978 through 1981 wrote off $30 million in pretax earnings as the result of a computer fraud, reported yesterday that it lost $47,000 in the first quarter.

title: National Steel Reports Loss
description: The National Steel Corporation, the nation's fourth-ranked steel producer, citing the lowest steel shipments in two decades, reported today that it lost $40.2 million in the first quarter this year, in contrast to earnings of $15.7 million, or 83 cents a share, in the first quarter of 1981.

title: Raiders Obtain Alzado, Pruitt
description: The National Football League draft ended yesterday as it had begun the day before: with a remarkable number of trades sending veterans to new teams in exchange for draft choices. Along the way, the 28 clubs completed the selection process by picking 167 players on rounds 7 through 12.

title: JOHN'S SIX-HITTER BEATS ANGELS, 6-0
description: Reggie Jackson did not glitter in his encore at Yankee Stadium last night. If Jackson had written a script for a repeat of his super performance of the night before, Tommy John shredded it before it reached the production stage.

title: PUBLISHERS FORESEE CLASH WITH A.T.&T. ON ELECTRONIC NEWS
description: Newspaper executives attending the convention of the American Newspaper Publishers Association here have been told over and over that their business is at the threshold of an era when information will increasingly be transmitted on video screens instead of paper.

title: NEW LABOR PACTS RESTRICT PAY RISES
description: Newly negotiated first-year wage increases averaged only 2.2 percent in the first quarter of 1982, largely because of wage freezes in automobile and trucking contracts, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Thomas Clock Plant to Close
description: The Seth Thomas clock factory, a 168-year-old fixture that gave this northwestern Connecticut town its name, has announced that it will close in November and move operations to the South.

title: Savings Unit Outflow Up
description: Americans withdrew more money from savings and loan associations in March than they deposited, reversing the increase in savings recorded in the previous month, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today.

title: Topics Lying 1, Lying 2
description: Lion's Pride

title: MORE AND MORE WORKERS HIT STRIDE
description: Here she comes: the ultimate, sophisticated New York career woman. Her hair is coiffed, her makeup impeccable. She is wearing a silk blouse, a dark blazer, a slim, expensively tailored skirt - and thick, white woolen socks and rubber-soled running shoes.

title: N.H.L. BOARD TO MEET ON FUTURE OF ROCKIES
description: The National Hockey League Board of Governors will meet Monday in Chicago to discuss the future of the financially troubled Colorado Rockies. One possibility continues to be that the team will move from Denver to Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: TREASURY TO AUCTION $9.25 BILLION IN NOTES
description: The Treasury Department is to offer investors two new securities as part of its plan to borrow a record $121 billion from the public in the current budget year.

title: Noguchi Begins New Job As County Demotes Him
description: Dr. Thomas Noguchi, under investigation on charges of mismanagement and ''unprofessional'' comments about the deaths of celebrities, was officially demoted Tuesday from County Coroner to physician-specialist. He reported to work today at the new job.

title: PAN AM'S LOSS LESS THAN EXPECTED
description: Pan American World Airways reported yesterday that it lost $127.3 million in this year's first quarter -less than some analysts had expected - compared with a loss of $114.5 million in the first quarter of 1981.

title: HIGH LEVEL U.S. SOVIET MEETING IN '82 IS SEEN
description: A White House official said today that a high-level Soviet-American meeting involving President Reagan, but not necessarily Leonid I. Brezhnev, was likely before the end of the year.

title: END OF INSANITY PLEA IN IDAHO MAY FACE CHALLENGE
description: When Idaho enacted legislation recently making it the only state in the nation that bars insanity as a defense in criminal trials, local backers of the bill called it a victory for law and order.

title: LANE BRYANT AND OHIO CHAIN IN $100 MILLION MERGER
description: In a move that caught many retail-industry observers by surprise, Lane Bryant Inc. said yesterday that it had signed a definitive agreement to be acquired by The Limited Stores Inc., a women's apparel chain based in Columbus, Ohio, for about $100 million in cash.

title: 76ers ROUT BUCKS
description: The Philadelphia 76ers routed the Milwaukee Bucks so impressively tonight that even the 76er coach, Billy Cunningham, joined the crowd near the end in applauding the effort.

title: Advertising; People
description: * John S. Ryan named senior vice president and media director, and Thomas P.F. Kiely has joined as a senior vice president at Ross Roy/ Compton.

title: Business Digest; THURSDAY, APRIL 29, 1982; The Economy
description: President Reagan and Democratic Congressional leaders failed to resolve a budget stalemate at a three-hour meeting. The collapse of the talks leaves little chance of a bipartisan compromise, participants said. (Page A1.) The task of drafting a budget for next year now falls to the leaders and committees of Congress. (B11.) Financial leaders expressed little surprise at the failure, but some were concerned it might harm the stock and bond markets (D1.)

title: BRIEFING
description: Small Program, Big Fuss

title: STAGE: GUARE'S 'GARDENIA' ANTEDATES HIS 'LYDIE'
description: JOHN GUARE is still at sea in ''Gardenia,'' which opened at the Manhattan Theater Club last night. It's hard to accept that the author of this emotionally blocked, almost willfully undramatic work is the man who wrote ''The House of Blue Leaves,'' ''Landscape of the Body'' and the screenplay for ''Atlantic City.'' Sad to say, it is all too easy to believe that ''Gardenia'' comes from the playwright who earlier this season unveiled ''Lydie Breeze.''

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: FURNITURE, FLOWERS
description: Work From the Masters, Pritam & Eames Gallery, 29 Race Lane, East Hampton, L.I., 516-324-7111.

title: W.R. BURNET, 82, THE AUTHOR OF 'LITTLE CAESAR' AND 40 FILMS
description: W.R. Burnett, a novelist and screenwriter whose first book, ''Little Caesar,'' in 1927 set a tone of tough-guy realism that he pursued successfully through a 50-year career, died of heart failure last Sunday in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 82 years old and lived in Marina del Rey.

title: Cody Willed Most of Estate To Aid Sick and Aged Priests
description: John Cardinal Cody willed the bulk of his estate to care for sick and elderly priests, making no mention of Helen Dolan Wilson, his lifelong friend who was the beneficiary of a $100,000 insurance policy.

title: Market Place; A Vital Panex From Duplan
description: SHAREHOLDERS eliminated in the Duplan Corporation bankruptcy proceeding of August 1976 must envy the new holders in the company - now called Panex.

title: ROYAL ROBERTO CARRIES A DREAM
description: A few months ago, Jimmy Iselin's family and friends took him to a French restaurant in Manhattan to celebrate his birthday. The lavish surroundings were a throwback to his privileged upbringing as the son of Philip Iselin, who owned the New York Jets and was president of Monmouth Park.

title: Sales of Funds Set a Record
description: Net sales of mutual funds set a record in the first quarter of 1982, according to the Investment Company Institute.

title: INDIANA BANK RELISHES ITS AUTO LOAN CHALLENGE
description: The Plainfield First National Bank and Trust Company in Plainfield, Ind., became a very prominent little bank when it lowered its interest rate on auto loans from 16.5 percent to 12.75 percent on April 1. For its trouble, the bank was mentioned on President Reagan's weekly radio broadcast, and the head of the bank, Larry D. Summers, even got a personal congratulatory phone call from Mr. Reagan.

title: Brandeis Awards to Go To Nine Today
description: C. Vann Woodward, who won the 1982 Pulitzer Prize for history, and the composer Stephen Sondheim, a three-time Tony Award winner, are among nine men and women who have received the 26th Brandeis University Creative Arts Awards, which were presented in the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum.

title:
Helpful Hardware;
SPECIAL LIGHT SWITCHES
description: ELECTRICAL switches activated by noise - a hand clap or whistle - have been around for several years and in the past were marketed as clever novelties. Now there are more sophisticated applications of the idea that stress convenience and safety.

title: Colgate Net Up 1.5%
description: The Colgate-Palmolive Company reported yesterday that its firstquarter profit inched up 1.5 percent, to $53.9 million, or 66 cents a share, from $53.1 million, or 65 cents, in the comparable period a year ago. Sales fell 7.5 percent, to $1.23 billion, from $1.33 billion a year before. Profit was reduced by $1.7 million for the quarter, the company said, because of unfavorable foreign currency translations.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Effort Rewarded
description: ''I hope you are not aspiring to an interview,'' said Hyman G. Rickover when he spied a reporter waiting for him in San Diego on Monday.

title: JUDGE COOKE'S STRIDES TOWARD JUSTICE FOR ALL
description: To the Editor:

title: Business Productivity Registers a Slight Gain
description: Business productivity rose slightly in the first quarter, after a record decline in the last quarter of 1981, the Labor Department reported today.

title: BOARD OF ESTIMATE TACKLES ILLEGILABILTY
description: Every other week or so, the Board of Estimate convenes at City Hall and drones through a calendar of encyclopedic girth, filled with contracts and rezoning proposals of greater or lesser significance and written in dry-as-dust language that leaves even committed bureaucracy-watchers gasping.

title: Leslie Fay Holders Approve Sale Plan
description: Leslie Fay Inc., a clothing manufacturer, said shareholders had approved a plan to sell the company's assets for $54 million, or $15.50 a share.

title: Sports People; Stockholders' Victory
description: In United States District Court in Boston, Judge Walter Jay Skinner ruled that Peter Otis and his sister, Helen Pavlidis, could file a class-action suit on behalf of 2,400 former or present stockholders against the New England Patriots and their principal owner, William J. Sullivan. Judge Skinner scheduled a pretrial hearing for Oct. 4.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Abascus Group, Chicago, has formed an advisory affilate, Abascus Realty Advisors Inc., and has named Thomas J. Steel executive vice president and chief operating officer.

title: Addendum
description: * Vickers Benson & Ayer, a newly formed company, resulting from the merger of N.W. Ayer Ltd., Toronto, in which Ayer will hold a minority interest, and Vickers & Benson International, a subsidiary of Vickers & Benson Companies.

title: STUDENT AT PRINCETON DIES OF TOXIC SHOCK, TAMPON USE IS CITED
description: A 20-year-old sophomore at Princeton University has died of toxic shock syndrome, according to a spokesman for the university. It was the first confirmed case of toxic shock syndrome among students there, he said.

title: Four Jersey Governors Join a Fifth
description: There was an unusual gathering on Wednesday of four former Governors of New Jersey. They joined the incumbent of the Trenton State House, Thomas H. Kean, to look back a bit.

title: ARA's Means Bid
description: The Justice Department announced that it was dropping its opposition to ARA Services Inc.'s bid for Means Services Inc. Earlier, in London, Dry Cleaner Sketchley P.L.C. said it would not extend its $33-a-share offer for Means after the expiration date Friday. Sketchley said ARA, which is counterbidding at $37, is accepting for payment tendered shares totaling some 86 percent of Means.

title: PRESIDENT APPEALS FOR SPENDING CUTS TO REDUCE DEFICIT
description: President Reagan tonight accused the Democratic leaders in Congress of advocating ''more and more spending and more and more taxes'' and asked the American people to support a budgetary approach that would rely on spending cuts to close the Federal deficit in the years ahead.

title: News Analysis
description: The breakdown of budget negotiations between the Reagan Administration and Congress leaves the nation's economy floundering, with high interest rates still threatening any chance for a sustained and strong recovery.

title: 4 Polish Union Leaders Unite to Fight Regime
description: Four fugitive Solidarity leaders have formed a committee to coordinate the fight against Poland's martial law regime until Lech Walesa, the head of the suspended union, is freed, a clandestine statement said today.

title: Chief Is Selected At Merged Railroad
description: Robert B. Claytor, 60 years old, has been named chairman and chief executive officer of the new Norfolk Southern Corporation, a combination of two of the country's most profitable railroads, The railroads, which will merge June 1, are the Southern Railway and the Norfolk & Western Railway: Together they link some 17,500 miles of track.

title: F.B.I. CHIEF DEFENDS UNDERCOVER WORK IN ABSCAM
description: William H. Webster, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, today defended the bureau's undercover operations, including those used in the Abscam investigation, against criticism that some of those operations had not been tightly controlled and had victimized innocent people.

title: LEWIS NICHOLS, TIMES DRAMA CRITIC DURING WORLD WAR II, DEAD AT 78
description: Lewis Nichols, a former chief drama critic of The New York Times, died last night at Franklin County Public Hospital in Greenfield, Mass., after a long illness. He was 78 years old.

title: Index; International
description: Thailand strives to turn turbulent region into ''happy south'' A2 Weinberger calls U.S. conven- tional forces insufficient A3 Iran is expected to launch an of- fensive against Iraqis A3 Around the World A5 Britons vent their anger at things Argentine A8 Government/Politics F.B.I. chief defends undercover work in Abscam operation A11 Senate rejects efforts to weaken nuclear wastes bill A13 Talks fail to end impasse over New York State budget B1 State assails judge's ruling on its care of the retarded B2 Mayor Koch is jeered on housing at ''town hall'' meeting B2 City may tie construction aid to hiring of poor workers B3 Washington Talk Briefing A20 Authors battle a copyright law A20 A special party for a special pharmacist A20 Required Reading A20 Decision File A20 General Around the Nation A10 Potential jurors questioned in the Hinckley trial A14 Ex-Justice Potter Stewart re- turns to Yale B1 Health/Science Industry effort to change Clean Air Act runs into difficulties A10 Study panel says red tape delays drug approvals A12 A study panel suggests safer means of curing meats A12 Religion Thousands in Chicago join in last tribute to Cardinal Cody A10 Weekend Events: Weekender Guide C1 Dozens of good ways to greet merry month of May C1 Theater: Broadway C2

title: LOOPHOLD IN THE MAKING FOR THE MOST AFFLUENT
description: To the Editor:

title: FILM: FERRER IN SASKATCHEWAN
description: ''WHO HAS SEEN the Wind,'' which opens today at the Guild Theater, is a sweet, generous reverie of a movie about growing up on the prairies of Saskatchewan during the Depression. It touches all of the topics obligatory in such small-town fiction, including life, death, hypocrisy and bigotry, all as they are observed by one little boy, Brian O'Connal, played with fine, serious, un-self-conscious assurance by Brian Painchaud.

title: A FAVORITE PHARMACIST IS THE GUEST OF HONOR
description: He plays pool with David Brinkley, gin rummy with Art Buchwald and stores cigars in his humidor for Senator John Heinz, Republican of Pennsylvania. Jeane J. Kirkpatrick has invited him to visit at the Waldorf Towers, where, as United States representative at the United Nations, she has an apartment; Judge Gerhard Gesell of the Federal District Court here brings him honey from his beehives in Maine, and the author Herman Wouk dropped in to stock up on prescriptions before a trip.

title: SENATE UNIT BEGINS DRAFTING A BUDGET
description: As angry partisan speeches whipped around Capitol Hill today, the Senate Budget Committee began the arduous task of drafting its own budget for the fiscal year 1983. As its first act, it adopted estimates that project a budget deficit of $182 billion if current spending programs were left uncut.

title: U.S. Steel Fills A Major Post
description: The United States Steel Corporation today made its second major appointment of a top financial officer in two days.

title: HAIG AND WATERGATE
description: As the trial of John Ehrlichman approached in 1974, the White House was asked to provide the defense and the Watergate Special Prosecutor's office with relevant documents, including the copious notes Mr. Ehrlichman had taken of meetings between President Nixon and White House aides.

title: OVERCROWDING AT L.I. HOSPITALS ASSAILED
description: Overcrowding at most Long Island hospitals has become so severe that supervisors frequently tell ambulance drivers that their emergency rooms cannot accept any more patients, according to health and emergency-service officials in both counties.

title: Owner of Rams Denies Bid to Block Davis
description: Georgia Frontiere, owner of the Los Angeles Rams, testified today she did not try to block Al Davis's attempt to move his Oakland Raiders to Los Angeles and did not even discuss the proposed move because she ''never thought he was serious.''

title: Maytag Planning Jenn-Air Purchase
description: The Maytag Company, a manufacturer of home laundry equipment and dishwashers, said it had agreed to acquire the Jenn-Air Corporation and its subsidiary, Jenn Industries, from the Carrier Corporation for an undisclosed amount of cash and notes.

title: Marks & Spencer
description: Marks & Spencer expects to maintain the 11 percent volume growth seen in the fiscal year ended March 31, the company's chairman, Lord Sieff, said today.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Ron Darling was the winning pitcher and John Pacella the loser in an International League game played between the top Met and Yankee farm clubs, Tidewater and Columbus. Darling is the Yale alumnus whom the Mets obtained from the Texas Rangers in the trade involving Lee Mazzilli.

title: ART: HOW THEY PAINTED THE AGE OF NAPOLEON
description: ''CONSULAT-Empire-Restauration,'' at the Wildenstein Gallery, 19 East 64th Street, is an enterprise in two parts, although not meant to be. There are the paintings and drawings, about 80 of them, with approximately one-third on loan from museums and private collectors. Then there is the catalogue, written by Georges Bernier, who also organized the show - to benefit the Lycee Fran,cais of New York.

title: Market Place; Shift in Debt At U.M.M.
description: THIS is a season in which a troubled company can sometimes be turned around by a stroke of a banker's pen. But it is seldom clear at the writing whether the ink will work its magic.

title: KOCH JEERED ON HOUSING AT 'TOWN HALL' MEETING
description: Mayor Koch was strongly attacked last night for his housing and corrections policies at a boisterous ''town hall'' meeting he held in Seward Park High School on the Lower East Side.

title: Computer Trade Secrets
description: In a ruling that might encourage similar suits, a California judge awarded at least $1.5 million in damages to the Microcomputer System Corporation, which had charged two former executives with stealing trade secrets.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Berlioz in Fisher Hall
description: Berlioz's Requiem will be presented by the Metropolitan Singers-The Greek Choral Society and the Little Orchestra Society on Sunday at 8 P.M. at Avery Fisher Hall, Broadway and 67th Street.

title: Henry M. Minton, Led Church & Dwight Co.
description: Henry M. Minton, the retired chairman, president and chief executive officer of Church & Dwight Company, the country's largest producer of baking soda, died Wednesday at his home in Glen Cove, L.I. He was 83 years old.

title: Kennedy Library Head Belittles Article on Tapes
description: The director of the John F. Kennedy Presidential Library said today it would be ''premature'' to say that some White House tapes made in the Kennedy Administration were missing.

title: No Headline
description: These are the most popular albums and singles nationally, compiled by Billboard, a trade publication. Singles and albums are determined by national sales and radio air play reports.

title: Friday; 'SAYONARA' ON 47TH ST.
description: Joshua Logan will introduce ''Sayonara,'' his 1957 film, tonight at 7:30 at the Japan Society, 333 East 47th Street. The film -about a love affair between an American Army officer stationed in Japan (Marlon Brando) and a beautiful showgirl (Miiko Taka) - won four Oscars, including those for best supporting actor and actress to Red Buttons and Miyoshi Umeki, who played star-crossed lovers. Tickets are $4 and go on sale 5:30 the day of the screening. Information: 752-0824. SOHO TV DOCUMENTARIES

title: 'THE CHOSEN'
description: ''THE CHOSEN'' is careful to disarm its audience right away. It begins with a baseball warmup, as a team of Jewish schoolboys in Brooklyn prepares for a game. Along comes the opposition - a team of Hasidic Jews wearing side curls, austere clothing, heavy glasses and very sour, unfriendly expressions.

title: Tetra-Tech Tie With Honeywell
description: Shareholders of Tetra-Tech Inc., a marine products company in Pasadena, Calif., approved a plan to merge into Honeywell Inc., Honeywell said.

title: WEINBERGER CALLS FORCES INSUFFICIENT
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger said today that the United States lacked the conventional military forces to defend the nation's vital objectives and international commitments.

title: Sports People; Bat Inspection
description: A bat that was altered by Toby Harrah of the Cleveland Indians is on its way for inspection to the office of Lee MacPhail, president of the American League. In Tuesday night's game between the Indians and the Seattle Mariners, Umpire Bill Kunkel ejected Harrah after it had been discovered that he had shortened the bat by sawing off the handle and refastening it with glue and a wooden peg.

title: MARINE'S NATIONAL OUTLOOK
description: Having emerged from a deeply troubled past, Marine Midland Banks Inc. is trying to make up for lost time by creating a nationwide federation of commonly owned, but autonomous banks.

title: Humphrey Browning Gets Records Account
description: The record industry, faced with the dual problem of home recording and commercial piracy, has retained the services of Humphrey Browning MacDougall, the Boston advertising agency, to research the problem and, if an advertising solution can be found, to develop such advertising.

title: PIPELINE BACKERS TO MEET IN BID TO FIND FINANCING
description: Sponsors of the troubled Alaska-Canada natural gas pipeline, frustrated by high interest rates and a worldwide oil glut, are scheduled to gather here on Friday to attempt to forge a multibillion-dollar financing plan for the project.

title: Nestle Result For Quarter
description: Group sales of Nestle S.A. in the first quarter of 1982 were 7 percent lower in Swiss franc terms than the comparable period of 1981, the company's managing director, Helmut Maucher, said at a news conference today. But if exchange rates had remained constant, turnover would have been 14 percent higher, he added.

title: Louis Danzig, 74, Ex-Director Of Newark Housing Authority
description: Louis N. Danzig, former executive director of the Newark Housing Authority, died Tuesday at St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston, N.J. He was 74 years old and lived in Livingston.

title: THOUSANDS JOIN IN LAST TRIBUTE TO CARDINAL CODY
description: They came by the thousands, the prominent and the obscure, the powerless and the wielders of political, religious and economic power, solemnly and with common purpose, to mourn John Cardinal Cody, the Archbishop of Chicago.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: restaurant that opened six weeks ago on 55th Street, between the Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue, directly across from the City Center. It is especially welcome there since it provides a variety of diverting dishes well-suited to dining before or after performances.

title: THE PHILARMONIC: BOLET AND REX
description: RICHARD STOLTZMAN'S clarinet recital Wednesday night at Carnegie Hall was dedicated to Benny Goodman, the man who made the place safe for clarinetists before the young recitalist was born. Aptly, Mr. Stoltzman dedicated the program to his instrumental idol in a modest little speech that bowed to the ''first man to perform American jazz and European classical music with equal artistic quality.''

title: INDUSTRY EFFORT TO CHANGE CLEAN AIR ACT IS STALLED
description: An industry-backed effort to make major changes in the Clean Air Act is running into difficulties in the House of Representatives.

title: IMPASSE WORRIES BUSINESS LEADERS
description: Except for cautious optimism from the automobile industry, business executives yesterday painted a generally gloomy picture for the economy in view of the budget impasse between President Reagan and Democratic Congressional leaders.

title: Baby Walkers Draw Warning
description: Babies who use walkers may get hurt more than those who do not, a new medical study indicates. The study, reported in The American Journal of Diseases of Children, found that use of the walkers for infants could cause cuts, skull fractures, serious head bruises and loss of teeth.

title: IMPASSE DISMAYS BOND TRADE
description: Credit market participants expressed dismay yesterday at the adverse long-term effects of future Federal budget deficits even larger than the $100.5 billion estimated for the current fiscal year, but their concerns were not enough to push interest rates higher.

title: THE TEA DANCE WITH VICTORIAN FLAVOR
description: There were, to be sure, fewer period costumes than in other years, but, with all the other minutiae important to such occasions, the Victorian Society's Tea Dance was a resounding success.

title: 2 Lead With 65's In Nelson
description: Vance Heafner was only 6 years old when Clayton Heafner died in 1960, so he had little opportunity to get to know his father, who had played on the golf tour from the late 1930's until retiring in 1954.

title: Photo of Argentine soldiers in convoy; ARGENTINA IMPOSES ITS OWN BLOCKADE AROUND FALKLANDS
description: Argentina's military junta said tonight that any British ship or plane found within 200 miles of the Falklands would be regarded as hostile and dealt with ''accordingly.''

title: Advertising; Shasta Remakes Its Image
description: WHEN the advertising budget for your soft drink budget is only 0.013 percent of the country's total annual beverage advertising, then you had better use it wisely and well.

title: U.S. Editors Protest Holding of 3 Britons
description: The American Society of Newspaper Editors has filed a protest with the Argentine Government over the detention of three British journalists on espionage charges.

title: Continental's Bid To Be Resisted
description: Management Assistance Inc. will ''vigorously oppose'' any attempt by the Continental Telephone Corporation to gain control of the computer company, Raymond P. Kur@shan, chairman and president of Managemeft Assistance, said.

title: FLIGHT CONTROLLERS SAY TRAINING LAGS
description: More than eight months after President Reagan dismissed 11,400 striking air traffic controllers, many controllers still on the job say the task of training new controllers is proceeding more slowly than the Reagan Administration predicted.

title: Food Fight, Across the Atlantic
description: Who should export food? Countries like America, Argentina and New Zealand, say economists: places with fertile land, good weather and relatively few mouths should trade their agricultural surplus for manufactures from densely populated, resource-poor Europe and Japan.

title: San Simeon Is Beaten
description: San Simeon, the Australian pacer who had lost only once in 34 previous starts, finished third tonight at the Meadowlands in a tuneup for the $375,000 World Pacing Cup Series. It was his first start outside Australia.

title: CABARET: FRISHBERG AND GRAND
description: DAVE FRISHBERG, who sings, plays piano and writes songs, is performing at Michael's Pub as half of a duo with Murray Grand, who also sings, plays piano and writes songs. But otherwise, there is little in common between them.

title: POP JAZZ
description: TWO concerts dedicated to the memory of Thelonious Monk, the jazz pianist who died Feb. 17, will be presented at Town Hall tonight at 7:30 and 11 by the Barry Harris Jazz Ensemble, a company that includes an 18-piece big band, a string ensemble, dancers, a 60-voice chorus and guest soloists.

title: Big diamond on the block.
description: THE De Beers Diamond, said to be the largest diamond to be auctioned in this century and the fifth largest polished diamond in the world, will be offered next Thursday by Sotheby's in a sale at the Hotel des Bergues in Geneva. Sotheby's is estimating officially that the 234.65-carat unmounted light-yellow stone may bring in excess of $3 million. But one of the auction house's specialists has told others that the diamond may well exceed $4 million. The record for any stone sold at auction is $4.6 million, the price paid for the Polar Star Diamond, a 41.28-carat stone cut to look as if there were a star within it, which Christie's auctioned in Geneva in November 1980.

title: Estimate Board Delays Midtown Zoning Vote
description: Over strong objections from Mayor Koch, the Board of Estimate yesterday postponed until May 13 a vote on new zoning regulations for midtown Manhattan.

title: SALES OF NEW HOMES FELL TO RECORD LOW IN MARCH
description: The rate of sales for new homes dropped by 9.5 percent in March from February's level, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 335,000, the Commerce Department said today. It was the lowest level since the Government began keeping records in 1963.

title: STAGE: 2 GRANDES DAMES IN 'THE CHALK GARDEN'
description: WHATEVER the drawbacks of the Roundabout's revival of ''The Chalk Garden'' - and they are serious - you still leave the theater full of admiration for three remarkable women. They are the evening's stars, Irene Worth and Constance Cummings, and the author, Enid Bagnold. The actresses need no introduction. The playwright, who died last year at the age of 91, may be too keenly remembered these days for ''National Velvet'' or for her last play, Katharine Hepburn's unsatisfying Broadway vehicle, ''A Matter of Gravity.'' She shouldn't be. ''The Chalk Garden'' is in a whole other league - it just may be a classic of its kind.

title: ART: THE ILLUSTRATED BOOK FROM FRANCE AT MORGAN
description: ''THE Art of the French Illustrated Book: 1700 to 1914'' at the Morgan Library is a pendant to an exhibition held in the same place six years ago and called ''The Illustrator and the Book in England From 1790 to 1914.'' Like its predecessor, it is drawn largely from the private collection of Dr. Gordon N. Ray, who is president of the Guggenheim Foundation and who was for many years a distinguished teacher of English literature.

title: China Growth Slowed in '81
description: China's economic growth slowed in 1981 as the Government spent less money on modernizing factories and farms, and efficiency was ''not satisfactory,'' the State Statistics Bureau reported today.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, APRIL 30, 1982
description: International Argentina warned Britain that any British ship or plane within 200 miles of the Falklands would be regarded as hostile and dealt with ''accordingly.'' The announcement came a half day before today's scheduled start of a British sea and air blockade of the same area. (Page A1, Column 1.) Argentina holds the key to peace in the Falklands, according to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher who spoke in an emergency debate in Britain's House of Commons. She rejected demands by the opposition that Britain turn to the United Nations or the International Court of Justice in an 11th-hour effort to avert a war. (A9:1-4.)

title: Economic Scene; Deficit Impasse: What It Means
description: THE failure of President Reagan and Congressional Democrats to reach a compromise on how to control the budget deficit spelled bad news for financial markets and the economy.

title: Lollar of Padres Stops Mets, 6-0, and Helps at Bat With Homer
description: Tim Lollar of the San Diego Padres, a former Yankee, held the Mets to five hits in a 6-0 complete-game victory today and added to his impressive batting statistics with a home run and two runs batted in.

title: 'SOUP FOR ONE,' ABOUT COMING OF AGE
description: IF movies were people, you might say that ''Soup for One'' is still struggling to get through its awkward age. It's energetic, sort of gawky, sometimes obnoxious, occasionally very funny and frequently endearing. All of the people connected with it are up-and-coming new talents.

title: Dart & Kraft Down 6.3% for Quarter
description: Dart & Kraft Inc. reported yesterday that first-quarter net income fell 6.3 percent, to $96.9 million, or 77 cents a share, as a result of the recession.

title: PUBLISHING: HOW DID NAPOLEAN DIE?
description: HISTORY records that Napoleon died in 1821, probably of cancer, during his exile on the island of St. Helena. But, in fact, according to ''The Murder of Napoleon'' by Ben Weider and David Hapgood (published by Congdon & Lattes), he was murdered by repeated doses of arsenic slipped into his daily ration of wine.

title: Sports People; Alouettes in the Red
description: How bad is the financial condition of the Montreal Alouettes? Well, according to Bob Geary, the general manager, the team doesn't have the $10,000 to pay a hotel bill that George Allen had run up before he resigned as team president last week. Henry Ornest, who has been left in charge by the absentee owner, Nelson Skalbania, gives a somewhat different account, saying that the Alouettes simply refuse to pay.

title: Sports People; Borg's Light Schedule
description: Bob Cain, the agent for Bjorn Borg, said it was unlikely that the Swedish star would play any organized tennis other than special events this year.

title: POSSIBLE HINCKLEY TRIAL JURORS FACE A WIDE ARRAY OF QUERIES
description: Potential jurors in the trial of John W. Hinckley Jr. were questioned today in the judge's chambers about their attitudes toward insanity, psychiatrists, the film ''Taxi Driver'' and other matters as the proceedings moved through the third day.

title: Bridge: Trusting One's Opponent
description: May Backfire in the End By ALAN TRUSCOTT

title: AID TO LOCALITIES STANDING IN WAY OF STATE BUDGET
description: Governor Carey and the Senate Republican leader, Warren M. Anderson, ended an extraordinary negotiating session today at 3 A.M. Their talk left them divided on what burden the state's localities should have to bear in helping the state balance its $27 billion budget.

title: TOWN HOUSE DEVELOPMENT GOING UP IN MAMARONECK
description: Diane Greenberg Millstein took a circuitous route to housing development. She was a planner who helped the town of Greenwich, Conn., establish its zoning a decade ago, and before that she had worked as a regional planner in southwestern Connecticut.

title: Volcker Hints at a Change
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that the nation's central bank would change its tight credit policies if it thought the country were in danger of falling into a depression. But Mr. Volcker told a seminar sponsored by Representative Timothy E. Wirth, Democrat of Colorado that he remained convinced that the economy faced a bright future in a new era of stable prices.

title: Auto Output Highest of '82
description: Auto production by the five major domestic auto makers this week will be at its highest thus far this year but will remain 23.1 percent below production for the same week last year, an industry journal reported today.

title: Money Funds Show Decline
description: Assets of the nation's 196 money market funds declined by $182 million for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday. It was the third weekly decline as investors continued to make withdrawals to pay income taxes, the Institute said.

title: Sports People; Zungul in Lineup
description: Steve Zungul scored 103 goals in 40 regular-season games with the Arrows this season but missed the last four because his contract did not obligate him after April 15. Now he and the club have reached an understanding, and as a result he'll be in the lineup at Nassau Coliseum tonight when the Arrows, seeking their fourth championship in the four-year history of the Major Indoor Soccer League, open the playoffs against the Buffalo Stallions.

title: Hooton Hurls One-Hitter
description: LOS ANGELES (AP) - Burt Hooton pitched a one-hitter as the Los Angeles Dodgers beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 4-0. Hooton (1-1) retired the first 10 Phillies before Ivan DeJesus lined a clean single to center on a 1-2 pitch.

title: ANGELS WIN AS JACKSON HELPS
description: Although his contribution was far more subtle, Reggie Jackson had a hand in the California Angels' 2-0 victory over the Yankees last night. To be precise, it was his right hand.

title: BRITONS VENTING THEIR ANGER AT THINGS ARGENTINE
description: When a tape of a pre-Falklands Royal Variety Gala was recently broadcast on television, viewers were treated to the entire 90-minute spectacle - with one exception. Elaine Page's performance of ''Don't Cry for Me Argentina,'' from the musical ''Evita,'' was eliminated.

title: SALVADOR CENTRIST CHOSEN PRESIDENT
description: Under intense pressure from the armed forces, El Salvador's Constituent Assembly today elected Alvaro Alfredo Magana, a political centrist, as provisional President of the country.

title: SCIENCE - SPY-ENCE
description: The Reagan Administration's efforts to screen unclassified research from prying foreign adversaries might usefully be examined by keeping in mind Robert Frost's passage: ''Before I built a wall I'd ask to know/What I was walling in or walling out....''

title: NBC-TV PUTS COMEDY FIRST FOR FALL
description: TV, which finished a distant third in the prime-time ratings again this season, yesterday became the first network to announce its fall schedule. The lineup includes 11 new series and leans more heavily on comedy than any new NBC schedule in recent years.

title: Goodyear Reaches Pact With Rubber Workers
description: Bargainers for the United Rubber Workers and Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company reached tentative agreement today on a three-year contract. Negotiations had begun March 9.

title: Landlords Cautioned On Sanitation Rules
description: The New York City ''nail and mail'' system of citing landlords for sanitation violations remains in force while a Federal judge considers challenges to its constitutionality, spokesmen for the judge and the Sanitation Department said yesterday.

title: CARIBBEAN AID: TROUBLED PLAN
description: The Reagan Administration is likely to face stiff Congressional resistance to a package of investment incentives that it has put together to bolster economies in the Caribbean and Central America.

title: A tale of twofers, or why the theater isn't really dying.
description: As always on Broadway, it is the best of times and the worst of times. Attendance is down, but because ticket prices are up, the boxoffice grosses are certain to be higher than ever for the season.

title: HOW TO GO A-MAYING: A GUIDE FOR THE CITY AND SUBURBS
description: MAY will arrive this weekend in a blaze of cherry blossoms in Brooklyn, on the strings of wild kites in Central Park and in the sounds, smells and sights of festivals and tours all over town. This is the weekend when New Yorkers and their suburban neighbors take to the outdoors. What follows are some of the ways in which you can participate.

title: Pacific Gas Unit In New Venture
description: The Pacific Gas Transmission Company, a subsidiary of the Pacific Gas and Electric Company, said it was forming a new company to engage in enhanced oil recovery from old oilfields.

title: CARET-BRADFORD QUARTET PLAYS JAZZ 'HOT,' NOT SAFE
description: THE West Coast has not exactly been a hotbed of contemporary jazz activity. That's probably because Los Angeles encourages musicians to take lucrative jobs recording film soundtracks and television commercials, and to play challenging music only as a hobby. If ''West Coast jazz'' still seems somewhat cool, this is a major contributing factor.

title: Decision File Recall Reopened On Slide Toy
description: One child was strangled and another suffered serious brain damage while playing on what appeared to be a safe wooden slide and ladder toy. The manufacturer swiftly responded by starting an extensive, voluntary recall program in 1980. It provided 50,000 free replacement ladders for the originals, which had treads spaced closely enough to become lethal nooses around small necks.

title: JUSTIFIED TAX CREDITS
description: To the Editor:

title: PREMATURE OPTIMISM ON HUMAN RIGHTS IN KOREA
description: To the Editor:

title: UAL LOSS WIDENS IN QUARTER
description: UAL Inc., the parent company of United Airlines, reported that its loss for the first quarter widened to $129.3 million from $21.3 million in the same period of 1981.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Gentle persuasion is not going to make the Argentine Government give up what it has seized by force.'' -Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. (A9:1.)

title: NEW LEADER IN SALVADOR
description: His visitors were asking about El Salvador's presidency, and Alvaro Alfredo Magana was talking basketball.

title: SOVIET PIANIST FINDS A HOME IN U.S.
description: Oxana Yablonskaya, the pianist, was asked the other day how she would like to be described. As a Soviet emigre? As a Russian? As coming from the Soviet Union?

title: CONSTRUCTION AID FROM CITY MAY BE TIED TO HIRING POOR
description: Advisers to the Mayor on the construction industry have recommended that builders who receive indirect city assistance, such as tax abatements, be required to hire a specific proportion of poor people.

title: Lockheed Unit Sets Australian Air Sale
description: The Lockheed-California Company, a unit of the Lockheed Corporation, will deliver 10 P-3C Orion antisubmarine aircraft to the Royal Australian Air Force, the Australian Government announced yesterday.

title: JAZZ: PAGE CAVANAUGH'S BACK
description: WHEN Nat King Cole began in 1946 to move away from his rhythmic, jazz-based King Cole Trio performances, one of the groups that moved successfully into the resultant musical vacuum was the Page Cavanaugh Trio. Using the same instrumentation, with Mr. Cavanaugh on piano, Al Viola, guitar, and Lloyd Pratt, bass, the Cavanaugh Trio developed a crisply phrased, intermittent but swinging instrumental and vocal style that was epitomized in their very popular recording of ''Walkin' My Baby Back Home.''

title: Asian Bank Bond Issue
description: The Asian Development Bank is offering up to $100 million of bonds denominated in Swiss francs, the Union Bank of Switzerland, the lead manager for the issue, said today.

title: IRAN EXPECTED TO LAUNCH DRIVE AGAINST IRAQIS
description: Western diplomats said today that Iran appeared to be preparing for a major new offensive to drive the Iraqis out of occupied southern territory.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An item in Notes on People on April 10 about Prince Edward, the youngest son of Queen Elizabeth II, incorrectly reported the location of the school in New Zealand where he will teach in September. It is the Collegiate School in Wanganui, 95 miles north of the capital, Wellington.

title: FILM: 'SOILDER GIRL' IN TODAY'S ARMY
