description: ''Soldier Girls'' was shown as part of the 1981 New York Film Festival at Alice Tully Hall. Following are excerpts from a review by Janet Maslin in The New York Times of Sept. 27, 1981. The film opens today at the Agee Room of the Bleecker Street Cinema, 144 Bleecker Street.

title: Fewer Hands on the Garbage
description: Garbage is not normally an upbeat subject, but there is plenty of reason for cheer in the news of an agreement between New York's Sanitation Department and its garbage collectors. It proves it's possible for a municipal union to change its job rules and share the savings with the city.

title: CIRCLE REP STAGES PLAYS BY YOUTHS
description: TAKE 10 plays, by 10 playwrights, and it is hardly surprising that their subjects will be diverse. One is about a homosexual affair between two boys at a private school in Victorian England and the triangle that results when one secretly becomes involved with a young woman. Another is about a mental patient tortured by the death of his best friend and about his sister's efforts to get him out of an institution. A third portrays the harrowing impact on a Puerto Rican family in the South Bronx when a son's girlfriend is raped and dies from her injuries.

title: Swiss Bank Gains
description: The Swiss Bank Corporation said today that its balance sheet total rose to $44.3 billion in the first quarter from $43.8 billion at the end of the year. Operating earnings were up from the first quarter of 1981, it said.

title: ABC TO BEGIN MOVIE-BASED TV NETWORK
description: In an effort to attract the sort of viewers who now watch pay television services such as Home Box Office, ABC yesterday announced a new movie-oriented service that can be delivered to homes equipped with video cassette recorders for a monthly subscription fee.

title: TANK UNIT SALE GIVES CHRYSLER PROFIT
description: The Chrysler Corporation today reported a profit of $149.9 million in the first quarter, but only because of a $239 million gain from the sale of its tank-making operation in March.

title: PRESIDENT ENDORSES A CONSTITUTIONAL AMENDMENT
description: In his television address tonight, President Reagan gave his strongest endorsement thus far to a constitutional amendment that would mandate a balanced Federal budget.

title: B.P. Field Half Depleted
description: British Petroleum's Forties Field, the largest in the North Sea, is now half depleted after producing one billion barrels of oil since 1975, B.P. said in a statement. Now producing some 500,000 barrels daily, equivalent to 30 percent of British consumption, the Forties Field is expected to continue at a slowly declining rate for the rest of the century.

title: Czechs Win Silver Medal
description: The Soviet Union and Czechoslovakia played to a scoreless tie in a lackluster finale of hockey's world championship tournament tonight.

title: No Headline
description: Top-seeded John McEnroe yesterday drew Chris Johnstone, a young Australian, as his first opponent in the $300,000 Tournament of Champions, which begins Sunday. The eight-day event has a field of 61, all of them tournament winners during the last year.

title: CAMP DAVID OR, OR ...
description: 3WASHINGTON - Now that Israel has returned the Sinai to Egypt, many people in many places are quick to pronounce the Camp David process dead and are suggesting that another way be found to deal with the Palestinian problem. What they do not realize is that Camp David is the only game in town.

title: South African Gold
description: South African gold production totaled 1.72 million ounces last month, the Chamber of Mines reported today. This was up from 1.7 million ounces in February but down from 1.78 million ounces in March 1981.

title: Schering-Plough To Buy DNAX
description: The Schering-Plough Corporation, a Kenilworth, N.J., pharmaceutical company, said it had signed an agreement to acquire DNAX Ltd.., a biotechnology research firm that concentrates on combining immunology, genetic engineering and drug deliivery systems.

title: Diversified Background Aids UAL's Chairman
description: Richard J. Ferris, president and chief executive officer of UAL Inc. and chairman and chief executive of United Airlines. its main subsidiary, yesterday was elected to the additional post of chairman of the holding company. The 45-year-old Mr. Ferris succeeds Edward E. Carlson, 71, who is relinquishing his chairman's post but will remain as chairman of the executive committee and a director.

title: Traveling the Road to Marriage, by Bike
description: Carol Chavanne was a bicycle-pedestrian safety coordinator for the New York City Department of Transportation. James D. VerEeck, a mechanical engineer, was chairman of the American Youth Hostels' bicycle committee.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A sports article yesterday omitted one school from a list of those with the greatest number of players selected in the National Football League draft. The University of Miami, with eight players selected, ranked third, behind Texas and Penn State.

title: PRESIDENT APPEALS FOR SPENDING CUTS TO REDUCE DEFICITS
description: Representative Richard Bolling, the Democratic Party's economic spokesman, tonight accused President Reagan of turning the budget negotiations into ''a partisan rat race.'' He challenged Mr. Reagan to resume the bipartisan effort to reduce the deficit for the fiscal year 1983.

title: DERBY FAVORITE BY DEFAULT
description: block clockers' stand perched above the backstretch at Churchill Downs Thursday morning, a voice asked, ''Where's El Baba?'' And there he was, over near the finish line, a big brown colt with red bandages on his legs who was about to breeze a half-mile under the twin spires of the race track where the 108th Kentucky Derby will be run Saturday.

title: BALLET: SUSAN JAFFE'S SWAN
description: Susan Jaffe is the American Ballet Theater's wonderful new discovery, the star of the future who radiates a star quality so vibrantly now at the age of 19 that one is dazzled at the prospect of her development.

title: F.S.U. Is Cleared In Bozeman Case
description: An internal committee at Florida State University today cleared the basketball program of most charges leveled by James Bozeman, one of its former players.

title: IDEAS FOR CURING MEAT SOUGHT
description: Radiation and acid-producing chemicals may someday be used as substitutes for nitrites as preservatives for cured meats, but more research is required to make them feasible, a federally sponsored research panel reported yesterday.

title: Tass Says U.S. Exports More Arms Than Soviet
description: The Soviet press agency Tass, rebutting a report by the United States Arms Control and Disarmament Agency that accused Moscow of exporting more arms than any other nation, said today that the United States was the world's biggest arms exporter.

title: Marathon Bid Opposition
description: A dissident group of 2,000 former Marathon Oil Company shareholders is expected to file an ''appraisal rights'' action in court in June in an effort to get a higher price for shares from the United States Steel Corporation.

title: Motorola Buyout Of Toko Partner
description: Motorola Inc., the Chicago manufacturer of electronic equipment, announced that it would buy out its Japanese partner Toko K.K., with which it had, for two years, participated in a joint venture, Aizu-Toko K.K.

title: 2 Witnesses on Sirhan Dispute Key Testimony
description: Two prisoners told a parole board today that another witness had solicited them to invent a story that Sirhan Sirhan had threatened to kill Senator Edward M. Kennedy.

title: A COPYRIGHT LAW IS AUTHORS' TARGET
description: One of the more unlikely struggles underway on Capitol Hill pits organized labor against such noted American authors as John Hersey, Barbara W. Tuchman and Garson Kanin.

title: Bell Canada's Growth
description: The Bell Telephone Company of Canada said today that demand for telecommunications services grew slowly during the first quarter. Two-thirds of its rise in revenues resulted from a rate increase, the company said.

title: EX-JUSTICE STEWART RELIVES THE ELI LIFE
description: Phi Beta Kappa graduate in the class of 1937, Law School valedictorian in 1941, Skull and Bonesman, distinguished alumnus and marginal intramural football player emeritus, Potter Stewart has returned to Yale.

title: ISLANDERS DEFEAT NORDIQUES, 5-2, AND LEAD SERIES, 2-0
description: Mike Bossy's second goal of the game broke a 2-2 deadlock tonight and sparked the Islanders to their second straight triumph over the Quebec Nordiques at Nassau Coliseum. The winning score was 5-2 as New York took a 2-0 lead in the four-ofseven-game Stanley Cup semifinal series.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF PRESIDENT'S ADDRESS DEFENDING HIS PROPOSALS ON BUDGET FOR '83
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's televised address last night in support of his budget proposals for the fiscal year 1983, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News:

title: RECITAL WITH A BONUS
description: An unusual tie-in recital-plus-disk event will take place Monday at 8 P.M. in Alice Tully Hall to promote the French pianist Daniel Varsano. Ticket buyers to the program will have a choice of one of two Varsano recordings-an all-Statie disk or an all-Faure disk-as part of the price of admission, which is $5 for all seats. The program will include works by Satie, Ravel, Faure, Debussey, Chabrier and Dukas.

title: The Right Signal in Seoul
description: Vice President Bush is learning. A year ago, inexcusably, he toasted President Marcos of the Philippines as a lover of democracy. This year he muted his praise of South Korea's current self-enthroned strongman, President Chun Doo Hwan. Better yet, during a three-day visit Mr. Bush found time to meet with Korean dissidents. It was a good start for an important fence-mending Asian tour that now includes a stop in Peking.

title: Epstein, Raboy Adds New Partners, Billings
description: Epstein, Raboy Advertising has added three senior partners and $4 million in new billings. The partners are Myron B. Poloner, 39-year-old president and chief operating officer; Erwin Ephron, 47, senior vice president and director of marketing, and Alexander Tsao, senior vice president and co-creative director.

title: NUCLEAR FREEZE: 'A RECKLESS EXPERIMENT'
description: To the Editor:

title: White Sox 3, Tigers 2
description: CHICAGO (UPI) - Ron LeFlore went 3-for-4, including a two-run homer, to lead Chicago. Dennis Lamp (2-0) gave up only two hits in six and one-third innings before being relieved by Salome Barojas, who earned his sixth save. The White Sox scored an unearned run in the second inning on Bill Almon's two-out infield single that scored Carlton Fisk.

title: Cohalan in State Race For the 2d Highest Job
description: The Suffolk County Executive, Peter F. Cohalan, today announced his candidacy for the Republican nomination for lieutenant governor, the first Republican to do so.

title: A MONTH'S BUDGET TALKS FINALLY CAME TO NAUGHT
description: The quest for a budget compromise had ended in failure, but nobody wanted to be the first to leave the President's Room, an ornate chandeliered chamber just off the Senate floor.

title: Sports People; Astros Release Ivie
description: Mike Ivie, whose eight-year baseball career has been interrupted periodically because of psychological problems, was released by the Houston Astros.

title: Tenneco to Sell Some Assets
description: Tenneco Inc., a diversified Houston-based producer of gas pipelines, chemicals and other products, said that about $400 million of the company's assets would be sold this year.

title: MRS. THATCHER ASSERTS ARGENTINA HOLDS 'KEY TO PEACE'
description: With the dispute over the Falkland Islands about to enter its most dangerous phase, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher asserted today that ''the key to peace is in the hands of the Argentine Government.''

title: The Editorial Notebook Smart Apes, or Dumb?
description: In the May issue of Psychology Today, 11 of ''the best minds in the field'' describe what each considers to be ''the most significant work in psychology over the last decade and a half.'' The results are astonishing: it would seem that there has been none.

title: LENDL FACING PENALTIES
description: The Association of Tennis Professionals recommended yesterday a $10,000 fine against Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia and an indefinite suspension from the organization. The moves came in light of Lendl's decision to play next week's Tournament of Champions at Forest Hills instead of the World Team Cup in West Germany.

title: John Billhardt, Ex-Chairman Of the Empire Savings Bank
description: John P. Billhardt, retired chairman of the Empire Savings Bank, died Monday at his home in Southbury, Conn. He was 74 years old. Mr. Billhardt, a graduate of New York University and the St. John's University School of Law, joined the Title Guarantee and Trust Company and rose to vice president in 1949.

title: ONLY A DRAFT GETS THE BEST INTO THE ARMY
description: To the Editor:

title: President's Red Ink Ran Dry
description: President Reagan had trouble tonight getting enough red ink to explain his budget problems with the Congress. The President's marker pen temporarily ran dry in his nationally televised address as he sought to cross out graphs showing budget-cutting compromises he had offered to Democratic leaders but that they rejected. The red ink started to flow after Mr. Reagan was handed a second pen.

title: Hutton and Jetero Officials in Bid
description: An executive of E.F. Hutton & Company and the chairman and president of the Jetero Corporation have informed the Securities and Exchange Commission that they plan to form a corporation to offer to purchase all the shares of Jetero.

title: Utility Names A New Chief
description: Commonwealth Telephone Enterprises Inc. has named Rui R. Lopes, a telecommunications engineer, president and chief executive officer. Mr. Lopes was formerly vice president of telecommunications for the Bank of America.

title: Eugene F. Roth Is Dead at 77; Lawyer and Company Director
description: Eugene Frederick Roth, a Manhattan lawyer who also served as a director of several companies, died Wednesday at his home in Rye, N.Y. He was 77 years old.

title: J.P. Stevens Bid
description: J.P. Stevens & Company and Stevcoknit Inc., a small textile concern operating under Chapter 11, announced a letter of intent for J.P. Stevens to acquire Stevcoknit. J.P. Stevens will exchange 240,000 shares for those of Stevcoknit. At J.P. Stevens's closing price yesterday of $17.125, the shares would be worth $4.1 million. The final agreement needs approval by Stevcoknit's bankruptcy reorganization plan and by both boards.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day on April 22 about quarterly earnings referred incorrectly to a major merger. The United States Steel Corporation ac- quired the Marathon Oil Company.

title: U.N. SET TO VOTE SEA-LAW TREATY U.S. OPPOSES
description: The United States is prepared to reject a sweeping United Nations treaty that would fix rules for the use and exploitation of the seas, American diplomats said today.

title: SENATE PASSES BILL GOVERNING NUCLEAR WASTE SITE
description: The Senate voted today to adopt a national policy for disposing of radioactive nuclear waste, overcoming objections from senators whose states could be chosen as dumping sites.

title: EXCERPTS FROM MRS. THATCHER'S TALK
description: Following are excerpts from Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's speech today in the House of Commons:

title: Iowa Forced to Reduce Its Prison Population
description: With Iowa's prisons filled beyond their legal capacity, officials today began a series of steps to free inmates before the end of their sentences.

title: GENERAL NUTRITION FACES LEGAL THREAT
description: General Nutrition Inc., owner of nearly 1,000 health-food retail stores known as General Nutrition Centers, is facing a legal threat that could force it to cut back its operations. The company had a small but mildly positive following on Wall Street until a recent drop in earnings.

title: BELL'S LEVY ON TIE-INS RISING 50%
description: The Federal Communications Commission today allowed the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to increase by about 50 percent its charges for connection with local phone systems. The charges would be levied on A.T.& T.'s competitors for long-distance service, such as MCI Communications.

title: O' NEAL AND HURT IN 'PARTNERS,' A COMEDY
description: THE one joke in ''Partners'' is that macho, heterosexual Detective Sergeant Benson (Ryan O'Neal) is ordered to go ''underground'' with mousey, homosexual Detective Sergeant Kerwin (John Hurt) in an investigation of a series of homosexual-related murders in Los Angeles. Benson is horrified at the thought. Kerwin is shy and apprehensive. He much prefers to work in an office.

title: Out of One Race
description: The prospect that the House of Representatives might get its first mother-daughter team was dashed yesterday when Barbara Boggs Sigmund of Princeton, N.-J., dropped out of her race for the House.

title: NEW MUSIC: 'RICERCATE,' A QUARTET
description: THE featured piece and only first performance on the final concert this season by the Group for Contemporary Music Wednesday night at the Manhattan School of Music was Susan Blaustein's ''Ricercate'' (1981), for string quartet, conducted by Charles Wuorinen. Miss Blaustein's inspirational model was Schoenberg's Quartet No. 1, in which ''successive reprises grow weightier and more laden with memory as the piece's history progresses,'' as she put it in notes available to critics but not the public.

title: STATE DISUPTES COURT RUILING ON ITS CARE OF RETARDED
description: New York State yesterday accused a Federal judge of engaging in ''sensationalized rhetoric'' and said it would appeal a decision that the state had failed to carry out reforms for mentally retarded patients.

title: List of 'Group of 17'
description: In Budget Meetings

title: U.S. SAYS HAIG EFFORT SEEMS TO FAIL AND FALKLANDS FIGHTING IS LIKELY
description: Administration officials said today that Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.'s diplomatic efforts had apparently failed to produce a solution in the Falklands crisis. They said heavy fighting between Argentina and Britain was likely to begin in the next day or so unless there was an unexpected development.

title: GROUP ATTACKS ENERGY PLAN
description: In a major criticism of the federal energy program, Canada's oil and gas industry warned today that the official goal of energy self-sufficiency by 1990 would not be attained within the framework of present policy.

title: THE ULTIMATE PROD FOR ARAB RECOGNITION OF ISRAEL
description: To the Editor:

title: Black Hawks Even Series
description: Denis Savard scored a pair of decisive third-period goals tonight and powered the Chicago Black Hawks to a 4-1 victory over the Vancouver Canucks that evened their Stanley Cup semifinal series at one game each.

title: NEW FUNDS FOR ALSANDS
description: In an effort to revive the Alsands oil sands project, a $13.1 billion (Canadian) complex designed to extract oil from the tar sands of Western Alberta, the federal and Alberta governments said today that they would be willing to acquire a combined 50 percent equity stake in the project.

title: Index Futures Decline As Stock Market Falls
description: Prices of stock-index futures posted sharp losses yesterday along with all the popular stock market averages upon which they are based. However, the moves in the stock-index futures were proportionately smaller than those in the actual market averages.

title: ONLY A DRAFT GETS THE BEST INTO THE ARMY
description: To the Editor:

title: SCULPTURE: DAVID SMITH
description: TO an extent not rivaled by any other artist, David Smith bears a sacred name in the American art of our century. Even in the art of the American past, only Thomas Eakins enjoys a comparable immunity from hostile comment. On moral, as much as on esthetic grounds, the work of Smith, like the work of Eakins, is believed to have inaugurated a new level of American awareness, and one of which posterity is proud.

title: Required Reading; Debate on the Falklands
description: Debate on the Senate floor after the introduction of an amendment by Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., Democrat of Delaware, calling for the United States to use ''all appropriate means'' to assist the British Government in achieving the withdrawal of Argentine troops from the Falkland Islands, April 28, 1982:

title: The U.N Today; April 30, 1982; SECURITY COUNCIL
description: Meets at 3:30 P.M. on letters from Organization of African Unity and President of Chad. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: CELEBRATIONS OF SCHNABEL AND BINGHAM
description: Celebrations of the hundredth anniversaries of the births of the pianist Arthur Schnabel and the composer and organist Seth Bingham will be held Sunday.

title: DANCE: DANA REITZ AND TROUPE AT THE KITCHEN
description: DANA REITZ is a dancer with the look of a slightly prim little girl who knows a secret. She is also an acclaimed experimentalist.

title: Quest for No.300
description: When they call him the Ancient Mariner, Gaylord Perry chuckles. And like the character in Coleridge's poem, this season he has ''stoppeth one of three,'' with a 1-2 record, even though he has allowed only four earned runs in 29 2/3 innings.

title: SENATE PANEL ASSAILS 'RED TAPE' IN APPROVALS OF PRESCRIPTION DRUGS
description: A study panel asserted today that new drugs could be brought to market much faster if Government red tape was reduced and greater reliance was placed on outside experts in granting approval.

title: JOHN CHRISTIAN
description: John Christian, a former director of the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, died Monday in Eustis, Fla., after suffering several weeks from a respiratory illness.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Genetic Engineering Inc. said it had agreed in principle to acquire Immunogenetics Inc. of Dover, N.H., in a stock exchange valued at $5 million to $6 million.

title: CABBY SCHOOL TEACHING COURTESY AND GEOGRAPHY
description: New York's first school for taxi drivers has opened to teach things that passengers say many drivers have apparently forgotten - courtesy, geography, safety rules and traffic regulations.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF BOLLING'S REPLY TO REAGAN ON BEHALF OF DEMOCRATS IN
description: CONGRESS

title: Biologist Seeks to Test Chemical Agent Antidote
description: A University of Arizona biologist wants to test antidotes for an arsenic-based chemical warfare agent on a hundred pigs and a thousand rabbits.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: THEY were asked to give a hand to the Girl Scouts, and some 50 c elebrities, from Maud Adams to Henny Youngman, did just that. On T uesday evening prints of their hands on plaster plaques were a uctioned off at the headquarters of the Girl Scout Council of G reater New York.

title: Elmer Ripley, Retired Coach
description: Elmer Horton Ripley, a member of the Basketball Hall of Fame, died yesterday in Doctor's Hospital on Staten Island. He was 90 years old. Mr. Ripley was born in Staten Island in 1891, a few months before basketball was invented.

title: 2 ARABS DIE IN NEW WEST BANK PROTESTS
description: Two 18-year-old Palestinian Arab demontrators were shot and killed today as Israeli troops sought to put down renewed violent protests in the occupied West Bank.

title: BLUES: CHARLES BROWN
description: THE ''Old Club Blues'' is what the West Coast singer Charles Brown calls his ballad-oriented brand of rhythm-and-blues, which flourished in the late 1940's and early 50's in such hits as ''The Drifting Blues'' and ''Merry Christmas Baby.''

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard TAKE FIVE. By D. Keith Mano. 583 pages.Doubleday. $17.95.

title: BRIEFING
description: About Those Sheep

title: The Economy
description: President Reagan called for greater reliance on budget cuts in coming years to reduce the deficit. He urged a constitutional amendment requiring a balanced budget and appealed for public support of his budget proposals. (Page A1.) The laca of a budget compromise leaves the economy floundering, with high interest rates threatening the recovery, economists said. (A1.) The reaction of business executives was generally gloomy. (A19.)

title: READJUSTING HICKEY UNFAZED BY LOSSES
description: Like many of his new teammates on the Quebec Nordiques, Pat Hickey, the former Ranger, played well tonight, but not well enough to win.

title: THE FLAT TAX
description: Over a decade ago, when Richard Nixon wanted a dramatic plan to reform the tax system, his economic aide Peter Flanigan made a flip-chart presentation in the Cabinet Room in favor of the ''flat tax'' - a drastic simplification of the archaic U.S. tax code, eliminating all deductions and slashing rates.

title: DANCE STUDENTS' ANNUAL AT JUILLIARD
description: Performing is an important part of a dancer's education. A classroom star can look like nothing at all on stage without such preparation. But it is hard to come by at an age early enough to make a difference. Second or junior companies connected to major performing institutions are one answer. But the New York City Ballet-affiliated School of American Ballet believes in starting really young.

title: 20 Entered in Derby; El Baba Is Favored
description: Twenty 3-year-olds were entered this morning for the 108th running of the Kentucky Derby on Saturday, which shapes up as a crowded and confusing race.

title: Hijackers in Honduras Said to Lower Demands
description: The 4 hijackers holding 28 hostages, including 8 Americans, aboard a parked airliner lowered their ransom demands today and were considering a Government offer to have them flown from the country in exchange for the release of their captives, officials reported.

title: U.M.M. Debt Plan Approved
description: United Merchants and Manufacturers, a New York-based clothing manufacturer, said yesterday that a proposal to modify the company's debt plan had been approved by bankruptcy court officials. The company, which was reorganized under Chapter 11 of Federal bankruptcy laws in 1977, has been operating under its current debt plan for four years.

title: KENTUCKY DERBY AND SHOOTING TEST
description: IT is that time of the year again at Louisville's Churchill Downs. Television coverage of the 108th running of the Kentucky Derby tomorrow will get under way at 4:30 P.M. on ABC with Jim McKay, Howard Cosell and Jack Whitaker as the reporters. Post time, however, isn't scheduled until 5:38, which leaves the television crew with a lot of time for light features and even lighter banter.

title: HARVESTER AND U.A.W. IN PACT ON CONCESSIONS
description: The International Harvester Company reached an agreement today on wage and benefits concessions with the United Automobile Workers, ending more than three months of wrangling over a labor contract that covers 30,000 workers.

title: CLEAN TAILORING, REFINED KNITS
description: As two weeks of concentrated fall fashion openings neared their end, the pace quickened and the quality of the designs improved considerably. At the beginning, there were plenty of serviceable clothes but few strong directions. By the middle of this week, memorable collection followed memorable collection. The fashion field itself was broadened as many designers, working at their peak, brought new character to tailored coats, suits and dresses as well as sportswear, which has been dominant for so long.

title: CARDINAL COOKE ASKS ARMS RACE CUTS IN PEACE APPEAL
description: In a letter to priests of the Archdiocese of New York, Terence Cardinal Cooke has asserted that ''the church has abhorred the arms race.''

title: Former Turkish Premier Is on Trial for Statements
description: Bulent Ecevit, the former Prime Minister, went on trial today on charges of violating a martial law ban against public statements by former politicians.

title: PRESIDENTIAL PANEL CALLS FOR AN END TO RENT CONTROL
description: A Presidential advisory commission called today for an end to rent control laws and said that no rental housing financed with Federal aid in the form of insured loans or guaranteed mortgages should be subject to such laws.

title: CELEBRITIES JOIN MAYOR IN NEW BATTLE AGAINST GRAFFITI WRITERS
description: ''Take it from the champs, graffiti is for chumps,'' reads the legend beside a tough-looking poster photograph of Hector Camacho and Alex Ramos, both local boxing champions.

title: BUDGET IMPASSE AT A GLANCE
description: The three-sided budget negotiations that collapsed Wednesday were meant to shrink prospective deficits in the next three years. Their larger purpose was to bring down interest rates, by diminishing the Treasury's borrowing needs, to improve prospects for an early, lasting economic recovery.

title: Marriage, acting and Miss Danner.
description: WHETHER or not movie critics liked ''Too Far to Go,'' which opened last week at Cinema II - and the reviews were mixed - Blythe Danner came up a winner. ''Radiant'' was the word most often used to describe her.

title: THAIS TRY TO TURN VIOLENT AREA INTO 'HAPPY SOUTH'
description: The insistent new phrase of Thailand's southern peninsula - a green pendant of mountains and beaches that hangs down from the Asian mainland - is ''tai romyen.'' The words mean ''the south in the cool shade,'' cool shade signifying peace or serenity.
